reviews.review: Mad, mad, mad. Hang on to your purses, keep an eye on your sanity, set your ears to mute; this place is bonkers. You eyes won't know where to settle. There's a cornucopia of performing animals all there to relieve you of your dirhams, there are stalls selling everything from superb and salty pistachio nuts to tables covered in used teeth, molars, incisors but not a great deal of wisdom! You will experience and olfactory overload with a variety of food on show from koftas to tangy tagines. Indeed some of the ingredients aren't even dead yet; one man was carrying around a fistful of live chickens! Take your camera and shoot from the hip. It's barking!!

Fun chaos!. This is a marmite place, love or hate it it's an assault on the senses. A lot of other reviews say about the snake charmers and monkey men, forcing you to pay for pictures, just avoid them. Walk around them and they won't bother you. We had a lot of fun here, just don't leave your common sense at the airport.

It's crazy good fun.. Walking across Jemaa el-fnaa at night is like trying to walk across a dance floor at a wedding. Except all the guests are trying to sell you something and some of them have monkeys.

Vibrant place with ups and downs. Walked along with partner in the evening. Had dinner in the market place (Aisha, stool one) it was pleasant to see it run by two sisters in this very dominant male culture.There were snakes and monkeys on chains (not a fan of animals being used for circus). The restaurants around are expensive. It s better to eat at a stool. Make sure you choose a busy one so you know the food is freshly cooked.Walked all the way to the big mosque. Watch out for pickpockets. Do not stop and watch the little shows, that is where they will try to get you.Overall: Use hand sanitiser before eating and keep moving

Crazy! . Fairly busy & has lots going on by day, but by night.... wow! What a place. It comes alive & can be a little intimidating in parts. Everyone wants you to eat at their place, but their stuff or have henna done. There's monkeys, snakes & black magic to name a few! It's a must see. You mustn't leave Marrakech without spending at least one evening there.

Crazy but wonderful. Great for wandering around and soaking up the city vibe. Eat at one of the food stalls - the food is fabulous, easy to order and great value for money. You need your wits about you and a big dose of humour for fending off the touts advertising their own particular food stall.Personally, I found the monkey and snake exhibits in the square outrageous, inhumane and very upsetting. I despise the people who pay to have their photo taken with the poor monkeys who are dressed in nappies and desperately pulling away from their neck chains and sincerely hope you won't be one of them.

Fantastic Experience. Absolutely must-see when you're in Marrakech. It's great--the people are crazy, the crowds are crazy, the food is pretty great (the snails taste like boogers though... just saved you a meal). *Watch your belongings* as the child thieves are brazen (I caught a girl with her hand in my back pocket fishing for a wallet while two other little boys "accidentally" ran into me). That's to be expected for any big bustling touristy area like this, so don't let it deter you. Its an amazing place. Watch out for the cobras all over (their mouths have been sewed/permanently glued shut--which is awful, but that's the way the world works I suppose), weird monkeys and apes, and all sorts of other critters and creeping things. Make sure you go both during the day and night to really appreciate how cool the setups are. Pretty much any tangible goods you'll find here are completely worthless, but you'll pay a premium and people will bold face lie to you about quality and who made it. If you're cool with that, it's fun. Otherwise get your goods elsewhere (especially rugs... please don't buy them here--they're garbage). Anyways, this place is a sight to behold, and it's worth a few hours of your time. Watch your things, don't buy stuff (the orange juice is awesome though--try to get some Pomegranate if they have any, if it's cold at night see if they have any Khodanjal (its a cinnamon spiced drink--tastes like you're drinking Big Red Chewing Gum--it will wake your mouth up for sure)-- Cart No. 70 has good stuff (I have no basis of comparison but that's where I got mine and it was weird--didn't drink it all, but glad I tried it).Also make sure you get some mint tea and watch the sunset over the square. It's fun and relaxing!

The 'heart' of town - a 'must' if you come to Marrakesh. Visited Marrakesh in october 2016 and went to the place every evening. Just strolling around or having an easy dinner at one of the open kitchens. The noise or snakes may scare you in the beginning - but once used to the vibrant spirit of the place - you will love it.

To be experienced. As long as your are sensible and keep any cash/valuables tuck away safely, ideally in a zip up pocket or money belt, then you can enjoy this amazing spectacle. I must point out that I would take the same precautions spending a day in any busy city centre. Marrakech is by no means exceptional for problems with petty crime.We found hawkers etc to be easily deterred as long as you remain firm and polite.The evening set up is exciting and well worth enjoying, from impromptu street fights, great selection of street food, fizzy drink fishing, on the spot dentists (dont..!!!), snake charmers and monkeys (the later two we fundamentally disagree with and therefore never engage with).Atmospheric, noisy, lively, colourful.......great.

Must go place in the day & night for a cultural experience. This is a vibrant public square, & a must experience as part of any visit. You will experience local & tourist culture here. There are many vendors selling goods, juices & other food. There are many performers as well performing tricks & music. The crowds are larger in the evenings & holidays. If you do not mind crowds & like the carnival atmosphere, this is the place to come.

Amazing!. To get the most out of your visit, make sure that you are here during the day as well as the night as the place is totally different. Mesmerising and mental (in a good way). You do get husselled by people selling their wares but it is all very friendly and nice.

night visit. I have visited many times during the day but going at night was a whole new experience! Absolutely amazing! a truly unique experience with all the hussle and bussle and noises and smells.

go both at night and during the day. Beware of people grabbing your hands to put on henna and of people putting monkeys on you.
Fantastic atmosphere but you are hassled to buy items.

Amazing square, and there's an exhibition that helps a lot to understand it. I wouldn’t bother to review the square, as it is a known must-see. But here’s a tip for those who do not speak Arabic and actually do not understand the performance: In the Medina there’s also Dar Bellarj, a former birds (storks) hospital, now a cultural institution; you can find in in TripAdvisor as well, it is not far from Jemaa el-fnaa. Currently they have an exhibition on the performers in Jemaa el-fnaa, including documentary films where they interview performers. The films have English translation, and you get to understand much better what is happening in the square. Entrance is free. Recommended!

Loved the hustle and bustle. We kept coming back to this square in the daytime and at night. Lots of tourists and locals alike. We always got the orange juice from the stands every time and loved seeing the performers in the square. There are the snake charmers in the day time (make sure you have change if you want any photos), and then monkey owners, games and story tellers at night. We loved going at night due to the atmosphere, vivid lights and people.Beware pickpockets. I got brushed a few times and saw this guy circling a group watching a show looking them up and down.
Madness and mayhem...... ......is all I can say! A truly manic experience which I am happy to have done. Non-stop noise and bustle, with something going on ALL the time.

Lots going on in the square. Jemma el-fanatic is the main square and probably the main attraction it Marrakech that everyone visits. It comes alive at night though with food stalls and snake charmers and all kinds of dancers and stuff going on. Prepared to be hassled by various sellers a lot and if you don't want to ideally don't make eye contact or engage in conversation particularly with young men under 25 who may try to take you off to a particular shop or souk where they will get a commission. Try one of the lovely orange stalls where you can drink fresh orange for as little as about 30 pence.

Interesting but not my favorite place. No one comes here for the views or the architecture - there's other places for that. People come here for the snake charmers and monkey handlers and hena painters the other people who all share a single goal of separating you from your cash. At least in the souk you walk out with something here it's just a photo or a memory that will cost you. Some like it but others find it too much of a tourist trap but as the main gateway to the souk you can't really avoid it so may as well try to enjoy or just walk as quickly as you can through it.

Be very careful. A place you have to visit at night but be very aware of pic pockets, they are very skilful here. I am quite worldly wise but they still stole my wallet from my trouser side pocket and I never felt a thing.

Too many not-so-nice hustlers. Lots of bling here ... if you don't mind being led astray and then hassled for money. We had several "helpers" when we appeared to be lost. They turned quite nasty when we refused to pay them after we sensed we were being led way out of our way. We have wandered through many of the world's largest markets. Some are worse than others when it comes to people who do this to lost tourists. But this was definitely our most unpleasant experience. The medinas in Essouira and Rabat were far more pleasant with no problems of this sort. We used a guide in Fes ... really necessary with over 9000 "lanes".

Wow. We went here both in the day and again at night. Two totally different experiences! Daytime was a bit stressful with hassling sellers. I kept the sunnies on and kept on with the simple no thank you, which worked a treat but hubby was hassled more but became proficient in saying la shukran, which was respected and they moved on.Night was hypnotic with African music, dancers, storytelling ( I didn't understand a word but the locals looked mesmerised). The food stalls where rows upon rows of outside stalls selling all sorts of foods from goat heads to beautiful petite fours. I personally wasn't brave enough to eat but plenty were! Watch out for the henna women though, they're speedy and before you know it they will have you! Girls we met paid 300 dirhams for tattoos that lasted 2/3 days not the 30 days they claimed they would last.We went to one of the many cafes that had a roof terrace to take photos.. amazing sights!!
amazing. We only visited in the morning, must have been so much better at night, but the sights and sounds will stay with me forever.

amazing and crazy. Arrive early get a view from a rooftop café and watch it all setup so much to take in and see. then walk around and enjoy it all. the storytellers,monkeys ,snake charmers etc. try to eat some local food and please try the orange juice. above the square are the souks you can get a calleche around Marrakech sort prices before you get in

Interesting Public Place. Though I find this place interesting and intriguing, and somewhat safe because there is a special police under cover at all times, watching everybody, because of the crowd phobia I have, I prefer to sit in a cafe in front of the square while my friends scroll around the square.

Breathtaking. A must do. View from the balcony of the cafe de France or one of the other bars. Whirling dervishes, snake charmers, story tellers. If you want to take photos of the performers make sure you have some coins for baksheesh. Then eat at one of the food stalls. Boiled sheep's head if you like, but less exotic foods also available. Experience of a lifetime!

A Dangerous Place. The only place in all of Morocco that I felt in danger. Lots of questionable looking characters there either to pick your pocket by slight of hand, or by persuasion. We didn't have any thievery, except by those selling food in the temporary tents. We ordered one plate of lamb squeezers (40) and one chicken Pastilla(30). Two plates of skewers later, we had only a quarter of a Pastilla served with a piece of eggplant. The bill should have been 70dh but it was 250! They charged us for double orders plus "salad". The table beside us argued their bill, but my husband prefers to avoid conflict. That's what they count on! So I recommend you eat at a restaurant OFF the square where honest work is being done.
An explanade full of stands selling almost everything. It is really interesting, there is a lot of markets arround, shopping, everybody wants to sell something.

David Quarterman. Watch out for pick pockets, we had our phone stolen whilst talking to traders. The stall holders can be insistent but soon withdraw when they see a police man. The pedlar start off saying you pay me what you want and then they want much more than that. At night it is noisy, dirty and full of beggars.

very vibrant market place. unusual place, don't give eye contact to anyone unless you want a henna tattoo, snake or monkey wrapped around your neck.look for the stall selling false teeth that made us laugh. the whole place takes on a different feel at night with lots of music and food stalls. and in the souks give them the lowest price, they will not agree to it then walk away. chances are they will run after you and give it for the price you offered. as there are so many places offering the same thing, they want your custom.Be prepared for the toilets, take tissue with you and you learn how to squat fast. as there is mostly only toilets with a hole in the floor in the public toilets. and they still expect a tip for their use.

Shopaholics dream. You must love shopping because there is not much else here, having said that the cafes and restaurants are very good, the snake charmers less so. A reasonable sense of direction is required if you are to venture into the souks-easy to get lost among the shops and alley ways but there are some real bargains to be had if you are to willing to haggle hard. Go and savour the atmosphere.
Not good for food good for show. Nice place I had bad experiences withe the one places they have food bad food every price they show you is not that they charge you they charge from five times more

Stalls, snakes and henna! . Lots to see and buy. I suggest getting some mint tea in one of the bars overlooking the square. Quite different at night so worth seeing it change if you can. Fruit juice from the stall was lovely but served in glasses so you have to stay there. Be warned if you watch the snakes they will want a donation.

endless touting, aggressive stall owners. Personally find the food vendors extremely aggressive. Every food stall have staff touting and many doesn't take no as answer. The moment you walk past them, they will start harassing you. Some just wouldn't let us go or continue following us. Later on I heard from the Riad owner that they are not allow to touch the tourist or they can be arrested by the tourist police. If you like this kind of experience, this is the place.

Beautiful must see location in Marrakech- Day and Night!. This is a 100% recommended location to visit when in Marrakech! In the evening, Jemaa El-Fnaa was lively, exciting and fun! There were a number of entertainments on going to suit everyone (adults and children) and all of them were free, most of the time! You were expected to pay/give a tip to many of the entertainers as this was their way of earning money. But most of them deserved it, as they were hugely talented. The square really came to life in the evening around 18:30 when the food stalls were set up. There were open grills cooking fresh meat right by your side. Many of the restaurants also offered free delicious mint tea after too. The only thing I would say about the square is that be wary of your bag as it gets very busy and if you're going alone as a female, be wary of yourself as there were many touchy/feely men out there trying their luck! Try visiting one of the panoramic view restaurants during the evening or day to get a beautiful view of the square and its surroundings.During the day, the square does not have the eateries and entertainers set up although there are still a few entertainers such as monkeys/snakes, talented henna artists and dancers around. The square is joined to the large souk which would easily take up your full day to explore. Be careful of the traffic of cars, bikes and horses travelling through the square though as I witnessed a few near misses! There are many restaurants and food places around the square for you to eat during the day. Lastly, the square has many fresh orange juice stalls which I would highly recommend! It is perfect to help you cool down and take a break during the scorching heat... Many workers of the stall will most likely coax you in anyway and you can't walk by the stalls without being caught! Would highly recommend to all- Enjoy!
This is what marrakech is. Spectacle, drama, noise, aromas, colour, sensory overload. Come at dusk and stay into darkness and try all it has to offer. Venture into souk and haggle.This is marrakech.

Oh my. An experience. Wander around this large market square/flea market/eating arena/performance area any time day or night, although evening is best, for a not to be missed experience. Buskers, snake charmers, music, beggars....organized chaos. Feels safe although we were warned to watch out for pick pockets. Food is mostly tolerable; fun to eat on the 2d or 3D floors of one of the restaurants around the market edge and watch the fun from on high.

Crazy exciting,senses overload!!. Wow we stayed in a lovely Riad just off the Jemaa el Fnaa (Riad Irhalne) which I would highly recommend ...so close to all the buzz and craziest markets and Souk shopping ever..The Jemaa is quiet in the mornings ,kept relatively clean and swept ..then starts to fill up with market action sellers snake gamers, monkey shows, music bands playing original cultural Morroccan music..then the food sellers set up shop about 3pm onwards and evening craziness and banter begins!! The Souks are in action all day ..9-till very late ..and bartering starts ..a little daunting at first ,then challenging ,then quite tiresome..
Fun!. Loved this market! If you enjoy the hustle and bustle of markets this is for you and you will enjoy soaking in the atmosphere. I really enjoyed this

Lively, enjoyed our visit. We enjoyed it here, bartering for goods, but it can be a bit nerve-wracking. Some sellers push their goods at you quite insistently. You have to be on the alert and have your wits about you, so that you don't get conned (or talked into paying for something you don't want). A few sellers here - when I wouldn't pay what they asked - reduced the price when we walked away. So walking away can be a good tactic to get items reduced. Some sellers follow you, if you've shown interest in their goods- they don't want to let you go. Although this was a bit harrassing, we didn't feel threatened at all. Most sellers are nice. Beware of anyone drawing henna tattoos on you, before you've had a chance to refuse- or agree on a price. Somple we talked to had been charged bout 400 dirhams and some had paid 600. Far too much- locals pay about 30 dirhams for henna tattoos. We enjoyed our experiences here, but I did feel harrassed at the end of it. It wouldn't suit everyone - we met some people who really didn't like it at all. And of course, you have to like shopping. We did get quite good at haggling down prices and got some bargains. Then we went to a rooftop bar and watched the activity below- that was great.

Souks galore. After having wanted to visit for many years I was overwhelmed with the hustle,bustle and persistent merchants. At one point we found ourselves going in circles around the maze of streets which did make me apprehensive. However, at no point were any merchants rude or antagonised by our low bartering prices, on several occasions we were given directions by locals without any expectation of payment. An experience worth having.

Really fun. Definitely recommend going shopping here. We had a guide that held all of our bags and showed us around the market and he took us to the Argan oil factory which he probably gets a commission but it was pretty interesting. This is a must see in Marrakech
Busy and noisy. loads going on. lots of souks and in the evening loads of food stalls nut all doing basically the same stuff.

Epic Markets both day and night. Yeah loved the markets...all the advice on Trip Advisor came into great use...thank you everyone. We manged to pay 1/3 asking price after much negotiating for our few bits...get lost and see the locals souks...pay guide to get us back...enjoy the orange juice...not get caught out by monkeys and snakes...and get henna done at right price...enjoy the food market and entertainment at night....aaaah glorious. Only thing i would say is our kids are 6 and 11...and they enjoyed but very overwhelming.

A must see, but the street food is pricey!. We spent our first evening watching the sunset from the terrace at Cafe de Grand Balcon, and ate at the street vendors twice. The stalls are all very similar; but be aware that the bread/olives/harissa they bring to your table come at a price! We paid 150dh each night for two, which is still pretty reasonable, but restaurants near the square are often cheaper, with less hassle! Still one not to be missed, especially the music, snake charmers and storytellers!

2 in One. Walking trough might be challenging, but it's enjoyable. The people stop you in each step to present their food corner. But after 3 days, you just get used to and enjoy it. Then you go the street theater, and pick the best show for tou, where you should pay your "Ticket" in someone's hat. Some nights it's like real talents show.

Iconic square. This place is huge and is covered with all manner of traders fro snake charmers to spice stall and leather goods. It is a great reference point if you go wandering into the souks. It does blow you senses apart so be prepared.

Marrakech answer to Disneyland. Anything for the tourists. And as long as it can seem ethnic and exotic it will probably go down well with most tourists. Truth is that Jemaa el-Fnaa is as capitalist and fake as Disneyland - but in Disneyland you know it.At first sight all seems authentic, but walking around the square and the souks for a couple of days, I realized that all that was being sold was the same in the different shops. And probably produced and imported from far away - could be China.The snakes, the snake charmers and the human teeth being sold were all very real, and in a commercial way authentic.

Sensory overload. Jemma el-Fnaa square at night provides sensory overload for visitors to experience. The outdoor food sellers music,snake charmers,dancers and a multitude of diverse visitors provide a heady potent mystical mix to the evening. This is no ordinary market square this is live entertainment and you will become part of the entertainment as you weave your way through the crowds. Take time to eat sweet meats drink fresh orange juice and mint tea this attraction is a must for Marrakech

Lovely . This is something else ..A sudden burst of colours and chaos and frenzy and madness..a hyperbole of adjectives could be less specially when marrakesh happens to be your last halt right after touring around morocco..The sudden refinement..the sudden cosmopolitan pulse ..the sea of white skin and blonde hair healthily mixed amid motley locals in variety of grabs is intoxicating .Jmaa el fena is life itself ..it beckons u at night ..it beckons u in the morning ..Right at 6.30pm..it comes alive with all hustlers and hawkers selling your wares ..entertainers galore ..food carts and henna aetistes.. ersatz perfumes and ersatz oils clamoring for your attention visavis the brick and mortar shops ..Go enjoy the experience ..music is rife ..and colour is unmistable ..jma it is !!!!And the souks surrounding it which meander from one gully to other is a labyrinth no doubt but wondrous ..Reams and reams of Moroccan glasses.. morrocan lamps ,wares..leather lovelies , tagine pots and shoes and Chinese duplicates and what not .. And it's amazing how they all quote different prices for similar things ..find your thing around..u will figure how to.haggle and where to make a full stop.usually; less than half the rate is correct .Remember one thing though .Moroccan hawkers and sellers are agressive,pushy and emotional .They lure u.they beckon u..they psstt you and drag u in their shop .u only need to look.casually at something and u can be rest assured; u ain't getting out in a hurry..They force u to quote a rate and incase u don't want it ..they get emotional and huff and puff as though u wasted their time .It's alarming sometimes and u need to be firm for no pushing ..Yet they are harmless.. it's just their way..It's actually fun how they operate and live ..observing small nuances and small cultural ethnical differences in humans ..Something that segregates their reactions from maybe ours ..Another warning ...Don't buy argan oil from just about anywhere . They could be fake .Right rate is around 500dirhams for a lite and purchased best from an apothecary. .best reverence is rehba kadima.shop no 156 brahims..the purest and original ..tried and tested ..or pick from essouairia..Also don't have the oily street food at jemaa.Unless u don't value your intestines ..stick to fresh grills and no tagine ..enjoy the orange juice and juggler acts galore at the square ..Don't miss the live band of musicians who drum themselves out mad at around 7pm..it's such fun..
World Heritage Site. The heart of the city. Fascinating place, different at different times of day. Very interesting, colourful and atmospheric.
Good for dinner. We enjoyed the food stalls and atmosphere in the evening. The only thing we did not appreciated is the chained sad looking monkeys.
Crowd and not funny . Number of sellers and oriental music performers gathered in a place which is not very safe or clean wasn't a lovely experience
A must see. Beautiful both day and night, well worth getting a spot at one of the upstairs cafe's and watching the world go by. Sunset is a particular good time to do this.

good to experience but a lot of nothing. I hate to say it because Jemaa el-Fna is so iconic to Marrakech and morocco but for me, it was a lot of nothing. It was so buzzing at night but I don't feel like anything was really going on. There are people standing in circles around different performers but to me it wasn't worth anything to watch. i'm glad I went and experienced the energy, culture, and history but found myself underwhelmed by it all. Be careful of the henna ladies grabbing your arms. I saw a lot of that (but didn't experience it perhaps because I'm a guy). yes the vendors will be pushy and follow you around but a few firm and polite no thank yours (no merci, la choukran) will drive them away..it also works if you can walk quickly to get away from them. I also found if you say no thank you and put your right hand over your heart while bowing head, it will also cause them to not be so pushy. Also, it works if you act like you cant speak English or French- they will realize they cant communicate with you and will leave you alone. Do stop by the many orange stands to drink a glass of orange juice. to conclude...you cant not go if youre in Marrakech, but keep your expectations low but your wits high. Go to experience the energy and hustle/bustle.
Not overly impressed . Hustle bustle good atmosphere. Street acts very poor. Make sure you get a plastic throw away cup if you decide on a fresh orange juice. Some venders use reusable glasses.

Be Careful!. Busy, yes. Colourful, yes. Intoxicating, yes! Just beware! The juice sellers are wonderful...40p per glass of pure orange. A henna lady grabbed my arm, despite my protests still did her thing... Once you've started, it's hard to stop. Her work took about one minute and then tried to charge £35.... No way! I eventually got away with £10... But still a massive rip off! Don't let them take your arm or hand!

A beautiful chaos. The best thing about this place is the popularity of it. There is always someone who is trying to sell you something or you can Find street performers who want to impress you somehow. In the evening, in the middle of the Square you can sample a taste of their traditional cooking and you should!!! Just be sure to barguin before you eat at one place because you can always get a better price

great experience sights and sounds , if a little full on and hassly. loved the mad games people were playing , less impressed with overly enthusiastic food sellers and men with monkeys but you got to see it if your here

Stunning. One of the best and most stunning places/squarea I have ever seen/been to. It covers all aspects the Moroccan culture is made of. Vendors, sellers, entertainers and many more. The best way to explore it is in the evening and at night as the place thrives. Definitely worth a visit and a must-see place in Morocco.

Place to bargain:). If you are the person who can bargain this place is for you :) good quality things you can buy there for a very good price :) if the seller telling you the price of 1800 dirhams you can buy defiantly for 200-300 dirhams instead:) just bargain!!! Only one thing I didn't like that we knew that we had to dresses up there to close most of the body and I was wearing dress just a bit lower my knees and one of the locals spilled something on my legs. Be careful!
A must see in Marrakech. Hectic place. But be prepared to be overwhelmed by the locals. Everybody wants some money from you. Even for taking simple pictures. So relax, and arrange prices beforehand.

Like markets, smells, tastes, colors, shows, attractions, shopping, sweet, storytelling, folklore show, traditional food. Square in Marrakesh, afternoon, becoming suddenly find special activities, attractions, colors, performances, thousands of stalls are opened, tens of thousands of people walking. Enjoy far much food of all kinds,The stallholders, smiling, welcoming, and the food is fresh, very tasty and very cheap, smells amazing.In Square, in addition to food, there are many shows, dancing, storytellers, dancers, snake shows, cafés, and the atmosphere is amazing and unique.Linked loaf spectacular market, and is split into many alleys. There are antiques, new carpets, traditional clothes, silver and gold, much sweeter, traditional Moroccan cakes, and more and more. It is recommended to visit this site, at least two days. See the square from the terrace of a cafe, how to square a turnaround from cars, and becomes one huge restaurant

The definition of madness. If you can get used to constantly being hassled for knock off tat, food you don't want, pictures with frightened monkeys or intimidating looking snakes, then this is a must see. Get a recommendation from your hotel / Riad for the food stall. We ate at #1 and it was fantastic. Day and night are quite different. Sometimes this feels like a scene from Mos Eisley in Star Wars. At others like you have stepped back in to a medieval era of spices and loud music and wailing weirdos. Highly recommend

Miss at your peril. We ended up in the square many times on our trip, some planned some by accident. It was lovely to sit in a restaurant and look out over the square and entrance to the Souks in the daytime - people watching. We came in the afternoon to see the snake charmers and in the evening to eat from the 100's of street restaurants. We ate at No 1 Aiysha's - good food and very cheap.
One of the most amazing main plazas I have ever been. Unexpected had heard a lot good things but nothing compares to be there and enjoy it, the people, the food, the atmsphere just amazing
Not to be missed!. What a circus, so much happening and to see, this is like going back in time, snake charmers, street food, shops, hawkers, joggers, acrobats -why would you miss it?
Real heart of Marrakech. Heart of Marrakech, lots of night shows, basically never sleeps. Watch your pockets and don't forget to taste great local food in the food court.
Quick visit. Beautiful and peaceful mosque....just a word of warning, this sight can only be seen from the outside as a tourist
Great place sums up Marrakech! . Great atmosphere, always busy loads going on and also great to eat from in the night, enjoyed exploring the place was a good experience would recommend

A Fascinating, Vibrant and Exciting Gathering-place. Jemaa el-Fnaa is a fascinating, vibrant and exciting place, particularly at night, of snake charmers, monkey-handlers, local musicians and food stalls. The shops on and around it are full of interesting spices, oils, local artworks and tourist stuff and there are many places to eat. The terrace cafes are also good for getting an overview and out of the throng. Essential to visit in the evening.
Amazing must see in Morocco. Amazing place to just sit back and watch the comings and goings great Street food just soak it all up a must see in Marrakech !

Wonderful site to see but a bit overwhelming. Wow what a site to see. This is a must do in Marrakech. A few warnings though. Keep possessions close or it may be gone later. Be careful with pictures. Snake Charmers, Monkey handlers, etc want money for pictures. If you have to have a picture, negotiate a price beforehand. I have seen some pay 100dh for a picture and others 5dh. The food stall people are the most aggressive people to deal with. They will not take no for an answer, keep walking and say no but you can get a great price if you want. We had soup, a drink, salad and green tea for 20dh.

Hectic and atmospheric. You just have to go to the square if you visit Marrakech - can't avoid it, especially as nearly everyone tries to take you there anyway! Be careful if you want to take any photos of the performers there as they will ask you for money. Still, why not, as some of them are entertaining and it's like buskers really. Not sure about the monkeys and snakes though ... Great place to soak up the atmosphere of central Marrakech - particularly lively at night. Grabbed a lovely fresh sweet orange juice on the outskirts of the market, and also managed to find a nice bar which served alcohol there too - Le Marrakchi.
Small Restaurants. There are many small restaurants. They sell different types of fish and skewers. The restaurant staff is too pushy to buy something.

Unique place. Enjoy the place, it is unique in this world. I liked to see all the artists at this place. Have a look also at the Riad Dar Bellarj with the exposition of "Al-Halqa", Thomas Ladenburger.

remarkable experience. Upon our arrival in Marrakech we were a little concerned that maybe we had gone beyond our comfort level. After a good night sleep and a tour of the median and souks we became much more relaxed and comfortable. We did go down to Jemaa el Fna at about 5 pm and stayed until at least 9 pm. We watched the vendors set up the food stands and eventually ate at booth number 1. Do not miss visiting Jemaa El Fnaa during the evening. The food is excellant and very reasonable. For 100 Dirhams we had chicken skewers, vegetable skewers, chicken tangine and bread. When we ordered we thought we would have one small skewer with about 7 small pieces of chicken. What we received were about 5 or 6 skewers with approximately 7 small pieces of chicken on each skewer. It was more food than we could finish. The tangine was excellent. The highlight is just hearing all the sounds coming from the performers in the square and the great aromas from the food vendors cooking their food. The smells, noise, and mass of people make this an exceptional experience that you should not miss if you are visiting Marrakech.

A circus. People are cramped in trying to get your money. Snake charming, henna tattoo artists, putting greens, ring toss, hustlers pushing food, drinks, wristwatches, telephones, paintings, cigarettes, toys, if you can think of it they have it are will get it. Numerous shops selling everything my friend. I loved it.

Must see but,,!. Will ummm don't know what to say, but it's a must see.Still an original place where ppl make the cobra and monkeys dance what I didn't like is that at each time you take a pic thy ask you for money !!At 18h thy put some traditional grilled food, not so clean but I tried it and it was not bad.Must visit ! Cause it's the heart of Marrakech

Be wary. While this is an amazing place, full of character. Be wary of pick pockets andstreet vendors that just leap on you, distract you, put henna on your hands as a 'present' then demand extortionate money. Put a monkey on your head take a photo and demand more money. Overly aggressive street vendors. Not Marrakech at its best.
Beautiful. Too see the real Marrakech come here... but mind the snake charmers who will try and put a snake around your neck and then they charge you money... Same with the monkeys ...

A buzz of activity. The central attraction in the Medina. By day, there are lots of stalls, ages and a variety of acts, including a number of snake charmers! If you are not a fan, it is possible to avoid them but still to soak up the atmosphere.

Overrated. The guide books insist you see this, and every Marrakech native who sees you looking lost will try to take you here, but frankly this was a a disappointing experience, all rather forced and with too much attendant hassle. You do have to go once, but don't count on staying overlong.

Busy and lively. This place comes alive in the evening. Its busy, noisy with lots of different things going on. We even found a man with a pair of weighing scales, charging people to weight themselves. You will either love it or hate it.

Watch out for Henna artists!. Had my hand grabbed by a henna artist, who started drawing on it before I could say "no". When I finally managed to pull it away, she asked for 400 dh (= 40 Euros!!). Having learned our lesson the hard way earlier in the day I flatly refused and gave her 20 dh just to make her go away. After that we climbed up to a rooftop cafe to watch the goings on from a safe distance. We never tried any of the street food, which I kind of regret, but the orange juice was heavenly!

Good experience but very hectic. Was good to experience beautiful place and so much too see, but don't buy anything on the first day you are there and look around , and make sure u haggle with them and think about the Max amount you would want to pay and if doesn't agree just walk away they will follow u and accept what u offered, make sure u have small notes and change if you can, and don't take pictures of the snakes or monkeys they will demand money, and don't go off with anyone who isn't prearranged guide,they will take you everywhere they know and they expect you spend money carpets argan oil, stay in the main areas and you will be fine and can get some real bargains its a must see and experience

Crowded, of course, but also a little creepy. Lots of people, some genuine characters, but too many hustlers, de-fanged snakes and rampant exploitation of he endangered native monkeys - the so-called Barbary Apes - some of whom were stolen as infants in the wild after their parents were treed by dogs and stoned by the local poachers. avoid paying to have your picture taken with them.
Where the action is. This is where you want to head to while in Marrakech. It is the start of the souks, and hub of many restaurants and cafes.

exciting not wowed. Ok so i thought from reading about this that I would be totally wowed but I wasnt, it was exciting to walk around but you were constantly hounded to buy something or come and eat something so stopping to take it all in or browse at items for sale was impossible
Madness. This square is something else and there is something new to discover each visit. It can be a bit daunting initially but you soon get into the swing of it.

Just as in a dream but be careful about restaurant here. how magic place jemaaelfna is..... during day some snakes, tattoo and show and during night? restaurent and animation... all is made to make dream but.....Be careful to eat here for two reason:1. u pay also bread 5 dh, olives 5 dirham everything the add on table also if u dont ask so.... they bring olive and as in morocco olives are served for free u eat.... bad u will pay.... so if u count 80 dirham for eating u will go out with 140....2. Food control: be sure u eat in a clean place cause as u can see they don't use fridge so is very dangerous during hot time and u dont know for how long food was out of fridge.But don't be afraid if u want to try the experience is nice and very folklore, just be careful.I did an intoxication once and from there i go here for eating but i choose always the same restaurent where now i am sure to eat safe.

Crazy...in a good way!!. Unbelievable...the party, the vendors, the restaurants, the smells, the sounds...it's completely different from everything i've experienced! Have coins to give them to the performances and tips to the restaurants, and just live!!
Ok. The reviews definitely were much better than the reality when seeing the square. Anyways, it's the central point to you should go.

Morrocan culture. An attack on the senses, from musicians and monkeys to snake charmers and food stalls one must visit when in town! Don't take a photo unless you're willing to pay for it, don't expect not to get involved or be hassled and most of all keep your belongings safe. We visited Cafe de France and La terrace de glaciers which were both great to relax and enjoy the spectacle with a drink and get great views. La terrace de glaciers does require compulsory purchase for entry.

Good chaos!. Just Wow!!!!This square is truly something out of the Aladin Disney cartoon!Chaotic with people, donkeys, horses, carts, snakes, monkeys, henna tattoo artists, shops, cats, more cats and beggars.It is beautiful and interesting to see this amazing culture concentrated in a square where locals exhibit locally made crafts, delicious freshly squeezed fruit juices and beautifully made lanterns and leather goods.It takes a while to get used to the traffic of everything everywhere but once you do you will enjoy it and be fine hahaha.

A must see. If you visit Marrakech you have to visit Jemaa el Fnaa, during daytime to visit the market where you can find everything (rug, leather shoes, bags, species, and thousands of things that Morocco has to offer) and at night when they have the food stands, it is an experience that no one should miss.

Nothing special and constantly harassed. Passed through but everyone is on your back, no pleasure at allThe views were terrible, even if you got to take an atmospheric photo without someone grumping at you.Best thing to do is parade through then have a coffee somewhere close (we were in Cafe de France) and enjoy the crazy place
Hectic but must see.. Hectic but must see. Monkeys, snakes (only during a day), street food (careful there), entry to souks (narrow streets with mini stores). Install compass app to navigate souks.

Crazy place in a good way.. If you love being chased by teapot sellers and henna women, whilst trying to avoid stepping on snakes or being hit by a motorbike..this is the place to be!It's mental, but we went everyday! The fresh juice is amazing, and the atmosphere especially at night is awesome! Even though it's so busy you still feel safe. Lots of police even though we saw no trouble at all!If.you are in marrakech you don't want to miss this.
Great place to chill. It is in a good location to explore the Medina&many of the attractions like the tombs.You can enjoy lunch on the roof top enjoying a view of the city.

Once in a Lifetime Experience. What a way to get a taste of Marrakech!!! All the tastes, smells and culture of the area all rolled in one place. It was truly amazing. There were individual stalls of local flavors and foods. You are treated like family. No better way to dive in! Every sensation is overwhelmed!

Dealing at the Markets. For those of you who haven't bargained at a traditional market before, Jemaa el-Fnaa is the place to bargain for anything. It's really fun. Don't be shy to bargain because that's what vendors here want you to do.I got a "magic" box that was 60% less than the price he marketed. Most vendors also speak English so don't worry about needing a translator.

It's a Big Square. Try some very inexpensive fruit juices, avoid Henna ladies, snake charmers, monkey handlers ect. Overall, this place is stressful and filled with tourist traps however, it is a classic Marrakech feature. Try visiting during the day as it is much less crowded. If you want the full blown experience though go at sunset and stay a bit to see the madness.

Unic experience. this pláza full of life good entertainment good food peoples animals monkeys snaks donkeys this place for everybody don't go there with western expectations after critizise everything this place unic they try to get your Business but they understand if not.This place not for shoping if like good food your stomack can handeled it go for it majority foods it is grilled We had lifetime experience unforgetable memories on positive way

Must see Marrakech highlight. No visit to Marrakech is complete without time spend in the Jemaa el-Fnaa square and most visitors will pass through it on many occasions and at different times of the day. Whether it is for food, freshly made orange juice, entertainment (snakes, acrobats, drummers, etc), henna art or just to people watch, this is the place to be. Always vibrant and interesting.

Slightly overwhelming. Marrakech can be slightly overwhelming if you are already quite anxious. While Jemaa el-Fnaa is a must see, be aware you will be constantly harassed, especially a night. I would recommend checking it out more during the daytime. I realise half the fun of it is in the evening as it comes alive, but I just found it too much - especially after getting lost in the souks. But if you're all for getting into the thick of it and have your wits about you - go for it. Just be aware of the henna ladies trying to grab your arm and the men with snakes!

Great vibe, but be wary of the food stalls. Square has a great vibe a night. Grab a balcony table at one of the restaurants and enjoy a meal and drink while watching the action. Walk through as well but watch out for snakes! Great impromptu entertainment - make sure to give them a few dirham for the efforts!!

World's most annoying place as a tourist. Tons of guys in your face trying to get you into their food stall to overcharge you. Juice stall guys caling to you as if their juice stall is any different than the 5 others next door. Touts walking into patios of cafes selling the same unwanted stuff as the other touts. Go down a street off the main square and you will be harrassed about where you are from and what accomodaruon you need help finding. Sharks pretend to be friendly but demand money later. Attached souk to main square was not too aggressive but main square was unpleasant as a solo tourist.

Craziness!!!!. People, horses, hawkers, vendors, dancers, musicians, and more people in the evening and snake charmers and shysters in the day. Yes it is crazy but you have to experience it at least once. If you are nervous take a carriage ride through the area and get a removed view. Leave money, cameras, and jewelry home and take a stroll through the square especially at night ...the lights and crowds are unprecedented!

Night adventure. The square is full of atmosphere and exciting smells of different food being cooked. One has to be very vigilant as there is quite a number of men that are trying to rip you off one way or another telling you they will be your guide etc. We ate vegetarian as we find with that type of food we don,t get sick if it isn,t cooked properlyVery interesting visit

Sensory overload. Where do I start...the sights, the smells, the people. It is bonkers! Personally preferred the quieter markets but going here is a must to attempt to see all that's on offer. Snake charmers, food, monkeys, spices, singing, dancing...the list goes on. Everything here is over priced and the quality of products isn't great (I. E argan oil is diluted) but as an EXPERIENCE, I think it's a must and recommend it.Warning though, watch your bags and (seems obvious) don't let anyone start drawing on you. My hand was grabbed by a women who started to give me a henna tattoo telling me 'it's free' but then her bigger, tougher comrade arrived demanding 450DH! After a typically un-British public dispute, they got a couple of quid from us and we ran away. Not sure about the quality of the henna as well as within minutes my skin was burning so washed off.

Henna attack!. You've gotta be so careful! Whilst I was walking around we were grabbed by a henna lady, I said no and she still went ahead and did henna on me and then demanded payment. We said no as I didn't want it, then she rubbed it off and smudged it up by boyfriends shirt!However, the square is a must see and as long as you've got your wits about you it's fab!

Mesmerising, chaotic and a must on your trip to Marrakech. You will know that you are nearing the square as you will start to hear the noise, thunder of drums and instruments long before you see it. Once you arrive, it is truly mesmerising and chaotic, great to just stand there for a few minutes and absorb the atmosphere before wandering around. We visited the square many times during our stay and we ate one evening at stall no.15 - great food!

Amazing experience . You must must go here if you are in Marrakech. Make sure you go at night time to get the full experience. Don't go inside the food stalls unless you really really really want to eat there, it's unsanitary and you'll get legit harassed by the guys trying to make you sit down at their stall.

Crazy place, too much for my taste. Crazy, crazy, crazy... Very loud, very crowded, loads of sellers, food stalls etc...Watch out for guys with the snakes as if they will notice that you are taking pictures - you will have to pay... I did had dinner in one of many food stalls! Never ever I would do that again, it's dirty, full of tourists and you don't get what you order! In my case, I ordered from menu but the guy brought me like 9 different plates that I didn't even order... of course you have to pay for everything... I would call this place a tourist traps, if you are not carefully, they will rip you of.....Must visit place while in Marrakech but only to see what it is like....If you do like shopping, then this is the place to go, but be prepared for lots of bargaining and very pushy sellers
Wonderful place. Very festive and lively place showcasing the life of Moroccan people and culture. A must place to visit

Has to be experienced!. This vibrant city square is a must, walk round and take in the colours, smells and pulse of the city. At night a hive of activity not just for the tourists but for the locals too. To not spend time here is to not really see Marrakech!
Chaotic and noisy - not a must to visit. Can give this one a miss - really touristy with lots of snake charmers and other kitschy items on sale.
Tourism. A must see if you go to Marrakech.Stalls and culture. Be careful not to be pulled in by the very pressing traders

Night-time excitement. If you have a picture in your mind of Jemaa el-Fnaa - this is the real thing. The Square comes alive as the sun sets and you are surrounded by 100's of food stalls, buskers, sights, sounds and smells. It is a feast for the senses.

Not for the faint hearted . Although you have to go, be prepared to shoo off the would be vendors. I got an unexpected 'black' henna on my hand. It will be there for weeks!! Street food at night is great.

Horroble. First time Marocco, first time Marrakech and my first experience gives me immediately a wrong impression of the people and country. Harassing men, overpriced, over crowded, annoying people (young and old). Food around the Djemaa el Fna is tasteless, hope this will be different when I'am leaving Marrakech.

Wow. This square is the heart of Marrakech and is the most alive, crazy, colourful, nousy, fun and totally insane experience ever. Its a total assult on all senses and a never ending wow experience. Cant wait to return.

Fascinating. Snake charmers, story tellers, card readings, spices, fruit, dubious looking good stalls! It's all here, you have to go. Just politely say no to all the vendors! Great experience especially at night.

Worth a visit to experience the madness, buzzing at night.. This place is just a must do while in Marrakech. The mayhem of it all just has to be experienced. It took us awhike to find it but we were just strolling around with no local map which would of made it easier. There's musicians, street performers, snake charmers, lads with monkeys doing tricks and locals selling anything from cigarettes to gold and leather. My mate wanted to go to the food souks but my god are you absolutely plagued by locals shoving menus in your face, literally one person from one stall on your left and another from the stall right next to it on your rightshoving a menu at you all promising the best food in Morocco and they have all the tricks and short greetings in most languages. One fella was spouting off some "Gaeilge" to us to even get us in. It's all the same stuff, lovely jovely, why walk down there when you can just get the same here. As soon as theh see you're not interested they're gone to the next. We eventually sat down at one food souk, I wasn't eating as I wasn't hungry. We were having fun with the cooks, posing for photos and then when I wasn't eating he said sorry but the seats are inly for 2 people eating so up we got and left. Walked through another aisle of stalls with more locals trying to get us seated to eat and at this stage I was so fed up with them and couldn't wait to get as far away as possible from them. So be prepared for all of this, including street traders and you will be fine. It's definitely worth a visit though. I'd say we stayed there for about 1 hour. A better option would be to find a good restaurant that overlooks the square, eat there and get a birdseye view of all the madness from one of the restaurant terraces.

Visit this UNESCO heritage as soon as possible. This is a must feel, must see, must smell, must hear reminiscence of traditional life in Marrakech. It will soon fade away: flows of tourists, chinese artifacts menacing to replace local traditional manufacture.

Busy and chaotic!. Jemaa el-Fnaa is a very unique place. It is a large open-air square filled with people selling food, drinks and various items (primarily souvenir related) or services (like pictures with monkeys, guys dressed up in stereotypical Moroccan wear and women doing Henna). Everything is negotiated in here. There are also various performances usually at night time and that is really when the square becomes alive. And hot food stalls also set up during the evening. Men singing and playing instruments in circles throughout the square while audiences build up around each circle.I think what is really important for people is to know that it will get busy and chaotic here. This is something you need to prepare yourself for and a fact you need to accept before coming into this area. It is possible that this is not everyone's ideal space to be in so that is something to consider.Also do not be gullible. People will try to sell you something or invite you in to something you may not necessarily want. For example one of the men dressed up in Moroccan wear tried to invite me to wear a Fez hat and take a picture with them as my boyfriend and I walked past. It all happened so fast and they just about put the hat on my head (without my permission). I quickly tried to brush the hat off and politely declined and walked away because I did not want to pay for the photograph with them. If you want this photograph and are willing to pay then this is all totally fine: they are very friendly. But do not assume they are being friendly because they randomly want to be your friend. They are trying to sell you something. That is business. So it is important to be aware of that to have a safe and good experience in the square.I rate this site 5 circles because it is truly a one of a kind experience that I enjoyed. Keep your wits about you and you will have a great time exploring the square and seeing the performances.

Closest thing you can get to a concert !!. This is a large open square on the edge of the Medina ( Market ) It is thriving with people at night and is a focal and meeting point for locals. Stalls selling food, traders selling their wares, snake charmers and dancers about. Horse and carriage rides, Tuktuks, you name it, they are all here. Very lively crowded place where the locals aim to fleece the tourists....well thats why you are here !! great fun, seemed very safe, no hassle other than from the touts trying to get you to sit at the food stalls and buy food and what is commonly known as the lucky lucky men selling fake iPhones, watches etc. Well worth a visit, but try not to be offended by the locals trying to earn a living.

Up and down experience. Ladies be careful because me and my friend were constantly hassled by guys every time we came. They'd say all sorts,"hello Chocolate, hello family Obama, this way to my house!" People our constantly trying to sell you stuff, there's a lot of beggars and it becomes quite crowded at night. Good place to get fresh juice but there's flies everywhere on the stuff the stalls are trying to sell.
Busy!. Busy market.. Bemindful of being dragged into the stalls for a look as they will bargain with you. Never take their first offer..All in all great experience

Medina Street food!. Visited here in the evening and wow what a wonderful experience. If you visit Marrakech you must try the street food! We wasn't sure what to expect but was defo worth it! At first we did get a bit intimidated with all of the hassle to try and get us to eat at the different places. You are literally bombarded with men and boys trying to get you to eat at their market stall. If you just keep saying 'no thank you' and continue to walk it isn't too bad! We eventually got through this and settled down to eat at one of the stalls. It had been raining so we needed to get shelter. The food at stall number 100 was so good! Such an experience to just sit there and order various dishes without really knowing what was going to be served! Very tasty food and so cheap! If you visit Marrakech you need to experience this!!

amazing sights. The whole experience of Jemma el-fnaa was amazing the food was good and the whole atmosphere was exciting and interesting we felt very safe and ended the evening by returning to our hotel on a horse and carriage which was fabulous.

Over rated. The side streets of the Medina along with other squares were far more pleasant to visit. Seeing monkeys tied to chains was disturbing and it was difficult to avoid the horse pooh. Loved Marrakesh and the madina area but the square was over rated

Busy and crowded . I went in the morning and at night. In the morning, you get to see shops opening and people getting ready for the day. At night, it can be overwhelming from the people yelling to get your attention to the music playing to cars honking. There are many many food stalls and shops you can choose from - be prepared to spend at least half a day here. I thought it was very safe to go solo as a woman. Make sure you haggle!

Cultural and vibrant . Absolutely smashes yr senses! The colours, smells, sounds, visual experiences, such a cultural education. People smiling, selling beautiful locally sourced and handmade products. I wouldn't recommend in the heat if u have walking difficulties or u r a nervous person but if u luv to barter for bargains and experience new lively vibes, I would say "Go+enjoy!"

Better at night. An average bustling square during the day, and a chaotic place at night! A must see for sure, but it's annoying to hang out there too long, with people shouting at you every which way you look. Ladies, watch out for the henna merchants who will just grab your arm and start drawing, then ask for money once they've finished. It's also sad to see all the poor monkeys in diapers on chains taking pictures. Basically anyone you take a picture of/near will ask for money, so be prepared to either pay or argue. Freshly made juice is nice here (and there's lots of sellers of it), and only about 10 dirhams.

Camel ride, Atlas Mountain tour including waterfalls and a guided tour of the Souks. Best to hire an accredited guide, cheaper than booking through hotel and more personal. striking up a brief friendship and learning some Arabic is respectful and rewarding.

All life can be found here. Snake charmers, food stalls, mint tea, restaurants with balconies, market stalls and hawkers selling their wares. You'll find everything and everyone in Jemaa el-Fnaa. Visit during the day and at night and you'll see both sides of this remarkable place.
Bustling Square . Must see while in Marrakech - particularly at night. The eclectic music and vendors make for a unique and unforgettable experience.

Exciting, but also scary and annoying sometimes. The Jemaa el-Fnaa is really special, if you aren't used to that type of market. Though food trucks are common in Europe/USA etc., there are also fortuneteller, actors with monkeys, snakes and many more "crazy" things. Some people like it, some do not.Also Marrakech seems to go through hard times, there are not many tourists. The salesmen are very annoying and bugging, therefore you should be careful as a tourist (even more if you really look like a tourist).

Trip. Briliant trip .Best one my mum and me did.Booked through the rep at hotel Coach pick up from hotel then to get on horse and carriage.Was nice going round at night seeing marrakech at night.Then to a cafe for a drink.45 minutes free time at the square to shop and haggle which we did.Or for those that didnt want shop sat people watching

A must do in Marrakech! . Visit one of the cafés and enjoy the bustle or buy a freshly squeezed orange juice.
Did'nt fancy the snakes and horses - animals should'nt be used as entertaiment for tourists and the horses were dirty and skinny.

Don't be put off. Day or night this place is phenomenal. The day brings about tourists,and yes hustlers, but they're usually harmless with a firm no. By night the food stalls and performers come out and the transforms into one huge party. Be careful of your pockets, but relax enough to enjoy the banter and fun of locals wanting your business.

Heart of everything.. Busy, noisy, colourful, fun and exciting. There is so much to take in.
Fabulous, especially from restaurant/ café rooftops at sunset onwards

Kind of gross and dirty . I would not recommend going to this destination especially at night without a Moroccan guide. We did not feel safe and there was not a whole lot to see. It smelled terrible too.

Don't make eye contact during the day. Full of hustlers during the day. One man was wearing a fez and had castanets, and was making goofy faces. I smiled, and that was all he needed to approach me. he asked if I wanted a photo. I said no. he shook my hand but would not let go, I asked him to let go. he did not. he asked for a drink of water. He took my water bottle, and wanted me to chase him for it. I didn't. We learned quickly not to ask for directions, appear lost, or follow people that want you to follow them. At night there are more people, and you can then browse and make eye contact without someone trying to take advantage of you.Tourist trap for sure.

Contained Chaos at its finest . Truly overwhelming at first, by it is certainly the key to Marrakech's charm. A visit to Marrakech without spending a large chunk of time in the main square of Jemaa el Fnaa is a shame. In the early morning, retailers are less overbearing and the shopping experience is far more enjoyable.Lunch time heat becomes almost unbearable however, there are plenty of little cafes and restraunts nearby to escape if need be. This is when the entertainers are out in full force and the square starts to come alive.By night the square completely transforms into a carnival of dancers, hundreds of food stalls and neon lights flung into the air by street performers. The minarets and mosques are lit up and surround the square with beauty.It may be overwhelming however, always remember that fortune favours the brave.!!

Madness . The square has a lift it's own, a sight to be seen but one we will not be repeating. Not knowing what to expect from the main square I can say we were overwhelmed, so many people in one place so many sounds, smells and sights, especially of a weekend. From a guess your weight teller to Bird men, live boxing and acrobats to name a few. Worth a wander but just a one off for us.

Exotic Marrakech. Snake charmers, wonderful things to buy and taste it's all good. But watch out don't backup into one of those snakes while taking pictures. While the shopkeepers are aggressive they mean you no harm. Just learn to say "no" and move on. Women should not be walking alone in the Medina -- go with a friend.

A cacophony for the senses. . You need to visit the square during the day and at night. During the day there are snake charmers, acrobats, monkey tamers, street hawkers, juice stalls, henna tattooists and more. Be warned if you want to take photos it will cost you. We stayed away from the monkeys and snakes as they are not treated well and paying for photos only encourages their use. Also steer clear of the very insistent henna ladies as they use black henna which contains harmful chemicals, go to the Henna Art Cafe instead. At night dozens of food stalls set up. They all have to compete for trade and will make you feel like their new best friends to get you seated at their stall, once you sit down they figure your hooked and their attitude changes. We were not very impressed with the quality of the food at 117 (you're in heaven-not) The other part of the square is full of musicians and entertainers which was fun. We found two nights was really enough.

This happens every night???. What an amazing experience!! We had about a 40 minute walk from our hotel which for some of the party was a bit much but what a sight awaits you. The hustle and bustle is never ending. We spent some time just sitting on the balcony of one of the many cafes just watching the organised chaos below us before venturing in to it for a short time.
Shopping. Amazing shopping, you will get good bargains here and also see the historic city of Marrakech.. just don't get caught up with entertainers they ask for a lot of money!

Like Camden Market but on a grand scale. One of the most impressive markets in the world. So many small side streets that hide hidden treasures.
Definitely something for everyone to see and discover though not a great place for animal lovers, given the treatment of the horses, donkeys, caged monkeys, turtles, reptiles all in very cramped conditions

Amazing place. Amazing place to visit!!Its better at night,a lot of people and shows,you cannot lose it!!Be carefull with monkeys and snakes photos,they will want you pay a lot of money,ask before it.

It's crazy . I rated this excellent not because it's a great place in traditional sense, but because it was so different experience for me as someone from Europe. All I can say that it's just crazy! The haggling, pulling and selling- oh my! Just be prepared when visiting! And watch your bag and wallet.

Too much harassment . Very bad experience over all. Every single person harasses you here either for shopping from their shops or for money. Every other person is begging here they follow you and force you to pay them. Disgusting
The medina of Marrakech. Worth a visit and spending quality time in the market square to see the culture, localities, shows and shopping
GREAT. Brill, loved ever thing about it, day or night something different always. third time and cant wait to go again.

More going on then I could absorb. Night or day. This is a visit to the past, present and future. Great foods and markets. Acts on the street, reasonable good. The weather is perfect the culture permeates your soul. Morocco is a diverse country but Marrakech was my favorite. I had no fear walking around alone and I am a white American. I felt safe.

Chaotic but fun. You have to visit the square; it's where it is all happening. Restaurants, snake charmers, market traders, souks , henna artists etc, it is all here. It's mad and it's brilliant. Sit on the terrace of one of the eateries and watch the craziness happening while you eat/drink/rest.

Agraba style :). It's like walking into the movie Aladdin... Snake and monkey charmers, street food and juices.
The square is just insane, full of life and culture...
A definite must see when in Marrakech

Have fun!. You have to come. Must be one of your reasons to come and visit this wonderful country in the first place. It is crowded! It is wonderful! Yes they have tourist traps but it's pretty much unavoidable. Try the food and ask for the final price when you order! They also have a few tea shops around the medina. Just walk around and have fun!

Crazy place but a must whilst you're there. You can't go to Marrakech without paying a visit to this place but be prepared to be hassled A LOT! Whether its people trying to get you to buy off their stall, med trying to put monkeys or snakes on you or ladies trying to get you to have henna tattoo. Keep your wits about you, don't feel pressured to buy anything and walk away unless there is something you want to buy and then barter! Be careful of the people with snakes and moneys and the henna ladies as they will trick you into paying for something you didn't want. A lady grabbed my off whilst I was there in an attempt to do a tattoo, I abruptly removed my arm and walked away. The atmosphere is great though, especially at night, give on eof the food stalls a go!
Busy square, center of all Marrakesh. Everyone. Everything. All at the same time... mosques, dancers, snake charmers, tourists, shop and cart people, donkeys, horses, moneys, people, cats

It's so busy! . I want to be clear, this was very much not for me. I don't really like huge crowds, being hassled or snakes... On reflection, this was not a good choice... There is a lot to see, but you need to be in the local mindset. At night it's far more enjoyable (for me at least) as it's less aggressive, but still quite pushy for trying to get coins out of you. I'd say it is somewhere you have to visit whilst you're here, but once was enough. Keep your wits about you, don't extend your hand to anyone unless you're willing to part with cash, and learn how to say "no" firmly but politely
Classic. Amazing place very rich in culture would deffo go again and nightlife is amazing and fun to haggle prices :D

exciting...... exciting ....busy ...be cautious with your belongings.... bargain.....to eat ....lovely fish....fruit ...fresh and goood.....the fresh juices...good.....but those guys are tooooo quick....can spin u around and u dont get your change back....could spend hrs absorbing the atmosphere.....

Horrible. Gives a bad name to a lovely city. Avoid this tourist trap. The snake charmers are charmless, the monkey trainers are aggressive and the kids are a total pain in the neck.If you go into a cafe for a drink, you won't find a beer at most and the loos cost money.Apparently it's a must see in Marrakesh, but it puts a pall over an intriguing and interesting city.Don't bother.

Annoying and average food. Very touristy place. We went there in the evening to eat. You are harassed by every stand to stop and eat. The food is keep on stalls that are not refrigerated. The quality of the food is below average and the prices are not so cheap. The meat was chewy and not very good. I would not recommend to go eat there. Also, to see monkeys being chained up with a diaper doing tricks is not really our thing.

So much fun in the evening. Loved finding a rooftop restaurant and watching the chaos and excitement at sun set. The smoke from the cooking and all the tiny electric lights was so atmospheric. I enjoyed it immensely. The henna lady who grabbed me, drew a completely crap design with a blunt needle (quite threatening) then demanded an extortionate amount of money really ruined my experience.
a day visit. not bad to wander around during the day but a diffrent place all together at night with all whats going on plus you have to stay switched on.

Avoid the monkey and snake men, but check out the view. Be sure to steer clear of the men with monkeys and the snakes (generally out at daytime), as if you get close they'll insist on putting the animals on you and then insist you give them money. Paying them anything is subsidizing criminal gangs and animal cruelty. The snakes often have their fangs removed and mouths sewn shut, and the mutilated snakes often starve to death. The monkeys (Barbary macaques) are endangered and poached infants from the wild.

Hassle hassle hassle . We visited the square first about 8.30pm and couldn't walk 5 steps without some street seller or food vendor literally physically trying to drag us to whatever they were selling.After about 1/2 hr we'd had enough and retreated to find somewhere to eat away from the square.After eating we returned about 10.30pm and although still hassled it was much reduced as many vendors were closing up and the crowds were much reduced. We managed to get close enough to see and hear some of the local entertainment that although entertaining was obviously much exaggerated local dances or music for the tourists. It was an experience that we really had to do considering where we were but not fussed to repeat

Jeckyl by day, Hyde by night. This is just a very large open, busy square during the day but transforms at night. If you can, go to one of the roof top bars around 7 and watch the square come alive is the sun goes down. It becomes a buzzing hub of activity. Yes, there are people that'll hassle you but for the travel-savvy it's easy to handle. There are story tellers, snake charmers, food sellers as well as people just trying to sell whatever they've been able to buy elsewhere. You can take photos of the people there but you'll need to donate. Otherwise, wander around and take in the smells and sounds for as long as you want then retire to a saner place for a drink.

A trip to the exotic. Marrakech has always seemed such an exotic place from afar and jemaa el fnaa is the centre of it all. I had come here with my daughter. We like to explore and this haven of activity gave us the ideal opportunity. Food, music, side shows captivate your attention, particularly at night. The souks leading off it provide a myriad of streets (over a 1000) we were told housing everything you can think of. Yes we were approached by sellers and their wares but nobody was unpleasant. Haggling is expected and I would advise trying a few places for the thing you want to measure reaction. If you walk away and they don't follow you have hit below their price! DO have a price in mind before you start the process. We walked to and from the square at night and felt perfectly OK. Crossing the street can be interesting. Advice is watch the locals and follow suit! Just enjoy all the hustle and bustle and have fun. If that is not your style pick somewhere else to visit!

Be careful.. It is not safe or tourist friendly . I was surprised by the low level of security and the rode of people to tourists ... I faced and heard the worst words in my life in this place ( just because we are not paying to beggars ) ... The food was really bad compared to other restaurants in the city.

Busy and Fun experience. Fabulous foods, especially the fresh orange juice and dates.Very interesting. Great if you like to haggle and share mint tea with the vendors. Lots to see day and night.I always felt safe.

Must-see in Marrakech . Interesting enough in the day, but Jemaa el-Fnaa should absolutely be seen in the evening (6pm+) to get the truly rich experience. Every evening (7 days per week, don't believe it if you're told otherwise!) the square and surrounding souks come alive. In the day it's all tourists, in the evening locals come out and join the crowds around storytellers and artists. The noise, the hectic hubbub, make for an electric atmosphere. The street food is amazing and the souks are fun if you feel like haggling for something and don't mind the typical marketplace pushiness. A word on this, and also a couple of tips... I strongly recommend taking Marrakech, and the souks in particular, as an experience. What I mean by that is that it is illogical to come to a place known for its markets and bartering and not expect some quite determined salesmen! This is their living and they are working hard for it, personally I absorb their insistence with enjoyment as part of the whole spectacle. If you don't want something, be polite, firm and walk away. You may have to put aside the manners you would expect to use at home and walk away with someone still trying to talk to you, but then again, you're not at home...Regarding bartering, DO! It's part of the way of life. There are a few places where prices are set (such as the artisans complex a couple km to the south) but not in the market stalls. As a (very) general guide, I would halve the first price they offer and then only pay maybe 10 dirhams more. Obviously this is relative to the product. The best method I found was to try offering a price I thought was fair -to-low and see the reaction. If they look nonplussed but continue in conversation, you can probably get them to that figure or close (it's simple good haggling to give a little!)If the stall holder freely steps back and lets you leave, without any attempt to keep you engaged, you know it's too low. Then you can adjust at the next stall until you hit the mark. Don't worry about finding the same thing again, I can guarantee you will!As for non-shopping tips, just beware the snake charmers and henna 'tattooists'. They can loop a snake around your neck to pose for a photo or grab your hand to start drawing and then will expect payment. Be insistent and pull your hand away; don't be afraid to put a snake (or anything else put on you) on the ground to be able to walk away, but do it immediately and don't take photos, as by that point you will be pretty much obliged.Biggest tip: relax and enjoy the craziness. It's a blast to the senses but a good one.

Beautiful vibrant square!.
