Great place to hang out and people watch, see the local entertainers singing, dancing, telling stories etc. The snake charmers, dancers, monkey guys etc will want to take money off you of you have photos taken with them so just be aware, but enjoy it! many many stalls here during the day and more in the evening with the food stalls (almost like mini restaurants)...you'll get a bit of pressure from the touts who are there to bring people in, with shouts of "takes you to heaven" etc...oh and expect to be introduced to "Moroccan Jamie Oliver" at almost every stall! Most of the food is pretty much the same everywhere so pick the one that makes you feel most comfortable or the right budget for you (we had a filling meal of couscous, tagine, bread, olives, salad and mixed kebabs, with a coke and complimemtary mint tea at the end, for around 170 Dirrhams, which worked out around £15 for 2 people, so it's not exactly expensive for what you get).Restaurants around the Jemaa will charge a little more but again you pay your money and take your choice and you shouldn't have much trouble...most of them have at least one waiter who will speak more than one language so you should be able to find somewhere with staff who speak your language.Henna "tattoos" are very overpriced here for tourists...the back of one hand should cost no more than 25-35 Dirrham...they'll ask for between 300 and 400 so beware of this, agree prices for anything beforehand and hold the money in your hand so they can see what they will get, so no misunderstandings, and pay on completion, smile sweetly and walk away. Photos with street entertainers will also cost you but pay a modest amount and don't get into a long drawn out discussion about it...at the end of the day it's just a photo and you have the rest of your holiday to get on with so don't let one experience spoil the time...a good tip is to keep maybe 20-50 Dirrhams in your pocket for such an eventuality if you WANT a photo...and ask them for one, tell them what you are willing to pay, agree and pay what you agreed and be polite but firm.Most people are polite and friendly here, just be firm if the pressure builds too much, and walk away with a firm "merci, Non" or "Shukran" (thank you in Arabic)The atmosphere at night is soooooooooooo different, you really must visit in the evening...we had warnings about pickpockets etc but in the entire week (and we were out and about almost all day every day) we never had any problems with pickpocket attempts or any kind of aggression from anyone.You can also hire a horse drawn carriage from the square for a tour around the Medina...again agree prices beforehand!

A truly out of this world experience. Can`t even describe how mind blowing this place is and I fully understand why it was given UNESCO world heritage status. Anything and everything you could possibly want shopping wise is to be found and all the fun is in the haggling! Remember to aim for a third of the price initially given by seller, its all part of the fun to barter and negotiate the final price! Food stalls are superb quality and excellent prices as are the rooftop restaurants that provide spectacular views of the human jungle that lies below. Cobras, berber tribal musicians and the freshest orange juices known to man all lie in its maze of artisan and cultural epicentre. I felt extremely safe and welcome by the locals at all times not just in the square but throughout the entire city. One day I will be back, Inshallah.

Very good place!. Listened to a few negative reviews and was a little concerned especially for my wife, but we thoroughly enjoyed wandering the square of Jemaa el fna. It wasamazing with all the sights and smells. all night with music and food and entertainments .

Bustling . We visited the centre as it is the best place to get gifts in the old quarter.However be prepared as you will be bombarded by street hagglers, beggars, henna drawers and cheap tat.Personally liked the looking, but hated the constant following and pressure to lift your money from you.Go with an idea of what you want, be prepared to walk away and to be firm and say No.Do not step into a shop unless you want to buy anything.Not for the faint hearted!

Extraordinary at night. During the day, this place is buzzing with performers, acrobats, wildly dressed water sellers, and people, mostly. Including snake charmers. The snakes have their mouths stitched shut. Awful. (Please don't give them money.)At night, it transforms. You can watch the sun set for a rooftop bar nearby, and watch the food stalls light up and the people come to eat, and it's mesmerising. The chanting from the mosques is incredibly atmospheric, and the smoke from the barbecues in the square smells mouthwatering.Down in the square, there is a huge assortment of food, from a plate of french fries to a roasted goat head, and everything in-between. Plenty for vegetarians. And the orange juice stalls sell the best freshly squeezed orange juice from the sweetest of oranges.If you're visiting Marrakech, there is no way you'll be able to miss this, but it is really worth a visit at night. The essence of the place.

Busy. Interesting to see everything around, but don't stand still for too long else someone will try and sell you something. Monkeys on chains wasn't a nice attraction, but can easily avoid the handfull of these
Disappointing. It's Times Square without the cute Disney characters. There were no acrobats, no firedancers, no story tellers, just crowds and pickpockets. Hated it.

Amazing!!!. We visited El-Fnaa square a number of times during our stay at Marrakech. The square itself isnt very busy during the day, but it does lead into the endless markets. If you wander into the markets without a guide beware of people trying to take you to other places, they seem very friendly but expect a fees at the end. Also remember to haggle when buying anything from market (we were told a product was 200 dirhams but the came down to 50). At night is when the square comes alive, The food stalls all looks amazing and its an amazing experience. Be prepared to be approached by numerous people telling you their stall is the best to eat at. They are all quite amusing. We ate at stall number 117 where the guys were a great laugh and the food was AMAZING! Definitely worth the experience!
Amazing . Could walk around here forever, so many interesting stalls and nice restaurants. People can be quite pushy but if you are firm and say no most leave you alone

Marrakech pro forma. In one way or another; when you are in Marrakech, you will end up here. It is best enjoyed from the rooftop of a restaurant like 'Cafe de France'. It is a facinating place to see what Marrakech is about. Cheap jus d'orange and heaps of stalls to buy all kinds of souvenirs. The vibe is certainly something special. Be aware; everybody wants to sell. Only looking at a snake will make the 'owner' demand money.The sad part, definately, are the monkeys and snakes. Don't know too much about the snakes, but the monkeys look terrible. The way their 'owners' treat them should NOT be allowed anymore these days!!

Like something out of Indiana Jones. Crasiest place I went to in Marrakesh. A square full of snake charmers, king cobras and guys with monkeys. Loads of roof top bars and restaurants to watch the madness from. Not sure I would stay for long but good to have seen it.

Nice atmosphere. . The atmosphere in the markets is nice however the market traders try their best to rip you off quoting ridiculous prices which you have to haggle to get to even a fraction of the cost you wanted to pay. Friends phone got stolen in market too so please be careful.

Crazy square 😉. I can't miss out this place, it's absolutely nuts lol there you can drink a wonderful fresh orange juice for 4dh(£0.30), find the guys playing flauta for the cobra , monkeys, dentist, henna tattoo and whatever you want to buy. At the evening they have the food market what's crazy all the guys trying to offer their food lol. Just be aware that the place specially evening is full of pick pockets, be careful.

Be prepared. Went here a few times and from the moment you disembark your taxi you are haggled and persistently approached do you want a guide if you do. Look for the registered ones have ID cards but then on through a row of smelly horses urine smell potent then you hit the square and its non stop snake charmers monkeys etc all trying to entice you in we stayed on the outskirts went into the souk once it's a maze and you could get easily lost here. Otherwise stay on the outskirts we didn't visit at night I'm sure the local foods are ok but we didn't partake
an incredible sight. this is a must see-everyone sees it in the day time and of course at night-just avoid the monkeys-so sad
Traditional Bustling square always loads to see, do eat. I love this square loads to see and do, cafes and restuarants to eat in, IF YOU STOP A WHILE TO WATCH ANY ACTS PREFER TO PAY/TIP THEM

Soak it up. This place seems a little daunting at first. Watch out for mad henna ladies who will splat henna on you and demand paying for it, the they key to this place is remain polite, but very firm. It's crawling with tourist police, if find you have any trouble the threat of calling them over settles any dispute you may have.

Disappointed with experience. We made a couple of visits to this square during a day trip to Marrakech.The first visit was during lunchtime when there wasn't much going on in the square, and we made a second visit at around 8pm when it was more lively.It looked as if things were just starting to get really lively when we had to leave.There were lots of market traders selling food and clothes etc.There were several sites which weren't so pleasant such as beggars, many badly physically deformed, snake charmers and monkeys in football shirts on chains

Crucible of Con-Artists & Hypocrites…. If you’re thinking of going to Marrakech and haven’t booked anything, do you & yours a favour and give this forgettable, over-rated part of the world a wide berth. I’m at a loss as to how this place gets 5 star reviews, but hey, each to their own. I’ve roughed it in similar countries over the years and have had better, far more interesting experiences. Anyhow, on the face of it, Jemaa el-Fnaa is a huge square that promises exciting insights into North African culture that might make you want to jump right in to gorge the senses. Scratch the surface though, and it really is just a massive dump full of rip-off merchants and folk who are about as sincere as the depth of your wallet. As for the hype about the souks, they are about as interesting as a glorified flea market…if the merchandise looks like a bargain of the century, it’s probably junk. On the other hand, if you haggle hard enough in the belief that you’ll bag a quality item, you might strike lucky, but chances are you’ll be screwed, and will probably feel confused and good about it at the same time. And watch out for those crazies on scooters & motorbikes that whiz about in the tiny alleyways in the souks, and that don’t stop for man, child, let alone a woman. On the subject of women, I would rate this place a no-go zone unless you don’t mind being constantly leered at…and don’t think that having a strong male by your side will deter these wannabe suitors with their tacky charm offensive. You won’t feel any more protected by the occasional presence of the local armed police around the square, as their record is apparently mute on the subject.So despite this well-intentioned heads-up, should you still feel the urge to visit this area, here are a few tips:-Carry small notes at all times and do not produce your wallet/purse unless a deal is struck…what’s makes a good deal is difficult to tell because of the generally crappy quality of the goods, but whatever they quote first up, offer at least half that….and be prepared to simply walk away as it tends to concentrate minds.-Beware of locals befriending you as you walk along and start telling you in earnest how they want to learn your language…these guys works in groups and will do their utmost to walk & talk you into some relative’s rip-off store.-The main tannery in the souks is touted as worth seeing….it’s stinks like hell and is nothing special and could end up being a bad experience if intimated into buying something you probably don’t want…also, as it’s deep into the souks, you may end having to pay some ropey local to navigate you back to the main square.-Don’t even look sideways at those snake-charmers who will latch onto you and try with their toothless grins to wrap a snake around you and then aggressively demand money off you.-Some will say you’ve gotta to try the fresh orange juice from the open stalls in the square….we tried 4 different stalls all offering different quality (usually watered down), but none nearly as good as Tropicana…seriously!-The ultimate hypocrisy was the woman in full burka regalia who desperately tried to seize my adult son’s wrist to scrawl a henna ink design on. Dare any male tourist to grab this dame’s hand back as it would seriously offend the whole of that world. And by the way, the henna ink they use is by all accounts lousy quality, but once they get you by the wrist you’ll be squeezed hard for money. These are just a handful of experiences that my particular group and many others we met on the trip experienced in Marrakech…in short, these people don’t deserve your hard earned tourist dollars.

Eating out beware! . Having been to Marrakech previously with a group of girl friends and this time returning with a large group of couples, reception from male morrocan food sellers was quite rude and intimidating. The square takes on a whole different feel at night and to be honest I felt safer travelling with girls than with our partners. The guys in our group were several times called skinheads as we walked past and we were a group of 40-50 year olds not young teenagers! It may have been their way of trying to be funny and mock the different English dialects but we found it very distasteful and down right rude! Especially when we decided not to eat in the square and head for the Argana restaurant and were told we "can't afford to eat in there cause we were on benefits! " really??? Market by day is lovely and non threatening but beware if you dare to eat in the market square after dark!

Vile. Busy, nothing of any interest - full of animal abuse and aggressive Moroccans. The market sells spices and tat. Do yourself a favour, skip Marrakesh and go straight to the mountains - or another country

Colourful and vibrant place. What a place to visit. It's really busy and full of people. But the scents and colourful nature of the place is amazing. If you don't want it to busy then visit in the day, but if you want the full expierence then visit in the evening. Try one of the rooftop bars to get a great view of the area

Colourful, noisy, crowded. This is the beating heart of the medina. Without it the Medina would be like any other congested, smelly medieval maze struggling to cope with the pressure of modern living. The food stalls are their own theatre and it is interesting to see what is on offer. The guide advised against eating there. The local folk bands add a constant if confused beat to the experience. Sorry but I can't be happy about chained monkeys and squirrels - that is cruel. India saw the light years ago and banned snake charmers - Marrakech should do likewise.

A must see/do!. You simply can't go to Marrakech without spending hours at the Medina. It is always busy but has even more to see at dusk when the acrobats, musicians, jugglers, snake charmers, scarf sellers, juice and food stalls etc set up.

Amazing square. When you visit Marrakech, don't forget to visite the square of Marrakech, or as they name it, Sahet El Fna "place of Fna". Usually stars late, from 10 to 11 in the morning, but they stay all the night, so visit during the night might be more interessant.
Best street food. If you like street food experiences then this is a stop you should consider. The moroccan food is excellent and very affordable.

Best place on earth. This is one of the best place on earth for me , I just love the crowd old market place all the lovely food (and tempting price ) specially in evening, food are clean and healthy and it's perfectly ok to eat , lots of locals, huge horse carriage rank , been many time and never get bored of jame El Fana
Marvelous place to visit. A unique square in the world with lots of crowd, happy people , many street dancers, snake players and more, must visit venue.
Smelly tourist trap. Smelly tourist trap where beggars and pick-pocketers are everywhere.It's a big empty square, which at night fills with food stalls. At the one i ate, the food was delicious.

Worth the visit.. Visited September 2016 as a couple, and as a group of 4.The Jemaa el-Fnaa (or as people called it, "the big square") is easy to find, has plenty of places to eat or drink, shops and various sights.It is a bit lack-luster in the morning and during the day, with the most activity being getting set-up for the evening. And it is the evening when the big square is at it's busiest. It is a real hub of activity as it gets later, with story tellers and musicians (but this is in Arabic), snake charmers, monkey handlers, "sales people", and food stalls.The food stalls sell really tasty food at low prices, and amongst all the touting / competition for your custom the people are actually pretty friendly and funny at the stalls.Having visited the big square 3-4 times and at different times of the day I can say that it doesn't compare to other sights of Marrakech. The snake charmers and monkey handlers will demand high prices for those pictures you're taking (unless you're very subtle), many people will tout for your business (best drinks in town), and the worst offenders are the woman who will grab the hands of your nearest and start drawing henna without warning. Of course everything is taken in light spirit, as the local people are much more to the point and crafty compared to the humble Englishman!The cafes do not even compare to the stalls for food, on both price and taste, but they do offer fantastic views of the square. The best thing about this place is the view during late evening, while drinking a refreshing lemonade or eating (expensive) ice-cream on one of the terraces.Tip: take a break by the carts and buy some freshly pressed orange juice. They are so cheap and delicious! If you're worried about hygiene, ask them to make it into your own flask or use a straw.Overall it felt too touristy and less charming, I certainly had higher expectations. It is not the best thing about Marrakech.3 1/2 stars (if I could give 1/2).
Worth a good haggle. This is worth a visit. Not for the faint hearted if you don't like snakes. Good fun to barter for goods. Amazing history fantastic market to wonder around.

Amazing experience. Jemaa el-fnaa is place you have to visit. From the 5pm there is thousands of people enjoying great cheap food or different traditional artictic performances. The square is surrounded with terrace restaurants from where is fantastic view over the whole square.

Gotta see it, but..... A bit hectic but fun. Be strong, avoid the sellers, monkey and snake handlers and begging children by saying no and being firm. All of the stuff sold around there is imported rubbish, buy in the souks for the genuine stuff.Have a rooftop drink and watch the show.The food market that opens at night was a bit disappointing in general as all of the stalls sell the exact same stuff and you WILL get annoyed by every stall thrusting identical menus and telling you that they promise no diarrhoea. We ate at one and the food was good and cheap but as said, the place in general has nothing more to offer. We had passed a few places on the way to the square I regret not eating at for a more authentic experience.
Lots of action. Great activity, lots to see! Beware that a small tip is expected if you take a picture of a snake charmer, one of the monkeys, or anyone that helps you.

Over Rated. It's worth going to visit the square once but it is a huge tourist trap. Beware of the snake charmers as they will come up to you and try to place snakes around your neck then demand money. They also have monkeys on chains which wasn't particularly pleasant. We visited the food stalls and found the food prefer average. They brought us food we didn't order too and added it onto our bill. It's worth trying the juice stalls but on the white you're better off going to one of the rooftop bars so that you can watch the goings on without being in the middle of it!

Worth a visit. We went here a couple of times during the day and once at night and night time is a lot more chaotic and imposing.During the day it is quieter and easier to navigate through the square and market but you have to visit at night for the atmosphere and ambience.Can't say we agreed with monkeys on chains being dragged around and snakes being used the way they were but lots of people there for this but we loved the bright colours of the market and a good way to get out of the midday sun!

Lively square but be very careful. Well, unlike any other market place this square offers more to tourist. There were good souvenir shops where you can practice your haggling skills. There were locals and monkeys posing with tourists but you have to ask for the price first otherwise you'll get ripped off. I was asked to pay 200 Moroccan dirhams for a photo with a monkey which was ridiculous! Of course I didn't that amount but paid 40 dirhams which some say is still a lot. I could have paid just 20 dirhams. Be careful taking photos of the snake charmers as they were very quick to ask for money and they will follow you everywhere should you decline. A lot of horse carriage around. There were local women who offers henna tattoo. The place goes lively esp at night when people starts to open their eatery for good moroccan food. Some tourists have tea in the elevated terraces to watch the lovely moroccan sunset.

Everything you would expect and more 😁. Absolute blast exploring our way around the markets. Anything you will be looking for - you will find. Be sure to bargain! For true travellers who want to take a piece of history and Morocco home - be sure to buy an authentic vase. We found the vases from Fes to be most authentic and craftsmanship of higher standard

Craziest place I have ever been. This square comes alive at night with stalls, snake charmers, musicians and generally a lot of people wanting your money. You do need your wits about you as one evening I had a young boy trying to sell cakes then started to hug me at the same time as patting me down to find my wallet. A good tip is don't carry a wallet as this is what they look for, anyway chucked him a few coins and made our escape. Be prepared to be amongst thousands of people which for some could be quite daunting but you need to go here at least once during your stay just for the experience.

the food.... Would definitely recommend eating in the square - better than some of the restaurants around it, and way more atmospheric. Prepare to have all your senses bombarded at the same time. Wish we'd done it every night!

Worth a Visit to See but Once was Enough. To be fair it is 3 1/2 stars for the novelty but really is just a tourist trap, boys selling knock of watches, and anything else you could desire. It has to be seen once but that will suffice. The food tents are rip off, we had a very mediocre, quite expensive meal there, there are far better options. We were there in Jan and it was chilly, so perhaps in warmer weather it would be nice to sit in one of the cafes that line the market and people watch.

So much things going on!. Don't expect to relax while hanging out on the square. It's packed of people selling various items, street food, fresh orange juice, musicians, beggars, women doing body painting with henna, little monkeys and so on. Definitely a must see in Marrakech! For the food, I strongly recommend Krita, the stand number 14 for the food. I've been advised by a local very picky with the cleanliness and the quality of the food. It was good and really cheap. Don't miss it.Ne vous attendez pas à un moment de détente en vous promenant là bas. C'est rempli de monde, de vendeurs en tout genre, des stands de nourriture temporaires, des jus d'orange pressées, des musiciens, des femmes qui font des dessins au henné, des mendiants et j'en passe. A ne pas manquer à Marrakech !Pour la nourriture, je recommande vivement, Krita le stand numéro 14. Conseil obtenu de la part d'une locale, très regardante sur la propreté et la qualité de la nourriture. C'était bon et vraiment pas cher. A faire !

Atmospheric centre of the medina . A must visit location. Don't be put off by the constant attention of snake charmers, henna ladies, monkey men and fake guides! Just accept it's all part of the charm! Try and visit late in the day and after nightfall as this is when you can see it at its best.Have a drink on one of the surrounding balconies and terraces to watch the world go by. Definitely come and eat at one of the stalls at night. You will get accosted by the stall holders but it is in good humour so keep smiling until you see the right stall for you. Always wise to confirm prices and exactly what you want to eat. Perhaps the lamb's heads are what you are looking for!!

Something for everyone!. The highlight during the day are the snake charmers and the fresh juice stalls. Juices are all freshly squeezed and are bursting with flavours. Nights are for the snacking stalls and try to eat at stalls that are busy. There are many shops selling souvenirs and do not feel shy to bargain. It is a way of life here!

largest party I hv ever seen. Bit of a culture shock but loved it. Lively and fun. Just need to learn how to say NO to people as many street vendors will try to get your attention which could resemble borderline harassment. But I truly loved the place.

Has to be seen but not a highlight. It's difficult...the square is such a hub that you have to go and see it and there are lots of bars around to enjoy a drink in the evening, but we both thought it was nicer viewed from a bar terrace than actually in the square. It's a nice place to grab a very cheap fruit juice, we didn't eat from any of the stalls but food was plentiful if you fancy it.We found the market and surrounding souks very pushy, in the main not very friendly and I favoured other parts of the city (Mellah and Kasbah). If you take photos of anyone they will actually chase you demanding payment, which isn't that much fun.I'd say go and have a walk around, soak it up but head for a drink on a terrace to enjoy the lovely sunset in a more peaceful surrounding.
Busy central square in the evening . Very hot during day, after sunset it was very nice and alive. Both tourists and locals. Was a circus to find bbq, hilarious. A must experience in Marrakech

The atmosphere of Marrakech. Jemaa el-Fnaa can be hot, noisy and overwhelming, especially at night, but it's a great place to visit! Be prepared to dodge the mopeds and scooters around the side streets and the Kasbah, try the delicious fresh orange juice in the square and sample the traditional tagines in the various restaurants.A good place to watch the square and it's activities is from the terrace of Café De France, sit with a coffee and watch the life of the square. Not to be missed!
Highly Overrated. I was pretty excited to go there but was left highly dissapointed it was quite dirty all around and was like any market in Asia or middle east

Certainly colorful but not the best part of Marrakech. The Jemaa el-Fna is certainly touted as the main sight to see (and experience) in Marrakech, but I found it to be a bit of an overrated distraction. The Medina has much more to offer in the winding alleys, souks, riads and courtyards than the carnival atmosphere in this touristy square. (By the way, touristy does nit necessarily mean foreign - the vast majority of people there were Moroccan). Definitely stop by to check it out at different times of the day during a visit to Marrakech (or if you only go once, go in the evening), but don't make this the main objective of a trip here. The food was unappetizing and stalls uncomfortable, while the entertainment was largely unimpressive with little true talent on display. Nothing of quality to buy, either. Don't miss it if here, but don't plan a trip around it either.

Nice w-e with my cousin and he's wife. And my wife and myself✌️🤘. IT was charming, amazing and all flavors and smells were definitly given something special this night with all the nights and the hundreds of people in the great place. It's something to see at least once in a life

Female, solo, 26yrs . A must.... Central to the marakeshi experience. Eat and drink the cinnamon herbal tea and doughnut balls. Watch singers acrobats, dancers, snake charmers, monkey performers and the water men. Keep your bag close and always say no unless you're with a few friends and you have a few coins and your belongings safe!!
Hustle and bustle. If you can put up with the smells and flies, this is a must. Witness trading at its best. Be prepared to negotiate every price you are given by 60-80%. The hub of Marrakech

Amazing Hustle and Bustle. Totally different in the daytime and nighttime, I definitely recommend a visit during both periods. Day time: peddlers, sellers, orange juice carts, snake charmers, henna artists - all sorts. Night time: Many food stalls, music, juice, stories, peddlers.Recommend heading up to one of many terraces of the restaurants and cafe's around the square and taking in the sights and sounds.
Place to visit. If you are interested to traditional morrocan food I do recommended to go and try.Very nice a d friendly people

Interesting, amazing, crazy, all in one place!!. Great place to go out at night if you like to mingle with locals and see live music bands, eat Moroccan food, see monkey and snake shows, and get submerged with thousands of sounds, lights and smells.. Great places to eat in the middle of the square, one of the best we tried was Number 81, very tasty food compared to some of the other we tried.

Chaotic!. Well where should i start.. my husband and i walked through the square everyday to get to other places. However we did visit the square in the evening and it was mad. It was so crazy filled with people, games, dancers, monkeys. i avoided the snakes as they looked quite vicious. But i wasnt bothered by the henna ladies or the people with the monkey. It was actually quite putting off when i wanted to get a fresh orange juice because the shopkeepers next to each other just started arguing. they get desperate for a customer so i changed my mind. The atmosphere was electric it was great to just see people play games and having fun doing other things. sometimes it does get too much being in the square so we used to visit other restaurants away from the square.
The heart of everything. Experienced the whole feeling of what I imagined Morocco to be. Full of all kinds of merchandise. Friendly people.

Magical. Fascinating array of shop lined streets and the infamous square where you can find Henna ladies, snake charmers and orange juice stalls. A must for visitors in Marrakesh. I found the shopkeepers far less aggressive that those in other tourist resorts in Morocco such as Agadir. Finally be prepared to negotiate!

quite the experience. I don't know where to start from, well beware of the snake guys they put a snake on you without permission and then they are trying to rip you off. other than that the square is AMAZING so much food, freshly made juice and the market very close by.

Its Marrakesh..... Marrakesh famous city around the worldTake horse carriage and make a tour its amazing then go to the place jamma el fnas enjoy the several shows made by local evry nightDont worry big variety of food just keep walking till you find a table and enjoy the food By the end go to argana caffe and have nice tea with mint and enjoy the view from up

Visit day and night. During the day when we visited it was fairly quiet, as long as you avoid eye contact with the snake charmers and men with monkeys they shouldn't bother you. The monkeys are not the nicest sight to see, obviously treated very cruelly we saw lots of them being hit.As others have said, watch out for henna ladies - I got grabbed by the arm so I couldn't move away and she covered my arm in an ugly, poorly done henna design. Demanded 500dhs but eventually let us away with 70dhs.Despite the above, it's nice sitting in one of the cafe terraces and watching the square.In the evening it's REALLY busy, absolutely full of people. Lots of street performers and food stalls, we didn't eat at any of them but enjoyed the sales patter. A must see whilst in marrakech.

Noisy central square and market. A "Must See". Morocco is one of the happier countries in the world, and that shows in this square with its stalls of produce, juice stands. Try the freshly squeezed oranges which are heavenly. At night, there are barbecue resteraunts, which have disappeared the following day.Dancers, snake charmers, monkeys are all there. Plenty of young boys scrounging for tips, but really not too bad. Many "guides" who are touts for stalls, particularly carpet sellers. Think of Last of the Summer Wine and the old lady with the junk shop x 10.Buy instead the exquisite almonds, figs, and dates, and the juice.Ladies, minimise hassle by wearing unrevealing clothes. .

A must visit when in Marrakech. Walk in the square where hundreds of years traders have come from all directions to exchange and barter their goods. Snake charmers, acrobats, boxing matches, food and beverage all converge here...around Sunset is the best time to arrive...go up to the balcony of any one of three or four restaurants and enjoy the chaotic scene below.

Amazingly big and noisy square. Visit during the day and ul see snake charmers and monkeys. Many kids run up to u asking for money. People will try to guide u thru the square, demanding tips. Oh it's an amazing place and I wish to visit it once a year at least!

Overwhelming Experience. From walking from the new town to the square be prepared for Moroccans making conversation with you on the way. Many are friendly and will just point you in the right direction, without hassling you. Some will say they work at your hotel. They do not work at your hotel! If you follow them, they will most likely take you to shops (where they will get commission if you buy something) or will provide you with a tour, expect to tip them you do this. Some will say they are a tour guide, most are and will show you their I.D, but again they will want paying. Once in the square it is very busy, have bags close to your body. Cyclists, cars and mopeds will travel very quickly, alongside donkey carts make sure you have your wits about you. On foot, again they will make conversation with you and try to get you inside their shop. If you venture into the middle of the square you will see many shops with a fixed price which is reasonable. I did try to haggle with them, even on a fixed price but they did not budge. You will see snake charmers, entertainers and monkey. All saying take a picture, again for a price. I had picture with a monkey, he wanted 200dirhams, then dropped to 100, then 50. I gave him my loose change and I would not give him anymore. He even said before taking photos, I will accept any amount of money, but then it changed to only accepting notes. Do not give in and stand your ground! Souviners are very samey, when you see them in one shop, you will see them again, again and again. Keyrings and magnets cost average of 10 dirhams. Bracelets 5 dirhams. Postcards you can buy good quality for 2 dirhams. Try not pay any more than this. Overall fantastic experience!

Cheaper than Primark! . My first experience of the old souks was absolutely terrifying! We went late night and were accosted and thrown insults left right and centre for not stopping at certain stalls. Defo wear a bag in your sight! There are lots of beggars, genuine or fake I can't tell you but they can become quite aggressive so try to carry loose change separate to any wad of notes! The second time we went was incredible! During the day. No beggars. Fantastic live snake charmers, henna artists ( 5 dhms) great customer service! Though the food stalls aren't open during the day, you should head to a rooftop restaurant grab a mint tea and watch the sun set and Jemaa Al Fnaa come alive! Always start at less than half the asking price, be confident, shake hands, and walk away if they don't agree to your price! They will whistle to you as you walk and agree on your first price! I'm not into fakes or replicas but you can nab lots of fake swag here! At the front of the market they will lure you and say everything is cheaper than Asda or Primark! It's not I can assure you! Some things are relatively cheap like t shirts (150-300 dhms) for designer replicas. Try looking further back into the souks as you will get better prices! Pay for quality items such as leather and gem stones but don't pay more than 5 dhms for souvenirs like key rings and coin purses! The soul is best for its craft and artisan pieces so make sure you nab some cultural pieces! Be careful of bringing ceramics back unless u have bubble wrap as the airport staff throw bags about a bit.. And if you want to avoid tears like me... Don't buy beautiful big plates and don't put them in your suitcase! Hold as hand luggage!!!

Night time the best. The square is amazing with all the sights and smells. Night visits are the best to see the snake charmers and spider monkeys. Plenty of cafes to simply sit and watch the hustle and bustle!

An experience. An absolute must if in Marrakech , visited both day and night, night time is my favourite, the sound, entertainement and smells. Can't say I agree with the monkeys and snakes and declined to take photos.There is a cafe in the corner that has a roof top sitting area, well worth a visit and look over the square.You need to be firm with traders and keep,walking when saying no.Drinks from the stalls are good value for money and fresh.Loved it ....
Magic . Different every day. Snake charmers, acrobatics.. Food stalls.. Fresh juice stalls.. Just magic! Go for sunset, perfect to take pictures.

Please don't pay for monkey photos.. Jemaa el-Fnaa is a must see on any itinerary but honestly there are nicer places in Marrakech to see. We were appalled at the treatment of the monkeys which are chained up and we saw them being beaten so tourists can have their photo taken. Please, please, please don't pay, no customers mean no business. There are nice restaurants and cafes, but we were advised by our local guide not to each at the stall, but go to a restaurant or cafe for hygiene reasons. We visited in the height of summer when very little was happening, even in the evenings, but it is obviously a place to see when in Marrakech.

Fascinating by Day and Night. A must both daytime and at night. The place is alive with traders, a myriad of stalls, animals, and people. The sounds, smells and colours are an unforgettable experience. This is Morocco.
Excellent. I was in Marrakech in last few day, it's beautiful city, and the Jemaa el-Fnaa place is amazing full action all night with music and food and entertainments ...I really enjoyed

Crazy . It's an experience. You need to visit.
Spend 1 hour here. Try the food from that stalls. Fresh and cheap. Buzzling.

Just so full of energy!. Great to see during the day, especially if you want to encounter the cobras! But the sunset view is incredible and the second levels of the cafes that surround the square offer the best spots to enjoy it.

Hub of activity. Jemaa el-Fnaa is where everyone gathers at night, during the day the vibe is so different to the night time vibe. Pick one of the rooftop terraces to sit, relax and watch the activities below. I enjoyed watching the setup before sunset of the food stalls, the bands of musicians and various crowd entertainers. Have a wonder through all the stalls before picking one or two to eat dinner, each stall has their people coming up to entice you to eat at their stall, I personally like their rhymes eg 117 takes you to heaven, 114 to the toilet door etc etc you have to laugh..... It's loud, noisy, busy, entertaining and not to be missed.

A true experience of marrakech. If you hate hustle and bustle don't come here. If you want to experience true marrakech lifestyle visit on the day and night. Much busier on the night. Head to le Salama after for happy hour cocktails all night to escape the chaos. And don't take photos unless you have spare change!

Amazing!. We walked around the medina with a tour guide organised by Marrakechdaytrips ,com and avoided all the hassle people complain about. It was worth to pay for a tour as it can be annoying to have tons of people trying to sell you stuff all the time. All kinds of shopping, snake charmers, dancers, food everywhere. Crowded lots of hustle bustle. Snakes, monkeys, Berbers,fresh orange juice(I recommend this guy, he always gave to me extra juice) a lot of cafes, restaurants and hotels, women who make henna. interesting visit - this a must because it really define Marrakech and Morocco - i would recommend to hire a guide because we can get lost easily and waste time

Market . This was a bit of a eye opener ... Lots of trading with everything Thai you can think of...Small monkeys that you could have your photo with, snakes dancing to pipe music...If you want 2 buy some fakes items Handbags and purses... Here a place you can go...I didn't buy anything here except Morocco key rings and fridge magnets...

Madness in Marrakech . A baptism of fire awaits those who have never visited an african market place before! The medina is chaotic, noisy, hot and quite incredible. A must see when visiting this area of Morrocco. Have your wits about you, your purse held tight and enjoy the craziness that is Jemaa el-Fnaa. If you want to eat be careful of the street food,we watched it being set up early on and left in the heat for hours. The streetfood sellers are entertainment in themselves, impersonating Jamie Oliver and throwing us some great catchphrases to draw us in. The square changes from day to night, and as dusk falls the music players and dancers, the story tellers and snake charmers, the tooth pullers and henna tattooists make for a fascinating spectacle. Be warned, you need to be firm. Only show interest if you are happy to pay for the view. And use the phrase non merci as often as you need!!
Place have to visit. The time passed very fast, as we was watching the art rounds.I think it's the only place in Marrakesh keep open after midnight.

Be prepared. Jemaa el fnaa is the heart of the old city in marrakech. With its wild street entertainment, wide variety of food stalls and restaurants and vendors selling everything from bracelets to plates, there's never a dull moment here.Although daunting and some may say not for the faint hearted, if you visit the square prepared it's actually a fun experience. People will try to get you to shop/eat with them and some may even try to steer you in to their places but don't be put off. A firm no (possibly repeated) and they generally back off. There are always police patrolling the area also which makes for a safer feel if you're worried about crime.Also be aware of the entertainers who will try to get you to pay for services you didn't actually ask for for example pictures with monkeys/snakes so it's best to take pictures from afar and/or stay a bit further back from them when walking past.Over all a crazy experience not to be missed!

Mesmerizing . Im Moroccan from Casablanca and I've known Marrakech since I was a kid. Jemaa el fnaa for me is equivalent to Marrakech, you cannot possibly go to the red city and not go to its famous place. Now that I live abroad every time I visit the city I have to go there, eat, walk around to try to figure out what is played in each and every circle. The scene is definitely incomparable. Ow and recently I saw that the snake charmers have new recruits; squirrels. I didn't get the chance to check out what is their function in snake charming business.

Crazy. Just utterly nuts (in a good way) :-). Immerse yourself in this madness day or night- DO IT :-) The vibrancy of this square is just incredible and with endless souks running off behind it- it`s a must .

You've got to do it but... . The storytellers, acrobats, smaller charmers, herbalists, magicians, orange juice stalls and food stalls all make it a magical must visit place.
But the street hustlers, food stall touts*crowds and constant requests for money become tiresome. Jean el-fnaa is amazing but it's not the whole of marrakech - there's plenty more magic in the souks and back streets.

Mindblowing . I have to be honest, strangely i was not aware neither of this square's historical relevance nor it's human dynamics. It's absolutely mindblowing! Is like a vibrant human gathering, with commerce of all types, musicians bands battling with each other for audience with it's very Marrakeshian way to get you, juices, Terraces, Great food... It's All you expect from Marrocos and loads of unexpected great moments.
Souks . Don't be afraid to explore the souks unguided they are very well signposted and don't forget to haggle dress with respect and remember your school French you'll be fine

Lively, interesting but stay alert. Walk around the snake charmers and monkey owners as they'll want cash for a variety of reasons.The restaurant owners will shove menus in your face if you're walking a lite too slowOther than that, a great square to walk in and soak up some of Marrakesh with its terraced cafes, stalls and mayhem Tip: If you want a photo of the snakes or monkeys, use a zoom lens from further back = free and hassle freePS. The bank ATMs in the south of the square are safe to use

Very annoying . Cannot walk two steps without being constantly hassled. The people are very nice, you dont feel at danger but it becomes very old quick the constant hassle for money and you always feel like being taken advantage of.

Never seen nothing like that. A big encounter of many artists, tourists and typical Moroccan song. Be careful on taking photos or filming: you'll have to pay some dirhams to do that. Good food you may find there too.

Lively market place. Super lively square in the medina. At night it fills with food stores and all sorts of local entertainment such as street boxing, snake charmers, bands, soda catching games etc. These are also avaliable during the day. If your keen on and energetic atmosphere then you're safe to find it here.
Bizarre. Quite a bizarre experience with the cross dress belly dancers and snake charmers. Can't recommend the food though, I got very very sick..

Bargain hunt!. A must go for anyone that is going Marrakech. If your after some local spices, food or you want to buy a lamp/light shade, b, leather bag, jewellery or fake watches and clothing. Even if your not you must go here especially after sunset as it really comes alive then.You've been all around the souks and you've done some sightseeing and brought some presents for your loved ones back home and maybe even for your home. It can leave you slightly dehydrated doing all the in the warm night so you head for one of the many fresh orange juice carts and for 2 dins you buy a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice. All off a sudden you smell all of them spices being cooked up into a local cuisine, your belly starts to rumble and mouth starts to salivate. "Let's just go and have a look" you tell each other. Before you know it your sitting down at one of the many fresh cooked food stalls tucking into some tasty grub.Don't be afraid to barter and enjoy as it really is a great experience which you will enjoy.

Exotic scenes. Snake charmers, food stalls, markets, souks, colourful everything and rooftop restaurants.
Beautiful earthenware, leathergoods, baskets, clothing, teapots and cups, lots of souvenirs to buy
Mad!. A great place to wander around, take a drink or eat the street food, lots of entertainers day and night
Dirty and very intense hassling. This is a very big square, it is full of lots of litter and the vendors can be extremely intense. Food vendors were better.

Holiday with my mum . We were staying just outside the square and the square is amazing at night and day very different experiences so worth doing in the day and at night!! Amazing food on the stalls and don't forget to haggle for goods!

less chaotic than I expected. typical square with trinkets for sale and some of the most aggressive food vendors I've ever encountered. They all speak french and english, and a few spanish, so if you answer with a firm "nein danka" they will leave you alone after proclaiming "oh, allemagne"

The square ! Not huge but amazing . The square as everyone calls it. By day just a few stalls and entertainment displays. By night a whole new world. Music. Drums. Food stalls. Sellers. Monkeys. Snakes. You name it. The food is centralised and they are all numbered. They will approach you trying you to eat at theirs. Basically they are all the same its just some do more fish. Some appeal to you more. We had chicken on skewers. Cous Cous. Salad. With drinks. Price 215 dirhams. Lovely food. You have to ignore all the people approaching you. Or you won't get very far. If you wish to buy say a low price then walk away. They always call you back. ! Never pay their price asked. The snake charmers we only saw during for day. The monkeys day and night. Lots of "marks and spencer price" "lovely jubbly" etc. Take it in the way it's meant. Good humour.
Nice place to visit for a change of scenery. The Jamaa al Fna Square is a must-visit at night so that one can see the ambiance, the mobile restaurants, the street vendors, the hennah ladies, etc.

Exceptionnel traditions . This place has changed but remained authentic in so many years. We get pleasantly surprised every time we go there. The food stalls are great. Although the staff tend to hound you a bit to sit at their boots. The great ones with a lot of popularity don't seem to need to do that. . The smells the sounds the street performers the animals the overall experience is a great way to spend the evening. Can't make it to marrakech without stopping by Jamaa Fna.

Interesting experience. Two different worlds divided into daytime & nighttime. Definitely suggest to come around in night when the whole city wakes up and gathers in the square. Just be careful of the masses and the attention you get for being tourist

Good evening atmosphere . We went there for dinner. It's got a buzz. We found stall 15 really rude. So we walked off as they insisted that we order lots of food And we just wanted one dish as our idea was to try out food at many food stalls. Stall 32 Chez Hussan was our favorite for the nite.

Utter chaos at night! Loved every minute!. During the day the square is full of locals selling their wares. And then something crazy happens. It slowly starts to break out into a massive gathering of people. All looking to eat, drink orange juice and experience the local music, story tellers and snake charmers! The smells and sounds are amazing. Just be careful when whipping out your phone for a photo or video as the locals seems to be trained at spotting you and will be shaking their fez's at you to give them some change. It is a mistake you only make once!!

All roads lead to Jemaa el -Fnaa. The heart of the city , and an invaluable street guide as when you are lost in the souks and ask for help everyone understands where you mean in so many different languages even if you just say "big square ",or "grande place " or make a square shape with your hand (as I actually did at one point !)

Go during the day. I went very late at night. I was advised to be very careful of pickpockets. Also not have my phone out because it could get snatched and the person lost in the crowd.The experience was great but the children begging was hard to resist but I would advise against it because you will become a target. I would stay very aware of people bumping and surrounding you when joining a circle to watch performers. Its an exciting place to be but I would only go during the day.

Mayhem but fun . Crazy place lots to see but can get overpowering as the touts do not leave you alone. Avoid the henna tattoos as some mixed with ammonia and can burn badly! Eat at one of the many restaurants round the edge and enjoy watching the sights Aqua is recommended for great food and their terrace is great to people watch. You can get food in the evenings from one of the many food stalls but be aware they will place more dishes in front of you and expect you to pay for them unless you say you do not want them so can be expensive! Look out for the tooth pullers..
So much energy!. Fun to just wander around. Try the street food in the organized central market. The city has organized the vendors and it's a much more sanitary set up then in the past.

Mad nights, quieter days. My first experience of thus square was at night by horse and carriage. You are told it's big, busy and amazing and it really is, we have been back during the day, without a guide but feel a bit vulnerable at night wondering around. Good shopping experience

My city. Considered as a world heritage site. Marrakech has been known with this big esplanade full of food kinds and an open theater since a very old time. Surounded by the souks.. Semmarine, debaghine, nejjarine, all artisanal shops…

Amazing . As a lone, female traveller I was a bit nervous about venturing out on my own to Jemaa al Fna so I went on a Thomson excursion first time round for a guided tour of the Medina and souks. The guides were fab and it was informative.The day after I went via my hotel shuttle bus on my own. I was a bit too nervous to venture right into the midst of the souks on my own for fear of getting lost so I just went around where I knew and bought some fantastic items. I didn't get hassled as I thought I might. I was approached but a simple, polite "la Shukran" and people let me get on my way. When I'd had enough I stopped for some mint tea in a cafe with a terrace and watched the world go by until it was time for my return shuttle bus.I also went on a guided trip on a caleche via Thomson at night. Jemaa Al Fna at night is super busy and I felt a little intimidated despite being in a group, purely with the sheer numbers of people walking around. I personally wouldn't recommend any lone traveller walking around Jemaa al Fna at night. Fabulous experience!

Lively . It's very busy even during off peak holiday season. People are nice though apart from the people that literally try to drag you to eat in their market food stall. We went there on our first night and regret trying the food on the stalls. It really was not nice, no taste apart from extreme amount of salt. But worth checking out the area and looking around.
Loud. Go down at night and watch the snake charmers, magicians, monkeys, drums, etc great fun, definitely a must

mixed feelings... . I have been told to go to that Market while I was visiting Marrakesh... It is an experience.... That s all. I definitely could skip that part of the trip. There is much more to see in Morocco and Marrakesh that you can definitely choose much more interesting trips then that one... Animals are treated very badly, (yes the monkeys are In old used nappies... and yes the horses could be treated better!). Henna lady's grabb ur hands and try to drag u to they places for henna (with a lot success) you can shout 'no' but they just don't care... Once they finish they will ask for money (£400!!!!!!)... A lot of begging people, people try to help u find way for money... And so on... As a old town (Medina) - pretty place, with nice restaurants n cafes with terraces on the roofs (my favourite - bazaar cafe).I personally think that market looks better in the night. And the best view is from restaurant, not necessary from the market...
Very cool experience. A must see! Worth getting dinner at one of the nightly stalls and stick around for some of the music and dancing all around.

Intense but not for the faint of heart. The main square is where the locals have been wheeling and dealing for centuries and it has an incredible atmosphere which is well worth sampling.But it is not for the faint of heart. As a tourist you should be wary. Everyone is after your buck - from the snake charmers, to the henna ladies to the food vendors. And they are all very pushy. So be polite, but be firm and confident as well.One word of warning - do not try drinks from the 4 MAD vendors in the square itself. The quality is poor and could make you ill. Pay a little more and get your drinks in a restaurant.

Don't be scared it's good fun! . Going to Jemaa el-Fnaa is a bit like going to a festival; lots of people lots of noise and a great atmosphere! People will try and get your attention and sell you things but a confident smile and a definite no thank you (la shukran) will usually work. If you are not interested just keep moving. We saw acrobats, musicians and dancers. We glimpsed monkeys but we didn't give their 'owners' any attention because we didn't want to support cruelty. We had a go at haggling for slippers and a few other bits. This was one of the things I had felt nervous about beforehand but it was great fun! You will always get something off the initial price. We ate at one of the stalls, they are in groups depending on what they are selling and all numbered. We were recommended one called Aicha (number 1) by our riad and it was really tasty, I had merguez sausages. It was a great spot to watch everyone go by and there were no nasty side effects if you know what I mean! xx

Crazy Place. A very busy place day and night.One of the worst sights I have seen in Marrakech are the monkeys being walked and pulled around on leads. The men were seen hitting the monkey when the monkey wanted some of his water. YOU SHOULD NOT PAY THESE MEN MONEY for a photo with the poor monkeys.Great Henna tattoo's however if your friend/boyfriend is with you he or she may also get a tattoo that he or she did not want and then the henna lady demands money! Great square for pictures and access to the souks!

An experience!!. You cannot visit Marrakech without visiting Jemaa el-Fnaa, well that's what I was told! Well actually I could, there are far better, cleaner, more interesting places in Marrakech than this. I appreciate its a tourist attraction and to that aim it's a success. Quite frankly I felt concern for the poor animals, the monkeys in dirty nappies, the constantly hassled snakes (which at times were poorly controlled) and the donkeys that looked malnourished. I know people need to make a living and these displays pull in the tourist but it wasn't for me. My teenage children didn't enjoy it either and my younger child was horrified. A must see for some... I won't be rushing to go back.

Go at least twice - both day and night!. This was one of the places I was most looking forward to when we booked for Marrakech. However the first time we visited the square it was mid afternoon and I have to say i was massively underwhelmed! It just didn't have the hustle and vibrance I expected. Sure there were a few Snake charmers, the folks dragging Macaques in football shirts around on chains and the obligatory Henna ladies, but it was just missing something.We went back to grab some dinner at one of the restaurants with a balcony overlooking the square and watched the transformation take place. The place certainly comes alive as the sun goes down! It was much more the experience I was hoping for. There are people everywhere doing every kind of trading, hustling to make a living. For me it was one of the enduring memories of Marrakech and would advise anyone to go at least once and get involved.
Local tasty food. Away from the fancy restaurants of Marrakech is Jemaa El Fnaa where you can have localled street food for very fair prices. I loved it!
Not much happening!. Maybe it was just our timing but whenever we passed through there was just sporadic people with snakes/monkeys, which I find a bit cruel anyway.

Big square -beware!. I visited on two days and in the daytime. It's huge and, while still quite busy, there's more elbow room than reports say at night. Nonetheless, the snake charmers, story tellers and other attractions are there and I found it an intriguing place to mill around. Caution suggests not getting too close to the snakes for photos. Their owners have a worse bite than the snakes, as they will charm you into photo taking, while expecting to be paid. I loved the juice stands which serve up long, cool, freshly squeezed fruit juices. Orange is delicious and very refreshing in the heat of the day. And so cheap. I would love to have returned in the evening, but that is something for another day.

Hustle and bustle. Great atmosphere as the name suggests 'a gathering'. Snake charmers, henna tattooists and orange juice salesman during the day. During the night plenty of food some of which is rank. They did have some events on whilst we visited but not very Islamic and considering the noise reaches the Koutubia Masjid it does put you off a little. Having said that it's a nice place to walk or just relax if you can find a nice restaurant charging you surplus amounts due to location. There are some non harassing shops leading up to the main open area with some good restaurants to choose from that are better priced and have better food. As always you do have to watch out for pick pockets and chancers as well as mixed cultures from marrakech (new to old). Other than that people there's not much to see so best to move along to the souk.

So much to see, great place to find a bargain . It's a lot of fun walking around the square and into the souks. Theres a lot of vendors around hassling you to their stalls though so if you're not in to that sort of thing you may not enjoy it.

truly beutiful. Such an amzing market. Lots of things to buy at bargain prices. You need to bargain alot though because the shopkeepers start their prices quite high and when you bargain it down they agree but you must be very strict on the price you offer. But excellent place. Next time i'm in here i will buy lots of lamps and lanterns as they are beautiful.

Lady visited before dusk. Ok i was a lone traveller, but had a very nice time until I left. I was followed by a young french guy, however i already spoke to someone about him and another guy told him to ... off. He did thankfully, but if you do go be wise not to leave too late and have a plan..theres lots of music and I can def see how naive people get robbed or something else here...however it is also a cool place to go just be aware that's all.....a very nice visit....
The best Square in the world. Every year some of its authentic charm seems to go. However, it's still one of the places you want to be impressed by when visiting Marrakesh

It's definitely an experience!!. I don't think you'd want to come here every evening while in Marrakesh but it definitely has to be done. The place is crazy and overwhelming - not for the faint hearted! There's snake charmers, henna tattoos, food stalls, male belly dancers and monkeys on leads. Some of this could upset you and I have to agree I didn;t like seeing how the monkey's were treated and wouldn;t give any money to something like this. We went on a food tour while in the old town and the man doing the tour told us that one of the snake charmers had died recently when his snake bit him!! Be careful of some of the food stalls and juice stalls and do your research well. I gave mineral water back at one place as the cap wasn't sealed (I've heard they do this a lot). We ate at one of the friend fish stalls that had good reviews and apart from the dodgy mineral water the food was good.You'll get a lot of hassle from people in the square so keep walking and don't let it offend you.

Heart of Marrakech. The square can only be described as the heart of marrakech. During the day the square is a nice place to relax and get some food from the number of Cafes and Restaurants located all around the square. The square on an evening is absolutely beautiful fully displayed by bright lights from various market stalls, I would highlight recommend having dinner at a restraints with a balcony as the view of the square is amazing. The square is an absolute must visit in Marrakech.

The mystique of Marrakech is Jemaa el-fnaa. The one place that is the definition of Marrakesh, from the oh so delicious orange juice (must try) to the snake charmers, to the shopping to the performers to the horse drawn carriage rides to the henna artists and the street performers, you can experience the 1000 and 1 nights in one place. Just love it.

Folk singers, snake charmers and food stalls galore!. An absolutely must see attraction of Marrakech, incredibly charming and comes to life until the very early hours of the morning. Full of folk singers, street performers, snake charmers, henna tattooists and food stalls leading to the cobbled streets of the colourful and vibrant souks where shop keepers await a game of haggling with passing trade. Can get very busy during peak times and the henna tattooists will attempt to start drawing on your hand without your permission in order to get money from you at the end. Stand your ground and be firm if you do not want a henna tattoo, a firm "la shukran" (no thank you) usually does the trick. Please try the freshly squeezed orange juice, so delicious!!! And only about 40p a cup.

Stressful. The sellers are soooo agresive. I was afraid to stop and look at something as it is hard to run away from them if you don"t buy anything. I was glad to wear sunglasses to avoid the eye contact. Also, it was even hard to stop and eat some ice-cream as some children came asking for money. And it happened a few times! This place should learn how to communicate with the tourists if they want their money as I couldn't spend more than 15 DHM which I paid for the ice-cream as I couldn't relax at all. Stress at every step.

Stressful. The sellers are soooo agresive. I was afraid to stop and look at something as it is hard to run away from them if you don"t buy anything. I was glad to wear sunglasses to avoid the eye contact. Also, it was even hard to stop and eat some ice-cream as some children came asking for money. And it happened a few times! This place should learn how to communicate with the tourists if they want their money as I couldn't spend more than 15 DHM which I paid for the ice-cream as I couldn't relax at all. Stress at every step.

Good place to hang out for a couple hours in the evening. We stayed in a riad near Jemaa el-Fna square so it was easy for us to get to it. It was crowded especially after dark. Besides the food and juice vendors there were also street performers and other sellers. We had some really good seafood from one of the stalls on the square and it was cheap. I think it is a good place to go where the local goes and enjoy for a couple hours.

Good at the evening, lot of hassle. The view is the best at the evening from one of the roof terraces. However, you will have to pay an entry fee buying an overpriced drink. Be prepared for hassle all the time. We didn't like what they are doing with the snakes and monkeys. Don't pay them for keeping the animals in such conditions. Everything you will buy there is more expensive than if you go off the main streets.

Awful . Visited this place in the late afternoon and it was a horrible experience. The people will not leave you alone, you cannot even stop for a drink without people coming up to you trying to get you to buy stuff. The children there are just as bad, they will constantly try to sell you tissues and follow you around. If you are a lover of animals I would avoid. They have poor monkeys on leashes who look very distressed and they have them dressed up. It's so sad to see. There's also cages full of tortoise literally piled up on top of each other trying to get out the cage. It's really terrible how they keep their animals. You do not feel safe there at all, a lot of the people are aggressive and will follow you for a good few minutes. I was terrified whilst I was there. I will not be back again.

Changes throughout the day. Come in the late afternoon and park yourself on a restaurant terrace to watch the action build until late evening, then go and explore it until bedtime. In the morning there is really nothing to see. If you don’t want to pay endless tips to the performers etc hanging around then best play deaf and dumb as you keep walking.

Hated the aggression . Far too aggressive sellers at night, all shouting at you making it very hard to even see what they are offering to eat/sell. More settled during the day. Obviously making money when they can but we were in negotiations for a mirror and offered the "fake" version for cheaper. Be ware of how tourist you look. Be confident with bargains and a rule we were told, 40% is the real price they want so work up to that.

Lovely colourful market must visit. I have been marekech 3x and love to go into the markets and buy lamps kaftans and even have black henna done . There is many restaurants nearby that are Moroccan . If you prefer fast food they have kfc which is very tasty . However be careful of eating food or fresh juices as they are not covered and are mostly out in the dreaded heat on the stalls I have personally seen loads of flies bees around the food which is disgusting as they don't cover , If you are looking to go into the small market shops be very careful in getting ripped off as they charge triple prices for tourists . So make sure you a calculater to convert and check how much they are charging you always give them a low price an be prepared to haggle they can end up following you if you walk out of shops given into your price so that is normal . There is loads of scarf and kaftan stalls . You will find spicies and loads of lamps . Taxis do over charge too so make sure you ask hotel for prices to and from there so you know . There are loads of henna stalls very fun to get they have pictures of designs for you to choose however again check you are not allergic to the black dye that is used is black henna .

Mrs Adam . We went lots of times to Jemma el fina Very busy place but lots of things going on . It was lovely and lively . Snake charmers , henna ladies . Juice makers and alsorts of other things. Lots to see and not too expensive to buy . Authentic morrocon items . Like cushion covers , bedding candals lots more . We visited this market at both evening and during the day . If you have young children then I advise you not to go after 6pm because it gets very busy . Overall amazing

Chaos...Look forward and dont smile as its very expensive lol!. Visited the famous Sq to get souvenirs and its as manic as people tell you, beware the monkeys and pythons as it can become very expensive unless thats what you want.Haggle like crazy and usually pay half of what they originally quoted!Good luck!

Nice but sadly to much petty crime. Nice feeling and still maintains a bit of old medina magic, but there is a bit too much petty crime and ultra-aggressive dealers if you are looking for a relaxed evening.

Heart of Marrakech . Snakes, monkeys, Berbers,fresh orange juice(I recommend this guy, he always gave to me extra juice) a lot of cafes, restaurants and hotels, women who make henna, souvenir shops, souk, local performances, taste of food at the evenings- all of these u can see and meet at the jemma el-fna! Just come and enjoy the time( especially at the evening )

nothing like it in the world. having traveled extensively, I have to say there is absolutely nothing like this place! pictures don't do is justice.. you have to experience it once in your life... then twice, thrice etc! will definately be back

Interesting but touristy. Was worth visiting as quite varied but lots of touristy stuff was a but of a putt off eg photos with guys with somberros and monkeys. Also kids wanting to act as tour guides and not taking no for an answer. However, despite this worth visiting because of range of stalls and nearby souk.

Lively and exciting. On our trip to Marrakech, we spent most of our time either in the souks or around the Jemaa el Fna. It is so lively and full of noise and the general hum of human activity as traders come from all over to buy and sell their wares. It's easy to imagine that this scene is largely unchanged over hundreds of years (only the introduction of lighting,motorbikes and tourists).A fantastic sight and experience, a must see in the city, particularly as the sunsets over the square

Saha El Fnaa. Nice place at night for traditional shows and big market for everything old and ancient in Marrakech. Honest people, clean place and nice atmosphere to spend a very good night and buy the stuff you like from Morocco.
Huge Square . Lots of shops, big market area. Food, drinks, horse carriage rides around the Medina. Worth the visit.

Typical...chaos!. It's maybe one of the most common symbols of Marrakech. It's like an open air circus. There's everything! You can also eat very good. But after a while it's too much, merchants and waiters for restaurants become from friendly to intrusive...Chose one of the terrace around to have a good view over the square!

A bustling outdoor market like no other. It is the craziest outdoor market you will ever see in Northern Africa. Go there during morning and they are barely waking up at 10-11am to make you a delicious breakfast. Go there during the evening and it is a completely different place: hordes of vendors, performers, street food stalls, donkeys, pottery, sugar cane stands, orange juice stalls, anything you can ever imagine, they have it. You will always need to haggle for souvenirs or lamps but food has got a fixed price. One thing I wish I had known: leather lamps look completely different in Marrakesh than in other parts of the country, as well as pottery, the patterns are different than the ones found in Fez for instance. A truly magical place.

Interesting visit. This is the main Marrakech attraction and for sure it's the most crowded. It's a big square full of street food vendors, musicians and animals performing tricks. All around you an everywhere you look you will find something interesting happening.Beware of pickpockets though and it might be overwhelming for kids

family visit to marrakech. This was our first visit to Marrakech. There are a lot of sellers on the square who will constantly badger you. There are also many folk trying to sell you excursions. If you visit the square be prepared and a firm no always did the trick.

Magical place . Every time I visit Marrakech I have to go to jemaa el fnaa at least a few times. This place is alive day and night. From entertainment, shopping to great food! My favorite is escargot! You can't go to Marrakech without visiting this awesome place!

An experience into both culture and business. Arriving in the night you can hear the noise from far away and as you get closer the lights of the stalls creates an interesting picture. They're storytellers with hundreds crowded around though you might not understand a word. They're different stalls and I highly recommend trying the fresh Orange juice. Argana is a nice place to sit in once you get tired of the hustle and bustle and watch the world go by. Be aware though that in the markets haggling is needed if you want to get a good price. A simple no is fine and do not over engage them. All in all its a must see but it's such a fast paced place that you cannot simply stand around in one place too long otherwise you'll be overrun by beggars and people asking you to come to their shop.

Busy!. Busy in the day and even busier in the evening. We felt very much like sardines in a tin when we visited in the evening. What was on offer was different in the day than that of the evening. I recommend that you go at both times of the day to get a full range of experiences.

The starting point for everything in Marrakech . It's one of the most famous places for tourists in Morocco. It's the real heart of Marrakech and, if you keep coming back, you'll find always new things.Mandatory.

Don't carry valuable things with you, dress modestly. This is the heart of Marakkesh. I always enjoy walking around. Here are some tips to help you, feel comfortable :1. Dress modestly Sexual harassment is a big thing in Morocco. Local women and girls suffer from it on a daily basis. It's alright to wear shorts and tops, but make sure that they aren't too revealing. Their stares will literally "disgust" you. So, protect yourself and pride. If you're a tourist, they will still look...but there is a difference between a glance and a stare.2. Don't be afraid to say "no"In Marrakech's old medina, people can become pushy , when it comes to selling handmade goods. If it interests you, stay for a few minutes. If you don't, just walk away. You don't have to justify yourself with a "no, thanks"3. Crowded places Keep your bag close to you. Take picture, but be aware if someone is getting too close.4. If you take pictures of local people, ask if it's okay.Taking pictures with a monkey on your shoulder is very popular, but don't forget that those people will ask for money. If you don't pay them, they might get loud and aggressive. Marrakech is a beautiful city. I hope that my tips will help you adapt this new exotic world.

Street theatre. Even if you only do it once, an evening meal and people watching is a must. We've eaten at stand 117 three nights running. They were delightful, overlooking square, not as pushy as many of the others. Food was fab and very cheap prices. Hardest bit getting the bill as they kept bringing over complimentary mint tea.The square wakes up at dusk with pop up restaurants which attract visitors and locals alike. Musicians are surrounded by large groups of onlookers. My 15 year old regularly commented on how safe she felt here. Her words, " I think it's because people are not drinking alcohol, no one is drunk". Really makes you think.So, donw feel afraid to visit here, come, enjoy and relax.Note also how clean it is, we lover the teketubby type hoover!!

cannot get enough.... went here everyday and discovered new things everyday. The people and shops that are away from the centre are far cheaper and friendlier and patient. when buying, please BARGAIN as you will get ripped off if you go with the first price given. love the atmosphere and food.
Very hectic. Good but crazy busy and the locals do harass. It's all part of the Marrakech experience and a must do.

Interesting. This place is extremely interesting, filed with colors and different smells, good food and smiling faces. If you are looking for a croudy and loud evening advanture, this is the place for you. But for me it was a little too much.

Busy busy busy. This market comes alive after 8pm. We arrived at 9pm but within five minutes I wanted to leave. The persistent and often aggressive selling took away from my pleasure of seeing the sights and sounds. Later we discovered the terrace bar of cafe dear France and watched from a safe distance. Keep your valuables at home for safe keeping.
