What a place!. It's like crazy- everything you can imagine can be found there: shops and souqs selling almost everything (bargain for half price of everything, go deep in the narrow alleys), cafeterias, snake charmers and monkeys, hours carriages and attractions to visit.

Stressful evening. Whilst an incredible spectacle of noise, sounds and smells, the main square is a circus of pushy stall holders where foreign tourists are singled out and cash demanded for watching 'free' entertainment. If having a monkey wearing a nappy sit on your head is your idea of fun then this is the place for you.It ranged from being mildly irritating to downright offensive when locals took to insulting us for passing by their food stalls. The #14 fish stall was the exception and the overwhelming highlight of the square where the kind and friendly staff serve exceptional 'fast food' for an incredible low price.

Market . Defiantly a place to visit best time to visit is at night as during the day you do get harassed a lot and also be aware of people coming up to you offering help or guidence. As they will want tipping .But once you become aware of it its a lovely place to go .
Jemma Al fena. Great place for family or friend to go. Full of entertainment and brilliant food stalls.. has soulk's and bazaars and brilliant for shopping too..
amazing. You have to visit by day and again by night....what a transformation. an experience not to be missed, this is true old town Marrakech

Be careful of henna ladies. It's nice but you need to be careful of henna ladies they say they do it for free and be for you have chance to say no they start making design and then request 600dh for henna which you never wanted done be careful

Crazy Crazy Place. One of the most crazy and dirtiest places i've ever been but................. Amazing!!!! What an experience, the place is buzzing all day and most of the night! Always something happening and something to see! Watch out for the guys with the snakes, they take a photo with your phone then want a load of money for it, trying to rip you off! Luckily my gf speaks Arabic so that seemed to help us not get mugged off, just be careful.Felt really safe here, we got lost one night walking round the back streets at around midnight but didn't feel worried or intimidated at all.

Just OK. It's history is unrivalled and we loved wandering through the souks to get there, but think it is more of a tourist trap. You see tons of shops and restaurants lined around the square with peddlers heckling you every step of the day. The snakes and viper charmers were interesting but it's more about making a quick buck than providing a traditional experience. The night market is interesting. It's definitely a must see as it's a symbol of Morocco. I really wanted to love this place, but sadly, did not.
Amazing must visit . Loved it here amazing very busy and lots to see. Beware if you take a pic of any performers you may have to pay. Make sure you haggle!
Marakech. Poor Quality food, diluted juices, sweat, kind people.open till late so plenty time to have fun in the old town

Real Marrakech . The square comes alive in the evening as its too hot in the day The henna ladies dotted all around the entrance. Entertainment is snake callers monkey chanting ( I'm not one who likes to see. Monkey chained ) . Then there is all the fresh juice sellers 4mad for single juice 10 mad for mixed stall 59 has the best juice !!!!!! Then the beggars pounce on you which is sad but keep your heart away from your pocket it's a business for them of keep loose change ... They want notes and there are genuinely poor people who we decided we will not give money but buy food or drinks this separated the genuinely poor from the scammers . Then the stall sellers who like to start with extortionate prices and then to local prices Moroccan style good for banter my wife hated it loll she loved fixed prices hard to describe but generally you will feel you have arrived in the heartbeat of Morroco small alleys with all kinds of goods the heart can desire mosques located at various place centuries old place well with the visit.

Jemaa el fna. Visited the square on one evening during our stay in Marrakech. Seems to be full of locals trying to earn a quick buck through various tricks. Anyway visited one of the food stalls and had a quick bite to eat. Paid 100 dhms for a few skewers of meat and a handful of sausages. Although they were tasty not worth the money. Be aware of thieves though. One of our party had some money stolen from a zipped up bag. The kids holding your hands are the distraction it seems so shoo them away.

Amazing place. We went to the square during the day and were amazed at all that was going on including a film crew making a tv programme. From snake charmers (who will chase you for payment if you take a photo) to dancers, artists the list goes on but the place really comes alive at night when all the food stalls open.Food is all fresh and cooked to order, you can eat like a king on paupers money, well worth the visit just don't be put off by all the shop keepers hasseling you to buy from them, it's all part of the Moroccan experience .

amazing. i loved it the weathers buetiful thou its really hot during the day but then again the squares more lively in the evening absolutely amazing must try the fresh orange juice and the avocado and pinapple haggling is a must or u will ripped off

The reason for coming here!. A huge and busy square by day and by night, more so by night. Take a good look around, buy nothing, eat in the centre at night if you dare, you should do it once.Take mint tea in one of the many terrace bars over looking the square and watch life in the making, it only looks like chaos lol.Never take your hands or mind from your wallet and phone.
Must do in Marrakech. Main square in Marrakech. Tourists during the day, mainly locals during the evening. Lots of street style entertainment.great place to sit and watch the world go by

Lovely vibe. The square is very busy with lots to see, eat and buy. Fresh orange juice is a must try. Food vendors, number 1 stall was the best food. Be careful with prices. Portions and prices are different at every stall. No 1 is still the cheapest with the best service and the tastiest food. Henna ladies are thieves. They call you, praise you and the country you come from and the next thing you know she's doing a henna design on your hand. Shocking price comes later. When shopping remember to bargain for better prices. It's amazing how much the price drops once you start walking away. Marrakech was an amazing experience. We enjoyed the square and souks but just a little disappointed with SOME of the vendors who would do and say just about anything to make an extra buck.

Best!. One of the best experiences! Nice food, nice people and nice stuff! Don't be afraid to try them all! Trade everything you wanna buy as much as you can, it's final price will be ridiculously lower than the original. Everything except food, food has a fixed price. Tip: If you're interested in seeing monkeys and you're going to Ouzoud Falls, avoid the ones in chains from here.. It's sad and you have to pay to have a picture with them.. Ouzoud Falls has wild monkeys and you can always see and feed them.

Crazy !. This place gets really rowdy at night ! It s part of the experience... Buy your lamps here as they are amazing and I have not seen them after anywhere i've been... this is one of my big regrets

A must visit and see. The hustle and bustle of the square is amazing. Make sure you try the fresh orange juice or 2 or 3 in my case. be careful of the traders being pushy for you to eat at the stand , have a good look around and see what you like. Just be firm and say no. The smells are amazing. Its so nice to see people out and bout even the locals come down relax in the square and the local park.the souks are near by so you can shop till you drop on your full stomach after. Bur remember to haggle, i had my sister with me who is a pro. Im far to embarassed to haggle.

Chaotic. Visitied during the day and night. The place is very crowded during the night and difficiult to wonder round in a relaxed manner as you are constantly harrassed by stall holders and keeping an eye on your belongings and other family members welfare. We ate in two of the restaurants surrounding the square, where food was nothing special and we are fairly sure that one of the family caught a food bug from there.
Fabulous!. Watch the square come to life on a roof top bar looking down. It transforms and the crowds of people congregate. Entertainment begins and its like another world!

An amazing bustling extravaganza !!!. You can go here any time of the day and yuo will hear music, people flogging you soemthing unorthodox and crazy. We walked here every night of ur stay, had plenty of fresh orange juice (4dhs in a glass or 5dhs in a plastic cup). The food can be expensive therefore shop around and due to th sheer number of people there, just be street smart, because people can try and hustle you if not careful. This place is unique and a must see on a trip here, nowhere in the world do you get such hustle bustle 24/7.

Night time madness. The square is amazing. By day it's a frenzy of snake charmers and stalls and people. By night the food markets come alive and the live music is fab. Every sense is stimulated. It's a must in Marrakech
Breathtaking. Defenitely a must visit in Marrakesh. Try out a fresh juice and have a dinner at the market if you want to experience real marrocon cuisine.

IT IS LIKE A REAL LIFE CIRCUS ....AMAZING!!!. I went twice to see the square. During the day it is busy with traders selling their wares as well as their many foods and drinks. At night, it is as though somebody hit a switch and everything came to life . The place was full of jugglers, acrobats, palm readers but how they told you what was in store for you I have no idea. The place is heaving in a really exciting way & what is very reassuring is the presence of the local police, protecting all the visitors & locals alike.

Madness. Like it or hate it I'm glad I saw it. Ventured in to this mass market place, pictures, video, TV footage can not relay the buzz and craziness of this place. Although it feels certain things are there for the tourists you are a minority. The food area is interesting but the over bearing staff is a put off, first rude and slightly aggressive people we had met especially towards our older sons. You have to go.

Horrible place. Stay away. We were harassed from the moment we entered to the moment we left. We tried a second visit at night to eat - bad idea... Walking into the middle my partner and I were literally separated and dragged apart by various stall owners trying to get us in to order food. It was quite frightening. I had to physically remove myself from the grip of strangers as no amount of 'no's would work. When we finally chose a place to eat, lots of food we didn't order was brought out to us and we were demanded to pay for it. We out right refused and walked off. Were accosted dozens more times just trying to get out. Needless to say we didn't go back. Awful place. Unless this is the experience you are looking for then stay well away!!

Sensory Overload!!. Wow. Incredible. To think that every night for hundreds of years a similar mass of people has come together to sell, storytell, perform, steal, eat, watch and buy. The kids stuck close to Mom and Dad through this one. Not to be missed...a true travellers experience!

A Must See Every Evening. The Jemaa el-Fnaa square is something everyone should experience. We arrived in the afternoon and wandered around the area for a bit and had a meal in the square. It was amazing to sit and watch them set-up for the evening and the square absolutely came to life after dark - the energy could be felt everywhere.
Marrakech . Was fun ! People are friendly but can be rude too when they wanna sell their staff ! The market has lots of staff. If they see you are tourist they always put high price. Be aware.

A Glimpse of Marrakech, the Heart of Morocco !. Morocco is the ‘Land of Contrasts’, they sayLet meLet me show it to you my way:-It has the vibrant red Sahara to the East with its sand dunes and ergs,And to the West, is the Great Atlantic where many ships have submerged.Turquoise Strait of Gibraltar to the NorthSeparates it with Spain’s Tarifa portAnd to the South, Toubkal - Atlas’ highest peakWhich many are trying to conquer as we speak!Despite of these variations, this place makes me feel at homeMay be because it’s like the country where I have grown.The inhabitants being Arabs, Berbers, Africans and EuropeansAll of whom are ruled by the KingCasablanca, Rabat and Fes are it's most important citiesBut Marrakech, a place very close to my heartIs the one about which I would like to, today, singMarrakech, the Land of Gods, with city walls all in pinkReminds of the glory of the bygone era and surely makes you think.Standing near Koutoubia Mosque, the inspiration behind Giralda tower in Seville, SpainThe guide explains us about the once misaligned mihrab, the pink stone minarets wallsThe floral motifs and the folklore, all cut short by the muezzin’s afternoon calls.Koutoubia MosqueOn hearing the call for adhan, like others, I too take-off my shoes to step into the mosque,To be told non-Muslims not allowed by law, even when there is only one God.This statement certainly makes some noises in my headBut not to question the State law, I slowly drift away and start walking ahead.After walking for a little while I reached a crossroad crowded with vehicles, To one side, drove a young couple in high speed in their black Mercedes newAnd to the other, an old pair leisurely in their royal horse carriage drew.While both paused for the traffic light, I crossed the street followed by the parking lot of horse drawn carriage fleetJamaa-el-Fna, Marrakech’s soul is the square where now I reach.It’s one in the afternoon, the place jam packedWith orange juice stalls, snake charmers, magicians,Water sellers in traditional red costumes with brass cups and leather water-bagsCharging anything between five to ten dirham for their single photographLarge green garden umbrellas dotted the squareBelow which sat men wearing djellaba selling everything from fresh fruits to clothes to platesWhile beautiful women in colorful kaftans and belghas, waited with henna cones to decorate.Beside them sat an old palm reader, with his hair as white as snowHolding loosely Misbaha (string of prayer beads), in his wrinkled handsAnd waiting eagerly to reveal the fate of your entire clanHe tells me, “You are one of those lucky few, who follow the heart,And I can assure that you’ll fall in love with this place before you part”.In order to get a panoramic view of this majestic square, I climb up the stairsPulled out a corner chair at Café de France, overlooking this giant fairAnd quietly listened the concoction of Chaabi and Gnawa musicAnd felt the happiness that filled the air.Deep down inside I wished, if somebody could translate and explain me the verseBut then they say, music is the universal language of love that touches the soul and need no words.The more I looked at this place, the more mesmerized I became.While I was still lost in my thoughts,A man in his thirties walked up to me and exclaimed, “You seem to be new,Why don’t you come and join us for a bowl of stew”.They narrated folklores of both hills and plainsAbout which I’ll surely write sometime later, cause there is too much to explain.With the sun turning dark red and the night slowly crawling out,The square became even more crowded, noisier and merrier now With the food stall owners calling out“Come try and taste our famous beef, mutton, rabit and chicken breastIf you don’t like them at all, we’ll serve you some fresh camel’s chest”.My newly found friends treated me with Couscous, Pastilla and TajineEach of which had some seven different kind of meats.Here in a country that’s thousands of miles away from homeTheir warmth and hospitality, makes me feel that I am a part of their own.Once strangers, now friendsWarn me not to walk in this crowded square alone“Coz in the shadows, you don’t know who’s your own.In these hours of darkness you’ll lose your wayAnd in the end blame us that we didn’t say”.“Fine, I’ll do as you say” Only condition being, “you all will, with me, some more time stay”.I wandered there throughout the night with my recently found friendsAdmiring the magnificence of hundreds of beautifully lit stalls,Enjoying the musician’s tunes and the seller’s callsAnd even this rainbow of chaos,Managed to touch my heart’s right cords.And with the muezzins final call of the day sounding across all Marrakech in unisonThe noisy square for the first time became composed,And with a heavy heart, we too called it a day.Though I part today, Memories of Marrakech, the soul of Morocco, would in my heart always stay.And finally, the swarm started leaving the hiveWith a promise to assemble again tomorrow, with some more nectar for the soul!    Pooja Kumar at 8:19 PMShare 10 comments:sushil basistaNovember 16, 2014 at 10:26 PMBeautifully written and nicely clicked pics makes it more adorable...Gud Work Pooja!! ��ReplyDeleteAkash PandeyNovember 17, 2014 at 12:34 AMVery well written.... and thanks for taking us thru marrakech...:)ReplyDeleteDivya RastogiNovember 17, 2014 at 5:04 AMWell woven thoughts and beautifully written ! :)ReplyDelete

Another world!. If you like snake charmers, henna tattoos and generally being hassled then this is the place for you!!! You can get horse and carriage rides from here, tho many horses look under fed :( We were told it comes alive at night, but decided it wasn't for us! Its definitely a very different experience from anywhere else I've ever been.

Amazing place. What an amazing place to pass the day and night. We wandered in and out of the square at various times and always found something different to entertain us. Acrobats, musicians, drummers, story tellers and many more. If you want to escape the frantic atmosphere you can escape to one of the roof top cafes

Medina nightlife. Book a restaurant in the Medina for dinner and leave the hotel at least an hour in advance. Taxis will leave you close to Jemaa el Fna square and after a short walk you'll be in the heart of Marrakech nightlife. Stroll for a while among the different attractions displayed on the square (snakes, monkeys, herbs, spices, local jewelry...) and inhale the different aromas of the Moroccan food cooked live on the square itself. Then look up at the many cafés with a terrace overlooking the square and choose your favorite. From up there the show offered to you is wordless and if you choose the right time you can also enjoy a wonderful sunset over Medina's rooftops!In August the square starts to be lively at around 6.30 pm till late in the evening.

WHAT A PLACE . Great place for shopping enjoyed walking around the market and seeing and learning new things but have to remember to haggle for what you want and one local told me haggling is a national sport in marakesh

Liveliest plaza I've seen!. This plaza is amazing, it vibrates with life. There are so many places to eat, music, sounds, snakes! Just be careful with your belongings and don't shoot your camera at people as you might get into trouble. I had so many freshly squeezed orange juices...mmmm! We were recommended the no.1 Food spot. The food was alright, the chicken was still raw we sent it back, but was never right. Whatever you do don't have the couscous in the plaza you can get the nastiest diarrhea.

If you want exotic. This market was all I'd hoped it would be! We moved confidently even when we got lost, and were respectful but firm, which decreased the barrage of pedlars requests or offers, but the downside to that was we couldn't just slowly browse. We went back a few times, so were able to buy what we wanted at a strongly bargained price or went for items with a reasonable fixed price marked.

Didn't live up to my expectations. I had thought this would be my #1 experience in Morocco but the place didn't live up to my expectations. It's basically a huge square with a large number of cheap (& possibly unhygenic) food stalls and a bunch of hawkers and street performers. Maybe because it was off season, the place wasn't even half full.
A little bit of everything.. A true invasion of the senses. From snake charmers to street dentists to every imaginable food. And its been going on for ages!

Eye opener. This is a must visit place.
The sights and smells are unique.
Felt safe,just say no.
Day time is best to go first as its quieter and you can get your bearings

Too much animal abuse. It's such a shame that the spectacle of this square is marred by the abuse of animals. Monkeys that have had their teeth pulled out, then have been dressed in ridiculous outfits, held on leads that they desperately pull against with their hands to stop them from being choked. They are put on tourists shoulders to have pictures taken for a few dirhams. The snake charmers goad the snakes out of boxes and baskets, harassing them with flapping material and sticks. The snakes appear listless and to have given up. The kaleshe horses are supposed to be inspected but I saw many lame and very thin animals, many with sores on their legs and bodies. I woke up at 5am to see the same horses still harnessed to their carriages stood in lines at the edge of the square. Some of the donkeys that are used to cart stuff round the city were also very thin, covered in sores and more often than not overloaded.Very depressing and ruins the square in my opinion.

Magical experience. a visit to Jamaa el-Fnaa in the evening is definitely a highlight of any trip to Marrakech. The vibrancy of the place is out of this world with the sounds of drumming, the evening call to prayers and the smell of food. There are so many delicious dishes to try and the mint tea was great. We had been warned to expect a lot of hassle but all the people we met were really friendly. The only warning I would give is that the Henna ladies are VERY persistent and will have inked your hand before you can blink but it all makes a good story to tell.
a must do. it's hot and loud and so perfect, everything you imagined Marrakesh to be, tip? take a mint thea on one of the terrases and enjoy the view as the sun goes down, it's a must-watch
Curiosity Killed the Cat. Best way to experience it: in the evening, from a rooftop cafe.Worst way to experience it: solo, in the heat of the summer afternoon.

Vibrant!. Lots to see in the square. People are all very friendly. Ensure you haggle as everything is over priced. Loved seeing the snake charmers and getting my black henna done by 2 lovely Moroccan american girls. The souks are beautiful with lots and lots of souvenirs and gift options. A place worth visiting at night and during the day for the different atmospheres.

The Downtown of Marrakech. This is definitely the main place to visit in Marrakech. Alive at night, full of people, full of street food. Don't miss the Tanjia, a slow cooked lamb stew IT'S SO GOOD. And the best place to see the Jemaa el-Fnaa is from the top of Cafe Glacier :)

You must visit!. I always say you must embrace the local culture and this is a historical local culture that has been practiced for hundreds of years! Yes its completly bonkers, yes you get hounded to buy bits and pieces, yes you will get beggars! But you need to see, smell and taste whats on offer. Sunday night is the time to go as its the busy night. I recommend going to the orange juice bars but get a plastic cup as I doubt they wash the glasses. Go to a roof top cafe to watch the mayhem and try some food, watch the dancing, listen to the story tellers and try te water from the water sellers.
Nice . A good experience .It sells alsorts just watch you don't get overcharged.Try not to go in the daytime when it's very hot especially with kids.

Nice BUT bargain everything . I liked the restaurants a d the bazaar but the prices are playable Its like the actual price is 30% from the given one I talked to locals and they told me how to bargain Other than that baggers will hustle you everywhere in the market

Daytime Nighttime anytime. lovely spectacle hustle and bustle and family friendly. fresh squeezed orange juice, monkeys and snakes and story tellers. pop up restaurants at night. it basically is what your expecting of Morocco :).
A must-do experience. With so much going on and so many noises and smell, the senses are overloaded. Superb but be prepared for the beggars and hawkers.

Awesome place but beware hawkers..... We went to jema el fenaa with two kids, one on a pram and I can say we were impressed. First of all, if your hotel is closeby, even a km away, comsider walking down Mohammed avenue, wide pavements and lots of families take this straight road to the fenaa. If you take taxi, don't let him persuade you that you can shop elsewhere better, its not that much of a problem, you can walk the back streets to the fenaa, its just its incredibly busy, hot and tourists stand out. At the fenaa, first of all make sure you get the ladies get hena done for no more than 10dh, find one which uses dark colours as they are beautiful and stay for longer. Note that all performances here are for money, so if someone dances in front of you, they're going to ask for money later. Avoid the snake and monkey charmers as they are aggressive and I personally don't like animals used for entertainment. There are amazing markets and food stalls, haggle as much as possible. Don't give any if the foods to young kids, the risk is to great. Try to stay till maghrib (sunset) when the lights are switched on. After sunset pop over to Koutoubia mosque and take your shoes off and walk inside and into the courtyard. Ask your hotel staff about mosque ettiquette, which should be fairly simple. After all is done, haggle and take a horse carriage ride either for a city tour or back to your hotel. Start asking from the back of the queue where prices are lower. This will give a lasting impression to kids, mine loved it!

Full of life! Must see!!! :). This place has an amazing vibe to it during evenings. Full of energy, color, diversity, and people! a LOT of people :) therefore watch out for your belongings... but no need to be paranoid. Take the usual measures you would in any crowded place. Don't forget to bring your camera, to drink orange juice, eat some street food and talk with locals. They will be happy to share their culture with you.
great place. very vibrant place to visit loads of shops and stalls some fixed price but others negotiable so get ready to haggle

Like travelling through time!. Apart from being the heart of the city, the zooko adds some spice to the adventure... like in the movies, a blend of the ancient with a touch of the new world. For "western world" citizens it's a must... advice, EVERYTHING is to be bargained for, definitely a part of the experience. From food to hand made crafts, spend a few hours here either by night or day time.

Average. Obviously worth seeing as your part of any trip in Marrakech but take note: it gets very busy and chaotic, especially in the evenings. During the day, it gets very hot too.Also, there are quite a few people walking around with monkeys wearing nappies/football shirts and on leashes. They will ask if you want to take a picture with a monkey. Don't do this. This is animal cruelty and should be avoided.
H. Very local placeWith local open air restaurants same Asians food court style..Variety of shopsLeather with very bad quality but lovely designsFoodnotvery invitingSShowswith animals

Go back in time here. Amazing square - one of the most amazing in the world. Snakes and monkeys, performances and fortune tellers, fresh fruit juice so cheap and loud ambiance you only find one place in the world. Amazing and truly memorable.
Try it if you dare!. The square transforms at night into a bustling street food extravaganza, kebabs, sheep brains, camel spleens, soups and tons more, a culture shock but a good one....
Amazing place, day and night,. Market in the day time full of bargins and in the evening one of the best entertainments places full of different things to do, full of atmosphere and noise, love it

Great but ..... You should be conscience about the business on the square, definitly when you visit the square in the evening/night. Its pretty busy then. Yet its wonderfull to see how alive it gets. Pay attention that not everybody on the square has good meanings....Keep in mind that there are a lot of foodstalls so competition is fearce and they do everything to try to get you to their stall. Be smart but enjoy is my advice

Don't leave Marakesh without visiting this square. It is the most popular square r. in Marakesh.you will feel the real city.  Remember you go somewhere that it's very, very crowded (people and Cats) so take care of your self and your pocket!!!If you don't like busy atmosphere go there in mornings but the shows start at RYou can buy lots of things such as food,fresh juices or things for gifts (cheap).There is a nice restaurant where you can buy good food in a reasonable price and watch square from the balcony.

So Ethnic and so Arabic. It was fantastic to be there .You can see monkeys and snakes which are dancing with music.And lots of local markets around the square..You can make your shopping to buy anything belongs to Morocco.You can drink fresh juices like orange tangerine or pomegrante. You should be careful for thives. There are lots of around!But enjoy the plc.

Sensory Overload!. I had read about visiting this square in the day and night, and thought I was prepared. However, nothing could prepare you for this place at night. We are a family of 5 with teenage boys, and we stayed about 10 minutes, as it was chaotic and overwhelming. We were constantly saying no to all of the people approaching us and they were relentless. My youngest son (13) ending up with a monkey on his hip (which, of course, we had to pay for.)

Fantastic atmosphere and local culture. I went both in the day and the night to the square.In the day it is fairly quiet and with alot of people trying to sell bags and sunglasses and is the entrance to the souk and is worth seeing.It is also a horse taxi rank to pick up to either go around the square or take further rides.The square really comes alive on a nighttime as it gets cooler, there is fantastic low cost street food here, mixed grills, fish platters and juice drinks. As well this there are snake charmers, musicians and dancers and monkey performers - all performing for tips but still worth going.The best way to view the square is from one of the cafes that overlooks the square but don't miss out on the wonderful culture on display.

Crazy busy! Watch for motorbikes!. This square is complete craziness. Very very busy and this is in August, Marrakech's "quiet" season, when it is very hot indeed.It is amazing but prepare to be overwhelmed by the sheer amount of people and things to buy, see and do. Have your wits about you as motorbikes, pedal bikes and carts share the same narrow winding streets with pedestrians. You can easily escape the crazy by ducking into one of the lovely restaurants and cafes that line the streets.

Loved. It's definitely a experience everyone must try out in Marrakesh. It's great with the snake charmers, monkeys and the henna tattooist. However be careful as the souks are tightly fitted together and there are over 600 shops. It is very easy to get lost so remember how you got in and how u can get out knowing where u are.
Great place for bargains . Went with family and brought plenty of bargains though be prepared to haggle!!The traders will try to offer you with offers or try to get you in but just say no thanks

Excellent vibe . Come in the evening cooler and more vibrant Check this site for price guidance eg orrange juice 5 dhiram Be carefully of set price menus Can get good food up the road for 4 kebabs burgers tagine 265dhiramMost in sauks charge about 120 per head and a set menuNice to chill but can take it out if u after a couple visits Repeat check prices prior to buying difference of at least half price eg coke can in shop 3 or 4 dhiram in a resteraunt 15 min see the differenceBarter Barter use can of pop as example half to 1 third UK price use that to balance purchases ask yourself is it a deal better still class 1 pound as 10 dhiram so easy to see

Experience the madness. This square needs more than one visit to experience it properly. At night, the food stalls are a real sight, best viewed from one of the grand balconies. We ate at stall 1 and it was very tasty.

Loved the hustle and bustle. Wow what an experience! Sights sounds and aromas! Absolutely no problems with rudeness or anything like that. Shopped till we dropped. Can be easy to get lost as there are so many narrow alleyways full of shops to explore.
Loved the haggling for bargains. Definitely not to be missed.

Loved it . It is very enjoyable to get little souvenirs or gifts for family, but you have to really try to get a bargain with the shopkeepers but they do it a reasonable price. Restaurants did really good food enjoyed my time there, but make sure you keep your bags safe there as there are thieves.

An assault on the senses. Very different by day and night. Early morning it is quite quiet, as the day goes on, more & more snake charmers, monkey men, and the like appear. In the evening it is full of fast food stands and circus style artists.

Absolute must - cultural overload . The main square is amazing. From the orange juice carts to the incredibly tasty street food stands, to the entertainers, rooftop bars, this place has it all. Had some amazing tagine beef here along with Roti- like bread. There are ample bars and cafe with rooftops overlooking the craziness. Often a cool breeze at night too! Plenty of local and western cuisine options around this location too, as well as ATM's. Steer clear of the snake man, he's extremely pushy and demanding when it comes to money. Had to pay what I thought was even too much (still a third of what he demanded), and firmly tell him I was leaving. Otherwise, a fantastic place to visit!

a buzzing place. This is a square quite like not seen before. In the afternoon it is quiet with spme traders selling different types of juices and wares, however,it comes alive in the evenng with food stalls and other sllers hawking their business. Be careful as the food traders will pull you into their stall selling you a yarn. The portions are not great but the atmosphere is five star. Always ask for the bill or you willfind that you are paying the waiter more than what you have eaten for.

The Square. The first time you get here it will be an explosion of how different an environment can be. If I can offer advice it's this, Smile, walk on (don't stop) and enjoy the huge difference to everything you will have previously experienced, that this square offers. Make it through to the other side and stop in a cafe, get a coke/coffee/mint tea and take a breath.Then... You've got to go back into the square, steer clear of the monkeys and snakes unless you want to pay to see/photograph them. Get a fresh orange juice for 4dhr (prices are listed), make a mental note of everything you see for sale with a price, then enjoy yourself haggling with other vendors.All if the family enjoyed the haggle and vendors played along, we normally got a 300/400% discount on most things within 50-100 feet from the main square and 200/250% further out.Regardless of what you pay, ask yourself am I happy paying this price for this item? If it's a no, walk away, most of the time the vendors will try to find out your walk away price and if they can, they will offer it to you.Smile and enjoy the experience.

The Times Square of Marrakech But A Must-Visit. I have always hated Times Square and I make this comparison to place Jemaa into context of size and energy. It is a must-visit at night, for a quick stroll to see the place and check it off your list, or to be in the moment and browse slowly, open to being solicited by juice stands, henna tattoo artists, food and spice stands, for the full experience. Vendors are aggressive but stand your ground and know what you're looking for. They are there to take advantage of tourists who don't know what they want. One night all the electricity went off, and many stands pulled out flashlights and kept working, and customers/tourists were all fairly calm, until the lights came back on five or so minutes later. Cool experience. I walked through at least once a day during my month long visit on the way to the souk, restaurants and to run errands, and it's been fascinating to see it at all hours of the day.

Amazing Jemaa el-Fnaa. This square you have to visit in the morning, in the afternoon and in the evening, when becomes the biggest open restaurant with great smell of moroccan specialities and you have to try this excellent food.

Lots of hassling. Very nice and hive of activity, good to see.Having said this, you get chased and continually pestered by the henna girls and the men with monkeys. They physically forced one of the monkeys onto my boyfriend and tried to demand money. When my boyfriend tried to push the monkey off the man became extremely aggressive, despite it being very clear he had never wanted the monkey on him in the first place. Basically great if you can put up with constant hassling - we found speaking in German puts them off slightly as they understand French and English well, but German not so much.
Amazing. Bit scary at first but it's a must see it's so busy with loads going on lots of bargains to be bought & sights to see
Wonderful!. You can find the best juice here!el mejor zumo de naranja!!! It's really fresh and delicious! And the sunset here is amazing!

Rip off, yet still charming.. OMG where do you start, This place is a market but everything starts high and you have to haggle to get it at the right price. Best way to haggle is try walking away and the more steps you take the cheaper the price!Not one item you can call genuine its all fake and knock-Off! Getting to the food bit, every person is "Your best friend" they try to guess where you are from to try to have something in common with you, I play a little game with them by saying "if you guess where I'm from I will come to your stall" The food is minimal and the service is poor do not be fooled by their promises they just want you to sit down at their stall then serve you slop!Take the time to find a good genuine place established small restaurants in the nooks and cranny's around the souks you wont be disappointed! another little trick to find a good one is if they take credit debit cards they are professional eateries with comebacks!

Crazy place. We didn't feel this was probably part of the real Morocco, and having now done a tour into the mountains, don't feel that it's a true reflection of all the wonderful people. We went to get a drink in a cafe first so we could get our bearings. One of our daughters suffers from anxiety, and she hated the hassle! The best thing to do is ignore most people, or give them a simple 'no thanks', but you couldn't stop for a second without someone trying to sell you something or ask you if you were lost. You need to experience it though!
Good ambiance. You can find what ever you want near its a good ambiance for the culture of marrakech citizens situated in the middle of the city
Magic. A must visit place , magical atmosphere , music , snakes, monkeys., medina people all around. Exotic food.

Loved this place. Visited in early June 2016 three times during our stay in Marrakech very different atmosphere in the day time to what it is at night. Daytime it's a large square with snake charmers, henna ladies and sellers tiring to sell everything from "genuine Gucci watches" to handmade souvenirs. At night the square comes to life and is a mass of pop up cafes and food stalls. The square also forms the main entrance to the souks, shops stalls and market areas where you can buy virtually anything. whatever time of day you visit it is an experience and we look forward to returning.

The best fresh-squeezed orange juice ever ;). overestimated as a dining place ;) nicely crowded with a lot of people willing to sell you something including pictures with a snakes and henna tattoo. Still worth to visit, but one can find better food and only slightly more expensive in a restaurants in medina.But the ultimate advantage is a freshly squeezed orange juice for 4 dirhams a glass (0,4 EUR). You can't miss it :) !!!!
dont get caught with a guide. We visited both day and night, day time was extremely hot and night time really busy and lots of people, not cheap though

Crazy!!. No matter you will like it or not, it is a must see in Marrakech .it is the busiest square in Africa , the stalls starts to be installed at night. We had a photo with the snakes, they asked me for 200 dirhams!! I gave them 40 which is still to much.Try to ask the price before taking any photos if they gave you time.The food stalls was ok. I expected to be more delicious but it didn't.Some locals recommended stall 1 and stall 14 for seafood

Better at night. We have seen it both during the day and at night. Definitely during the night the place looks much better. It is very crowded and loud but that's its atmosphere. It is a must be place for everyone travelling to Marrakesh. We have tried lovely juices, we did not get a courage to try snails but now we regret that!

Crazy! . In the day it seems vast and empty. Only a few stalls selling fresh orange juice (which is beautiful and delicious but make sure you get your change!) and some sad monkeys with chains round their necks and snake charmers. Bt at night it's insane! Keep your wallets in your hand as it's classic place for mugging, that being said the atmosphere is amazing. You have to have your wits about you and learn to say no to the end lessen wanting you to sit down and eat at their market stall. I saw acrobats, snake charmers, lots and lots of musicians and what seemed like magicians or Street entertainers of some sort. Defiantly go in the evening but embrace the mayhem!

Amazing, Must-See!. You cannot NOT going to the square! This is the heart and essence of Marrakech! Yes, there are aggressive vendors, but everywhere else in the world has aggressive sales people too. It's ok to say "No" to something and walk away. This place is magical and I was in it every day. I did not try the food, put I just enjoying hanging out and watch all the activity.

Hustle and bustle. Love this place! The evening comes alive here...so many people from all walks of life! Colours smells all of it is magical! From a distance it looks like the square is on fire but it's just the food being cooked! Well worth a visit at least once!

Amazing but overwhelming. One of the spectacles of the world, but go after dark, or from dusk onwards. During the day it is hot and deserted. After dark it is organized chaos, and if you do not like crowds, stay well away. It is worth visiting for the experience, but personally I found dressed up monkeys, de-fanged cobras and tortoises flipped on their backs onto the roasting hot ground too much and disturbing. Yes, I know it has been this way for centuries and will do so for many to come, but it is not for me.All I can recommend is to walk around for the smells, sights and sounds, and then head to once of many restaurants with a terrace to sit and watch from high above the milling crowds. However, if you want something alcoholic to drink, licensed places are rare, but the orange juices both on the terraces and in the square itself are to die for.A warning; be very careful of pick pockets, and the beggars are very demanding, more so than in Tangiers, but I guess if that is what you survive on, you have to be. Marrakech as the gateway to the Atlas was great, but personally I prefer Essaouira in every way.

Great but weird. So we went to the famous place on our first day and our impression was like omg we want to leave! The reason for that was that all these people who want to sell you stuff or want money for photos or want to get you in their restaurant, are just running towards you and trying to get your money! But as soon as you get less nervous and less stressed when you realise that just saying no and ignore them works well to get rid of them, this place and the souqs are just over beyond! It's so different and you should just take yourself a few hours from 18:00 to 22:00 maybe to try all these funny things! And for the hennah We got ripped of and paid 200 drh for something that would have cost 30drh as a maximum as later our riad manager told us! So don't let you rip of and if you really don't get the price you want just leave and tell them no!

Unforgettable controlled Chaos. You've never seen anything like it, i promise. People everywhere, trying to sell you touristic "musthaves", food of other stuff, men with snakes, monkeys of traditional dances, women with henna and thousands of people watching, buying amd tasting. Go there early in the evening (like 18.00), pick a cafe with a roofterras, sit, watch and enjoy!

Major toursist attraction. Hugh Jemma el-Fenna square with thousands of people who gather to see the sights sounds and smells of this unique place. A must do while visiting Marrakesh.This place really comes to life from evening till late at night from food vendors to dancers , snake charmers etc. This is the real deal you either love it or hate it.
An amazing experience. Loved Marrakech but especially the square. The bustling life was different to anywhere I have ever been before and every good experience for children

Busy, loud and absolutely great!. Experienced it first in 2011 on my own and again this July with my husband and 5 children. It will always have a place in my heart. A real experience for all the senses.

Busy nightlife. Although the big square is never empty it really does shine at night time, when street food and other vendors emerge. Walk through the buzz and sit down to a lovely tajine in the square.
Marrakech madness. Be prepared with lots of water for the incredible heat. Do not be taken in by the hard pressing sales. Just take your time ad enjoy all your senses being tickled with delight

An experience! . It's fair to say that Jenaa el fnaa is an incredibly interesting experience! From the snake charmers to the monkeys, there's lots going on in the square!There are lots of ladies doing henna and trying to get your attention, plus lots of men walking around trying to sell items such as watches and sunglasses. We visited during the day and thoroughly enjoyed sitting in the Cafe De France terrace overlooking the square people watching! It's well worth a visit if you don't mind being harassed!

Very busy place. In Marrakech, we can only get out at night. It was unbearable hot when the sun is up, so your best bet is to chill in the hostel or find some other activities and wait for the sun to set. At night, we felt like a whole Morocco is having a rendez-vous here at this famous square. The medina is a maze, a real one, though, we didn't get lost, thanks to some kid walked us out of there and somehow we ditched him. My experience in Marrakech wasn't very nice. The day I arrived in Marrakech was also the first day I arrived in Morocco, was also a first day I was in Africa. I took the taxi from the airport to the hostel which cost 200 dirham, which I shouldn't have done it. It would be so much cheaper if you take bus 19 from the airport and it will drop you off at the square for 30 dirham. How convenient. It was my first time, I didn't know better, but next time, when I come back, that's what I would do. Outside the airport, walk to your left and across the street, you will see the bus stop and get on bus 19. When the taxi dropped me off at my hostel, I was threw off by a guy walking me over to the hostel from the taxi for about 2 steps and asking for money. I didn't give him any, but I had a bad impression about this city. I learned that if you need help or want to ask for direction, go into store and ask the store owner, they will be glad to help you. Don't rely on the kids or people in the street, they will always ask for something in return after they help you. But we also got some free help along the way, so it is really your luck and play it smart. I was nervous, but I was fortunate enough to meet 2 girls at the hostel who were kind enough to take me around the medina for dinner ( I wasn't even feeling hungry, but I know I need to eat). My first meal in Morocco was lamp head dish. I am going to leave my comment out for this one. We walked around, drinking juice, watching shows until late at night. It is totally safe to be a girl and to be out that late in Marrakech. So stop worrying yourself sick from whatever you read on the internet about Morocco. The entire time, we were in Morocco, we felt safe and not once we felt threatened, though, you felt annoyed by Moroccan men and store owners from cat calling you, name calling you, and constantly inviting you to their shops. Only on one incident, there were some touching, but I stood my ground and yelled at them, they backed up. Also, the local women stepped in to help us and protect us. So you just need to be tough, and things will work out for you. The local women are very protective of you. We met so many solo female travelers. And also, it is not necessary to carry toilet paper around in Morocco, because everywhere we went, cafe, hostel, museum, studio, there are toilet paper. Another time I was in Marrakech, I got sick the last day I flew out of Marrakech. It could be the bad food we had the night before, since I decided to stuff myself with Moroccan food on my last day before going home. Not a smart decision. Also, there was no air conditioner at the hostel we stayed at, so I was sleeping in my sweat and it turned into a cold the next day. Try to buy water at convenience store, if you pay more than 6 dirham, you overpay. When going to the airport, I was going to take the taxi but the guy at the hostel advised me to take the bus. Going from the square to the airport, just go to the bus stop where you see the tallest mosque, get on bus 19 to go to the airport for 30 dirham.

Great Attraction... Not sure about the foodd. A very intriguing spectacle for sure. I thought I was being overly picky by not eating with the rest of our group, but my concerns were verified by a local restaurateur later that night. He said there is no refrigeration (confirmed), and unsanitary handling of food (confirmed). Now I know that this is a really unique experience and while no one in our group became ill, the whole notion makes one a little queasy. Especially, when untouched skewers found their way back onto the grill and were served to other patrons. This made me ponder the origins of our food. If you are of strong constitution and not worried about potentially spoiling your trip, eat away!

Nice place. Was nice to visit the market had a lot going on. However was forced to get henna by one of the ladies who then asked me to pay 400 dr im not sure why... Did reduce to 120 dr but they are quite sly so should be careful.

Great Experience. This is a must do! Experience the hustle and bustle of a Moroccan square, but we were careful not to make eye contact so we weren't fleeced for the price of a photograph! Everything from hair braiding to dancing monkeys (poor things...). The souk was great, and we picked up some leather bargains!

What a crazy lovely experience but hold onto your belongings. The square is an interesting place. Be sure to read a bit about it - the history is interesting. And remember that just below you there are still prisoners in holding.There is a good police presence but you should continue to be vigilant. There was a moment the entire square lost electricity. Be sure to grab your handbags etc close to you if that happens.

Crazy sqaure. Crazy place to go. during the day full of snake charmers, monkey handlers and all sorts. Be aware they try to lure you in and then ask for money. Excellent fresh orange juices are available too here during the day. Becomes a massive food market after sunset - didn't try the food though.

Absolutely beautiful & Amazing Experience. All the tourists go to Jemaa el Fnaa. You should try all that delicious foods that they cook in this square after the sundown. I also recommend to take a table in Argana restaurant before the sundown ant take a look how they get ready for the marketIt's a must see if you're visiting Marrakesh. Busy at night time with all kinds of activities. Be mundfuld of the scammers and you'll have a great time. Don't hesitate to get lost in the old city, it's part of the experience! And just follow one of the signposts in blue/green/red, and you'll get back to the square. It's not the direct route, but it'll take you there past some sights.
Crazy. Absolutely crazy, enthralling, busy, noisy, hot, harse, captivating. Loved it. Arrange a price with the henna ladies before being decorated in henna and glitter.

Not for the faint of heart. The place is basically a large noisy circus act. Large plaza-like, is the central hub of Marrakech. Food and drink stalls are numerous and quality of food generally good and abundant. Good cheap food. What truly detracts from the whole place is the aggressiveness of the sellers and performers. Didn't bother me as much as my wife. It was a great experience, for one time visit.

Diverse Night Life and Entertaining. There is a lot going on in Jemaa el-Fnaa. Snake charmers, barbary apes, people watching, food, barbeque pits - you name it. It is quite the place to visit and well worth the visit when in Marrakech. There are tons of things to see and it is the place to be at night.Be a bit prepared for performers looking for excessive tips (i.e. snake charmers, ape handlers, etc). I speak Arabic since I live here and they know a tourist and will pressure you into giving excessive tips. I'm generally ok with it as it is their living but when they get pushy I generally just say, "you can take 0 or you can take 10dh (or 20dh - although both are frankly excessive in Morocco!)". In the grand scheme of things it is a few dollars but if you take 1 picture be prepared to shell out money. Well worth the visit!

Live Acts, cheap awesome food, but too many annoying beggars!. Great place to visit in the evenings, swarms of people but security is very good, the police take policing very seriously when it comes to tourists so be rest assured. Live entertainment, Henna on hands etc, but there very hard sell becareful and agree prices first.. Food is awesome and cheap and I never had an upset stomach, although a local friend was became sick . Lively buzzing part of the city, a must go for all who visit Marrakech. Be aware of rip off taxis, but that's another story...

Awesome Orange juice. . Ignore the henna and fake snake charmers eat at the night market and drink as much of the fresh orange juice as you can. Fixed prices so you won't get ripped off ( but check your change ) 4 DRM a good sized glass. They have other juices for 10 DRM but I just loved the cold fresh juice. Tell them no water before you buy. Some will try and water it down. We used stall 28 for a week he was totally honest. We were staying in the Medina. Used to come here every day and get 1 1/4 liters of fresh juice for 24 DRM. Now this cold for breakfast is just awesome. I mean a glass is good but you can't beat just tasting unlimited fresh cold juice sitting on your rooftop.

haggle. Visited on many occasions it's a busy place a sea of colour and there is a feeling of busy activity Haggling is all what it's about Its a fun place generally the shop keepers are polite and helpful You do have the odd pushy one but it's up to you to assert yourself Great fun

Interesting and amazing. Jemaa el-Fnaa is an interesting open area to visit. There are snake charmers who try to get as much money as possible for a picture or video of a dancing cobra. Don't let anyone put a snake around your neck or a monkey without expecting to pay. I really felt sorry for the moneys. They had chains around their necks and they looked scared. There is a lot of fresh orange juice to be had. There are many shops and restaurants also. This is an area where you can go to the post office, or get a cab. Make sure you determine the price you'll pay before getting into a cab or tuk tuk.I don't know how it is here at night, because we made sure we were in our riad before it got dark. This should definitely be on your list of places to visit in Marrakech.

Definetly worth seeing. It's straight out of Aladdin everything from food stalls to snake charmers. Best seen in evening or at night when it's cooler, or viewed from the balcony of a restaurant nearby so that you can soak up the theatre that unfolds in front of you set against the back stage of colour noise and fragrances. Not for the meek as the hard sell is a way of doing business for all the stall holders.

Medieval feel!in a good way though!. Missing this place so much!although it is very rough but for an adventurer like me it was heaven!was immersed totally with the people and the culture,it was just amazing!i found it exciting haggling and joking around with the locals.They weren't very happy if u don't buy their products but all you have to do is smile and leave and continue in another shop until you get the item&price that you want.We went to the market during night&day and it was just unforgettable,i have an issue with the hygiene but you just have to try it and for me everything was just delicious and cheap!if you don't want to see the animal cruelty,close your eyes and move on as we cannot do anything about this.This is their culture since time immemorial and this is how they survive everyday,earning a living to feed their families it just unfortunate that another creature had to suffer nevertheless i still recommend it as your Moroccan experience wont be complete without stepping in this attraction.Enjoy!

bargain bazaars. The square is so lively and buzzing at night time. In the middle of square they all the entertainment, monkeys, street dancers, musicians and much much more. All around the square they have variety food stalls and their exotic orange juice and other fruit juice and refreshing. And last but not least all shops where you will find everything you need at very reasonable discounted price. ( after haggling down, of course ) tip: They will always ask for high price but decide what your final on your mind and then start negotiating with them.In must of the times you could haggle down to 50 percentage. Best part of marakech.

What an EXPERIENCE!!!. Can't describe the vibes here - there is so much to see, smell, eat, hear, and feel here. The buzz, excitement, allure, and energy is UNREAL. Grab a seat in one of the cafes on the 2nd floor and watch the show unfold each night!!!

You can't go to Marrekesh without visiting Jemaa el-Fnaa!. You can't go to Marrekesh without visiting Jemaa el-Fnaa! I am not too keen on the snakes and monkeys but the rest is amazing; the smells and sounds! It's addictive! Our kids enjoyed the haggling and I wished I could squeeze all the rugs, lamps, ceramics etc into my suitcase!Be polite, if you are not interested and the sellers will not hassle you!

Heritage status is obvious!. Every once in a while we come across a location that takes our breath away. This is one. Sure, it's noisy, smelly (most good, some not so good ;-), loud, vibrant and busy but that's the attraction of this place. Too often cities are homogenous, this leaves you in no doubt that there is variety and originality left in this world. One of those real experiences never forgotten.

Excellent and Bonkers in equal measures..,. We find this hard to describe. It's so bad that it's brilliant! Narrow streets, with more narrow streets coming off them, a labyrinth with a vast array of traders from spice sellers to modern day clothing, In Marrakech, a must!
Impressive. Really impressive, especially at night. There are people offering many kinds of amusements. There are also some great food stalls!

Cheap & Nice street foods . *At the morning- search the place and remember how to go and back to your hotel because the streets are look the same, there is no signs so you have to make your own sign to go and get back.  *Its better to spend time here at the evening from 7pm or 8pm,. There's a lot of interesting food stands in the square,Souvenirs on the street, shows, etc*Attention!!! Be careful of your valuable things because there's a lot of people there. You may just go with some money and a mobile phone , the less you can have your things the more you can enjoy the place safely. **Don't ever ever!! Let the ladies get your hand to put "henna" on it!! They will charge you about 200 dirham's or more for that! They are so fast on this! And the "henna" that they use is bad for your skin! Seriously!

Absolutely mental. If you like organised chaos in a thermally challenging environment then this is the place for you. Snake charmers,monkey handlers, dancers are a plenty but unfortunately so are the pretend guides, pick pockets and swindlers. Stay well away from the Henna ladies as they may well draw a pattern on your hand before you notice and then demand 500 for the "art work". They will scream,shout and attempt to intimidate people out of cash. Keep your no face to hand and just say "La shukran" ,no thanks in Arabic. Easy walking distance from most hotels it is a series of food stalls by day but best seen early evening. Sit up in one of the balcony cafes to witness it all relatively hassle free. Dress appropriately ,long trousers and covered arms is a good idea.Do not shake hands with anyone and look to pay 1/3 of what they are asking. There is a gentler paced government shop a few minutes walk away where the prices are fixed
average . Really I don't like the behavior of the sealer, but as oriental place it's ok , tooo much food kiosk and clothes shops , oriental shopping zone

Amazing. The Jemaa el Fnaa square is a must visit in Marrakesh.It's amazing how lively this square gets specially at night, with all the food stalls, performers, story tellers, henna ladies, vendors...Café Argana or Café Glacier for a great view over the square from the terrace.

Over hyped . I think the whole experience is ruined by the money hungry people there, do not even think about pointing your camera in the direction of someone, unless you want to pay. I have no issue with people trying to sell, but relentlessness and rudeness of some is too much for me. Worth a visit if in town, but would not spend too much time there.
Market . Super busy and you need to be rude and ignore people but you will have a great time and plenty to see buy and do

Read your guidebook ....!. Read your guidebook and it will tell you what you should see in the square.Its all there...right in your face...monkeys,henna,storytellers,transvestites,water sellers,porters,fortune tellers,.....and so much more.

Always busy and alive. Jama al Fena is not for everone. If you love to see live snake charming or monkey dancing, then it is okay. Sometimes, the snake charmers put a snake on your shoulder and demand money without prior warning which can be scary for some.

Oriental fairy tails. Jemaa elFna is a magical place.... Just magical... Indulge yourself into the truly Arab , genuine exotic... This is the place which will definitely impress you. Acrobats, magicians, snakes..... But be aware of thiefs, do not bring tangibles with you and be very careful here.

Jemaa el fna. Jemaa el Fna was everything I expected and more, very busy and a lot of tourists, !Interesting things to see such as dancers, snake entertainers, monkey keepers, I enjoyed the berbers music.

Heart of Marrakech. It is the main square for a lot of things, This place leads to the souks.It is extremely crowded and noisy. Just be very careful of lot of women henna designers, They are very forceful and will grab your hands and start applying henna even if you say no. What scared me the most was the tube that had a needle that they use to apply henna with. Not sure how sterile those things are.There are lots of juice options too and the one we encountered was very rude.Place comes alive with a lot of entertainers in the evenings. I loved the souks and they are one of the best places to shop all things authentic Morocco.

The heart of Marrakech!. Busy busy busy!!! We lived minutes from the square and this was our home for the week, if you go Marrakech and don't visit Jemaa el Fnaa then you haven't experienced the true Marrakech!
No place like it ,. Love, love, love it !! Can't get enough of it . The atmosphere and ambience is so lively and not comparable .

Bright, buzzing, music, just fab. We used to go here every evening, for me the best place to be. It's just so vibrant and interesting, stalls, ppl buying selling, in the morning a lot of business, Moroccan biscuits, juice, ice creams sold, at night music, lights, it's intoxicating. You could buy stuffed pizza like things fr 10ds absolutely scrumptious and filling. Ice creams were a treat, crepes, food everywhere, carts outside, snake charmers, henna stalls, and what not. The true culture of Morocco could be experienced here, and don't be offended if people as you for money, just politely say no to them if you don't want to spare change. It seems that it's customary there. The atmosphere of Jemma el fan is a must experience if you go to Morocco. Will def go again if I get the opportunity.
Funny place to be. you definitely want to visit this place at different time during the day, and the night, to get all the best out of the experience!

Awesome. Great place for tourists to enjoy
I recommend some cold orange juice to refresh the hot weather in summer
Madness I tell you, madness!. Just take a wander around and you'll see exactly what I mean! It's a crazy old place Marrakech and this place typifies that craziness!

Must see. This is the main place to see. Must visit at night as that is when things are really active. Not sure why but every food stand seemed to be selling almost exactly the same food. I forget which one I picked but it seemed to always be full of locals and the only one where a guy wasnt trying to get me to eat there. I remember the meal was just bread and sausages.

Okay but not brilliant. It's worth a visit but not too much of your time, we went at night (apparently the best time to go) and although the atmosphere was exciting and interesting there are a lot of pickpockets and people with henna pressuring you to get it done (do not! The henna there is not good quality and could be very bad for your skin) one woman even grabbed my hand and tried to put some on me so i would have to give her money (this was even after I had refused several times) also for women you may be stared at a lot and even harassed but ignore it and walk away (however this is not common and only happened to me once). Just be aware of your surroundings here!

Enjoyable Chaos. What an experience it is to visit this square, it's a must to visit by daytime and at night. It can be very crowded so only take with you what you need, eg be very discreet with jewellery etc

Fabulous at night. The square really comes alive at night when the night food stalls are set up. There are snake charmers, hanna ladies, drink vendors - make sure you buy a cold orange juice for 4 dirham (stall No. 21 was lovely), storytellers, African bands and dancers. Sit on the sidelines and sip a mint tea (Berber whisky), and just watch the world go by.

Interesting place. Visited the place during the night in Summer time.You can say that almost all Moroccan traditions are getting together in this unique place.If in Marrakech is a must to see this place.

Crowded But Worth It. This market is VERY crowded, and you should watch out for pick-pocket (as you should everywhere you travel) but this is important because of how crowded it is and easily distracted you get. There are vendors everywhere selling everything, including food. If you are looking to buy hash, absolutely refrain from buying it from the locals here as I believe they work with the police to get tourists to pay big fines. You'll find snake charmers here and people with monkeys offering you to take a picture with the animals. It was definitely an experience!
Hot, tourist trap, expensive. an experience you have to have if visiting Marrakech, but move on in to the souks and side streets, far more interesting and so much cheaper

Snake and tourist charmers. Especially alive in the evenings with groups making music: jamming and improvising. But also men trying to get your attention with monkeys and snakes or just selling water. There are stalls selling meals, fruit juices and soups. Mind your wallet. Most prices are fixed, but they just try to add an extra dirham or more. Security has greatly improved with plainclothes police men present and a network of informants. Once you are aware of the dynamics, a place to enjoy.

The Hub of the Medina. Food stalls, drink vendors, snake charmers, musicians, beggars and all manner of trinkets, a brilliant place to observe the iner workings of the Marrakech mind. Be aware of hustlers and thieves, get streetwise & enjoy!
Where it all happens. Great place to spend as much or as little time as you want, but definitely a must see place in Marrakesh. It all happens here!!

Business . You have to remember that people in this square are trying to make a living. Therefore they will try to sell you their goods and be persistent, so get ready to reject and ignore people. You should make a visit during the evening, when it is most busy.
great. the plaza is alive at all hours of the day, the restaurants are amazing and the amount of people there is insane

Good experience. I enjoyed visiting here as it was gave me a huge insight of the Moroccan culture. There are loads and loads of stalls selling dresses, souvenirs, food, juices, toys etc. However, i did find that the stalls were very repetitive and they all sold pretty much the same items and there wasn't really a greatnamount of items to buy. Nevertheless, it was an enjoyable experience. Do keep in mind that people will most likely approach you and try to sell you things. Also, if you are interested in buying something from any of the stalls, be prepared to haggle prices!

Cultural and full of energy. Jemaa El Fna is like stepping back in time. During the month of July, the action only begins in the evening, and is like a carnival ever night of the week until about 1am.There is a lot to take in here; the juice salesmen, the outside traditional BBQ stands, the music, the smoke, the performers, the beggers, all of the people, the salesmen. Its a lot to take in, and it can be hard to let your guard down, but you can.The Bad:-Everyone is trying to make some money, you are approached by a lot of people if you walk through the square; selling anything from morrocan hash to cigarettes to napkins or toys. Some of these people are legit businessmen and some are just beggars. It can all get a bit much, but it is a great experience.-The performers are very nice at first but then turn very sour, rude and even offensive. On one occasion a man was very jolly, he put his hat on my head as I was trying to walk away from him and I couldn't give him anymore signs that I did not want anything to do with him or a photo. Then the jolliness soon turned into an evil look and a smarmy Arabic comment underneath his breath as he walked away with no dirham from me.-The vendors can be to much sometimes, you could be approached 10 times in just 1 minute in a busy section of the square. You soon learn how to be nice but very clear about your standing.-The beggars, you can't help everyone.- The souks close to the square are aimed at silly tourists and are ridiculously over priced.The Good-It is a spectacle everyone should see.-Some of the vendors are very nice and do not turn sour if you do not pick their BBQ to eat at. -It is like stepping back in time
Shopping galore!!!. Absolutely loved loved loved this place!! The people were so welcoming, friendly and great to haggle and banter with. Would definitely come here again and again in the future!!

Great place to eat and have drinks in the evening. During the day nothing beats their delicious freshly squeezed orange juice! In the evenings there are quite a lot of eateries to select and have your dinner. The range of food available is large however I was a bit disappointed that no camel meat was on the offering.

Real Moroccan experience! Thank you Marrakechdaytrips. If you stayed in El madina you can walk to everything ( Snake charmers, monkeys on chains, music, aromatic smells, restaurants, fast food- the medina has it all and more). We had a great Tour with Marrakechdaytrips. com. The guide walked us through the Kasbah, Medina and Souk. We had a great lunch which was included and we saw all the important historical sites in a timely manner. Jemaa el Fna square is a total assault on all the senses - in a good way. It can be very busy, hectic, loud and smelly! But that is part of the experience of Marrakech. I highly recommended tour if you only have a day or two to enjoy Marrakech.

Just bonkers. Unique, fascinating, exciting. So much to see and do day or night. Be prepared to say no thanks quite a lot, but in our experience reports of being hassled just didn't materialize.Obviously if you don't want to be handed a monkey, don't wander too close. Acrobats were amazing and well worth a modest tip. Restaurants were ok, there's better dining away from the main square, but you should go at least once during the day to watch the endless activity. Most don't sell alcohol here.Night time, dining at the stalls is huge fun, good food, didn't feel ripped off at all, and sat alongside a Moroccan family who were really friendly.If you sit near the front, you'll have to go through the no thanks routines all over again with the cake etc sellers. Not a big deal. Fresh orange juice stalls afterwards are not to be missed. Go and enjoy.

Great place but beware of sellers.... The place is quite large and you can spend a lot of time to go through or around...beware in summer it is HOT. The sellers are very active - if you focus any short time they will immediately jump and it will be hard to release ... I got in the end the snake on my shoulder and they asked for money for the photo opportunity !!!

Insane atmosphere and Remeber to Look up!. We had been warned as two young girls not to go into the main square at night. We are SO GLAD that we went!!! We felt totally safe and its when the city really comes to life in the cooler hours! The souks sales were much easier to haggle down to lower prices as the keepers want extra sales for the day, the Lantern stalls are at the most stunning with all the lights lit up! If you want to be flattered, take a walk through the street for area where every two metres someone will try to draw you over to their seating area with charming, and often hilarious calls! Will absolutely put a smile on your face! Tip* Remeber to look up! There are so many hotels or restaurants with balconies or roof terraces with incredible views of all the action! We watched a couple of sunsets from up in the hotel de France and somewhere on the corner so you had an amazing view of the whole square!
Hustle bustle. Great market.. just walk around find out prices and don't let anybody take advantage. Great hammams. Avoid eating from the stalls

Visit at night and join in the activities.. At night this place really comes alive with many street restaurants selling every sort of food and lots of activities such as singers and snake charmers. Join in but don't get seduced by the tricksters.

A very intresting market.. Here you can find fake branded bags. Stalls of fresh squeeze orange juices/fruitjuice.restaurants.lady who does henna.night market.and be brave to haggle prices cos it can go down to half the prices of what they're asking.what i really don't like is they don't tell the real price so id rather go to the places where they put there prices on the items being bought than haggling for the prices.you can find nice leather sandals in here.nice scarf you typical souvenir shirts and fridge magnets the cheapest one that we got for fridge magnet are 10dirham.keychains would start 5dirham.a kids shirt i got for 50dirham.from new town to here cost you 20dirham for taxi it takes 10mins..but if you want to walk i guess 20to30mins.we din't go walking because it was too hot to even move.enjoy haggling for the prices.
Lovely experience!. The staff are very nice and assisting. The food is lovely!! Best experience of a Tigine in there! Yum! If you can, definitely try and go for a meal out.
Special. Special place to visit if you go to Marakech you can try a nice food and buy souvenirs viva Marakech and don't forget to try orange juice
Beautiful and Interesting . It's really amazing place!!! You can walk many hours looking many interesting things where you can find anything!!! Good price!!!

Remember The Life of Brian?!. You've seen it on travel shows and in magazines, the circus that is Jemma el fna delivered for us day and night. It's not for those of a nervous disposition. Taxis weave through the square, exhausted looking ponies pull tourist carriages;scooters, vans, donkeys, handcarts all over loaded with people and/or goods come from every angle! And then, of course, come the hard sellers, thrusting belts, watches, any old thing in your face. The assertive henna ladies reminded me of Terry Jones! I'm certain the Monty Python team took inspiration from Marrakech.It's exciting, noisy, colourful, a bit scary at first; it's almost a parody of itself. We had a snack and mint tea on the balcony of cafe de France. Perfect spot to see everything and to take photos without being asked for money. Behind all of the relentless money making we discovered that the Moroccans are very warm and generous. Despite getting there early It was 46°, our daughter almost fainted outside one cafe and the locals couldn't do enough to help her.Tips: a polite no merci stops most of the attention. Cafe de France terrace for people watching, a waterspray fan and mint tea.

Busy but Beautiful!. We saw Jemaa el Fna during the day and in the evening - both times it is very busy. I definitely recommend going in the evening and finding a roof top terrace to watch the sun set, it really was beautiful.
Mad World. This is a mad mad place to visit in that it is full of life both day and night. It certainly comes to life at night with the snake charmers and places to eat.

A unique experience.. I first visited this World Heritage site at night time. It was thronging with people and the noise and people were overwhelming. In the daytime I could see much more. The large square is surrounded by touristy shops all trying to sell souvenirs, leather goods, traditional clothes and lights, creams and potions etc. There are many shops selling the same things. You can see snake charmers, barbary apes, traditional water sellers, all trying to get you to pose and have a photo taken for a few dirhams. Ladies try and sell you a henna design and children try and sell small packets of tissues. Acrobats tumble in front of the cafes and pass round a hat afterwards.
