It is a different world, the noise of the snake charmers flutes and the constant drumming add to the atmosphere. The atmosphere is what I like best about the Square, the pressure to come and look in the shops, to eat at one of the food stalls or to have a henna tattoo are the things I like least. I declined to go near the snakes, but the man was persistent. I absolutely hate snakes. I declined to have a henna tattoo and the lady said, it is a present. Of course she went on and on up my arm and then demanded a huge sum for her 'present'. The traders are there to earn a living of course, but if you don't want something you have to be firm or they will take advantage of any perceived weakening. If you take a camera ask if you want to photograph an individual, and be aware that the regulars will expect money. Pickpockets and thieves are expert at relieving you of your property so carry your backpack in front of you and keep your hands over the fastenings, especially in crowds. Because it is a tourist area the cafes charge more for beverages and food, but look for the cafes that the locals use. They are cheaper. Even so, the food is very good value. There is an open air food hall with countless food tables at night and I can recommend Stall 14 for fish, calamari and shellfish. It is unlike anything I have seen before.

Lovely atmosphere . We visited whilst we were on holiday for 4 days. It was very close to our hotel so we found ourselves there quite a lot. Loved the amount and variety of things there were to buy and see. Don't be put off by the pestering to buy at all the stalls..it's part of the game. If you don't enjoy a little bit of haggling..don't go! (haha) Lovely place to visit at night as everything comes alive but be prepared to tip the entertainers if you whip your phone/camera out.

Crazy Square. The place its something completely different to the whole world, you will find, monkeys, camel, circus to one traveler dentist pulling teeth in the middle the street.. you will enjoy every minute

Very busy at night. You visit this place at night as during the day it is so hot. It gets extremely busy at night and you need to be wary of pick pockets. Sometime men pretend they are from your hotel and offer to show you around be wary they are scammers and will rob you. This is snake charmers here and you can get your photo taken with a monkey all for a price of course. Henna tattoos and market goods are on sale here.

Night time visit is a must. Go here or miss Marrakesh. Watch out for taking photos as the monkey man will want serious money. We ate at a popup street stall for about £5 for 2 for evening meal. But it's the sights and sounds of the square which are amazingly night.

No peace in mind. I find the place overcrowded and very noisy. It's not clean as well and despite many choices of restaurants, I couldn't eat there. It looks there are many things to see but you can't have peace in mind to make your choice with everybody looking for money.
Vibrant.. If you can see pass all the craziness in the square, then it's the place to be, in the evenings mostly. Enjoy orange juice and late night food.

A must see. No visit to marrakech is complete without a night stroll in jemaa el fna. Of course it is a unesco protected place so very crowded and touristy so you obviously get harassed by touts. Nevertheless, the square offers some very unique sights and experiences and is not to be missed especially at night when all the magic happens.
Very buzzing. Must visit! If you haven't been here before, your Marrakech experience isn't complete without visiting Jemaa el Fna.

Jemaa el fena square. If you've been looking for something very different,this is it.. You'll see everything from snake dancing to folk singing,etc..then the food section in the middle with sheep heads and inside the guts bits.. Not for the faint hearten. Be very careful of pickpockets and shop keepers hassling you.
Unique Shopping Experience. Lots of unique stuff to shop for. Pottery and Moroccan slippers are very nice to get as souvenirs. You can negotiate the prices.

Fun. What can i say,,, its a fun place for family and kids. There is many entrances but the one i accessed is full of little shops on the sides,, with different things including clothes,,, food ,,, artifacts,,, and we enjoyed the ice-cream of course because if the hot weather ;)Also the kids and us enjoyed the shows that take place around with different themes including traditional dancing,,, monkeys shows,, and beautiful singing.There are many restaurant to eat at and taste the traditional Moroccan kitchen.If you come to Marrakech you have to experience Jemaa El Fna

Good at night . I was there in July and it was unimaginably hot during the day time and there was almost no shade . But at night time this is the best place to be - very lively , with music and performances . The only thing I didn't like - was very pushy people trying to sell you stuff . But I guess it's their earnings, so you just need to say you are not interested in things they offering you.

Shopping Time. Loved this place, food court was amazing. If you cant haggle dont enter this place or else you will be ripped off, i like haggling and enjoyed it. Horse and carriages are great, ride backTo hotel was amazing.
Love it . Different world. It's lovely!!! Experience it! The culture! Make sure you haggle. Be aware of the henna ladies. THEY WILL GRAB YOUR HAND! Just politely pull your hand back!

A lively atmosphere. What I love most about Jemaa el Fna is how lively it is. During the day it's too hot and the stalls are empty, but in the evening....wow.Overloading on freshly squeezed orange juice (yum), we walked around and soaked up the atmosphere, The locals working at the stalls have a great sense of humour (they also have a great knowledge of British accents with one correctly guessing my cousin was from Yorkshire haha)There wasn't a whole lot to do at the square as we're very cautious of eating street food abroad but it was a good way to end the day before heading back to our riad.

Unavoidable. Jemaa El Fnaa is unavoidable. Good news is, it is a must-see...As the main square of Marrakech, Jemaa El Fnaa draws a very diverse crowd from the city and its surroundings. What's interesting about this square (which is not square at all, by the way) is that it displays different facets throughout the day. I recommend to visit it in the morning, late afternoon and late night - you will see obvious differences. Feel free to enjoy a dinner in one of the numerous stalls installed when the night comes...

Wonderful square with a cautiob. Jemaa el Fana is wonderful during the day as it is the heart of the city. There is nothing you can't find from tarot card reader to snakes charmers and henna tattoos however you need to be very careful so if the market traders can be pushy. The square get transformed at night it becomes very lively with live traditional music, dances food and market traders I will say the real hustle and bustle of Marrakech. It is a wonderful experience and I will recommend everyone to visit the square at least once at night. Be careful of the traders they will try to push you to buy things and always agree on a price before as they tend to change their price. There are a lot of small shops with fixed marked price I will advise you to buy from them. Morocco is well known for their Argan oil and every trader will advise you to buy from them but please double with a guide or your Riad that they are proper Argan oil. Enjoy the city it is very safe, I was travelling alone and didn't face any issues

Busy! . Very busy square in centre of Marrakech. Street vendors can be in your face but they're just trying to get your business. Watch when ordering food as they'll bring breads and olives to your table and expect you to pay for them. If they do ask before you start eating them if it's free.

Fun place. I recommend to go at night because there are more food and juice spots, which are cheap and tasty, and other attractions like music players, the typical henna tattoo, horses, monkeys, snakes, etc.
The place is bit dirty, but is ok.
And obviously, like in all Morocco, everyone will try to sell you something.
Amazing must see!. Amazing and vibrant at night. Sights and sounds that will stay with you forever! The street food is fantastic and the touts encouraging you to their stall is all part of the fun!

Must See. magical square, calm in the morning and afternoon and mystical and a sensory overload in the evening. A must do: Eat at a vendor, I HIGHLY recommend stall #32 the sausage is amazing! It's fun to watch the massive amount of people stroll into the square around 8 pm every day. Also, try the fresh orange juice, juice stall #10 is super sweet.. HOWEVER beware of henna artists,snake charmers, and monkeys on chains. They are all trying to get a buck from you. The henna artists in the square are everywhere and I'm pretty sure sanitary measures lack. The snakes look like they are drugged (probably cause they are), and the monkeys look depressed since they have CHAINS on them. It's awful to see the monkeys in that environment.

Too busy and noisy . This plaza is way too chaotic for my personal likings. Not a fan of the henna women grabbing my arms or the poor monkeys on chains. However, the fresh orange juice is a life saver in the heat, and it's only 4 dirham!

Worst place ever seen in my life. Terrible terrible terrible. Rude obnoxious people who rip you off at every stage. Don't eat drink or try the henna there. Everything is cheap bad quality stuff. People constantly touch you and pull you force you to eat at their stall and if you refuse they swear at you or make fun of you and mock you. And not just the square it this city I would never want to return to. Casablanca is much better place to visit in Morocco if you must.

The magic of Marraquesh in one place. This square in considered one of Marraquesh's main attractions and a must visit place. The square is huge and its life starts at the end of the day, when people from all over the place start to crossing it. And you wander: who are they, where did they come from, where are they going? And then, suddennly, you are in the middle of an almost medieval show: musicians, dancers, fortune tellers, trained monkeys, "traditional" travesti dancers, snakes charmers, the smell of spices, of fresh squized oranges, etc, etc. If you like you can mix up with and let yourself go with the crowd, but a good idea is also to see all this show from a restaurant or bar balcony. From time to time you hear muslim prayers from the mosques nearby, you can catch a tuk-tuk or a caleche or you can adventure yourself throug the souks. And the funny thing is that a century ago the square shouldn't be much different from today. Don't miss it! Just magic!

A place like no other!!. I've been to the square twice. The first time, about 10 years ago I felt less intimidated. But this time there is still lots to see, taste, smell & buy but the locals seem more aggressive. There are snake charmers, monkeys in clothes, dancers, boxers, food stalls, spices, trinkets & tat! I took a picture from 30 yards away of some men in costumes before they even started dancing & got abused by one who appeared beside me asking for money. I would pay if they were dancing or performing but they weren't. The man got right in my face & swore at me. My friend felt very intimidated. I would suggest going in a group for safety and if you go shopping in the souks round the edges of the square go up & come back down each alley because if you turn off you'll be lost forever!! You should go as this is a definite experience, whether you will want to return remains to be seen.

The essence of Marrakech!. Great experience, in this place you live the real Marrakech culture. Starting from 6 pm to 2 am. Be ready for a really nice cultural experience, with the dances, music, and artists in the plaza.

Like nothing I have ever experienced!. During our trip to Marrakech this was the most memorable place we visited. The atmosphere was an assault to our senses in terms of sounds, smells and sights. We visited both during the day and in the evening and both were amazing. We felt safe - albeit wearied by the constant vying for us to buy from virtually every stall we passed. The trick we found was to only engage if we felt that we truly wanted to buy something. That said, the people were friendly and we loved the sounds of the call to prayer; the music; the chatter and the ambience. The smells were heavenly with a mixture of exotic spices; incense and foods. We felt it was important to dress respectfully and wore a scarf to cover bare arms and a low top. The souks were a sight to behold. Came away feeling truly humbled and with a great respect to the friendly people of Marrakech. No words can truly describe this place. A must for all visitors!
You have to visit at night. This is a must see, and must be seen at night, when it comes alive and it's slightly cooler. The sights, smells and sounds are unfirgettable

Wonderful Place. The square is beautiful well worth a visit. Don't be put off by people constantly trying to sell you something ... be polite and smile no merci. If you take photos of the snake charmers or any of the entertainment be prepared to pay .....
Overcrowded place in Marrakech. If you want an experience of the old city and buy cheap stuff, this is a MUST visit place. Beware of the street sellers and beggars.

Stay alert. The area is obviously very crowded, so you have to be very careful. The food is amazing and cheap. My only problem was how much harassment I encountered walking around the square. The people will get aggressive and go so far as to touch or grab you, even surround you, when it comes to them trying to get you to come to their restaurant. It's truly frightening.

Like nothing you will find in the West.. This famous Square, which is the gateway to the Souks, is just amazing. Lots to see, experience and enjoy, be it the acrobats, snake charmers, henna painters or just to sit at one of the cafes and people watch. A must see AND experience when visiting Marrakesh. Having done so you can then wander through the Souks for yet another assault on the senses, situated at the north of the Square. Take your time and just surrender to it all. A word of warning - do not eat in the Square, better to go to one of the cafes or restaurants around the Square where you can get a table upstairs and enjoy the views from above. Great place to hang out for all the family anytime of day. It get very very lively as the sun goes down. Also a place where you can book trips to locations outside of the city. Cheaper than the hotels.

Wild. It is a cauldron...challenges your senses. Some desparate sights that will live with you for some time...however without doubt an astonishing place especially at night. We ate in the food market at night...great experience and very cheap.

Best at Night, for the proper experience. We went down earlier in the week during the day which was interesting enough with snake charmers and lot of stalls, at night it is wow, just like the movies with so much light and noise. Be prepared to be hassled but they are only trying to make some money. I was offered a local delicacy twice but declined, didn't fancy prison.
Very mixed feelings. On the one hand it is definitely authentic. But on the other , there is no Moroccan magic. Only annoying people who are trying to get some money from you

Don't miss this!. It's crowded and crazy, but you've got to go to Jemaa at least twice - once in the daytime and once at night!Allow enough time to walk around to see what's going on and have time to stop where you want. If you get tired and need a rest or something to eat or drink, the square is surrounded by places you can go. Go to the upper levels and you'll get a birds-eye view of the activity below.If you stop to watch the snake charmers or to take a picture, be prepared to pay up. There is price negotiation, but you're in a better position to get a lower price before they take your camera and offer to take your picture with the snakes. It's a great souvenir if you don't get freaked out by long squirmy serpents! Of course, you can always watch someone else with the snakes and snap a picture for free!
An experience you won't forget. The bustle and noise may not be up everybody's street , but it's worth a visit.Fresh orange juice at just 4 drm. Food stalls interesting especially the snails.

A different world . Well, you can't go to Marrakech without visiting Jemaa el Fna, it's like going to Paris and missing the tour Eiffel! This place is amazing and annoying at the same time, it really does test your patience so be prepared. It's amazing the way people come and go in every directions, there's all the food stalls and the juice stalls, the musicians, the monkeys, the ladies who do henna hand art, there's people selling pastries, there's belly dancers (which I am 100% positive are men dressed up but still have not figured out why) and there's restaurants and shops on every corner. If there's money to be made it will be made here, and this is where it becomes quite annoying. People are constantly harassing you at every chance "hello hello come here, maybe another night?" which unfortunately I struggle to accept even after 8 days! However, it is definitely a must. Just to stand there and take it all in, to wander aimlessly around the crowd or to try a bite to eat ....when in Rome and all that!

Wow! Wow! Wow! and no thank's i've just eaten. Beautiful and BIG, in the center of the Medina is become my favorite square at all! in the night is full of life with juice shops and full of places to eat! i have found just one "bad thing" everytime i walked near a food shop there was a man who wanted to make me eat in his shop...and this happens for every single shop!

Jemaa el Fna. Crazy, busy place. A lot is happening in that square after 9pm. It is very, very loud and chaotic place. You can buy everything that you may wish. It has a nice feeling walking around the square. It is like big squares in Paris and London.Plenty of people trying to sell you things from tissues to private tours and all of this in very chaotic way. Anyway for a tourist it is a must see. Close to the square there are many nice restaurants from which you can see it from above. Must see for sure.

Best Night Hangout. This area is so alive in the evening. It is so much fun to hear the street music and so crowded. The best time to visit is in the evening and if you stop to take pictures you must pay the singers.

Must visit this place at least once. . Very exciting market place with tonnes of things happening everywhere, from snake charmers to little kids running around trying to sell you tissues! There are many stalls and shops offering traditional spices, souvenirs, handmade accessories, bags, jewellery etc. A few good restaurants nearby. The fresh orange juice stalls are a MUST to try out. Its only 5 dirhams for a refreshing drink. If you are going to buy merchandise, please haggle a bit. I have seen many people paying the asking price for everything, but the correct way is to negotiate prices down in a respectful way. You'll save some money and it will give you an idea of the culture by talking to them.

Crazy busy, cultural experience. The main square is a huge area with tons of excitement 24/7. Be prepared for locals to approach you constantly asking to buy things. The trick is to look at the product when walking instead of the people. It may feel like you're being rude but eye contact means you're interested in buying something.

Fun but busy. You have to visit, it is on the list. Get lost, get hassled and take in the smells and the sounds. It is superb. Just say a firm 'no thank you' when it comes to salesmen!! And I don't care if you have a family to feed, so do we!

Little begging area. Did not get to look around as much as i would have liked. Young children out with or without adults begging is very off putting. Even if you would like to give you cannot or you risk been swarmed. If you cannot haggle best not to go. My friend paid 200 DR for henna which was later offered for 20 DR by another person. This is my second time and i felt much more comfortable 9 year's ago. Some good items for sale but very repetitive.

Al Matjar (Au Fil D'Or) Bazar. What a magical place! If it's an authentic carpet then looking here is a must. The selection is extensive and the price isn't a disappointment either. They had some lovely vintage Berber handmade pillow cases that found me having to make some difficult decisions about what to leave behind. I could have taken the whole shop if my baggage allowance was bigger.

Chaotic. Interesting square filled with crowds of people trying to make a living, cats skulking round the edges and hawkers with snakes monkeys and hawks, dancing troupes, even fortune tellers and many beggars. Could have bought at least 50 "I phones" whilst there.Many stalls selling orange juices and dozens of restaurants offering views ovr the square.Definitely a must see whilst in Marrakesh.

Unpleasant experience . I found some of the market sellers extremely aggressive and rude. We bought football kits from one stall and then was recommended to look at the cottony dyeing market. Do not go there it is a con! They have a few bits of wool hanging from poles which have been dyed. They show you the dyes and then expect you to either buy a scarf (which was probably made in China) or pay some money for the experience. When we didn't want to buy anything the "dyer" was really aggressive and said nothing in Morocco is for free. I may return to Marrakech but not to Jemaa al Fna. There is nothing really decent to buy there anyway. I preferred Carre Eden for a more sophisticated shopping experience.

Exciting at Night. The square comes alive at night with food stall, snake charmers and all sorts of entertainers. If you take a photo of some one be prepared to pay for the privilege. All good clean fun

Medina madness. Madness in the sense of the hectic goings on. A great cultural experience, lots of activity and entertainers of all sorts. keep your wits about you and remember, there is no such thing as a free lunch!!!!

Busy, chaotic, wonderful!. Jemaa el Fna was an interesting, wonderful busy place. We spent some time there while in Marrakech recently and I enjoyed it very much. There were not as many street performers as we had hoped, which was one downfall.Another was the constant badgering for money from the performers, and the beggars. A word of advice about taking pictures. Make sure you have settled on the amount up front and then stick with it. We ran into a situation with one of the snake charmers, we settled on amount to take a picture that included me with the snakes, and then he wanted more. We offered and paid 50 dirhams, which was a fair price, we thought, but he insisted he wanted more. We finally walked away.Also, unless you want to pay, do not stand too close to the monkeys. They have apparently been trained to jump on people, and once they do, their handlers immediately want paid, whether you wanted the monkey on you or not.Also, if you decide to walk through the souks to get there, make sure you know your way. There are signs along the way, but we are not sure they take you the quickest way. And if you ask for directions, make sure you ask for Jemma el Fna, not the square. The square is apparently another spot.Overall though, it was a wonderfully exotic place, the people were generally friendly, and it is ringed with cafes that provide excellent food and some of them provide terraces where one can watch the chaos from above.

A sight to behold. Be prepared for anything from snake charmers, monkeys, kids boxing, dancers and bands. Crowds of people, clouds of smoke and the call to prayer and things quiten down a bit. Worth a visit. Food is good at the numerous food stall, lots of banter and salesmen. There are some cafes around the edge where you can get a good view of the mayhem below. Ps completely different in the day time.

Visit during the evenings only. . If you go during the day, it'll be empty and you'll get heatstroke. It starts to fill up pretty quickly once the sun starts to set. It's a place full of noise and sights and stall foods. Be aware, there's no where to sit unless you go to eat somewhere.
Market. Go in groups, as constantly harassed to but items saw a few hairy moments with couples and the snake monkey people.
Day time is better!. Visit the place during day-time. In the evening the food sales men are aggressive and insulting if you do not buy.

wow. What an experience a must do snake charmers monkeys belly dancing you can buy anything, maybe not for everybody but thats morocco take the best forget the worst its a wonderful country an experience TO REMEMBER

Don't visit the place during Ramadan!. During Ramadan, the famous place is definitely not as busy as it is under normal circumstances. It is dead during the day and during the evening payer. It is also empty when everyone is enjoying the evening meal, after a whole day of fasting. If you want to see the real thing, do not go during Ramadan!

Morocco in a square. This is a place a like ti check out whenever I have time. It's a unique experience; a place qhere ate the same time you can listen to story tellers, enjoy diverce musicians and singers, see acrobatic shows, play strange games, and eat authentic moroccan food ranging from sheep head to snails.

Great Feel for Marrakech!. The Jemaa el Fna can be a little bit intimidating when you first arrive as there is a lot going on! During the day there are snake charmers, puppet shows, music and monkeys in nappies! At night time there is also a food market and stalls selling local produce.Beware of taking photos of entertainment etc as people will try and charge you for it! Also, for things like henna and things they will advise you that its a free sample but then make you pay so be on alert!!

Cool to see - but very pushy people. Was very cool to visit the market and I'm glad we did, but it wasn't the best experience. It was VERY busy and the locals were very pushy to the point of a woman actually grabbing me and putting henna on my hand, even though I'd said no. They also had a lot of caged animals - lizards, tortoises, monkeys in AWFUL condition which I didn't enjoy.But it was great for shopping, clothes, electronics, spices, herbal medicines, house products e.g. carpets/lamps etc.

real Moroccan experience. packed with culture.constantly approached by men and women selling goods. Brilliant place for buying gifts and souvenirs.Make sure u negotiant very well as these people like to start with high prices for tourists.If they offeer you an item for 100 dhms, offer 30 and slowly make your way up to 45 (max).....if they say no then walk out. They are almost certain to call you back and give you it for the price you want lol (do the same with taxi's)really good food here too

Amazing nighttime spectacular. Find a roof terrace and grab a drink to while away an hour taking in the sights and sounds of this nightly spectacle. Snake charmers, music, street food. Just remember if you have your photograph taken with a snake, monkey or any of the other attractions you will be expected to pay.

dont look at anyone or you get hassled. Fun but daunting. Just keep walking. A day is enough of this and Souq included. beware of flea ridden moneys being out on your shouldes and dont let your children be alone.
Must Do. You can't visit without a night visit. I went during Ramadan so at night Jemaa would come alive with ppl, food, and culture. The vibe and experience is essential to visiting Marrakech.

The pulse of the Medina. Is one of the must see in the Medina. Specially at night. Food is OK but not the best. Very aggressive young men trying to convince you to choose the place for dinner. They get angry if you don't choose them and even offensive.

Fun for a look but be ready to be harassed . We had heard so many amazing things about the Jemaa el Fna and about the street performers and entertainers. We were even recommended certain food stalls to try, specifically 14 for the seafood and fried calamari. However, after about 2 minutes walking through the square, we were accosted by a performer with a monkey. When my husband refused to want to take a picture with a monkey, it was placed on him against his will and then asked to pay for the handling. After a confrontation about payment, I was grabbed by one of the henna ladies and after saying that I wasn't interested in henna, she grabbed my hand to start the design. I literally had to pull my hand away and shout no! On our walk back through the square to go back to our hotel, again, we were a accosted by a snake charmer and asked to pay even though we were literally walking by. I am okay paying performers when watching or partaking in a performance or service is something that I am seeking out but this was ridiculous! We have traveled a lot and this was the first place where I felt very uncomfortable and it was more of a Hassle than enjoyable. There were some great performers out that did not use this tactic (the musicians) and they were entertaining to watch so if you can bear the crowds and the harassment by performers that aren't drawing the crowds, then give it a go!Another option is to go on top of one of the roof terraces overlooking the square and grab a drink! You get great Ariel views of all the people below without the hassle and hustle. As for the foods stalls, 14 is hit or miss to when it is open. It wasn't open for the 2 nights we tried going to I can't review it personally, but we had multiple travelers as well as locals tell us to try it!

Night time is the best time to explore. Because of the heat and family life, day time is not very interesting and you will be accosted every 3 minutes. Night time is a different vibe, especially during ramadan. North Americans often associate night time with danger, but this is the best time to visit. With families, women, children out, we were basically left alone. Be aware of your surroundings and firm around the sellers, snake charmers, etc. Also, it goes without saying that quiet, dark alleys can be intimidating. Definately don't be put off by the seller culture and try an evening out.

Bustling day & night. Jemaa el Fna square is a total assault on all the senses - in a good way. It can be very busy, hectic, loud and smelly! But that is part of the experience of Marrakech. Relax into it and enjoy. You are likely to get hassled - it is a trading square with people trying to make a living. If you do receive unwanted calling / attention, just be polite, but firm, smile and walk on and all should be fine. Taking a cold drink on one of the many roof top terraces is a great way to see a different view of the square. Around teatime is an especially good time when you can watch all the stalls being set up for dinner in the square. Eating dinner in the square is an experience you should not miss in Marrakech. Choose a stall you like the look of - they all serve similar fayre. It is basic and cheap and great fun.

lots of different things to explore. you need to be very careful with the geography as most streets have no names and in the souks there are many narrow alleys in which to get lost. It is a place to bargain politely when buying.

Circle of finality . What a trip!
Finished up a mad, mad, mad tour of Morocco in Marrakech & had a wonderful time with all the loose nuts in Jemaa.
Everything taken at face value makes for a very visceral & real experience!
Nice people
Good food
Great hustle
Laughed a lot

Wow -for many reasons. We first walked through here during the middle of the day the day after Ramadan concluded and it wasn't very busy. There were some vendors and restaurants open, but we didn't get hassled. However, once the sun begins to set, this place transforms. It's called the big square and the name is suiting, it's a very big square. There are all sorts of vendors: juice, fruit, candy, clothes, jewelry, etc. Restaurants open up in the middle at night and are good meals at a decent price, expect to spend about 70-100dh per person for nice fish and tagines. Be prepared to be hassled, the people are ruthless. One man followed us for a long time then started yelling expletives at us since we wouldn't give him money. Others will stop fairly quickly, but it's a lot to handle. If you're in Marrakech, definitely go for the experience, but it's a very overwhelming place.

A Disappointment. We arrived here during Ramadan so it may be unfair to share our story. At this time, the square did not get lively until after sunset. After purchasing a fresh juice (at your own risk...I got intestinal problems), my fourteen year old daughter was accosted by a henna tattoo person who immediately began to design her hand and forearm. Within five minutes, we "owed him" 350 MAD!! (about $35.00 USD). I was furious and my daughter was near tears because I made such a fuss...you can see where this is going...WE stayed away from the snake charmers because I couldn't go through the process again. The city should clean up their act and post more police to stop the assaults on innocent tourists.

A festival in its own right. no better way to get the taste of old marrakesh than sitting on a roof terrace watching the music and dancing and cooking food and snake charmers. The hustle and bustle. moroccan life.
Prepare to be hassled. It's an experience that you look forward to, and look forward to it finishing. The souk salesmen and the boys getting evening diner custom don't know the words "no thanks"
a must visit square. a really nice place to get in to at night for some local food you need to be extra careful about ur stuff,

one must see. a must see in morocco. from masters of snake to all sorts of other entertainment , this place is alive 24/7..it is like a rave in a different kind. Behind it there are the small streets with full of small shops selling all sorts of oriental and sometimes very artisan stuff. negotiating is a must here when you buy something.

Amazing. This is an experience you cannot miss in Marrakech. If you think you've seen streets busy after football or Christmas Shopping then ten fold it and you're close. There are a multitude of cafes, food stalls, entertainers and market stalls. This is the real Marrakech and is alive from the morning till 3am. You either love it or hate it but you must experience it when you visit.After trying many food stall I cannot say anything negative about any of them. If you simply want to go for the atmosphere then simply go to one of the many orange juice stalls which for a few pence will not disappointed. Love or hate it you will talk about it for years - enjoy!

Worth experiencing. The square has a real buzz about it, it's full of life and adventure. It's great to wander and take it all in. You do get hassle from people wanting to sell you stuff especially if you stop and look at something but this is all part of the culture and adds to the atmosphere of the place. Just remember that you do not have to buy and remember to haggle hard if you want to buy something.Generally if you say you are just looking they don't try too hard. I have found that the best way to get money off is to tell them that you don't want it and walk away - the price soon comes down. When haggling you need to have an idea of what you would be happy paying and if they are happy with it they will agree - if you are not happy keep walking. If you want to buy an item, stop and ask the price and then walk away, look for it somewhere else, ask the price and walk on. Doing this I was quoted 120dhr, 90dhr 80dhr and 60dhr all for the same product which I finally agreed to pay 40 for! (Although I did give them 50 in the end as I didn't have exact change and I thought 50 was reasonable and we'd had a bit of banter!!)Remember that they want to make a sale so just tell them you have found it cheaper elsewhere and stick to your guns. If they don't want to sell it for that price they won't, they just want to make as much profit as possible and you can't blame them for that. When you find that you are arguing over less than a £1 you have to think is it worth it - it may be time to concede that 10 or 20dhr!People will come up to you in the square trying to get you to have your photo taken with a snake or a monkey or to have a henna tattoo. If you don't want it say no and keep walking, don't engage in conversation. Say no in Arabic, la shukraan, or I don't like it, mahaj'baneesh but most of all just smile and keep walking.The cafe's around the square are expensive and charge 'tourist prices' it is better to go off the square a little way where things will be much cheaper. If you stand in the square looking towards the nearest, biggest mosque there is a good selection of cafés such as Nzaha Snack Restaurant to your left. Here the food is really good and a fraction of the price of places a few hundred yards away. Chicken tagine is 30 dhr compared to 60, a soft drink is 8 and not 12. I had a really nice vegetable omelette for 12dhr and the bread and sauce was free whereas some other places charge for it. The food her is really good and the restaurant is popular with the locals.The square really comes alive at night and is well worth experiencing. Food stalls are set up in the square at dusk we usually go to No 1 Ayeesha, apparently she is the only female chef in the square and stands command over her army of men! Most of the stalls sell the same sorts of foods, just chose one you like and sit down. Generally you don't get hassle when you are at one of the stalls so it's a great place to watch the madness that is the square. If you really don't want to engage with anyone or be asked to buy pastries or tissues, or African paintings or carvings, then sit in the middle of a stall and away from the thoroughfares.I have found the Moroccan people to be lovely, very warm and welcoming and have made some very good friends here. The people like to stop and chat and ask where you are from. If you remember you are in control and you don't have to buy anything unless you want to you it will be ok! It's fun just enjoy the experience!
Heart of Marrakech. Be prepared for lot of street vendors, unofficial guide, fresh food, orange juice and tamers of snakes, where is at first necessarily check price for photo.

Tourist Tips. While making your way, to and from the Square you may be approached by youths telling you that the road ahead is closed for the Mosque - this is a lie / scam.No roads or streets are out of bounds in Marrakesh.Walk on the right hand side of the street to avoid the Mopeds, cyclists and donkeys and cartsThe average daily pay for a Moroccan is 200 Dirhams Be careful of your belongings as there are pickpockets.It is against the Moroccan law for anyone offering to show you the area other than the Official Guides.
Wow. What a place, a visit at night time is a must, so much going on, lots of eating and drinking places and of course, people selling almost everything..even a stall with teeth and dentures !!!

rude, obnoxious and foul langueg. it was pure harrassment, its hard to walk 2 steps without being harrassed by the food stall vendors. they touch freely which i am surprised with. i told one guy at stall #22it was not nice that he was touching my arm as i was walking away and he asked me to f-off. earlier he was telling me that it was the same sh&* different stall, so probably not that motivated by the business he is in. i do wish the authorities would make it less obnoxious to take in the food options before deciding. all stalls fall into 3-4 catgories. seafood, sheep/lamb head, sausages and vegetable options, eggs and bread. the locals seem to prefer the last one.

Embrace the Energy. My sister and I ended up visiting Djemaa el-Fna a number of times, both during the day and in the evening. In the evening, the energy is just electric. The constant hustle and bustle can wear on you and my sister and I looking very much like tourists was a constant beacon for every salesperson there! Be street smart and keep your money well hidden on yourself. Don't let the chaos scare you off, you're in Morocco and everything needs to be experienced. You have got to visit the square...so much life to be found there!

Highlight of Marrakech. We easily spent the most of our time in the main square. There are plenty of signs that can direct you through the winding souks and small streets Jemaa el Fna so it is very easy to find. There are no shortages of stalls or things to buy. Definitely visit at night when the majority of stalls open and the square becomes more vibrant
Great people watching. Having visited with the family this is a great place to explore the stalls or just sit back in on of the cafes and watch the world go past.

The real deal.. Jamba el Fna, what a square which changes from day into evening with performing artists. It's obvious that we are westerners when we are travelling and naturally that causes interest to those willing to sell us everything. There may be a lot of people interested in selling to you but a polite no or if your prefer French as it is there language then I would suggest non Merci. You may have to repeat it but they are not threatening and if you are polite and respectful they will be to you. The square is unremarkable to look at but in contrast an amazing place to be. The souks are great places for shopping and always barter. If you are staying in a hotel look at the hotel shop prices to give you an idea of what not to pay. If you are thirsty or need food there are plenty of places to eat and drink, but very few which are licensed. We ate in the Le Marrakchi, which is on the square and has great views and is licensed to sell alcohol ( See my review under the Restaurant name). There is also another place where we only had drinks and did not eat which is called Le Salama which is licensed and you can eat or pop I. For a drink (again see my other review).Have a great time shopping and enjoying the sights sounds and smells of Marrakech.

Haggle your life away!. Fortunately I went with a family of Arabic speaking people, otherwise your white skin will get you mugged off. Remember everything is beautiful but is fake, so consider that pricing. A t-shirt shouldn't be more than 100-150dhs for example. Not the 400 they tried to get me to pay when I bartered by myself

Real Eye Opener. Great for haggling - you can feel overwhelmed your first visit here but you soon feel confident to say no and walk off! - 171 is a great cheap place to grab a bite to eat - tagines are 40DH

Interesting. Visited the central market square most evenings and although interesting and atmospheric the attention you receive from the various hawkers and restaurant throweriners can become tiresome.
Comes to life in the evening with your senses receiving a good workout, you'll need to walk through to the souks and the restaurants so its part of Marrakesh life so embrace and enjoy.

Bustling. You will almost certainly be approached and hassled by people wanting to sell you something or "help" you, a firm "no!" always worked for me. A great and vibrant place to enjoy, but you will have to turn a blind eye to what I can only call animal cruelty.

Interesting BUT obnoxious . You must spend some time in this square to see the snake charmers, the people, monkeys, food vendors, etc. it is a true spectacle. However, we were very irritated by the constant harassment and unwanted solicitation by the vendors and beggars. Often the same vendor would solicit you more than once and sometimes they would not leave you alone. Everyone who offers to help has an angle and wants money. My children were very uncomfortable with this and I worry they got the wrong impression of Marrakech in general.  To mitigate this experience I suggest going to the square during the day first, don't take a lot of extra stuff (purses, bags, etc), and do not be timid. Marrakech protects its tourists and it's undercover police step in quickly to remove overbearing vendors. In short, the square is safe but you may feel harassed.

Go at least once in the evening. This one is like a 2.5 to me. It's interesting to experience the nighttime intensity, but some of the vendors there get too aggressive; grabbing your arm and pulling you to their tables. I've travelled all around the world, and these are the most aggressive vendors I've ever seen. They don't mean any harm, but it can be pretty annoying.I do recommend going here right before sunset; you can get a good pic of the Koutoubia bathed in pink sunlight.
Wow!. Sooooooooo exciting! There's so much going on, it is quite overwhelming. You can't stay in Marrakech without visiting this square. There is so much going on, especially at night.

Excellent food. Went at night was excellent!! Didn't expect it to be so lively as it was Ramadan. The square was full of stalls for food I thought give it a bash what's the worst could happen dodgy belly turned out the food was tremendous and fresh and cheap had a great night. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the locale

Terrible. As soon as you step of the coach from a hotel theres men saying they are tour guides and saying that they are taking you around. They arent tour guides they are trying to take you to there family or friends shops to buy carpets or moroccan oils! I have no idea how anyone enjoys going here maybe its nicer at night?!? Pushy people trying to sell you stuff you clearly dont want and follow you everywhere. Horses on the side of the square with no water, no food and in the heat of the sun all day no idea why anyone would enjoy seeing this. Animals dont deserve to be treated like this. Would never go again during the day.
Not entirely sure what all the fuss is about. Overrated tourist trap. We did visit during Ramadan, so it could have been a bit tamer than usual, but we both felt it was a bit of a waste of time.

Crowded. The place is very typical and famous for its authenticity. I advise you to stay away from beggers. They can become aggressive if they are not given what they want. The best time to visit is in the evening.

Marrakech is so alive during night time! . Food, monkeys, snakes, markets, drinks, henna everything in one place! A gigantic square with a lot of people! Traditional food but pushy waiters and sellers! Amazing experience and wonderful at night!

Interesting in the Day, Comes Alive at Night. Jemaa el Fna is the quintessential Marrakech experience. It's frenetic in the day, but seems to really come alive around sundown (which is a beautiful experience). This is when the snake charmers, storytellers and food sellers come out in their masses and the atmosphere is electric. I wish we'd had more time to sample the different foods on offer, but, either way, it's a wonderful experience.

Don't miss it (but avoid the animals). Loved the hustle and bustle of the square, especially at night! During the day there are a lot of street sellers offering the chance to have your picture taken with chained monkeys or snake. I would honestly avoid even making eye contact with them as the minute there's even a hint of interest they pounce. Unfortunately my unsuspecting Fiance was caught out and the next thing he knew there was a snake around his neck and he had to pay about £10 for the pleasure. Apart from that, it's a fab place to soak in the atmosphere.

Intense!. The market is full of people trying to sell you something/everything!! It is extremely intense but don't give up;-) Give a day or two to get used to and revisit. Remember, they are asking triple for their product then what it's worth. Offer ALWAYS less than half! If you have too, walk away and they'll surely come after you to complete the sale. Try to enjoy the process and most of all the product!

Heart of Morocco, I think.... All you could imagine when thinking of Morocco. Then once there a whole world of curiosity opens in front of you. Not just tourists, but locals go there too, especially at sunset when tens and tens of little restaurants opens in the square.

An experience!. Absolutely mental here ,so many people asking you to look at there shop! Beware girls of women wanting to do Henna on you , they will charge you a bomb and it will be awful! Really good to experience it

Amazing but overwhelming. My top tip would be to come here after dark. That's when it gets really interesting and fun. It's very pleasant to sit in one of the cafes with a good view of the square from above.Lots of locals come to hang out in the evening, the street food stalls are open until very, very late (at least midnight I think) and there's lots of entertainment. Also, unlike in the West, no drunk people walking about, which makes it feel a little bit safer. And the shops are closed late in the evening, so no people aggressively trying to sell you stuff!In the day, this is a great place for freshly squeezed juice. Freshly squeezed orange juice costs just 4Dh (the equivalent of about 35p in British currency).If you're a woman, beware of the henna ladies, especially the burkha-clad ones. They are worse than the shopkeepers as they may literally physically grab you and try to start applying henna to your arm.

Cruelty to animals. People with monkeys kept on chains, standing in the sun being forced to do tricks at the entrance. Starving chameleons and turtles kept in small cages in the heart of the market. Not a place for animal lovers. I was glad to hear they have recently introduced compulsory water and vaccinations for the horses that pull the tourist carts out the front. Apparently it took a few horses dying in front of tourists to have that cleaned up. Absolutely disgusting. It should be illegal. Would recommend a visit once all the animal cruelty is stopped.

Food street at night. I like medina here compared to fes here is much better.. a lot of street food !! Dont go Fes just go Marakkech.. if you want to bargain the rule of thumb price is 25%.. if seller dont sell that price just go away. You will get it .

Disappointing Tourist Trap. We last were in this square 40 years ago! It has changed and has become a tourist trap and rip off. The snake charmers, fortune tellers, monkey people are all over you the minute you are seen with a camera and in a couple of situations became quite aggressive because of my refusal to pay what they wanted for a couple of photos that I took. In a heated argument I deleted the photos just to get the man away from me. Furthermore there is severe cruelty to these snakes as I have been told their fangs have been pulled out and monkeys should not be in this environment. The food stalls look fun but again we were continually hassled to eat at their stall. The final straw was my wife being grabbed by the arm by a woman that wanted to sell her a henna tattoo. Probably our most disappointing part of Marrakech - would not recommend this place at night

Very busy, very different experience . It's a great place, but some people might find it a little bit too much! Personally it took me two days to get comfortable with the greeters pulling you into their shops (some of them might grab your shoulder), street performers putting monkeys on your shoulders. There is a charming place, might be too different for a westerner at times. However I do recommend to try some mint tea on the terrace of any restaurant overlooking the square and watch all this crowd! Best time is before the down, the view is just magnetising! Great experience, try it!

Large market good food. Large market great for wondering around, plenty to see and do. You need to be able to say No as some vendors are pushy. The henna women are the worst, don't allow them to paint you without securing a price beforehand as they will charge a crazy amount. Also eat away from the main cafes on the square where food is expensive
Culture shock!. This place is amazing - so vibrant! The only thing I would mention is to beware of pick pockets, and have patience with hard sellers.

Love the square . The square is an amazing place that comes to life as the day goes on & by night time it is buzzing. There are magnificent carts selling fresh orange juice for next to nothing & delicious nuts freshly roasted. Wonderful restaurants surround the square with all sorts of food, tagines being the specialty. Horse drawn carts wait outside the square to take you for city tour or back to your hotel. It is a great place to wander & soak up the atmosphere or just relax, have a drink & watch the world go by.

Not sure what all the fuss was about. Travelled through Morocco, only stayed in Marrakesh for one night. Didnt see much I wanted to buy, all overpriced when they see tourists coming. Saw a monkey get thrown against the ground, not sure why they are allowed to be kept.

Nice place. I like this place. Though the people are very agressive when they try to get you to buy something. People would get mad at me when I refused to eat at their tent.Also be careful with women trying to sell henna tattoos. It is black henna and they will put it on your hand without permission then make you pay for it.

Tourist trap. When strolling the medina everyone seems to think you'd like to go the 'square' pointing you in whatever direction.The square is ok, however it seems to cater only for tourists nowadays. Especially the chained monkeys and birds are disappointing.

The 'Big Square" as it is explained to tourists. We went to the square twice. Once at daytime, but you really want to see it again by night with all the lights. Really a lot to see for tourists. A lot of shops with bags, Orange Juice stands, People to show monkeys and snakes, Women want to put henna on your skin. At night a lot of mobile food stands. A bit pushy people and salesman, police told us to watch for pickpocketers at night. A place you have to see as a tourist when visiting Marrakech, but not really that special I suggested.

Orange juice in the square. On a hot and sunny walk around the square,a really refreshing way to quench your thirst is by enjoying a glass of freshly sqeezed orange juice.Didnt realise something so simple could be so tasty and reinvigorates your senses ready for another' assault' in the Souk.

Comes alive at night. The square really does come alive at night, I had previously been warned of taking pictures and if they spot you, they'll charge you, like literally follow you around and hassle you till you pay up. So I was covertly taking some pictures, when my flash went off I was cornered and my husband had to cough up some coins to appease them.Words to the wise, make sure the flash is OFF!It's alright to go and see, you've got people 'boxing' kids doing gymnastics, quite a few different musicians, snake charmers etc.We did go with kids around 9pm, and it was fine, surprisingly there were a lot of kids out. Probably because during Ramadan there's no school, so there were good vibes.Also a few of the market shops are open too, so I case you need to get some last min shopping done before an early fight the next day, there's the place to go.

Spectacular -- and can be incredibly annoying!. We've been to the Jemma el Fna several times. Each time it's just as spectacular -- at night, especially. The only downside is the incessant come-ons by hawkers for the string of restaurants. They are very difficult to deal with. They're not rude exactly, just really, really persistent. Sure, they're just guys trying to make a living, but they make the place nearly unbearable.

A good experience. This is a busy area both during the day and transforms into a night market in the evening. It is good to experience although at first can seem very daunting with a lot of people trying to get you to spend money or look in their shops. You need to be careful as some people will try and guide you to places and then demand money from you! - this includes children. There are men who walk around with monkeys and will try put them on you then get you to pay. One woman also tried to get me to have henna done and followed me and my partner. After I said no she took my hand and started drawing henna on it - I was not happy as it stained my hand for 2 days. However after our first experience and accustomed to the culture we enjoyed coming here to look around and practice our haggling skills. - also the orange juice from the stalls is amazing!!

We love this place. Such a joy to visit, such a wonderful place to be.Our 4th visit to Marrakesh - each time we go, we make sure we vary what we do, but always, Jemaa el Fna becomes the focus. Daytime, early evening or late-night, there so much to see.Most of the food stalls are great, but our favourite is "Simon 81". Let yourself be persuaded to eat here, enjoy the lovely food & good service, and watch as fellow tourists get the full-on "best place to eat in the Square" treatment. Hilarious.Many of the Square's restaurants have balconies overlooking the hustle & bustle, and most serve good traditional Moroccan dishes and are good value. Hint: from the Square and Mosque area, you can stroll down narrow roads or wide boulevards, exploring this great city. Give yourself time to relax and observe what's going on, pausing for a coffee, snack or ice-cream.

Tourist Rip Off. I liked everything about Marrakech except this place and the taxis cuz they know how to cheat foreigners. The area was nice and beautiful, old town type. However no items have price tags and the amount the quote is based on what you look like. You literally have to bargain or else u pay ten times the prices the item is worth. Even to click pictures of things around, some of them demand money so be alert of ur surroundings when u click pictures. Asking for directions, they take themselves to be ur guide if they show u around the place and again demand for money.Best is to go an enjoy the place without having to interact with the locals only in this area.

Wow, a must see and enjoy. Take time to enjoy. A crazy place to see and enjoy. Be careful as there are lots and lots of people. A must see just so you can tell your friends about how slow our life is.

A real spectacular. Well worth a visit during the day, the real time to come and see the square is at night. It's worth eating in one of the many eating establishments with first floor seating. Looking down on the square, you get to see all the action enjoy the atmosphere. It's worth taking your camera too - though light conditions are challenging. If you can take a shot of one of the kitchens in the square as a pan catches fire (seemingly an occupational hazard!

Worth going once for the experience..!. If you don't like being antagonised by street vendors, and animals being exploited for entertainment purposes, then I'd avoid Jemaa el Fna square. The food stalls at night are really cheap, but I'd read your guide book carefully (we ate at stall no.1)!

Not too great during the day. We ended up here at the end of a guided walking tour and as soon as you walk in you are a sitting duck for harassment. The henna tattoo ladies harass and try and get your hands to fleece you of 500 dirhams and the poor snakes look half dead and the chained monkey's are not a good sight. I felt much safer in the souks and this feels like a throwback to a past type of tourism. The rest of the city seems to be moving on but this is clinging to the 'old' ways and it's not good.

Heartbreaking. Should not be called an "attraction". We just returned from visiting the "famous" Jemaa el Fna - the renowned market square. All I can say is that I am perplexed as to how tourists could enjoy seeing the state of the people in such a beautiful country. The poverty was heartbreaking. Seeing people follow us and beg for money and repeat things over and over was initially frustrating until the penny dropped. We walked past dozens of people sleeping under bed sheets, children from the ages of 5 to old men in their 60s desperate for a few pounds. It really was heartbreaking and I fail to see how anyone with a deepened level of conscious empathy could possibly enjoy such an experience. Sure the food and spices smelled amazing and there was a buzz to the square, but we are now sitting in our Riad wondering how a country so beautiful and rich could leave the people in such poverty. Families melting frozen water to drink, going through rubbish bags for food. Monkeys in chains and boxes being used for tourist photos, ferrel cats everywhere. It's heartbreaking and if you really enjoy yourselves there I think you need to get more in tune with reality. Praying for those in Medina struggling. For the babies sleeping in dustbins and for the families sharing door entrances.

A must if you are in Marrakech.. This square is a must for any vistor and you should go twice. During the day you will see the water sellers and the snake charmers at night the whole place comes alive and you gave to be there and feel the atmosphere

Great atmosphere . We were there during Ramadan so it was very quiet half for the square was empty but you still got the real Marrakech.Great food and orange juice. Just the ladies wanting to do the henai were a bit grabby. Definitely worth going.

Nothing like it anywhere. The souks are one of the oldest markets in the world and Jemma el Fna is your entry into the Souks. Not to miss especially at dusk as the whole square comes alive , with the dancers, drummers and music. Food stalls stretch for blocks and serve a variety of Moroccan brochettes seafood. Take pictures at the grand cafe balcony to get the best view.

no words to describe this plaza. the Jemaa el Fna hits you on your 5 senses...on the afternoons it's a market plaza but when the sum is going down, a bit before sunset magic takes place and the plaza becomes crazy, dancers, smoke, cookers, people all over the world, people talking loud and laughing, sounds of LIFE! YOU MUST BE THERE at the ground floor first then at one of the Cafés on first pavement to see it from above. MARVELLOUS PLACE! I want to go back again! Imediatally!!!!

Busy and hectic but definitely worth the trip!. Definitely worth the visit. A bit hectic but as long as you a firm and say no when you want to, you will be fine. The sights, sounds and foods are amazing! A must see before you leave morocco. Tip . . . . Stay away from the snake vendors. They are VERY aggressive and a negative run in with them almost ruined my trip.

Wild in the Streets. Jemaa el Fna is the Times Square of Marrakech, or maybe the vortex of Islamic Honky Tonk. Snake Charmers, hustlers, african drummers, magicians, waves of bozo tourists, howling touts with restaurant menus with boiled snails and lamb eyeball stew, not to mention the endless variation on mundane tajines. everyone screaming for your attention. no doubt you can buy anything at the lowest price, two year against diarrhea guarantee my friend, you speak english, german, french? Fact: best deal is a big glass of fresh squeezed orange juice for 4 dirham (about 40 cents.) you will not get sick. the belly dancers? a selfie with them is probably not a good way to kick off the evening.

Tourist. Lively, bustling, constantly changing. If you like people watching grab a seat at one of the many cafes either at ground level or for a slightly loftier position in a terraced one. The price climbs with height! Some of the terraced bars are equipped with an outdoor a/c solution which makes you feel like a plant being constantly watered. Really nice. The place starts to buzz when the sun goes down and it becomes bearable not to have to be in shade. Now your choice of eateries trebles all with good natured touts. You can't come to Marakesh and not come here.
Not authentic enough for us. We love Marrakech and the Medina however Jema el fna felt a little inauthentic for us. This area is to crowded with tourists in my opinion.

A cacophony of noise blasts your eardrums on first sight. The main square within the medina is larger than it looks on first sight. It is filled with street vendors, henna artists, snake charmers and more. It comes alive at sunset when it is filled with people eating, drinking, shopping or just looking. There are many souks that lead off of the square and lots of restaurants, cafes and eateries around. Try eating at one of the little restaurants/cafes off of the square as they will be just as good but cheaper.

Busy busy!. A nice zone to walk around but quite busy. In the evenings in the food tents it can be a bit overwhelming as all vendors are trying to convince you to stay at their shop. The view of the square is nice from the terraces of the restaurants.

Hectic. This place is like Marmite. It's lovely to experience the African culture, there are snake charmers and freshly squeezed orange juice etc, but the level of harassment we received was enough to put me off. Even when you repeatedly say no to someone offering me henna they continued to put it on me and then we had to pay. Also the animal welfare side of me wasn't too pleased at seeing a monkey back flip after the owner clapped his hands. A very lively place full of lovely things, but not for me I don't think

Another must do for anyone travelling to marrakech,. Another must do for anyone travelling to marrakech, Prices are a little higher so check out and agree a price before buying.A truly Lively place which seems to come to life . there is definitely a deal to have if you are happy to haggle.

Not a pleasant experience. Too many over jealous sales people who do whatever they can to engage you in a sales pitch. Some wouldn't take no or completely ignoring them as an answer and became hostile, aggressive and abusive.

good finds. we always get something from this place... food and souvenirs!
we went during the day, it was hot but enjoyed looking around for some great finds we cant get from US...
Busy and alive. There are plebty le people everywhere trying to sell anything or just being welcomming with tourists. It's a magical place to be in!

Mad place. Must do.. There's hustle and bustle and then there's this place. 11 out of 10 for hustle and bustle. You need to go there at least twice on your trip. This is to allow for a cautious observation on your first visit. See the Mad antics of the snake Charmers and monkey trainers. Watch them argue with tourists and fight amongst each other. Even the over supply of orange juice sellers get passionate for your business at around $0.50 a cup. The persuasive staff at the pop-up BBQ eateries will make you feel obliged to a eat at every single one of them. Check out some of the side stallswhere you can get a deep fried sardine in a bun, check out the flamboyant henna tattoo artist who will smoothly charge you $24 for a tattoo you you can get for $3 in Southeast Asia. If you don't want a monkey or snake on your shoulders don't shake hands with their handlers. They will put them on within 2 seconds. On your first day, spending some time on a roof Terrace observing the spectacle is recommended, even for the photos. But make sure you go down and get amongst it. As with anywhere in Morocco you have to be quite Savvy with your bargaining skills, firm but reasonable. Don't be led astray and don't lead them astray. Quite often I have noticed the vendors having heated arguments with each other. I would love to know what it is about you sometimes. Some of the Stand-alone acrobatics are quiet world class and all they do is ask for small change from The Observers. Get there before Sundown to watch the setting up as well as good photo opportunities of the Koutoubia mosque minaret. Keep your wits about you and by the third visit you may even feel at one with this mad place. Nothing will fully prepared for 'the square' so go there and have your own experience.

You need to visit in marrakech...but truly i was disappointed. It's a big square with tons and tons of truly obnoxious vendors. It is definitely a place you have to experience, but don't spend much time here, there is much more to the medina than what you will find here. Better food, better prices, etc elsewhere. you can get a picture with a monkey sitting on your shoulders and head though....

A true flavour of Marrakech. I love this area of Marrakech as you sit on a terrace high above the square sipping a cold drink, the whole square changes & comes to life. During the day you have the market stalls selling spices & all kinds of things. People juggling doing tricks to entertain etc etc then as dusk falls out come the food stalls, all cooking local delicacies and it is almost like the whole square is on fire. I just love to watch, to mingle & to eat, wonderful atmospheric place.

Busy exciting great atmosphere, but you need to be very aware. Had a great time , we stayed in the Medina for seven nights, and going back in September, loved the square, but got a little fed up with being asked for money every time i even looked at my camera, and when we went to get taxi home, 3 chaps tried to get us into a unlicensed one, when we wouldn't they got very aggressive .The only time I felt unsafe , so stayed with are usual driver from then on
Nice place. This is where we could find true local place of Marrakech. Lots of shops selling all sorts of locally produced items, like clothes, purses, ceramics, jewellery, dry fruits etc.

Big market. That kind of market places are all around Marocco. This one was full of turists and prices was a bit higher than for example in Casa.But there we found very good restaurant, where to eat nacional cusine.

Amongst the chaos. If you like the trill of crowds and souvenirs- chuck food in the mix and basically that's what you have in Jemaa el Fna. I passed this square almost every night of my visit and there is always something going on. In some of the smaller alleys of Marrakech it's nice to have this open space.

a rare experience. marrakech is in fact two different cities, the square being in the old part. in the morning this is a market of fruit, henna tatoos and food. in the evening it is a hub for "human jukeboxes". people/artists who wil act for you if you give them 10 dhm. they will start performing and it is so magical that you are experiencing this that you will be enchanted. it is also filled with food stalls where you can sit and feast on delicious food prepared right in front of you. if you dont want to pay, do not linger around a specific artist or they will demand money from you. you can walk around, see whats happening. around the square there are the souks, more easily visited during day time.but you have to let go, relax. stop thinking of dangers, threats etc. if you give in, this is a unique experience.
Surely worth a visit. Surely a must see in Marrakech but a bit overrated. Very touristy. But the snails are definitely worth a try. Try one of the terraces above it for nice peoplewatching.

Be streetwise and enjoy yourself. It's essential to experience the Moroccan life and watch the Moroccan people live their everyday lives once in Marrakech. Be very street smart as there are pickpockets. Wear simple clothes and women please remember to cover up the knees. Don't fall for the gimmicks such as the gift shops and so on. Rest is to be enjoyed.

Where the time stops..... Beautiful scenery, millions of small souks, shops, and food stalls in the middle of the Jemaa El-Fna. I drank there best orange juice squeezed from fresh fruit ever! Colourful and very busy. Most beautiful and attended in the night.

Buzzing!!. Very busy after sunset. Can get good bargains (but check shops for prices,most of the times souvenir shops had cheaper staff) Watch for ladys who offering henna tattoos, 100% dont believe their price. I needed to rise my voice to get my price. (they said will be 10DH for two hands and was asked 300D,in the end give them 30. Defo try fresh orange juise :) just make sure they squeezing front of u. Food stalls are great!

Looks like a scene from a movie but..... The square and the souks -- the old walled part of the city with small vendors looks almost like a scene from a movie. There are stalls of fruit and snake charmers. We were there in February and it was already hot. The square is visually impressive and frenetic but also very dusty and smelled of manure. The souks were difficult to navigate with all of the mopeds speeding by and some of the vendors pressing and calling everyone who walks by their shop. I had very mixed feelings about my stay in Marrakech. I have to say that like Susan Orleans, I loved the hard working donkeys the most from that trip.

Jemaa el Fna. Its a happening place. Lots of different type of Moroccan Food on offer. But the Jemaa el Fna of today, compared to the Jemaa el Fna of two decades ago, has grown a little ugly. The street vendors are annoyed and even sarcastic when you don't patronize their stall. Some wont even let you take photos of their colourful stalls if you are hust browsing and making your mind up about to eat. There are many touts. In short, over the last twenty years, Jemaa el Fna has become uglier ... a congested tourist trap. You probably should experience it once, but the second time it wont be so pleasant anymore. Just like Egypt where the tourist are simply looked upon as dollars ready to be milked. And woe befall you if you innocently point your cameras at any locals. Seems like no photography is allowed anywhere there are locals.

A must while visiting Marrakech!. I was kinda like the Time Square of Marrakech. Has a bit of everything with a lot of hustle and bustle. It's the most active when the sun starts setting, You'll see everything from snake charmers, henna painters, drum circles to food/drink stalls. If you don't like crowded place It might not be for you but still worth dipping in there for a quick second just for the experience. You can also hide out and joy the calmness from one of the many rooftops patios.

Enjoyed . We visited the market during Ramadan which personally for me is the best time to visit as you get a break from it from the hours of 3-8ish.I enjoyed the market stools, yes they can be pushy but the things they sell are wonderful and we purchased a lot of great trinkets and home items for next to nothing at a good quality. At night the square is buzzing, it's a really good atmosphere, again you can get pestered and feel harassed but you soon learn to either ignore it or be firm with them, remembering they are only trying to earn a living. I'd probably steer clear from any stool or stand selling food and drink.The views are fantastic, you're surrounded by mosques and the call to prayer is a lovely haunting sound of that you can hear from the main square clearly. If you're in Marrakech you have to go here. I would say to dress appropriately, the streets can often be very wet and dirty.

Amazing place. . A great place to be. A must go in Marrakesh especially in evening with all the food stall and performance circles. We loved this place. Guys selling various stuff like hats and watches etc could be annoying at times but that's all part of the fun. Having said that don't pay 200 dhr for taking a picture with money or snake. Just pay what you wish and walk away.

Worth the visit!. Definitely one to check out - great hustle and bustle, although quite touristy! The food and atmosphere was unique and quite interesting, definitely go in the evening and don't be put off by the crowds!
an experience. This is a must to visit, I went in the evening it is an experience and is the essence of Morocco. Have fun and enjoy the food stalls

Busy busy .... While during the day the plaza is almost empty, at night it truly "awakes". Food stands are built up, the evening prayer in the mosque next to the plaza starts and all kinds of entertainment is offered. Especially nice are the smoothies and cheap orange juices! For 20 dirham (approx. 1,90€) you can even get a 1,5 liter bottle of fresh pressed orange juice. Make friends with one of the guys selling it by going to the same stand regularly, and you will even get juices without any water addition as it is customary here ;)Be aware though that even goods offered for "free" have a high price afterwards and never agree to a purchase without knowing and debating the price upfront! Can not say it often enough. If you want to oversee the wholePlaza, enjoy a dinner at the "Chez Cherona" on the roof terrace - it is amazing and prices at good, 10€ for a menu :)

Worth a visit but can get hassled a bit too much.. A must go to place when in Marrakesh. You will get hassled but a quick and friendly no/not interested will see them off. Be careful going in to the souks from here as you can find it very hard to find your way out again. Try to remember your route and come back out the same way.

once in a lifetime experience. Jemaa el fna is one of the most beautiful experiences in my life, and I am glad I went. The food, music and atmosphere was amazing and especially of you are Moroccan this square gives you little bits and pieces of Maghreb. If you hate the heat thats fine because this square becomes vibrant at night time and has great authentic Moroccan BBQ to eat with your whole family there was 10 of us and we spent about 450 dirhams on food and we ate until we dropped, that and the snake charmers, Gnawa, and the dancers there is unlimited things to see in this square alone! you won't be dissapointed

Over rated though worth a short visit. Over rated, in my mind too touristy (even though I thought it would be kind of touristy). The souks around was far more interesting so don't get stuck in the square.

Great experience but too much!!. Great experience! Love the hustle and bustle and all the shops and local people! However my only issue was the constant number of people trying to pull you in different directions! I kinda understand it however as a place targeted to tourists, they should realize that the tourists like to feel relaxed and this will just push them away outside the centre! However other than that.. def worth a visit!!

Dinner at Jamaa el Fna. So on Day 1 after exploring the Medina and Souks we went back to Jamma el Fna for dinner. The place a was teeming with people a mixture nationals and tourists. The stall owners are all wanting your business so it can be really intense with people shouting and directing you to their stalls, but its all fun navigating the area.
Very Busy Spot. The square is abuzz with life, human and animal, including snakes and monkeys for visitors amusement.
The best atraction. a beautiful place, but in the hours of more people , I recommend being in some of the terraces for dinner and see the movement of people des heights

One of the best-known squares in Africa. A bridge between the past and the present has been part of the UNESCO World Heritage site since 1985.The square attract tradesmen, snake charmers, dancing boys of Chleuh Atlas tribe, monkey trainers and musicians playing pipes, tambourines and drums. Come in the evening to enjoy the atmosphere.

They WILL harass you.... Yes, the atmosphere is great BUT you can never relax as you need to have eyes behind your head at all time.
