It never feels dangerous at such, but it feels like if you stop for a moment you will get someone coming over asking for money, if you make eye contact with any vendor he will call for you to see his merchandise, if you look towards a stall the vendor will come over to you and talk at you until you are forced to walk on.Even if you just walk quickly, as a tourist you stand out like a sore thumb and therefore little kids will cling to your arms trying to sell you packets of tissues, guys will try to flog (stolen?) mobile phones and watches, orange juice vendors will call after you, others will come up to you to convince you to eat at their restaurant and so on.Probably the best way to enjoy this square is to get a table upstairs at the Cafe De France or Argana and just watch it all from a safe distance...

Visit in the afternoon. Verly lively square with street food and snake charmers. Best to visit by sunset when it gets most lively. Beware cause every photo you take costs money but dont let them intimidate you, a few dirhams is enough. You can also enjoy the view from one of the many terraces. Great place!

A must visit - though be prepared for the hustle and bustle. You have to visit here to get a feel for the real Marrakech. It is hectic and Scooters, people on bike and foot are everywhere so travelling the narrow alleyways to it is an experience. The smells are varied. By the fresh juice from a stall holder it is delicious. Be aware of unofficial guides they are everywhere and clever at lulling you into their idea of a tour, be firm and say no. At night it is transformed with lots of eateries, we chose not to eat here as we found it a bit intimidating. We did spend an afternoon at one of the eateries overlooking the square, a perfect vantage point to watch the comings and goings.

Awesome experience!. If you visit Marrakech you have to go to this place at night - be prepared for a lot sales guys ;) Try the food and enjoy the entertainment on the streets. The cafe france is also a very nice place to see! You can see the whole place from there.
Amazing and worth a visit.. We visited just before sunset during Ramadan. Picked up some great bargains after haggling. Amazing archway with all photos etc. of the history of the King.

Good experience with family.. Make sure your children don't take anything from a passers-by seller as that almost constitute a sale accordingly to the seller. Very hard to tell them to leave but if you are persistent, they go away. Taxis around the square is start from 50 dirham even for a short journey but often can negotiate a little discount.

Jemma el fna. Quite an experience! Very busy and hectic. Everyone trying to sell you something mostly at tourist prices! Interesting but very pushy and be careful you don't get ripped off!!! Especially when ordering dinner. Check the prices first and don't be pushed into buying stuff.

A blast! Nothing like I expected.. I read online and had friends who've been to Marrakech tell me how aggressive Marrakech was but I was pleasantly surprised to find that was NOT the case at all! We first visited Chefchaouen to help ease us into the whole souk experience and In fact Chaouen was even more aggressive than Marrakech! We had an amazing time, stayed a several Riads throughout our stay - I recommend Riad Aliya however Riad L'Aziza was much closer to the square. Their big suite is straight out of game of thrones, it was our splurge room. The food stall vendors were the exception to aggression. It was SUPER aggressive, in your face and shouting "guaranteed no diarrhea" was pretty gross..... and funny lol. FWIW - they lied but I still would have not changed it lol.Food stalls:#32 - you will see smoke billowing from it - on the corner - was our fav. Best Kebabs we had but were small so we ordered a lot. Make sure you sit on the outside! Its crazy busy and they spill food and even hot tea on you lol. Its always busy!#115 was really good as well - calamari here#5 You MUST get your mint tea here! Its 5dh and the best I had in Mk. The guys are super nice and the glasses are big. Snails - they're snail booths on the edge were really good too. Not as good as Paris snails but pretty dang good & noteworthy. *Dont forget at the food stalls you get charged for everything the put down in front of you (except the bread). Just waive it away if you don't want it. I love food stalls, we always eat street food on vacation, its the best. Don't be afraid, just take some pepto or Imodium just in case.  * If you see a lady making "tortillas" with what I think was bright orange cheese, on the sides of the ally - GET ONE. They're a green opinion flatbread amazingness roll. Actually one of our favorite things we've had anywhere and we would get one every morning and every night on the way to and from our Riad! Date rolls too from pretty much anywhere and lots of orange Juice of course! Some random guy selling coconut, pineapple and fruit - was delicious. I heard some will water it down but I didn't worry about it and it was all very tasty. In fact I bought an orange juicer when we got back lol. We were on the hunt for a non wool rug - I LOVE the boucherouite style and its so expensive online. We cant have wool - we live in the tropics and it molds. I found an amazing boucherouite 6x8 at the stand near the spice square for $120! It would easily be a $600 rug online. His card says "Carpet Souk Marrakech Rahba Kdima near Cafe des espices - 93 Carpet Auction". He was really nice, NOT pushy at all whatsoever and a straight shooter. He didn't haggle that much but we settled on the price pretty quick. Also some GREAT deals on wedding blankets down the ally directly behind his booth. In the $50-$60 range! I just didn't have anymore room and sadly the little metal disks would just rust here. All in all we haggled, but we found the prices to be fair. We did walk away a few times to be chased down but mostly I knew what I would pay and stayed firm. I got taken on one item, a big silver fish that we way overpaid for but I feel the rest was great. Don't buy into the hype, locals were SOO friendly, it was a blast and you can tell their tourism board makes sure tourists have a great time. I know I was curious on prices so I am adding a few of what we bough here:$5-7 Shoes - embroidered leather$10 Brass Camels and other animals$20 Large hand of fatima door knocker 9+inches tall - brass $2 each - little custom made teaspoons (really cute - hand hammered)$25 Sterling Silver Berber hand stamped bracelet (I LOVE this!) Make sure you tell them "pure silver" or you'll get the cheaper stuff. $5 each - cool embroidered loomed cotton towels$5 each for funny hats with colorful fluff balls$8 small teapot $40 two medium sized vintage wedding blanket pillows$2 each - moroccan tea glasses with metal sleeves - there are cheaper ones, these are handmade$15 round gold colored metal hand stamped plate - was amazing to watch him make these. At the entrance to the medina by the spring, as you go in you go through the narrow entrance - that booth, he makes the plates and will demo for you. I bought $50 in stuff from him, he also let me take a photo of him working which is pretty hard to get. Its true they REALLY hate photos. *SHIPPING:We didn't ship back the rug, they wrapped it up nice and tight for us and I managed to fit it into our suitcase 6ftx8ft! We spent two weeks in Portugal (cold) so we did ship back all of our cold weather clothes and kept a few outfits that would mix and match. The post office was easy to find - its close to the main entrance where the horses line up. They don't take CCs and our clothes were a whopping $120. Ouch. No one there speaks english, I bet I could have shipped a different method that was cheaper - I guess mine was just morocco post - and gotten better deal but I just wanted room for souvenirs. Box arrived a week after we got home. I wouldn't ship too many souvenirs home, I was worried about them getting lost or damaged - the box of our clothes was BEAT up really bad.
Market Square . Central hub of the city. Loads of touts and bustle. Amazing at night...party atmosphere especially in Ramadan. Atmosphere changes with day to night. Horse carriages from here.
A Experience.. . Loved it.. Took my shopping list and got some bargains..Loved the bartering..You must try the food don't be put off

An undescribable experience. Our third trip to Marrakech and the jemaa el fna stills holds its facination. The monkeys, snakes and henna tattoo artists are still there, but so are the food stalls. Set up everyday and taken down at the end of the evening. Boiled sheeps head, escarot by the tub you owe it to yourself to try it all. The square can be intimidating as the sellers are quite agressive, but if you have a good idea of what you want to eat make a note of the stall number. They seem reluctant to try and take business away from the competition so just say "oh we are going to # ???". The souks surrounding the square are quite good, but as expected the sellers are agressive. Price compare between one seller and the other. Keep it good-natured and you will be surprised at how much the price will be reduced by.

Unique experience - Great orange juice. The square is pretty tame throughout the day, although it is the place to get amazing orange juice for barely nothing. It comes alive at night, but stay away from the food and the snake charmers and be careful of taking photos/ looking at/ approaching people as they will want money

Jemma el Fna. Being in Marrakech and not seeing this place is like being in Paris and not seeing an Eiffel Tower. You can buy there nearly everything ! Get ready to haggle but be respectful !! People there are very proud of their products that haggle to low. You will have people approaching you all the time so get ready;)

Crazy and fantastic!. The square takes on a whole new life at night. The amazing buzz, brilliant characters trying to entice you in to eat and so much going on you don't know where to look. The only negative is monkeys on chains were a little sad, but looked well cared for. A must see.

Vibrant, Busy Square - a must see stop. Sitting on a terrace, in a café, sipping Mint Tea overlooking Jemaa el Fna, watching the sun set completes any visit to Marrakech.The square has a rich history and offers up food, drink and entertainment in the form of story telling or photo opportunities with snakes and monkeys.The food stalls are a sight to be seen, serving every part of the animal imaginable - nothing goes to waste.If you have ever wanted to touch, have a photo taken with or have a snake draped around your neck then this is the place to visit.We visited the square during the day and at night and would recommend both. It has a different atmosphere during the day and is less busy, but still worth a visit to fully appreciate just how big the square is.
The Heart of Marrekech. As the sun was setting it was an amazing experience taking in all the sights and smells of the bustling square..

jemma el fina. Very good Experience for me and the kids lot of attractions to keep you occupied.Best time to go there will be in the Evening as this is when it stars getting busier plan your self for the day.

Everything you imagine it will be. If you have seen "Raiders of the Lost Ark" or certain other movies that have take place in the Arab markets, it's usually this market area. The snake charmers are there, the monkey handlers are there. Many, many people will try to see you something, and will not take no for an answer. There are numerous places to get juice or food, and many jewelry vendors are there as well. Beware the people you want to take pictures with or of want to be paid and will come after you aggressively if you do not pay what they think they deserve, especially the snake handlers. The markets are right next to their big square or plaza, so they are both doable in a couple of hours.

Crowded, stressful, but interesting and MUST-SEE!. You cannot go five steps without someone approaching you trying to sell you something. Your personal space will be invaded and it will not be a comfortable experience. At the end of your walk in the main square, you will feel tired and spent. The trick is to simply say no or walk away. However, this is a must-do and I highly recommend having a dinner overlooking the sunset in the Jemaa el Fna!
Experience. Make sure to visit this place late in the evening. The food market opens up and it becomes much more lively.

Amazing, but be aware ... +:It's a must-do if you visit Marrakech and better to go at night!Near souks, you can try food, there is street games, music/dance, you can do henna..great atmosphere-:harassments in the souk and in the place, they are annoying.. they scream and do not let you do what you want, they push you for buying stuffs food/henna/souvenirs, they will not give you the exact price so double check the bill!
This main square is a great hang out spot. Good restaurants with views, shopping and entertainment!Must have fresh squeezed juice! Negotiate with shop owners and pick up hand made Berber carpets!

Meh. Great cultural experience but the people working here are very in your face and will grab at you to look at stuff or to put henna on you then expect paid. It's difficult to tale pictures as the people there all want money.

Hectic!. ..but thats what makes it unique. It may also seem a little chaotic especially with a toddler but the people are friendly..well most of them atleast.Bargain bargain bargain. Whatever you shop for dont forget to bargain and you can have some decent deals with the vendors making decent profit too.Its better to go in the eveings. Avoid mornings when the sun and heat are at its peak.

It is what it is. Been back after 15 years and yes its become more tourist friendly but you still get hassled and treated as a walking cash machine but then i guess that is all part of the experience? With a buggy your kid is the same height as motorcycle exhausts and so breathe in loads of fumes!

Busy. The big square is lively but not as manic as I imagined.lots of things to do and see and well worth the visit. Not much hassle from locals but beware of snake charmers and monkey handlers. Food on stalls all looks good but did not try, a orange juice is a must though.

Must See!. Great food, entertainment and people. Much better than anything in Fez and much more liberal. Get some great food at stall 100, snakes, monkeys, boxing and dancing. You better see this if you are in Marrakech.

Exciting but also annoying. Nice to look around (I was there late afternoon) but everybody is after your money. So in fact you are the attraction and your money is the main dish. Be carefull for people with animals they will put them on you and the demand your cash loudly!
Square . international square,it's in the heart of Marrakech. I love the red color at night, amazing memories. Different types of music (Arabic/Amazigh).

Amazing sight - Best Guide ever organised by Marrakechdaytrips. A very unique place to visit. Its easy to get lost in this vast labyrinth of a huge variety of 'shops' selling locally made products of every conceivable type. I would suggest hiring a guide who will take you to all the interesting places ( Booked with Marrakechdaytrips ,COM) . Our guide took us all over the different areas of the market. We enjoyed strolling around, looking at the locals who flock to this place in the evenings, peering in various shops, looking at the wares of street vendors etc. We tasted all different types of morrocon fare,we saw the spices and herbs used for cooking and medicinal purposes, Sellers of everything you can think of, beautiful teapots,tajgines ,tyres used to make furniture and decor for the home.

Best place in Marrakech. Very good place: the aroma and the colors of the souk, a lot of people of many countries, you can find good hostels and riads around there. Restaurants (try the msemen and tajine), cultural presentations (just be careful cuz they can put a snake on your neck to take pics lol, yeah it happened to me, but the cobras are nice, don't be scared).Try to not get help with random people, especially if you're a girl, i had a problem with a boy who tried to take a taxi for me and it was awful. He offended me in many languages hahah but ok. Although this, i loved this square <3
very touristic but a must seen. ...and you anyway can't miss the place due to it's location. you can eat there and buy all the souvenirs you have not already bought.

Bustling, Exotic, & A Bit Dangerous. Go as a large group, and enjoy the cultural experience of being haggled amid snake-charmers. The significance of the UNESCO world-heritage site shows in all five senses.

Marrakech at its Liveliest!. This is Marrakech at its best and liveliest. One of the best and easiest to navigate medina in the country, Jemma el Fna has so much to offer to visitors. It is a fantastic place to walk, eat, shop, take pictures and mingle with the locals and get a feel for the daily life of people in the city. It is a must see.

The good and the bad. This square is a hive of activity, especially on the evening when the market restaurants open up. You can expect to be hassled as each restaurant tries for your business. I tried three stalls, they offered similar menus at similar prices and all were good and cheap. I didn't appreciate being charged for bread at stall 1 though as we did not request the bread and the other stalls offered it free of charge. All day there are juice stalls and a glass of orange cost just 4 dh. Away from the food stalls, there is other entertainment- small bands, snake charmers, dancing monkeys and gymnasts. The monkeys were sad to see but other tourists clearly consider it entertainment so it is income for their 'owners'. Overall the square is definitely worth a look and provides good value food and drinks.

Jemaa el Fna square is a place like no other - well worth a visit - though the snake charmers are far from charming!. We visited Jemaa el Fna Square one evening before going onto PepeNero restaurant, which is about a 5-10 minute walk away.It's a place like no other. Full of street vendors, market stalls, food stalls, street entertainers, monkeys dressed in clothes, snake charmers. Horses and carriages, restaurants, cafes. Busy, noisy, an assault on all the senses. A fabulous place!We didn't spend long there, but it's somewhere you could spend the whole evening shopping, eating, watching the entertainment. Another must when in Marrakesh. And it's easy to find as most places we visited in the Medina had signs for the square. That in itself means no excuses, as it's possibly the one place you can find without getting lost.One word of caution, as we found in the Medina, there are scams and shifty locals looking to rip-off tourists, so be aware of them. Keep your wits about you and if all else fails call the nearby tourist police! Though it's unlikely to come to that.We - perhaps naively - almost fell foul of a snake charmer. What started out as a funny and pleasant experience - the snake charmer chatted to us, put a little green snake around my neck (the snake was friendly, it was fine!), and took a photo of us in front of a big snake that he "charmed" to sit up in front of us. The photo was great and worth paying for. The problem was, how much to pay for it. The snake charmer demanded 200 Dirham (around £14.00) and wouldn't accept any lower. He demanded 'paper money only' and rather than what we expected to be a good-humoured haggle to a reasonable price he insisted we paid him 200 Dirham. That is way over the top. A local told us an acceptable price would be around 50 Dirham. In the end we put our first offer of a 20 Dirham note in his hat and walked off, with him shouting after us. A snake charmer without the charm indeed! But again, as we later found out, a well-used tourist scam. Which was a shame as if we had entered into a good-natured haggle we would have paid more. Bear in mind a 30 minute taxi journey to the square costs 150 Dirham, so an un-charming man taking a couple of photos for 30 seconds is hardly worth 200 Dirham.But all part of the experience, and if you do not want to talk to snake charmers, henna ladies, the owners of dancing monkeys, just ignore them and keep your cool if they persist. They will soon move onto the next person...Overall Jemaa el Fna is a great place to visit and something for everyone, whether that is the tourist attractions, shopping, enjoying street food or sitting watching the world go by.

one of the most beautiful and absurd squares in the world!. Smie, thank and say no, if you do not want. Otherwise, do not be afraid to fully enjoy all kinds of experiences in one of the most beautiful and absurd squares in the world!
amazing place to visit. jamaa el fanna is marrakech for us you can't visit marrakech without feel in love with this place is really nice to visit even by night

Straight out of a Hollywood movie !!. The feeling of walking through a Hollywood movie set was overwhelming every single day. Snake charmers, Flame throwers, Musicians, Street dancers, Magicians, Dry fruit vendors etc.. The Square as they call it would have around 5000 people on any evening, it's like a carnival every evening. Surrounded by terrace restaurants (with amazing views), this is a must visit when at Marrakech.
Feel the city.... It is the corrct place to feel the city! harmony of the colors. right place to taste local street foods. do not forget to have your henna tattoo. be carefull with the monkeys! :)
Very busy square. Really interesting place great cultural experience. Cool shops and stuff to buy. Most vendors are extremely aggressive. avoid the hena!, which can get very annoying sometimes.

Busy.... Wow what a busy market, this place is bonkers when it's in full swing. Definitely an experience motto be missed. Have your wits about you & your hands on your valuables. Don't shake hands unless your making a deal with anyone & don't accept directions... That costs too!!Get in there-try the food, talk to the people but stick to your guns if you say no to something

Not a pleasant experience. It is totally designed to rip off tourists from the minute you step on the square you are confronted by people either trying to sell you something or offering a guide service. It was seriously a bad experience. We thought we would go to a bar to escape but this still does not stop them coming in to offer all manner of things. Not nice!
Enchanting. Such an interesting place. We experienced no hassle here during Ramadan and loved the people, food and trinkets on offer.

haggle haggle. So much to see. Lovely place to go and eat and relax on the rooftop of a juice bar. Lots of shops but don't forget to haggle as they know you are tourists and can charge what they like. Be careful not every photo is free especially with the snake charmers and monkeys. They want something for it !! People are so lovely. I love going to Jemaa el fna.ENJOY !!!

My experience . The square is a rural traditional place with all sorts of characters - lots of tourists, shops, traders, hawkers, drummers, entertainers, horse drawn carriages, cafes, freshly squeezed fruit stalls and police presence so it felt quite safe. Beware of traders over pricing their goods so haggle down to between 1/2 to 3/4 of the initial price given.
Great Place. Special place. very busy and a lot of tourists, just go there! Interesting things to see such as dancers, snake entertainers, monkey keepers, I enjoyed the berbers music.

Sensorial experience. Jemaa El Fna square is probably one of the busiest places on Earth. So many different sounds, smells and colors makes the place unique. People selling all kinds of things (even dentures!), dancing monkeys, snake charmers, music, etc. It´s definetely a must in Marrakesh!
Buzzing Jemaa el fna! . Buzzing square in the centre of Medina, you'll hear it before you see it (given you go at night, which I'd recommend)! A must visit if you are in Marrakech.

It's Almost Impossible to Miss This Square. This square is more impressive at night and it will be cooler. We went during the day 2x. You pretty much are always going to walk through the square. We found the Medina came alive at night when it is cooler. Go at night and sit at a terrace restaurant.

Gorgeous, but very chaotic. As an American, we got endlessly accosted by people trying to sell us a ton of trinkets and things I had no interest in. Pretty at night and restaurants around have a pleasant view

Be prepared to get lost!. A must see to experience real Morrocan food and street trading at its best. Make sure you barter for all your goods, they expect you to. We paid a guide to show us round the souks and provide us with a little bit of history and their culture.It is a maze and can be very intimidating the further you go in but the people are friendly if you are friendly back and just a polite but firm no thank you should suffice.We experienced rooftop bars watching the sunset over the mosque whilst listening to the call to prayer, very mystifying.
The one place you have to see. It is one of the most famous places in Marrakech because it is authentic and elegant. It's great if you want some delightful street food.

Great fun at night- watch out for snake charmer scam. At night this place comes alive. Lovely food and snappy service at a cheap price. Dive in and eat or you'll be hassled to eat all the time. We wanted a picture of the snake charmers but I would strongly advise against it. They will try every trick in the book to get more money from you. Firstly they approach and try to get you to take the picture before agreeing a price. Don't fall for it. We agreed 15dihrams, but afterwards another character said I'd offended him by not giving him the money and demanded '100 more'. I refused and he squared up to me and got his well-rehearsed 'crazy eye' going. I gave him 15dms and walked off. He came chasing after me and said that I'd given him a coin that wasn't Moroccan (that he'd obviously) swapped. I kept walking away and he gave up. Keep well clear as this incident left a bad taste in our mouths.

Busy crazy square.. It is the heart of Marrakech and a must visit but not for that the best place of Marrakech. It is a big splanade, full of people. Local people trying to get some coins. Tedious sellers trying to sell you lampls, hand drums, kleenex everything that you could imagine. There are a lot of henna tattooers and juice shop on wheels. At night there are a lot of small terrace-restaurants with local food. The most recomendable restataurant terrace maybe is Chez Chegrouni. Three floor restaurante with two square view terrace nice for taste local food and see the people on the square.
Crazy. its crazy to see how many people are at this square on weekend evenings, never seen such a diverse and vibrant atmosphere. Truly stunning. Its a must when visiting Marrakech
Highlight of Marrakech. Cannot be missed when visiting Marrakech. Very touristic, but also very nice to walk and look around, especially at night. Also nice to have dinner at the square.

I must be getting old. At the risk of sounding like some boring old hippy from the 60's - it just isn't what it used to be.When we visited 11 years ago the square was probably an equal mix of locals and tourists mingling together. The souk stalls around the square were always over priced compared with further in but the stuff on sale was the same as everywhere. Now in the daytime the bad imitation kaftans are out numbered by the knock off football kits and dodgy looking watches. At night last time we found the locals sitting around socialising, watching acrobats and listening to storytellers and some genuinely crazy locals posing for photos (for DH of course what do you expect this is Morocco!) and the food stalls were set up each night and again, were a mix of locals and tourists sitting side by side alongside some serious health and safety hazards in the form of flaming bbq's and displays of everything from tame chicken skewers to obscure sheep innards and eyeballs. The prices were negotiable and affordable for locals and tourists alike and everyone mucked in together. Now the food stalls are on a fixed footing and set out like mini restaurants. There's nothing more challenging than sausages (not an eyeball or sheepshead in sight) and there isn't a local in sight apart from the seriously aggressive touts and the bored looking cooks - with not a flame in sight on the gas bbq's. We didn't bother staying for dinner. Clearly there's been an attempt to make the place safer and more user friendly for a european audience - but Disnification never improves a place. If you have to pay rent on a permanent stall I guess you have to get aggressive with marketing it - it made me really sad actually and I'd avoid the South Western end of the souk altogether now and go seek out the friendly moroccans who are to be found everywhere else but here.
Too much hassle. To be honest a novelty at first but after a while the pestering really does grind you down! Visit just the once, otherwise steer clear.

Square full of life. The heart of Marrakech. Lots of activities take place in this square. Foods and drinks are sold on temporary shopping carts. Orange juice is very cheap, only 4 MAD. However, bottle of water are expensive. I found the best place to buy cheap water is from Menara Mall. Food stall is bigger and they have funny ways of attracting the customers. Probably cheaper food here but didn't try anything. If someone stops in front of these stalls to buy something, 'heena' ladies will certainly be around. Some of them are so desperate that they don't even bother to ask and after that one must pay according to their demand. There are also a number of street beggars in the square specially near the shopping carts. Snake charmers and street dancers along with watch sellers are very active here. One should have changes to take photos of them. I paid 10 MAD for one photo of a snake charmer with snakes.A safe place I would say but nothing to loose if one keeps an extra eye around. In all, one can certainly enjoy the evening here. Must see if one visits Marrakech.

Blend in. Went here a few times . So much happening day and night . So many people vying for your attention (dirhams) . A good phrase to remember is 'La shukran' meaning 'no thank you' although this can sometimes just be ' la la la la la la........' Especially with the snake charmers. Having said that once you become used to the bartering and realise that this is the way of life you will love it.

Must see for food souvenirs entertainment. Its a good place for entertainment. Snake charmers, dancers, musicians, magicians every evening at 5 pm. The traders here will often give you about 5 times the normal price of things so you have to be prepared to bargain.

Fun cultural overload experience. If you've ever been to an African, South American or South East Asian country, you will be familiar with the challenges of an open market. Everybody wants your money, there's significant competition for it, and as a result all of the Hockers are competitive and aggressive. That notwithstanding, what a great experience! Try the street food, take pictures with snake charmer's, haggle with shopkeepers, and take experience all in!

Busy place. This huge and busy place is the entrance to the vast souk area of the Medina. It is a truly amazing place. You can find anything your heart desires here, or well, almost, depending on your individual taste.It is a very charming place,and there are lots of snake charmers here too. You can sit down at a cafe for a coffee, or a restaurant for a meal, or even to buy and enjoy a gelato. You may decide to go through the square in ten minutes, or more likely an hour or three, or even longer.

An impressive square. During the day this square has monkeys, snake chalmers, henna painters, and so much more! The sights, sounds and smells are uniquely Moroccan; you can't miss it!Make sure you try the freshly squeezed orange juice; it's delicious. One of our party literally called it a 'revelation', and said he'd never realised just how bad what we drink at home really was! I don't know how you pick which vendors include ice (for those worried about getting sick), but I had plenty from different vendors and had no problems.

Interesting place, cafes are fine, avoid the food stalls. I'm a pretty independent, confident traveller. I've haggled in Cairo, driven in Delhi and managed to not just survive Chandni Chowk - which has to be the busiest place on the planet and makes the Moroccan souks look positively spacious - but enjoy it. Jemma el Fna is picturesque enough - though there are a lot less stalls than I was expecting (it's Ramadan, which may explain it). The cafes around the edge provide a comfortable and stress-free place to take photos, and the prices aren't that bad (30 MAD for a juice cocktail, 15 for a tea). The food stalls, however, are another thing entirely. The menu prices bear little relation to what you're charged for - all the "extras" you think you're being given are going on your bill. We ordered a mixed skewers (60 MAD) and a chicken tagine (40), two cokes and a Fanta. We ended up with two portions of skewers for no particular reason, but somehow the bill was 450 - the olives, bread, vegetables and couscous (all of which was provided as standard to everyone who sat down) apparently making up the difference. After arguing (in Arabic) the guy knocked 50 off and then started to get hostile, so we left annoyed and disappointed - only to be hassled for a service charge as we stood up!It appears that the Koran's instruction to do business fairly doesn't apply to tourists in Morocco, even in Ramadan. Shame. Shop during the day, but eat elsewhere.
Disappointing. Hot during day and busy. Night time lots of people but not very entertaining. Felt was overrated. Felt safe walking around. Usual market feel. Too touristy for my liking

You have to be too paranoid to enjoy!. Jemaa el Fna is an impressing big place with a big number of food stalls and groups performing dances, charming snakes, etc.Starting from the late afternoon it becomes quite turbulent with the various groups starting their performance and staff at the food stalls trying to get you to eat something there.This, however, is when the nuisance starts. Everybody tries to get some Dirhams out of you and especially if you didn't pack your camera away, some of them will even follow you asking you to pay for photos you didn't take.Also the various groups only appear to perform for money, but as for dancing groups for example only very halfheartedly. I was also quite disappointed by the snake charmers. Would have been happy to give some Dirhams for a nice picture, but there was no effort, whatsoever, put into presentation and you constantly had to watch out, whether one of them wanted to put some snake around your shoulders and make you pay for it.Especially this last aspect keeps you nervously looking around all the time and at least getting us to leave the place rather quickly.

I'd say overrated . Every day as we passed by, we saw people fighting, arguing, etc. Can not have a peaceful walk-around as everybody's shouting to have a try at their food stall or shop. Although must visit just to see the place, very nice in the evening towards the mosque.

Lively market - people watching. I love watching people and this place is great for it. During the day (heat) you can visibly see the numbers are down, and around 7pm people are starting to come out and the square fills up. There's plenty to feast your eyes on, from fruit and veg to food to jewelry, to clothing etc. Snake charmers, monkeys (poor sods on chains), selfie stick, phone, sunglasses, and all sorts of sellers...

Crazy little place . If your into shopping and markets and food in particular then you'd love it here! It's fairly quiet by day but at night it comes alive! Great smell of various foods everywhere you go loads and loads of stalls and indoor markets to get your presents from...locals can be very in your face trying to sell you things but are generally quite polite just tell them No Thanks a couple of times and they'll leave you alone but if you want to buy the stuff then you can haggle in price...Watch out for people with chained monkey's wanting to charge for photos of you with them. Very rude and don't like no for an answer...Other than that it's a beautiful albeit different kinda place.
Awesome square. This square is a lot of fun especially at night. Get some orange juice and hang out. Know that there are a lot of hustlers in this square so you'll have to brush a lot of people off.

Lots of fun !. Food, souvenirs, clothes... you'll find it all. Just be careful when you walk around at night with your fragile souvenirs in hand : yound poor kids, sniffing glue , running around everywhere .... one bumped running into me and the ashtrays I had just bought got broken.
Buzzing. What a buzzing place!! This place is a must if you're in Marrakech. From the moment I stepped in I remember people trying to sell me something. So much culture here I loved it.

Vibrant. All roads lead back to this square. We used this as our meeting point as we could see the large tower of the mosque for miles. Be prepared to be hassled to buy everything under the sun but once you're used to it, a great vibrant location.

Quiet! And listen to the heart beat of a city.. One night is not enough to absorb all that is going on at this playground. A playground to have a cobra around your neck or have a monkey stand on your head. Watch the dancers, listen to the musical groups, gather around the circle to hear the story tellers. And then there is the food! Succulent, fall of the bone meats and fresh grilled seafood. The food is delicious at the stands in the square. Or go to one of the restaurants who's terraces look out over the square. Enjoy a great dinner, watch the sunset and the crowds gather in the square below you. Its a true feast for the senses, sight, smell, sound and taste. Enjoy!

Frightening . The square was amazing the atmosphere electric and cultural but it was frightening to have small children there. There were so many people all trying to sell and trying to put items in the children's hands saying it was free! But obviously was not! There were teenagers driving through the crowds on scooters trying to grab bags! I loved the square but would not take small children again!

Exciting, exotic and at points challenging. This vast square's vitality is evident from the sounds, colours and scents that bombard the senses - a veritable cacophony. Busy and engaging, watch from the cafes, enjoy the stalls, but beware the donkey herders, coach drivers, camel herders, snake charmers, musicians and the apes. Quite disturbing to see animals treated so badly today - surely Berbers are sensitive to animal rights?

A little over rated if I am honest v. I have a very mixed review about this as- Loved the culture - simply amazing. - Did not like the constant being harassed to buy - we learnt a couple of local words and so this helps (like how to say no thank you). Was annoyed in the evening a little as felt the men just pushed and shoved into you almost on purpose - so we came back to the Riad after our food Did not like the people begging - Appreciate this is something that is everywhere, but did not like the fact that a couple of people actually swore at us because we did not give them money. This was not everyone - just a couple of people and did not let this get us down. The constant haggling is VERY exhausting - but is definitely worth doing. In once case, we went into one shop and was told something was 900 Dhiram - he ended up selling it to us for 220 Dhiram. And it did not even take that long. This is annoying and can be deceiving for those that are not particularly clued up about this. I was trying to buy a tagine and found this one place which I didn't realise was actually 2 shops - they confused me so much as they kept contradicting what the other was saying - so ended up not buying one. This however, will not stop me from going back, but will only tolerate this as a short visit and will only go to buy something if I really need it.

Must see it day and night but do your research beforehand. This is a pretty interesting and amazing place. So much to see! You need to be firm and polite. Don't show the henna ladies your hand. Probably best just to keep them in your pockets. There are cheaper places to get it done elsewhere, if you are interested. They will charge you 100 times the amount. Haggling is an art form. 'Looking is not actually free' You pay a price with all the time you spend trying to get out if you browse. Go to the market and souks with an objective and don't take photos unless you're prepared to tip. Or bring a long lens and snap photos at a safe distance :-) Be aware of the people who try to get you to go somewhere or help you find your way (especially ladies on their own). Its very different to experience it in the day than at night. Do both. Lots of music in the evenings and storytellers. Its a great experience, so have fun but be aware.
You need a guide. you NEED to book a guide to get to this place since it is very traditional you cant just go inside you need to go with someone who knows what they are doing.

Too crazy!. Not my cup of tea much better things to see in and around Marrakech! It's way too busy, smell of so many different types of food, and everyone trying to sell you everything. Some people might actually enjoy this type of atmosphere but not me! Food doesn't seem sanitary either, I wouldn't risk it.
Brace yourself for an assault on the senses. Don't only go during the day, at night it's mesmerising, crazy and exhilarating.Sit at one of the cafes and watch the show.
Wow. The busiest bazar square I've ever been. Super awesome! The experience is totally worth having.I didn't know where to look. So many things to see, so much to hear and listen !
Ok.... The square is okay, but I dont like all the animals being used there. The square is best used for walking through to get to the souks...

Tourist trap. We went to the Jamaa el fan for dinner an what a bad experience that was. All the pop up restaurant , trying to get you into there one. We ended up walking out of the square an into a restaurant off the street. Much quieter an good food. Don't come to Marrakech. It is now just a tourist trap. Nothing what it was 15 year ago.

a must see. During the day this square is relatively quiet but at night it is buzzing. You have to visit at night there are lights everywhere pop up eateries by the dozen and musicians and acts everywhere you look, fabulous.

Bustling and busy..see these tips!. The square is open early but things really kick off later. We have been a few times now so here are some tips:- if you take any photos of the water sellers, monkeys or snake charmers etc and they spot you, they will ask for money if you try and say you weren't taking a picture ture of them, they will ask to see the pic on camera.- if you have young kids (I have a 4yo ) be careful of the young men selling little lights, balls etc. They will put the toy into the child's hand and then ask for money.-the horse and carriage rides are great but haggle as they bump up the price ALOT for tourists.- The henna artists will grab your hand and start putting the henna on before you say anything sometimes so be aware.- As with any crowded place, pickpocketing can occur so keep belongings close.- The souks can seem intimidating but they are safe. If you think u are lost, look for signs or ask shopkeepers who sell food etc. The reason for this is there will be a lot of people especially young kids asking if they should show you the way to the square. But they will ask for money the end.- The food in the souks and square is amazing and safe: you can see seafood and meats being grilled in front of you or moroccan crepes being made inside the souks as well as sweet delicacies.- the alleys in the souks are narrow so do tread carefully. Also it is normal for scooters and bikes to use the alleys, sometimes cars! So do keep your wits about you; they all seem to be very aware of pedestrians and we have not witnessed anyone being knocked over. Yet.- The deeper in to the souks you go the better quality some of the stuff is and more reasonably priced. There are different sections such as the spice market or the clothes section or metalwork. - There are so many hidden gems in terms of restaurants so do look for them in the souks. They can be deceiving from the outside but once you go in they often open up in to courtyards and rooftop terraces - breathtaking and romantic. There are also lots of cheap eats.- At the end of the day it is a market pace so people will try to sell you things, some will be more persistent than others! Do not feel harassed or fed up just be polite but firm and keep walking. As my husband says 'look with your eyes not your hands': as soon as you touch something they will take out another 10 to show you!- There are lots of taxis around for taking people back to their hotels after shopping: however the rates go up after 9PM.Don't be put off by people approaching you, it is a tourist attraction and you are tourists, they are trying to make a living and a lot of the stuff is amazing. Enjoy the experience!

Crazy busy but must do once. The square becomes extremely busy at sunset when the food carts open up for business. There are people everywhere yelling to get your attention. If your going to eat on the Square, do your homework online about which stalls are the best. A bad choice could make a big difference. We ate at stall 32 and got the sausages and it was great. There are a lot of locals at that stall and we even went back the next night for the same thing.

Top time! Best thing about Marrakech. Top people watching spot... Shops..and restaurants
Loved it!
Beware of scams as like any tourist hot spot
Saturday nights it gets rammed and is like the Disney land for locals.. games taking place everywhere.. it was great fun

Intense and vibrant. If you heading to Marrakech you will undoubtedly end up at this most famous of squares. During the day it is filled with traders, juice sellers, snake charmers and henna artists. At night the square explodes into a cacophony of drum beats and the noise of food stall owners touting for trade, smells of grilling of meats and boiling of snails from the ubiquitous food stalls, and all in a kaleidoscope of colour. Demand for tables is high and queuing isn't an option. Best to take a check on the menu, Moroccans tend to eat all of the lamb, bar the eyes. If you want to watch from above the Restaurant Argana and Cafe Glacier are good choices.
A must see, unique place. I was there first during the night, it was unbelievable, I felt like I was in a fairy tale. So many different activities, all kinds of people.

Worth a visit. It is definitely worth a visit however it all gets a bit samey and boring after a while - everybody is trying to sell you anything or yelling at you to go to their stall. At night the food people at the market are quite aggressive at one point we had about 5 men around us with the exact same menu trying to get us into their "stall", when you just want food that can get very very annoying and you start to get angry. The shops are nice and I got few lovely things but be warned they do rip off tourists (a man tried to sell us a pair of shoes for 220dh when we knew it was worth 70dh) and a good tip to remember is that stuff is always a third of what they actually offer. The orange juice is a must and sitting in the balcony of a nice restaurant overlooking the market is really fun as well.

Enchanting . Great atmosphere at Jemaa el Fna, lots of great shops and food places. We initially visited in the morning and it wasn't as lively. Would definitely recommend visiting around 7pm as all the food stalls are up and buzzing at that time! Purchased some lovely scarves and jewellery pieces from the shops, remember to haggle though! The shopkeepers do start at inflated prices!

A great cultural experience. Visited Jemaa el Fna both during daytime, evening and nighttime. Worth a visit just to stroll around and observe the culture. Some of the local vendors/artistans can be really aggressive though. I recommend a visit both during daytime, evening and nighttime.

Intense but glad I experienced it!. We came to buy handbags and experience the atmosphere, yes we were approached a lot, however a simple no Thankyou was enough for people to leave us alone. Haggled with a shop keeper, great fun, and went to the medina hamamm too, again a brilliant experience.

Must do in Marrakech. Head to the square early in the morning (before it gets too busy) and also in the evening (so you can see how it changes as it gets busier and all of the food stalls open). Definitely enjoy a fresh squeezed orange juice. Be prepared to ignore a lot of calls for henna tattoos, from cigarette vendors, etc. Also don't be surprised if a monkey on a leash starts to follow you around or if a snake charmer thrusts a snake in your face. Although the buzz at night was great, we preferred the square in the morning, when it was less hectic.

Sensory Overload. Daytime into Nighttime, the Jemaa el Fna is a non-stop, vibrant, festival atmosphere. Grab a seat at one of the rooftop restaurants or stroll the nighttime food stalls and pick one that speaks to you, you can't go wrong. You will be entertained, mildly annoyed, astounded, and energized. It's a not to miss "event" when in Marrakech.

friendly. Very friendly place for girl only party. You feel safe even after midnight when the square is really kicking. You will need to do some hard bargaining when u r there...which is friendly. Never pay the first price
So so. Really great cultural experience. Cool shops and stuff to buy. Most vendors are extremely aggressive, which can get very annoying sometimes.
MAD. Crazy but amazing place... be warned for the ambushing of monkeys and snakes and henna though! But it's a definite a must see at night!
don´t miss it. Dive into the crowd. I love the food at Aicha´s Place with Number 1. she serves a big variety of vegetarian food. Also nice: enter a roof terrace to watch the spectacle from above.
Bonkers. One of the most bonkers places you will ever visit. There is everything you want here fro street performers, snake charmers to the smells of the food stalls. A must see

The best choice for a city break. Marrakech, Morocco - full of warm, friendly people, the most religiously moderate of all Moslem nations. Sip mint tea while taking in the exotic entertainment of d'jemma el fna. Dine for pennies at the outdoor food stalls. Shop for bargains in the extensive souks. Take advantage of amazing photo opportunities. Take a trip into the High Atlas Mountains or down to the Sahara. And read "The Kings in the Kasbah", a novel set in the mediaeval heart of Marrakech, by Maggi Smith, available on Amazon, for a foretaste of your pending trip.

Just as beautiful and crazy as it looks!. I would recommend to come here early evening. Take your time at one of the roof top restaurants and see the sunset. See how the square transforms, all the vendors shoot up.Be prepared that the food vendors don't like photo tourists or just that you stay to look. they will be very pushy to get you to sit down,..

Very busy square. Lots of food and orange juice stalls.. and lots of women offering henna along side men with snakes and monkeys.. be careful when they approach you as they will take a picture for you and demand a lot of money! There are also a lot walking around selling all kinds of things from sunglasses and watches to wooden snakes and tissues. These people are very very persuasive and take a lot of telling before they leave you alone. But once you learn to accept this and ignore them.as much as possible you can have a reasonably good time. Lots of very good place to eat aye bargain prices and the food market is very cheap and definitely worth the experience!

WOW !!. At 1st impact you hate it.The heat, the swarm of vendors trying to sell all or something to you. But then.... it hits you... and you are inlove with it... You learn fast.. with the local language the essencial "no, thank you".From the fresh juices till the fast food on the mid square where quality of service is Non Existent. But friendly and really happy people. You can stay in the center of the arena and watch the show that JeFna is, around you.The restaurants surround the square offer all types of food.. from fruits ..pizza to the typical food..and can offer good service too.The shows in the square... be careful. . Nothing is free...The pictures with the monkeys..snakes... all of it.. has a few euros attached..Spent 1 day in it...and every evening I could, with a lovely fresh orange juice from a restaurant panoramic terrace ..just observing the hectic life down on the square with the sunset in front of me.A tip.. go for it !!!

Crazy, amazing & unreal!!!. I have been waiting to go here for 30 years. It was insane!! Not for the weak at heart. I went during the day & at night. It is a must to do both. It is 100% different at night. Try to have a meal up high so you can look down on the square. Be careful about taking pictures of locals. They will want money. Always have a lot of coins on you. You will need them. Either for the WC or wanting photos. ASK if it is ok to take the locals pictures.
not much too see. I didnt find this area too interesting there wasnt much to see, and I found it quite noisy. But thats just my opinion you should still visit this area

LIVELY!. Great place. Lots of different people. Interesting things to see such as dancers, snake entertainers, monkey keepers, market place where you can find pretty much anything and amazing orange juice for 4DHS!

Insanity!. I enjoyed this place in the day, the calm before the storm. Late afternoon and well into the late evening this place comes to life. Be prepared to constantly be asked to buy things or to pay for pics... basically to hand money over to whatever local you see for providing some sort of novelty service or unusual sight, for example, snake charmers. Be prepared for the crazy and aggressive energy of the Medina.

Tourist trap. This is the worst part of Marrakesh, with tourist hungry souk workers ready to hassle you and squeeze you for every penny, it's uncomfortable and unnecessary! Although the terrace restaurants are nice I would avoid the shops and the street food at all costs. The items are over priced and many of the workers lack manners.

By day or night worth a visit. Night time was better than day for us as the sounds and smells assault your senses from the minute you get there. Got a little hassle from the stall holders but nothing too annoying, they were trying to sell there goods after all.

An amazing place at night. A bit of a tourist trap by day but at night, particularly on Saturday is full of locals (outnumbering tourist) all meeting up and being entertained or chatting in groups that every second is genuinely enjoyable.

A treasure trove. A must if you come to Marrakech. But be prepared to be majorly hassled, especially at the entrance by the horse carts where all the 'guides' wait. They aren't proper guides but will just take you to shops where they get a commission from. You can find all sorts but again, bargain bargain.... Oh yes and there are snake charmers, a couple of monkeys and in the evenings, food stalls are set up serving tongue and sheep's head.

A carnival every night. Snake charmers, story tellers, henna artists, orange juice stalls, escargot and food food food food! My advice is to take a seat at one of the cafes lining the edge and watch the entertainment until it's time to go home!

Feast for the eyes!. There's so much to take in at the square! Freshly squeezed orange juice, leather goods sellers, buskers, even the random guy trying to sell you an iPhone 6 by showing you a Samsung phone. Snake charmers who spot you taking a photo from 20m away will come asking for money. The Jemaa el Fna is a great place to watch the world go by over a cuppa. Plus the weather in May was awesome. The sun sets only at 8.30pm, giving you plenty of day light to explore. Come night and the square transforms into a huge feast for the stomach. If you are adventurous, try the snails, lamb heads, meat skewers and more. We had a great time trying and wished we didn't eat at the restaurant (though the view over the square was great!). I would suggest not buying souvenirs and leather products from the areas near the Jemaa el Fna. Things do get much cheaper further out and in other towns like Chefchaouen.

Beware the henna ladies!. I see others have mentioned this. I knew not to take pictures or directions (unless I wanted to pay), but I did not know about the henna ladies. I see others have noted them in reviews--oh I wish I had read them first. The woman grabs me and drags me to a stool. I'm trying to decline politely, and she is saying "free sample, free sample" and goes nuts with the henna. She had about 8 inches of henna on me, and her friend starts on my leg--I said no, couldn't figure out what to do. Luckily, no leg henna, but when she finished, my husband gives her 20 dirhams, and NO! She wants 300 dirhams. I offered 20 for her "free sample" to be polite. The two women are screaming at me about they have given me a gift and now I must give a gift. And they are almost diving into my purse. I grabbed 200 dirhams--the first bill I could find, and threw it and ran. So, beware the henna ladies. You'll be covered in henna before you can say "no." Other notes on the square, it is a little overwhelming, but most people are very, very nice. The Cafe Glacier opposite the French Cafe is nice and cool with good people watching. The best place was the Cafe des Epices. It's air conditioned, and the cinnamon coffee was amazing. The people watching was divine. My husband was so bad at haggling that the hat seller actually haggled himself down to about half price in sympathy. It was our first day in Morocco, and I found that Moroccan people on the whole are extremely sweet and generous. One exception--henna ladies.

Brilliant chaos. It's hard to describe on e of the world's leading tourist attractions, but you should know that it is absolutely authentic. Sure, there are the snake charmers, the palm readers, the monkey handlers for tourist photos, but the shops and the people use this as their central meeting spot. It's an extraordinary mix, and as has been said in previous posts, the difference between the square at night and during the day couldn't be more opposite. The food and music come out at night, the square packed with sights and scents of the city.It's a magnificent place. During the day, wear sunscreen! I got a bad bad burn.

One of the most beautiful squares. Jemaa el Fna is a most beautiful square I've ever been. Hard to explain, you have to go there :) Snakecharmers, insane orange juice sellers, tagine and people from all across the world.

Crazy amount of culture. So much diversity goes around this place. Go there and get lost. I strongly suggest not to buy anything right in the place, you will get rip off. Wait until your next city and you will find, and I swear, the exact same thing for half the price. Nuts are 189dh/kg in the place and if you walk 5 minutes in the souk it is 140. Scarfs for the desert start at 200dh, we got them for 60 and by the desert they started at 30 haha! But eh, that's part of the trip. It is crazy, full of life. Enjoy it!

amazing street food. there are two sides to the square the day wild life that should not be there, its very sad all for tourist and i felt was a downer in all this wonderful culture .then the night great food comes alive lots to try and enjoy
Lots of shops. Do go here for a visit. A big selection of little shops, restaurants and entertainment. (Monkeys, Snake charmers, horse carriages too!)You can also find money exchange offices.

Chaotic but brilliant . We thoroughly enjoyed the hustle and bustle of this busy market place- although it was a little overwhelming at first. Some great food joints, fresh juice bars, stalls selling everything from argan oil to leather handbags and showcasing everything from snakes to monkeys! Keep your purse close, prepare to haggle and steer clear of motorbikes and or horse drawn carriages speeding by!

Different night and day. Be sure to visit both during the day and at night. During the day it's predominantly a market place. At night is comes alive with locals all coming out to relax and have a good time. There are usually groups crowded round in small circles playing and observing local games or watching performers. Plenty of food and drink choices. It gets crowded though so like anywhere, watch your personal belongings.

A Fun Time. We were a bit disappointed in what the square had to offer, but still had a fun time. We visited twice during the day and once at night. At night, there are many food stalls set up which offer just about any food you can imagine. Hawkers stand outside their stall and try to entice you with all kinds of reasons for eating there. Stall #25 - "eat at 25 and stay alive," Others promised that we wouldn't get diarrhea! There is also some music and street theatre. During the day, the street stalls are gone and the monkey handlers, water sellers, henna ladies, fortune tellers, snake charmers, musicians and street performers all show up. I'd read about the henna so was prepared with long sleeves. They will grab your arm so beware. The snakes and monkeys looked tired but the water guys were full of energy and will trap you. We found that if you just say "no," they will leave you alone. There weren't as many performers as we'd anticipated.There were probably as many Moroccans there as tourists which made for interesting people watching. There are horse carriages available at the end near the mosque. Go and have a good time.

The square Marrekesh. very interesting but a bit hectic I don't like snakes but when the snake charmer put 2around my neck they are not so bad at least it alleviated my fear of snakes but I did refuse the python .be aware you can get ripped off down there

Crazy assault on the senses.... A wonderfully chaotic square which truly comes to life after sunset. Beware off the snake charmers and monkey handlers.... they will say you took a photo and then demand a payment. Some visitors may find the treatment of these animals distressing.The crowds and noise can become quite overwhelming. Beware of the beggars.Good to visit during daylight and also after sunset when it has a totally different feel.Well worth a visit.
Great place. Despite the touristic appeal, it is a great place to be once in Marrakech. The food stalls during the night are a must!

good fun. its worth the visit we spent literally everyday there on our holiday. you have to avoid the snakr charmer and the monkey man he wants you to pay over the odds for a picture. nice food aswell plenty of things to see especially in the night. haggle when shopping they always give in.

Street Theatre. This is the highlight of the city. We went every evening, even in the rain, there was lots of activity - vendors of everything, snake charmers, monkeys, storytellers, boxing matches, food stalls. We ate twice in restaurants, some have great views from 2nd and 3rd floor terraces, then discovered the food stalls. Good food, with entertainment.

Great fun but be careful. Jemaa El Fna square in Marrakesh is a mad place full of all kinds of people selling all the things you don't need, henna tattoos, photos of you with a monkey on your shoulder, cheap cigarettes and watches to name just a few. All around are eating places which offer good food at very reasonable prices. The square leads into the souks which are really more of the same. Don't get caught by the offer of directions to the tanneries by a man who just happens to be going that way, they offer a free visit to the tannery and then ask for money as they pass you to a leather goods seller who expects you to buy his wares. They get aggressive when you don't pay up meekly!The key to this place is to walk with a purpose, don't look at your map and say "NO"Enjoy.

Great shopping and experience. If you are looking for market shopping in Morocco then there is no better place then here. tons of shops off this main square that becomes filled later in the day with performers. Be sure to barter and just take in the sites and sounds. One of my favourite places in all of Morocco.

Amazing hussle and bussle every night. This square is breathtaking and packed with locals and tourists every night. It is a UNESCO world heritage site and this is well deserved. Try delicious food at food stall no. 1, the only woman cooking on the square. You have to pay for photos of the drummers, dancers or the people with snakes. Sit in one of the roof-top restaurants for couscous and watch the action from above. It is not expensive, but no alcohol served. April was perfect temperature.

Fairytales, cobras, the wealth and the poverty of all of Arabia and Africa. Lazy at noontime, bursting with life, sounds, smells, tastes, wonders and uglies at night. Careful - highly addictive! You feel horribly displaced with all your Western-style modern clothing and camera and all, and find yourself all of a sudden tumbling out of a time-machine having placed you in the middle of an medieval market square with all its pities and wonders...

A bustling, high energy market . This place was amazing. The majority of our 3 day trip was spent here. All the merchants were charming and fun to talk to. The views in the restaurants nearby were great and the food was cheap also. You can get tajine for anywhere from 30 to 60 DH which is 3-6 euros. Being that this is definitely the most touristy spot, that is a good price. Tons of musicians and performers. Snake charmers, street acrobats, Berber musicians, you can find it all. I loved the snail soup and it was only 10 DH!

Worth checking out . Go for a wander through this area and prepare for an assault upon the senses - particularly sight and smell! Watch out for the men holding monkeys (poorly treated in cages and on chains) as wanting photos only results in this horrible practice continuing. Also keep an eye out for the snake charmers who if shown any interest, might throw a snake around your neck - all for money of course. Final warning - the ladies with henna who can grab an arm and begin before you've even had the chance to decline. All that being said - it's a safe area, and as long as you're observant and say no thank you in French, English or Arabic you'll be fine and enjoy the spectacle that this place is!
Somewhat over rated. It isn't as amazing as it may sound. Many of the things going on are snake charmers, monkeys, boxing, restaurants and story tellers. So in general it was good but not great.

Very noisy and smokey with repeat items in all the shops. I really did not see the attraction of this market. It was loud with people everywhere and every section you passed they were beckoning you in. I felt all the stalls were repeating the very same stock in their shop. At night loud music surrounds the square but instead of it being one group there are about 10 all paying the same repetitive music overshadowing each other.
A kaleidoscope . Vibrant atmospheric and a cultural mix. The pop up restaurants in the evening particularly no. 98 Mustapha's, great food at a great price. A must visit!

Visit the el Fna. A trip to Marrakech and you cannot miss the Jemaa el Fna. A large area full of life, stall selling orange juice , henna tattoo , snake charmers everything real and fakeIt really comes alive after 7pm especially on Sunday's being the weekend. The sounds of Berber music cooking and dancing it's a what you imagined it to be and its here. Watch out for bikes and pick pockets both come at you from all direction s

Nice but be prepared . As soon as you arrive. You will be Harrassed by every walking seller. They will follow you. And if you do like something and make a deal. As soon as you ask for change. It all changes. The refuse to give money back or your price goes up loool

Amazing. A wonderful cultural experience very hard to describe. A collection of buskers and entertainers, food and drink stalls, smells of incense. I know it doesn't sound great but it is! Hold on to your purses and west ham out for puck pockets but go anyway. we loved it.
Always magic. The square is always magic and always worth a visit! Ambiance is always very strong and unique! That's the real Marrakech
Water falls . Have to visit this place if you come to Marrakech. The Waterfalls is a very big attraction.Just make sure you wear trainers when you go.

Overrated tourist attraction. This tourist attraction is a tourist trap. Harassment of tourists has been elevated here to a perfection, as well as in the neighbouring souks or markets. People sell products way above market price anywhere else. So-called Berber Natives dressed in red costumes will let you take photos of them then force you to pay 10 dirhams or 1 euro per picture taken.Taxis will illegally charge without using their legal meters. You can report them and have them charged there is a police station right on the Jemaa square, take pictures or film them on your camera. Tourist racqueteering is a common type of action here.

Truly an experience. It might be looking a bit scary and overwhelming at the start, but this place is really so great, you really have to go and have dinner somewhere. Don't be intimidated by the people trying to convince you to go to their stall, just let it be part of the experience. Food is cheap; you can get a delicious dinner for not more than 60DH. And afterwards go and check out the crazy acts, with snakes, monkeys, music. Arabian nights, this is.
amazing maddness. be brave.... but strong.... there is a strong police presence and plain clothes men and women police at all times in the square as some of the traders can be intimidating

Mixed views. Jemaa is an interesting place with a wealth of entertainment, local food and drink out lets. It is a rich tapestry of mixed cultures. However, it is spoilt for anyone looking like a tourist as you are bombarded with sellers! iPhones, Samsung galaxies, watches, cigarettes, cakes, tissues, knives, carvings and while four or fives no's gets the message over you seem to be doing this constantly. But the biggest gripe is trying to take photos. Usually when you lift your camera someone descends on you demanding money. This was so problematic I eventually put my camera away. No direct threat but the constant harassment wears you down and I was relieved to start the walk back to the hotel
Vibrant, fun and exciting!. A great, vibrant square in the middle of Marrakech. So many exciting activities and colours, as well as a great atmosphere! Loved it.

Annoying. It's an interesting place with lots to see and watch and try but found all the hawkers harassing you trying to sell you anything and everything and the snake charmers etc demanding exorbitant amounts for photos etc detract from the experience and make it stressful. Grab a fresh juice or a nous nous from a cafe on the edge and watch it all unfold from a distance!

Boring. Boring and fake full of rip off merchants so not worth the hype surrounded by this place. Ordered a mango and pineapple juice from one of the many juice stalls only to be served with orange juice.You can get better quality items and food from the souks which are only a few minutes walk away.All the hustle and bustle is just a tad dated now and it's the same rubbish but just on a different night.Be prepared to haggle even on the juice stalls as all prices are not fixed.If you want a horse and carriage please haggle and walk away as they will come and bring you back and give you the price you desire.A good price to pay for anything at the very least is a 1/3 of what they originally quote and if you are very much in love then pay half the quoted price. Anything above this is stupidity and daylight robbery. Don't fall for their sob stories. Also remember in this day and age we can get everything within the UK at a fraction of the quoted price so do not lose your head and buy only what is required and at the right price. If in doubt ask yourself howmuch would this cost back home and do I really need this item.
mosque so picturesqe against the blue sky. it stands alone in the beautiful geardens a haven of tourists taking pictures not too much shade near it so on hot day wear a sunhat

Market galore. Typical great festive vibe as you mill through the streets of the Marrakech market. I especially liked that i could bargain by lowering each suggested price by 50% and most often walked away with my goods and a happy smile !
Quite an experience!.  Lively, souk. Like you'd expect. Should visit when in Marrakesh but spend too long and it all gets very samey.
Lively-Great at night. There is always something going on. At night it comes into it's own. Lots of musicians and performers and lots of street food.

Terrible Tourist Trap. Every tourist comes here when visiting Marrakech - and the locals know it. We saw snake charmers, musicians, monkeys and owls on strings, horse drawn carriages and numerous food stalls. Plus rude locals who drag you over to their snake pit for photos, put a snake around your neck when you didn't ask, then try to charge you 200 DH (about A$30) for the "privilege". Don't get conned though - I gave him 30 DH and told him to get lost. I received plenty of abuse in response, but saved 170 DH! Same with buskers - take their photo and they will demand money and swear at you if you ignore them.This area is definitely not typical of the people and places of Marrakech. The authorities should really clean it up - it gives the ordinary people of Marrakech, who are lovely, a really bad name.

Sort of a tourist trap but a fun experience. I highly recommend getting the orange juice at one of the Stalls and trying to get a shish kabob. However other attractions are sort of like a tourist trap. It's not a bad idea to get a place at the top of one of the restaurants for evening View of the market.
Live & eat in Marrakech. Great place to haggle with the locals to grab a local bargain followed by drinks on a cafe roof terrace over looking the bustle of the main square.
Just to go . Great place to go and see night and day and we felt perfectly safe. Lots going on and in the evening the local people go to the square very family orientated.

Absolutely riveting !. Me and my son just came back on the 20/05/2016 after a week in marrakech.The souks were busy at night and have lots to offer from snake charmers to monkeys, to haggling with the locals , drinking lots of fresh juices and buying argan oil or rugs and scarfs etc Would recommend going in morning not as busy with tourists lovely walks browsing around the shops.

A different world. The perfect place too sit have a drink and people watch.You will find everything from stalls selling spices, leather, wooden items and much, much more but you will pay more at these stalls than you will in the Medina so shop arround before you hand over your money and aim too pay 50% of what they ask or less.There will be men with monkeys and snakes please think twice before you have photos taken with them as what they are doing is cruel...monkeys should not have nappies on and dressed in human clothes (in my opinion).If you want too eat at night I can recommend stall 100...clean, safe, good food and nice guy's, we eat there every time we go.Yes there will be beggers but just say no firmly and they will move on.Don't have any money or phones in your pockets and have a little bag across your body for thoese items.Above all have fun as there's no where like it in the world.
The Best. It's all what you looking for on a holiday it's cheap and good quality and it's enjoyable. I will deafly recommend to shop here

Crazy! . This place is where the magic happens. All kinds of performers come out at night along with snake charmers, different of food and orange stalls and Henna artists. Make sure to take some cash to tip; some of the performances are definitely watching and worth tipping! Make sure to get henna tattoos from here because the henna is of good quality. I only let my henna stain for 1 hr and that color lasted 3 weeks! I regret not buying Moroccan henna!
Buzzing!. You'll need your wits about you! Don't get ripped off with henna tattoos like we did haha. Sit upstairs in Cafe glacé and watch all the action. Great fun.

Jemma el Fna- lost in history. This square is not for the faint of heart tourist or for children- by day, just a large meeting area, but as soon as the sun goes down, it's like travelling back thousands of years! Snake charmers, incredible caravan style street restaurants and orange juice stands, street performers and henna artists everywhere...truly an experience that cannot be explained but must be experienced first-hand. You need to be an assertive seasoned traveller to experience this culture at its finest, and don't get me started on the amazing Souks! Even better if you know some French. I'd highly recommend the Hotel/Riad Cecil- just take the city bus or petite cab (under $7 Cdn from the airport) to Jemma el Fna square and walk clockwise until you get to the rooftop restaurant. Keep going one or two streets to find the hotel. Tips: use an iPhone compass and landmarks so that you don't get lost in the Souks. It's too easy to do. If you do (which I did twice), just bribe a teenager to show you back the "Jemma" and then pay them what you think is fair, or offer them half of what they ask...To escape the city, take a public bus to Essouria on the coast- like paradise!

A good place to hold a monkey. Place Jemaa or the "big square" is the heart of the Medina and something that every traveler should experience at least once. During the day, its fairly busy, with all of the shops and cafes around the edges of the square doing a decent business. But at night it turns into a complete madhouse. Jugglers, snake charmers, monkey handlers, drummers, dancers, jugglers, acrobats, and food vendors of every type come out of the woodwork. And throngs of people show up to experience the craziness of it all. People walk around, avoiding the aggressive IPhone and watch vendors who will hound you mercilessly if you dare to make eye contact. Make sure to avoid stepping on a monkey's tail as you're running from the woman who wants to give you a temporary henna tattoo. And don't show too much interest in any one food stall before you make a decision, or else you may just cause a fight to break out. Luckily, as a Muslim country, most of these people are sober through all this. Because if they were drunk, I can't even begin to imagine how insane it would be. So come one down and give it a try. The party starts about 7:30 pm.

Mesmerising!. Evening at the square is fascinating and a must see. A complete hive of activity with sellers and entertainers. Be firm if you are not interested in buying, a henna tattooist started drawing on my hand telling me it was free. I repeatedly said I wasn't interested even though she had my arm trapped! Another woman joined in and when I refused to give any money saying I had none she said I could go to the bank. I stood firm and repeated that I had not wanted it doing and would not be giving any money.
