The frustrating thing was that the henna did not come off for several days - I did have an excellent one done on my other hand at the Henna Café. That kept them away! Don't be put off though a firm NO works wonders, smile and walk away and enjoy what is going on around you.

Not to be missed!. Easily one of the most visited places in Marrakech and while it is undoubtedly catering for tourists it is worth experiencing all the chaos and commotion it offers. The best time to come is just before sunset as the square transforms into a bustling market with food stalls, snake charmers and live music. Don't do your shopping here though as you will pay a big premium and the shopkeepers are less inclined to haggle. Enter into the souks insted and you'll get the best prices.

Lively square in the middle of the medina. Great spot for people watching. The monkey and snake charmers are quite aggressive. Gets a bit exhausting dogging the henna and people selling sunglasses. The square really comes alive during night with storytellers, "carnival" games, and food stalls.

First time. Came here as part of the Marrakech by Night trip organised by Thomsons. The square is vibrant, full of amazing smells. Only got 45mins free time would have loved more time. Tried haggling and got myself a good deal

Must do!. By day, this place is dead. but you can go into the market and barter. Better go into the market in the day time as there is a possiblity you WILL get lost!
Be prepared to haggle hard- they are very good! Be warned, taking photos is hard work. You have to pay to take photos of everything!

An experience I won't be repeating. I've been to many Arabic Countries and I am used to haggling. Found this place uncomfortable. Wasn't scared but was an experience. Hated seeing horses mistreated and being driven even if lame. I've ticked the box done it but won't rush back

A great place to watch it all happening. Definitely one for the tourists, but an interesting place with lots to see and many good restaurants and cafes. Be entertained by snake charmers, acrobats and dancing monkeys. Have henna tattoos and buy bangles from the Berber women,or buy pretty kaftans and scarves from the shops. Be harassed by Street hawkers selling iPhones and watches, and kids selling tissues and cakes. Watch the faithful fill the 2 mosques at prayer time and the fig sellers make way for the street food stalls as night falls. Money exchange, a bank and pharmacy can be found here, and in one corner of the square a row of splendid looking horse-drawn carriages will take you outside of the Medina to other parts of the city for a reasonable sum. A great place to people watch and absorb the spirit of Marrakesh.

Ok - no amazing. not much variety in the goods on offer, most seems to sell very similar items and alot of touristy items that you really wouldnt want to buy. It was disappointing as I was really looking forward to exploring here.If you do go, expect to haggle and to get hassled as you look around.

A must. El Jna Square is a must visit for all tourists to Marrakesh. Its where it all happens at nighttime when the heat of the day has subsided, and all the hawkers, stalls and street kitchens come to life.Be charmed (or horrified) at the snake charmers who have no doubt removed the fangs or venom of the poisonous snakes. Have a photo taken with a monkey or avoid the monkeys due to their exploitation. Its all there. Be prepared to be harassed, but avoiding eye contact and smiling kindly whilst continuing to walk will soon have the hawkers looking for other targets. Saying La-shook-ran (no thankyou) will let people politely know that you are not interested.Moroccans generally don't like having photos taken unless you seek permission first and pay (who can blame them ), so don't wave your camera around taking photos or walk around with a selfie stick.

You will go here. If you go to Marrakech, you will invariably go here at least once. The best time is at night, when all the food wagons are brought in and it takes on a carnival atmosphere with snake charmers, dancers, and food galore.
Amazing place. We sat in a bar overlooking the square at night and it's a sight I will never forget, best to go at night, lots more going on than in the day

Less interesting than expected. Before coming to Marrakech I had high expectations of the Jemaa el Fna. However during day time, it is just a large empty square. At night it comes alive with people selling small items, people doing tricks for money, people with monkeys doing tricks for money, people with snakes doing tricks for money, etc. Not something I found very interesting or animal friendly.

Shop shop shop!. Love this place! It's the third time I've been here!Each time I return I buy bags and slippers and converse! I tend to go back to the same shops each time, they know me now and always offer tea.It Can get a bit overwhelming at night if you don't like crowds but people are so friendly.Haggle and haggle some more to get a good price!I've never eaten the street food but the smells and colours at night are just beautiful.You have to sit in one of the terrace cafes at night to watch the sun set behind the mosque, it's just stunning.We will be back again!

A tourist ' must see ' ( but not for me). Many, many tourists go here to experience the chaos of the city. Locals selling fruit, food and anything else. Snakes, monkeys, rabbits, all can be seen, and not under the best circumstances. You need a strong stomach for this ' theater '. One visit at night was more than enough.

Fantastic atmosphere. Such a fantastic place to visit. We all loved the stalls and the haggling with the shop keepers. Grabbing a mint tea on one of the roof terraces over looking the square was memorising. But watch out for the organised beggars, espically the little kids who try and pick you pocket.

Amazing . We had 2 days in Marrakech and still didn't make it around the whole square.Do not listen to locals on the street and trust your instincts. Remember you do not have to pay anyone that requests money off you if you don't want to.

this is a strange place. Jemaa el Fna is a unique place that you shouldn't miss. The place is full of people the whole day. there are always some stalls selling fruits and nuts. native woman calling you for henna tattoos. some other stalls selling herbs, argan oil and other traditional Moroccan products. Later the day it gets more and more crowded here. around 6PM the food stalls start to open. snake-charmers, story tellers etc. this is a very lively place. On a personal note, everyone says that it is difficult to shake off people in Marrakesh once they decided to sell you something. My experience was otherwise. If you say a firm "no", nobody really bothers with you. This holds in Jemaa El Fna too.
MAin square in Marrakesh. Vibrant, a must visit place when you visit Marrakesh. Make sure you go at night and in the day as the square changes as the sun goes down.
amazing place after dusk. amazing after dusk, full of character, food and entertainersbeware taking photos normally require a tip, this is how they make their money in may places in the square

Snake Charmers, Belly Dancers, Magicians, Monkeys, Food and drink, Shisha!. It's definitely worth visiting and spending time here, but as soon as you stand still for more than 30 seconds or watch a show for more than a minute or two, someone will ask you for money or want to sell you something. Make no mistake, all the people in the square are there to make money, and if you're watching them, they're watching you. The food stalls are a laugh, even before you have chosen one to eat, and so long as you take it all in good humour you'll be fine. It's just the Moroccan trader's way of doing things!

Crazy meeting place - just don't look at anything if you're not interested!. I felt very safe wandering around the market Square - you just need to be aware that anything you watch - monkeys, snake charmers, etc you have to pay for. We were prepared for this and took some small change, but we weren't ready for the price tag (without warning they asked for 200 Dh!!) - we managed to barter this down, but be careful!

Beautiful Square . It's a must to see in Marrakech during the day and also during the night you will see how different it is. I would advise the girls not to wear revealing and tight clothes if you want to have a nice a peaceful visit. It's important to respect the culture and avoid attracting the attention of the local men on you ! Be polite and say no from the beginning if you don't want to buy. If you will take pictures of the monkeys or of the snakes prepare some money to give to the guy with the animals. If you don't want to pay don't take photos and don't get too close to them.

Marrakech square. This is a fantastic place to do all your shopping and see snake charmers it comes alive at night when it's cooler there are cafes to eat in all around here the food is good and the people are lovely, get lost in the market is a must and you can see where the locals shop be prepared to haggle in the market but there are loads of shops around this square that have fixed prices don't miss it !

Hustle, bustle and full of surprises. A vibrant place to visit to eat, shop and be entertained by snake charmers / dancers and other artists. Be careful though as if you stop to take photo's there is an expectation that you will pay!. At night the market transforms into open air restaurants - however I wasn't that impressed with the food. I had some of the best freshly squeezed juice in the market - a must try.

Full on entertainment. The square is busy during the day, with the waterman walking around, snake charmers, monkeys, people offering henna tattoos and selling their wares. Everyone is trying to sell you something, whether it's goods or a photo. On an evening this square comes alive, there are the above mentioned plus fire breathers, bands, story tellers, every time you move you are moving to the next entertainer. It is a completely new and exciting experience.Just a couple of tips Do not take a photo of someone or their stall/ snake/ monkey etc without first asking permission. If you do take a photo you will be expected to pay, that is how the entertainers are making their money, currently the excepted rate is 20dhs, however people will try and get more. If you tell them it's not your first time visiting they leave you be.If you have a photo with someone, be watchful that they do not have all their friends join in, they will all want paying individually. Keep you money in a small clutch bag in front of you, this is a busy square, there will be pickpockets.

Watch out. You either love it or hate... I loved the vibrant colours smells sounds and hustle bustle atmosphere it brought all my senses to life.... Although Beware of people leading u to their spice shop... This happened to us as we got off our hotel bus a man greeted us and said he worked in our hotel, he said he would lead us to the square... We realised he was lying after following him some of the way as he was telling us about his spice shop ... but we did end up getting lost for a while...!! Once u know where u are going and the art of bartering it's a lot of fun..

An experience in itself!. Have been here before and it's always an experience coming here. During the day you can stroll through the market and and up getting lost, be prepared for the market traders tempting you in with their patter. It's all good fun but be ready to haggle. During the night it's all about the open air food stalls with the smells wafting through the air. This is a must see if you are visiting Marrakech for the first time.
Very famous square. Traditional music, authentice food, folkor dancing henna tatto and souvenir all this in Fanna square very nice attractive shows we had nice time there

Not to be missed !!!!. Frenetic activity, particularly in the evenings. Restaurants abound in this area, so sit back and enjoy watching the snake charmers and the variety of people walking by. Fresh squeezed orange juice from one of the many stalls in the square is a treat not to be missed. Don't be afraid to sample the street food...most all of the vendors have the same menu, so choose one and enjoy !

Magical experience! . Must visit!!! Will want to buy everything! But always make sure you haggle because you will be able to get it for much cheaper than they say!!!!Must try the Fresh orange juice, it is amazing. We visited only during the day as we were 3 young women, we didn't want to go at night for safety reasons but even during the day be cautious always because there is someone always trying to make money off of you even for simple directions. Be wary of taking pics of snake charmers or monkeys because they will want money! Amazing; lots of pretty things to buy and see

Woah what a place. . Amazing place skje lovely stands and shops to look in. Be cautious of the dodgy counterfeit goods . The cafes overlooking the square offer a great vantage point to look out over the market.

You will visit it anyway if you are in Marrakech. You will inevitably visit this square if you are in Marrakech. Yes, sellers and vendors may be annoying, but you have to understand that this is not 5th avenue NYC shopping. At Jemaa el Fna you are made part of a giant show.Just stroll around and watch. Make sure you have some change on you because as soon as you join the crowd to watch a performer you will be asked for money.Monkey owners may offer a free photo op. Remember that there is just one free thing: cheese in a mouse trap!Food-wise, there is a million of food kiosks and stalls. Just see where the locals are and eat there. We sat down at Kiosk 13, I think it said Ayisha cooking. It was good and inexpensive. Just make sure you understand the price of the dishes you order, otherwise you may be up to an unpleasant surprise.4 Dirham orange juice kiosks are a must (40 US cents) per a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice!

Awesome place . This is the must see place in the whole of Marrakech. Really comes to life as the sun goes down. Keep an eye on your wallet but plenty to see here and delicious Food to try out. Not to be missed.

Amazing atmosphere and amazing. We went there 2-3 times when we were there. It was very lively but the snakes were scary. The clothing was good quality but the most expensive thing was a Ferrari parked in the middle. And there was horse carriages parked up to take you where ever you wanted and we went on it.

Awesome is an understatement!. So much activity in this place! By day it has market stalls amd by night it is food stalls and snake charmers.
Absolutely gorgeous food, just sit down anywhere that looks good to you and let them feed you what they want. It's amazing! Tried sheeps head and snails here, both delicious!

Very lively square. During the day there are tons of juice stands and street sellers, where you can find everything (even dentures!). For the evening they open food stands where they´re trying to lure you in. Be aware of what you´re ordering and for what price. Food was excellent but for a tourist it can get incredibly pricy.

Overly-aggressive snake charmers followed us. We VERY RARELY say something negative about a new place, but this one stands out in our mind as a horrible experience. There are a number of street performers in this square, including snake charmers looking to earn some money from you. If you make the mistake of even glancing in their direction from far away, they will stand up and chase you down for money for the "performance" they gave you, even if you were walking away and not close to them. In our case, the performer brought his snake with him to chase us down, and we felt very threatened. Not cool. Do not recommend this location for anyone.
A bit tiring!. Be prepared to be harassed by street/shop vendors who might approach you in a friendly way inviting you for a mint tea and then not being nice anymore if you do not buy!

Madness of the best sort. Loved going to the square each evening, eat for about 8 euros, drink the freshly squeezed juice, banana and orange my fav, Sit and have coffee with the locals, if you would like a beer or wine, find the hotel just off the square. The noise, the vibe, the energy is so special

Lots of activity, lots of hustling. Sellers hustle to get your attention with sad-looking monkeys, snakes, music... Some "henna tattooers" can get aggressive and grab your hand. Make sure to pull it away. Taking general pictures of the plaza is impossible as sellers from every corner will rush to make you pay for it. Sellers at food and drink stalls scream out to you for attention which at first is fun, but tends to become extremely annoying. It's a good place to eat snails and sheep's head though. Select a stall with locals and join them.

Brilliant. Lots to see, loved the atmosphere. would always go back on every trip to marrakech. you have to see it to believe it. loved haggeling, you have to be up for it, smile smile smile and you will enjoy it more. don't be afraid of saying NO, or walking away. loved the food stalls in the evening. TOP TIP: You can judge the expense by looking at how much a bottle of coke is... best price we found was 6dhm and highest was 15dhm.

Vendors and noise. Be prepared: photo means cash for the local "artists" with their snakes, apes.... Walk a little further and immerse in the thrilling world of fruit- and vegetablevendors. Piles of oranges, heaps of dates (the fruit, not the ....), all kinds of fresh fruitjuice.For photographers: a delight. Enjoy.

Holiday experience. A lot to see and pretty busy...u can find so mnay things around this place and e,perience the varieties of food and culture all in one place.... a good experience for first timers like myself.

You don´t have seen Marrakesch without this place!. The heart of Marrkesch like it might have been hundered years ago. Make a visit in the morning through the musicians, snake charmer and the oldfashioned men selling water. Your second visit should be by night when the place turns into a big openair Barbecue area surrounded by storytellers!

creazy magical place. very different by day and night
very hot during the day, but you can still walk and enjoy some of the experience. some good roof terraces restaurants around , so you can eat and enjoy the view of the square.
by night the craziness starts, monkies, snakes, street food, dont miss the experience

Busy, atmospheric square . Absolutely love this place. Our second visit was just as exciting with lots of food, music, people enjoying themselves and having an awesome time. Lots of restaurants and things to see and do. Definitely beats the streets of Rishton! Heh.

A must do in Marrakech. During the day its full of snake charmers and somewhat aggressive performers and henna artists, but just smile and say la chokran (no thank you) and they will move on to the next. At night it turns into a huge outdoor restaurant and actually quite a few locals will gather here as well. Worthy of a visit during the day AND night as it is a completely different place after 8pm.

Fantastic atmosphere . Amazing cultural place to visit. Eating, plenty of. We went to a restaurant. Called Marakech Restaurant which also provided local entertainment. Moroccan salads was awesome to share. Be careful when getting your taxi home, bartering was difficult as there was 4 of us, we still do not understand why that effected the final price.Be sensible and keep your personal items close to you. It is a very poor country.

Fascinating but stay alert!. Yes this is a fascinating place and should definitely not be missed. But you need to be aware that traders in this huge square are there to earn a living. We have been before on several occasions but this time were with a younger couple for whom it was a new experience. They were walking slightly behind us and before we realised what had happened a monkey had been placed on one of them and then money requested for a photo. Moments later a lady had tightly grasped the girl's hand and, with amazing speed, had put a henna design on the back of her hand, ignoring the fact that she was saying "No thank you". She then demanded money to be "paid for my work". As fairly seasoned travellers who have been to Morrocco several times we successfully negotiated a very small payment for both incidents but it made our younger friends very wary and slightly soured what could have been an amazing afternoon and evening for them. Do not be put off going as at no point did it ever feel unsafe and there is an incredible amount to see and do here but remain alert.

Must see but be careful. The place to visit of course and the medina. Many things to see. Be careful taking pictures as they will always ask you for money then. At nights there are many small restaurants but it is expensive and the quantities are low.

Daytime visit is best. At night everything is really crowded so it is difficult to see the performers and snake charmers. Stay away from the monkeys, they have had their teeth pulled so they cannot bite you - It is really sad to see.

one of the places to go while you are here. The "PLACE" you can't miss, I even do think when you get lost in the souk, you always end up at " the Place" and when you are not, when you look around like a tourist, almost everybody is pointing towards the direction of "the Place".It is really worthwhile to visit and see how every evening all the little "hawker places" arise and sell their food. Enjoy all the positive and negative things of this place (maybe you do not like the way monkeys and snakes are treated...) it should be a part of every visit.Did we feel safe? Yes we did, there is quite a bit of security around nowadays and even in some restaurants they are checking bags before you can enter.

WOW Wow wow !. This will blow your mind and you need to visit more than once and at different times of day - you won't be able to take in all the sights, sounds and smells ! have your wits about you, look like you have done it a hundred times before and absorb everything there is to see, try and do !! I cannot list here everything this amazing place has to offer - we were drawn back to it, time and time again during our 6 day visit :)

I want to be there right now.. fresh orange juice, cheap and delicious local eats, artists, vendors, snake charmers, monkeys, i can go on and on. we frequented the Jemma el Fna at least twice a day every day we were in Marrakech. At night the place is an absolute dream.

Big, busy . Interesting. We visit at night. It is very colorful, hectic place. Music, snakes, monkeys , clowns, acrobats and food.It is probably a 'must' place to spot the magic of the Moroccan night, but for me it was too busy and stressful .People kept asking for money, if you just stopped for a sec, or took a picture Felt rude and sometime agresive

The square. The jemaa el fna (or square as it's known to the residents) is a very large outdoor square containing lots of fruit/veg and spice stalls. There are snake charmers and monkeys walking around on leads. You have to visit it during the daytime and also the night time as it's completely different on both occasions. Lots to see and buy. Highly recommended place to visit when in Marrakech. Horse and cart is a lovely way to get from a to b and a great way to see the sights.

Crazy wonderful place!. An assult on all your senses. So much to see, do, smell and taste. Peaceful in the day and then really kicks off at night! Just be careful of being conned into taking photos and then being asked for money!

Wow. It's amazing and it's crazy and if you walk around its perimeter once in the dusk you'll have seen the best of it in my opinion. There are many fantastic and amazing sights in Marrakech and this is just one of them, it's worth looking further afield as this is not all that the city is about.

We ran back to our Rendezvous point!. Lol! Beautiful experience near magical! You have shops to buy from all around you have street food sizzling around you, snake charmers, story tellers and little monkeys hanging around! An absolute MUST see and experience..BUT beware of the relentless begging that seems to be the job of young children and old women. It's not totally a bad thing though you don't feel threatened only really uncomfortable! The women selling henna are quite rude when they are refused and hardly take no for an answer! Be firm. And walk away.But for us we had to run! The kids started gathering like a hive around us! Insistent unwavering begging, you give one, they are the happiest buy it attracts all the others! our friends behind got a little slap and at that point we high tailed out of their as fast as we could! Tip: always be nice friendly and respectful but firm when you need to be. And you'll enjoy this experience!

Definitely an experience, but I prefer to be in the back streets. I wasn't the biggest fan of the medina because of all the tourist traps inside it. There were locals with snakes everywhere, monkeys with chains on, women harassing you for henna. I prefer to be tucked in the back streets in the souks with all the hidden gems. The food market at night was interesting though, food good but don't get caught out in their traps. One of the guys serving us brought us out each dish each whereas we asked to share these dishes, therefore he charged us double! This is a money scam so be careful and specify exactly what you want- if they do it wrong on purpose do not pay them the extra!

Beautiful place. Big Vênus where you meet the wonderful and different moroccan life! Don t give too much confidence to locals, ir they won t just let your feet! You have lots of things to do there, I totally advise to take a orange juice there. Amazing place! Ps: you have to get used to the dirty and the smell!

Welcome to the (good) madness!. Having only ever seen the Square on television I wasn't quite sure what to expect. In reality I was utterly blown away by the size of it, the numerous alleyways, the noise, sights, sounds, smells and the utter ordered chaos of it all.What an amazing experience this place is!Sure there's the usual array of tat for sale by unscrupulous vendors - but there are also a number of serious traders with well made products that are happy to haggle in a polite and respectful way with you to a sensible price for both parties. If you're avoiding obvious designer fakes and going with unbranded local made items you'll be much better off.In the evening the Square transforms into a night food market with fresh orange juice, exotic food types of every description and snake charmers and local musicians and story tellers - a very different sensory experience to the daytime and well worth a 2nd visit.I cannot express just how wondrous this place is and if you've ever been intrigued having seen it in a documentary you need to visit in real life!

Amazing experience but too crowded. Even though the experience is unique, and without it a visit to Marrakech not worthwhile, I find the Medina too heavy in terms of not feeling quite safe. I find it better at the Place des Epices, a true experience for the senses.

Not for the faint of heart. Jemaa el Fna is a must see on any visit to Marrakech, but a word of warning is in order. Once you enter the square you will experience a bombardment of solicitations from henna artists to snake charmers to monkey wranglers and they are very VERY persistent. In fact, they do not take no for an answer. If you are not very stern in your NO (La La La in the native tongue), you will soon have henna on your hands and monkeys on your head. They will tell you it is free until you try to walk away. If you do not compensate them, it can get unpleasant. You have ben warned.

Hustle and bustle. The food stall hawkers can be very aggressive, and we encountered some rather dishonest juice merchants.. but I must must must recommend stall 32 for hospitable friendly folks with some spectacular skewer and grill offerings and a solid harira to boot! Stall 14 is also worth visiting for seafood. Didn't encounter any animal charmers or pushy folk during my visits, suppose it's luck of the draw.
The crazy square. This square is the highlight of Marrakesh trip. Very unique place with different ambiance during the day and nighttime. You have to experience both.
chabakia and garita good.. imposible not visit.crear pleace.you can funny and enjoy and but a lot of thinks. you will have a great time.
Crazy and love. Forget the monkeys and snakes... It'scan be the mostly different experience in your life. Exotic never ever sawed something like this. Is safe nice and fun

Assault on the senses!. An amazing location to be especially at night. We spent some time in the square of every evening in our 5 day stay in Marrakech. The square is full of hustle and bustle and turns into a large party at night with street performers, food stalls, hawkers, etc. Definitely the best highlight of the whole trip.
chaos in Africa!. souks, monkeys, donkeys, snakes, horses its all happening here! a must see, we haggled haggled and haggled

Jemaa el Fna. dont be disapointed if you dont see this place, nothing authentic about this place apart from the buildings and method of bartering, had three incidents which nearly ruined our holiday.my advice in the day sit and watch the square from a cafe or a bench unless you gt a guide. beaware of the henna snake charmers and in the night the local lads who want you to eat at there stalls cheaper than asda will make you smile and there charm often jekly n hyde characters. watch yre pockets if you have no intention of buying dont touch and engage in a conversation be polite smile dont let me put you off tho.

Obligatory stop in a trip in Marrakech. Obligatory stop in a trip in Marrakech, wonderful the atmosphere that changes from day to night. I didn't like to eat in local stands in evening, in my opinion too touristy. Beautiful view from the terraces on the square.

Pure chaos. In five minutes you can take a picture with a monkey, have lunch, buy fresh juice, people watch, avoid the scooters, haggle, get scammed, watch the carriages, and buy scarfs, ceramics, keychains, magnets, shirts, jewelery, postcards, figurines, cell phones, and occasionally something genuinely exciting. Crazy place.

If you have been to large populated country this should not be anything new. I don't know what is the hype about this place other than cheap delicious food. There are many such open crowded squares all around the world.

Crazy square but worth the visit! . The square is crazy both day and night with sellers trying to sell you everything from tissues and henna tattoos to pictures with snakes and monkeys wearing sunglasses.At night the square turns into a food market selling evening meals for cheap prices. The food here is delicious but be careful to check your bill at the end (they often make "mistakes" resulting in a larger bill than originally thought!)The square is worth the visit alone to listen to the humour provided by the front of house staff at the restaurants giving you their best English accents and claiming that they are from "Wigan" and asking you to "take a butchers" at the menu!
Nice place. Its nice place for anyone who visit marrakech i had good food good ppl and i enjoyed my time in jeamaa el fnaa
Mr Shazad. Awesome. Food and shopping in one place. Plenty of it. Love the bargaining. Brilliant experience. Would recommend to anyone.
Nice . Really good authentic perception of Marrakech. Busy at night always be careful as it looks like an ideal place for pick pockets. Apart from that is got a really nice vibe atmosphere

Very busy Square. Very busy square lots of restaurants with nice terraces. there also a lot of thing to explore, the Berber dancers, snake charmers and henna tattooists remain. There is shopping, food stalls, fresh fruit juice, snake charmers,monkeys, singing, dancing...

So much going on. The square was exciting with so many things to look at and keep you occupied for many hours from snake charmers, jugglers, water men in traditional dress to market stalls and at night the fantastic delicious food stalls

A circus.. From the second you arrive at the square, in fact before you get off the bus you'll be pestered by folk looking to sell you junk, rip you off, or otherwise cheat you. We lasted 30 minutes before seeking shelter in a cafe overlooking the square watching the bedlam below while awaiting our bus to return. If you don't intend buying anything then don't go. "Having a look round" just isn't possible - they don't give you peace to do that.

Interesting experience. The famous square is full of people. you can catch the sunset from one of the roof-top terraces that are around Jemaa el Fna. Food options are good there, but I recommend eating in restaurants, that are not situated directly at the square.

immortal thrill. been there since I am 6 (am 48 now) , it is always a pleasure, the coulours, the scents, the hot grilled chik peas, the frsh orange juice, the colours in the sky at sun set, the violent mint leaves ....
Busy square . Very busy square lots of restaurants with nice terraces l. For me the entertaining monkeys on chains wearing dresses and nappies was too upsetting.
must see. if you're traveling in marrakech, this is a must stop in the evening. Take your time, take in all of the sights, the smells and the excitement!

Full on . An experience that you cannot avoid if travelling to or through Marrakesh. Barter and haggle to your hearts delight. Do not take pictures of the entertainment unless you are prepared to pay (or unless you have a telephoto lens). There are monkeys in dresses and snakes including cobras all over the market place with men in local attire charming them with pipes and drums. They will if your not carful simply put one around your neck and charge you for the privilege. At night the locals open up food stalls in the centre which are excellent value. Look for the busy ones. A lot of the food there is brought out Frozen not fresh despite what they will tell you. There are also an abundance of juice sellers. A glass for 4dn. Something like 30p! each. If you can go to one of the elevated restaurants. Not only are they good value for money but offer amazing views over the market but the action is on the street. If you sit at a street side cafe you will draw attention of the street vendors. Watches and sun glasses are mostly on offer here. Not legit but affordable merchandise. They will offer but will seldom persist if you decline. Law of averages they work on. Lose yourself in the surrounding market streets. It's cooler for one and ultimately you can not get lost as it is a walled city but you can walk for miles and miles until you find your way back, but you will experience a different Marrakesh, and not be so troubled by the shop stewards.
Great place. The place is buzzing with a great atmosphere, loads of stalls, shops, food stalls and restaurants etc.

Spectacular. One of the most exciting squares in the world at both night and day. The centre foods stalls at night are quite aggressive towards you as they encourage you to eat. Remember, if you take a photo of the snake, pay the snake charmer or risk having the snake thrown around your neck. Seek out the musicians at night and buy one of their CDs. Action packed, colourful and thousands of super photo opportunities. Restaurant Cafe France, Le Marrakech and Argana all great places to eat! Have fun.

Amazing Place. Don't be afraid to go here, it's an amazing place by night or day. My daughter and I have been here many times and yes they like you to barter and buy but, it's all done in a friendly way. If you are rude to them they will be rude to you, they are just trying to earn a living. The freshly squeezed orange juice in the square is most refreshing but if you want to sit down and have food or refreshment head for Cafe Arabe. We have bought many lovely things including slippers, pashmina's, bags and lanterns.

Exciting . We visited the vibrant market. Be prepared to haggle at -120 at what they state & you be expected to pay half. However we found the shops already had the item at a fixed price, where we spent 15 minutes haggling !!. People are friendly. It started to rain and the shopkeeper invited myself and my husband to sit in the shop while they say elsewhere.Lots of beggars about and also make sure your bags and pockets are closed.
amazing. something different however its changing fast if you go deeper into the souk its more authentic but more risky

THE BIGGEST. This is a must if you are in Marrakech the hotel I stopped at was a 15 min walk to the square. The first time you go, go in the after noon to get your bearings look for the restaurants with a viewing area on the roof. Then go on Friday or Saturday night that's when you will see snake charmers belly dancers, if you won't to take photos then be ready to pay for the photos they will catch you and chase you

Great food and atmosphere . A great place to go for dinner with a few people then you can try the specialty of a few different stalls shared anongst the group. Great way to try the flavours of Morocco and imerse in the ambience

Will definitely go again. This is "The" place to be in Marrakech... You get everything there...During the day it is predominantly occupied by orange juice stalls, water sellers with traditional leather water-bags and brass cups, youths with chained Barbary apes and snake charmers

Inflate all your senses.. Great place to visit at any time of the day. However, at night the place comes alive. Restaurants pop up in a matter of minutes. Try small portions of local delicacies and move on to another. Plenty of story telling at the weekend, which is fun for the locals. Watch out for the snakes, you will get charged for taking photos. Felt safe at all times and local traders were not over the top.

Archetypal Marrakech . The Jemaa el F'na is everything you expect it to be. Quiet in the morning, it gets busier from midday onwards and then really gets going when the sun goes down. One of the most touristy places I have ever been. There are stalls selling food and fresh juice drinks. There are also dancers, drummers, story tellers, snake charmers, people in Berber costume, and a whole lot more. Not for the faint hearted - they all want money from you, even if you only glanced their way.

Must see. Jemaa el Fna is a must see when you are in Marrakech. It is very busy and after visiting twice I got tired of all the people trying to sell you something, but very nice to have a look at all the different people and things they try to sell.

a trap. I read all these reviews and was expecting something exotic and interesting. I do not feel this square lived up to the hype. The snake charmers were tired and incapable of understanding that their audience might be more interested in photographing the snakes than in taking pictures of them dancing and waving an orange plastic bucket in front of the snake. Taking a picture of the square in general resulted in a hoard of mean-spirited street people decending- demanding that the picture was of them and they should be paid.Maybe this was something in the past-- now it appears to be coasting on its reputation---- as Medinas go, Fes was more interesting.

Walk around the big square . Top place to go in Morroco. You can find every single traditional Moroccan goods, loads of the same thing for different prices. Salespeople will be chatting to you and trying to make you buy stuff for a ridiculous price. Be patient and argue the price, you can everything for less, ALWAYS. Careful with the henna women, they'll try to show the pictures of her job and will start drawing on your hand to make you pay for it. People are really friendly but be smart. Orange juice for 40 cents of Euro, drink loads, instead of paying loads for the restaurants on the square try the snails and fresh fruits from the food trucks.

Must see place in Marrakesh. Huge place full of people, food and attractions. Colourful and vivid. However be careful with food. We have bought grilled chicked (not to get any bacteria) and after eating it I have got an alergical response (that actually occurs only in the case of one particular antibiotic). And if you buy something - always bargain - you can get stuff for almost 50% of the initial price.
Attractive. Each time we visit marrakesh we need to go daily for this site which caractrise this city with shopping eating and seeing the locals activity it is endless fun

Definitely check it out. This is definitely a place much more boisterous than other parts of Morocco. I suggest seeing it during the day (snake charmers and other performers) and also at night, when there is a totally different vibe and a whole development of food/drink stalls that aren't open during the heat of the day. It is true that you shouldn't really take any photos or stop and watch any performers without offering to pay, because they can get a little more aggressive than some people are used to when asking for compensation. But if you walk with a bit of purpose it shouldn't be too uncomfortable to get through. Quite a sight.

Not to be missed. As we walked up to the square past the horses and carriages you could smell the food cooking and hear the music. It became more intense as you reached the square and what an amazing site! Local People mingling with entertainers and tourists. The henna ladies were out in full force, don't let them get hold of your arm! They have a vice like grip! It's fun just to wander round and watch everything going on and then escape to a rooftop cafe for a refreshing glass of mint tea.

Staggeringly average. Djema el Fna is the big square in the centre of old town Marrakech. This is where all of the snake charmers, monkeys and tricksters can be found. If you take pictures of anything here, prepare to be hassled for money. If you're easily upset by animal cruelty then definitely avoid the square.Some people are fascinated by what goes on around Djema el Fna but I guess I'm not as patient as most others - hence I didn't enjoy it. I'm also not as wowed by snakes and monkeys as others.. perhaps. Oh and be prepared for the pungent smell as you walk up to the square from Koutoubia mosque - do horses usually smell that bad?!At night the square is filled with food stalls. The storytellers come out sometimes too but their stories seem to only be in Arabic/for locals. There were other forms of entertainment like music on the square too - which drew in a lot of tourists. If you want to hear some traditional stories in English head over to Cafe Clock in Kasbah on a Thursday evening. You can walk it from the square if you're good at navigating. Otherwise get a taxi.. they're cheap anyway.There's a street full of banks just off the square (near the mosque) - if you need an ATM you'll find half a dozen nearby. And all of the market stalls/souks are around the square too.

Movie in real life. Jemaa El Fna is so bubbly and alive with multiple activities simultaneously that to me, it seems like watching a different live movie with each turn I make. The hawkers selling all sorts of things, the animal men luring tourists to pose with their monkeys and snakes to make money, the henna ladies, the juice stalls and the street food stalls that come alive in the evening makes this square stand out from any other square you're used to until now. It is quite an experience worth writing home about.

Do not make eye contact . Very nice however avoid eye contact with snake charmers as you will have a snake draped on with camera taken off you for a photo you before you can blink. Was asked for approx £45 for a photo but gave only a £5 but had to be insistent.
I did not like it. I was not comfortable with having people approaching us for various things. You have to constantly be on alert. Chaos in not something i generally enjoy.

Society Alive!. I recommend you to go to Jemaa el Fna first if you visit Marrakech. Yap this can be an introduction to Maroccan people to get closer to them. This place is so amazing! You can find anything you want even a glass of orange juice, there are lots of orange juice sellers.Don't get lost or maybe you won't because even lots of paths will confuse you, they are connected each other. The only thing that you have to worry is that ocean people. Yeah people from around the world will visit Jemaa el Fna once they are in Morocco, so be careful of your stuffs.

Evening meals are an experience!. We decided to go during the evening, so missed out on seeing the snake charmers. The ambience at night time was a real experience though, and the food stalls plentiful and hygienic.

Huge Open air food experience. We went to the Jemma el Fna at night for dinner and were immersed in the cultural experience of Morocco. There were food stalls everywhere with most of them serving traditional Moroccan food... Kababs, Harira soup and Cous Cous. We walked by a few stalls which were packed and settled on one with a few empty seats. We ordered the Harira soup, mixed Kababs and chicken Pastilla. Everything was good including the bread we were given. We enjoyed our experience and hoped to do it again the next day except it started to rain so we ate dinner closer to the Riad.

Cultural submersion . The atmosphere completely changes depending on the time of day. In the morning it is mainly just people selling orange juice and henna tattoos. In the evening the food markets come to life and there are lots of different types of street entertainers. It's also great to sit in one of the restaurants and watch the medina come to life.I wouldn't recommend it for anyone who doesn't want to be constantly hassled by people trying to get you to spend money. Only a couple of people however became what could be classed as aggressive with us when we didn't want to buy what they were selling.

Overwhelming experience. My family and I got our first taste of the Square on our lengthy trek to get to our Riad. To be honest it wasn't pleasant as we had just come of a flight and fought through customs, then having to fight through the throngs of people wasn't great.The following day was a bit better and not so busy. There are a lot of traders desperate to sell you their wares and will try anything.I did have one altercation with a women wanting to put henna on me. She grabbed my arm and wouldn't take no for answer, so much do I had to get slightly aggressive, she in turn then jabbed her henna needle in my backside. Don't think I've ever been so angry. The men with the monkeys are also quite pushy but do back off if you assert yourself. Putting that aside most vendors were polite and happy.Don't try taking obvious pictures of the snake charmers/monkeys or the colourful men in costume as they will run after you for money(daughter can vouch for that)In the evening the volume of people doubles, the atmosphere and noise is crazy as are all the smells from food, horses and incense, your senses are in overdrive.Soak it up and enjoy it, be aware and don't be afraid to assert yourself, just do it with a smile.

Mad, mayhem!. A mix of humans selling, buying, entertaining, eating and spectators jumbled together. Sounds, smells and sights. The day scene seems tame and orderly but as night falls the place takes on a circus like atmosphere.

Must do. Nothing crazy here but it's a must see while in Marrakesh. From snake charmer to monkeys to stands selling fresh orange juice, nuts, olives, crafts.
I wouldn't spend too much time here but definitely have to stop by.
I've heard it's great to come around dinner time to see street performances. Will try that out later in the week.

Culturally interesting. Worth a visit to sit in a cafe overlooking the square but beware the pedlars with tacky goods and the cruelty to birds and monkeys if you don't like to see that. Definitely worth the visit though.

Hustle and bustle . Having visited this market place during the daytime we noticed a huge difference in the night when it was so much busier There a snake charmers monkey men and so many other colourful characters about it is a visual delight Be prepared to be swamped with watches being offered to you & belts and other such merchandise and remember to haggle it's expected !The fresh juice carts are perfect in the hot evenings 5 dirhams will get you a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice

The Jemaa el Fna has to be the number one attraction in Marrakech. By day Jemaa el Fna is just a massive open space for a leisurely stroll but its in the evening when this place magically transforms into a fairyland of lights as the square fills up and a carnival atmosphere ensues. Has to be the main attraction in Marrakech without a doubt and when you get tired exploring the many street acts there is always the Cafe,s with their terraces for more relaxing overview. I love this place.

Good for a number of reasons. A range of food places. The souks are an experience. The stall owners will try and entice u but they do not pester you as much as those store owners in Turkey Marmaris. Very busy at night...You know what just go there and let yourself decide!!! Ohhh and what out for pickpockets! Use a bag for all your belongings. Peace
Great souk. Fasinanting a must visit if in Marrakesh. Lots of interesting souvenirs clothes shoes etc. Great place to eat especially at night when the square is alive with people snake charmers

Amazing and very busy at night. Very busy place where you can make shopping, have a drink, eat some real morrocain food and enjoy the local traditions. Recommended at night and be ware of taking photos as it might cost you money, have a deal first.

Very busy central hub.. This the main square of Old Marrakech and has a number of restaurants surrounding this square, which offer terraces to sit and watch the busy Moroccan life go by.There are a large number of stalls which offer fresh juices, which are a must try. The old snake charmers were also out on the square, but this was not our cup of tea, and their handling of the snakes was a little upsetting.The hotel Ali which is just of the square offers the best exchange rates for currency conversions.When trying out the horse carriages near the square, be sure to negotiate and agree on an hourly trip. We found this out after we agreed in a price for a "long trip" to a number of locations, which only took 35-40 minutes, and included commentary such as " this is a hotel", "this is a hospital" , "this is a restaurant" etc. There is usually a price list stuck on the carriage but you struggle to find it, and no one adheres to the prices anyway.Also be careful of the usual trick of people trying to show you directions, especially to the Berber market or the leather district. If interested, this trick works in the following way: you may be passing by and someone asks if you are looking for the market. He then attempts to point you in a particular direction but somehow miraculously finds a gentleman who is going in the direction. Anyhow, this person walks ahead of you attempting to guide you (we were told that if the police find these guys they are immediately jailed for 3-4 days, hence they usually walk ahead). The goal is to get you into one of the shops under "no obligation" where you are pushed into purchasing something.We were taken to a leather /tannery shop owned by a supposedly nice elderly gentleman, which had a view of the tanning workshops from the first floor. Someone else came and explained the view from the first floor, and showed us some goods. As we didn't purchase anything, the old man got very angry and abusive. Anyhow, after we left the shop, the men who explained how the tanning works (referred to themselves as the Berber cooperative) in the shop and our passerby guide appeared with some friends and forced us to pay them a fee for the free explanation by surrounding us in a narrow street. Moral: Avoid this situation, and don't follow random strangers.

See the bustle of the city, not just tourist traps. Yes, a lot of the stalls and sellers are dedicated to trapping tourists in their nets (monkey owners, snake charmers, henna artists...) but if you look to the side, in the evening, it's also a place for locals to gather to listen to music, storytelling, or just to hang out. If you are a tourist make sure to stand at a distance so you're not expected to give change, but you can get a sense of the local culture. If you choose to come here for dinner in one of the food stalls, beware. The guys all say "same stuff everywhere, eat here! You want kebab? Couscous? Vegetable? Yes, I help you." What they are really doing is up-selling you. You might end up paying around €45 pp for a lackluster meal that they chose for you. Definitely go to the snail stands. They are nice, delicious, and cheap. The other stalls are an experience, but don't get scammed!!
Marrakech tour . Really magical place. Must see on any Marrakech visit. Local food really delicious. Lot of activities and fun.

It's a real pearl. The heart of the city! I could spend hours watching around, listening to music.
But beware after making fotos, local "clowns" will ask for lot of money. Don't give more then 1 euro. On my opinion, they are pretty harmless)

A lively night out. Alive in the day with snake charmers and monkeys, many little shops and lots of juice stalls (an orange juice costs 4dh and other juices 10dh).At night time the square is even more lively with story telling (in Arabic), henna and entertainment. Around the many food tents prepare to be invited, (often aggressively) to see their menu and eat particularly if you look like a tourist. A good experience and popular with both locals and tourists!
Not for everyone . Only really for tourists, very pushy sellers and even pudgier henna ladiesReally did not enjoy the hassle and cheap goods for sale there

Interesting. Probably better observed from one of the surrounding hotel terraces so that photographs can be taken without being hassled this square is worth a visit. Snakes charmers try to induce sleepy snakes to dance and monkey handlers try and encourage passers by to hold their charges whilst every salesman around tries to sell you their wares. The most interesting feature to me were the story tellers who with or without costume clearly held the local people entranced.

My main disappointment in Morocco. We visited the square during the day and during the night. He food stalls are amazing. There is too much noise, nothing worthy attention was going on, very pushy people trying to sell you staff you can't take pictures of anything without somebody trying to make you pay for that

Always very busy!. Careful with the restaurants in the evening, as they basically drag you in. Same goes for the guys with the snakes and the monkeys.If you want a fruit juice, go to the stand 33 and ask for the mixte :)

Can't be missed. You can't miss this place but it will soon wear you out Snake charmers, acrobats, hustlers etc etc Good fun but you'll know when you've had enough. Take a seat on one of the terrace cafes for mint tea and relax and few bargains to pick up too
Avoid. Avoid going to this place, very rude people who try and sell rubbish, beggars everywhere and if you say no they swear at you. This is not a place to visit more like a place to get ripped off

Total let down.. Having been to other parts of North Africa like Algeria,Tunisia,Egypt I was so excited to come to Morrocco,well what a let down, Djem El Fna is a glorified begging bowl, everywhere you go there are men women and children begging for food and money- if you are going to eat in one of the restaurants try not to sit to close to the door or Windows or you will be heartbroken at the sight of people scavenging for food, or trying to sell you stuff, as much as you may want to help them all its impossible,and then you have to deal with restaurants overcharging you or trying to add stuff to your bill you haven't ordered- steer clear of bbq number 31- it is absolutely filthy and they will try to rob you. If you make eye contact with snake charmers or guys with monkeys you will have a snake or monkey on your shoulder whether u want it or not,and then hey demand payment in a most aggressive manner, it is so cruel what they do to those animals- you will see lines of horses and carriages but if you look at the horses ankle you will see the rope they use to tie there legs together to stop them moving to far. Taxi men refuse to turn their meters on and if you don't agree a price before you get in they will charge you treble what it should be- from the square to any hotel in the area it's a max of 30 dirhams. If you really feel the need to go to Marrakech do it for a max of 3 days and spend at least one day in the beautiful mountain region of setti fatma which is on the way to Ourika. From the square to the airport max 100 dirhams. If you have to go to the medina be prepared to haggle,they will not give you a fixed price, if you want to get fixed price go to the centre artisans. It's a beautiful little shopping area and all fixed price.

Buzzing square . There is so much going on that you can't be bored in the square. From snake charms to monkeys, drums being played and everyone trying to catch your attention and sell you something. It is a MUST see if Marrkech. Get a tea on one of the roof top terraces, watch the sun go down and witness the square change and come to life at night.

Bizarre. We went here during the day to have a look around and unless you want to be hassled by beggars and see monkeys chained up don't go here. We was told to go back of an evening but was apprehensive to do so as a teenager tried to steal my bag whilst being over my boyfriends shoulder and if that happens during the day I presume it's much worse in the evening. I understand they just want some money but coming at you with a monkey with a chain round it's neck and a football shirt isn't really the sort of thing id want to pay to have a photo with. Try not to visit with a bag at all if you can help it and just be polite to anyone begging or asking for you to have your picture taken with monkey/snake.

Crazy !.... Yep ! everybody is right ! it is a crazy venue ! - for all tastes there is a something: from fortune tellers to dancing monkeys, snakes and orange juice, dealers - more or less serious... best time to go: in the early evening: can get a bit packed. Watch pick pockets !

the time square of Marrakech. i really wanted to go visit this place because i have been told this is THE place to visit but i found it a bit overwhelming - there are a lot of things to watch but every time we watch something ( like the snakes or the guys with the monkeys) or every time we take a picture, they ask for money which is a bit annoying -

Crazy place. A place worth seeing and strolling at different times of the day. At night it seems like musicians are fighting to see how plays louder. Henna tattoos, snake guys hassle you, etc. Not a place to relax, but a must see. Orange juices And shakes are amazing! Cant beat the price of 4 dr

If you don't like AGRESSIVE men, stay away.. My husband and I really disliked this tourist trap experience. The square is packed with people and the "performers" hound you for money and attention. The snake charmer men kept running up to me with snakes to put around my neck! They trapped my husband into it because he didn't say no. After I took a photo my husband gave them a couple bucks and he started demanding 30 euros. He started yelling at us that we didn't give him enough money. Everywhere you go in the square there are men shouting for you to come eat at their food stand or juice stand. It's impossible to even enjoy strolling around because of their aggressiveness. I was also bumped into by young men that seemed unnecessary and inappropriate. I don't know if it was a sexual thing, or a pick pocket attempt. Either was I was uncomfortable with it and not sure why people flock to this nightmare of a place?!?!?!?

Must see.. The Jemma el Fna is a must see in Marrakech. From the daily snake charmers, acrobats and fresh juice stalls to the night time musicians, story tellers and street food. Pull up a bench or crate and sit and eat fresh Moroccan dishes with your hands. Walking around smelling the smells alone is amazing but to eat while watching the mixtures of cultures and sights walking about is another thing all together. Like noting I've ever experienced before. Don't believe all you read about this place. Yes there are people who will ask you for money, try and sell you tissues, throw a monkey on your shoulder or stick a snake round your neck. However if you say no a few times they will leave you alone. There is no malice in what they do and at no point did I ever feel unsafe and in fact had a laugh with most people who did try to get money. As with every city, you need to be vigilant at night, here will always be dodgy characters anywhere in the world. However I felt safer walking around the square in the middle of the night than I do when walking through London in the evening. Just take it all in your stride and don't worry about people and it will be the best experience you can have.

Not to be missed. Highlight for many a visitor and popular with locals as well, Djema el Fna is Marrakech. Go there late in the afternoon, enjoy the sights, the hustle and bustle and some fresh juices or cheap food. However, be aware of piclpockets and do not spend money on people with their trained monkeys (this type of attraction should be banned !)

endless entertainment and noise. all day fun at this place - snakes, monkeys (with diapers :), people selling everything you can imagine. Sit before the sunset at Cafe de France - last floor - nice view of the moving people.

Hectic hassling, sights, sounds and smells . The main square of Marrakech for hundreds of years - the Berber dancers, snake charmers and henna tattooists remain. There is shopping, food stalls, fresh fruit juice, monkeys, snake charmers, singing, dancing... So much for the senses to digest! However the hassling by the vendors, artists, dancers and charmers is incessant. We ate at a seafood stall which was busy with locals and tourists. Decent calamari, cod, chips, aubergine and tomatoes. Costs around 50dirhams a head. We'd been advised against the henna tattoos in the square as they use cheap ink and chemicals...Stopped for a minute or two to watch the dancing - Dropped a few dirhams into a collection hat to be looked at with disgust (what's the going rate then?!). Another collection hat came round not a minute later and we said we'd just tipped, only to be prodded in Arabic for more. We ended up leaving after a minute's chatter. Episodes like that leave you feeling like a walking dollar sign - and a rude one at that: the only way to avoid the hassling is to ignore completely, feign no understanding of any human language. Explore the square, have some food (if you dare), but mind your pockets and get ready for an experience!

Buzz. Jemaa el fna...fortunately I know arabic English and have stayed in Marrakech plenty of times...although magical and lots of fun and I understand people to need to make a living but most of the times most of the people really really get ripped off..so my advice would be to predetermine a price and politely stick with it..
FUN. FUN Snakes Monkeys we had lots of fun around square good to see man drinking hot boiling water dancing on fire

An organized chaos square market. We absolutely love this place. They have everything from food, fruits and juices, nuts and spices, performers, souks and restaurants, cobra and monkey entertainers, and hagglers. It's crazy, loud, fun, frustrating, confusing, welcoming, magical, high pace, chaotic, and overwhelming market that you must experience. So much to see and try that a day isn't enough! Take in all the colors and smells and chat with the locals...you will have a great time!

Vibrant centre of the Medina.... This is the central square at the heart of the medina and a great fun place to visit. By day you get the hustle and bustle of snake charmers (before of what they try to charge you for a photo!), hawkers, cafes and tourists arriving. By night it turns into a sea of colour and noise with 150 or so food stalls and local people coming out to sing, play instruments and tell stories. Join in and enjoy, as we did...

Stay for the food (but not for the entertainment). This is great for an entertaining evening meal at one of the numbered cooking stalls, but don't expect high quality from the 'shows' in the square. It's interesting to see it all together, but the shows are mostly all build-up to generate excitement, with little or no pay-off (I only saw quality entertainment from the music players). If you take photos you will be harassed for money, but they didn't actually try that hard if you just walk off.

Strolling Entertainment. Jma el Fna is the central place in Marrakech and is an interesting place to visit at any time of the day. Entering the square there are loads of horse-drawn carriages offering tours of Marrakech. Like all things the first price is not the price to pay. The stalls in the square offer all sorts of things, but it is often better to go into the souks to get better pricing. A must to try is the freshly-squeezed orange juice. There are various choices and prices but simply opt for the basic offering at 4Dh. In the evening there are many great places to eat at reasonable prices, and also lost of entertainment, such as singers and snake charmers. The only downside of the square is that you have to watch out for pick-pockets.

A must see but be forewarned.. This is THE place in Marrakech and everyone knows it. Monkeys, OJ, henna tatoos, argan oil, musicians... all at a price of course, so look (barely) and don't touch. Great fun to observe. We didn't feel up to the overpowering experience of eating at one of the numerous food stands that open in the early evening, but a lot of people do. Lots of competition and everyone wants your Euro/Dollar/Dirham. All in good fun though. And wash your hair afger , otherwise Grilled Meat Perfume. : )

Marrakesh Madness!. Faint of heart travelers, beware! This bustling and aggressive square can be overwhelming and off-putting if you don't know what to expect. Merchants will approach you with snakes and watches and phones and just about anything, looking to make a sale. This is a part of town where anything goes - and locals will point you in a direction with then extend a hand expectantly, so stick to your guns and know your whereabouts. Engage and buy and barter if you like, but don't start a conversation unless you are prepared to make a purchase.

Very interesting stroll by anyone's standards!. Lot's going on, sort of chaotic and an overload for the senses - people watching, drum circles, interesting street food and souvenirs galore - go get down with the people, isn't that part of why you came?
Must do. It's a see of people and food. It's a must do and have the spiced tea it's amazing. The food smells are out of this world.

Manic but enjoyable. Its as vast as people say...but very enjoyable we had no issues or hassles from the stalls. Haggling was done in humour and thoroughly enjoyed the experience.. to enjoy this place you have to go with the flow and be realistic with your haggling as they need to make money too!!!

It's everything you expect - and more. Nothing really compares you for the madness of Jemaa el Fna. Day and night, it's crowded, noisy, and absolutely fantastic. By day it's filled with snake charmers, fortune tellers, henna ladies, kiosks, and lots of people. Come sundown, the food sellers take over and the crowds swell to greater numbers. There are dancers, music, fresh and wonderful food, and so much more. It's a must see for any visit to Marrakech.

Wow!. A photographer's paradise - there is so much to see but be aware you will be asked for a fee if you are seen taking photos of the street acts. The most interesting site to visit in Marrakech, in my opinion

Loved it. It's loud, dirty, smelly and bit scary - I loved it.You see all walks of life and it and it's probably a world away from what you're used to, but that's part of it. All the Moroccans we met were friendly and welcoming, and glad to have us there.Didn't like the monkeys on chains in the square but just avoided them. See if you can spot the dentist, sitting at his table in the middle of the square with a pair of pliers and 100s of teeth for you to browse! Thank god for the NHS!!Find a rooftop bar around the edge to people watch in comfort.

Nice during daytime, very hectic in the evening. During daytime this place is nice, with some tourist attractions. Buy yourself a 40 cents (euro) fresh Orange Juice and visit the roof garden restaurants. In the evening it gets very hectic. Little unpleasant sometimes in a way that it might not always feel safe. Although in my two visits it never realy got to be unfriendly of unsafe.

Encapsulating Morocco. This is the heart of Morocco, encapsulating its food, culture, history and art like no other place. It is an extraordinary venue where you are likely to see cooked snails or sheepheads; brain, tongue and offal meats or simply a place serving soup for 3 dh.  Yes, there are snake charmers, musicians, storytellers. Yes, there are peacocks that prance and monkeys that dance for your pleasure. You'll feel drawn in, unable to leave the craziness and carnival atmosphere unfolding before your very eyes..  There's the fortune-tellers, astrologers, henna artists and potion sellers all contriving to rid you of your dollars or dirhams. I saw a dentist? ready to pull your teeth or sell you dentures on the spot. Before sunset, chefs are scurrying to set up their stalls in an open-air dining area lit by gas lanterns and fire pits. Later, the smells and smoke permeate the air adding a eerie glow to the proceedings. I was partial to Mechoui Alley on the east side of Souq Ablueh where I enjoyed slow roasted lamb carved for me for a paltry 50 dh On one corner is the medina, on the other the souks displaying their wares, aggressively pursuing a sale. Around the corner horse and carriages are ready to take you through the city.  My only warnings are the pickpockets operating here and the scam artists. Watch for fake currency or being given a present only to have money demanded. There is a police station on the south east side of the square. This is an amazing experience. Enjoy...

Get lost in the busy streets. Lots of smells, sounds and colours. Doubt it suits people that easily gets headache, and is touchy to smells, but I highly reccomend you to spend a day or more just wandering the streets in the souk, and acctually taking time to watch all the spices, bags, shoes etc. Try not to mind the sellers. They are the way they are, and they won't change. Just block your ears and enjoy the exotic place.
A must see and good food. This square has a long history, interesting to see and very good food. We had a fresh orange juice every day, the best in the world!

The pulsating heart of the medina. Snake charmers, colorfully be-tasselled ambulating water sellers, roving toy noisemaker vendors, ladies applying henna, Barbary apes on leashes, families pushing baby carriages, juice stands selling their wares for 40 dirham, all against the call of the muezzin from the nearby Koutoubia mosque minaret. As day turns into night, the Berber storytellers come out and gather eager customers around their lamps, faces lit by ersatz campfire glow as the sounds of the stringed instruments keep a frenzied rhythm. An occasional horse will clip-clop by, pulling a carriage of tourists--local and not, mouths agape. Smoke rises above the crowds, reflecting and diffusing the electric lights around the perimeter, creating a glowing haze in the air. Come here to feel the heartbeat of the old city before you dive into the warren of the souk; its vast space filling and emptying like a human tide over the course of the day. It is a feast for all the senses, so much to take in. When you've had your fill, you can retire for a while for the traditional pleasures of Moroccan whisky (mint tea) and sugary pastries in one of the bakery/tea shops on a nearby side street. You cannot say you've been to Marrakech without having set foot here.

Just go for the juice. This is a place you need to see once and speed walk through. The snake charmers, monkeys, and their owners are all absurd. This area feels the most like an amusement park than anywhere else in the medina.Be careful, more aggressive vendors here, with cheap products. The snake charmers will approach you and will sometimes put the snake around you literally ensuring you pay them.The pros: jus d orange. Fresh and you can get for 4dh(about 50 cents).Make sure they juice it for you, grab a cup and get out! The souks are less maddening than this area!!

Avoid the snake charmers. This is a great place to just wander around and go in and out of the souks. Just be careful of anyone trying to sell you stuff in the square and show as little interest as possible in the snake charmers..once they latch onto you it will be very unpleasant and costly. Care also in the vans selling fruit and juice . The one we picked tried to seriously overcharge us. You just have to have your wits about you.

Fun, vibrant and interesting :). Full of colour and energy! Juice stands, henna artists, snake charmers, shop carts etc! Leave your valuable at home and head here for a wander around the square. Do not be scared - they are just being friendly - just walk away if it gets too much they won't follow you. Fun and super interesting!

the biggest square in africa. a mix of humanity.. the biggest square in africa. a mix of humanity. monkees and snake-charmers for the tourists, music and storytelling by evening and lots of food stalls, promising' no diarrhea!'

The main attraction of marrakech. As the main atraction of Marrakech you have to go there at least 2 times per day - during the day, if you want to shop in the souks, and during the night - 8 Pm- if you want to have some traditional dinner,(I would recommend the number 44) see the snakes, have some henna tatoo, or simply wandering in the square which is at night full of life and people.

Gnarls eat your heart out - the true meaning of crazy !. Acrobats, monkeys, snake charmers, dried fruit stalls, perfect freshly squeezed orange juice, smoke and henna tattoo ladies. The difference between day and night in the square is dramatic. Sit on a terrace in one of the cafes on the edge so you can survey the scene before you venture into the middle. In the evening nothing can prepare you for the waiters from the food stalls and their application to persuade you to eat !
boff. Just a big square with market and spectacles (for me not so interesting)be carefull to the pickpocket and taste some orange juice

Mystical Marrakech. We have been on holiday to many places but this was our first true city break and it didn't dissapoint. We decided on 5 days including travelling, which was only a 3 1/2 hour plane flight, and it worked really well. We stayed in a Riad ... please, please stay in a Riad, your experience will be so be so much better than if you stay in a '5 star' all inclusive hotel. Our Riad was in the Medina but far enough away from the main square to be very quiet and calm amidst the daily hustle and bustle of everyday life. Once you go through the big wooden door of your Raid you really are in another world. Jemma El Fna is vibrant, lively and totally bonkers, surrounded by many restaurants in which you can taste the local fayre - mostly Tajines of some kind or another, but we did find some other restaurants (reviewed separately) where you can get very good food not cooked in a clay pot. The Mosc is quite imperious and stands at the top of the Medina and apparently is the oldest in the country. The Souks are plentiful and sell local goods as well as some more touristy items. Always haggle! The spice Souks are interesting although I was not particularly wanting to buy spices which had been sat on the side of a dusty alley. However, one of our cooks took my partner to a spice shop not exposed to the elements where they ground the spices in front of him, and it was quite reasonable considering. We undertook a number of excursions during our five days which made it a busy break rather than a relaxing one but the culture of the old town is second to none and the architecture and history is amazing. A definite place to cross off your list. Would we go back? Probably, but only after we have explored many other countries. Have fun, haggle and don't be fooled by the stories the locals spin you

Not sure..... The square that isn't square is very big. You emerge from the souks to an abundance of noise and visual chaos. It's a lot to take in and before you know it you are being cajoled into fast food stands, before you've caught your breath.There again a good wander and you absorb the sights of local bands and entertainers ( don't like the men with trained monkeys ) do it before the sun goes down so you get your bearings before dark.....not that it's badly lit but it helps.The food is the same from all areas....just depends on who you choose or who chooses you :) we avoided the stalls with sheeps head...obviously one for the locals, but the meat and kebabs were tasty and freshly cooked.....choose a busy one to ensure it is freshly cooked. There are priced menus......use it so you know how much it will cost. We didn't and it cost us nearly as much as a Restuarant including wine. It didn't spoil the experience though.There are some nice , very nice ice cream stalls at the south eastern side of the square ...would recommend at a good price too.Twice was enough for us
Rush as typical Arabic. uncredible rush,, but exciting atmosphere... Try orange juice, and be strong when called for eating. Men are quite ofte very rude, so pickup what do you really want to eat

Caution: Cactus fruit scam. At the east end of Jamaa el fna, in front of Hotel Art Place, you may see a cactus fruit stand. After taking some pieces the seller demand 10DH per one piece! (Normally 5DH per 4 pieces)DO NOT take it.

The energy is amazing!. A Unesco Heritage sight with a festival type atmosphere. Cobras with their snake charmers, monkeys, Berbers banging drums, Food stalls, fresh juices, herbalists. You can go on and on.

Crazy noisy hectic. You have to have a look at the Place but it will soon wear you out
Snake charmers, acrobats, hustlers etc etc
Good fun but you'll know when you've had enough
The drummers drove me mad!
Take a seat on one of the terrace cafes and observe from there but don't expect a beer!

Busy square at night with food stalls and entertainment.. Main square, with lots of traders, monkey and snake handlers to see. henna tattoos are popular. street food very popular, quite dark so ensure you keep your money/belongings safe.

Lions, Tigers and Bears, Oh My.... Miss Jemma el Fna Market and you miss one of the world's last, authentically magic markets.Acrobats, Snake Charmers, Beggars, Carnival Games, Hena Painting, Robust and Buzzing Maze-like Stalls -- with great food! -- and Charming-Verbally Provocative Local Shop and Restaurant Owners make for an unforgettable experience.My kids and I simply couldn't stay away.
