Do both a late afternoon (daylight) and then the ultimate evening dinner at the market -- followed by a window-shop-stroll for souveniers, and an overall jaw-dropping walk around.Watch your wallet, keep a big smile on your face, take it all in, and enjoy, enjoy the marvels of Marrakech and Jemaa el Fna!

Frenetic energy at all hours!. Jemaa el Fna is a large square at the edge of the Marrakech medina. It is jam packed at all hours with tourists, locals, performers, music, food vendors, shops, etc. The bustling energy is contagious and fun.

The heart of MARRAKECH . The best place to visit if you are in MARRAKECH. No place that so effortlessly involves you and keeps you coming back for more. By day, most of the square is just a big open space, in which a handful of snake charmers bewitch their cobras with flutes, medicine men,... and the square gradually fills until it becomes a whole carnival of storytellers, acrobats, musicians and entertainers. Come on down and you’ll soon be immersed in the ritual. As dusk falls, the square becomes a huge open-air dining area and the air is filled with wonderful smells and plumes of cooking smoke spiralling up into the night (see Jemaa el Fna food stalls).
Experience. One of the best experience in my life. You have to visit Jemaa El Fna during the day and in the night. Completely different but always amazing

You must visit here!. If you visit Marrakech, please visit this place! This is a very busy place, but I met many friendly and nice local people, had beautiful food and drink, enjoyed interesting street performances, music and bought some gifts for my friends. You can feel and enjoy "Local atmosphere" for sure! Just be careful with accident, as I mentioned, this place is very busy, so I saw some motorbike accidents while I was in here. And pay attention to your belongings.

Classic tourist trap - but fun!. An obvious center of attention and action in a city that clearly thrives on tourism. Don't get caught by snake charmers or monkeys, unless you really want to. Instead, check out the food stalls (#14 is good) and remember that even taking someone's picture will cost you.

Eat your way through the square. During the day, this is a large opener market place filled with vendors, snake charmers and folks taking in he sights. By night, this is a large food curt. Walk around and take in the sights and smells. Try some of this and a little of that! This is truly a once in a lifetime experience. Go for it!
Flea market . Jemaa el Fna is a must..! Its better to see in the afternoon when they are open, especially for the street food. We eat lamb chop for DH 60 (2 porsion) and its very good taste.

Busy, colourful, must-visit spot. Very busy, street performers were okay in our time. Lot's of sellers but the best part has to be the fresh OJ at such a reasonable price. Street food is distinctly average though couple of good restaurants around the square.

Great for people watching.... This place is really the center of everything in Marrakesh...but to be honest I did not enjoyed it much for the simple fact that you cannot do anything without some 'Fatima' pouring fake henna on your hands...or someone screaming at you cause you're taking a picture of your partner and they want to charge you for taking pictures on the square....ridiculous! A lot to see...but would prefer less harassing and a bit more respect towards people!!! We buy what we want to buy...dont really appreciate being forced into anything I dont want!!!! As a relaxed tourist and a tourism professional....not my favourite place to be or go back!!

Mayhem!!. So this is what you come to Marrakesh for, you've seen it on all the TV travel shows going back to the 60's and it probably hasn't changed. During the day groups of snake charmers, acrobats story tellers etc and in the evening transformed into one huge barbeque where you can see the smoke rise all over the town. All the food stalls appear from nowhere around 5 onwards where you have the choice of over 100 places to eat, They are all trying to pull you in arguing among the "touts" which stall is best - all good fun so in the end either choose by whet you think looks OK or what has been recommended, we chose stall no 1 as we had been told it was good and the food was fine and cheap, but the main experience is watching what is going on around you, hundreds of people, the noise and the banter, as I said just what you came for - a nights entertainment for the cost of a cheap meal!
Is crasy and lots of fun. Good cheap food on this place and very good and dont worry you dont get sick the tayin is wounderful great to takr the familie there
a must in Marrakech. I guess you have not been to Marrakech when you have not been to this square, a hustle and bustle especially in the evening! It is the gate to the souks!

Fun and safe. I was not so enthusiastic in going to the souk without a guide in fear of being bothered by kids asking for money, people forcing you in their shops.... No one bothered us!!! It was so pleasant . The snake charmers were doing their thing, so were the palm readers and we just walked through feeling safe at all times.

A blast! . A world heritage site, plan to spend hours people watching and then shopping!!! You can have a freshly squeezed juice, purchase EVERYTHING Moroccan from the Souks and spend half a day watching people go to and from.

Worth a visit . My husband and I thought the square was worth a visit. This is where all the markets are and lots of restaurants and cafes. Be warned you do get has hassled by all of the venders. However a firm no and they leave you alone. We were quite distressed by the animal cruelty that happens on the square. There are snake charmers and monkeys. The monkeys are chained by their necks to their owners, who encouraged tourists to pay money to have their photos with them. We found this distressing. Besides this it is inserting to see hustle and bustle of the Marrakesh square. It comes alive at night.

Real Moroccan souq . Think of it as live-action channel-surfing: everywhere you look in the Djemaa el-Fna, Marrakesh’s main square and open-air theatre, you’ll discover drama already in progress. The hoopla and halqa (street theatre) has been non-stop here ever since this plaza was the site of public executions around AD 1050 – hence its name, which means ‘assembly of the dead’.By 10am, the daily performance is under way. Snake charmers blast oboes to calm hissing cobras; henna tattoo artists beckon to passers by; water-sellers in fringed hats clang brass cups together, hoping to drive people to drink.The show doesn’t peak until shadows fall and 100 chefs arrive with grills in tow, cueing musicians to tune up their instruments. This is a show you don’t want to miss – but stay alert to horse-drawn-carriage traffic, pickpockets and rogue gropers. Arrive early in the evening to nab prime seats on makeshift stools (women and elders get preference).Applause and a few dirhams ensure an encore. It's a bargain show, and critically acclaimed too: for bringing urban legends and oral history to life nightly, Unesco declared the Djemaa el-Fna a ‘Masterpiece of World Heritage’ in 2001.

Humanity's melting pot...... There is something quite exciting about Jemaa el Fna! it is an eternal meeting place for humanity & it gets really crowded. The buzz in the square just makes you feel glad to be alive and a part of the human race. BUT keep your wits about you - if it looks dodgy, it probably is! Don't encourage the crooks with the animals - they are treated abominably! Snakes have their mouths sewn up after losing their fangs and slowly starve to death & the macaque monkeys must be so miserable AND IT IS ILLEGAL TO TAKE THEM FROM THE WILD! Everything else about the place is just amazing.l

Wait until evening!. Visited the square on several occasions, and it is far better in the evening when the rooftops come to life. Bustling, loud, colourful, great smells - it is a must see. Be careful not to touch the animals from the street venders as they can become quite rude and demand money from you. Similarly don't let the ladies who draw henna tattoos touch you, as they are not afraid to grab you and start drawing then demand a fee. Be careful when eating to ensure you have clean cutlery and plates. Definitely try the orange juice!
Worth A Visit. Just for its iconic status do you need to visit but beware of the snakes!!!! Early evening is the best time to visit before it gets too crowded.
A must to visit!. Bustling and busy with all sorts of people, food, shops, restaurants, street entertainment, weird and wonderful!

Disappointing part of Morocco... I've been in another markets before in Agadir, Essaouira, and Rabat and all the shopkeepers made fun about Marrakesh ("you can come in and take a look, we won't grab you and chase you for miles"). I always thought that it was just a common joke and couldn't be that bad. But i was wrong.First of all, let me say that it is beautiful indeed, specially at night, with all the music and all the vibrant colors on the main square. It is also a market where you can find absolutely anything you want during the day. However, even if you like haggling, this place gets annoying after a few minutes. They literally chase you after you said 5 times "no", trying to get you to change your mind or visiting his cousin's shop. Restaurants are even worse. They battle to show the menu, and i got seriously annoyed when one guy grabbed my arm because he insisted to show me the menu and the prices, even when i told him that i had lunch already.Beware of the snake charmers and monkey trainers, if you take a picture with them on it, they will ask you for money, and in absurd amounts (20DHM for a picture? come on..)Maybe i was tired after a long trip around morocco, or maybe i got used to all the other markets in different cities actually treating people with respect.It is a must see, but make sure you go relaxed, well rested and with huge amounts of patience
Crazy and hectic by night. An amazing, crazy and hectic experience- well worth hanging out there. By day it's full or snake charmers and monkeys and by night its a mad food market.

Entertaining. Nothing to it during the day, but in the evening it is packed. There are snake charmers, storytellets, music playing, people trying to get you to have pictures with the snakes, monkeys, birds and then ask money...there is all sorts. Keep your distance though if you don't want a photo as i was just looking at one of the monkeys dressed up in a dress and sunglasses poor thing, and immediately the man kept insisting i shake the monkey's hand and even though i kept saying no, he wanted to shake my hand in a "ok, no worries" kind of way and the monkey ended up on my arm!

Come hungry and be open-minded to try different food. I am sure you have watch enough you tube to know what to expect. We did too and ended up with sharing a 1/2 of a lamb head. We ate everything except the bones and yes it was one of the experience I will never forget. We then had some traditional sweet cake, and tea, i was told the name, but have forgotten it. I

be careful with children . it is very busy so if you do travel with young children be careful it is great for shopping but need to haggle need to go and check it during the evening as the whole atmosphere changes
Beautiful Fascinating Amazing . Definitely worth a visit, prepare to be mesmerised with this fabulous place! The souks are full of fabulous itmes and the people couldn't be friendlier.

Really interesting. Really interesting to see the morrocan culture, restaurants, food, and even snakes gathered here.
Dont miss drinking an orange juice here, the best I have ever tried.

Mixed feelings. It's fun to discover de difference between night and early day-time. I hate to see the little monkey's struggle and the snakes got hitten all the time. They are rude to tourists standing still to look at musicmakers, they will come for money if you just stand there fot 2 seconds. If a lady want to put Henna on your hand (she says 1 little flower for free), just pull your hand cause she will finish a big hennatatoo and asks for money. Just don't pay for stuff you didn't ask for. If you want, 20 till 30 dirham is a good price (some will ask you 250). Always bargain! With evertyting!Don't buy souvernirs around the square, here it's more expencive and the man are rude. You can find nicer ones in the streets around in the Medina.The food looks good but they sell left-over food from the day before. Some dishes are pretty good but be picky.Go to discover other smallers cities like Chefchouen before the rudeness of Marrakesh people ruins you.. In other places people are so friendly! You'll find them in Marrakesh as wel but you have to be carefully.The jucebars on the square are pretty amazing!! If you got lost, just ask the shopowners for the big square. If you ask just random people hanging around they will walk you (not the quickest way) and want money. The shopowners can not leave the shops and will just help you out. Just say square this way? and they will point you.

Must to see . It is really a must to see! Day time full of snake wispers, sellers and tourists. Night time everything is changing - tourists are not the part of the life in here anymore. Local people are enjoying story tellers, local dancers and local food courts. Argana coffee house is the best place in the night to have a coffee, ice cream or a food and enjoy all the movement down there. Be carefull about you money, phones. Barging it is a must in there.

Jmaa El Fna. This is Marrakech at its heart. It is a crazy, hectic, busy square, people of all sorts come and go (and stay!), full of flavours, noise, during the day it is a market place, with the stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice, at night - the square transforms itself into an open air theatre - with street performers, people playing games, and the food stalls inviting you to sit at their table and eat. It is a very intense experience, a must in the city, can become a bit tiring after you have been there for a while, but still a world away from what we are all used to.

Celebrating my Birthday in Morocco. Upon entering the hustle and bustle was amazing, snake charmers, monkeys and the array of smells and colours was fabulous. I have been to Morocco many a times and this was no different apart from it being just my daughter and I. The only thing to be vary off is if you’re a female on your own which can be extremely daunting. We were followed around by a male who decided to walk alongside us asking what we were planning to buy, if we wanted any Argan hair oils and if we would like him to accompany us to the souks where we would get good deals, his English was very good. I politely declined his offer yet he chose to walk and try and make conversation. As there are many people we blended in around crowds and soon lost him. The second encounter was when I requested to see a bracelet which was priced extremely high, the cost was not revealed to me at first, I asked to see this and before I knew it the bracelet was being tied on my wrist, I said I was just browsing and not interested to buy this, I was suddenly surrounded by 3 men who kept asking me how much I was willing to pay, I said I was not interested and felt as though they were invading my private space as they were so very close to me. We somehow managed to get the message across and leave. A word of advice is not to venture too further into the Souks (markets) on your own! Now back into the busy square after 15 minutes of trying to find our way out of the maze. I heard a lady say “Henna tattoo henna tattoo”, again I politely declined and said “Shukran” which in Arabic is no thanks. She grabbed my hand and in English said “don’t worry it’s no cost, I will just do a small pattern for good luck and marriage”. Before I knew it she pushed me towards another lady who was working alongside her and she quickly started to paint henna over the WHOLE of my hand. I looked over to my side and the original lady was doing the same on my daughter. I kept saying “No” and she said “No problem”. After the henna had been done roughly 20 seconds they started to demand money!! I felt so scared. It came to a point where they demanded 300 dirham. I said I didn’t have that sort of money, they said give us English money meaning £’s. I said I had no change, they even went as far as saying they would give me change. Again I said I had none and they then started asking for my lipstick…. My daughter was terrified, I was then told to the bank directly opposite and get cash, one of the ladies said she was watching me and not to make her angry. No security could be seen. I walked over to the bank and ran to the left without looking back daughter in tow. We grabbed the first Petite taxi and went straight home. As I have said before this is not my first time here but certainly the first time as a female with a child on her own- Not a place for the Tourist Female. Beware and politely decline gestures of FREEBIES! If possible always try and travel in groups or have a guide.

The big square. This is the must do, it's Marrakech to the extremes! From the food and market stalls fighting for your custom, to the snake charmers, to the henna artists and story tellers, they all basically the same so just pick one - if you don't like the price walk away there is another doing the same thing a few yards away. Do watch out for the snake charmers though, I found them by almost stepping on a snake! They are not massively obvious and they don't rope off the area where their snakes are so watch your feet. Worth grabbing a drink on one of the overlooking roof terraces but recommend eating in the food stalls themselves - as with any late night food stall they earlier you go the fresher the food will be.

good for a one-day visit. noisy, smelly and busy.. the souks off the main square have more quality items for sale. In the square it is over priced. We were also advised not to eat in the square so we had coffee on the terrace of Café de France where we people watched for some time.
djemaa el fna. is nice but beware you have to pay hassel about the paying the tips for everything. if you stay on a distance or go on the rooftoop you can watch more relaxed
The big square. The Highlight of our trip.Try to spend as much time there in the evening.It seems that not only tourists like it but the locals too.We had some amazing fish at stall 14.

Cultural explosion . Love it here- a complete assault on the senses and a feeling that you've stepped back in time. Lots of people trying to attract attention (and sell) but polite and firm is the key. Ate in the night market twice and it was amazing
The market. Didn't really find anything to buy or bring back. A bit of a disappointment. The atmosphere at night is brilliant though.

Interesting, yet appaling. Of course this place is interesting, it has been for over a century: first for locals and travellers, now for tourists too. But a tourist trap it is!
Daytime and nighttime are quite different, both deserve a look. See what they sell (from second hand dentures to fresh juices) and what they show (snake charmers and the lot).

Best at night. The Jemaa el Fna is a large square in the centre of the Souks. It comes alive each night with food stalls and entertainers such as snake charmers, fire eaters, acrobats and musicians. It is risky to look too affluent or openly carry valuable possessions. Every time you take a photo you will be expected to pay someone a fee. The food is not safe to eat. The cooking methods are unhygienic and the plates and utensils are often just scraped off and not properly washed before being reused. It is certainly an experience but I think that it is grossly overrated. You can view the square and its goings on from the safety of cafes around the square if you don't want to dive in completely. During the day it is less hectic but not as vibrant or interesting.

A Must. This is a real highlight in Marrakesh, because it is Real. This is the place where you entertain and get entertained - like in the olden days. And, the entertainers entertain the citizens, not only the tourists. Here I also got the opportunity to photograph without disturbing anyone. Café Glacier offers a shady balcony where you can rest from the heat and sip the mint tea or have a nice glass of juice - while everything is happening just below you. Snake charmers and their cobras, monkeys in bright dresses on the back of their owners, bird men showing off doves and owls, acrobats and jugglers....Look for groups of people and see who´s standing in the middle. A real treat.

An experience!. Sensation overload as you walk around all the stalls, being enticed to eat by very persuasive locals. No.1 stall looked busy and claimed to be No.1 on TripAdvisor, but delve a little deeper and you will find other stalls as equally good. We settled on No.15, where the locals were friendly and very amusing, clapping in anyone who chose to dine at their stand. The food was excellent, local and beautifully cooked. I think dining at the stalls in the main square is a must to all visitors to Marrakech.

Frightening Chaos. Not horrible by day, but be very wary at night. Be wary at all times for men who slip up and put a snake around your neck or a monkey on your shoulder attempting to get you to pay for a picture... Again, one must walk with eyes averted or downcast to avoid being mobbed. By male vendors.

Lovely market place. Definitely worth a visit to experience the full flavor of Morrocan life. The array of food and drink available is breathtaking and tasty. Bartering for goods in the souks is great fun and never pay the first price asked for!! Have in mind the maximium you want to pay for something and be prepared to walk away if you don't get that price, sometimes that will seal the deal for you! If you are tempted to get your picture taken with the snake charmers or monkeys make sure you agree a price first!

Amazing experience. An amazing experience, don't be intimidated by the crowds, on an evening it's quite manic and the touts who try to get you into the cafes to eat are sometimes overwhelming but just ignore them and they will go onto the next person.It's a great place to people watch, nothing is free and if you want to take photographs of the snake charmers and musicians they will want paid. You can't go to Marrakech and not experience this place but just be prepared for the madness before you go

you can't miss it. all roots goes to Rome, but in Marrakech they leads to this place. Enjoy the ambiance but be directly very clear to all kind of people who want to sell you sommething. Be aware of al the guids who are only interesseted in your money. Keep away of snakes and aepes. Go arround 16u30 on a balconnery and enjoy the spectacle of the set up of all the eat-market.

Enjoy it both day and night. I think you need to experience the square both at night and day. At night, enjoy the dining and eat at the many choices of food stands, sit and soak in the surrounds. It is busy. In the square join the locals watching street acts etc. Of course shop as well. In the day, shop again and explore the many alley ways and shops. There is also a Post office and Police station at the square too.

Meh. To be honest, it's mostly because this type of tourism is just not our thing. We sat at one of the cafes that had an excellent street view and simply people watched. Which is far more interesting then the Cobras and the monkeys. We walked through this plaza several times during our trip and pretty much hurried through it on our way to something else. You should see it for yourself though. Don't skip it based on bad reviews.

evening better atmosphere. evening better atmospherethis big "market" square is always busy. But in the evening the atmosphere is even better, as there will be restaurant booths and lot's of music. be prepared to be chased by snake charmers, monkeys, henna ladies... taking a picture always costs money!

Bustling and beautiful. Very busy market place, you need to be very strong to maneuver around the sellers. Also beware of being cheated! We ordered a few dishes but got two of each as we were two people... Otherwise, unique atmosphere, great experience, lots of fun.

An assault on the senses. Definitely a 'must see' on any trip to Morocco, it combines street traders and market stalls with entertainers such as acrobats, dancers and snake charmers. Be careful when taking panoramic photos as you'll be hassled if these unintentionally include an entertainer. And be cautious of 'free' hena tatoos as there's no such thing. Ensure you have some 5 and 10 dhm coins in case!
not worth the hype. we went in daytime - very dirty, lots of stalls selling oranges, beware of monkeys dressed up and cobra snakes

A little underwhelming. Since it is often trumpeted as one of the top must-sees in Marrakech, we expected this grand square to have more of an impact on us, but frankly it was a bit of a let-down and left us quite unimpressed. Lots of small shops and cafes, similar to the ones found in the Medina in a addition to a few henna and fruit stands. Try passing by at night where there's more going on. You'll find some gatherings here and there playing music and percussions. If you speak French or Arabic you can try being humored by those fortunetellers with tarot cards huddling together at the edge of the square.
Great for a morning coffee and people watching!. Sit in the sun, sip a coffee and just watch it all happen - just perfect!Basket weavers, henna tattooists!

Interesting place. A must visit because it has many interesting people - be very careful with your personal items and people wanting money for everything e.g. taking pictures with them. Be careful also of the restaurant workers - we were over charged for street food.

shopping area and good cheap food. If you wanna buy cheap items, this is the place to go. Don't hesitate to bargain. Prices fo people comming from Switzerland, UK and Denmark are often multiplied by 10. Keep your wallets away from any reach : this place is overcrowded !

Definitely go at night!. Our friend insisted that we visit at night. I didn't quite understand why until I saw it. The vast sea of human activity after dark is a wonder! I wish we had scheduled more time so we could eat dinner in the square!We came again in the morning, and it was great for shopping, but the experience just wasn't the same as it was after dark!

Loved the food. Wasn't swayed by the boys trying to encourage you onto their stall. Looked, smelled, decided. Grilled meat skewers, grilled aubergine, fish, seafood, salads and of course tagines. The two of us ate and drank for around a tenner. The fresh orange juice all day long was thirst-quenching and cheap 40p!! Wandered around the evening entertainments and loved the atmosphere.

An experience but be careful. We visited here as part of a tour,then went back and had a stroll around ourselves. You have to be careful, whilst we were buying a delicious mixed fruit juice,a couple of very young children were hanging around us,trying to sell us packs of tissues, they didn't seem to understand french when I politely told them "non merci" and kept hanging around us one in front and one near my husband in the end I pulled hubby away as I was concerned that the kids had been taught to use distraction techniques to pick pocket so please be careful. Also I hate snakes and had to run from one of the charmers as he tried to put a snake around my neck! Also I did feel sorry for the monkeys. It is an interesting place to visit just be firm and if you take photos, be discreet.

The heart of Marrakech. When visiting Marrakech your stay won't be complete until you visit the Jemaa El Fna square. It's where the magic happens! Snake charmers, monkeys, food, drinks: everything you need and everything you can think of! Surrounded by the Souks, a lot of stores and banks this is where you need to be at night to grab a bite to eat, a fresh fruit juice to drink or for some entertainment. We absolutely loved hanging out on the square, there's always so much to see and marvel at.
perfect atmosphere of marocco!. this is a must in Marrakech, it ha severything, people every type of food and things to buy, there is always music and exhibitions at every hour

Average square..in my opinion. The square was OK...I guess you can go and see it if you are there, but it wasn't anything too fascinating that you can't see in other countries with similar cultures. There were an abundance of juice stands(all selling the same thing at the same price). Similarly henna ladies, nuts and fruits stand as well as little craft stalls all selling the same thing at the same or similar prices. In addition, there were individuals with monkeys and snakes, selling cds and just about everything as well as little kids begging. There is also an abundance of restaurants lining the square selling a variety of cuisines. All in all it was nothing too exciting for me to see.

Amazing !. I suggest that you view the square from one of the rooftop restaurants, the best time is sundown of course - when all the colourful characters are out to entertain. Beware the snake charmers, they will ask for money so be prepared if you want a photo with one !

Like snakes??. Unless you like snakes give this place a wide berth. Square had a huge amount of people with monkeys and snake charmers who take delight in attempting to get tourists to hold the snakes whether they want to or not.Souks lead off the square selling the usual range of tat and counterfeit goods.

Marrakesh madness!. No trip to Marrkaesh is complete without spending an evening here. Late in the day the food stalls start setting up, the snake charmers and story tellers arrive, along with what seems like half the city's population. From freshly squeezed orange juice, to snails in broth, to brochettes of meat and vegetables, there is food for the timid to the adventurous. It's like being a part of the biggest extravaganza possible. And when you tire of the chaos, retire to one of the many cafes for a good coffee or soft drink and watch the show go by.
unfortunately changed a lot for the worse. Used to be amazing back in the 80´s but now it is full of cheap tat and chinese toys A great shame...

Wonderfully caotic. Everything you've seen in movies is true! Snake charmers, story tellers, dancers all of it! And all comes to life as the sun is setting. The stalls full of dates, figs, walnuts and fresh squeezed juice (yum) to peddlers selling their wares. It can be a little overwhelming but just stand back and take in all in. Then jump in head first! Its a wild ride you won't soon forget. Don't loose your group though cause you'll never find them, but do get lost together. That's part of the fun. There's a hidden gem around every corner.

Must see . A nice experience, lots of different artist, food stands and lots and lots of beggars. Just be carful.
Otherwise just get lost her and get soaked in the experience.
Close by are the souks where you can find almost everything no one needs.
We bought some spices and herbs here and of course argan oil.

This place is nuts!. Fascinating! Totally transforms from snake charmers and monkey handlers during the day to a major block party at night. Packed and full of food and music. A couple of tips: our guide said never pay more than 10 dirham for a picture. If you don't have exact change, have them give you the change first before you hand over your larger bill. Otherwise, you will never see your change. These guys are very expert in ending up with your money. Also, he advised that you not eat from the stalls or even drink the juice. Instead, go to the permanent restaurants around the square.

Worth a visit, but beware. This like the souks is worth a visit, it is very cultural, but there are so many scams around it is hard to deifcer till it is too late. One woman tried to make us get hennas, we said no, and she kept just randomly chatting, then said she liked my smile and grabbed my arm and started drawing one, I said I don't one, but she carried on holding my arm very tight, and then demanded money. Beware no one is nice for the fun of it. they all want money in one way or another.

Exciting. During the day, the square is alive and bustling. Sure there are all sorts of people trying to do something to get your tourist money, but you don't have to give it to them. Maybe even talk to them instead of giving them the 'German Wave' and ignoring them? At night the place is pure exciting madness, with superb food thrown in.

Marrakech: Medina . Colourful , vibrant and noisy. Don't take any pictures or you are quite aggressively hassled for payment. Friendly people offer to help if you are lost- but beware... They get commission if you buy from the shops. However, it's an amazing city, huge history and absorbing.

Awesome to see, but don't eat there.. We went up to Le grand balcon du café glacier, which had great views of the square, especially at sunset. After Sunset we also went down to the street vendor stalls and were not impressed with their food or their attitude at getting travelers to eat at their restaurant. Their food looked a little old and before you could really look at the food, they would try to shove a menu in your face so you couldn't look at how fresh the food was that they would serve you. At this point we adopted the phrase I have already ate just to look and see. It was all about the same. I still would recommend getting a drink (non-alcoholic) because that is all they serve and watching sunset at Le grand balcon du café glacier.

Avoid it a night if you are a girl. Jemaa el Fna is definitely unique, especially because there's a party there every evening/night. However, the amount of people coming to you in order to get a few coins (beggars, "artists", etc...) is becoming increasingly exhausting. Also, if you are a girl, you should avoid it at night, even in groups (except if you have a strong guy with you who's keeping BOTH eyes open). There is a he number of young boys/guys who go around the place with one unique goal: getting close enough to foreign girls in order to "inadvertently" touch bottoms or other body parts. This is REALLY annoying and often shocking.

Spirit Of Morocco. Yes the title is true. This place is spirit of Morocco, snake dancer, monkey holder and little grocery shops. May be it is not very luxury but when you go there you will see real Morroccon spirit and lifestyle.

The main square. Something that becomes apparent in MArrakech is that all roads lead to the same place. The marrakech souq and the Madina and the JEmaa el Fna are all around the same area. Not exactly the same place but go to the square and next to it is the souq and the old town. Be wary of being dropped by some taxi or horse and buggy to a random shop in the old town.. clearly they are on a cut from the shop and certainly the shop may have interesting stuff but you walk out and there is nothing around.. The square by day is interesting.. juice bars and people with monkeys and snakes.. who charge you to take a picture with them or of them. lots of hawkers trying to sell their goods. At night it transforms to become a food eatery - loads of stalls doing bbq food and so on. certainly the main place to visit in Marrakech.

Intagible World Heritage. You will be probably finding everything you expected here, in the heart of Marrakech: snake charmers, date sellers, colorful dancers but, most of all, a huge crowd, especially from afternoon on. Try to keep calm or go and visit it during the morning.

The Vibrant Heart of the Medina. There's always something going on in the main square, whether it be street performers, market traders or food vendors on an evening. This is a fascinating place to visit time and again offering a different outlook depending on the time of day.

Hustle Bustle. Love the atmosphere here, go into one of the souks and you win't be escaping any time soon.
We walked so much but once we get out we end up going back into the souks!
Unforgettable experience. Loved it!
My . My holiday in Marrakech was very great and cannot forget the time which we spend it there . The people very friendly and funny .

Different morning, noon and night. The largest open square on the African continent is rightly famed for its hustle and for its hustlers. In the morning you will find the snake charmers, the monkey men and the Berber musicians. You will find yourself draped with a snake or have a monkey put on your shoulder and immediately be asked for money. Keep away from them because once you are drawn in they will not let you go without your giving them money. There are more beggars at this time of day. In the afternoon there are the storytellers. This is an ancient Berber and Arabic custom and there is little point in joining the throng around the teller unless you speak the language. There are also belly dancers and stalls selling orange and other juices, nuts and spices, false teeth, stuffed animals and anything else you might wish to buy. As evening descends the square is populated by pop-up restaurants all of whom have been patronised by Jamie Oliver or Rick Stein. To avoid an upset stomach it is recommended that you look but don't buy.

Lively vibrant place to wander at dusk. At dusk this is a wonderful place to wander around. The smell of the cooking, the crowds out strolling enjoying themselves, the various groups of musicians playing and dancing and the street sellers of various oddments. During the day it gives access to the Souks and is just a short walk from the Koutoubia Mosque.

Great atmosphere. We stayed a short walk from Jemaa el Fna and visited it quite a few times. I preferred it at night when the place really came alive with almost a carnival feel. Be aware of taking photos of the snake charmers and monkeys as the owners will expect you to pay them for it. Also be prepared to haggle over the price of anything you would like to buy, we got some great deals!

Love it or ate it . What a place - full of people , excitement, musicians , belly dancers, snake charmer etc....a lot of places to eat around - also the entrance to the souks are right there - if you decide to eat on the market stalls, keep a open mind and bring your Imodium for the next day !!

The market is this way. There is no shortage of 'help' on offer to find your way to this massive square. You will get a delish orange juice for 50 dirham but who knows what exactly goes in it? The stalls are a repeat of the souks but dodgier. Animal cruelty doesn't seem to be a concept either with monkeys and snakes being misused for entertainment. Want a cheap watch? No problem. This is not the place to go for a rest. It is a commercial premises. Cafe Argana is worth the visit though. Cheeky waiter and great smoothies and ice creams.
As expected!. Hustle, bustle, noisy, smelly, great fun! snake charmers, magicians, story tellers, a feat to all sences, you have to try it once in your lifetime!

Ok. It's my third time in Marrakech & the mystery and magic has diminished a little over time. Very exciting first time around & great if you love wandering around the stalls. I'd steer well clear of the overpriced food stalls in the square but the fresh juice is lovely & cheap

Amazing. No words to describe the atmosphere here, during the day its full of sellers, entertainers, juice bars, and at night its a different world with food stalls and its just mad in a good way!! brilliant experience and a must visit

Exciting and full of energy!. Every time I went through or by the square, it felt full of life. Night or day, there was always something happening. But at night it really came alive, with the food stalls brimming with people, and the constant drumming from all of the street performers, dancers and bands. It is like nothing else you'll experience.Although full of touts and everyone wanting to offer something for something, no one is aggressive and it is not intimidating if you just say no thank you and keep walking. It is a very exciting energetic place.

A must-see. Definitely recommend visiting this square. So much to see - from snake charmers to monkeys with Messi t-shirts on, and obviously people trying to sell you things on their stalls. Be careful not to take direct photos of these people as they usually ask for money if they see you take a photo. A must-see both in the day and at night. Totally different atmosphere but both are great

Quite an experience!. Monkeys, storytellers, snake charmers, and music. The only thing missing was actual flying carpets! Recommend the food from the vendors, but be careful to order yourself, or you'll get a sampling of several items, each at a price and quantity for a full meal each. You will pay for each item brought, whether or not you eat it.

Crazy. This is a crazy but interesting place it's a must see, just have you whigtes about u sadly there are opportunist about , the evenings are much crazier but still fun , you must try the snails they are. Delicious

What a place!. We spent 2 evenings at the market square. Best time is after 5 or 6pm when the sun is setting.There are so many alleys with different items, its mind blowing! However, be ready to haggle as the prices are quite exorbitant for cheap items, probably imported from China/ India! Try to get a table at one of the cafés that overlook the square and watch the sun set and get an over view of this UNESCO World Heritage site! ALWAYS ask before you take a photo of the people or shops! They are so particular about being paid for taking their photo! A must visit when in Morocco!

A DAY OF FUN. If you are in Marrakech, you must spend 4~5 hours around Jamaa el Fna court where you can see almost everything & anything. From story tellers, songs, dances, snake charmers, magician, animal circus, restaurants, juice stalls, coffee shops, etc. Around the court are the old Bazaars where you can bargain for every things. Never pay the asked price, you can get things below 50%!

exciting, but beware the henna artists!. We loved the hustle and bustle of the square- especially at night! It feels like a magical place with unique smells, sights, and sounds. 99% of our experiences there were wonderful, but the first day I was pulled in by a henna artist who wouldn't stop painting even after I asked her not to. My skin began to burn and then she demanded my money. Made for an unsavory experience, but the only one we had. Every other person we met was lovely!
Lights up in the evening. Fantastic! One of the reasons I visited Marrakech. This truly lights up on the evening and the food on offer is fantastic definitely revisit!

Wow, loads to buy, beware paying to much. Great place with snake charmers, monkey's, traders and nice cafe's. If you're staying stay in one of the many riads close by, be prepared to barter for the best price, the traders will ask you to offer a democratic price lol, best way is to start low, then if they're being too difficult be prepared to try another place selling the same thing, if the trader is willing to sell he will follow you then just knock them down further :) happy trading, comes alive at night. Great experience.

Sites. So much going on. During the day it is not as crowded, as locals tend to be at work. Look out for the snake charmers, it is all a lot of fun. But if they see you near there spot, they may approach you with a snake and put it around your neck. Then you are, or feel forced to pay a small price to have them removed. That said you can get some great photos, for a small price. In the evening there is a real carnival atmosphere and it is very very crowded. Keep your wits about you. It is safe, but with the crowds there is obviously an opportunity for pick pockets.
Great place. Everything is going on in this square! During the day and night. You can have hours of entertainment, shopping, food and fun in this lively place.

Can't miss the square!. Among the sad monkeys and depressing snakes being flung onto unsuspecting tourists, this historic square was the site of beheadings long ago. Great place to grab a bite and get diarrhea despite what the pushy, aggressive salesmen will tell you about their BBQ at night. And watch out for the henna ladies who will literally grab your wrist and start drawing then demand lots of money for a terrible job! Still a must visit for anyone passing through but you've been warned!

Lots going on. This is a happening place and great to watch the goings on from a terrace bar. When walking through I was approached from behind and had a snake coiled round my neck which I won't forget in a hurry !!
jemaa el fana sqaure. amazing place went there every evening to enjoy food and entertainment and shopping its a experience you must go
Wow! . Just an amazing place that needs to be seen, heard, smelt to be believed. Incredible by day or by night (do both) and make sure your camera battery is full!

Exciting but be prepared to pay!. Very interesting place. From acrobats to jugglers, from snake charmers to monkeys dressed in football strips with sunglasses and caps, from henna tatooists to musicians, EVERYONE wants money for photographs! Be prepared to give some change or some do get aggressive. They have seen you with a camera before you even decide to take a photo! If you can handle this you will have a fantastic experience. NO EYE CONTACT!!
amazing place. You'll either love it or hate it, people dancing, snakes, monkeys , Hena , shops and lots of entertainment , I ate there once but wouldn't recommend

A fun night out! . Won't recommend any food if you don't like bland tasteless food.. Make sure to load up on fresh juices. Be very careful when ordering authentic Moroccan cuisine.. They will bring things you didn't order and then charge you a lot.

The essence of Marrakesh. Must see part of Marrakesh. Make sure you see it at different times of the day, it changes radically.Amazing place to start the day from. Get there before 9.30am and watch as it starts to come alive. First with the snake charmers and the drummers, then with people rushing to work, and then the stalls. Great place to start the exploration of the Souks.At night is when the bazaar and square come into their own. Amazing sounds, smells and sights to assault the senses. Haggle, eat and people watch.

The Source of the Stereotypes. A bustling market. Snake charmers. Monkeys. Infinite varieties of street food vendors (don't miss the snails!). The sound of Prayers echoing over the chaos of commerce. The famous tower silhouetted against the setting sun's orange sky. This is a perfect place to de/compress before & after getting lost in the timeless maze of Marrakech's streets and alleyways. Dive in and enjoy!

The best and worst bits of Marrakesh. At night this place is really something else; the noise, the smell, the atmosphere etc. Really spoiled by beggars and cheaters though. If you took them out of the equation it would be great. Do not assume that anyone is being friendly, there is a price for absolutely EVERYTHING.
1001 night. Go back in time and explore 1001 night. An explosion in music, food, snake charmers, monkeys, story tellers toghether with 1000+ people every night.

Definitely worth a visit!. The square was everything you read about. It was lively and a complete (awesome) chaos! It really comes alive a night with lots of food stalls and little temporary stalls/shops you can buy trinkets at! Be wary of the tourist traps! What's even more interesting is if you go behind the square and get lost in the maze like streets! We saw some real amazing things there (also local food!)
Booming. Love the place, but beware of the people selling you unwanted things, the HENNA lasts for 1 hour, food is awesome, jemaa el fna is a place to visit to experience, words cant describe

"You go Marrakech and not visit Jemaa el Fna". You go Marrakech and not visit Jemaa el Fna, that's one place not to be missed, the shopping market and the street food. Mind blowing.Lets start with the market, the sellers start the price so high that I always say the lowest and come to my price the I would pay.At night it was wonderful the lightings and a lot of tourist who mainly came all the way from Agadir.

Jam-packed eccentric square full of life. We spent 3 days in Marrakech and spent as much time as we could every day exploring the Square. All of the branches leading into and out of the square held different experiences. Snake charmers, barbecued meats, music, dancing, food, ice cream, and shops, everything you want out of Marrakech is in the square. And if you're there at the busy time you have to navigate your way through hordes of both tourists and locals. Keep your bags and purses close to you at those times! Overall a great experience and a wonderful way to see the energy of Marrakech.

No no no. Awful!!!!!!!!!! Terrified my children, not recommended for children in a mother view anyway!!! U get hassled non stop, and if ur against animal cruelty it's a definite no no, monkeys on chains and snakes everywhere!!

The square!. "The square", this is what the locals referred to when asking about Jemaa el Fna.We visited this place on our very first evening in Marrakech. The very first thing we noticed about this square, was the number of people that are here. The sheer volume locals here is overwhelmingly and a wonderful sight for tourist to see the hustle bustle of the nightlife in Marrakech.There were stalls for all types of goods, from juices to dates, to pottery to pashmina scarves. You can find many of the local products in this square. You can even begin walking through some alleys here that eventually takes you to the Medina! If you intend to shop, be prepared to barter with them. Ask for the price, feel free to say no and they will counter offer you with a "how much?", this is when the negotiations and the fun begins. Ensure you have plenty of space in your luggage as you will find that there are so many local products on sale here. Remember, there are dozens of stalls that sell the same goods, so be patient and wait for the right deal.In the evening, you will smell the aroma of grilled meat and fried calamari! The smells alone are amazing for the nose and you will find yourself exploring the many stalls open for trade. Be warned, you will be approached by many of the locals tempting you in to their stall so you can part way with your money. My only advice here is to look for somewhere that's busy with local people as I found this is where the better quality food is served. One last thing, once you are seated, be prepared to say no to whatever they push on you. I found that in a couple of the food stalls we sat down at, they automatically serve you things you don't wish to eat as a way of making you pay more, so don't be afraid to be firm and say no.If like me, you are of the oriental look, be prepared for some casual racism. Don't be too offended, there is nothing malicious about them as I found them very nice people. It wasn't just me but also other "exotic" looking tourists to the locals.

Holiday. This is something very different. First thing to note, nothing is for free even taking pictures of snake charmers. The souks and stalls is a dream for shoppers, making you want to come again. Remember to haggle hard.In the evenings the square come alive with various entertainment and food stalls. A great family atmosphere. Be firm with beggars and guides in saying no.

Crowded , fun but has to be your thing. The square is the life and soul of the medina at night and defiantly worth a visit. Having travelled extensively it is great to see a place for locals not just tourists and traditions like the story telling and acrobats living on. It is fun and bustling and you need to keep any eye on any possessions (especially your wallet) . The dampener for us was the animals and the way they were treated - the monkey trainers and snake charmers did not appeal. That and the idea of having Adders and Cobras lying about the place makes you take a wide berth !

the centre of all life in the Medina. This square has a character all of its own that develops over a day. The crowds gather here as they must have done for centuries past. The story tellers are popular and you can watch all aspects of life go on here. The touts can be a bit pushy for their henna tattoos or monkey or snake charming photos. The fake rolexes are in abundance but the place has a soul and you can;t get bored watching the evening unfold.

The fnah fnah. Don't get hennaed here, watch out for hawkers. It's loud it's super busy it's full of food smells and everyone wants to sell you something but it's also an experience very lively and you'll get cheap street food which is decent quality.

Fascinating busy focus of centuries of tradition. A gloriously lively space full of entertainment and feasts for the eyes and mouth. We love the food stalls for fruit, nuts, and meals. The street entertainers are skillful and friendly. There is always something to watch.

Chaotic fun. Generally people will beeline for the main square as soon as they arrive to Marrakech and get overwhelmed by the hustle and bustle only to take refuge in one of the less traditional and more expensive cafes around the outside.We were no exception but after a week of travelling around Morroco and easing ourselves in to the culture, returning to the Jemaa is no longer daunting and we can really enjoy all it has to offer without feeling intimidated. The outdoor food stalls you can find in the night time are really something special and much better value than the what the restaurants offer.
Must see. A Must see. Try to avoid getting a henna tatto here. It is expensive and bad quality. Sometimes they don't even ask you and take your hand and start doing the tattoo...

Foodies spot. To be honest, we did not try a single meal there and landed up only for the experience. You will get all Moroccan cuisines there including variety of fresh juice & dry fruits. There are a host of street performers, snake charmers & stores for souvenirs as well. Unless you decide for eatables, it can be wrapped in 30 minutes top.

great main square with tons of things to see.. Eating there seems a challenge but just go with the flow, the food is good and fresh...you can point or check your neighbour's plate if you aren't sure. Some of the delicacies are not your usual fare but we managed quite comfortably and budget wise
Holiday. Good entertainment and culture its almost like no one ever sleeps alway lots of activities going on any time of day, great food and lots of it.

It's not what Morocco is all about..... I suppose the square is one of those things you feel you should 'tick off the list', but having been to Marrakech many times now, it doesn't get any better.Playing up to the tourists, it's like a permit for traders & entertainers in that area to be pushier & ruder than in other areas of the city.To be honest, with so many beautiful parks, museums & charming artist co-operatives, plus the plethora of fine dining experiences in Marrakech, I don't know why we still force ourselves to see this as an experience of a true Morocco. Take a few snaps from the sideline for the photo album and then explore the more palatable sights of the city.

Marrakech is magical!. Difficult to put into words the Jemma el Fna experience. Monkeys, snakes, magicians, gnawa music, water sellers. Things you may have never seen in your life before. Wonderful experience!
Have fun here. Easily accessible from hotels and well worth a visit. Acrobats, snake charmers, story tellers, musicians, food stalls. Great in the day if you are wary but vibrant at night.
Dangerous place for young women without men.. Very dark, lots of sex pest males trying to grab women. Make sure you cover up and hold on to your bag. A much safer place to be during the day.

Nightlife . The people of Marrakech come out at night to listen to folk music and shop and eat. It's fabulous to visit. Henna ladies waiting by the side can do fab designs.
Watch out for the touts.

Anna. Very buzzy and busy place to visit with touristy trinkets, snake charmers and various food vendors - nuts, freshly squeezed orange juice and meals. Be wary of women completely covered by a burka who come up to you and start putting henna on your hand and say it's free - they will demand payment. They cover up so you can't identify them later. Beware of pickpockets later in the evening.

Crowded but lovely. When you first see this place, you will find it so crowded, but then you will find lots of food kiosks and moroccan shops all providing good prices, in addition to the singing shows which are so lovely ... Love it...

our holiday to Marrakech. This is a wonderful place to visit.It has a huge souk and we enjoyed getting lost in it.The square offer lots of places to eat and lots of stall selling goods of all sorts eg. gifts and sevioneers. there are also Street artists and watch out for the snake charmers.

Crazy & Awesome night time experience. A must-see while on Marrakech - especially at night! Explore with friends and if you're smart, hire a reputable local guide who speaks the language to get the most out of ordering from the hundreds of eateries. Watch families participate in unusual games, see snake charmers and fire throwers, dine like a glutton for under $10, enjoy the best tasting orange juice in the world and take in the chaos of the square from one of the roof top terraces. Bring 6 dirham coins and leave your wallet and passport in a hotel safe for peace of mind - this isn't the place to shop at night.

Must See. While the square was chaotic, it was so different from anything I have seen. While there are similarities to other city squares in the world, with the music, performers, shops, restaurants and culture this is a must see. Add it to your itinerary if it is not already on there.
Amazing!,. The colors, sight and sounds are truly amazing, words and pictures do not do it justice--it must be experienced!!

A bit overrated. Whilst everyone raves about the majesty of this square, I would urge people to spend more time exploring the back streets of the Souks or to visit the Palaces. It is very commercial and overpriced.

One of the best thinks in Marrakech . I have been there in a trip with my boyfriend my husband now and we loved it during the day and during the night just take care of your wallet and don't be afraid to discover the nice restaurants that are available on the square during the night

Hustle and Bustle . Looking for a bargain, this is the place to be. You will find everything from fake designer bags, clothing, shoes etc. Plus fresh local herbs n spices. Great gifts from moroccan, traditional wood carved items, great handmade pottery items, oils, health and beauty items etc. Basically anything and everything can be found in the many souks/shops. There are snake charmers, monkeys performing in the main square, have a picture taken but be aware they will hustle you into paying hundreds, I only paid 20 dirhams for each picture which is less than £2. Many stalls selling fresh fruit n veg. Drink fresh orange juice for just 4 dirhams approx 30 pence, great outdoor food stalls, lovely smell of bbq and grills going. Basically it's a main square with everything to keep you busy for the day and with night time all the lights are on, and the story tellers, performers come out to entertain you. Downside popular square with tourists so they will try rip you off and charge any price they want but remember to haggle hard and you will leave happy.

Very Interesting and Mildly Depressing. The square is very large and interesting. I would recommend seeing it, I just could stay there too long cause it was just a little too depressing seeing how they treated the monkeys and snakes there. Never a fan of animal cruelty. But do see it, personally I just needed to avoid the animals.
Jemma el Fna. An essential Marrakech experience in the evening to see the square in the center of the old city with its crowds, stalls and performers

It's crazy out there!. Go and see it, you won't believe your eyes! It is very ethnic, full of locals, sadly lacking in tourists. The locals welcome you with open arms as they need tourists. It is crowded, slightly intimidating but don't be scared, full of madness and fun. Don't be scared!

Like something out of an Aladdin story book. Noisy, exciting, snake charmers, food stalls, orange juice stalls, restaurants overlooking the action. It's a very exciting place to visit, if a little exhausting. Don't miss it though if you are in Marrakech.

Far nicer places to visit in Marrakech. Due to it's fame, no trip to Marrakech is complete without a trip to Jemaa el Fna. It is exactly what you might expect - a large square with stalls hustling you for custom, a variety of restaurants and street performers or people getting monkeys to perform (something I did not particularly like).Advice - sit on a rooftop terrace of a restaurant to watch the world go by to avoid being constantly hassled on the ground floor by people selling/begging. Ensure you always haggle on prices for things you are being sold, including horse and cart rides and tuk tuk rides. Be sure to check out the souks too, and also the side street where you can buy hunks of cooked lamb to eat with bread!We enjoyed the brief experience there, but felt there were other places in Marrakech we preferred to eat (without the price hike of Jemaa el Fna) and places we were far less hassled.

Crazy, madness - must see but be aware. Like any other markets in the world, this one is filled with market traders too BUT obviously here it's Moroccan style so be mindful of your surroundings, don’t take photos unless you ask and/ or pay, use “la shukran” on numerous occasions IF you don’t want to buy various items on offer and “blend in” with the craziness of the square life. You will see the famous snake charmers and performing monkeys although I wasn’t impressed much by both mainly due to how the owners treated them. We didn’t experience the square at night time because we were travelling with kids and didn’t feel it was safe enough.

Throw yourself into the culture. This place is buzzing and can be overwhelming if you do not like crowds. Snake charmers and Monkeys will try to have you take pictures but you don;t have to say yes and everyone will try to sell you something . This is part of the culture. Stay at night to watch the sunset from the cafes and try the fresh juices , snails and local outdoor diner places that are all clamped together. We loved it!
Had an excellent time visiting this place and shopping. We spent few hours here and did lot of shopping. Great square. Be sure to negotiate as they quote a very high price.

Full of culture and really comes to life in the evenings.. We spend a few afternoons and evening here, both shopping and eating and drinking. We had a rental car and there is a small carpark right next to the entrance of the square and also a carpark couple of mins away. There is a KFC which the kids loved and many many eating options in the evening. BEWARE if you walk through the eating stalls to be hassled by almost every food stall. AVOID food stall 81, the people appear friendly, but were very pushy and EXTREMELY RUDE to us when we refused to have food there... Shopping in the souks is a great experience, I recommend you do not buy the first item that you like, because you will come across the same item further on. Try and ascertain what the lowest price the seller is willing to offer. This will give you an idea of the price next time you see that item. Always smile and be friendly when haggling and if the price doesn't suit you then be firm and say thank you and walk away, in most cases you will be followed or asked to come back, but tell them your finial price and walk away. You will find bargains and some great stuff, but more then anything enjoy the atmosphere of the busy souks. There are cafes dotted around the square with roof top terraces, which I would highly recommend to sit and have a drink or snack and take in the atmosphere of the square. I would also recommend a ride on the horse and cart but you will do well to agree a total price before you get on. We did a tour during an afternoon and also one during a night time.

Mayhem & madness!. The main square in Marrakech is much like any other city's focal point in that it's a great location to start your day or a great meeting point,as it is situated just across from the tallest building in Marrakech, the Katouibia mosque.Filled with market traders who ply their trade from sunrise to sunset, snake charmers, performing monkeys, horse rides and then street performers who come out at night, the square is rarely dormant.The best way to appreciate its vibrant nature is to find one of the many cafes with roof terraces around the square and sample a mint tea. Here you will avoid being plagued to buy hand carved wooden camels, have snakes draped around your neck or feel compelled to buy yet another 'Prada' bag and still be able to people watch to your heart's content.

Jemaa The Jewel of Marrakesh. This place is great! It is filled with souks, cafes, restaurants, shops and much more. You can get haggled a bit by the locals...but hey its part of the experience! If you fancy a cuppa, try the spiced Moroccan tea...it'll get your taste buds going!

Lively. What a place to visit. During the day it has great fresh juices (brilliant for the hot days), watch out for the snake charmers and monkeys. At night it's comes alive with grilled food and a buzzing atmosphere. There are a good few cafes and shops around the edges.Defiantly worth a visit or two.

Haggle til your heart is content 😍. Love watching the transition from day to night! The square cones to life from about 5pm and hoes on til late! Best place to be while watching the fun is the terrace portion of Cafe Argane! It was amazing! Their food is fabulous! Totally recommend their Tagines and Tanjia's!!!

Grapefruit, Orange and Lime Combo Juice is Fantastic - Avoid the Snake Charmers. We found a spot in a restaurant overlooking the square near sunset and watched sunset unfold with the constant sound of snake charmer flutes in the distance. The cost of the drinks was about 30 DAM, but it allowed us to remain at our perch as long as we wanted. Down in the square we found that the juice sellers were marvelous. A glass of orange juice was 4 DAM and a combo drink of grapefruit juice, orange juice and lime juice was 10 DAM and the best drink we had in all of Morocco. We went back for this combination several times. Very sweet. We took a turn venturing into one of the snake charmer activities and they swarm you, taking your camera, putting non-venomous snakes around your neck and then engulfing you with demands for 500 DAM, an extortionate amount of money. I initially gave them 50 DAM, then upped it to 150 DAM, before walking away with them screaming and hassling us. That was unpleasant.

Monkeys, snakes and mind-blowing musicians. Not to be missed in the evening.You have monkeys in diapers, snakes, messy street "restaurants" and people trying to sell you absolutely everything.And, in the evening, you have the most increadible musicians! My strongest impression of Marrakech: The sublime Jemaa El Fna musicians!

Overcrowded, tourist trap!. This is the heart of the Medina and as such, every visitor, tends to gravitate to it like we did. But once we found ourselves in the Jemaa, it didn't take us long to want to get away from it!!! The place was crowded, full of pushy hawkers trying to sell one a variety of kitsch; rows of open air eating joints and young, aggressive lads trying to hustle you to their restaurant... If you enjoy being constantly harassed by "helpful" locals trying to show you where to go with the ultimate aim of getting you to one of their shops in the souk, then this is your kind of place otherwise, I would take thew shortest route through the Jemaa so that you get a quick feel for the place without staying around long enough to realize that it isn't all that is touted to be.

The worlds most famous square!. Amazing during the day, but even more so at night with all the street vendors and food stalls. Be aware of the left side of the square, there is where you might end up with a snake around your neck and a monkey on your shoulder! many good restaurants, I like Chegronui the best around thin nave in Marrakech.

Every thing finded !. a lot of people and shoppes are there... very very noisy ! local people are not kind there and most of them are rude and want money even for taking photo ! try not to test the food !

Not to be Missed. This huge square is a hive of activity day and night and not to be missed. The atmosphere is quite electric particularly at night. There are musicians and performers. There are vendors of every type including snake, monkey and bird handlers and there is a bevy of open air food stalls offering quick sit down meals. There are also a great many restaurants surrounding the square.

A must see but be street wise. This is the usual market scene with rows of stalls selling juices, hot food etc. There are a lot of street performers too. However, it is more for tourists than authentic so as other reviewers state you need to be prepared for the very forceful entreaties to buy and look. Have a few friendly but firm lines prepared and keep walking at the street performers if you are not prepared to pay. We ate at street stalls and the food was ok. We had one instance where we did agree what we'd ordered and they still brought additional dishes (which we thought were part of what we'd ordered). It seemed like this vendor was doing this to other customers but they'd spotted it when the food arrived. We ended up paying much more than we expected.

Would be better without the harassment . Worth going to, very busy and lively. Nice to walk around especially in the evening.However, you will get harassed from all sides. Some will leave you alone if you clearly say no thanks, but one woman physically grabbed my hand and tried (and actually succeed) to put henna on me without consent. Don't take photos of the performers unless you want to pay them.

Overpriced tasteless food. I had some delicious food here three years ago and I went back a few days ago but it was a big disappointment! Everything is overpriced and not tasty at all. I am not fussy about food but it was a very big difference from what I ate three years ago. Also, be careful and ask for the total price before eating because some people will charge you extra for bread or olives, even if the rest are giving it for free with the meal. They will chase you and be very talkative and friendly until they get you to sit down and eat and after that they completely ignore you and are not friendly or polite anymore. It's a shame to find this place so changed comparing to what it was three years ago. Also be very careful when taking pictures of snakes, monkeys ir dancers because they will literally chase you to pay them.

Vendors overload. Nice place but too many semi-aggressive vendors are a big let down. Be vary careful for photos with monkeys and snakes etc. They trick you to take photo and then demand 200 dirham per person. If you refuse they can be very rude and aggressive. The best way to counter the aggression is firmness. I ended up paying 40 dirham for photo with snake and 100 dirham for the monkey photo for which I was not even keen. The whole attitude towards tourists is very negative and tourists are treated as cash cows with little or no respect. Very average food. Beware of pick pockets and too many beggars

You can't miss this square . The Jemaa al Fna is at the heart of marrakech. No trip to Marrakech is complete without a visit to this square. You will find everything from restaurants, to juice centres, to little shops, snake charmers, performing monkeys, horse drawn carriages to street performers. If you do visit, be sure to meander around the Souq after the square. You will find some excellent restaurants nestled between the shops. Haggling around the place is also an absolute must.

An assault on the senses. I have been in other similar places somewhat like this in North Africa, but this is a real assault on all your senses all at once with noise, smells & sights, especially at night with all the eating stalls, musicians but I preferred to eat in one of the many restaurants surrounding the square and look down on the spectical .

Maze. An outdoor circus and market all in one. Beware, everyone (old and young) is out to get some money off of you! Lots of beautiful home goods. Moroccans are great artisans. You need to bargain, bargain. Start with a quarter of what they ask for and go from there.

Crazy experience. During the day watch snake charmers, avoid the monkeys and marvel at the old me with piles of extracted teeth and the tools they used to extract them.An experience you can't miss but be prepared for more hassle than you get in other parts of the medina from people trying to get you to pose with a monkey or have dubious henna painted on you. (FYI don't have the henna done, much better to go the henna cafe, pay a little more, get real henna and support a good educational charity.)At night the food stalls are manic, you can try walking down the centre of the stalls to avoid the salesman trying to get you into their stalls or just go with it. The food we had was good and at £3.50 per person for starter, main and drink you can't go wrong.

I was overwhelmed and very underwhelmed. I crumbled under the onslaught from the snake charmers, monkey handlers, musicians etc. I stumbled into the square after a 7 hour car trip from Fes and wasn't prepared at all for the assault. After taking a picture the request for money started. I didn't give enough. Next person I gave the requested extra dirhams but again this STILL wasn't enough so up went the amount. The next vendor said there were 2 of us so it had to be double the amount. Seems that any amount I paid was not enough. I wandered to a group of people around some musicians and the hat went out for money but as I was just wandering by I said no. Well he rose up like a conductor and swished his arms and the music stopped and they all turned to stare at me. That was the end for me. I just wanted to go back to my inviting riad and get away from all the hassle. I don't think I am faint hearted as I have haggled with the best of them in Vietnam and Cambodia but I think I was tired and it was all very "in your face". The night vendors were all rushing in with their cooking stalls so all in all it was just chaotic and I guess I was just not in the right mood to take it all in. A pity as it was one of my highlights for my time in Morocco.

A bizarre but fascinating place to see. So much atmosphere and life all in one space!It's a bit sad/ confusing to see monkeys on chains, but the overall atmosphere of this square shouldn't be missed.Just prepare to be harassed a little by vendors!Best to go in the evening for full atmosphere, and amazing smelling local food stalls to choose from.

Times Square Hassles X 10. Substitute Time Square's Elmo for Fez wearing dancers and you have the picture. I guess if you want to see staged snake charming and be hassled for the equivalent of $20 for a picture, this is the place you want to go. Don't be deluded you can sneak a snap from long distance...they have spotters who will badger you until you give them something. I gave it 3 Stars out of fairness to those who can't resist diving the midst of this madness, My recommendation, find a terrace bar and look down. That's cheaper and smarter.

An Experience. The main reason to visit Marrakech was to visit this square. It was an experience wandering through all the stalls and the entertainment. Be very careful when taking any photos as the locals will be straight over to you looking for money, also if you have a phobia about snakes , watch out for them with the snake charmers.

An Experience. This must be a required visit if you go to Marrakesh. The noises, the smells, the colours, the music, the excitement - wow!! Yes you get hassled and all the sellers "know" you but unless you are particularly interested in their goods they are easily discouraged by just walking away. Good ATM facilities and some restaurants as well as the street food (which is pretty standard fare and unexceptional).

Tourist Trap. If you like touristy things then this is for you. We had a lady approaching us about henna and started it on my girlfriends arm saying she was showing us. Of course this turned into the whole thing and we didn't find out the price until after. Blew most of our entertainment budget for the day. Don't get me wrong it is beautiful, just make sure you set a price prior. Hard to haggle once the service is performed. Instead, go do a horse tour. Was well worth the price. 200 dr for one hour or 300 for two with a stop at the jardin marjolle.Would avoid this area next time in Marrakech.

Bright and colourful. It is a nice place to go for bargain hunting and shop for some local products.Make sure that you do not lose the way as it is pretty easy to get lost and google maps may get a bit confusing.Bargaining here is an art and the locals enjoy it if you do it well.Happy Shopping!

Vibrant center of Marrakech. This is the heart and soul of Marrakech, one of the most vibrant and interesting places I have been while traveling. We spent some time here every day/night of our time in Marrakech. During the day there are vendors selling juice and snakecharmers looking to scam tourist money (it works). Beware the vendors selling jewelry or henna tattoos as they will try to grab you and make you pay for a bracelet or some tattoo before you know it's on you. It's also so hot during the day (were there in late June) which means you will want to find shade at a nearby cafe or in the souks.During the evening, the square lights up. I recommend finding a restaurant/cafe on the square to sit in around sunset and watch the square transform from day to night. We went to Cafe Glacier which seems to have the best views (though not the best service). It's truly incredible. At night, an entire market of food vendors pops up, lots of smells everywhere. There are storytellers drawing huge crowds, we even saw boxers one night. It's very crowded but feels pretty safe - just be aware of your surroundings.
Marrakech. Assault of the senses. This place wakes you up and leads onto the most fascinating parts of a great city.

Best part of old Marrakech!. We went yesterday there (Friday evening). The area was full of people, old, young and very young, mostly Moroccans, but there were many tourists as well. It is an awesome Jemaa; Arabic for gathering. It is one of my best places I have ever been in the Middle East. Despite this may be a usual place for local Moroccans, it feels like a cultural festival that you don't want to miss.The best plan for a visit is to go in the evening and have dinner there.
An experience but beware..... Great to visit at night and drink a cup of spicy tea, but beware of pickpockets and look out for any young ladies in your company....

Later is better. My five cents are: in many touristy places we saw the street artists performances ~ some of them at the very professional and amazing level ~ acrobats, painters, comedians, actors, dancers, rappers, jogglers, etc. The Jemaa el Fna doesn't really match ~ even a middle ~ level of acting skills.
