Our score of 4 of 5 doesn't come from performance level, but from watching a local crowd. It is amazing, but the square is filled more with locals than with tourist. The later you come, the less tourist and more of locals you get. And since attraction is to watch authenticity of people reaction, the later is better.

Good to buy gifts and souvenirs! . Visited one afternoon during a family holiday in Marrakech. Very busy with locals and tourists. Be sure not to let go of your childs hand. Be sure not to take pictures of animals, monkeys/snakes as they will ask you for money, even for videoing or taking pictures of the human entertainment. I'm somebody who doesn't like shopping anyway, Jema El Fna is a market good for buying gifts to take back home, souvenirs and finding those Moroccon cultural bits. It's not an everyday shopping place for clothes, perfumes, household stuff, although you can get genuine designer fakes if you like that sort of thing. Prepare to be bothered a little by shop keepers/workers to come and have a look around, if you're going to buy I suggest you haggle to half price as they ask for double or sometimes even triple the actual price knowing you're a tourist or a foreigner. One outstanding good thing from the market is that you can book excursions from here at a lot cheaper price than what they will be asking at the hotel. We booked the Atlas Mountains tour via a team at the market (which includes transfers) for 200 dirams pp whereas our hotel was asking for 860 dirams pp! This included breakfast and lunch, a tour of the village, argon oil factory and the Atlas Mountains and waterfall.
CRAZY. Everyone must go to the souk, it was a great experience, must be strong and firm with the locals and not allow them to bully you into buying things!

Busy and bustling. A must visit in Marrakech, both during the day and at night because they don't compare. During the day the square is busy with snake charmers and monkeys, but at night it really comes alive. Pushy food vendors and local singing and dancing fill every corner, giving it a massive buzz and a very interesting place to visit.

Touristy, yes, sensual overload yes, typical Morocco probably not, just enjoy!. Yes you will get hassled to eat, watch, take photo's and it will all cost you, but not a lot! Best avoided in the evenings if you are easily stressed by noise, people, snakes and moneys everywhere - but worthwhile if you can take it. Orange juice from the stalls is great, didn't eat here so don't know what food stalls are like. We preferred to wander further from the square and explore the back streets and souks, but be wary of being told "don't go that way, it's closed, follow me" - it's not closed and just simply a local wanting to take you back to the square for money. One cheeky local tried to con me out of 100 Dirhams (about £7) on out first day for insisting he show me to our Riad (when I knew the way in any case). We bought a leather handbag and a silver bracelet from one shop, the price started at 1250 Dirhams and ended up at 500 (which was a good price.
Hustle Bustle but beware. Buzzing here at night, loads of food places, be wary of taking pics, they will hassle you for money. Extremely busy at night.

Extraordinary although very touristy. Of course one expects the tourist factor here, but it´s kind of overwhelming. The noise, the permanent "have a look", "have a seat for food" and so on made it for me a little bit stressful but still an experience one shouldn´t miss

Not good. Went to Marrakech in March and visited this central square. In the evening it was full of people. Lots of snake charmers, pet monkeys and acrobats. There was nothing new and the artists were too predatory, chasing you and asking for money

Nice place . Visited this place with friend, nice and busy at night, snake chamers, monkeys, dancers, people there would not let you go thou every corner you turn people asking you to come in and try their food well annoying to be honest.

A "must" when in marrakech. An overwhelming experience but a must see when in this city. Avoid eye contact if you don't want to be hassled. Beware that you will be asked for money if you take pictures of anyone who is dressed up or carrying animals, snake charmers, etc. We opted to eat at a cafe off of the square because we read that the food quality wasn't that great in the food stands. There are lots of cafes with terraces to watch the square from above.
This place is nuts.. . It's fun up to a point if you don't mind being hassled. This bloke got stroppy when I didn't give him 50Dir for taking his phot!

Energy of this place will make you smile. A packed square with many entertainments and cheap food.A must see in the trip and the food on the terrace cafes around the square are simply delicious.Managed to catch a sunset on one of the terrace while sipping mint tea.. Good life

You can't help it !. A big square with alleyways in and out of all sides.. It is a sight, both at day and night when the food sellers set shop.The orange juice is simply amazing as it is so fresh and not transported halfway around the world.The local cafes provide the best views and food.( please check previous reviews to avoid tourist traps, it helps to note down a few names before going there)Shopping :Be prepared to haggle upto 70% off ( yes ! Think Apprentice !!).don't buy everything in Day 1 or you are sure to regret finding the same thing at half the price on day2.Enjoy and soak in the atmosphere .

sensory overload. interesting place to experience but if you spend too much time and are not used to the constant din, it might get to you. thankfully we found one bar that served drinks overlooking the square and were able to decompress before trekking back to the riad.

More Disneyland than I care for.... ... except it ain't pasteurized. Looking for a touristy place? This is it! Definitely not my cup of tea. If you're looking for real people and real folklore, go somewhere else (probably not in Marrakesh though)

There are much better places in Marrakech . Full of noises from the many people trying to get money from you. The cheap fresh orange juice is really good tho.If you're going here I recommend you go to one of the roof top restaurants and have a look at it all from above. But really put your energy on the souks instead :)

Very very Busy!!. Our riad was very close to the square so we had to go through it every day to walk to attractions or the souks. It is an extremely busy square with food stalls, people trying to sell you fake watches, toys, pashminas etc and the henna ladies who grabbed me by the arm to show me their designs even though I politely said 'no merci' many times. There are also snake charmers which I hated as I have a phobia of snakes so my partner and I were trying to avoid. It is worth seeing though even once.
A must visit. You can’t go to Marrakesh without stopping in to see the madness! Get some orange juice, some nuts and sit and have a meal, you won’t regret it!
Active place to hang out. The best time to go is sunset especially on Saturday. There are a lot of food stalls and people trying to entire you to go these stands which are set up each day.
Must be seen.. A feast for the senses. Music, snake charmers, merchants selling their wares, food and spices. Very noisy if you are of a nervous disposition!

Experience Marrakesh of Old. The square is full of food vendors, shops, and entertainers. During the day it is almost calm and relaxing while the evening offers a barrage of your senses. It is a fun experience! Entertainers expect money if you watch for a while and/or take photos (1 or 2 DH). Vendors can be pushy and persistent so do not be afraid to give a firm "no" as you walk away. Don't be afraid to ask shop keepers for directions but beware of those offering to help you (especially children). I found it interesting to watch neighboring snake charmers try to out perform each other to attract a greater crowd/money.

Snakes alive. Different experiences by day and by night. By day its an empty square to be admired from the local roof top cafes whilst dining alfresco but at night it comes alive with street entertainers and local food stalls. Amazing sights and smells waft over you as you wander through the food alleyways passing stalls offering meats, fish, local delicacies, fresh fruit drinks and ices. Its a sight to behold then move onto the musical snake charmers that are enticing especially if you have some spare dinar to hand. The square at night is noisy, smelly and smoky again best enjoyed from dining at the various roof top terraced restaurants located directly onto the square.

An experience . This is a very busy area however it is a lovely place to visit to see what marraketch is really like. The restaurants there are lovely to sit in as you can view the whole square and shops. We was abit worried about coming out as 3 young women but it's not that scary, we did go as a group of us but you don't have to worry, if you tell the people no then they will leave you alone. You have street performers there and henna tattoos, it is a lovely place to go and visit even if your not into shopping. I would recommend going at least once in your holiday. If you go with a coach trip like we did they drop you off outside the mosque so if at any point you get lost just look for the mosque and it will lead you back. I know you might be thinking how will you see it but it is the highest point so just look up and follow it. We didn't really buy much just went to see what it was like but if you are interested in shopping there please make sure you don't get ripped off.. They will put the price high expecting you to haggle with them. If they don't budge on the price then just act like you aren't bothered and walk away, they will soon follow you and say that they will do it for a special price just for you and not to tell anyone. This is all part of the holiday aha

Experience Marrakech at its core. Jemaa al fnaa is the main square in Marrakech it holds hundreds of stalls and shops. You can lose yourself in the shopping, quite literally as it's really difficult to find certain boutiques. All the side streets and shops look the same yet still a nice place to shop. There is also various street acts which are worth observing, I won't reveal all the secrets of the square but you can spend hours here enjoying the food, entertainment and shopping! I found myself coming back to the square every evening though you must visit the square during the day also!

Not too keen on this..... Preferred the little side streets. This was too full of Orange Juice stalls, poor little monkeys and snakes. Not nice at all. Probably a LOT busier at night, luckily we went during the day so fairly quiet.
Great experience . Loved the experience of marrakech very mysterious and magical.Great for people watching and have traditional morrocan food.

Overrated- but still worth a visit. Everyone talked about the markets so I was really looking forwards to seeing them.I went with my friend we are 2 young females and we felt a little unsafe, large clusters of males who look at you with a not so welcoming expression wasn't really what I expected.There weren't many market stools on the square. Perhaps this is because we went out of season? But they were all food stalls with the owners shouting at the top of their lungs at us to try taste and buy their goodies. Not really very pleasant when you're just looking and exploring the area.Most of the stalls which sell tourist gifts and traditional Moroccan things are tucked away and the majority to my dismay sold fake knock off bags, clothes and trainers. The odd one sold lanterns, candles and leather bags. I know this all sounds negative- I don't want to put anyone off going- by all means go see it but don't expect anything amazing is all I'm saying!

Be prepared!. So interesting to be here in the late afternoon/evening and watch this space transform. All the food stalls are set up, with heavy competition for your money. We walked around to check out what they had on offer, but dined elsewhere. Not a fan of the poor monkeys or the half dead snakes the way they are treated by their owners who of course are only in it to make some money. We went to a terrace cafe on the corner overlooking the square to get a better view from above. Of course we had to buy an overpriced drink to gain access, but it was still worth it just to view the spectacle in front of you. You have to go here if visiting just to say you have experienced and survived!

Lots of action & great food. A place to experience. Lots of color, people watching and the smell of many different types of food being prepared. Go there hungry. Yes the vendors are aggressive,but that's their job. Just say no(I forget what it is in Arabic) a couple of times, and push on thru, if you give up early, you may miss something you wanted to try. Lots of great looking and tasting food. Find one you like and enjoy. Ask for the price before you commit to any meal. Check out Andrew Zimern, Bizarre foods, episode 1 to get a preview of the market. Something that you probably have never experienced. I will eat there next time I go to Marrakech.

Nice place - but not easy with children. We visited the market place a few times with our kids when staying in the Medina of Marrakesh. It is amazing to see all different artists and players but it is also difficult to keep the people a bit away from the children since we did not want to buy every little toy or so.

Vibrant,amazing,attention needed.. Quiet by day, but come the nightfall everyone is out particulair on a friday night. Muscians.snake charmers.monkeys. flashin lights, street sellers,horse and carriages.You will be pushed ,dodged,conjoled and engaged. A polite No and keep walking, when approached by food vendors a pat on your tummy says I've already eaten,next time will be the answer. It is a sight to be hold and when it becomes to much retreat to a restuarant with a upstairs to take in the whole sight you won't sorry.

Busiest square ever!. Very busy square where everyone hangs out. Lots of different stalls (food at night, fruit juices, spiced tea, spices, souvenirs) and entertainer. Do visit both during the day and night to see the difference.

something on the way. it's pretty much the center of downtown, it gets a bit intimidating with everyone being pushy. There is no shopping to happen there, all the well priced items are in the souk and away from the Jamaa.

A sight to behold. If you come to the medina it's not like you could ever miss this place but do stop and spend some time here. It's not as scary as it perhaps first looks. Take some tea, wander and watch. It's really is a world site of culture. Just sit and watch, story telling, food, hawkers, friend. This isn't really a tourist spot, or at least not mainly. This is the heart of the city where a million deals and events happen every day. You could spend a whole day and still not scratch the surface. At least at sun down you are rewarded by another epic site, and amazing food.

So chaotic but once you get used it is very nice. The first evening I went to jmaa, I did not want to come back because it was so crowed with people and people asking for money etcetc.Then I got used to it and just ignored the annoying people; that is when I could really enjoy it! Advice: - do not take random pictures of people acting or wearing funny clothes; often people ask money for that. - there are people who put a hat ontop of your head (without you even wanting it) and then ask money from you. If they come near you just say no and continue walking- best thing to do is not to make eye contact when you dont want to be bothered by someone- i was adviced by locals not to eat meat or snails at jmaa el fna be (only in restaurants just to be sure that it is well cooked)

Busy, interesting but be aware. As a tourist, Jemaa el Fna will be no doubt be your first port of call when visiting Marrakesh. Its interesting and busy but be aware of those friendly locals. Once they've engaged with you, it can be quite difficult to prize them away. Be polite to them as most of them will respect that. A quick "La shukraan" (no thank you) goes a long way. Bear in mind that once they do hook onto you, you will be parting with money.One further point to be made aware of is that if you start pointing your camera towards these locals/hawkers, will be asked for money. Gangs of sort do operate there and have eyes everywhere. I joke you not. They can spot a camera coming out at a 100 yds.I guess in some respects its little to pay when you consider that this is their sole source of income.

Main square in Marrakech. Average may be a bit harsh on the square which is well worth visiting. The reason for the down grade is the number of out and out con artists asking for money at any opportunity. Be warned if you take a photo in the square several "merchants" will approach you DEMANDING money, if you give them some they ask for more.

A little bit of everything, but can be overwhelming. If you are bold, brave, open-minded, love to negotiate and don't mind being hassled by beggars and shopkeepers - this is the place of you. It's an eclectic mix of shops, cafes, restaurants, souks, food carts, street performers and just about anything you'd want to find in Marrakech. However, the constant haggling and the pressure to buy things can be fatiguing. Don't look at anything unless you plan to make a purchase! But if you're in Marrakech you must visit the square. It's a unique experience. You'll find beautiful merchandise and the views from the rooftop cafes are amazing.

Busy, lively, eyes only. Fantastic vibe day and night. Good food, but pushy vendors. Before you get into the depths of the square, remember: No is an answer. So when they want to charge you for taking a photo, or put a snake around your neck and ask for a ridiculous fee: just say No. And walk away. Works.

Necessary experience in Marrakesh. Has to be seen if Marrakech.You are your most vulnerable at your visit.Perfectly safe but if you are not aware you will get charges for something you don't want.Certainly at first visit I would constantly just say "No Merci" and avoid getting into a conversation with any one in the square about anything.Any innocent initial interaction is rapidly manipulated by experts into a service or sale with purpose of releasing you of some money.Once you got things sussed out a little then you can be a little more adventurous if you really want to.There is no problem in going into the various cafes around the square,having a drink,relaxing and watching the world go by.

What an experience!. This is a really interesting place! There are snake charmers, monkeys, henna ladies, storytellers, singers, dancers, everything!! At first it can be quite intimidating but once you get used to it, and appreciate its craziness, it's actually a really cool and amazing experience. Something not to be missed while in Marrakech. We got conned into eating in one of the food stalls, was not good and was overpriced! Probably best to eat in other food places.

Infinitive stimuli for the senses. The Square itself is the playground of many old, yet touristic, performances. Many people are looking to get your money, but easy to get rid of them. Just enjoy the chaos and finish with a moroccan Tea from any of the balconies.

Be aware of the snakepit, that this area can be. Do not take a camera. If you do, always point upwards and take photos of the buildings and distance shots only. Do NOT take any photos of individuals, groups or entertainers unless you negotiate a fee first. Not even people nearby. Otherwise expect a very aggressive confrontation from more than one person. Keep walking through and watch, do not stop unless you want to pay for something.Show disinterest and do not look interested in any thing. Sun glasses help as they watch your eyes. You can then enjoy the place and take it in. A good tip is to use the nearby restaurants for a drink. 50p for a bottle of Coke. Normally I would happily give money but this is where tourists are pure prey and any mild interest causes an unwanted interaction which becomes very annoying and tiring. It takes a lot to make them go without getting angry. In reality there is nothing you can't buy from a shop elsewhere. If you are happy to splurge the cash then photos with snakes and singers etc are available. The more you pay the more they will help you take great photos.

Everytime a lot of different life. At the Jemaa el Fna you will find every time a lot of diffent life and a lot of Business. Of course you will find a lot of traditional african Culture, but also a lot of comerz. Be carefull.

A Must Do Experience, But Not For The Timid. The Souks are a must do. They are colorful, fragrant and are especially lively during the late afternoon/early evening hours when the performers come out. You can find some good finds if you are patient and willing to bargain hard. While I don't enjoy haggling, I enjoy walking away with a good find at a fair price. My traveling companion, kept instructing me to stop making eye contact with people and they would abandon their approach. It seemed to be working for her. But what do I say? I'm a connector, and the youngest in my family so don't like to be ignored. I offered a polite but firm no merci and it usually worked after the 3rd or 4th firm time with a raised voice and a smile. They are persistent people and this was their livelyhood so I sort of get it. It was suggested to me that we hire a male guide the first time going, but I was surprised at that suggestion based on my New York daily living. I personally did not find the guide necessary, but if you do not have a strong sense of direction, make sure you note some clear markers for yourself to exit. I would not have been comfortable going alone though. Be careful because people will grab your hand to put goods into it. The best and most surprising shopping experience I had was while I was soon to exit the square was with two young girls were hard at work. The older one, probably no older than 10 was selling little toys with lights that shoot into the air for a modest 20 dirhams. The younger one which I assumed was her sister approached me with a little package of tissue. I had no need for the very practical tissue, but my nephew would appreciate the other not so practical item I purchased. I did not have anymore 10 coins, and told her no merci, but reached in my bag and gave her what I had. A single dirham. My intent was to give her something so she too "made a sell" though I did not require the goods. She looked at the coin, looked me up and down, then returned it to me and walked away. I just stood there with my mouth hanging open. That story illustrates there are serious business people of all ages in Marrakech.

Not my cup of tea.... We stayed in a rihad pretty close to the "square" and we had heared this place is the place to be when you come to marrakech, so in our first night we went here. The place is crowded and filled with small eating areas and surrounded whith small shows of all kinds. The dishes is like tapas but in morrocan style, we ate some mix of different food and it tasted ok. Why a dont like the place at all is beacuse of you cant take one step witehout someone dragging your arm or dosent stop nagging which pissed me of. Not all can be for everyone :)
Great visual treat - even with kids.. Had a lovely 5 hours just strolling around the medina, eating, chatting to the locals and indulging in an ice cream.
Must go !!. We went several times to the plaza.Entertainment 24 hours a day.We loved the food vendors where we had the best shoarma ever.

Go at sunset and watch the place transform. During the day Jemaa el Fna is very similar to other squares in the Medina only larger. There are lots of fruit stalls and henna painters but nothing extraordinarily exciting. As the sun goes down the place completely transforms itself. The atmosphere changes and there's a real buzz. There are more exotic acts like transvestite dancers, monkeys and snake charmers. The restaurants pop up and there smell of food or incense is everywhere. The traders become a little more aggressive in their selling style but you're still very safe. I'd definitely recommend seeing it both day and night as even the contrast itself is quite interesting. It's as if you're visiting two different places,

Not that exciting!. We when arrive it seems amazing but half an hour later is a tiring affair...They do not live you alone! Huge competition and rip offs!
Better to eat in the restaurants on the terraces and enjoy the view!
Ubed. Good to look their traditional culture but prices are higher compared to the u.k . There is no toilet facilities

It's okay.... To be honest I thought it was mostly commercial full of henna tattooists (who I wouldn't trust as some of my friends got infections from henna), snake and monkey charmers, shops with touristy stuff and cafes that basically serve you rubbish drinks and charge you tourist prices.
I prefer the inner roads of the markets/souks in the medina!

Just go and enjoy! . It's really refreshing to see a place where people come at the end of the workday just to eat and have fun. It's a huge celebration that happens every night. The sights, sounds and smells are crazy. And it's a melting pot of cultures as people visit from all over the world. Tremendous fun! The tea at stall 69 is anazing! Just try it. You'll thank me.

This IS Marrakesh!. We were in Marrakesh for 5 nights and spent time here every night just enjoying all the activity. It is definitely more atmospheric at night! Story tellers, snake charmers, dancers, music! We ate at the food tents where the food was fresher than what is served in most restaurants. We spent time on the terraces of the surrounding restaurants taking tons of photos which was frustrating because it's impossible to capture the scope of it all! An amazing memory - a "WOW" place!

Graet Atmosphere. You have to experience this place at least once in your lifetime, it can be a little over-whelming at first but once you get used to the place it is amazing, the whole square is busy all the time with lots going on, especially in the evening when the whole square seems to come to life.You do need to be aware that you will get hassle of street vendors and everywhere you turn someone will try and sell you something. Also if you take a photo of the snake charmers or water sellers or any of the street entertainers you will be expected to pay them so make sure you take plenty of smaller notes and coins and don't let them see you have more cash.My friend got accosted by a lady doing henna tattoos and even though she said she didn't want one the woman grabbed her hand and did one anyway and then demanded money, she would not leave us alone until we had paid her....The roof top terraces are a must for watching the world go by either during the day or by night and the prices for food and drink vary quite a bit from place to place but on the whole very reasonable...If you want to get some cheap souvenirs the market stalls and souks are a great place to start and you can pick up some real bargains...The fresh juice stalls are a must and for 4 MAD you get a glass of freshly squeezed OJ and the bottles of water are really cheap too.All in all a great experience.
Interesting place to see. Nice and interesting stuff there, stay away from black magic . I didn't try street food because in wanna be on safe side . Just be aware of your bags.

Boring, Ugly, Dull, Worst City I've ever visited, this is a large square full of Morrocans in track suits and a few dead. Boring, Ugly, Dull, Terrible food, unfriendly people Worst City I've ever visited and Jemaa el Fna is supposed to be the highlight of the city, it is just a large square full of Moroccans in track suits and a few dead/drugged snakes a couple of men in dresses and the odd half dead Monkey, if you like oranges then your in luck because there is an abundance of fresh orange stalls but not a lot else, seriously though 'Tripadvisor' number 3 top ten cities!! I've been lucky enough to have visited most of the others in the list, all delightful, interesting, beautiful cities but Marrakesh is truly awful. The locals seem to hate tourists, I 've never been anywhere where the people are so miserable and unfriendly, the food is disgusting, not allowed in mosques, it really isn't 'westerner friendly' it really is the worst place I've ever visited.

Assault on the senses!. By day this ancient square is populated by snake charmers, henna artists, Berber, dried fruit & juice sellers and potentially any other host of weird & wonderful characters & experiences. By night the square literally transforms before your eyes into a large open air dining outlet with hundreds of stalls selling a range of traditional culinary fare. Be prepared for a cloud of thick smoke as charcoal grills ignite. In addition, craft sellers of all sorts litter the square perimeter, lanterns lit at the ready. We also witnessed story tellers, dancers, fire throwers, talisman crafters just to name a few! We even saw an enterprising gent charging people to stand on his weighing scales. I have been to the square numerous times and never experienced any difficulty, violence or as much as an unkind word. There is a great atmosphere and it is an intoxicating experience in a place overtly intoxicant free!

Very exciting place to watch life go by. Busy and every thing is happening around you form dancing to snake charming and trading. There are food stalls and all sorts of interesting things not seen in a modern European city where everything is sanitised and safe.

As different as night and day. We went during the day and it was underwhelming. The square was half empty. We were approached by snake charmers which made my skin crawl, adorable but abused monkeys, carriages drivers with horses that looked past lame and stank, fake watches sellers, ladies offering dubious-looking henna designs and kids that looked like they were the Artful Dodger's long lost family.At night, it was a different place. It came alive with traditional dancing, food stalls and just a general vibe that you have to experience at least once. Ladies dress modestly and you'll cut the hassle in half.Eat where the local eat (Hassan at stalls 31 and 32) and you'll get decent cheap food.And finally take picture from afar or you'll be hassled for tips. Enjoy.

Ordered vhaos. Just go there to experience a variety of humanity although geared up for tourists the locals participate too. Expect hassle but friendly. You not eating? But you are so skinny! Have a go at hook-a-fizzy-drink. The impending sugar tax in Britain would discourage such an activity! Pity about the monkeys on leads and snakes but that is Morocco! Enjoy!

Monkeys, Snake Charmers and Gucci Handbags!. This should be the first thing you do in Marrakech. Go, soak up the atmosphere and wonder round.People will wonder up to you offering you things from bracelets to pictures with a monkey on your shoulder. If you don't want something, be polite and firm and say no. Beautiful square!

Popular place to visit in Marrakech - collection of all traditional shops and open market. Me as el Fna. It is a popular place to visit . You will see all the tradition goods , dresses, hand crafted in shops and in open market, food , restaurants , cafes, fourtun teller, snakes dance all sort of activity . It is enjoyable place to visit. Every visitor to Marrakech will visit Jemma el Fan as it is a very big open area full of people and sales activity.

Great fun, from snake charmers to transvestite dancers. Go there late afternoon, maybe after a few hours of exploring the souks. Don't listen to those that tell you to watch from a rooftop - sure, you get a good view from a distance of everything that's going on, but it kind of defeats the point of being there to soak up the atmosphere and be there amongst the action. Just keep your hand on your money in case.

Bustle hustle bustle. Place Jemaâ El Fna is a square located in the Médina. It's an hectic area and not for the faint hearted. A horse and cart can be rented from the selection awaiting services. The square has the same items for sale throughout and has nothing different to offer. How many spices and orange stalls do you need in one place. There's many beggars and random sellers wondering around selling toot. Before 1pm you're liking to get run over by the cars passing through the square. Off the square through the many narrow streets was a dusty affair and there's always a bike, scooter, donkey or something or another trying to pass / run you over. It felt like a mixer of Thailand (china town) meets Egypt for me. I was with a personal guide and wasn't harassed much.

Be prepared for oriental live and beggars on the street.... ....but the atmosphere is always fascinating. Not everybody may like snail soup but it is a local specialty. Ornage juice and sweet candy offered in the streets are also worth trying and the souks of Marrakesh have something for everybody.

CAN BE INTIMIDATING. We went here during the day and it was very quiet as it was during Ramadan. We enjoyed walking through the souks and bartering for things. At night time it was completely different! At first we just enjoyed wandering round, looking at the different things going on, until a snake charmer demanded 300 dirhams for taking a picture. We gave him 100 dirhams and walked away but he followed us, shouting that we had not given enough money. Then a henna tattoo woman grabbed my daughter's hand and tried to give her a tattoo saying it was free. My daughter managed to pull her hand away and we walked off. Another guest at the Hotel we were staying at said the same thing had happened to her so she allowed the woman to give her a tattoo as she had said it would be free, then when it was done she charged her 300 dirhams for it.We were also constantly hassled by the food stallholders to eat at their stalls. This we took all in good fun as some of them were coming out with hilarious sayings, but this changed when we actually decided to sit at one of the stalls and eat. Because we didn't order the more expensive food that the stallholder wanted us to have, he suddenly became stroppy, even telling us we couldn't have what we wanted until we showed him it was actually on his menu. The food was nothing special either. After we paid and left we were walking across the square when a stallholder from a different stall ran after us, asking why we hadn't eaten at his stall. He got quite aggressive with us and started calling us names, loudly!! After this we had had enough and decided to go back to our Hotel, having decided not to make eye contact with anybody anymore. What had started off as an enjoyable evening, we felt had been ruined by the aggressive behaviour of some of the people. We knew there would be beggars, that if you show interest in something on a stall or shop you will be hassled to buy it, that you would have to pay if you took a photograph, but what we weren't prepared for was the aggression shown to us. Maybe it is because we were two women on our own. This was our first evening here and it left a sour note. Thank goodness for the friendly staff where we were staying and for the lovely people we met over the following few days but we made sure we didn't go back to the square again. On a future trip to Marrakech I most probably would go back there, but I definitely will not eat at one of the stalls.

Food Stalls. We really enjoyed eating at the stalls and would go more often with more time. The portions weren't huge but were tasty. What was on offer at some of the stalls was a variety of fish which is something we struggled to find in the restaurants.

Very different day to night. This main square which is opposite the Koutobia mosque is the main route to enter the many souks. By day the orange juice sellers operate 4dhm for orange juice in borrowed glass or 5Dhm for juice in plastic cup. There is a caleche taxi rank, many assorted sellers. Watch out for henna tatto ladies...'la shokran' or 'non merci ' works best. At night many performers, snake charmers,story tellers are around and many food stalls so the atmosphere is completely different. I personally found I felt completely safe day or night and which I don't do in London.

Not to my taste. The actual Square of the Medina was poor in my opinion. Dirty, largely open planned with very little in it except for street sellers. Monkeys on chains and snake charmers will try to impose upon you and want payment for any pictures you take. Also, beware the Henna ladies - I'd read about having caution regarding not knowing what ink they use - but other than this, I saw one lady grab a girls hand and draw Henna on it before she could refuse, then a group of them chased the young girl and her friend demanding payment. Not as forceful as I found Egypt, but still quite intimidating and imposing.

Be careful . Not just be careful about ur things coz the place is crowded some people jump on u on purpose and they fake its normal just to pick ur pocket,be careful if u r foreigner the prices for whatever u ask is 3 times more the real price

Must-see but watch your money!. big square which was once international trade crossroads, where merchants would come and be entertained by story-tellers, acrobats, etc. It is still very cosmopolitan, with tourists from all over the world mingling with throngs of locals at the food stalls (try snails!), Watch out for- snake charmers : they will immediately take your camera or phone and offer to take pic of you behind a big cobra but then demand money, and if you offer them 20 MDirham they will demand 200!!!! this is intimidating. Do not be intimidated !- the smiling women henna artists will grab your arm and start doing a design before you realise, then isist it is for 'good luck' as you protest that you don't want one. Again, if you offer 50 MDirhams (about £4) they will demand 200 and it feels very intimidating. This is how we lost a lot of our travel money on the first day!!!- don't take pics unbless you ask people first, many strict Moslems do not want their pics taken- don't try to take pics of performers surreptitiously, they have hawk-like eyes and can spot a phone fro 100 metres, and will invariably demand payment- do try eating with the locals at the bsuy food places on the square (but never drink the water and keep immodium handy)- sit on the terrace of one of the large cafes overlooking the square to enjoy the spectacle without the hassle- be security savvy: the armed police are there for a reason

A total madhouse, inmates friendly, fascinating, assault on the senses. Shop, eat sketchy street food, see a cobra smoke a cigarette.Hold a tame monkey (picture costs something). Watch people, stop for an impromptu concert, lose yourself in the madness.
Horrible experience but cheap souvenirs available!. We came across beggars and pickpockets. The place is not nice unless you like noisy haggling markets.

An unforgettable experience.. We enjoyed exploring all the narrow streets and shops in Jemaa el Fna as we had never seen anything like it before. It was a fascinating experience with all the price haggling that we did. We did have a guide with us which was essential as we would've got completely lost on our own. It was very tiring as you end up walking a lot.

love or hate is a fine line. You will either love or hate it here on one hand you have to spend your time watching your pockets, ignoring the animal cruelty and avoiding the pushy salesman but on the other watching the dancers, musicians and enjoying the night food markets make the square a must visit, if you are unsure go to a cafe with a balcony that surround the square and enjoy a coffee whilst enjoying a good people watch

post climbing stayover. The jema lies at the heart of Marrakesh and is the central point for exploring the whole of this majestic and historic city, as well as the heart of all the commerce and activities which are of interest to tourists. By day it is home to street artists - one tip, beware of the scam around the numerous snake charmers; everyone wants to see them but they get very fussy about payment and you will get some hassle for cash - certainly expect to (quite rightly) pay something for the privilege of taking photos but also watch out for men draping snakes around your neck as you watch the main show. These are harmless and their owners only want to get you to have your photo taken with a snake but it can come as a nasty surprise!By night the jemma turns into an open air series of restaurants. They are good places to eat but there are more established and comfortable eateries adjoining the square.

Four Friends Travel to Marrakesh - Riad Moullaoud. OMG, what a place... a colourful vibrant market places with snake charmers, monkeys, beggars, people selling teeth and leather and textiles. Lovely friendly locals. lovely food and amazing mint tea.

Has to be done. An assault on all your senses - people everywhere, music playing, the smells of incense, food, and horses;, jostling, grabbing, and so on. Make sure you avoid the grabbers as they either want to sell you something you can get cheaper elsewhere, or paint some henna on you.The square is mad enough in the day, but at night it is insane. Keep an eye on your bag/wallet, but keep your other eye on the sights. If you decide to eat at one of the stalls check the prices. We got an amazing meal at one, but it was the most expensive meal we had while in Marrakech, so its definitely a case of Caveat Emptor. Otherwise an amazing experience!

Very bussy, nice from a rooftop terrace. The square is very bussy and you should be careful of pickpockets. Its a must see and very nice atmoshpere at night. Dont go to the people with snakes and monkeys to take pics of/with them, its pure animal cruelty.
Must visit the square. Colour, atmosphere, tradition, noise, food, everything you thought was there is there. Get a drink/ lunch from one of the terraces overlooking the square.

Awful Place, Animal Cruelty, Aggresive western hating locals, Sexist disgusting vile men, thieves, stinking, unclean !. I was harassed, followed, intimidated, insulted, sworn at and threatened despite being covered up and polite. I found this place to be a sad hell hole and is the worst of human kind all in one place. Full of vile, western hating thugs. The vast majority of men here are racist, sexist scum. Most are jealous and suppressed individuals.They have no respect for tourists, westerners, women, animals or themselves. I saw hideous displays of animal cruelty and aggression towards non locals. I Had many people try and fail to take money from me, forcefully, through trickery or by forcefully begging or by trying to sell me cheap rubbish and getting aggressive by me standing my ground and saying no. DON'T LET THESE IDIOTS INTIMIDATE YOU INTO GIVING THEM MONEY, At least they ended up far more frustrated by me! Not sure why tourists ignorantly continue to support this vile place. Had I have known about the hatred and cruelty in this place I would have never visited, nor will I EVER return. If you believe in peace and equality, if you believe in treating others with respect and kindness. If you believe that no sentient being deserves to be abused. If you believe in human rights, animal rights and equal rights for all regardless of race, sex or sexual preference THEN DO NOT VISIT THIS HORRID PLACE AS YOU ARE SUPPORTING IT'S VERY EXSISTENCE.I simply cannot understand the positive reviews about this place. Perhaps the people were nicer to them as they allowed themselves to be continuously parted with their money, but even so there is no way you would miss the abused horses, donkeys, snakes, chained moneys, caged birds, ducks screaming whilst being carried upside down by their legs. The stink of sewage, the unclean environment and the dangerous roads? If people find this acceptable I'm ashamed to be human!
Must see, especially after sunset. Must see!Something..really exotic, something else..traditional..vibrant atmosphere..Monkeys, snakes, urban musicians and food ;)

Fantastic square for eating and shopping. The square is a great central location of the Medina, with the Souk (Markets) leading from the square. It is the perfect place for shopping, and is surrounded by some great restaurants, most with rooftop terraces so you can enjoy the beautiful sunset while eating a traditional Moroccan dish, Tagine! I only gave the square an average score as some of the 'attractions' on the square can be perceived as wrong. be warned to travelers who are new to Morocco. The square is filled with groups of Snake charmers - yes real snakes! and men walking around with Monkeys, which can be a little hard to witness for some travelers. Ladies - You will also try and be forced into having henna tattoos done! If you are not interested, whatever you do do not take their book of ideas from them that they will offer you ... before you know it they will have already started doing their 'artwork', which is not fantastic, but they need to earn their living! If you are in Marrakesh this is a must place to visit just to experience the hustle and bustle!

Busy, riotous, noisy, fun, interesting.. This is the place to be in Marrakech, you would probably find it hard to avoid anyway, as all roads in town lead there. During day time it is dominated by the orange juice sellers, with henna painters, musicians, monkeys and a few snake charmers dotted about. When the sun goes down the music goes up several levels, with ad hoc bands setting up all over the square attracting various kinds of dancers and acrobats. The food stalls really get going at night too and many were really busy selling all sorts of familiar and less familiar foods, including sheep's heads and eyes for the unsqueamish. There seems to be a lot more seafood available from the stalls than we saw in the restaurants. It can be a bit overwhelming and you would be well advised to observe the demure dress code, especially the women, as it can get 'raucous'.
To experience the true spirit of Morocco. We had a quick and authentic lunch in the little food shops enjoying a delectable atmosphere and feeling the true spirit of Morocco.

Bustling hub of activity. A feast for your senses! So much going on at all hours. Lovely juices. Dried fruits. Bbq stalls. Found the bars overlooking over priced and crowded but probably worth going once..
Well you have to don't you. The essence of Marrakech. How can you not love it?? Just remember to watch Alfred Hitchcock's 'The Man Who Knew Too Much'

Wonderful sight. To experience the madness and wonderment of Marrakech, the square is a must in the day but especially at night, when the sun sets all manner of local entertainment is on display but if you take a photograph of any of the entertainers it is necessary to give them a few dirums but well worth it.

Amazing!. We were on a Gate 1 tour and for our first night in Marrakech we all took horse drawn carriages though the Jemaa el Fna square which was amazing. It was a Tuesday night and there were thousands of people in the square and we got to see it from our carriages. Snake charmers, food vendors, everything is here. After our carriage ride we were dropped off at Lotus Privilege for a wonderful dinner and entertainment. The group loved the evening.

It's a must. You can't visit Marrakech without visiting this square. It's very chaotic in the evenings, noisy and full of people. A full bowl vegetable soup costs less than an euro. At the daytime it feels safe and also interesting. But still the souk is much more interesting place.

great to experience the true atmosphere. You have to go to the square to experience the culture and atmosphere just watch though that yyoyu do not get roped into getting picture taken with snake charmers, dancers, monkeys etc as you will have to pay for the privilege

Magnetizing atmosphere...yet... a raw feel (maybe due to the pale Jan. light )about the place imparts an uneasy feeling initially.Coming down from a romantic horse carriage drive, marred by the strong smells of the "pampers" of the horses), was warned not to show handphones in this very public place.Amidst fruit vendors and others selling voodo paraphernalia of driedamphibians and incense, drums and local music groups were setting up. Followed by the infamous groups with their piles of dull but poisonous snakes (apparently some have their fangs removed but why tempt trouble?).At all times, people stream from all directions, quite an experience..Like a huge open party.
Lots of people. This is a place with a lot of people and a lot of noise, drums and flutes. Snakes, monkeys and dancers. A very busy place but also very exotic.If possible , eat at the night market.

Intense. You kinda have to go. It's full of tourists and touts, and you'll continually get harassed by horse carriage drivers, snake charmers, monkey wranglers (?), henna women, guys selling fake watches/phones/probably Chinese-made art and children selling tissues (don't feel too bad, probably a scam) if you're at street level, but it's an amazing place to watch. Preferably from the balcony of a cafe. Arrive late afternoon, get a pot of mint tea, watch the square come alive for the evening, and then venture down to eat at a stall. We found ourselves spending several afternoons/evenings this way. Sunset over the square is great.If you're getting harassed then simply smile, shake your head, and continue walking - do not engage beyond saying "no". If you're firm then it's not a problem, just an annoyance.

Vibrant must visit heart of Marrakech. The energy and atmosphere change depending on the time of day, but whatever time you visit it's always an extra sensory experience. Colors, sounds and smells are incredible. Best time to visit is at sunset as the light changes spectacularly across the square and the crowds and energy increase in size and vibrancy. The snake charmers are amazing to watch not least for the Cobras themselves, but also how defensive and sometimes aggressive the charmers (not particularly charming to tourists) are to those taking pictures or getting too close without paying up for for the privilege.

Overwhelming. Listen, we hit the square on our last day of an 11 day tour of Morocco. We were out of gas and worn out. I think if we had started in Marrakech and seen the square in our first few days in the country we would have had the energy for this bustling square.

The true heart and soul of an amazing magic place. First the facts. This central square means Assembly of the dead. But there is nothing dead about this at all. This is one of those most do bucket list places like the Great Wall of China, the Grand Canyon, Mount Kilimanjaro etc. When you go you will see snake charmers, acrobats, water sellers, amazing food stalls, fortune tellers, caleches and tooth pullers. That is just for starters. We were there both during the day and at night. Felt very safe. Absolutely recommend.

Hmm.... I avoided it in the daytime as I hate snakes. Walked through it at night but too much hassle to eat at various stalls, so ate in Café France, on open terrace overlooking square. Food not very good, doesn't serve wine as we'd been told. Lots of touts for other restaurants, stalls etc. Not for me.

a visual feast. a vast array of stalls and entertainment. snake charmers, berbers and whirly derviches combined with stalls of spices, fruits and food stalls selling sheeps brains and eyes to lamb tagines. seeing is believing
Unique experience. The foodie paradise, lots and lots of foods stalls. Make sure to visit the square both day and night.

Feast For The Senses. The 'big square' is a feast for the senses! There is so much to do, look at, taste touch and smell! There are also many cafes and restaurants situated on the sides. Of course there are many people trying to get your attention and sell you pointless things but hey - it's Morocco! Make sure you can haggle and be firm when necessary.At night if your dining in one of the restaurants with a balcony the view is superb. You can see the musicians, snake charmers, henna ladies, monkey men and various other 'entertainers' weaving through the throngs of people. I loved the hustle and bustle.

Amazing Experience. Jamaa el Fna is very busy, yet amazing place to learn the Moroccan culture, shop and enjoy your time. There are some nice restaurants there with lovely views and other local ones. If interested in shopping, I would recommend to go there with a local person, otherwise you will be charged a lot of money! I really enjoyed my experience in Jamaa el Fna, which I visit many many times during my stay in Morocco :)

Love this place. This place is fabulous. As long as you can withstand the constant bombardment of people trying to sell their wears. Great at night a sensory overload. So maybe not everyone's. But it is mine.

Great fun. Visited Jemma el Fna morning, afternoon and early evening. Loved every minute. Looking forward to returning to experience late evening events. Visited with my pal and as two females travelling together we felt completely safe and fully enjoyed the experience of haggling for what we wished to purchase - it's all part of the experience and, if done with a smile, is thoroughly enjoyable.
Main Square of Marrakech. The main square or Jamaa el Fna; is a living stage, performing for tourist everything that may lead to a deal.

Hagglers place of heaven. If you love haggling then this place is right up your alley. The square can get very busy with many people and stalls during the day but it's all part of the moroccan experince. You will get many stall holders trying to get your attention by continuasly calling you, but my best advice is just firmly but politely say no once and when they continue badgering you just completely ignore them and carry on. I personally feel it's pointless repeating to them again and again when they just take no notice of you when you say no. Also ladies beware for women who grab your hand to apply potentially harmful henna on you and then ask for an extremely high price afterwards. Do not let them as you have no idea what chemials they have added to the henna. If you really want to apply henna go to a reliable place like a hammam or cafe.

Madness spoilt by locals.. A place all must experience, really comes to life at night, 3 stars as its spoilt by rude locals looking for any chance to empty your pockets. Henna lady's are to be avoided at all costs demand 500 dirhams or 50 euros, go into the souks and find a more pleasant person for henna at 20 dirhams. Mokeys and Cobras are interesting to see and the atmosphere is buzzing, must be seen by everyone but probably wont go back.
Wow be prepared for the unexpected. Fantastic experience a must try for the pop up food stalls at night ! Sheeps head, boiled snails to name a few, cheap and an exciting experience don't be put off!

The real centre of Marrakech. Huge square full of markets and stalls selling freshly made orange juice for 4 Dirhams a time. Snake charmers, monkeys on people's backs, etc. This is the real Marrakech. You get hassled by people wanting to polish your shoes and sell you anything and everything literally under the sun.We also saw the horses and traps and initially walked past them. But when we wanted to go to the new town and were quoted 100 Dirhams, we took up the offer. We had a fairly good ride into town for what was clearly less than we would have paid by motor taxi. So, it was good value. But, if you want an alcoholic drink, you must search long and hard. See my review of Le Salama.

Busy at night. This is a review of the square only. The souks disappear off from the square and are the bits you will get lost in. You will find it difficult to get lost in an open space! The square is a place to sit and have a drink, preferably from one of the cafes that have a balcony (of course you pay for the privilege for this) There are the usual people trying to sell you stuff you dont want. The fellas with the colorful garb are selling water. Be warned if you try and take their photo they will insist on being paid! At night the area becomes extremely busy with groups of people all over the place, musicians, medics, hand readers, tatooists, monkey handlers, snake charmers. I am not too sure what the deal is with the night food stands. They were not there every night so if you are going there to eat you may need to find out first.

can't miss it but won't miss it. obviously this is THE must see in Marrakech. it is really awesome during the night, all the lights, the sounds, the smell. but that's pretty much all there is. everyone is trying to rip you off, people are kind of forcing themselves onto you (do NOT get a henna tattoo from the ladies who basically try to paint your hands while you pass by). as a foreigner who doesnt speak the language, you cannot enjoy the story tellers, the display of snakes and monkeys is a disgrace (sad that animal abuse is legal), and despite hearing the food is delicious, we opted for the better safe than sorry option.there is a certain kind of beauty to it, we felt safe all the time but I guess that kind of chaos is just not really our thing. definitely come here to experience it, but let's be honest we see no reason to come back here after seeing it once

Dissapointing, lacking authenticity. Visited at night. Ate at the food stalls (stall looked busy, but food rather bland). Lots of hassle/rudeness from young guys pushing you to eat at their stands. Lots of people hanging about square selling cheap tourist rubbish and not a lot else going on....
Nice but very crowded. The square is a nice and lively place. Mainly also during the evening with the lights.But every 'attraction' will ask you for money. This can be after a while, very disturbing.

A pretty intense visit. But it must be done. IT IS A LABYRINTH. I know now that when travel agencies describe this place as a exciting visit to get lost in, YOU REALLY DO. You walk around taking in all the stalls, the sights, the smells and you fight off people left right and centre to "show you" something. I found it hard to relax and enjoy myself because of the constant hassling. When you find your way out of the ever winding street and find a court yard you have to TAKE A SECOND TO BREATH before you go in again. Make no mistake, that market is a Labyrinth! Everything looks the same. Every turn. The signs mislead you. And god help you if you appear to be lost because some "helpful" person will come to your aid to "show you the way out" but not before taking you to their stall/home to visit their family. SiiiiiiiiiiiiiighThankfully it isn't claustrophobic in there. Although it is relentless. I refused everyone except this nice man that sat calmly in his stall and didn't hassle me at all. I was happy to buy from him. Even after experiencing threatening snake charmers, grabby henna artists oh and lets not forget the begging children that come out of nowhere. After it all I'd visit again. But at least this time I'll be prepared.
Toooo messy. Great to see but just too much to deal with all people selling something and trying to grab some of your money in any possible manner. It also gets extremely crowded and noisy

Can I give this zero reviews?. The Medina, with its winding roads and picturesque crumbling buildings would have been a dream come true for a photographer as myself. But as a woman, getting screamed obscene sexual profanities the entire time I was outside was completely out of control. Mean while, I was completely covered up and wore no make up. If you're a female and traveling with other female friends, avoid this city above all costs. The amount of anxiety and fear from the local men is ridiculous. The city really needs to do something about this behavior or no one is going to want to visit this historical city. It was a complete disappointment, and I was absolutely terrified. I have been to over 20 countries and never in my life have I ever felt so incredibly scared to walk outside. I have been chased, screamed at, and well I also ate a snail, but c'est la vie no?

An attack on the senses. Large square full of stalls selling all sorts of things leading to the shouks. Cafes all around with terace views. Wonderfulsmella at night with the food stalls. Prepare to be hadsled by everyone and dont stand still too long or a man with a hat will want money off you. Got to go at night once to experience the patter

It is a must visit, but there's a but.. If in Marrakech, it'd be a crime to miss this place. But you must know what you're in for, the hustle and bustle of the place is quite special but if you're a tourist, you're basically a target for a ripping off and it gets annoying when all you want to do is take the place in. Be prepared to have your wits about you and be harassed at every glance you make.

Circus comes to town. All you could want,Carriage rides,snake charmers,Monkeys,Camels Pungent spices.street hasslers.A welcome sight after the scary claustrophobic maze of the Medina, souk bazzar.All of that and more.Don't get lost!!!.
See my review of restaurant Dar Essalam for more info.
Must see. Can't miss! Check out during the day and in the evening to participate in the broad spectrum of people the environment here.
Completely. Totally. Amazing.. This 100 character limit is ridiculous, as is Jemaa el Fna though in completely different respects. Just go and get lost in there.
Jamee lefna. Jemaa lefna is the main square in marrakech which is considered as one of the most attractive corners in the city center

Only 1 day is needed . You will only need a day to wander around Jemaa el Fna. Majority of the stalls and markets are the same, the entertainment in the square is simply 3 snake charmers, monkeys kept on chains and ladies offering henna tattoos (which would prove difficult to maintain wet hands whilst shopping).Quality of mint tea is not the best, many people were quite rude and it is an area with unashamedly opportunistic mentality towards visitors.

Monkeys, snakes and other animals!. Was warned that this would be a stressful experience with people being too ' full on'. Not at all. People trying to all you 'stuff' perfectly happy when you say no.
Holiday. Again another great attraction for experiencing the atmosphere of Morocco beware of the guys with the monkeys as they are after money even if you just want to take a photograph !!

Main place to visit!. Has great and interesting stalls, the atmosphere is lively especially at night time a lot of food stalls and fresh juice stalls, snake charmers, music players, monkeys which you can hold would recommend this for kids as the monkeys are trained and friendly!

Bonkers!. It's a real feast for the eyes in the square. You simply don't know where to look, there is so much going on. Beware of the snake charmers. If you take photos of them they will pursue you! Have a fresh orange juice and watch the chaos unfold as the sun goes down. Amazing, stunning, a must see!

Complete sensory experience!. We were there on the night and my god the vendors really do harass you if you're a woman. I'm talking racial epithets, unpleasant references to being women, references to being English. That meant we cut our visit short but it wasn't all bad - the smells of the food and the sights and items were great, I just wish we could have had less harassment.

Essence of uniqueness.... ....but it doesn´t mean you you shouldnt keep eyes on your belongings. Jemaa is real gem with all its imperfaction with dirty corners, rough sides, sparklink and polished places.

Moroccan mayhem. Great place to mix and mingle with cross-section of Moroccan society. Some of the cafes overlooking the square are a good place at dusk to take photos of the action below and get the sunset. From early evening the square has a large number of booths selling a range of traditional dishes. The north side of the square has several entrances to the souq and a good place to wander and to happily get lost.
Buzzing with life.. Go at least once at night to see it all so differently; yes it is crowded with locals as well as tourists but it has a special atmosphere.

You go once and you have seen it all!. On the square the food is all the same, overpriced and not good, very poor quality and quantity. Snake charmers and monkey trainers spend whole days there waiting for tourists to take photos and charge you for it!
Atmosphere was electric . Great place which kept the kids entertained for hours. They got henna tattoos, had a photo with a monkey and a snake and we had a great meal from the food stalls!

Good atmosphere . Good place to visit, very colourful and authentic. Beware of taking photos of the snake charmers as they expect money for this. Also the henna may cause allergies in sensitive individuals.

Square of happenings. There's always something happening in Jemaa el Fna whether it be snake charmers, traditional dancers or boxing matches. Walking through the food stalls on a saturday night is an absolute must - if you have a sense of humour and enjoy passing by the stalls that almost suck you inside. It's a battle to walk through on saturday evenings but it is well worth a go. Easy to find and a good meeting point for locals and tourists alike.
Shopping. This place is very busy and not to miss and it is very big shopping areas which would haggle the price and sell everything there. Their were food stalls aswell

Dont get in to it. Interesting place, lots to see. Beware of making pictures, they will come to ask money for it and than they are not nice. Beware of the monkeys, we saw they biting and getting your rabies shot is not fun over here. On the square u got good food but dont get overloaded by putting food on the table. Accept what you order and know the prices. Dont get into with the people, be clear and say no and walk away. They very purchased. If u stand still to look at something, dance snakes or what ever, its not for free. So if u find out the rules on the square relax and have fun. Rooftops are expensive but nice views!

Go at night . Definitely worthy of the unesco listing. During the day it's a bit of a heat Island, but it really comes alive after the sun sets. Snake charmers, story tellers, dancing acrobatics, Arabian transvestites with full veil (must be the easiest drag gig in the world) and loads of food stalls.Food hygiene was fine for us, though I have heard it is not always the case. The normal rules of eating in developing countries should be applied. Try the Moroccan snails stalls for something completely different to your normal fare.
Must see!. You must visit this square while you are in Marrakech. It is extremely busy, exciting, and the heart of the city. There is street food, restaurants, music, and a lot of shopping.

Vibrant, noisy and colourful place to feel life moving. Not for faint hearted, this square is full of traditional folklore, food stalls, crafts and people from all corers of Morocco as well as other countries. Everyday life begins all over again here. A very enjoyable place day and night where you feel the heart of Marrakesh.
Wow. Prepare to be awed and amazed from the dentist to the animal handlers, snake charmers and countless food and souvenier stalls

Shame about some unscrupulous traders. We stayed in Marrakech for 4 nights and visited Jemaa el Fna on several occasions. During the day it is time for the snake charmers to do their stuff and also for the men with the monkeys (as I don't agree with the way the animals are treated we refused photos with any of these).There are plenty of traders selling orange juice for 4 dirhams but the one we bought front number 45 tried to rip us off so be careful as they will try it on and try and get extra money from you.In the evening is when the street food stalls set up we tried the food one evening and weren't disappointed. They will put bread and olives on the table as soon as you sit down and do charge for this but it's best to just go with the flow.We used a couple of cafes that are dotted around the edge of the square just to do some people watching and take in some refreshments.

Disappointing. We went to Marrakech because we saw Jamie Oliver's program of him cooking at the Median al Fna and we couldn't wait to go and try it ourselves. But the Stall No.1 where he went, was full of people, and guaranteed good by Trip Advisor, but the food was pretty average and not so great. Bit of a let down.
Impressive - lot of life in one busy spot. Many things happening, and certainly worthwhile visiting! Try the orange juice - delicious. The food didn't attract us but many people were eating.

Magical. This is the most amazing, crazy place in Marrakech. I love this square it gives me everything I go to Morocco for. I respect the Moroccans so much for retaining their heritage and there is nowhere that is more evident than Marrakech, how ancient customs survive among 21st century luxury is bewildering.This comes alive at night to the sounds and smells of Morocco. Please take at least an hour after sunset to walk around then another hour to sit sipping mint tea in a cafe overlooking the square.

Busy, Busy, Busy.. Situated in the Mdina, the square is a large area given over to locals selling anything from holiday trinkets to raising money by snake charming to acrobatics. At night there are certain differences with people being attracted to the restaurants around the edges and fast food places within its near centre. It is a great place to just walk and enjoy the carnival atmosphere but stop for a meal and drink in the process. You can spend a little money which the businesses want you to do and have a great time.

Keep your hands in your pockets, and keep moving.. I made the mistake of showing an interest in the snake charmer and as I was taking a picture some horrible woman grabbed my hand and started hennaing it, no matter how hard I tried to pull away she held tighter and pulled me in the opposite direction to where I was walking, then wouldn't let go of my bag until I paid her. As soon as I glanced at the monkeys a man was pushing me into a seat and putting the monkey on my head. Awful awful experience, couldn't wait to try and get out of the maze of the souks to find my hotel. If you are planning on it, go with people and do not show any interest as far as possible.

Amazing - must do!!!. Hectic, vibrant, manic, but so amazing where else could you experience so much - great street food, snake charmers, Berber dancing, and constant haggle ring from the vendors but all part of the fun!!!!

Magical. Like stepping into another world. Sublime! Love the craziness of it all. Snake charmers, drums, incense, food bars, souks....so much to take in. I did not like the men with the monkeys and saw a lot of the monkeys flinching which can only mean one thing :(We loved watching the sunset drinking our coffee at the famous Cafe De France...a must!

tourists, but non only. the Jemmaa el Fna is the central square and the heart of all the Marrakesh hazzle. You may get fed up after 10 minutes or stay for hours, depending on your mood. But definitely there is plenty to see and experience. If you do not feel like beinig part of the mess, join the tourists on the rooftop places and wonder from there.

Tourist trap. Off course you need to see this huge square with it's snake charmers, trained monkeys and locals dressed up in ancient costumes - all in honour of photo-eager tourists with cameras and enough Dirams to spend.
Amazing!. Wow! Amazing place! Even had my photo taken with a snake! Felt completely safe and loved listening to the music on a night!
Nosiy. We had to pass through the Square a few times. It's noisy , many things going on . You can sit and watch every thing in the cafes around it. IT is the heart of old Marakech.

Wonderful colourful chaos . This place is incredible. There's so much going on and you fist have to accept very quickly that this is going to be a very different experience to enjoy it fully. There are aspects of it that felt a little uncomfortable; yes you are approached many times be people trying to sell you something and their attitude can be a little full on - you just have to be firm but friendly and they will get the message. They're just trying to make a living. The Barbary apes on chains to us seemed quite cruel but as I say, it's a different culture. The range of food is vast, we had some really tasty fish and we are going back tonight for snails!We've been drawn back to Jemaa el Fna pretty much every day of our stay in Marrakech. It's a fantastic place to visit and feel like you are part of Marrakech, not just observing it. .

Like visiting another world!. This is really is an incredible city with over a million people ( and mopeds!) crammed into a fairly small area, so everything is fast moving. Don't tr driving in the city, you'd need eyes in the back and side of your head, as there's so much traffic, The square itself is filled with stalls selling spices, leather goods, rugs, carpets, herbal drink mixtures and snacks, huge selections of the most fabulously tasting nuts, as well as men with monkeys, cobras , and rattlesnakes! Absolutely fascinating!

Evening visit to the main square in Marrakech. This square at the heart of Marrakech is worth visiting by day but more especially by night. It is a lively, bustling place full of colour. There are numerous street entertainers, snake charmers and food stalls all jostling for attention. It is an ideal place to while away some time on the way to dinner or on the way back.

Be extremely wary of this place. We visited here on our first day of our holiday and never went back. Full of locals trying to fleece you out of money and we were never left alone to enjoy the area as we would have liked. We also felt very unsafe. Avoid unless you an an experience ms guide.
Busy market. A busy market place, not worthy of the attraction hype in my opinion but worth a look. People watching is the best thing about it

Must see. This square is an essential part of the old city. The orange juice from the stalls is probably the best i've had in my life. Beware of the guys with monkeys and snakes, they will just plop the things on you demanding money.

A "must visit" for Marrakech, but not all that great. This is one of those places that everyone says you have to visit, and it is certainly main site in Marrakech. However, it is all tourism, all the time. If you want to ride around in a horse drawn carriage there are scads of them, same with snake charmers, drummers, people in ethnic dress, etc. Anything to get you to stop, take a picture, and tip them. Certainly not worth a separate visit.

crazy but you just have to see it. daytime is a good intro to the place, snake charmers and monkey handlers will try and rip you off. I paid 150 mad for a picture of me with a snake but it's not something you do every day. night time the madness increases, but it's safe and great fun. there are restaurants to people watch and plenty of taxis and horse carriages to take you back to hotel. lots of bustle but you really need to see it

Surreal, Mad, Wits Required!!!. Having visited Marrakech many times, I always do end up at this square once or twice. It is very different during the day, compared to the night. You should try to see the square at both times. Calmer and more peaceful during the day, where one can comfortably avoid a lot of the hassle, and enjoy a glass of juice or a bite to eat. Come sunset, the place is transformed and the constant drumming from various drummers and other musicians plays well into the night. So many different things to see, from story-tellers, to snake charmers, to many many places to eat. This place can be frustrating as well, with people hassling you constantly, to buy this or that or eat here and there. There are also numerous people begging, especially little children, so it can be hard to bear sometimes. Of course, if one wants to give charity, they can do so. I found that the best is sometimes to give food or drink. A bottle of Pepsi seems to be something the kids really want!In terms of food in the square during the night time, prices are reasonable, and food is of a decent quality (depending on what you get). Plenty of choice, from tagines to kebabs, to snails etc. We only ate there once and found it OK. However, one guy in particular seemed to take offence that we did not eat at his stall, and ate at someone else's stall. He did behave very strangely - he seemed to think we had promised him we would eat at his stall, when we clearly hadn't. All the stalls pretty much sell the same food at the same prices. I would suggest eating here once, just to feel the atmosphere etc, but after that it is better to eat elsewhere - there are plenty of good restaurants/take-aways near by for a fraction of the price. Take a walk down from the Bab Agnaou - lots of nice places to eat for a few £s! There is also a nice cafe here called Cafe Glace which has brilliant views of the square from high up. Have a cup of mint tea whilst watching the scene down below...A word of warning in the square - it seems everyone here is to try make as much money of you as possible, from crazy prices to asking for money for showing you the way somewhere! Be wary of anyone who wants to show you something, or when you ask for directions, they want to physically show you where you need to go - they will ask you for money showing you the way! Even looking at someone or something (e.g. looking at the snake charmers), they will want money from you. Taking pictures of such things - you will be asked for money too!The Jemma El Fna square can be a fun place to be, but have your wits about you at all times to make sure you have a great time. And try not to take some people too seriously - it'll help you keep sane!

Very Touristy. While most of the hub bub about Jemmaa El Fna is justified, it is a great place to see, smell and taste lots of new and exciting things. Be careful with the merchants. Always get your pricing up front before any service are rendered. Some of them are tricky and will try to gouge you for extreme amounts of money afterward. Be especially mindful of the henna artists that will take your arm and start drawing without any previous discussion. Other than that is was a good experience and shouldn't be missed.
Jaw dropping. Always something going on, where ever you look you will see something different. From Day to Night it explodes with life and smells. watch out for the snake charmers at night..

Food Stall 26. These guys are really bad, although super friendly you have to be so careful with what you order, they sting you for everything.When you are dragged in they sit you down and in front of you at the table are olives and salsa, now everywhere I have been they are.... Well free! Here not so free they work out 30dirham on your bill, then the simple skewers you would be lead to believe they are meat when you order and yes they bring you meat but they are 65dirham on your bill, for 5 plates and 2 drinks we paid 385Dirham but in a local restaurant for the same only 180dirham and we did not get the runs from the restaurant.

Great for shopping and getting bargains, wear comfy shoes. You will get some good bargains here, the sellers are not too pushy. Make sure you haggle to get the right price.
