There are men with monkeys on chains and snake charmers in the square which I personally do not like to see. There are beggar children and women but they are not too pushy. Just say no, unless of course you wish to give.
The greatest spot in town . We had a wonderful experience we had a Snack and enjoyed the acrobats, musicians, performers and Ibrahim's comments were very interesting

Mad Mad Mad. This place is absolutely MAD, do not go home without spending some time here.You must visit Jemaa el Fna during the day first then revisit after the sun goes down, this place will blow you away.You will see and experience the real sites, sounds and smells of the real Marrakech, during the day the square is quite relaxed, stop and have lunch or a morning coffee in one of the many café's, at night just stand, listen and take all of what the square is all about.

Pre-negotiate EVERYTHING!. It's a great square, lots of people and things to see. My wife wanted a Henna tattoo, so we approached some ladies dressed in black abayas. I tried to pre negotiate, but they grabbed my wife's had and started in on it. I stopped them demanding to know the price first. I was in the middle of negotiating when they grabbed her hand and the lady negotiating with me said "You pay what you wish". I figured she said it, so her friend did the tattoo. Then they wanted 400 dirham (40 bucks). I gave them 120 and said I wouldn't do more. Well, she freaked out. So, don't listen to any "you pay what you wish" stuff. Get a price first. I wish the tourism police were there so I could have complained.Other than that, going into the shops was fun. Negotiating is not fun, you can do that in Mexico. Wandering through the great Medina was quite an experience. Just happened to have a bad experience with what I felt were "scammers".

Bustling hub to check out. Passing through here was quite different during the day than during the evening. In the daytime it's full of musicians, snake charmer's, and orange juice stands, while at night it's full of people, very loud, and there's many street performers and food stands. It's a great viewing area for the mosque and I recommend a visit during both day and evening to really get a feel for it. It should be an easy place to come through because it's very central to all the shopping and restaurants
Loud and noisy at night. Its very lively at night and unrecognizable during the day.Lots of places to shop and eat and lots of people wanting your attention.

Fantastic but be aware!!. Just had 3 days in Marrakech and spent a lot of time around the square,the daytime is busy with snake charmers,dancers and traders etc and leads into the souk, it is an amazing place the resteraunts surrounding have great views the food is varied, tasty and good value, however be careful taking photos the locals will want cash !!! Carry small change or notes and be firm they will ask for fortunes but settle for a few dirhams, get used to being asked to buy everything from spoons to an iPhone and there is a good amount of beggars,in order to appreciate the beauty of the square you need to be a bit 'thick skinned ' .The evening is wild,10 times the people,10 times the entertainers and row upon row of street food , we ate at a stall and the food was varied and tasty however be aware of the cost you think it would be cheap but will be your most expensive meal in Marrakech trust me! We had a few skewers of meat and couscous with veg and a bottle of pop and it cost 480 dirhams(40 quidish) for 2,considering we ate in a lovely resteraunt the next evening for half that!! Overall a great experience and I would whole heartedly recommend it but beware it's not for everyone !!

Fun time. We had a blast. Such a fun place to spend hours enjoying the shows the artists the entertainment and the great street food. It's a happy place for groups families and everyone visiting. The shopping is also part of the fun there. What I liked the most is the happy vibe you get from visiting.

Crazy, just crazy. A sea of people and all kind of street performers, and, of course hundreds of souks. Be aware that restaurants around the square do not take credit cards, and they don't volunteer this information, so be prepared to pay cash if you dine here. Do not take any photos with performers in the square unless you pre-negotiate the price. Otherwise, they will demand outrageous donations and claim that you are cheating them.

Sightseeing . If you don't like crowds, then this will not be your cup of tea. It is a continually changing place with snake charmers to acrobats, pop up shops, lots of cafes and restaurants and lots of souk entrances winding off it. Well worth a visit.

One of the most exotic and exciting places on the planet!. I highly encourage you to visit Jemaa el Fna in the daytime and the night -- both take on completely different personalities. By day this place is filled with snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers and musicians. By night, the landscape changes as food stall open and the air is filled with grilled fish and meats and bakers roll out carts filled with almond desserts. The sights and smells are the most exotic I've ever witnessed -- this place should definitely NOT be missed!

Crazy fabulous place. A day spent in the square is exhausting, but absolutely amazing. There is soo much going on here, it's a constant demand on all of your senses. There's so much to see, to buy and soo much to do. Obviously as long as you're switched on and aware of your surroundings and your possessions, you'll be okay. Haggling for your purchases is so much fun, there's great deals to be had, test yourselves!

Night and Day it alive. By night it is alive with, acrobats, food street stalls, and hawkers. Fantastic experience!By day it is juice stalls ,snake charmers, monkey men and hawkers.A must visit and watch the sun go down from one of the rooftop restaurants.

A must in Marrakech. One day we went there early, around 10, when all the acitivity of the place hadn't started yet. Take a tea at one of the restaurants with terraces surrounding the square: that way you can enjoy watching people arrive, setting up stalls etc from above - it's a great experience. Walking around you see dancers, snake charmers and sellers of the usual henna tattoos, oils, scarfs etc. A juice at one of the stalls (and there are about 60 juice stalls) costs from 5 dirhams - well worth the money.

Must go, obviously. This is the major square in the medina. It can be a little overwhelming and there are always sellers harassing you, but its so lively and full of all sorts of things. You must see the medina and the souks in it by getting lost, it is the only true way. So go on ahead and take a fork and see where it leads! Careful of the scooters! Careful of pickpockets and overpaying for things. Most things are fake. There's a lot of great food though--we actually didn't get sick, but that might be case by case.

Crazy and fun once you get into the swing of it!. In a nutshell this place is fantastic. It's crazy, full on and an assult on all your senses. No thankyou in french goes a long way and so does a smile. Prepare for the odd wierdo that is present anywhere in the world you go as you will get comments if you are female only group or solo. H'shuma is arabic for shame on you, use this if you get harrassed a little too much for your liking. It will attract other locals that will defend you. Once you've learnt to cope with the odd bod you will really enjoy Marrakech. May i say we wanted to leave after our first day here as we were ripped off, felt unsafe and had abuse thrown at us. Sod 'em and don't let it ruin it because since that day we got into the marrakech flow and had an amazing time, we are gutted to be leaving after a week of being here! Must visit food stall number 1 with the female cook, a recommendation from trip advisor and an absolute must visit for Roti d'or, unbelievable food and the cheapest we had here! Going back for a double dose tonight! Enjoy fellow travellers!
Heart of the Medina. A must do after dusk, when the food stalls set up. Local food on offer includes snails, kebabs, fried fish (our favourite), lamb, as well as vegetarian options.

Crazy and full of life. The most genuine experience in Morocco you get it in the Medina. In the heart of it there is Jemma el Fna Square. The most amazing moment of the day to be there is sunset, you can start walking around looking some of the local shows and then go up to some terrace to see the sunset and have a mint tea.

Great food . Me and my boyfriend ate always in the food market . Which is called jemaa square . Hundred of places . They are all friendly and food was in good quality . When you order your meal make sure you get what you order . Because usually they bring you different staff as well and you end up paying double . 2 people pay around 130- 160 dram . Not more than that . Fresh juices are very cheap around 4 dram. If you want to buy things make sure you offer less price . Their fiat price is always high and they go almost half or 1/3 . Never pay what they ask . About food that all restaurant has menu . So make sure you see the prices .have a good trip

Brilliant place lots of tiny stalls selling the usual . A must see for the experience. Many stalls and you don't get harassed like EgyptYou will get asked if you need a guide just say no and browse at your own pace. Lots of little bars and cafés to sit and there are also panoramic views which are brill.

An interesting experience. In the heart of the Medina, a visit to this square both during the day and at night is worthwhile. During the day the square is a circus of acrobats, snake charmers, water sellers and other traders. At night, there is amore of a carnival atmosphere with a huge array of food stalls, orange juice sellers, and other 'circus' type acts like transvestite dancers, 'boxing bouts', musicians.Pros: Its a real flavour of traditional Marrakech lifeThe food stalls provide a decent and cheap mealThe stall owners are friendly and usually speak good EnglishSitting in a rooftop café provides a great overview of the atmosphereYou can pick up a horse / carriage ride from the edge of the squareIt feels safe and you could take children around to soak up the atmosphereCons: Nappy-wearing monkeys on chains are not everyone's cup of teaDon't take photos or watch for too long without expecting to be hassled for money

Amazing place be careful if eating in the centre. This is the must visit in Marrakech and we went there everyday for a walk around to see the snake charmers etc.We eat there on our first night and were ripped off about 10 euros so just make sure you order off the menu and check the bill.But an amazing place

Great to wander around and for purposeful shopping!. We love this square. There are some fun colourful stalls and surrounding some good restaurants for lunch or tea. We also use the banks just off the square.If you know not to break your stride for over bearing stall holders and just fancy wandering about taking the atmosphere in, the square is ideal.We love to sit up on one of the terraces to enjoy the sun, a salad and tea.

The square at night.. Worth a visit. Food stalls are good but you are under a lot of pressure to buy. Take your time be a bit brave and say no look at what deals you can get. Don't take anyphoto's of the snake charmers as they will demand money. They can get very agressive.

A cross between Blackpool, Camden Market and WOMAD. Better viewed from sun down on wards this square has many small groups playing a range of local music. You will be hassled to put money in the hat if you stand and listen too long. Lots of fresh orange juice stalls, food placed cooking over coals seem very popular. As always there are lots of people trying to sell complete tat and then there is the entrance to the big Souk on the North side of the square. View the whole place from a terrace of one of the surrounding cafe's.

Welcome to the circus. Snake charmers, monkeys, dancers, food and people, people, people. The square is a scene. It makes for great people watching. Go after 5:00 when the tour busses leave and the place is filled more with locals

Fantastic way to get lost in Marrakech.. As a solo female traveller I was a little bit concerned for my safety in Marrakech but other than a few random comments from a few random men, there were no problems. Lots of time could be spent people watching and eating some of the best street food I have had on holiday. The monkeys and snake charmers were the only thing that put me off.
The Medina of Marrakesh. A must for the experience. I loved it 1st time and so returned years laster with a friend. My hubby did not enjoy the constant has selling from sellers. Not for the reserved!

Visiting in March - Harrasment and Animal Cruelty Review. We read a lot of reviews regarding harassment from the souks and the Jemaa el Fna before we visited in March - now I don't know whether it was to do with the time of year or the fact we are both around the age of 21 but we hardly got harassed at all. The only time we got harassed was when we decided to walk straight down the middle of the food market which was our own fault as all you have to do is walk around it to prevent being harassed. If you ignore them they just don't bother with you so don't let the harassment reviews put you off because we experienced very little and we walked through the souks every day for a week. However, if you feel very strongly about animal rights then this might not be the place for you as the way they treat animals here is horrendous. They lock monkeys in tiny boxes with no windows and keep them on chains, the donkeys and horses are in terrible conditions and over worked - so this will be a massive culture shock for most people but this is their culture so even though it's not right it is worth visiting to see how different cultures treat animals.

Beware the scams and enjoy. It's well worth a visit, and lots to buy. I came here as a solo female and on my first day I did find this area and the market a little intimidating as the touts do tend to target and follow people like me. I've been to markets all over Asia but it's a little more difficult here. Watch out for the henna tattoo ladies. They will come up and grab your arm and start putting it on you straight away, asking you questions they are very forceful and will tell you it's free because you are beautiful then their colleagues come over and you are ripped off. Put your hands behind your back if they try and keep walking. The touts don't ask you if you want a specific item, they will start asking your life story to engage you and even follow you quite a distance of you keep replying. I usually just said no thanks and kept walking. And don't let anyone "show you where ur hotel is" or show you around the stalls because they will demand money from you. Favours don't go free here.Stay away from the animals. There are monkeys in nappies with chain leads on, please don't pay for a photo they are treated horrendously. Other than that, there is lots to buy, most are willing to haggle, definitely the place to get your shopping done!

So exciting. We were there in Christmas time. Atmosphere, experience and wheel of life..all in one you can see here. Daytime in this square is full of vendors, animals and tourists. But in the evening came sellers with their kiosks and they offer typical marrocan food. For me is exciting that Marrocan people are eating here also with the tourists together.
Wonderfull. Wonderfull, must see and experience from the roof of café de la Fance, by walking around and by visiting the sook.
Vibrant main square. Felt safe here wandering around and looking at the sights. Didn't like to see captive monkeys tho. Lots of shops and orange juice stalls

like nothing else anywhere!. jemaa el fna is the busiest place I have ever been, its great for entertainment and haggling with the natives, and its great to stop off at one of the excellent restaurants for a lamb tagine and watch the world go by.

Keep your wits about you! . If in Marrakech you must see the square atleast one in the day and once at night- the transformation is amazing! My friend and I were lucky enough to have made friends with some locals who showed us around and kept the beggars away from us, however it was still a little daunting! Even our local friends kept their hands on their wallets in pockets and made sure we kept our bags close. Food markets smell gorgeous and you can get black henna designs from some of the local ladies- I paid 200 dirham for a design on both feet. Lots of monkeys in clothes who if your not careful and quick enough will land on your shoulder for a picture!

Classic tourist must-do. Constantly busy day and night. Loads of street entertainment - which you are expected to give money to, if you watch it. Lots of stalls, photo sellers - your photo with a live monkey is a favourite. A different atmosphere in the evening with a complete mix of locals and tourists. More entertainment including musicians, dancers and snake charmers. Lots of mobile cafés also pop up at night.

Wow! An experience never to be forgotten!. You have to keep popping back at different times during the day to experience how this place changes. I found the constant drumming in the afternoon a little draining but it was easy to escape it by heading up to one of the roof top cafes and people watching with a glass of mint tea

Tourist Trap. Nice from above to watch the sunset but not so nice being down on the square. Drugged monkeys, henna ladies, constant hassle to buy cheap rubbish. Was there with a friend but would not feel comfortable there at night alone.

A lot of fun. You must go.. Beware that you will be a walking ATM to the vendors. 'LA' means no in arabic, so it is a good word to know (but they no what 'no' means, they just ignore it). If you have small children, I suggest keeping them away from the snakes. There are no safeguards, and if a cobra strikes unexpectedly it will be the worst holiday ever. We looked, but kept our distance. Amazing place though!

A unique experience. This is real assault on the senses. We visited in the morning when it was not so busy as we did not feel like facing the night time crush but it was still an amazing place. We sat at one of the cafes and had delicious mint tea.The square is ringed with stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice and other fascinating products. The snake charmers were performing, monkeys were vying to have their photograph taken with you as well as other activities going on. We were not unduly hassled and it was a unique experience.

A true must see in Marrakech. Any tour or independent travelor will at some point end up here. A few notes, the square is very crouded at night, so daytime is better for the anti social. Also the vendors are aggressive but harmless. Also the quality of goods at square perimeter is low quality. Go further in the souks to get the best stuff and cheaper.

Entertainment!!. Great place to visit, especially around diner time. The little resaurants set up every evening are great fun and good food for a good price. Be carefully with monkeys, shoe police etc. Many trucks to get more money from you than you like. Great view from restaurant cafe de France.
Just Okay. This place is a bit intense. Be prepared to be harassed by sellers and henna artists from the moment you enter. But if you can be light hearted it's an interesting place.

Polar opposites!. This is one place you should visit during the day and night. Quite busy during the day with fruit juice stalls and some shops to visit. At night its another story. Heaving with a great atmosphere. Lots and lots of food stalls to choose from if you want to eat out, lots of little groups of competing musicians with their individual little audiences and a very buzzing atmosphere. Well worth a visit, even for a short while if you find it overwhelming. Keep a firm hold of your wallet!

A bit touristy for us... A bit tourist, many people out on the scam for money in one way or another.Everything is more expensive around the square....but it did make for an interest couple of hours sitting on roof terrace drinking tea and people watching.

Not great for women travelling alone at night. During the day crowded with people selling trinkets and snake charmers. Entrance to souks at the top and places to grab coffee alongside. At night full of fruit and nut stands and many stalls selling food. A lot of orange juice sellers and people selling junky lanterns etc. I did not like it after 8pm as it was full of young men who were hassling me and my friend (females alone) with rude comments. People shoving things in your face to try and get you to buy items. Much more aggressive than in the souks. One guy tried to grab my camera when I was taking a video of musicians from far away. It honestly didn't feel safe at night off season.

HORRIFIC. we were robbed within the first 20 minutes. the people are dirty, aggressive and intimidating. we had abuse, aggressive and sexual, thrown at us, despite being dressed conservatively. I was travelling with my boyfriend and we are in our early 20's. this country is vile, I'd never go back and certainley wouldnt recommend anyone visit. I also have no idea where theyre getting these photos from, in reality the place is filthy, filled with litter and dirt and people pee in the street, disgusting!!

Scary at first. I am not going to lie at first it is all intimidating but after the second visit you will get hold of the whole experience. People are there to make money and tourists are the source of it all. You will NEVER see a local shopping there. You get hassled a lot, ignore it all. In Marrakech out of every 10 people you come across 8 will try to rip you off but you will find some gems. Would definitely recommend a visit here. Marrakech trip would not be complete without it.
So much fun . Such a lively atmosphere, packed with people, you can spend hours there without getting bored, there are so many different types of entertainment.

Fascinating to get involved or simply observe. Jemaa el Fna square is central to a visit to the medina and the maze of souks lead off from here. You will find water sellers and fresh orange juice, food stalls, traditional street entertainers and much more. There are an array of cafe,s that surround the square many with roof terraces which are the perfect spot for resting and taking in the busy activities of the square below. We visited in the day time, however from talking to other visitors I believe the square takes on a different ambiance in the evening and the hustle and bustle continues until around 2am in the morning. A must visit place whilst in Morocco

Another world after sundown. This is a very interesting place filled with food vendors, snake charmers, street performers, fruit and juice vendors, and lots of people. This is the equivalent to a town square were everyone gathers. In the evening, the place is filled with portable restaurants with vendor after vendor offering "the best food in Marrakech". The food was delicious, but a word of advice, know what you are ordering and what the price will be. These guys are masters at upselling. A dinner for two can easily cost the equivalent of 60USD if you don't say no to the suggestions. Definitely an experience to be had. Pay attention to the crowds. Though I didn't experience it, this place is a pickpocket's paradise. It's very easy for your attention to be taken by the street performers or snake charmers while your valuables are taken by someone in the passing crowd. The best values are "snail soup" and freshly squeezed juices. A bowl of delicious steaming snails in broth is less than the equivalent of 1USD while an orange juice squeezed in front of you will run about 0.40USD. Fresh fruit and dates are also in abundance.

Fun but watch the entertainers :/. The square is an incredible hub of activity: horse and carriage rides, snake charmers, music, games, monkeys, fresh orange stalls; you must try!! Food stalls and bits to buy.GO DAY AND NIGHT!At night get to a restaurant or cafe roof top terrace for a birds eye view of the hustle and bustle ! If you watch the street entertainment close from the street level they will expect you to give money; snake charmers, musicians, people with monkeys, and if you take pictures do it carefully or you will have to pay, my boyfriend got harassed by a snake charmer and when we refused to pay 2 at the same floor space they shouted 'f&!k you' at us, not nice after we gave coins. Haggle as the sellers put prices up to give you a 'good deal' and shop around, wooden carvings for 20 MAD at one place will be 10 at another. But good vibes and its great fun. Eat at the market stalls for half the price of restaurants but still get great food! ;)

Overwhelming but fun! Recommend food stall #44.. Crazy place, world class though. Really want to give a shout out to stall No. 44. This is the spot the locals eat and is a bit crowded but the food and value were the best I found! They treat you great and the many 20 dirham plates I had were awesome! Tell them your friend from Alaska sent you. Enjoy.

Lively, exciting, noisy and vibrant! Fantastic at night. Be aware if you want to take photos of the acts or people they will expect you to pay them! Otherwise sit on the balconies of the Restaurants and watch the activity!

Busy bustling place . Great place to feel like you are in morroco, market for everything , food good and lots of entertainment in the evenings. Felt safe , people friendly , I must do experience while in Marrakesh.

The mytic square. This square is one of the wonders of the world in my opinion you just about to see what you int never seen before in one place,serpent charmers,monkeys,magic tricks,henne tatoos,the largest open restaurant in the world,orange juis for foor dirhams,escargots meals,ganawa music,its a big open crazy amazinng square,its the melt and a meettinng spot of Marrakech

Charming insanity. This is it. Walk around and suck it in. Everyone wants your money but they also want you to have a good time - get used to it and relax and your experience will be fantastic. Look out for the henna ladies in the day and the snake charmers at night, everything else is easy to control. And go there at night. Have a cup of tea on a terrace and watch the sunset and look at the place come alive, then head down to the stands to get your dinner!

Great to see and witness. Visit in the day to get your bearings. But make sure you experience it in its entirety at night. The hustle and bustle becomes apparent and you'll have a better sense of the people after their siesta style period.Snake charmers, fruit stalls, olive markets and souvenirs are all on offer and the food is exceptional in pretty much every place you visit. Surprisingly, the cost is lower than in other parts of Marrakesh.

A must see for any Marrakech visit but keep your wits. Me and my partner went through the day and at night and whilst we've been and it was vibrant and entertaining we just couldn't shake an uneasy feeling. Everyone is out to make a fast buck from the tourist which can be relentless at times, however this was expected as it was a market... it was more worrying though that it felt you were being eyed up for an easy opportunity at every turn and not by market stall sellers...even away from the market areas you felt you were being studied. Like every city you really have to keep your wits about you.Felt sorry for the monkeys on leashes and hated the snakes...just creepy. Liked being away from the hustle and bustle and watching from some of the rooftop terraces and some amazing pictures to be had. if going through the sooks I would recommend getting a reputable tour guide...otherwise you may get lost although everyone is willing to help you get back...for a price of course!! Food was great from the stalls...the smells just tempt you in and so many to choose from, street food at its best. As I said must place to visit and tick off your bucket list but personally wouldn't rush back!!

mixed feelings. A very unique place but you get hit for money and tips just walking through....Tips for taking pictures are demanded before you even set your camera.....Overall, too much demands for tipping, just makes it a stressfull experience

Interesting!. Jemaa El Fna, meaning place of executions so I was led to believe by my guide, is the main square in the Medina. Ultimately you'll love it or hate it. Whilst relatively calm during the day from mid / late afternoon it teems with performers and hawkers of every type all wrapped up in a cacophony of noise from the musicians. In the very centre there are countless food stalls although fairly, or otherwise, our local guide warned us off them. Jemaa El Fna is a buzz and and experience but my wife and I soon tired of it. After a while the noise, eternal sales pitches from sometimes quite aggressive sellers just gets to be too much. Maybe I'm cynical, maybe I'm just utterly boring and shouldn't be allowed out, but I found the square to be little more than a convenient place to get as many tourists together with the single objective of fleecing them of their money.

Lovely city. in the evening you get a feel of love with the city when you choose one of the restaurant roof and get your self a drink then you watch the smoking food of the Jemaa el fna square. is it's absolutely exquisite

Take pictures from far. I went during the day when it was quite empty. A tip would be to take zoomed pictures from far if you dont want to pay for close up pics. Overall, there were a few hinna artists, some snakes and some monkeys on leashes. Otherwise it was empty during the day, which meant it was nice just to walk through the square to get to the souks.At night is when the food stalls open up, but was told by my hotel to avoid and eat at somewhere proper. If you are alone then I would probably eat there but not if you have a family

A must visit. No trip to Marrakech can be complete without a trip to Jemaa el Fna.Be prepared to have every shop owner try and get you to come into his shop. It's great fun to walk around and see what all the shops have to offer. There are a number of Orange juice stalls who will be shouting to get your attention! They will also give out free tasters to entice you in for a drink. I would highly recommend getting yourself to a stall and getting a freshly squeezed OJ! They are very sweet and you can't go wrong for 40 dhirams. There will be snake charmers, be wary of them as they will shake your hand and try to get a snake over your neck and then ask for money. I would stay alert when around them, however it's good to just walk over and see the snakes. Don't take pictures unless you are prepared to pay them.There are a number of food outlets, so you are are spoilt for choice on foods! This place is a must visit, especially at night when the whole square becomes even more alive. A visit during the day AND night is a must. Try to have dinner on a roof top terrace and watch the people of Marrakech go by during the night. It is an excellent experience and you will throughly enjoy this.

Vibrant and truly amazing. This place is alive until the early hours of the morning with lots of stalls staying open late.So many food stalls, totally spoilt for choice. Fresh juice stalls galore. A must visit.
Once is enough. Despite all the hype, the Medina has little charm. Worth seeing once but the novelty soon wears off.
local square. jemaa el fna was a local attraction , very interesting , magical things , everything was so nice in this place

A DAILY VISIT TO THE SQUARE WAS A MUST. We would normally for one of the cafes or restaurants which circumvent the square and just sit and people watch. There was always variety and on a fairly regular basis a group of young male acrobats would appear from nowhere and their acts would culminate in a human pyramid.

Jemaa El Fna. By day, quite subdued and empty, but by night......a complete assault on the senses. Vibrant, noisy and just fantastic. Unless willing though, do not stand too close or linger near the entertainment (i.e musicians, monkeys, snake charmers, etc). For even just looking, you may be asked to give money. Myself and my partner stayed in a lovely Riyadh actually on the Jemaa El Fna and as much as we loved it, by the 3rd day, we were definitely ready to move away to somewhere more relaxing.

a real taste of marrakech. wonderful vibrant place, fun and great food at stall 117 very freindly, warm people , lots to see daytime and evening, very safe, markets you need to be happy, polite and play the bargain game its really good fun, fresh squeezed orange juice for 40 cents such amazing value , oils creams soaps etc fantastic for skin, make sure you take a hamman and massage whilst here so good, people are wonderful xx

Day or night, it's a happening thing. In the huge square below the mosque featured in paintings by Churchill and others, life is busy during the day and even more energetic at night. Marketing is a daytime activity; the white tented area features book stalls, and it's fun to see familiar children's stories written in Arabic. You can also buy a dual wall calendar: included are both 2016 and 1479 years. If you're lucky, snake charmers will entrance you and the snake - be sure to leave coins.At night, try the delicious snail soup and broth. Watch acrobats - they aren't really dancers. The displays of hammered metal lights give an exotic light to that area of the square. Use common sense; enjoy the energy. Not to be missed.

Very Different!!!!!. Went once in the morning and again in the afternoon. A very busy place and am told it is even busier in the evening but was not brave enough to try that. Lots of hawkers trying to sell you all sorts of wares. Did not really like watching the snake charmers or the Barbary apes wearing nappies. The traditional water sellers were very colourful. The side streets off were also very lively - everyone trying to sell you something but can't say I was really badgered into buying. Sitting down in the square having a coffee was well worth it just to watch everything that was going on. You can hire a guide to take you all around Marrakech if you are a bit nervous to do it on your own,.
A must. Cannot be missed when visiting Marrakech but not up to expectation but still worth a visit during the day and night.

Bizarre, hectic, fast moving and unique . You have to be with song nerves to survive in Jemaa El Fna. It's crowded, dirty smelly and unpredictable. People are trying to put their hands on your money every second. The food in the night is really tasty and cheap, but it's better not to look how they are preparing it. They touch everything with hands, however every dish is so delicious.You can see many random things from snake charmers to just squzed orange juice; from henna tattoos to monkey in a pampers; from mini turtles to cosmetic products. Just take your sense of humor with otherwise you won't survive.
Fascinating. This marketplace is full of exeptional activities: snake charmers, musicians, tradesmen of all sorts.

The square of excitement! . Constant buzz of activities from snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers, musicians , and food stalls . Constant changing through day to night never a dull minute and take time to chill on a roof top balcony and survey the scene over a mint tea or coffee
Ronald souter . Great place to visate a must see choice of dozens of open air eating stalls snake charmers musicians all sorts of displays going on

Hustle and bustle . Very touristy but still quirky. Soent 4 days in marrakech and the square became a bit same same but still quite quirky and something new everyday.The fresh orange juice is a must. The food at night is plentiful and varied but not sure of the hygiene standards. I think they reuse water to wash the utensils tbrough the night. I didnt have any poorly tummy issues to be fair but ask for your food on paper or disposable plate and use your fingers or disposable cutlery if you are a bit delicate.Funnily all the chaps speak english with a cockney accent as they beckon you to their food stall :-)

Very hectic but worth visiting. This was a great place to visit however with all the stands selling souvenirs and people trying to make money out of everything I guess the square loses it's charm. It is definitely interesting to see the belly dancers, baboons and cobra snakes. It seems that in the evening there is more going on than during the day. A lot of fake guides will try to help you and point you to the square. Don't be fooled though as they will ask you for money afterwards. If you have a map use it; the square is easy to find. If you don't want to use the map get a beige taxi.
Worst place ever. People trying to scam you,they'll make you pay for everything 20 times the value, even if you haggle don't expect much as prices for tourists are always ridiculous.

Interesting place . This is easily Marrakesh's main sight and a place where you can easily spend a couple of hours just walking around or watching the scene. Here, you will find all kinds of arts and all kinds of food in an entertaining setting. The square is what comes the closest to a place out of 1001 nights and is known for its snake charmers, henna tattooists and storytellers. The name can be translated as “assembly of the dead” and is the main entrance to the medina.If you want to try Marrakech street food try it there. Don't worry we ate there & we love it I recommend restaurant no. 15

Madness. Its mad there but i loved it thing about dome travellers is they get annoyed if they get haggled or beggers coming up to them but you people need to understand thats how they make a living whole point of people going there is to experience morrocan life and thats their life yes you have people coming up to you but if u say no in a polite way they wont bother you i loved it there its an amazing market sooo much to see and buy would highly recommend people to visit only if they like to experience not for stuck up people who look down on people or their lives

Must See but beware. Jemaa el Fna is a definite must see while in Marrakech. Flavours, colours and a foodies dream.Just beware...every single stall tries to lure you in with someone outside. It gets irritating after you told the 2nd person that you want to see what's going on 1st.But something you should experience in Marrakech. The sausages and tajines a must!

Just nuts but dive in head first, you'll love it!. On our first visit to the square we were a bit 'shell shocked' by just how buzzing it was but if you love a bit of people spotting, haggling, eating and shopping then this place should be on your list. Eating street food in the evening is an event in itself.......anyway without wishing to spoil your fun I'll say just go there, absorb the atmosphere and dive straight into the ways of the square and Souk markets...you'll never forget it!
best cullinary place. I love this place , some food are delicious and the orange juice is to die for . All the attraction in this area is very entertaining ... I love Jemaa el Fna

Cultural. ok in day time walk best for me is to walk around and have delicious Juice. but the night is magic, It is a great home atmosphere, full of local people and tourist together in a square. lights, games, food and dance.
Food market . Food here is very nice specially juices The juices stall are really good try the mix juice cost 10mah
Must seen. The center of Marrakech, with all the diversity, confusion and rich local culture. Stop at the roof top cafe and take a good view of the place

Why wouldn't you?. Its definitely part of the character of the Medina but not necessarily the best part. Its character changes throughout the day - from morning when you'll be intrigued but approached by Berbers, snake-charmers and hawkers, through to the evening when the whole square becomes an open air street-food emporium - a really buzzy, lively atmosphere that shouldn't be missed. Plain clothes tourist police make the area as safe as you could hope for and if you're firm with peddlers they'll leave you alone.

The great entrance to the Zouks. This is the square right in front of the Zouk also bustling of activity. Many food stalls, snake charmers and henna painter, some beggars and basically busy day and night. We loved seing the snake charmers, but strongly disliked the pushy snake attendant that insisted of hanging them around our neck. Sure we took photos, but instead of letting us watch the show, the kept asking for more money - pushing us away in a very unpleasant aggressive manner. A pass through this is a nice activity, but not as a stand alone thing.
Open day and night.. What ever your budget, your food and shopping likes it's all there and more beside, good place to meet and visit from.

Out of comfort zone. I stayed in Marrakech for around 5 days with a group of friends. We spent around two days at the market and had numerous meals there. The people who work in the market can be quite intimidating at first but you end up getting used to them. Try not to offend by offering your price too low. Also I highly recommend the fresh orange juice they have for sale, it's cheap and refreshing in the heat.
Amazing action!. We visited the square late afternoon and it was hopping with vendors, snake charmers and all kinds of activities.

Eye opening. Very different but in a cultural way, if you don't like entertainers then this isn't the place for you. Great views across the square from many terraces that serve food and drinks however not all sell alcoholic so if that's your thing then choose wisely

Crazy. If you have small children go between 4-9
Lots of beggers
ALWAYS AGREE ON PRICE ON EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU DO ANYTHING WITH MONKEYS AND SNAKE CHARMERS
food at night is overpriced and unhygienic
But overall it's the atmosphere that's good at this place

Beautiful sights and smells. Old Marrakech at it's best.
Wander round the shops, markets, take a horse and carriage ride or just sit in a cafe and people watch. Awesome.

Crazy fun. This is a real vibrant place. The souk, te restaurants, the mosques, all the people, the stalls with fresh fruit juice (try them they are great), tours with the coaches with horses, all the different entertainers (snakes, belly sancers, soothsayers, monkey trainers, gambling, storytellers, you name it) its is fun to watch and stroll the square.However be aware that once they put a smake on your nek or a monkey on your arm, you will have to pay. As well as trying to make pictures that will cost you some money.Around 17hours the square is emptied and from all corners of the square groups come with kind of a whole restaurant equipment to set up their pkace on the square and within an hour or so it has changed in the biggezt open-air restaurant you have seen. Its a great spectacle to watch and enjoy the sausage or fresh fish.We did both just go where the locals are !!The view from the grand salon upstairs is great.

Liveliest place in Marrakech. My wife and I are spending 4 days and nights in Marrakech with one and a half days left of our holiday. After walking around the medina and visiting the most recommended sites I can honestly say that the Square is the most lively and exciting placebo go to. During the day there are juice stalls and a few stalls selling brick a brack, but at night at around 6pm the food stalls open and the crowds gather. There are loads of random things happening in the square, we saw a group of teenage boys doing basic acrobatics, snake charmers, men with pulling monkeys around, groups of men dressed in traditional clothing playing music and dancing and most random of all, people doing boxing, but not underground fighting, more like a middle aged man (in his smart winter jacket) trying to prove that he's still got it while swinging at a young guy who was clearly darting around and trying not to hurt him. It was unclear at this point whether the older man had paid to spar with him as everything that happens in the square seems to cost something. I got bored and left. Anyway lots happening and when you walk through the food stalls the workers will always try to grab you and usher you into their stalls. As mentioned by loads of fellow trip advisors, don't give in, just smile and keep walking until you pick a place you want to eat at. Me and the Mrs tried 3 stalls over 2 nights. The number one stall, which sold boiled snails, this tasted mainly of bay leaf to us and I wasn't able to appreciate the taste, though the locals I'm sure would disagree as they kept downing the broth that came with it and couldn't get enough of it. The second place we ate at was stall 98 mustapha, as it was recommended by a fellow trip advisor. They sold fried stuff: fries, calamari Moroccan style fish. It was decent, but had nothing on my local fish n chip shop at home. The aubergine was nice though. Also as others have mentioned nothing is free at the stalls other than bread and tomato salsa which my Mrs loved. The last place we ate to date at and is also my recommendation was stall number 31 Hasan. We were going to eat at this place last night but it was super busy and I didn't want to queue, but today we got there just after it had opened and they had about 10 locals sitting there eating already. This place sells grilled meats as well as tagines and like all the other stalls, you get given free bread and salsa. We ordered grilled sausage and mixed skewers which were hot and tasty as well as fried aubergines and olives. the best bit though was that we had the privilege of sitting next to the boss who was making some meat patties at the time. This old fellow was super friendly and welcoming. He did his best to speak English with us and made sure that our food was cooked for us straight away. Last word of advice, at busy stalls be prepared to be squashed. You sit on these little benches which the owners will keep adding people to until you elbows are digging into ur neighbours ribs. I say don't get annoyed though and just go with it, the locals don't mind so why should we.

Bustling, fascinating and annoying. Being the epicentre of the action in the Medina, Jemaa el Fra of course cannot be missed. There is music, theatre, food stalls and lots of people. But there is also an abundance of beggars that keep nagging constantly and you cannot take a picture of anything without somebody claiming to be on the picture and wanting money for it.

Interesting, but people pester you endlessly.. Very interesting. Plenty of market stalls - food and non food. Snake charmers, people with monkeys wearing football shirts and much more. However, if you want a quiet walk and browse, this is not for you. Sellers and others will approach you enthusiastically. They block your path continuously and are extremely persistent - even after you have asked them to leave you alone. They all seem to speak good English - so you can't even tell them that you don't understand (ha ha). If you take a photo of a snake charmer, or a man with a monkey, they will expect payment. I walked through the square on my own on one occasion - and I wouldn't recommend this for the reasons I have pointed out above.

A mad place all together! A must!. Snake charmers, pushy henna ladies, bustling stalls and Music. This place is a must. Ones senses come to life here it can take a few moments to adjust. Be prepared to be hassled on the square, don't make eye contact or engage. During night time the place is more hectic. Packed with food stalls, all competing for tourists to eat at their stall. Go to a stall that is busy, it indicates food is fresh and good. One stall sang 'Shakira Waka Waka' until we ate there. They were great fun and let us go behind the stall for a dance and a picture. It was amusing watching them trying to stop tourists with their charm and wit.
wow local place. i have never seen a place like this , it was so magical , lol , we had a great time seeing local people , walking through it was a great things we did

Stories, smoke and monkeys. This is a totally unique and one off part of the world. The square at night has a character totally unique and must be experienced while you're there. There are story tellers, snake charmers, food stalls, boxers (also telling a story), monkeys and everything in between. Busy, noisy, amazing.

Worth a visit. Better by night than by day, but wasn't as chaotic or exotic as I imagined. Only saw one snake "charmer" (and that was during the day not at night) didn't see any acrobats and only a couple of belly dancing acts. We imagined it would be much busier and much more going on. Food stalls at night were very popular and have a glass of fresh orange juice as it's most refreshing.

Not for the faint- hearted!. Having visited before in 2007, we knew what to expect from this unbelievably sensational market square.Prepare to have your sense of humour in place as you are led through a multitude of colourful noisy and exciting myriad of stalls selling everything from leather goods,clothing and dried fruit and nuts etc.Its all very reasonably priced,once you have haggled ad nauseum!I didnt try the food in the evening,which has a festival feel to it..dont have the iron constitution for it.The range of food is plentiful if you like to try local cuisine.I would recommend shopping on the square during the day close to lunchtime as its quieter .You can then weave your way through and select at your leisure from the range on offer.The beautiful Koutubia mosque nearby is a must see and you will also be able to access taxis and the red tour bus from here.Do see the square,even if its just for an hour,you will get a true essence of Marrakech here.

It can't be missed!. Are you ready for the onslaught? Be prepared to be pestered endlessly. Pay special attention at the evening food stalls because their hawking became significantly more aggressive. Two men tried to block our path. Also be prepared to strike hard bargains. We suggest starting to practice bargaining with small purchases before undertaking larger ones. There are valuable lessons to be learned from your initial forays into bargaining. All that being said, however, this is a vibrant and visually arresting area. The best time to visit is from just before sundown until the later evening hours. There are street performers, food vendors, henna artists (who will grab your hand and start applying before you can say no- literally), labyrinthine side streets full of shops, and every imaginable colorful character. Also note that our impression is that the higher quality items are found much deeper into the side streets off the main square whereas the cheaper touristy stuff is found closer to the main square. Have fun!

The heart of Marrakech. This place is crazy, in a great way! Unless of course you hate snakes as there are plenty of snakes and charmers. Be careful of pick pockets and beggars here.There will be plenty of people trying to get you to eat in their restaurant or visit their stall so 'shop around'.

Marrakech equals Morecash. Marrakech could be best described as Morecash. Everywhere you turned, people had their hands out for more cash. If you asked for directions they demanded cash and more often than that they sent you in the wrong direction.Even if you tipped or paid, they demanded more money. I have been to cities all over the world and people have willingly pointed me in the right direction without asking for payment. Not here.Constant hassle from hawkers trying to sell you stuff. Nobody wanted to speak English except they were trying to sell you something. Even the taxi drivers ran a cartel from the hotels in Hivernage area where most of the hotels were situated.Don't visit the tanneries as you will be led to a shop selling leather goods from which there will be no escape. There are no pubs , not even a glass of wine to be had in the restaurants, apart from the antics in Jemma el Fna there is nothing to do at night Believe no one and trust no one.Everyone is on the take or on the make.

True Moroccan Cultural Hub. Jamaa el Fanaa Squire ساحة جماع الفناء is a wide open space and market place in old city of Marrakech which is the most popular place in entire Morocco among tourists for its cultural and folk value. It is the UNESCO World Heritage site since 1985. The squire is located just adjacent to old medina. A labyrinth of complicated streets opens into the squire which presents so many attractions to the spectators such as snake charmers, monkey mongers, acrobats, magicians, mystics, dancers, musicians, herb sellers, story-tellers, dentists, pickpockets, juice sellers, sweet stallers and entertainers in traditional dresses. There are a large number of restaurants and food stalls in the squire which offer food at reasonable price. The squire is an amusing place after the evening for those who love entertainment, color and enjoyment. A visit to Marrakesh is never complete without an evening visit to this squire.

Great after dark. We spent 4 nights here for dinner as our hotel was near by. During the day you can buy plenty of fresh juice (Govt set tariff /price), really refreshing. Just avoid the constant shouting and screaming by the vendors to grab your attention. Make sure you ask for a plastic cup ( glass ones are just rinsed in a tub of local water)The square feeds a few souks (markets) so it's a good place to start walking. It all comes alive after dark where the food stalls come up and again the vendors try and get you into their stall. We went where we saw majority locals and we enjoyed the following. 2 soup only stalls. Awesome soup (Harira, 3D, ~ £0.25) a bowl. We loved it. Bread, egg or olives were a bit extra. We were the only ones having just 1 bowl!!A couple of stalls just selling sausages (Markaiz). I bought a sandwich for 20D (£1.5). Fantastic. Families were just sitting there dipping them in a tomato salsa. We are 3 nights at #1, Aisha's stall. Couscous, mixed grills, etc. See separate review soon. Great service, lovely people to talk to. Lots of weird shows of dancers, snake charmers and ladies doing henna. Plenty of other shops around the square and a book fair at one end when we were there. Gets quite noisy, we used to be there between 1900-2200. It's the highlight of the old city after dark.

Great place to visit. During the day its not much to do there, you can go around small streets and buy cheap stuff, but the real thing starts at night, when alk the food arrives. Absolutely must have is snails, even if you don't like frenchor kretan snails, you will live this, taste is amazing, you also need to try lamb (I am nit a big fun, but Morrocan ona is wonderful and tender) and traditional tee. It's also an adventure (during the daytime) to go a bit further from the main place, you will get to more lical market, with fresh(alive) chicken and stuff like that. It really gives you the taste of Morroko.

Most different place have ever had been before. If you are going at night you can have a modest dinner, really cheap! but before, careful at the people who try sell any thing to you. During the day the local is hot, and if you are women, don´t go alone! I went, and I didn't feel safe... My cloths was ok! a long dress... Better safe than sorry, go with someone else.

Must visit. Any visit to Marrakech is incomplete without a visit to the main square. There you will find snake charmers, monkeys, snack and drinks vendors.Useful tips:1. Be careful of your belongings during any crowded situation. Keep valuables in front pockets and wear the backpack in the front.2. If you want to buy stuff like scarves, leather bags, and other souvineres, this is the place to do it. It will likely be cheaper than the small shops your tour guides take you. Remember no prices are fixed (including SIM cards). Aim for 60% of the offered price and be willing to walk away and shop around.3. Go in the late afternoon where there is still light (so you can see the sights/ things you're buying) and when it's not too hot. An added bonus is that the sunset over the mosque beside the square is beautiful.4. Wear respectable clothes. Although morocco is quite liberal, they are still a Muslim country. We are travellers and guests in their country.
Wow. This is a place which you have to experience yourself. Especially during Saturday nights, when it seemed to be liveliest.

Busy but beautiful!. I wouldn't recommend eating at any of the very touristy restaurants around this square but definitely stop by to see the busy bustling life during the night and day. Very interesting.

Buzzing, buzzzing. This square is the life of Marrakech and it's just waiting for you to take part. Here you can see it all, from the beggars to the performers and to the stall holders selling their wares. Sit in a cafe on the edge of the square and be a people watcher while you rest your weary legs and indulge in a coffee or an ice cream. You will never tire of this place, it's always the same and it's always different.
Spectacle of sight and sound. Do not miss this. Many interesting things to see. Much street entertainment-snakes, monkeys, dancers. Watch your wallet.

The Centrsl Hub Of Marrakech. It all happens in Jemaa El Fna - ranging from snake charmers to monkeys on leads to water sellers in historical costumes - there are also many food outlets which sell a range of meals that are frankly restricted to a few "specialities".
Must see ... but a bit disapointing. It is the heart of Marrakech .... but at the end it is just a bunch of people performing ... some fruits, tagines and couscous ... nothing really special

A Sensory Spectacular! . A magical place! Every sense is awakened! We absolutely loved this place, the people, the entertainment, the noise, the smells, I could keep going...one tip when in Marrakech, keep smiling, the locals love you to look happy (seriously).
Marrakech visit . This was a bit disappointing, only went during the day and found it a bit overrated.Did not feel intimidated in the slightest, minor pestering but no worse than anywhere else.

A completely different experiance. Coming from London, I haven't seen anything like this before,Jemaa el fna known as the Big Square is a heavy populated area with many things going on. - Food such as main courses and desserts, taste out their main dish such as Tagine and couscous.- Snake chramers and monkey's in nappies- Mini shops selling souvenirs, bowls, lights herbs, spices, animal skins, pets and many more- Fun little games played by the locals and tourists.Just be careful of beggers as the streets are filled with them, little kids will keep on asking and pestering you. We've been told by the locals that they are not poor as their fathers/ husbands are working and this is how the wife and kids make some money.Make sure to haggle prices when you are buying anything from the shops, you can knock down the price more than half. If they charge you 200dms, they will knock it to 100dms, keep saying no and if he ain't budging then walk out his shop, he will then drop it.The deeper into the market you go the cheaper the items will become, and oh boy it is a BIG market, spent 3-4 hours inside!Over all the experience is nice and something different, a must visit place.

Interesting place to visit. Be clear if you don't want pictures with snakes monkeys etc and if you do negotiate in advance. We did not have any problems but I have heard of tourists being agressively pushed for giving much more than the going rates. Be clear about what you're willing to pay before entering any transaction (including taxis).

Try both food from the market and the restaurant. Jemaa el Fna is crowded place, so make sure you keep your belongings safe with you. There are many food stalls in the market which offer decent food with cheap price.Beside having meal in the market food stalls, we also tried one of the restaurant with panoramic view. I recommend to have dinner in the restaurant terrace if you want to have beautiful sunset view of Jemaa el Fna with Koutibia tower in the background too.It's not only about food, in this place you can also find souvenirs, snake attractions, henna tattoo, and other things. Jemaa el Fna is a must visit place in Marrakech.

prepare for chaos. So everyone will tell you 'enjoy hustle and bustle' and 'immerse yourself in the the culture and just go with it'... but they won't tell you - this will overwhelm the hell out of you! my god, all the vendors are at you all the time, they do not leave you alone and if you try to get rid of them they get offended... just go with it. for a long settled london resident the need to be pushy and constantly say no seems almost too rude to swallow but once you get over this initial shock its actually very enjoyable. The food stalls are lovely and the food itself is delicious - i would recommend 'hassan's no 32' always seemed full of locals and people were always waiting for a free seat.
Vibrant. Busy buy day, vibrant by night. Go there for music, a fruit juice and a simple market meal. Proppers will try luring you in the whole time, but gently ignore them and you'll be fine.

A highlight of Marrakech. The plaza changes....it's a market in the morning, more of a festive circus with snake charmers and performers in the afternoon, and a huge food court at night. It is well worth a walkthrough at the different times.

Food stall number 1. Best food stall with lovely staff. Was unsure about going into the market to eat at first as I didn't want to get ill. But we found stall one and gave it a try. Well the food was amazing and very good price we both ate and had drink for 100 dirham for the both of us. We ate dinner there for 4 nights after that. Would highly recommend you give them a try.

Becoming more organised and rather less fun. The evening transformation of the huge square is much more organised than it used to be and the prices for the variable quality street food have gone up appreciably, but it's still worth a visit.

You'll either love it or hate it!. This is our third visit and we love it! It's full-on and you will be hassled by the stall holders, but hey you are the difference between them taking a few Durham and taking nothing each day. I'd always recommend visiting one of the two Ensemble Artisanales early in your trip to get an idea of prices. Then haggle - it's what the souks are all about. We have found that you can pay at least a third less, sometimes half and even a quarter of the price. But only if you are prepared to walk away if they don't get to your desired price.

Great atmosphere. Amazing.... But watch out for the snake charmers and the monkeys. Packed in the evenings. The food stalls are crazy we never ate at one but the whole experience of walking through is very amusing
Amazing. Cheap stuff good quality. Although people try to rip you off if you are a tourist. However it is a nice place to go and visit and buy traditional items

don't miss. very hard to describe, esp as so much has already been said about this place: bustling, locals, tourists, artists, merchants, restaurants set up just for the evening - it's hard and not recommendable to miss it when in Marrakech

An experience not to miss. A trip to the square as the sun goes down is something you have to do if you're visiting Marrakech. The street food stalls set up and there's an amazing atmosphere as night falls. A word of warning - if you photograph the guys with the monkeys, you will have to pay them - they have eyes in the back of their head!

Loud, busy and fascinating!. The Djemaa El Fna is really busy especially at night! A lot to see and even more to buy. Be aware that moroccan market salesmen want you to buy stuff! And the others want you to eat!! Or drink their fresh orange Juice.. it's really interesting and exciting. Definitely go and have a look. During the day buy some of the cookies these women sell around the place, some more careful than others (not touching every single one of their cookies) - but they all belong together i assume ;-) at night some Restaurants provide spectacular views in exchange for a Drink - absolutely worth it.

No respite. Trekked across the Jemaa el Fna both day and night, better in the night to avoid the barracking traders and showmen. That said, has to be experienced ! If you are concerned about animal welfare you'll be upset about the paraded monkeys, removing reptiles from their true environment is wrong as well. However the water sellers are colourful and the acrobats risk takers. Sit in a terrace cafe with a coffee or mint tea and watch the thronging humanity!

Everyone goes because everyone goes. It's a huge space, half full of stalls and framed by hucksters with monkeys and snakes and plagued by itinerant sellers of cheap watches and sunglasses. Prettier by night.

A tale of two halves.... Jemaa el Fna is a different place during the day from its night time guise. During the day the square has stalls selling spices, dried fruit and juice, with the compulsory snake charmers and henna artists. Be careful...everyone wants your money! Don't let the henna ladies mark your hand or they will expect you to pay and take photos carefully or a fee will be due!At night the square transforms itself to a space for fun and food. Endless food stalls all wanting your trade. Whether you want tagine or sheeps head...it is all available!

The heart of Marrakech.. Go by day and night. By day--snake charmers, amateur dentists, monkeys. By night, food stalls, story tellers and bands. Rule one: pictures are not free and can be expensive. Go up to one of the many cafes with a balcony to get a good view, watch the sun set and then go down into the throng.

A spectacle. Great square lively, colourful and noisy. Snake charmers, acrobats people selling everything. Some care is needed as taking a photo will cost you. Keep a smile on your face and wander around. Alternatively go up to one of the many roof terraces that surround the square and watch the world go round.

Unbelievable. You have to see this place to believe it... From a fairly busy square at 2in the afternoon by 4 it is a mass of stalls, pedlars, snake charmers, dancers and smells that I couldn't begin to describe. You have to see it.

A personal view..... Crowded, bustling - too many people, too much hassle, too many 'interesting' smells. We are musicians and tried to listen to a group play. within 3 seconds we were shown a hat, and given some juicy abuse when we said we wanted to listen a bit more first - For example.....! But - relax, if you're clear about not buying, you can meet and talk to some great people, and if yo do want to buy, go for about half the first price and you can get some beautiful bargains!
Full of Life!!. The square became our main landmark and so we probably were here about 6 or 7 times at various times of the day. Absolutely fascinating!!

Wonderful atmosphere. Having wandered around both during the day and the night, the main thing that stood out to us was the atmosphere. The noise and the buzz during the evening was brilliant. There are lots of gatherings of story tellers, musicians and street performers, and there are plenty of cheap food stalls. During the day there are a lot of people trying to sell overpriced souvenirs and cigarettes, snake charmers, henna stalls and horse and carriage rides, but be prepared to pay for photographs!It is a very safe area and is well patrolled by guards. Try to visit one of the cafes with a roof terrace for a wonderful view.

This is where it all happens. Noisy,crowded, dozens of stalls selling various fruits,condiments,fresh fruit juices, rugs,trinkets, fake watches, belts etc etc, by day. By night it is turned into a magic fairyland with lights, mosques lit up, dozens of popup eating shacks with all the goodies in the Morroccan cuisine being freshly cooked and sold to the sit down and eat customers. Excellent value for money.

A "Must Visit". An experience not to be missed whether you visit during the day or at dusk when the square becomes a massive outdoor restaurant. Buy and try the food even if you're not sure what it is. It's cheap and there's always something else you can try at the next stall if it's not to your taste.

Beware of sharks. Of course the plaza is a place one has to visit -- it's completely mad, heaving with humanity, and crazy with colours, smells and noises. High pressure salesmanship going on all the time -- you just have to ignore it. The rows of competing cheap food stalls are a feature -- noisy, brash, and something one has to experience once in one's life. Can't really imagine anybody wanting to eat there more than once! No bills are issued for the food and drinks consumed -- we had a big row with a head honcho who tried to sell me a whole chicken although I insisted over and again that a half chicken was just fine. I got a plate with chicken bits and pieces on it, and when payment time came he tried to charge me twice the price I was prepared to pay. Big standoff, and raised voices! So I paid him for the half chicken I had ordered, got up and left. I bet that thousands of European visitors are charged the wrong prices, but pay up anyway......... my advice is to work the bill out for yourself, and have enough small notes and coins to pay it exactly.

What an experience. You cant visit Marrakesh without coming here. It really comes to life at nights and the street food is really nice and cheap. Just watch for the snake charmers and guys with monkeys who try to rip you off by sticking the animals on you unexpectedly.

Markets are quite 'samey'. It's a must do, but doesn't have to be an every day thing. A lot of the stalls are near enough identical. But the atmosphere is great, although I wouldn't recommend losing yourself in it too much as the locals will jump at an opportunity to grab your attention when you least expect it.

Center of life in Marrakech!. This is one of the best place in Morroco! For an EU citizen, this is an interesting experience. It's like a throwback in time a century :)! I loved this place for his night life, for his orange juice and for the street perfomance.

WOW!. How could you NOT go here? This place is, as another reviewer called it, the Greatest Show On Earth! It is beautiful, vivacious, overwhelming, loud, filled with music, snake charmers, food vendors, henna painters and has biggest bazaar with anything and everything you would want to buy. Do yourself a favor and experience this amazing place!
wow , magical place. jemaa el Fna is a magical place in marrakech , so attractive and daily life of marrakchs , you sould visit it if you are in parrakech

Busy and everything you would expect. Full of snake charmers, monkey men, rip off phone sellers and life. If you don't like being hassled then avoid otherwise plunge in and soak it up because this is Marrakech

Eye opener. This a place you will love or hate , I loved it during the night as it was full of characters that love to entertain you, from the male belly dancers, snake charmers and many more to the food stalls were it is the norm to sing every time a new diner sits to eat. My one tip is to have plenty of coins as the moment you stop to look you are ask for a donation. During the day the square is a much quieter place with less shows but this gives you the opportunity the gather your bearings .

An assault on the senses!. Like something out of a movie! Best visited with a Moroccan guide. I went with Amine from blue touareg tours, he helped me through the maze of stalls and helped me get a good price for my very own authentic tagine pot :)

Alot to take in. The market place is a wash with the typical market traders and is a little crazy at times. The food sellers at night can be in your face and the food wasn't really very impressive but that's just my opinion as I like to make the most out of dinning out so in a market place just didn't suit me. The souks around the main square are very samey the stalls selling pretty much the same stuff but if you are willing to haggle then it could be fun if you don't want to buy just walk away saying no thank you as as soon as you look or stop they will swoop saying good price etc. Best advice is enjoy the atmosphere and keep you hands tugged away if your a girl as if not careful a henna tattoo may appear that you may not want! Best viewed from a roof top with a nice cold drink

Characterful chaos. Most of the food stalls offer similar fare. Very pushy staff. Look for the ones with the locals sitting at them. HEAVING with people at night. Safe and alcohol free though. Souks are good at night too. Exotic with hint of petticoat lane!

ok with all the hustle and bustle. Very busy and crowded at night. Everyone trying to sell something to you which could be annoying and tiring. You even need to bargain for a bottle of water. We stopped to watch a woman doing exotic dancing, and took a picture as a natural response. A second ago the woman was still smiling, and then suddenly she changed her face, turned to me and shouted, 'give me money!' There wasn't sign saying no photos or anything. That just shows their ugly side, and even give a bad impression to tourists about general Moroccans, for their dishonesty, always after your money.... Overall it was an eye opener but was not necessarily a pleasant experience.

One place you have to see. Must be about four years since I was here last.We visited in the evening the atmosphere, smells of all the different foods ,the incense burning .The musicians, dancers, glassof sweet orange juice what a place. food cheap and good you can see every were in the middle were food area is busy busy.If you are not used to being hustled,well prepare yourself especially around the streets off the square .But just say no and walk away ,there did appear to be a lot more people selling this is probably due to influx of people from other areas .The Moroccans are lovely people

avoid this place, there is nothing good to see, eat or buy here. Of course you have to visit this square once, when you're in Marrakech. Bit there is nothing good to eat here or buy here, exept from the 4 DH orange juice.

Stay away from the night food offerings at the place. Low quality food, high pressure sales guys to pull you into one of the "restaurants" overpriced for tourists. A complete rip-off, a tourist trap.There are much better places in town - just ask at your hotel reception for nice options.
nice attraction. this attraction is a magic of marrakech , we had a great time it it , it has a great view especially in the night , so lovely

Not average, just very different. It's not that this attraction is average, it's far from that given the hustle and bustle, sights and sounds, but our first experience here was our first evening in Marrakech and we were tired. I didn't react quickly enough to a lady who grabbed my hand and started painting a henna design and we didn't even have any dirhams yet so she got quite irate and followed us around when she realised she wasn't getting anything as her manner was too aggressive and intrusive. We didn't try any of the food stalls and that was a mistake, we should have. Don't go here straight from the airport unless you have the energy as it's a bit of an assault on the senses. During the day there's snake charmers and touts with macaque monkeys for photo opportunities, which frankly I don't agree with and don't agree with how they exploit their animals. However, there are some wonderful photo opportunities here, go and sit in one of the cafes overlooking the square to do so.

Awesome to see!. Coming from a western world and mind set, this was entirely bizarre and beautiful to me. I will say that you should avoid taking a lot of pictures unless you're ready to pay a guy who has multiple Cobras at his disposal.

A must visit when in marrakech. When you say Morocco you say marrakech and when you say marrakech you have to say jemaa el fnna. You have to visit it two times a day. During The morning to see and take pictures with snakes (oh yes) and during the evening to taste Moroccan dish yummy. But the weirdest and bad thing is that you have to face the sellers when they try to attract tourists !!! Don't forget to go with a morocan native speaker if you want to buy smthg

The beating heart of Marrakech. This square is an arena - full of juice sellers day and night, full of storytellers and snake charmers, with the smell of spices overwhelming you and lots of entertainment as the sun sets over the city. This is a place where to experience the smell, taste, sound, rhythm and life of Marrakech.

A must see - in day and night!. We took the advice of our Riad (Dar Anika) manager Antonio and went to the square on two separate occasions. It really is and experience like no other on earth! By day there are loads of stalls selling orange juice (just the ticket after you've been walking out in the sun), and just hundreds of people - from snake charmers everywhere you look to blokes with monkeys who will take advantage of you for a pic (if you don't want this, just walk on by), to ladies trying to henna your hand (again, if you don't want this, a polite 'no' and walk on by). It's a bustling area and just totally out of this world. Our best tip? Grab a coffee or drink on the terraces of the nearby hotels, cafes or riads - better still a rooftop advantage position to look at all this going on without the hassle of sellers and such. You can take it all in at your own speed. By night, the square turns into a totally different place! It's where all the locals gather to catch up on the latest news with their friends, pull up benches into little groups and play drums, sing and play traditional instruments. We soon found the best way to enjoy this is to throw in some coins - and then you are welcome to watch and join in. It's basically the locals having a night out with their friends, not really for tourist entertainment or taking pics (some groups frown upon this). but it is a great experience! There's also a lot of smoke and fires from the food stalls in the middle of the square, and other things going on, such as dancing, people gathered around to hear traditional tales - and even dentistry - actual dentists pulling teeth live in the square (again, not really for entertainment, but it is entertaining to watch!) You really have to experience it! Our top tips: 1 - remember how you entered the square - as you enter, turn around and make a mental note of the way you came in - better still take a pic, as all the entrances and exits look the same, especially in the dark2. Keep your belongings close to your chest - there are loads of tourist police everywhere you look but don't let your guard down with your valuables just because you are on holiday. 3. Soak up the experience! Allow the drums to carry you into this world - so different from our own! 4. try some of the street food... It's cheap, and although some may put you off with tales of how unhygienic it is, you should try it (if you are worried, have something vegetable-based). My husband had the best flatbread-filled kebab for about 80p!

Not a fan!. I hated it :( me and my partner went during the day - WORST MISTAKE!! i love moroccan decor so we went back at night , being followed , hounded for money , having men point at me (despite dressing conservative) , being chased with the henna needles and the lady grabbed my arm and wouldn't let go , someone tried to throw a monkey on me - not a fan!!i did get some lovely Hareem trouses though.
