Avoid food stall No 12. The market is interesting and lively. Unfortunately there are tourist traps like the food stall no 12 (Hassan). Food is less than average and the prices are ridiculous there. Almost everybody has discussions with the waiter when it comes to settling the bill. Very unpleasant.

Be there for the transformation!. The pickpockets and solicitors are annoying. Once you get passed that, enjoy the fresh OJ on offer. Best time of the day is at dusk, when the square goes from boisterous to really boisterous with the food stands setting up and the smells of fresh food being prepared!

Worth seeing. Wow, what a mixture of colour and entertainment! Go at night thats when the square comes alive. The children trying to sell stuff can be a bit of a pain but they do take 'no' in the end! Very entertaining but could be a bit too much if you dont like crowds.

At night the madness comes alive. At sunset the stalls are selling food BBQ meats salad s and vegetables I ate bean soup one night for 3 dihram ( pennies) it's like running the gauntlet once you walk past them but just sit down when you're hungry and choose from the menus provided - I think the most I spent was 40 dihrams the food comes on little saucers but is cheap and tasty - thry are all selling the sane just different prices - stall 81 was my favourite but I ate at lots every night of my stay ( I tried a couple of restaurants at lunch ) but the stall were better as I was on my own and loved the vibe and the food - the orange juice around the edge is worth buyin very cold and refeshing 10 dihram - about 50 pence The drummers and dances are dab to watch just maje sure you have some change in your hand/ pocket as they come round with a hat , during the say it's much quieter - I lived it and stayed really near so I could wander in every night ,

good to see...hard to "survive" out there..... of course while visiting Marrakech you can't miss such a place but also you can't miss a good infusion of "NO's"! you must say try to refuse all the offers you receive until you going to eat or buy something. I found it particular, nice in one way but also noisy and pushy over my tolerance limits sometimes... and believe me I have laaaaarge limits :). solution for EVERYONE WHO VISIT - TRY TO IGNORE if you are not interested. if you show your interest somehow... YOU ARE "dead" (in the nice way I mean) :))enjoy it.

Bags of atmosphere . Come here at night to get the true flavour of the main square in Marrakesh. The sights sounds and smells are amazing. The best food is in one of the little restaurants above the souks or on the side streets. Avoid the restaurants overlooking the square, the food isn't bad just disappointing.Enjoy haggling with the traders. Beware of the ladies doing henna tattoos, if you show the slightest glimmer of interest one of them will grab your hand and start a design then try to extort money off you.
Large scale cabaret dinning!. No1 for kebabs and No14 for fish and chips Moroccan style. After walk around listening to the different sounds of the musicians.

So cool! . Busy day and night, this square is a hive of activity all the time. The orange juice sellers have delicious cheap juice available during the day. The food stalls at night have delicious meals for only a few euro. There are pottery and sweet sellers, henna artists, story tellers, jugglers, snake charmers, monkey trainers, muscians and all sorts of entertainers. Locals seem to equal or even number more than the tourists here at night enjoying the entertainments.Great place to wander, shop, take photos and just soak up the atmosphere
Must see!. Just like any other market, this place is a must see! Near the largest Mosque in Marrakech and the center of the city. Simply amazing!

Back in time. If you have never been to North Africa this grand square will amaze, enthrall overwhelm. It's huge in size. Snake charmers, tribal dancers, storytellers and many still holders are a constant presence. At night it is even more interesting as lanterns are lit everywhere and the sounds of drums, singing and dancing fills the air. Cafes surround the square so there is always a chance to look and take it all in while drinking mint tea

Has to be experienced!. For a must see experience of this amazing city, walk through the night market, and experience the hustle and bustle. You will be continually hassled but not in an un-friendly way, just be polite and move on. If you watch any of the entertainment, be aware that you must tip so keep some coins on you for this. Also if you do not like snakes, be aware of snake charmers and that people will be carrying snakes around potentially - as a person who does not love snakes - the was pretty horrendous for me, but still do not let if put you off this amazing place and there are plenty of restaurants over looking the square so you can watch from afar!

AMAZING and EXITING. jemaa el fna have not similar and it is uniform.this square is very beautiful,amazing and exiting.this square surrounded by several kind marketing especially nuts,shoemaking and handicrafts.nightseening in this square is very very beautiful.
Day and night. You can't go to Marrakech without visiting the square both day and night.. It's definitely an experience

La place incroyable . Place jemaa El fna it's an amaiziiing place to being with family u can find anything u think about it food drink musics cloths accessories animals :p coffees hotels and spas. That's place it really the heart of that red city.

Part of the deal when you visit Marrakech. Perhaps the most famous place in Marocco, but certainly in Marrakech is the central square ("la place"): Jeema el Fna. Located in the medina, the square does not have a fixed shape or clearly stated boundaries, it has more or less organic borders that are not visible to the eye until you realize that you have left the square or suddenly appear on it.During the day time it is a fairly busy square that is used for all sorts of activities: from locals crossing the square to quickly get to the other side of the medina to real tourist traps (e.g. dancing monkeys, snakes and the almost unavoidable "super real" Rolex sales guys). Every time I crossed the square I had to say "no" 35 times or more up to the point that you cannot even have a normal conversation with your travel companion. After two days this really starts to become annoying; in fact the entire medina with its souks is more or less like this. Also beware of seemingly friendly "guides" that walk with you without you asking for it; they will surly want a reward for showing you which direction to head for (it is almost inevitable not to fall for this at least once since you can get lost quite easily; make sure you have small change with you for these kind of circumstances; 10DHM is already more then enough although they will beg you to give more, even more so if they have seen the other amounts in your wallet).In short: part of the deal when in Marrakech; go see it for sure. Pick a roof terrace for the occasion and absorb the square (especially in the evening when the square comes to life), but don't buy anything here and also if you have other options don't eat here: you pay a huge premium for dinging close to the square and the food is actually quite average to bad in some occasions.

Fantastic place a real eyeopener. When we first got there we were in shock it was so busy people walking in all directions.
Snake charmers,monkeys,souks,beggars,food stalls so much to take in.

Sirkus . First I went here in the day time and it was not so much going on. Was actually just crossing to get to the souks. Came back later in the evening and the circus was just getting started. As a female traveling solo I didn't want to stay till dark, although that's when the fun really begins. If you like snakes (they've removed their teeth), a lot of noise and people this is the place!
Worth it. Snake charmers,monkeys, camels,horses list is endless!! Sooooooo much to look at and take in! I never get tired of the diversity!!
Amazing square . A beautiful place to spend hours. Dive yourself in Moroccan culture. Delicious Street food. So many things to see and do.

Exhilirating culture shock!. This square is a "must see" for visitors to Marrakesh. It comes alive at night, with a seething mass of locals and tourists, beggars, traders, snake charmers, henna tattooists, drummers, dancers, musicians, story tellers, donkey carts, motor bikes, horse drawn carriages,you name it! It's tremendous fun just to walk around and absorb the atmosphere, but there are endless food stalls and cafes and orange juice sellers, too, if you're hungry/thirsty. A couple of words of warning: the locals expect to be paid if you take photos of them, especially the traditional water sellers, with their wildly decorated hats and goblets strung round their necks, and the guys with monkeys and the snake charmers. Either snap them from the cafes' roof terraces with a zoom lens, or offer them payment in advance - a few dirhams are usually acceptable. Secondly, if you stop walking, you will immediately be besieged with kids selling tat or begging, and dodgy blokes selling fake watches or weed. They can be v persistent, so a useful phrase is "La shokran" which is "No thanks" in Arabic. Best to then walk away. Thirdly, it's v easy to get lost in Marrakesh. There are hardly any street signs in the old town medina, and they're in arabic script, so do remember landmarks as you walk. Many locals speak french, if you need to ask for directions, but some may expect to be paid for directing you, and others will give you completely wrong directions with a great air of authority! If you get so lost that you need a taxi back to your hotel, hail one on the street and insist he switches the meter on. The ones parked at taxi ranks are the worst for overcharging.With those few caveats, I found Marrakesh a safe and hugely enjoyable place to wander round. As a 60 year old woman alone with my 25 year old daughter, I'd been a bit worried about safety before going, but we encountered no problems at all. Definitely recommend it for winter sun and great cultural experience!
Unbelievable . Fantastic, amazing, excellent...any other brilliant words you can think of?Hassle and bustle is superb, people friendly and fairly cheap.
Jemaa el Fna Square. A BIG and Chaotic square. This is the real spirit of this city.Here u can find tamer of snakes and monkeys, fresh orange juice retailer, spice, silver, leather and cheramics.
Mad Place. A deffo when in Marrakech. Amazing shops and experience.A busy place but it's all part of the old square experience.

Amazing Sight. This has to be one of the great sights of the world. Right in the centre of Marrakech's old Medina this is where everything happens from food stalls, snake charmers, acrobats, folk music people pulling teeth, souvenirs, cafes etc. Right next to all the souks. Amazing sight.
Nice. A little bit overwhelming (hundreds of people), but really interesting and nice. A must if you go to the city.
Madness. Completely mad place day or night. If you don't like masses of people do not go it is a crazy place!! Like all of Marrakesh it is an assault on the scenes.

Crazy place... You must see it!. Crazy square with lots of noise, horses, snakes, monkeys, music and people selling... Lots of people selling! If possible, visit one of the restaurants with a roof view. It's a must see, if you are in Marrakech!

Sensory Overload. I visited the square at night & it was packed with people of all ages, both tourists & locals.There are plenty of fruit juice & dried fruit stands but the main attraction are the rows of food, ranging from seafood to skewers to cuts of lamb.Most of the stalls are repeated but the food is nevertheless fantastic. I ate from stall #81 and thoroughly enjoyed my mixed grill. Do also pick up some of the pastries on show, but always remember to bargain down.

Tourist trap . Of all the places in marrakech this has to be one of the highest concentrations of touristy pap. If you do go there try to avoid the groups of monkey handlers and snake charmers. There are better stalls and quieter, in the souk. That being said it does offer a certain manic charm. Go there at 7am for a different quieter street scene.

Crazy. During the evenings its so busy but fun. Lots of noise, action, smells wafting pass you amazing is the word, just three and a half hours flight from Gatwick and your in a whole different culture. We ate at Hassan 32, very good, as mentioned in the Sunday Times.

BIGGEST OPENAIR RESTAURANT OF THE WORLD. It's the biggest openair restaurant of the world. You can eat fish, meat, tajin or drink fresh orange juice. You can wach the snakes or berber man singing. You can't believe how crowded square it is.
Total assault of the senses. Noise, lights, smells, - tastes if you are brave, colour, depends on your preferences but an hour was enough!!
Busy. Busy place but you can get pretty much anything here. I enjoyed it for the second time. But it can get a bit much with the hustlers all around you.

Keep your wits about you. I found the main square (and the souks) exciting to visit but it was a pretty uncomfortable experience. The thing to realise is that you are entering into a deal with the locals as soon as you set foot in the place; you are looking for an exotic experience you won't find at home and their aim is to liberate as much money as possible from your pockets. I expected the bartering at the market stalls but I was less prepared for the snake charmers and henna tattooists that launched themselves at you at every opportunity - and then the histrionics if you tried to get away without paying for that henna tattoo you never asked for or that photograph you took of someone in all innocence.

Unique Atmosphere. The main square of Marrakech was interesting for the first few minutes with the crazy amount of humanity gathered there & being entertained but as its mostly targeted towards the locals does get boring after some time. In the morning its quite calm with few hawkers selling dates, spices & hammam accessories and a row of orange juice stand. As it gets to evening the place really comes alive. A lot of food stalls open up, including a row just selling ready to eat snails. Performers of music, snake charmer, fortune tellers and dancers can be found all around, storytellers are in abundance although they speak only in Moroccan. The square is popular with locals as well as tourist. Locals crowd up to hear the stories and seem to drink up the superstitious talks. Tourist are mostly crowd watching from one of the many cafes which face the squares with only the braves ones trying the local food stands. Almost all the tourist will be haggled with beggars or sellers of questionable goods (weed/ imitation watches/ iphone/ hammam).

Amazing experience . Djema is an assault on your senses. The sights, sounds and smells are great.During the day you will find orange juice sellers all over. You have to try the freshly squeezed orange juice!! There are guys with monkeys on leashes, which is heartbreaking to see and cruel. As are the snake charmers, neither animal should be treated like that for the amusement of man.At night is when the square comes truly alive, with hundreds of food stalls and entertainers. You have to eat at least one meal here (lamb tagine of course) while in Marrakech. You could be more adventurous with the sheep or goats heads on offer. There are people and groups singing, dancing and telling stories. You can have a meal or drink at one of the restaurants on the edge of the square, for something quieter.

Actually two attractions - of varying quality . As per the title, Jamaa el Fna at night is so different than during the day that they can scarcely be considered the same attraction. Personally, I found the night time visit to be much better than the day - I would give the former a 5 and the latter a 3, hence the 4-star review. During the night, the sound and ambiance of the square is something to be experienced at least once in your life. The travel brochures might sound corny and a bit Euro-centric when they say that it "awakens all your senses" but the experience is truly amazing, from the street theatre to the fresh juices to the tasty Street food. Prices are very competitive, and although there is a bit of tourist-hassling going on, it is by no means oppressive or even uncomfortable. We finished our tour of the Jamaa with a drink on the terrace of one of the nearby bars, which gave us a great view of the whole proceedings and was a good way to wrap the evening up. Definitely eat inside the square itself and save the bars for drinking! Unfortunately, our trip to the Jamaa the next morning was nothing like our wonderful outing of the night before. Street theatre and music gave way to frankly quite sad displays of snake charming and monkey acrobatics - you get the feeling that these animals, climbing around their minders in chains and wearing nappies, would rather be in their natural habitat in the Atlas mountains. The harassment here did get quite out of hand and you feel that everyone is out to make a buck at your expense - most of the time a firm No (or three) will do the trick but be on the lookout for veiled women grabbing your hand and spraying cheap henna tattoos on it, then charging you an extortionate fee for their poor handiwork. The souks are much more interesting than the square itself, so just quickly walk through on your way there to get an idea of what it's like.

A typical tourist attraction - prepare to get hassled!. I visited the main square on my first night and was quite disappointed. We were told to go at night for the atmosphere, snakes, monkeys, great street food and markets. We just got hassled the whole time (which I know you need to prepare for in Marrakesh, but having now spent a few days in Morocco there are much better ways to escape the hustle and enjoy the city's chaos and charm). Having spent many days in Morocco now I wouldn't recommend this as a place to go and experience the culture.

Just stand still and let it was over you!. I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. It is completely chaotic, with myriad sights, sounds and smells. There is never a dull moment and it's impossible not to feel the excitement. I suppose it could be overwhelming but I fell in love with it the first time I went there - and my love affair hasn't wavered on returning!

Crazy and Mad . Soon as you go in to this area and you look remotely like a tourist expect to be hounded endlessly by beggars, kids selling tissues and roses, entertainers, street food stalls.Becomes a little bit unbearable after a while.If you get lost by any chance while going through the maze of Hundreds of Souks the locals will know you are lost and willoffer their help to get you back, this comes at a price as you HAVE to tip them, some even say how much you have to pay.

Dates from the dry fruit stalls are out of date.. A must see in Marrakesh is the central square It's certainly a very noisy place.There never seems to be a dull moment in and around this area walking about for 3 hours and always be someone trying to sell you something wherever you turn.Stalls selling anything from Orange juice to freshly cooked snails, the sights,sounds of the dancers, snake charmers, monkeys, spice sellers & food stalls which offer lovely food at great prices.I bought 4 kg of dates from one of the stalls to take home with me and it was money down the drain as they tasted bad and had "zingy" smell.They give you a good one to taste then they sell you the very old stock,so my out of date dates ended up in the bin.The fresh orang juice stalls tell's you fresh squeezed and they pure the juice from a jar half of it is water.Oh while I was there one afternoon I so a British film crew shooting a film in the square.You have to experience thus at least once.

Bustling place, crazy energy!. As much as this place is historic, you really have to brace yourself as all tourists are fare game for the 1001 rackets and shennanigans going on simultaneously. I found the merchants here to be more aggressive than the ones in Fes. Got some great deals on some bags Argan oil, and the same "walk away" move that works in Shanghai works terrific here. I got hustled as we were on the way out, this African guy in traditional garb started dancing the "Waka Waka" and shoved his cap to my face. As I meekly take out 10 dirhams he then put the cap on my head and shouted "Picture!" Goodbye 20 dirhams.

Interesting. The Djeema el fna square definitely is an interesting place in the city, it is full of live and a lot of business minded people and jugglers. Unfortunately you have to be quite careful and watch out for pickpockets and people who want to rip of tourists. There are also people who have small monkeys chained which actually is cruelty instead of funny. Anyways it's a place one should visit when in town.

Low hygienic level of food. Its sad to see the monkeys on chains and diapers. The snakeguys put a snake around your neck, encourage you to take a picture and get aggressive if your not willing to pay a ridiculous price for it. We deleted the pictures in front of their eyes so they left us alone. The quality of the food stalls at night is very low. We all got a sick stomach. Be wise and dine at a real restaurant not a tourist scam.
Weekend break . Very nice and busy and different from the England. Love the shopping there. People are very nice and friendly. Food is excellent. Would definitely come for short break.

You need more than one night to take this place in.. As my title suggests you need a couple of evenings and days to really get a feel for this place. If you're not an experienced traveller it may hit you hard at first but it is an inspirational place to be in. So many excellent places to eat. And too much to see in just one day. Take your time and enjoy this place.

The heart of marrakesh . This is one place you must go, although very crowed at times but so much fun and such an amazing atmosphere. Ohh and do try any one of the fresh bbq stalls dotted around towards the back. Street food at its finest.
must see, but once is enough!. chaotic, crowded and filled With pushy people but worth a visit. once was enough for this reserved dane.

Be prepared. Really good place to visit to take in a different atmosphere from the UK. Plenty to see and plenty to do. We took a picture with a monkey and a guy wanted 100 dirhams. I told him to take 20 or leave it as I work to earn as well and not to make a monkey of me..lol..We didnt get hassled as much in the square and just minded our own business without asking anyone for directions etc. Brill time, just need to enjoy the whole experience
great night life!. great place friendly locals ,the food was fresh and lovelygreat breads and kebabs would highly recomend

A special experience indeed. Had great expectations regarding Jamaa el Fnaa and they were certainly fulfilled. Very very busy with snakehandlers, hennapainters, artist, foodstands, juicestand (fresh juice only 4Dhm) and many other things. The souks have theyre own charm and so does this. Consider a rooftop dinner or coffee overlooking the square just before sunset and watch the square transform as the sun sets and the darkness is broken only by the many many lights accompanied by the sounds of the people the music the dancing etc. My main reason to visit and i recommend a visit for sure.

Crazy busy.. As the main attraction in Marrakech this square is a must see but care does need to be taken due to the multitude of 'shady' characters which abound, hoping to part you from your cash. Although interesting enough during the day it really kicks off at night when it becomes very crowded and sometimes a bit overwhelming with all the madness of it all. Well worth the visit and very interesting to watch from one of the terraced restaurants overlooking it.
maic place. we enjoyed visiting this place , food , magical stuff , local people , discovering the souks , really it was amazing ,
Must-see. It's one of must-see in Marrakesh. You have to go there early morning, but also at night - it looks like a different place!

Timeless chaos watch out for scams. Love this place but be a sensible traveller. The latest scam seem to be fake mobiles. They appear to be the real deal but are cheap Chinese androids in Expensive mobile clothes.
Crazy!!!. Plenty of people, great atmosphere once you start ignoring people who want to sell you things even if you don't want. Lots of interesting food stalls, juice counters. very interesting

Mixed feelings about the square. I find the square both vibrand interesting and at the same time bit scary. The scary piece is the snake trainers and those who through a snake around Tour-starten necks and want money to tale it away. A guide told us that the snakes are not poisenous and those throughned around your neck is harmløs watersnakes. all that put aside there is a vibrant pulse at night witth the food stalls the musicians so go look anyway

Visit after dark. This is a unique experience all the hussle and bustle of life in one place arrive hungry eat in as many stalls as u can enjoy the entertainment quite amazing if you are an early riser then greet the dawn facing the grand mosque stunning

Not to Be Missed. Of course you wouldn't want to miss the center of this major city by day or night. At night the food stalls are out and delicious very inexpensive food to had. All is fresh since the government requires all left over food donated to poor so everything is freshly cooked. Besides the storytellers, snake charmers and all sorts of entertainment out!

Busy hustle and bustle . Very overwhelming place. Remember you don't get anything for free. They charge you for taking pictures with the snake charmers, street monkeys so beware. Even if the direct you! If your happy to pay to take a pic then fair enough. Sometimes then can b quite forceful and just throw a monkey on your shoulder without warning!! I learnt to just walk away no eye contact they will leave you alone. The souks are massive loads of shops you can get lost in them . Shop keepers are very pushy so i learnt to say no and walk away. You have to haggle to get a good price so best to have a app on my phone which tells me the price in pounds made it b easier dnt want to get ripped off. Loads of horse carriages there we went on one nice experience. We wnt few times here 1st time cn be scary second time we got used to and knew when to say no and not get persuaded in.

Good to know: . You have to see this place but;- in the evening there's soo many people. It's better earlier at the day. - don't take pics with snakes, monkeys, guys in funny clothes unless you discussed the price BEFORE taking the pic. It's not free!!- take care of girls with henna-tattoos. Some just grap your hand and start painting and expect money, even though you didn't ask for it. - the restaurants with rooftop is definitely the best way to experience.

Squalid, chaotic, husslers and animal abuse!. We visited this square on the evening of our first day in Marrakesh. I wasn't sure what to expect but it was a very traumatic experience. The sheer number of people all trying to get money at any and every opportunity, the incessant harrassment, the pungent smells of the food cooking and the din or people shouting, the 'entertainers' and the snake charmers was totally overwhelming. What stuck with me was the horrifying site of the gorgeous monkeys being dragged around on chains, clearly terrified of their handlers, being thrown at unsuspecting tourists who are then railroaded into having their photos taken and then having to pay for the privilege. It was a very oppressive intimidating place, squalid, filthy, overcrowded and in my opinion best avoided. The poor carriage horses at the entrance across from the Koutoubia Mosque are in generally poor condition, are overworked and I didn't see any fresh water for them. It was very upsetting to me and I hated the place!

Beautiful square with the best orange juice to buy. I went here everyday while I was in Marrakech. It was fascinating, full of locals and stalls selling delicious food. The orange juice which I bought from different stalls was fresh and delicious.

Vibrant, safe, amazing. You must visit Marrakech. Walking through the square during the day is amazing but at night it is spectacular. Always be aware of where your bag is securely over your shoulder and in front of you. At times lot of police and plain closed police. Felt sad for the animals but donkeys and horses pulling carriages overall look well fed and in good condition. Snakes getting annoyed by snake charmers to sit up. Monkeys with nappies on. Flute and drum sound echoe through the square. Food in cafes at side of square where locals and tourists eat very good value. 10dm or 15dm for bowl soup, pizza 30-40dm, salads 30dm, tajines, couscous. Lots of lovely food in an amazing location. Cafe Babouch (down street with Marrakechi restaurant at corner of square), super place run by young folk, with young male group (lovely voices) and one of the waiters sings as well. Delicious pizza, pasta as well as local food/try the veggie pastilla and morrocan salad with some mint tea.
Overdose of Moroccan spirit. Amazing place with a lot of people singing and dancing, u must take a look to that place and um sure u will be surprised with everything

A variety of stalls and sights to see. There was a plethora of restaurants to choose from which offered great views of the market. The orange juice was spectacular! You just have to be very resilient towards the hundreds of people trying to sell you everything under the sun. Would recommend still.

A vibrant and enchanting wonderland ... a must see sight at BOTH day and night. Jemaa el Fna is the beating heart of Marrakech and a must see site. The sights and sounds and smells are enchanting. The atmosphere changes from day to night. Watch the snake charmers and definitely try a glass of the delicious orange juice from the market traders. I would suggest visiting later in the day before eating at one of the roof top restaurants before experiencing the vibrancy of the square at night.

Where it's all happening!. One of the top ten city squares in the world, no trip to Morocco is complete without a visit to Marrakech which includes time at Jamaa el Fna. Go during the day and enjoy the various performers and entertainers, don't go too close to the snake charmers though or they may hang a large snake around your neck and expect to be paid to take it off! Then go after five p.m. and sip a drink on the high terrace of le Grand Balcon Café Glacier while you watch the thronging crowds below.

Quite and Experience !. Got to soak up the atmosphere here, and go at differing times of day for the expanding perspectives. Once you get past the con artists, fake dentists, snake charmers and being hassled for every dhiram you will love it !!

Fascinating - but beware 'guides' and 'freebies'. Marrakech's main square is lively and fascinating, and also a great landmark in a city where it's easier than most to get lost in the hundreds of souks and narrow streets and alley ways.Most locals are friendly and welcoming, and happy to point you in the right direction. But a few might insist on payment for their services as your 'guide'.I was jumped on by a henna wielding lady who scribbled all over my hand (in spite of my 'je n'aime pas' protestations), then tried to charge me 400 Dh.So, great place, but be a bit careful, especially as a solo traveller. I felt physically safe there, but didn't enjoy the pestering...

Huge Open Air Theatre - Must See in Marrakech. This is a must see in Marrakech and I visited twice, both during the day time while I was there. The first time was mid week, late afternoon and wasn't too busy. The square was filled with food stalls, ladies offering henna tattoos and people selling gifts. The snake charmers can be heard before they are seen as they play there musical instruments and were easy to avoid. The monkeys dressed in clothing were a little more trickier to spot but also avoidable. There were also musicians and dancers in the square. My second visit was on a Saturday afternoon and it was very busy. On my first visit I went to a café with a roof terrace overlooking the square which had a wonderful view point.

Welcome to the souk!! Fun shopping and eating. Bustling with people - tourists and locals! The square leads into a labyrinth of streets full of vendors vying for your attention and money. Time to get your bargain hat on - its all fun and part of the process. We walked and walked - you can find just about anything from clothing to meat and spices. There are great upper floor restaurants that surround the square - a great vantage point to people watch...Monkeys on leashes and cobras being charmed. we managed to even find a restaurant that served wine! We visited during the day and at night - it was much more busier in the evenings - we felt very safe (we are a well traveled pair and have been to many third world countires).
One of the craziest place in the world. go there... you wont regret! the place is so caothic, so full of people, colors, perfumes and magic. you have to see it at least once in a lifetime
Night time visit. Went to the square as part of the Marrakech by night tour.Lovely to take in the sghts, sounds and smells of Marrakech. A polite no thank you and we didn't get pestered at all.
magical place. Jemaa el Fna , was a magical place so friendly and puplic place , enjoy local marrakech , and enjoy it

MARRAKECH MADE EASY. We have condensed all info regarding marrakech visit for couple with young 15 month old son.Tips and Info for Marrakech Tourists1.Stay in traditional Moroccan Riads and some come with free hamam if you book ahead for 3 nights2. Baby push chair is not a problem to move around.3. Airport to Riad book it through Viator from 7euros to 10 euros, most of the riads charge 18 euros4. But book tours through Riads comparing with viatore as riad deals are usually cheaper and you can have a deal with the same driver if you want to visit anyother place in and around the city5. Moving around at night is not a problem.6.Have a bright smiling face, words like no thanks, may be later, may be tomorrow, and big Harlem style headphones if you don't want hagglers disturbing your shopping.7. Make sure you ask about price before touching any product be it in riad or souk or any shop and this applies to photograph requests with locals/entertainers. Selfie stick is worth an investment and you can get it for 50 dirhams in the square.10 Dhs for photographs. Charity as you please. 8. Make sure your kid doesnt get forced in with any toy or balloon as you may have to pay at the end to the kids selling it.9. First day don't buy but go for window shopping, but DONT buy. Have an idea or make a list of what you like. Second day, go to Ensemble artisanal 5-10Dhs by Taxi or 15 mins walk from square. Good quality products, no bargaining, good for everything including argan oil, perfumes,incense, crafts, decoration stuff, thuya wood box,carpets etc and a lot under one roof. Serious shoppers will spend one day, but minimal shoppers can spend an hour or two. It has two floors. They have chinese stuff as well but buy what you can get only in Morocco. Unfortunately no discounts. Prices may be slightly higher than souk but its worth the time and saves precarious shopping despite bartending.10. Food- Enjoy Jemaa elFnaa food in stalls(Just for an experience). Make sure you decide what you want to eat be it bread, salad,sauce before dipping your finger in as anything can have unusual price and you could avoid extra charges by just saying No thanks I dont want this! Next to definitely try is snail soup, spicy tea with cake and orange juice or orange+grapefruit. Make sure you ask how much if its in a disposable cup. Next, dont have food in McD,KFC,Italian or other western or asian stuff. Eat authentic Moroccan when u have a solid aopportunity in Morocco. Definitely try Mechui. Go to Hadj Mustpha between 11:00- 14:00. Best option is to ask for 500gram meat from portion of your choice with sheep head. This will be 80+80. Make sure you get the quantity what you need and confirm the 500grams and pay before taking the stuff with you as the trick is to tell you after you've had it that it was 800grams and charge you extra. Next, have rabbit tagine in Tiznit 20 steps from Hadj Mustapha. You can also have early sunset dinner at Taj in Darna restaurant facing the square for the photograp with square in the background and good food. Other good places are Naim Food and the street from Jemma elfnaa towards El Badi palacehas very good restaurants for seafood. Just ask the way to el badi or HadjBrek(is another good restaurant that localites frequent to) the seafood restaurants will be on your left.11.Moroccans are good polite and help[ful people except for a few who can misuse tourists for their gain. Beware of intruders who can tell you that there's a tannery here, a auction sale in this street etc, don't pay heed to them. Kaftans- smarine souk, pastries and eatables-ElKassabine souk. Henna can be done in square but not great- expect to pay not more than 50Dhs for two hands even if its light/dark brown with those shiners. They say it can be washed away in 5 mins. My wife left it for 40 mins and it lasted a week.Buy dry fruits, olives and herbs for mint tea in the square. 12. Majorelle garden 40 mins, menara garden- 15 mins, palm grove 40 mins.Bahia palace 40 mins. Badi palace 40 mins. Saadian tombs 15 mins. Thats it!13. Money exchange- best near the square compared to airport. difference of 2Dhs. Airport shopping do accept euros and Dhs. Hope that was helpfulEnjoy Marrakech and see you in the next TravellogNaveed

Jemaa el fna. Jemaa el fna is a market square with shops and street stalls of fruit juices snake charmers monkeys and other street artist Hereby will find all most anything u want but prepare to walk around the square and look for the best prices there are a lot of little alleys leading to different alleys and could quite easily get lost but if you have some sense of direction imagine as a big square eventually you will come out somewhere you recognise Everyone is out there to get as much money out of you as possible you try to haggle the price and have s price in mind what you want to pay for it if not be prepared to walk away and try somewhere else It is a must to see the square as this is the Morrocan everyday lifestyle and shopping experience it normally starts getting busy around 3 in the afternoon

Amazing Square. The atmosphere is just fantastic -make sure you visit at night and eat at stall 1- superb.The square is vibrant and if your looking for a great place to stay then book in at the Riad Dar Alsaad -i highly recommend it

Interesting, but be careful of force selling. Very lively, music, craft sellers, food stalls, but be careful of the people forcing you to have henna tattoo done. They pretend to be talking to you and wishing you good time in Marrakech by grabbing your hand and holding it tightly so they can painti your hand with Henna then expect you to pay. Even when you say no and trying to pull away, they hold it so tight and won't take no for an answer.Also be careful with people following you around pretending to be your guide, and again expecting you to pay them even when you don't require their service. Also the little kids wondering around late at night selling pack of tissue, asking for your spare change, and there are so many of them.Otherwise, a nice place to hang out at night time and grab a bite to eat.

Very busy! But amazing.. The market is amazing to look around!But it is very hectic, with lots of people trying to hassle or pickpocket.Be careful!!Prices of Orange juice were amazing and tasted incredible!!Would recommend going during daylight rather than at night like we did.

Not so good with kids. I took my 15 year old to the Jemaa, she hated it. It's very busy, a complete assault on the senses in every way, especially the souks around the square, which I thought were amazing. She found it all a bit overwhelming, street kids begging, snake charmers and monkey handlers were a bit unpleasant for her, but the food stalls are brilliant, don't forget to haggle your prices down and remember each item is priced individually, including bread, olives and sauces. Shopping wise, Essaioura is a much less hassley place and cheaper than the centre of Marrakech...It's still pretty cheap though if you are prepared to haggle hard!
Fascinating. Fascinating, exciting, and amazing. A must visit. It all happens here. Snake charmers by day, food stalls by night and so much more

A whole new and different experience. Lots to see and do but be aware of pick pockets --- I had money stolen from me while eating at the street market.You will be pestered continually to buy things but you soon learn to smile and walk on.

Frenetic and colourful. This large square is at the hub and heart of Marrakech. Filled with stalls selling every craft, fruit and veg, and meat too. Lots of food cooked in a tented village in the middle offering very good value for the adventurous. At night light from many cable lights and the surrounding restaurants make it a very attractive place to stroll.

Dirty noisy and "arnaque". The famous Jemaa el Fna..Not only you have to hold on to your bag and belongings, but you have to avoid looking at anything,Shop sellers will harass you like never else in marocco.Story tellers and musicians will stop and ask for money to continue as soon as they see you..The atmosphere is really tense and tge place hasnothing architecturally interesting or prettyReally sad to have finally seen that famous place and it actually as nithing to show...Most see of course but di not expect anything.

Hustle bustle shouting singing. This place is like something out of the film Blade Runner! You can buy anything for the right price. The hustle and bustle can be overwhelming but if you keep a tight grip on your money, and sanity, it can be an awesome experience, and one not to be missed.

What you would expect of Morocco. The Jemaa el Fna square is exactly what you would picture when thinking of Morocco, large square with a multitude of food vendors, throngs of people, nearby souks, snake charmers and assorted hustlers. If you do not like crowds, this is not the place to visit of if do not like high pressure sales tactics, consider visiting one of the restaurants located around the square that provide an elevated view of the area. That way you're away from the masses but can still observe all the action from a distance. I didn't try any of the food from the vendors, even though it looked and smelled quite good. I was concerned about the hygiene. I didn't however try some snake charming :)
Summary of Marrakech. Entertaining place with a different groups and comedians ( halka).A must see as it is unique in Morocco.

I Love to haggle but this place leaves a bad taste. Fact 1 you will get lost!!Fact 2 the starting price of everything will be high.We came here knowing full well we need to haggle and haggle respectfully. (In fact a a market seller in Thailand commented that she gave me the discount because she enjoyed the politeness and charm in my haggle.)We were in search of a Pashmina found one place selling them for €1 we were told pay max €6 or 60mad. The guy went into a spiel on the quality he covered my face with a scarf, my wife's face with a scarf made us took photos.My wife picked one and he showed us a really crap one rubbed the dye on to his hand and said that this is rubbish and it's the 10mad one. (ok cool so your sign is a pile of lies to get us into your stall.) Price started at 650mad and the more we pushed on price he got angrier and angrier he was rude to my wife (I had stated she was the "rein the cost in" boss) at which point we weren't comfortable anymore and decided to leave, his price got down to 50mad as we were leaving when we declined he just threw everything to the floor and mumbled some stuff in Arabic and/or French. So we left quite quickly and got lost!! We never bothered to get a pashmina in the end!

Jemaa el fna. Wonderful place todo shopping you will find all traditional morrocan goods great atmosphere the souks deep inside the square are beautiful feels like you gone back in time very traditional place has kept its heritage shop owners are a bit pushy but great todo a bit of haggling as they always start of with a high price for items. think of a fair price and stick to it 90% of the time they will accept it. the juice stalls are delicious fresh fruit woderful
The Square. This square very typical, it self has its own life and charm. Visit during the day re visit at night time. Eat a meal in one of the many daily rebuild restaurants.

unique and intriguing. Writing about Jemaa el Fna Is like trying to depict abstract art. It is not an open air theatre, nor a dining space, or a bargaining square for whatsoever, a crossroad for donkey-drawn-carriege, or a daily performance show with musicians, charmers, painters, orange squeezers, dirham chasers - it is altogether and more. This is something to feel and see with your own eyes and believe about it's existstance only after you figure that it doesn't fit to any other frame you have pictured.

The Maddest Place Ever!. My wife hit the sack whilst I had a walk to the The Jemaa el-Fnaa, which is one of the best-known squares in Africa and is the centre of city activity and trade. At sun down it turns into a huge multi stall restaurant, market and street theatre with snake charmers, henna tattooists and shady looking arabs who will throw a monkey on your back and demand money if you're not vigilant. Beware of pickpockets as its very dark in places. If you choose to eat, make sure it's busy with the locals and not just tourists, this will insure it's of decent quality and safe. We ate the snails for two nights running and used stall Number 5 on both occasions as the cooking sauce was nice and peppery. Tried quite a few Orange Juice sellers, the best we found was Stall 40, well worth the 4 Dirhams a glass, so refreshing. I recommend trying the Blood Orange too, you can feel the goodness as you drink it.Bartering is a way of life, whether you love it or loathe it, you can't get away from it in Morocco. Many reviews suggest offering a quarter and settle for half; when I have done it this way I always felt a bit ripped off! I do it different as I spent some time in India. Offer a quarter of the asking price with a smile on your face and settle for a third of the price, many will refuse, so just walk away; they will either follow you and come to some agreement, or remember you the next time you walk passed. The nearest shop to the Riad El Farah, is run by a friendly Berber lady also called Fatima, she's really lovely. I had my eye on one of her Berber hats and my wife on a real leather handbag. We knew they were quoting the bag at 700 Dirhams at the leather/tannery market. Fatima gave us the initial price on our first day of 400D. My wife is useless at bartering, so I went in with an offer of 100D, each day we walked past Fatima slowly brought the price down to 250D. On the final day I went out on my own to do some last minute shopping, went to Fatima's, with a raised offer of 150D for the bag, she then came down to 200D, I smiled and picked up the Berber hat I had my eye on, threw it on top of the bag and said final offer 200D for the two; Fatima snapped my hand off, we both laughed and hugged each other. It was so much fun, so always barter with a smile on your face...
affordable food with a great view.. There are so many cafes and restaurants on the square. Try the Cafe Toubkall.The staff are friendly, great food, cheap prices.

Entertainment, Social & Foodie place. A must see in Marrakesh is the central square, It will keep you amused seeing all the Hawkers and shops competing for your custom.It's certainly a noisey real experience with massive crowds on Friday and Sunday evening.If you like street food the square has about 60 kitchens which only open in the evening.The most fun we've had in the square has been when we've been sitting up on one of the terraced restaurants, drinking coffee and watching it all unfold below us.

Crazy!. The sights, sounds and smells of Marrakesh can be experienced all in this one place. There never seems to be a dull moment in and around this area, whether you view from a balcony of one of the many restaurants and cafes or get in the mix at street level you can't help but love this area of Marrakesh! There will always be someone trying to sell you something wherever you turn, but if you keep walking whilst saying that you have already bought whatever it is elsewhere they will generally leave you alone!

Crazy Place!!. One of the craziest places I've ever been to! Stalls selling anything from Orange juice to freshly cooked snails, the sights, smells & sounds of the dancers, snake charmers, monkeys, spice sellers & street food fill your senses - while everybody tries to catch your eye so they can tempt you into their shop or stall!

Most awesome buzzing experience! Such a diverse mix of food, cultures, smells and treasures for sale. Lifetime memories!. It was an onslaught to the senses to visit this market in Marrakech. Mix of cultures, food, spices, smells - exotic in every way! Snake charmers, witch doctors and fire eaters and food sellers. Even more fun at night. All the weirdest things you could imagine to find in Northern Africa compressed into one small market square. Experience never to forget. Truly awesome. Watch your pockets though!

A very intense experience. The central square, and social hub, of Marrakech is a bit of a must-see, and it's certainly a real experience, but personally I was quite relieved to get the experience out of the way.In some respects, it's amazing: thousands of people throng the square and give the place a permanent festival atmosphere. There are snake charmers, and musicians sitting with listeners on little tables, and loads of unofficial street vendors ducking the police. It's rammed with everyone who lives there or ever wanted to visit.The downside is that if you look like a tourist at all, you will be constantly beset by people who want you to give them money. One woman wrenched my hand out of my pocket so that she could force me to accept a henna tattoo. People follow you around, you get accosted every few feet by people asking if you're lost/want to eat/want to buy a thing. The result has been that we've found ourselves marching purposefully even if we are completely lost, because at least that way we won't get hassled.In my home city of Glasgow, if someone notices you're lost and asks if they can help, it's because they want to help. In Marrakech, it always seems to be because they want money. That's caused a bit of a culture shock.The animals, too, can be upsetting if you're at all squeamish about that sort of thing. There are Barbary apes wearing nappies, or sometimes silly outfits with sunglasses, or locked in tiny boxes; horses waiting in line for hours on end, attached to carriages, with no access to water or food or just the chance to not be tied up; even the snakes look unhappy. It's difficult to watch if you're used to quite strict animal rights laws.The most fun we've had in the square has been when we've been sitting up on one of the terraced restaurants, drinking coffee and watching it all unfold below us.

To frenzied for a first night!. All the reviews, the guidebook and the advice was to visit Jemaa el Fna. So on the first night of our trip after being subtly cajoled by a self-proclaimed guide who found us and took two lost looking tourists to a supposedly authentic Moroccan restaurant which was clearly overpriced and allowed him to receive a cut. Once he realised that he was not going to gently manipulate any more money out of us, we were left alone. We wondered along the darkened streets and souks and found our way to the Jemaa el Fna. It was frenzied, busy, hectic, with a mass of people as it transitioned from stall holders to night-time entertainers.People thronged everywhere, you were constantly be heckled to buy something and there was a mass of people and activity, which left you somewhat overwhelmed and confused in the organised chaos.Wearing walking shoes is a must and on a different day, say day 2 or 3 of your break, the square might have been easier to engage with.
Nuts. Very interesting sometimes intimidating place. Very busy, you must have your wits about you.We wasn't really hassled but if your a lone female traveller I think it would be very different.

Organised chaos!!!. When I first saw this place it was evening. Dark. The nose and the hustle and the crowds and the smell of cooking and the sound of drumming and the strange music and the mopeds and the donkeys and....... Yet 2 days later it felt like home. There is a logic in the stalls, and a friendliness in the people that makes this "centre of the world" a place all should visit, and stay awhile. To be in the square when the call to prayer resounds from all sides ( lots of minarets) is truly awesome. Survival tips? A smile, a shake of the head, and as much small change as you can acquire for the beggars. To give alms is a good thing.

Amazing square the centre of Marrakesh. What a buzzing place but beware you will be approached by all sorts. So much to see and vibrant but you will be expected to pay for looking at anything and if a tourist you will be hassled especially if white female.

Holiday in Marrakech.. Totally amazing frenetic nightlife. However be prepared to be constantly harassed by the street food vendors, the beggars wanting to sell tissues when you are eating. The street performers expect a tip if you linger too long. Should you take photos be prepared to pay. NOTHING is free.

Mad mad place. Visiting this Square really is an experience like no other!! It's huge, packed, frenetic with people trying to sell you all manner of things which mainly you don't want. Watch out for being ripped off - juice seller tried to give me change for 50 dirhams instead of 100, until I protested, and at the stall where we ate the waiter tried to persuade us to order the most expensive thing on the menu! Watch out for snake charmers and monkey owners, trying to 'offload' their animals onto you and demanding silly amounts of money in return. An amazing place, but one afternoon and one evening visit was more than enough - exhausting!!

Love it........Wow. I love this place. I visited for a day trip in October 2015 but felt it was not enough so I vowed to return to spend more time there. Im so glad I returned quickly just to soak up the atmosphere. The place come to life at night and is a hive of hussle and bustle. The night food stalls are a must do....... The food is superb and the atmosphere is great.
Lively square. Great experience taking in Moroccan life sitting in the square with a coffee. The downside; local women come up and pull ones arm to get attention which can be off-putting for some.

Must see...but at a distance.. It all happens here. By day, acrobats,snake charmers and all sorts but keep your distance or they will aggresively persue you for money if you so much as look at them.By night it is mad with even more performers plus you have the many food stalls which offer lovely food at great prices.Do not sit at the front! Take a seat at the rear of the stall otherwise younmeal will be constantly interupted by people thrusting tissues, watches and carvings under your nose and they will not take no for an answer.It is and experience for sure but not always a pleasant one.

Fun. A true experience to say the least. Real hustle and bustle, snake charmers, dancers and street food. This is a must for anyone staying in marrakesh. It all starts around 5pm and continues into the night
Delightful chaos. Worth a visit and the food section is good and cheap. We went at night. There were thousands of people and it was all about the sounds and smells. Atmospheric!

It's ok. . On first look that seems to be lots to see, but it's repetition of that which is already in the mendina/souk. A lot of people hassling you, and at one stage of vendor took my wife by the arm and pulled her rather forcefully. Overall it's worth a look, but that's it.

Madhouse. Jemaa el Fna is at the centre of town and is a must see for visitors. During the day there are fruit juice stalls, snake charmers, monkeys, music and people selling anything you can imagine. At night the snakes and monkeys disappear to be replaced by food stalls. The food stalls all seem to sell similar food and I am not sure about the hygiene levels as there is no running water in the square. The atmosphere is incredible or scary depending upon how you feel and how busy it is. Be prepared to be hassled by henna artists and barter, barter, barter. We chose to eat at the restaurants overlooking the square so we could watch what was going on without being swamped. We were very glad we didn't have kids with us as some parts of the square get very packed.
Hectic but fun . Well I didn't quite know what to expect but this place exceeded my expectations. Vibrant bustling place.
Well of course a MUST see. You cannot avoid this amazingly awesome experience. It IS Marrakech. Do not miss it... Well you can't really :)

Full of Life!. I got a henna and we both enjoyed a wander around. It can be pretty sad seeing the monkeys however, and some of the locals can be very pushy. Definitely go see but have a price in mind of what you are willing to pay and don't be afraid to walk away.

Loved This Square. We visited first on a Sunday afternoon 24th Jan and it was quiet around so we returned again on the evening.What an experience and ambience -its buzzing.You must visit it and don't miss a night visit

Amazing. We really enjoyed the market. Wish I bought more though. Make sure you bargain! Often the price that they tell you, you can bargain it down to half the price ;) Also.. Watch out for people who self appoint themselves as your tour guide.. you wont realize until the end of the trip.
Manic manic manic . The first night we came to the square I felt scared. The 2nd night I was like a pro. Just be polite and say no and you will be left alone.

Madness. You need to experience this, but you also need to blank out some of the tourist driven hype and take everything with a pinch of salt. You will be quoted prices 3 and 4 times the actual value, so decide what you want to pay, do the obligatory haggle and walk away with a smile and a wink, thanking your seller but not today! By day a sellers hangout and by night a street food empire. If you take a photo of the various entertainers around the square expect to psy them (5 or 10 dirham's), and the henna ladies will grab your hand and start to paint you before you can say no, but just pull away and politely say no thank you. If you are simply out yo experience the atmosphere hold tight and go with the flow and enjoy. Restaurants around the square are more expensive than the side streets and the street food is OK if you look where the locals are eating and go there. You can eat well at the stalls for 20 dirham's.

Nice site to walk around. It is nice to walk around! Specially during the day there are may street perfomers with snakes and monkeys (the monkeys were with chains around their necks which i found very disturbing), DO NOT TAKE PICTURES UNTIL YOU AGREE A PRICE!Only give one Euro or 10 dirham for a picture, if you don`t agree before you can end up having a bad time and paying 20 or 3 euros... Be aware of the food stands at night, people try to get you to eat there and they can get very agressive!

What to look at next?. We LOVED this place. The smells, sounds & sights were as we'd imagined. Yes, the snake charmers are a bit tacky and yes, you have to pay for every photo opportunity involving water carriers etc but it's all worth it just for the memories. We ate at food stall numbers 25/29 and were welcomed back each time. A hint if you eat here....only order half of what you think you'll need! Loved the theatre of it all. So much to look at, so much to buy and so many haggling opportunities, all taken in good humour. If you're a cat lover, this will be heaven for you!
Freakshow for Tourists. It is difficult to avoid walking through this square, but most days it is likely to appeal only to visitors for whom anything unusual or gross seems worth the bother.

Alas this has become tame. The last time I visited more than 10 years ago the square changed from day to might; food stalls with gas or paraffin lanterns were wheeled into place at dusk and a myriad of different foods appeared to be sampled. Now the 'stalls' are of uniform pattern, do not change as the day lengthens and take up most of the square on a seemingly permanent basis. There are still a few snake charmers with their mournful trumpets and a few monkeys dressed in clothes but not much is left of the old magic. Now there is incessant drumming from groups of youths and some dancers, the stalls piled high with oranges and dates, a few trinkets some handwork.....
The real vibe. You can feel here the real Marocco, taste the food, see the shows, stroll around, meet people, buy stuff and never leave :)

Eye opening and jaw dropping.. An amazing bewildering experience awaits you when you visit.A cacophony of sound, sights and smells.Everything from snake charmers ,water sellers and dancers in the daytime to eateries and acrobats in the evening.Should be on everyone's bucket list.

Amazing food. Come to the market area post 5pm. It really livens up and there is much to see and do. Most nights we had dinner in the market area. Particularly food stall 1. Amazing food freshly cooked and great prices. :)

It's a must see location but in small doses. I spent time in Marrakech this month and elk through and around Jemaa el Fna on several occasions day and night. There is always something or someone vying for your attention be it snake charmers, musicians cross dressing dancers, soothsayers or drummers. During the day the square is also filled with juice and fruit stalks and at night dozens of restaurants open up. It's a hectic place that I found best experiences in small doses and admired from above in the roof top of one of the many restaurants and cafes that line the square.

Crazyyyyyyy. Wow! this place encompasses the culture of Marrakech from every corner. It s vibrant and colourful, a zany mixture of local snake charmers, acrobatics, not sure about the monkeys on chains though. Many many stalls with goods ranging from fez s, Argan oil, wooden africanised artefacts. There are restaurants in abundance to suit everyone s palates. Each evening the place becomes a circus ring and the atmosphere buzzes. Many sellers will constantly try to entice you with their wares or tempt you on excursions, beggars will follow you, young children will offer you a local delicacy , however this is their way of daily life and a polite refusal is mostly accepted. Always barter for items that interest you especially the horse/carriage. For a 1 hour ride we only paid MAD100 even though the starting price was MAD 500 . Live this experience and you ll certainly appreciate your own home comforts and not take things for granted.

Wonderful Market place, well worth a visit. . Visited twice, day and evening; wonderful market square with literally hundreds of stalls ranging from spices, fruit juices, clothes, street food, traditional Moroccan goods to snake charmers etc! Must be visited after dark! Excellent restaurants around the square giving wonderful views over the market especially in the evening.

An interesting experience. Went on aThomson's trip with a guide. The Square is huge and it's fascinating to people watch and try to understand their way of life. We went late afternoon, just as it was all coming to life. Everyone is trying to make a living, but if we weren't interested we just said 'la shukran' no thanks in arabic and didn't have any problems .I was glad we went.

The heart of Marrakech. Market, food, snake enchanters, henna tattoos and fresh juices. This is the place to go in Marrakech (you will anyway land here anytime you do a walking tour of the Medina). Be sure to get an orange, lemon or pomegranate juice from one of the many kiosks, it is just fresh and excellent. This is also the place to take a picture with some snakes around your head and neck, just remember to agree a decent price before you do it.

Amazing place!. Beware but enjoy! Amazing sights. You will be bombarded with traders trying to sell you their wares. Don't let the henna tattoo ladies hold your hand. They say 'only 20' which makes you think in Dirham, but then they try and charge 20 euro when done. Saw quite a few arguments.Not nice to see the monkeys on leads and dressed up but it's definitely a 'must visit' place

Must see in Marrakech. You cant get around this square when visiting Marrakech. Visit more than once as the square looks completely different depending on the time of the day. In the mornings it is quieter and you can enjoy a fresh orange juice while in the night there are restaurants and lots of street artists.The only thing that gave me a stomach-ache were the chained monkeys in diapers and fancy dresses as a tourist attraction...that was horrible.

Busier than you can possibly imagine. Brilliant experience day and night. Noisy and so much to see. Everything you could possibly imagine is for sale and as evening approaches the people just keep coming. You will be approached constantly to buy and eat but declining politely is accepted. You have to experience thus at least once.

Must see but shame about the vendors trying to rip off tourists. Went twice during our visit. Yes it is a must visit given its history but I wouldn't linger after some photos. 1. First was in the evening. Looking for dinner. Sat down at stall 95. It looked busy with locals and tourists. We ordered one tagine with meat, one tagine with figs and two soft drinks. They brought olives, two portions of salads (which we didn't order) but fine, didn't mind that, knowing we needed to pay. Then the tagines came. One was lamb with figs and the other was beef with prunes which the waiter said was 'meat came with prunes'. It wasn't exactly what we ordered but after trying to clarify the waiter said that is what we wanted. Tagines tasted ok but was extremely oily (not the best meet quality) and small portions. So in the end we got charged double for the tagines when we asked for the bill. Including the side dishes we didn't order. It came to 250 Dh between the two of us. We may as well have went to a restaurant!2. Went to one of the many juice stalls in the market in the middle of the afternoon. The sign clearly states 4 Dh for a cup of orange juice. The seller first asked us to taste a smallsample of the mixed juice (a cup priced at 10 Dh). We had the taste but still wanted the orange juice only. He used the plastic cup we used for the tasting, filled it with orange juice, and handed over money. When we got the change back, he had charged me 40 Dh instead of 4 Dh, claiming that he had to sell me the plastic cup and hence the extra cost...!!!! We refused and insisted on him giving us back the money, only to have his attention when we mentioned the word 'police'. By the way he took back the cup of juice, and the cup was used already for tasting. Don't think he would be throwing the juice away...

Hustle & Bustle with no peace in mind.. This area is a landmark of Marrakech. You can find cheap eats, counterfeit goods, armed police, horses, monkeys, snakes and hustlers. It is a must see on any trip to the city. Although one time was more than enough. Be prepared you will be constantly bombarded to walk into someone's store, buy something that you really do not want, eat something that doesn't take great and have a monkey sit on your head. Beware of the latter as any performer that asks you to take a picture or an interaction with his monkey (pun aside) will ask you for an incredulous amount of money to compensate his aggressive behavior. Do not fall for this, be strong.

Lively by day, buzzing by night!. A fantastic place to visit and be blown away by so much going on and to see! From snake charmers, dancing monkeys, belly dancers, acrobats water wallas, henna tattooists and so much more! At night it really comes alive with amazing street food stalls! Don't be intimidated by the locals, they're just trying to earn a living... If you're not interested, a smile and no thanks works wonders! Remember a free gift is never a free gift - especially from the Henna Tatoo artists!!!

Fantastic at night. We visited the square twice during our stay, once during the day and the other at night. We preferred visiting at night, was great to see all of the stall, street acts and sit in the cafe and watch the world go buy.

facinating but with caution. truely unmissable to see the centre of so much life in Marrakech, between sights, sounds and tastes the experience offers so much to so many.as a vegetarian, I was as usual caught with not a lot of choice, but it did not stop the chance to people watch.Watch is exactly the note of caution, especially at night when its too easy to be distracted by all the street performers and flickering torch lights - be aware as with all such opportunites there are many who will seek to lighten the load of your wallet or purse.Do go - its worth the effort, just be careful

Jemaa el fna never sleeps!. Very busy area, would advise families with young children be careful, don't go into the crowded places too much. When I went there I loved it because they had so much variety of clothing, food, toys, etc. It was like a never ending circle. At night they do mini shows in the middle of the markets for entertainment; snake charmers, dancers, singers, magician and so many other types of entertainment. Would reccomend to go at night.

Amazing sights, sounds and smells.... What an amazing place this is, it was like going back in time: musicians, dancers, story-tellers, snake charmers, gamblers betting on (rigged?) boxing matches (!), henna tattooists, vendors selling everything from cigarettes to handkerchiefs to kitchen utensils to cakes, breads and sweets. An area set aside for colourful traditional carts selling only freshly squeezed fruit juices that were delicious. There was a huge selection of food stalls selling all kinds of traditional foods, one specifically just selling mint tea and traditional broth served by a chap who was the spit of Chris Kamara (you might have to be an English football fan for this one). The food stall and street vendors calling out to attract trade, the musicians playing guitars, drums and finger cymbals, the cheers of the crowds being entertained all blended into one. Don't miss the pitch and put man - a golf club and ball, green felt mat, raised hole at one end, great fun! For the best and most popular attraction by far - look for the crowd of people in a large circle holding long poles with string tied to the end with a ring dangling on the bottom of it, trying to hook the ring over the neck of various fizzy drinks bottles with looks of total concentration - totally addictive!

Must visit. The square is a must visit when in Marrakech, especially at night! It's always busy, full of locals, snake charmers, henna artists and food stalls. We didn't eat in the square itself as were recommended by our road owner that the restaurants surrounding the square would be much more hygienic. The square really is a great experience but do expect a LOT of hassle as a tourist
cheap and delicious food. cheap and delicious food. Interesting place.Interesting people. delicious orange juice just for 4 drh.

Great both night a day. Right in the middle of things!! Everything happens here, snake charmers, dancing transvestites, monkeys, story tellers you name it you will see it here, loads of places to stop and eat/drink and people watch.

The craziest place on Earth!. I'm currently staying in Marrakech and I must admit that the medina has totally blown my mind. Our first visit was early afternoon and it was busy but still very chilled. Lots of small stalls selling fresh juice, and quick traditional moroccon food. I must warn all that there are shop owners who will try to scam you!! A lady on henna stall called us over and asked about mine and my partners tattoos, she then grabbed my hand and started doodling away saying it was free (I didnt have much choice in the matter! I really didnt want it done!) I tried to give her 20dh tip and then she tried to charge me 300dh! We got away with 50dh! The henna she used was also bad, my hand went really read as well as painful! Many shop owners are like this but we've learnt if you stand your ground and move on you can avoid this and police are never too far if you need help! Shop owners do try to drag you into their stalls. Other then that the medina is wonderful place full of wonders! Make sure you also visit in the evening and have lunch on a roof top restaurant, thats when the place really comes alive!!

The square. The mist important touristic attraction in Marrakech, this square is where everything starts. Some local restaurants around, markets everywhere and all the time full of people trying to sell you something or bothering you for money....

Great people watching!. Brilliant place for a spot of people watching. Pitch up in one of the many cafe's around the square and drink your mint tea.......a wonderful way to recover from the exhaustion of walking the souqs!

At night this place really comes alive. The centre of the Medina, this place is a really eclectic mix of stalls selling food, drinks and trinkets, to small traders, snake charmers and story tellers. To get a really good feel you need to be here at night, when the whole place comes alive. Lots of great different sounds, sights and smells. Highly worth a visit.

Moroccos Most Famous Square. Yes this UNESCO square is a little crazy, but you should visit the "heart" of Marrakech for some sensory overload. Visit in the morning for some shopping then return in the early evening for an authentic dining experience at one of the many stalls. Take your time to wander the square but be careful should you take a photo of one of the performers they will expect to be paid.

where the magic happens.. This was my favourite part of my trip to Morroco.The flashes of pinks and reds as i wandered through the Souks.Every trader making deals.The smell of oranges was in the air and fresh orange juice was being sold everywhere.I had the chance of seeing all the morrocan kids rush out from school to buy ice cream.But when the sky darkened and the lights came on that's where the magic happened.Snake charmers,story tellers,henna artists and dancers dotted everywhere and the hustle and bustle of a city that can't stop.Horse and a cart rides brought in more and more tourist street food was being eaten at every corner .This was the one of the best experiences of my life.
Must do. The sights and sounds you will never forget. It can be a bit intimidating but it is unique. My daughter loved the food on the stalls and said it was her favourite meal whilst in Marrakech.

Street Food to the max!. At night, it's a street food paradise! Steel your nerves, because you will be called out to by everyone there to come and eat with them. It's all a bit of fun though, don't be intimidated as I was at first. Have a laugh with them, and they will do the same. And even remember you when you come again the next night! Best calamari EVER!!

Excellent and traditional. The most important square in Marrakesh. Is a must. Be sure to try the excellent foods and check the prices before finding a place as they are different for the same food. Do not leave without drinking the famous fresh orange juice for just 40cents. The only down size if that everyone will try to sell you something. If you take a picture of the snake or monkey people they will ask for money. Avoid them.
Very life. it is a very life place, you will go there because it is the main attraction in the old city. you will be amazed by the different shows performed for tourist.
Too busy for me. There is lots going on that's interesting but be prepared for constant hawking and be on the lookout for your possessions!

Amazing night life. We eat here for two out of our three nights. Two people can eat for about £12 including soft drinks (no alcohol available). There are around 100 stalls selling hot food in the center. If you stick to bbqd meat or tagines where you can see the lumps you should be ok, we didn't try the stews. There is quite a bit of hassle from the proprieters trying to get your custom but if you remain firm but friendly it is not too bad. There are also 20 or 30 stall selling freshly squeezed orange juice - one of the highlights of our trip, plus lots of entertainment. We gave the henna women, snake charmers and monkey handlers a wide bearth but the story tellers, drummers and dancers were very entertaining

Beautiful market, quite exotic for an American . This market is the center of Marrakesh. The souks are so unlike anything you'd find at home. It is a lot of fun to simply browse the beautiful wares. Remember to bargain if you are going to buy.

Absolutly mad here at night .. We went on a Friday night and it was very atmospheric . There was music,, drumming and some dancing. The street food was excellent to eat and very cheap. I haggled for a drum but I already knew how much I wanted to pay for it max.

VERY INTERESTING PLACE. Of all the 12 places we visited in Morocco, we like Marrakesh the best of all. In Marrakesh, this is the main square where all the action is especially at night. There are food vendors, cookie salesman, guys with monkeys, snake charmers, acrobats, musicians, gambling, games of chance and general merriment and hoopla. At night, the place is wild and crazy and really busy and full of action.My suggestions: make yourself pick-pocket -proof, leave valuables at riad. Remember how to get back to your riad as once you get turned around everything looks the same! Food vendors are safe, clean and cheap so eat in the square. I would avoid the monkey guys, they were a little aggressive for tips.

A great view of a different world. We visited the square during a day trip to Marrakech. The square is hot and dusty and very atmospheric. Full of snake charmers and orange juice stalls. The snake charmers expect tips so if housetop to look, you can be sure that someone will ask for some money. The orange juice is delicious and cheap and very welcome after a hot day sightseeing. The nearby souk is fabulous

Unsettling. Extremely pushy and invasive merchants- not afraid to cross personal space by putting monkeys, snakes and henna on you with no permission and making it extremely hard to get away from a cash exchange. Once you become used to this and learn how to avoid these people it's a great experience. Rooftop restaurants and cafes are amazing with cheap food and incredible views. Thoroughly recommend getting up to one of these just before sunset and watching breaking the madness below. Overall great if you can ignore some of the less friendly and money seeking merchants and animal handlers
