Must See. Amazing experience! A real assault on the senses with sights and sounds and smells. Take care if you want to photograph snake charmers or similar as you will be expected to pay! Night market is well worth a visit. Just enjoy it and soak up the atmosphere or you can dine in one of the restaurants around the square and watch it all from the roof terraces.

A must see square in Marrakech day and night!. Jemâa el-Fna - a main pulse of Marrakech, a must visit square ( in my opinion). In our 2 nights stay we went twice, during the day and night time. In the day time the square has all kinds of activities: musicians, performers, snake charmers, fortune tellers and henna artists and you can also wonder in the surrounding souks/medina. At night the square is transformed into foodie heaven ( maybe 70+ stalls). We enjoyed the ambiance, chatting to the friendly locals, the stall owners and enjoying the delicious street foods. We felt safe and no problem walking back to our hotel past midnight

a menagerie of humanity, animals, culture, and haggling!!. The heart of the city!! It is in your face with colors, smells, a zest pool of cultures and countries all making for an unforgettable recipe. I am going to give you my tips and thought about this place. My first suggestion for where to stay would be at the Palais sabban. The hotel was a palace at one point an due to this it has a lot of ground to cover. Never the less it is traditional moroccan design. The room are unique and charming. there is a huge courtyard with a pool and amazing flower shrubs and trees. there is also a courtyard in the top, now there are no great panoramas, but many of the hotel in the area did not have any as there are no building higher than three floors. if you go to the website the photos do not do them any justice. We only stayed here for a night because we put a lot of weight on the photos, but man was I sad when we left, not only because of the palaces beauty, but because the food was amazing, and there alcoholic drinks were incredible as well as there food. I recommend the lamb tajine!! another great hotel is riad wow. the location is just as good. the service was great, breakfast was the best we had. The decor is modern morocco and did not quite have the charm of the previous. However this place was still top notch. The drinks left me wanting and expensive!! Now, remember than morocco is a muslim country and the only place you will see alcohol served everywhere. Okay, back to the Souk. We spend about 5 days touring the souk and even that was not enough time. We would be out for 5 to 8 hours at a time and even that was not enough time to see the whole place. The souk streets are amaze that intertwine back and forth and i believe local get a kick out of lost tourist scamping wildly thought the streets. so keep this in mind and give your self lot of time to explore. shopping and the souk require patience, and haggling. My advise to not buy at first sight, but compare prices with other vendors, but keep in my that is you think you'll find that shop the next day your more than likely will not find it again. There was a shop we wanted to return, but could not find again. The big seller is souks are the carpets and these can fetch astronomical prices, the king of souvenirs!! The leather is amazing, and not too badly priced. There was a shop that i found that the gentleman had his shop in the back so there was no middle men and his prices where amazing!! and the product excellent, once again i can not tell you where it is located cause i never found it again. just remember not all products are of the same quality so inspect them.The square itself. At night it is full of food vendors and tourist. try the orange juices while your there. It is the most amazing tasting and one of the cheapest thing to buys, about $1 for incredible taste and freshness. The US could only dream of having such quality!! Beware of the snakes charmer!!! Please be warn that these guys will approach you with a huge smile on their face and be uber friendly. When you ask them how much it will cost to have a photo taken they will answer "don't worry, small price" not that i believed them, but I figure what is the most that they can ask out of me, maybe $5 to 10 dollars, so I, even you might take the chance. After snapping several photos they tell you the price, which is between $25 to $50!!! and they will gang up on you and haggle you. Luckily, I only has 20 dirham, $2, on me at that point. so they vexed about this and i told them that i could erase the photo and at this point the took my $2 dollars disgusted. Now, I was not the only one that this happened to. I witnessed as these guys did this to another tourist and the same scenario as mine played out, except the guys had to borrow money from his buddies to pay them off. Be ware of people giving you "free samples" most of the time this involves food. once you bite it they will shake you down for money. Now with all this you would think that there is lots of crime and theft, but you could not be more wrong!! This morocco was one of the safest places i have traveled in and the square is the same. I would walk after dark, around 10 at night, with my camera equipment and feel at easy. There are police everywhere and guard and as much as the vendors try to extract crazy amount of money from you they provide for a safe environment.now, when it come to bargaining the only thing that I can tell you is that you should not accept the first price ever. cabs, try to agree on a price before you get on. At places that have set prices try to haggle it is part of the culture and you'll usually get it about 25% cheaper.now is you are in a large group tour and you have a guide and you go into a "co operative" let it be know that that you guide get a cut of the sale, so there for the vendor will care you more for that a item. So if you have time in marrakech it is better to come back by yourself and you get a better price. Now if that is the only evening you have at that location than use you judgment. I am not sure how much of a cut they get, but I heard that even official tour guides get a cut. Now if you take a guides tour thought your hotel they will charge you a lot more. Our official guide in Fez was only $15 and he was amazing, and his english was second to none. He had also being Ronald regan guide in the 80's. So my time in marrakech was great. i have a great time at Jemaa el fna, but I was glad to move on. The souk will try you patience and good will, but I am glad to have done it. hope this helps someone!

Souk Square. Wow, what an experience! Each day is a delight with something exotic waiting around the corner.If it is just for sightseeing, or haggling in the many shops or drinking and eating all the varieties of delicious food, you have to come to the square with a relaxed attitude to enjoy this carnival square.Kuki ☺

'The Sizzle of Marrakech'. Without a doubt, a visit to this vast square at night is an assault of the senses. The sheer size accommodates the many 'food stalls' where local food is cooked on the premises; clients sit at large tables on long benches; the hubbub of the total activities around; the vendors with barrows selling 'desserts'; all contribute to the atmospherics.At the 'stalls' you choose from the menu, then are asked if you'd like other food items - beware these are not included in the original price, but expensive extras. The dishes and cutlery are washed in a bath on the premises!Other restaurants are around the square; some accessed by two flights of stairs ( no handrail nor disabled access). Assertive 'Touts' vie for business to the restaurants and shops.Groups of 'Berbers' local folk in Berber costume, sit in circles with their musical instruments and invite you to sit and listen. A small donation is appreciated. The Square in daytime, is minus the food stalls, but has stalls selling fruit, dates, figs, fruit drinks. Vendors 'on the hoof' sell mobile 'phones, watches, toys. Cafe, Le Classico, is good for snacks at reasonable prices.Adjacent to the square are the horse drawn carriages available for hire. The brasses are well polished and the horses in good condition.

Crazy lively square!!. Monkeys, acrobats, men dressed as women dancing, snake charmers, food, juice snails!!! This square has to all!! A bit of hassle towards tourists that stand out. You have to come here to experience it though.

a special place, Moroccan to its core. I visited it both during the day in the afternoon and in the evening, after dark. it's filled with Moroccan traditions and culture. you can have juice all day, but the food stands and the real feel of the square can be felt only after sunset. worth seeing.

Entertaining snapshot of the culture. The square is filled with street food vendors, musicians, snake charmers, fortune tellers, henna applicators, boxing and more! Very colorful. Book a seat at one of the terrace restaurants that overlook the square for a birds eye view.

Eat at one of the local food courts. Djemaa el Fna is an awesome place. Vibrant and full of magic. You can see snakes. My tip: eat dinner at the one of the food courts, it is the best food you can get in Marrakech.

Very unsafe, full of examples of horrific animal abuse. One of the worst experiences in Morocco. A classic tourist trap - during two long walks through Jemaa el Fna we were approached by literally dozens of people trying (sometimes successfully) to scam us. They act like friends at first and offer help or advice, but soon they ask for money, sometimes very aggressively. The place is also filled with the worst examples of animal abuse I saw in a while - beaten monkeys kept in dirty cages, de-fanged, mutilated snakes, small shops offering young chameleons and hedgehogs in various stages of physical deterioration. Zero stars. I hope that local authorities will do something about that sad, shameful tourist attraction.

Tourists 4 Eyes and Patience!. This is very buzzing and Noisy place where women should walk with their bags in the front. Since people kind of harras you to sell stuff. You say no and still they will be coming on. Beware of the monkeys they supposed to sometimes take things from you. I really did not like this place at night better in the afternoon where you can see plenty of things going on but without feeling uncomfortable.

Worth a visit but a real tourist trap. The famous square is of course worth a visit - but keep your wits about you!If a henna lady gets a hold of your hand or a dancer/acrobat sees you watching be prepared to fork out! At night the place comes alive with food stalls - they're all selling the exact same thing and become quite aggressive in their attempts to drag you to their stalls! The orange juice stalls are great and cheap - but make sure you specify orange or they'll serve you a 'mixed-fruit' juice and charge you much more. Steer well clear of the poor, sad and sick looking monkeys being dragged about by chains on their necks. The animal mistreatment here is truly heartbreaking!!

crowded. a bit scary. big market. its really crowded place. scary sometimes. but its a must sea place. food shops doesn't look so clean. you can sea snakes shows, scenes... etcits a must sea place in Marrakech
Excellent. A must visit. Its not just a square square. So much goes on here: Horse drawn carts, food stalls etc. Also the gateway to the madina

A must see!. Everybody should visit this at least once in their lives- you will either love it or hate it!During the daytime Jemaa el Fna is a busy thoroughfare, bustling with, horses, traffic and tourists. However as dusk falls Jemaa el Fna transforms into a vibrant hive of activity with some of the best food stalls in Marrakech, snake charmers, teeth pullers, and henna tattooists- hold on to you handbags and be per armed to be hassled!!!

Very interesting.. After walking through the dark alleyways which contain most of the souks, Jemma square is the light at the end of the tunnel.Around its edges contain some great cafes and restaurants and riads.We stayed in a great riad, but I would rather of been based around Jemma el fna square.Fantastic rooftop resteraunts with ridiculous prices, the hustle n bustle let's you know that civilisation as you know it is a long way off.If you need to wake up and smell the coffee you have to do it here in morroco.

Bit overrated ...... Personally think this attraction is a bit overrated. There are stalls and vendors on the square all day, but it is the evening when the place really livens up, with the food stalls popping up and the musicians really getting into their stride. However, I think if you removed the food stalls, juice stalls, henna ladies and people selling argan oil, there would be very little left - just a couple of snake charmers, photo-op people with monkeys or traditionally dress water carriers, the odd troupe of acrobats, few musicians, few vendors of pottery nik-naks and metal tea lights and that's about it.Seems quite popular with locals as well as tourists though and I guess if you're in Marrakesh, you have to visit the square at least once. There are lots of cafes and restaurants around the square, some with terraces, so you can view the square whilst dining. Felt safe and at ease, but ladies, don't allow any of the henna ladies to get hold of your hand, unless you want to have a henna tattoo and are willing to haggle a price for their service - I gather they can be quite aggressive and unpleasant to deal with, but have no direct experience in this area.To me, the souks are much more interesting and offer a great deal more.

Shocking and Alarming - We're Going Back :). Humanity as it should be. No nanny state health and safety rules about not stepping on the cobra or letting the monkey hug you - you just have to take responsibility for your own actions in this complete upstage of anything PT Barnum could have ever imagined. Be ready to be pitched to repeatedly for everything on display. Don't take photos of people unless you want to annoy them or pay big money for the privilege. Just dive in and enjoy the spectacle of snake charmers, monkey wranglers, story tellers, musicians, food and henna stalls, juice makers and maybe 150 barbecue stalls. Every day of the year - nothing stops the Square.
Great street theater. Jemaa el Fna is travelled through every day by locals and Moroccans, and tourists. From snake charmers to musicians, storytellers and lots of food, there is much to see.
Amazing. Wow what a fantastic place to visit. Not for the faint hearted mind. Always keep walking to the right or you run the risk of hit by a scooter ! .

Must to see Arabian Bazaar. It is very interesting to see local market and several local attractions. You can also try real local food. Be careful, there are many pretty aggressive traders. You could get easily henna on your hand not really willing it. But the fresh juice is great. We had it twice a day. Be also careful with local "voluntary" guides. In reality you have to pay for everything and they will bring to different shops with whom they have contracts!

Amazing . If you're in Marakesh or nearby you have to experience Jema El Fna. Absolutely amazing culture and scenery. Don't be put off about beggars scammers etc. Myself and my friend went (both 23) & didn't get any bother. Just say thank you & carry on walking.

Unique Experience. This place is full of everything, from Henna tattoos and orange juice to monkeys on chains. If you can barter and don't mind what might be described as a busy crowd, this is full of sights and smells and sounds which will overwhelm your senses. In the evenings it lights up and you can buy anything you can think from the multitude of vendors. Especially nice place to eat, whether you want adventurous food from a market stall to watch in peace from a rooftop terrace. Probably get offered Hashish and vendors are pushy if you're a tourist, but no more so than in the souks - a strong no will always make them leave you alone. One henna tattooist did grab my girlfriends wrist so hard she left a mark, but once you're used to behaviour you might not see in the UK (for example) it is a wonderful place that never fails to intrigue. Spectacular.

Best at night. The noise and light of the square of an evening are something else. Traditional Berber music, fire, water carriers, snake charmers and men with monkeys along side the busy Souks.A wonderful mix of old and new, home made crafts and Nike trainers.Careful if you don't want to be harassed, cover up and politely say non merci or la shukran.I prefer Souk shopping in the morning but a wander around the square of an evening is great (there are a lot of stalls there in the day too but no atmosphere).You can see why this is a Unesco world heritage site!

There is no other place like...Jemaa el Fna. Jemaa El Fna, is the main square of the market place of Marrakech’s Medina.It is, what makes Marrakech famous.I will also add that it has to be the most known attraction in Morocco.You are also surrounded by roof top terraces, restaurants, the market entrances, a range of juice stalls and handcarts that are piled with dates, dried figs and a range of nuts that are freshly picked from the local countryside.The main square itself, is a huge open space that quickly fills in the late afternoon with a plethora of acts.These will fluctuate from an assortment of local medicine men, musicians, water bearers, story- tellers, acrobats, monkey tamers, snake charmers and the list goes on…Be careful and be aware of the procedure here, of taking photographs.You need to respect the local artists and they will expect payment.This is primarily their main source of income. Set your price and do not change it.50 Dirham, is the standard price for a photo at the time of this posting.Ten photo’s for 50 cents AUD, is very cheap for you and virtually costs nothing.On the other hand, it provides a living for the locals, helps their economy and individual feed their family.

Must see in Marrakech; listen to some stories!. This is the place in Marrakech where you can still find 1001 nights of stories and food you have not discovered yet! Watch the artists and listen to their stories, music and buy some of their art.
Exuberant!!!. What a place! Full of life and action. Cannot be described enough by words. Truly you have to be there to appreciate it.

All goes around it. You can't say you've been to Marrakech if you haven't been to Jamma el Fna.This is the real center of the city where everything happens. Food trucks, artists, people selling waters and lanterns you can find everything you want here.Spend some time walking through the stands or having a rest on the terrace of the restaurant facing the place.

Awe sme souk. Jaml_fna is the main attraction of marrakech'this place get busy after 5pm'sunday is jam packed due to public holiday.try food stall no 42.for awesome lamb dishes and green tea'highley recommended'and in jaml_fna'between 11 am to 2pm go to lamb Ali f awesome dry lamb'which is tender and tasty.there r shops f dry fruits every where.

Experience Real Marrakech. The square is an attack on all the senses, but if you can handle the culture shock you will have an experience unlike any other place in the world. Grab a roof top cafe and enjoy watching below for hours, or get in the midst of a true market place.

A must see, but it can be overwhelming. In my opinion, after a brief walk through the square, the best way to enjoy Jemaa el Fna is on a rooftop terrace. I would recommend Cafe France or L'ancien Cafe. The square is the hub of Marrakech, where traders sell their wares and food from stalls. Based on reviews, we decided not to eat at any stalls as some of them are not hygienic. As with every tourist spot in Marrakech, you will be bothered by people and traders who see Western tourists as easy pickings to sell things to. If you relax and accept the culture difference, you will normally find that a smile and a polite "la shukran" (no thanks) is enough, but with others, it is necessary to be slightly firmer - however, do keep in mind that the tradition of trade is so established in this culture that the people can seem pushy and sometimes even rude. It is the unfortunate consequence of tourism that you will hear things like "Cheap as chips" and "That's Asda price!". If you do want to buy something from the traders in the square - as you'll know from the first research of Marrakech - the initial price is hugely inflated. Bartering is a way of life here and prices are only rarely displayed for small souvenirs. There are government owned shops for those who aren't confident in their haggling abilities. The two we found are called Centre de Artisanals and one can be found across from the Cyberpark on Mohammed V ave - the other is at the bottom of Rue de Kasbah across from the souk there. You cannot avoid Jemaa el Fna, so try and enjoy the experience.
Busy Busy. Great atmosphere, but everybody trying to con you out of your money. Trow a snake around your and aggressively harass for money for photo.

Spent most time here!. Loved the square....perfect for shop lovers. Able to pick up good bargains but need to haggle quite a bit. The people are nice and friendly. We went with young children during early days of January and had a pushchair and had no problems. I think during peak times between march-august it is busy so the pushchair might be a problem but can't say for sure.

Crazy Place!. The first time we visited this square was on an afternoon. It was relatively calm with a few snake charmers and women offering henna etc. It was not the cleanest place and i found nothing very exciting about it. Had afternoon tea in the Argana cafe which is lovely.Night time is very different with large groups drumming, boxing, gambling, you name it, it's going on. The street food stalls were amazing, there were so many of them and the smells were mouthwatering. You do not know what to choose.It was an experience i'm glad i've had but would not rush back.

Interesting view of life in Marrakesh.. The sights, sounds and smells here are overwhelming.During the day the music is constant, from the snake charmers to acrobats playing instruments. In the evening the music dies down but the number of people increases as the market transforms in to row after row of mini eateries.In the heat of the day, pick one of the coffee shops on the edge like the Cafe de France. Sit, enjoy coffee, absorb the atmosphere and then later brave the chaos.At night the square changes entirely, but do eat here. If worried, choose food that's well cooked and eat like a local.Before we travelled, we had read up on the square and were well prepared to be pestered. Thankfully things have improved. Just bear in mind that a lot of the people make their money from the pictures you take of them. Be respectful. Set your price, do not budge and you'll be good.One last thing, local guides a really worth it. They will get you round quickly, help with any annoying people and are a great way to find out more about local culture.

Very busy market. Don't get suckered into paying money when you are forcibly given a snake to hold, or a henna tattoo. Bargain as much as you can. If the price is 100, offer 20, you'll pay about 50, sometimes a lot less.

Huge Square. It's a huge square with lots of people & entertainers. Other TA contributors have written plenty. I will add that the square has a money changer that seemed to give the best rates of exchange. It was recommended by our tour guide & is open 24/7. Location is just past the Poste Medina & has a lighted exchange board on a pillar, usually has a queue.

Fantastic Experience - especially at Night. Great Experience, especially at night - You must go here if you visit Marrakesh. The Smell of food, the sound of Music - You feel like they are putting a show on just for you - but it is everyday life in this Square.
Must visit . Well it's sort of centre of Marrakech. Seems like everything starts from here and end here too. You cannot miss this place and if you do then it means you haven't been to Marrakech.

Nice busy place but some of the people can be annoying . Lovely place to visit but you have a lot of people coming up to you either to sell something or want some money. The beggars try and sell packets of tissues to you but instead really want the money. The other way people try and get money is they send there young toddlers up to you and then you cant refuse in giving them something. The snake charmers are no good at all, its all a waste of time. Just for taking a photo of the snake you can be charged. I took some photos and the man realised and he came up to me and said "give me 20 dirhams" i said "for what" he said "you took picture" i said am not paying 20 dirhams nope" . Then he said "delete photos now, delete, delete ". I listened to him but as soon as i got back to hotel I retrieved them from my deleted items. Everywhere you go money money money. Even to use the toilets. You can get lovely fresh orange juices here just for 4 dirhams.
Wonderful atmosphere! . If in Marrakech, make sure you stop by this famous square with its different food experiences and thousands of souk merchants!

Recommend stall 31&32. Jemaa el Fna is best to visit at night because the square really comes alive at this time. The best food stalls in my opinion are 31 or 32 because they serve traditional morrocan food at a great price (they don't overcharge tourists like other places). All the other stalls serve almost the same food.

Go with empty pockets (or they'öö be emptied for your). Food is very poor and expensive. Juice is very poor and expensive. Go for a quick look but don't stay and don't take your wallet if you want to keep it!

Eat like a native!. When we are in Marrakesh we always eat at least twice in the Square. We like stall 98. The food though is great value and the choices amazing no matter which stall you eat from and all are regulated. It's a very good way of trying loads of different dishes like barbecued goat and chicken, flat breads, sauces and dips, salads and tagines all in 'taster' sized portions, without spending a fortune while soaking up the atmosphere and the culture of 'real' Morocco at the same time. It also helps when eating out in restaurants later because you may then recognize some of the dishes. The Square looks like organized chaos when you enter it and it is! but don't worry about the constant calls from the various stall holders to come and eat at their particular stall - just take a 'browse' up and down the rows first and then decide. And if you don't like the 'hassle' of it all, well then you shouldn't be in Morocco full stop.

Crowded!. It was surprisingly crowded place. The seller was nice but they offer a dramatically high price. Youd better try to bargain and cut the price at least a half of their prices! it's true, because in the first time they told the price was 650dirham, but eventually they gave me 200dirham.And be careful! if you want to do a "henna" in your body, youd better to see the price first!!!!!!!!!!!! dont let them to draw a henna until you decide which pattern and price you want. otherwise, youd be surpried........... I was charged 500dirham (in the catalog said that it was 800dirham) for only lefthand henna. I was so disappointed with this treatment. they just grabbed my hand and did the henna before I said so. and, I was so guilty why didnt I see the price first :(Important message, dont let anyone to guide you. because they will ask for money and money. dont feel intimidated. just walk confidently through the crowd, have your map in your smartphone or paper so you dont need anyone else help. If you are lost, just call the person incharge of the place you are heading to. Hope this help :)

Go and have fun. Just have fun, avoid during Morning and Noon time. Even better when it is not rainy. Suggest you to wear boots or a flat shoes need to walk quiet a bit around and also carry 20 MAD in smaller change to give tips in case.

jemma el fna . in our opinion, it's very cultural and magical on evenings. However, it's not everyone's cup of tea as it can come across very intimidating and if you buy anything you can easily get ripped off... As long as you keep your wits about you, it's amazing.

Market madnes. It seems as though the main market square is a must visit when in Marrakech , well it is. I made a point of going there shortly after our arrival and hotel check in at the Sofitel ( see review ). Having read about it before hand I was expecting to get hassled by sellers and children offering to guide you through the many passage ways for a small price. Be aware you do get hassled but they are only trying to make a living. Have fun , be polite, tell then maybe later , maybe much later , they will laugh with you, your not the first person to walk buy, enjoy it, take it in. I was offered a lovely Morrocan tea set for 150 mad , so I'm going back for a couple at 70 mad each . The passages are vast, and we got seriously lost, we decided at this point to sit down and eat , just a lite snack and to refresh , my beef tagine with prunes and apricots was delicious . Salad , tagine , olives , bread , Coke , and sliced oranges with cinnamon and sugar , oh! And mint tea for two people came to just 130 mad ( appx £9 ) really !!!!! . The guys were happy and pleasant , the food was good, happy days. After being told how to get back to the main square and after a lovely horse and cart ride ( I happily agreed 100 mad , probably could of bartered him down but hey ☺️) back to the hotel we returned that evening before our restaurant reservation at Le Strass ( see review ). The evening at the square was so different , I had realised that food sellers would be there then but not to this extent , OMG. The people , the food ( we are going there to eat tonight , tagines, mixed grill, kebabs, mussels . Prices looked so cheap 40-50 mad for a meal . A little girl was selling what looked like macaroons for just 1 mad each , I tried one , they taste lovely , I bought 4 , she was very happy and she was over the moon when I gave her 20 mad , smiled at her and told her to keep it . Definitely taking a box of 20 or 30 of those home . The orange juice sellers offer fresh juice at 4 mad but make sure you tell them you want 4 mad orange juice otherwise you get mixed juice at 10 mad. I don't like being had , I told them that and got my 4 mad juice. I play the game fair but you can't kid a kidder ( or London taxi driver as I am best in the world we are X

Exhilerating. Great place to really feel like you have escaped the bland UK for a few days. During the day it's mostly just the souk and cafes lining the square. During the night, it comes alive with the food stalls and music, especially if you're lucky to visit during one of the local festive days. Walk around the food stalls and don't be intimidated by the hawkers and stall "ushers" who were universally friendly if a little mad. Look for stalls where Moroccans are eating and not just tourists. There are some stalls that offer something different and it's usually worth looking out for them. definitely try the slow-cooked goat's head!

Sensory overload!. I like the vibe especially at night when the food market opens. Do try out some of the food and snacks.Be careful of the snake charmers and the guy carrying monkey. They were very persistent to ask for tips although you are not interested to take photos with the animals.Lively atmosphere.
The hub of the medina. This is the place to be in Marakkesh. Here is where you find the attractions for tourists and alot of places to shop and eat.

Hustle and Bustle but worth it. The hustle, bustle and comical sayings to get into shops...I was called Lady gaga and Hanna Montana- despite the fact Im black. This lively square is great for people wanting a good deal and laugh.

"All of the above". Yes it's nuts. Yes it is amazing. Yes you will get pestered to death every 30 seconds to buy something or try something...and, yes, you will see cobras and flute players, and chained monkeys etc. But, this is THE place to go in the evening in Marrakech! It comes alive as the sun goes down. Walk to the square from Koutoubia mosque, pass the horse-drawn carts waiting for customers, and enter another world. The smell from the food stalls, the noise from the banging drums, the view of the minaret lit up at night...these are the reasons you travel. We would recommend having a drink high up at one of the many places with balconies and terraces for a relaxing view of the square while you chill and wonder wether or not you could improve your haggling skills and got your recent purchase for a few dirhams less. Not coming here on your visit would be like going to Paris and not going up the Eiffel Tower.

A square of miracles. You can see everything, snakes, monkeys, dendists, musicians and when the dark come it is transformed in a huge restaurant.You can smell everything, dirt and fragnances, horses and delicious food.Something a traveller should not miss.

markets are great, but the square itself is filled with terrible hagglers. The markets surrounding the open square are great, but the aggressive hagglers in the middle of the square are extremely annoying. It was especially hard because I was traveling with three other girls, and although we did our best to not stand out, it was obvious that we were from the U.S.- this made us a target. My friend was grabbed and had a monkey shoved on her shoulder, and our hands were grabbed for henna with out our consent. After this experience, we just stayed away from the middle of the square and walked around it. Negotiating for prices is also something to always keep in mind because they do try to sell items for ridiculous prices.

5 stars because you can't miss this.... This place is crazy nuts. You have to go and experience it first hand. Don't miss this; go once during the day and once at night. It is a chaotic, loud, crazy; everyone is in your face or following you around. Don't miss trying the boiled snails and the orange juice. Take pictures on the sly or you will be harassed.

Interesting but very touristy. We came here once and that was enough- we'd seen it. There are snake charmers and men with monkeys- really didn't like any of that- and generally people selling tacky stuff. There are a lot more beautiful things to see in Marrakech!

Don't forget to HAGGLE. So many shops to buy different things...from original to fake.So many many eating and drinking places...So much attraction...miles better than Convent Garden of London!Take a stroll, relax or take a horse carriage trip round the place!

Good for people watching!. We went out of season so it was quite possibly a bit quieter than normal but still a good atmosphere with the usual snake charmers etc, Top tios, the orange juice is a bargain at 4dirham and very tasty. Steer clear of the monkeys and snakes etc if you don't want to be approached, you can get good pictures from the roof top cafes with a zoom. Ladies keep your hands in your pockets when near the henna tattoo ladies if you don't want to risk an unwanted tattoo.. heard a story of one lady trying to ask for 600dirham for one so if you get one agree the price (in writing) in advance. We did eat at one of the street stalls in the centre, stuck to the grilled skewers but be careful a/they will put food infront of you and if you accept it you get charged, if they try and give you something extra that you don't want then give it back and b/ check your bill.. even if they add it up on paper infront of you, ours tried to charge 495 dirham which I knew was wrong, as soon as I questioned it and asked for a menu to add it up myself they left me to it and just accepted what I said it should be! 270 dirham ! (Stall 15) !!
Amazing. This is the one place you should visit in Marrakesh, it changes from a quiet square into an amazing site at nights with all the food stall, snake charmers etc

A Place Where You Can Time-Travel.... Well, this is something! I have been to this place several times and it still gives me shivers... I doubt there is another place in the world that gives you such an intense feeling of being alive. With all yours senses occuppied and overwhelmed. The best time to visit is (of course) right after the sunset. An experience incomparable to anything else.

Nuts. No snake charmers a or belly dancing whence were here but the vibe is great and so is food but not cheap as chips_ good and well priced but don't expect cheaper than the stalls a bit further out

Amazing. I stayed in Marrakech with my girlfriend and the main square is brilliant. So much fruit juice for amazingly low prices. Always something going on all day and night. And at night the food stalls throughout the square do great tagines and couscous dishes.

Hectic by Day but 'Buzzing' by night, must be Experienced to Believe. By day the main square is busy and hectic, alive with hawkers, performing monkeys and snake charmers. Many people shouting their wares or vying for your attention. Avoid eye contact if you are not interested and don't stop to watch the snake charmers/performing monkeys unless you are prepared to give some money. The same goes for taking photographs - NOTHING in Morocco is free!By night the square comes alive with noise, colour and smells (mostly nice), a real assault on the nostrils. There are many 'pop-up' restaurants. The food looks and smells incredible but we were warned against eating there. The locals have stronger stomachs than tourists. There are many bars and restaurants surrounding/overlooking the square to choose from. The square is a meeting place for locals at night and is VERY busy.It really has to be experienced to believe it!

Chaotic and hyped. For us there was just too much going on around. And the fact that you cannot take a snap without being hassled ( even when you are taking a generic picture and not a particular act or person) does not leave a good taste.Even when you tip an act they would haggle you for more money.Its worth a short vigilant visit but thats it.May be having a local guide with you would improve the experience.
Pintoresque. You can find snake charmers, storytellers, street musicians and dancers, water sellers, soothsayers and an endless parade of colourful characters:

Pretty Good. The square here, is clean and looks well organised and well policed. went there 2 or 3 times and it is worth to go at different times of the day as there are different activities. Be aware that photography is not liked by all. They also want payment. keep an eye on all valuables at all times.

Good for cheap street food, that's about it. I visited Jemma el Fna a couple of times during my stay in Marrakech. Once during the day and the other at night. There are snake charmers and monkey tamers in the square - none of which appealed to me, I think it's plain cruel. The poor snakes looked lifeless and monkeys are chained around the necks which are constantly getting pulled by their handlers. Also beware of the women applying henna, negotiate prices first else they will just grab your hand and start to apply.The shopkeepers too, will try charging extortionate amounts for items which can cost a lot less in Rahba Kedima (always remember to haggle wherever you go). To be honest, I think Jemma el Fna is only good for cheap street food (stalls opened in evenings) and drinks. There are many stalls selling fresh fruit juices costing only 4dhs. As I'd mentioned earlier, Rahba Kedima square is a lot cheaper for purchasing souvenirs. It seemed to be the place where the locals did their grocery shop as well - there were plenty of spice markets around and fruit and veg stalls. Madressa Ben Youssef is also in the same area which is worth taking a look at. It is inevitable that you will get lost within the souk, the signposts aren't particularly helpful so you will just have to have a bit of a walk around to get out. Be prepared to get gawped at by the men too.The alleys are narrow and scooters are always riding past, as well as donkey drawn carts so do be careful!
Surreal. Pretty stressful for most, everyone shoves stuff in your face to sell it, a bunch of people will follow you around, but unique and fun.
Busy. Beautiful place..beware of the cheaters..and the people with poor animals like snakes and monkeys. Orange juice very cheap only 4 dirham

A great place for dinner. The main square is the heart of the medina and is the perfect spot for dinner each night. It has a number of pop up restaurants as well as being circled by restaurants and cafes. There are also a number of great performers and stalls in the square. Unfortunately, there are also a number of animal based attractions.

1001 nights experience. What a great square to stroll around by day and by night, a wonderful and amazing experience with snake storytellers, local food stalls, animation with apes, pure enchantment some where between the Middle Ages and modern times.
Cultural experience of different Moroccan cultures.. An amazing place at night. Dancers, palm readers, henna artists; Chez Hassan food stall; Honey covered nuts; Fresh orange juice

La Place: The buzzing heart of Marrakech. Oranges, figs, snakes, lamps, beggars, toddlers, tourists, bikes, carts, voices, shouts, music, dance: this is the heart of the city, a must visit for each visitor of Marrakech!

Busy and full of colours. Nice place. Must visit during day and evening. Stay away from snake charmers and do not take photo with them or snakes. They will charge you to take photo. Haggle hard if u want to buy something. Start with 1/3 of the price people offer. Do not pay more than half of what the guy asks to buy clothes or anything else. Taxi is only 20/30 dirham. Don't pay more than that. Stay away from guides they will mug u off. Buy a watch for 30dh. Try horse ride

There is no other place like that one. You have to go several times to this square.You will always discover something different. One has to eat at least one time at the open booths. Food is good andso cheap. Be careful when negotiating prices. There is a lot of room. One has to go there when the sun sets or in the night. The el Fna is surrounded by good cafes and restaurants. So take your time. From El Fna you reach all Soukhs and all Soukhs at the end arrive at this square.

An assault on all of your senses..... The smells, the fresh OJ sellers, the touts, the snake handlers, the adhān call to prayer, the henna tattooers, the Berber drummers, the food, the carriages.....its all here for your sensory pleasures. An amazing experience which can be overwhelming upon first stepping foot in Jemaa el Fna, but one which you will thoroughly enjoy once the initial shock to your system has worn off. No trip to Marrakech is complete without experiencing this most important square. Must see!

Best place to eat in Marrakech. The market place is a wonderful place to visit. The sights, smells and sounds are captivating. This is also the best place to grab a bite to eat as the square is full of food stalls selling a variety of hot and cold dishes at low prices. Sadly our experience was once again spoilt by overdemanding locals. Who, on two occassions actually got angry with us when we didnt part with our money! If only these people realised that we would gladly spend our money and look at their stalls if they werent so aggresively trying to make a sale!

What kind of person are you?. I'm not going to lie... this place is bonkers! If you are looking for an in your face market experience with a touch of animal cruelty you will find it. If you are, however, looking for a quiet coffee and a panoramic view of the madness you can find that too. It is very much a place to choose your own adventure. I would suggest a few quiet beers at Cafe Arabe before diving into the food markets in the evening. You can find an absolute throng of food stalls at night serviced by boisterous individuals who have a rehearsed and at times hilarious patter. My highlight would have to have been "mushy bloody peas". It is all a little same same but different but if you can find the courage it is well worth it. The atmosphere alone is worth the cheap price of the Moroccan style tapas. I would suggest that you keep an eye and maybe both hands on your personal belongings if you intend to immerse yourself in the crowds. Allegedly pick pockets are rife within the square at night but we seem to have gotten away unscathed so far (unless you take buying trinkets in the souks into consideration). I can see how the square would not be everybody's cup of sweet mint tea but it is a fascinating place to visit.

Must See in Marrakech. This is the place if you want to find souvenirs from Morocco or just to have a sensory overload. I'd go further away from the main square to get better deals though. When you're there watch out for people putting monkeys on you and snake charmers. Also, I wouldn't recommend getting henna done there either. My husband decided he wanted to take a photo with 2 cobras (he was in the background but he angled it so it looked like he was close to them). One of the guys grabbed his phone and took a few photos. My husband gave the man equivalent to $5 but he demanded $20. We weren't giving them another dime so hubby snatched the phone back and we got out of there.It's definitely an interesting experience. My advice is to go to one of the rooftop cafes surrounding the square, grab a soft drink or tea (they make you buy something of course but don't expect to pay more than $2-4), and enjoy the view from a distance.

All Moroccan goodness gathered in one place!. Food, accessories, herbs, henna artists, fresh juice kiosks and antiques all in this festive place which is up almost all day long.. Don't leave without trying their food and fresh citrus juices

go in the day. straight in straight out. jemaa el fna just like most other places in marrakech is a bit of a dump especially at night. during the day its full of drugged snakes, chained up monkeys that need a wash and one guy in a suit doing the same dance all day long. you will find kids and women who will follow you around begging till the point you either snap or someone else snaps. the women will even go to the point of taking out their breasts to show you she cant breast feed and needs money for milk for her kids.at night the square is full of pick pockets and people selling old food that will poison you if you are not careful. the food is old and out all evening covered in flies and they will bring the same old food out again the next night and sell it again.one day i seen two snake charmers place a snake on a man whose wife naively took a picture and they then held him physically and forced him to give them money and even when he handed them 20 dirham they got more agressive till he handed them 100 to let go of him.one another occasion a man tried to place a monkey on a lady but she said no so he throw the monkey at her for it to jump onto her back, she jumped out of the way and shouted at him so he approached her as if he was going beat her up so she walked away quite upset.the horses are all stationed in one place and it absolutely stinks, the horse look malnurised and the drivers are hustlers and will rip you off at the first chance

Fun place . Two sides to this place during the morning a great market with souk and open market style, snake charmers monkey men and Berber men, at night it turns into a massive dinner hall with food stalls popping up everywhere, we are the big mamas place nice food great peopleBeware of the people trying to get you to wear there traditional Berber hats and take a picture as they will charge you what they want and this can cause issues don't try or talk best way and say no thanks

Wow - there is so much to look at. This square was full of things to look at. Monkeys, snake charmers, entertainers and more. There was so many food stalls and market stalls. I loved all the people and atmosphere. I did struggle a bit with all of the continuous attempts to sell me things. Maybe someone needs to tell the sales people a lot of Australian's don't like to haggle but more importantly feel harassed to buy something. If I could look and ask questions without the big sell I know I would have bought more. So for something interesting and fun. Yes. Just be prepared to be tempted insistently to make a purchase.

Moroccan icon. Almost no picture or documentary of Morocco is void off this square. It has become the icon of Morocco. It is bustling with everything be it snack and food shops, snake charmers, performers, singers, etc. It also has a unique blend of visitors ranging from locals to tourists from all over. I ate some snails that were sold there. They were ok for a taste.

Crazy, chaotic fun. Hit this spot up at night for a real taste of crazy Marrakech. Obviously catering for tourists, we had to barter hard but the food was good and the atmosphere electric. Careful walking down the aisles of food tents as you will be grabbed from all angles and coaxed inside by different vendors. However the food is fantastic and make sure you try a fresh orange juice as well. As with other places be wary of pickpockets!
lots going on!. Absolutely amazing place, comes alive in the evening.so much to see, theres monkeys, snakes, horse and carriages and best of all the Soukes.

Mr Tung Tran . Too noise too much but hey we are in North Africa. Moroccan and Muslim country .becarefull with guys menus on hands and sweat talking in market( they are very push : food not always good as they said to you and you can get overcharge .so stall number :53 Husain was my choice .

Good to see in the evening as well as daytime. We visited the square during the day and in the evening when it takes on a different atmosphere. It reminded me of Hull fair in the evening without the rides. The smell of food cooking on the stalls and seeing the crowds gathered around listening to the story tellers was a memorable experience. We sat in the rooftop cafe of the Cafe de France where we had a good view of all that was going on.

Oldest active market place in the civilized world. I believe this is the oldest market still functioning since the one in Constantinople is no longer. It is worth visiting and seeing the social culture of Marrakech displayed in the square. It's open and empty by day and crowded with food stalls juice stalls dining open air community tables, and families and kids and young people, tourists... Unfortunately the tourists get a hard court press for pictures with snakes monkeys, cheap trinkets... All for money. Keep politely refusing and go sit and drink a juice or sit upstairs on the terrace of one of the several dining places and drink tea and watch the sunset...

The Times Square of Morocco. Jemaa el Fna is the Times Square of Morocco — crowded, crowded, crowded. Enjoy all of the performers and keep your hands in your pockets, as pickpockets abound. I've seen Jemaa el Fna on many people's can't-miss list. But don't worry, you can miss it.

Life in microcosm. Jemaa el Fna is a must-see for visitors to Marrakesh, since it showcases Moroccan life in microcosm: traders selling a plethora of goods; snake charmers; henna artists; tame monkeys to name a few. Fresh orange juice is a steal at a few dirhams per glass, food stalls offer local specialities and the square is ringed by restaurants and cafes with open-air terraces overlooking the action. Expect to be approached by vendors offering their wares, but banter is good-natured and a polite rebuff readily accepted. As in any crowded space, take care of your belongings but, for atmosphere, Jemaa el Fna after dark is a spectacular sight.

Moroccan Time's Square - chaotic, crazy, fun.. The orange juice for only 5 dirham has spoiled me forever. I may never enjoy OJ again. The snake charmers are exactly as I expected; the men drumming and dancing were fun to watch; the food was delicious; the gambling was surprising. This place is full of surprises and can be overwhelming. My family visited for two days and were in love with it and in hate with it depending on the moment. We did have one poor experience where a henna artist grabbed my daughter's arm and would not let go. She forced her art upon my daughter and we had to pry her off... she was physically manhandling my daughter and I literally pried her fingers up. This one event colored my daughter's view of the place.Had this event not happened I think we all would have had a better experience and opinion of the place.

Smoke,snakes, snails and spells. A feast for your eyes as well as your belly, Jemaa el Fna is a clamour of colour, and a wild carnival of snake charmers, fortune tellers, dancers, boxers and mad musicians . Sip the soup of spicy snails, take your pick from the stalls that will try to capture your business. Be there for the sun going down. You will know you have left Europe behind and you are now in the swirling wild world of North Africa.
Great atmosphere. Drink orange juice and see snake charmers during the day, eat great BBQ food at night. Jemaa el Fna is at the heart of Marrakech.

That's incredible. It's difficult to describe this square with only words: it is a mixture of purfumes, sounds, people and culture.During the day and the night a lot of people walk here bargaining the price of several items (olives, pastries, food, cooked snails, spices, snakes) and the voices of the Muezins praying can be heard at scheduled hours five times a day
Weird yet Wonderful!. Do you want to enter another century of snake charmers, belly dancers, and sellers of all wares? Grab a glass of freshly-squeezed fruit juice and some native food!

Never eat lukewarm chicken!. I love Jemaa el Fna, and spend time there every time I visit Marrakech. The grilled food is outstanding at night, and the orange juice definitely worth a try during the day. At all times of day and night the square is well worth a stroll. Despite my 5-star review of the square itself, I'd recommend sticking to the grilled lamb and avoiding the chicken. On our last visit, a group of us came away with two kinds of food poisoning from lukewarm chicken - the only time in my life I've been poisoned and I've eaten in all kinds of dodgy places!

Crazy, busy square yet good vibe. The atmosphere is so hard to describe but it's definitely busy and chaotic at times... in general it was a good experience and would be going back here again but not in the near future.

The heart of old Marrakech. This square is crowded and noisy even in the down season. Tourists are everywhere, as are hucksters, snake charmers, dancers, henna women, and more. Everywhere you go you'll be approached by people asking for money or trying to sell you things. Get into the mood and soak up the electricity in the air. Sample spectacular foods at the carts, or sit in a cafe and watch people go by. You'll be amazed at what you can see. Remember the word "Balak" - or "look out" (usually called by someone trying to pass you on wheels).

Sorry - this was not for me. Perhaps for those who like exploitation of monkeys, snakes, horses and disabled humans. Well...Your taxi drops you off (after standard argument on pre-arranged price). You walk through a patch of land absolutely reeking of horse urine and feces, as someone tries to sell you a horse carriage ride that you really don't want. You walk further to see 20 plus identical orange juice stalls trying to sell you orange juice. You trip over a man with snakes (charming.. not) - and almost get bitten by a very tired and angry monkey being dragged along on a chain. A man in a wheel chair with the majority of his limbs missing "asks" for money.You feel you are in the constant company of crooks, thieves, cheats and failed circus performers. It's dark and you feel not entirely comfortable.Then you finally reach some food stalls where a man says..and I quote "I guarantee my food won't give you diarrhea". You can then head into a shopping area where no doubt the hassle level increases further.I think I either missed the point of this "attraction" - or civilization has moved on.Now hold your breath as you walk back passed the urine drenched horse stands....

Hectic but oh so interesting!!. If you stay a bit street savvy, this is a great place ot visit, such sights and sounds and smells! Don't get sucked into all the sales patter though or you will be relieved of all your dirham pretty quick!

Huge square. Finally found ourselves in this square which changes dramatically at different times of the day.The snakes and monkeys on strings were a little upsetting. This place is absolutely filled with activity and there are cafes and restaurants around the perimeter. Although everyone wanted to direct us to the big square - we tried to avoid it if possible, preferring other routes around the town.

food stands. absolute must-do when in marrakech - i highly recommend having dinner on the square in the little food stands, everyone is so funny getting your attention and then you will get the best service in the food stall. and also very good food: it is local meat and soups, sandwiches and salads, i would order a bunch of plates and then share to get to taste as many different tastes and spices as possible. And there is no need to feel intimidated by the people there trying to convince you to eat at their stand, take your time to see where it suits you most :)

Crazy bustly place. The square was full of people with animals. Snake charmers demanding money, and men with monkeys on chains. Not pleasant. At night the square comes alive. I would recommend grabbing food at one of the stalls. amazing value for money

Fascinating but watch yourself. We came both during the day and at night to view the square. At night the entertainment was fascinating. During the day, the snake charmers and monkey trainers just wanted money for pictures and did very little to nothing to actually make you want to give them money. Sometimes they got very pushy and that was annoying. Also, despite the fact that I was walking with my husband, 2 children and parents in law I still was accosted by an older man. After a quick feel of my backside he continued on but it was uncomfortable for me. Eating in the square was an adventure and getting sweets was a highlight of our time in Marrakech.

Keep your wits about you. Again you can easily get lost here. There is all and sundry here. It gives you a flavour of the place. But it is for the tourist benefit really. If you want to see genuine market then go to either the tannery of food market on a Saturday.

A must visit, but only once.. You cannot avoid going to Jemaa el Fna, quite literally all the locals will try and guide you to this main square. I wouldn't eat (going on local advice) or buy anything here. It's overpriced and pushing to the tourists. However the atmosphere at night is a must. Keep some spare change handy as plenty of people will be looking for a few Dirham - for 5drh (30p) you can play with a monkey or try and avoid being bitten by a snake.

Taste of Marrakech. Just like day and night, the square changes its activities depending on the time of the day. Vendors and play makers dominate the bulk of the day, the highlight of the evening is the food street! This square happens to be the 'place' where locals meet tourists!
Beautiful place. Very authentic, beautiful, vibrant, Morroco and traditions. To see and visit even on a short trip is the must.Gifts buying. Safe.

Nice place to kill some time. This square is a good place to go get an idea of what lay in the souks ahead. As well as shopping it offers food, cafes and some entertainment (animals lovers beware, it's a place to see animals subjected to bad conditions here). That being said, take a PHOTO and you will be harrassed for payment. If you take one get away quickly or you will be expected to pay. With that, don't accept the friendl offers to have a snake draped around you for a photo. They will not remove said snake until you pay them...again many tourists get trapped by this daily. That being said, it's a great atmosphere especially by night. It really feels like the heart of the city.

ONE OF THE BEST BITS ABOUT MARRAKECH . It was very good we spent shopping all night long and it is a place to see at night full of life. The famous fresh juice stalls serve the best fresh chilled orange juice you will have anywhere.
Crazy place!. This is a must see whilst in Marrakech. The noise, smells and general hubbub are quite an assault on the senses! Do not drink the orange juice as it's made with dirty water ice!

a real disappointment. Apart from the interesting wares for sale ( be prepared to get ripped off though ), this place is horrific! the animal cruelty is unnecessary and the cafes around the square are dirty, the service lacking as well. By all means go and have a look, but prepared to be disappointed...

Enjoyable but expected more. I visited the square a both during the day and night using the complimentary shuttle from my hotel. It's a different experience each time, the day was calmer and I spent most of the time wandering the souks. At night the square really comes alive with the traditional music and dances. I ate at stall number 1 and had a delicious meal, it was nice to get a bit of calm from the hustle and bustle. Bead, dips, chicken tagine, a mint tea and water came to no more than £3It is a must do when visiting Marrakech. I went as a sole female traveler and had no trouble beyond the usual banter you'd expect from a market place.I do highly recommend ladies to cove up and be respectful. Sunglasses also helped to avoid eye contact.The henna ladies are always trying to grab you hands and stall owners are very persistent but a strong NO was enough. There are bargains to be had if you haggle well however, on the outskirts there were a few shops with fixed prices if you wanted an easy sale. There were also endless caleches available if you wanted a ride around the town.

Stall 14 all the way. We went to stall 14 as it has best reviews and were not disappointed! Lovely fried fish and calamari. The aubergine puree is out of this world. The noise, communal dining, being shouted at by other stalls staff. It was an experience! Also recommend tea at stall 70 it cured our colds!

Buzzing with Life!!!!!. This place simply offers a life experiences for all your senses. There are different smells, tastes, noises, colors, vibes, sights, movements, you have to keep looking and watching out for everything. You can eat something different every day. The down side is that it is too touristic in the sense that people will try to sell you anything at any price, the motorbikes are not supposed to be there but are there all the time, so you have to be alert. If you are eating at one of the stalls, you have to watch out for anything MIXED as they will inflate the prices, charging each of the items separately. The freshly squeezed fruit juices are amazing, you have to try one, #48 is a good one.Regardless of what one can say, if you do not visit this place, you simply haven't been to Marrakech.
Nice especially at night. A must see upon any visit to Marrakech. At night turns into the hub of the city with locals eating from stalls.

So busy. The big square in Marrakesh is never quiet, but it really comes to live in the late afternoon and evening. Thousands of people gather there, locals as well as tourists. You can try many different foods on the food stalls, take a tour in a horse cart, get a henna painting on your hands, or just enjoy watching the crowd. We did not like the snake charmers, because these snakes are really stressed. Also we did not like the men who had little monkeys on their shoulder, where you can have your picture taken with the monkey for a fee. This does not help animal welfare.

Well, what a waste . La place is absolutely not fab anymore, touristic, dirty and lots of crab to buy, of course overprized! Only the food places at night are highly recomended! But still its a must see!

Enjoyable and bright square. I was there in July, during Ramadan, so the square was quite during the day but very busy in the evening, after 19:00ish. Amazing and lively atmosphere, with music from the snake charmers to the ones dancing with tambourines. Very entertaining. At night is full with food stalls and the food is ok (not too special the tagine I had), specially orange juices!!

Interesting. Everyone visiting Marrakech will probably view this and it's worth seeing. I would recommend picking a spot in a cafe and watching the transition from day into evening.I wasn't a fan of the monkeys on chain in the square or the relentless pestering from the souk owners
Heart of Marrakech. Visited every night during our stay, always felt safe. Loved the music, food and dancing along with the opportunity to sit up in a cafe and watch the square activity below.

Lively place. In Marrakech, this place is very lively. Someone can easy spend 1/2 a day walking around, taste food, marketplace. There r people who may ask various services or try to sell stuff. You can stop or walkby, they wouldn't bother.
All life is here. from orange juice to evening meal, this place provides the lot. Whatever you want to buy, this is the place to start. Beware of snake charmers; don't let them hassle you.
Be prepared for some hassling . A lot to see! Local food and vibe but quite touristic.. and everybody is trying to make you eat on their place... tiring

A Mesmerising View of the World - an experience not to be missed!. My first visit to this square, many years ago absolutely astonished me! Fortunately now have had the opportunity to come back and spent more time in this astonishing 'Time Warp'.If you can stand the hassle and constant bartering, it is a wonderful experience day and night...but particularly at night!The square is Surrounded by shops and stalls, and a fantastic choice of cafes and restaurants. They are quite happy for you to sit with a pot of Mint Tea! (many drank!)During the day you can experience the snake charmers, Henna Tattooists, the 'poor' little monkeys, musicians & bell ringers brightly dressed waiting to snare you for a price!!! But what an experience! IN addition at night the story tellers and magicians come out, to stand among the crowd and to listen is fascinating even although you don't understand a word they say! But the expressions make it an experience! Rows and Rows of every type of food - with long trestle tables and benches, you have to be pretty agile on occasion to squeeze in!Not just a tourist attraction because you can find yourself on a bench and every person in the place other than you is Moroccan!The transformation which takes place at dusk is amazing, day time you can buy virtually anything, but masses of stalls squeezing oranges into a glass in front of you, to the many other other Moroccan and African attractions - and the lights!!!!! these still all remain in place, as an army of all ages set up eating stalls! An amazing sight! You can buy from the very cheap to relatively expensive! My favourite for many years standing is my Bowl of Soup... still only 3 dirhams, which is less than 20p(sterling)!!! There is a lot of haranguing due to pressure to have you visit their stall and can be more than a little daunting. As for the sweets that get pushed around on carts....!!! I don't tell Slimming world about those! But not a place to miss if visiting Marrakech! You will never forget the experience! They even opened in the rain!!!

Bussy Bussy Bussy. We visited this place couple of times a day. It was still really bussy. I liked the entertaining stuff the people are doing there during the day. At night the court changeshoe it face to a big food market with different offerings. I was only anoyed about the guys forcing you to visit their stands.
Marrakech steaming centee. In your lifetime you should be sure to enjoy a night in the boiling heart of Marrakech. Keep eyes wide open and let the craziness begin.

Poor. It is one of those places that i feel you must visit at some point in your life just to experience it. Its like a circus. Being a tourist it is impossible to walk around without being hassled. The men who have monkeys and snakes will try to put them on you and then charge you to take them off. Unknown to us at the time, if you cause a scene the undercover tourist police will come and help the situation.
Had I great moment at booth #47 (Baolo). Traditional food especially for marrakech people. You can take lot of thinks like tanjia, head of sheep, mechoui... of course lot of tea with Sahara flavour.

Amazing spot. The square is a bizarre and fantastic place to spend an evening. Not for the faint hearted! From monkeys in nappies on leashes to pythons being wood by men playing the flute to boxing matches and henna artists...a really incredible place.

An experience of sensory overload. The evening market is an absolute must for visitors to Marrakech with as much enjoyment derived from observing the visitors as experiencing the food stalls, thee vendors, the snake charmers, the entertainers and the musicians.

All your senses come alive!. Jemaa el Fna is the main square in Marrakech. It's a real feast on all your senses. All the different smells and sounds. At night, this place comes alive with the passing trade from locals who have worked during the day. You see snake charmers - don't take any photos unless you're prepared to pay. People playing music on the square. If you want to take any photos, it's best to go to one of the cafes and take them from the terrace. Koutoubia Mosque is the prominent feature in the square. If you get lost in the Medina just look out for it as it's the tallest building in Marrakech, you'll then be able to make your way back to the square.

Lively heart of Marrakech. It is hard to describe all action, sounds, smells that you can experience on this square. It is very different than anything that you could find in Europe. This is very busy and lively area where you can find anything from snake charmers, street theatre to street food. It is lively during the day but real action starts when the sun sets and food stalls are set up.Everybody tries to sell you something and it can be bit tiresome to walk trough the food stalls where everyone tries to pull you in.

Mad crazy place - snake charmers, monkeys, the souk. Love it - all human life is here.Snake charmers, monkeys, drummers, games, exotic food. Try the fresh fruit stalls and but some nuts & dates .. Or a chameleon or a tortoise!

Life writ large. How can you not be bowled over by this place? Even if you're the conservative type who hates hawkers and being approached uninvited, you have to admit this place teems with life at night. If you access the square with a smile on your face and your heart open to human communication, you'll adore this place - even as it saps your life force! EVERYONE is trying to sell you something, and they've all learned enough of every major language to make sure you are a potential customer, no matter where you come from. If you're an English speaker, '5 year diarrhea guarantee' and 'Marks & Sparks quality' are just some of the quips you'll hear from the food vendors as you pass. Laugh and give them high fives if you aren't interested and they'll be delightful in defeat. Show contempt and you'll get a hearty dose in return.We adored this place and I hope it shows. :)
Busy Place. good place to visit to see snake charmers and any thing else you are willing to pay for. Worth noting do not encourage the purchase of cheap spin offs
Just remarkable place. Fully packed out.Need to negotiate price for goodsGreat horse carriage rideMore like Christmas Markets

Quite an exciting place to go at night to soak up the atmosphere.. This is a must at night.Personally i would not eat at the food stalls but i always er on the safe side in Morocco food wise.There are always story tellers and musicians there.
Hustle bustle of a bazaar. Very happening place, specially at night, lots of shops, food stalls, and street performers. Very lively and can spend ours going through different stalls and shops.

This place breathes life to the city. What a place ! Lively full of culture definitely worth a visit .food stalls Moroccan soup harira barbecue chicken and above all freshly squeezed orange juice .also try hot Moroccan mint teaDefinitely a place to visit

Just wow. Instead of choosing a restaurant, try eating in one of the street places. You'll love it.Avoid the henna tattoo ladies, they literally oblige you to have a tattoo and then charge you impossible amounts of money.Buy lamps from the people selling on the street and buy Moroccan candy from the guy with a cart.
Shopping. Very busy market. Many stalls. You have to negotiate to get a good bargain. I don't enjoy shopping so not for me.

tourist trap. yes it's loud and noisy - but also full of vendors selling cheaply made tourist 'gifts'. Constantly hassled - and if you ignore them, normally verbal abuse then given (not nice!). If you are into having your picture taken with monkeys in nappies and on chains - or seeing snakes that are kicked when they try to lie flat - then go...otherwise too many other places to visit in Marrakech.

Fun Place,. Again another lovely spot in Marrakesh, full of life and pushy traders. Lots of street food to taste though similar on most stalls. I have to give them credit, they do make an effort to speak in English compared to the staff in Hotels!!

Magic. One of the most magical and fun places I've ever been. Make sure you eat there while you're in Marrakech, it gets busy by 8pm. We would recommend stalls 44 (get tanjia for 20 DH each) and 97 for the brochettes and harira soup for 5dh! Learn how to say no and you'll have a great time here.

Busy and overrated. Can be quite intimidating. At first sight you feel you need extra protection. Every person from the food area is asking you to join them. So if you don't like this don't walk through it. But it is very cheap.

Feast for your Eyes but beware of aggressive Girl beggars!. I Went there first 8 years ago. The market vendors can be quite intimidating often shouting at you to come and visit their stall. There are lots to see and some dangers as scooters and bicycles rushing past you. This time we went there twice and both times had young girl beggars following me for money and one got hold of me around my waist, as my long lost daughter, demanding money, after seeing me negotiating a price for horse carriage ride.

A must visit. Difficult to get too, must walk through the entire medina; depending where you are coming from. But greatttttt place to walk through. A lot of suks and stuff to buy and bargain! They say fixed prices but you can always bargain. There is a lot of options of places to eat in the jemaa el fna.

Fuss for tourists. Jemaa el Fna is definitely worth seeing, it is sort of a catchy mess. You feel the hustle and bustle is made up purely for tourists, but it is hard not to be tempted to be part of the scene.

Main square visit of Marrakesh. It's always amazing to have a visit of such place which reminds us old history traditions. In my busy schedule here in UK I got a plan to spend my holidays in Morocco. And I am happy. One more thing don't forget to have orange juice from square stalls.

a must one off experience. The people harass you alot so just stay patient and sit down where you want to and feel comfortable. also you dont have to eat there as not everyone will be comfortable, but it's definitly a good experience. Beware of the orange sellars, some try to rip you off it should be 4/5DH ONLY per glass of pure orange juice

Daytime was relaxed. We went in the daytime and had a guide round the souks but he left us to wander the square later on. We saw the snake charmers and monkeys. If you want to take one or two pics of snakes/monkeys you will need to tip about 10 dirham. If you want a lot more of your family with attractions the guide suggested a maximum of 50 dirham tip.

Absolutely appalled by the a airmail cruelty. Having booked our road trip to Morocco some months ago, I was really long forward to ending our travels in Marrakech. Sadly, our visit to the square has left us with a bad taste in our mouths. Having travelled through the Atlas Mountains and staying in various traditional towns and villages throughout the south of Morocco, this square is in no way typical of the country. The smell from the area containing the horses and carts is atrocious, rubbish can be seen in piles and as for the "entertainment", well I'd rather eat my own eye balls than spend any time there. EVERYONE wants money. Be carful where you point your camera as some plucky lad will accuse you of taking his picture and demand money. Even asking for directions will cost you money. As an extensive traveller, I have found that most locals are more than happy to help tourists without feeling the need to rip them off. I certainly would cross the street to help a tourist when I'm at home. The stalls are selling tacky, mass-produced items for above average sums of money. I can't comment on the food served on the stalls as we did not eat there but can you see any fresh running tap water? We have spoken to people who have had very bad tummies after eating at a stall so we chose to avoid. If you approach the food area, you will find yourself being shouted at by all the "waiters", trying to coax you in. They are more than persistent and even become hostile when you politely decline.You will be deafened by musical groups who are appalling.Finally, the treatment of the monkeys and the snakes was the final nail in the coffin for us. We were appalled to see the monkeys dressed in human clothes and sunglasses and being dragged around by metal chains. As if this isn't bad enough, they were surrounded by European tourists who actually paid to have their photos taken with these poor creatures. As other TA's have posted, please ignore these horrid, cruel individuals.....you are only encouraging their behaviour.I know we are in the minority as most people posting appear to find this place to be fun, entertaining and a "must see". Please, if nothing else, think about the animals.

best medina we have found. So many wonderful things to purchase in the Medina. Low the bartering and this is more colorful than Tangier. The best is to walk to the tanneries and purchased a great camel bag. Don't like all the Senegel people trying to sell you things when you are eating.

Am not impressed. As I prepared for our first trip to Morocco I read several travelguides and tripadvisor. It seemed that this square was not to be missed. Well, we walked around, saw lots the usual ''am trying to con you into giving you as much of your money possible'' hasslers. you can't walk 2 steps without someon epulling your arm. 1 of my daughters wanted a henna ''tattoo'' on her hand. She got 3 choices : orange, brown or black. Orange lasts a few days, brown a week, black more than 2 weeks. So she went for black. It was done within 5 minutes, dried for sevral hours and..........dissapeared completely after 3 days. There were guys playing intruments making a snake angry and few people with pitiful monkeys. Prices of fruits were 3 times more expensive than ''down the road''. So all in all : not impressed at all.

Too many crooks!. Jemaa el fna is worth a visit, but be wary of virtually everyone. The trders in the souk inflate prices ridiculously, rather than being honest or fair, forcing you to spend most of your time haggling, rather than shopping which is fun, for 5 minutes - then just irritating.
