Beware the gangs of women pedaling henna tatoos - Black Henna is common and my companion despite protesting that she did not want one was given one anyway "for free" on completion the woman demanded 500 dirhums for 5 minutes work. We refused and paid 100. The henna she used has now left serious scarring on my partners hands. AVOID them. The food stalls in the square itself seem to have hygiene standards well below par to be serving cooked meats and meals. Its a crzy place, but think its lost so much of its appeal in the 4 years between visits.

Interesting hustle and bustle but can become unbearable. It's the busiest part of marrakech we saw. It's a great atmosphere, especially at first but an hour or so in and you're begging for the exit as beggars, merchants and 'guides' try to get your attention. It is never ending and spoils the experience. Otherwise it is a decent little wonder. Be careful if you're a Muslim becsuse so.some of the restaurants sell pork and wine so ask before hand!

Hustle Bustle!. A great square where all sorts of activities occur during the day and evening. Snake charmers, acrobats along with the usual fake-goods touts. We didn't feel unsafe at all, although we took sensible precautions with our bags to deter pickpockets. In the evening, numerous food stalls spring up.

fun. I loved visiting Jemaa el Fna, it was a great place to visit and to spend the day. There is so many things to do, Like seeing and taking pictures with the monkeys or a snake. you can also get beautiful henna done as well or just enjoy the café and look over everything

Vibrant souks. Its beautiful especially during the nights, lots to see, be careful not to take pics as people will ask you to pay for taking pictures of them, lots or children beg for money, careful once you give to one others follow, can get a little annoying.

Eat at the red stands. Great fun at the square. Whether staring at snake charmers or getting some fresh orange juice, the square is always filled with excitement! Definitely recommend stand number 1 for clean delicious Moroccan food! Great eggplant and brochettes! Enjoy!

The greatest party in Morocco. An unbelievably captivating atmosphere. The best time to go is around 7-8pm, particularly on a Friday night. There was a great range of entertainment, sights, smells, and sounds. It's also a good place to watch the sunset behind the Koutoubia Mosque.

Noisy place. First thing we did was visit this square in Marrakesh. Amazing atmosphere, crowded and noisy. Tends to get on your nerves after a while though. Hawkers rip you off if you try and buy anything there. Have the fresh orange juice from any of the stalls, i recommend No 42, friendly guy, will offer you half a glass free. Also try the mixed juice. Try one of the food stalls at night for real street food.

over rated. reviews sound as if this square is a ''must see'' but if you are used to traveling in africa, it's not that special. Just a lot of people, show artists (read con-artists) to try and rip you off. SO be strong. 1 of my daughters wanted a henna painting on her had. We were told it would cost most if it would be black, the black henna lasts 14 days. We bargained a bit for a small henna print, costed 50 MAD and would last. At the time of writing this (airport Fez) it's 5 days later and all of the henna has disapeared already. Be sure to be strond, know what you want and don't want, before you set foot on this Square.

Lovely chaos . Exactly what you would expect it to be. Chaos! But worth the hassle - just go for it, embrace the smells and hustle and bustle. Fascinating for people watching so get to a cafe in the square and watch the world go by.

Such a magical place . We went to Jemaa el Fna in the evening so it was even more beautiful since all the lights were turned on, my little brother was able to hold a baby monkey and take a picture with it, my father held a big yellow snake and also took a picture with it, after that we played in a game were they give you a stick with a disk attached to it and if you catch a bottle of soda with that disk you can have the bottle, we were unable to do so but had such a good time playing as a family. We also bought some cheep games for the kids to play with, but since we already ate before going there we just had orange juice and left.

Traditional Market. I would say if you visit morocco you should not miss to visit Jemaa el Fna Market. The best time to visit this place is an hour before sunset and stay there for 2/3 hours.Nice to see and try the traditional food. The orange juice places are worth to try.

Hussle and bussle. Could not get out of the place fast enough. Got hassled to death. No pleasure due to constant "You buy". The spitting by the locals was disgusting and the smell of the horse urine was overwhelming

Normal Local Area. Nothing unique here outside from the already known Morocco stuff you find in every boutique , I would suggest its a great experience except that all the begging and kids running around you make it a terrible experience if you are not in the right mood .Dont walk around with a lot of money, Take care of your belongings.A lot of seller will ask you to pay money if you took picture of them or what they are selling , Just ignore them and walk away.

Must see. Must go.. The main focus of Marrakech is this huge square where every night marquees are erected by many food sellers. We had dinner there and ate well for all but a song. It's lined by cafes and to have a peppermint tea whilst watching the people is great! I felt sorry for the monkeys though. Lots to see and watch and of course, to buy.
Hoilday. This place is massive and has alot to see. There is a big market area where you would find most things and eating places are plently.

Lively market. The lively market is hectic, full of every thing what you can imagen .All thow after a few nights it is kind of too much.The food stalls are good if you have done your homework and know where to eat,we ate at nr.1 stall and had lovely lamb dishes, very cheap,also the grilled vegetables are very tasteful.The orange juice is the must and you will not regret it.The stall serving super cheap snails are also a very good joice.

A must, but can be overwhelming. It is the essence of Marrakech, so you need to see it. But there is a lot going on... it can be overwhelming. Fortunately there are many cafés with terrace around, so you can enjoy some mint tea and escape from the crowd to relax. Food sold in the stalls in the evening is delicious and cheap.

must see in Marrakech. Energy personified. see it by day and see it by night. It is very different. Try the street food. If you don't like snakes, beware of the snake charmers that want to wrap them around your head.
Happening square. Lights, camera, action! There is so much excitement in the air in this ever-so-busy square. Worth the visit even if you're not intending to buy anything.

The spirit of Marrakesh . This is a must see to take in the culture and spirit of Marrakesh! So many things to see; musicians, snake charmers, acrobats, food, and many goods to purchase. Be prepared to barter for everything! Be focused in what you give your attention to otherwise you will be haggled by everyone! Everyone wants your money so hold tightly to it and be judicious in how you spend. The atmosphere is electric at night. If you can accept that many people make their living here by selling or begging then it will be easier to be in this intense atmosphere. We visited 3 different days! We enjoyed the culture

The heart of Marrakech. This square is the heart of Marrakech. You should go there more than once to enjoy dinner in the open air or buy souvenirs from the shops around.The place is trouble free but.Its is better not to talk with strangers approaching you as scams are possible so be careful.

Crazy and interesting square. There's always something going on at Jemaa el-Fnaa. Just watch out for the snake charmers and monkey handlers as they can be very aggressive in wanting to part you from some cash in exchange for a photo. If you dont want to be caught by them then avoid eye contact, dont engage in conversation or shake their hand. Best experience is having a couple of drinks at one of the terrace cafes and watching the square come alive as the sun sets.

Better than Fes, but still, dirty and filthy . You can not take pictures if you not give them money ..... Children will show their hands to you for begging money..."Hello, excuse me! Come come ...!" Just another town of hassle, but better than Fes

Main square. Right, this square is really busy and has a lot to see, listen and experience! However, beware, people who are extremely friendly or giving you un-requested help or guiding services are often after your money. Some of the attraction like the snake charmers and monkeys are after crazy amounts of Euros... Beware of fake leather and souvenirs. I enjoyed one of the best orange juices in there. Also becareful with the henna ladies, specially black henna. Other than that enjoy the views, the music and see how the locals entertain after a long day...
Fun place. Beautiful view specially at night time. Something for everyone. Make sure you negotiate the price before buying anything. Great place for coffee tea and eating.
Excellent typical food. Very nice setting where you can find all kind of typical moroccan food. There are also nice ltittle shops around.

Fun and Madness. Another brilliant trip and days and nights on the square as colourful and wild as ever. Plainclothes police and uniform military more evident than usual but this place manages to feel wild and safe simultaneously

Fooooddddd. Hahhahaa. Yes food! At night we love the food.You can have some real good food for not to much money.We spend around 300 dirham for the two of us.We don't like the animals or henna ladies. When buying something make sure you count whatever they return as change money.We also got into a horse wagon for a ride. We paid 240 dirham for 2 persons for one hour ride.
Must see!. Fun to experience all the sights in the square. Definitely a must see, but the food isn't great so plan to just walk around and have tea and see everything.

Enjoy it from the surrounding terraces!!!. It is a nice experience to visit and at night / late evening it gets busy and bustling with sounds and smells. If you don't like the crowds visit it around morning and early afternoon as it can be overwhelming at night!Beware that every thing you try to take a picture of like snake charmers, monkeys, artists they will ask you money for it. So kindly refuse them when they approach you (they can be very pushy) or be prepared to pay for it!Beware of your personnel belongings at all times!!!!The best thing to do is to go to the surrounding restaurant terraces from where you will have an amazing view of the whole plaza and have a nice meal and drinks sitting down and absorbing the amazing atmosphere without the hassling! Not to be missed!!!!

An experience not to be missed!. I came to Marrakesh 35 years ago and it was a pleasure to find that the activities there were the same... but with a completely paved floor, even in the souks, that made it that much more enjoyable (actually Marrakesh is now a very clean town, very different than what I remembered!) snake charmeurs, all kinds of music being played, monkeys and a host of fresh fruit stalls that make amazing fruit juice....

The Sunset place to be. This is the place to be just before sunset. Take a seat in one of the many restaurants with a view over the square and watch the sun go down. Great for people watching and preformers. Stalls selling things and food, music and dance. Great !

Interesting sights and sounds - must visit.. To experience true Marrakech,with its hustle and bustle, definitely a must visit - with all the souks and restaurants and street performers, definitely can spend hours at this location - but remember to bargain with the vendors and not get flustered by the crowds or street performers.
Family trip. Great place to visit with family and children. Stay away from monkeys and snakes. Great food while enjoying panoramic view.
A must . See Marrakech at his finest in this carnivalesque square. Make sure to be there in the evening to see the height if excitement.

Magical Experience. Jamaa El-Fna is a must do experience for any trip to Marrakech. Be advised that you must be vigilant and beware of pickpockets, however, for the most part this is a relatively safe place to visit. At night the square comes alive with souvenir vendors, orange juice carts, food stands, and entertainment from all over Morocco. Be prepared to give tips if you want to take pictures or video, so have change with you. The wide varieties of music is enchanting as well as the story tellers, snake charmers, and playful monkeys. It does become very crowded as this seems to be the place that everyone in Marrakech goes at night, but well worth the visit to really get a magical experience.

beware snakes underfoot. while walking around there were lots of snakes to have your photo taken with but you can walk into the middle of them without realising as they are all over the floor. there was even a poor little hedgehog among them.
Always a gong show. Worth a visit for orange juice and entertainment. Don't pay more than 20 MAD for pics with the snakes or monkeys. 50 MAD max for henna.

Energy, food, snakes and music late into the evening. Definitely recommend a trip here, especially at night! This is a fun place. There are snake charmers, food, music, and it's crowded until late into the evening. Just remember to watch your wallet as it's very crowded and remember that nothing is free-even taking a picture of something that belongs to someone.

Short break. This is where all the action is, a true Aladdins world type place,much to see and eat, People like snake charmers, and street performers may demand money off you for photos even if you have thrown some in the pot,They can be quite aggressive.I seen this happen to some tourists but it didnt happen to me. You ll also get people giving you the one finger salute down the trading streets off Jemaa El Fna. Which is a pity. However I got lots of great photos due to my long lense,and ability to go unseen.The streets here have lots of secret police and are undercover so are very hard to spot,so its very very safe here. The food market in the centre is a nice place to sit down eat and watch the madness, the chefs and waiters here are very nice and the food even better.Stall 51 is a good start for food.

Amazing but keep your wits about you! . Love visiting the square. After dark is when it comes alive. It's an amazing place and the phrase 'assault to the senses' sums it up well. For me the highlights are the food stalls, the orange juice and the spicy tea. The sight and sound is like nothing most of us get to experience and everyone should visit at least once. As always, it's important to stay vigilant in crowds but I never felt unsafe. The key is to be firm: don't let the women doing henna grab your hand without your consent. Also don't take unauthorised pictures of people with things like snakes and money's (no idea why anyone would want to in the first place) but they will demand payment if you do. But the atmosphere is second to none and needs to be experienced at least once in a lifetime!
Snakes and Monkeys...oh my!. Lots of fun to wander around. Different attractions day and night. Closed to traffic from 1pm on. Watch out for the snakes and monkeys that are everywhere!
Too crowded. Uauu, it was really too crowded there, too noisy and too loud! In the evening this is crazy place! If you like circus, you should visit it, otherwise better to stay on the edge of place.

Earth's heaven. Very good place to enjoy the deferent Moroccan folklore and test some original food …!!! Very famous place in Marrakech city … monkeys, snakes, comedy, small spectacle an music … you found every and anything around this place!!!!

Daunting but good. An assault on the senses but in a good way. Our first night was a little overwhelming but we grew in confidence and enjoyed ourselves immensely. A fabulous place to people watch. Just be aware of potential pick pockets!

Brilliant. The nightlife is INDESCRIBABLE! So many people come together in the night to enjoy themselves. Food market, and fresh juice stalls. Small souvenir shops, and just a vast range of talents being showcased constantly!

Nice food but very rude people. A big variety of foods. It's always been hard to chose a food stalls. Expect to be approached by individuals urging you to chose their stalls. They keep latching at you. Nevertheless, do not give up. First, go around most busy stalls, take a look at the food they serve, then pick and chose for yourself. Check prices before you order!!!

Certainly an experience!. Positives - Some interesting circles such as the clowns and the dancingNegatives - Lots of people begging, lots of harrassment to buy things you don't want and people do not accept "no" for an answer, animals in the square (horses, monkeys, snakes) appeared unkempt and neglected, the floor is covered in animal faeces, locals will railroad you into purchases, had a random man put a red hat on my brothers head and try to charge us 100 dirhams for that, performers are very aggressive unless you give them money, lots of children begging, very expensive prices - more pricier than same items in the UK, lots of orange juice stalls next to each other charging the same amount and trying to steal customers from each other, ladies applying hemna are very forceful and expensive with poor quality henna that doesnt last a day.

Chaotic and vibrant!. We visited here nearly every night as our riad was close by. It's chaos anytime of the day or night but it really livens up at night. Snake charmers, monkeys, food stalls, shopping and a variety of other "characters" abound. Watch your wallet, steer clear of the henna artists (purported to use less than authentic materials in the henna) and enjoy the fun. I have read many mixed reviews of the food so we chose not to eat here but we saw many locals enjoying fresh juices, steaming bowls of escargot and other Moroccan foods. Seems to be a gathering spot for all. I was fascinated to see many large crowds of males and very few females. Our riad assured us that the square is full of undercover police so we were safe but we were on high alert anyway. An easy place for petty thievery for sure. You haven't visited Marrakech if you haven't been here.

Don't get charged double.. At night the tented eateries open up with busboys practically begging you to sit at one of their tables. Since we were hungry we sat down to taste some of the food on the menu. My girlfriend and I order a few dishes. Food was mediocre at best. Time to pay and the bill is twice of what we ordered. He tells me since there are 2 of us, we are being charged double. We just wanted to share the small dishes!!! Don't get fooled by these guys. Moroccans are greedy and they're not ashamed of it. They'll take the clothes off your back if they could.

Tourist trap. For first timer to marrakech i think it would be good to just come by and have some dinner in one of the restaurants. But it is overly crowded and very touristy. If you are a tourist than this place will intrigue you but as traveller it is not my cup of tea.

Way to stressfull. Too many pushy seller especially at the food court.I went there on my first day and i got ripped of by the boost. I would suggest going only the boast where they are not aggressively trying to sell you sth

Food was good, being hassled not fun. We ate here twice and had a few teas on the rooftop terraces. We ate at No14 and No117. The food was good at both and the price was reasonable. We didn't like how much we were hassled in an attempt for us to eat at there stand though, sometimes you think it's just worth the trouble. But it was a good experience. Recommend it.

Great energy, but beware..... The energy of the square is fantastic. My favourite elements were the cheap fresh orange juice and the gymnasts. I hated being hassled for sales constantly, though, and it seems getting ripped off when eating at one of the food stalls is par for the course. I'd advise against eating at stall 25, where we ate, as we got ripped off there and the food was no cheaper or better than at the nearby 7 Saints Cafe.
Tourist trap. I guess one must visit when in Marrakech, but this place is just one big aggressive tourist trap, where you will be hassled for money as soon as you look, or worse, touch your camera.

Must-See Marrakech Attraction. The Jemaa en Fna is a must-see while you are in Marrakech. A bit touristy if you have travelled extensively in Asia or Africa, but still fun to see nontheless. The cafes with terraces around the square are a lovely place to relax and watch the action.

Interesting place, but ..... 1. Avoid the bread on the street! We watched them dropped some bread on the ground, picked them up and put them back on the cart. It didn't happen once, it happened many times at some places. Yuck! Even if they are not dropped, the sellers and the buyers used their bare hands to test and feel them.2. When you want to buy any products in the souk, bargain from not more than 25%. I got myself a caddle lantern down to 155 dirhams from 350 dirhams, but it was actually still too much!! Should've bargain from 80 dirhams.3. Beggars were very persistent to get money and they liked to touch us with their dirty hands. Be stern!4. The sellers were very pushy. Again, be stern!5. When we were speaking in English, more people came and bugged us. However, when we were speaking in Indonesian language, the number went down a lot. So, if you don't want the hassle, speak in unfamiliar languages.6. Don't stop moving or somebody will charge you for any show.Overall, it's an interesting place, we enjoyed the trip. Do get on the horse carriage for a 40-45 minute tour around Marrakesh. Try the snails soup if you dare! It's nice. :)
Touristic. It's not disturbing, but you're - being a tourist - a kind of prey. Eating or drinking in one of the places at the square gives you a moment of rest.

The heart of Marrakech. As coming to Marrakech from North America, i will say it is quite a culture shock your first day or two when you get to Marrakech, however after walking around the streets, and visiting Jemaa el Fna, you get to love the Moroccan culture, the kind people as well as the food! Dont be scared if you get lost in the square, which you 99% will, its not a big deal! If you do, just try to go to the restaurants to ask for help or ask a shop owner or a female. Some of the men will help you however they just want money.

Wicked shopping area. This area for shopping is realy realy good. The shop owners/workers stake up the prices the moment they find out your a tourist which i feel is wrong but u barter with them from half the price and in moments you will find u achieved a great deal. I love shopping here. The people of marrakech are so friendly and loveing. Cant wait to go again in the near future.

An amazing place. Visited here both during the day and the night. During the day there are lots of stalls selling juices and fruits and some interesting characters such as water sellers and snake charmers!At night the atmosphere is completely different, especially as the film festival was on. The square is packed and filled with food vendors of all sorts. It's very noisy, crowded and chaotic but just hang on to your belongings and you will have a great time.

Lot of foods, have to negotiate, variety local products.. You need to negotiate the price when you purchase anything. The restaurant on the roof top is very delicious. Try lamb or couscous. This market suits for souvenirs.

It's all go!. Visited this area many times during our visit to marrakech and found it changed every time.They produce what has to be the best orange juice in the world here, you must try it!We are there a couple of times at various places. One of the most enjoyable was The No 1 stall, don't worry you will understand when you get there, all the food outlets have numbers not names!Just have to be a bit careful that you don't strol into a "Snake charming" stall otherwise you might find you have one placed around your neck!

Be careful with local guides. I was looking for my hostel and certain locals keeps offering help and when they brought you to the place, they will ask for euros where initially for free. They will even shout on you if you give less than they expected. Poor me on the first day but generally, still like Marrakesh.

Enjoy the swarming humanity of the square and its entertainers and stalls and traders. You can't help feeling like Indianna Jones as you make your way through the mass of traders, entertainers, stallholders, street sellers and beggars. Act smart and avoid the thieves and pickpockets. Buy a freshly squeezed orange juice for about 35p from one of the many stalls.Dive into the souks and be amazed at the sheer number of shops and stalls in the miles of streets and passegeways, but keep coming back into the Jamaa el Fna to keep your bearings. When you need a break, find the cafe Glaciere, and insist on a table on the balcony. The staff will try to seat you downstairs. Insist on the balcony.Order a coffee and if you've been lucky enough to secure a table at the edge of the balcony, just watch the snake charmers, monkey touts, dancers, acrobats, singers, traders, beggars, locals and tourists wandering about beneath, oblivious to your gaze. From here you can safely take pictures without being chased for money. But be fair. distribute a few tips when you descend. It's a few quid to you, a living wage to them.Ignore the beggars.

Unpleasant visit to Jemma el Fna. It felt like the place is full of people whose only interest is to get money from you. Even after looking at something for a moment one is invited further and soon is asked for an inadequate amount of money.

A Famous Square With A Lot of Activities. This is almost empty during the day but starting late afternoon people would drove in groups to Africa's largest and Morocco's most famous square. Here you can eat, watch, stroll, sing, dance, shoot and shop. If your stomach is not that sensitive, you can try eating at the food stalls. There were ATMs also. I just did not like the constant disturbance from locals offering their products and entertainment but you can always and politely say no. Well it was an authentic experience of a livelier Morocco compared with the other cities we have visited before that. Marrakech means "more life" indeed!

dry and unapetising with loads of hassle. save yourself the hassle and disappointment of the tables and restartaunt in and around the square and head for the souks, where the locals eat. you can still get a burger but it'll be cooked fresh and you won't pay a fortune for grilled meat which tastes of lighter fuel

wow.. All the crazy-ness in the world is here. From snake whisperers and mimes, to street food stalls and fake jewellery vendors, they can all be found here...mostly locals frequent it, and it is always crowded!

i tried to eat qvasi everything. sooo here we are at most famous squerre in Marrakesh...lot of people.lot of variety see food.meat.vegy etc over there...i took a photo whith kobras and crazy monkey...you will pay almoust the air there...i tried 1 time in m life snail and was discasting but sheep brain mixed wi. some other meat was njami...fresh pressed orangw juice ist a bingo...was verry interr.to see such a lot of moving

Disappointed. This is the largest square in Africa - it looks very impressive but didn't like the constant hassle and maybe just not adventurous enough for what it throws at you. Was so looking forward to visiting here but left feeling it was just a ploy to get money out of you and not in pleasant ways - not relaxing when you feel like you have to be on your guard all the time.

Because everybody else goes there. I can't say exactly what I was expecting, but having seen it, I am underwhelmed. Especially after sundown, it gets really busy (but not jam-packed, or I would have fled immediately). The entertainers are really for locals, as a foreigner, you can barely make sense of what's going on. And your chief thought is that this is little more than amateurish hyperactivity to separate you from your dirhams. The food and drink stalls don't offer much variety, and I have the impression that you can get better quality and better value not far away. Ignore the carts selling desserts, they're all just minor variations on the cookie formula. On the other hand, the boiled snails in some sort of herbal soup are worth a try. I didn't like them, but it was interesting to at least try (10 dirhams,1 Euro for a bowl).
All the worst sides of Marrakech. If you would like to see the city in a good light and away from tourist traps/tat I would recommend missing 'the square' altogether.
Always exciting. Always exciting in the the Souk of Marrakech (near Djema al-Fna).And test the "fast food" at Djema al-Fna in the evening.The only annoying is that many do not take no for an answer.

Haggle With Humour. It is better if you could haggle with humour here and they like it. But most things are overprice, aim at tourists. Example, 1 kg of dates could be 200MAD here while the same dates were 40MAD at other markets. You could get cheaper things in Esaouira souks and calmer than here. The price offered by road sellers who like to follow tourist bus/van were also much cheaper. I find souvenirs in Egypt and Turkey are cheaper than here.

simply amazing!!!!!. we started by arriving here at around sunset, the food stalls were starting to get warm, snake charmers, henna painting, juice vendors, acrobats, belly dancers, man with monkey, everyone is here, what an amazing square, for the best and unforgettable and commanding view of the square, go to 'cafe balcone du glacier' go to the top floor (entry only for paying customers 100dh for coffee) hehe but its worth it.

Snake charmers, sun set, fresh orange juice and goods from all of North Africa. The centre of Marrakesh and the hub and hive of activity. This is where all the souks start from and a great place to have a Tajine. There are numerous places you can go up to the roof and get a good view and its worth getting a fresh orange juice while you are here. Be careful of any sellers that put things into your hand or any scams. An exciting place full of activity, but stay on alert while here. Its safe to be in, but keep your wits.

Bustling marketplace at the heart of Marrakesh Medina. This is the must see marketplace of all! Dating back a millenium it truly evokes the history and lifestyle of the Moroccan people. From small stalls to boutique shops and carefs, restaurants surrounding the square, you will find something to interest the whole family.Early in the day it is much quieter, frequented mainly by shop owners and a few wandering sales people. Guides for the shops and souks will approach you to offer a guided tour of the souks, but we did not find it necessary to hire a guide. If you do hire a guide then expect them to steer you towards the shops and restaurants owned by their family and friends!Best advice is to simply lose yourself in the labarinth of streets in the souk, and if you use a smart phone, google maps will get you out with ease!It is a crazy bustling place with pedestrians, cyclists and motorbike riders all competing for the same bit of narrow lane, so keeps alert! Also, keep your handbag or other within sight and ensure you have your valuables well protected as there are many young kids on the prowl.At dusk the square comes alve with foodstalls setting up and offerings traditional moroccan dishes, including vegetarian, fish and meat. The food is prepared in front of you so it is not for the faint-hearted!Snake charmers, gift sellers, acrobats and dance troupes can all be found there at night....enjoy!
Lovely market. Very busy, too much haggling, but good stuff. Lots of different stalls, music, snake and monkey shows.

Its the one must do place in town. All roads lead to the square, and once there all the people in the town will be there as well. Entertainers and sellers cover the square in daylight and after dark the food stalls set up to deliver all manner of delights. Highly recommended for eating, people watching and souvenir hunting in the surrounding souks. Go deep in though past the tourist stalls for the best deals, and haggle like mad.

The heart and soul of Marrakech. Wow, feels so good to remember the experience I had at Jemaa el Fna! We went there twice because we just couldn't get enough of it. It's an amazing, magical place. It has its own vibrancy, its own life. Not sure the locals are aware of the jewel they have there. It's just amazing. I want to start by saying that we never got lost, even though we wandered the narrow streets of the Medina and checked every little souk. It's spider-web-shaped, so wherever you go, you'll end up in the main square at some point. No guide, it was just me and my husband. Never felt unsafe, but I respected their privacy, didn't take pictures, tried not to make eye contact, ignored the aggressive vendors and just enjoyed the experience. It wasn't as bad as people described it, sellers in our markets back home are sometimes similar to those in Marrakech, so nothing new for me. Avoid the place where they park the carriages, the horse smell is unbearable in day heat. We went to Morocco in September and it was hot. My husband was a bit overprotective and was always on guard but, to be honest, there's nothing to worry about. Have some common sense and, as long as you respect their privacy and culture, nothing bad will happen.You can mingle but never be under the impression that you'll go unseen, that's an illusion. They know you're a tourist from miles away and will always try to rip you off. Keep your wits, be polite, walk away and be firm if you're not interested in what they're offering or just buy what you like. Enjoy the main square, it's an experience I'll never forget!!!!

Crazy, fun, exhausting!. The market area is hectic, to say the least! It is fairly exhausting saying no to everyone. A word of warning, scrutinise the items you are buying very carefully. Some items are made in China and you can probably get it cheaper in Camden market with half the hassle. The food market at night, though, is a definite must and lots of fun deciding on a table to sit at. I would personally not support the snake or monkey handlers. The monkeys are badly abused and the snakes are barely alive.

Not what I was expecting. After all the hype with the square I was a little disappointed. We ate one evening in one of the many food stalls. Whilst the food was good I did feel it was overpriced. The square has so many stalls selling orange juice you wonder how they make ant money. The events at night are very amateurish and really do not a look. During the day there are snake charmers but if you dare to take a photo they will pounce on you looking for money. The entrance to the square from the main road is where the horse and carriages line up. There must be over 100 of these and the smell of horse droppings is sickening. Overall I was please I visited but is not a place I would rush back to. Where as the souks and medinas that surround the square are bustling and definitely worth a visit.

Just don t.... Or be prepared to have some situations. i m a very open minded lad BUT many ppl tried to take advantage of me during my stay. One of those said he was not a tour guide, guided to some places around Jemaa and charged me 100DHR for that. Nice welcome!

Monty Python meets Arabian Nights. If you saw this square in Disneyland you might think it was over the top - but it's real! By day, it is a busy square with souks leading off and various stalls. By night, it is a seething, joyful mass of people. Snake charmers, monkeys, male dancers dressed as women, musicians, comedy acts (largely meaningless if you are not a local) food stalls and the all-pervading smoke from stoves filling the night air. The throbbing music and insistent rhythm of the pounding drums are mesmerising. Apart from the snakes themselves (??looked like hooded cobras - but probably harmless - their owners handled them without bother!!) there is another serpent to contend with - the pick-pockets. Unfortunately, we had a camera stolen while there. With so many people pushing and bumping into you, it is a paradise for the forty thieves. So, carry the minimum amount of cash for your outing and keep a very firm hand on any valuables. But even so, do not be nervous about going there - Jemaa does not feel personally threatening.

Smelly and crazy. Keep your wits about you in this large and crazy public square and that's in daylight. At night this place fills up with a market, food stalls, snake charmers and is completely insane. that said, daughter and I felt reasonably safe. It was worth a look but we didn't delve too far into the middle of the mêlée.

Exotic. Keep calm. Just join the crowd and best to get citymap2go app. Ignore people who tells you the road in frint is closed. They are just trying to confuse you so as to earn a dollar from you to show you the direction via an alternate way.

Full of life!. Loved walking around in Jemaa el Fna! There is always something going on - snake charmers, take a pic w/ a monkey (?), different acts etc. Be careful though, if you look at those acts long enough, you are most likely expected to tip :) Me and my husband walked around the shops and got a sense of the prices for the goods. Definitely over priced for the tourist - best is to go from shop to shop and bargain! Also - if you like something in Jemaa el Fna - see if you are able to go out in the city and get those goods (or inner medina perhaps). A tea pot set with glasses & tray, which we couldn't get for lower than 900 dh in Jemaa el Fna - we were able to get in inner medina for less than 200 dirhams. Just bargain! It's fun. We went in mid November, so was definitely a bit chilly after sunset - so have a light jacket or sweater with you. Also, do try the sugarcane juice - it is so good & refreshing! Cant exactly remember the name of the place, but it's in the alley where there are many shwarma restaurants.

Barbecue Madness. Given this 5 star because it's a 1 off experience. In truth you dare not ask the price of anything, don't let anyone think your interested in buying something and for all the spices on offer all the food tastes like barbecue lighter fluid. On the plus side it's cheap and a good place to meat like minded travellers.

Crazy place. Busy spot especially after dark.Lots of people trying to make you spend your money.Snake charmers , guys with monkeys , beggars, hawkers etc. If you take a photograph be prepared for people looking for money because they were in the frame. Mind you pockets especially if a crowd gathers around any particular performance.

Great night markets!. This square really comes alive at night. My husband and I had dinner here and it is amazing to see all of the sights and sounds. You can stop and take a look at numerous attractions, even snake charmers.

Dont be intimidated, just get in there and see the sights!. The main square offers everything from tasty Moroccan cuisine to freshly squeezed juice which costs practically nothing, traditional north African music to belly dancing men in drag, snake charmers to second hand teeth sellers!!! I can't tell you everything you will see here, it's a melting pot and it changes every day! Prepare for it to be very busy in the evenings, can be really dusty and noisy too. To the newly arrived tourist can be quite a daunting or even intimidating experience but don't let it make you feel like that on your first visit because by the time you go back for a 2nd time you will be de-sensitized to it all and be more mentally equipped to take it all in! Men will try to sell you anything and everything, just don't get involved in a conversation with them, be firm, shake your head and keep on walking. It's a great place to experience, expect hustle and bustle though, this ain't for the fainthearted!

Unbelievably busy and chaotic. We have visited souks etc in Tunisia but this square is absolutely mind blowing. If you like unusual entertainment this has much to offer but beware if you take photos you will be expected to prefer at least 2 Dirhams! Keep plenty of small change. Good overall view from surrounding hotel terraces, but you have to purchase food or drink. Orange stalls and in the late afternoon it really comes into its own. Very noisy
not for americans. we got harassed on this well know placed,could not enjoy anything and took a rickshaw back to the hotel

Square with a life of its own. I visited in May 2015 as a single female and I had a wonderful time. The vibrancy of this square is palpable. From the dozens of freshly squeezed orange juice vendors, the henna artists, the snake charmers, the shop keepers, the belly dancers, the makeshift restaurants to the locals, there is not much else one can ask for in a single location. Chances are you would be approached by several vendors asking you to buy their merchandise, which if you are interested, it turns into an opportunity for you to hone your negotiation skills.The locals are exceptional people, everyone wants to have a conversation and offer you the best mint tea in the world. I would return to Marrakech and to JEEMA EL FNA.

Great square. Great life. One of the most interesting points of Marraquexe. This square is full of life, during the day and night it is one of the must charismatic points of the city. You can find everything in here. Snakes, monkeys, argan oils, spices, restaurants, street performances, street food, juices (Orange juices are very typical, very tasty and cheap) and you have also a variety of market shops. Beware of people asking money. Sometimes the vendors are very persistent and annoying. Don't forget to bargain.

Dont worry-be happy!. After reading reviews of Marrakech and Jamaa el Fna we approached visiting the square with trepidation but the worries were unfounded. Friendly stall holders, plenty of tourist police, just say 'maybe later' and everyone will leave you alone to enjoy. Dont miss it!

Madness but a must see. Obviously you cannot leave Marrakech without seeing the famous Jemma el Fna. But it is dirty, noisy, smoky, pricey, etc etc. And several people I know have got sick after eating here. Its appearance and character during the day and the night are completely different so perhaps good to come twice. I prefer it during the day when several Berber men and women sell stuff they make themselves.

Crazy. Visited Dec 2015 for the First time, I have been to many countries and I can honestly say this place is the craziest, a very busy place and it feels like everybody wants to get your attention, this can be a bit overwhelming at first. To eat street food at one of the many stalls was probably a highlight, amazing food at very reasonable prices. The amount of traffic, which could be cars, motorbikes, cycles, horse and carriage, Donkey and carts made me feel like I was in a game of human dodgems BUT I would return.

Busy busy busy . Great insight into how the world used to be many many years ago - including the west. Not a place is buy anything as its more for the African market are the goods in my opinion but worth a visit with many cafes restaurants and snack vendors.

One of the most incredible squares in the World. Jemaa el Fna is one of the most amazing squares in the world. It has so much going on in it. It completely changes from day time to night time. During the day are musician with snakes and monkeys and at night the food stands in the middle open up. They can be quite overwhelming and some are better than other, I recommend #32, they had great sausages and grilled meats.
Entertaining. Several very good street performers - snake handlers, musicians, jugglers, illusionists. Throngs of assorted peoples, very lively, great for people watching,

Excitement and bustle. The square is very exciting, particularly in the evening. But be wary of the snake charmers, and do not encourage the people with chained monkeys. Don't take your photo with them because these poor monkeys are treated terribly. People will warn you not to eat in the square, but I ate there several times and everything was delicious.

Wonderful Morocco in one square . Go to this square in the evening. Be overwhelmed by all the debts, food, music, snakes, monkeys, dancing, fire! Walk around and have a drink on one of the rooftop bars!
Interesting sqaure. Lots of shopping and live shows. Main square in Marrakech. Lots of history. Just be careful not to get lost in that labyrinth.
An amazing experience!. A must do if visiting Marrakech!!! Be aware as people will taunt you into things with great expertise!

Vibrant visit. A must visit for Marrakech!! I would recommend going in the day and night...but if you are short on time, evening/ night would be my suggestion. Full of loads of different stall and people looking to get your money. Plenty of snake charmers, monkeys and all sorts of other tricks and treats. Be careful in giving money to any beggars as soon as one sees this, they all come and even hold on to you - watch your pockets!! Certainly a very busy, vibrant and authentic experience of Marrakech. Would recommend a visit for sure.

Hustle and bustle - good too see. A must see but personally only tolerable for a few hours. Sit on the glacier cafe balcony to watch over everything if you dont like getting hassled like me and my finace ( the meat skewers with chips 50mad are lovely there too). Much of the shops all sell the same things. There is a great wee shop that only sells postcards on the south side of it. Snake charmers, dancing, monkeys ( watch out they just come over and get the monkey to jump on you and as i observed whatever anyone gave them they always made out like they were unhappy and asked for more money but stick to your guns and they dont seem to be too bothered and walk away. Lots of henna ladies about - i wore a long sleeve cardigan because i heard they just come over and grab your arm and before u know it u have to pay for something you didnt want - but i didnt see this happening. If u want a horse and carriage ride there is a load of them just up from the square - not my thing but alot of them looked in better condition than i have seen in other countries.
Well worth a visit. Went on 3 occasions during out holiday. The best was on a Saturday night. There wad so much going on. Lots to see, hear and do.

One of the most difficult ratings.... Where to start... I decided to go to Marrakech instead of Malta for this!! I went once before in 2007, but I guess I was too young to remember how horrible it was. I was so excited to be there sitting by the stalls, smelling good food, sampling different options, sipping tea, enjoying the beautiful lights and colours... It's a different reality though. As soon as you set foot in the square, be prepared to be harassed by anyone within 5 meters of you. The hustlers just cannot let you pass without annoying you with their products or restaurant menus. They do not take no for an answer and I can assure you, after the 5th time (make that a few meters), it becomes VERY VERY ANNOYING. The first day, you have patience and you keep saying no politely. But it does not get any better, and I had to devise methods of not being harassed by looking down and avoiding eye-contact. Some people can make you very angry as well by blocking your way and then having a laugh when they succeeded in ruining your day. This has been a general experience in Marrakech. Now to come to the square itself, during the day, snake charmers, monkey owners (dirty!) and women who apply henna will harass you the moment you make eye-contact with them. Do not take any pictures, unless you are from very far away! At night, the whole square becomes bustling with light, people and stalls selling food, most of them having the same thing; there are 3 kinds of stalls: all the mixed meats, lamb head and harira soup. They are all pretty much the same. Word of advice, make sure you add your bill before they tell you the total, as my stall tried to overcharge me 60dhs (that's another 2 meals!!). And the stale bread you have when you sit down, is not free; make sure you want it or else you'll pay 20dhs for stale bread. Prices are very hot as well; 70dhs for a seafood platter to sit on a wooden stool, when 70dhs can get you a 4-star restaurant meal! As much as I wanted to be there and enjoy this place, the stereotyping (not to say racist) hustlers just ruined every time I went there.
Awesome . My type of market both in the morning or at night. I enjoyed all the bargains and the madness in the square. The oil merchants or "call guys" can be rude sometimes. Amazing visit.

Lights up at night. Enjoyable place to visit. However there are too many people trying to make a quick buck out of you. My wife had henna put on her hand without her consent and then was asked to pay.

Just sit at any table - the menu, price and taste is all the same and no one cheats you. Try to sit inside the maze as beggers keep approaching you when you are seated outside the square. Dont be surprised when a desert trolley comes to you. I didnt thry the deserts though.

Madness at it's best. If you visit Marrakech then you must visit Jemaa el Fna. If you visit Jemaa el Fna then do it at night when the place really comes alive. Through the day it's a bit drab, a few stalls and some awful side shows with snake charmers and monkeys. But at night - amazing. Nothing quite prepares you for the sensory overload, the sights, sounds and smells. Some great food stalls and interesting entertainment.
a little weird. I must say, I heard a lot about this square. Wasn't really my cup of tea. I actually found it strange. There were a few odd characters who had a bad vibe about them.

Aggressive Tourist Trap. I was reading somewhere that the King of Morocco would like to double tourism by the year 2020 (or something of the like). Here's a word of advice, you really need to get the people who frequently deal with tourists under control if you're going to want visitors to keep coming back. They really prey on tourists here, for sure, so you really need to #1 be prepared to be harassed by the most aggressive sales people that you'll ever meet. #2, be aware of your surroundings at all times to make sure you're not going to be taken advantage of. #3, know how to, and be prepared to say NO, no matter how aggressive the vendors are. As I stated earlier the folks in the square were overly aggressive, and really made the experience generally unpleasant. Unsolicited, we were approached by a guy with a monkey, who basically threw his monkey on the back of my wife, who did NOT enjoy it. Of course, everyone expects to get paid for every little thing if you take any pictures, so we politely declined to take any pics and went on our way. A few seconds later, we were aggressively approached by a henna tattoo artist, and despite telling her multiple times we weren't interested (she was fluent in English), she basically threw some henna ink onto my wife's hand, and left a stain. Really? Was that necessary? Do you think that's going to make us come back? There are a bunch of snake "charmers" in the square as well, so as we were leaving, we were approached by a guy trying to sell us merchandise again, so we politely declined. Then he reached into his bag to pull out a rubber snake for sale which scared the crap out of me! I'm not that afraid of snakes, but we had just walked by about 10 cobras, and that rubber snake was life like! No thank you!!!Anyway, we don't plan on coming back to Morocco after this experience unless significant changes are made. Here's another piece of advice, have the folks in the marketplace post SOME prices, and start hanging price tags on the merchandise like every other civilized country. The sales people in the marketplace could literally charge ANYTHING they want, and get away with it with uneducated tourists. Luckily we had done our research and knew what was a fair price, but having to haggle over EVERY purchase is tiresome, and honestly just made me want to leave sooner than we should have, and made the whole experience not as enjoyable. We had plans to spend 2-3 days shopping here and at the various souks in the Medina area, but once was enough, and we didn't really want to come back. I'm giving this 2 stars just because, yes, it was a unique experience, and something you have to do when you visit Marrakech - but anytime you have a generally unpleasant experience, and don't want to come back, warrants a 2 star review, at best.
Top notch . Best souks, good food , lots of bartering. The fresh orange juice sellers and food stalls are a good experience. It's worth the experience
Okay but nothing great!. A big market place. Mainly cheap tat! Some nice views from the rooftop cafes. Look out for motorbikes, they ride about like crazy!
interesting place. This is a good place to go at night we went in the day and at night we saw bill murry on stage at night plenty of places to eat

Showtime. If you are a people-watcher, I can think of few places as fascinating as this famous square, a magnet for locals and tourists alike. It's like going to the circus except you get to walk around in the three rings where the show goes on and on. Acrobats, drummers, stands with delicious orange juice for 40 US cents, snake charmers, hucksters, food at every turn, cafes to sit in when you need a break and from which you can continue to watch the show at a slight remove from the action. Then there are all the twisted alleys of the souk, taking you by shop after shop with everything you might need and many things you don't: shoes and leather goods, copperware, silver, more shoes, olives, slow-roasted lamb, djellabas, cotton shirts, fabric, souvenirs, and more. Be ready to bargain, and you probably shouldn't ask about things you don't intend to buy, but other than that, it's the free market in action. Beware those Invisible Hands!

Amazing place . Stunning. Exciting. Vibrant. A feast for the ears and the eyes. Full of energy. Unmissable and well worth its status Ada heritage site. Too many sellers and too much perspective which can cause a frustration but a small price to pay for such a magnificent and fulfilling experience.

What you might expect. The best way to see the square is from a balcony view above it all. Pay for a soda and take in the craziness from a quiet table before diving in to the experience. Crowded, loud, bustling...just as you might expect and certainly a "can't miss" while in Marrakech.
Babylonian at Sunset. It's the heart of Marrakech. Total Babylonian with snake chargers, story tellers, hena tattoos, and many vendors of all products and foods.

Sit on a rooftop and watch the world go by. I love Jemma el fan, I would recommend eating at the food stalls on the basis that you aren't put off by telling people no and you are open to food ideas that you probably would never see at home. Otherwise sit on aloof terrace and watch the world go by, it's a wonderful buzz to watch.

Interesting . This place is a big open square. Be careful when you're walking, taxis are everywhere. You cannot tell if it's a walking path or a road. I would suggest to go in the morning as it's much more calm and less monkeys and snakes. You MUST drink their orange juice it's only 4 Dirham a glass. It's fresh squeezed and it's amazing! After midday more people are out to sell stuffs and if you're not interested just shook you're head, say no thank you and keep walking.
All senses of Marrakech. Enjoy the smells, sounds and views of Marrakech. Lots of people, lots of food and lots of to watch. A must see both during the day, and at night.

One almighty market. It's pretty much a market the size of a small town. Many things to buy if they take your fancy, all the usual market items, I.e. Traditional items as well as all the fakes, which they will try their best to convince you are real. Don't be a mug and you'll be fine. Thousands of people all going about their thing, it's best just to find a roof top restaurant and watch that madness go by.

Amazing At Nightime. Vibrant and full of life a must for when visiting Marrakech! Great atmosphere and funny banter from the store holders. Enjoy them trying to get you to eat at their stall! Fresh orange juice for 4Dhm (31p) what's not to like! The fresh mint tea is yummy, didn't try the snails though!There are a lot of beggars small kids and women (selling tissues) they're a bit pestering but if you give them a firm no they will go away.
Hectic place to visit . Too caotic, crowded and hectic for my taste. I would avoid it during late afternoon when I visited it.
Great experience. Don't take photos of local street performers they will demand money.Food stalls are very good and are there every evening. 3 course meal for two people including drinks 13.00 GBP

Life and soul of Marrakech. Our Riad was a stone's throw from the square so we passed through every day. Sunday night was absolutely seething and full of atmosphere. I'm fairly sure EVERYONE was there that night. It was a stark contrast on Monday night when it was very quiet and we were singled out by the sellers much more often and strangely latched onto by a drunk (which is the strange part in itself, in a dry area), who kept asking for my phone number - while my fiance was walking next to me. We still marvelled at the vivid life each visit we made, enjoyed the fresh juice, got asked our country of origin many times, got called blondie a few times, almost man-handled into a carpet shop, cursed by a little girl when the waiter chased her away, and generally just tried to stroll and take it all in. We couldn't go crazy on the shopping anyway - we'd only flown with hand luggage!

Chaos! . Exactly what you would expect, it's absolute madness! It's what a lot of tourists want to see, snake charmers, drum players, jewellery and art sellers, make sure you haggle with a smile and don't be afraid to say no and walk away. Stay away from the henna ladies, they use black henna which causes bad reactions, instead head to the henna art cafe where they train and employ local women fairly and they're not for profit. Poor old monkeys definitely avoid because intelligent animals shouldn't be treated that way. The orange juice stalls are all fantastic, they are fresh and delicious! Keep your safety head on and you'll have a great time seeing crazy things, sometimes chaos is fun!

Great atmosphere!. We spent time at jemaa el fna every day as you pass through the square to the souk. It's full of life and it looks beautiful. At night there are so many different market vendors who all try and get you to eat at their place cheering when you choose theirs! The food is great though most stalls have roughly the same things. The mint tea is so good! At night there are jam sessions and you can pay to fish for fanta bottles!

Great experience. This place is amazing and mental! Just keep your hand out of grabbing distance as you may be dragged by someone to take a picture with their money/snake or with them.Also don't feel obliged to buy anything. You may feel like you have to, just say you will come back later or no.Also shop around and go off the beaten track for the best deals.

Watch out for the henna girls. Busy square, lots to see but beware of the henna girls! They grab you, say they are "giving a gift", squiggle a bit of henna on your hand then demand 700Dirhams!!!Refuse to pay. If you haven't asked for it don't pay for it!

Vibrant colourful all day attraction. After coming out of the rather dark medina with its narrow market streets you step into an open sunlit square where shopping (Marrakech's main interest) can continue, but with a twist. Alongside more stalls and shops, you now encounter snake charmers, henna tattooists, musicians and other street entertainers. Still some risk of being run over by motor bikes, but much fewer than in the medina, and easier to dodge in a wide space. Wonderful stalls selling fresh fruit juice are everywhere. The square provides loads of cafés and restaurants for all tastes and budgets. Lots of waiters trying to get you into theirs, but not such aggressive hard sell as in the medina. When eating in outdoor cafés you do get irritating interruptions from sellers and baggers that are allowed to wander in and hassle you. The square is busy in the day time, but really comes to life after dark, when more entertainers appear, and extra people pop up to sell stuff just from a box or sheet on the ground. If you want a quieter experience, I found there was a brief lull around dusk between day and night visitor traffic.

A Must See!. A central spot, the square is a must see for all visitors to Marrakesh! Go at sunset and grab a rooftop drink at one of the restaurants surrounding the square for an incredible aerial view of the snake charmers and other street performers, food vendors and sightseers. Watch your pockets and purses as the chaos makes travelers vulnerable to pickpockets. Additionally, our guide warned us not to eat any of the food sold from the vendors in the square. If you want any of the nuts or fruits, buy them from the vendors in the souks (where the locals go) as everything is more fresh and hasn't been sitting out on display for days.

This is the square to be at. Day and night this square is full of people merchants, tourists and people shopping for their daily needs. Just stand there and take in all the different colours, smells and people. Very interesting street performers with dancers and music, some with monkeys and snakes (felt a bit sorry for them though I do in a zoo as well). Definitely go there and up one of the cafes with a terrace to take in the view of the square from above.

The Heart of Marrakech . We had our lunch at (Chez Aicha) No. 1 clean, great and tasty food with very reasonable prices. The place is crowded with people, small shops distributed allover the place.People are friendly and if you have negotiation skills you can buy good products with good prices (leather bags, silver plated tea pots, gallabyas, souvenirs, Tajins, silver accessories ect..) Drink Natural Orange juice and eat Halazoon (snails) have fun there, banks and money exchange is nearby.

This is Marrakech. I didn't have a lot of time to know the city, but one of the things we did was to walk a lot in the square. What a breathtaking experience, there was so many things happening at the same time it was hard to focus on only one. The place is full with tourist attractions, snakes, monkey, henna tattoo, etc. I think is a must go, just remember to take care of your things ( there are pickpocketing), eat in some terrace of the restaurants around, enjoy the view and maybe the sunset. There are scarfs, lambs, plates, leather things, all with a rustic and local design. Other tips:- Make some shopping and remember to always ask for a lower price.- Eat there thamaras and damascus - Drink the mint tea and one orange juice- For a photo with the monkeys I payed (10 dirham).

Have to see it to believe it. This place must be the most exiting place on earth at night. The music, drums, smells, noise, smoke, story tellers, pick pockets, food, spices, people and sooo much more is like no other - just love it.

Chaos, aromas, markets, MARRAKECH. A must see or better said, experience when in Marrakech. There is so much happening that it's impossible to see everything that is happening at once. Than there is also the difference with the night and day, so you must experience both.

a feast for the senses. We had a ball just engaging with all the things going on. The jamming sessions were the best, on a monday night there were hundreds of young men really enjoying making music. The buskers hat was not the main reason they were there - people were there for the music - from Toureg to trance. However there are a couple of women who are very aggressive about putting henna on your hand and wont let it go, and avoid the snake charmers as they chased one of my friends demanding more money after she had taken a photo of a snake.

busiest market ive been to. interesting mix of food vendors souvenir stalls horses and traffic. watch out for the snake charmers/ monkey owners who will charge you for taking their photo but I didn't find them too pushy.
so joyfull. you can eat seafood, meat, something traditional or just fast food. drink coffea tea ,dance, watch dancer, buy some argan oil products. whatever you want...

Watch out for aggressive people! Don't eat at food stall #31. It's interesting to walk through the square one BUT beware of aggressive women trying to grab your hand for henne AND aggressive men trying to push their menus in your face! Do note that food stall #31 (corner stall) is ripping tourist off! They will put a bunch of small plates in front of you...don't expect it to be free....they don't tell you, but they will charge u afterwards. They only do this to tourist! The woman that sat across from me got the same dishes and was not charged at all! My bill doubled because we were 4 ppl (3 or 4 plates we did not asked for each plus they charged for bread). Stay away from food stall #31!I did had a great experience at the soup stall! They were honest and mostly locals go there! Sorry, I don't remember the stall number. Hope this helps!

Here right now. Well open air market place.lots of things going on.monkeys on chains with climb on your head. There is 100 plus different food and drink stalls to try.be warned dont walk down any dark alleys as we spent an hour lost round the back somewhere.deff go again if i am in marrakesh

Awful. Horrible dirty smelly and loud. Unsafe at night and parts are just downright filthy. Didn't want to touch anything or buy anything. Just awful. On the plus side we didn't get lost as we had a guide which is essential!!!!!!!

Travelers beware, especially solo women. I opted to get out of Marrakech after just one day that began in Jemâa El Fna. I'm from NYC, so I'm down with the big city vibes, but this place was so aggressive that I couldn't stand it. The night prior, I was dropped off by a family I had been visiting outside of Marrakech, and an employee of the Riad I was staying it came to meet me there to show me back to my accommodation. Even with a local family by my side, I was immediately swallowed into this insane whirlwind of people constantly approaching with toys, snakes, offers for henna, men dressed in traditional Berber outfits, and guys just flat out asking for money. The next day on my own without the shadow of the family covering me, it was 100x worse. People got physical- men demanding money from me, refusing to stop following me. A younger kid grabbing my canvas tote bag, a guy thrusting a snake in my face and refusing to leave me alone after I said no thank you several times. The men are VERY grabby with women who are alone- there seems to be no public consideration or rule of respect. I met up with a make traveler there and walked through with him- he was physically assaulted by 3 me demanding 200 Dirhams for taking a picture of the square, which they claim they were in. The place is total insanity. The only reason I'd ever recommend it is for the orange juice & the nice guy selling it @ cart #18

A must pace to visit in Marrakech very busy at night. Jemma el fan The place is great and must be seen during the day as well as at night most of the intertanement snake charmers and other activities are going on . Freshly squeezed orange juice 40 cent approx or 4 diremDuring the day you can visit the souk which is all around the square but be prepared to haggle or say no.Monkeys in captivity I didn't like and were offered for photos at a price of course .The square comes alive after dark out door restaurants set the smells of the cooking is hard to describe but it's beautiful They must cater for thousands of people and the food is very reasonable.As during the day there is all kinds of intertanement going on .no alcohol in side the medina so don't be expecting beer ot the like Martin Castlebar
Amazing and busy; not to be missed.. Whatever your heart desires. Great and cheap food, at night in one of the many food stalls, snake and other charmers, and the entry to the wonderful souks.

Nice, VERY busy. My travel partner didnt like men pulling his shoulder and arm and walking in front of him.I LOVED it. The diversity, shops, odd people, fantasies reality, etc. Sunset is a special time, just before the sun goes down, the vibe changes at the market: the magic comes out. The prayer is the moment the sun in down.

a special place. changing in its charms throughout the daily 24 hours. It is entertaining, fun and annoying at the same time. It presents itself as a touristic classic and seems to re-stage itself every day. But besides from the snake charmers and story tellers there are many authentic presentation which are enjoyed by the locals as much as by tourists. And this fact makes it more inviting to have a closer look, to take your time and melt in into this attraction. And yes, be careful - every photo you dare to take will be paid or you are cursed - so fill your pockets with coins!

Mass of Humanity. This square really represents all of Marrakech, all its craziness, life, exotic, rich, poor and foods. You can find a cross section of Morocco in this crazy place. You can't miss it and you can't stay away.

An experience, but stand your ground. As you might expect the square is a central point for tourists and so, people trying to make a few dirham off said tourists with which I have no problem, its part of the experience. And I learned very quickly, a firm but polite no thank you repeated means you will be left alone if you are not interested. We had one negative experience when in the square over a number of days where when taking photos some "performers" jumped in to my photo then tried to insist I pay them for them actually wrecking the photo I wanted actually, I obviously refused as I hadn't wanted their photo, just their scam that may work on others. I stood my ground refused and walked away - obviously being cursed out as I did, but hey ho, it could have been worse. Apart from silly things like this, the atmosphere is fun, there's always something interesting to see and some of the food here is awesome, and quite cheap. I prefer the souks in general for better atmosphere and intrigue, the square was some entertainment though.

One big tourist trap. We really don't get why people keep visiting this place. Marrakech is a beautiful city full of wonderful people. This square does not represent anything from Marrakech or indeed Morocco. Don't think this will be one of the highlights of your trip, because if that's the case you really missed out a lot.If you are, like me, a seasoned traveler who likes to visit a new place and see it from a locals point of view, you will understand. If you do want to go, just be careful of your belongings and don't take pictures before asking. We met to many people who didn't...

This square is jumping day and night!. By day there are men charming cobras and men taking your photo with a monkey but each night there are brightly dressed dancers from Senegal who beat drums relentlessly in an effort to drum up a donation. Also about 150-200 small food stalls set up every day. It's good to get a recommendation - 114 was suggested to us. In typical Moroccan whimsy the numbers are all over the place. Plenty of food options.

Good fun. To wander through looking. Most vendors were put off with a firm no.Enjoyed it very muchGot there early enough to see the snake charmers- very touristy but fun. Watch out they will charge you for photos

How many people, that many activity,. A million man, dancing, playing eating, selling sth, monkeys, snakes, fortune tellers,... plus locals passing by, on the way home, walking in the square but not there at all. Like a, ummm,... .. I can't describe the anarchy, go and see.

Such a fun place to meet very friendly men. An exciting and lovely place to visit to discover the mysteries of the Magreb and the inner most secrets of Marrakech.Wonderful dancing and special tricks makes it such a great and fun place to visit.The men are sooo sooo friendly and willing to come to your room to show you even more special tricks and things!!!You will enjoy so much. It's very fun.

Join the throngs of locals but don't let anyone offer to take a photo for you with any animal!. Monkeys, snakes, pigeons and Falcons all want money. Smells and sounds are exotic and pleasant. Watch and see, preferably from the safely of a roof top restaurant. Most do not do alcohol so check first if you need a drink. The canteens in the market are clean and fun but expect to pay normal restaurant prices. We ate for just under £20 per head and had a bit of everything mezza style. Not sure it was a good idea but chance to try stuff out.

The lively town center. After shopping in the souk this is the center to town to see and be seen. To people watch like no other place. To see the snake charmers, fortune tellers, henna artists. All the food venders from cooked food, fruit juice, many stalls selling snail soup where the broth is supposed to help with a cold. Everyone is looking for a tip from the tourists. You can't watch the snake charmer without giving them a few coins. But you don't feel hustled. The one thing I hated to see were the monkeys on chains and the horse carriages for the tourists. You can see the animals are not well cared for and its a cruel way for them to live. If the Moroccan government cleaned that up the square would be perfect.

An amazing experience. You cannot visit Marrakech without visiting this attraction. The square comes alive in the early evening with snake charmers, monkey's, henna tatto, and lots of things on sale. there ar lots of food stalls to choose from or if you prefer you can find a restaurant around the square.The square is very busy so take care with bags and cameras. The people are poor and see tourists as rich with lots of money to spend. Most of the people are really nice and helpful. However beware of the women walking around the square doing Henna tatoos. They walk towards you and start the tattoo without asking and then they demand 300 diram for the pleasure! Other than that we had a great time. Take care not to photograph people as they will charge you.

Good place to hangout and for picture.. Nice place day time night time for picture.A lot of activity monkeys, snake, orange juice.There are a lot of options for foodie there.There are some places that are worth to try.I like that places for pictures sunset and sundown awsome picture.

What a circus!. Interesting place for a night but once you have seen it...move on as its pretty much Disneyland. Those poor monkeys being used as ways to make a cheap living...ignore them and it may just save a monkey from the poachers. Same goes with the snakes.You must try the tea stalls....very tasty! Also the fresh orange juice stalls.Overall an interesting place.
Electric!. Jemaa el Fna is interesting during the day, but you must go at night for the full effect. You'll be blown away by the sights and sounds - truly as exotic a place as you'll ever see.

Intense but worth it. Experience the crazy hustle & bustle of Marrakech. Expect to be hassled big time particularly if you're a woman and don't go out without your thick skin. If you don't like snakes, when you hear music walk in the opposite direction.
Overrated and tacky. Monkeys in nappies, sad-looking snakes. Avoid it if you can. The definite lowlight of an otherwise enjoyable few days in the city.

Awful place. Avoid at all costs. I was fortunate enough to visit many other Moroccan cities before I came to Marrakech which gave me a wonderful impression of Morocco before I came to this hell hole.This square is a tourist trap. There are men there with monkeys with metal collars round their necks that they drag about for photo opportunities with tourists. There's snakes on the floor that are more drugged than charmed and the souk people are forceful and aggressive. They walk in after you to try and stop you getting out and at one point a very aggressive stall holder had hold of my wrist trying to stop me from leaving.I am quite a strong willed woman, unphased by pushy sales people but I found this pretty intimidating.The entrance to the square is lined with malnourished horses pulling carts and most of them look as though they have conjunctivitis and they are all twitching.The food in the square is apparently nice but any food on show is covered in flies. I will definitely return to Morocco but will avoid this square at all costs.

Absolutely fascinating place. Be prepared to bargain for everything with the vendors, and definitely worth plucking up the courage to eat at one of the stalls that set up in the square after nightfall. Just be prepared to be selective and don't go to the first one you see - despite the attentions of the blokes trying to get you to sit down!

Prepare for sensory overload. Jemma el Fna is a dizzying experience and one that's well worth experiencing. The downside is that if you point a camera at anything you will be hassled for payment - the usual sum being 100 dirhams (around £8). To some travellers less experienced this could be fairly intimidating but, ultimately, Jemaa el Fna and the souks beyond are very safe. The trick to negotiating this part of Marrakesh is to avoid making eye contact with anyone unless you are interested in buying from them. If you should get lost in the souks (as many people do, even locals) don't make the mistake of asking directions or, again, you will be expected to pay even though, most of the time, you are being sent even deeper into what I can only describe as a labyrinth. In our one and only venture into the souks, it took my friend and I three long hours to get out again, during which time we were cajoled and hassled by vendors and locals looking to part you from our cash. If you must go into them, make sure you remember how to get back to where you started or hire a guide.

crazy marrakechhhhh. enjoy the food of Marrakesh The best time to experience the markets is at nightNice place to spend your evening ONLY IF the street seller and the food stall owners stop trying to intemidate you for your custom.This place is full of life and is the true Marrakesh. It hits all your senses and comes to life in the evening.

It's a must......... You can't go to Marrakesh and not visit the night market!! It's vibrant and fun!! The stall holders touting for business!! There's a great buzz about the place!! If you're eating be sure to visit stall 32 it's where all the smoke is coming from and where people stand around waiting for a seat!! The waiter/cook was fascinated by my red lipstick so to guarantee quick service and a seat pack a red lipstick in your bag!!!

everything in one place. Jemaa El Fna is a place where everything happens .You want a ride, get a horse and make it .You are hungry , make the best choise and eat it .You are thirsty , buy anything your soul desire and enjoy it .Buy many suvernirs , clothes , many interesting things and you will be more than thankful .
