You want to dance , leave yourself to the music and do it .Everything in one is Jemaa El Fna .
Busy busy busy. Brilliant for bargains, always quarter the price there asking and walk away. Good leather goods to barter for, it's an experience.

Amazing place full of adventure. Visited most days on our 3 week stay in Marrakech. I love monkeys so took the monkeys a banana most days. It's a lovely place to visit as the sun is going down, you can sit on a cafe terrace and watch the sun disappear whilst having a nice drink. Can't get enough of the square especially at night.

Spirit of the city. Be prepared for the hagglers and ready to dodge people selling everything, but this is a unique spot in Marrakesh. During the day you'll find the snake charmers and henna artists and at night food stalls galore. Worth a stop by to see the true Marrakesh...

A nightly circus of activity!. Dancers, musicians, snake-charmers, monkey hawkers. food venders of all kinds inhabit the beating heart of the Medina, a dizzying swirl that reminded me of a ten ring circus on steroids. Even the occasional call to prayer barely disrupts the endless party!

Disappointing. Tacky. Tick it off the list and move on.. Perhaps I had high hopes from all I'd read about the square. Yes, I saw snake charmers with hooded cobras (a load of). Monkeys on leads encouraged to jump on you for photos. In fact take a photo of anything and you'll be hassled for payment. The food stalls are not that special. I wouldn't eat there again. Whole place is geared up to rather over enthusiastically trying to part you from a few Dirhams.

Abusive men. Went with a friend who is also female both in our twenties. The food market at night has pretty good food but the amount of hassle to get to eat somewhere is overwhelming, with verbal abuse and the people swearing at you if you don't eat in their stall, and constant creepy men saying horrible sexual things to us. Go with a man!

Interesting , busy but a must visit . This is a big open space that gets filled up at night with pop up restaurants, juicers and street artists. Your eyes will be all over the place and you don't know what to look at at . So much to see.It gets very busy and crowded so take extra care with you pockets and bags. Although this is my second visit to the city and I have never had a problem. If you take a photo with the street entertainers you must pay. I ask you kindly not to take photo with the monkeys in chains. They have chains around there necks and get pulled around the Jemma El fna so tourist take photo with them. There tails have been cut and they are put in clothes and nappy for our entertainment. I sat on the roof and watched how bad the handlers treat them. Pulling them around , kicking them and hitting them .They look so sad. Maybe if people stop paying there handlers will go and find real jobs and stop abusing these poor animals. Go to one of the roof top coffee shops and just chill as the world runs by under you.

Felt very safe. Had so much fun with my husband and 10 month old little girl. Felt very safe. All the men were very respectful of me and when I needed to breastfeed my little girl a man shut his shop so I could feed her in private I didn't even ask him! Babies are true VIPs in Marrakech. Fantastic place to holiday

Fantastic place. Have to see. Spend an entire day into the early hours of the morning. Places to shop are much cheaper away from the square. And people are much friendlier than the square. If you do jaggle and stay firm in the square you will get good prices. Its a really phenomenal experience.

Fascinating. Very crowded and live place. You can see monkeys,snakes and thousands of people in one place,literally like ants. Little bit dirrty and unsecure,you should be careful with your bags and personal things. Worth of seeing anyway,especialy at night because it looks really magical.
This IS Marrakech!. This square IS everything you imagine Marrakech to be - buzzing with life, colourful, noisy, I spent hours sitting on roof terrace restaurants just soaking it up and watching!

1001 crazy nights. the centre and heart of the "souk" is a must see, but be aware that you will need patience. try to get to a bar or restaurant on a terrace to enjoy the bustling and countless shops with merchants and the food stalls from above.

Very nice place, . Nice place if you are looking for bargains. It's an open market where you can find all sorts of stuff. In the evening there is a lot of entertainment taking place in the centre. Worth paying a visit.

Simply Crazy. The best time to experience the markets is at night. But you need to be prepared, a strong constitution, and ability to say no, and a willingness to try anything are essential qualities if you are going to truly explore the markets. Don't offend by walking away after haggling for 10 minutes, but do your homework first. Give a dirham or 2 to those who cannot work, and at then end enjoy the food of Marrakesh. Remember it's just Crazy.

Too crowded and not at all what I expected.. Nice place to spend your evening ONLY IF the street seller and the food stall owners stop trying to intemidate you for your custom.Kids will try to sell u anything from a toy to a pack of tissues.Do not make eye contact with anyone unless uou want them to approach you and start asking for money for anything like putting there hat on ur head for a picture that you take from your camera.A beggar stopped us and said 'as salaam walekum' we tried to ignore him and didn't gave him any money and within 3secs his tone changed and he sweared at us. Very shameful act by an old person.We found it very intemidating when in Jemaa el FnaKeep ur personal belonging close to you and safe.
Great but scary. Lovely place but scary. Need to keep all senses active. Lots of crazy stuffs happening in the area and extortion.

A square not to miss. Jemaa el Fna is a must see if you are in Marrakesh. It has everything from food, juice, snakes, monkeys, food stalls to street vendors. Make sure to be there during both day and evening time since the atmosphere changes quite drastically. A good way to get an overview is to have a break in one of the roof tops around the square

Full of life and hits all your senses.. This place is full of life and is the true Marrakesh. It hits all your senses and comes to life in the evening. Snake charmers, cobra fights, monkeys, music, food stalls, quality orange juice, dates are a must watch and try and the souk salesmen keep your head turning and keeps you on uour toes. You need to be alert as in any city, but it is safe. There is a police presence and if you look carefully the whole area is covered by hi tech cctv, which is reasuring. The moroccan authorities appear to have the area under control and allow the tourists to feel safe.There are multiple roof top cafes and restaurants with a great view over the square which you must try for a mint tea and moroccan pastry.
Stressing, but still charming.. Snakes, monkeys, street sellers, street artists, pocket thieves, fake merchandise, street food, cheap cafes etc... Worth 1 visit!

Great fun but keep your wits about you. Fascinating place to visit during the evening with a genuine buzz. Everyone is pushy though so be prepared to be hassled especially in the area where the restaurants set up. Be alert for pickpockets. And take small change with you to tip the various performers that you will see.

Watch for the snake charmers. You can always tell where the snake charmers are because of the music. There will be pipe/flute music and if you like snakes, head for it. You can hold one, have it draped around your neck and photos taken.....If you don't like snakes, then head away from the music. You won't be bothered by them.This square is in the heart of Marrakech and everything is available. I mean everything. Go with an open mind and you'll see how it used to be.

Must-see in Marrakech. Visit both during the day and during the night -- two totally different experiences! Loved it despite of and because of the chaos. If you are hesitant because of harassment, I found that avoiding eye contact & complete silence when provoked helps.

The biggest open festival . Very big plaza with a lot of Marakesh people.They dance,sing and try to earn money by the good or rude way.Sometimes they are very rube but anyway.Snakes are dancing and monkeys are jumping around.You can drink fresh juices in every stet with 0,40€ or to eat in the outdoor tends traditional food Is need to be very careful in this area all the day.
Must see. Jemaam el Fna is a must visit location and I was staying in a riad only 10 minutes walk away so I went daily. You can relax in a cafe by the side and take in the sights and sounds.

Always be aware. So we stayed in the Marrakech Medina which was very close to Jemaa el Fna Square and the square is quite quiet during the day, but really comes alive at night! Its exciting, but you still have to be aware of what you take pics of and who you make eye contact with. Oh and we ate in the square one night, it was probably the worst meal that we had all trip and maybe the worst restaurant I've ever been to.

Underwhelming Spot. The main square was a bit disappointing, unless you want to buy orange juice from the many, many juice vendors. The snake charmers and folks with trained monkeys are there, but primarily out to get your money. Provides a good entry point to the souks, though.

WOW!. We had been in this incredibly large plaza in the morning when it was plenty lively w all sorts of vendors, snake charmers, beggars, etc. But to return at sunset to one of the rooftop cafes is an otherworldly experience. Many more vendors had set up in the plaza and they all are cooking! It's just fascinating to the average Westerner to sit and watch this very exotic world pass by. Don't miss it!
Fun to wander around. Good for people watching! Not so good for taking pictures, unless you're willing to pay for them. There's plenty to see and plenty to eat.

Great Place to visit. This is the busiest square I have ever visited. Packed with traders, hawkers, snake charmers, water sellers, monkeys, to name but a few. The street food stalls are excellent and fairly cheap, but for a better quality meal the Marrakchi, by the Cafe de France, offers suberb food and wine. The square is a fantastic experience by night or day.
Must be visited in the evening. It's loud, very impressions, snakes, pickpockets, food and magic. Although it is a bit too much of everything as it should be visited at least once during the evening.

Better at night. Visited during the day and there wasn't much about. However the hustle and bustle starts to come out as the sun goes down and its a completely different place. Famous for all the food markets the guys inside will say anything to try and get you to come in and eat at their place. Some are pretty funny! This is where there are lots of entertainers including people dressing up monkeys and snake charmers (not to everyone's taste, but have to accept this is a different country and way of living) Watch out for the Henna women. Some people are allergic to henna, and they the henna in a syringe with a blunt needle on. This is so that they get more precise lines but it is a little unnerving when they come up to grab your hand and try and henna you. Just be cautious as with everything. One of the Moroccan men even told us to keep an eye on our bags! HOWEVER its not all gloom as its a massive part of Marrakesh and a DEFINITE visit. Alot to see and do.

Amazing and cray place!. Definitely a must see! It is the heart of old Marrakech and day or night - there are things to see. If you go at night, do eat at one of the stalls that pop up for evening dinner. We recommend Stall 26 - the family is all there and the food very good. In the evening note of warning - watch your pocket! When viewing any of the side shows - the "performers" will draw you into the circle and they have cronies who come up next to you and try to pick your pocket! It happened to my husband but fortunately we wore a money belt along his waist. He felt the pick pocket, but also noticed the guys friends surrounding him (the pick pocketer) so he could make a quick get away and you would be blocked from going after him.Other than that, it is a marvelous place to wander around feel the pulse of the city. We recommend having a break at the Cafe France restaurant second floor terrace and watch the stories unfold below.

An experience. Full of tricks and twists. Good bazaar for shopping. Not too much hassle until you show interest in buying. Snake charmers and monkeys that are clearly drugged are not P.C. The tourists seem to love it. Everyone ends up here at sometime during their trip. Not to be missed.

So interesting!. This place is fascinating in the evening! I knew not to take photos unless I wanted to fork over some money, so I didn't have the experiences some of the previous reviewers had. However, we learned that if you are standing waiting for some entertainment to begin, someone may come and tell you to give money. When that happened we just said that nothing had started yet and we walked away. They usually went to the tourists first. I have never traveled anywhere where people asked for money so much or were so aggressive of sales persons as in this country. By the time we went to the square, we had learned how to say, "No" easily. The square is certainly not to be missed. I would not take young children there in the evening since it is so crowded and dark in several places.

Crazy place!. So easy to get lost, we got scammed the first night, paid about 40 quid for a meal that should have cost no more than a tenner each, but i guess its all part of the experience. There are so many exits and all look the same, be weary of leary men and do not take pictures with any men with fez hats, they chase you for ages asking for money. In the end, we just avoided eye contact with everyone, it seemed the safest way.
Good for shopping. Busy shopping square. Everyone is out to rip you off you have to haggle and haggle to get good price. Good quality stuff here. Food stalls are really nice. Stall 114 is the best

Exciting. When we first arrived here Gavin and i were speechless! Hundreds of people milling around from all over the world the brightness of the colours and the noise was exciting. Lovley little cafes where u can sit with a coffee and watch everything from snake charmers to musicians i will never forget this....

Just take a walk at night - al exotic Marrakesh in 1 hour. You have to go there, stroll around -you do not need to buy - but look and compare. Most of the sellers are only paid if the sell . so they are eager to show you what you want. Haggle - haggle - but do not buy, if you think the quelity is not correct.And then take a stroll down the Mohammed V. avenue, where there are shops and cafes etc. And buy some of the fine patisserie at Patisserie des Princes.

An overwhelming experience. I cannot imagine any tourist not going or winding up here.During daytime there already are quite a few market stands. Most of them selling souvenirs, fresh fruit juices or nuts/dried fruit. I would recommend to at least try the fruit juices. They are freshly squeezed and cheap; you can drink them from a glass on the spot or have them to go in a plastic cup.In the evening the square really comes to life. Music groups and all kinds of other "artists" do their thing and a circle of mostly local people forms around them. If you enjoy what you see you are expected to leave a small amount to give expression to your appreciation.Furthermore, the food stands open up. You should really try them. The food is absolutely safe and prices are low. A two person meal including drinks (no alcohol obviously) will cost you between 150 and 250 MAD, unless you're a really big eater. Most of the stands offer the same for exactly the same prices (we counted four kinds of food stands), so just pick the one that looks best to you. Or have yourself reeled in by the men in front of the stands. It's kind of a sport to them. We liked to go with it and choose the stand which had the best talk / pitch that evening.

Complete sensory overload! . Definitely recommend going, it's like nothing else. The snake charmers pipes, the musicians drums and then at certain times the call to prayer. The smells of the cooking and the leather in the souks. It's incredible!

Graet place. At night the square changes with the emphasis on entertainment covering boxing, gambling, transvestite belly dances and other delights to behold.The sensible watershed for the souks is to leave by 10pm for tourists to avoid any potential problems associated with night life.

Quite a sight - but beware taking pictures. Lots to see here but don't take photos of people or their stuff without asking/agreeing a price first. We both got stung here - first at an impromptu boxing match where a picture of the fight cost me 20 dirhams (they wouldn't take anything lower) and then when my girlfriend took a picture of a snakecharmer. The two gents in the attached photo came over & asked her for a donation then, when she went to pay them, instantly became more friendly, dressing us up & taking our picture with them. They then demanded 100 dirhams (£6.65) each and became quite aggressive when we suggested a lower price. We eventually walked away, a little shakily, having given them a total of 120 dirhams.Jemaa el Fna is a must-see and it doesn't disappoint. Just beware such potentially nasty incidents. We saw similar things happening to a few other tourists over the course of a couple of hours.

Beware the Snake Charmers. I must admit, I was somewhat familiar with what to expect when I entered the main square in the medina of Marrakech, Jemaa el Fna, but that still did not prepare me for the reality of all the sounds and sights of what I experienced. Apparently in all my preparation, I completely missed the part about not photographing the snake charmers unless you are willing to fork over some moroccan dirham. Yes, I made THAT mistake. Next thing I know I am being chased and hounded by one of the men surrounding the snakes. The lowest dirham amount I had was 100, the equivalent of $10 USD-but there I was being forced to fork that over or cause a small riot in the square. Next thing I know, another man goes up to the man hounding me. They proceed to exchange words and the shoves and there I was, in the middle of what appeared to be an all-out brawl about to happen because I didn't pay the snake charmer. With that, I threw the 100 dirham at the man and left in a panic due to fears that my iphone camera would be smashed. But again, I didn't learn my lesson because I wondered over to one of the henna artists. Completely absorbed by the quick artistry of the woman, I snap a picture with my iphone. Next thing I know, a woman comes up to me and proceeds to grab my hand and start to draw with her henna bottle. I told her numerous times that I did not have any money-it went to the snake charmer-but she kept doing her thing. So there I am standing with a beautiful design on my hand and no money to pay the woman. It must have been the final and strongly asserted "NO MONEY" that made her grab my hand again, take her finger and wipe the design off my hand. If she didn't have a veil covering her face, I think she would've spit on me. So, there you have it-the stupid American tourist tale of Jemaa el Fna. Even with that bad experience, there is nothing like the square-enjoy it, absorb the sights, listen to the lovely call to prayer that blasts from the speaker above the mosque in the square, and have a freshly squeezed orange juice from one the of million stands. But whatever you do, don't photograph the snake charmers or henna artists unless you have some dirham to pass out!
Boiling atmosphere. Lots of selling people chasing You. Tiring bargaining. Pleasant evening atmospere and terraces. Not as exotic as the dreams

If you come during the day, don't forget your hat and sunscreen!. During your visit to Marrakech you'll undoubtedly come here and of course you should to see the spectacle, eat a meal at the food stalls, watch people, and maybe shop.Stay aware of your surroundings and be alert for possible scams, pick pockets, and aggressive snake, monkey and henna artists.It's much quieter during the day and really gets going at night!

interesting sights, smells, sounds. one of the must sees in Marrakesh, do not attempt to take a photo for free though, everyone expects payment. food stands in the evening are okay but avoid the salads and don't use the cutlery. we stuck to grilled meats and cooked vegetables and didn't get an upset tummy. there is no alcohol anywhere in the medina but there will be someone who will offer you some. do not follow unless you want to be led down narrow lanes and be charged £7 for a half pint. and then pay for someone to give you directions back to the square.

A must visit. The big famous square in Marrakech is a real must visit when in Marrakech. During the day the square is a little more quiet, with stalls selling dates and other dried fruits, and stalls selling fresh orange juice for just 4 MAD. When it's get dark, the square get's more busy with all kinds of performers. Watch out for pickpockets when visiting the square after sunset.

Good Coffee in Arab Cafeteria - Good Serice - Low Price. "From an experienced Voyager " in the day-time just a HUGE MARKET PLACE - passed Riads and Stalls en route Visited Two Palaces and El Saadi Tombs
Wow........ What can I say...... you have to see, hear, smell it for yourself, and incredible place day or night....
A must to visit. The place is a must to visit, is much better by the evening as they offer different activities and more active.

Morocco at it's best.. Jemaa el Fna Square is an amazing experience by day when it's quieter or from dusk when it's buzzing! It may not be everybody's idea of fun but a true cultural experience. The locals will try and get money from you at every opportunity but either go with it and soak up the atmosphere or stand firm and enjoy from a distance. A great place to enjoy a mint tea or an orange juice and watch the frantic pace of the square unfold with so much to keep you entertained. From here you can then wander through the souks and enjoy or hate the 'haggle' banter with the local shop keepers. A great place to visit but always happy to leave and return to a bit of normality in Gueliz (new town).
Magical. Magical place I visited for my 30th Birthday, planning my 2nd trip and really looking forward to it. Recommend it to all.
Amazing. Full of charm, culture and so much to see and do, beware of people selling dancing,henna, as these have to be paid for including photos, but worth a visit

Awesome atmosphere. Awesome atmosphere & food. Interesting snake charmers and traditional dancers. Monkeys never sure of to me its just a cruel gimmick.. The henna woman are rude & very aggressive, steer clear of them! Plenty of great places to eat and watch the craziness of the market unfold

A must see, but go prepared!. A visit to Jemaa El Fna is an inevitable consequence of your trip to Marrakech, so dive in and enjoy the madness. During the day time there a some stalls open but these are predominantly orange sellers where a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice will cost you 4 dirhams, roughly 30p depending on the exchange rate you get. We had lots of these and they were all delicious. All the stalls display the same price around the market. There are also snake charmers, people with monkeys and water sellers in traditional costume. All of these will want you to have a photograph taken with them. If that's what you want then fine, but they will expect payment in return. Most will ask for 'paper', meaning a note, 20 dirhams or about £1.50. Some will suggest that it's free. Nothing is free in Marrakech, you'll get pestered for the money, so accept that is how it is. Top tip is to carry plenty of change, 5, 10 dirham coins, which you can give for tips if you really want those photos. If you are friendly but firm in saying NO then you'll have no problems. If you look like a soft touch, you'll be pursued recently. The market people will have been told NO a thousand times already that day, so it's no big deal. Just walk on, you don't need to be too polite and British about it!Many ladies will wonder about what to wear whilst out. In general it's fine to wear short sleeved tops and shorts. Just understand that the tops are best not too revealing and the shorts not too short. You do not have to cover your head.Tourists wander around the streets entirely safely, even in the dark alleys and souks at night. The locals will almost invariably be respectful and courteous. Public displays of affection are best limited to a hug and a peck on the cheek and perhaps holding hands, to avoid causing offence.Another top tip when out and about is to have a decent street plan and after your arrival have a walk around and get to know your way. If you need to ask the way it will cost you, remember everything has its price. What can happen is that you ask the way and you'll get sent in completely the wrong direction, then when you get lost, miraculously the same person will then stumble across you and very politely take you on a big loop back to where you wanted to go, then expect a tip. Just go with all this kind of thing, let's face it a few dirhams is a lot of money to the locals and nothing to most of us, treat it as part of the experience. If you fight against it, you'll not enjoy Marrakech at all. In the evening, around 1900 hrs at this time of year, the place really comes alive. Loads of stalls, loads of food. Some of it is good. Go to where the locals gather is the best tip. Always order off a priced menu, otherwise you'll get all kind of things and a big bill you didn't expect.There are all sorts of gathering for everything from storytellers, musicians, even boxing if you fancy it! You can happily watch all these for no cost, so it's possible to spend and evening out for little cost.If you are buying in the souks, obviously never pay the price you are asked. A reasonable rule of thumb is to offer around 1/3 of the price asked, but sometimes this can be too much! You'll know you've got the lowest offer if they let you walk off without selling it to you.Never do anything without knowing the price first. Local trips of a couple of miles in a taxi should cost around 30 to 40 dirhams. A trip to the airport around 100. There are thousands of taxis, you'll never ever have to worry about finding one. If you take an hour long trip on one of the many horse and carriages that should cost you around 100-150 dirhams. It's all pretty cheap.The sweet pastries on sale everywhere look lovely, just be aware that they are not as sweet as they look and may might not be to your taste, so ask to sample first.One final tip, Never Ever change money at the airport. If you do, either in the UK or Marrakech you will receive a truly miserable exchange rate. At Gatwick 1000 dirhams cost us £104.00, from an ATM in Marrakech HSBC gave me 1000 dirhams for £66.00. I will never make this mistake again, I urge you not to get caught out.In short, if you practice saying NO thank you and carry a pocketful of change, you can't go far wrong. I've been twice and will definitely go again. My partner wouldn't want to go alone, but many people do. It's safe, but the faint hearted Can find it a little intimidating.

You need to enjoy. I think there is not a lot to say, except that you have to go there. My biggest advice: Enjoy all you see, the attractions that are just there to make you pay as well as the food. BE careful when you watch something: Ask for the price PRIOR to touching a snake or taking a picture - afterwords it is difficult to negotiate.

Lively!. Amazing place to watch people everywhere. By day an entertainers playground. By night wow what a transformation. Rows and rows of stalls and lots and lots of food. Really cheap to eat and a great way to chat to tourists from around the world.

Enjoying Jemaa El Fna. This is a place of two worlds. Enjoy the fresh juices on offer, see the snakes and monkeys throughout the day or get some henna art applied; then watch the world go by from one of the many terrace vantage points in the square. Then by night the square comes alive great food is available at great prices. You can also enjoy the Berber storytellers, for a small token (between 10 - 50 Dhms) you might even be welcomed into the circle as we were every night what a great experience.

Welcome to the gates of Hell. Can't deny this place is the best rush you'll get in an alcohol free zone.Strap yourself in for the ride.Its simultaneously exciting and scary.Dodging the relentless onslaught of desperate Morroccans trying to separate you from your cash.Hold your nerve and you'll be fine but I would avoid the food stalls.They have one bucket of dirty water to clean the dishes.

Every time amazing. Every time I came back to the square it suprised me with somthing new. A very rich place in all kinds of experieces, not only shopping or drinking orange juice - try the surrounding restaurants and caffes, smile to local people and they will smile and talk back - in all languages!

Umm!. Got to be done, but this is only part of what Marrakech has to offer.Crazy, like the Blackpool of Africa!Basically a large tourist market with mainly low quality souvenirs but there are some wonderful items in between if you have the patience to outlive the constant harassment.If you care to talk to the sellers once the tacky Alibaba, you want to buy stage, they are lovely people with a wicked sense of humour.The square draws you back but for me, not everyone I'm sure, there is much more to see and do.

OK . Very hectic and busy. Also had one woman grab my arm and quickly do henna and wouldn't stop bothering me money till I paid although I didn't want it in the first place! Good if you like busy markets and lots of people but a little too busy for me.
Haphazard. I went to that place in November 2015 during my city tour in marrakech but I didn't like it so much due to lack of organization and money a skers, nothing special.

Unmissable!. Jemaa el Fna is one of those places that everyone should experience once in their lifetime! It is best experienced at night when it really comes into its own. The hubbub and atmosphere is really brilliant.. Hundreds of little stalls beckon you and everyone says their food is the best! (of course, it's all the same, so the choice is really who you like the look of most!)

A Must See In Marrakesh. Saw the square during the day with snake charmers, monkeys and so forth but returned at night to get another view. The square is crowded and people do not follow basic stay to the right (or left) when walking through the open air shops. Some of the people do not take baths everyday, if you catch my drift. During the day more tourist are shopping and at night many of the locals are eating at the shops under tents. Prices for nuts and candy are shown in kilo form. You can buy small amounts for much less. Interesting place, you will not get bored just people watching.
Good atmosphère . It's a big square crowded of people especially in the evening , with a lot of restaurants , cafés and bars , there are some with terraces where you can have a good view on médina

An experience. You have to go here by day and by night. By day it there are sellers, snake charmers and a lot else. By night you can get a meal outdoors which is good quality but not cheap by Moroccan standards, but still not bad.
Great. Vibrant exciting place to visit. Nice food stalls and restaurants in the side. Worth a visit during the day for fresh juice and night for restaurants.

Fantastic!!!. It is a tale of two sides, it has a totally different atmosphere in the daytime compared to the evening, both are unique and must be experienced.The snake charmers, henna ladies, story tellers, musicians etc,etc will keep you entertained, even if you dont understand exactly what they are saying.

great atmosphere - great bargains!. Its an amazing atmosphere, so lively and vibrant. lots of amazing shops - ranging from gifts to household trinkets. Great place to eat and they do some lovely fresh orange juice to keep you refreshed.

Must be experienced!. A crazy, lively, frantic ball of pure energy that must be experienced to be believed- that's the Jemaa el Fna at nighttime. Grab a meal at one of the many food stalls, and just sit and take in the atmosphere

This is what you come to see in Marrakesh.. This is the famous square filled with snake charmers, musicians and merchants. Ringed by carts with food and crossed by horse drawn carriages. Walk through then go to a cafe with a second story viewing area.

A one off place.. If you go here. You will have monkeys thrown at you!Manic place. During the day it's hot, it's full of people, you have your pick of hundreds of different stalls, there's live music and plenty of options in regards to food.At night is where it really comes alive though, 6pm until 2am, this place is buzzing.It can be aggressive at first, people seem aggressive and pushy. But once you learn to say no sternly, and they know you mean it, it's fine. I also found that being a ride aggressive yourself and threatening violence casually seems to make the sellers laugh and then it gets friendly.There are guys with monkeys who come very close to you and will often sneak up behind you and lob their monkey on you. They then haggle with you for a price to get the monkey off. This can be a bit scary, as the monkeys are quite big and have obviously sharp teeth. But being stern helps and the guy will leave you alone.There's also snake charmers. If you get close, you will be asked for money, if you take a picture, you will be asked for money. My tip here, is pay first! I offered 20 dh just to get close and take a picture, the guy said to me "fine, but pay after" he then lets you take pictures and takes your phone off you to take a picture of you himself with the snake, he then insists on a group picture etc etc.Then you go to leave, and he says 20dh is no good, and refuses to let you leave until you pay 200dh. To make sure you don't leave, he wraps a python around your neck and asks you to hold the head, and he continues to push (aggressively) for the 200dh.Do not be polite here! it doesn't work. With these guys, when they do this, you must be assertive.I threatened to knock this guy out and I was firm and rude about it. I also threatened to remove the snake and shuv it up his ....Entertaining though... you'll have some good stories.The food markets are also very pushy trying to get you in. But they're good natured and it's all fun.Food on offer, snails, sheep spleens, goat heads etc.Live music is always on offer, and this is really great music. Gnaoua music is like a trance music and you will be hooked on it.There's so much going on, it's not worth talking about. I won't cover even a fraction of it.Good times!
CHAOTIC VIBRANT EXPERIENCE. We visited the square by day and also at night for the experience of the food market and were not disappointed.

Not for the faint hearted. Although the vibe is certainly 'one of a kind' and do think everyone should go at least twice (once in the day, once in the evening) while in Marrakech, you need to be in the right frame of mind. Take it with a pinch of salt and you'll enjoy yourself. We didn't brave the food stalls- the pressure tactics put me off but we did have an average dinner at the Cafe de France which overlooked the square at night. Loved the orange juice stands though, so sweet and refreshing.

Utter Madness. Busy, hectic, amazing, an experience. Some really pushy people but a must if only once. The monkeys on chains and the doped up snakes are a bit upsetting as is the obvious poverty but, still worth going. Be careful when the Henna women start putting their hands on you.

Buzzing. The Jemaa el Fna is the hub of the city and is genuinely full of life right through the day and the night. I developed a habit (somehow) of eating outside of mealtimes when I was in Morocco and I actually found this worked really well in this square. During meal times it's absolutely packed. You have to be on your guard at all times. But if you ate outside of these peak times, it's much calmer, much quieter and you get a lot of attention from the staff. Be careful of the henna women in the square though. They will try and try to trick you. They won't even wait for you're decision. They'll say 'let me show you' and then start drawing. Then they'll ask for money. Don't let them grab your hand and you'll be fine.

Hope you like orange juice. This is the souk as you think they are before you visit, but all the narrow streets and souks radiate from here. There seems to be a 100 fruit juice sellers. Suddenly I felt my wife grab my hand and hold tightly and I do mean tightly. I thought she was trying to save me from the traffic. No, she had just seen the snake charmer and it was pure fear!
You just have to visit. Square of Marrakech is a must see. It's amazing. Everything from food to snake charmers. Pots to spices.

Was nice. Seen on photos,I'm glad I've seen it in person now and if your in Morocco then I would say visit.it was very hot when we visited and there was a lot of bad smells around the building and beggars as well.That spoiled it for us but we did go in the morning and it was July so may be it was to do with that time of day.

Wonderland. I had lived in Marrakech for a year for my studies.What to say about Marrakech and its plaza Jemaa el Fna.It's really worth visiting, it concentrates entertainment, nice cheap food, shopping and divers activities.Go and have a look, you'll be thrilled.

Lovely. It's always amazing to see an open market full of wonderful surprises and this jamal el fna is an exciting adventure. There are so many varieties of little shops selling all sorts. Be careful of pickpockets though and be prepared to walk.

Crazy place. Did the square in both daylight and nighttime, it really comes alive on a night, the food stalls are hectic but worth the experience , everyone is trying to get you to eat at their stall, beware taking photos without asking , the happily chase you until you offer payment, the ladies doing henna are very persuasive so be careful before you know it they have your hand and are going henna before you know what's happened, the snake charmers are mostly around during the day along with the monkeys , not my type of thing but still a sight to see

The centre of life in Marrakech!. One of the most mytical places in Northern Africa. The entire life of the city begins here. You must start from here if you want to visit the souks. From the end of the afternoon, the square transforms itself in a major spectacle with artists, dancers, magicians and other representatives of the marrocan life.

Exuding Energy. I called it Mad Square as it is formidable but must be experienced. It has an intense frenzy that builds at sunset and everywhere you look you will see talented people displaying their wares and skills for some financial help. Ok there are hassles and chaotic rip offs but also some exceptional skills and talents - e,g, the gymnasts were truly awesome, musicians always good. It is easy to get resentful as a visitor to the constant hassle for cash and feel you are just a walking ATM but I saw one of the Henna Bandit women set up and start the full on hassle for about an hour with the hand grabs etc. She finally got a customer and then disappeared. I saw her half an hour later and she had gone to get something to eat with the money she had just earned! I still didn't give in to the hasslers (and some could be insistent, aggressive and rude) but (as I had dinner with a couple of local people I knew) realised that most of them were living hand to mouth and a few dirham more would make little difference to me but would help some desperately poor people and their families in most cases so was happy to help out the quiet ones,

Touristic. This place is definitely the place where every tourist is going, when passing through Marrakech.Nevertheless take care: when tourists are expected, tourists have to pay...Some of the common tricks: - avoid taking picture of the snakes or the monkeys on the place... for each picture you will be charged.- at night the place is getting very busy, and some local "fast food" restaurants appear. It is a great animation, and many people (especially tourists) are going to have dinner. Take care, and order always with the menu, after agreeing the price. If you are offered the possibility to have a choice of different specialities, take care: the trick consists in giving to the tourists many small dishes of every kind to "discover moroccan food". All those dishes are charged at the full price even if the quantity is very poor, and the bill can sum up to several hundreds of euros!!!!
A good place to people watch. A very busy square with lots to see. I found it best to take a seat in a restaurant and over a tea watch the very different people who pass by.

Bustling adventure. This was a fun place to explore...after we figured out how the food stalls worked. When entering the jemaa, you will be bombarded with people lobbying for you to choose their food station. Once you accept that you just have to keep walking and ignore their pleas to sit at their station, and begin see all of the different stands, the fun begins. There are a variety of interesting foods on display and a variety of prices, but at the end of the day you can get a full meal for 2 for under $15 easily. The lesson we learned was that the more patrons you see, the more likely that the food is good and freshly cooked. Overall this is a fun experience, and you can eat normal moroccan food or you can get adventurous and have snails or whatever part of a lamb you choose, for example, but no matter what it is a fun eating experience like no other. As a personal recommendation, I recommend Chez Aicha (stall No. 1) as the place to go. She is queen of the jemaa for a reason.
Simply, a must. We spend our last evening at this Square. It was simply an experience so special and different, including a lovely horse ride!

It's a boot sale on steroids. Would love to describe the bizarre array of items on sale but it's so much more surprising to discover for yourself - examine every little table and blanket! Grab a roof terrace table at dusk and watch the place come alive. Don't be put off by some of the food storage standards you see in the back streets of the Medina, Aisha (stall no.1) won't let you down

spoilt by aggressive touts. A very interesting and entertaining square, full of sellers, snake charmers, monkey men and at night a host of quick restaurants, if you can put up with the constant barrage of men and woman trying to sell their wares,maybe a trained money or snake , maybe henna tattoos,they can be rely hard to get rid, one guy followed me for a km trying to sell a carved hippo, I offered him nothing ,so in the end I got it dirt cheap, but one guy grabbed my camera to check if I had taken photos of his snakes, he was very disappointed he could not find any.this is a den of thieves, they will overcharge given a chance so bargin hard and walk away.the food is ok but they will double what you expect to pay.

Fantastic Evening Spectacle!. This is the main square and gathering place in the Medina and comes alive in the evening time! Food stalls, Snake Charmers, Mobile Dentists, Souvenir Sellers - it's all there. You can't miss this when you are in Marrakech. If you don't want to wander through the throngs, perch yourself at one of the many rooftop cafes around the perimeter and get a birds eye view.

Best & Worst experience of the trip. This square is crazy ! You can hear the drums at night from far away and it sounds like the square is pulsing. It looks really pretty at night if you are sitting on the roof terrace of one of the local restaurants. The orange juice is also delicious. The bad thing about it is you will be hassled SO much by stall holders, sellers, henna artists etc. to the point where it's completely overwhelming. You cannot take a photo of anyone without them wanting a tip and that's fine but they will get aggressive if you don't tip them enough. Also, as a western woman I was harassed by men a lot.. Some of which where touching/grabbing me but they would quickly walk off into the dark sea of people before I could properly react. WOMEN: be very aware of who is around you.. I saw men getting extremely close behind my friend whilst she was watching a performer obviously trying to rub up against her. Just be very careful of this.
Magical!. This place in unique in the world!I love the magic, the thrill!Djemaa el Fna is the place in Marrakech that must be visited!

WOW. Wonderful, magical, chaotic place. Jugglers, acrobats ,comedians, Moroccan bands and so much more. Cafes at edges serve good enough food but just get a tea or coffee and sit and watch the action.The monkeys and the snakes are a bit offputting but steer clear.Do try the orange juice at stalls. Tastes fantastic. Wish they sold in our shops.At night food stalls sell every kind of food but beware they put bread,vegs,spices on plates in front of you without you asking. Eat them cos they will charge you for them at end. But all good stuff.

magical. the Jemaa el Fna is just amazing. in every corner there is always something happening. i love the noise and the smell of it. you'll fine the snake charmers, henna tattoists, plenty of restaurants, shops, dancers, acrobats etc etc.

Smelly, dirty and in your face sellers!. I was so excited about vising this much talked about square and was hugely disappointed to say the least! The sellers would literally try to pull you towards them which was quite frightening! I thought the food would be nice but all the uncooked meat was filthy and full of flies and the portions were miniscule! There was one stall selling baklava and it was covered with a thick sheet of flies! I couldn't believe people were still waiting to buy from them! The best part of the experience was the fresh orange juice they sold - make sure though you actually see them taking out the juice otherwise you will have a cup of diluted pre juiced orange juice!

Magical place. I wish I can teleport myself here from time to time, this place is alive, clean, safe, and loud! full of great food options, sneak charmers, and all kind of merchants. If you want to buy souvenirs go inside the medina, as for the food, the place is packed by several restaurants. try the Tangia Marrakshiya and snails !

Get with the flow and enjoy it!. The world's largest open air market, theater and street foods all packaged into one phenomenal experience. Be prepared to be amazed, delighted, confused, confounded with this one of a kind experience. Don't overthink it, just go with the flow and enjoy it! Totally safe.

The world in motion.... Located close to our hotel so we frequented the square a lot and at all times of day and night. It is quite a place as there is always something happening - henna artists, snake charmers, musicians and performers. The places really comes to life at night with stalls selling street food - my abiding memory was the welcoming greetings of waiters followed by any expletive if you passed them by!!! Don't get offended just laugh and move on...on the whole the place is OK, but once you've seen it there is little to drag you back time after time - nothing changes.

Great experience . Definitely a rich experience - both good and bad. Reasonable food and some interesting street entertainers. Use of animals - monkeys and snake is distasteful especially the cages that they are retuned to after a long day of being trust upon tourists.

You cant help walking through- its bonkers and very in your face. You will go through this square a number of times at different parts of the day. During the day its quite loud, full of snake charmers and people trying to flog you pictures of you with their monkeys..avoid speaking to them and if you sneak a picture , then dont get caught as you will be hounded for money....By evening it makes the day look empty...very loud, many many people and stalls, smoke, heat ...but kinda fun. Wander through on your way to souks and restaurants, avoid eye contact but enjoy....

The true Morrocco!. This is a must to do both in the day and night time whilst staying in Marrakech.In the day it is a jostling mass of humanity so beware of pickpockets .Heavily policed so you don't feel insecure.A vast landscape of Souks to snake charmers unfolds before you which defies description in a short review but a must see.The tackier goods are for sale as you enter the square so it's well worth exploring into the Souks at the far end which sell higher worth goods.But be prepared to bargain hard!Many of the restaurants don't sell alchol is if you want a fortified drink read the menus first!!At night the square changes with the emphasis on entertainment covering boxing, gambling, transvestite belly dances and other delights to behold. The sensible watershed for the souks is to leave by 10pm for tourists to avoid any potential problems associated with night life.We are well travelled but found all this an experience well worth making a most do on your itinary
Entertaining. Circus during the day and one massive food stall at night. Keep an eye on the snakes during the day.

Over-rated tourist trap. Invariably flagged up as the major attraction of Marrakech, I found little to enjoy about the Jemaa el Fna. It's basically a large open space where the same stuff is sold that you'll see throughout the medina. In addition, it's filled with henna women, guys with monkeys (who will try to put the poor thing on you), snake charmers and dancers. It's all a bit tacky really. There are also food stalls - which we chose not to eat in so I can't really comment on them, but they did look over priced for what they are. Also there are horse-drawn caleches roaming about but we didn't go on one as I felt sorry for the poor bedraggled horses pulling them.

Find you inner hippie!. If you have a hippie spirit inside you, this place feel like home! Of course you can call it a tourist trap, but you can say that about almost every "city center" on earth. The old market is FULL of life and it is so much fun "getting lost" in the market, just walking around and looking at all the stuff the locals are selling, spices, beautiful tea glasses, pasminas, fabrics, all kinds of crazy medicine in the pharmacies, and you name it!. You see a lot of expensive crap but you can also get a good deal on good stuff if you are a master of bargaining. That is what they want you to do. Just start by taking half of the price they start with and work your way up, or down for that matter. Just decide on what you are truly ready to pay for the things you want and stick with that. It´s a little show you make together, you and your seller. Sometimes it´s good to just walk away end they will run after you and offer you a better deal. And don´t buy what you are looking for at the first shop you see, take your time. Often you'll find exactly the same stuff in another shop much cheaper. Try to find a small place inside the market that offers mint tea and have a seat and chat with the host. The square is full of people with animals, henna tattoo artists, fortune tellers, story tellers and you name it! They will all try to sell you or "show" you something and they ALWAYS want money. It is a good rule to start every conversation with "I am not going to pay you anything" and then later if you feel like it you can of course always pay. You can also except to have kids coming up to you and offering to show you the right way to some restaurant or if you are a bit lost in the market (it´s huge and easy to get lost) and they of course want your money too. My husband started to have a lot of lollypops in his pockets and give the kids instead of money. You have to be very firm in every situation if you don't want to give everybody money! The orange juice they are selling on the square is so good, some people say that they mix it with tap water and you can get ill in your stomach but I have not had that experience, I just love it and you can taste how fresh it is!! And it is also great fun to eat on the square with the locals…very cheap street food that they make on the spot. It is one of my favorite places that I have visited, and I will be going there regulary until I die! Then I would recommend to go to one of the oldest neighborhood in the city, Kasbah and take a walk there…it is as you´ve been in a time machine!!

Greatest Show On Earth. They say Ringling Bros. named the circus after this square. In a few minutes we saw snake charmers, monkey tamers and water sellers. Not to mention all the shopping. A must see.

Exciting experience. The wonderful Smell and noise definitely ensured you knew you were somewhere special. Great food and local shopping. Fun banter with boys trying hard to entice you to their stalls

AN ASSAULT ON THE SENSES. This was my third visit in 5 years, never disappoints. Its like an impromptu Cirque de Soleil production, atmospheric, fun, lively and extraordinary. Yes there are snakes, monkeys tied up and you will be pestered, however this is Morocco, and not too be missed.Have fun bartering, a short firm no thank you and you will be left alone.One tip when wandering around the medina if you are getting lost look at the stones on the floor, the smaller the stones the deeper in you are going, look for the bigger stones on the path this will lead you back to a main street..

Mental!!!!!. This place is like nothing I've ever seen before!!! Busy by day even busier by night. Market stools and food everywhere. Watch out for the henna ladies who may try to draw on you then charge you for the pleasure. And the kids who beg for food but are not hungry.
Animal cruelty. I didn't like witnessing how animals were unfairly treated and felt harassed by street sellers. The ladies doing the henna tattoos were very aggressive

Overwhelming. Seeing and experiencing this square is an unforgettable experience, you have snakes, monkeys, fortune tellers, shop lifters, you have everything there. The smell of the small pop-up restaurants is exotical, each owner tries to convince you of the uniqueness of his restaurant, a real spectacle!

THE QUINTESSENTIAL DEN OF INIQUITY. The square sums up Marrakech perfectly. There is every walk of life in this square including loads of snake charmers, monkeys....the lot. Everyone is out for your tourist money from the food stalls at a night time to the Henna Tattoo sellers, Orange Juice sellers & Snake Charmers of the daytime. It's a sight to behold & as long as you can keep saying No to everyone then go & see in the daytime & at a night time.

Overrated but necessary. Overpriced everything, dodgy food and very pushy stallholders. Not typical of the rest of the city. If you walk ten minutes in any direction the people are completely different

" Crazy - But What An Experience !". This is a must - By day it is the place where all the alleys of the Medina meet.By night time, this is where everything happens in Marrakesh. There are numerous street artists, food stalls, music and noise enough to entertain everybody. Watch out for the henna tattoo ladies who don't really like the word no !
best juice. one of the best places i have had orange juices and other juices and also try the fresh dates and other food which is made by ur own eyes

A vibrant lively place . A great place to do all of your shopping! I speak Arabic so I found it fairly easy to Tam call me haggle with the market people, however I understand it can be difficult for westerners because they do often ask for 5 times more than the value. We developed a technique of chanting "50 dirhams, 50 dirhams" as a group (or however much we wanted for the item) this would both make the shop keeper laugh as well as embarrassed and they will often give it to you for the price you offer- we would also always clap and cheer when they agreed the price! They found it entertaining and we got our price- win - win really! The thing I found most annoying is the shop keepers harassing you to come in and have a look, we often found that the ones who let us be were the ones we bought from. Be sure to acknowledge their harassment or they tend to get pretty rude and take it very personally. Also be very firm about beggers and where you point your camera. If you take a photo of he performers they'll harass you for money. We bought so many things from here. Be sure to visit!

Beware of pickpockets . This place is interesting but less so than the guide books etc would have you believe. Witnessing a sand storm happen while we were there was fascinating though.Mind your belongings - we witnessed a girl being pick pocketed but were too late to stop it. It's all very "hussle hassle" so you need to be in the right mood! Have plenty of small change with you for every time one of the "entertainers" demands money from you.... :-)Sunday night seemed super busy with loads of Moroccan families out for a stroll. That was the evening (early on) with the nicest atmosphere.

4 stars as an experience but has some negatives. The Jemaa el Fna is one of the must see attractions of Marrakech. It is very hard to visit the city without spending some time here. It is vital to have your wits about you in the square though. You must be ready to say "no" to pretty much every person you see as almost everyone there is trying to sell you something. I would give this 4 stars as an experience while in Marrakech and it certainly is a must see, however, there are a number of downsides. There will be a number of people walking around with monkeys on chains who will try to put the monkeys on your shoulder and offer pictures then will try to charge ridiculous amounts of money for this. The best way to deal with these is to either give a firm "no" and keep walking or if you do really want a picture, get the monkey off of your arm and demand that the price of a picture is agreed and written down for you before any other step is taken. Additionally there will an array of others trying to sell you one thing or another from food to henna tattoos to orange juice etc. The most important thing in the square is to be very firm but not rude with everyone and if you do not want something refuse it firmly but politely.Finally, there are a number of restaurants with rooftop dining areas overlooking the market which are worth eating in at least once for the views of the market. Overall it is definitely a must see but it must be remembered that the vendors there will be trying to sell anything to you. Just be careful and enjoy the sights and sounds.

Beautiful, dirty and different. A good taste og Morocco and Marrakech, but quite touristified. Fun, strange, chaotic, noisy, different, lovely. The food market is a mix of good and bad I think. We got the bad :-)

Birthday adventure!!. This place is AMAZING!!Came here to explore the market. We got here around midday walking past the horse and carriages into the market square. it didn't appear to busy.We took a walk exploring the various tightly packed narrow streets! This place is heaped in tradition..However it became a different place at twilight. You could feel the shift in the atmosphere.There were large circles of men either sitting or standing but all totally engrossed by the storyteller.The sounds and smells became more potent. Traditional lights were lit by sellers and at times appeared to light the way for your feet around the square.With the La Koutoubla lit up and over looking it all, this is truly a time to immerse yourself in all that it offers!

Crazy place but full of character. Loved walking around the big square... Wow that was crazy place Lots of stuff was going on ... From fresh fruit juice to fresh food.... We never ate there but it was one busy place. It's an experience must visit when you come to. Marrakech

Find a Terrace and Sip Mint Tea. The Jemaa el Fna is a feast for the senses; horns tootling, snakes twisting, drums drumming, ladies (or are they?) dancing, meats roasting and stalls selling, stereos blasting - it's fun to wander, and then a delight to find a terrace, order dinner - a nice tajine - and sip some hot reviving mint tea. Watch the action, take your time, no one will hurry you.

Where everything happens. By day time, it is only the place where all the alleys of the medina meet. By night time, this is where everything happens in Marrakesh. There are numerous street artists, food stalls, music and noise enough to entertain everybody. this is also the place where some of the most expensive restaurants in the city are located, with terraces overviewing the square and alleys of Marrakesh

Alive at sunset. There's not much happening in the square during the day, but it is a good place to aim to get back to if you are lost in the labyrinth of the medina - look for the signs mounted on walls above the streets. The Jemaa comes into its own at sunset, when the food stalls and street traders are in full swing. The bustle, the smells, the noise - it's a fascinating place

3 stars during the day, 4 at night. You have to go, it's part of Marrakechi (and tourist) life, but we went only in the day to get out baring really. It is at night that we enjoyed it most, much less imposing and we felt much more comfortable watching the entertainment. There are good natured pleas and persuasion to eat each stall, and you learn to spot quickly where the freshest food and most people are eating. I was not keen on the monkeys or snakes in the daytime, but there were many more locals enjoying the music in the evening.

Must See and Experience!. This square defines the character of Marrakech..lively, vibrant and not to be missed. Wander around in the day and take in the snake charmers, stalls , drink the fresh juice or simply sit and watch from one of the many balconies. At night taste the street food (we had great service and delicious dishes from no. 100) and watch/listen to local entertainers. We didn't like the way the monkeys were dressed up, the heavy loads of the donkeys. Beware of taking photos; you will need to tip..otherwise enjoy the very different culture, sights and sounds.

Open Sesame. A few blocks from my hostel is in the vast open square named Jemma El Fna.In addition to the music of Berber men drumming and singing, the musical entry for this issue has to include to plaintive flute music of the snake charmers with their cobras in the vast open square named Jemma El Fna. As the evening deepens and the air cools off, the vast open square fills with people. Rows of food stands are set up, each complete with its own seating. A row of carts sells dishes of cooked snails. Other rows of carts sell freshly squeezed glasses of orange and other juices. There are storytellers, acrobats, monkeys with diapers, women painting henna tattoos on tourists, shoeshine men, and people set up on blankets selling all sorts of items. I enjoy walking past the carts that sell spices and incense, as the fragrant smoking samples perfume the evening air with frankincense. Around the perimeter of the square are dozens of small stands selling all manner of Moroccan souvenirs. As I walk past, the proprietors call out to me, “Hey, Ali Baba!” To which I respond, “Iftah ya ssimssim!” (“Open Sesame!” in Arabic). We all laugh.

An interesting sight. An area where locals and tourists come to feast in stall after stall of self indulgence. It's like Leicester Square on acid. Worth a good visit and to people watch. Watch for scams of course and protect your wallet like in most large cities anywhere.
WOW. An out of this world experience. Has to be seen to be believed. Such a great atmosphere and def worth a visit at night!!!

So full of life. Never have I been to a square where there s so much life no matter what time of the day you come. During my stay in Marrakech I stayed right at the square and even in the hotel, I could hear the sounds comming from here. I fell in love with the square and this is what Marrakech is for me. A square full of locals and tourist packed together. You can be entertained here, or simply go shopping, buy food or sit in one of the many cafes or restaurants around the square and just watch life goes by. It's an amazing place.
A bit crazy with tourists and snakes etc.... You have to see it once, but the aggressive snake handlers with languid, mistreated snakes, is a little too touristy.

Fantastic but crazy!. Be prepared for a manic level of activity here! From snake-charmers to trick monkeys dressed in pyjamas, to street acrobats, fantastic Moroccan music, scores of locals selling their wares esp. fresh orange juice (never seem so many orange juice stalls!), tempting Moroccan sweet pastries, the ubiquitous argan oil, lanterns, different types of tagines etc). Make sure you haggle if you want to buy!! We had lunch everyday in the 4 days we visited in different terrace restaurants at Jemaa el Fna. its a super way to sit back and enjoy the atmosphere of the place while sipping on mint tea and enjoying the cuisine.
Not too impressed . Too many people begging on the streets. Too many people pushing you to buy stuff you don't really need which gets really annoying and keeps you from enjoying your visit.

A Marrakech must visit. This place is the 'heart' of the old city and for all its negatives that you may read about is a great place to visit and experience. We were actually not pestered too much and did not find it at all threatening.Just go and absorb the atmosphere of real Morocco!

Interesting but not for everyone. I am sure many people find this square exciting and delightful. Personally, I found it overwhelming and it was sensory overload. I preferred other local points of interest and shopping in the Souks.

Plenty of activity and fun.. For the best fun, go at night when everyone is wanting to relieve you of your money - snake charmers, musicians and food stalls all compete. During the day it is much quieter, and you have a better chance to wander around the souks to find clothing or handicrafts to buy. Worth a visit.

Overpriced food stalls / Předražené stánky s jídlem . The food stalls are overpriced and although the food isn't bad, the price difference isn't justified. Add the annoying and almost aggressive touts and you are better off with any regular restaurant (experience from stall no. 65).Stánky s jídlem jsou předražené, naháněči otravní (zkušenost se stánkem 65)

Lively place to be... Loved roaming around the square; advise: settle the price for heena first before getting it done, expect to buy fake watch which will run for two hours only, amazingly fresh orange juice, must drink and most of all don't forget to buy dates, they are many types and all worth trying.

still horrible. this place is still something to avoid... just annoying people who try to put monkeys and snakes on you and then you have to pay to get the animals off.... horrible to see what they do to these animals.. not human !
Vibrant. A place you must visit so many delights to see! Evenings are the best time to go as all the entertainment starts then!!

Horrible. Nothing to see there. You can have freshly pressed orange juice, that's about it. There are people with apes and they will try to put it on your shoulders - and the charge money for that!Then there are the guys with the snakes. the animals are like paralysed, it's not a nice view. Last but not least, there are women trying to paint henna on your hands by forcefully grabbing them. They wíll not let go, until they are finished. And for that "service" they of course want money.

Fun but not as hyped.. I went there with family to see the infamous Jemaa El Fna and try out the nearby souks. It's a large square with cool buildings and shops surrounding it, and you can also see the Koutoubia Mosque in all its glory from there. Lots of juice stands and food stalls with hype men trying to get you to visit theirs. There were a lot of snake charmers and dancing monkeys, along with dancing "ladies" in drag performing for crowds. Be careful when taking videos or photos because as soon as you put your camera up, they will make a beeline to you and harass for money. Also keep stuff in your pockets and money safe as there are pickpockets around.Not much to do there, except give money away to people selling fake watches, fake argan oil, or tissues lol. Just look around and enjoy the spectacal and hold on to your butts.

Snakes and monkeys and he a ladies.. A large open square that is great to walk through.Many small shops and sales people here as well.We watched a troupe of college acrobats perform here one afternoon. They were quite good.Sit down, have a cup of mint tea. Have two cups.Choose one of the restaurants that are on the 2nd floor for the best view.

Really?. Not sure why this place is so famous. It is full of touristy attractions (snakes, monkeys). It might be nice at night but we were there during the day and were not impressed. The good point is that despite being very touristy, you are not harassed at all. And the medina around is very nice.

Prepare for all of your senses to be thoroughly assaulted!. Snake charmers, colourful water sellers, drums, pipes, food cooking, orange juice carts, caleches, tuktuks, henna tattooists and all human life can be found here. Loud and crowded but fun to take part in or watch from the terrace of one of the many cafes. Some, myself included, may be sad at the sight of monkeys kept in cages no bigger than themselves or on chains, dressed in football shirts, flamenco dresses, some wearing nappies. Intelligent animals exploited by their keepers for money for photographs. Enjoy the sights, sounds and smells of the square, but please don't indulge this cruel practice. Also (we were warned) steer clear of the "fresh" orange juice. The same fruit cooks on those carts day after day and is probably best avoided. Don't take photos without permission and remember people will often ask for money to take pictures.

A must- see highlight of our visit!. There is nothing like this place - an enormous square filled with snake charmers, stalls selling local produce and entertainers. On an evening the best place to eat with over 100 food stalls - clients rub shoulders to eat with other tourists and also local families coming to find a good meal from 66p a couple! Buzzing, noisy and plenty of roof terrace cafes to have the local mint tea and enjoy the panoramic views!

A must see in Marrakech. This is the main place to visit in Marrakech. The market stalls and the street vendors are brillilant. You have to bargain a hell of a lot but its fun doing it. There are a huge array of items to buy.

This is real Morocco. I was expecting to see this square from the beginning of our trip and it worth waiting. The souks, the sellers, the mint tea, the 100 food stands that are opening once the sun goes down, the live shows in that huge square cannot be missed. I could stay there the entire day without being bored.

Amazing . Very entertaining with a great atmosphere. Has fabulous street food. Trying the orange juice is a must. Getting lost in the souks is great fun. Stall holders are very friendly. Keeping your sense of humour and realising that these lovely people are trying to earn a living will help tremendously. Do not haggle for something you have no intention of buying, and stick to your guns with your "best final democratic price", and you'll get on fine. Sitting in a pavement cafe or up on the terrace & watching the hustle & bustle is a great way to spend an afternoon.

Eh....take it or leave it. Lively, crowded, frenetic....the market reminds me of New York's Chinatown on a much bigger level. The men with snakes and monkeys will try to get your attention. The woman with henna on the street will physically grab you, quite hard. It was not my cup of tea. We took a cursory look around and then headed down the side streets in search of a bit of calm.

a chaotic riot of craziness. You have to be very careful in the square, dont let ANYONE take your hand and lead you away to their stall, monkey, snake or henna stall. The stall holders will attempt to charge you way over the top for everything, just be wise and refuse to pay over what you think is fair. There are tourist police that you can report traders to. Be careful but definitely a sight you MUST see.
Crazy market. Be extremely careful of pick pocket thief. Cannot stress this enough! Trust no one. Don't buy phones, they are ALL fake!

Sunset destination. One of our favourite places in marrakech. A truly sensory experience. Highly recommended at any time of day, but best at sunset in a rooftop bar followed by a meal in a street cafe below. We recommend Number 1 (lady owner)

Busy!. Lots of places to shop, eat, drink and live entertainment. Hot during the day as there is no shade in the main square. Cooler in the evenings. I preferred evenings there as it was bustling with entertainment. Do not take your camera phones out unless you want to give the entertainers money. As soon as they see your phone in hand, they ask you for money and behave rudely. Don't make eye contact with any stall holders or entertainers unless you want them to bother you. Take your time there and enjoy the atmosphere.

Sensory overload. No matter how many reviews or advisories you read about Jemma Al Fna - nothing can prepare you for the assault on your senses. This place can be very very overwhelming and you need to just take your time with the place. give it a couple of visits and it will definitely grow on you. dont dismiss it on the first visit itself. make sure you are firm with your NOs. there are all manner of people vying for your attention, there are street performers, monkey wranglers, snake charmers and Henna-appliers just make sure you are firm with your NOs and dont extend your arm out too much lest they grab it . people here are generally good natured and all just looking to make a quick buck. it is a photographers paradise with so many opportunities to click that amazing travel-blog/magazine worthy picture. but these people are quick and even when you think you are sneaky with your photography they will descend on you to ask you for money. instead agree a price for a picture first and then take the pictures your want to they will ask for an absurd amount of money and be firm with how much you want to pay them. do not miss the orange juice carts - the sellers are all very good natured and they put on an act of being disappointed when you chose another cart than theirs and its all good natured banter. after the second or third night in Marrakech we began to love the energy of the square and were sad to be leaving at the end of our trip. we didnt sample the food there because we are vegetarians and didnt feel like eating there but we saw a lot of people eating there so if you are feeling brave then by all means go ahead! if I ranked it on first visit it would be a 2 star but it grew on us and we hope you give it a chance as well
market. is a must take it all in and barter hard lol walk away if they want t much they will soon come and find you and take what you are offering

Wowsers. Loud, frenetic, busy - an attack on the senses every which way you turn! Look out for the henna women. I doubt very much this is genuine henna and these women have a vice like grip once they get hold of your arms and produce their syringes. Try eating in 'meat Street' during the day and at any of the street stalls in the middle of the square at night. Great fun and really really cheap. You can feed a family of for with great food for about £15. Be brave and try everything!

Interesting experience. Refreshing fresh orange juice the best, looks like eating here will be rewarding but we never had the time. Avoid the snake charmers and water sellers, they'll harass you for a tip if you as much as look (but do take a firm 'NO').Worth the walk through into the souk/medina.

A vibrant Square at night. Visit in the evening when healers, tattoo artists, snake charmers etc are there and cooks cart in many restaurants specialising in barbecues, salads etc. quite an amazing sight.

Only for tourists. Basically a big empty expanse in the centre of town. The hustle and bustle might be nice for someone who hasn't been to a souq, and it's fun observing from one of the many terraces, but in the end it's completely geared towards tourists and seems a little fake. If you understand Arabic, or have someone to translate, the storytellers are definitely a highlight. The rest is tourist make-believe, with snake charmers for instance trying to charge 100 Dirham (10 €) for a photo. You can't stand still on this place without somebody approaching you and wanting money in some sort or another. It's understandable, but it's not for me.

Once or twice is enough. You have to visit the square of course, once in the day and once at night was enough for us - it is busy and lots of different things are going on but it is very touristy and people are constantly bothering you! Perhaps get a drink at Cafe Francais and look down on it all!

Not my Marrakech highlight. Beautiful scene from one of the café terraces at night!!Best fresh orange juice in the world!However, there is so much more than this square to see in Marrakech. Still, you cannot go to Marrakech and not visit it.We read all the reviews, stayed clear of the snake charmers and monkey tamers, so no issue there. Dress conservatively! Then you will not get your bum pinched!The food stalls however bring this rating right down. The one we ate at did everything that people warned you about in the reviews, a completely unpleasant experience. We did not get sick, but felt taken advantage of and ripped off. Every tourist eating at this stall was questioning their bill.Rather walk through to absorb the atmosphere, but eat at one of the restaurants. Will cost the same and the food will be better!!

Crazy fun madness!. Great for people watching during the day and absolutely crazy by night! HUGE square surrounded by shops, stalls, cafes and restaurants, many with great rooftop terraces to view the whole square by day or night, in relative peace. Eat at the street-food stalls at night.....silly prices and the food is excellent (Stall numbers 1 and 15 are great!)

A must visit for sunset and that's it. Well, it's one of the icons in Marrakech, you can have a great view over the square, the Koutubia and the amazing african sunset if you go to the terrace of Cafe Glacier. Apart from that, you can do a small tour and see some arts and crafts but very touristic and busy. I'd certainly skip the monkeys and snakes circus.. and all the counterfeit.

Town centre. All the sights of North Africa are on display here, from snake charmers through acrobats to cheap eats , expensive drinks and buy anything. Haggling is good fun and should not be taken too seriously; remember to start your offer at 50% of whatever is asked for.
If you love shopping.... Awesome experience. Friendly people and all up for a good haggle. This is a great place to pick up your souvenirs and gifts at a bargain price.

Visit in the evening..... I first visited during the day with my teenage daughter. The square is quieter with stalls selling delicious fresh orange juice for approx 50p - not to be missed.
