My teenage daughter found it quite upsetting to see the monkeys ( chains around their necks and dressed up in diapers). At the far side of the square close to the Mosque La Koutoubia there are many horse and carriages - the horses looked very tired and not so well looked after. She did not want to go back, but I managed to persuade her to visit in an evening.....The square came alive with many food stalls selling all sorts of Morroccan dishes, sweets, fruit, dates and nuts. Of course we were hassled to come and eat, but it was not intimidating and fun if you joke with the friendly sellers. Our only regret was we had just eaten and did not try any food. It all looked so delicious.. The monkeys and snake charmers were still there, but not so i"in your face" as they were shadowed by the entertainers and music. Not to be missed in the evening, but avoid in the daytime if you are a bit sensitive to animal welfare.

A Fascinating and lively cultural experience not to be missed. Snake charmers, acrobats, henna artists, story tellers, musicians, monkeys, cameleons, street food, and much, much more -a feast for the senses.

Prepare for pressure selling. We have visited the Jemaa el Fna twice now. It would be a fabulous place to look around, IF the stall holders would leave you alone. We could not pause to look at anything before we were set upon by persistent and some times slightly aggressive sellers. If, you did stop to look, and were invited in to browse, fine. But if the seller didn't have what you were looking for he would "stay here" I will get you something. Then the stall holders wouldn't let you leave. I found this VERY stressful, and because of this pressure, I don't want to go again. Plus, I find it very distressing to see animals being made to perform for tourists....at a price. Sorry, but the Souk, Jemma el Fna is not for the faint hearted or the easily stressed.

Vendors can be agressive. My friend and I visited the market and during the day it was a fairly pleasant experience. At night it was buzzing and crazy but my friend and I were disappointed with the vendors particularly where the food stalls were. They were very much in your face and aggressive. We were polite and told them we were just looking around and they swore and spoke to us quite rudely. Which for two young women isn't a particularly nice memory of such a lovely city. We tried to purchase a couple of traditional dresses and when we tried to barter the vendor still wanted to rip us off. We told him we didn't want to buy them and we walked away but the vendor grabbed my arm and held it tightly I had to prise my arm out of his hand. That really put me off. The women who do the henna they get you to look at the designs they say they charge 120 dirhams. We told her we'll come back she said to my friend let me give you a present and took her hand and starting doing a design which then became a full blown design. My friend gave her 30 dirhams she said this is nothing I told you it's 120. My friend said you told me it's a present! I understand they need money but to feel like you're being taken the piss out of on your holiday can spoil it. We found the local market close to our riad a much nicer experience. The vendors are less forceful and a lot more friendlier.

An amazing hub of activity.. Once you get used to the seething mass of people, you could spend hours here just people watching! This is Morocco at its best - from snake charmers to the Waterman and the Monkeys. There is so much here to see and do it would be impossible to write it all down. Just go there.......it is amazing! And of course you haven't been to Marrakech if you don't go to Jemaa el Fna!

The heart of Africa. Be careful of scams.. In the six days we've been in the city I think we've visited the place 20 times. Morning , afternoon , evening . Always lively , very attractive . VERY IMPORTANT : Especially not you sit down to eat without asking before prices because they will charge you three times what it's worth.

Buzzing. An amazing experience with so much to see and do
A very colourful buzzing place with friendly staff
Smells were wonderful - except the horses poo
Food was great

Crazy!. Go here during the day, to visually inspect the surroundings and to do your shopping. Go here at night for everything else! It is insane! Poets shouting things you cannot understand, snake charmers who chase you with cobras, there is a man who has a cheeky monkey who knows the difference between a 20 and a 50, organized kid boxing matches, artistic performers and even people who dance on fire….. it is insane! Be careful, and vigilant as there are pick pockets around and a lot of scams. But even with that, this place is crazy and so much fun!@instabuilt

Don't miss it!. Great hustle and bustle of a place with something new to experience at every turn. The guys on the food stalls are great fun - i suspect there is not a lot to choose between any of them - we ate at 117 and food and drink for 3 of us was 350 Dhm. then wandered around the music and "shows". If you don't enjoy the hassle (which is all good humoured and great banter) just rub your stomach and say full! Not met anyone who had any food hygiene problems. There are some weirder things to eat if you search them out - snail soup, sheep brains and offal of all sorts, the prickly pears are very nice. As elsewhere in Marrakech we never felt at all threatened nor were my wife and daughter ever inappropriately treated. Moroccans seem such lovely people.

Total Madness!!. This place is bonkers!! Its the place to have something to eat in the night and where you see the snake charmers and men with monkeys on a chains which you can have your photo with, for a price of course!! Its terribly sad to see these creatures being treated in the way that they do and if your an animal lover like me you'll give them the widest berth you can!! You can just hang around here or get a horse and cart to take a trip around the medina, from this area you can also access the souks. There are very pushy ladies who what you to have henna tattoos, they pester you all the time and its a pain!! The area is surrounded by freshly squeezed orange juice stalls and snail stalls, you can also eat here but you have to take pot luck because your unable to stop to look at the menu's, the men absolutely torture you if you slow down or even make eye contact! We ate there, we had unidentifiable meat and veg and veg and couscous, it was not that cheap and very bland! But in saying all that, its a place you have to see to believe and an experience you'll never forget!!

The heart of Marrakech. It's impossible to visit Marrakech without ending up in the square. I would much recommend going late afternoon to evening to witness the sunset on the bar roof terraces. During the day it's just full of orange juice stalls, snake charmers and henna tattoos; beware some henna has chemicals in which can harm your skin. For orange juice freshly squeezed to order I would recommend stall 30. At night the square really comes to life; snake charmers disappear and the square fills up with mini food stalls. It's quite funny as there are over 100 stalls that all sell pretty much the same food. We went to number 98, I highly recommend it for good food and great value for money (plus none of us were ill the day after!)PS. watch out for pickpockets, there are security around the square.

BE VIGILANT. Please don't take this as xenophobic or negative; it's purely factual based upon our experiences.HENNA LADIES: Be aware that you may be approached by ladies ''hiding'' bags of brown dye in their hands. A polite ''la shokran'' may work, it may not. A more forceful ''no thank you'' may work or may not. Our experience was that when VERY POLITELY told ''la shokran'' (no thank you), you could be ignored and an attempt to paint you regardless may continue. Being more forceful is met with ''Oh my God'' or a very dismissive ''Jeez''. DO NOT FEEL BAD ABOUT LOOKING AFTER YOURSELF AND SAYING A VERY FIRM BUT POLITE ''NO''.We only ventured in by day when the market wasn't at full flow so cannot comment on evenings in the square. Daytime was enough for me personally - busy, vibrant, harassing, smelly, uncomfortable and constantly waiting for the henna hag from hell to abuse us for not wishing to be dyed with some indeterminable gloop. If getting henna'd, I'd advise to go somewhere established where the product is less likely to cause a bad reaction and you'll be able to barter the price BEFORE being ''inked''.The ladies in the square will try to make you feel really crappy for rejecting them. Don't fall for it.Everywhere we went people were literally shouting at us to go buy their orange juice. It's neither here nor there and was acceptable as everyone is trying to make a living. Just be aware this kind of thing may happen. After reading on TA about others' experiences, I was weary of even getting my phone out let alone of taking pictures, so took none. By day, there's little to see to be honest.The souks were far less forceful - however, I did dress respectfully; covered head to foot, arms covered with a headscarf on which bought me more time than the average tourist as I didn't stick out like a sort thumb.Jemaa el Fna is possibly something to experience by night providing you are incredibly aware of the fact that practically everyone is trying to part you from your cash by fair means or foul.

Mandatory visit required although generally unpleasant . If you're looking for a relaxing experience this isn't the place for you. Expect to get harassed, shouted at and generally forcefully sold whatever goods or service the nearest tradesman has to hand. If on the other hand you don't mind the heckling, shouting and general smell about the place, at night all types of curiosities can be experienced including chance eat sheep's heads/brains (store 47), tarot readers, snakes and tied up monkeys (less pleasant). Keep an eye out for the ice cream parlour on the east side of the square which was welcome relief in heat of day. In general, has to be experienced but not wholly pleasurable.
Amazing.. What an amazing experience. The heart of Marrakech. You can shop till you drop. Use your bartering skills. Many a bargain to be had. Colourful and vibrant.

living back in time. one place not to miss is Jemaa el Fna by night.During the day its like any squarere full of tourist/ By night its like going to a totally different place. Its like you are part of the arabian nights A must for every one going to Marrakesh

Centre of Marrakesh. Definitely a must-go when in Marrakesh to experience the sights and sounds.During the day, line-ups of juice carts (mostly selling orange juice/lime juice), snake charmers, monkey-handlers, henna-stands and pop-up stores gather in the centre. In contract to the evening, the smoke from busy kitchen stands lay across the square.NOTE: Go during the day and come back at night. Like other iconic eatery plazas, food prices in Jemaa el Fna are quite expensive in relation to the food portions. Although there are numerous stands, we only tried a few and they were not a true representation of a Moroccan meal. I would say, go try the food for the experience :)NOTE: The snail-stand is definitely recommendable. Delicious and cheap! Watch out as you walk in between the food stalls or near them, people are very upfront and can be quite physical when trying to convince you to dine in their food stall. (My partner was physically dragged into one of the stalls while 3-4 people are trying to convince us into their stall, we politely refused.. tiringly) Fun experience

Magical!. A few weeks later and I still miss this place and the people in it. The orange stalls, the people handing out the fliers (one who we will never forget), the Henna ladies (Don't get too close, check out Henna art cafe) and the beautiful food stalls (Number 1!) made it one of the most incredible holidays i've ever been on. This place is magical, and I can't wait to see it again.
Big square. Full of people. Donkeys, horses, cats, monkeys, cobras, humans and much much more! To work here as a police man must be a nightmare. On the other hand it have its magic.

Great fun day and night. This square in the heart of the medina in Fes is huge and filled with all sorts of acts (monkeys, snake charmers, and water vendors all requesting money for photos taken) during the day and at night, the fun continues with the performers- musical, acrobats. You can eat from the different grilled meat stands, sit at long tables and watch the world go by. Lots of cafes and restaurants ring the square, too.

Madness and Vibrant Rolled into One. Monkey, Cobras and a man selling both false and real teeth, all alongside sheeps heads for sale and live chickens being prepared before your eyes.Go to one of the restaraunts that gives you a high up view over the square and take some photos from there.
Great atmosphere. A very auuthentic atmosphere in this spot which is nice to have a little meal by trying all the shops and products around

crazy and fun. Great fun but if you are not prepared to pay for an act or photo avoid the attraction/sight and don't look. Taking a photo and not paying is a no no - its better to confirm the price of the photo opportunity first too.

Wow!. One is mesmerized by the shear number of people in the square, and of the number of food stands selling much the same food. The difference is how well you are sold in patronizing them. There are of course several entertainers around from snake dancers, musicians, and hawkers.If you are not inclined to eat in the stalls, then there several restaurants along the perimeter of the square offering food services. This place lives up to it's reputation.
Amazing!. Don't miss it. Discover it both day and night! Exotic for people watching, especially at night, lit up and fascinating. Be aware, during the day there will be snake charmers.
A must for every visitor. Your bound to end up here once or twice during your trip, it's worth coming into it at night or sit up high overlooking the square for lunch, busy busy busy

be careful. Although we said no, a snake was put around my husband's neck. when we asked, "How much?', we were told, "whatever you like". After I took a picture, the guy demanded 200MAD, about$20.We were prepared to have a picture with the monkey. At the last minute, his friend came and put another monkey in my husband's arm. After the picture, EACH guy demanded 200 MAD, $20.Seemed like everyone wanted to sell you something from henna to dentures.
Amazing. They say this is the center of the world - always something happening, great place to try street food

Loud and vibrant. Snake charmers, musicians, orange juice sellers and the call to prayer - brilliant.Horse-drawn caleche are great but fix a price before you get in and expect the driver to try to up the price by adding on extra sights to see, even during the journey. Night food market from about 6pm is brilliant - look for the one or two stalls amongst the 100 that have locals eating and don't have hawkers trying to drag you in. Cafe Glacier has great views from above the market and do a great tagine.

market visit. what a nice market , all type of food are available at evening time but i am not advised to eat outside food, i like fresh oranges juice and dry fruits and yes what bird and animals public saw in open market.it's really nice market place to visit i like that.

Great atmosphere!. Great atmosphere, particularly in the evening once the sun goes down and the crowds come out with plenty of music going on and the smell of food in the air. Just watch out for pickpockets and be wary of the snake charmers and guys with monkeys as well as the street kids trying to sell you things. Plenty of nice terrace restaurants and bars to go to just off the square.

A must-see, but only once. This is described as a must see but we found it a bit too hectic with people always directing us to it, or trying to sell us something. It is worth seeing but we found once was enough for us!
Open air market place in Marrakech. This is a crazy area mainly for tourists now, but you can get great street food here, and beautiful bags and incense. Be prepared to haggle and enjoy the madness

hot crazy and wonderful. Jemaa el Fna is a must see when visiting Marrakech. During the day it is much easier to get around around than at night,with the sounds and smells you will never experience anywhere else in the world - it is wonderful - There are snake charmers, monkeys, you can get yourself a henna tattoo.. fresh orange juice and amazing food stalls

It is all its made out to be.. You've already heard about this square, it's all true.If you want to eat at any of the food stalls, I can thoroughly recommend N° 14.Have a good a time as I did!Cheers,Brian

A crazy place!. So much is going on in the Jemaa that you don't know where to look. It's easy to find from anywhere inside the Marrakech Medina - especially since everyone everywhere assumes that is what you are looking for and points you in the general direction. Beware of those who want to walk you right there - or walk you anywhere, for that matter. The trip will end with a hand out, palm up, demanding money for the service. A service that you didn't necessarily ask for, by the way. But that is the way it goes in Marrakech. Anything can be had for a price. And even when you agree on a price first, an extra service or item you didn't request will ratchet the cost up a bit more. The Jemaa is geared toward tourists. Henna, snake charmers, dancers, musicians all abound. And if you linger anywhere close to where they are "performing," or, God forbid, bring your camera up to snap a casual photo, you will be immediately accosted - "You take photo, you pay!!" At night the scene changes. Food stalls everywhere, with cooks and servers all doing their best to lure you in to try their offerings. Most of them seem to have the same food, although a few have goat, sheep and calf skulls on display on the tables where customers eat. Not sure what that's trying to advertise but it didn't look too appetizing. Most of the kebobs are good and tasty. The pastries that are sold from the carts look better than they taste. It actually seems to be a "chain," so all the carts offer the same little cakes. The Jemaa is a must-see, day or night. It's easy to figure out what to try and what to try to avoid.

Madness on Saturday Evenings!!. The central square that leads to the Souks, you will find snake charmers, henna artists, food vendors and all types of stalls.
Be careful of pick pockets. Take to one of thee many roof terraces for a cuppa to watch all from up high.

soo much to see and do. everything all in one place. A bit like a zoo but the animals are not caged up. There were snake charmers who almost chased one lady with a snake, monkeys who force themselves on you and horse carriages which almost run you over. I personally thought it was quite cool and different but can understand this place might not appeal to all people. I kind of liked that you could take a picture with the animals and play with them and you give what you think is a good price and they are more than happy to accept whatever you give them. Freshly squeezed orange juice available at almost every turn. their also lots of women who were doing henna tattoos.

The Best. This was the best time of my 7 week vacation tour,every thing from living arrangements to post ,food,transportation is right there.Shopping And haggling with the locals was great .Just don't trust the snake charmers.the place and surrounding city were very safe.I was there 5 days and already would love to go back!

Another must. If you have never been to a similar place, you could feel a little uncomfortable at first. But, do not let that put you off. Well worth the visit, a walk around and searching for the right stall at which to sit and enjoy excellent local food, Unbeatable prices.

Plenty of sights and sounds. Snake charmers, monkeys, henna ladies, horse carriages, carts, donkeys, street performers and fresh orange juice by day, story tellers, magic performers, hot street food stalls of different varieties by night!Always bustling this is one of the main attractions of marrakech, try visit the Koutoubia mosque and its lovely orange tree lined gardens if you want to relax for a moment.

Great place. The big square is the heart of marrakech and is the best place to visit in the day time with snake charmers,monkeys,and henna pepole,the night is the best part of the square that i loved,dancers,food,shopping the lot loved it would def do it again

Inside the caos. This place is amazing if you get on well with the caos. The smell of the spices mixed with the sound of the drums and flutes are the DNA of this place. A must-go site if you're visiting Marrakech, it will become an unforgettable moment for the rest of your life.

Jemma el Fna. The square to visit for people watching! Come here at different times of the day to gain a new experience! Water sellers, snake charmers, dentists, street food etc . . .Visit the surrounding cafes with panorama terraces to watch the excitement unfold! Enjoy a mint tea whilst watching . . .delicious!

Crazy. Jemaa el Fna is a must see when visiting Marrakech. During the day it is easier to navigate around than at night, the sounds and smells you will experience you will never forget - it is like a whirlwind - There are snake charmers, monkeys, you can get yourself a henna tattoo.. fresh orange juice and amazing food stalls. At night the square really does come to life the smoke fills the air from the worlds largest BBQ.

'Disney-Marrakech'!. The ultimate in Marrakech tourist experiences. Competing sounds of drumming and snake charming, various barbecue smells, food stalls, souk stalls, aggressive vendors etc etc. We spent much more money than we intended but it was fun (for an hour or two).

Must see by day and night. Definitely an interesting and worthwhile experience, especially at night. Between the food stalls, musicians, drummers, snake charmers, and vendors, there is always plenty to see and do. Even though it feels almost entirely tourist-focused, you can still see the centuries of history and local use. There are great prices on pashmina, leather goods, pottery, woodwork, tile mosaics, and just about everything else you could possibly be looking for. On the negative side, I was definitely more nervous about pickpockets here than anywhere else in Morocco since the square is open and swarming with people, and there were a fair number of child beggars. I felt pretty horrible for the collared monkeys on chains - they looked well-fed but miserable. The overall experience shouldn't be missed.

Unmissable. We went to the square quite a few times during out week in Marrakech. A fabulous noisy atmosphere of music, drums, families out enjoying themselves, lots of food being cooked, street sellers, snake charmers, wonderful. Felt completely safe, we loved it.

Magic! Enjoy a feast for all the senses!. Snake charmers, fresh orange vendors , market stall selling just about everything, street food , temporary restaurants , drummers, singers, acrobats......... I know I missed something. Should not be avoided - it IS in essence what Marrakesh is about!
A Must!. Lots to see. Especially when the sun goes down. Visited day and night and it is two different places. The view from restaurant Glacier was perfect.

Overwhelming at times. This place is not for the faint hearted. At night it becomes alive but is full of very pushy hard sell traders. This is part of its charm but also quite unbearable too. Very exotic and you so have to experience this but at times it is completely over the top. We ate good food at the night food markets but equally had to endure quite aggressive marketing which at times became almost threatening.

What an experience!!. Bit late to submit my review but I'm sure a lot hasn't changed in a year. This tourist trap really is an assault on your senses. I was SO glad my husband and brother-in-law were there with me. They understood the culture and bartered very well!! It really is worth a visit but beware ... it's very much 'in your face'. So be prepared!!

Busy..bonkers..mayhem..snakes..monkeys... The main square in Marrakech... busy in the day, totally mental in the evening. It is a complete no-holds-barred assault on your senses... smells, tastes (even if u don't eat anything!!), sound, sights and touch... cos believe me, you will be elbow-to-elbow with a few thousand other tourists and locals, snake charmers and monkeys on leashes... ...crazy, jaw-dropping feast for the senses!!

Amazing, just amazing.. Jemaa el Fna is an amazing place. I have never seen anywhere else like it. During the day it has market stalls, snake charmers and people with tame monkeys posing for tourist pictures. However, after dark it really comes alive with Berber music, jugglers, fire eaters, acrobats and stalls where you can sit and eat street food for incredibly low prices. The quality of the food is OK, but you can't be too precious about hygiene because they rinse plates in a bucket between diners. Having said all of that, it is quite an experience and one that I would recommend highly.

Organised chaos . Great place to see! Very full on but have to check out the markets and eat some street food. Even though it's very busy and everyone's trying to get you to eat at there stall it's still very entertaining and locals are all very kind. Just have you're wits about you and keep your wallet and phone close!
Fantastic!. A must for anybody visiting. Be prepared for the engaging stall holders. Never ending changing experiences here... be prepared to haggle, give...and enjoy.
Very nice place. A good place to visit if you wish to try the local food and experience the market which is still very authentic.
dear god the stench. its a must visit location, but be aware it is a proper tourist trap, how anyone eats here with the stench is beyond me

Eat here at night for an experience. We ate at the market at night to experience this. First do yourself a favour and walk through the food market to experience the different families trying to lure you in.. Then choose one as they are really all the same.. We did not get sick and don't think too much of the cleanliness just Eat..... don't use their knives and forks as they don't really have proper facilities to clean cutlery just eat with your hands and enjoy the cultural experience.

Not particularly interesting, a bit uncomfortable.... We walked through here when we had to, otherwise we avoided it because of the pushy sellers and pungent smell of horse poo/urine. There were also men who had monkeys in nappies on chains, trying to sell tourists a photo with the monkeys. The monkeys were always running and jumping to try and break the chain. Carriage horses were in terrible condition, and women grab people's hands in an attempt to sell their henna services. The good news is, it has a few nice cafés, some ATMs, souvenir stalls, and other useful services.
Exotic place!. A buzzing marketplace well worth visiting. Many groups of loud musicians playing for money. Food stalls with interesting food.

worth a visit. the square is worth a visit vibrant colourful site sounds smells BUT be aware of very aggressive beggars around the sides Dont go inside any shops you will find yourself surrounded by aggressive sales men Do Not follow anyone down any streets they will try to mug you ! enjoy ?
Mahem at the Medina. Great place, lots to see and experience. Just take a seat at one of the many cafes and watch the locals enjoy their day

Beware. Stressful and horrible. Got attacked by a henna woman who insisted on drawing a little design on my hand as a "present" after I clearly said I did not want henna and then chased me down the square demanding money. Got cursed at and called ugly for saying "No thanks, maybe later" when a man asked us to eat at his stall. Poor chained monkeys with nappies, don't look at them or the snakes or their owners will demand money from you. Filled with aggressive hustlers with nothing but contempt for tourists. Don't trust anyone who is friendly to you.

amazing place. have been here twice now and still find it an amazing place to visit during the day its nice to people watch but at night it comes alive from acrobats snake charmers the list is endless not to visit would not be avisit to marrakech must do
Busy, exotic and busy. The central square is always busy day and night. Fruit and fresh orange jus sellers by day and street food by night.

You just got to see it!. Amazing, you'll expérience a lot in this square and it differs from day to night.
You can drink, eat, watch and shop all in the same place under a clear Sky.
fabulous assault on the senses.. amazing smells, sights, sounds and so much to experience. very full on. brilliant if not slightly scary experience. A def must do in Marrakech

Another Must See. The "big square" is a fascinating, bustling center of the Medina, especially at night. Food is everywhere, including oranges, kebabs and other goodies. There are snake charmers, musicians, dressed up characters, monkeys and , yes, handout seekers. It is safe, just watch for pickpockets. Restaurants surround the "square", but not the best in Marrakech.

Best by night. During the day it is a very open space. Odd snake charmers and stalls selling orange juice. Far better to visit at night when all of the food stalls are set out and the atmosphere is brilliant. Many families are there late in to the night, so you feel safe.

An experience - another must see. The central square in Marrakech is alive with activity all day and well into the night. In the evening, food stalls abound. During the day and into the evening, merchants sell all sorts of products and souvenirs. It is important to bargain and that can be part of the fun. There are also some unique attractions, such as the snake charmers. The square is a great place to get some food and watch the spectacle.

A must see. There is no way to be in Marrakech and miss Jemaa el Fna. Quite the opposite - it's an unmissable place where one should see its busy crowds, smell its scents, hear its sounds and taste its flavours. My heart was won by incredibly delicious orange juice.

Like Nothing Else. This square is like no where else I have ever seen. Hectic at time but you soon get used to it. A nice mix of tourists and local Marrakeshi people. Make sure you do at least one evening there as the sun sets as you an watch it jump into action.

Cobras & Monkeys.. I took a selfie with a Monkey, and I shot a video of my girlfriend with the Cobra guy. Yeah, he's got the Cobra with the little clarinet and the whole bit. The monkey guys will take ten Dirhams for a selfie. The Cobra guy doesn't awaken his viper for less than a twenty.

An Excellent Live Show of the Locals.. Morning, Noon and night. The place give so many perspectives of lives. Please in different days try to see different times of the day of your trip. Eat, listen , smell , see , touch , take a photo and try to dance with locals . Maybe you could think differently but be sure to take your place of this show.
Like nowhere I have ever been!. This is a truly fascinating place - a feast for the eyes! There is so much to see at all times of day!

Simply amazing. I loved this place. By day it was a frying pan of snake charmers and, unfortunately, poorly looked after monkeys. By night this place comes to life! Thousands of people, hundreds of places to eat traditional food, but be wary of places trying to rip you off, and lots of sellers and sounds. You also cannot forget the orange juice sellers. These guys are amazing, all fighting over getting your sale of exactly the same thing! Some may try and sell you 15-20dirham juices but just stick to the 4 dirham orange. It is very refreshing.

Good But Not The Main Attraction. We visited the square several times over our holiday. The orange juice is very nice but do make sure its not watered down with ice. I recommend stall 19. The henna women were a little forceful. There are some great places to watch the world go by from a terrace cafe or restaurant. I found it all a little too touristy and there was a lot of people bothering us. Although we never went during the night which I have heard is nice with all the lights etc.

Unusual city. This is a very strange city with so many donkeys, bikes and motorbikes trying to access very narrow streets that Jemaa El Fna is a welcome retreat. To just have so much space as it is a very large square. There are plenty of places to stop for food and drinks, especially those selling fresh orange, which is very cool and refreshing and costs only about 30p.
Best at night. OK By day but really comes alive at night so many places to eat,lots of street performers and loads of people a tourist hot spot

Crazy place. Well what can you say about this place. It's certainly an overload on your senses from the sounds of the snake charmer to the smells of the food being cooked at night. Start taking photos of the snakes, the monkeys or anyone and expect to be shown a hat to put money in. In the food market at night expect to get hassled by every stall plying for your money. A bit daunting first time but we had some good banter and a lot of laughs too and a very decent lamb tagine, cous cous and coke that cost around £6.50 for 2 people!

A Must See in Marrakech. This is the place to see in Marrakech, it will be an explosion on several of your sense, sight, smell, taste, hearing. Wear comfortable shoes as there is plenty of walking around the souks and ensure you have a hat and water if visiting in the day as can get very hot.Orange juice is plentiful and a must try along with the food that is sold by a number of vendors both in the square and just on the outside the square. The souk in itself is an experience and easy to lose your way. If buying spices such as saffron ensure you do not buy it in powder form and ensure it is strands. Some vendors may try and pass saffron of as another spice. Remember to barter in the souks and walking away often helps lower the price even further.

Hustle and bustle of traditional Marrakech . You must visit here if you are in Marrakech. Come in the evening and eat at one of the market food stalls we ate snails on one night and then the night after had a selection of what was on offer, very cheap (soup was approx €0.50) try the sheeps head, it will surprise you how tasty it is!! Stay away from the henna ladies unless u do want a tattoo and be aware of the monkeys on leads, they will try and sit one on your shoulder but if you keep your wits about you then you will have an amazing time soaking in the atmosphere

Not for the faint hearted!. I like it. There is so much to see and take in, it can overwhelm.If it's your first time I recommend eating at number 25 (i have eaten here6/7 times over two trips) I found the men that run it very honest and polite. The guy in the red shirt speaks good English. For orange juice i liked number 36.Every store claps as you enter it is a greeting and almost a thank you for stopping don't be embarrassed or alarmed!If they bring something you didn't order simply say so! Or tell them it wasn't you that ordered the dish. Don't let it sit by you.. moroccan menus keep the food coming this is where this practice comes from it is to make you feel at home, not to dupe you as a tourist it is to ensure you leave full and more than likely happy. Do query your bill if it Is higher than expected, they will explain and if they make a mistake it will be corrected.After eating If it is your first time I recommend heading to the roof top bar next to the bank. Go upstairs it overlooks the main square. Entry is the price of a drink (25dh) from this height you get to take in the beauty and atmosphere of the square and skyline without being asked to 'have a look' - when you do brave the square and you're asked to have a look and are not interested say with a smile 'maybe later' or 'fo-lus ka-las' (means money has finished) the locals will laugh and laugh with you, possible pat your shoulder and send you on your way.There are small children and old people begging. If you are looking in your bag/ have a kind face expect to be approached. Enjoy your time here, let the good times roll! Don't be scared or put off, the culture is very different but embrace it!
Madness. A great experience if you are not of a nervous nature. Enjoy the souks, snake charmers, acrobats, and drink mint tea on a roof terrace

Go to eat at no30. No 30 was the best food. The one next to it on the edge was full of tourists (31) personally i like to go to ones that aren't like that..Loads of entertainment at night..If you like street fighting, monkeys on chains and snake charmers then venture around.Some fun games too!!

Amazing. We visited the Jem twice during our holiday and both times were truly amazing. The best time to visit is at night when it really comes to life with food stalls serving a dazzling array of local foods. During the day it is mainly water sellers, snake charmers and stall holders selling everything you can think of. Avoid the people with monkeys as they want you to have your photo taken and it will cost you dearly. There are wonderful places to eat and drink overlooking the square. It will be a once in a lifetime experience and one you shouldn't miss.
Exotic and exciting. Wow! Noisy, colourful - a sensory delight everywhere you look. A must! The aromas of saffron, amber and smoke combined with music, story telling, snake charmers - great place.

Good for one visit but not more. When you go there the first time it is very intressting but you'll be annoyed by the many people who want to sell you this standart tourist rubbish. Take care of your belongings at night and be careful when you cross the street (the traffic is a little bit chaotic).You can get a lot of good food and it is defenetly worth a visit. For me one visit is enough.

Great open area. Big "square" (more actually a triangle) outside the entrance to the Souks. During the day there are plenty of stalls selling fresh juice, shoe shiners and general bits and bobs. Stay away from the men with monkeys or snakes, even taking pictures near them they will ask for money.If there is a special occasion or national holiday, hundreds upon hundreds of people gather in the square and play music and dance, it's a great atmosphere and can lead to some great sights if you're on a terrace of nearby restaurantsIf you're looking to shop and have something specific in mind, shop around, most of the shops sell exactly the same things so see what price you can get.

A world experience. You must visit the square at any time of the day.Stay away from the monkey and snake guys... they charge you a lot of money for a picture. Be firm in your voice to tell them that you are not interested. This goes for the "guides" as well.. you'll be ripped off by them.A firm "Non Merci!" or La Shokran!" will do after a couple of times.Please don't let them scare you off when they keep on following you.You'll get used to it and makes it easier to shake them off.

Insane!!. This is an insane square- so much energy and vibrance. Even though it's a but hectic and people are trying to sell everything from leather goods to pictures with snakes to great fresh orange juice it is a lot of fun- especially after a few times when it becomes less daunting!At night it really comes alive and is absolutely spectacular. The street food was consistently good and cheap. Enjoy !

Interesting but be careful what you buy.. As you wander through the square and the souk, be prepared to be accosted by the many stallholders who want you to buy their wares. Just walk past. If you do see something you like, you are expected to haggle.

Commercialised and Touristy. The square is an experience but it is full of tacky stalls selling the same things. You have to go and visit and sit in a roof top cafe to absorb the hustle and atmosphere but it is not a great place to shop. The Medina is much better and more authentic in places but again you need to look for it.

Cultural tapestry Great shopping Meandering wonder. These markets have everything. Wonderful homewares eg 2 silver pouffs for $20A each. Leather handbags on trend styles and tons of homewares. Even live chameleons! Great place to spend at least 1/2 evening (gets hot in the day) and changes at night with locals coming out also and becomes quiet crowded. Good to find a highset restaurant and drink it all in with some morrocan local dishes. I also bought moroccan 25 spice from here for my cooking.

A must see for anyone who loves travel.. My wife and I have been to Marrakech a number of times and always stay in the old medina. It is an experience like no other. Jemaa El Fna is the main square of the old town and is a World Heritage site. The square itself is huge and changes in how it presents itself from hour to hour and day to day. In any case it is like walking back in time and can feel like a film set, but in a good way. The cafes and restaurants are good but the view,the noise, the atmosphere and yes the smells are what it is all about. The experience will never leave you. Be careful of the street vendors, they can be somewhat bothersome and avoid the street vendor food unless you have an iron stomach. The cafe food is safesafe. The adjacent souks are fabulous but maze like, don't bother with a map just lose yourself for a few hours. Jemaa El Fna should be on everyone's bucket list. Oh and if female, dress modestly or you will get unwanted attention.

Fun. Not the first time to visit the Mosque of Al-Fanar but several visits in different years . I enjoy shopping and visiting shops and Alltsoar with animals , as well as its great tasting food diversity . They have to spend a whole day until the evening and dine him . I also enjoy drinking Moroccan tea and juice refreshing

Amazing Place full of culture but watch out for pick pockets and bum-grabbers. What a place...full of thousands of people every night. Food, games, animals and unfortunately bum grabbers. We all look out for pick pockets but from my experience of 3 nights in the square bum grabbers are the main threat. Ill be honest, I was annoyed it wasnt my bum! but my girlfriend took the brunt. Guide books said that we were to expect this but whilst I watched my wallet I left her bum unattended. Oh the whole a great experience I would recommend to all

Famous Moroccan marketplace. Colorful, cultural and exciting place to visit both day and night. Daytime showcases incredible markets of unusual items, snake charmers, water sellers and monkeys. Night brings a fabulous feast of taste and smells-- many foods from meats, tagine stews, vegetables, fish and kakobs. When in Marrakesh, you cannot miss this open air extravaganza.

Depends on the time in the day.... If you are at Jemaa el Fna on the day, where there snake charmers and the monkeys at a chain, that's not what Marrakesh is great about. When the sunset and the evening starts many little food stands open, the smell of the place changes and all of a sudden you get invited to taste the great food of Morocco. That is the time you want to be there.

Fascinating. The square is transformed on a evening, we watched dancers, snake charmers, monkeys, the colours and food smells all mingle together to make an impressive experience, watch out that you may get your bum pinched!! Go to the square on a daytime and it is a different place, some lovely places to try the local food and look around the Souks.

busy square. this is a square full of little shops in the morning and at night the square turns into a square of different restuarant all grilling away. i enjoyed and loved walking around jamaa fenna. you can find anything to buy as gift. problem is you must negotiate price at all times. be careful of pocket picking

chaotic and hectic. Hard to sum up this place in a few words - it's big, noisy, hectic, intriguing, fascinating ... and a must see for everybody visiting Marrakech. But beware ... the snake charmers aren't very charming and only interested in ripping you off and they know all the tricks in the book. One of them threw a snake around my neck, took my camera and said "picture, picture" ... and only afterwards did he ask for an OUTRAGEOUS amount in dirhams before giving me my camera back and finally removing the snake from my neck. Kind of a dirty trick - he must be a wealthy man! But we learned not to get fooled so easily! At night it's quite a struggle to get past the food stalls, because everybody comes up to you and guarantees that theirs is the best place to eat. Just pick one of the places - they more or less all offer the same food and it'll save you for a lot of struggle getting past the sometimes almost aggressive people trying to get customers. But - after all, this is a good place to learn your lessons ... go there on your first day in Marrakech and learn the rules. Knowing how to bargain will make the rest of your stay a lot more pleasant and will save you a lot of money!
fun place. food stall as far as the eye can see....dancers, musicians and snake tamers mix in the crowed. worth a stroll.

Everything Morocco, Good and Bad. Day time, a little on the boring side but the place comes alive at night.Expect people to be in your face everywhere. Especially anywhere near a snake or monkey, where even checking the time on your phone results in someone on you right away demanding payment.Depending on where you come from, the fresh orange juice stalls for 4 dirham are a nice refreshing break, but try to find he ones that juice before and keep it in a jug with ice. The fresh juice can sometimes be warmer.If you have the opportunity, try and get a reservation at one of the medina restaurants with a terrace for around 6:30 or 7:00. You'll catch the sunset, and have a great seat for the change over from day to night. The food's not great but the action is exciting.If you not something a little more local, try one of the orange roofed food stalls, but do know that as soon as you sit down, they might start putting food in front of you without you ordering. If you don't say no right away, you'll be on the hook.

Once experienced never forgotten. Its lively (!) but do not be put off by that. Nightime especially great fun although intense. Even if busy is not your thing a place you have to go to. It will be an abiding memory for us until the grey cells go...

A vibrant and unique place.. It is impossible to avoid this place, and rightfully so. I am not going to describe what you will find there, as this is very repetitive. I gave it an excellent rating because of it's uniqueness. This is the Marrakech you want to know. Get hassled and negotiate at the stores, visit some of the cafe's with a roof terrace, walk around the stores and soak it all in during the day and come back after sunset and you find a complete different scene. Really amazing. Even though it is a huge organized confusion, we never felt uncomfortable and there is always enough police around. A must do. However, one advice DO NOT EAT at the open air dining area in the middle of the square. Repeatedly we were warned by the locals not to take any food there. However, the juice stalls are safe, excellent and cheap. Also, make sure to have enough change with you to fill your camera with photo's of the beautiful dressed up berber members and dancers during the evening hours at the square,

One great big con. But do it anyway, it's kinda fun. Everything you cast your eyes on comes at a cost. Walk to close to the snake charmers and they demand money, to close the the stalls and they hassle you like your the last customer on earth. The food stalls will all give you the Delhi belly, and they put food out for you you didn't want, and didn't order, then charge you for it. The army and police are everywhere to try and stop the pick pockets, but they fail. The cash machines are like target practice for the pick pockets. BE ALERT! All this said, if you can keep your wits about you, don't carry more cash than your happy losing, it's good fun. Laugh off the unwanted attention, refuse to pay over the odds at the food stalls, and make sure your tucked up in bed before the streets turn quiet and nasty.Have fun xxx

An Exciting Assault on All your Senses. The square has to be seen to be believed. Thousands of people, smells and sounds. Snake charmers, donkeys, motorbikes, hawkers selling their wares everywhere. A must do in your life time.

Couple tips. ORANGE FRESH: Ask for a plastic cup right away. The cost is 5 DH per cup. The taste is average - it's fresh, pulpy, but probably made from mediocre oranges.SNAILS: Cost is 10 DH per plate. Taste is bitter and spicy hot. Digestion not affected. TEA: Made with cardamon and other spices - very intense taste. Comes with a piece of sweetish brownish dough which helps to balance out the taste of tea. For 2 teas and 1 dough thingy we got some change from a 20 DH note. Digestion not affected.BOXING: In general ok to watch, but keep a couple 10 DH coins at hand for when the showman makes rounds. Digestion not affected.SNAKE CHARMERS: They have a lookout guy who spots people taking pictures and comes running to collect a fee. If you got a good shot already - ignore him. Wanna take a better one - don't ask how much, just give 5 DH and go take a close up.
Fantastic . No visit to Morocco is complete without a visit to this crazy yet organised chaos .Amazing, food,great shopping and a must visit.

Anthropological wonder in Marrakech. Jamaa el Fna is the main square leading to the open air market in Marrakech. By day, it is a collection of storytellers, snake charmers, peddlers, pickpockets (be careful!) and children selling all sorts of chinese junk. By night, it turns into a massive "food court" with hundreds of stands selling local food. You can order drinks in one of the bordering restaurants with a rooftop view and get a wonderful overview of the whole circus. Or just wade in and wander around.This square is where the ancestors would gather and tell the children the folktales and songs which where passed from generation to generation - thus the daytime atmosphere of the square. You can spend an hour or a day, or just continue on into the market and get lost among the alleyways.Either way, it's a wonderful experience!

Comes to life at dusk, very interesting!. Well, once the sun goes down the entire square comes to life, people galore arrive en mass. There are all type of tourists, hordes of locals trying to get you buy knock off wears, countless entertainers (gymnastics performers, Berber music, pet monkies on leashes ), tons of food stalls serving all kinds of food. It is basically a big giant mosh of many different things all at once. I would say just wade in and enjoy with all your senses, smell, sight and sound!

A must! . My favorite place in Marrakech and by far, there's so much to see, do and explore in these very busy market, you can dpend countless hours in Jemaa El Fna, tourists and locals there at all times, but after 8 it's when the real fun begins!!!
Moroccan food. Good place to see and feel local food. Tajine and all. Its hard to decided which tent you have to go since ita all similar. Choose wisely.Cos its a amazing.

An experience . In the morning it's orange juice sellers (amazing value) and surrounding souks and stalls. As the day progresses out come entertainers and Acrobats. And it all comes alive after dusk when about 100 competing food stalls set up. Grills, tagines - smells wonderful and tastes good too. Can get crowded and noisy but has to be done.

Touristy but a must-do. Crowded and gimmicky-touristy, but still a must-do while in Marrakesh. See the snake charmers and monkey handlers, have a picture made with them if you like, and enjoy the people-watching. Have an orange juice from one of the venders. Best fresh-squeezed OJ we've had anywhere!
Fantastic. A mad crazy wonderful place that you must must see ! everything is just so different , a total must for a trip to marrakech .
wow. food was goo but I got sick .. but it was a Great experience, snake charmers, monkeys. gets crazy at night !

Outstanding. This place is extraordinary ..So much going on here with food stalls , tourist, local crowd and street performers .You can spend a lot of time here just looking at the hustle Bustle of this square. Surrounded by nice French cafes this place has some thing to do with everyone.

Ok and worth a visit but over rated.. This is the main place to go at nights, you get variety if food places from stalls to restaurants, souks and traders and not very good shows. Initially the senses are overwhelmed with the crowds, music, noise, smells,lights etc and is worth a visit but it can get tiresome after a while. It is better to visit at night than the day in my opinion.There is far too much hassle here which after experiencing the souks in the day can really irritate. Apart from the stalls you will be hassled by street traders with sweets, henna artists, snake charmers, people with monkeys, people at the so called shows if you stop to see what is happening especially if you try taking pictures, food stalls and small taty restaurants. Be warned that alot of the people don't understand the concept of no and can be quite sarcastic when you walk away so try to have a light hearted approach even though it can be hard.The food at the stalls is nothing special, good enough to fill you for a a cheap price. Less than £15 for 2 people including drinks but you get what you pay for. The foid is the same in all the stalls and be warned they will charge you for everything, nothing is free including the bread and olivs they give while you wait for your food even though you did not ask for it. Also you Street traders selling fakes watches etc approach people while they are eating which can.be frustrating.The best thing about the square is the fresh orange juice stands. The juice is amazing and starts at 30p for a regular cup from mcdonalds in the UK. The stands are there throughout the day and night.All the stalls sell the same tat throughout the medina. For those that do not want to trall through the he souks constantly and go through the process of haggling or are not too confident, I recommend doing the shopping from here at night. Over all the items are more resonably priced and you can get them for a good price without haggling too much, also many stalls have marked prices on smaller items. You will also find some items that you wont in other parts of the souks.The square also has a few nice restaurant that do good food and also have terraces offering great views.
Mr. Watch your wallets and phonesGets pretty busy You have to experiance it..Also avoid big crowds if you can. The sights are great during the nighy
Sights and Sounds of Marrakech. A very mesmerizing place, a feast for the senses! The sound, smell, and sights capture the spirit of Morocco!
Different to any other market place. What a fantastic place to go like no other market place I have ever visited and felt very relaxed with thecwholecatmosphere.

Crazy but brilliant! . At night time this place turns into a crazy but magical place it's like nothing else I have ever experienced. If you wish to watch any of the dancers and performances make sure you take small change with as they get angry if you don't give any money!!! As a blonde female I did get a lot of attention but it was all friendly and if you just walk away they leave you alone. I must do whist in Marrakesh anytime from about 6pm through till 2-3am. It is a family friendly place, I felt safe as I was with a male friend but don't think I would go on my own. So much going on lots of people and a great festival environment!

Crazy but nice place. The sounds and noises and smells transfer you back in time to what marrakech looked and felt 100 years ago minus the scooters :-) most visit for any visiting marrakech , the foods stalls are crazy so id the snake charmers

Totaly Amazing, a must see!!. Visit during the day to get your bearings , then return at night when the square comes alive . You never know what you might see , snake charmers , musicians, dancers and much more. There are also lots of food stalls set up in the square at night , it looked like an open air restaurant with tables and chairs set out around the stalls. No alcohol served in the square .

Go at night!. During the day, the square seems full of various touts and hawkers, all aiming to make some easy money from the tourists. At night however, real Moroccans are everywhere to be found, making it a great place to spend an evening, conversing with the locals. Eat at one of the kiosks - the Sheep's head is great.
live circus. Hard to avoid when walking around - here you will be entertained but also cheated if your not awake.

An experience. First time to Marrakech and visiting the Square was an experience. It was lovely to walk around and lookng at small stores. The square came more alive from after 6pm, buzzing with 1000s of people.

Packed during holidays and in the evenings. Go there during the evening to suck up the atmosphere. It is great to see the locals enjoy story tellers or musicians, also try some food from the little stands.

Madness (but awesome). You can't go to Marrakech without coming here, especially at night. During the day it's nice too, but around 8pm the square comes alive with lots of food shops (didn't eat there, though many people gave a no diarrhea guarantee) and music. Be ready for the crowds!

Lots to buy/ eat well worth a visit.. Lots of pressure to buy, fine if you want to but otherwise can be annoying. Never pay more than half requested as always ask for at least double price for tourists.lots of places to eat the busier they are reflects quality of food and or cost. Found better to pay a bit more and avoid upset stomach.

Looks great at night though it's a 100% tourist trap. Day time it;s just an open square with absolutely no features. Nice to have a meal on the 1st floor of Cafe the Francois and just look at the hustle and bustle of tourist.At night the place comes alive but it's all for tourists so not much authenticity to find there.Still worth a visit for 1 evening.

Mad but a must do!. Anyone visiting Marrakesh has to visit Jemaa el Fna. It is a complete assault to the senses but so different from anything else that you are likely to encounter. You never know what you will see - acrobats, snake charmers, monkeys, birds, story telling and so much more!

Worth a Visit. Visited during daytime. Not as large as expected and full of locals selling orange juice from trailers.Beware women trying to get you to buy henna tattoos, very pushy and try to ink hands without you agreeing then they demand high payment.If buying leather goods there are numerous shops in alleys off the square but be prepared to haggle. Never pay price you first get quoted.

Amazing, must see. We visited nearly every day we were in Marrakesh but at different times. There was always something different to see. Snake charmers, dancers, musicians and so much more. Night time was the liveliest with so many places set up to eat you could eat at a different one every night for a month and still wouldn't experience them all. We always felt safe and the locals were very friendly, but once you said no they didn't hassle you.

Worth going to (once). Went at night. Incomparable to what it was like 19 years ago - much busier and poorer quality street food (the hassle is horrible) and street performers - OK if you spoke Arabic. Lovely fruit juice stalls. Didn't like the groping and felt as two sisters uncomfortable - maybe because it was a Saturday night...

Must visit (once) but beware of henna women. The square is one of the main attractions in Marrakech and so makes its a must-see...but only once. The majority of the sellers are friendly and if you tell them 'no' once, they will leave you alone. There are a lot of stalls and loads to buy! Bartering is quite fun and you can usually knock them down to at least half the price of their original offer. There are a lot of beggars and horses/cats which isnt very comfortable to be around. Beware of henna women! They don't tell you the price of the henna and keep decorating you until you physically pull your arm away then charge you extortionate prices! My friend and I asked for a design on our hand but she started to go up our arm. When we said stop, they told us it would cost 800dhs each (£130 total!). We didnt have this much money on us. We only had 50dhs and so had to surrender a scarf and a purse as payment before they would let us go! Completely shameful behaviour and makes the rest of the sellers down who try to be fair to tourist. Now that I've been, I can tick it off the list and not have to visit it again!

The most amazing place where you meet people from around the world. The most amazing place where you meet people from around the world and you can experience many things like to meet people to tell you about how to find your problems can solve by the easy ways and many restaurant that will make the most amazing Morocco food.

Great. Great for experiencing completely different cultures...snake charmers, music and story tellers, cafes and bars. It had it all. The only thing that let's it down is the poor treatment of the caleche horses. Poor horses forced to stand all day and night tied to carriages with no food or water in 40C heat. Poor things.

Top attraction of Marrakech.. The square turns alive at sunset. There are some 20 stalls selling fruit juice alone. Certainly in September, the freshly squeezed orange juice at less than a £ a glass is one of the best things in Morocco. There are other stalls selling Moroccan food - BBQ, Steamed Clam, bread, tagines etc. Street entertainments are an added bonus. Because there is a great deal of hustling on tourists, keep walking and do not stay in one place for too long. Get some coins ready to pay the street entertainers. Be cautious of pick-pockets.

The place to eat in the evenings. The square comes to life for the evening, when about 100+ food stalls start making food. They are next to each other, often difficult to decide what seting area belongs to which but they pretty much d the same food: the grilled food ones(kebabs, veggies, often tagines, soup - some veggie broth soup, somewhat underseasoned but still nice) and the ones you won't know what to make of: half flat bread stalls where they cut the bread, fill it with mashed boiled potatoes, egg and olive oil. Ahh and the orange juice stalls. Again, if you wondering which one to pick: even they will tell you, they all do pretty much the same food! It is quite smokey within the square but also the little restaurants and cafes around the square are worth looking at, if for nothing else then go to the roof terrace and enjoy the evening views. Also some of those cafes have the same prices as the actual stalls. Prices: a soup is 5-10 dirhams, bread 5 dirhams. Kebab sticks cost about 40 dirhams and you will fill up. Even if you are really hungry, you wont spend more than 80 dirhams and be painfully overfed!One thing i found quite annoying was that once they get you to sit down, it might take a while to actually get some food so do not be in a great rush. Also the food is safe, noone had any funny tummy from the 8 of us stuffing our faces.

Not good ! Beggers, abused animals and filthy food stalls. One big confusing effort to try and get your money. Animals being abused for entertainment - children as hustlers, filthy food stalls, beggers everywhere - what not to like ? However, the fresh orange juice is outstanding.

STAY AWAY FROM THE SNAKE CHARMERS ITS A TRAP!. STAY AWAY FROM THE SNAKE CHARMERS!!! the snake charmer chucked a snake around me without even asking and then demanded all my money before he took it off!!! he refused to take the snake off me until i gave him literally all my money. STAY AWAY!!!!!
A must in Marrakech.. A must in Marrakech. Take in the sights and sounds, and one or two smells of the souks and go back in time 200 years
Madness in the centre of the medina. Completely mad! Smoky and noisy but enthralling. Snake charmers and musicians , monkeys and lots of food stalls.

Alot going on.. Let's face it, your in Marrakech. You have to go.It's not really a relaxing place. As a tourist you are looked at like you are rich. We were approached by a number of begging children. It wasn't pleasant.The women offering henna are constantly harassing. The sight of a monkey on a lead also wasn't pleasant. I was prepared for these things having read the reviews. So also be prepared.We went to the rooftop cafe to watch the sunset which was my highlight. Check sunset time and get a seat in plenty of time

Part of holiday. This square has to be one of the best attractions in Marrakech and ,to have all the benefits of the visit you must go in the day and when the square really livens up at night.There is so much going on ,snake charmers,story tellers ,singers and watch out for the monkeys ,the lads put the monkeys on your shoulders and then expect to be paid if you take a photo.All of the people putting on the shows expect to be paid if you take photo's so be aware with your camera's.There are a lot of food stalls and bars and restaurants around the square and the place keeps lively into the late hours.It gets very busy so beware of the mopeds and the horses and carriages that come from every direction.Also the markets are excellent for a wander around however most of the shops basically sell the same things, its still fun to go round the alley-ways where most of the shops are located .

Frenzied Hive of Activity. The square was the highlight of my stay in Marrakesh. Yes, it is a den of iniquity. Be warned to have your wits about you 100% as there are scammers and groups of pickpockets EVERYWHERE. But, perversely this is a part of the appeal of this frenzied hive of activity.Have a drink on one of the many cafés roof top terraces and take it all in in relative peace.There are monkeys and kestrels and of course snakes – all being plied as photo opportunities, which personally leaves me cold. There are hawkers and fortune tellers, but, it is after dark that the square really comes to life. Dozens upon dozens of stalls that were empty during the daytime become mini cafes (all ready to rip you off like almost everyone else in the square) with a huge range of basic eating options. Dancers, musicians and street entertainers spring up everywhere, together with pop-up fairground sideshows like hoopla and golf putting etc!You can’t help but appreciate the culture. Breath in the sights and sounds. The colour and the vibrancy is quite something.
a taste of the marocan crowd,. to be seen at sunset for the attractions monkeys and snakes and all the little shops around .very colorful great for photography.

Mayhem in marrakech. Snake charmers warble their tunes while monkeys wait for photographs all amid an array of shops stalls food orange juice and the whole place just cascades with people and noiseQuite an experience just to be here the real fun starts at night
not to be missed. Should be visited both by day and at night to fully appreciate the contrast. It really buzzes at night with food stalls, story tellers, acrobats, snake charmers and much more.
Madness of the square.... Wow! What a different place! Never quite encountered anywhere like it. Make sure you always barter. I got a straw hat for £2 from £15....
Underwhelmed!. By day noisy, sparse & plenty of hassle. Not for me. By night with food stalls & more sellers better.

Evening is the best time to go. This is a not to be missed stop and it is right outside the Medina so it's convenient and really the main square where everything happens along with local food and drink. You'll find several okay restaurants lining the rim of the square selling good local food (always try the Tannin first and foremost) also you must try the Orange Juice from any of the sellers - yes the orange juice is unforgettable. Day is nice (wear sunscreen) but come back in the evening for the real crowds and beautiful photographs. The square is filled with entertainers, sellers, tourist and locals alike.
Souks . Very good square, buy spices or clothes but you have to haggle the price always offer half the price quoted ! If you walk away they always call you bk for the price you offered

senses overload!. Going to this place is an experience in itself. Our senses were tested from the aroma of grilled street food to the stench of horse pee. Our eyes don't know where to look after seeing all the beautiful colors of what the artisans sell in the Medina to snake charmers on the square and the orange juice carts. Our ears enjoyed the sounds of the music being played by the street performers and the friendly greetings of the different store owners to the horns of the motorcycles on the road. Its an amazing place. Our favorite discovery is food stall 13, their lamb dish is quite good.
cool. The heart of Marrakech. An amazing experience, well worth the effort and time. Take some time to explore the square and all it offers.

main attraction in marrakesh!!. best street food ever!! picked the stall with lots of locals and had the well known tangine dish!! very very flavorful and a must try. Also got a Henna tattoo from the street and did some nighttime shopping. Be careful, keep your money safe, it is a very busy place.
Insane. What an insane place A real sensory overload If your not a fan of crowds jostling and haggling it won't be your cup of tea Truly magical at night

Pure madness. Pure madness in a crazy place ! Loved wandering around the square watching the vendors, and food sellers and all the hustle and bustle which goes with it. Never experienced anything like it, but don't let that put you off.Could have done without the monkeys and snake charmers, but goes with the territory I guess.

Over rated. I would say that this place has been given more importance that it should. Where tourists are, then attractions follow, mostly Berber music and folklore, combined with snake and other shows. What I liked mostly, is the stalls with freshly squeezed juices at relatively low prices. food stalls all over the place, with acceptable quality and regular prices. To me this is a place for one visit only.
Worth seeing once, no more. Interesting place to visit, but tiring and noisy. Mind your bags and pockets in the evening as it becomes crowdy

The real Morocco. Nice square, delicious orange juices, the night life is unique, lots of colours, smells and tastes. 100% recomended. Excelent hostals near the square, good food. It's an excelent place to hang out.

A different experience. Apon my visit to Jemaa El Fna it was nothing I had expected. It was very interesting to experience the hustle and bustle, the way of life of the Medina. I did enjoy the stay and would go back again.
Cool experience of culture . Really enjoyed this experience. Would recommend visiting the square at day and night. Again, it's haggle for everything. Very rushed but friendly environment.

A must see but expensive food at night. When in Marrakech........................Crazy place which changes throughout the day and night so several trips are recommended. Great to look down on it from one of the roof top bars as wellWe found the food at the stalls more expensive than we thought it should be and we would eat before we go next time.If you want a pic with any of the "performers" make sure you pay (say 10 drs) BEFORE you take the pic and NOT after!!

Primordial swamp of humanity.. The square comes to life after dark there are a huge number of food stalls, cafes and restaurants to chose from catering to most tastes and pockets. The atmosphere is chaotic as the masses bustle around looking for bargains or for a spot to eat, the noise aromas and sights transporting you back in time. Entertainment comes in many forms from dancers, snake charmers, story tellers or just observing the crowd my favourite being watching the gangs of young pickpockets ply their trade. If you visit Marrakech if you only do one thing you must pay the square a visit.

A must see in Marrakech . We visited the square after a guided tour through the souk, we would also recommend that you do this. During the day it's awash with market traders but it's at night it really comes alive with entertainers of all description, cameras at the ready for a real taste of Morocco.

Amazing. Though I'm from an arab country, this was the extreme oriental experience for me, the smell the sound the crowd, monkeys and snakes shows and the best place to bargain for the price, everything that reminds you of marrakech is there, and there is a coffee shop that got a terrace that overlooks the place with amazing moroccan bread called "msamman" that is mainly served in the morning with an old fashioned glass bottled orange miranda.
Exotic. Walking around Jemaa El Fna takes you back centuries...its loud, crowded, exotic, durty smelly and wanderful at the same time a must do. ps: try themint tea delicious

Excellent food and relaxation. Excellent food stalls in the middle of the square. There is bench seating. Food was nice. Around the square you have shops, banks to change money. There is also a post office. There are entertainers with monkeys etc. The place has food till late. We went to it around midnight. The streets around are quiet at night but seemed safe.

Be Careful. This applies to anywhere in Marrakesh it's very easy to be conned or taken for a ride, If you shake hands with any one Count your fingers afterward, so many of the traders & snake charmers etc just want your money, don't be put off "Just Be Careful"
Great experience. Visit during the day and night to get both experience. The square and souks come alive at night and there's lots of great bargains to be had. Definitely try the orange juice!

BuZZingggg, So Much fun, BUT, Be Careful!!!. This place is totally buzzing. It is so much fun and so busy. There are different kinds of entertainment going on and so many different food stalls. Its so funny because the Moroccan guys have learnt the English/Cockney accent to catch our attention and try and get you to eat at their stall. We had such a laugh with one of the guys from stall number 31! So funny! The orange juice they sell there is so refreshing, I need a glass right now!Now, the 'Be careful' bit....So all the different entertainers, they will just grab you, and role you into part of their show/service/whatever they are offering, and then, when you try to walk away, they wont let you go because they start demanding money! It gets a bit uncomfortable and strained when you try to walk away. Do NOT just let them put snakes on you or hats or take part in anything unless you want to and you are prepared to pay them. Always bargain and half the price of anything and everything you buy/use because the horse & carriage people, taxi's, keepsake sellers will always try their best to take as much money as they can with you.Putting all that aside, I loved it! :D

Wonderful !! . The sounds, the smell, the hustle, the bustle is something you MUST experience. I took my family with 3 young ones and it can prove a little tricky. We made sure we didn't venture too far towards the Soukds. One tip from me, don't attempt to take pictures of the snake

Come here if you want to be harassed.. I've been to lots of markets around the world, but Jemma el Fna is hands down the worst one. The nanosecond a shop owner noticed me looking, the non-stop pressure to buy would start. On two occasions, I was actually grabbed by a shop owner. Not a fun experience. I was also cursed at, for not buying an item. There are other markets in Marrakech that less aggressive, and that have the same merchandise. Jemaa el Fna is a tourist trap, full of aggressive shop owners. I won't be returning ever again.

crazy!. It starts in the morning and goes on all day and into the night.Snake charmers, dancers, musicians, story tellers (wish I knew what they were saying, but they certainly do draw crowds of Moroccans) and street sellers. Then in the evening the food stalls come to life and everyone of them tries to get you to eat at their stalls.Its all very loud and colourful, but then the downside. They all think we are filthy rich, and by their standards we probably are, so you are constantly battered by beggars some looking as young a 3 or 4, mothers with babies in their arms and disabled men in wheelchairs all with their hands out. You just have to be tough and ignore them.But then, forget the downside and enjoy the mayhem!!

What a place. Madness at it's finest. Freshly squeezed fruit juice, monkeys and snakes, dates and nuts, dancing, singing, storytelling. Protect wallet etc, normal common sense applies in a crowded square. Experience this at least once in a lifetime and you won't be sorry. Henna hand paints are best avoided unless you know what you're looking at. Saw a couple of people with dramatic allergic reactions. Be warned.

Unloosable. There is no way to tell what experience it is without being a fine writer, like Dante or Dostojevskj. In that square anything happens, The people meet each other, eat, stand by storytellers. Whole families join there to cook and eat meals. Snakes and monkeys playing for the wonder of tourists, Very loud sounds of fifes, smokes coming from dozens of street foods' wagons, joung boxeurs fighting each other, that and more is possible to see there, Most important is to go there in the evening, because during the day the square is empty. In conclusion is an experience that hits all our senses, far from our western way of life: simply unlosable!

Assault on the senses!. Has to be experienced, by day & night; the heart of Marrakesh. You can find all sorts of exotic, weird & wonderful things here - banter with the locals & stall holders is second to none:) You should also experience the food stalls & fresh orange juice - not to be missed!

A MUST VISIT IF IN MARRAKESH. A place like no other place which is a must if you are in Marrakesh but make sure you have many bills of 20 (in local currency) because you will end up paying a lot without noticing and practice how to say NO before entering the Square.If you have a sensitive stomach then stay away fro the food there but if you are used to street food then this is your heaven.I loved the placebetter to visit after 5 p.m and it is open till midnight
A Must See. Best seen at night from one of the surrounding cafes. Gets very crowded but the atmosphere is great. Not to be missed - especially the freshly squeezed orange juice.

Lots to see and buy. Lovely during the day and even better during the night - however, you have to be careful about taking photos as the entertainers will charge. Take time out to sit in one of the many terraces to enjoy food and enjoy people watching. Must try the orange juice (one stall even made me lime juice at my request so do ask)

Full on at night. This is the main square of Marrakech and it is a large open area full of small shops/cafes selling Argan, ceramics, clothing, leather/metal goods, lanterns, spices, and sweets, fresh juices and Moroccan food. Best to come during the day first and take a look around the sections that interest you and then come back during the evening/night time for a different but incredible experience. Very noisy, smelly and stuffy so find a place to stop and relax in one of the cafes before setting into the Medina.
