There are so many scooters/motorbikes running around and if you are not use to it then it can get a bit overwhelming. Stay alert and enjoy the experience

An amazing experience. You definitely need to visit the square both day and night, as they are two totally different experiences. Surrounded by lovely rooftop restaurants, serving traditional Moroccan food and everywhere serves pizza and pasta, if you're not feeling adventurous. Every stall sells the same sort of thing, so have a look around and barter your socks off! I would definitely recommend trying the fresh orange juice from one of the stalls in the centre of the square, it's delicious and only 4dhs, which isn't even 50p. As two young girls we did get some unwanted attention from men, but they soon got the message. They will try and attract you into their shop by saying things like geezer, fish and chips and various other britanisms but it's all in good jest. We didn't get pictures of the monkeys or snakes, as it was clear that they were being poorly treated although our vey nice taxi driver did tell us to pay no more than 30dhs if we did, so keep this in mind. They wil approach you and out the snake around your neck without you asking and then try to charge you about 600dhs, as will the henna ladies. They will grab your arm and just start doodling away, but if you didn't ask DON'T PAY. As the hours go by the square will get busier and busier and be prepared to be knocked about when they call for prayer, as they rush to the mosques. There are at least three around the square, so the call is very loud. Definitely worth a visit if you are visiting Marrakech.

chaos on earth. got dropped in the wrong place, should have been at the other gate so had to make do. harassed by hawkers and beggars and saw a horse fall over in the traces of a carriage. however there was a nice cafe and some nice shops which i did some of my Christmas shopping in before giving up and returning to hotel. i am not a good enough walker to be able yo have enjoyed this place.

Unique experience...!. I've been several years ago at Jemaa el Fna and I was very impressed with the surroundings. It's so much different from Europe or Western civilization. Many types of local food (or street food) available, the central market becomes even busier during evenings with many tourists flooding the market and the narrow Medina streets. You'll definetely experience something unique here! Enjoy!

Will be back (I will... you know..... I will...). One of few places you know you'll visit again the minute you leave. After two weeks you still know you'll be back. Definitely. And after 6 months you still feel it deep in your guts. The inevitability of your return.Truth is, you probably never will visit it again, but still... that feeling will never leave you.
Time Travel Square. Jemaa el Fna lets you travel in ancient times. The robust trading done here makes the square pulsate with wonder and adventure.

Show Time in the Jamaa (main square). The Jamaa, or main square of Marrakesh, is a quite large open area that is relatively quiet until lunch time, and then each hour gets more and more busy, and noisy.Snake-charmer with their flutes, monkey men with their diapered monkeys on ropes, musicians and drummers of all types and sizes provide most of the free 'entertainment'.Well, they do expect tips so have a pocket full of small coins to keep them happy if you intend to be their audience and not just someone walking by.By night-fall the noise becomes deafening and the square fills up to the brim with both tourists and locals out for the night.A number of restaurants and cafes line the square and my favorite is Cafe France, which enjoys perhaps the best location and has a third floor terrace overlooking the square and all that goes on therein. A mint tea now costs 14 dirham, about a dollar fifty.There are, however, a number of ridiculously cheap restaurants which set up under awnings in the square but the level of hygiene they have is positively subpar. Same goes for the numerous 'fresh' fruit juice stands where a tall glass of fruit juice cost about 40 cents.Never forget, you get what you pay for, and Marrakesh is a spot where this saying could not be more accurate.

Loud, busy, overwhelming but brilliant. Visit during the day and also night time to get to amazing but different experiences. Be aware of the scams before you go, such as the henna ladies and be prepared to pay if you want to take pictures of the story tellers and dancers. We returned before sunset and got a great spot up high in one of the terraces and enjoyed an amazing view with some mint tea as it darkened and the lights came on and the market place came alive. It's a place not to be missed if you come to Marrakech, so come prepared, have your street smarts about you and your camera, find a great spot to sit and eat tagine and then sit and drink it all in.

Amazing. All 5 senses will be driven crazy here.A fabulous place.Sellers and buyers in a constant to and fro of activity.Daytime the monkeys and snakes are a constant song.Night is for storytellers and henna tattooists.

Wonderful experience but ladies be careful. Wonderful vibrant, lively experience. The sellers and performers try to delight you into parting with your money. Henna ladies desperate to paint your hands. The evening food market is a cornucopia of smells and sights. The food is generally fresh and tasty. Prices vary from stall to stall and some are reluctant to tell you before you sit down. Beggar children come round frequently, I stopped our stall holder shooing them away and gave them our leftovers - rightly or wrongly. Ladies please be ready for many inappropriate comments from the local men. At times amusing at others down right scary. I hate to say this but you are safer if with a man. Don't let this stop you going but be forewarned.

Busy market best viewed from a terrace. We visited in September and found the central square a great place to people watch. We recommend you visit just before sunset and find a table at one of the restaurant terraces overlooking the market square. A great way to see the market place fill up without being overwhelmed by the hustle bustle.

Market of boredom and horses that crap a lot. . Boring, it's like every other black market in Asia. Once you've seen one you've seen them all. Other than the two shops we made friends with, every other seller is trying to rip you off and call you friend.
Impossible to recreate. By day a large open space with access to the surrounding souks, cafes and restaurants. By night one of the most atmospheric places on the planet
A must see. Absolutely fantastic place to walk around any time of day. Hawkers always out along with monkeys a nd snakes

Don't Eat at the Night Market. By day this place is a mix of chained up monkeys, sedated snakes, and people trying to sell fake watches amongst other junk. Avoid.By night its full of food stalls trying to rip off tourists. We ordered some dishes and got brought/had to pay for something which looked similar enough that we couldn't tell the difference but costed about 3x as much. If you are going to go make sure you tell them you have a budget limit (say 100DHS).What I can highly recommend are the various restaurants with terraces scattered around the square. Good food, as cheap/cheaper than the stalls, and much more chilled out.
A magical Place. OMG this place is unique in the world.... Marrackech whithout Jemma el Fna is a comun citie in the world....to see day and night

Blow Your Mind. This is an experience you will never forget Go after dark and see street entertainers Snake charmers and the best street food you will ever taste Have your photograph taken with Charlie the monkey but be prepared to pay for the privilege A pageant of colour and costumes that really defies description A blast!!

chaotic. very chaotic, but in the bad way. People everywhere trying to sell every sort of thing, let you take picture, taking you in some absolutely perfect/stunning/amazing cafe/restaurant/riad/hammam etc, and so on. they don't let you enjoy the moment and the magic of the place you are in.

Crazy chaos. Everyone wants a piece off you, a firm "no merci" ,hand up a smile worked most off the time. You will get lost in the souks and young men are everywhere wanting to help you, for cash. If lost ask a shopkeeper or a woman and they will generally point you in the right direction.

sit back and enjoy the sights, sounds, smells and general buzz about the place. You'll have seen the photos and its probably the principal reason you are in Marrakech. Don't be alarmed. It’s safe to wander around at night. Just be aware of the scams and accept if you play any games you'll lose. Eat amongst the stalls. Items are priced to be easily understood and while you may have bread and mashed tomatoes with herbs and a spicy sauce added to your order without asking, that’s standard and is only about 1 Euro and is nice. Otherwise sit back and enjoy the sights, sounds, smells and general buzz about the place. Cafe du Glacier has the best aerial view of the square at night from where these photos were taken. Small minimum soft drinks fee, 20d, for the rooftop.
Second Visit. This was our second visit and the kids enjoyed it. Food and drinks reasonably priced and always fresh

evening visit. Imbedded in a different culture: the people,the noise, the flavours make it an overwhelming experience
Taste a minth thee on the first floor terras of cafe de la France to take pictures at sunset

Truly unforgettable. What a place to visit! If you love open air food and large crowds then this is for you. There is a beat around the place and the beautiful locals were all friendly.By the time we visited we were used to the Moroccan haggling and did not mind the sellers.Food is good and very cheap. You can eat for 30 dirhams which is about £20. I tried snails, brazed sheep head and brains. The deep fried fish was lovely. I visited the food stalls with the most locals. The competition is quiet fierce and I was lured with praises like " Hey you look like Will Smith"...but make up your own mind.Whatever you do try the freshly squeezed orange juice for just 4 dirhams. Nice unforgettable place that I will surely visit again.

A fun experience. This quintessential tourist area in Marrakech is a "must-see it to believe it" for sure. It is a whirlwind of sights, scents and sounds. There are monkeys, traditional musicians, snake charmers, merchants, street vendors and many food stands. I loved it but there are some tips to make it a fun AND safe experience: It's best not to carry a handbag. If you want to take photos of the entertainment acts, be prepared to pay them or they get very nasty. Give them what you want, ignore their insistence on more, they always want additional cash. Beware if you are afraid of snakes or monkeys, you will have one on you the second you come close, then get charged for the photo op, like it or not (I have a viper-pic to proof it haha). Vendors are on tourists like ticks. Firmly saying "La", which means "No" in Arabic, gets them to disappear a little faster. They miraculously speak just about any language and will engage you in endless sales pitches and negotiations. It can get annoying and time consuming. The souk around the plaza is fun and interesting also, but the souvenirs are more expensive here. Overall though the prices in Marrakech were rather low. Shopping here won't break the bank but hackle a bit and keep your cash hidden at all times. The fresh squeezed orange juice at stand # 38 was delicious!

Shopping day at Jemaa el Fna. This is a must do if you are visiting Marrakech... This city is known for its souks and markets filled with spices, scarves and moroccan souvenirs. Make sure to bargain with the sellers because they increase the prices like crazy for tourists... It helped that my husband is Moroccan. The trick is to divide the price by at least 3.... Also, avoid the snakes in the middle of the souk... They trick you by telling you just to look but then they put the snake on you and don't let you leave until you pay them. Besides that, it's fun and a great experience... Just know where you are going.

What acontrast during the day and night. The contrast between the day time and at night is so different. You need to ask yourself, is this the same place? During day light, the square is nearly empty except for the vendors who have there pitches and the tourists who just like to wander around. But at night, all the locals come out as well as the tourist filling the square.There are food stalls, street acts and lots more. You really need to be there to fully understand the huge contras.You can really have an inexpensive night out. Just be careful if you want to grab a bit to eat. Stick to the cafe's & restaurants.

We ate here and saw the kitchens! Survived to tell the tale the next day too. You cannot visit Marrakech and not go here. It is very busy and comes alive at night. Worth a visit and if you don't want a snake around your neck or a monkey just say no and don't tempt hassle. They do not like you to take a photograph so if you do you will prompt a response and a request for money.

Crazy not to have a night on the square. If Im honest other than the orange juice vendors I didnt like the square in daylight. However come dusk the place comes alive with a great feeling and loads of atmosphere. The street stalls or pop up restaurants are an experience in themselves. Could it be that you pay too much for just a decent meal. Sure. However, will you have that experience anywhere else in the world? I think not. We took our daughter who was 11mths old at the time and she loved it. The whole experience was super family friendly and very safe. Be smart about what you choose but we had no ill effects from eating from the stalls. Also loved the dessert sweets carts that came around and sold boxed sweets to go. What wonderful memories you will make here!

The main square. This is the heart and soul of Marrakech. On the main square during the day, you can wander amongst the orange juice stands and street vendors, and watch the snake charmers and belly dancers. It's also the central hub for accessing the souks. Despite being tourist-driven, the hassle of everyday life can also be seen here. Once night falls, the square turns into a street food markets with lots of stands offering Moroccan style food such as meat skewers, tagines and a whole sheep's head (including brains and tongue!) The night market has an electric atmosphere, with music and entertainment scattered everywhere so has a festival-style feel too it. It does get exceptionally busy though especially on Saturday and Sunday nights. Be prepared to be harassed by hoards of locals trying to get you to eat at their stand, there's a lot of competition, and once you are seated, they don't want you to leave.

Great Experience of Morocco. A wonderful place to go to experience moroccan culture both day and night. Can be very hot in the day but theres lots of lovely places to drink on the rooftops and to watch over the square. Very busy at night but lots of entertainment with music and lights, didn't really enjoy the food but plenty of stalls to chose from. Wouldn't recommend if you don't like being approached by locals to buy their items and to have photos with monkeys and Cobras. Definitely a to-do whilst visiting Marrakech.

Souk. Excellent and great experience. Loved every visit i made. Horse carriages were lovely and relaxing. Have to haggle a lot on prices but fun. Wore henna but colour didnt come out a bit. Love to visit again. Dont miss it!!!

Joyful and charming. A jump in the heart of the Moroccan culture. At night, the atmosphere is magic thanks to lights, music, children (watch out to pick pockets, yes, mostly children) and snake charmers, food stands and much more!
Place to be at nghr. This is the place to be at night, food fun and much more. Closes around 2pm . Defiantly go a few times during your stay. One of the best thing at night

A Marrakesh must but avoid the food stalls. I'd give it a 5-star rating if it wouldn't be for the sometimes totally insane behaviour of the food stall staff. I fully understand that people performing dances, music, snake charming etc definitely deserve a tip if one wants to take pictures (after all that's why we tourist come here for), but if you decide to have dinner in one of the food stalls be warned: It can happen that all of a sudden six or more guys will physically grab you to pull you into their respective booths, and they just don't respect that one maybe just wants to get an overview first of what is available. After litterarily escaping we decided to eat where we were bothered the least; food was, by the way, o.k., not as good as in real restaurants, and due to this experience we never went back. The place and its ambience itself is nice, I strongly recommend to have a blue hour tea in one of the roof top terraces such as the Cafe France and to observe from above.

WOW!!!. This place is buzzing!!! Best time to get here is after 8pm when there are story tellers, snake charmers and monkeys around. The buzz and smell around this place will leave you in awe and you will feel the real Marrakech here. This place was a short 10 min walk from our Riad La Maison Arabe. Be careful though. Don't take any pictures of snake charmers, monkeys etc unless you intend on paying. There arr also places to eat and do try one of the juice stalls. There's so many! Another wonderful experience is the rooftop café at the square where you can see the buzz from a wonderful view. A must visit here!

Excellent. Alot of shopping to do whilst in marrakechSo much to buy and cheap things to buy alsoU can stop buy and have a refreshing orange drink for 4dhs and have some small snacks like peanuts and raisons snake charmers are around and monkey playersCard readers also there and henna ladies during the night is more alive small music groups form and make it lively places to eat open they make everything infront of you alot of restaurants are open and u can view the whole squareBut haggle for everything

One of a kind experience . Scams. People shouting. Snake charmers. What's not to love? Get ready to lose some money and eat some sub par, over priced street food. But, you will never get an experience like this again. Five stars, hands down.
Djama Fnaa. I liked the area, you find all sorts of juice and cookies. People perform there some dance, some play with serpents...It is a nice atmosphere.

Once is enough. Worth a visit, especially at night. You will get harassed by the men trying to get you to eat at their stall but they are polite about it. Be careful of the ladies doing the Henna, they will grab you even if you don't want it and then swear at you for not paying. Where the horses are parked stinks to high heaven.

Very enjoyable experience.. During the day filled with dancing monkeys, snake charmers etc. Must be careful. They seem very friendly and let you take pictures etc, but they do expect some money which is understandable.At night, a different story, filled with places to eat enjoy some exotic food.The fresh fruit juices are amazing.

Time has not changed this unbelievable place!. Everyone who visits Marrakech must see this truly Amazing Place which hasn't changed much since it first was created. There are still snake charmers and pet monkeys. Ladies paint hands with fantastic designs. Horses and carriages line up , patiently waiting to ferry tourists around the surrounding sights.
Freak show. Noise, hassle and just not my kind of fun, go experience it because it might be right up your alley, personally you'd have to pay me to go there :0)

Amazing, what a beautiful memory and experience. Wow, what a visual and sensory delight! This place has so much going on all at the same time, so beautiful and colorful. I want to go again. The pic shows the orange juice wagon, where if you know the special word, you get a free refill :)

Not my favorite place. Very touristy and I would warn women to be observant as my sister and were touched inappropriately - actually my sister was accousted. Good inexpensive place to eat - the soup and mint tea was very good.

A different experience altogether.. A loud, busy and bustling experience. The square comes alive at nightfall, with everything you read about and more.Your senses are bombarded, not least by those trying to sell you something! I found it best to avoid eye contact, repeat 'no thank you' and keep moving. Once you stop or smile....well good luck at your attempt to escape.Although lots of locals, it seemed to be a tourist 'trap' in every other sense. From 'water men' trying to capture your attention by their hats and clatter of tin bowls to women grabbing you to apply henna (in my case her grip was so tight she offered and quickly applied a free flower...even though I really did not want it. Of course she was then very insistent that I pay her!).If you like crowds and don't mind the continual request for your attention (be warned ONLY ever to extract money from you) then that's ok.Yes it's an experience, but in my case best observed from a vantage point of a cafe/restaurant terrace.Not for the faint hearted.

Very busy, lots going on. This is the square before you enter the souks. You will see various street performers here: musicians, belly dancers, boxing!, snake charmers (during day), performing monkeys as well as market stalls. At night many stalls open cooking and selling Moroccan foods / kebabs, freshly squeezed OJ, snails and many more.At night it's very dark as there are few lights.I was gripping my handbag the whole time as it was so busy but locals assured me I was safe and there was little crime.It's best to wear closed toe shoes and cover up a little bit more. I wore a short scrappy dress one night and I was stared at my males and females!

sights, sounds, smells - a must visit. I visited the square many times over four days with my five year old. During the day it is an amazing market with sales of many goods, belly dancers and snake charmers. At night the food stalls bring the square to life again and the smells are incredible. We ignored the lack of hygiene and ate there a couple of times with no problems - the food was wonderful. I would urge people to be careful here as although it is an amazing place there does also appear to be a more sinister underbelly and I would suggest that valuables are kept close.

Vibrant and colourful. Truly the hear of Marrakesh at all hours of the day. But when they really get going is at dusk right into the wee hours. Full of people. A wonderful way to take in the true essence of Moroccan and life in Marrakesh. A must see!

Be careful. All very colourful, noisy, bright, but beware of making mistakes. Any photo opportunity, ASK before you snap away. You will be expected to pay a small sum. The food stalls are lovely and the locals love it too. Great experience.
The pulse of Marrakesh. A place to be while in Marrakesh. Its a must. Lively, vibrant, colorful place full of energy and life.

Marrakech's heart. The sights and sounds of the square are like no where else in the world, ringed on one side by good restaurants, and the souk on the other sides. Can recommend the fruit juice stalls for a much needed cold drink, but beware or the evening food stalls, great fun but a little expensive by Moroccan standards.

Overhyped tourist trap. Firstly: If you are in Marrakech, you definitely have to visit this place,it's the center of the Medina and it's fun to see all the hurly-burly on andaround that place both during the day and during the evening.However, we felt like a walking ATM walking on that place, bothered by localswanting money from us for stupid things. Once my girlfriend was "attacked"by a woman starting to draw a henna tattoo on her hand without asking. It wasn't possible to have a moment without having someone aggressivleypursuing you for money around you. We felt sorry for the animals, especiallyfor the carriage horses - some of them had bad arthritis with swollen joints.Be careful with the fresh orange juice, hygienically it's very questionnable(we also felt sick after it).Nevertheless, it's nice to pick a place on some of the restaurant/cafe terracesand watch that crazy place during and after sunset. For the place itself, be preparedand take the craziness with humor. Have strong nerves that you'll also need in the suqs.

Exciting But. Jemas el fna was such an experience. One must realize that although this is one of the most famous tourist destination in the world, there are some things that might jeopardize that title. The prices for one are extremely high, and the vendors know exactly that their prices are high knowing that the demand is somewhat high also, when you try to bargain a price they tend to look at you like you are out of your mind. The central food kiosks in the middle of the place had no apparent refrigeration in sight, most of the food displayed was out in the open, so we didn't dare to give it a try. A little work in at side would have made us try the food which did look delicious. Good street entertainers, lots of rhythm. So many people but not any security forces present, at least not to the naked eye( maybe under cover) overall it was a nice experience, just a little improvement and we will go back...

mayhem in the medina!. wild place and great fun as long as you Don t mind being in the thick of the crowd and action! the food markets in the square are fabulous after dark! not to mention the snake charmers, water sellers, souvenir shops with every Arabian trinket you can think of and of course the koutubia minaret dating from the 12th century! the square is around a thousand years old and you can still feel and see its antiquity all around you. be sure to eat at one of the rooftop restaurants around the square to really relax and enjoy the atmosphere

Large, Noisy, Quite Delicious. As you probably know, this is the heart of Marrakech's Medina. You've probably seen a lot of pictures, read a lot of reviews. I don't know how much more I can expand on that. What I will say is, it's bigger than I thought. It's quite a large square, and depending on the time of day, the stalls may only take up a small part of it. The rest is snake charmers, monkey dancers, storytellers, and all sorts of street vendors, many of which will be unfamiliar to you. We went in August, which is when many Moroccans get their vacation, so most of the tourists were domestic. This made it more fun, and it was interesting to see what the locals were most interested in.Vendors can be a little pushy, and can annoy you trying to get you into their restaurant. Be ready for this; either ignore them completely, or a firm 'no', 'non merci', 'la shukran' usually gets the job done without the need to be rude.I mean, if you're in Marrakech, you can't not go here. Why are you still reading reviews?

All the world comes here !. Visit day and night as it changes significantly. Nothing fantastic and I preferred the souks but the whole is greater than the parts. Well worth visiting if this is your first time in an Arab country.

True Marrkech. Went to Marrakech for a week in September, and this was the highlight of my trip. I went here 4 days out of the 7. This is a 100% must do when going to Marrakech, and day and night trips are both worth it.At night you have stalls on stalls of street food and drinks for very cheap prices. Two of us eating would come to around 150dirhams including drinks and tips. Although not the cleanest as the food in unrefrigerated. Beware of snake charmers and monkey handlers. They ask around 150-200 dirhams to take one photo! In the market stalls there are plenty of gifts and souvenirs to buy, but beware as the prices are VERY high. You can usually buy goods for 30-50% of the price they ask for! Don't be scared to walk away if they say no for the price, as there will definitely be another shop selling the same thing. The owners of the stalls are very pushy. Just give them a firm no if you don't want to look or buy. Don't be afraid to get lost as you will always find your way back. Don't ask people for directions as they will charge you.
Good restaurants. Lots of nice restaurants, many things to see but some things are a bit of a shock like the monkeys chained up. Also note that if you want to photograph anyone you will have to pay
Must see. Great choice of juices and dry fruits. Everyone trying to grab your custom only drawback everyone trying too hard. At night completely different atmosphere and plenty of food.

Huge square full of all sorts.. Snake charmers are quite annoying they come near you and put the snakes on you without asking then try to charge you for it.Everyone is always calling you over trying to get you to buy stuff from them, just a polite no thankyou will do but if you give them any indication you are interested they will hassle you.Most of the stuff is all for tourists you are better off goin in the souks which we did with a thomsons tour guide which took away all the worry of getting lost etc. Would deffinately advise having a drink in one of the ropftop restaurants/bars and seeing the view.

Vibrant. Wandered through on a number of occasions just to soak up the atmosphere. Avoided the snake charmers and poor monkeys as well as the ladies wanting to give you a Henna Tattoo. Loads of places to eat and drink if you felt the need, we were always full when passing but would certainly try some stalls on our next trip. Quieter through the day but it gets really busy when the sun goes down.

You are not in Kansas anymore. This market is a whirlwind, especially at night. Street artists, story tellers, monkeys, snakes, henna tattoo artiste sellers of all kinds of wares. It really is a sight to be seen. If feels like the entire world is there. There are numerous food stalls. Each area has a different speciality. One evening we stopped in for skewers of Lamd and Chicken. The touts who try to get your attention have a wonderful sense of humor as well as a knowledge of American slogans. While you are there try the Orange juice it was the best I have ever tasted. Just go and enjoy the sounds and aromas

Busy and brilliant. This is what Morocco is all about - Bright vibrant colours, dusty horse and carts and the smell of warm spices. The haggling of prices and the laughter of the market holders. Brilliant!!

Too crowded , a bit scary at night.. I feel claustrophobic with so many people around and the place is not well lit.The food mostly looked unappetising and surprising, e.g. cows udders. I had freshly squeezed orange juice which gave me a diarrhoea , I was told afterwards never to have the juice as it is diluted with tap water.

Expect to be harassed. Famous location for the continuous entertainment of snakes monkeys and story tellers. Be ready for aggressive approaches from people wanting to engage you to take photos and then pay them a non optional "tip". I went to take a photo of the snake charmers from a distance and was aggressively pursued for a tip within seconds. Probably better to visit in the evening and take it all in from the terrace of a nearby restaurant. The souk is full of the same tourist oriented goods as the rest of Morocco and aggressive touts. We were a bit over it by the time we got here.

Great market place plenty of bargains . This is a very old market so don't expect it to be organized in the evening it gets packed the food is great and there's plenty of things to buy but you need to haggle don't pay the asking price .Definitely a must for Marrakech visit

Colourful and vival. The evening wandering around and shopping it's a must. There are of course lots of nagging people but just be polite and ignore them. You can buy lots of nice and very cheap souvenirs, 3 times cheaper than in the shops with fixed price and many very cheap leather products. Some of the prices on some stalls are fixed but very often you need to negotiate the prices especially for the bigger items. Just be careful as if you will try to do the photo of someone or cobra, they will then ask you to pay them for that. If you go for the drink to one of the top restaurants then you will have a good spot of the photo from there. Enjoy! As it's very unique and unforgettable experience!

very busy. plenty of stalls and shops....you have to be able to haggle with the traders otherwise youd get ripped off...nice foood olaces and good place for snake shows...monkeys...henna and very nice juices

Scary. This place is busy and full of crooks. The snake charmers put a snake around our necks and then charged us for it. I know it's our fault for falling for it but he got really nasty when we argued which I didn't like. Lots of pressuring tourists etc. The orange juice from one of the stands was nice though and cheap. We've kind of avoided it since though.

Complete day to night contrast. We visited during the day and felt quite intimidated by the hustle and bustle. Cars, mopeds and donkeys everywhere. There are snake charmers everwhere and people with monkeys on chains which I didn't like to see. It's so easy to go and see them wild! At night however, the place really comes alive and it is a sight to be seen. The locals are all out with their children and the world and his wife seem to congregate here to feast and shop. The atmosphere is fantastic. We were never hassled by day or night. I loved it and definitely want to go back.

MUST VISIT!!.....endure the hassle!. A vast market of sights sounds and smells. Do not be put off by the many scary reviews of being hassled by people trying to sell you stuff, anyone with half a brain can stave off the advances of these street retailers. Dont show interest and you will not be hassled. It is a very safe place to be so even should the vendors start shouting or swearing at you just walk away, there are police everywhere and tourists too. This is all part of the fun....take this aspect away you are in any fruit/veg/rag market here in the uk!

An Obvious Must See in Marrakech. The history alone, of this tourist attraction, means it is a must see. For almost 1,000 years this square has attracted tourist, for one reason or another. Do not let people say it is there just for the 'foriegn' tourists, if someone does, just ask them if they can understand Berber. The Story Tellers and actors are speaking in Berber and are there for Moroccans. At night it transorms into an amazing open air restaurant where people of all cultures, dine and chat. Again you will see more Moroccan families than foriegn tourists.
A lot of everything.... Funky as ever, a real assault on the senses at first glance. Great atmosphere, though of course also one giant tourist trap. To be consumed in small doses...

Organized chaos!. By day just a big square, but after 7 a big crowded circus. Loved it. Snake charmers, belly dancers, henna painters, and food, oh so much food! For 5 euro's you get a good meal with drinks.And it's fun to just sit back and watch all the people walk by.
The Heart of the City! . In here You can find anything, and its the poiting start to everything tour Around the City.If You can t stand crowds, dont even think about going after sunset!

Fun. It's lively and fun! Dancers there, fresh fruit juices and food stands. Place to hang out in evenings later on. Entertainment going on. All stalls are marked with a number so if u go in a group, keep a number like 100 where if anyone gets lost, u go looking for them there expecting them to be there!

Very hectic..and tourists are not left in peace. The place is great but it is impossible to wander peacefully.. people keep hailing from everywhere trying to get you to their stalls to eat,or know the best shop and will lead you there..only to ask you for some dirhams... and women with henne will ask you to draw flowers on your arms.. and even when you refuse..still do it..and ask for money..too bad Marrakech somehow has lost the true Morrocan principles of hospitality and kindness... starting to look more like a tourist trap where the tourist is there to be milked.

A must visit. If you come to Marrakech you come here. So full of snake charmers, dancers, storytellers, musicians, food sellers and loads more. This place is hectic and I think is best seen at night. There are cafes and restaurants all around the square wher you can sit and observe the goings on. It really is one of the reasons why you come to Marrakech. Just meander and look at what is going on. I didn't try the food in the Square but others did - don't know how they fared afterwards! We tried the restaurants surrounding the Square some of which you can book and ask for a good table - although when you get there you can be put anywhere. We turfed up a several restaurants and just sat whoever.

Amazing Experience. The square changes about 5pm into a mad, crazy, bustling food experience. All the food venders offer very similar menus, so we based our choice on the most entertaining technique's to entice us to eat at their venue. The food is never going to set the world on fire, but for sheer fun, this is a must place to try.

Awful. I visited with my husband and 3 kids (11,8 &7) Prior to visiting, I had the impression we would be seeing a beautiful, busy, vibrant hive of activity with stalls, food, entertainment. What we actually got was a vast, unattractive square with a couple of snake charmers and a few stall selling cheap tat. The kids wanted to see the snakes so we peeked around some other tourists only to be grabbed by an old man who then stuck a snake (which looked dead) around my daughters' necks and then started demanding money! Now I am good at saying no and can be very firm but this man got very unpleasant and even grabbed my daughter's shoulder and stated telling her that I was bad for not giving him money. She was understandably frightened and was then very nervous for the rest of our trip. Once you get past this area, the markets are lovely, especially if you can make your way to the leather and silk areas where you get to see little workshops as well as stalls.Maybe the square is different at night but my kids didn't want to go back so I never got to find out!

Madness. What a place ... noisy, colourful, busy, chaotic, fun.This must be one of the busiest places ever.Probably one of my favourite places. You must go with an open mind and to not take offence at the constant badgering.Treat it all with a smile and good humour.A must see

Jemma el fna. Really busy,lots of stalls selling food and juice.There is also varied entertainment ,Street entertainers ranging from snake charmers,monkey dancers,magicians, men wearing veils doing belly dancing ,palm readers, henna tattoos,and horrific and brutal street boxing involving young boys. the food should be avoided,flies everywhere,there appears to be no hygiene.We tried one of the many freshly squeezed orange juice vendors, cheap nasty watered down and gave us both bad stomachs.There are many resturants and cafes overlooking the square ,they are all cheap and actually good.
WOW. The smell, the sight and the sounds. Sensory overload. Best of Marrakech. Don't forget to eat the boiled snails!
Amazing . Simply Amazing atmosphere! Missing it already!Watch the extra charges for dinning on terraces of Cafes... Also service charges to use the terraces

A must go-to in Marrakesh. One of my favorite places in the world. As the sun goes down, the activity level rises. There are snake charmers, women painting henna on hands, orange juice stalls among all the many, many food stalls. I wasn't feeling well, so all I had was rice, but my husband ate from one or two fo the stalls and was just fine. Get there in the late afternoon, go sit upstairs at the cafe and watch all the activity. It was so wonderful; I could have stayed for days.

Mad, mad place. Many good and bad things about this totally mad location. We loved it as it was noisy and busy from 10am to midnight. If you like a quiet life, stay away!The overriding ethos in the square is that all tourists are game! Every single person has their hand out, literally in most cases. This does not make it a bad thing, but there were some overly 'aggressive' selling methods that you need to be aware of.Henna - if you are a lady who wants their hands covering in henna, then great as you have plenty of choices. Just sort out the price BEFORE they start covering your hands. Saw a few occasions where women were physically grabbed and had henna on them before they knew what was happening.Animals - Snakes / monkeys/chipmunks, etc. Basic rule, be prepared to pay for asking questions, taking photos or sometimes just being mildly interested.Guides - don't want one? Then just politely keep saying no to anyone and everyone who wants to help you get to the 'big square' or tell you the best cafe, or point out what is open or closed. Lovely people, BUT they don't talk to you for nothing.As I said early, We loved it. It is an experience, but you must be aware of what is around you, be prepared to haggle (50% of original prices is a good pointer), it is a vibrant and amazing place and should not be missed. But EVERYONE is there to make money from you. Accept that and have a great time.

Sit and watch the world walk by.. Great place to watch the tourists. Excellent entertainment. Remember though don't take photos of people unless you are prepared to pay for it. A must see night time and daytime if visiting Marrakesh.

Scams at the tent restaurants - they'll try to overcharge you big time. The square is interesting to visit in the evening if you are NOT planning to eat there. Beware of the dining places that pop up under the tents, especially if they are not full of locals, in particular the first or second one on the right as you enter from the direction of Riad Zitoun Lakdim. For some mediocre street food for three we were charged Dh 470 (for comparison, in non-touristy places you can get an egg omelette with veg or a bowl of harissa soup for between Dh 3-5, and a tajine for Dh 35), even though two of us were Moroccans.

GO AND ENJOY THE EXPERIENCE.... Visiting here is a MUST!It is incredible, very busy and a bit daunting at times but absolutely great (you may get lost, but that's all part of the experience). I never ever haggle but I did and it was fun, prices are cheap, loads of things to buy, loads of things to see (food, clothes, music, tricks, animals, bags). A firm "NO" is all you need to say and you will be fine.It is alive, bustly and mesmerising, day or night. I LOVE the place.I travelled with 2 females, no guides - no problems, we just stayed together, remained 100% observant and polite at all times and did our thing.GO AND ENJOY THE EXPERIENCE.
Worth a visit. Still worth visitng, although some of its original flavour has gone.Now thgere are more eateries and dieser story Tellers, but still worth a visit
lively place. must visit. very nice and busy place to visit or even chill back in one of the square restaurants and watch things happening

Magic Atmosphere. There's no doubt that this place got some Magic!!! This UNESCO site it's "All in One" of Marrakeche's experience.
Great to see from the Top balcony of the bars all over the square, It's just melt your mind, Magical Feelings!

I love it. I was here for a tour alone and it was warm climate. I arrived at 17:00 jema el fena and was eger to see the crowd and try food especially dates and brain of lamb. It was really delicious and sunset with atlas mountain view.... oh my days i cant express it.

Breath in the atmosphere. The whole square is a massive hive of activity with such an assult to all your senses. One of my favourite places ever. Food, music, entertainment all in one place. Go at night for the fantastic evening atmosphere plus it's cooler temp to shop in. Watch out for pickpockets and be prepared to haggle like your life depended on it.keep your hands by your side or the henna ladies will paint you in a flash.

a night visit is completely diferent. The visit depends on day and night time. It's quite different. During the nights is croweded and it is not that safe. During the day it depends: when they are parying it could be almost empty

Crazy place - must see. Crazy place and has to be seen to be believed. See all sorts of goings ons. Would recommend going to top of cafe de france for a view of the whole square at sunset. Need to have wits about you and be prepared to say a firm no to all potential sales people as some can be pushy (generally though not near as pushy as other places I've visited though I must say). Also the horse carriages are cheap and good way to see the town - we got one for 50 dhm and lasted about 45 mins.

Love love loveee. Basically you cant go to Marrakech and NOT visit here! Its an absolute MUST! The markets arw awesome although you really do have to haggle with them. Some traders do get rude/irrate but dont let this put you off! The stalls inside are much cheaper then ones outside. The markets are like a maze and you can easily get lost in them so make sure you have hour navigation hats on! Lol The abundant food stalls and awesome and very atmospheric! Have a walk around before you decide on one. Theres are many restaurants and cafes on the outside for people who life that environment for food. Some have great balcony seating overlooking the square.There the LOADS of street vendors which can get annoying.. Especially the children selling you tissue.. Whom may i add i spent a lot on because im a softy but don't make this mistake as they remember you and will continue to hassel.

Marrakech square. Vibrant, colourful and really interesting, both by day and night. Snake charmers, fortune tellers and live music all add to the incredible atmosphere. Absolutely loved it. We felt safe and no-one hassled us.

Interesting.... The main square is interesting. In my opinion the souks are better...perhaps locals are nicer in there as they want you to buy. Whereas in the square the unwanted attention that all western women were getting was in my opinion too much. We tried to dress respectfully and fully covered but this didn't seem to work and made the whole experience stressful, which was a shame. I would recommend sitting in one of the upstairs restaurants, as we did, and watching the hustle and bustle from above
great trip out. .this trip was very good you get to see all the different aspects of marrakech on horse and cart it was very safe and we all enjoyed it very much.

See it at sunset. What a beautiful place! We were wary at first of pickpockets but had no trouble at all, just the ladies trying to sell us henna and putting it on us after we said no! This is a big tourist attraction and you should visit in the afternoon to see the snake charmers and monkeys and as the sun goes down, get a drink and go up on the terrace of the Cafe de Glacier on the corner to watch the sun set, it's so beautiful! The sounds and smells are wonderful too, a definitely must-see on the Marrakech sight list!

Must go, more than once. When visiting Marrakech, you will for sure end up here at some time of your stay. You will learn how to love it, and I recommend you to go there at different times of the Day. During the Day it is just Crowded, and people selling stuff here and then. During the night several food stalls show up - it's cheap, you cannot look at hygiene, and it's reaaaaally tasty. There are several people selling orange juice there, but europeans or people not used to it shouldnt drink, because they add tap water and it CSN be bad for your next days health. Alsonduring the night there are people playing games and music. Just be aware at your phone and wallet and enjoy the place. I also recommend the terraces around for a better look at the place jeema.

Full on immersive experience but good to retreat back to Riyad.. Loved it and loathed it... it's pretty full on during the day but at night it's almost overpowering. Keep your wits about you unless you want a snake or monkey draped over your shoulders. Felt safe though.Make sure you're firm with your food order and what it includes when buying from the stalls "No diarrhoea here for 2 years!" is arguably one of the best lines I've ever heard from a prospective meal provider. Orange juice stalls give amazing drinks.

Place definitly worth visiting. What an impressive square,best time to visit is around sunset when the whole place comes to life with snake charmers ,fortune tellers ,food vendors and much more .The square transforms you to ancient times when traders and visitors assemble in one huge space ,this place has a carnaval atmosphere but at the same time very authentic , the fresh squeezed juices are out of this world specially when you emerge from the hot and humid Souks , the foods looked good but we were warned about the health hazards , and how it can be a hit or miss adventure so we preferred to stick with reputable restaurants.

Nice visit . It was a very important visit to discover beautiful thinks and To assist to the charmer of sneaks and popular théâtre .M'y familly and i were very happy to ne in this place the ambiance was gold t hanks a lot.

Impressive, out of this world!. Jemaa el fna was really out of this world. It is the most interesting and unique place in Marrakesh. A lot of food courts (you do not have to worry for their cleanliness, I do not here anybody get sick from these restaurants) and nice Moroccan live music shows. Also you have to try fresh and delicious orange juice in here which is only 4 MAD. Just be careful about monkey and snake dancers, do not give any attention to them.
Cultural experience. Just took a walk around. Food from the food stalls are terrible. Don't eat there. Horse pee stench everywhere. Not much to buy. Just interesting to see.
avoid it.. hated it. full of people trying to rip you off by putting dead snakes around your neck and then demanding money for it! get past this tourist trap quickly before looking round the old town
North Africa epitomised !. Fun place .Some good and varied food stands..Very local atmosphere particularly in the evening ! Even snake charmers in action!

Prepare for an exiting excperience. This is about as mad as it gets, however all on a very positive note. The place is alive (in more ways than one) with activity and things to do, eat, drink, see. A fabulous view on a wholly different world

A crazy place. Perfect start to a trip to the medina. Soak up the heat and frenetic sellers and when it all becomes a little to much escape to any of the roof top restaurants to enjoy it at a comfortable distance. The horse drawn carages are well worth trying

Jemma El Fna. A crazy place to visit, but a must see if visiting Marrakesh. We went firstly during the day, but the central stalls are closed and only come alive after 5pm. Having said that there still lots to see! Be prepared though to be hazzled continuously by the local traders. They don't seem to understand the word NO!! Went back again in the evening, and it was sheer madness! Lots of street entertainers, food stalls and beggars! Keep tight hold of your belongings!! Nevertheless, a must see just to see the magnitude of the square itself!!

The ultimate Berber extravaganza in a jam-packed square. This square is like something out of Alice in Wonderland, but with a desert Berber setting. By day, it is much more tame, but by 'tame' I mean there are still venomous snakes by the dozen on blankets surrounded by Berber snake charmers and men holding leashes on collared macaques who are sometimes wearing diapers and/or children's clothing. So much as look at any of these creatures and you will be accosted for cash. The fresh orange juice stalls are a must - it was the best orange juice I've ever tasted and at about 20 cents per glass, one cannot go wrong. Come nightfall, the snakes and macaques go away only to be replaced by hundreds of outdoor food/drink stalls (the orange juice vendors being an all day mainstay) along with huge group circles at the center of which Berber soothsayers, storytellers, shamans or dancers dazzle onlookers. The square becomes so crowded by night it is truly difficult to process, but absolutely must be experienced. Unless, of course, you suffer from agoraphobia in which case steer clear of the Medina altogether and especially Jemma el F'naa.

Emblematic square that's a must when visiting Marrakech. Eating at the booth-restaurants on the square is an experience. A very emblematic square that gets particularly interesting after sunset. It could be scary if you don't like snakes, crowds and hustlers but if you don't mind it's a recommended experience to sit down and eat at one of the booth-restaurants on the square.

Squared out square square oh God rectangle. Once you go to the square you will see snake charmers, monkey performance and camels.The food at night smells brilliant till you try it. Both me and the Mrs had toilet issues hence ate at KFC. The square leads to the souks bazaars and is a good walk and experience.However beware everyone annoys you about the best way to get to the square. Do not take directions from people as they demand money and if you pay little they get obnoxious.
atmospheric. a fantastic and atmospheric place to eat - try food from any of the stalls for an authentic experience of Marrakech. Worth a visit at night before or after a wander around the souks

Not good at all. The place is filled with beggars. People would beg and beg so you buy their products. The place doesn't look particularly good, and it is also dirty. Horses excrete and urinate everywhere. Cars and motorbikes drive around here which is very dangerous. There was a good restaurant by the name of Naim foods. Overall I couldn't enjoy this place with all of these problems surrounding it.

Must see!. A must see place in the day and the night. Night time has hundreds of food stalls serving all kinds of food cooked right in front of you. The square has snake charmers and all type of entertainers. Beware they try and charge you for taking a photo. lots of stalls selling fresh orange juice. If you don't like hustle and bustle then it can be daunting but not to be missed.
Fun square . It's a fun place in Marrakech, full of music, fresh drinks and food but if you want to eat make sure the place you're interested in practices good hygiene!

"BREATHTAKING". A very interesting place to visit. This "incontournable" place of Marrakesh is a big box you need to tick in your holiday sheet!However apart from the strong unwelcoming smell (horses) and the -imho- "overexploited" bits and pieces of Moroccan culture, be careful what you eat and drink....We've ticked the box and not sure if we will visit again.

Noisy and surrealistic experience. You have to visit this square to get a real Moroccan feel, along with the obvious tourist traps and cruelties. Positives - late night impromptu performances by groups of musicians, who will welcome you (for a few coins), fresh orange juice, stalls that sell friend fish with a quick turnover, so probably fairly healthy, the sights, sounds and smells. Negatives - snake "charming" - don't let them put one round your neck as it gets ever costlier to have it removed. Even with my antipathy for snakes I felt sorry for them in the hot sun. And small apes in tiny cages, chained, please, no...

Jmaa El fna. The central square has many attractions and stalls. Buzzing every night. Alot of places to eat. Can get annoying with people trying to sell things to you, haggling is a must but can be quite tiring, so be ready to get lost in the all the shops if you can handle it. More entertainment there at night than in the day. The fresh orange juice from the stalls is a MUST.Its cheaper to go shopping there in the day than in the night. A great place to visit.

Madness gone mad. Totally out of this world. If you want to buy it you will find it here. If you want to trade ur partner in for a newer model then this is the place to come. Maybe this is the place to take the mother in law.Amazing food stalls. Freshly squeezed orange everywhere. If u fancy just sitting and watching life unfold in front of you with endless cups of coffee then this is the place to come.

Deep Culture. The Jemaa el Fna IS Marrakech....rooted in Berber / African history and culture. Leaving without having experienced the atmosphere created by snake charmers, evening food market, carpet and pashmina sellers wound render your visit void ! Don't be put off by hecklers, expect it as much as the Moroccans love it...have fun with them but be firm -Ladies, leave it to the Men ! Join the local families for evening meal at the food market and really get to know what a lovely, caring people they are ..... Smiles, gestures and body language are all that is needed in the absence of Arabic speaking skills !!!

A trip back in time. After sundown and the call to prayers has finished is when the square really wakes up. That's the time to enjoy the atmosphere and to interact with the food and orange juice vendors; snake chamers and buskers. The really good experience was the square was also full of locals out for an evening walk. We found the people of Marrakech to be extremely friendly.

Scary on a Saturday night! Perfect on a Sunday! . Well where can I start? I've never ever seen as many people in 1 place the crowds were beyond belief! We travelled as 3 young women and out 1st night we went down to the medina which was a Saturday. Got there about 9.30pm and it was wall to wall men very hustle and bustle and I'd wound myself upto a frenzy by reading all these reviews before I got there. Yes it's overwhelming yes it's busy yes it's different but at the same time it's extraordinary and unbelievable and wow just wow! Saturday eve is defo boys night and I found (as a tall blonde) there eyes were all over me, we got followed a few times but nothing bad happened. They try there look and I think there opinion of European women is that we are all hungry for sex so they try it on. Not for me I found it too much (and I'm quite ballsy!) Didn't want to return but my friends did so we went again on sun eve and it was a totally diff atmosphere so relaxed family night lots of women about and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Wonderful sights, smells, totally smitten with it. So different. So worth a trip!

Marrakech market madness. The central square of Jemaa el Fna is not for those who dislike people trying to tout for business. Every single market stall holder and busker will try and get you to spend some of your dirham, some will be rather aggressive about it! If you don't want to be hassled it's best not to stop to long at the snake charmers or other performers!The disappointment of the square is that it's the same orange juice stalls over and over and over again, not exactly a great shopping experience.The square should be visited at least once at night time for the atmosphere but just be prepared!!

Organized Caos. This is total y entertaining, from snake charmers, people setting up stalls, the orange juice stalls are a work of art to watch them set up. eat with the locals its very tasty and cheap, fishing rods fishing for coke cola, it's bizarre.

A time capsule to a historical era!. I felt like i was travelling back in time! The drums, the wonderful aromas and the ambiance all added to a wonderful experience. As i am a huge spice lover, i was in heaven with the variety of fresh spices, all worth the money. It is a wonderful sight at night and the experience is etched in my mind.

Beautiful at night, you feel in another world.... take a hrira with some mechoui, on one of the little shops, it is like a big spiritual circus...it is one of the places in the world to absolutely visit once in the life time....It is great...
amazing must see!!. just go to this place it will blow you away, like stepping back to another time,felt like i was in a indianna jones flim,""the music and the people, just unique very good at nite,

Goes On All Night. A pretty crazy place and an experience not to miss. Very colourful and really the best to visit at night. Depending on how close by you are staying, the horse and carriage or an open taxi are probably the best ways to get here. I simply walked through the city to Jemaa el Fna and took in the full craziness of central Marrakech.The spices are very fresh and well worth buying. I recommend that you pluck up the courage and try eating some of the food amongst the tent cafe thingys too. All adds to the wacky experience of visiting Morocco.

Mysterious and wonderful. Great atmosphere in the evening with drums getting beat and hawkers calling out all to the backdrop of the call to prayer when sitting on the top floor of a restaurant on the edge of the square. Lights, smoke what else can you ask for. We all loved it and haggle to your hearts content but do it with a smile and a couple of nice hand gestures. The o.j is to die for at only 4dirmha about 30p. Carriages to hire are on the edge of the square and a few Police were to be seen around the edges of the square. We all felt very safe but paid close attention to our purses. If you haven't been please go before it becomes too commercialised. I dong think Marrakesh is suitable for young kids but my 13/15 year old granddaughters loved it and were great at haggling.

Unique experience . This place is so unique; you can enjoy watching the cobra dance, and monkeys show, after each free show you may pay few dirhams (2-5). Also there is some walking bands dancing and singing in a funny way, I really enjoyed that. Many traditional clothes and some hand made crafts are available there, you need to bargain to get a good deal, never accept their first price. Some good restaurants available their offering a good traditional Moroccan meals. Also you can try the horse cabinet ride for about $10 (after bargaining)

Love this. Try to avoid the many tourist gimmicks simply by shaking your head "no" and walking away. They will try to place a monkey on your head and then ask for money afterwards. Or they will try to aggressively hawk you items to purchase. An old lady sneakily grabbed my hand and started drawing a clumsy henna then when I grabbed my hand back and said no thanks, she kept following me demanding me to pay. It took about 30 minutes for us to get rid of her!I've also heard stories of pickpocketing but like any other super busy area, keep your personal items close by and be aware of your surroundings!Aside from the con artists and pickpockets, we felt generally safe. We actually ventured too deep at one point during the night and found ourselves amongst the working men and women and families who actually lived there. A young man saw us and realized that we were sort of lost and pointed us into the right direction back to the main square. But what an experience! Truly a sight to see! At night, there are entertainers, magicians, and storytellers and the whole square is filled with lights and music. Really a must when in Morocco!

Weird wonderful and fun !. From snake charmers , exotic pets for sale to the guys who want you to have your picture taken with a monkey ( please avoid - animal cruelty ) not to mention orange juice sellers and at night a vast array of everything you can think of and more besides ! Not for the faint hearted but this is what you go to Marrakech to experience

The Hub of Marrakech!. I love this place. Day or night it is the place to be in Marrakech. Lots to do and see, but be careful not to get conned by some of the traders and entertainers. Some of them can become quite aggressive if you don't buy from them or give them money. Also watch the orange juice stalls and ask to see your juice being squeezed and put into the glass, otherwise you may get a diluted version of their famous orange juice! There are many great shops and stalls here, loads of cafés and restaurants and no shortage of people trying to sell you something. It's good to get a Cafe terrace and watch the square's activity with a nice cool drink. A definite must visit!

Fun the Fna Fna!. This place is so vibrant & lots of fun if you take it in good spirit!...During the day the market is frequented by orange juice sellers, snake-charmers & local guys with Barbary apes, many of whom will try to entice you over for photographs (if you want to avoid this then don't make eye-contact!)...At night it is a completely different scene altogether; the snake-charmers and company all leave and are replaced by story-tellers, magicians & acrobats. The square is also filled with dozens of food stalls, where you can eat well & cheaply...I loved the banter I had with some of the food sellers!...The square is edged on one side by the souks, and on the other sides by hotels & cafe terraces. I would recommend taking a seat on one of these terraces in that late afternoon, drinking some mint tea (or something a little stronger!) and watching as the market transforms from day into night, the smells that waft up from the many food stalls is incredible!

Amusing but overpriced fake goods.. Yes, this is the big market in Marrakech which takes you so many years into he past when you experience it. However, most goods are overpriced, mixed or fake. Eg spices, bags etc etc So be specific about what you want to buy. Sometimes you can find the real thing but again they expect 10 times the profit from foreigners. A really cool alternative for shopping would be the markets in the seaside town on essaouria, very calm, no forced selling, more neat and no chasing customers.
Very Interesting and Happening Square - the centre of the old town. Great square. Lot's going on and loads of interesting things happening. Would definitely go back when in Marrakech.

Complete Madness!. The Jemaa el Fna at night is a complete assault on your senses. The food we ate was delicious and cheap, cooked to order, served on paper napkins and eaten with our finders. While we didnt like the snake charmers and found the treatment of the monkeys quite upsetting, we absolutely loved the unique atmosphere of the place. Dont miss the musicians, transvestite dancers and theh wonderfully mad tooth pullers. Soak up the unique atmosphere and enjoy!

Good food, but the locals are too pushy and things are overpriced.... We went there as two friends after visiting Casablanca and Rabat. Since this was not our first day in Morocco, we knew how the locals tried to trick us and get the most money out of us. This helped a lot to avoid the unpleasant situations.The square has indeed a special atmosphere, stalls everywhere and food is available of all kinds Moroccan. The locals will shout at you, talk in a rather pushy manner to lure you into their restaurant. It is funny for the first time, but can become annoying and sometimes they make comments that might be a bit aggressive...The prices are a bit high compared to the standards of Morocco, but still cheaper than the typical touristy restaurants in the city. All in all, you can have a decent dinner from about 60-70 dirham per person.Don't spend too much time on comparing the prices of stalls, they are nearly all the same, rather look for the place where more locals eat and not only tourists.Food to try:- snails- harira (chickpeas soup) with dates and sweets- lamb's head- different types of kebabs (lamb, beef, chicken...)- fried seafood (this was not so good...)- olives/bread/chili sauce- grilled vegetables- different types of tagines- variety of couscousGood advice:- Ask for the price of everything put on the table, there is no free stuff in Morocco, whatever is put there and you haven't asked for but touched is quite likely to be charged on the bill- Don't eat fresh salad and other fresh things...Risk of contamination is high.

Night time is a 100 x better. I really liked the Jemaa el Fna but thought the atmosphere was very busy and hot. There are alot of beggars and poverty but it is a beautiful setting at night with food and the lights !

Splash of colours and culture! . Going to Morocco is probably one of the best holidays we've ever had. The market square comes to life at night time. The food was amazing! In the souks you can buy cheap leather goods but you need to learn the art of haggling and negotiating. Don't ever be embarrassed to haggle, It's part of their culture and they will show much respect to you once you've done a good bargaining. To give you a good bearing of the city, I recommend you take the city tours buses that take you around to some unexpected and pretty places! We will definitely go back and do it again.

Hot, hot, hot!. It was over 100 degrees Fahrenheit during the day when we were there. Walked around the merchants shops. Came back at night at the square was transformed into sword swallowers, fire eater, snake charmers, grilled meats, carriage rides...more like a carnival atmosphere. So glad we did the trip to Marrakech.

An amazing extravaganza. The square is a huge hub of shopping, food stalls entertainment and tourists. The noise is incredible, drums, cymbals, snake charmers, and then the mosques start calling. I have never experienced anything like this before.

Must visit!. I love this place! You find everything you want here make sure you haggle with them never go for the first price they will try to sell you a item double the price but you can haggle and get to were you want!

Come here for a short time in the day, then stay all night as the fun happens after dark. Jamaa El Fna is simply the market square, a huge open space where market stall holders sell their wares or food. By day it is totally different than by night, but be sure to experience both.During the day it's more subdued, lots of juice and water stalls, dried fruit & nut stalls, some snake charmers, henna tattoo artists and people selling argan oil in all forms. At the juice stalls you'll get harassed by the local kids begging for money - offer to buy them a juice, they are really poor and this simple, cheap experience for you will be something important to them.There are also a bunch of horse and carriages for tourist rides. It's busy, it's dusty it's smelly but it's an amazing experience. The juice at the stalls are incredibly cheap and with all the Moroccan sunshine taste sweet and quench your thirst. Watch the charmers but don't take photos as they will expect a fee (maybe hide behind some people and be quick!). Henna tattoos are very popular but be careful as there is no hygiene here and you can get an infection. By night the place is like a market, nightclub, restaurant, theatre, festival all wrapped into one. You'll hear the drums and the music being played until about 1:00am every day and you'll see the lights across the Medina as far as the eye can take you. This is when Jamaa El Fna comes to life - all the day stall holders and entertainers are still there but now add, musicians, singers, theatre entertainers, rows and rows of food stall holders with seating - you must eat here regularly, it's fantastic - acrobatics, flying toys being sold and a tonne of people. I love, love, love this place at night. Each food stall holder sells something different, chicken at one, seafood at another, lamb at another and cooked all different ways. Don't forget the delicacy of snails which are popular too! Local kids love the snails but often can't afford them. They are so cheap to Westerners, if you feel so inclined please buy a local kid a bowl of snails. They will come up to you asking for money, but just offer to buy them a bowl of snails and they will smile.Please enjoy Jamaa El Fna, it's a mix of wonderful things, cultures and experiences just waiting for your participation.

Harsh but true?. I have been here a few times. The crowd are a huge mix but the majority of the public are in a rush and are hot tempered. I would not recommend taking children here ESPECIALLY at night as there are snake charmers, people who have taken monkeys and use them as tourist attractions amongst other things.Shop keepers may seem persistent but are polite if you decline. There's alot of good shops in and around the square but I would only go if it was a necessity such going to a place that has been vouched for, or you know what it is you want.Please avoid at night if you have children.

Embrace the chaos. This is definitely the center of activity in Marrakesh. Nothing much happens during the day time, but the whole place starts to burst with activity once the sun comes down, and it lasts until the wee hours of the morning. It's a great place to immerse yourself in moroccan culture, with different performers attracting a varied crowd. There are lots of cheap eats in the area as well during the night time. And it's funny how every server proclaims that their food comes with a 3 year diarrhea free guarantee lol. Others may choose to avoid the madness, but if you have even the least bit of interest in moroccan culture, i advise you to embrace the chaos.

Highly recommend . We were a bit wary of eating here as we've never had street food before. It can be a bit intimidating as the vendors all call you and shout for you to eat at their stall. Pick a stall that's busy and sit there. Order what everyone else is eating and dig in. People are very nice and will help you pick what to eat. Some people even offered their food to us to taste which was very nice. We went to three stalls and ordered one dish each at each stall so we got a good variety of foods.

3rd class. The people (sellers and shopkeepers) take the bargaining to the extrem such that one hates to buy. We observed very unhygenic conditions behind the food stalls (only one bucket of water for all dishes) we could not eat at all.Ministry of tourism does nothing -absolutely nothing to help these poor people to better their products and services. Taxis too enjoy the lawlessness, even infront of Airport they were fighting with customer on charges.The so called 5 star hotel did not offer a glass of water at 13:30 july 14 (outside temp. 47 deg-C) it is not in their culture to see visitors as sources of income rather enemies whose money they should fleece by any hux and crux. Booking.com too is helping them in that hell.I never recommend both of them the booking.com and hotel Jardin dela agdal.

Amazing!. Love the atmosphere of this place! Lots of shops to buy anything you can think of, stalls for beautiful henna art or fresh orange juice!People complain about the beggars... seriously we are all human, give them a dirham or two (20/30p) will it really hurt you? Try Snack place for food or Henna Art Cafe both serve delicious food :-)

Prepare the senses for the deep end...!. Do your senses yearn for an assault from all sides? Do you, as a traveller, wish to submit yourself to a cultural melting pot of chaos and colour, and get lost in a world away from the comfort of home? If so, Jamaa el Fna is the place to go.Accessing it along a street opposite Koutoubia Mosque on Avenue el Mouahidine (provided you aren't struck down by the crazy traffic first), you enter the heart of the old city of Marrakech along with a seething mass of tourists and locals, traders, motorbikes, and horses pulling decorated carriages. This is where the aforementioned carriages and their drivers line up to entice tourists, offering a tour of the city for wallet-melting prices. My better half and I affectionately named this route as 'Rue de Horse P*ss', as the lack of any purpose-built drainage means that the road is often covered with puddles of urine that wake the olfactory senses with something of a beating.Make it past that, and you find yourself in a vast, open space where thousands of people swarm. The heart of this market square beats with the sound of snake charmers and traders during the day, and surges to a new level of life at night when the dancers, drummers, story-tellers and entertainers, monkey handlers, henna artists, and everything inbetween emerge to ply their trades or promote their talents.Across the square, a bright horizon of juice vendors and food stalls eminate such noise from the edge of the souk (market) behind them. All will fight for your attention, urging you to try their juice (albeit they all sell the same thing for the same price), or their delicious, cheap food. Young men will step in front of you as you dodge and weave your way through the swarm, greeting you with comical cries of "this place like Sainsburys, come and eat", or "more reasons to shop at Morrisons", and attempt to steer you to their little business. A word of warning at this point: the water used is rarely bottled, and likely to cause considerable unhappiness. The food is unprotected from the flies that naturally thrive in such a climate, and the crockery and cutlery is often only rinsed under tap water by hand. I am sure it tastes wonderful, but we were not disappointed to have avoided such places.The markets remain open until around midnight each night. The cool evening air catalyses the mixture of sights and sounds, and brings out the most incredible stageshow of culture, chaos, and crafts as leather meets silverware, meets spices, and meets silk.The square is policed - officers can be seen patrolling on occasion, and there is a larer police station on the edge - however pickpockets gravitate to the tourist-rich centre, and young men such as myself will be asked by questionable-looking characters to join them for 'hashish' when the officers aren't within earshot. Entertainers and dancers will latch onto those taking photos or filming, or even looking a little bewildered by the whole thing, and will pose for that snapshot or two before insisting on being paid for the pleasure. Having fallen for that trap early-on, I can only recommend maintaining your wits as best you can, and hiding a majority of your cash where nobody can see it so you can demonstrate, with empty wallet open, your inability to pay them the £5 or so that they demand in Moroccan currency or Euros. Vendors and market traders are the same; expect an unhappy response to attempts at photographing the mounds of spices, beautiful lamp collections, or colourful silks unless you tip them for the privilege.The square is, without doubt, a place to revisit during your stay. Don't be put off by one bad experience - being mobbed by entertainers for money, for example. Learn to say "no" (I found the phrase "non, c'est bein, merci", accompanied by a wave of the hand and walking on briskly, ignoring any pleas, worked brilliantly) and instead soak up the immense atmosphere and amazing whirlwind of this vibrant, beating heart of the city. Haggle if you wish to buy - it is accepted practice and expected in the souks - and grab yourself a bargain or several. Alternatively, seat yourself in one of the many coffee shops around the edge of the square, and enjoy the spectacle from the comfort of your table.Whatever your desire, and whatever your agenda: visit Jamaa el Fna. You wont be disappointed.

Crazy Atmosphere . Moroccans don't really watch television so they go to the square for entertainment.During the daySnake charmers Monkey actsHenna artistsSome juice standsEvening Loads of juice stands Loads of market stall type restaurants Story tellers (shame it's not in English)Musicians Must see when in kech!

Crazy!. The Djemaa El Fna Square is one of the craziest, in a good way, attractions you can visit anywhere in the world. During the day it is full of snake charmers, henna artists, monkeys,birds, orange juice stalls and plenty of people.
