At night time it transforms into a wonderful sight with street food stalls popping up everywhere.If you don't like the hustle and bustle then avoid at all cost, but like me if you don't mind any of that then this is a must of any traveller. Whilst you're there do not forget to try the freshly squeezed orange juice, I guarantee it will be the best orange juice you have ever tasted - go to stall number 39 where you will be greeted with a warm smile every time as well as free juice from time to time.

A stunning heart. What is Jemaa el Fna?It's hard to describe, but I'd say it's a heart that pumps blood in a viril way. Their veins and arteries are the souks, the alleys and small streets that surround it. The blood are the people who swarm around in a constantly back and forth. And when the sun begins to fade into the horizon, the heart pumps even harder. The square builds on itself and becomes a bustling hive, chaotic, noisy, intense. A living organism that is not to see but to feel. Only few places in the world have this intensity and will cause immediate feelings as contradictory. Astonishment and fear, between wanting to go and wanting to stay. However after some time just a feeling might overturn all the others, in my case was to let me swallow.Tip: Whenever you want to say no to salespeople, the photo hunters and beggars, don’t need to be unfriendly, a smile and a firm attitude are enough. 99% of the time results.

A great spectacle . Relax and enjoy, as much as you can. Don't be mean, get your hand out of your pocket and spend a bit of money and everyone will have a good time. There is nothing else quite like this square.

Benidorm in North Africa. I am completely at a loss as to why and how this place has been accorded the status of a world heritage site.If one disregards the hassle from the vendors, which of course is to be expected, the selection of goods on sale is somewhat disappointing, comprising primarily fake clothing, footware and bags.Considering the skill of the local artisans it is surprising that they are not more prominent in this area which is frequently by the tourist that are bussed in and out on a regular basis.The standard of hygiene which I witnessed precluded me from risking trying any of the local food on sale in this area.Considering the mystic which is associated with the name Marrakech and in its main square I was very disappointed with the experience.
Fabulous. The square is amazing. Night or day you will be amazed at the sights and sounds that are impossible to explain. You must go x
what a lively place. I can tell you, if you want to see a lot of people, things and everything going in every direction. This place is fantastic to taste, the real Moroccan food!

Arabian magic.. The square is unique, if you visit doing the daytime you will find henna ladies, snake men, monkeys and dancers, doing the evening, the food arrives and it seems like a totally different places.A lot of the sellers in the souq, speaks English, they will try to sell you a lot you don't want, at a price that are in the sky... Just smile and work on. If you find something you want to buy, try to get the price down a bit, take it as"part of the game" the every one will have more fun!

Chaotic and exciting. By day the Jemaa el Fna is an interesting place to viist and if nothing else i would highly recommand that you try some fresh orange juice from of the many juice carts. As the day extends into night the square takes on a who new feeling and can be a little bit crazy with snake and monkey handlers, african dancers and musicians.There are dozens of food stalls selling fairly cheep food, but beware they wash all of their cutlery and plates in buckets of water that gets dirtier the later it gets.TRy one of the many restaurants around the square and enjoy the show.

Loud, noisy, touristic . I didn't like the place at all. Its too loud and noisy. The poor animals are made to take silly pictures and wear diapers. I don't get what about that is supposed to be fun or enjoyable. Stayed away as soon as I saw it once.

Felt like a victim, not a tourist!. A frightening, smelly, oppressive dump where you'll be constantly harassed by locals who work together in a team to scam you out of your money. They treat tourists with utter contempt. Food is terrible and hygiene non existent. We saw confectionary swarming with flies and bees. My boyfriend and I both got food poisoning and had to miss a planned and paid for excursion. You can't browse, take photos or even sneeze without someone aggressively pursuing you for money. You cant trust anyone, especially those who appear to be nice, because they'll rip you off too. Could not wait to leave and no amount of money could persuade me to return. Just awful.

OUTSTANDING. The food stalls after 5 were the best expereince I had in Marrakech. My wife and I ate sardines, olives, fried potatoes, salsa, bread and tea for 2.50 USD total. DO NOT miss this place after 5 pm.....

Busy and crazy. We loved how busy the place was. There is always something going on. Salesmen can be quite full on so its important to only glance at products as a look to long gives the indication you want to buy something and they will insist you buy. In the evenings the food stalls open. Always a vibrant atmosphere!

Crazy and fascinating. What can I say that hasn't already been said. Dont be put off by the worriers. Yes you will get bothered by traders and touts but nothing too intimidating and a polite no thanks with a smile will usually have them move onto the next person. A little common sense goes a long way - if you choose to wander around with your wallet on show or expensive cameras or electronic items in hand, no doubt you run the risk of something getting stolen. If you're careful and keep valuables hidden away and money in a front pouch or pocket, you should be fine. On a busy weekend night, this place is heaving - its vast but when busy every single inch is full of every kind of person on earth. Local musicians join up for impromptu jam sessions - if you want to watch and listen, be prepared to drop some coins in the hat as it goes around - after all they do need to earn a crust. The transvestite belly dancers are fun - they wait til someones gives them some money then dance for a short while for the benefit of the person paying. They then stop dancing and taunt the crowd til someone else coughs up, great fun and worth donating a few notes for. Watch out for the henna ladies - they are probably the most aggressive in the square. They do tend to want to grab your hand and start drawing before you realise it, then are likely to demand some money for it. Just avoid them, they dont attack they just take advantage of those who arent concentrating. As soon as you say no firmly but politely they go away and try someone else. Also annoying are the small children trying to sell packets of tissues - they have a habit of walking right in front of you and its often hard to avoid tripping over them. They dont seem to take no as an answer as easily as the traders and food vendors. Dont be tempted to give them money, youll be a target for hundreds more. It's noisy, crowded, in your face and an assault on the senses but it's a once in a lifetime opportunity to see something that will make your jaw drop.. There are some good bargains too to be hard at the stalls in the souks leading off the square into the rest of the medina. It's not all nasty tacky rubbish, the main open fronted shops in the alleyways just to the north of the square sell some exquisite stuff. Just be prepared to enter into lengthy and tiring bartering to get anything however. The stalls and street vendors in the square itself are mostly cheap stuff but some fun items for jokey gifts to take home if you wish. Plenty of nice cafes and restaurants around the edge of the square, some with roof terraces three or four storeys up from where its a great viewpoint to look over the vastness and volume of the square.

magical gathering at night. I only spent 4 days in Marrakech, but every night I would go to Jemaa el Fna often to eat among the many at the open-air "restaurants" but more particularly to drift among the incredible mix of people, tribes, entertainments.Take the time to sit down somewhere, close your eyes, and let yourself be swayed into a magical trance by the rhythm of the drums, of people singing, of people moving endlessly. Do keep your belonging in front of you / under your arm as sadly, like any places attracting a large number of people, it also attracts pick-pockets; but rest assured this is an amazing gathering that happens every night - go and experience it, it is unique.

can't miss it. If you're walking around within the medina walls, you'll eventually enter this huge square - whether you intend to or not! You'll see random sights, like dancing cobras and monkeys or chickens, and lots of little congregations around dancers, storytellers, and other street performers. Lots of food (and smoke) - it's an assault on your senses.

Hustle and bustle . We went to Jemaa el Fina in the day time and the night. Both times it was amazing. Lots to see and do. Fresh orange juice was lovely and we had some fabulous sea food from one of the food stalls 117 which I would recommend. Be aware though everyone is out to make a buck even taking a picture with the monkeys cost. However you can't go to Morocco without visiting Jemaa el Fina

Everything you imagined it would be. Jemaa el Fna is not going to let down you !
it can't .
(although be wary if you are looking for Selfridges it's really not going to be for you)
You just have to join in here , there really is no choice.

Spectacu. Wow, an experience for all the senses. Recommend heading their during the day and the evening to get completely different experiences. Confidence is key, look and sound confident in what you do and you will have a better time

A Must See but Very Touristy. This is a huge square with all kinds of stalls for drinks and food, tourist souvenirs, and street performers. It is definitely worth a quick walk through to see it, but be sure and protect your personal belongings and refrain from buying anything here as it is definitely a tourist spot now.
Jemaa el fna. Great place to visit. Not much on in the day but comes life at nigh, with food stalls and entertainment. Be careful of the money grabbers though.

Be Careful!. As with everything in Marrakech, you have to pay for the privilege to walk through the square. Be prepared to be hassled with every step you take. If you are going to get orange juice, which is recommended, go to stall number 49 as he is kind, doesn't harass you to visit his stall, and if you're lucky, gives extra orange juice for free!While we do agree that the square has a lot of culture, you may find that it's almost all the same. Although the sunset view is one to be marvelled at, be warned that the restaurants with the terraces charge you for the privilege whether you order food (over market value) or not. One tip to avoid the constant scamming is to eat on the side streets which run off the main square as these offer much better value for money, with a kebab and chips costing just 14 dirhams. In addition, do not even attempt to take pictures of the snake charmers or monkey handlers as there are a team of them looking for anyone attempting to. They will also come up to you with the poor, abused animals demanding money.Also, do not let anyone give you directions or any help as this may seem like a kind-hearted thing to do, but it's a scam to demand ridiculous sums of money for doing so. Keep in mind that unofficial tour guides in Marrakech are illegal which the locals wholeheartedly ignore, where a simple 'no thank you' will get you verbally abused. However, if you are able to ignore the constant bombardment of stall owners and locals, the square can be quite pleasant, especially when the sun is setting and it starts to come to life.

Believe The Hype. Whatever the hype, this is the place to go not only in Marrakech, but all of Morocco. It's a circus, a zoo, a bazaar, a freak show. Whatever you want to call it, it's the definitive Morroccan experience as they want you to know it. You've probably read enough reviews to know to beware of your surroundings, to not stare and generally to be careful. Yes, do all that, but free your senses to take it all in--the sight, the sounds, the smells! Keep much spare change with you for tips, trinkets, treats and tricks. If anything, try the freshly squeezed orange juice (served in glasses but more in takeaway plastic cups) at stalls everywhere. If this local flavor isn't your taste, at least head up to one of the many rooftop cafes overlooking the masses. They're generally cheap and pleasnt to get away yet stay in tune with the hussles below. Jemaa el Fna is introduced in every travel show ever about Morocco, so you must go. Besides, it's how you'd get to the two next best attractions in Morocco--the souks and the riads--so give yourself a whole afternoon to explore this unique experience
What an experience !!!!! Amazing !!!. Just an amazing place to visit which we did a lot of the time during our 2 week stay. So different during the day to at night when it really comes alive !!!!!

A Must See. This is an iconic site to see when visiting Marrakech. I would recommend going at nighttime. The place is lit with lights, and there is a lot of energy. If you can, gran a seat from a rooftop cafe, that makes for great people watching. There are tons of food tents and shopping stalls. The shopping is also good to do in the day if you like to have to browse. More fake goods than you can imagine--some are good but if you've seen then once, you've seen them all. I think this was supposed to the spot from the Sex And The City movie as well.

Lively, busy square!. The shuttle bus service dropped us off here whenever we visited and the second we were off the bus we were approached by men claiming to be with our hotel who wanted to guide us to places. They are very persistent but take no notice and walk away- they soon get the message. The square has coffee shops etc for anyone who wishes to sit and watch the world go by, but otherwise if you stand still for too long you will definitely be approached by people selling goods or offering photographic opportunities. My husband offered the snake charmers a small amount of money for one photo but before he knew it they had a put a snake around his neck and taken his camera so they could take more pictures. They expected more money at the end but we refused and walked away so be careful. There are monkeys also which saddened me as they are on leads and wear nappies and people pay to have photos taken with them. We found we were harassed more on the square than in the souks. We didn't see the henna ladies but had been warned that they might just grab our hands and start painting them and then charge us. All of this made me quite nervous and wary so the experience was not especially enjoyable as I spent a lot of the time feeling very suspicious of everyone! I'm a very polite person and being rude doesn't come naturally but at times you have to be very abrupt with people and walk away without engaging in conversation. I'm sure some people will love this whole atmosphere and although I'm pleased I have been to the square, I wouldn't be in a rush to go back.
Great. Go back in time in this square ... everything is the same as it was hundreds of years ago (except for all the smartphones lol) ... watch out for pickpockets and runaway snakes

Just wow...... A visit here is a must and if u can visit at night.. even better. There is so much to see and buy..wear comfortable shoes and bring ur haggling skills!A "jus' from the orange sellers at 4dh(30pence) that beckon u over is very worth it. Un registered guides will ask if they can show you where u wish to go or just ask u to follow them so beware if u are not up for an adventure to a family members shop! Having said that...it is a great way to see parts of the old town off of the tourist trail but be preparred to pay a couple of pounds.

Great experience if you don't mind being hassled by shop keepers. This is definitely the place to go in Marrakech -- especially at night. It is like a nonstop party. During the day there are snake charmers, 'dentists', and other interesting people-- don't take a photo unless you are prepared to pay them a tip. They usually pack up for the night festivities-- so you won't see them at night. At night all the food and drink carts -- which are delicious and cheap! Definitely have an orange juice and go shopping! Just keep landmarks around you otherwise you will get lost!

Maybe better at night. It's interesting to see the story tellers, ladies drawing henna, the juice stands, the snakes and monkeys, all the caleches, but there is not really that much to see. A little 20 minutes visit + 10 minutes caleche ride for 50 dirham will do. Maybe it's better at night I went at 4PM.

Very lively square! . Great place a little overwhelming at times with the heat, amount of people and the souks but a once in a lifetime experience, spent two hours there which was enough for us to grab some keepsakes.

Crazy and fantastic. Noisy but never boring. We were warned about the monkeys and snakes and kept us therefore reasonable distance from them, but fascinating to DeltaE in a performance that could take place 200 years ago. A must if you are visiting Marrakech

Nice place if you have your wits about you. Great food in evening. There are plenty of con-artists, thieves and dishonest traders in the square, all trying to get a slice of tourist cash. If you're careful and have your wits about you, you could enjoy it. As previous reviewers said, don't look too interested in things, don't take pictures or you will be expected to pay, and agree on prices beforehand, refusing to take anything or use any service before agreeing. Walking away is the best strategy to force someone to give you an honest price. Expect to be hassled, so try to be low-key (i found buying and wearing a moroccan jellaba reduces hassle by at least half!).As for the square, the attractions are probably quite interesting for children i imagine. I wasn't very impressed, and I found el-hedim square in meknes to be a more pleasant, low-pressure alternative to the fna in marrakesh with many of the same stalls and performances. It's still hectic and interesting, but with more opportunities to peruse at your leisure without hassle, though there isn't much going on during the mid-day heat.Where the hdim square wins hands-down is in the evenings when the food stalls pop up. The variety is immense, and the food generally fresh and good quality (go to the popular stalls as the food will be fresher and have spent less time standing). The competition from the many stalls means quality is good and prices are reasonable.

Organised Chaos. A must see/do but be prepared to be harassed the whole way around. Lots of things to buy, eat and drink and a definite experience. Sitting in a roof terrace with a drink over looking the square is also a must do/see.

Welcome to the jungle. Always an amazing place to visit but not for the faint hearted or those with an inability to negotiate!You also need to keep in mind that you WILL be approached every 10 meters unless you perfect your 'it's not worth it annoy somebody else face'An assault on the senses and potentially your wallet if you don't keep it safe. Great tastes smells and on balance I think we'll worth the experience.

Djmaa el fna by day and by night. Djamaa el Fna is the central square of the old part of Marrakesh. This enormous square occupies a central position in la Médina, the old city of Marrakesh, and is the converging point of many of its streets and souks.It has even been named a ‘masterpiece of the oral and intangible heritage of humanity” by UNESCO.During most of the days, performers of every kind put up their shows, continuing until the evening when food trolleys force their way in and occupy half the area and all of the attention of the audience.There are plenty of cafes and restaurants with a rooftop terrace, a great way to see the spectacle unfold while enjoying a drink or a meal.The square has a very long tradition of partying and celebrating - it is here that caravans in the past finished off their route after having spent weeks and months in the desert. Caravan people would therefore stop in this square to celebrate the fact that they were still alive. Djemma el Fna starts out exciting and finishes off wild! Storytellers, acrobats, snake charmers, water sellers, musicians, magicians and just about any other form of entertainment you can think of.Love it or loathe it, Djemaa el Fna has to be experienced at least once. And I say 'experienced' rather than 'seen' because Djemaa el Fna needs all the senses - tasting the food, smelling the spices and aromas, and hearing the endless noise of the horns.

A crazy chaotic fun noisy carnival for senses!!. This is a must! Go at night its like a carnival - eat there too - its great fun if not a little chaotic!! ignore anyone who tries to put a hat on you - don't take pics of snake charmers before agreeing a price! or it will cost you... don't accept offers to give you directions... Apart from that wander about and enjoy something different

Upsetting. I have very mixed views on Jemaa el Fna which is a shame as i'm not a fan of leaving negative reviews. During the day the square is full of orange juice carts, snake charmers, horse and carts and monkey's. I am completely against using animals for tourism so for me that was already a no no. The monkeys looked distressed, flinched when their owners moved, were chained up in the heat and looked bored and distressed.The horses stood in the heat all day (45 degrees when we were there) had poorly fitted shoes, scars on their bodies, and were under weight. When you come from a country with great animal welfare rules it becomes very evident when animals are not being cared for properly. If you're reading this please don't feed the animal trade.

Approach with caution. The negative comments in reviews about this area are all thoroughly justified. My own particular experience was extremely upsetting. On arriving with my teenager daughter we were quickly targeted by a group of 3 henna women. My daughter often has henna designs done when in the Middle East and was keen to get one done here. The woman who was leading proceedings would not give us a price but said we could pay what we wanted. She showed my daughter a book of designs without prices. She spent about 3 or 4 minutes carrying out the design and I gave her the equivalent of 8 euros which I felt was fair. She then produced an identical book of designs but this time with prices alongside which were about 30 euros. A long and unpleasant argument ensued during which all 3 women rounded on us. They grabbed my daughter by the arm a number of times and told her to tell me to pay more. She was becoming upset at this stage and just wanted me to pay up so we could go. In the end I gave them about 15 euros and we managed to extricate ourselves and walk away at which point the ringleader shouted '**** you' at my daughter who by this stage was in tears. She was badly shaken and just wanted to return to the hotel.We also fell foul of trying to take a photo without realising we would have to pay and yet again it was an aggressive woman who shouted that if we wanted to take a photo we would have to 'pay good money'. A few days later we were the victims of a friendly young man who offered to point out directions in the souk and would not take no for an answer. He insisted on taking us to his family's pharmacy but there was not anything we wanted to buy there, unsurprisingly. He asked for money and I gave him the equivalent of a couple of euros and he became unpleasant, saying it wasn't enough.As a mother and daughter visiting without my husband we were easy targets. People may well think we were naive and gullible, and to some extent maybe we were. I have had years of dealing with pushy shop owners in Karama in Dubai, but this made Karama look like Westfield. I don't think I am a pushover, but I really did feel this was all a little too edgy to be enjoyable.My advice would be to keep your wits about you, dress conservatively (as we did), remove jewellery and watches beforehand and spend a little time reading about the most common scams in Marrakech before visiting. The square is certainly vibrant, lively and interesting but approach with caution and see it as a one-off experience. Marrakech has much more to offer; we particularly enjoyed Les Jardins Majorelle.

Be prepared to be amazed. We visited in July and nothing could have prepared us for the craziness of this place. We were constantly chased for money!!! Do NOT take pictures of snakes or monkeys on chains not even from a big distance as they will chase after you and hassle you for money. On a more positive note the fresh orange juice was wonderful especially in the 45C.Have your wits about you, stay safe and enjoy the experience
The name for a mosque. Amazing from snake charmers, to false teeth, you can get it allAnd find that bargain, but they don't haggle anymore, its all fixed prices

daylight better than darkness. Food stalls, henna hasslers and snake charmers complemented by the smell of horse and a strong police presence. Preferred watching stalls being set up in the morning to the above things at night.

Horse drawn carriage tour was lovely. We went by horse drawn carriage around the new town and then into Jemaa el Fna, what an amazing experience! Like going back in time as you enter the square. This really is a must for anyone visiting Marrakech

Full of mystery and Intrigue, but be prepared!. A hive of activity, different by day to the evening when things really come to life. As others have said, you must have your wits about you re snake charmers and henna ladies, give these a wide berth unless you want tp part with more money than you intended! Also watch for those who appear to know you and want to take you on their own tour!None the less a real cultural experience, and some bargains to be had . Also some nice restaurants, some within the market itself

Interesting Local Scene and Congregating Place in Marrakesh. Our guide took us to this square one evening. We enjoyed strolling around, looking at the locals who flock to this place in the evenings, peering in various shops, looking at the wares of street vendors etc. The surfaces of the streets and in the square are uneven, so one needs to take some care in walking around. I do NOT recommend eating in one of the open stalls here, though they are much touted in guide books. Our experience eating at one of the stalls was dreadful.

Always lovely and nice to have a walk. Of course it's well known that in this famous place the sellers will always try to grab your attention to attract you to their shop. You'll also need to learn to bargain, a lot ! But the place is really nice and you can find all the souvenirs that you want !

Exciting square . Exciting square to visit. Be sure to haggle to get the best bargains! Also women need to beware of the 'henna ladies'.. They will grab your hands and not let go whilst they syringe henna onto them. Everything else is harmless. Would recommend Aqua cafe/restaurant and La Perle du Sud restaurant.
Amazing place. Different cultures of all world in a very busy and espetacular square. Lots of things to buy and to visit.

The Heart of action in Marrakesh. A breath taking place, with mane performers competing to catch your attention (and tips): snake charmers, traditional dancers and food vendors. You get an unbelievable view from the balconies around the square wile enjoying Moroccan tea. Very vibrant and colorful.
fna square. this was a lovely lively place to go the orange juice was the best lots of stalls we brought little camels and the henna ladies are really nice nd we did our henna there on last day bc

Wakes into live as soon as the sun starts going down. This place really come alive at sunset, with loads of market stalls...mostly selling the same things! Food, freshly squeezed Orange juice etc. Beautiful and picturesque when lit up. Try not to take pictures of any snake charmers unless you want to pay them!
hold on to yoyr money!. Buzzing with life! Be aware of the sneaky excuses for money I.e. photos with snakes and henna (they start decorating before you have a chance to ask how much!)

Crazy, Beautiful. This place is beautiful in a chaotic kind of way. There's so many things going on in one place-- snake charmers (careful not to be seen taking photo, they will charge you!), henna women (if you want to have a henna, agree on a price first), open stalls have different things to eat from snails to sweets and meat. We went here on a labour day, imagine the mess! But it was an experience I am glad we had. And oh, Sex and the City filmed here (if it matters to you, like it did to me)!
Go for the evening food. Quite touristy during the day time, but a different place at night. Local cuisine is cheap, plentiful and tasty. Definitely worth a visit.

Gross, weird and fascinating . I couldn't stand this place, but I can see why it's so intriguing. The poor treatment of the horses that pull the carriages that line the square were enough to ruin my experience. Then there is the man in a djellaba with a huge monkey on his shoulder- now, I love monkeys, and I wanted to play with it and I could've for a fee. But I didn't want to support that; I don't know if the monkeys are well treated or simply used to make money- like the horses. We had a guide but if we hadn't, we would have been over run with vendors and hustlers. Henna artists, fortune tellers, stalls serving goat brains with the meaty goat skulls hanging in front, people dancing, people watching people dancing, balloon sellers, jugglers- you name it. Anything a person can feasibly do for money is being done with whatever tools they can get their hands on. We spent about 15 minutes there before I asked that we leave, dodging all manner of nastiness pooling in the streets.

Put simply, just awful!! . My boyfriend and I have been travelling around Morocco now for about 3 weeks and decided we wanted to do Marrakech properly and stay in a Riad and soak up the atmosphere. Jemaa el Fna is a 5 minute walk from where we are staying so we have experienced it during the day and at night. For people who believe this is culture and the real Morocco I suggest going anywhere but here to find out what it is really about. There is nothing authentic about it. Snake charmers drug them first and remove their teeth then hit them if they do not go in the direction they want them to go in. Men are dragging monkeys around in chains. Kicking them when they pull against it. Some have nappies on. I saw one in the afternoon as I passed that was soiled and when passing through again later the same nappy was on. My boyfriend took a picture of the general square and then one of the dancers came up to him demanding money. When we said no he became aggressive and squared up to him and started shouting at him. Luckily he is not intimated very easily. This happened on numerous occasions during the night. The locals seem a lot more aggressive here than anywhere else we have been. Regardless of whether you give them something or not it is never enough for them. Women beware - I was approached for a henna tattoo. Repeatedly told them I did not want one whilst trying not to be rude. I went to talk to my boyfriend and they grabbed my hand and rushed a tattoo on it then tried demanding 300 dirham (about 20 quid) for it. I only had bigger notes on me and they would not leave until they got something which ended up being 100 dirham for shoddy work that I did not want or need. Even the women get aggressive here!! Much nicer places to see in Marrakech such as the palaces and the museums. If you are an animal lover do not go here. If you do want to visit I suggest you be prepared and be on the defensive when approached by anyone. this place is not culture it's a circus and an awful one at that!!

Amazing!. Seeing the sun go down on the square had been one of my ambitions for years and it didn't disappoint .. get a mint tea at one of the rooftop cafes and watch the square come to life .. one of my all time best memories!

Amazing chaos! . The sights, sounds and smells are incredible- we headed here every evening and never got bored! Yes the restaurants are a bit more expensive- but if you can see the square- the entertainment is worth it! The snake charmers, the Somali musicians- the tooth pullers! Just hold on to one another and be aware that Saturday night is super busy!

Unmissable and always fun. The square is hectic at almost any time of day and is very representative of Marrakech in this respect. The wide variety of street sellers, snake charmers, henna artists, caleches and entertainers makes it the best place to spend an evening in Marrakech if you are just there on a flying visit. The entrance to the souk to the North is also the easiest to find your way back to!

A five sense experience - Must see !. I am skeptical when it comes to crowded touristic places, but this has left me breathless. All your senses are in action, looking at so many colours, so many smiles, hearing conversations, feeling different materials, scents of leather mixed with orange blossom, it is a must see to loose one self. The bargaining process is tiring but so worth it as you end up sitting with the merchants and enjoying a cup of tea.

Admire Jemaa el Fna but keep a distance and if you go for pictures from the near, agree on payment first!!!. The central square of Marrakech is world famous. It is a gathering point for all kind of merchandisers and fortune seekers. It is worth seeing, but one has to be very careful not to be lured by henna painting and future predicting women and snake and monkey players. Picturing them will cost you a euro at least, when you have asked them first. Taking pictures without agreement will cost you a lot more, a big discussion will follow and the whole family and related group will start pressing on you. Be very careful, best thing is to stay aside and admire the activities on the market square from the side. Folks and merchandisers on this square are rather basic folks, be advised!

Hectic and over touristy. Make sure you are well slept and in a great mood to be able to tolerate this square. Just travelled a week through quieter, slower, more authentic parts of morrocco and when we arrived at the square (our first introduction to Marrakech) we just wanted to leave again. Super stinking hot, super hastling, monkeys in nappys doing acrobats, snake charmers - snakes fangs are pulled out and they are forced to preform - I'm not fond of snakes but thought this was pretty low. Tacky shops. Tourists everywhere, as you would expect, but if you want to get authentic morrocco go else were. The people here all also very abrupt unlike anywhere else we have been. Spend more time in essaouira or just use Marrakech as a brief base to the amazing landscape beyond.

Spend a few minutes here . The square is impossible to miss and worth seeing but will not take too much time . It is very different at day and night, so be sure to stop by both times. I am not sure when it opens/closes but was deserted at 8:00 am and was very lively past midnight on Sunday/Tuesday.The restaurants around the square are cheap but mediocre. It is worth have kebabs at one of the stalls for lunch or dinner one day. Most of the shops right in the square are just selling junk though . There are also a lot of beggars that hound you and will grab at your arm . If you need at ATM, this is the place to find them . You are out of luck as soon as you leave .
fun evening. nice fun for full evening and delicious food and its aroma. You will lost in market but remember to do bargaining. To start bargaining is at least 50% the price of seller.

Good for those ok with crowds. The mosque is so interesting, you do not go inside. Then you have lots and lots of people selling Moroccan stuff whether bags, spices, ... And also people dancing, playing tricks... Etc. it is a fun place and very beautiful at night. It goes without saying that you need to haggle with sellers.

perfect place for culture. This was a wonderful experience and I gained so much cultural experience here. The markets are a complete maze and you get lost in them! We actually had to have someone guide us out! FYI: if anyone tries to guide you somewhere you will be expected to pay them, however in our situation it was very worth it! I loved the hustle and bustle here and it was very different to any market i have been to before. It was very fun to barter and we got some good deals, but be prepared for the shop keepers to be annoyed with you, (but that is part of the fun!) The colours from the markets stalls are just fantastic, from the multi colour shoes, fruits, colourful bags and many pretty, shiny lamps, ornaments and decorative plates!A must see! =)

Awesome place. The one and only place in the world. It's amazing also for those who doesn't like shopping. All handmade, unique products. But the best thing is go there in the evening. thousands of people, gathering in smaller groups for some different events, starting from reading books (not may Moroccan people can read) finishing on animals hows, snakes, dances, musicians. You just have to see it on Your own.

Have to visit . Can't understand why you wouldn't visit, it's a great experience we went a couple of times night and day and the contrast is great the lights music etc.You do have to be firm with people if you don't want guides/henna etc or a monkey on your shoulder but we never got followed or hassled and had a great time walking in to the proper sookes where people were making garments wooden toys shoes etc. Or just sit and watch from a cafe. Great experience

Great for shoppers. This place is worth the visit during the day as well as the night, you get 2 different experience. Beware of taking pictures, you will likely be chased for money if you do. Shops are excellent but needs ALOT of haggling with owners to get the price down, shop around for deals. Small alleys had tucked away shops that had better prices for same things in larger shops and ALWAYS carry change more than bigger notes. The market gives you a great feeling of being in Morocco, if you don't like loud noise this place is not for you as the music can be deafening. What ever you buy or eat agree the price beforehand, speaking nicely and smiling will help you a lot.

Bustling place but keep your wits about you. Obviously being the central part to Marrakech this is where all the tourists go and there are some lovely restaurants and bars which overlook the square where you can watch it transform from day to night.As a female you will get hassled, they come up to you with monkeys and snakes and ladies almost force henna onto you - my arm was grabbed by a lady who had the henna in a syringe so be careful! Dress respectfully and you won't get as much hassle - this is a muslim country after all so be wary of their culture.The food stalls at night are an attack on your senses and you could eat pretty much anything you wanted too - including sheep's heads! Orange juice from the sellers during the day is so refreshing and delicious.Definitely worth a visit and a great place to experience the almost none stop bustle and noise - but lovely to get away from it too and see the peaceful gardens of the city.

A great performance. From about 10pm the square is a great experience with music and street performance. If you are a western tourist you will be a magnet for good and bad attention. If you like a performance it's easiest to give a little money at the start so you can stand and watch for a while and take photos without being targeted. The food stands are also good but the salesmen can be intense. You get less hassle if you smile sweetly as you say no thank you ("la shukran") and take it with good humour.
excelent. jamaa lefna it's between the perfect place can you see in your life for that don't miss it .great animation, popular food it's wonderful , lovely people.brief visit it

Won't leave you alone. We were there at the time of end of Ramadan, so it was very busy at times, especially at night time where all the locals came out to eat and buy stuff. It's a nice place to be at start but my poor ratings is because of the hassle you get from the shop and stall owners, if you just glance at the shop they all over you and won't leave you a sec on your own. Shame they don't understand that actually if they leave you alone you might look at the stuff and even buy something. I bought nothing.The other thing is beware of the guys with monkeys and snakes. Don't take a photo of them cause they'll charge you for it. They will throw the monkey on your shoulder to force you take a photo, don't let them, just say no.I would recommend the horse and carriage ride though, the driver was very nice and helpful, he showed us around and even stopped in places so we can take photos, they will jump on you to take their carriage for a ride but don't be put off by it, it's worth the ride and the experience.

Go with the flow but always have a plan. This is two different places - by day and night. Both are loud and will assault your senses. NB We were there during Eid so it might be different at other times.By day it's orange juice sellers, stalls selling random stuff and people touting photos with animals. My advice - drink the juice it's fab (choose the place by the way the person makes you laugh), ignore the sellers ( there are many better in the Souks) and avoid the animals. Spend some time in a roof top cafe and soak up the atmosphere.By night it's different - loads of food on offer. There's got to be a risk but it looked ok so we went for it. Every type of Moroccan food is on offer. Usual method of selection (after general appearance) was the amount they made me smile. As ever agree the price first but then just go for it. If your instinct is to fight the place, you won't win so go home or better still keep smiling and tag along for the ride.

Busy Noisy Square. This is the main sq with snake charmers henna artists food and drink stalls, to be honest i found it a bit boring everybody is after your money ,it costs to take pictures of the snakes , the food stalls are average the Orange drink stalls are ok cheap and fresh .theres plenty there for tourists to look at and a range of shops it just left me a bit bored

The Hub of Marrakech!. We've been to Marrakech 4 times and you have to visit the main market area to get a sense of the atmosphere. However, do take caution of your belongings in 2009 my partner had her mobile taken from her bag. Saying that items are stolen all over the world and this did not deter us. An eve here can be magical/mystical what with incense burning, snake charmers, and the general ambience. Bartering to purchase is top of the menu and we experienced one very young (14/15 yrs old) trader who turned out to be quite rude; I asked him to understand respect and other older traders agreed with me. The souks/alley ways can be a challenge especially when hot (mostly is in summer), and a tour guide book is useful. Definitely recommend when you feel confident - getting lost and working your way out through browsing and trying to navigate. Allow plenty of time for this kind of trip. Some amazing sights, smells and experiences to be had. Plenty of water required to hydrate, but many shops sell it. Be prepared to be targeted by locals especially the ones keen on getting their hands on your cash. This is a 3rd world culture (so we are seen as having money). However, a majot benefit of Morocco (Marrakech) is it's very close to home (UK), yet guarantees the weather unlike travelling into Europe which can be a longer flight and weather still unpredicatable. Bear in mind Marrakech is a City so no beach here yet a trip to Essaouira (pronounced 'essa-weera', or 'es-Sweera' in Arabic), on the West coast and about a 2 hr drive away, is well worth a visit/stay. We stayed here in Feb 2009 for 4 nights, having driven in a hire car from Marrakech and located accommodation with ease unplanned. I could say more and will another time as got to go out..............TBC.......

Fascinating place to people watch. The streets around the square are numerous and it would be easy to get lost. I didn't find the quality of most items around this area to be very good. It is very touristy and poor quality but it is very cheap too. It depends what you are looking for. I bought things at Menara Airport and Jardin Majorelle Boutique as they were so much better quality and more original. But it is a fascinating place.

This is why you come here.. Buzzing, lively and full of the expectation of the Moroccan way. You'll get hassled to buy, have some banter, you can always walk away but you may be chased. Always something going on and at night comes alive and has outside food stalls with larger than life characters (watch Jamie does Morocco on you tube). You can buy all you want here and stuff you didn't know you wanted. Restaurants are all good as far as we could see, and just have a great time...

Enthralling. like a beautiful bellydancer Djema El Fnaa creep under your skin and take you prisoner. It's as beautiful and enchanting as Aladdins magic lamp, your wish is her command. Prepare yourself for a holiday like no other.

Just as described!. The square is a must-do in Marrakech even if it can be stressful at times! There are men trying to get you to buy their wares, pose for pictures, drink their juice. And fully veiled women literally grabbing you for henna tattoos! The orange juice is amazing and a great break from the heat. We actually saw a cobra charmer and walked away from so many people trying to sell us things.

A must see in the Medina. Hassly at night but a must see. Great to sit in a rooftop café with a mint tea and watch the action. Also a useful reference when you get totally lost - head back here and get your bearings again !

Must go day and night.... day time visit - very quiet, no atmosphere, I was thinking what is all the hype about this place? Night time visit I got why people talk about the place. The sound, the atmosphere, drums, smells it was interesting to see something so different that I'd never seen before. Yes there are ladies wanting to henna you up, the phrase I must have used 100+ times during my visit..'non, merci' and I was soon left alone. I didn't see any snake charmers though there was a poor little monkey being pulled on a chain that I wanted to rescue..
Definatlly worth a visit. Great big Square to wander around looking at basically everything! Lots of shops and restaurant to chose from and most attractions is around.

During the day, lazy cobras. At night, sight and sound overload.. During the sweltering afternoons, the snake charmers left something to be desired, and their cobras definitely seemed bored with the whole thing, but come nightfall, this fairly sleepy square explodes into all-out sensory overload. Lights, smoke, dancers, henna, grilled meats, strange teas, twirling fez tassels...you name it and it's there somewhere. Enjoyed wandering the Jemaa el Fna much more than I anticipated.

Monkeys and snake charmers galore!. If you appreciate different cultures you'll love this place. Where in England would you walk down the road and see monkeys on leads and cobras being charmed by a man with a musica instrument!

Jemaa el Fna, still good but lost some authenticity. Early July, we visited once again the great Jemaa el Fna place in Marrakech. More food shops (fixed now. They don't build up anymore every day) and more tourists. Less original, as for the souks.

Horrible. People were rude, too many beggars just an absolute hassle to go there. People chase you for money and it is just not worth the effort, if you want to relax and have a nice time, DO NOT COME HERE

One of the wildest places you've ever seen.. Honestly, if it wasn't for the occasionally pushy to groups who stand still sellers, this place would get a 5. From snake charmers, monkeys on chains, all kinds of spices, people selling everything and bargaining, stalls with escargot or lamb spleen, you'll wonder if all this is legal. However, more importantly you'll be delighted in the non-Western format of how presentation with souks and shops occurs here. Enjoy yourself and take it in.

A happening scene. Really comes alive at night - vibrant, noisy festival like atmosphere. Regardless of time of day, watch where you're walking per the snake charmers and monkey handlers. Also, consider that the "henna" tattoos may have other toxic components mixed in before committing to getting one.

Chaotic Culture Shock. The Square is Massive, crowded and a real culture shock - with people everywhere hawking thier wares and shouting at you for attention its intense! We didnt appreciate the hand grabbing and physical contact to get you to buy or look at the shops and stalls etc but this is obviously the way they've always done business. I was ambushed in the evening by two ladies armed with Henna and I was very upset with their conduct grabbing my hand and putting the henna on (badly) dispite my protestations (Avoid talking/acknowledging the women more than the men as they are persistent!) overall the square was easily navigated and the side streets ended up melding together but just aslong as you check your bearings you should be fine. Dont accept help from the locals as you will be hassled for money and regret it! Dont be intimidated and hold your ground!
Nice attraction to be done once. Once you are tired of the crowded market, have a fresh juice as you watch snake charmer and donkeys (but be careful of the cone-men all around...

Great orange juice, shame about the snakes and monkeys.. You'll go whether you want to or not if you are in Marrakech, it's impossible not to. It's best at night and probably from one of the expensive restaurants overlooking it.It's a great experience and the Orange juice is the best I've ever tasted. I really disliked the treatment of the snakes and to a lesser extent the monkeys but it's something you have to accept I guess.

Busy, busy, busy.... Great and lively place. Don't let lakes grab your hand and make you do henna and watch out for people literally throwing monkeys on you and then asking for money, even if the monkeys are so cute :) and finally - best orange juice, ever!!!

An experience but not that pleasant. Glad we visited but I was very disappointed the square is in a continual state of chaos with small motorcycles continually weaving around walkers. Whilst in the square you are continually pestered by people either trying to sell stuff you do not want or begging for money. On the way to the square we were befriended by a man who would not go away turned out he was just after a small donation and was not happy when this was refused. I am glad that I visited and experienced it but would not be in a hurry to return, too much of a culture shock.
Don't go during Ramadan. When I was there, it felt empty. I know it is known for having a unique atmosphere but there wasn't much happening. I would love to visit here again but not during Ramadan.

Bustling tourist centre . Didn't go at night but I've heard that's the time it's at its best, but even in the day it's a bustling tourist centre with hawkers and people trying to entertain you for a few dirhams - snake charmers and monkey handlers. Our favourite bit was to watch all of this from the surrounding rooftop terraces before absorbing it all in wandering around with amazingly fresh orange juice

Night and Day. You need to visit the square both during the day and late at night; it is as if you have visited 2 totally different places. During the day, the square is relatively quiet with a small number of people.At night (after 22:00) the square lives up to its reputation as "crazy" as it is filled with people, sites, etc.It is a necessary visit when in Marrakech.
Cheap and good food.. A must try. The square comes to life at night with countless stalls selling very cheap and very good food.

You have to see it by day and by night. . It's two completely different scenarios. By day a lot of hot during summer and by night there is more life. Be aware of the Hena tatoos, don't let them take your hand because they will ask for money. Also the monkeys. We ate in one of those stands and it was very nice. As always you have to negotiate the price an always say 4 time less for what they offer.

One of a kind. We traveled during Ramadan so of course during the day it was slow and pretty empty. However its sheer size is impressive it would be a site to behold during high tourist season. The square had snake charmers, monkeys to hold and take pictures with, Henna artists, OJ vendors and of course your souvenir shops. Again due to the religious holiday the restaurants were pretty bare yet still open. Highly recommend dinning on a terrace of a restaurant off the square and watching the goings on.

Least favourite part of our trip: full of scams, thugs and poor quality products. I always trust a local's opinion, and everyone we spoke to advised against buying any products on the square as they were 'third grade quality' compared to the markets elsewhere. On the two times we visited the square, we were harrassed by peddlers, including one that grabbed my hand to paint henna on me by force, and another that grabbed my friend's arm and pulled a monkey with a dirty nappy onto him. Not cool. Aside from the random aggressive woman that yelled at me for taking a photograph of the square (she thought I'd taken one of her face and wouldn't stop screaming abuse even when i showed her the photo) and the beggars that kept touching us no matter how often we said thank you or no, the only highlight of the square is the tables in the centre that serve grilled food. We recommend table number 31 and try the grilled mutton. Otherwise, avoid this square or just walk through it.

old value tradition market great for haggle!. huge markets are fantastic everything u could buy and best to haggle, especially ornage juices are very fresh tasty. and breads are amazing nice taste yummy. some dancers and singers, include snake out of the basket! very old tradition. it was 2007.

Interesting. Lots to see. People very friendly. On the outskirts of the square there are snake charmers and men with monkeys, as an animal lover I was not impressed, however the stalls of fruit and spices were impressive.

"A Square like no other". When in Marrakech you must visit the Jemaa el Fna. The Square is located in the center of the Medina and accessible from any location within a five minute walk when staying inside the Medina. The place becomes alive at night and the energy it's fantastic. Here you would have an opportunity to experience the local customs, food and entertainment.As mentioned the city becomes alive with story tellers, henna painters, snake charmers charming their cobras, musician, etc... If possible have a nice dinner at at the many restaurants with open terraces facing the square.

Must see. Jemaa el Fna at night is an absolute must see. The square just comes to life with locals, tourists, food, jugglers and music. Tradition and modern life combined. Recommend grabbing a drink on the rooftop terrace of one of the surronding cafes to watch the square come alive at sunset and afterwards join the people on the square for dinner. Walking past the food stalls can be a bit annoying as every stall has one or two people chatting up the passer-bys, but everyone stays friendly, especially if you just smile and say "maybe later".
A must. Somewhere you have to go. Went a few times and in the evening during Ramadan it was an incredible experience
Vibrant place. allow yourself to emerge in the crowd and feel the trading temper Arabic way. Take care about your belongings and possibility that some "tamer" put a snake around your neck.

Do go if you like animals. Don't drink the orange juice. It sounded interesting on the internet, but I did not like this place. Don't take picture of people, especially the berber who dress up in colorful clothing without paying. There are a bunch of horse drawn carriage waiting to take you around for a charge. I feel really bad for the horses. Most have bad arthritis with swollen joints. I don't think their own care. The monkeys are chained at the neck and jerked around. If you plan to go to Jemaa el Fna, put aside your compassion for animals. All my friends that drank the orange juice got sick that night. When we got back to the hotel and was asking for diarrhea medicine, the concierge told us that people get sick all the time drinking the oranage juice. Glad I didn't drink / eat anything uncook their.

A real experience of traditional Moroccan marketplace chaos!!!. We visited here twice. The first time with a guide and the second time without. I would definitely recommend not using a guide. They tend to direct you to the higher priced stalls/shops deep within the souks whom we suspected they had prior arrangements with. The square is easy to find anyway and we found the second visit far less stressful and were able to enjoy the atmosphere and visual displays more. Beware though, if you pause for too long to admire or wonder at anything you will soon find a snake or monkey being draped over you or your hand being decorated with henna...for which you then have to barter a deal for something you didn't ask for in the first place. The smells of spices and argan oils create a unique smell within the square which will both delight and confuse your nostrils at the same time! Plenty of cafes around the square to sit and enjoy a chilled glass of water or mint tea. A must visit and a real experience to take back home with you!

Must See. Come to this square at night. In the middle is street food (for tourists). All places looked about equal, but stand #117 cooked their lamb perfectly and made dinner an enjoyable experience. Around the square I would also recommend trying the snails. Aside from food there are many vendors, musicians, story tellers (in Arabic) and magicians. Day or night, you can also sit and drink tea while you people-watch. The crowd is a mix of tourists and locals. Take solace in knowing that the square has always been like this - its not a contrived attraction, just one who has slightly evolved.

A real Morrocan experience. Fascinating place to watch from a restaurant balcony. Be careful as you do get hard sells. My 2 daughters got conned by 2 women for getting henna done and they ended up paying well over the odds. Can be quite daunting until you get used to it

Better in the evening.. This square is a mixture of things. While its a bit touristy, it still feels like it is very much at the heart of traditional Marrakech life. Certainly worth seeing. it comes alive as the sun goes down and locals come in to enjoy the food and entertainment.

Madness!!!!. I enjoyed my time visiting here and yes it is absolutely bonkers but not in a bad way. Full of people and yes most of them are trying to get your money one way or another but just chill and don't take it too seriously. Enjoy the food at the stalls (number 15 is good) but they will pile everything on your table (at a cost of course). Watch out for the Monkey men who will literally throw the monkeys at you and then charge you 300 dirhams and the henna ladies that jump you and start painting you before you even have a chance to say hi. To avoid this grab a drink at one of the many cafes and sit back and people watch and take loads of photos. Don't forget to haggle when buying anything its all part of the game, even with the taxi drivers that will try and rip you off. Most of all have fun.

Crazy bit of culture. Lots of things to see - stallholders selling allsorts, food stalls with very tasty wares, snake charmers, monkey handlers, the list goes on. Food was good. Need to be careful with your camera - people always want money if you take a photo. A must see, but there are so many places to go I didn't spend a great amount of time there. The roof terraces are good to have a drink and see the spectacle from above.

Awesome Experience!. This is truly a unique square. You walk through the Souks and end up in this big area that seems like a carnival without the rides. So many things going on. Snake charmers, horse carriage rides, monkeys, shopping, the post office, restaurants and food stalls. You have to haggle shopping for clothes as well as the stall they want you to come eat. Its a funny sight. The best is the snails stall. They are hot and yum. This place is great! A must go!

marrakech madness. crazy, smelly, full of hustlers, see it once and move on and do not eat here, it is a spectacle and a feast for the eyes, but nothing of value to purchase, just people watch the crazy antics and move on...

The only place like it in the entire world. I've lived in three continents and travelled many countries and cities, and have to say that Marrakech is along the most vibrant, unique and most entertaining without one having to do anything. Its hard to describe it, were to start with the square performers, the pure orange juice sellers, the markets, the hustle and bustle, the transformation in the evening, the aromas of different foods, the noise of all those pushy salesmens, the familys, the friends, the couples and then the locals & nationals, man its too much to describe. All I can say is if you want a world experience make your way down to this place.

awe inspiring. we visited jemaa el fna while in morocco during the day there were lots of people about, there were snake charmers and story tellers and people singing and playing instruments who got you putting hats on and joining in the fun i thought it was great we decided to visit at night time to see what it was like well it was fantastic there was food stalls selling an array of things that smelt and tasted delicious i did not try any of the delicacies i am not brave enough but the locals were out enjoying all there was to offer like the story tellers i was stood transfixed watching and listening i just wish i knew what they were saying those who did were laughing if you go visit day and night for a truely moroccan experience you wont regret it.

Once is enough. You see it once you see it all, the hawkers selling there wears pestering every individual sat enjoying the sites.The hassle from the horse and trap drivers and the acrobats with there cap going around the audience who didn't ask for the show.It's too touristy and it takes away the ambiance that was once thereWhere did the tourist police go as it feels like you need to be wary now at every turn.Go once and then avoid for the rest of the trip!!!

A must see!. The square is a bustle of activity with traders trying to sell you everything! At night the atmosphere is great. There are many places to eat around the square as well as the stalls in the middle, beware of eating salad as this is washed in tap water! The square is worth a stroll around

Unlike anywhere else. Unlike any other place I've been the noise the smells the banter from the stall holders, Tesco prices, the man selling false teeth though I'm sure he makes more money from tourists taking photos. Truly a magical place.

Don't believe the hype. In all honesty this square is extremely over-rated. During the day time it has some stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice which is delicious and very cheap, but probably best avoided if you have a dodgy tummy like my family & I had. When walking through it you are constantly harassed by women trying to do henna tattoos on your hands. They grabbed both my daughters and started drawing despite us all saying No. In the end we had to pay €20 and €15 for two awful tattoos which my girls hated. Then you are up against the snake charmers who walk up to you and try to put snakes around your neck despite you telling them a firm No and walking in the opposite direction. The worst thing we encountered was guys with poor monkeys on chains and dragging them around to catch tourists for photo opportunities. The monkeys were trying to hold the chain to stop the men from pulling them too hard. It was horrible cruelty and I can't imagine any decent tourist paying these people. At night the square is cleared and all the food sellers come out. They set out little cooking areas and have tables, seats where you can eat very cheaply. We were totally ripped off at Stall 34/118 and had a horrible experience (see separate review). We spent 5 days in Marrakech and this square was our least favourite part so would only recommend that you visit it once or twice purely as an observer - a very shrewd one at that.
Okay. if you want to buy Moroccan things the place is good. At the night you can See snakes and roosters doing tricks

afeast of sights and smells. I love this place there is a lot to see at night there are berber/arab musicians, dancers acrobats, always entertainment, also there are tarot feaders, snake charmers, monkeys and people selling false teeth there is no place like it.It is good to sit in one of the little cafes overlooking the square and drink moroccan whisky (mint tea) and people watchThe food smells lovely but would rather eat in hotels or restaurants for fear of upset tummies. If you visit the souks make sure you barter with them and pay only half or less the price they are asking for they are quite agggressive sellers so beware

Mesmerizing!. There is so much to see day or night!Don't like the snake charmers or monkey people but the rest is great to just wonder and take in the atmosphere.At night the place takes on a mesmerizing quality with drums and acrobats and the amazing food sellers.Must try some and enjoy the experience.

Take care and enjoy. Wandering round it is safe as the police are there to make sure of your safety and stop excessive hassle.Have a glass of orange but you will be offered blood orange which is more expensive than the prices shown.If you take pictures of people you Will be asked for money, so be firm because whatever you give is never enough.Get good photos by having a cup of tea in one of the overlooking caffes, much better view.

hmmm. average, not a highlight in Marrakech. just a place to see/ i would spend my time in the palaces and souks but not on this tacky square. However, lunch or dinner in a nice setting overlooking this square, is quite an experience!

Great shopping and cultur experience. Visiting Marrakech cannot be complete without a shopping trip around El Fna. The souks the market it is just great to experience. But you need to be pacience, don't get irritated by the traders young and old trying you to get in there shop. Shop at your own pace and relax, in the end the know you're not in for a change of plans. Brows smell and discover, there is still beautiful stuff to bring home, but you need to source carefully. Just enjoy this melt pot of business, heat and crowd. This is Marrakech.

Thousand and One Nights. The Jemaa el Fna is simply mystical and at dusk the closest you will find to a Thousand and One Nights setting. The one place where live storytelling and the oral tradition is on display alongside snakes, monkeys and the traditional water-porters. If you are squeamish about the treatment given to some of the animals, don't go as it may be too hard to watch. On the other hand yo will miss a lot of other events and scents. Warning: don't try to take pictures without paying for the privilege.

Essential Marrakech!. Wild, exotic and unlike anywhere else on earth. By day this huge square is relatively quiet, with licensed carts selling freshly squeezed orange juice at around 25p a glass (amazingly delicious!) and a few traders selling hats and belts. By night the food stalls appear - snail broth, sheep's heads, and unrecognisable delicacies that the locals seemed to be enjoying. Go at dusk and watch the square come alive with snake charmers, transvestite dancers and gambling. It was intimidating and alien, but I covered my head and used the no eye contact "non, merci" you have to master if you're not going to get scammed in Morocco. The storks circled above us and the caleches (horse drawn carriages) moved through the crowds of people. Total sensory overload, but unforgettable and unmissable.

A Marrakech 'have to'!. The centre of Marrakech and a must visit place for every traveller I think. I'd been warned about crowds so visited in the morning when it was quiet. I was fascinated by snake charmers but avoided the exploited monkeys. I returned at night to see the square come alive with friendly street food vendors and circles of people listening to storytellers - interesting in any language as they each had a partner to act out the story! Be wary near the henna tattoo ladies unless you want to find yourself grabbed by the hand and blobbed with henna - they re quick and persistent! I loved the busy chaotic vibe but was almost disappointed it wasn't more so as it didn't quite live up to its reputation!

Tourist place. Ok, this is definitely a place you will go to if you visit Marrakech but other than going there and roaming around I would not recommend. The food you can eat in the evening is just average and extremely expensive compared to what you can find elsewhere

Tourist trap, but a must see at least once when you're there.. Very busy, full of salesmen trying to sell you anything possible. Unfortunately they all carry one of the four big types of products so you're just wading through a load of the same crap. Restaurants are there plentiful and trying to lure you in with a promise of the best food of the market. Just go there once. For the bucketlist. Or sit somewhere around the square on the third floor when the sun goes under.

An experience!! . The market in Jemaa el-Fnaa is crazy!! There are many traders in the center of the market all looking for your attention. Be prepared when going at night! The traders in the stalls are a little pushy but by no means intimidating. It's the ones at the entrance to the market you have to be aware off. They are a little more agressive towards you. They will all approach you and try to get you to buy/take photos or pet their goods/animals. The snake charmers are the worst..... stay well away. These men are overly agressive and look for large amounts of money if you take photos or express any interest at all. The best way is to just ignore them completely! Don't be a push over either... stand your ground and don't let them take advantage. Don't be afraid to say no and walk away. The same applies to the street performers. ... If you don't want to pay then don't express any interest. Haggling is expected.... don't be afraid to push it a little to get the price you want. ***TIP,dont get a taxi in the square itself. Walk to the outskirts and get one from there. Always agree your price first and try speak a little Arabic or French(they are generally more receptive if you make an effort)

Loved it !. you will see tones of stuff and things to buy in a square . From fruit to tooth :) you can drink fresh oranges, eat yummy pastries buy incense, herbs and tea. lot of entertainment but be careful if your going to take pictures try not to let them see you or else give them some money cause they will not let you go for free :)loads of ladies drawing henna first they offer it for you for free then if you tip them 5e they will start complaining and asking for more money and will not let you go if you don't give them less than other 15e.

Intersting hustler experience.. Interesting experience! Full of beggars and hustlers!Visit it in the evening. Next day we wanted to have breakfast and this hustler got on our back and showed us the way through narrow streets where we got stuck in our car. (Don't go there by car!) We said that we don't need anymore help and even gave him a tip which he refused to take. Then we started to trust him thinking that he really is a good man and he lead us to some place where everything was expensive. Of course, we said no and then he showed his true face and demanded 50 MAD (about 5 eur) from each (we were 5 people)! Taxi driver helped us park in narrow place and didn't take money as well but when we returned he demanded money and stood in front of our car until we gave him 5 or 10 MAD. :D I was really pissed!:DWhen you're in Morocco, ask the people if they are arabic of berber. Arabs are really out of control bold-faced and rude! Berbers will lay back if you say a strict "no".

I was underwhelmed. I found this place to be disappointing. I expected many stalls of spices, handmade artifacts and street food. True they were there but in such an agreesive and sometimes abusive environment. The many stalls seemed to have homogenous goods with their owners shouting at you to come in, look, buy, where are you from. I found that I couldn't stop and look, particularly at a food menu without being harrassed and physically man handled towards the stall. Lots of poor animals on chains with owners insisting on you having your photo taken with the animal. Be careful taking photos, some people don't want their photos taken which is understandable. Others will insist that you pay them to take their photo. You're going to visit here anyway so just be careful!

Extremely Exhausting. As we`ve read the food corners and booths should be very good here, and we love tasting the traditional cuisine, we wanted to have dinner here. But it has been a unique running of gaunlet. For me, I would love to have time to choose on which booth I want to eat, but no chance. From everywhere staff comes and tries to catch and to convince you. We`ve taken then booth no. 1, as in that moment, it was the next. Food was not good, french fries tasted like fish, couscous tasted very boring and olives too bitter.

A very busy and interesting place. A vibrant and very interesting place to experience. As with any busy place, keep your wits about you and don' t try to photograph anyone unless you are prepared to hand over money to them! Everyone seems to be trying to sell you something but if you don't want it just be firm and walk on. You will get used to it - you get past one seller and walk right into another!Plenty of places to eat and drink soft drinks - there are not many places in the area that serve alcohol although there are a few.

good fun. lots of snake charmers, people with monkeys etc all after your money. Good atmosphere though restaurants round the square are medicare and will not serve you a beer. Beware of stray cats everywhere if you eat here - go for a rooftop view.
I wish I hadn't gone there. Not my favorite place, I didnt feel safe, and people harassed me a couple of times, poor monkeys and snakes leading an awful life so that tourists can take photos

enchanting. You must go in the day and again at night. Two different places  Be careful of the souks it's easy to get lost so don't panic and always ask shop owners not people the street better still look up there are a few signs and try to remember where you are walking A bit daunting at night I would stick to the main streets it worth the visit or two to get your bearingsBe careful not to take pictures unless you want to payWatch the traffic it comes from all directions and is most entertaining Must sees are the mosque remember to cover up x don't go off with tour guides you will be taken to shops for the hard sell x

A Sight To Be Seen. I've always read about this place so had to visit to mark it off me bucket list. I'm glad we came. During the day, there is an assortment of traders selling bits and bobs and the charmers. We heard stories of the snake and monkey charmers threw them at you then demanded money but we saw nothing like this although we did avoid them at all costs.Come dusk, the place changes into a huge food palace. Lots and lots of traders beckoning you to come and eat at there stalls. We did not eat at any of them, only because we are not into heading sheep's heads etc!. We did however drink several glasses of orange juice which at 4 dhirams a glass works out at 25p. It is sweet and very refreshing although we were advised that it is watered down. You can tell the difference when you have some at one of the many restaurants that overlook the square. The guys beckoning you into their stalls are very polite and friendly with plenty of jokes, all to be taken in good spirit. If you are in Marrakesh, do not forget to visit this place. You'll love the hussein and bussle.

Dirty Tourist Trap. I did not enjoy my visit to Jemaa el Fna. It was huge, dirty and had too many animals that were clearly poorly treated. Horses that were malnourished and whipped by the drivers, were being used to drag overweight lazy tourists around the Medina. Monkeys with chains around their neck are made to jump on unsuspecting tourists for photos. Hundreds of shops in the alleyways selling the same thing - slippers, bags, etc. I have experienced it, but not keen to rush back. Other amazing things to do and see in Marrakesh in my opinion.
mesmerising. a step back in time..a must visit for anyone..some of the traders are a little over powering particulary the monkey trainers but otherwise all very very good

Trade all around. In fact all Medina is like a large open-air market but this place concentrates everything. Even if you do not intend to buy anything it is worth to walk through narrow streets of this site. And surprissingly in a majority of cases sellers are not annoying, they do not approach you before you show interest in something. And bargain might be a joy if you try it. It is so difficult to resist buying local spices. And traders are really good in telling every little detail about their goods.Only thing we found annoying are ladies offering henna tattoes, and those really are of bad quality.
1001 night. very charming square and lots to see and taste, worth visit i will go back, and back again an again!!!

Sensory overload. It's a good thing.. Walking through this square anytime of day there will be activities, people selling their wares or the snake charmers. In the evening, starting around 530pm, the square starts to come alive with vendors of every kind offering foods, fruits, dates, feasts of all kinds. The square becomes a flurry of activity along with all types of noises, music, singing, etc. You really do not know which way to look first. What a unique experience. This square was also featured on Bizarre Foods.

Very hot and then Very busy .... pAs mentioned in the title, it is really hot during the day and not so busy (even more during Ramadan). But after 5pm it starts... I would recommend to go after 9pm and see the activity from the terrasse (always the same tip, but it is nice!).

Unmissable, raw human nature. The best and the worst of us humans in this chaotic square.Street food, market stalls selling everything, absolutely anything you can think of. Smells of spices, colourful kebabs, snails, moroccan sweets...Wander around, it is worth seeing how human race has managed to split us all, between those struggling to survive and those who watch how others struggle to survive. Felt generally safe, sometimes amused, sometimes saddened... But after all, happy to hace visited such a place. Recommended no matter what.
