Only missed dining at one of the rooftop restaurants overlooking this labyrinth.

Some great musicians here, but extremely touristy.. In my opinion the square and it,s near surroundings are very touristy, almost(not everyone) everyone wants to fleece you. There are very few places where you can get a straight answer, prices and general directions etc. Even taking a photograph can be real hassle. Saying that there are some great musicians playing music in the area, but be expected to get hassled, it,s difficult get to a alcoholic drink in the Medina, but almost every other Moroccan wants to sell you Hashish.
a 'must do' experience. Fantastic location both by day and especially by night - it's a full on experience which stimulates all the senses

Got to see it, eat nearby for sunset, then get out.. This is the tourist trap of Marrakech. There are drugged snakes with charmers, monkeys on chains, people selling all kinds of basic things (hats bangles sunglasses watches) but nothing traditional or exotic. They force themselves on you, grabbing your wrist, or worse my gf's wrist and pulling her away from me. One example was a henna girl who grabbed my gf's wrist and in seconds, chanting "gratuit, gratuit!" Had done a haphazard henna on her hand, and then a group of them appeared refusing to release her unless I paid them. Lost all faith in Moroccan people.

Interesting but.... . This is definitely an interesting place. It has thousands of souvenirs is that a tourist would be interested in. I would recommend you go to the glaciers cafe panorama terrasse and have a look at night at the place of El fna from above

A must is the sunset over amazing square. We experienced the quiet afternoon in the square..but it's all about coming alive in the evening at sunset... It's total chaos...food stalls.. musicians... snake charmers...everyone should experience it..at least once in a lifetime!!! awesome...

Craziness. Enjoyed visiting this place during the day for sweet fresh orange juice and during the night for eats at stall number 1 ... No stomach bugs after after eating there twice. Also lovely mint tea 2 stalls away. Nice people at the mint tea stall too. Unforgettable experience and really cheap too.

Interesting Chaotic. We went to the square early evening to watch the vendors set up and the sunset from the roof of one of the buildings. Well worth the visit as there was so much crazy chaoticness to see!Snake charmers and poor monkeys (didn't like that part), make shift boxing rings (about 5 of them by the time we left), street vendors, food vendors, shops and more....Loved watching the place come alive as the sun set and as the bustle increased. Definitely something to do and see.

Mystical at sunset. A group of 10 of us headed for the square and sat in a cafe to watch the sunset and dusk fall upon the square.
It really does come alive at night.
This evening we will return to eat there for our last evening

Best at Night. During the day, it is quite overwhelming. There are people, stalls, and animals everywhere. People with said animals will try to get money out of you, so it's really best to ignore them. A looked at some monkeys on chains and before I knew it, the man who owned them put one in my arms. It was sad the amount of animal cruelty there was. For shopping, I'd say try your luck in the souks instead. The square is really amazing at night when dining tents are put up. You can get a meal for two for under 10 euro and the food is really good. I know it might seem like unsanitary street food, but that dining area was one of the highlights of Marrakech. There's also freshly squeezed orange juice that I recommend too.

A busy square that changes from day to night. In the daytime you may see fortune tellers and snake charmers and various people selling something. However be careful of taking photographs unless you want to pay for taking them. The people showing various acts will chase you afar if they see you taking photographs. This is how they earn their living.We never saw any snake charmers when we went here because they are in the square in the daytime.At night tons of kiosks are set up for food preparation and you will find a huge variety of foods to try. Many of them have seating in front of their kiosk.There are other items to buy such as spices and many other things.Children may try to sell you gum or a trinket. We've seen many squares but this one is a little different because it's in Morocco.

Local life always on, day or night . What else can be said about it other reviews haven't already said. Sure impossible avoiding it, the true heart of the Medina, it failed to impress us as much as other fellow travellers. Being there at night or during the day with all the pushy vendors resulted in a weary experience. We only had orange juices a couple of times. Animal wise a bit of shock yet a place with a vibrant touch not to be missed. We felt pretty safe and able to fend off unwanted attention.

What next ???. Well worth a visit, sit in one of the cafes and watch the enjoy the life go by. watch the snake charmers do their tricks, enjoy the delicious coffees and ice creams, and barter for your presents to take home. this is what its all about, enjoy it !!

Noisy and aggressive sellers but fun. Even the orange juice, dry fruit and water sellers all are prepared to hard sell their wares, shouting or running over to you and start their sales patter The noisy "music" acts, sellers, ect are not photogenic and get really aggressive if you try taking a pic. Either you need to pay them or seek permission and begin the stress of haggling in fact haggling for anything. The food sellers will block your way if you hesitate and look for a second or two.its noisy, mad, but interesting especially at night.

Verry nice. This is a great place to visit and there is allot to see and eat ,you can easily spend there half a day but beware of the people with the animals,before you know it you have a monkey on your shoulder.

Overhyped. As Indians, we're not too impressed with snake charmers, spectacles of other sorts and rows and rows of kebab stands or fruit juice ones. Other tourists might enjoy this a bit more. The only reason the Jemaa was useful to us was there were signs pointing its direction in the medina, which helped us get our bearings and figure out our riad/ destinations in relation.

Nice enough square, but the food stalls can be overwhelming. The square is lovely, and lively. The best part are the orange juice stands, a glass is only 40 cents, and so delicious. During the day, it's not as crowded. I got a really fantastic hammam scrub and massage at Le Cinq Sens just right there. You will love it! At night, the food stalls are open. Get ready to be accosted in a friendly way by the young guys that work the food stall as they try to get you to eat in their stall. The food is all the same of course. It can be annoying after a while, so walk on the outside, then go inside once you decide. The performers also want €1-2 for each picture of them that you take, so be prepared for that too. They have spotters, so don't sneak it as they can get confrontational. The stores are cute, they sell colorful souvenirs and shoes etc. it's nice for one night. It needs to be experienced. I enjoyed it. Oh yeah..count your change, somehow they always try to shortchange you after you agree on a price :-). It is quite a safe place though.

Animal Cruelty everywhere you look. I travelled to Morocco with my boyfriend in early June of this year. We stayed in the Palmeraie district of the city, just outside Marakkech Old town. I was aware that the locals used horses and donkeys as their livelihood but nothing could prepare me for what I witnessed when we got to Jmaa El Fnaa. Monkeys being dragged around with chains wrapped around their necks, Donkeys and horses being forced to cart tourists around that weighed far more than the poor animals themselves. Constant and brutal whipping of the animals in clear view of the tourists, one example of when one Man stood next to his horses and just whipped them as hard as he could, the poor things screaming in pain and trying to get away. It was a scorching hot day (40 Celcius) and I didn't see any of the horses offered water or shade, I personally witnessed a cyclist collide at full speed with some horses and the poor things being used as battering rams for cars, trucks, lorries etc. to push themselves through busy traffic. Blatent and barbaric animal cruelty. I would insist that anyone with any ounce of compassion or empathy towards animals not to promote this business by riding one of the carts, or even visiting this place. You can't get away from it, from the minute you enter Marakkech until you leave.

Must Go, But Avoid Buying and Eating (That sounds weird to write). Seriously, you're in Marrakech, you obviously have to visit Jemaa el Fna, the world famous open market.But you don't have to buy anything directly in the market, I suggest going to some of the shops just beyond the market for souvinirs. Plus, the food, avoid it. What you'll notice is that barely any local people are eating at them, and for good reason. Do yourself (and your stomach) a favor and do better research on top restaurants in Marrakech. Finally, pictures. If you start taking pictures, be prepared to be harassed to pay the person you're taking pictures of. If you're listening to music in a big circle, someone will ask you for money. If you don't like being harassed, this area is not for you.

Entertaining. Can pick up great souvenirs & food. I highly recommend trying the food, esp. The grilled options. It's very entertaininb too. Be aware as tourists, they all want your attention so learn to say no, other than that it's excellent

Overwhelming, but fun. Culturally amazing, snake charmers, whirling dervishes,(don't make eye contact or take pics or they will expect money) and food kiosks that set up every day. All of this surrounded by restaurants. ,Overwhelmed by the street level happenings we chose a second floor restaurant to view it all. It was so different from anywhere I have been- a must do in Marrakech. (hint: get a guide approved by your hotel so you aren't accosted by vendors and street people)

Too hassley.. The square is regarded as a good focal/starting point for foraging out from or getting to. However take out a map/ satnav at your peril. If you stand for more than a few seconds you will be set upon by people " who are not " guides, who are students of English etc etc. Gets very wearing. That said it is a worthwhile visit but just keep on the move and watch out for taxis that come from all directions.

Must see. On one of the guided circuits around the medina, this place is a must see. I was surprised at how little we were hassled compared to our visits to Fes, Meknes and Rabat. The only thing that let it down were the plentiful displays of animal cruelty which I found to be quite upsetting.

Hasn't changed in 40 years. I loved this main square when I first visited Marrakesh in 1973, and the lively array of local entertainment has not changed. Keep in mind that this was not designed primarily for foreign tourists; it came about to entertain those coming from the mountains in the region, travelers from the south along the trade routes and others from north Africa. There is never a dull moment in the square, but it really rocks after dark. Don't miss it. This is one of the best squares in the entire Arab world.

Overwhelming the senses. This is quite somewhere to visit, in the heat of the afternoon it is staggering to enter this square after being in the souks, it is very drab in the afternoon but really comes to life as the evening and night progresses. During the day you will have people offering animal photos for a charge, this I found off putting because all the monkeys had diapers on, and it is very very exploitative of the animals. At night you see Sufi mystics dancing and playing music alongside places to eat and drink juice. I found the evening easier from the heat but more overwhelming for the senses.Keep in mind Morocco is an Islamic nation and as such dry (you can get alcohol if you visit the modern town and tourist hotels and maybe with a meal in some places) I would suggest finding one of the rooftop terraces, sip mint tea and watch the night market.

One of the coolest places in Marrakesh. I could stay a whole day in this place and I'd still be able to find something interesting to do or to see. At first glance, it seems a great confusion. But, give a chance to locals conquer your attention. Always bargain, even with food.

Souks are better. Well - don't know but I found the Souks much more interesting as this place! The restaurants much more expensive as the little ones inside the souks and even changing prices as higher up you sit (terrace prices are different than ground floor). We just went for the last day as we haven't been but to be honest ... could have left it out without any regrets. Much more like the busy souks and the little rooftop terrace restaurants than here. BUT ONE THING DONT DO HERE .... don't get a henna tatoo. Did one and mostly disappointed about it. The ladies under their umbrellas promis you the world and the tatoo will held up to 15 days. Mine one was already mostly gone after 2 days and it never ever looks good after the henna paste has gone. Very disappointed about this. Spend rather a a few Dirams more and you will have a good one. Mine just looks like I haven't washed my hands for a while. Also did the women increased the price from asking up to paying from 20 to 50 Diram. I was really p... off. A NO NO here.Certainly interesting to watch the snake charmers .... would say that's it about this place.

Crazy!!!!. You could not go to Marrakech and not visit the square- it really comes to life at dusk onwards. There are snake charmers, monkeys, street food and the list goes on!!! Watch your bag is zipped and keep your wits about you as before you know it you'll be paying someone for something you don't want!!! Unmissable though!

A Must. No trip to Marrakech would be complete without a visit here, and its a great central spot to get your bearings around the city. Do try and visit the square during the day and in the evening as its two different experiences, during the day its much calmer you can see much more clearer how the square is the heart beat of the medina , how the souls operate and its not so easy to get lost, by night the square explodes into a kaleidoscope of colour, the open air restaurants start up, the square is fully of dancers , musicians, all sorts of street entertainers , the henna tattoo ladies, circus shows and vendors selling the most bizzare items I have ever seen. However all of these people have one goal, and that is to relieve tourists of their cash, so be careful of taking photos as many insist that you pay for the privilege , and of course the square has its fair share of pickpockets. At night the tourist numbers must increase by 10 fold and quite frankly its bedlam.

Sums up the entire City best described using 2 words, one being "hole". Marrakech has been for many years the boho/chic city of choice for many and believe me all girls will have seen many articles of expensive boutique hotels and exotic things to do which women seem to really go for. These could be fine if you have a tonne of cash (see caveat 1) and I mean a tonne in gold at least. Caveats:1. Money: Basically if I had a tonne of gold to burn on a holiday I would go somewhere nice for starters. Marrakech just isn’t nice. Burn your hard earned in nice surroundings. What the glossy mags show and what is reality are poles apart and this is an extreme example of that;2. Hustlers: It has millions upon millions of hustlers and they will get aggressive at some stage;3. Tourists: It has millions upon millions of tourists cheek by jowl and you will get aggressive at some stage wishing to kill the offensive hustlers trying to sell you garbage at prices 10x that of London;4. Tat: They are always hustling the tourists and the souk (meaning market) is Africa’s largest souk selling exclusively tat/garbage/tourist trinkets and all at exorbitant prices. You get hustled even for breathing;5. Rip Off: The cost of everything is more than London even after haggling. London here I live is expensive but not as expensive as this hole of dirt;6. Food: The food is merely “OK” but far better in any western city that I have been to. You are highly likely to get very very sick if you eat anything in this city. Frankly I can cook better. The best restaurants are an absolute joke apart from the bill which is like swanky London;7. Drinking: Hard to find anywhere serving alcohol and is usually at rip off prices.Marrakech may have been nice once. It is a dump now and absolute dump and it depressed me how awful it was. I did some nice things but I have to look very hard. AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

Overrated and nothing special square. During the day you will find way too many orange juice stalls that add sugar water to the actual juice, few odd snake charmers, some henna tattoo ladies and then beggars and people offering you guides etc... There is just absolutely nothing special.. I was then really looking forward for the night on the square... I was disappointed to find few circles of people dancing and singing, beggars, some lame game of catching soda bottles and the henna tattoo ladies... There was the promised 100 stalls of street food, except wait... 30 of them offered exactly the same brochettes and grilled meat, other 30 offer exactly the same fish fast food and the rest 30 offered all the same soup and or sheep... Then odd empty ones and 4 offering snails... So it is actually only choice between less than 10 different stalls... All the hype about this place is absolute rubbish. I cannot understand what the UNESCO world heritage people saw in this place... If you happen to be in Marrakech do check it out as you will pass by anyhow... But do not make a special trip to Marrakech just for this..

You can't go to Marrakesh and miss this place!. Full of life, food stalls, street performers, horse buggies, snake charmers, merchants selling everything and anything, souvenirs. It's so lovely to just pick a terrace to sit and watch the Marrakesh world go by. Try to eat the sheep's head (Bouzellouf) and other delicacies, you can down it with some mint tea.Only downside is really the hassle to buy this and buy that. if you ignore you'll have a great time. I can't wait to go back!

Great fun. Absolutely fantastic. Very busy, lots to see and do, different smells and sounds. Try the freshly squeezed orange juice off the stands. Make sure you agree a price before taking photo's of the monkey's and snake charmers. Enjoy a cold drink in one of the many rooftop bars and take in the atmosphere - try this both day and night as the difference is amazing. During the day the space in the square is taken up by snake charmers, little stalls selling traditional things, women doing henna. As the evening draws in, the food stalls open (which you must try), and the delicious smells fill the air.

Hectic!!!. A must see place, one of the most famous and hectic square in the world.Is like diving backin time, story tellers, snakes charmers and foodstalls are the main attraction but just sitting in one of the cafe watching the world goes by is an experience not to be missed.By night is when the square becomes alive with a great mix of locals and tourist.

Great fun but busy !!!. A must see in the day and the evening. Evening has hundreds of food stalls serving all kinds of delicious food cooked right in front of you. The square has snake charmers, entertainers. Beware they try and charge you for taking a photo. Enjoy the fresh orange juice. If you don't like hustle an bustle then it can be daunting.

jemaa el fna. This is fantastic. There is so much to see here.Did not like to see the men with the monkeys but otherwise it is great with the snake charmers and stalls.The sound and atmosphere is great. I travelled with my mother and we felt totally safe all the time.

No trip would be complete without going here. A must when in marrakech. The square is very busy but especially worth a trip at night when the food stalls, musicians and snake charmers are in full flow. You need to keep alert as everyone wants to 'help' you and offer you something. Be expected to pay. A snake charmer saw us taking a picture of the square which they might have been in, asked us over then took our picture and then asked for a lot of money. We gave them a lot less than they asked for and moved on. We also ate in the stalls. The brochettes were freshly cooked and a good meal. There is a lot of competition in the food stalls. The sights, sounds and smells are an experience and i would recommend the experience.
Better enjoyed from a distance. If you enjoy large crowds and tourist entertainment, go. If not, just have a peek. I enjoyed this square most from a balcony, looking down onto all the mayhem.

Interesting cultural experience, great orange juice but food a bit bland. You cannot visit Marrakech without spending a lot of time in the Jemaa el Fna! During the day it's more quiet but at night crowds of people - more locals than tourists. There are snake charmers, dancing monkeys, carriage rides, men in traditional costumes etc so lots to see. Lots of hawkers and ladies doing henna. The orange juice stalls serve delicious freshly squeezed juice. This is all my Moroccan friend would have but I ate at the food stalls twice and was fine however the food was bland and the price the same as eating in one of the restaurants in the alleyways surrounding it.

Is this really the main attraction of Marrakech?. Maybe after reading all the great reviews on here and hearing from friends I had high expectations but I am shocked that this is the main attraction of Marrakech.Yes the fact that there is so many people in one space at one time is an experience in itself but other than a big open space with the odd snake charmer, monkey handler, henna tattooer, and more orange juice stalls than anyone would need, there's not a lot more to it. Personally I didn't enjoy having my arm grabbed and having henna done without requesting to do so, nor did I enjoy having to constantly dodge men putting snakes, monkeys, and smelly traditional hats on me for the privilege of having to pay to remove them.Some of the stuff on the markets are interesting, but this soon fades upon wandering further into the souks, where everything is identical to the previous stall and the diversity of goods is non-existent.I would advise a visit so you can say you've been and who knows, you may love it, but my suggestion is to go in with low expectations and if you're scared of snakes/don't want to catch rabies off a monkey, stay WELL away.

Buzzing with life all hours of the day. This square is like no other that I have ever experienced. There was something for everyone to see, eat, smell, touch and taste. It''s up to you to decide how much you can take. I didn't get a chance to eat in the square as my timing was always off but the food stalls looked very enticing. I carried my money in a body bag and always felt safe. Make some time to wonder around and absorb the cultural life of Marrakech, you won't be disappointed at all.

Got to be done. Amazing World Heritage Experience - Just has to be done at least once during your visit to Marrakech. Noisy and bustling but safe and friendly! Great place to grab a cheap but delicious meal. Sadly there are monkeys on chains and snakes in baskets all waiting to be exploited but I guess that's to be expected. Sardines to die for and great fun deciding where to eat. Just make sure you're undercover in case of a thunderstorm!

Beautiful Square. Ancient square full of food stalls and orange juice. Always bargain don't pay what they ask, square full of snake and monkies shows and people doing show of dancing. Henna decoration for cheap price. Lots of things you can enjoy there.
Just great....the best atmosphere.. It's a wonderful place. So full of noise, fun, food and atmosphere. And at night it is ablaze with the aromas of the bbqs and outdoor eating places. Go there!

Jemaa el Fna is Magic and the Heartbeat of Marrakesh. An amazing place where you can listen to music and see snake charmers. Go at night. It's the best time for people watching. Marrakech feels very welcome to tourists! I loved it and want to go back. Make sure to try the orange juice...heaven in a glass!

Is this really the famous square??. Like most visitors of Marrakesh I had heard and read a lot about the square which is a must see in Marrakesh. Well, I would not say I was thrilled to see it. Yes, there are some music bands, you can have pic taken with a monkey or snake, you can buy orange juice at the numerous carriages. But what is so special about the square? I am afraid I have missed the point.

Worth a visit. We stumbled across the square in the day and was dead but we went back in early evening all it was heaving. We did not eat from the stalls as not that brave but had a walk around and saw all the entertainers such as snake charmers, fully clothed belly dancers etc. Surprisingly we did not get hassled other that a few women trying to sell henna tattoos but we just said no and they left us alone.

Not sure what all the fuss is about.. Considering all lanes seem to lead to this place we were disappointed. Went back at lunchtime, morning and late evening to see what we were missing. Aggressive snake charmers, hags trying to tattoo us, some water sellers and no promised acrobats. Not to mention the terrifying monkeys and emaciated horses with no water to drink. The food market in the evening is good and the mountains of snails are impressive as is the atmosphere there. However when you stray away from the lights of the stalls it is dark and a strange mixture of people trying to sell you drugs, beggars and a bus playing dance music. Still a good place to get a taxi elsewhere but agree a price before you get aboard.Overall it seems like it might once have been full of mystery and magic, but now it is a tourist trap and not a fun one.

Out of this world. A must see place, see it to believe it
Snake charmers, souk, food clothing, incredible place and next to Koutoubia

Marrakech identity. Its the best place to know Marrakesh! And its not only touristic as most people there are local spending their time watching the musical presentations, performances of all kinds... For a tourist, mainly in the first contact with Marrakech, its a lot of information there, a thousand things happening at the same time, but after a while, you start to capture interesting things! I recommend spending some time there, just watching!

Very atmospheric. The very heart of Marrakech, this square is not to be missed. We visited the square twice, once at early evening when the food stalls were starting up. There was a great atmosphere then but I think it would have been better later when people were buying from the food stalls. What I am saying is that it is great to visit any time but later in the day is probably best. There are plenty of cafes around the square where you can go up to the first floor, if you buy a drink, and look down on the square which I enjoyed more than anything. I took a video on my camera and playing it back here in England seeing the sights and the sounds makes me very nostalgic.

Great traditional place full of locals and tourists alike.. This is a place you absolutely have to see at dawn-night if you go to Marrakesh. It is perfectly safe, and it is full of locals enjoying the street food and street attractions. Just keep in mind that almost any interaction with the locals will be followed by an expected small payment depending on what the interaction was. There are people with monkeys that you can hold and pet and take pictures with, for that you would pay about 20-30 Dh (about 2-3 USD). There are also people doing street performances or selling stuff. They will always ask for much more than they expect to get, so you have to haggle. To get back to your hotel, again, it is better to haggle with the taxi driver, and to agree on a price before getting on the taxi. A fair price for the ride if you are staying in the hotel area is generally around 30-50 Dh (3-5 USD), but of course they will initially ask for more: if they don't budge, you can walk away and look for a different taxi.The rule of thumb is: ask for the price first, then haggle until you get to a fair price (keeping in mind that they will initially ask for much more than they are willing to sell it for, generally about 3 times, sometimes up to 10 times more), and then do the transaction and pay for it. If you accept a service before agreeing on the price, you will pay much more than necessary.

In the heart of the action. I LOVE the Jemma el Fna. Loads of fun - madness all around. Monkeys on chains (wearing nappies), horses & carriages crossing your path, Berber women selling baskets, crazy juice sellers during the day then at night it all changes - eat at one of the stalls - you'll be assailed at every turn by lads trying to entice you into their stall (even if you've just eaten) and when you finally choose, there are barbecues going on all around, skinned sheep's heads, friend aubergines, harissa sauce, harira soup and lots more to tittilate your tastebuds. Couldn't be better as far as I'm concerned. Yes, of course it's not that clean, nor is it without hassle, but gird your loins and GET IN THERE.
Brilliant. Lovely people, great stall. Couldn't believe the transformation from day to night! Loved every minute of this holiday.

Exotic. I'm baffled at many of the negative reviews of Jemaa El Fna. You really need to adjust your expectations and be open to immerse yourself in the atmosphere. If you come here with a shiny DSLR around your neck, walk at a snails pace and give money to every beggar and trader you see then of course you're going to have a bad time. Come here for the experience. Get lost in the winding alleyways and just observe how crazy it gets and I guarantee you'll bring back fond and unique memories!

Crazy fun.. Ok this place is an ambush on all your senses but fabulous. Great for shopping haggling and eating out. Some amazing places to eat and drink around the Square. The Souks are fabulous and you will find some lovely helpful and friendly shop owners. The square is chaotic. Be firm but polite. Don't have eye contact or photograph unless you want to engage or buy. Especially Henna artists and the monkey Handlers. A polite and firm no Thanks you and walk on by. Watch your hand bags and dress respectfully and you will have a fabulous time. I love it there. :)

Jemaa el Fna square. It's vast and always crowded but not very special. Everyone tries to attract you or sell you something for a very unreasonable high price and if you're not careful you'll be bankrupted. For example bargain and fix a price before you touch something or take photo with someone (like snakes). The normal price to have a photo with snakes in 40 DHM but if you don't fix it before they will charge you with 200!There you will also have the chance to get something to drink or eat.

hustle n bustle. When in Marrakech you have to visit here, by day a few ladies with henna, snake and monkey charmers and juice sellers - by night the place takes a different pace ram packed with stalls selling food and with you being practically summoned to eat at their place - we didnt eat here just took in the sights sounds and smell!!

Don't miss the magical sunset. It magical to see how the square is transformed when night comes. In about 30 min to 1 hour 97 street food spots are mounted to serve delicious Maroccan dinner and drinks. It's a special hour that happened everyday it's a must see on your trip.

Market by Full Moon! YES!. Day or night a lot of fun!! Stayed in a riad so we were able to walk at leisure to visit the remarkable atmosphere! It is all that your imagination said it would be...I loved it! Tourists and local families sitting side by side eating, laughing,and enjoying their time out.Step out of your comfort zone.....GO!

Exotic Place to Visit!. We visited Jemaa El Fna in May 2015. Really interesting place to visit especially at night. We were there twice the week we were in Marrakesh, on a Tuesday night and a Friday night. Fridays the place is packed with people. Many interesting things to see especially the dancers. Be careful to ask before taking a picture, it might cost you a pretty penny. Have something to eat in the eateries. Orange juice is awesome and cheap. If you shop you might find a treasure as a souvenir at a real good price.

a feast for the senses. the square comes alive at night with dancers, music, acrobats and food stalls. The atmosphere is amazing with a festival feel that is lively and vibrant without being intimidating,partly i think because everyone is sober so things didnt take on the mindless aggression that crowds of drunks can slip into. By day the souks are great. If you dont mind lengthy, often sociable and good humoured haggling then you will have a great time shopping.Be warned, the Morrocans are master sales people and will employ every technique in the book to get you to buy something you dont want for a price greater than you are willing to pay,dont be intimidated or feel bamboozled ,just get into the swing of it and stand your ground,a good bit of ruthless haggling on my part earned me many a handshake,rather than causing offence.Please dont have your photo taken with the monkeys,they are not treated well and without the participation of tourists ,hopefully this will end.I travelled with another female friend and felt safe day and night.I was relieved as i had read that it wasnt the safest place for female travellers to be.A trip out into the mountains is a must,a cab really isnt that much ,and unlike bus tours you can stop where you want along the way.

Crazy . Nothing beats the crazy place that is Jemaa el Fna. Crazy yes but a good crazy; you can spend hours sitting around watching the place come to life; from the stall holders in the early morning to the drum beats of later evening. The best way to enjoy it is to chill out and go with it; yes you will meet lads wanting to shine your shoes and yes you will meet guys trying to sell you watches and sunglasses ( umbrellas too when it's raining ) but remember they are only trying to earn some money and will usually accept a polite " no thank you " - no need to disrespect them, they need to eat like everyone else. You can't go to Marrakesh without visiting the souks; leave your map in your room ( probably not acurate anyway ) and just walk; part of the enjoyment is getting a little lost, don't worry, there are plenty of people around who will gladly point you back in the right direction and if you need to give someone 10 or 20d then in the scheme of things that actually isn't a lot. Enjoy
A must see. A definite place to visit - very busy and a bit scary with the snake charmers. At night it is very exciting a theatre/circus combined.

Crazy place. Returned a few weeks ago and still fresh in my memory is the noise, sights and smells of "the big square".This is one for the bucket list, just don't be scared by the banter of the food sellers.

Disappointing. The Jemaa el Fna is often cited as the main attraction in Marrakech, but my partner and I found it quite unimpressive. The market stalls are not as good quality as those in the rest of the medina and don't have the same level of character. Further to this, the atmosphere is somewhat tainted by the regular cruelty shown to the monkeys which are tied up for the amusement of tourists. Perhaps worth visiting, but the markets elsewhere in the medina are probably a better way to spend your time.

Madness! But a must!. A must visit both day and night if you go to Marrakech! It's absolute madness but at the same time calming in a funny sort of way. Always something to look at and always some where to eat, and a rooftop restaurant is nice retreat to overlook it all and there are plenty of them.The souks/stalls are abunandant, the trick is to try and not make eye contact if your not interested but a polite no thanks with a hand gesture always did the trick. The food stalls in the night is a must, they are not really excellent value but the experience cannot be missed, nothing is complimentary either so if it's put in front of you without ordering you will end up paying for it!Overall it's great, never once felt unsafe... If you look like your lacking confidence etc they will pounce on you so you have been warned, but they won't bloody harm you! A truly cultured place which should be on everyone's bucket list!

Madness everywhere. This is something you have to experience... crazyness every second, monkeys calling you, noise, music, every 2 seconds someone calling you to buy an orange juice, to take a photo with a snake, with a monkey, with men dressing in a traditional outfit, to buy hats, to get a henna tattoo, to buy some oils... it is crazy but enjoyable, on our first day I felt kinda uncomfortable but after I got used to it. Keep and eye on motorbikes they DONT stop they just beep the horn so you have to move.

Mystical and unique. Wonderful street food and street entertainment at its very best, vibrant colours and smells, try to ignore the begging children with their big brown eyes they are usually working for gangs, all in all a must do when in Marrakech
mad marrakech. night market a must see also market in daytime and souks but be careful of traffic motorbikes in souks can be dangerous

Fascinating Bedlam...........until you look closer.. We stayed as "out of towners" at the Palmeraie so dipped our toes into the chaos whenever we fancied after short taxi rides into Marrakech. Not for the faint hearted, and if you are an inexperienced traveller, you may find many of the practices and goings on quite abhorrent...... until you look a little closer. (I'll explain later) Mostly I take things as they are, and respect the culture of the locals, especially if it isn't directly affecting me, or not to my personal taste. We went for the "vanilla option" on our initial foray and wandered around the touristy bit, haggling, enjoying the deals and following the "international haggling formula of course", looking at all the snake charmers and story tellers and henna artists. A few cups of tea/coffee at various locations around the square, (not missing out on a freshly squeezed orange juice- absolutely sublime!) Back into the fray more haggling. Then escape out of the madness for a glass of vino at the hotel.On following visits late afternoon and night-time we realised there's a rhythm to the place. Everyone has an area, the hawkers come round like clockwork, the police patrols just as regular, the street beggars on a circuit too. Then the nightmarket foodstalls are cleaned off and scrubbed and assembled in the square, and then there's puffs of smoke and the food market becomes alive. Even if the light is failing you cannot fail to find it due to the smells of cooking wafting everywhere.If street level is too much for you, make your way up to the rooftops and the cafes and restaurants overlooking the square. We stopped at a few but the best view and mint tea and coffees and fruit shakes we had was in the Brasserie Aqua, and in my estimation the best view of the square, great service and a good friendly chat.Leaning over the balcony, removed from the hustle (literally) and bustle of the plage, you can kick back, enjoy the view over the rooftops, never seen more satellite dishes, and the watch the world go by in the square, the only thing I've ever seen in my life that's similar is an old Attenborough documentary about bees in the hive, passing signals, interacting and generally buzzing about. (sorry.)A must do when visiting beautifull Morocco, we will be back.

Center of Marrakech. This is the center, a great atmosphere! Also called the "big square" so If you get lost just start saying big square and people will point you there. So many orange juice stands and food stands, plenty to shop for, monkeys, snakes, and a great taste of culture!

Array of sights. Jemaa el Fna is an area bursting with sights. An array of street traders, like snake charmers, henna artists, souvenir sellers, traditional clothes wearers for photos, horse drawn carriages for tours, etc, line the square, sometimes a little pushy, but don't be deterred, a stern refusal tends to win the day. Be careful of high prices, so be prepared to haggle the price down. There's no shame in that. At the entrance to the square, there's a wiff of horse "leftovers", but that's to be expected. The square is a busy meeting and gathering area, and is even more attractive as the day develops. There are many food stalls, both in the centre, and on the fringes of the square. The smells, and sights really bring out the flavour of Marrakech. Be weary of food stall waiters literally dragging you into their stall. Be patience, and make sure you negotiate the price. There are loads of these guys, though pushy, they are quite friendly, good natured, and charming. Enjoy the whole experience because it is a real treat. Enjoy.

Fascinating!. One cannot visit Marrakech and skip this place! Go in the late afternoon so you can see the daytime situation and also the more lively evening situation. In the afternoon, you can see the snake charmers and the monkeys. There are also some food options and souvenirs. You can get a henna tattoo. Then, once the sun goes down, more things happen, including the setting up of the many, many "restaurants" where you pick fresh ingredients and they cook them right before you and you eat there on picnic tables. I was particularly fascinated by the snake charmers; however, I did think their pushy tactics running towards folks who took a picture demanding money were rude. It made me nervous. I told one up front I wanted to take many pictures and video and that I would pay him. That was the only way I could have any peace. I'm not a big fan of people who think you owe them just because you took a picture of what they're doing in a public place. Anyway, you cannot miss this place!

Buzzing and interesting !!!. This place does what it says on the tin !!! During the day its a thriving square with lots of hustle and bustle, but at night it's a different ball game.The smells and sights are totally amazing, but you will be harassed to death. If you think your in for quiet evening stroll forget it.The locals want a piece of you no matter what, . but try and stay calm, enjoy the experience and smile. This is a totally different culture but the people are friendly and hospitable Just try and take it all in as its over in a flash!!!!!

Busy square, great in the evening. A market/souk/cafes/town square. Doesn't really come properly alive until lunchtime/afternoon when all the food stands get going and it gets really busy. Great place to spend a couple of hours eating and drinking and watching the world go by. Don't miss out on the street food stalls in the middle of the square.

This is quite horrible . Rarely have I come across such a nightmare!I see nothing attractive about monkeys chained up so stupid tourists can have their photos taken with them. I don't see the appeal of snake charmers abusing their reptiles for the same reason. This is a smelly, ugly square populated by aggressive Arabs preying on idiot foreigners who passively condone animal abuse. During the day it's depressing and swealthering, at night it's just mayhem. All of the cafes are sub standard and expensive, the hygiene is foul. I think it's a nightmare. Crosby Stills and Nash have a lot to answer for!

Interesting. Good to see and experience smells and sights. Avoid henna ladies. They will be nice to woman at first and then try and put a henna on woman( some ink is poisonous) didn't like the monkeys on chains. The poverty is evident and quite saddening. The haggling is good fun but why are quite rude once they have made their sale. If your going to Marrakech and done your research you know what to expect

Hustle and bustle . Whether by day or by night this is a thriving square with plenty of atmosphere. By day as a woman you will be enticed to get your body beautifully decorated with henna by the women. You can see an array of orange juice stands, merchants with various wares who seek your attention for a chance of selling. Bartering can be fun if you know how to play the game so both seller and buyer are happy. By night I loved it, go and try the outdoor food spot. You can get spicy cinnamon tea, escargot and I highly recommend #31 barbecue! Enjoy! we did.

Such an atmospheric place. Always so much going on; from the music of the snake charmers and other street entertainers to the market stalls the atmosphere is amazing. Be aware of the actions of some, and it is the minority, but a polite "no" always seemed to work for us!! The whole square changes early evening with the food market starting, the smell is so good :-). A lovely place to be; do be careful of some locals but make sure you enjoy every visit to this square.

Much more exciting at night. Having read other reviews before our trip, we knew that we would have to visit both by day and by night.At night the food market comes alive (not open during the day at all) serving all sorts of local delicassies including sheep brains. It is a riot of colour and excitement as, somewhat like covent garden but a little more atmospheric, in the square performers gather crowds around them, Please note, if you take a photo you are likely to be pursued for a tip, and all those we saw had performers speaking in french or arabic.Meanwhile by day there are a few snake charmers performing under umbrellas and fortune tellers, but i really wouldn't make a special trip to see it. It is likely you will walk through it or onto it whilst visiting the souks or the nearby mosque, so don't make a special trip

revisiting previous holiday site. WOW! overwhelming place. Hard to believe that it goes on day after day, everywhere so busy and such a lot to take in. Be prepared to be accosted ALL the time, with men asking you to look at their stalls and to buy stuff. Always the cheapest price, and always better than 'Asda' or 'Tesco's!'Great fresh orange juice and really good food in the evenings.

Unforgettable Moroccan spectacle.. This busy Moroccan square has changed little since I visited there in the 1970's. Lots of people milling about, vendors selling just about everything to attract the tourist. Snake charmers, musicians, dancers, boxers, pigeon racers and areas selling food and drink. Be aware that if you take photos, you may be expected to pay for the priviledge! Be also vigilant regarding pick-pockets and keep bags closed and secure.

GO IN THE EVENING!. Brilliant experience.Better at night, mingling with the locals the place really comes to life.Plenty of haggling for bargains.You WILL get lost in the warren of lanes/alleys, so you can get a guide to take you, but we just mooched at leisure & had a great time.

Big square. to many people the smell is awful the local always try to scam you with money not talk to anyone or you will and up paying 50 euro for something you didn't even want beware from snakes and monkey keepers not only they will charge you just for looking but they treat horrible the pets also pick pocket is regularly practice also too many beggers they are all over the place do not talk to anybody!!!

Day and Night. Look, this is Morocco, it is not a sanitised Universal Disney production piece, its dirty, its smelly it is a little crazy, utterly bewildering at times, but safe and rather a lot of fun. If you want snake charmers or a little neon dart, its all here, the food at night is good, the patter of the guys trying to get you to there stall is amazing, a feast for all of the senses.
Huge square with lots of everything. I was there during the daytime so it was not a mob scene. There were still plenty of people and stands and it is an interesting place to visit.

It was better than I expected ... but still. The riad we were staying at (Riad Maissoun) was practically right next to the Jemaa el fna so we spent most of our time there sitting in cafes people watching. Whilst walking around it your trying to take it all in and have a look at what people are selling but the experience is tainted by very loud sellers constantly trying to talk to you and get your attention and always having to watch where your going so that - 1. your not standing on someone merchandaise -2. your not knocked down by a horse and carriage/ speeding motorbikes ..which are everywhere -3.so you dont go near performers or people with animals to take pictures so they dont make you pay for something you didnt ask for -4. so you dont bash into people ( which there are plenty of ) and get your bag stolen. one of the women selling henna even came up to me and grabbed my hand and she wouldnt let go .... and at that stage i was getting quite cranky . its a bit overwhelming at times ... as well as being uncomfortable. At night it does look very pretty ... but i wouldnt recommend bringing younger children here it would just be chaotic, im a teenager and at times even i felt intimidated and didnt want to get lost and was very conscious of being stolen from. But one tip is to actually have a look if you can at what the people who are coming up to you in cafes/restaurants are trying to sell to you ... i got la vie est belle which is usually 80 euro for 30 euro and it was perfect condition/quality ... :)

You gotta do it but ..... Great atmosphere- a real coming together of people
Stalls brimming with food - steaming escargot, broiling meats, snake charmers, musicians, pickpockets - you have them all here
I frankly didn't have the guts to eat the street food so it wasn't really all that much fun
Ok for about 30 minutes or so

Impressive square. Jemma El-Fna is the heart of Marrakech, go there at different times and you'll see how it metamorphosises. Especially at night, you'll have a unique contact with real Marrakech life.

impressive at night, but watch out for your wallets. a very busy square, specially at night. be prepare to have loads of coins in your packet because everyone will ask you to pay: for a picture, for watching snakes. they will try to sell you everything for a "good price". also at the night where people are gathering to see performers, be careful as loads of pickpockets are out and they might steal your goods form your pockets. I personally didn't like it as it was too crowded, to many motorbikes passing by next to your feet, performers ( even if you didn't make any eye contact) were coming to me, grabbing my hand pushing to take pictures and then shouting for a "paper money".

Too many people trying to take advantage of travellers. I believe the booming tourism industry in Morocco has ruined Jemaa el Fna. The people here are way to quick to approach you and will stop at nothing to make a few dollars. You cannot even look at things in the square without people touching you and harassing you to buy something. We went here once and did not return. Definitely do not take any pictures as someone 500 yards away will come up to you and tell you you owe them money for the picture you just took. Stay away from the snake charmers as they will put a snake on your neck, demand you take a picture, and then demand a payment. Keep your money in your front pocket. If someone tells you a street is closed, they are lying to you, and are trying to get you lost, then they will magically "appear" to get you un-lost for a heavy fee. Would recommend seeing this place once and then moving on.

Charming but intimidating!. Its a charming little place with lots going on, lots of stalls, places to grab food, lots of orange juice makers, nice ice cream shops, snake charmers, monkeys on leads and henna ladies. Well first of all my partner literally had monkeys thrown on his shoulder which they make u take a photo of, then demand money! I was physically stopped and held by the hand to a lady who drew some sort of henna art on me, even though I profusely told her I was allergic to many things! She then reached to my partners bag to demand money from him! Its impossible to look and shop as they harass you to buy, and if you don't buy, one man in particular became very aggressive and unwelcoming. We would visit Marrakech again, just not here. But go for the experience!

Worth experiencing one evening. I'm not a big fan of places like this but it is an experience you shouldn't miss. It's loud and crazy. You'll get hassled at every turn. A fake snake may get put on you shoulders. A lady may grab your hand to do a Henna tattoo. Crazy! But it's the heart of Marrakech. It was fascinating to see, especially watching all of the locals participate in the action. You can watch it all from one of the restaurant balconies but it's not the same as a walk around. Go after dinner for the full action.

Not my cup of tea. This was not really my cup of tea but I can see why there is so much fuss about this place. I guess I am used to traveling to third world countries and used to the chaos and the hustle and bustle.
Amazing culture great bargains!!. Absolutely loved the atmosphere the culture the shopping everything! You can find everything you want for great prices. Remember always haggle!

Lots of people. Too many people in the square. An uneasy feeling when there are people ready to pick pocket you.Language is a barrier as they don't speak English, only French and Arabic.It's something new, seen this place only on TV now am able to see it with my own eyes. Unbelievable.

Vibrant!. The square came to life at night. It's vibrant! Experiencing the food is wonderful. Love the snails cooked in pepper and spices. Experiencing the food at the stalls may not be everyone's cup of tea because some people may find it unhygienic. Every stalls will have some one trying to get you to patronise their food stall. Just need to smile and politely say no will do. Travelled solo and independent and am woman I find it was perfectly safe at night to wander around.

You cannot loose this place. If you are in Marakech you must spent one night is this square. the square is a Unesco world heritage site. A wonderful atmosphere, very characteristic, with the possibility in the evening to dine local dishes...but being honest the price you pay is for turist, much higher than what you pay if you go eating same things in the restaurants around the square, all with nice terrace that let you look and live the atmosphere without being in the caos of it.

Worth Seeing Once. The best way to see this spectacle is from the balcony of a nearby restaurant. I would have liked an alcoholic drink but instead was brought mint tea, "Berber whiskey," at Cafe Le France. A guide on a 3-day, 2-night expedition told us that cobras are not naturally found in Morocco, but are brought in for the medina square. it's sad to see the monkeys in diapers being dragged around. Another bad experience was a woman who grabbed my daughter's hand and began applying henna without her permission. It is an interesting spectacle, but clearly has downsides for tourists that include beggars and persistent vendors.

Filthy health hazard. What an awful place, people trying to rob you everywhere you go, and trying to sell you pointless rubbish. Anyone who doesn't like snakes avoid this area as they try to put the snakes on you. Avoid the food too as it gets covered with flies. Beggars everywhere, really sad.

Colorful and exciting. Wow, what a place. Exciting, energetic, colorful, crazy fun. Heavenly oranges during the day, great food in the evening. Entertainment at all hours. Water-carriers in their outlandish costumes, snake-charmers, monkeys, sausages, soups and more oranges! Keep your wits about you and enjoy.

Unbelievable!!. If your in Marrakech you need to visit the square Jemaa el-Fna! Never have I seen such a sight. So much going on its hard to take it all in. The first night was pretty freaky but after a few visits we really enjoyed our time there.

Tourist trap. I wanted to experience the market first hand but I found it like running a gauntlet and the locals see europeans as prime targets and do not let up from doing the hard sell and you can be sure the prices are markedly inflated because they think you will pay over the odds ....... I found the treatment of animals hard to take - even the treatment of snakes ...... overall I escaped to the calm of a hammam down one of the side streets which was running the gauntlet again ...... however a bit more lightheartedly .....
Lovely atmosphere. There's lots of places to buy food and souvenirs and a lovely atmosphere in the evenings. I don't like the animals that are used for entertainment.

Scruffy pastiche for tourists. A tourist attraction that is now out of place and out of time. One can only have sympathy for the few remaining snakes and monkeys being "charmed" and exploited respectively. The souks sell the same old tat you find anywhere , at high prices. The place has a certain interest and the cafes out the sides are surprisingly good value for a tourist trap and the food and drinks pretty good. Once seen is enough.

very lively place. Probably like any other popular market in every city, but still there is some special vibe in the air.. Very busy market, teaming with people who master different crafts.. Always ask for a lower price because you would be amazed by how little you could pay for things if only you tried harder.. You could be harrassed by people who work in the shops so make sure to be super patient.

A square constantly in motion. This square, in the Medina of Marrakech, is almost never silent. In many ways it's a natural "entrance" to the souks of Marrakech. At daytime, it is like a market place with snake charmers, music from flutes and drums, new smells, crowds of people, ladies asking if you want a henna tattoo etc. Try the orange juice which is sold at multiple locations here!In the evening, lots of food stalls offer you different kinds of local food, in addition to entertainers dancing and playing the drums. Be prepared to get requests from most of the food stalls as you are walking past them. We had no problems after eating here, so I recommend having dinner here at least once during your stay, while absorbing the atmosphere, sounds and surroundings. This square has an exotic atmosphere both at daytime and in the evening!

The Drums. The Snakes. The Monkeys. The Oranges. NO - It's not a Band!. It's Jemaa el Fna. The Big Square. La Grande Place. The place to be whether you want to or not. I take you there... Big Square Yes? Small Fee? Probably not.All roads lead to the Big Square/La Place/Djmaa el Fna. Even some roads that don't. We realised this once we left our Riad as everybody tried to direct us to the square or even better take us there for a small fee (or was that the Small Square for a Big fee?). Best advice for anywhere in Marrakech - know where you are going. Take the map your hotel will have given you. If in doubt a shop like an art gallery or similar will give you honest directions that won't take you to someone's brother's riad/rugshop/spiceshop - you may have to browse for a couple of minutes though. Once you reach the square, the sounds of snake charmers horns and the smell can be quite overwhelming. Some people find it less than charming, especially during the day, but like a moth to a flame, I was drawn in. The square is quite amazing - we saw snake charmers with flutes, and drums blaring, monkeys on leads (really?), people walking around in colourful costumes making more noise, henna tattooists dead keen on marking up clean skins (with or without permission) and of course, the ubiquitous orange juice stalls. These are a must - just 4dh a glass (about 40 euro cents) what a steal. At the moment Marrakech is in the grip of an early season heatwave with temps in the mid 40s, so we did a lap and headed back into the souks - they are covered and considerably cooler. We returned later in our Marrakech stay to see it by night (last time we saw it was a couple of years ago). We headed along when dusk was falling and the square was coming alive(er). The food stalls were all spruiking like crazy - look out for a laugh at No. 13 - "We have pool, air conditioning and 3 year no diarrhoea guarantee!" - we weren't there for food, just the atmosphere. Smoke in the air, hypnotic drumming, snakes, monkeys, henna, and the sun setting and sending rays of light up behind the clouds - quite magic actually.

Do's and don'ts!!. In Marrakech - follow these tips and u will have a great time!Prepare!Prior to your visit in Morocco apply for a halifax clarity card, as this provides you with free cash machine withdrawals. The currency booths in the airport have very long queues and are very bothersome. You also get a much better rate withdrawing straight from the clarity card. we got 15.7 DH/GBP when locally 14.7/GBP was the best we could find. Brush up on your French, as knowing the local lingo will provide you with better opportunities. Download the offline version of trip advisor, it has an excellent map of the city. Download the Google translator app.Download the currency converter plus app.Do's:Aeroport/airport. You are required to complete a passenger form when arriving AND departing, these can be found in the terminal. There are NO cash machines in airport, we asked our taxi driver who drove us to one.Pre-arrange an airport transfer with your hotel/riad..Getting around: don't be scared and use the bus, although it is busy, it is very cheap and costs 4 dirhams. We used it daily as do the locals, often we were the only tourists on the bus! Which was a novelty.Most buses end at jeema el fna, ask your hotel or riad if you are not located in the medina which bus number you need to take. Haggle with the taxi driver BEFORE you get into it. Pay 25-30 dirhams in the day maximum, be firm.if u choose to travel via taxi (make sure it is a petit taxi -Peugeot and Dacias- for 3 passengers or less) be prepared to haggle, if you don't haggle they will charge you lots of dirhams. The most we were quoted was 80 dirham in Gueliz. We managed to get the price down to 40.Grand Taxi's are more expensive and are double the price of a petit taxi, these are normally older Mercedes cars. Fnaa Square:Keep an eye out for Katooba mosque, very tall pillared building, this means u are near Jem El Fnaa square if your struggling to find it. Eat at number 32 (Hassan) in Fnaa square, lots of international people eat here as well as locals, we recommend a big sausage meal and the mixed kebab. You can have a veritable banquet for the price of a McDonald's back in the UK. You will find Hassan with huge plumes of smoke that come from his BBQ we ate here without any problems at all. Afterwards, Sit in a terrace cafe to take in the view/atmosphere. Terraced cafes are usually 25 dirhams per person entrance fee which includes a drink, you can try haggling and some are successful although we weren't! The view is worth 50 dirhams to see sunset over the square and kotouba mosque.Haggle in the fnaa square in the day time, it is a lot quieter and less pressure. Only show interest/browse if you are actually buying. Haggle 1/4 of the price they start off with. Be firm and to seal the deal by walking away,...give them your best price...., your only price.We were given a starting price for a large leather bag at 1500 dirhams, my partner got the price down to 300 dirhams!!There are Many cash machines as u enter the fnaa square. We recommend visiting the square at least 3 times to get to grips with it all as it can be quite intimidating at first. Visit the KFC opposite the fnaa square for some air con and respite. Be aware that the locals see white folk/tourists as a huge walking dollar sign, it is a big game to them so do not be taken advantage of. Walk with a purpose and take the bargaining in good humour, realistically you may only be arguing over a couple of pounds but it will be a huge difference to the locals! If you are buying something have a look and decide what you're prepared to pay and barter from there! Don't:Drink the orange juice in the fnaa square as it is watered down and will make you ill, (it wiped me out for 1 whole day!) Do not make eye contact with people who are trying to sell you henna, monkey and snake photos as they see that as an opportunity to lure you in for a photo and then ask you for large amounts of money. Work out before how much u are willing to pay, we paid 100 dirhams for cobra/ snake photos even tho they wanted 300, Just pay when you have had your photos taken and then firmly walk away. Obviously if you don't want the photo don't approach, we thought it was quite novel and worthwhile. Don't follow a stall holder to his 'factory' down the alley ways. Try to stick to a wall in the medina, if you have a good sense of direction you will be okay. If not allow a few hours and you will pop out somewhere, although it may not be where you started. Do not let the taxi driver take you to his friends shop, be firm about your end destination. For info, Petit and grand taxis do not have air con.VisitsGet to Jardin Majorelle early as it is popular and gets very busy inside. Inside you can find the gardens revived by Yves Saint Laurent after he purchased the site in a state of disrepair. The colours, plants and architecture are a real testament to design and you should allow a couple of hours to soak in the atmosphere. At the time of writing there was an excellent Berber display in the museum that is well worth visiting even though it's small, we found it fascinating. The total cost for museum and gardens is 75dh per person. We were recommended to visit the palaces by an Australian couple who we met but unfortunately we did not manage to go.

Exotic and touristy all at once. It's so sad to say but: keep your interactions with the locals to a minimum. It is not dangerous but they are all after your money and sending you to someone in their network (where they get a percentage of your purchases). They will lie, tell you "Dont go there it's closed", pretend they are guides, will want to help you find your way, etc. Get directions from the staff at your hotel, from your phone, from people you know... Having said that : it is a fantastic experience. But dont let your faith in humanity fool you! :)
Great ambience. Great experience, not for the faint of heart or PETA activist though since treatment of animals is really poor here.

A crazy wonderful place :). Musicians, magicians, water sellers, "dentists", snake charmers, henna tattooers, all kind of crazy happy people walks in this square. At night the movida is absolutely fascinating. Keep your bag closed, and enjoy the music, the colours, the atmosphere. It will be unforgettable.

A thousand years of nonstop outdoor theatre. Everywhere in the medina leads to the Jemaa - even when you want to go somewhere else. It is like nowhere you've ever been. Like going back to biblical times but with motorbikes and taxis. Keep your wits about you and walk with confidence and ignore people who attract your attention as far as you can.

Magical Morocco. Such a wonderful experience , don't be put off by what you hear . We had people try and sell us hats watches lunch , etc but as soon as you decline their offer they politely leave you alone. No one oversteps and it is an atmosphere that is undescribable in words. Truly magical. The smell of fresh nougat and the leather and the orange juice all mixed in with the heat and the friendliness makes it an experience you will never forget. Go now! Or regret it forever! We loved it there

Eye-opener but READ MY HINTS AND TIPS!!. This place is quite an eye-opener, especially at night. The place is buzzing, filled with market traders, food stalls, snake charmers, musicians, and so on. The food is very cheap indeed, and good value for money. I stayed here for four days and didn't get any tummy upsets, so don't be afraid to try the cuisine.The few things that did disappoint and/or anger me, are:WALKING THROUGH THE SOUKS: These are a maze of avenues filled with stalls selling everything from leather goods, wooden ornaments, spices, shoes, and so on. However, the constant hassle from the traders is tiresome. Us Brits like to walk around shops, picking up items, inspecting goods and generally having a good nose, but the minute you show any interest in any of the wares, you end up being hassled. And the traders will try and sell the goods at a silly price, so go in at one-third of what they ask and hopefully you'll meet in the middle.FRIENDLY 'GUIDES' - On the first day, a chap zoomed up to us on his moped and said he recognized us from our hotel. So as not to be rude, we shook hands and spoke. This was a mistake. From then on, he was like a limpet, and he ordered us a taxi to the kasbah where obviously he had friends with a herbal pharmacy who tried to rip us off! In the end I gave him 100 Dirhams to leave us alone (about £7), but it was worth it. He even lied to us, saying the souks were closed - and they weren't we later discovered, as they never close! In a way, I am glad I had the experience as it gives me something to remember, but I felt angry that he hoodwinked us.THE TANNERY - this is worth a look, even though the place stinks. However, again, we had a 'friendly guide' who said we couldn't go round it without one, and at the end wanted 200 Dirhams (about £14). And he took us into the 'cooperative' shop there where again we felt compelled to buy things we didn't want. These guides tend to be your best friend until after you pay them, when they go quiet and disappear like a f*rt in the wind!BEGGING: There are a lot of beggars in Marrakesh. Each day I gave coins to a seemingly downtrodden person, but don't go giving to everyone otherwise you run out of money.ANIMAL WELFARE: If you're like me and love animals, you will see some sad sights. There are many stray cats that look like skin and bones, and the donkeys that are used to pull carts look slake with thirst. I also don't like seeing monkeys and snakes being used for shows.SHORTS: Some travel guides state that because Morocco is a Moslem country, that you should not wear shorts. Don't believe a word of it. Many, many people wear shorts there, including the locals!!
amazing busy square. allsorts of stands and restaurants here, amazing at night as it gets very busy with food stands and people, what an atmosphere!

the only place in Morocco that disappointed me. Marrakech is an amazing city and out of the ordinary, monuments and palaces to visit are beautiful and a must see. Very characteristic are the souks although we owr best buys, in terms of quality and price, were actually outside the Medina, in the new town, or on the way to the Atlas.The Moroccan people that we got to know during the trip was friendly and courteous and we spent beautifull days.We obviously made a couple of visits at the famous square of Marrakech, Djemaa el Fna, and we really surprised in a negative sense that this square was so praised by previous reviews and by travel stories. Even more we were surprised that this place enjoys the attention of UNESCO. If there was something traditional in this square I'm sure now it losts everything, it is more a concentration of swindlers and underhanded street vendors. I suggests definitely a step in the square to get to know all of Marrakech, but do not buy from people that animate it; I think it's the only place in Morocco that until now I have been disappointed in terms of discomfort and brutality of the people I met.

Carefully... Jemaa el Fna is the heart of Marrakesh, no doubt! It is amazing! But be careful to refuse anything you are not ready to pay for. Even if you just want to look at the amazing snake charmers or monkeys there is a great chance that you`ll have to pay for it. Like my friend wanted to take a picture with snake.. He went to a charmer and asked how much it would cost, but the man just put snake on his shoulders and took him to where more snakes were.. I started to take pictures with them. In a short while I felt snake on my shoulders as well and even though I immediately told him to take it off, it wouldn`t help.. After that we were both asked to pay for it and as I refused the snake charmer just squeezed the snake tighter around my neck! I said ok, I will pay just take it off, but I didn`t and the man was angry. He asked, I think, for about 80 euros from my friend and from me, but we ended up paying him 20 or 30 and even than the angry charmer was shouting as we walked away.. So my advice would be enjoy the market, but keep your eyes open and say "No" before it is too late :)

Heart of the action. The famous storyteller, who could still capture an audience some years ago is now gone, but the show goes on. Most of the shops lining the square sell the same products as down in the souk, but the men are so arrogant that I avoid shopping here. I might buy tasselled keyrings, which make a good souvenir and a large bag with a funny camel to pack my shopping. Jemaa el Fna is full of restaurants with rooftop terraces, this time I liked to take my lunch at Tajin Darna, which serves a cool and fresh salad nicoise.At sundown the food court comes to life serving mainly the same things, meat or vegetable skewers, grilled aubergines, peppers, tasty small sausages, salad marocaine with tomatoes and finely chopped onion. The whole circus is right beside, snake charmers, dancing dervishes, monkeys and simple games. Watch your belongings!
No charme. It was a place full of charme 40 years ago...now cheaps and turistic kiosques ...not interesting at all...so shame

This is the place to be after dark. This is where the bizarre meets the foody , from snake charmers to exotic food displays. This place comes to live after dark since Marrakech is warm during the daytime. Free entertainment and people watching, the food is great if you are not afraid to try something new. Enjoy yourself but keep an eye out for pickpockets.

Hustle and Bustle of Marrakechi city life. The old city square boasts traditions, shopping, and some tourist traps. Stay on guard but enjoy the creative chaos! We definitely recommend getting some of the sweetened cashews, trying the orange juice even just once, and grabbing a terrace lunch with a view over the square.

Mesmerising!!!. This place is really out of this world. During the day, it's full of monkeys, snake charmers and henna artists. Yes, these guys will ask for some heavy money, so always make sure you agree the price with them before hand. As the sun goes down, the place transforms into a bustling spot filled with people and food stalls. The food is definitely something you should try once, it is part of the whole experience. Enjoy a Mint tea at take in the view from the rooftop of one of the buildings. It is really indescribable.

Best at night. You can't miss it; inevitably you will be drawn towards the plaza square in the centre of the city. Experience at least one of the orange juice sellers (nb the grapefruit is also superb); at night take to one of the surrounding restaurant balconies, and watch and listen to the action

Good but not great.. I liked the square but it wasn't amazing as it was hyped up to be. We didn't eat there because we were warned about the risks of getting a stomach bug so just stuck to the orange juice.There is alot of entertainment, however everyone is on a hustle and you will be constantly hassled by people for money. If someone offers to take a picture for you they will charge you even if they say it's for free.Keep an eye on your pockets and your bags.Maybe it was because we were muslims but was really sad that children were sent specifically to us to beg for money....and they don't leave you alone even when you politely but firmly tell them you have no change, at one point a girl came and practically took my ice drink from my hand. But alhamdulillah as annoying as it was at times we gave what we could in the name of charity.When you want to buy things you have to haggle hard! This means if they say 120dh you start at 20dh, more often than not they will give in.Nice place to buy gifts and souvenirs.

So what?. OK, we did NOT visit at night as recommended but in the afternoon. Place was half empty. Big and boring. And annoying. Try to stay away from people that want to touch you, paint you with Henna or at least watch your back while being distracted by them...Want to see animals treated badly? Little turtles lying in direct sunlight for ours? Lizards in way too small cages? Little apes as tourist attractions? Well, then going there you should... Oh, and illegal copies of any media, who doesn't want that? Yalla, yalla... Not my cup of tea.

Vibrant and Amazing. Wasn't quite what I was expecting but was an eye opener. So many people around , horses, mopeds and food stalls. We are here 1 night and wasn't as tasty as I was expecting, the people were very pushy 'eat here 'eat here' even when you've eaten your ushered around by people. As a young couple I felt intimidated at times but this is what marrakech is about the square at night, the smells the experience

Wow!. If you like the hustle & bustle of cities along with monkey performers, snake charmers & a host of souks, restaurants & so much more then you will have a great time in this lively square. We particularly enjoyed it in the evening when the lights come on & there is some relief from the heat!

People watching..... The square is a great place to go and just watch what happens..... Don't get put off by all of the traders trying to make money out of you... After all, you are in Marrakesh...!!!

Much Ado About Nothing. A mecca for masochists who loved being accosted by the most aggressive operators outside of Moroccan rug merchants. During the day it's relatively empty, with not much to offer except to say you went there. We took a caleche ride, which saved our day experience, but only after a major effort sorting through clamoring drivers. At night the square is filled with food vendors and street types forcing monkeys on you for photos at price, performers and snake exhibitors. Unless you are a forgiving type or loose with the term "exotic" I would go there, to perhaps observe from a restaurant above the confusion. By the way Jemaa el Fna means "final journey"...it's where they performed executions back in the day.

Incredible and really cheap food!. Dancing, music and great food at unbeatable prices. Careful which stalls u go to as some are better than others. I think we went to 22 and 91 and they were both great. Try and go to the ones where the locals are eating, you may have to eat a couple of minutes. A must see in both day and night!

Horrible place. This square is a place you have little choice but to visit while in Marrakech. It is crowded with aggressive street artists out to get money off you in very unpleasant ways. Nobody is smiling in this square. It's noisy and you don't feel very safe walking here. I saw a number of fights breaking out and a motorbike plough into a family which required a young boy to be taken away by ambulance. The only time this square is not so busy is early morning when it is being cleaned of all the filth from the night before.

Wow! Crazy busy but worth a visit .
