Pretty quiet during the day apart from a few snake charmers and men with monkeys but at night it had to be one of the busiest places I have ever been!Non Merci works well on the stall owners inviting you in, if you do stop to shop remember to haggle and be prepared to walk away if they don't meet your price, it's the way things are done!Find a terrace cafe for dinner and you can just spend hours people watching all the comings and goings on the square and see the lights and smoke from the food stalls. Is truly an experience, be prepared for huge crowds and lots of noise from street performers and enjoy!

Go to fez. One hears so much about Jemma El fna as to what a coulture shock it is but this has got nothing on fez. This appears to be so popular that it is aimed these days at the tourist. Admittedly it is different to almost any thing else one see but not such a culture shock as we were expecting. Nevertheless a must see and many hours of pleasure will be spent here.
Fabulous.. Go early 9ish or early evening for shopping. Heat is stifling at other times. Night time great atmosphere, good food and music. Plenty of tourists and feels safe.

so busy!. This was another kind of an experience! as an european, you will not be used to this. it s a very busy market place, be aware, ppl will constantly try to sell you stuff and run after you, even if you turn them down. they will grasp hold of the men and put monkeys or snakes on male tourists. men will leave female tourists alone, but female merchants will grab a female toursits hand and draw a horribly expensive henna on your hand. if you are not willing to pay they will rub it all over your skin and unless you have sterilizing alcool with you, it wont go away for two weeks!other than that it was extremely loud and busy. they will sell food and drink there in plates that have not been washed- so you ll probably end up with diarrhea if you eat there. nevertheless it was really awsome going there, we went to the djemaa el fna every single evening because we enjoyed the spectacle so much! you will just need to be aware of your bags and jackets all the time.during nighttime all those little stall appear out of nowhere and will sell very delicous and cheap food to you. we asked a local and he told us that he d never ever in a million years would eat on djemaa el fna, but we stil ldid, and we were lucky and weren t struck by diarrhea- but all other tourists we met were sick for two days!during daytime one can discover the market. on every corner the merchants sell the same stuff, probably made in china, but it was still very much fun to walk through that massive market.we got lost about 10 times in the little soukhs and maze like streets, eventually we found our way out. the locals dont really give a damn if you ask them for help- unless you pay them.

One of the busiest, craziest places I've ever eaten. During the day the Jemaa is a wide open square with orange juice stands and the occasional snake charmer or traditionally dressed water sales man - all of whom will let you take a photo for a price. This is where you come to hire a horse and carriage and it's one way to get access to the medina.At night, it comes alive with hundreds of food stalls selling all sorts of traditional foods with men bellowing out orders and entreating you to come to their stall tomorrow. It can be a bit overwhelming at first but find a place you like the look of; sit down on the bench and order what you want. It will be served promptly and taste good. the soups and merguez are my favourites and some of the easier Morroccan dishes to start with

Enchantress - Where magic happens. If you want to feel something very different, this is the place. I was born and raised in Marrakech, i have seen this place changing so much during the past 10 years. I am a bit nostalgic of what it was, more rustic ... But still, it has something that cannot be explained with words, it is like those place that makes you feel free ... I go to jamaa el fna let's say three times a year, when my friends coming from abroad want me to take them, i always have this : "fffff, a lot of people, a lot of noise, a lot of ..." and when i am there, i feel something very deep, something real that reminds me somehow who i am and where i come from. It is a magical place. i'd recommend you to go at night !

Marrakech big attraction. This was an enjoyable experience. Stay away from the snake charmers. They are after your cash. They want money for both of the people there. We shopped in the bazaar and had a good day.

Fun but be a smart tourist . We enjoy our time at Jamaa ElFnaa every time we go. However, take note that it could be what a local told me a "tourist trap".Negotiate and bargain; chances are prices are up to 4 times more expensive for tourists (personally experienced and was able to bargain an authentic plate from 200 MAD to 50 MAD).

Everything you Expect. This place and its crazy Souks is definitely worth a visit!... Don't get sucked in, Bargain Hard as this is the most expensive place to buy anything whether you are a local or a tourist! Don't worry so much about getting lost in there; i think it happens to everyone! haha... I spent a small fortune on Henna but it was worth it, the ladies i went to were really happy to chat, AVOID the snakes and the monkeys and don't buy the orange juice as its watered down, beautifully atmospheric and cultural though!!

Happening square . The square is a very happening place. It's a madhouse of people selling things, entertainers like snake chambers, dancers, food and what not.This is a photographers paradise and you must come at different times of the day to capture it.My tip would be to go to a cafe/ restaurant terrace and enjoy the view and take pictures from there.
The square. An adventure in colours, smells and taste, so much to see and do, enjoy sitting with mint tea and watch the people.

Overrated?. What to say...I had expectations and they were not met. It is an impressive place because of the business, the confusion, the smells, the haggling...BUT I found it too much. The food was not that great. The smell of urine was often unbearable. Men approaching you to take a picture with their monkey; snake charmers that were rather scary looking...no, it wasn't for me. I think there other nicer squares/places in the city to hang out at.

Interesting and beautiful but AVOID FRAUDS!. It is a very nice, beautiful and interesting place! I really enjoyed myself there and found a lot of nice Items and souvenirs. The activities at night are fun. You have to be very careful for frauds! I have been violently dragged by a couple of ladies to get black henna that I DID NOT want. They forced me to get it, tried to rip me off and assured me it was 100% natural. The black henna is henna mixed with petroleum and kerosene. AVOID BLACK HENNA! I am now medicated. When you say no you really have to be firm with those kind of people! Other than that the view was amazing some of the restaurants were good.
5 days in medina. I love the atmosphere of this square!! Snake charmers , henna artists, spices, everything exotic !!!

Something for everyone. The square is an active market almost 24 hours a day. In the daytime there are stalls, acrobats, snake charmers et al, if you watch them they will expect a coin or two in the hat, if you photograph them you had better have a note or two. That's the way it is but that's how they make their living and its good fun! Join in and enjoy the atmosphere. There are lots of restaurants/cafes around and the Souq that maze of a market is beside the square! wander in and get lost, but be warned the majority of the goods in there are craftsman made and good quality, you will end up buying something! Enjoy the haggling!

Interesting, in the evening. My hotel was a few steps away, had to pass through the Square, each time. It is quite an experience, people working hard to entertain you , the snake charmers, the monkeys, acrobats and comedians ( hard to understand, if English is your language)

A must see when visiting Marrakech!. Lots of things to look at and to see. Best time is sunset or later. Watching from one of the touristy restaurants is fun. We ate skewers at stall 32, had orange juice from stall 40. Mostly it was fun to walk through the souks and end here. The Post Office is on the corner of the square, but most shops selling post cards have stamps (learned that after the long post office wait :)) The snake charmers, monkey guys and henna ladies are not aggressive if you don't look interested. I regret not getting henna, but reviews freaked me out!

Fantastic, but stay alert.... Jemaa el Fnaa is the main plaza of Marrakech, and is definitely worth a visit, especially at night when the street food vendors come out. However, be warned, especially women: People will harass you to get henna, to buy their orange juice, to eat their food. Take it with a grain of salt, but be aware that people will yell at you.

Do it!. My star rating is for the experience that is Jemaa El Fna.Jemaa El Fna is at the heart of Marrakesh.Love it or loathe it...Jemaa El Fna is a MUST do whilst in Marrakech.Yes, there are monkeys, snake charmers and belly dancers and the smell of the bbqs lighting up for the evening will get your noses twitching.We saw boxing and acrobats and characters of all sorts, sizes and creeds.Watch the belly dancers and form your own opinions!The orange juice was ABSOLUTELY delicious.....for 4 dirham.....better than any I've had in Spain. And many stalls will give you a plastic cup and straw helping to allay any fears of the dreaded tummy bug!Go with an open mind. The Jemaa El Fna is a once in a lifetime experience. It IS Marrakech

The sideshow at a circus. Step right up to a fascinating attraction. To the left you have the snake charmers, to the right you have the acrobats. But, buyer beware, ask before you take any photos otherwise it will cost you 300 dirham. There are monkeys on leashes, people playing music, places to get henna, psychics, all that one can imagine. The square is filled with locals looking to make a dollar, or dirham for that matter, off of strange, and unique talents. It is a sight to be seen. There is even the occasional boxing match in the square. The festivities come to life as the sun sets.Beware of the scammers and pick pockets as your eyes will surely dart from one attraction to the next. The area is teaming with locals and tourists.There are also many food stalls, all with numbers. They will try to entice you to dine at their "restaurant". I ate in a few of them and they were quite nice. Very inexpensive street food. There are also many juice vendors. Orange juice is 4 dirham, everything else is 10 driham. If it is too crowded and you just want to observe, there are some cafes that overlook the square and have balconies. You must purchase to get a view, but the cost of a beverage is worth the amazing views.

Big caution. Had a wonderful roamed about the souk by the square and generally around the medina. However, the store keepers are only interested in relieving tourists of all their money, often misleading visitors on prices. You really need to banter (50%) of any thing on offer. There were plentiful food at the square, if you are game, often more tasteful than main restaurants.Lots of music, dancing and display of performing artists. Loved the atmosphere but concerned about security. Not for the faint hearted.

Buzzing Square!. Just like any main square in any city, it's a tourist trap and at times, seeing it once in your life is more than enough. I honestly enjoyed watching the square when it started to be empty at 7.30am and then during lunch and then at 5pm. Watching the contrasts change so quickly was amazing! I sadly have to give this square 3 stars as I was very sad to see monkeys in chains as one of their main attractions! I have read about them on reviews here on TA but seeing them in person really made me sad. I was also trapped by one of the women walking around giving henna tattoos. I was taking photos and she just grabbed my arm and said, allow me to give a welcome gift to you. After a few seconds later, she asks me for payment aka my gift back. For some people, this may be quite a negative experience. In fact, alot of the locals I met, even tour guides are very embarrassed by their fellow Moroccans with this kind of behaviour. I just laughed at her and gave her a few coins. I even bid her goodluck as other tourists aren't so accommodating as I could be...sometimes! Haha!

Ok ....once... Visited here once during the day and once at night .Each time got hassled by stall holders / restaurant staff/street hawkers .Saying no just didn't suffice .I'd advise to say no once and walk on .It's full of stalls selling the same stuff and poor quality .At night time it's very lively , lots of music/ entertainers wanting money for pics.1 lady grabbed my arm and started a henna type painting, I said no , pulled my arm away and she asked for money, I looked her in the eye and said "I said no, you know it, you shouldn't have done that, I'm not paying you".she got the message and walked off .It's a shame that most are aggressive ...because it would be lovely to just wander freely and not have to look over your shoulder every 5 mins .Worth one visit at least...after that it gets a bit tedious with the constant hassle .

The epicentre of Marrakech, but steel yourself.... My guidebook described this square as 'picturesque' though I found it a big disappointment. It's a vast open space filled with people selling everything from orange juice to watches. The water sellers, dressed in strange and colourful costume, are intriguing but don't try and photograph them or they will harass you for money. In fact, don't bother taking a camera at all, as the chances of using it are slim unless you're willing to pay for every shot you take. Snake charmers, musicians, henna tattooists are all after your money and you need to steel yourself. Monkeys on chains will dance for the crowds at the order of their owners, which I found disturbing. We walked through the place as quickly as possible to escape the harassment. Head for the souks instead, they are actually much less stressful! Or visit one of the balconied restaurants that surround the square and view it from the periphery.

One of the World's Great Attractions. Don't miss it!!!. Having traveled now to Marrakech on 6 different vacations, we love the place. And part of the love is the Jemaa as Fna and its sheer insanity and otherworldliness. During the day find every type of entertainment (always for a tip) from trained monkeys to colorful water sellers, to storytellers (you won't understand a word, but watching the locals is part of the fun),to dancers, to cobra snake charmers (once our guy charmed 6 cobras at once!). I really believe this place was an inspiration for several Star Wars scenes. Go ahead and give a few dirham for tips and you will enjoy your pictures forever. Don't miss the tooth seller - a mound of human teeth available at any size,to replace any you may have lost along the way!! And go at night when it transforms to lots of outdoor restaurants. We shied away from this on the first couple trips, but jumped in at trip 3 and found out what we had been missing. A great meal at a bargain price and the atmosphere of the locals is wonderful. Everyone is your best friend. During the day just beware the henna ladies - if given the slightest chance they will adorn you with henna tattoos that will last for weeks (whether you want it or not) before you know it and then demand payment.

As assault on the senses. When we came to Marrakech recently we knew we had to come to Jemaa El Fna and it did live up to its reputation. There is so much to see and do from snake charmers to acrobats. Some of the people are very pushy but as long as you are firm with them you will be fine. We didn't eat from the food stalls in the evening. The amount of flies and wasps put us off but we are glad we went and saw the spectacles that there are. Some of the souks around are brilliant and you can really grab a bargain.

My street food experience. Bland, bland disappointingly bland. It's a crazy experience indeed in the square and even more so in the evening. Action and activity very much geared to the tourists and is so very much the way of life there. So, we went to experience the food stalls and...The food is cheap enough to eat but despite going to the number one rated place we were served a poor quality excuse for Moroccan food in the guise of tapas such were the size and number of tiny dishes that appeared. Severely lacking in any flavour, one single piece of meat in the meat couscous and dried out chicken stuck into a traditional shaped pot and passed off as a tagine. Also, I've seen bigger chunks of meat in a packet of Felix than appeared on a skewer presented to us as a kebab! Take the advice of others, mooch about, soak up the atmosphere avoiding the henna ladies and then go eat in a restaurant!

Medieval. You cannot go to Marrakech and not visit Jemaa El Fna, even if you don't think it's your thing; you have to, it's like visiting London and not seeing Buck House... Jemaa El Fna is the epicentre of the Medina, which in it'self is the middle of Marrakech. Whether you travel in from North, East, South or West, all roads, paths and alley ways lead to El Fna.It is like stepping back in time, or looking at historical production. Sure, there are new cafes and restaurants which overlook the square, but they are merely a vantage point for what lays below.The square is packed with locals and tourists alike, snake charmers are common place, monkeys on chains and Calèches line the street waiting to show you around the city.You will notice some orange covered stalls, they may not look up to much, but these are where you should head for food around El Fna at night. On the subject of food, the nearby cafes are good for a drink to view the square, but do not eat around here unless you try the stalls, the food in the restaurants is very poor indeed. To the north of El Fna the souks can be found where you can buy anything and everything.When you come away from this place, you may take any number of thoughts with you, ranging from 'what an interesting spectacle', to 'how can people still live like this', one thought that everyone shares though, is that you can't say you've done Marrakech, without witnessing Jemaa El Fna.

What a scene!. What an amazing place! It was so much fun to watch families enjoying the storytellers, musicians, and water sellers. We could have stayed for hours just enjoying the scene. The fresh juices were delicious and it was so interesting to see the many foods available--sheep's head, anyone? The only negative was that we were very sorry for the sad monkeys. However, as long as people have photos taken with them, they will be there.
Sums up Marrakech. This really is what Marrakech is all about. Hustle and bustle, manic, heckling, haggling, random types of transport, all in one square a great atmosphere just to wander round.

Chaotic but amazing. . This square is vibrant and fun, especially as the sun sets. Please be wary of the henna ladies who will literally grab your hand and hold you in a death grip, even as you try and pull away and say no. They will tell you it is free, hold you forcefully and draw a pattern on you - and then demand payment at the end and harass you until you pay. Avoid all eye contact with them and if they grab you do your best to pull away if you can!

Sensory Overload!. Jemaa el Fna is sensory overload and can be intimidating and overwhelming. On our first visit we quickly retreated to the safety of the rooftop of terrace of the restaurant on the corner. Luckily, we were able to get a table on the corner with a perfect view of the action below. Yes, you over pay for the one soda that you are required to buy when entering, but If you think of it as price to one amazing show, you will realize that you getting a deal. Before we knew it four hours had passed. It is the perfect place to watch the sun set and the square come alive with performers. My favorite time in the square was during the evening call to prayer when the action takes a break and the square is noticeably but only slightly more still. On the last day we visit we fully submitted to Jemaa el Fna and overpaid for photos with the snake charmers. Of course you are being ripped off but it was worth it for the experience. I also recommend eating once at one of the nightly food vendors on the square for the experience.

Magical Madness!. This square is the most colourful magical mad place ever! The whole world is here! You're transported back in time - the fanatastic street food stalls, the snake charmers and the dancers, the drummers and the sellers make this an experience you'll never forget. It can end up a bit 'Monty Pythonesque' but that's the fun of it all, don't take it too seriously and you'll have a great time.
Blah!. Not so nice if you have kids with you, since locals are very aggresive in sale and also try this on our children. Sorry... a no go.
Great market. Really a buzzing place at night not to be missed loved it , drummers, dancers , transitional street food, and surrounded by souls if you like lively you will love it

Vibrant. A good landmark and starting place for getting to the souks or other landmarks. Also a great place to eat - the rooftop terraces are wonderful for a view across the square and getting out of the hustle and bustle. I recommend the juice stands, which sell lovely fresh glasses of orange or mixed juices. The square really comes into its own at night, when the empty stalls become little restaurants. These are a really fun way to have a meal and try some different food. After eating (or before), check out the various folk bands, dancers, boxing matches and other activities that appear at night.The only real downside is the stream of snake charmers, monkeys, ladies trying to henna you, horse drawn carriages, street stalls etc who are all trying to sell you something. You get used to that after a day or two though.

If you want to get ripped of, eat there. The Djemaa el Fna is definately the place you must visit when being in Marrakesh. Jumping into the crowd is a nice experience. But do not eat in one of the stables on the square. The prices they ask are higher than the restaurants on the edge of the square, and the food is poorer. The scam is that after your order your table will be filled with all kind of food you did not order but what you are supposed to pay. For an order of 300 dirham, they charged me for 800 dirham, after negotianting I ended at a price of 600 dirham. At a normal restaurant for a comparable diner I payed 280 dirham, with better food, good seats and friendly staff.

This square sums up the craziness of Marrakech in one place. A trip to Marrakech is not complete without visiting Jemaa El Fna, especially during the evening. A huge array of foods to sample, fresh orange juice to hydrate you after a busy day, henna tattoo ladies for artwork to take home (stick to the brown as the black can be toxic to some people), and plenty of shopping to be had in the surrounding souks. It is worth paying a little extra to sit on a terrace at one of the many restaurants to get fantastic views of the entire square.From an ethical point of view, I chose not to engage with people with monkeys or snakes, however that is a personal preference.

MUST visit!. You must be prepared to visit the Square. It's the place where everything happens....but not pleasant as it could be....lots of people selling everything, monkeys and snakes to take pictures with... fresh juices, which I havent tried...and wont recommend... its a place to see while you cross on the way to the souks.People trying to sell you hats and clothes are ennoying... a tourist trap...must see it once!

All of life in one place. You can see every human condition in the one place here - from the youngest to the oldest, from the very poorest in society to the most privileged. The local people are friendly and can be a little pushy - but they do respect if you say no and mean no.The square does get very hot during the day - so early evening it tends to come alive with hundreds/thousands of people meeting, eating, shouting, watching snake charmers, buying freshly made fruit drinks etc. People watching at its finest!

Jemaa el fna. Go to Jemaa el fna, as you go to a party where you dont know anybody, take a seat in a restaurant, sit outside or rooftop, to see the colours and chaos. This square changes every hour, coming from India, for me it wasnothing so special as I had seen it all, but I could see the amazement and unbelief in the eyes of westerners.The snake charmer, the monkey man, the belly dancers, if you dont want to go near a snake, dont go near them at all,but if you go near them, they put a snake on you and you can take photos. If you dont want to do this stay a bit far and watch from a distance. I took lots of photograph of the place, but nothing of these plays. Its a very colorful place, always keep an eye on the mosque minaret, so where you are you can come back to it. They serve fresh orange juice which was very tasty. we drank a lot of mint tea, which was really refreshing.

One of the best experiences. To walk the square with all the amateur showbizz people, the smell of spices, food... is one of the best experiences that a traveller can have. Then have a meal and stroll to the market.

Wonderful Moroccan Square. Top tips: Come around dusk/sunset to get the best atmosphere and watch the various activities around the square. Have a drink (non-alcoholic) at one of the restaurants around the square with a terrace to enjoy the sunset. Eat at the open-air BBQ stalls (stall 1 comes highly reccomended with great quality food and hygiene)Wander around the souks to see typical Moroccan trinkets Have dinner at Nomad restaurant (opposite Café des Epices) for actual good quality food at decent prices (order the calamari in tomato sauce and the courgette and feta fritters!) Avoid eating dinner at the restaurants directly overlooking the square as the quality for price leaves alot to be desired! Be mindful of those with animals (snakes & monkeys) as they can charge up to 300 DH (30 EUR) for a picture and often approach you unsolicited. Always make sure you negotiate a price for anything before receiving it

Horrible, crowded place!. This was like a nightmare! Keep your head down and walk straight through to wherever you need to get to - will never forget the face of the poor monkey on a chain being dragged around by its owner - full of tacky Chinese toys and rubbish!!

You must go here after 4 pm if in Marrakech. Having visited the square by day, it was simply a square, lots of people milling around, but that's it. But on the return visit at about 5 pm, it had completely morphed into an expolsion on your sensory organs. The noise of drummers beating out rythyms for african dancers, the snake charmers blowing their flutes to waken their dancing cobras, the story tellers with crowds enthralled and the general hubbub of the crowds as they gather, is one thing, but the smells also of the large outdoor kitchen where probably 100 stalls are vying to cook you a meal, make this an experience like no other.

Either feel overwhelmed or just go with the flow. This place takes on a different complexion in the early evening and the sun starts to set and day turns to dusk. The square can become overwhelming for some with the intense sights, sounds and smells. You will very likely get hassled for cash by a vendor or a guy with a monkey in nappies but you will almost certainly have a chance to sample some cheap and cool fresh fruit juice or piping hot and sweet mint tea. The food stallts / eateries here will have something for most people - everything from sheeps heads, brains, entrails to snail broth, fried fish, kebabs, etc etc. You can binge on fresh seafood (fried mackerel, sardines, calamari) for instance and it will be an incredibly cheap meal! Be weary of taking pictures of entertainers - they will want money. Just... be weary of your surroundings. It's an experience to have, certainly. Just be prepared...!

Non-stop circus. Just know that tourists are really walking dollar signs coming into Jemma El-Fna. Be careful taking photos as if you happen to aim it in the direction of a street performer, you might be hit up for money, and quite aggressively. Snake charmers in the day, the square really comes alive in the dusk as food vendors set up and more performers take their spots in the square. You can really see all of this in a matter of minutes and get the whole experience, but it wears on you after a while with the aggressive touts and performers wanting money.Food-wise, it's not bad. It might be something to try, but be sure to watch your bill. If they want more money, they'll charge for bread even if you didn't ask for it.

Must see. This is totally like nowhere else. As the sun sets this place comes alive with food stalls, henna painters, snake charmers, magicians and sadly performing monkeys etc. a place to wander and soak up the atmosphere and all very safe - there is very little crime in Marrakech. Wander through the food stalls and shouting and cooking and pulling ensues. The food is cheap and authentic but don't expect napkins or even a knife!! We had fish selection with bottle of water which cost about £7. It's all quite safe to eat and you should experience it when you visit though it is a bit of a relief to get away from it. If you go back to the edge of the square you can pick up a caleche back to your Riad though make sure to haggle price for this too as they can charge different prices. We were in Riad by Rue El Bacha and it cost about £15 which is not bad and more fun than a taxi. A must visit and as two girls we felt safe and whilst there's a certain amount of hassling a firm no does the trick.

Was a big disappointment after coming form Fes!!. To be brutally honest.... I did not like Marrakesh. Especially Jemaa el Fna square!! After coming from Fes I found it overcrowded with tourists, full of pushy store owners & scammers & full of dirty black smoke puking scooters.... We walked through the square during the day, it has the same old shops, drank a delicious fresh squeezed orange juice, ate some tasty food. Theres snake charmers, story tellers (not in english) people with monkeys on chains, including baby monkeys! it was actually horrible to see. We stopped to get a photo with this guy and his snakes when some veiled woman offered to take a pic of the two of us with the snakes, no problem. When she gave me back the camera she grabbed my hand and proceeded to squirt hena on it. I said no thanks and tried to pull back my hand back, but she had a good grip and told me "its a gift" so I reluctantly stood there furious that I had to go thru this ordeal. (The reason I let her was because we were told its rude to refuse a gift) So after she was done with the poor attempt of hena (it was really bad, just a big squiggly mess on my hand!), the first thing I did was look for somewhere I could wash it off! We started to walk off and thats when it all started.... she started asking for money for the hena. I said you said it was a gift.... blah blah blah... she was almost yelling and it was embarrassing! We gave her some money just so she would leave us alone (that's how they make their money). I went into a restaurant and washed it off immediately but it has already set in and I lived with that horrid souvenir for a good week. There were guys dancing around in the square that would cut you off and dance in front of you for all of 10 seconds and then put their hat out, we ignored the guy at first then he seriously told us we needed to pay him for his dancing. Needless to say he didn't receive any money or nice words from us, as we had just had our horrible hena experience! We came back that night to check out the food stalls because we wanted to try all the different food. Walking through the food stalls we were harassed so much, we couldn't even do one full lap to see everything first. Guys were grabbing us and pulling us toward their stalls. One guy put his arm over my one shoulder and his other hand on my other shoulder and turned me around so I wouldn't walk past his stall. That was the last straw for me, I spun out of his hold and made a big deal in front of everyone about him touching me like that. I can usually handle all the touts with smart comments and humor, but after the negative experiences from that day, my tolerance was low. I'd had enough of the B.S. and just decided to make a point in the hopes he would realize thats not how you get a tourists business!Keep in mind this review is just based on my personal experience. Im not condemning the place nor am I saying dont go there! Its something you have to experience! Just take all the info you read on these reviews and become a smarter traveler. Learn from other peoples experiences and know how to avoid the negative ones.It says below visited in May 2014, but we were actually there in Jan 2012. I just started a tripadvisor account and am going through my travel journal putting my experiences online.Actual visit January 2012!
Horrible experience. The locals are ruining it for the tourists with their appalling attitude and behavior. Probably the main reason why I ll never go back to Marrakesh again.

Eat at Aisha's Food Stall No. 1. A fantastic experience was had at Jemaa el Fna! The Atmosphere at night is electric and crazy! It will be a marmite experience - you'll either love it or hate it. Personally I loved the noise, the sights, the crowds, the small huddles of locals playing games, singing, playing music and dancing. The 'street food' stalls all basically sell the same things - look on lots of youtube pages after searching for Jemaa el Fna. Stall number 1 is run by a lady called Aisha and the food here is cooked perfectly. She is clearly in charge of the chefs and waiting staff and watching her in action is an experience in itself - I would definitely return to her stall! I noticed she gets a mention in reviews going back quite a few years! Go Aisha!

Amazing - not to be missed. All you expect from this square, Daytime the market where you can buy just about anything. Nightime just so special, snake charmers, acrobats, traditional music and dancing. You do get a little hassled by the traders but they usually take a firm NO and leave you alone. Worth putting up with any amount of hassle just for the experience

Interesting to visit - don't bither eating there. At sunset the entire square comes to life as food vendors and tourists merge. It's s fantastic place to walk around and soak up the atmosphere, but don't bother eating here as the food is generally average in taste and overpriced. We do reccomend visiting cart 72 for some spiced tea - a real treat on a cooler evening.
Great place. The square is great place to try all new foods very busy but fun great atmosphere and if feeling brave snake charmers to have your photo taken lots going on all day

Back in time. The cultural experience that you must see, specially at sunset. You get to experience music, food and all sort of commerce on this big open square. Hard to describe so you better live it.

Fun place to visit. This square is heaps of fun, worth visiting more than once, keep your money hidden!
Lots of places to eat and watch the crowds.
Good fun for kids

Unable to see this square in a positive way due to the distressing sight of monkeys dragged about on chains.. We were staying in a Riad fairly close to this square so walked through it several times during our stay. Although it was worth seeing as a totally full on sensory experience (interesting smelling food, noise of drums, hundreds of people trying to make a living from having their photo taken, selling bangles, henna tattoos etc), I didn’t like it. Although everybody sees things from their own perspective and I realise that I shouldn't judge their method of making a living, I found seeing distressed looking monkey’s pulled around on the end of chains, and snakes being exploited very upsetting, so not feeling I was in a position to challenge (although I thought about it), spent most of the time trying to avoid seeing them (& avoid being run over by the bikes & cars passing so close as although the locals seem to have excellent spacial awareness, I don't!). Having said that, it isn’t to be missed as it’s a huge part of the Marrakech ‘adventure’. Wanting to see what it was like at night, we found one of the rooftop café’s and after a while, got a table where we could see over the square and for me was a better way of absorbing what was going on but with a bit of space. A word of warning ‘though, we were told that the henna used in the square has a derivative than can cause skin to react. Also, the nice ladies coming up and ‘giving’ you a bracelet want something in return, so don’t put one on unless you intend to buy one, which seems fair. Also worth remembering if you are going to take photos of the men in their twirly hats and other sights, then have some cash ready as for many this is their way of making a living.
Famous Square. Full of charm and bustling energy. One of the top tourist spots in Marrakech and well worth a prolonged visit. The fresh orange juice sold in the Square is really thirst quenching.

Heady fun in the square. What an amazing place..totally transforms at night. Grab a cold drink at one of the rooftop terraces and watch the performance unfold. Loved the buzz..exciting vibrant noisy smelly!

Mad and crazy!!!. A sensory overdrive! The noise, smells, sights! Be careful of the snake charmers and monkey men as they will try to get a you to take photos...for a price!Visit in the afternoon and at night!

"Lively and Exciting". Me and my wife visiting the place in daytime and at night aswell. Its better at night time. If I talk about the activities and the shows there nothing much to say some snake charmers, laddies putting henna tattoos, some are trying to play music, some are trying to do majics,some are beating drums, most of the people trying selling goods which are not very good in quality. Very high prices, food stalls in the square cheap but lack of hygiene. But this place has something in it which makes you thrilled may be its the music or a big crowd. Orange juice is nice and restaurants, cafes and ice cream parlours on the sides are good. Their food and hygiene is better than the stalls in the square. People are ok there is nothing to worry about you just need to carry on your way.

Brilliant. . Amazing. Take in the hustle and bustle. Spend your dirhams on the tat. Always always haggle. Try the orange juice. You will never taste any thing like it again. Watch the sunset over the square. From one of the many rooftop cafes.

Seriously different. watch out for the snake charmers they will try to fleece you and the henna art may be a problem. A wonderful culturally very different experience. I went with my wife and 4 daughters and had no problems. Women's dress is fairly relaxed and I saw people wearing the kind of clothes that raise eyebrows in the UK apparently without problems. It is much more progressive and relaxed than I expected. Very little hassle mostly very nice people who are a lot poorer that us wanting to do a deal but without real pressure. recommended enjoy it and the Medina

Times Square in Marrakech. Jemaa el Fna is a tourist trap during the day. At night, it is transformed into a bustling dining and entertainment scene for locals and tourists. We ate at stall 1 based on a recommendation, and the food was just okay. We found the aggression from the vendors to be over the top (to the point of one yelling derogatory comments at us simply for choosing to dine elsewhere). You can eat here to say you did, but I would recommend getting just a snack and saving the full meal for less of a trap. Also, definitely go where the locals go in terms of the stalls. Some are busy, some are empty.

Watch the madness - Dont buy anything or let anyone start henna on you!. A true tourist experience of Marrakech and a place you will likely wander through a number of times and will learn to avoid walking through the centre by your second visit.A great place that I am glad I visited but did not hold much allure to me as someone who does not like being scammed or little mass produced trinkets and forced to paying for common courtesy.Take a wander through but I would advise doing your shopping further afield where it is easier to haggle and people are less desperate and you are not just a camera carrying cash bag.

Wow!. To see this place at its best you have to come at night, this is when it really comes to life. You'll see people boxing, transvestites dancing, musicians playing, people golfing, fortune tellers, henna artists, people fishing for pop bottles, snake charmers and lots and lots of food and drinks stalls. It's a great place to walk around and people watch or if you can get a spot on one of the cafes' terraces you can get a great overall view of the chaos. The vendors can be very humorous when trying to tempt you to their stalls. You will find yourself walking around chuckling as you drink in the atmosphere. A must see when you're in Marrakech.

Crazy crazy nights . The Jma'f'na is a pretty interesting place to visit during the day, plenty of market stalls and characters, but at night the craziness steps up by an order of magnitude. Everywhere you look there is someone trying to make money from something and they don't do it quietly. The raucous atmosphere has to be seen to be believed. Learn to say no or you'll walk away with henna, Arian oil, and countless photos with monkeys, snakes and water sellers.

Mind boggling. One must visit this square while in Marrakech to take in the swelling sea of humanity. Be careful not to snap pictures of the water sellers, snake charmers. You will be expected to pay!
Bustling Square. This square is straight out of the movies, in my eyes it is everything that Morocco has to offer with culture, food and people. Great place to spend a few hours peopleWatching.

Beautifully HECTIC!. I love this place. The atmosphere, the food and the culture. It is very touristy but that is to be expected. Make sure to go here at night to go to the night food market (stall 117 is really yum). You can use the square as a base to explore Marrakech medina, whenever you get lost exploring the souks (which you will) just make your way back here and startover. Be careful of street vendors grabbing your hand a trying do draw a henna tattoo on you, they'll try to charge you 70euro. Also, be careful what direction you point your camera, people will try and get money out of you for "taking a picture of them". The only reason I don't really like this place is the amount of animal cruelty, the snakes, monkeys and donkeys here are treated terribly. DEFINITELY DO HAVE A LOOK THOUGH!!!!

Just extraordinary for someone from northern Europe.. Just WOW. Amazing. The fresh orange juice is the best I have ever tasted, anywhere. Everything is here. Water sellers in their colourful costumes, Snake 'charmers', and in the evening fabulous street food. Beware the donkey pulling a cart, and especially beware anyone who invites you to take a photograph of them; they will try and charge you a lot of money for the privilege. It is, however, an amazing experience, and while you're there , go and get lost in the souks! Also a great experience.

Visit, but no need to linger. Don't come here expecting to see the authentic Marrakech. The square and surrounding souks are entirely geared towards tourists. The hassle factor and sensory overload can be a bit draining. I can't imagine having come to the city and not visited the square briefly, but unless a touristy carnival atmosphere is your idea of a good time, don't plan to stay long. Tip: the food stalls are a fun experience, but we got massively overcharged by failing to specify that we wanted one of each of our dishes, not one for each of the 4 people in our group.

Like a theme park on steroids. This is THE place to visit if you are looking for culture shock. The square in the "cog of the souks wheel", all the pathways to the souks radiate from this central public square. When you get lost exploring the souks (and you will), keep making your way back to Jemaa and start again. Its fun, its noisy and its packed with pickpockets, snake charmers and vendors.

visit at different moment of the day. We went 5 times to the place and it was total different every time.Always busy and a lot of people, the heart of the city, the heart of the daily life.If possible go to a roofterrace around six PM. You will see how the vendors build the restaurants ... and sun goes down.Great view.

Unique. A trip to Marrakech is not complete without a visit to Jemaa el Fna.During the day you can see performers with monkey and snakes. If you want to take a picture you have of course to pay, or you can pretend to just carry your camera and shoot a few candid anyway.I watched the sunrise on the balcony of a cafè, which I recommend as you can see all the vibrant colors of the food market too.As it gets dark it feels like a different world. There's music, colors, smells; I felt like I was in a movie!It's really unique but you will be still asked for money at every corner.In the food market every single person at the stalls will stop you and invite you to eat.As it gets more crowded be very aware of pickpockets.

Where do I begin?. You will see soldiers with guns protecting this world heritage area - unfortunately this is since the ice cream parlour was blown up.The area also has a tourist police station - they want you to feel safe and ultimately spend money.NEVER take things off people because they expect you to buy it! If you don't like snakes give them a wide berth - you might end up with one around your neck! I have been told that the snakes have had their fangs removed but they can still spit and make you ill. Obviously this is the poisonous ones not the boa types. If you don't like monkeys avoid these too. They are chained and wear clothes and end up on your head or shoulders for the photo opportunity, which you pay them for.The water carriers, dressed in red also expect to be paid if you take their photo.There are stalls which sell delicious fresh orange juice and SEALED BOTTLED.WATER. I mention this because I have seen people filling water bottles out of containers to sell. DON'T buy if the seal is broken!There are fruit stalls and at certain times plant stalls but obviously you cannot buy them. Don't be tempted by the coconut sellers - looks great but they swill the coconut off with water from a container I would not like to hazard a guess as to there this comes from! There are always people who do henna tattoos but they can cause skin irritation and usually don't last. You can even buy the henna kits to do your own.They even have dentist stalls - this makes me grateful for our dental care lol!At night the square is totally transformed into a more manic area. This is a massive fast food extravaganza. If you eat here watch how they prepare the food first (hygiene wise) and if uncertain there are plenty more places to eat. The salads always concern me because you don't know how they have been washed. Use your common sense and you should be ok. Many people eat here - ask someone leaving the stall how they have found the food - people are always happy to help.If you walk around you will see boxing contests which can involve children, acrobats and many other entertainments.

Vibrant lively square with so much to look at and smell and experience!. I had read a lot of reviews about the square and was a bit worried about what it would be like. Of course, it was nowhere near as bad as I had feared, although you do need to keep your wits about you. Unless you want to be photographed with a sad looking monkey in a dress on a lead, or a big snake, then keep well way from them and look only at a distance. Similarly, give the henna ladies a wide berth if you don't want a tattoo - although they never tried to grab my hand, despite many review saying they might.The stalls in the day are fairly typically full of the usual tat, with over-inflated prices and a hard sell. But if you just keep moving and ignore the attempts to make you buy, then you will be fine. I was wary of taking photos on the first day, but got braver as time went on, and never got any hassle. That said, I was careful about what I photographed, and always kept my phone and camera secure. We tried the orange juice from the stalls, and it was gorgeous and no upset tummy afterwards!In the evening, its a crazy manic bustle, with the food stalls all vying for your business. Its quite entertaining at first, but after a while it gets a bit wearing. All the stall holders will try anything to get your attention "Rick Stein here, bl@@dy good food", "no diarrhoea guarantee" and "we all sell same sh@t". In the end we ate at Stall 31 on two occasions, primarily because it was full of locals and there was a queue to eat there, so they did not need to pull tourists in with lame hooks. If you can turn a blind eye to the plate washing and don't worry about how the meat was stored etc, you may be fine. We ate food that was grilled and cooked in front of us, rather than cooked earlier and warmed up. It was cheap and cheerful - although the bill always came to more than we expected! Beware the cover charge of bread, olives, salad etc is not free and all adds up! Stall 14 is best for seafood. There are also loads of young lads with dessert trollies - a box of cakes that you choose yourself. We tried some - they were mostly dry and bland, but all part of the experience. It is busy and noisy in the square at night, but actually I didn't find it imtimidating. There are quite a few beggars, young children with their grannies etc and stall 31 very kindly gave uneaten leftovers (bread, salad, olives etc) to these beggars in a plastic bag.There are also lots of kids selling cheap toys, biscuits, cigarettes etc. You just need to be firm if you don't want to buy, and haggle them down if you do,Its a must see place, but exhausting after a while.

An experience like no other. Just back from Marrakech. The square was high on our list of places to visit having seen and read so much about it. As previous other reviews say different times of the day give you different experiences. Day...... Quieter, ladies enticing you to have a tattoo. Even if you say no, they may still try to grab your hand and start anyway, when you still say no, they may ask you to pay for the henna they have used against your will. This happened to me and I stuck to my guns and wiped it off. But not all of them are like this. Some do understand, that no thankyou means no. There are snake charmers and men with monkeys. They are not keen for you take photos without payment. This I understand as they are trying to make a living. We had no trouble with this as we stayed away from these. The freshly squeezed orange juice is the best I have ever had. Amazing for 4 DH. The exchange rate for us was just under 15DH to the pound. In the evening the square gets very busy, with lots of hustle and bustle. The monkeys and some snake charmers are still around, but now we have the added street performers. More stalls appear selling traditional dress, argon oils, incense, etc etc etc. it's all very colourful and lively. People do beg and the sellers do try their hardest to get you to buy. Just be firm and politely decline offers to look for free. Nothing is free here. We found the final price we paid for things cheap (didn't buy anything we didn't think was a bargain, but our bargain Price may not be yours) . We paid about 60DH for argon oil, 100 DH for tradional trousers, we even found a tradional dress stall and bought them for 50DH. We ate at three different places around the square. Paid £20 ish for 2 adult meals with non alcoholic drinks. Included mixed grill and tagine. Bargain ! We even tried sitting right in centre of the square on stall number 1. This seemed popular with locals and tourists , lots of long tables with everyone packed in. 3 course meal for 2 with water under £15. All food excellent and no dicky stomach later. We stayed at the Meriem Hotel which was in the new part of the city. Prices for transport back from square. taxi 80DH, they charge for size of taxi. Ours was a big old merc. Horse and cart 200DH, Rickshaw style moped 50DH. The square is something to be experienced. I wouldn't say it was something everyone would enjoy. I wouldn't take my children, and being an animal lover not overly comfortable on the way animals are used. But I love the hustle and bustle, the smells and sounds, the overall atmosphere, the complete chaos. Somehow with everything going on around you I still managed to stay relaxed and calm and enjoy my moment in a city where not much makes sense and amongst the chaos there is some kind of order.
Not a highlight for us!. There are many places more interesting to visit than this noisy place full of cheap merchandise and pushy people....

skip it. Knowing that this is a UNESCO World Heritage site made the noise, chaos, constant hand outstretched for one from snake charmers, monkey handlers etc all the more unpalatable. The square is huge, unattractive, and frankly not very hospitable. If you can stomach experiencing the hustling for pictures and the pandemonium, go by all means but don't expect this site to be on par with any other UNESCO World Heritage site. It's a shame that it has earned that title.

Dinner nightmare experience!. Don't go for a dinner at Jamal El Fna.The restaurant on the Big Square are totally fake.They are very expensive, they cook very bad food and totally tourists targeted.The smell is terrible and when you will back to your hotel you mut clean your clothes.There are a lot of good restaurant in Marrakech, all the restaurant at Jamal el Fna are defenetely bad.

Unique and crazy experience. Like nothing else really..... Be ready for snakes and monkeys. And henna and lotions and potions andm haggling and saying NO with a smile. Nothing is for free. Pay no more than10-15 dirham for a henna tattoo, BROWN only. Don't give to begging women with babies, except perhaps bananas, it is a scary business of often rented or sleep drugged babies. Pay about one third of "very good price", one half maximum. Know your top price and don't pay more. It is a game, do it with a smile. If they are mean, leave! There are thousands of fun sellers. Watch the night market set up from 5pm...remarkable feat. Food is similar prices, loved 117 in the night market, fun lads! Orange juice in the market 4 dirham in the cafes with views 12!

Magic-less in Marrakesh. Squalid and cheap is what we found in el Fna, "The Big Square". The place has two shifts. During the day the square is full of the women doing henna tattoos and selling the local skull caps and men in stalls selling orange juice - there's only so much you can take of this. In between are other traders abusing animals from the lame horses struggling to pull their carriages, scruffy donkeys, very unhappy monkeys and hundreds of half-dead snakes trying to look charmed. Around the square are stalls selling tack and alcohol free bars - who wants that when on holiday? Beyond these are the souks and as you enter these you realise things can get worse!Youths work in teams to "guide" you in, rather they shepherd the unwary deeper into the sections they are being paid by. We were shepherded into the Tanneries where the stench was appalling so we headed back out. The whole place is intimidating and threatening as you're being offered "the best price possible" for the tack by in-your-face traders. There really was no fun in engaging in haggling here.This place is really not for the faint-hearted looking for holiday entertainment!Around five o'clock the night shift starts coming into the square. Gangs of youths pulling and pushing carts full of the various parts that they put together to make the food stalls. These teams have never heard of Food Hygiene Certificates. You take your life in your hands if you eat here in the evening. The snail sellers were serving up the poor creatures before their stalls had been fully erected. Deregulation at its extreme here. The nightmare continued as other stall holders appeared and the variety of foods increased. Where had it all been cooked? We left the food stalls and saw a large crowd gathered with uproarious cheering. On investigating we found a boxing circle where poor boys were being pitched against each other while the encircling crowd placed their bets. We found it distasteful. Again not for the faint-hearted so we left them all to it and searched for a civilised bar and a beer to help us get over it all!

Lively, but not for everyone. We expected more from the square after reading such great reviews and after the feedback from the Riad staff. In the day there are loads of people selling goods, snake charmers etc At night the square comes to life with loads of food stalls. Its not just a tourist trap as there are many locals that come here too.its worth seeing once, but personally I was expecting some thing else, something more mysterious and fascinating

A must in Marrakech, but.... The rest of the reviews pretty much spell out what to expect. I'll highlight a few tips: Visit the square at least three times: once in the morning to enjoy some fresh orange juice, once in the daytime to view some of the street performers (snake charmers, water servers, tooth pullers, etc) and once by night to eat at one of their multiple food stalls. Okay… you know you want a picture of that snake charmer… and it will cost you. The mere action of pointing your camera their way will cause them to immediately go your way and ask (better said demand) a tip. The trick of the trade here is to ALWAYS negotiate first. Negotiating the photograph of the snake charmer BEFORE you actually take the photograph will mean the difference between 30 - 50 dirhams and 300 dirhams (at least having them demand 300). Make sure the snake charmer is 100% agreeable that they are not taking a single cent more from you before you start shooting away. I actually went as far as clarifying the amount of shots I was planning on taking. Doing it this way actually makes the experience very enjoyable. Avoid the henna merchants in the square. This is normally a scam. If you do want a henna tattoo, negotiate first and decide on a fixed number and tattoo before they start. Do not accept a "what ever you want to pay me" offer. Make sure to walk around and see the different performers around the square at night. You will notice that many of them are geared more at the local crowd. This does not mean you can't participate (as long as you tip). Our best experience was actually with a group of Berber performers catering to the locals. We were even invited to sing in that performance! The group was very kind and welcoming (and so was the crowd). Last but not least, enjoy the local food stalls. Not only are they very cheap, but also delicious. I ate a little bit of everything and never got sick. Snails, teas, pastillas, kabobs, pastries and the fresh juice are a must!

Day night entertainment. Full of entertainers , snake charmers , pet monkeys , henna painters , lots of stalls , fresh juices , night time different type of entertainment traditional singers and dancers be careful with valuables

Circus like. The square is crazy. We saw monkeys, snakes, musicians, dancers, food vendors, beggars. Everyone, all at once, trying to get your attention and your money. You should go in aware that you will be hassled. Try to have a thick skin, and a good attitude and you won't get overwhelmed. I don't think I've ever been anywhere quite like it. Shouldn't miss spending time there at both day and night.

Money for nothing.... Frankly speaking, I don't think that this open market/bazaar exept the souk reflects the Moroccan lifestyle. There are spots but they are all fake because of money that has been asked for every occasion.

Even the locals love coming here.. There is so much to see and do in Djemaa el Fna. Daytime is when you'll see all the street performers, monkey's, snake charmers and such. There are also several stalls with fresh squeezed orange juice. Yum! At night you will find the best street food around. Lots of outdoor coffee shops that offer some of the best people watching in Morocco.

Eh...just a show for tourists...not my favorite. Everyone said this was the number one attraction in Marrakech, so our expectations were high. We found it, well, a big circus show for tourists, which is not our cup of tea. It's street theater, which you can get anywhere, and people hustling you, which you can get anywhere. The "restaurants" setting up shop made the nighttime visit interesting, but we felt once we saw it, we didn't really need to go back. It just wasn't an authentic experience for us, and it was jam-packed with tourists, which didn't help.

amazing.vibrant and buzzing. wow.only 5 mins walk from our hotel .the medina gardens .we were transported back in time.amazing.the sights .the sounds .the smells.the people.the entertainment.horses and carriages line theentrance to it.beware of the smell.horse pee.ugh.at night it is much busier.everybody in m,orrocco seems to be here.beware .if you take any pics of morroccon entertainers you will have to pay for it.i ghad quite afew arguements over this issue. take a coffee or mint tea overlooking all this mayhem in a rooftop cafe or restaraunt.its amazing.not to be missed experiance.
The best of Morocco on one square. The smell, the tastes, the noises, the colours. Just let go and enjoy :=) Go to the food vendor that has most people, that s a sign of best quality and great taste!

The heart of Marrakesh. "La Place" as everyone calls the square is a Unesco site, because of the events that happen there. Daytime and night time are quite different there. During the day there are stalls and snake charmers under umbrellas, that will drape a dopey snake around your neck while you have your photo taken. There are brightly dressed water sellers, juice and food stalls and the entrance to the souks. Little bands of musicians and story tellers too. The "Night Market" there seems livelier with transvestite dancers in the mix too. Everywhere there are groups of people around an "act" - the more money you give, the louder the music, the more exciting the story and so on. Don't miss a visit to La Place - it's unique, but take plenty of change - a "tip" is expected if you want to take photos etc.If you go on the terraces of one of the cafes around the edge, you will get a good overview of what is going on.

A must see. We recommend going to the square and night and trying the food. There are food stalls everywhere and it is great people watching. My hotel recommended stall #1, but we had #64. The food was so-so, but the atmosphere was fun. Venture into the souq afterwards and prepare to bargain!

A must do place to visit and soak up the feel of Marrackech. Really interesting square, full of life, at the edge of the market. Snake charmers, henna tattooist, monkeys, street performers, drummers, stalls with freshly squeezed juice, others with delicious food. Like a number of previous reviewers comment, use common sense, wear a smile and enjoy the experience.Best In the evening, enjoy a sundowner in one of the bars overlooking the square.

Vibrant heart of Marrakech. No trip to this city would be complete without a visit to the Square of the Dead. Take some time to sit in a cafe and watch the monkey trainers and snake charmers ply their trade. Alternatively sample the fresh orange juice or haggle for some figs and dates

Not as atmospheric as expected. We had been so excited about coming here, to be honest it was a bit of a let down, it was upsetting to see monkeys being pulled about on leads, some were really distressed and their owners were just making it worse, we kept as far away from them as we could.There was always something going on and it was very busy both during the day and at night. We never got any real hassle, just the usual people trying to sell things or beggars.At night it comes alive will all the food stalls etc, we did eat at no 31 as recommendations were so good, we seen some really poor hygienic practices here and were also overcharged, we did challenge this but they refused us our change, I believe it is pretty much the same in most of the stalls, just check the price on the menu, refuse the dishes they give you without ordering them, as these will be charged, nothing is for free, have the correct money as well. We recommend Chez Zazza and Kui Zin for eating, you can check these out on trip advisor, not much of a difference in price and way nicer than the stalls.

Busy, feels like a tourist trap at most of the stalls.. It's busy, crowded and so touristy. Every stall is focused on selling. Ate there. But nothing special, if i compare it to other wonderful places Marrakesh has.

lots of sights and sounds. The large main square in the Medina of Marrakesh is packed with snake charmers, dancers, fortune tellers, and henna painters. They will aggressively ask for money if you take photos so take care.

Cacophony. Ate here with friends in evening. Fun street food with plenty of flavour. Enjoyed bustle of cooking activity and plenty of banter and people watching. Not so keen on daytime with snakes and monkeys.

Lively centre of Marrakech. All routes seem to lead to this huge lively square in Marrakech. Here you can people watch, eat, drink, shop....whatever you want. It can be quite intimidating, especially at night when all the street vendors and performers come out, but it is fascinating nonetheless and a must visit for the city.

A true wonder of the senses. We arrived via shuttle bus from hotel and was met by a guide who offered his services....he expected no payment as he works for a tourism company, but we gave him 100dhm for his time, knowledge and friendliness at the end of our 3.5hr visit around the market....which wasn't enough time to fully explore. But we had to get back to our bus. I didn't visit the market at night but I'm returning in October and intend to do so.Yes there is haggling but I never felt harrassed, I found everyone jovial and extremely pleasant, and everywhere was clean. Don't be afraid to wander down little alleys and discover an erray of alladins caves full of treasures and wonders, colours and smells....and haggle hard! Know a price in your head and stick to it.Crossing the road is another experience altogether in the city, there are traffic lights but even still you do have to take a leap of faith, tho I made it safely....held firmly onto my guides and friends hands lolI'm looking forward to returning in October.

Crazy!. Our first impression was this is crazy. But then you get used to all the drama happening around here and you just enjoy the unique atmosphere. Definitely worth more than just a quick look. There are tons of stalls selling orange juice, snake charmers, henna tattooist ... the square is alive all day long, ad it gets even crowdier at night, when they add numerous food stalls, serving delicious food. Like one of the previous reviewers said, use travellers common sense, wear a smile and enjoy the experience.

***Must See*** Local Flavor at it's best!. The Market is amazing. On the walk across the square, be ready to take pictures with monkeys and Cobras, get a Henna Tattoo and enjoy great street food. Allow plenty of time to explore the local treasures.

A bit of a let down. I had higher expectations from the square before I arrived and after all the things I was told by the Riad staff. Lots of people selling stuff and lots of snake charmers during the day. At night just stalls with food. I was expecting some thing else, something more mysterious and fascinating :-/

Worth it. May be confusing, don't worry too much. After hearing so many warning about aggresive hard bargaining sellers and scams of snake charmers, henna tattooists, etc. I came here a little cautious. Until I realized I was born and raised in hectic Southeast Asia and this is pretty much the same thing going in my own backyard. Just enjoy the sights and shops, don't look overattached to any item, give a big smile and use traveller's common sense, and it's an amusing have-to-do-at-least-once experience in Marrakesh.

Long weekend. Jemaa el Fna is the main square that sits at the heart of the Medina in Marrakech. The square is full of musicians, snake charmers, monkey handlers and huge numbers of henna tattoo sellers ( they can be a pest). Fruit and nut stalls add to the hive of activity. The square is surrounded by a host of restaurants, bars and fast food outlets as well as being the gateway to the souks.At night around a 100 fast food stalls open up selling everything from grills to goats heads to snail soup to fish a chips (fresh and not much batter). It is a hectic and popular place but actually not as big as we expected and once you categorise e food stalls not as broad a range as you expect. It is a hip place to hang out to experience the 'real' Marrakech. You cannot get a drink though!It is a must see place to tick off the list but we visited all 4 days we were there and the gloss soon wears off. It is however the reference point for exploring and you always end up there - even if the locals do sometimes send you off in the wrong direction! Beware

Must See. One proviso - visit during the evening. It's quiet during the day and some evenings are busier than others. We visited on a Sunday and you could hardly move, other evenings were less busy. We can recommend Hassan - 32 if eating at one of the multitude of food stalls.

Happening!. Quiet in day but happening at night. In the heart of old Medina where you can find souvenir, foods and much more. Love the night market as they have cheap and good food sell at night stalls. Don't forget to visit stall no 1 for the food. Worth a penny!

Number 1???!! (Why????). Just back from a trip to Marrakesh and was keen to find out if it lived up to its new TA ranking of "Number 1 Worldwide" - and for me it's a very easy, resounding "Non!".What is it about searing heat, dust, being hassled, motor bike / donkey cart dodging, bottom pinchers, a relatively limited amount of truly outstanding "historical / cultural" attractions, limited access to sensibly priced food and drink (and yes, I do mean alcohol), etc etc - that TA reviewers are "raving" about..??!!We had a lovely hotel (Meridien N'Fis) and met some lovely people and had a good time - BUT...Now I haven't been to that many places, but here's just a few that I have been to that I think beat Marrakesh hands down - and I'll start my list with ones beginning Ma..Manchester; Majorca; Madeira; Madrid - but sorry Malaga - you don't make the list!..Not to mention the ones that don't start with Ma...Foz d'Iguassu; Rio; Santiago de Chile; Cordoba; Granada; Most Greek Islands; Bangkok; Paris; Amsterdam; Italian Lakes; Tuscany; French Alps; Pyrenees; Prague; Budapest; Barcelona etc etc etc

Wait for the evening. I was really disappointed when I first visited as it was during that day and it lacked the atmosphere of the evening.I had photos taken with the snake charmers who then asked for 300 Dirham, I gave 20 and no-one complained. Similarly with the gnawa players and the water sellers.However, at night it's one of the best places on earth. Such a buzz. It's like the biggest barbecue in the world.

Overrated Hassle . Umm I wanted to enjoy Marrakech I wanted to experience it all, but honestly it just leaves you with a bad taste in your mouth. I never go near monkeys on chains or snakes in baskets as seems abusive and I certainly would not pay to photograph them. Being openly offered stolen phones? No thanks ! Souk owners being frankly offensive when you don't want to buy an overpriced bit of toot. Marrakech is currently the number one destination to visit this will change if they don't start to embrace tourism rather than see tourists as people to rip off ! I am respectful of the culture, and have visited many cities, this is nod I won't return to.

I was expecting more. I had read so much about this square and I had seen so much footage on TV that I had imagined the place much much much bigger than what it actually is. Of course if you are in Marrakesh you will go to Jemaa el Fna but if possible refrain from eating there. Food is overpriced and sometimes staff from the different stalls can get a bit too pushy trying to convince to eat at their place.Go for a walk, take pictures, talk to the people but go and have dinner somewhere else.Something I did not like at all was the people with monkeys and using them to pose with the tourists. The same goes for the snake enchanters.To get the best view of the whole square go upstairs to one of the terraces facing Jemaa el Fna (the best one is the one above the pharmacy)

( Fooooood ) ( Entertainment ) ( Vibrant ) ( Colourful ) beautiful experience.... thee place to visit in Marrakech ... every evening the square comes to life and the atmosphere hard to describe .. u got to be there to feel it, early evening is like entertainment time where u have snake charmers, man with monkey, magician, henna artist, amateur boxing matches literally many things taking place at once.. and while all this happening food stalls are being set-up on its designated area.. must go before sunset and head up to any nice rooftop terrace café, sip mint tea and simply enjoy whats going on in the square..

Berber and Berber. The whole world and it's monkey seems to be in this square. During the day the snake charmers and tumblers fill the square, at night the sounds Berber music and the smell of charcoal punctuates the square. A scene from Dante's inferno or a scene from Indiana Jones take your pick. this is one site that you should visit once in your life

A unique experience!. The Jemaa El Fna truly feels like the hub of Marrakech, by day it is full of stools selling water, orange juice, souvenirs and snacks. It also comes complete with women desperately trying to put henna on you, snake charmers and for a price you can have your picture taken with a monkey on a chain (personally, this really really isn't my come of tea and I felt quite distressed seeing the animals chained up in the sun all day, but this seemed to be a very popular tourist attraction ...).By night the square transforms into an entertainment venue with singing, dancing, theatre and performers - there is also a HUGE food market which is definitely worth a visit. It's incredibly cheap to eat dinner in the square, and is great fun - the food was good and it was enjoyable to mix with other people and have this truly authentic experience in Marrakech.

Bruce Willis and Lady Gah-Gah's Review Below.. The Jemaa el-Fnaa was both a low point and a high point for my husband and I visiting Morocco on our honeymoon in Sept 2013 (happy Belated-Trip-Advisor-Review-Day to me!). You can’t really miss walking through here at some point on a stay in Marrakesh, and why would you want to anyway? Well, I’ll tell you why: because there are snakes. Everywhere. On the ground. And monkeys. On leashes, but they are still just hanging out and about, free as birds (there were no birds, that I recall BTW). Next thing you know Abu is chewing your face off like that crazy chimp here in Stamford a few years ago. So, you are walking and in the distance you’ll see little groups of people and baskets on the ground. Under those baskets are cobras and some kind of other antidote-requiring serpent. I didn’t get close enough to find out what kind of snakes they were. In fact, I made a point to walk in the farthest circumference possible from these mini-camps of reptile petting zoos I could. So far in fact, that while keeping an eye on the snake-stations in the distance, I’d have my back to a monkey man who I was inadvertently creeping up on (or, was he creeping up on me?). Yikes! So, you have to distance yourself from the monkeys and snakes equally, all the while acting like you don’t hear them calling out to you to, “come here little girl, these snakes are friendly!” Yeah, right. I’m from Texas where it’s always a snake-show out the back door, except when you do see a snake, you don’t go toward it. You run like h-e-double-hockey-sticks to the shed to get a hoe to, well, you know what comes next. My mother raised me right and therefore I have no interest in the basket snakes, the chained monkeys, the boxed Box Turtles (what’s up with that!?), or any of the other creatures of Marrakesh. And don’t think you can sneak a picture with your phone of this action because they will call out to you to tip them. So, I have a LOT of blurry, half-fingered covered pictures of this scene. My husband did talk to one of the no-so-charming snake charmers who said he’d just gotten back from Orlando where he’d worked at Disney as a snake charmer for a number of years. So, the irony there is not lost on me. That was the low point. The high point was the actual food stands they set up at night. It is beyond! Endless nuts, figs, dates, fresh juices, and not super cheap, but still really fun to experience. My hubby LOVES figs and dates, so we bought what felt like 100 bucks worth and he was in heaven. The scene at night is far different from the day. Lots of crowds and it all feels a bit more congested due to the food stands and trucks that take up a lot of real estate. We didn’t try any of the actual street food, but I’m sure it would have tasted just as good coming back up as it did going down (I keed, I keed). It’s a chaotic hot mess. There are those people selling the little light up toys that they shoot in the air similar to the Eiffel tower scene. Whatever. Oh, another high point (for my husband) and a low point (for me) was that everywhere we went, some proprietor of Moroccan goods would try to lure us in by telling by hubby that he looks like, “Bruce Willis” (he does) and that I look like “Lady Gah-GAH” (I don’t). Why does my hubs get to look like a total hottie and I look like, well, a nottie?! I’d have rather them tell me I look like Beyonce or at least Cher. Overall, this place was unforgettable.

An amazing experience. In the evenings you literally immerse yourself in a sea of people of all colours and styles watching snake charmers and monkey handlers together with hordes of locals and tourists thronging through the various food stalls where you can drink freshly squeezed orange juice or eat a sheeps head. The quality of the foods available was excellent and very cheap, as four of us ate for a total of 220 Dirham (15stg)

I blame Crosby, Stills and Nash. In all honesty Marrakech is over-hyped and while it seems a romantic destination the truth is somewhat disappointing.
