If you like being harassed by taxi drivers, horse drawn carriage drivers, market stall holders, unofficial guides, sellers of nicked i-phones, Argan oil, water boys, anyone you turn a camera on, restaurant touts, acrobats and the dubiously disabled, not to mention the owners of each and every outlet in the souks that you look at, then this is the holiday for you.If you like being ripped off by the temporary restaurants in the square in the evenings with their clever trick of taking your order then bringing you a few olives, some bread and some salad, which any proper restaurant provides as a freeby, and charging you exorbitantly for these on top of your order, then this is the holiday for you.If you like bland food, despite the mounds of spices being sold right next to where you are dining and, if you are female, like having your arm grabbed by a wandering henna artist who will have a design on the back of your hand before you can react and then want paying for her 'art' then this is the holiday for you.If you simply want to stroll unhindered, photograph the goings on, the street artists. the acrobats, the musicians, without hassle then this definitely not the holiday for you.The smell of sewage that emanates from the each and every manhole cover is not at all pleasant and on entering the souks early enough you will see the stall holders trying to block up any holes in the covers with whatever comes to hand.We spent the most of the holiday saying 'No' to every other person and were left with the impression that it was once a great place that is now overbuilt and drastically in need of a shake up. Pavements are a disgrace and are broken and in need of repair even in the new town, Guerliz, The saving grace is the collection of parks that are a delight to wander round and which are well tended and offer a quiet respite just yards away from the hustle and bustle of the streets.All that said we met a man who said he was on his 14th visit and who was recently engaged to a local girl. It takes all types. We've been, we've seen, we've experienced Marrakech but we won't return.

This is the real morocco! The Medina experience. This is the one place you must visit when in Marakech, the medina or market is what moves the city. It's the busiest and most interesting site. You get to experience old school morocco. The plaza is this huge open space surrounded by small shops selling lamps, crafts, dinnerware, leather items, amongst many others. At the back you will arrive at the food section and you have endless possibilities! I know we want to be super adventurous and get the best foodie experience but I would recommend staying away from the food carts for food, instead go to the cleaner, bigger, a bit more expensive stands surrounding the area. And this was advice from the locals here, they said carts are not hygienic at all so it's a hit or miss. Do try all of the juice carts, amazing citrus juice! In the center of the medina is where all the entertainment happens; comedian, snake charmers, monkeys, singing, music, etc. You will probably be staying close to this area so just head out there and explore. I do advise hitting a drop pin on your phone map when you are in the hotel so you can at least see your location on a map. Behind the medina, where most of the hotels/hostels are, is another shopping section full of little alleys and you will get lost, be prepared! But as long as you have a clear understanding of where you are on the map you will be fine. Don't think you can ask around, not a lot of people know about the hostels or hotels around the area, and if you are staying at an expensive hostel you probably don't want people knowing you are heading out there. Just saying!

Your typical north African square. Snake charmers, monkey men, donkey carts, hawkers of counterfeit goods and overpriced cafees with rooftop terraces - theyre all here. Gets old and annoying pretty soon.

Must experience the world famous market square. It's a one of a kind experiences, densely packed market which is always alive with various performers such as snake charmers, trained monkeys, amatuer artists and musicians, not to mention the myriad of shops and food stalls. However it can be a drain after a short while as most basics of human interactions such as asking for directions or taking a picture seems to require tipping the local and they throw a strop unless you tip "generously" which doesn't make for a very pleasant experience!!

An overload of sights, sounds, and smells.. No visit to Marrakesh is complete without spending some time at Jemaa el Fna. Snake charmers, dancing monkeys, fresh juices, and more, more, more. Don't miss having dinner at the stalls in the evening. Most of them are about the same, but take a look around and chose the one that suits you. Have tea on a terrace overlooking the square and soak it in. A truly amazing place. Beware the "belly dancers", most are men. Beware the "Henna" girls that will grab your hand and tatoo you before you can say "no". Sometimes you just have to be a little rude. Don't be alarmed when someone expects to be paid for a photo that you have taken of them. I just tell them that they happened to be in the field of view and that it is not of them. If they insist, I delete it for them.

The Beating Heart. Jemaa el Fna is world renowned. A large square surrounded by market stalls and on the edge of the Unesco World Heritage Souk. Performers, street vendors and tourists bustlr around the busy place. A must see and worthy of any visit to Marrakech.The street food is really good and part of the experience. The square is flanked with vendors selling all sorts. Some of it sit down food with an obvious Morrocan twist.Try eating here for an authentic visit to Jemaa el Fna.

Buzzing and fun. A great place to go in the late afternoon and early evening. Lots to see, with fire eaters, snake charmers, musicians, dancers and the list goes on. A huge selection of street food vendors with every possible local delicacy. Beware, you are expected to pay to take photographs and, while this is not unreasonable, you can get asked for money by people who are not even in your picture. A must see attraction.

A must see.. I went during the day a couple of times, and once in the evening, although they can be extremely crowded. The barrage of stimulus is exhilarating. If you have seen the Hitchcock film The Man who Knew to Much it hasn't changed much!

Disappointed. Market stalls, cruel snake charmers, monkeys on leads and dressed in nappies... It's a good spot for food and watching the locals listening to story tellers. 20p Orange juice is good. We felt a bit let down by it really.

I just love it. This place is THEE amazing open air theatre of Marrakech. Over the afternoon guys with monkeys / snakes and birds, historical red dressed water seller, and any other musicians you can just imagine try to get you on a picture to earn some money. It is actually amusing how great this always works... even a lot of people might not be happy with it. But just keeping your distance and not giving them your hand ( to grab you ) will keep you out of trouble.Later in the afternoon the food stalls open and offer their selling practices and nice food too. With loads of story tellers, sellers and guys setting up funny games under the sky.The best way in my opinion to enjoy this whole place is to laugh about and to dive into the atmosphere. It is just a great funny game which you hardly see anywhere else.I loved it so much that I even recorded all the noise that was around me.What a different but fascinating little universe.

What a fantastic place. How atmosmeric is this square in the Medina? Packed with stalls piled high with dates. oranges, spices, t-shirts, metalwork, bread etc, etc. As night falls, it fills with story-tellers, djembe drums, acrobats, henna artists. (I was disappointed not to see any snake charmers, though). I was accosted by "Hana", who held my hand in an iron grip and proceeded to draw a henna design on it. I kept saying "I don't want this", but she persisted. it's a pity as I'd love to have taken my time and had it done properly, but in the time that we were together we had a nice chat, and of course I gave her some money. she did seem genuinely desperate to earn something for that day. (The square hadn't been very busy). I am aware of most of the ways to get you to buy stuff, but that was a new one for folk to look out for. Anyway, Marrakech is indeed a challenging place but well worth the effort.

Incredible place!. This is one of the best open markets I have ever been too. It's so rich in every way. The food, entertainment quality, architecture, ambiance and history...just mesmerizing. It's simply beyond words when trying to describe the wealth of this place and city overall. People are amazing! You must visit here at least once in your life!

A cacophony of sights, sounds and smells!. We visited Morocco in June and just loved Marrakesh. The square is an amazing place to visit. You need to get your bearings quickly as it's very easy to get lost just off the edges. Pick a landmark and imprint it into your brain so you know where you are. The snake charmers, story tellers, henna artists, acrobats, dancers and the many other entertainers were fascinating. The sights, sounds, smells and tastes are incredible but be careful of pick pockets and people trying to take you to their shop! A truly fascinating place.

A must!. Highly recommend viewing the square changing from day to evening from the rooftop terraces of Cafe France and Glacier. It might be a little bit intimidating at first but just dive in. After reading reviews I was nervous of the street food stalls but my boyfriend forced me to try them and I'm glad he did because it's a fun Marrakech experience! We also paid for some great photos from the snake charmers but don't let them trick you into paying too much!

Great square annoying men!. As two female travellers this square was a bit much at times. However the Tangia from stall number 47 was amazing in taste and value.We felt safe enough while watching the entertainment but had to keep moving due to the local men standing too close. Many of them don't seem bothered by hijab, but in general it was only mildly irritating.Go and watch the boys fishing for soft drink bottles, sounds odd but it's kind of memorising and they were very friendly and descent with us.Best seen in the evening.

Mad Maroccans all over!!. Hustle and bustle cubed by 100!! Only go there if you can cope with a constant stream of vendors trying to hustle for business!! try the street food as seen on Hairy Bikers!!! Recuperate in the Cafe de France!! Don't get lost in the Medina!!

A three ring circus without a tents. This is the once place you have allow time to savor. I arrived an hour before sunset and walked around visiting with the snake charmers while food vendors were setting up for the evening rush. Get a seat at one of the many roof top cafes and order a drink or snack and watch the sun go down over the city. Its a great fun and a visual delight!
Fascinating. Loved the food and drink stalls, did not much care for the performing monkeys and snakes. Very energetic dancers!

jemaa el fna sqauare. Just about any tourist who comes to Marrakech ,comes to visit Jmaa el Fna square, and its easy to see why? During the day there are snake charmers, storytellers, music players, stalls selling food etc even people with small monkeys doing tricks and somersaults on wooden tressells. At night the square is packed with tourists buying tringkets, having there photograph taken with Berber tribesmen (at a price ofcourse), people having Henna tattoos, not to mention the countless stalls selling fast food and local cuisine (cous cous etc) In English Jmaa el Fna literally means 'Place of the Dead', but in reality this could not be further from the truth, because most nights, this place seems as if its the centre of the universe?.

The square. Went to the square during the day. The weather was cold but dry,snake charmers and monkey's galore with plenty of stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice.The souls were busy but remember to batter the price down they will come down full off hustle and bustle in the evening the rain was torrential and ruined the evening not many food stalls arrived but I can imagine if the weather was fine it would have been a great evening

7. Great place to visit, don't be scared to' haggle' it can be a good laugh, the morrocan people might sound aggresive, but they are just doin'g there thing, Smile and you 'll be fine you will get what you want if u've got the' patience' and a open mind..

brilliant!. This was our second time here. The first time we were on a cruise trip and got rushed round, this time we were staying and we just took our time going round. It is brilliant just to soak in the atmosphere and barter. I can't wait to go back!

Very Interesting. Don't have an early dinner at the cafes on the edge. Wait for nightfall and the vendors that come and setup all kinds of dining stalls bang in the middle of the square. The guys with the monkeys and snakes can be nasty if you don't tip well after taking a picture. Beware!! But one of the key attractions in the city.
A treat for the senses!. Although it can get intense when the crowds are at their fullest, there is always a quiet spot to be found and an understanding shopkeeper to let you in to take a breather.

Tourists targeted. Brace yourself to be seen like a walking source of cash! Henna women will grab your hand and start tattooing you before you notice; men with monkeys or snakes, drummers, will demand cash if you photograph them or look for too long. Boys will suddenly perform summersaults in front of you and expect a tip. Hawkers of goods will pester you constantly. Suitable for those with a strong nerve!

Excitingimpressions. Huge square in front of the Souks: dancing monkeys, snake charmers with cobras, waterman, dawdling with junk, story tellers, drumming musicians;I had the possibility to have a snake on my shoulders .... ;we've been on place threetimes, one was near evening, all of Marrakesh people came together to eat at the stands ...

Authentic market place experience. First night in Marrakech my friends and I enjoyed the food stands on the square Jemaa el Fna. We had a mix of grilled specialities, vegetables and bread with dip sauce. Very simple but altogether an amazing experience counting the smell, people around, faces, sounds - all your sences fullfilled.

Fascinating. You've read the reviews in Rough Guides and Lonely Planets...now immerse yourself in Marrakech. Drink the juice, eat the food, henna the hands, listen to the call to prayer and enjoy the spectacle.

A feast for the senses. A concentration of marrakech in a single square. All your senses are heightened here. your attention is disputed between all the exquisite smells, exotic sounds and personnas! A must in marrakech.

Everything. Sounds smells sights.This is what I expected and wanted from my visit.
Careful of the "guides" and wide boys everybody needs to make a few bob.

Soak it all up!. Huge square in the middle of Marrakech where everything happens from performing monkeys to acrobats to snake charmers and story tellers and the best freshly squeezed orange juice! At night it turns in to a vast open air eating experience with dozens of pop up restaurants all touting for business and all serving excellent food. Give it a go you won't be disappointed.

SNAKES , abound , also monkeys. My wife is TERRIFIED of snakes and we had to be ultra alert as there seems to be no pattern to whether they are in evidence or not on a particular day. It may have been because it was cold and wet while we were there or some other reason. The noise of drumming musicians , belly dancers , street venders vying with each other ,the food stalls the beggars, the --- just go and be overwhelmed

Henna. There were lots of interesting things to see here...monkeys in dresses, snake charmers with cobras, carts full of spices. Watch out for the women with the henna. They saw me buying some leather camels from the man next to them and then grabbed my hand and started drawing on me. They would have gone completely up my arm, if I hadn't forced them to stop. I then had to pay them 600 dirhams before I could walk away.

Lose yourself here!. Take the time to wander. There is so much to absorb - sights, smells, noise, etc. I preferred the interior of this area to the large square with all the snake and monkey handlers. However, make sure that you take the time to have a drink of delicious fresh orange juice and get some dates/nuts/figs. In the interiour part of this area, you will find every kind of retail imaginable and some that you would not even think of. The shop owners were friendly and two in particular were just great - Berbere Tapis, a rug shop run by Chez and his father, and Chinquett, a small jewelry store fun by Dhaidiha Mohamed. Both were very helpful and easy to deal with.

Crazy Busy Market with alot going on. Monkeys,snakes, music, drums. There's alot going on here. But you need to be on guard. There is a alot of shaddy people who are there too.Dont take photos on anything without expecting someone to want you to give them money. People will even want you to pay them if you ask them for directions.Go here with your wits about you and you should be ok. Eat off the stalls at your own peril !!!

be prepared. You can love or hate Jemaa el Fna. towards 5 - 6 pm and onwards it is so full that you can feel intimidated. If that is the case, go more than once to start to like and enjoy the place. If you can overcome the crowds and sellers trying to sell you everything, its a really good and fun experience.

Real Marrakech!?. This was one of the nicest squares I have ever experienced. Experienced is the right word, because there are so many things to see, smell and taste. The juices were great, as were the soup and the grilled meat and fish. The tajine vegetables were a bit overdone (we tried 2 different locations), so you can probably find better around. Next to the food, there were also a lot of different activities ongoing, for the tourists (monkeys...) but also for the locals (story telling...). Sunset with the mosque in the background was great... Prefect place to wander around, completely different in the morning, afternoon en evening!

Sensory Overload!. Its a must see in Marrakech so we did. Quite an experience. The assault on your senses is overwhelming, but remember this is what makes the square what it is famous for. Take it all in but be careful. Unlike open air performances in other parts of the world where you are requested and not obliged to drop some change in a hat - this place is merciless in its demand for payment for anything you look at. Its entertainment - Moroccan style.

The main square - what an experience!. The main square has two faces - the day time face and the night time face. Both are completely different and both are really interesting and various stuff goes on at different times of day and night. The night market was brilliant, we had some great food and there are also some stalls selling pretty gross stuff - sheep heads, eyeballs and snails to name a few (we didn't have any of that, funnily enough!). We met some lovely Moroccan people whilst eating at the night market - everyone is really friendly, especially if you can speak French or even a bit of Arabic! There is a handy ATM right next to the main post office, or you can change money inside the post office in office hours. (You can't easily get Morrocan currency in the UK, but don't worry, there are ATMs all over the place). We did keep a close hand and eye on our bags at all times though and sadly, there are lots of beggar, which can be a bit sad and upsetting at times!

Absolutely mad!. I was extremely scared on my first visit to marrakech. At times i can be very timid and heard so many horror stories! on my return i cannot stress enough to ignore the bad things you read, and to visit with an open mind. take a walk, get lost in the souks and enjoy. people will haggle you in various ways, just be confident with a firm no thank you. you will make mistakes (i was forced in to a henna tattoo as i was too polite to pull my hand away - she wanted 600 dirhams (we paid 150 - it should be 80!!!) but just laugh it off. it is experience, harmless and funny. say a third of the price they offer and start to walk away if they say no..they always come running!! agree a price BEFORE taking any photos of the snakes or monkeys - they will ask for more after the monkey is on your head if you don't. just be brave! at times it can be intimidating (then i just hid behind my boyfriend) - but smile & have a joke - 98% of the morrocans i spoke to were friendly and smiled back!

Fun place to visit, but the vendors are aggressive!. There is a lot of things to see, hear, eat, watch and enjoy...but the vendors for the entertainers, the shop owners and the food vendors are VERY AGGRESSIVE. Be wary - this is the hot place to visit and hang out, but if you start taking pictures, they will start demanding large sums of tips from you. Also food vendors will get very angry when you walk away.

Not keen. I already had a feeling I wouldn't enjoy the main square after reading other reviews. As an animal lover I did find it quite difficult to see the monkeys/snakes/rabbits/birds/turtles being used for entertainment, especially as its incredibly hot and loud, they must be terrified...Also I have been places where you are pressurised into buying things but this was something else, we were very firm but some just wouldn't give up! Regardless I didn't feel unsafe so that was okay, just irritated.

Mixed feelings. First experience couldnt have gone worse, went on day of arrival for a few hours at about 5pm. Must have looked like new arrivals because we got jumped by what seemed like everyone we passed. We stopped at the outer edge to look about,at which point a henna "artist" grabbed my wifes hand and started drawing on it with a syringe of what looked like poo. Despite saying no and my wife trying to pull her hand away the woman carried on. Upon finishing she demanded 500dh for her child we ended up giving her 200dh and going home early wondering why we came to marrakech. Day 2,older and wiser we returned and had more of the same but used the maybe later or no thanks technique which seemed to work. Had lunch on one of the terraces which worked out about £6 each including tip and was pretty good. Wandered the souks and found that trying to avoid eye contact and again saying no thanks worked. Managed a bit of bartering and found that after a visit to arinsal craft market that we had figures in our head of prices so went 10-20dh lower as our topline and the telling them you will look elsewhere tended to work. Lot of stalls are set up with mostly tourist tat and knockoffs but worth a look anyway. The cake and cinnamon drink stalls were great and only about 10dh a sitting. Orange juice was great value at about 20p a glass. Food stalls we tried were very cheap and all were pretty good where you could order a selection from menu and we never paid over about 100dh for 3 courses including drinks each. In the evening all the food stalls pressure you to dine with them and it is actually quite an amusing experience,they will watch you come out of one after eating but still pounce on you to eat with them. There is an ice cream shop with a terrace right at the entrance which gives a great view out across the entire square and you can sit and people watch for a while. The sad part is the condition monkeys are kept in, made to wear nappies and chains which they pull at only to be disciplined by their "masters" then thrown on the next passer-by. In conclusion this has to be seen but i almost feel if i hadnt then i would have gotten over it.

Interesting experience. Very interesting Square with plenty of Souks, cafes, Restaurants, Riads and alley ways. The souks are very pretty but shopkeepers make your life hell unless you buy. You have to haggle a lot to get good deals. There are plenty of roof top cafes with good views of the square and some of the alley ways. The square changes a lot at night where you see tens of food stalls and they also tout you to stop and eat there. although all the hassle we had I thing it was an interesting experience

Almost overwhelming there is so much to see. Loud, colourful, busy, smelly - sometimes all at once! Quite something during the day, incredible at night as it changes atmosphere considerably - food stalls at night are worth wandering around (calamari, chips and aubergine one evening was lovely and very cheap). Could wander round here for hours, people and animal watching. From spices to snakes, monkeys to musicians - so much to see and hear.

Fake City!. If you like your discounted items and "real" fakes as the vendors like to say, then this is the market for you. It is a maze of incredible winding alleys, full of merchandise.Haggling is a must! In the day, in the square you will see monkey dancers, snake charmers and singers. In the night, it turns into somewhat of a crazy eatery with lots of food stalls who can get a bit aggressive to get you to sit down and eat. Be warned. In the square you will find huddles of street performers or "buskers" singing songs for a price. Be careful though, taking pictures, or even giving attention will end up costing you. This often comes in the form of the entertainers demanding some form of payment. 10 Dirham coin is often enough, don't let them intimidate you. An amazing fusion of European, African and Arab.

Main market square. Take it all in and try it all. Just came back having stayed at Riad Andalla just off the main square. My daughters and I took in the whole experience and left nothing back. The taste and smells of Marakesh are like nothing else. While not a typical meals go have a seat and the carts selling goats heads for diner. Try the mixed plates and the meat stew. It was all delicious and perfectly safe. Enjoy!

Bustling and Busy. If you don't mind bartering for items you will enjoy the evening market, the locals are very friendly and you can have a good banter with them as lots do speak good English. As you walk through the food stalls they do hassle you a little but if you just say no thanks they will leave you alone. The square comes alive at night with snake charmers, dancing, music, and lots more, if you do want a photo taken then the locals do expect a little payment! Especially the man who sits playing his banjo with a chicken sitting on his head. The atmosphere is excellent, but make sure your keep your wallet or hanbag close to you.

shoppers heaven!. If you like a bargain this is definately the place to go! I expected to get hassled by shop keepers but was pleasantly suprised. Be prepared to haggle as you really can get some great bargains!You can easily spend a few hours here without even realising the time. There are plenty of restaurants and cafes to stop for a drink or something to eat.Dining is very cheap can have a meal for two for only £10

Magical market. The food stalls really compete for your business to the extent that some of them have their entire staff stop and break into song to attract you!The food is good and cheap!Some of the staff are delightful in their expressions such as "Happy wife...happy life" with an impish look that it's hard not to smile.One yound lad spoke english in a Cockney accent saying Fish and Chips.. The hassle that I experianced living there 44 years ago has all but disappeared.It's now a tourist venue but still has a middle east type of charm.There are musicians and story tellers and even men in drag attracting crowds.You can also enter the shopping medina from here.Guides not are offically licensedand have ID discs. It is now official policy not to hassel tourists.
Surreal!!. Snake charmers, acrobats, street vendors....the square pulses and throbs and intoxicates. See it before you die!

A mad space. Not a square at all but one large stretched out rectangle with smaller spaces off at odd angles. Full of crazy goings on dufing the day and thousands of folk at night. Watching the world go by from one of the cafe terraces overlooking is a must. Coffee is good as well.
good shopping. shops are all basically the same tat but you do get good fake stuff for a very good price if you are willing to haggle

You are going to have to do this, sooner or later. Yes, it's the famous square with its snake-charmers, tooth-pullers, musicians, orange juice sellers and the night market, so you have no choice. Your friends would never speak to you again if you did not go at least once.Your reaction to the square will depend on your experiences elsewhere. If you have been living a sheltered life with your idea of hassle the check-outs at Sainsbury's on a Saturday, you will be bowled over and dazzled, but more experienced travellers are likely to be a little underwhelmed by the experience.The problem with the square is that it is a victim of its own celebrity. Most activity there is designed purely for the benefit of its visitors (tourists and locals), so that snake-charmes, musicians, tooth-pullers and water-carriers are there to extract money for photos, and nothing more.The night market was a little more lively with masses of tented restaurants put up to serve freshly-made food, if you like that sort of thing.So go there, take a few photos if you can, raid the souks if you have the energy, then get on with what Marrakech really has to offer.

A must do. If you are precious about personal space and noise avoid at all cost but if you want to have an experience of colour, sound, bartering and amazing food hang around the square until night fall, Eat at the local stalls and walk the medina,...flat shoes needed! Watch out for being charged for items you did not order but which are given to you freely...olives are generally free and if not ordered specifically by you would not usually be charged for but they will try!!!! Watch out for pick pockets and dont talke anything expensive with you and avoid weating jewellry. Dress simply and go with an open mind and you will enjoy an evening of entertainment, colour, food and culture, Make sure you have a stash of dirham coins for those that wont leave you alone.... take the experiences in your stride and stay calm with your sense of humour turned up high.... you'll love it,,,,,,

a must see + a must be carefull !. a very large square , a impossible mix of non stop 24/7 shows of : story talkers, exotic animals, funny musician and stand up, traditional medicine and many others.in the evening a very sheep, fresh and tasty food market- a must place to be

Chaotic and wonderful!. Main square bustling with snake charmers, street performers, carnival-type games, tea/water carts and food vendors. At night it transforms and by sundown there are hundreds of little restaurants that pop-up in the square surrounded by groups of musicians everywhere! Loved it!!

The very heart of Marakesh. I arrived at the Jemaa el Fna after midnight ... when hectic atmosphere gradually calms down..then returned again in the morning when the market is recovering from last night madness ... this is the very heart of Marakesh ... vibrant, full of memories.
very bussy and colorfull. Lots of interesting things, shows, food... A must see in Morocco. Be carefull of your belongings and expect people to go after your money.
fun. nice market and full of life,people go there for food and drink,all around are hotels and bars also good for shopping nice fruit and good leather goods

Depressing. The best thing about Jemaa el Fna was hearing it,on the wind, from the rooftop garden of the Riad we stayed at. It sounds haunting and mesmerizing,but in reality it is deeply depressing. It is a market that has lost its original charm. There is general 'tat' on sale, knock off goods touted, and dodgy looking mass market food outlets 'enticing' you to dine at tables with Fanta and Coke laid out ready. Worst of all was seeing monkeys dressed in childrens clothes and sunglasses (for photo opportunities), and listless cobras being prodded and poked into action. Sadly once seen, never forgotten.
Visit by day and night - what an amazing place.. Take a drink in one of the Glacier bars or any rooftop bar to enjoy the sight and sounds of all that goes on!

All of Life in one place !. You have to come here when you visit Marrakesh. It is really interesting to wander around all the stalls seeing what is on display. I was not brave enough to eat here but the freshly squeezed orange juice was delicious. As it turned dark the market seemed to come alive more as the lights lit up. I managed to get a seat on the terrace of a restaurant before the rush started and had a great time watching the sunset and the lights below me. I took photographs around the area and had no hassles or trouble and felt as safe as i would anywhere else.

prepared to get hassled ... a lot. Everyone visits the square as its recommended that you get a good spot in one of the cafe's nearby, watch the mad rush to set up all the food stalls in the main square and watch the sunset.I'd recommend getting there for around 4- picking a good spot, having some tea and then leaving once you have your pictures.The square is pretty much solely a tourist area, in terms of all the local surrounding market stalls- they're all pretty much selling the same stuff (pottery/ magnets/ mass produced trinkets/ leather bags), in the square you also get ppl selling fake electronics like samsung phones/ beats headphones/ fake football shirts- you get the idea. I can't imagine any local shopping here.The food stalls were also a disappointment, apparentally stall 1 and 14 are recommended. Food was cheap- a lot of deep fried stuff, next time i'll probably try eating where i can spot the locals.The square is pretty much alcohol free- though apparently you can get some alcohol served in coke cans if you know where. there are a lot of street performers, i particularly disliked the monkeys on chains, which were all made to wear nappies. A particular trick is just for their owners to plonk the monkeys on the shoulders of unsuspecting tourists and then ask for money to take a photo. There are so called snake charmers with their defanged cobras also asking for money for pictures.Women will also hassle you to get henna done.I just felt hassled constantly from all sides.

Full of life. Jemaa el Fna was bustling with life and fun. We did not dare to eat from the stalls, as there were no paper plates. The ladies in our group had henna done to their hands. Do shake on the price before you extend your hand. It gets a little crazy in the evenings as there are bikes and motor bikes going in all directions. We had coffee at Cafe France and Cafe Glacier and lunch at Del Bel Kabir and Cafe Chegnouri, all good.

Hectic Marrakech at its best. Whether by day or night this large square teems with fascinating local life - snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers, stallholders and traditionally dressed water sellers. It's worth paying a small charge (about £2.40 per person) to go up on to the balcony of one of the cafes overlooking the square, especially at night.

Drink Lots Of Fresh Squeezed. As they say - no visit to Marrakesh would be complete without a visit to Jemaa el Fna. Go, and go again. It's a completely different experience from day to night. However night-time is a must !! All the food stalls open in the center of the square and the various entertainers are in full swing. Sunsets there are great !!And drink lots of amazing fresh squeezed orange juice for 50 cents a glass - BEST I HAVE EVER HAD.

Must See. You can't go to Marrakech without going to Jamaa el Fna. Crazy place, but there is nothing like it anywhere. It is extremely crowded every day and a lot of fun. Acrobats, snake charmers, vendors, fortune tellers, etc. Easy to get lost in the crowds. Best to go early in the morning if you want to shop.

Crazy mad square!. So much to see and buy!...... Quite mind boggling...but fun! Make sure you barter.....expect to have to ask for help to find your way out of the souks...... Paying the locals for this service is well worth it!

Exciting. Going to the markets is a must! We went at night and apparently it's very different from the day experience!
Belly dancers, and monkeys are just some of the exciting visuals you see but the smells of the street food gives you the proper Moroccan feel!

A pain in the backside if you want peace, great if you want some bustle.. When you rock up here for the first time you'll be inundated with people trying to sell you rubbish, throwing snakes around your neck or otherwise trying to badger a few dirham off you. Never pay more than 20dh for a picture and always haggle. If you've had enough of someone just smile and walk away, there's nothing they can do but follow you around with their hands out saying "l'argent", they'll soon get bored as you're not playing ball.Otherwise the food is good, a bit expensive and cheaper meals can be had by walking north out of the Medina. I was here at new year and they put on a show with fire and camels, it was alright.

The heart and soul of Marrakech. No trip to Marrakech is complete without a visit to the Jemaa El Fna. It can be a bit of a shock at first with the hustle and bustle of it all but it is an experience. We found early evening a lovely time to visit as the food stalls start to open and the scents start to flow, join in the manic atmosphere as the evening kicks off then we'd go to one of the restaurants with a roof terrace and watch the sun set over the square. You do get hassled a lot but if you smile politely and keep on walking you will be left alone. I found the treatment of animals a bit shocking especially the monkeys, birds and snakes and refused to pay for photos of them and let their suffering continue whilst they are seen as a valuable asset to their owner. I found my money much better spent at the orange juice stalls which were amazing! For a few pence you could have a glass of the most delicious freshly squeezed juice ever and a bit of banter with the friendly stall owners.

New Experiance. Loved this place! It was so different to the norm. Go at night time when you can experiance the great energy of the place - the color, the smells, the texture - it's a real experiance! Make sure you give the exact fee to the biscuit sellers as you may not get back the correct change! Go!

In March not busy. Not as atmospheric as expected and teasing animals not our style. T.V. taken over at night time but a few groups acting out stories and traditional music. Food looked great. Cool in March. Daytime busy with tourists. Watch cars crossing. Certainly not to be missed day or night. People who have visited years ago saying it is not what it was.

A challenge to the average British holiday maker. I wanted to be warm, because it's cold here. This was warm but challenged some aspects of my comfort zone. This was a busy high pressure sales area that was highly stimulating to all the senses. Sadly if people can make a buck out of you the culture seemed to be they would. To survive - Man up and barter.

Very Large Open Space With Lots to Eat. It is in the centre of the Medina. It would be hard not to go here as all roads seem to lead here.The good:The different sorts of food and markets aroundWe came here twice a day. Once to get a mid-day orange juice. And once to get a snack at night. For the orange juice stands we always seemed to get a 2 for 1 deal. Just once we were told we were being unfair for asking and went to a guy further down and got the deal.The bad:Being harassed at all times to eat at a certain place. Even told some offensive things for not choosing a certain food stand.Don't go to the tanneries.

Great market for morrocan traditional souvenirs. Big market with so many different souvenirs to buy, from paitings, dresses, henna tattoo and restaurants everywhere... Visited the Jema el fnna mostly everyday of my trip. A must go to when in Marrakech

marvellous. I loved the square. It makes life back home feel so mundane. It's so vibrant but they will try everything to get a few coins off you but we have so much more than they do so enter into the spirit. What a great place to visit.

Lively but caution with the snake charmers!. Lots to entertain you and the food stalls offer interesting food at good prices. The fried fish stall (no 98) is particularly good. Exercise caution with the snake charmers though. One tried to charge me 200 Dirhams (about £13) for taking a photo with my phone of me with a snake (the size of a slow worm). I gave him 20 Dirhams and walked away.

Marrakech a must do!. The square during the day for me is a bit of a nightmare as I'm snake phobic and its full of snake charmers, but I love Marrakech so it's take deep breath and stick to the edges of the square and you are fairly safe, a lot of the day time stuff can and does contain cruelty to some birds I saw a kestrel on a piece of string with its tail feathers cut off performing tricks. Generally the animals are not too bad, cats appear to do quite well and the horses and most donkeys/mules looked ok the odd one made me a bit sad, but they provide food for them. The souks are a must, and are a lot of fun, yes you can get hassled but generally they will stop when you say no thanks and continue your shopping, I have never felt the slightest bit threatened as a woman, I fact I would say the people are very respectful and helpful. It's a place to enjoy the experience sit and drink mint tea and have fun. At night it completely changes all the day time people disappear and as if by majic the food stalls are there and almost the whole square is transformed into a big food area, I love it!! A lot of the food I would not choose to eat but I respect the fact that this is what the locals and visiting Moroccans eat and at least they eat every part of the animals they kill. But that to one side it's a really good oportunity to try lots of different food, you can see the food and I must say I found a good level of hygiene and have eaten on a number of occasions and not been ill in the slightest. Just watch the water as local water is not for drinking.

Early evening visit. Best seen in the early evening as the various attractions converge on the Square. Be selective about which stall to eat at, and have a good look around before deciding.Food is so so, and you need to be careful when it comes to paying as the bill may be higher than you expect. The stallholders can add a few things if you do not check carefully notwithstanding that a) they have to make a living and b) to most westerners the experience is still relatively cheap.

WOW!. A huge market/bazar in the city where you can get everything you wish - as well as freshly pressed orange juice for 40 Cents! If you're looking for souvenirs - this is the right place. If you go further through the market you will also find nice roof top bars and restaurants. Awesome place and I can definitely recommend it!

Madness. The place varies by the hour but the time to visit is when the sun is setting. Wow; it is an explosion of the senses. Wait a bit for the queues to form at the best restaurant stalls. We went to one of the fish ones and had to wait 15 minutes for a bench but well worth the wait. Prices are made clear, portions generous and food freshly cooked.Lots of varied activity occurs on the outer fringes; well worth the promenade.
A MUST. One cannot leave Marrakesch without spending some time here Pamper all of your senses. E N J O Y....the sights, sounds, scents and flavors of Marrakesch.

Its not for the faint of heart!. A place to go for experience,i love the orange juice stalls, they are fresh and cheap at only 5dh per plactic cup..there is a lot to see especially at night from the food stalls to the monkeys and snake charmers. But what i really dislike are the pedlars that forces you to eat or buy what they are selling even the ladies who does henna tattoo, they keep on pestering you to the point of harassment. Hence you have to be firm to say no and a polite no is no good. One of the pedlars in the food stalls even tried to hold my arms just so we would go and eat at their stalls..the food in the stalls are also serve by hand. I think it is acceptable for them to touch the food they are selling. By and large, still its a must see!

Noisy, busy, colourful!. A great place to go in the evening. Fantastic atmosphere! Loved the orange juice stalls and the spice merchants. Disliked the attitude of some pedlars if you don't wish to buy anything. But all in all a great experience!

A must-see experience in Marrakech.. A must-see in Marrakech, especially at night. There's a few interesting sights (monkeys, snake charmers) and we would certainly recommend eating in the market. Probably the best meal we had in Marrakech.

Good fun but don't take photos unless you are willing to pay for them.. It is all good fun. During the day the snake charmers etc get. Dry aggressive if you take photos and don't give them some money. Same goes for everyone In this square. However at night there is a much lighter mood among the food stall sprookers who will have a laugh with you. We really enjoyed the theatre of the food stalls at night.

bedlum. Rated 3 stars as worth the experience to say you have been. But for me was too many guys wanting to sell me phones, glasses and watches. Noisy hustle and bustle, you have to embrace. Hated the monkeys, sad to see commercial gain from making animals lives so miserable, performing for tourists.

Something different – good and bad. Jemaa el Fna is the great square in Marrakech, the noise, smells and atmosphere can't be captured in a photo. Cobras, monkey on-a-chain (treated very badly), story tellers, acrobats, belly dancers etc. are part of the bustle on the square. Watching is free, photos result in demands for money-don’t pay more than 10MAD. Always be firm, don’t be afraid to say no.It is an amazing square with entrances to the souks and surrounded by cafes - go for one with upstairs terrace where you can sit and observe, and take photos without being hassled. I recommend the one on the right side when you walk from Koutubia into square (tea/coffee 20MAD).The orange juice, freshly squeezed orange juice for 4 MAD a glass or in a plastic cap 5MAD, grapefruit 10-15MAD for a glass. I recommend juice stall 24 (very good quality juices) – opposite of number 25.After 5pm the square fills up with food stalls. Avoid food stall 25 – the food was crap and they asked for 280MAD for 2 person! 4 German guys sitting next to us, paid 100 Euros-unbelievable! I just refused and paid only 150MAD. Again, be firm when they try to con you and before you order, ALWAYS ask for a price! And by the way, maybe it is worth to eat there once just to see it, but we preferred to eat far from the square where other locals eat so you still have real Moroccan food and often pay less.

Unmissable. Better at night when it really comes to life. Stroll through the myriad of activities or watch from a first floor vantage point with a coffee or ice cream. So much to see, and do, and buy.

Vibrant and slight mad especially in evening.. Visited almost every day but only once at night to eat. No ill effects thankfully after eating brochette, cous cous, frites and vegetables at one of stalls, Loved the theatre of it all. Stayed with non-advernturous menu and didn't look too closely at some of the other offerings. Saw Moroccan ladyboys, snake charmers, performing monkeys ( anyone who worries about animal rights don't look too closely). Watch out for anyone who wants to show you anywhere and ignore any advice on ways being closed or attractions not being open.

Too commercial and very unfriendly people. I did not find it as magical as Always said, very commercial, too many tourists, many fakers and liers, locals will not help you there if you need to find something, they will point you to the wrong direction, everything is available here for money !

Madness!!!. Did not like the snakes or the monkeys on leads one bit even though they are part of the Square. But the noise and hussle, shouting and smells are fantastic! Stay chilled when you go in the evening - you are going to be enticed to eat at every stall or to buy something for 'best price' - it's fun rather than scary. One thing though - ladies DONT let a hena artist have your hand for a little taste, it's not good and they will hound you. It's an amazing sight by about 8pm

A fascinating experience!. By day there are stalls selling orange juice,local produce, tourist gift shops etc. By night the square transforms into a crazy market with grills surrounded by benches selling food, singing, dancing and entertainment. Steer clear of the snake charmers and monkey performers as they will ask for tips to look, and keep your belongings safe as we were warned repeatedly about pickpockets.Be prepared to be hassled by the men working on the grill stands as they try to get you to eat there, but if you carry on walking and say no thanks they move onto the next person.

The square. Seeing monkeys dressed up for photos is cruel I didn't like to see that. The square is full of the same stalls selling oranges, or nuts and dried fruit or cheap cafes selling morroco no fast food . Better to go eat in a nice Riad like cafe Arab or any other good places. The square is good to walk through to see. A crazy place but nice and safe.

Great orange juice. Swear clear of the monkeys , the snake charmers, and the Berbers selling water, but DO try the freshly squeezed oranges, the carts are beautiful and at only 4 dirhams each drink great value

amazing plaza full of life. This plaza is well know in all reviews. There is not a single review that can prepare you for it. During the day, you see the odd stand with guys and snakes around it playing instruments and such. Even people asking you to dress up as locals for pictures and a tip of course. At about 430 pm until late at night this plaza explodes with life. Countless make shift restaurants, stands with all kinds of pure juices, stands with all sorts of nuts and people selling everything. You can also find people telling stories, people betting in really fun games, singers, performers, you name it. All the shops in and around as well as restaurants are also open. The ambiance is superb and definitely a must see. The best part... extremely safe regardless how late it is.

FANTASTIC ATMOSPHERE. We went here at dusk and watched the medina come to life from the balcony of the Cafe Glacier - great views from up there! It's a fascinating place with all the street sellers / snake charmers / food stalls etc. and definitely worth visiting in early evening to take in the sunset and watch the square come alive.

Food market. Beware. When the food stalls are set up in the evening they will all naturally vie for your business. That is when the problems start.You sit and order. Meanwhile small dishes are set before you with what looks like tasters on them( we sent ours back..didn't go down well with them). Noticed two couples near us with a few dishes laid before them. One couple in particular had more and more arriving all the time. The first couple naturally questioned their bill. Only to be told it was correct as each plate was counted. Far more than they had expected. The next couple had a bill of 40€ for a lot of food they hadn't ordered or even eaten. It was just sat on the table untouched. They payed but clearly not happy. When it came to us. I had already totalled our bill and because we sent away all that we hadn't ordered they decided to increase the bill anyway. When I told them they were wrong that they should bring me the menu and I would show them. They tried to bring me a different menu in a different language. I refused until they showed me the large menu in English which one of them had just moved. At thus stage they told me to pay what I wanted! Beware...nothing is free , despite what might be implied.

Jemaa el Fna. Best time to go is at night. Try and get to Cafe de France, top terrace and get a mint tea as you watch the sun going down over the market - be seated by 6pm. Fabulous views. The market is a hub of activity and haggling is expected. The stalls in the centre tend to be cheaper but we found an amazing stall en route to the Berbere market which had kaftans for 50 dirhams - stunning ones. 50 dirhams is less than £4,00! The noise, lights, music etc were all thrilling. At no point did we feel unsafe and there was no sign of the pickpockets we were warned about. taxis are plentiful for the return journey to the hotels, but you need to negotiate a good price - we paid 40 dirhams for the return journey of around 2-3 miles and felt that was fair as taxi drivers have to pay to get a spot there

Atmosphere in bucketloads. Whatever time of the day you visit there is always something going on. For the basic stalls selling veg and fruit and orange juice to the snake charmers, monkey handlers, Berber bands it is a feast for the eyes and senses. It is especially atmospheric at night when there are loads of stalls selling food , cheaper than anything else in the city,all vying for your business with delicious local dishes. Plus the bands, the firecrackers, the smoke, the colours and delicious smells........go!

busy and chaotic. busy and chaotic but interesting must see if in Marrakesh we go to the restaurant on one the roof tops and that is the best view you can have of all the snake charmers and all the other dancers and henna tattooers, there is lot to see.

Experience. This is a good experience, go hang around, eat at the many places around the square, have a drink. Watch the world go by and enjoy the entertainers. Be good, if you take photos remember to pay for the privilege

aka Main Square. Stalls selling the usual tap but interesting to stroll round. Restraunts spring up in the evening but did not sample. Upset to see photographers using monkey to attract tourists. One tiny baby trying to crawl up owner. Obviously desparate for comfort

Very lively place. A must see!. The Jemma al Fna is truly remarkable. Do:- Visit the square during the day first, to get a feel of the place and gather your bearings. - Try the food the different stalls offer. They are freshly cooked in front of you and locals eat there too. Usually after 6pm the square comes alive. - Have a freshly squeezed orange juice for 4 dirhams. It's very refreshing as the square is noisy and chaotic. - During the day have mint tea or a soft drink whist sitting on an upstairs terrace and take in the gorgeous view. Don't:- Buy things you are not interested in. I was approached on numerous occasions to go into shops and then look at things which I had no interest in. A polite, firm no is sufficient. (Everyone is friendly but they can also be pushy into making a sale). - Exchange money at the hotel. There is a small bank situated by the entrance of the square which I found offer better rates. - Take photos of the snake charmers, unless you are prepared to pay for the privilege! - Be confined to stay within the square, venture into the lanes and explore the souks.
Festival madness. Like Glasto only bigger and without the mud and great music :-) No I can't bloody say more, i have a life
Exotic and fascinating. If you are in Marrakech you simply have to visit here. It is a hive of activity - monkeys, snakes being charmed, dancing, music, traders.

Noisy, busy, chaotic ... Fantastic. The heart of the city, watch it from above in a terrace and get down into the chaos of the square.Don't miss the change of scenary at about 4:30 when the restaurants appear as if from nowhere.Take a walk around them all, see what they serve and how busy they are then go and enjoy dinner in one of them .We went to number 32, very busy, very noisy, geat fun!
Busy but interesting. The main hub in Marrakech, everything from snake charmers to fruit juice. Noisy, busy but an essential visit.

Interesting place. By day there are snake charmers, people with and berbers all wanting you to pay for photos. At night the place fills with places to eat. The square is always a good place to get your bearings.

Chaos that is unique. Coming from India, I am pretty used to crowded streets and chaos in general however this square is different in its own way. So many people yet a sense of calmness. The shopping in the smaller lanes connected to the square are worth a visit
Love the bargain. If you can bargain then you can do a lot of shopping..luckily I had brought an empty suitcase so I could bring back a lot of gifts and souvenirs.. :) love the hectic atmosphere..

Everything you thought it would be. It all happens here. Thoroughly enjoyed it. I came back night after night for more... it never changes but it's never the same! Always something new to see or experience! Enjoy

Good for people watching. Amazing huge square with entrances to the souks opening off, and surrounded by cafes - go for one with upstairs terrace where you can sit and observe, and take photos without being hassled for baksheesh! The orange juice , freshly squeezed for 4 dirhams a glass, is gorgeous.
A must-do. Enjoy it in the morning , in the afternoon and in the evening, 3 different experiences, do not forget to eat in one of tyhe food stalls, cheap and good, at least my experience!

Disappointing. We found this famous square did not live up to expectations. We arrived just before sunset as we had been told to go to one of the cafes and sit upstairs with a drink to watch events unfold. It seemed everyone had the same idea and the cafe we chose charged over-the-odds for drinks, we had to queue to get in and couldn`t see much when we were there. The square was very crowded so found it difficult to get close to any of the happenings. After some time just wandering we decided it wasn`t worth the effort so made our way back to our peaceful riad for a delicious dinner!

An experience and a must in Marrakech. It's vibrant with life and an entirely different exerience in the evening as the place fills up with food stands and people of all walks. The ideal is to experience the place Jemaa el Fna in the late afternoon and evening as you see and feel the place become and amazing hub of activity and the smell of food, crowds and noise reaches it's climax. All around the place are the souks so you can eat an shop to your heart's content.

Loads going on but be prepared to be badgered. All manner of stuff going on in the square. It's all about getting money from you though so be prepared to be sold all manner of stuff. Nice views from various eateries surrounding the square. Felt quite sorry for the monkeys and snakes.

Focal point of Marrakech. start here before sightseeing.cafes line the square.and are fine for lunch too.used to be packed with stalls ,people, carts , mules, and horses.less of all of that nowadays, and scooters and cars are taking over.the character is still there, but it is fading.......

Evenings offer great food from stalls. Jemaa el Fna is the great square in Marrakech, a convenient point of orientation for all your wanderings in the Medina. February isn't the best time to visit, as the daytime entertainment by locals is rather limited - a couple of snake charmers, one lone, sad monkey with owner, and a few other attractions. But at night it is more interesting, especially the huge array of excellent food, freshly prepared for you. It's also more entertaining, with a drum circle or two, more wandering entertainers, etc. During the daytime, it's pleasant to eat in a terraced restaurant with view of the square.
Wonderous at night!. We went here on a tour booked through thomsons partners and we had only 40 mins there with the group but we found great deals and unique items a must see!

Amusing chaos - almost free. This is Marrakech! The square is the entry to the markets, which were the historic consolidation point for trade through two key mountain passes in the Atlas Mountains.Today, much of the merchandise is "made in China" or similar, yet the atmosphere remains.Dancing cobras, monkey-on-a-chain, fortune tellars etc are part of the bustle on the square. Watching is free. Photos result in harsh demands for money - your choice
Authentic food. Attention, don't eat at the outer lines of the food stands at the plaza, try to get inside where the locals have their meals, much better food and cheaper!!!

Both day and night - Jemaa el Fna excites. We went our first day and found snake charmers, merchants, dancers, food. It was glorious. We went back today for dinner and found more food and merchants. The atmosphere was on full tilt. A blast for us middle aged folk but saw many kids and young adults having a great time, too. People watching, running away from merchants, having fine food, tea or dessert. A favorite!

Amazing place. if you are looking for action, this is the place to go! especially in the evening. There are places to eat dinner, to have dessert, to have a fruit juice after that, and if you dare, also have a snail soup.

craziest place I've ever been makes Cairo seem tame. The noise smells and atmosphere can't be captured in a photo You will be accosted by henna tattooists snake charmers, belly dancers and even a monkey in a dress !! Great fun place but not for the faint hearted Also some excellent food stalls in centre

The heart of the red city. Jemma el Fna is like nowhere else I have been. Yes it is not a beauty but it is the heart of Marrakech especially at night when the place is filled with food stalls. During the day it is a fascinating mix of snake charmers, musicians and purveyors of orange juice, teeth and hen tattoos.

"Disgusting". I visited this square and was disgusted with what I seen , the donkeys and horses are whipped to death , they all looK so sad, malnourished , fur all matted and spend all day and night attached to the carriages, the monkeys really broke my heart , they are kept in the smallest boxes and when they are let out they are tied to a chain and made to do tricks and tortured. Tourists need to stop funding this behaviour It is not acceptable , it spoils what could be a nice place!!

Energy packed environment. Jemaa el fna is one of those places which transform completely once the sun sets.The daytime bazaar with shops and charmers and stands, trying to sell you stuff, change into a food square with an enormous choice of food.

Overwhelming experience . This place is heaven and hell! Once you dive into it and the souks (which are really one thing...) the overwhelming diversity of flavours and noise might just take your breath. Most of the places and People around are likely to Start shouting, singing, dancing,... to get your attention. This place is one of the touristic hotspots of the city. In case that you will want to eat sth. this is also a good place since the whole square faces regular controls (food security). A great Start is one of the many stands which sell fresh orange juice for 4 Dh (approx. 0,4€) and then take a long walk just following your own nose. Be aware that you will permanently be asked to pay either for taking a picture (beware of monkeys and snakes) or be drawn into one of the many shops (or people sitting on the floor). If you look alot like a Tourist (and you are most likely to do so) know ahead that every favour you will receive will be followed by a request for money. I still recommend you to get sb to show around, since especcially in the souks it's hard to find the way to certain places on your own. For example once a week the Berber people are coming to the city to craft the leather which is interesting to see. And there is Way more in the souks starting from here.But most Important: take your time to see and experience this place. And try the juice!

WORTH THE TRIP TO MARROCOS. This is an amaizing square, huge, very lively, a must visit while passing through this Earth ! We were there ona Friday ad a Saturday night, hyndreds os thousand of Marrocans enjoying this trully public space. Food and market are incredible.

Crazy Place. An assault on all senses - sight, sounds, smells. Beggars, snake charmers, monkeys, shoe cleaners, orange juice vendors, henna ladies, crazy taxi drivers, mad people on mopeds. Go during the day and it's hot and dusty, as the sun sets the hot food vendors set up their stalls. Use your fingers to eat off the paper, it's cheap and fun.

Openly cruel to animals. If you are an animal lover i would avoid this area.I have just arrived back from a 5 day trip to Marrakesh and was shocked by what i saw.I was unable to enjoy the good attractions on offer due to the cruelty openly displayed. Monkeys on chains , wearing nappies and dresses being dragged about to be placed on tourists shoulders for a photo!!!! then when they are not needed being placed in a small box until the next tourist comes along.Snake charmers continually making the snake perform and when not obliging giving it a slap. Horses being used to cart people around in carriages from dawn till dusk in the heat and the manic traffic. I understand it is a way of life and a living for these people but if tourists condone the abuse it will carry on.There were lots of people begging on our way to the square and we did witness disabled people being wheeled into an area to beg and hopefully collected later as they were unable to move the wheelchair themselves.Our guild also warned us of pickpockets which a lot of time are children being used by their parents to do this.Unfortunately the whole trip was mard by the lack of respect for animals and we wouldn't return not just to the square but also morrocco.

Ramedaan Madness. This is "the place" to see in Marakesh. Snake charmers, artists, food, food and MORE food! Jam-packed with people day & night. Crazy during Ramedaan because tempers are getting pretty short around 4 p.m., due to fasting all day - no food 'til sundown! Also,hard to score an alcoholic beverage during this time!

don't give the snake guys money!. No visit to Marrakech is complete without visiting this place. It is out of this world and worth 2 visits at least: one in the day and another at night. The actual Jemaa is a large square where a lot of the old merchants would have their stalls but now in the day time it is host to snake charmers, ladies trying to give you henna tattoos, kids trying to sell you packs of tissue and small bands playing traditional music. The snake charmers were amazing but be warned: if you choose to take a picture (and you look like a foreigner) they will come up to you and will not stop hasseling you until you give them money and not "coin" money but "bill" money. We went to the Jemaa on our first day in Marrakech so my bf and I lost a bit of money: 400Dh to be exact!!! We made the mistake of feeling some sort of obligation to give them what they asked for (which quickly dissipates the longer you are in Marrakech). So my advise is One: stop taking pictures so obviously, 2. never take out your wallet (always have some small bills and change in your front pocket and say "this is all I have, take it or leave it. They will always take it if you are firm that that is all you have. 3. sometimes watching is enough. This is a don't miss kind of place in the medina.
lively and interesting. A great place to soak up the atmosphere of sellers and street entertainers - and bag a bargain! People very friendly and more hassle-free than expected.

Wonderful by day, beware of bullies at night. As exciting and wonderful as this plaza is by day, we had repeated incidents where local men tried to bully us into contributing money to musicians, snake charmers, monkey handlers, etc. For example if you just glance over at a group of musicians playing in a circle on the ground, several of these blokes will jump up and demand that you give money for the entertainment. Same thing when taking photographs -- you can find yourself suddenly surrounded by a bullying mob demanding that you pay. It's entirely unclear who will actually receive the "ransom", the bullies or the musicians. Until the local authorities show a bit more presence and help get this under control, just beware of this plaza by night.
F A N T A S T I C. Unmissable! If you love street food, mixing with locals, hubbub, street seller, that's the place! Eat there 2 or 3 times and never the smallest problem. Loved it.

Constant. If you love noise, crowds, entertainment, bombardment, colour this is the place for you. Beware the women who do henna. They are very persistent and a bit intimidating as they can hold your wrist and get you hooked in before you even know it. Be aware that there are dressed up monkeys who are put on you unless you give them a wide berth. Once 'trapped' it is very difficult to escape - anything!!It is a fascinating place to experience but if you like taking photos they will often approach you for payment. Toilets often require payment. The best places to go are the better restaurants and hotels. Not all eating places have toilets in main square. Dress conservatively (particularly women) as you will get stared at. The square is smaller than I anticipated although there is lots to look at, - if you get the opportunity or are prepared to constantly say no.We really enjoyed the experience, but in our opinion, once or twice is enough.

Jemaa el Fna. Great area to visit during the night and day. Lovely stalls selling bags, clothes and souvenirs to bring back home. Prices are inflated but this is a place were you have to bargain to get a good deal. Plenty of places to eat too and its nice to taste the local dishes. Be prepared for folk to always ask money. If you look at a show or take a picture of someone then they will ask for money and trust me they know who is watching their acts and who is taking a picture. It can get a bit to much at time but over all a good experience.

woot woot woot. Amazingly unique and crowded with all the buyer, the seller, food stall, tourist, street attraction..Magnifique energy....I love this place, a lot of fresh food , try the freshly squezzed orange juice and the snail snack, it is amazing.. one of the best place in Marrakech, interesting shop selling very special nature stuff, try to bargain on everything you buy.. Jemaa el Fna is an experience

Walk quickly and carefully through this Square to a cafe or the medina. Unfortunately it could be fun and wonderful, full of interesting sights, sounds and colors, but it is ruined by all the hassling,begging and fakery. It is best to go over by the fruit sellers and watch from behind one of their carts. I would happily buy some oranges to be left alone!

Fun!. This place is really neat- very much what we expected when thinking of the Jemaa el Fna with the snake charmers and performers and selling booths. It was fun, if super touristy, with lots of places to sit down and just observe the pandemonium. Careful not to take pictures of one of the performers unless you want to pay.

Qevening visit.. S everyone says you can't come to the city without coming here. Our best experience was in the evening as the sun went down and the strings and single light bulbs came on around and above all the food stalls creating interesting up lighting of the many smoking stalls. We spent one evening walking through and sampling but a couple of days later we enjoyed taking tea and a light meal in one of the rooftop cafes looking across the square. Atmospheric even if you have done it before.

Unmissable . Provided you are expecting the hassle you are going to get them this is one of the best places in Marrakech and truly unmissable. Read the guides on how to deal with the street performers and salesmen, when you can see past this minor irritation it is a truly magnificent spectacle. The stalls get set up at 4pm, combined with watching the sun set these are two of the greatest things to observe. Head to one of the rooftop restaurants on the east side of the square and get a good seat early and enjoy some mint tea.

Unique. Love it or hate it this is like nothing else.Busy during the day,but any of the surrounding cafes serve a good coffee.Evenings are very different,the noise is tremendous,smell of food,and so much colour.We did not stay around very long (my husband hated it)but it's still an experience not to be missed.The henna ladies are a pain as are the ones selling silver bangles.

Visit at sunset and beyond. Use your travel books for the best views over the square, everywhere knows u are waiting for sunset so they don't hustle u to move as u nursing you mint tea or coffee.. Still an amazing place and the kids were overawed. Look out for the tooth pullers and the fixed price stalls round the outside- a great non hastle way of buying a few bits and pieces before your return.

The Real Thing. We eat at # 1, Endorsed by trip advisor had a lovely and economical dinner on the plaza. I'm sure the fish and meat options are richer in flavor, but I don't eat meat and fish seamed risky to me when traveling. We had tea in one of the rooftops and made some friends, easy to make friends in Marrakech.

Worth The Visit!!!. From what I heard and what I saw, I'd say it was overrated. That being said, if you get an opportunity to visit the square you gotta!!! Good banter, vibrant colours and fun visit all round!

A must.. While in marrakech you must visit the food stalls in Jamaa el Fna at night. It is very annimated, prices are quite reasonable but do check your bill before paying! Afterwards you can wander round the square and see the snake charmers, monkeys, story tellers and even have yoursely weighted!!!
Bizzarely Gorgeous. This bustling with energy square is beyond description with words. It is a place you have to experience for yourself rather than reading about it. Very highly recommended.

amazing square. this square is one of the most fascinating I have ever visited. It's not just the architecture of the buildings surrounding it that will capture your eyes and imagination, it's the never-ending variety of human faces and stereotypes which will amaze you. Man playing with dangerous snakes, with monkeys, man singing mysterious ballads at night. this place never rests and offers you a different spectacle in the morning, in the afternoon and at night. I would love to come back one day.

Eye opener . Absolutely love this place. As people have already said it is a huge assault on your senses. Vibrant colours, music from many street entertainers, monkeys, snakes, call to prayer from the 4 surrounding mosques, the smell of tagines being cooked in the many restaurants and street stalls. The list goes on but I would be here all day. Can't wait to return to the hussle and bustle of Jemaa el Fna

Widespread Animal Abuse. Jemaa el Fna is an experience--everyone is trying to make money on the tourists selling various tchotchkes, henna painting, story telling, etc. All this could be quite exciting and exotic except for the widespread animal abuse. Dozens of monkeys are yanked around on chains and forced to do flips and pose with tourists. When not out attracting tourist cash, they're in tiny dark cages. Various snakes are put out, wrapped around tourist necks, dragged into crowds to be "charmed." Then small hungry rodents are let out of their cages and need to run a gauntlet of snakes in order to reach their food. All this in the name of entertainment. Then there are the carriage horses. These poor creatures stand on stone surfaces all day wearing steel shoes rather than rubber to absorb some of the impact. In February many were overheated; I can only imagine how awful it must be for them in summer. Turtles for sale are crammed together in filthy cages. Everywhere went in the medina I saw widespread animal abuse and it made me sick. I could not enjoy the other aspects of Marrakech.

A bath in a sea of people.... We visited this square a number of times during our stay in Marrakesh at many different times of the day, from six in the morning to midnight. Every time it was completely different. And most of the time charming and bustling with people. We will most certainly come back.
assault your sences. crazy mad place lots going on just stroll in best at night a mad but good experience very safe and the smells and sounds are great

busy and crazy. We had a horse and cart ride. Very good. The entertainment in the main square at night was very Berbers music and dancing based. Lots of groups, but pretty much the same.
The food on offer was the lesser parts of animals and snails etc. ... if you are into heads, ears, eyes then this would be a delicacy

The only place I felt unsafe. I really didn't like this place. Everyone wants money for something. We were bombarded by people trying to get us to take photos for money. Women grabbing my hands to try and henna tatoo them. Children begging, pick pockets roaming the crowds. It is overrated. Give it a miss.

A place that comes alive by day and night.. Everything about Marrakech revolves around this place. The souls, dances, snake charmers, food stalls, orange stalls and restaurants. If you want to look in forum a distance I recommend the balcony restaurants around the square.... well worth a visit!

i love this place!!!!. Wow and wow again its all here guys hustle and bustle fakirs snake charmers monkeys with dresses on and fabulous things to eat , i visited four times and could'nt get enough of it just go with theflow and like all holiday destinations just be careful of your bags and wallets its no different to anywhere else

Central place to visit and start seeing Marrakesh. This is the great central square, a mixture of colors, languages, sellers, tourists, and scents. A great place to have a fresh juice, talk to locals, eat something, and purchase pretty much anything you want.Be weary of scammers, and pick pockets as usual in placed like this, and negotiate very very hard on anything you want to buy.There is no price on anything for a reason. General guideline, pay 25% of what you are quoted at start or less.
Interesting!. The snake charmers and the monkey handlers want your paper money....not coins. Negociate a price in advance.

Weird and way too touristy. Very phony activities designed to attract night life and get money from tourists. Not my cup of tea. Go for a walk through the old town and get a better feel for life in Marrakech.

Stand 120. We always try and eat with the locals when e go aay and this stall seemed to have more locals than tourists. Great food and service. Dinner for two of us cost 150 Dirhams including a bottle of fanta each. They sat us near the back so we werent hassled by street sellers, had great banter and no pressure to buy, tip or leave. £10 dinner for two, cheaper than Asda as they like to say.

Didn't enjoy. Too many animals being used.. Photos with monkeys in nappies having photos taken with tourists.. Understand they have to make money but didn't like this aspect.. However enjoyed colours and national costumes

Take a seat and watch the world go by. The centre of Marrakech life - grab a coffee at one of the numerous cafes and just people watch.....traders, performers, beggars, tourists - they're all to be found there.Yes it's very touristy and there is always someone trying to get you to part with your cash but a firm and polite no works. You have to visit at least twice - during daylight hours and again as the sun goes down when the atmosphere changes and the food stalls are touting their wares.
