We have been numerous times and have never felt unsafe (no more than any other big city) and again enjoy the banter with the guys trying to entice you to eat at their stall. Just go with the right attitude and if you want to have fun you will!

Chaotic and crazy. Pretty chaotic- full of music, smells, colours and people. But beware all the rip off merchants e.g. snake charmers and henna tattooists just waiting to aggressively demand money for not very much at all. You have to haggle like crazy because their initial price is fantastically over-inflated. Good things to buy are local spices, sweets, leather goods and local arts/crafts. Fake merchandise isn't that obviously displayed and of average quality. Dont bother with a 'guide', the area is actually quite small and you wont be lost for long. Eat the food at your own risk!!

Just enjoy it. Just enjoy the hussle and bussle of this square but still pay attention to your belongings. Eat at one of the market stalls at night or have a fresh orange juice and some nuts and look at all the people that are there. The fortune tellers, the snake handlers, the guy who sells false teeth and unfortunately the guys with the monkeys.

Soo much to look at!. Worth visiting during the day (keeping away from the snake charmers!) and then sitting at one of the terrace cafe's overlooking late afternooon as the locals set up the stalls and the square totally changes! Very noisy and busy but that's Marrakech! Eat at the stall's, pick the ones with the most locals and that seemed work for us! 14 & 31 are the best and cheapest! wait for a seat rather than getting convinced to move on to another where all the tourists are! Had food there most nights and no tummy issues (including an 8 year old child).

Manic,Mahem but Marvelous.. THIS SQUARE IS WONDERFUL. We thought stall 114 had the best food, you can look at the food and choose what you want, 114 has certainly the most entertaining waiters. Sit and eat and enjoy the hawkers, singers, musicians, snake charmers, monkeys, foot traffic, bikes, motorbikes, donkey and carts and call to prayer and experience the life of Marrakech. Then walk off your food through the souks and learn to haggle even though it's good value to start with!!
if you enjoy the hustle. you will like it, trained monkeys for photos with children, and other circus-like attractions during the day, more music after dark, the square is always packed with crowds

Magical Place. i stayed in Marrakech for 4 days recently and no matter how often we visited Jemma'a El Fna'a, we just couldn't get enough of the place.it is a magical experience...snake charmers, smells of spices, candles and lanterns, sizzling food, muezzins calling, vendors hawking, singing, dancing, story-telling, lads selling fillings. it is just an assault on the senses and absolutely magnificent.Sunset is fabulous there too, so many rooftop cafes to choose from but for me, the Cafe El Chegrouni was the best view. Brilliant place, you can't avoid it... but you won't want to leave it.

Not bad and not out of the world. all reviews of the square are either totally positive or totally negativeThis place is a plaza or a square, it is huge and it is full of people.... So there is always energy and life Its full of locals and tourists which means its not a pure tourist trapMy high points wereThe orange juice guys - have 2 glasses a day at leastThe evening street restaurants - an entire seating restaurant market sets up in the evening with good foodThe tea and sweet street carts ...after food grab a glass of tea here in the middle of the squareWhat I did not likeThe pushy touts trying to sell you something or pull you into a restaurant.Its central to the tourist life in Marrakesh so love it or hate it you can't skip it ever
Why else would you go to Marrakech?. An assault on all of your senses and not to be missed - but nice to retreat to the calm of your hotel

Touristic but a must see. Come here late afternoon when the place fills with eateries and public. Drink an orange juice (and a second for the real, half price) and wonder that not too many things have changed over the last centuries.

A great sensory experience. Brilliant during the day. Worth a visit at night but a bit overpowering for me and my family. A bit more fluency in French would probably have helped stave off some of the attention

See it by day and by night. I enjoyed wandering around the square and did go a few times as it was very close to our hostel. It was also a good focal point to head back for (or be directed back to) whenever we got lost. During the day it was fun to have freshly made orange juice and look at various items for sale. There were also several cafes just on the side of the square to have some nice food in before heading into the souqs. It was also a different experience to be in the square when the call to prayer happened from the nearby mosques. At night, we went to visit the various food stalls (there were over 100) for dinner on a few of the evenings. Most of the stalls seemed to be selling the same and we didn't find the food to be as tasty as in surrounding cafes although it was a really great experience to sit in the busy square and eat. Even though the sellers advertise that it is "all the same food, just different faces selling it" we did notice a difference between stalls and learnt to go for the busiest stalls.What puts me off giving the square a higher rating was the number of monkey trainers and snake charmers that we came across. We did not go near these but saw how the monkeys were chained and pulled around for photos with tourists and it made me and my friends really sad to see.

Hell. I'm claustrophobic, which might be one reason why I though this was hell, but if you enjoy being harangued by thousands of people, seeing animal cruelty and buying very inexpensive oranges, then this will be much more to your taste.
Unforgettable. Must-see especially at night, when all lit up and teeming with singers, dancers, foods, gifts, and people from all around the world
Nice. Crowded. The heart of marrakech. A bit scary by day though. Be aware to give the correct tips for the cobra keepers

Must to visit. It is the heart of Marrakesh. A place worth visiting any time, at least I would recommend to visit during the day and also at night. It will allow you to have two completely different experiences.
amazing. steeped in history and tradition you really need to go with a guide, to get the full history of thia amazing place

Not all that. The square was one place to see after reading its reviews. According to us it was not all that. Kids trying to direct you the wrong way, staff trying to pull you into their restaurants. A big chaos place according to me

Hugely overrated and horrendously touristy. Snake charmers and monkey keepers trip you up at every turn. The restaurants serve poor food for bumped up prices. View from a distance and don't waste too much time here.

Food great but limited choice of entertainment. This is a busy, bustling square which encapsulates the energy and life of the city. People and stalls are everywhere, there is much to see.The best way to get a feel for the square is to be in it, but if you don't like the hustle and the hassling then lots of french style cafes surround the square and they give an excellent view of the square whilst serving both drinks and food.The food stalls in the evening are great (despite many of them selling the same thing), but it is cheap and tasty.However if you push your way to the front of one of the many mini-crowds which form around the entertainment you will find that most of it is much the same, and in truth has little entertainment value. Furthermore if you don't speak French or Arabic then many have no value to an English speaker. Finally the snake charmers do have a tendency to hassle you, and put snakes around your neck without being asked. I am ok with this - my girlfriend is not! They will also ask you to delete any pictures you take of the snakes unless you pay them. They have no right to do this but they get quite aggressive if you do not.Overall it is definitely worth a visit and it is the main meeting point and entry point of the many souks (markets) which expand from it like spider webs. I very much recommend it for dinner as a cheap, tasty and cultural way of seeing Marrakech at night.

Ok. My 8 year old said "In the Jemaa el fna square it was very busy but there were some nice/ good things to buy and eat. People are begging you to buy wooden snakes and those things. Over all it was good! Snake charmers and musicians brought a crowd around them".

Lots to see. Lots going on, get in early if you are not keen on crowds, snake charmers or monkeys on chains!
Take time to sit at a roof terrace cafe to watch all that i going on but without getting involved!
The square. Where it all happens! Snake charmers fortune tellers story tellers acrobats and musicians. Interesting food stalls, didn't fancy the snails though!

A must see. You cannot possibly visit Marrakech without going to Jemaa el Fna ( just ask for the big square).
Its heaving, noisey, smokey, buzzing and mad.
Just go, have a laugh, be hassled, taste the food, drink the orange juice, take some photos ( don`t forget to pay) breath it all in and feel alive.

Heart of Marrakesh. The most magical part of Marrakesh where you are faced with the locals and rich history of Morocco. I would recommend you visit it at different parts of the day to truly experience it fully! From busy bazaars, souks to snake charmers and monkeys. The food in the square is authentic and delicious, so I would recommend to eat Couscous or tagines here. You wouldn't have visited Marrakesh if you don't come here. I would like to point out though that the poverty struck me at first and at time were shocking. nevertheless I was enchanted by the whole experience of the souk.

dont let others put you off. We went for the cultural experience and got it in spadesful. Don't let people put you off visiting here, we went at different times of the day and you must do this as the experiences are very different, no one will pester or bother you, just say no thank you, try the Arabic, and they target more likely customers.We did not eat here, I was not prepared to risk it but many westerners were dining al fresco and it looked great.We went up onto a terrace, the guy charges slightly over the odds for a coffee or Pepsi but it really was buttons, but you then get a prime seat overlooking a world heritage spectacular, in many other countries such views would be monopolised by the uber rich.We found Moroccan's generally laid back and welcoming, in the medina, particularly were the food was being cooked it was literally like going back 2000 years, had Christ rode by on a Donkey he would not have looked more out of place than we did, we saw a guy cooking take away food for locals using a kitchen that was exactly like those we had seen in Pompeii and Herculaneum. Its interesting to see how motor scooters, donkey carts and even tourist horse and carriages drive through crowded alleys and no one turns a hair, in the U,K "angry of Leamington spa" would have been straight into the letters pages complaining of a 12 year old cyclist on a 10 foot wide pavement.Go see it before it disappears.

Interesting. First what we liked - the food, the stalls, busy all the time (exchange your money at Societe Generale for good rates), everything available. The night food stalls are great. What we did not like - careful when you pay your bill at the stalls - ensure the total is correct and do not hesitate to challenge. Everybody wants a tip - a henna lady almost grabbed my wife's had applied henna and demanded money! But we were prepared by other Tripadvisor reviews, gave her 5 dirhams and smiled and moved on. Avoid the 'travel agencies' on the Square. Haggle like crazy - start with 20%, Haggle even for the bottled water.

An attack on the senses!. It was a fantastic place to see, smell and feel all sorts of different things but you must be quite hardy to repel the constant hassle from everyone you pass trying to sell you something, show you where to go, give you advice etc which is really draining and quite intimidating for the more gentle natured. You have to be quite tough and robust to get through it and even then, it's really draining constantly fighting off these people - my 11 year old daughter hated it and was really scared but gradually got used to it. Not for the faint hearted!! But a great experience and not to be missed.

Exciting. We were entertained by the enticement methods of the food stalls. Try not to go to the first one trying to hook you in. No 14 was always so busy that we never ate there, surely a sign that it was worth eating at. No 1 was good and we ate there in the evenings mostly.

The most amazing square in the world. Never before have I seen something quite like this square. There's always something happening: snake charmers, acrobats, food stalls, there's a bit of everything here. There's always something happening here, and it would be a crime to miss it.

Amazing place. What more is there to say... Lots to see, food to try and an enjoyable place to soak up the atmosphere of Marrakesh. Yes, there are some pushy people, but it is generally good natured. We always said 'non merci,' and were generally left alone after that. We didn't experience the problems with the henna painters that some people seem to have had. It looked like younger people are more likely to get hassled, so practice being politely assertive before you go. Stalls selling items round the square are more expensive than those further into the souks.

Main Square. You must see Jemnaa el Fna on differnt hours of a day. In the morning it is quiet and the locals are shoppng like yourself; in the afternoon offcourse lots of tourists, but in th evening the magic atmosphere with storytellers, musicians, and lovely places to eat. Personally I didn't like the women, they are pushy especially with the Henna Tattoos.

Entertaining!. It is well worth a visit. You should go during the day and see the snake charmers, monkeys and people selling their wares. Having coffee and watching is fascinating. It is also worthwhile going down to the square around 3/4pm and get a drink on one of the roof top terraces and watch how it changes. It comes alive at night and is a wonderful atmosphere to take in. There are entertainers and many things going on. Great place to visit!

Day and night are very different. The day isn't so interesting and it was disturbing to see people trying to get tourists to be photographed with captured monkeys. Try the orange juice though! 4 dirhams. At night, the place is buzzing and food stalls are set up-we liked number 1 the best! All are really cheap, but no alcohol is served within the square.

Busy hub. Central square packed with men selling all sorts. Tons of snake charmers, street entertainment, drums, fruit sellers, trinkets etc. if you take a photo someone will ask for money so stuck to your guns. The best way to experience the atmosphere is head to a rooftop bar like cafe France around 4.30pm and watch the sunset and chaos unfold. Really comes alive in the evening. Nights in the square are mad. Stick to the main touristy area after 8pm, don't go wandering deep into the narrow alleyways of the souk.

The madness that is the square. The first time we went to the square at night we were quite overwhelmed. Now it's as familiar as going to Oxford Street. The music, dancers, snake charmers etc have to be seen. I've eaten at quite a few places there and have never been ill. Don't be scared, the germs are killed by the fire! I've even figured out how to keep the beggars and hawkers away

the beating hearth of Marrakech. a mess of colors, smells, sounds....touching all senses!first time Ive been there 30 years ago or so, there was no concrete on the streets, only red dust and this square was full of camels, burning meat and hypnotic flutes playing intriguing arab melodies....Jemaa didnt change much, apart from the concrete - its still the red door to the Sahara desert - best moment to be is at sunset, when life awakens on the square.Have fun and avoid at all costs eating barbecue from the stalls - I ended throwing up badly!
hustle in the evening. It is a part of the city you have to see. The busy streetfood, men with monkeys & snakes etc For me it is ok for once .

Best place in Africa. This is where all the fun and real Morocco is. If you go to Marrakesch and don't visit this place then you have wasted your time. You see street shows. The most tasty and cheap dinner is also available in this place.

Hit your senses!. This is a fascinating square that will hit all your senses at once. The smells and taste from the food and drink stall, touch of the trinkets, sights galore and noises of the traders and musicians all come together in this bright and busy square.In the day time its relaxed and the perfect place to do a spot of people watching. Take a seat in one of the roof terraced cafes to get a view of the whole square. Most of the trinkets on the square side stalls and shops can be found at a cheaper price if you wander down adjoining streets on the edge of the souks.At night it is a riot of noise and smells as the food stalls and entertainers take over the square. The food stalls seemed to be arranged in their specialties e.g fish or kebabs. It was extremely busy and not for the faint hearted.

Best experience ever. Within the first 5 minuets of stepping foot on jemaa el fna we already had our henna done, held a snake and got ripped of many times. Remember that people there are extremely pushy especially to tourists and know how to take your money, once you get past the fact you lost loads of money and build you confidence to tell them to back off its an amazing experience. At night the square comes alive also being a fair skinned tourist we got a lot of attention which was scary at first but soon became funny and felt like a celebrity haha. I would say never split off from you friends/family because you can lose them in seconds! DEFINITELY if you visit the square at night you HAVE to go to stall 14!!! i would also recommend stall 5 for tea and soup. I advise to write down on a piece of paper dirhams to your currency and work out what you want to pay for things as you can barter with pretty much everything!

1001 Nights - day and Night!. Colours, fragrance, exotic ambience, like wandering from one page of the 1001 Nights Fairy Tales to another page. The chaos, to some disturbing while to me fascinating and captivating. DAYIt bleeds my animal loving heart to see the hawks, kites, eagles, sand-vipers, cobras and Atlas Macaques used to entertain both domestic and Foreign tourists. The jongleurs, fortune tellers, henna painters, medicine sellers, dentists, clowns, story tellers etc etc etc takes you to a world from the Arabian Nights Fairy Tales or stories from Sinbad the sailor. It is a sight you never will forget!Should you feel thirsty please do try fresh mixed citrus juice from one of the juice sellers. You have to only walk past, they will beckon you to taste one of the many citrus fruit juices they sell at riduculous prices should you convert it to USD or EUR . The best you can ever get!NIGHTBy the fall of dusk the scene at Djema el Fna transforms like Magic. Like mushrooms, there pops up an array of small Food stalls that serve from snails, Sea Food to a gamut of delicious local meat delicacies. Even my fancy up-nose friends after my perseverance, tried the Food dished out here. Though reluctantly at first they ended up eating there sevaral Nights. The sellers are always trying, yet in a gracious and respectful way compared to many other Countries I have been. Extremely friendly and helpful people. Dare to take the first step forward, relax and open up ....... a whole new exotic and beautiful world awaits you in the medina. I love Marrakech, Moroccon People and the Berber Culture that many prowdly retain. Moroccon People are extremely friendly and kind. But this does not mean that you should leave your antenas and brains behind.I would not recommend you to take out Money from the ATM vending Machines at Djema el Fna. Your card might end up being copied or fished.A Fairy Tail land for both children and the adults whose inner child is still alive.

don t get in a Jam ma in jemaa el fna. I recently went to the jemaa el fna it was full of beggars and performing monkeys I was told that it was not advisable to eat the food within the square owing to the unhygienic practices of the food vendors, the place was filthy and smelt .Do not under any circumstances visit this place at night particularly as a lone woman for fear of being accosted .

Wow and Wow. This square really is mind blowing, just so much to see and take in, stalls, shops, cafes , street performers, hawkers,to name but a few, the best thing to do is sit on a roof top terrace and watch it all happen

A whirlwind of madness. Am told this "square" is always busy, but of an evening it is frantic. The locals make the area come alive. As the darkness descends the activities multiply: snake charmers, performers, story tellers draw large circular crowds of enthusiastic on-lookers. Street sellers throw lighted parachutes into the sky to intrigue the youngsters. There are scores of temporary eating venues, hugely populated with customers wrapped in coats as the temperature begins to cool. The locals are focused on their pleasure.One was warned about pick-pockets and one could have a sense of fear, but it was also magical, strange and intriguing. The outsiders frequently watch activities from tea-rooms over looking the square, but to feel the manic, warm charm one needs to be amongst it.An experience never to be forgotten.
brilliant. amazing place love it food was great at night, full of fun, and cheap. good fun. during the day was also good to watch the entainers.

The heart of Marrakech. You have to see the main square, it is always busy whatever time of the day. During the day there are the snake charmers and locals with monkeys who want you to take pictures and then pressure you for money, this can be quite intimidating. Also stay away from the ladies who want to draw motives on your hands, if you are not careful, they start to draw without your permission. In the evening it is nice to see the locals listening to the story tellers or the many bands. The best thing are the food stalls which are set up in the early evening, you can soon see smoke rising from all the freshly fried food.

Comes alive in the evening. By day it's a sprawling area surrounded by shops, cafes and souk entrances containing a milling crowd of people attracted to (or repulsed by) assorted animal trainers (monkeys and snakes), street vendors selling all manner of (mainly) rubbish, many stalls selling fruit and fresh orange juice, all priced identically. But it bustles and it's a good place for people watching although don't stare or, even worse, take photos of them without permission, Islam is not keen on images, photographic or otherwise. In the evening it comes to life with dozens of food stalls with their grills and barbecues all vying for your attention and custom. For most Europeans this is an exotic location and one would normally be a little wary of street food but all the stalls have to have a license to operate, which includes meeting good hygiene standards, and they are inspected regularly to ensure those standards are maintained. Nothing is guaranteed but they are probably as safe as most European cities, if not more so, I certainly had no ill effects. Best time to see it is as the sun sets, casting a glow over the steam and smoke emitted from the food stalls. Definitely better in the evening than in the day.If you are "caught short" be aware that the public conveniences (bathrooms!) are Arab-style with a glazed hole in the floor with foot rests on which you squat. Clean up is by taking a can of water with you into the stall to wash the relevant areas. Not recommended for the novice, to avoid this go into one of the larger cafes which have western-style pedestals, although you will need to purchase sheets of toilet paper.

Wow what a place!. Very busy. If you want to eat something you do not find anywhere in a restaurant, this is the place to find it at very inexpensive money. One of our friends likes to eat sheephead. Looked around and found one table offering the cooked head for 3 Euros. If you are thirsty, glass of fresh squeezed on the spot orange juice is 30 Cents.

Visited Before Sunset. So we heard so much of Jemaa El Fna but since we lived slightly out of the city, and we only spent a short time in Marakesh, we were only able to visit the square around lunch time. What a mess!! So many aggressive hagglers and low life's, tried to force us to carry there monkeys and snakes. One of them insisted to teach us how to handle a poisonous snake! One of the monkeys pissed on me! We were then forced to pay them! NEVER AGAIN!

Hustle and Bustle at its finest!. You must visit the square when in Marrakech and dine with the locals. There are plenty of food, drink and entertainment. In the evenings it is especially busy with monkeys etc. You will find plenty of beggars and everybody tries to sell you everything! I say go and embrace it. Wear comfy clothes/ shoes and go and get involved with the culture. A must see when in this beautiful city :)

Jemaa el Fna square. The sounds from the square are unique and unforgettable. Snake charmers, entertainers, barberry monkeys, henna tattooists, dentists, orange sellers, traders. Sit on a terrace of a bar and watch as the sun goes down and the square transforms to a public barbecue.An experience not to be missed

A world away from London. We loved the craziness of the Jemaa el Fna. Have a drink in the surrounding terraced cafes and soak up the buzz. By day its relatively calm - snake charmers, guys with monkeys, the orange juice stands amongst other stalls. Be careful not to take photos of the snake charmers or monkey guys as a second later you'll have them around your shoulders and you'll have to pay! By early evening it completely changes... various big crowds surrounding locals with drums and the chaos of the 100 or so places to eat. You'll be pestered and have numbers of the food stalls to eat at but just smile and walk round. Try something different - the snails were delicious!Listen to the noises, soak up the smells and buzz off the atmosphere. It makes London seem boring!

Great for night out. This is the square at the end of the Souks (usually signposted so a good escape point). it has a few fruit / juice stalls during the day, but really comes to life in the evening with many food stalls, and lots of groups of entertainment. This is a great mix of locals and tourists.Follow the tip we were given - eat where the locals are! We were recommended to try food at stalls 1 (for meat) and 14 (for fish - take away Calamari as no seats left in a Tesco bag!!!)Great Fun and locals are so friendly you feel safe.

An experience. It's everything it says in the guidebooks. An interesting experience but be prepared to be hassled. Take a picture of the hawkers and they can spot a camera a mile off. They also push for more and more money but can be put off with persistence

It's just crazy, but it's another culture up front!. Yeah, it's crazy out there. Snake charmers, food stalls, horse drawn buggies, donkeys pulling food carts, women doing henna tattoos, people doing other shows I've no idea what they were actually doing, the few sordid folk selling hashish, etc, etc.But this is a different culture! Look closely and see what's going on. Hear the noises. Smell the food and spices...During the day or night, there's something going on. Here's a few things I learned.Snake-charmers: Don't take a picture unless you want to pay. We were 15 meters away and my girlfriend wanted a photo, so I took one. Mistake! Their ears are attuned to the shutter click, even amid the chaos that is the noise. One immediately turned around (their backs were turned to us) ran over to us and more or less pulled us to the snakes, wrapping one around me (which is fine - I like snakes). They will start playing that tune that everyone knows on the flute when you think of snake charmers. We took lots of pictures. 1 minute later, they said 200 dirhams. That's $20 US DOLLARS! Laugh. I said no way, while at the same time another said 300 dirhams!! Laugh again! That's $30 dollars. I said you know what, here's 100 dirhams ($10 dollars) and walked away. Really I should have just thrown 'em some coins...Juice stands: It's 4 dirham for a fresh juice drink. That's roughly 40 cents! They squeeze the juice for you right then and there and it is delicious. Use the straws provided - I've read they don't wash but only rinse the glasses they give you, even after other customers have used them.ATMs: There are several at the square and down one of the larger pedestrian roads adjacent to it.Food stalls: So at night a hundred or so food stalls materialize where earlier in the day there were none. They are cheap and very good. Maybe $10 for two people. But, what I found is to eat where the locals do, and you'll pay LESS than $2 for two people. There were two particular stalls, one serving just soup and dates (oh sooo good) and the other stall serving sandwiches, filled with nothing but butter, cheese, potatoes, egg, and a type of red spicy sauce. I recommend trying these. At both stalls we were the only tourists, but I didn't care - the food was great and so super cheap.Shops: Yes, they want you to buy their wares. Even looking for more than one second in a shop or at an item displayed out front, or even just lingering in front of a shop for a few seconds, they will beckon you to come in. It is annoying, no doubt. But, you'll become deaf to it in no time. Remember, it's their culture to trade and barter. They also make a very meager means of living, especially relative to tourists. As such, they go to great lengths to sell you things. Just smile and say no thanks and move on. Their feelings won't be hurt.Look, it is hectic and kinda crazy, but you've gotta just go with the flow. Try the food, wander around, and smile. Life is short.Recommendation: Pay a little more for a meal in one of the many restaurants and sit on the rooftop terrace to get a good view of the square and the happenings in it!

carnival atmosphere. I really enjoyed the sounds and smells of this area, as others have said its not for everybody, if your dont like seeing Monkeys in chains and or snakes then this is probably not the place for you.We ate at the Food stalls one night and we both enjoyed the food and it was cheap.you did get a little hassle especially if they thought you were taking pictures of the said monkeys/snakes etc.Some weird activities went on such as teenage boys boxing/people telling stories etc but the locals seem to enjoy it so who are we to complain,

Your senses will be overloaded. The central square is a delight for the eyes and ears. The activity is the morning and early afternoon will be rather tame but the activity magnifies as the day wears on. Good place to people watch and rest after meandering in the souk. I am not a fan of the animals used in the square (more of a triangle) as I feel they may be abused. Nice place to have some food and enjoy the mass of humanity.

Charming but intimidating. Can be intimidating at first, but once you get used to be singled out as a tourist by the local salespeople, its quite alot of fun and you get great banter from the locals: 'You come in my shop, i give you Asda price'. The resturants surrounding the square were also lovely, with Le Marrakechi as the go to place for an authentic moroccan experienceThe one thing i disliked was the Henna ladies. They were quite aggressive and tried a few times to paint on my girlfriends arm despite her saying no repeatedly and i had to resort to pushing them away
brilliant. Frenetic but exciting. If your polite to the beggars and guides when refusing, they are polite to you. Stall holders really helpful and not all were pushy.

Stage play in real life. Jemaa elFna is like a real life stage play or three ring circus. Many things going on continuously. Food galore. (I ate the snails and survived) Don't buy anything here (better deals all over), just walk around and absorb the culture, the sounds, the smells.

Give the noise a miss. The souks radiating along the square are fun to explore. However it's very easy to get lost. You need to ignore every shop owner beckoning you to come in. Make way for horse carts and people pushing carts even though it's only about 5 feet wide in many places.You are scared to look closely at any product as the owner and staff descend on you to make you buy the product. I learnt that a lot of the scarves, shawls etc are made in China; we were recommended to go to the Souk Kasbah as that's a fixed price souk without any bargaining. Also it's very easy to get lost and we had to pay 5 Euros to a lad to guide us out of the maze in the Souk back to the square. GET A GUIDE as it's worth the hassle and people don't accost you as often though he will take you to his fav stores.

Hustle and bustle..... This central square is busy and loud and although no vehicles cross it you need to have your wits about you. There are so many people, stalls and things going on. I found the hassling by sellers, henna ladies and others a bit much at times as I just wanted to wander and people watch. It is a great place to experience but not somewhere I would want to spend too many days in a row as it is exhausting and you start to feel like all they want is your money. You can wander to the souks from here or some side streets witH some interesting shops. There are cafés along the sides and one with a great roof terrace which is good to take a breather and watch the craziness below. At night they set up lots of food stalls and the place continues to come alive!

An experience by day and night. Yes you will get pestered by stall holders, henna ladies and various others. If your not interested just so no and they'll move on. it's still worth a visit for the sights and sounds. During the day it's snake charmers, date sellers, monkeys etc. In the evening there's pop up restaurants, music.

Great place to visit to have a cobra around your neck!. The Square (or "Place") in Marrakech is a MUST-SEE for anyone spending even just one day there! So much going on that you could spend hours walking around people watching. From there it is just a few steps to the wonderful medina. If you are in Marrakech, you MUST go to Jemaa el Fna!!!
Manic. What an experience hahaha Just watch your money, like everywhere else where there are tourists to be exploited

Nice to see but prepare to be hassled.... Jemaa el Fna is the main square in the center of Marrakesh and is the starting place for the maze of Souks.First thing that will happen is you will be pestered and practically begged to take a horse and cart which is utterly pointless.Then you will come across henna ladies, men with monkeys and snakes and things. They will try and get you to take a photo with their animal but be careful, if you do it you instantly owe them quite a lot of money.The souks are filled with pretty much the same stuff but the worse part is the hassle you get from the traders to come into their shop and see what they have. If you don't mind that sort of thing you can grab some good bargains for some local stuff such as tagines and souvenirs.They also have a large collection of fake handbags, wallets, scarfs, etc.All in all not a bad place but you probably will need a lie down once you have finished your visit.

Avoid the henna ladies. I went in low season and the place was still too busy. The henna ladies were waiting by the ATMs /cash machines so they know we only have notes and no change. They grabbed my hand and I pulled back and said no. They insisted "free free" and still had my hand so I thought ok (silly)... When done they demanded 200dirhams (20 euros). We walked away and they followed. They would not leave until we gave them something so unfortunately all we had was 10 euros and they ran with it. Their faces are fully covered so the tourist police dont know who they are. If they come keep harassing you, mention the words Brigade Touristique. They are located on the edge of Djemma el Fna square near the Ketoubia mosque. The phone number is 0524 38 46 01.

Loved every second. We visited Morocco for a few days and this is the main attraction in Marrakech. We visited during the day and night.It has everything at this place as previous reviews mention.  restaurants, food stalls snake charmers, men with monkey's acrobats, story tellers, you think of it it had it. Even to the souks everyone is trying to sell something from fake garments to toys to worn battered items of clothing like old tops and shoes. It's sad to see the poor people trying to earn and living elderly people selling stuff which have no value and won't sell if it was the last thing on earth. You get elderly and children selling tissues and biscuit. The sad part is when you're eating people approach you and ask you for your food.The souks can be a bit of a maze and you can easily get lost. Don't listen to the people guiding you which way to go. To be honest if it wasn't for my other half I would have been lost. I saw videos on the markets and I really wanted to try a dish called meshui it's a little side alley just of the square it is a whole lamb slow roasted in a clay put in the ground. I highly recommend it, they will cut you off some of the meat and serve it with bread sprinkle a little cumin and salt on it. Avoid the snake charmers and men with monkeys. They treat the animals really bad. You can see the pain in the faces of the little monkeys holding on to the chains. We also visited the new town didn't think much of that. Make sure to try the little restaurants in square they serve really good food. I didn't. Eat at the stalls was a little out of from the hygiene. We went to a place called la salama just on the road next to cafe France for drinks and Shisha.It is very expensive compared to he rest of Marrakech for food but it's prices what you would pay in England.

Never a Dull Moment. To get a real feel of Jemaa el Fna, sit at any of the restaurants bordering the square. From the outdoor seating you can see all that the square has to offer. Sitting at the right cafe, you can see the snake charmers, watch the men with the monkeys getting tourists to take pictures, souvenir sellers, juice places, and more and that is just during the day. At night, the square adds food stands. I would recommend that you visit during the day and then at night.

Busy. This is the main square and double the price of the medina or souk. There are entertainers there who will hound you for money for taking their picture. The food was poor there and it is busy busy busy

Watch out for the rip off merchants!. Although a centre of interesting local activity, on our first day walking past a henna artist, she grabbed my hand and started drawing and it was hard to get away. Her friend then hassled my partner and they had a ' divide and rule' technique so we were unable to talk to each other to agree a cost and they completely took our money as we quite aggressive. Women, just keep your hands hidden!

Interesting spectacle first couple of times.... The square is interesting for the first couple of visits, but after that it's a bit samey. Lots of people trying to flog you things you probably don't want or need. Didn't see the famous snake charmers, but saw some monkeys on chains in ridiculously small boxes. Don't let the henna ladies catch hold of your hand, as they will start to paint you whether you like it or not. Nearly lost a finger (and my wedding ring!) Refused to pay much to their annoyance, but whenever I saw them after, they always waved and had a laugh. Try not to take things personally and don't be embarrassed to just walk away.

A must for evening food. Some of the daytime stalls are cleared away to make way for the food stalls, All cooked in front of you it's great. It starts about 6pm and finishes around midnight (we did not stay that late). There are thousands of people milling around, with street entertainers, and the atmosphere was great. If you like fish, try stall 14, several types of fish, including calamari and sole with chips and bread. The cost for two was 75 Dirams (less than £6), a real bargain. No cutlery provided, you just eat with your fingers, so take tissues, just like the old days. The food is cooked in front of you so no upset tummy, You will need to get drinks (non alcoholic) from another stall, It you enjoy different sausages, try stall 31.

Bustling markets.. Lively market square full of every handcraft imaginable, food markets, clothing, restaurants and cafes. The atmosphere and surroundings are forever changing throughout the day and by night are filled with stalls selling traditional cooked food. A must see! Be on your guard in this area for scammers - Henna ladies!! My advice is to keep your hands in your pockets unless you want to pay for a henna tattoo as some of these women will approach, take you by the hand and before you know it you have a tattoo before even saying hello!!

a lovely place to sit and watch. Sitting in a cafe at the Jemma El Fna and watching the crowds go by is quite an experience. One needs to politely refuse the many hawkers who will come around every minute. The mint tea and the morrocon coffee is special

Wow! - not to be missed. Amazing experience. The noise, hustle, bustle, colours, smells, sights & everything is an assault on the senses. Comes even more alive at night with multi-coloured parachutes flying around. Just amazing to soak it all up. Snake charmers, jugglers, acrobats & of course lots of folks trying to sell you something - all part of the experience. Just make sure you have a few coins and do not be afraid to say "No", even when a snake is put round your neck !! Be careful of food sellers in middle - even though it smells good you may get a dodgy tummy; best to use a recommended cafe and stay healthy !!

A 'Must See'. Somewhere that every traveller to Marrakesh simply must go to especially in the evening when the market stalls are coming to life. Beware trying to take photographs of the snake charmers or you'll be hassled for money but apart from that take some time to really soak up the atmosphere.In the evening the square becomes a hot-bed of food stalls jostling for your business and the stallholders can get a bit 'in your face' so be prepared to say no thank you firmly if you don't want to eat.

Transformation & Sunset both amazing. Visiting the square at anytime of the day you get the feel this is the centre of the life of the city. The change from late afternoon into the evening is amazing, get a seat at a cafe with a mint tea and enjoy. The place just comes alive! Watching the sunset here is also a must do. Be careful though, the snake charmers and guys with monkeys, the henna girls will all try and get money. Its safe you just need your wits about you. Probably 100 places to get food here at night as well!

amazing place. Jemaa el Fna comes alive at night - during the day it's not very interesting, so you should come at about 9-10 pm, have cheap and delicious dinner at the food stalls and then just wander around - there are dancers, snake charmers, water sellers and some of the best street musicians in the world. of course, they all want your money, but they are mostly so nice about it that you find yourself not minding that at all))

Great place but !. i really liked that place, it is full of colors and new things to see, but you have to be careful about one thing: the noisy people in the plaza ( sahaa) they are trying to ask you for money and keep bothering you. So be careful and enjoy it.

Very cultural and vibrant. If you visit Marrakech you should visit this place. It comes alive at night with various entertainment shows hosted by the local and the stalls are brilliant. It really tested my bartering skills but was great fun

Lively buzz day and night. Try to arrive late afternoon and watch transformation of square into even more livelier food stall market area. Noise, smells and sights are amazing. Soup and mint tea are a must...if you don't want to try the snails!!!

Tourist trap but interesting. Yes touristy but well worth a visit. There is a lot to take in and see, men with monkeys, snake charmers, orange juice stands, Tea, Coffee, smoke filling the air, bands and men hawking anything they can.The only down side is if you try to take a photo you will be chased for payment, every which way you turn someone wants money for a photo. Better to go on top of the roof top restaurants and take some photos from there,

Funny for 30 minutes, but very annoying afterwards. It's nice to be on the square for some time, but after a while you get very annoyed, especially by the food places. They literally take your arm and try to pull you in. We felt a bit ripped off when we had dinner at a food place: they told us eat here and get free tea. They gave us a lot of different food without asking and of course we had to return that as it is a way to charge more money. Anyway, we ordered some food and the tea. When we got the bill we had to pay 10 dirhams (1 euro) each for the cup of tea with the explanation that we got the big cup and that one isn't free. After being a bit angry we got a new small cup for free but had to pay for the bigger one. This is one of the many ways they try to make money of you. I'd rather recommend to go to the mountains, it's beautiful and the people are way more honest.
Unique. A real taste of Arabic life. A buzz like no other. Would rank with Times Square or Piccadilly Circus in having a "let's play" feel!

The bustling heart of old Marrakech. ;The noise and colour of this central part of Marrakech are unforgettable. Every day of our short stay inthe city found us walking through the stalls, musicians, dancers, hawkers, beggars and what seems like half the city population.We ate twice in a restaurant overlooking the turmoil, observing the more devout Muslims answring the call of the muezzin. It was fasinating to see it all.But even with all the crowds and activity, the friendliness and good humour of the locals was wonderful. More than once we were wished a "good day" by a complete stranger; people went out of their way to direct us if we were lost; and the man standing outside a restaurant to attract custom charmingly directed us to a bar when we said we only wanted a drink (Marrakech is not an easy place to find a beer!).You haven't seen Marrakech if you haven't been to Jemaa el Fna!

noisy, lively, and unique to this city. a must see- especially at night when everyone gathers around the snake charmers the berber music and the dancers. lots of food stalls, funny to walk around as all the stalls waiters will try to lure you in- be polite and friendly the ppl might come across agressive but if you smile and joke back it is fine!

Two essential Arabic words!. Well, what an experience this was! Actually, more than one because the square at night is so much more exciting!OK, it's lots of people putting on little shows to make a living from tourists - but you know that before you go and expect it (at least if you've read the reviews you do!).But the sights, the smells, the sounds! Just brilliant!Don't be intimidated, though, just smile and don't get into a conversation. No thanks or Non Merci will get you off the hook usually but the magic bullet is the Arabic "La Shokran". It just means no thanks and the hustlers just disappear! Travel rep told us... And it works!One other piece of advice... If you wander into the Souks and get lost DO NOT get into conversation with anyone who offers to show you the way out. We heard so many stories of unexpected visits to tanneries and demands for expensive fees that we were almost put off the place before our first visit!If lost, either ask a stallholder or just keep wandering till you find your way out. Actually, we found the Marrakech Souks far less intimidating than many others we've been to!Have a great time in Marrakech but don't miss Marrakech food tours - the highlight of our week!

The time of day to visit is key. This square is very much the gateway into the old town, hence many tourists gravitate towards the area which brings in the locals looking to capitalise on the opportunity. In the day I found this area to be quite barren - there were large gaps between the stalls and entertainers with even the snake charmers looking uninterested although it was a particularly hot day!. That said, there is some entertainment (and sanctuary from street performers) in people watching from the cafes on the periphery. At night, the square becomes an open air restaurant which i found to be the most atmospheric and interesting time of the day. Just remember to smile and take any approaches from the street performers and henna ladies in good humour.

Amazing.... Very loud, very colourfull, thousands of shops, restaurants..you need to see jama al fana with your own eyes to experience the vibrant buzz..be prepared to be hassled by shop keepers and food outlet sales staff. But thrn they are only trying to earn their bread...some of the tv accents the food outlet sales guts put on and knowledge of the uk...for egsample tesco asda aldi and eastenders ect was funny to listen to when they entice to come in to eat...

the entertainment of the night. During the day there are market stands with fresh fruit, nuts and souvenirs and then the entertainers with snakes, monkeys and stories. At night the square is transformed in to a huge food place with excellent food and cheap prices but pushy sellers. The locals all seem to hang out in circles, listening to stories and music. It went on for long hours.

never again. you get constantly pestered by market owners, you can't look at anything without them trying to buy you other things, we also got pushed into spice shops by other market traders, even a taxi driver. we told them we had no money left as we were going home that evening and they were trying to get us to pay for things via card. You also had to buy a minimum amount so the prices start at £10-£20 in English money or 100-200 dirhams. we barely got in before we decided we know longer wanted to go further, we didn't even bother looking for the main market square.
Must see - but very touristy. Snake charmers, monkeys, bands, fresh orange juice stands, and mint tea overlooking the shopping space. There is a ton going on in the square, but it's a tourist trap.

Fun, food, henna thugs and animal cruelty.. The El Fna square is the central hub of the old town. Unlike the souls it's open and easy to know where you are. Just like the souls it is full of touts and salesmen but they are slightly easier to avoid. In the evening the place is livelier , and there are cafe's charmingly competing for your custom. We found them to give decent food at a cheap price although it's even cheaper elsewhere. The street theatre is fairly lame, they wouldn't earn a coin on a European street. Drumming bands add to the atmosphere. Bad points: the animal cruelty is highly uncomfortable, please stay away from the chained monkeys and abused snakes. Also the Henna ladies are dreadful, one yanked my wife's hand unbidden and started drawing on her, she then demanded money despite basically committing assault.

Chaotic, colourful and tasty. A trip to Marrekech is not complete without a visit to the main square at night to see the market stalls, musicians, snake charmers and other performers, but above all, it's about eating at one of the many stalls selling a variety of Moroccan food. It can be a bit stressful to the uninitiated - a lot of waiters can be a bit aggressive in trying to get your attention. We particularly recommend stall #14 for excellent seafood.
orange juice!. The place is a big experience! Definitely try number 52 for the orange juice. In comparison with other stands his juice is the best I have tasted (and I tasted a lot...).

Mad Moroccans. It's bedlam out there but it's great fun to watch and participate. The vendors are all on the make, of course but as lot as you're firm with them they don't trouble you too much. A lot of it is good-natured banter. The place really comes alive at night when they set up all the food courts. We'd already eaten so didn't sample any but it looks impressive.

Crazy Place!. Lots to see here. A cacophony of sounds with snake charmers, acrobats, Cross dressers, orange juice sellers, and just about every hawker, busker, and hustler that Morocco has to offer. Why go anywhere else? its all here!

WOW. The visit during the day was amazing the array of fresh fruit amazing. The atmosphere friendly and large groups watching & listening to the performers!The visit at night! WOW! So different. Very dark! Lots of restaurants all wanting your custom. Fortunately we had made a reservation in a restaurant overlooking the square , but the temporary restaurants looked amazing and were very insistant on your custom! But the food looked good!We had a bit of a bad start with a pair of henna tattooists who before I had realised had put a flower on my hand and were insistant on money!! That aside, what an amazing atmosphere just be careful but plenty to see. definitely an amazing sight at night and would return at night when returning to Marrakech.

shopping square. This it a huge market square with "thousand and one" things to buy. However many sellers offer the same goods. Market is surrounded by small streets with even more booths and stalls. Sooner or later everybody gets lost. It is like a labyrinth of paths without names. After some time everything seems to look the same. This place is too noisy and you will notice unpleasant smell, but it is worth to visit. Marrakesh itself is loud and this market is no exception, so it is a good idea to find a quiet restaurant in neighborhood as we did, and go there after visiting the market. We didnt buy anything there and we werent courageous enough to risk to eat. We just went to see how it is look like and we escaped to Latitude31, restaurant which reviews You can also find on Tripadvisor.com.

A sea of humanity. If you like people watching you will see it all here, acrobats, tranvestite belly dancers, snake charmers. I thought it would smell spicy but the donkey and horse smells tend to override the fresh oranges. Personally I don't like to see animals exploited so to see the, snakes and monkeys used for entertainment was distressing. The donkeys are a necessity for some but looked like they were suffering. We went up to one of the roof terraces to get the flavour of the place without the hassle of hawkers and sellers.

Certainly an eye-opener - An evening visit is a must!. Hectic, hectic, hectic. A must for all visitors to Marrakesh. Take in the sights and be aware of your surroundings. Don't be intimidated by the constant offer of goods. A must in the evening with snake charmers, dancing monkeys, musicians and a buzzing atmosphere. If you want a real taste of morocco then make a visit.

Jamma El Fna. What can I say, I enjoyed the full day around here and bargain all day for a better deal. It was fun if you like that type of things or you rather eat good restaurants which taste good or you can go on horse carnage for a good ride (be sure to bargain this too)
nice atmosphere at night. bets to visit this place is at night.the only annoying thing is shopkeepers keep bothering, as well as the snake charmers, horse carriages. This place smells a lot tooo
Wow. Amazing time. Watch those kids. They bargain too. And watch the guys selling Hashish. It's funny but I'd advise staying away. The laws are different and no one wants to get into trouble

Walk around 2 days and interact with locals. Take some cash with you and buy some hats, collars and presents for you and friends. Take pictures with snakes, monkeys, local musicians, etc ...Never buy in the first day, research and always offer half or even less. For example somebody can try to sell you a scarf per 300 Dh, but the real local price is 40 Dh. I think it is fine if you pay 70 Dh.Learn how to bargain is part of your trip.

Worth a visit but it is crowded noisy dirty -. The square is a fantastic place to see but not a place to linger. It is full of Moroccans who will try almost anything to extract money from you and can be quite rude when you don't give them money. People demand money for anything - photographs or giving directions. There are those who just beg. We found it quite edgy and enjoyed the history but 2105 reality is not very pleasant.
fantastic. should be experienced, not possible to explain. SPecially food was much better than othe luxury restourants.

Awful treatment of animals and watch yourself!. I know I'm probably going to be berated for this review as its a different culture etc but I really couldn't handle the abuse of animals here.... Monkeys with chains around their necks and snakes left on Mats being poked and prodded....horses being kicked and whipped...wanted to cry....Apart from this henna ladies who grab people's hands and do henna designs without asking them then demand Money!! Luckily we had been made aware of this via our reps and I kept my hands firmly in my pockets! Small children trying to pickpocket me! Luckily I didn't have anything other than snotty hankies in my pockets!The touts are awful too.... We sat in a cafe for a drink in the hot sun and they follow you in trying to sell stuff and won't leave you alone! If after a polite no thanks they left you in peace I would have been happy! But they don't!That being said the orange juice sellers and food stalls are fab and worth a visit and are the real stars of the show here!! Do not make eye contact with the snake charmers / monkey owners / water sellers or they will want to charge for pics...again we were lucky to have been pre warned!!! Such a shame because I would have spent more money in the square if we hadn't been so.harassed....felt far safer in th souks tho...

Definitely the highlight of the city. Its jut mad. You got to be there to experience it as its hard to describe. Its like you have been transported back 30 years in time. Snake charmers, boxing matches, palm readers, Astrologers, orange juice sellers fill up the square during the day. At night its filled with food stalls each with about 10 sales people all trying to get you to come to their stall. An experience not to be missed !

The Night Market. The Night Market in the Jemaa el Fna was crazy! There were snake charmers, water sellers and all sorts of other entertainers working the crowds and entertaining people. In the dark everything was a bit wild and scary but lots of fun. We ate at one of the restaurants and they just kept bringing plate after plate of food to us. It felt like being at the carnival! Also it was school break so lots of families were out and about.It is very easy to get to by bus.
Hectic square but you have to visit it. particularly at night when hundreds of little pop up eating places appear. Food is fun but not necessarly that cheap.

Exotic Chaos. Very cool to walk around and negotiate for prices, makes the whole experience funnier. Avoid the stalls for eating, just a few of them are good, there are better places a few steps away, such as the Tiznit restaurant. It is a safe place but be aware with keeping things in your back pockets. Always offer at least half of the price they ask, I can buy things for less in Camden in London. But I really enjoyed the music and diversity. It worth a walk to Kasabah market as well, less crowded and better prices.

A unique experience. Not to be missed - late evening is best time to visit for the full atmosphere this area generates ! Try a fresh orange from one of the stalls and enjoy a drink on the rooftop terrace bars/cafes.

Colourful and noisy tourist trap. For the first time visitor to Marrakech, this place is fascinating especially at night when you don't see how clean ( or rather not) things are. A very colurful place with overpriced cafes one sits at for the view, the water vendors, orange juice stands, snake charmers are all very colour ful...a one time visit is great, more, not necessary!
.. The locals and the busy feel of the place made it wonderful and a great experience to visit. It was bustling with people and activities

Nice atmosphere, but better food can br found away from the stalls. The atmosphere was brilliant, especially when walking towards the lights, music, scents and smoke. Snake charmers etc were something different. After reading countless posts recommending certain stalls over others, I ventured to certain ones I.e. no 1 aisha and the one recommended for fish. I'd much rather go to the many better restaurants. the fresh orange juice is amazing and cheap!

Fantastic - day and night. Vast paved area to the south of the main souk area surrounded by restaurants with panoramic roof terraces. By day stalls selling fresh orange juice, dried fruit and nuts plus various entertainments of snake charmers; monkeys; henna tattooists and more. By night the entertainers are replaced by a miriad of food stalls all numbered so it is easy to find your favourite.

Unforgettable experience!. First trip to the square was at 7pm and was I overwhelmed by the sounds and sights. The food carts were amazing. Enjoyed the sunsets from the terrace cafes and the souks around the square were wonderful for shopping.
Don't take pictures. Don't take pictures on this square. If you are unlucky and have a local in the picture by accident, they will force you to pay.

Fun but a lot of aggressive touts. Jemaa el Fna is a fun square with great shopping, loads of food stalls, snake charmers etc. It's a must-see and is full of energy but some of the touts are just too aggressive. Personally, I found the vast majority of locals in Marrakech really nice and helpful but the square was different- many of the women selling henna tattoos grabbed my hand and started drawing on me while I was trying to pull away- then they got really angry when I didn't want to pay for the mess they had made on my hand (it's also really hard to wash off). We were also berated and cursed at by food stall owners when we politely declined to eat at their stalls. In saying that, the orange juice stall holders are super nice and having an oj in the square while listening to the drummers and snake charmers is awesome.
Buzzing square. Grab a table on the roof top of Cafe France and watch life pass by on the square below. Get there in the afternoon to see the sun set behind the mosque minaret.

Great shopping. Awful people.. The variety of things to buy is overwhelming, in a good way. But the aggro you get from vendors is far too much. No is not a word in their vocabulary at all. And be prepared to be "mocked" for being English. They think it's a quite bit of banter when in fact after a while it just became bloody insulting.

A must see. The main square in Marrakech, colourful, with tantalising smells and crowded with Henna artists, snake charmers, food and drink stalls. Visit it for the experience, I recommend to eat elsewhere though. And remember everything cost money, so unless you want to pay look away!!

It`s Marrakech - You Must - Fatima the Henna Hustler. Throw yourself into the chaos and when it gets too much head to one of the balconies overlooking the plaza. The fruit and nut stands don't like to sell small quantities, be firm if you only want a quarter or eighth of a kilo.We were waiting in line at one of the ATMs located on the edge of the square when Fatima engaged my wife in conversation. Next thing you know she had seized my wife`s hand and was drawing a henna design on it against our protests. Finished, she demanded 400 dirhams! To her outrage we gave her 20 dirhams. "Take twenty or nothing" we countered, as we did not ask for this. Then we turned and walked away.Yes, there are snake handlers, but if you look terrified they leave you alone. Likewise the guys who have monkeys on leashes. You can get your picture taken with either of the above, but expect to pay for the photo op. Negotiate the fee first, before you agree to anything.The square can be entertaining or overwhelming. If someone is pestering you, be firm in your refusal and then ignore him. If you waver, you're a goner.
A Visit to a Circus?. Lots of animation with snake charmers, somersaulting guys, drummers and many other strange activities. Worth a visit

Wow!!. The place is manic! Complete assault on the senses from the min you arrive - from acrobats to singers to men trying to sell you items from their stalls-amazing.after the initial shock one is able wander through the stalls soaking in the atmosphere. Try to see the square both during the day and at night to get a true appreciation of the place . You must go!!!!!

Lively in the evening. Always something to look at, good for people watching and food, fresh juice almost 24hrs a day. Sometimes in the evening people get a bit annoying when they want you to eat at their place.

Exciting. The square is thrilling. Far exceeded expectations. Beware of people wanting to take you anywhere as you will go well out of your way and end up in a tannery and leather shop. Although we did ask where we could get a drink (alcholic) and were taken to a fabulous restaurant not far away and hgad the best morroccan meal with belly dancer

dangerous place to visit. I visit this 4 years ago with my familly, but it so frustrating how people are trying to rop you. For people who have never been before in a Islamic country could this be great experience.It is too crowdy and you don't feel yourself save.

Over-rated. Colourful, noisy, dirty, smelly, crowded. The centre of Moroccan story-telling, street entertainment including snake charmers and dancing monkeys in nappies kept on short chains, stall-holders selling everything you can think of who hassle you to buy (although most of them do go away when you say no thanks, some of them are quite rude) and people who demand money in return for a photograph. With the exchange rate fixed by the Government and linked to the Euro, Marrakech can be a very expensive place......

Utter madness!. I'm giving this and excellent rating as its an excellent experience. However you do need to be prepared before arriving! Its a constant onslaught! People are generally friendly in the souks and love a good barter. Just be prepared!
Noisy. It is full of story tellers ,snake charmers, street food. It is noisy and smelly, you have to visit this for the experience, whether you return is a matter of style and taste.
A unique "must see !!". Don't miss it - all life is here - snakes, monkeys, music, dancing. story telling etc etc. You can eat at one of the stalls in the evening for about £5 pp and it's very good !
Amazing Square. If you don't visit Jemaa el Fna while in Marrakech, you have completed missed the point of going to Marrakech.

Frantic, fun and fabulous. All of the above. Hold on to your wallet, learn to say no firmly and ignore any persistent sellers, and enjoy the wonderful sounds, sights and smells. Also quite nice to sit on the roof of one of the surrounding cafes and watch the goings on below.

Be prepared!. Yes, it would be a shame, not to have been here, on a trip to Marrakesh...But be prepared. It's mostly just a large tourist trap, where locals either yell at you (including insults and profanities) if you don't come in to their shop; snake and monkey tortureres wanting you to photograph their poor animals; and henna tattooists who aren't afraid to hit you, if your wife/girlfriend doesn't want their tattoos. Arrive there no later than 9:30, if you want to experience the square, without all these unpleasantries, or escape to one of the terrace restaurants if it all gets too much... Their mint tea is lovely :)

terrible tourist trap. I have given this place a poor rating,,, I knew roughly what it was going to be like, but in reality it was worse,,,,, I tried to be polite to venders if I did not want to buy, but in return some were very rude.... I get no pleasure from seeing monkeys ill treated on short chains and kept in a box no bigger than monkey its self..... very sad.... Id say have a walk through to say you have seen it but that's it.... very sad place

Must See (at least once) while visiting Marrakech Medina. Square at the front of Marrakech's historic Medina comes alive at night with numerous stalls selling everything from fresh fruit juices and tagines to snail soup. Make sure to come here after 6 pm and grab a seat alongside the locals and enjoy the vibrant entertainment in the square. Moroccans are kind, but remember to tip if you take a photograph with them or enjoy their performances.

Be careful, a little. Great spot with lots of atmosphere but watch out for the tourist-oriented performers (snake charmers, musicians etc) who will try to fleece you if you stand still for long or try to take photos of their 'act'. The juice bars are great!
Wow. Yes wow, very busy with people and traffic, great atmosphere, you will always find your way out, you will get what you want at your price be patient.

This place is a must. This place is something special which you will find very seldom in the whole wide world. It is only allowed to walk over this square. Except in the morning even taxis are not allowed to drive here. But it seems that there is an exception because sometimes you can see some Motos driving through the souks which you will find at the end of the square. The best time to be on this square is starting when the sun goes down and it is becoming dark. Then you will enjoy this atmosphere. it is a mixture of adventure, excotic, noises, romantic, multi culture, animals, artists, small business, restaurants. Here you will see apes, snakes, card players, birds, chicken etc. You can have a coffee or dinner in a restaurant and of course you can find souvenirs. Or you go shopping in the souks. Do not forget to buy spices. But search for a shop were no tourists go inside! When almost only locals will buy there then you will find the best price. Do not forget to compare prices and try to make good deals. Best would be that you know some locals that makes things easier.
Mad. Eat at one of the stalls, have tea on a cafe rooftop, watch the monkey/snake/acrobat acts. Not for the faint hearted. All human life is here...

Amazing Atmosphere. This is a must visit for anyone who visit Marrakesh - nothing more to be said. The sellers aren't that agressive, they are just persistant and you need to be clear that you are not interested. Don't let it put you off, there's nothing to be concerned about. But like any busy city centre, keep you bag zipped up and be wary of your surroundings - and try not to get lost in the souks!

Little bit overrated. Visited the sqaure multiple times during our weeks stay. Durijg daytime a lot of juice tents (4 dirham for fresh orange juice) and people trying to get tou to iether take pictures with snakes or apes or giving you a henna tattoo. We did not dare to go there at night, so so busy and probably a problem waiting to happend. One thing that absolutaly will happend is that someone will trynto sell you something.

January trip to Marrakech for 50th year celebration. Lots going on well worth visiting at different times during the day and evening. Street food stalls in evening has some entertaining characters serving

Beautiful area- but if you're a woman be very careful. The highlight of any trip to Marrakesh is wandering through the tiny walkways in the souks and eventually finding yourself in the Jemaa el Fna, the main square always bustling with people with tons of things to see. Getting to Jemaa el Fna can be difficult as none of the streets have names, maps are difficult to read/are incorrect, and some Moroccans take it upon themselves to try to direct you only to ask for money in exchange. The square itself is filled with food stalls, snake charmers, people with monkeys, and women selling jewelery and offering henna tattoos. I would avoid the food stalls AT ALL COSTS. It is not worth saving like 50 cents only to get seriously ill when the place selling you orange juice reuses the same straw over and over again. The restaurants surrounding the square are considered overpriced by Moroccan standards but are steal an incredible steal by American standards. Several have great outdoor seating options with seats on rooftops and balconies, and this is an experience in itself to just sit back and watch everyone around you and the daily life in Marrakesh. Women take note, some of the men here are INCREDIBLY aggressive and will stop at nothing to touch you. I've had random men try to kiss me, grab my butt, hold my hand, take me inside their shops, etc. Most of the Moroccan men are incredibly nice and friendly and just want you have to a good time in their country, but the few that harass you and yell at you while you walk and ask how many camels they can buy you for, ruin it for the rest. I hate to say this but this is definitely a place where traveling with a man is recommended.

Jemaa el Fna. Visited both during the day and evening. The day was busy and I was wary about seeing animals being used. However there were some apes on leads but they looked healthy - though still not happy. There was a number of snake charmers and one wizen old chap with a lovely kestrel - again I was baulking at this. However again the kestrel looked in very good shape and appeared not to be stressed and happy to perch on my head and wrist. The usual stalls with more or less the same sort of stuff. Night time was a blast. Dark but the entertainers had their own lights - storytellers and fortune tellers - men dressed as dancers with their own musicians. Large circles of people around the more interesting spectacles. I was dragged into a large circle to try the 'belly dance' with the he dancer. What a laugh and I got applause from the mainly Moroccan audience. Heaps of food stalls with sitting area - the food looked delicious and the eaters all looked to be enjoying it. A must see.

Covent Garden plus. Acrobats, brilliant cheap fresh juices, shoe shine chaps, wonderful macaroons sold by mums clutching their babies ,monkeys ( cruel I think)and snake charmers justy to mentioon a bit of the wonderful chaos of this square. In the evening do try the food markets brilliant food for very few dirhams.

Tourist trap. The square is worth a visit but be aware you will be hassled by beggars, shoe shine men, snake charmers, etc. etc. If you are not fazed by this you will enjoy the experience if you are, you will get annoyed! We rapidly got the "looking into middle distance" technique down to a fine art and didn't get bothered too much. As previous reviewers have said, tourists are viewed as walking cash machines. Even whilst sitting at cafes you will be approached by beggars and would be shoe shiners, which doesn't make for a relaxing break. If any of the stall holders see your eyes straying towards any of their goods they will be over like greyhounds out of a trap. Best place to see it at night is from one of the restaurant roof-top terraces where you will not be bothered at all!
meal out. tourist trap, food and menu same at every stall, overpriced and chased by every waiter wanting your money
Step back in time. This area of the medina is as it must have been for centuries, alive and kicking, with traditional mixed with modern. Something for everyone!

Springs to life at night!. The place really come to life at night! Would highly recommend eating from the food stalls. Food there is generally cheap. However two people could eat to their fill for around £8-10. Be careful when taking pictures of the snake charmers and the other entertainers as these come with a price. Always have some coins change as most never have any change. Saying that though I must say the atmosphere here is wonderful.

It's fame is greater than it's attraction.. Perhaps it gets tired in the winter. The food and fruit stalls are good but the entertainment is a bit sad, Not very many people around. It's worth seeing but don't expect too much.
Our trip to this place. The place of jemaa el fna is a good place to visit in marrakech , Thre's a lot of things to see and to buy ...

Jamaa El Fna. Central square in Marrakech old city (Medina) where you will find food stalls,shoeshines,horses and carriages,water sellers,magicians,snake charmers etc.Backing onto the square are the numerous aleyways of the souks where you can buy just about anything but mainly moroccan pottery,leather goods,slippers,rugs,spices.Atmosphere changes after dusk as more of the square turns into an open air eatery with food stalls everywhere.

Strange and Intriguing Location. A large open area - a little strange and intriguing in some ways. There were a lot of traditional moroccan activities, juice vendors, small shops and souks, snake charmers, horse carriages. If you would like to experience the heart of Marrakesh, this is the spot, but do not expect too much of order, it is a little chaotic and the people, can be quite intimidating,

Great to see the culture. We thought it was great to see the traditions and culture, but it is obvious that most of the "entertainment" in the square is based on targeting the tourist. In other words, show an interest or flash your camera and it will cost you, not only dirham, maybe an aggressive confrontation.

A unique place. Wandering in the square on a Saturday evening is a chaotic experience. Snake charmers, monkey handlers, and hustlers of all kinds inhabit this place. Fascinating, but a little more than our aging bodies and minds can handle.

This where your journey begins in Marrakech!. This is a central square that any visitor has to visit in Marrakech, whether they want or not, you cannot avoid it. You cannot visit the souk for example, unless you cross the square from one side to another, where you will be passing all of chaos that takes place within this square. The origin of its name is unclear: Jemaa means "congregational mosque" in Arabic, probably referring to a destroyed Almoravid mosque. "Fanâʼ" or "finâ'" can mean "death" or "a courtyard, space in front of a building." Thus, one meaning could be "The mosque or assembly of death," or "The Mosque at the End of the World". Another explanation is that it refers to a mosque with a distinctive courtyard or square in front of it.A third translation is "assembly of the dead", referring to public executions on the plaza around 1050 AD. Anyway, regardless of the explanation of the name, what makes it so special is the activities that takes places within this square, that includes many traditional activities including youths with chained Barbary apes, water sellers with traditional leather water-bags and brass cups, and snake charmers. During the day it is predominantly occupied by orange juice stalls, which is one of the very best things juices we had. Well worth the visit. The problem here, and almost anywhere in Morocco is the lack of public toilets!!!!!

A bit too touristy. We had seen a few documentations on the place and maybe our expectations were too high... it is amazing as there is all sorts of stuff going on, however the food is largely prepared for tourists, few locals eat here.
