The guys trying to get you to sit in their restaurants are a bit too motivated and one or two have become offensive. See it if you are in Marrakech, don't bother if you would travel only for this.

"Is this real?". Firstly a few words of warning:If you are obviously western/white/overly touristy looking you're going to be a target. If it's your first time in marrakech or a situation similar this could be quite a culture shock, but you'll get used to it.Things to be aware of: a little bit of child exploitation with child boxing fights, you'll see these by a circle of men congregating and different areas in the square, personally my friends are not into this and didn't pay attention but if this is your kind of thing then please be aware you're likely to be pick-pocketed standing so close to people.Animal abuse: monkeys on chain, monkeys in clothes, monkeys being punched and kicked and twirled round on a metal chain, baby monkeys watching this happen to their mothers. If you make any form of eye contact with the owners for a period of time they will approach you with them. Again, if you're into this please be aware you'll have to pay for the privilege of a chained wild animal to sit on your head etcetc.Horse carriages: plenty of carriages and touts trying to get you to ride in them, no water for said horses and over-grown hooves been made to canter/gallop on cement roads. Not particularly pleasant for the animalsSnake charmers: dancing snakes-they might try to put them on you-you may want to take a photo-you'll have to pay/they'll try to swindle you.Child beggars: selling tissues etc, adorable sad tiny children following you for a good 10mins, we usually have them food instead of money.Henna: henna artists may approach you and put the ink on your hand, this never happened to us, we were very quick to say "no merci, maybe later/next time inshallah" this worked very well for us (in all situations), however we watched other tourists being pestered and bombarded for money and having their hands forcefully henna'd. A tip here is to be strong and polite! This go's for pretty much all of marrakech, don't feel bad just assert yourself and you'll be okayOkay the good things: food, banter with locals, great trinkets and gifts to buy, it's a crazy experience that you need to go into with an open mind, it helps to laugh and accept it for what it is.

Must-see in Marrakesh. This square, bordering a few souks, is the main square in Marrakesh and is a must-see. The square is filled with market sellers, monkeys, snake charmers, fortune tellers. These people may use agressive techniques to get you to pay money and will always demand money if you take photos, so photos should be taken from a distance.I would also highly recommend stopping by "Le Grand Balcon du Cafe", a cafe on the right hand side overlooking the square as you enter from the Koutobia, which gives a very good view from the highest level across the whole of the square. Here you can order drinks reasonably cheaply and take photos and enjoy the square without being harassed.I was surprised that some of the souvenir shops on the square are also very reasonably priced (after bargaining) compared to the souks or other tourist destinations in the city.

Full of beggars and street traders. My wife had been there many years ago and it was much quiter.bkeep your valuables safe but to be fair if you are polite they didn't bother you too much. A tip, don't let them put the monkeys on you,but will cost!!!!

A very Unique place. Jeema el Fna is a good mixture of Berber and Arabic cultures. Always buzzing, always busy. During the day one can take freshly squeezed fruit juice for a really ridiculous price, accompanied with a smile. After sunset musicians appear and start up playing fascinating music. Since you are in Morocco you should not have expectation but carry an open mind to without judging and repeating the slogans of the mass consciousness. Take it on board and learn from it. REally nice.

The weird and Wonderful Place to be. Its well worth a visit looking at snake Charmers,tooth pullers,water sellers, monkeys doing tricks and lots more. The atmosphere is great and it's best to see it from the many terrace's having a coffee or a iced tea

Animal cruelty. Not a square more of an open space where you will see snakes constantly poked and monkeys with chains around their necks.Orange juice stalls are good and cheap but food stalls not worth the hassle.

Welcome to Bedlam. It is impossible to have a dull moment in the grand square.Pure entertainment. From magicians to the old guy selling individual human teeth.Do try the street food. I especially liked the snails and lamb kebabs are a must.Just relax and absorb it all.

Bit of a must see.. Best at night. Certainly interesting. Excellent orange juice. Avoid the snake charmers, I have been informed that it is common practice to sew the snakes mouth shut, it then starves to death..but no matter you can always get another one! They charge you to take a pic as well. I avoided the monkeys as well. At night there are covered stalls which sell good value food, I had no problem with my tummy all the length of my stay. You can even get sheeps head or snails if you are of a mind to! I found it one of the better places to be as a lone women as there are more police around. I had no problem with the hassle others have complained of, I just ignored them and it was OK, its just part of the culture and a fact of life.

Must see. This place is crazy. Prepare yourself for being harassed left, right and centre. Use common sense and you will have a good time. Expect to pay the entertainers even a small fee if you want pictures of their monkeys or snakes. Personally I did not get a picture with the monkeys for ethical reasons as they are kept on chains. Women should be wary of the henna ladies, they can be pushy and will try to take your hand. I found that just keeping my hands out of their way helped. The orange juice is a must do as well - make sure it's the fresh one not watered down. There is one guy in particular who is nice and honest, I think it's cart no.43 from memory. (His cart is in the middle of three or four and facing one of the entrances to the medina). One of the things I found most interesting was the switch between day and night. In the late afternoon the men who run the food stalls come and set up entire mini restaurants in such a short time. Whatever time you come here there will be something to see. If you are really worried about being harassed or ripped off then get a guide (costing approx 80dh) to show you around and tell them you're not interested in buying anything. This will keep the sellers off your back.

Rubbish food, great orange juice and interesting people. Our first experience of the central square in Marrakech wasn't a great one. I've experienced hassle before but not on this scale, the men enticing you to eat at their stall can be quite aggressive, annoying and some pretty funny. Hungry, we were trying to choose a stall but couldn't choose ourselves so we just chose one that didn't hassle us. The food was highly disappointing, cold, under cooked and pretty boring. looking around later on with food in our bellies and a clear mind we discovered that except for a few stalls selling soups and sheep heads, it's all the same food. The presentation of the food at the stall, the menus and no doubt the origin of the foods are exactly the same.Aside from the food, the orange juice is absolutely gorgeous so that was a great plus.There are other entertainers at the square which are great. The snake charmers, musicians and dancers fun. Beware of the men holding monkeys as they will throw them on you and demand payment, which is fine if you're happy to pay for a picture. There are ladies with henna which most, are pleasant when offering their services. However there were a couple who would grab your hand and even one who dug her nails so hard in my girlfriends hand it left a mark, so do beware of this.

Crazy Fun. We were a bit overwhelmed at first as the square is very busy and you are approached by alot of the locals to buy their goods. But after a while you get used to it and the people are bargaining all in fun. There are snake charmers, people with monkeys, dancers, all sorts of food. At night the restaurants set up under their awnings. We ate at No.1 Chez Aicha. Very fresh and tasty food.

I expected more. I don't know if it was because of the flu I got, but Marrakech kind of let me down. And so did it main attraction. Much smaller than I had envisioned but still much more stressful. I just don't work with the fierce approach the entertainers and merchants use on tourists.

Unique!. A must for anyone travelling to Marrakech. Having read all the previous reviews , I did fall traps to the snake charmers, money men and did not pay anything either. I visited the square practically every hour, it is never boring. It is always alive.

Fantastic. There's everything in this amazing place. Dentists, oranje juice salesman, snake charmers and jugglers. In the evening there're many places were you can eat. The smoke and the smell of the food give to this place a unique atmosphere. Nearby you can find the labyrintic Medina, where you can buy anything.
simply amazing. noise, smells, sounds, entertainers, acrobats, juice, smoke - just breathtaking. a real feast for the senses
Interesting. Bustling atmosphere. Good to see it - you have to see it to believe it. Snake charmers, acrobats, musicians - the lot!
Charming place. it's definetly one charming place, I have always heard of this place, and it was beyond my expectations, definetly worth spending some hours
main square. very lively at night, we walked around during day and night time what a difference between a few hours
lively. the square is a fascinating place both by day and night where you can experience fresh cooked food and see snake charmers and story tellers. an atmosphere to be experienced.

Great slap of culture. It is a lovely sight. We went in Jan so not many other tourists around. If you don't like being hollered at--maybe not the best place to go. But I thought it was fun. Some guy tried to make us pay to take a picture with his Monkey. Other than him everyone was funny and friendly and really work hard to keep their business a float. Really cool experience!

Madness!. You cant miss the place and its the hub of everything that goes on in Marrakech. We didn't really enjoy the snakes and monkeys who were being tortured rather than charmed but aside from that it is a life experience!
Busy market - better at night. Hustle bustle, acrobats, people with snakes and monkeys.Good number of cheap good restaurants and plenty of taxis and horse taxis
Gret place, especially at night. Full of co.our, life and energy. You must visit if in the medina. Classic place on all the photos of marakkesh

Very disappointing!. We had read a lot about this place, but we're disappointed. Perhaps because of bad weather, there was not much to see during the day (just a few snake charmers and stands) and even at night,just food stands, but we did not think it was so magical. Perhaps, we are spoilt as we are originally from Italy.

Hussely bussely.. Exciting frightening. Well where to start...WowMental!SheeeeeeeeeeeeezBest just take it all in from a roof top cafe or grab an orange juice on the way through. Foot stall 31 is delicious..food stall 1 is annoying. Don't encourage the snake charmers as they sew the snakes mouths shut.

Central reference point . When you marauding in Marrakech you need a central reference point - this is it. Once you have this place sussed, everything else centres around it. Best spot for food (especially at night when all the street sellers set up. Good spot for coffee and an amazing entertainment area with snake charmers, acrobatics etc.
day trip. be prepared for haggleing they love it,not much to buy apart from silver which is cheap.dont believe all what they tell you,strangers to the truth!!!!!!

Déjà vu!. Really something, just as I imagined it to be, thank goodness!The noise, the smell, the chaos, the magic, the craziness the people, so vibrant! Love love love it! You will get pestered, it's normal, be firm and polite they will see you are sticking to your guns and move on to their next prey!

An absolute must in Marrakech, just nothing like this.. This place, different every time we passed by or hung out, is like a massive magnet gravitating everyone and everything. Culture, food, entertainment, smells, tastes, sights (not to forget cobras), and just everything! If not spent one full day in this 'everything' place, you haven't been in Morocco.

Heartbeat of the city. This is the centre of the city where the local people trade in traditional items and local delicacies. A lively experience and good way to get a feel of local traditions. The only negative is the pushy nature of the salesman, in most if not all shops. However, a definite must.

crazy. I personally love the souks and haggling and the hassle! It is not for everyone but you have to experience it. Lots of crappy things to buy as little gifts for home and every shop sells the same things! Must have a fresh orange before you leave and try the place in the evening as well as the day for a different experience. Evenings are for eating as you will see if you go. It's like marmite... you either love it or hate it.

Excellent. The most famous place in town, of course! I found very stressing all the people asking you to buy something or paying for a photo. But I know in most arab countries it is this way.A picturesque view of the city and the people who lives there. A great experience despite all the people stressing the tourists.

Not to describe. Words are Not able to describe what is happening over there. You must feel, smell, taste, hear, see, enjoy and let yourself be overwhelmed with this square and the atmosphere. The food in the evening is good, just point at what you want to eat and let them surprise you. It is not expansive. Make some jokes with the boys who try to seduce you to eat, buy and visit their shop their restaurant or whatever they sell and do not overpay. But most of all, enjoy this place!

Fantastic atmosphere at night. Whilst during the day the square holds a number of 'entertainements' - snake charming, musicians, fresh orange juice stalls etc, it is the evening when the fun begins. Rows of 'street food' stalls are set up producing freshly cooked meals; all done with lots of smiles. Good hygene and the food tastes good too.

Noisy, busy, fun. Marrakech has transformed itself since I last visited. Very little hassle now and visitors can wander easily on their own. But beware taking photos of people in interesting costumes in the main square as they will pounce for their fee!

Heart of Marrakech. You can not visit Marrakech and. Not come to the square at least once if not Twice there is so much to see.Although it is one of those places where you ether like it or hate it due to the environment it is in. This is truly an experience in itself. You have to know how to deal with the locals. Everybody will claim there are a guide and almost everything you do expect to be asked "Anything for me Sir or Madam'" which basically is money giving.Overall it is a good experience really cultural and defines Marrakech.

Must see place in Marrakesh. Wonderful atmosphere with food stalls in the evening, fresh orange juice stalls, snake charmers, acrobats, live Moroccan music - it's all here. It's not expensive to sit and have a drink (no alcohol) on a balcony in a bar/cafe overlooking the square. On the road between the square and the Koutoubia mosque are the ranks of caleches - the horse drawn carriages that you can hire for a tour of the city.

Haggle for some bargains. If you want some bargains here , haggle away! There is nothing to cheap we purchased a turtle for 15DH approx £1, even though we returned it a day later as we were flying hme!

Place to see. Being there during day and night really lovely place with a lots happening, snake, monkeys, dancer, beautiful sight of Koutoubia mosque, then walk along the place and get lost in the souk where you can find everyhing and anything, don't forgot to never say yes straight when buying sommething in the souk always lower the price and if it doesn't work try an other shop, i did work for me and my best friend. If you look for a restaurant try Bazar Cafe, the food is really good and affordable, and the view on the atlas Mountain and the all souk just make it worth it.
Busy, busy, busy!. The souk is very nice and gets busier as the night goes on. Be prepared to haggle with all the vendors, it will also take a couple days to explore!

A vibrant market with much to offer, only don't let the locals overcharge you!. I visited Morocco in June 2014. Jemaa El Fna is definitely one of the main attractions in Marrakech, and I stayed in a Riad (Moroccan house) on one of the side streets leading off it.The market square has all sorts of goods on sale: food, spices, ornaments, furniture, jewellery - you name it! Also there are various people with animals that you can take photos with, for a fee of course. My main word of caution is to not let the locals overcharge you. While it is probably acceptable to pay £1 or £2 for a photo they will try to charge you £15, so that you end up settling on something much higher than £1 or £2. Just hold your ground whenever bartering, and set the price before you do anything like take a photo or have henna painted. Don't flash your cash either, and be firm in your decisions and you should get good deals out of your visit. The market (in the building part) also has various fruit, nut and spice stands, and these generally have prices so you won't get cheated. They also let you taste their goods, which is useful!I definitely recommend visiting this market, you will enjoy it for sure :)

Breath the real Morocco !. A huge square surounded by the mosque on one side, Maraquesh suqs on another side, and most important - two floor restaurants which you can see the whole changing proccessing from its second floor.You have to stay here at least from noon till late at night. At day time watch the people and the attractions there: fotrune tellers, hena tatoos makers, story tellers, nonoriginal merchandise sellers, Belly dancers and other endless attractions.Aproximately at four afternoon, the square changes its face. Wagons with construction tools starting to aproach in from all corners around. The morning peple moves away and the square turns into one huge restaurnt of Maroccan dishes in less than half an hour.At late afternoon people starts coming in thousands. Sit and eat good Moroccan food, speak with the sellers and with the Moroccan visitersFeel the atmosphere, smell and breath the real Morocco !

jemaa el Fna. totally loved it. sights, colours, sounds, smells. transformation between day and night. just wandering around or sitting in one of the cafes having a coffee and people watching, brilliant way to spend a few hours.
A Must Do. This is where you can see snake charmers and performing monkeys. Don't heed people saying that things are closed because they are just trying to get you to visit some relative's shop.

Vibrant square not to be missed. Jemma El Fna is a must go of course but for the snake-phobiacs like me it's more like a "must go...carefully". Anyway, around the square there's a lot of great Souks and a lot to enjoy. One can also pick a nice restaurant with rooftop overlooking the square.
kataubia mosk. you can see the biggest mosk from here, katoubia mosk, all the smells the sights you would expect from life in marrakech see the snake charmers, monkey keepers ect
Bustling main square. This is where the action is, especially in the evenings. Good market food - the locals eat here as well

Exciting square. As with everything in Marrakesh, beware of people trying to get money from you. But this square is definitely worth staying in, and I would recommend getting a Riad that is walking distance from here. Come during the day and you'll see the snake charmers, come at night for the food markets which are absolutely delicious!
Fun. This centre of living culture and entertainment is a gift for all to enjoy. Everything I read about and much more. It's easy to see why the community love it.

Hectic. Jemaa El-Fna will probably the focal point of your walking across Marrakech's Medina. You will find yourself heading here everytime you'll get lost in narrow streets of the medina. But it's worth coming - on purpose - in the evening when it shows its best. At twilight storytellers, snake charmers and a lot of common people gather here making it hectic.Try the food stall, despite the number of tourists, some are still authentic and attracting locals as well.

Oh, The great North Africa. Snakes, oranges, juices, food, noises, tourists, locals, youth and vivid spirit. In one word: Life! This was the first time in my life, to meet Cobra in person, without glass. I loved the food at the Market.

Morocco's heart. You have to stay in this place at least from noon until late in the night. During day time watch the people and all the attractions in the square. Afternoon follow the food sellers coming from all over and build their "restaurants". Late afternoon people coming in thousands. Sit and eat a good Moroccan food. Speak with the sellers and with the Moroccan visiters. Feel, smell and breath the real Morocco !

Jemaa el Fna. Busy square full of hawkers trying to sell everything from Fake sunglasses to fake I PhonesBeggers dressed as water sellers charging for a photographMen with monkeys charging for a photographSnake charmers charging for photographIf that's your scene go for it!
Shopping in the suqs. The excellent craftsmen and the variety of goods availableThe flexible pricing and haggling was a bit problematic for me

Amazing!. We went in the afternoon and found a rooftop restaurant to sit and watch everyone set up for the evening which was a great way to watch. Stay away from the monkey man and snake charmer though!!

Madness!! (In a good way). The main square of the old city. Visit the night market from 7pm onwards. The atmosphere is electric. From the entertainers and the smells of the outdoor restaurants, this place is amazing at night. Watch out for the snake charmers and henna ladies!!

Take a seat and enjoy the madness and chaos. This the central square where you can see a range of entertainment acrobats, snake charmers, henna artists as well as lots of juice vendors. In the evening the pop up restaurants appear and there's lots of lovely banter as the restaurants vie to get you said own in their restaurant.

Amazing fresh juice, worth a look.. Food and performers. Everyone wants your money. Front Entrance to the souks. Horse and Carriage rides at the front. You can also use the horse and carriage as a taxi if you can both come to a price you are happy with. The fresh squeezed orange juice stalls are not only great value the juice is gorgeous! The dried fruit and nuts are also goegeous and whats great with both of these is that they all have the same price. There is a wealth of grill stalls to choose from all pretty much offering the same thing for the same price. In the evening the sqaure fills with the smell of charcoal smoke and bbq meat. There are 3 soup stalls which sell a gorgeous soup. It is 3D for a bowl of soup and also 3D for the dates or 'sweet' which you eat alongside it. 9D for all 3 is a steal and really good hearty food. You will see a lot of locals eating this soup. This is a good way to enter the Souks, you may not get out that way as it is very easy to get lost in the market alleys. Choose a cafe with a terrace for a different view of the Jamaa el-Fna. It's interested wathcing the sun go down and the market change. Some will try to charge more for the benifit of the terrace rather than downstairs. Towards the evening to other foodstalls start arriveing and the sqaure fills with more performers. Locals also gather to hear stories and you will see circles of people watching others performing their tales.If anyone puts a snake or a monkey on you or puts their hat on your head and dances with you and you take a photo they will want paying. If you so much as look at a man with a snake he may try to make a beline for you to put it around you neck. Just walk on from these people or if they are close enough to try and get an animal on you then a firm but polite no does the trick.If you take a photo of someones snake, monkey or them with thier snake or monkey... they will want money. Do it from a distance. If you do decide you are happy to pay for the novelty they will try to rip you off. Have some coins ready in your hand £2 pounds or 2 Euros is MORE than enough for a quick photo with a snake but they will try for hundreds. Just give them your change and walk away.

Has to be seen to understand. Loved the hive of activity that is the Jemaa el Fna! Fascinating place to sit and watch. Went here for a few evening meals. It's much of a muchness between the stalls but we went back to number 1 because they had the merguez sausages and it all tasted a bit better! Ha ha! Certainly a place that cannot be compared!

Dinner there. I recommend this square in the evening so u can have a great choice of good for dinner ! Don't be scared to eat there just because they don't look very careful of the cleanness !The people there can be very annoying and pushing during the day ! Just don't look them, don't lose your time discussing with them cause u took a photo on their monkey and now they want u to pay them ! Just avoid them! They can ruin your vacation ! Morocco is a beautiful country , but not so much the people !
Not a Particularly Nice Area!. A very busy and crowded area where you need to be on your guard. Well lit at night though and the mosque is a good landmark.

Lively square. It is a square which is different in the day, to the nightYou must get a nice chilled orange juice - it is amazing, not exp. at all and sweetThere are loads of stalls for food in the night, we only went to one which served the usual dishes, bread for starters with some sauces and a finger mix of mixed grill.. there are loads of people selling the same things, so dont be alarmed if they are trying to get your attentionMake sure you haggle as the initial price is often higher than the price you would close the deal with, but hey thats businessAs long as your kind and respectful to others, they usually treat you good tooTry not to talk too much as it would look bad if you walk out without buying anything, as they are salesmens their main goal is to get things sold, so walk away and say thanks if your no longer interestedYou will find some people and kids selling watches, just ignore them or say no thank you and also look out for pick-pocketters as with any crowded place, no issues from our group of friends but keep your bag with you, faced towards you infront of you at all times, no point of risking itWe didnt go to the snake charmers or monkeys so cant comment on that but we did get a carriage in the night and the initial (going price) at that time was more than the taxi, so we didnt bother, thankfully someone just offered us our final price with no objection and it was a good journey home to the hotel which wasnt far

Bombard your senses. Changed throughout the day from market stalls to eateries.Amazing sounds, smells and spectacles. Great fresh orange juice.Best value food with huge choice of places.Hassled by food stalls to choose them.

An experiance. The main square certainly has the hustle and bustle that I'd heard all about. It's a fairly spacious area that part is converted nightly into over 100 hundred different eating places. We ate there on our first evening, it was good fun although the salesmen to each restaurant are relentless. The food proved to be good and perhaps more expensive than we expected.The other part of the square is set aside for snake charmers & storytellers which is interesting in it's own way. Overall an experience, and a must if you visit Marrakech.Be very careful of any valuables, at any time when you visit here.

over touristy. I was not particularly "charmed" by all the snake charmers, acrobats, and other sidewalk performers in the square. We set out one evening with the intention to eat in the "tent city" of eateries that springs up each afternoon and in to the evening, but the high pressure hawkers pushing menus in our face for each stall was off-putting enough that we ended up dining in a small cafe just off the square.

Nice place where everyone meets. What i really liked about this square was that it was not only tourists walking around. There you can really feel the local ambience. Lots of marakish people go there to eat, have fun and listen to storytellers. Have one of those refreshing orange juices and taste local food.
Much craziness is here. snake-charmers, water sellers, henna artists, street food, nuts, dates, (and flies), it's all here. Particularly bonkers at night but never threatening

You Can't Go to Morocco and Miss This!. The heart of Marakkesh. The charm of snake charmer, the energy of acrobatics, the banter of haggle, and the simple fact that this place is the place of the locals and not staged for the tourists makes it an unmissable experience. Love it. Morocco you are a wonderful people and country.

An experience. You can't go to Marrakech and not see the square even though you might not want to go in. By day it is full of snake charmers, people who mistreat monkeys and horses and donkeys and is best avoided. You will be harrassed but a polite and firm no or non Merci said with authority works. Keep your wits about you and you will be fine. By night, the food stalls and entertainment take over. It is definitely an experience worth having as long as you can put up with hustle and bustle.

Frenetic activity, colour noise - amazing. Having made your way through the confusing streets and alleys, be prepared for an assault on your senses !The square is a riot of activity, colour, smell and noise. Food, goods, clothes etc. are available - but at night is when it really becomes fun. Added to the mix are the snake charmers, musicians, monkey handlers, dancers and story-tellers (wish I could have understood).Be careful when taking photographs as everyone will want money. This is not for the faint-hearted due to the crush of people, overwhelming calls to purchase and, of course, poor treatment of captive snakes and monkeys.This a "must see" but it takes a number of visits to take it all in and to enable one can start being selective. Also, you must eat, but be equally selective as to what food you think your stomach will handle ("no diarrhea" is one of the calls you will hear as an invitation to eat). Ask your Riad staff to suggest ( we were told to go to Aisha's stall). I will go back one day !

Massive square is very entertaining. During the day there are fruit juice stands and snake charmers who will grab your camera and take terrific photos, but beware the price they want. Not for those afraid of snakes, as they drape all tops over you as you pose for photos. At night it gets much more crowded. Food stalls are wonderful - have snails at stalls 1-6, sausages at stall 32 and other snacks at stall 1. All food was tasty and safe. Say hello to locals, they hate to be ignored as they try to hawk their goods and are much more friendly that way, and will accept you decline if you don't want their items.

Assault on the senses. Great by day even better by night. The sights smells and noises here are amazing. Interesting to witness the response to the mosques call to prayer the noises silenced then all start up again. Don't be intimidated, walk around have a good look smile and politely say no if you are being asked to try etc. Be sensible with your belongings especially in the crowds.Its an amazing spectacle and great for people watching even if doing it from afar in one if the rooftop terraces. Just be aware that everyone's after money even if you are just taking a photo. Politely say no.

Didn't come home with the drum we wanted. The Jamma el Fna is a sight for all to see. As I read all the reviews prior to the trip, the outside square was smaller then what I thought. The inside with all the shops and shops and shops are more than what I envisioned. I saw my husband move closer to the men dressed in carnival wear so I thought he had dropped coins in their cup. So my daughter and I were behind him so we couldn't see what he had done so we took a picture with the 3 men. They expected us to pay for the photo, so I said, we had already paid and my husband hadn't paid he was just walking close to them and probably just waved to them and I miss read it. (Anywho, since all the horses are in one section in front of the Club Med, that area has an awful barnyard smell) Siad was a great Caleche driver. We took him back to Sidi Ben Slimane parking lot one night - horse carriage #126. He good information while on the trip and charged us 100MOD flat to go to the newer parts of the city center, near the Novotel Suites and Le Comptoir area and onwards to our Riad. The next day we came to the market (Jemaa el Fna early to have lunch and boy were we surprised........the lunch carts hadn't set up. We didn't know that they are mainly up after 3:00pm - midnight. So we had to go elsewhere for lunch.) We had no idea we couldn't get lunch from the inner carts around 12 noon. I had a lovely Calligraphy work/frame done with our names on it for 50MOD and it includes the frame. I have the 3 names of my family members on it and can't wait to display it. I love helping artists and felt that since the young man only had a table and his art behind him to support him. I didn't get his card but he is near the lane over near the post office that sells all the Chinese imported clothing gadgets. He is very quiet and just looks down at this work. He was quick and he wrapped it nicely in newspaper. Every place we travel in this world we always bring a drum back home to my daughter to add to her collection. The stands/stalls we went to to bargain for the drum was not willing to give it to us at a good rate. Once the merchants hear your accent and know you are on holiday they don't give you great deals. You just bargain the best you can and if you can live with it fine. If you can't just leave. This part of shopping takes up a lot of your time. Just go to places with the prices already written on. We only had 2 days in Casa, 3 in Fes and 3 in Marrakech. WE did not have a lot of time to keep bargaining every station we went to. It eats up a lot of your holiday. Make a list of what you would like to take back before you get to Morocco. Here was my list: Argan oil (for the body), berber rugs/carpets, small souvenirs and Orange blossom oil for the body. I got everything but the drum. Go figure.
Great Atmosphere. I don't think you could possible go to Marrakech and avoid the square. Keep your wits about you and your hands in your pockets!
Be carefull if eating there at night. Make sure you only accept what you order as they will keep bringing plates of different foods that will end up costing a fortune. Definitely an experience

Marvellous madness. The first evening we arrived in Marrakech we made our way to Jemaa el Fna the main market square and were overwhelmed by the hustle and bustle of the square and constant hassling from market traders.Monkeys, snake charmers and motorbikes or coffee, orange juice and dates all constantly being pushed upon you; you soon learn to say no and move on.The following day the square was a completely different place with a different but still manic atmosphere.By the end of the week we learned to love the madness and constant commotion. Hassling and haggling became part of the appeal.We ate street food in the square and as the dishes were so cheap we ordered a selection to share, some we loved and others not so much. Once you are sat down there is no rush to serve you so take your time to enjoy the experience, soak up the atmosphere and partake in some people watching. All restaurants in the square want bums on seats but the best are the ones the locals hang around so watch where they head and you'll get the best food.

over the top. this place is truly like the arabian nights- food stalls, water sellers, snake charmers, bands playing, jugglers and acrobats, stalls selling everything and anything, and man pulling teeth....

charming madness. brilliant, real energy , we were totally in awe of the surroundings, the narrow maze of souks , what an experience, like stepping back in time. great bargains, hassled to buy everything but a really firm no does work , if you do buy something be prepared to haggle even if you don't want to, drink mint tea in shop, then haggle some more

The heartbeat of Marrakech!. You could spend hours in Jemaa el Fna and never get bored. At night it turns into a local culinary mecca with dozens of food stalls dishing out brochettes, tagines and other local fare.Beware of these over-friendly restaurateurs though as they tend to charge you for items you may not have ordered. Point to the items listed on the menu that you wish to order and reconfirm the price.Do try the ginger and herb tea from the tea stalls in front of the food stalls!There are many other activities that keep the place busy - street shows, henna artist, snake charmers etc. all vying for your attention!
Place . In 2001 this famous square was proclamed a interlacing stucco work flanked with hells, columms with capital. Its nice place.

Morocco's No 1 Tourist Attraction. Apparently it is, the square of the dead, as it is where the condemned were executed. During daylight hours it is a series of shops monkey tamers, snake charmers, children boxing and the like. Was disappointed, plenty of photo opportunities but anyone caught in shot will ask you for cash - not unusual in Marrakech, as you should ask permission first but these guys want paper money only. Allegedly, as I didn't go back, it is more exciting at night. Women should cover legs, not smoke, nor hold hands with partners as this is frowned upon, and boy is it frowned upon, especially on a Friday

Why the monkeys?. The place is alive especially at night but surely snake charming and monkeys on leashes should be a thing of the past ....the musicians and story tellers are enough without animal welfare issues
the same as the medina...such a mess. the place is really big and full of people, vendors, incredible stuff, vegetables and fruits, snakes' enchanters.

Marrakesh market is not for the fainted heart.. I was yesterday in Marrakesh, at jemma el fna, the famous market and no one grabbed me and if someone touched me I would scream and call the police, so I think they have a natural sense for dangerous tourists like me. The public bathroom in the market is horrible..is a porcelain hole in the floor..so you need to squat and target the hole...ok just horrible. Now, is useful to know how much is everything so you tell them upfront you won't pay nothing else more. Like I did, not even taxi drivers could take one dirham more from me. Like my mother used to say, do you wanna play crazy? So I will be crazy and a half, but if you don't have this kind of personality, avoid Marrakesh, seriously, because you can be very tired to fight the sellers and the rude people. Now having said that, if you focus and don't listen to no one trying to sell anything, if you ask the drivers to turn on the taximeter, and focus in the beauty of the city, you can leave the city with the sweet taste of the best orange juice as the one I had in jemma el fna. Be aware that not all foreign cards are accepted here, mine was not and the cash machine took in my card, I had to call Brazil to have cancelled. And don't ever travel with checked luggage containing iPad, iPhones, jewelry,...they tend to vanish in the airport....

What a place. The square really test all of your senses. The sights, the sounds and of course the smells of food. We loved all of the and would recommend an afternoon visit and watch the square transform when the food sellers arrive, and then start to cook. Could not get enough.

Exciting and enchanting . Before arriving in Marrakech, I had read an article or caption I should say, by national geographic on Instagram about the Djema Al Fna... I was absolutely awed by the description and couldn't wait to go there. Upon arrival I was greeted with locals trying to sell me many things along with an enchanting array of shows. A Berber family dancing and playing music, a game, a lady applying henna tattoos, and a fortune teller. I was a bit disappointed that I missed any snake charmers but the authenticity and vibe of the place made up for it. My family and I skipped the food stalls in the front, where there were men promising us no diarrhoea for the next two years, or others speaking in well rehearsed British accents... I didn't have the heart to tell them that I'm not British. We started off with a harira soup at a very busy stall void of any tourists and packed with locals. The soup was brilliant. Next we ordered mint tea packed with sugar but the perfect pacifier for my sweet tooth. Being pretty adventurous, I decided to try the meat. I kept my head down, trying to seem local and unassuming. But with a giant DSLR hanging from my neck, I didn't quite fit in. In another row of food stalls, only selling meat delicacies like tongue, brain, udder or the more orthodox option beef stew (which I stuck to.) I had some delicious food, the Tunjeya was great and hearty. The square was brilliant and warranted another visit again two nights later.
A thousand years in action. Let the music and action flow around you as a thousand years of culture awaits you. Dine at the Cafe L Ahambra and watch Marakesh go by.

Crowded and touristy. The square is famous for its entertainers in the evenings, but we found it to be a massive tourist trap. Watch out for men pestering you to eat in their cafés, and women pestering you to let them give you henna tattoos, it's hard to escape the constant bombardment of tourist-hunters.
Great place to watch the action. Massive square, stalls, snake charmers, monkeys, cafes and many people, I don't like bartering, but if that's your thing then you'd be in heaven

Interesting. A must see!Is it enjoyable? I'm 50/50 on this one, whilst it is a fantastic experience seeing all the live acts and things happening in and around the square the constant hassle of being asked to dine here or purchase this takes it's toll.My partner also got food poisoning by eating at one of the stalls, I however was ok. If you are an animal lover be aware that there is some definite mistreatment going on, in saying this though it has been happening for centuries and a part of their culture.

I never tire of visiting this throbbing, vibrant and intoxicating delight. If you visit the square after 4 in the afternoon, I would highly recommend going to the eastern end of the square, which is easy to work out as you will be at the opposite end of the square facing the grand mosque minaret and the pending sunset. Find a table in one of the roof terraces which overlook the square, just a couple of floors up, and watch one of the greatest shows on earth unfold before your eyes, as smoke rises from the food stalls and dances on the evening sunlight.Do not randomly point your camera at anyone and everything, as you will be asked to pay for such photos. Politely ask people if you may take a photo and give them a small tip. Do not allow yourself to be bullied or harassed as some of the guys can be pretty full on and heavy. Watch, absorb and enjoy this dizzy delight of daily Moroccan life in Marrakech.

Interesting and fun place for foody. It is an open square in the middle of Marrakech.. as the sun goes down, many food stalls starts opening and preparing specialty food. If you are a foody or interested to try local food, this is the place to go. Make sure your stomach is empty so you can try the food from many different stalls.. Its a must to visit this place.

Such a beautiful place ruined by greedy locals. If you're looking for a relaxing break...this is not the place to go. The square is such a beautiful place, steeped in rich history that I find absolutely fascinating. In my opinion it has been absolutely ruined by the people that live there. They seem to hold tourists in complete disdain. It's impossible to sit and have a coffee without people coming up to you literally holding out their hands until you give them money. When you don't, they become abusive, swear and intimidate. My fiancé and I had a situation where we're taking a photograph of each other when I man came up claiming that we had taken a photograph of him and his snakes. We were very polite and insisted we were only taking a photo of each other, but he grabbed my arm and shook it causing me to drop my phone on the floor. Luckily my other half is quite a burly sort and grabbed the guy back and he backed off but I was left very shaken and with significant bruising around the top of my arm. Please don't think we are affected western tourists, I have been to many places across the Middle East and have always been respectful and courteous to the locals and their cultures, but Jeema El Fna is the worst place I have visited. We ended up spending most of our trip in the new city, which is nowhere near as historic and fairly soulless, but we felt far safer and relaxed.

Busy place! Lively but can be intimidating. Me and my husband and our son went there in the day time around 12, it was really busy and people were just everywhere, i dont mind people just not a fan of snakes as there were quite a lot of them around. And monkeys! Dont take their pictures unless you are willing to pay!
Maddest place ever.. Maddest place we have ever been. Great fun and crazy people. We saw some things we never thought we would ever see. Dancing Monkeys, Snake Charmers and more...

Avoid the snake charmers. Go for music in the evening. If you go there during the day time you are asking for being pushed by pesky snake charmers and the monkey men. Go in the evening for street music. There will be acts to avoid but you will find the good stuff eventually. Street food is nothing special and should be avoided if you are staying with bottled water. Much less expensive street-food options exist elsewhere.

A large open space with no character. Tourists, juice stalls, vendors, noise a peculiar smell, snake charmers, some people aimlessly loitering. some old people playing hand made instruments, in general one unholy mess

Wonderful. Yes it isn't the cleanest, yes everyone will be trying to get your money, yes people will actually touch you and not respect your boundaries but in all seriousness I have seldom felt more alive than when I was walking through, watching people in and eating and drinking in this place. The food was generally great and fantastic value. The orange juice is legendary. The fish stalls were wonderful. The tea was clearing, the soup was hearty and the meat was all packing great flavours. The entire place has a constant heartbeat both from the thrum of engines and the various drummers. Once you decide hat you are willing to do, who you are willing to give money and you are firm you will not have any problems. You have to be here to believe it.

It all depends.... Well, if you read the reviews, I find that basically everybody describes the square exactly the same, but only the ratings are different ranging from 5 to 1 stars! :)So fact is: The square is crowded and abysmally smelly (even worse during the day), the snake charmers and monkey handlers are cruel (if you take a picture, they will ask for money and coins won’t do), the musicians are a sorry excuse, the food stalls look dodgy, the henna ladies are pushy (stay polite as long as possible, but get very firm if anybody touches your hand), everything is helplessly overpriced and of cheap quality.Is it worth is? It all depends on your state of mind and probably on the experiences you’ll make. You might have a nice evening with tea on one of the terraces, maybe a snack and heavenly orange juice from the stalls, make a small bargain for a souvenir, and marvel at the peculiarities like the water sellers and dentists. Or you might be shocked by some of the sights and smells, have your cell phone stolen, might be shouted at for 10 Eur for a photo you took while just passing a snake charmer, molested for another 10 Eur by a henna lady who draws a undefined and unwanted swivel on your hand (it is really amazing how quick they can be sometimes…) and for the grand finale might be urged to have an awful overpriced meat skewer that will lock you in the bathroom for the next 24 hours… Both options are possible and I recommend everyone to go there to see it for yourself. Try to stay at the outskirts at first, stay a little alert and do not let people push you into doing anything.

Ok for a look see. The main square is big and bustling which is good but it's not the nicest area of the Medina. I'm not a big fan of seeing animals used for tourist purposes so steered clear of these. The food market at night is good to see being put together from about 4.30 but the food isn't as great as we'd hoped so ate at other places scattered through the Medina.

Cant miss it. Literally, you can try as you might, but you won't be able to miss Jemma el Fna in all its crazy glory. The essence of Marrakech is concentrated into this square. Be very aware of your pockets and belongings. Take pictures--but be prepared with a pocket full of coins to give them. I was forewarned and had coins to give, but i saw a woman being accused of taking a picture of the snakes and didn't want to pay bc it was a misunderstanding, and she almost had a snake thrown at her. Don't get into any arguments... seriously Dirhams are pennies on the dollar --pay up, enjoy and be firm when saying no to henna tattoos and purchasing things ;-) Enjoy!
the square. lots going on got to be sharp or you get a henna design on your hand or a monkey on your shoulder - both cost you dirhams only pay what you think is fair stick to your guns and walk away

Main square Marrakech. An interesting place which changes from daytime to night. Snake charmers and monkeys by day and even more loud Moroccan music etc by night. Once you get used to the noise and gain a little confidence you can really enjoy this place. The restaurants overlooking the square might not be the best food available but a must if only for a drink or snack. The evening food stalls can be a little daunting with every trader trying to get you to eat at his. We were advised not to eat there so didn't try it although the food looked amazing.

Interesting experience, but not exceptional.... We enjoyed walking around Jemaa el Fna and getting some fresh orange juice, but it didn't feel particularly safe, even with the large police presence. Also, there isn't anything particularly unique about the experience, unless you are interested in watching the snakes and cobras.

Weird and wonderful. If you don't like getting approached by vendors of food,watches or other items then this isn't for you. Street entertainment all around although we didn't hang around to get a monkey on our backs or a snake over your shoulders. Wonderful,diverse,different .and wacky,best let your hang ups go. We got suckered at a street food stall at night for not saying no, a word you'll need to use a lot in Marrakech.

Amazing sights and sounds. Busy, busy, busy. There is so much to see here in the square. Make sure you look for the local 'dentist'. We refused to pay to take photos of monkeys or snakes as we didn't like the monkeys being pulled along by tight chains round their necks, but everything else was so entertaining. The night time food restaurants were busy, never a dull moment.

Visit it several times at different times of day / evening. Chaos. Just chaos. But I felt each visit was an experience in itself. Beware of pickpockets & expect to get approached even if you happen to glance in the direction of a stall selling something. But Moroccans are good natured and don't hassle you for long. Soak up the atmosphere from a cafe balcony.Mostly charming chaos but like many, I found the animal cruelty difficult to handle regarding the monkeys.

Must see!. Check out Jemaa el Fna for great performances from music, games and henna to snake charming. Theres an abundance of outdoor places to eat and restaurants with rooftop terraces and various types of food for good prices. Theres lots of small shops that sell souvenirs, spices, clothes, fruits and nuts. Be sure to haggle for the best price! The square is buzzing with activity and great place to visit during the day and at night.

Pity it's so intimidating. Wonderful place. Unique experience. But as a solo female traveller it was way too overwhelming and intimidating. Had done a lot of research on Marrakech in advance so knew what to expect. But didn't expect quite how much I got hassled. Literally couldn't walk throughout the star without guys constantly jumping in front of me throwing menus in my hand trying to get me to eat with them, pulling at my arm, pulling me over to shows. I just wanted to relax and enjoy the experience but it felt impossible to do. Make sure to get orange juice. Had read how tasty it was, but it really was so yum!!The guide books recommend if you're not interested, then ignore whoever is hassling you. Seems I felt bad doing this, so on a couple of occasions said things like 'maybe another time' etc. But then the hassle was even worse next time I passed their way. They really remember people and was told I hadn't kept my promise, needed to come in to them etc. Very, very intimidating. Yes, perhaps better to ignore if not interested, as the guide books said.

Overawing. You can't really miss this square as it is the hub of Marrakech. We visited on the first night, not long after arriving, and found it intimidating, but once we'd seen it in daylight it was manageable!! It is absolutely jam packed with women trying to sell you henna tattoos, snake charmers, water sellers, guys with plastic tat, restaurants (at night), men with performing monkeys (not pleasant, but I couldn't believe the number of tourists who wanted to be photographed holding a terrified-looking monkey wearing a Real Madrid football shirt...), policemen with big guns etc etc etc. Sitting in a restaurant overlooking the square and watching the goings on is definitely recommended.

Busy bustling square. Definitely worth visiting here in the evening as comes to life and fun to see all the market traders buzzing around and the lanterns lit up. Obviously a tourist spot and like any city need to be aware of pickpockets. Lots of food stalls, monkey handlers, snake charmers, henna tattoos.
busy traditional and very tourist oriented. sunset and evenings best time to soak up the atmosphere try the different juices and if your a meat eater lots of street food to choose from

Always something to watch.. But be careful for pickpockets, people who want money for a picture even when they are not even in it, and the women who make henna tattoos. Before you know it your hand is covered in henna that won't come of for weeks and they demand money, The restaurants on the square are nice for a coffee, but not for dinner.

Chaotic Wonder; but DON'T SUPPORT THE ANIMAL CAPTIVITY. The square/place is still a bustling hub of merchants, food vendors, and entertainers. I visited with my friend that lives there and he called the entertainers (dancers, actors, musicians) authentic, but the Theatre of Crap (his words not mine) as they're for the poorer classes that come here to watch.Disliked: I saw a handful of people clearly there scoping out tourists to pick-pocket. Be careful, especially when it's dark.Disliked: do not support the animals here (monkeys, snakes). Your one photo and dirhams support a lifetime of cruelty & abuse. The monkeys cower from their owners, indicating that they are routinely beaten. If you take a photo & pay some dirhams, you are supporting cruelty.
Fascinating place!. There is no better place to discover Arabic culture! You will love the whirlpool of emotions what this bustle will give you!

#1 on your list for Marrakech!. A must-see and experience a full day at Jemma el F'na. The souks, the food, the life! After visiting the merchandise in the souks, as night falls, the tents are raised and an abundance of food is being prepared. One must spend an entire day here!

Fna Fna!. This square is pretty amazing! Snake charmers, storytellers, acrobats, juice stalls, restaurants, and the entrance to the souk all clamour for attention, as do the horses and carriages at the top end of the square. Beware that you cannot buy alcohol in the square, and also if you sit ground level at the front, you will get an endless stream of 'looky looky' men. The square is a very hypnotic place which gives you the impression that you have actually time travelled.
An experience. Busy with snake charmers, mutilated monkeys on chains and beggars. Lots of people trying the hard sell and hassling you. Good for the Moroccan experience I guess but not for us.

A must during the evening. we visited this place during day and evening time. It is really a must during the evening to wonder around and eat a bite on one of the hundred small shops which are installed in the evening. You eat for not even 10 euro for 2 persons. Ok, it is touristic, but it is really your time worth.

It's a MUST. I've been lucky enough to take two trips to Morocco....and been here several times over each trip. It is fascinating, energizing, confusing, exhausting and WONDERFUL. Soak it up, wander, watch, listen and experience. It's a MUST...more than once! Enjoy!

Great orange juice!. Come here for the best orange juice (stands throughout the square).. otherwise it's not all that special, just a huge plaza with lots of people selling things, snake charmers (if you're willing to pay for a show), food stands

food. We loved the food in the evening, the stoty tellers (even if we didn't understand a word...) and the whole ambiance. Once you need a break, go for a coffee or tea to one of the terraces around the place and enjoy from far.Some waiters and sellers are quite persistent, stay brave and do, buy and eat, whatever YOU want :-)

Adventure for some, overwhelming for others. Visiting the Jemaa el Fna is essential when in Marrakech. It is noisy, crazy and for some it can be overwhelming. My children were nervous at first, but became less scared when they saw the whole thing as a show. Take your sense of adventure and humour with you and it will be an experience to remember for the right reasons. Forget that you are part of a large circus and performance and you will struggle to enjoy the atmosphere. Yes, you will be hassled, but not unduly so. Yes, there are issues with animal welfare, but don't take photos or watch the performances if it upsets you. Yes, there are small children begging, follow your heart and give or withhold change as you see fit. Go there, absorb the insanity of the place and then gratefully leave it behind.

Unmissable. For a real introduction to Morocco this can't be missed. From snake charmers to acting monkeys (stay away from both is my advice) the best bit is to sit and eat at some of the pop up restaurants and drink freshly squeezed juice

Not your average square. From rustic pop-up restaurants in the evening (number 31 was the best we tried), to orange juice and snack stalls, to the snake charmers, to circles of locals playing music, this is a once is a lifetime experience.

Its a mad mad world.... By day its a bustling market with music everywhere, stores laden with fruit and nuts. By night it turns into a market come dining event. Food stalls everywhere selling everything from Tagines, BBQ, the smells are amazing and the clouds of smoke from the stoves fill the air. Not to be missed.

Amazing!. Even though you know that the performance put on is mainly for tourists it's still a sight to behold! There are snake charmers, sadly performing monkeys. Amazing drummers and other musicians,. Veiled women who will henna your hands, Berber water sellers and pedlers selling everything from track suits to plastic camels. The best way to view everything is from one of the many cafe balconys. The food they serve is poor and there is no alcohol but it's more than a worthwhile experience.

It's all happening here!. So much going on, with ladies offering henna "tattoos" and snake charmers, general hawkers and people offering their guide services. Didn't like the performing monkeys, they made us feel very sad, so we kept well away from them.

Jemaa el Fna. I just love this square, during the day it's so interesting but at night it's amazing, the atmosphere is completely different. I'm a single lady traveller and felt so safe and secure walking around at night.

THE place to see. You can't avoid this place and it is probably something you have to see, but I always try to go across quickly. Too much noise, feverish activity, selling things you don't need (though the vendors respect you when you say firmly no), all these snakes (how do they make them lie around so calmly?) And monkeys. Best and best priced orange juice. The food in the evening stalls is of poor quality, avoid it.

Jemaa el Fna square. A must visit place in Marrakech. Totally out-of-this world kind of experience. Night time is even better with carnival atmosphere with food, free flow of berber whisky, music and dancing. Be careful though because nothing is free. Get ready with small change in case they ask you to pay for their performance.

Crazy!. It's hard to describe what the Jemma el Fna square is like. It's huge, crazy, seedy, and exotic all at the same time. There are cobras and other snakes (don't get too close!!), monkeys, women putting henna on hands, people selling juice of all types, people selling fake iphones, and others selling all kinds of fake stuff. It's dangerous after 11:00pm, but doesn't feel too safe during the day either. It's definitely something to experience, but I wouldn't plan to spend too much time there. It's a prime spot to get pick-pocketed.
A myriad of colour <3. Absolutely wonderful maze of colours and smells - fantastic shopping experience!! Highly recommended
Welcome To Marrakech!!!. This square is a crazy crazy place but a great place to start exploring Marrakech!! There is a melting pot of food, music, monkeys, snakes, tea and rooftop views!
Brilliant shopping and atmosphere !. a great place to sample the real Marrakech and get some great bargains ! We loved the haggling and the kids came away with some brilliant souvenirs !

Never boring place. Visit this place during the nighttime if possible as it truly comes alive after dark. You will find it very vibrant and never boring. There are dozens of food stalls many of which are similar and serve normal tourist fair however there are several that serve more traditional unique flavor. The ones we highly recommend are: freshly squeezed juice with no water (orange or mixed with grapefruit and lemon), lamb sausages (look for the smoke rising from it), traditional soup, snails and for the more adventurous there is a stall that sells brain, head and other unusual cuts of meat. In general as long as you stick to cooked food (no salad) you should be fine. We didn't get sick even though we ate street food all the time. Don't feel pressured to sit at any stall by the continuous pushing of the vendors but sit wherever its busy, use your judgement and follow your nose. The good places are usually less pushy.Besides food you will find snake charmers, different handcrafts and products to buy, boxing matches, traditional dances (by men dressed like women), street performers, monkeys, etc. The night is particularly interesting because of the lights, the smoke, the amount of people walking by and it is completely safe. There are dozens of police officers around and multiple tourists everywhere. The souks (markets) begin at the periphery of this plaza. This place is a MUST!

A must do in Marrakech. Loved the craziness of the place - but felt a little uneasy at times. We steered clear of the snake charmers and monkeys - not really our thing but we were fascinated by everything else going on. The sounds of drumming and smells of food at night were amazing, everywhere you look there's some sort of entertainment. The transition from day to nighttime is incredible and looking out over the square from one of the cafe terraces is a must do.

Historic. Having recently watched Hitchcocks the man who knew too much it was clear to see that the square is virtually unchanged since the early 1950s. The worst culprits for hassle were the Henna women - Avoid. Photos of the snake charmers, acrobats, boxers etc will be expected to be paid for.Do not go the Cafe de Paris for tea. They will deliberately overcharge with a smile on their face.

great atmosphere,nothing's free!!. This place is the centre of all things marrakech,gets very crowded but is a must see if only for a stroll through. You could spend hours here but be aware that even having your picture taken standing with a snake charmer is going to cost some amount of money. Personally I strolled through bought an orange juice then disappeared into the souks. The evening is very lively and you can go,sit,eat and soak up the atmosphere but am not sure it would win any hygiene awards!!
Charming chaos. You have to go there to feel the real atmosphere of the city. Great delicious and cheap food at the market stalls. Be prepared to pay for taking pictures of enterntainers.

Magic. The square seems like it is celebrating some special city festival and this keeps the place constantly busy with people wanting to see the action. The programme changes automatically during the day with no one dictating what should happen next. Never seen anything quite like it.Bring some 5 or 10 diram coins to tip if you like a particular spectacle. It is customary to do so and the locals do it too.

Worth a walk, but very tourist-y. It is worth a walk through, but we personally found it a tad too tourist-y. I wouldn't recommend eating at the food stalls unless you have local recommendations; there are far better places in the medina to eat. It is certainly very exotic and quite the spectacle at sunset, with the food stalls going up, the snake charmers, performers, etc.

Harassment and animal abuse abound. I found the swarm of snake charmers and monkey handlers depressing and when I took a snap of anything, sharp eyed vendors rushed over to claim a fee. I chose to delete my photos and pay nothing, moving on swiftly to see more appealing sights in Marrakesh of which there are many.
Turistic circus!. There are a terrible hectic and noisy atmosphere. The local people are very pushy and there are a lot of caged animals...

Don't be scared - its amazing. The square is amazing if you embrace the chaos - take time to whatch the shows and hold a snake etc - give what you want but 5 MAD seems to be a good amount. Eat at the food stands and get some fresh OJ - 5 MAD to take away 4 if you stand there and drink it.
Theme park. This is a must for visitors but it is clearly now little more than a theme park version of what it once was. It is raucous and colourful nonetheless.

Get lost in the Souks it makes for a great story. Jemaa el Fna is a mental place. We got well and truly lost, then became mildly panicked and finally paid a lad £2 to walk us back to the centre... looking back now it was totally worth it.We saw snake charmers, monkeys, I was offered a Zebra hide (which I declined), there were toothless relics squatting in doorways and we were nearly run over my mad mopedists a thousand times..... I'm still grinning now
Fascinating. Just so much to see. Visited in the daytime and at night. At night quite a sight with pop up restaurants. Really buzzing atmosphere.

Jmaa El Fna: The Good, The Bad & The Ugly:. THE GOOD:•Cultural history and the sound of the calls to prayers•The souks and their mazes.•The exotic, colourful and aromatic display of all sort of products.•The scene of the square at night time. Musicians, Acrobats, dancers•Tasty and spicy Moroccan Cuisine •Great weather•Vicinity of Atlas Mountains and EssaouiraTHE BAD:•Chaotic and noisy traffic•The constant offers on the streets to buy goods and services•The smell of horses dung•The pressure of allure from food stall holders and souvenir shops ownersTHE UGLY:•Begging•Pick pocketing•Rip-off greedy merchants•Been hassled for money at the slightest glance to street entertainers•Fake goods•Some nasty henna ladies•Animal cruelty (Monkeys, fangless snakes, tired horses and donkyes, live poultry hanged upside down…

What makes Marrakech different. Really enjoyed the many times we walked through this madhouse. The food we had was very good especially the snail stalls and grilled merguez sausage. The hypnotic drone of the many groups of musicians set the mood and I have never seen so many snakes and their handlers in one chaotic place. Enjoyed every moment and was never hassled.

Never seen something like it. This square was the highlight of my family's trip. We were amazed at the storytellers, the snake charmers, the performers and all of the music. The 40+ orange juice stands were perfect for a cool drink, and you are able to head straight to the souq from the corners of the square. We came here during both the day and night, and would reccomend both times, however, stick together during the night time, as it is very crowded and you could get easily seperated.

Jemaa el Fna. Fantastic place. An amazing melting pot of snake charmers, henna tattooers, orange squeezers that in the evening transforms to a huge food place, storytellers etc. The smells, the noise, the crowds, the dirt... Everything just fantastic.

A place of good and bad. A bustling market place even in December, I can't imagine how much busier it is in the summer, we were happy to come at this time of year to avoid overcrowding. Come later at night unless your shopping as there's not much to do really other than eat and drink tea. Avoid the snake charmers and monkeys as the will try to rip you off, we avoided them but saw plenty of tourists get caught out with a monkey on their shoulder or snake in hand without asking and had to pay to get them removed. Main downside is the amount of kids and other beggars but every city has them so stay strong you won't be able to help all although I highly recommend getting rid of your spare coins to the kids or the ladies selling cookies on the street as they will be the most grateful for anything unlike others who expect only paper money

Cultural but tricky!. Probably this place it is one of the 1st contact that you can have in Marrakech and you have to go with you hart and eyes open! You have to open your eyes to understand that it´s a peculiar culture with a lots of dance, music, flavors and markets. You can feel a mix between enchantment and hanger...The people are going to be very insistent with you. They going to try to sell you everything all the time and you have to be prepared for this. If you don´t like this, here goes a precious tip: just avoid eye contact! When they look at you, just look in another direction and remain quiet...If you going to by something in the markets, you really have to negotiate. And try don´t look back after to by something, because you going to find the same article cheaper in another place.Beware about what you by. Many products comes from China. Try to by herbs and spice only in the herboristerist (special pharmacy´s supervised by the government), otherwise you can by a fake product.Don´t eat there because of the cheap price, but because of the experience. In Guelize (15 minuts from Jemaa El Fna), you can eat the same dishes, with superior quality and paying the same prices (sometimes even cheaper!).

Exhausting, exhilarating, crazy, mind-boggling - You must go there!. This is a place to visit - at least once but more than once is better.This is Morocco city life at its best. Can it be a tourist trap? Absolutely! However, we knew this going in, therefore went with the flow and enjoyed ourselves.Went there at least 1/2 dozen times and found it to be very safe, as is Morocco in general. Did we find a gazillion people trying to get us to part with the excess Dirhams in our wallets? Of course, but that is par for the course in a marketplace.Just getting lost in the souks is a great experience, permitting us new and interesting experiences. Yep, everyone and their dog wants to help you get back on track with the inevitable little "Baksheesh" expected at the end but let's be honest; we are talking a Euro or so and, if you can afford to go there, you can afford the expense of a tip - after all Morocco is strongly dependant on tourism.At night the square really comes to life; with many performers strutting their act in the hope of attracting some change into their hats. You can buy anything and everything there, including getting your teeth pulled – seriously!The people are amazing and they do respect "la shukran" (no thanks) with grace, thanking you with "Insha'Allah fima borad " (Allah willing, later). We continually encountered a great sense of humour.So much to see, totally exhausting in a good way and provides many hours of great memories of Marrakech.Bernd and BettinaWilliams Lake, BC, Canada

Morroccan hospitality at its lowest. Watered down orange juices, beggers asking for money, begger kids asking for whatever you're eating, eat food vendor almost forcing you into their eateries to consume tasteless tajine (I've tried it in hotel, and a few other restaurants, they are million times better), and if you don't comply, they even customise the swear words they use to the language you would likely understand. Yes, they know them in a lot of languages. We had a member of our party with her hand held viciously by a henna "artist", snake charmer chasing you for money for a passing glance you might've had while walking. The monkeys are not vaccinated so better be safe than sorry. I'd still visit it with no plan to eat or spend money and staying well away from most of the stalls, and taking very little money to allow pick pockets to have their day.
Nice open space. This square adjoining the medina comes alive in the evenings, but is very touristy in terms of the performances by the artists, though the food stalls are interesting
The heart-throb of Marrakech. Whether in the day or night, a great place to be. Time flies in the Square, and the food stalls are worth a visit.

Amazing!. We were almost put off by the bad reviews but this main square is a sight not to be missed. The sounds and smells are one of a kind. At first it's overwhelming and may seem intimidating, especially at night, but it's very safe and the locals are such warm and friendly people. Yes they get your attention because they want you to eat at their stall rather than the next guys but it's all very good humoured and a smile and a cheerful 'no thank you' sends them on their way. Just don't be hesitant as they 'pounce' if you offer them a glimmer of hope!

Too crowded and feeling of insecurity. While this square is world famous, it is in my opinion overrated.
The most fun are the plenty of fruit juice stands. Beside that you are continiusly bothered by beggars, and people who are trying to sell you anything fake you can imagine.
It's definitely worth experiencing it , but once will do...

La Place to be. You can't really go to Marakech and not visit Jemaa el Fna. Evening is probably best when the food sellers set up their stalls and do their best to invite you in to try their wares. It's buzzing with people, locals and tourists and a few snakes being charmed too!

Interesting. You definitely see it all here, I can't say I would return but it was a good humbling experience. When in Marrakech it is definitely worth experiencing and seeing. We visited both in the day and night and preferred the night as the square lit up. As mentioned in other reviews there are snake charmers, monkeys, orange vendors, stalls, food stalls and more. You will be hassled here but you just need to ignore this and continue walking. Also be careful of belongings. Quite sad to see stray dogs and kittens and also the horses and monkeys being used in the square. I love animals so this really made me feel sad but I guess there is always bad everywhere you go it's just different when you actually see it. Overall it was a good experience to visit once but we would not return.
Visiting the square. all crazy but Google hearted . Don't trust anyone that says they are taking you a shortcut etc etc you will end up lost lol

The crazy square !. You just see everything here - the good, bad and ugly. From snake charmers to monkeys to orange juice vendors to the food stalls at night. People selling fake watches, bags and you name to what ever you want. The place turns into a bazaar of sorts at night when the food vendors come set up their stalls at 6pm. If you aren't too adventurous the best place to watch is one of the terrace of the surrounding cafés. We did that for about two hours and then went down actually and walked around the entire area. Be careful though of people being pushy and aggressive and stay clear of anyone offering any free services. Walk around and enjoy the scenes :)

Over rated. I found it very overstated, liked the Berber market a lot more.The stalls were selling largely fake items and snake charmers were probably the biggest draw.Not more than a one time visitThe adjoining markets are lovely though--- one can spend a full day wandering!!

Get ready to be chased. This is geared toward street food of the Jemaa el Fna. If you are a non-local looking in appearance, then you have a bullseye written all over your back. It seemed to especially bad in the evenings when we walked past the food vendors. Young men would come toward us, one after another, telling us to come to eat at their booths. We just wanted to see what the different types of foods were available, and instead we were trying to either dodge them, or zigzagging back and forth to have them stop following us. I was even more shocked, when the cussing or insults starting flying from mouths, just because we didn't take a seat in their stall. I was very excited to see all the exotic cuisines that were being offered, but extremely put off by the rudeness of the men. With the aggressiveness of the men, I didn't feel at all comfortable going back down the other aisle to eat knowing the same thing would occur. Having this experience the first night, the next night, we wanted to be more prepared. We stood away from the food stands, and talked out which food we would like to try, so we wouldn't wonder aimlessly through the stands, and even from afar, men would start coming toward us, telling us to come eat! This is was by far, the worst part.....now for the good side. Food was very cheap. We ate 3 nights in a row at various stands, and our bill got cheaper and cheaper each night. For two adults to eat, the bill was 120, 100, and 75 MADs. There will be lots of variety to choose from. Our first night, we had the chicken with couscous and little sausages. Snails in broth, meat skewers, and eggplant for the second night. Lastly, we tried the tagine and sheep head (1/4 head).
