All were very tasty, and would try again in the future.Some things to keep in mind:#1Be prepared to have thick skin while venturing through the food stands because you will be harassed. If approached, just keep moving on till you are ready to stop and eat.#2Be firm on what is placed in front of you and if you want it or not. We got bread, tomato sauce, olives, and another vegetarian dish without ever uttering one word. #3Make sure the worker writes down the price for you, so everything is calculated correctly. The first night, the place was so busy, they just gave us the total, but all the other places, each item was written down on paper, so we knew what we were paying for.#4Not all menus will have English. Primarily, they will be in French and Arabic. We could guess some of the French items, but mostly we would look at what other people were getting and then point to indicate our order.Overall, it was great to see the Jemaa el Fna at night and try all the new foods, but I could have definitely done without the guys in-your-face aspect of it all.

Day to night. We visited the square in March and again last week.The transformation from day to night is incredible.We are at No 117 in march and again this time and all the staff recognised our children and really looked after us.

over rated bazzar and heaven for pick-pocketing. there is no doubt that it is a like a live stage and absolutely an experience,but beware of rampant pick pocketing and don`t expect any help from police
You can't miss this!. You've seen it in movies, you've seen it in documentaries: now go get yourself a coffee in a cafe with a view and enjoy the sights, sounds and smells of this spectacular place.

Crazy little square with huge personality. This was a complete contrast to the quiet gardens of the hotel. The sounds and smells completely set your senses dancing and not only that the people watching is so worth it. Get yourself up on the balcony of one of the bars overlooking the square and watch it change from afternoon to evening its unbelievable how quickly the change happens and is so entertaining.

Craziness in the Medina. This square is where it all happens. Cafes, restaurants, carts selling juice and snacks, clothing and souvenirs, it all happens here. It's most crowded at dusk so hang onto your backpack and purse. Especially liked the snake charmers with real cobras! Lots of entertainment like boxing and other events men were betting on. Might be a bit much for small children and if you haven't traveled in the 3rd world, I might hire a guide through your hotel to guide you through the madness.
Awesome. Great square, full of people and stands... Beware with the snake charmers, if they see you taking a picture, they'll go after you to give them some money. Good traditional restaurants there.

The hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Shopping, haggling and a true experience of what Marrakech culture. To ensure you do not get hassled by shopkeepers etc just avoid eye contact and keep walking. Also Cafe de spices is the best one - the large French one and some of the others are not worth the visit.

Enjoy. Big open theatre and market with a lot of exotic displays. You can observe from terraces in the surrounding cafes or mingle with crowd. Food stalls are essentially similar menus and prices. Mind you, Marrakech is away from sea, opt for the meat.Prices of Goods are generally 50% cheaper in Medina than on open market. Fresh orange juice is fantastic (4 dirham's a glass cup or 5 dirham's in a plastic disposable cup). Grape fruit or red orange or mixed juices are 10 Dirhams. Again, Moroccan tea (green tea+Green Mint) cost 10 Dirhman for a pot or big cup.

Interesting, intriguing, beguiling. One of those places not to be missed. Unless, of course you care about animal welfare, at which point you ought to avoid visiting, or at least boycott the locals who exploit the creatures unmercifully here during the daytime.I've been here a number of times on business, and have learned from bitter experience not to touch the cheap food on the stalls in the evenings, unless you have something deep fried, and therefore fairly certain to be safe. Despite having a pretty strong constitution, I've had predictable stomach upsets every visit, because the hygiene standards are woefully lacking. (I've never had upsets in India, where you'd have thought they were almost unavoidable) On this last trip I suspect the salad garnish I foolishly ate after being so careful to avoid the ubiquitous tepid offerings. Imodium to the rescue again. On a previous trip, my wife contracted salmonella, and was off work for 5 weeks.These provisos in mind, enjoy the undoubted colourful atmosphere, but be FIRM with the shopkeepers touting for your business. The Soukhs off the square are amazing. Wonderful spices, leather, jewellery in a labyrinth of tine alleys. I have a legendary sense of direction, but have struggled a couple of times, which can be alarming, so try to remember some landmarks to help you retrace your steps. Please resist offers to take you to the tanneries unless you are with a properly organised group. I fell foul of this several years ago, and after a very interesting visit to the tannery, we were 'handed over' by our 'guide' to a carpet shop owner, who refused to take 'no' for an answer. When we walked out of the shop, we found ourselves alone and a very long way from the Soukh and the main square, in a very rough part of town. Fortunately we stumbled on the best way out, but it could have ended up a very different story.Overall, YES, do go, do enjoy, but please do be aware this is a different way of life here, and be cautious.

Interesting place. We were only here for few hours considering the limited time we have. Coming from another country that is used to this kind of market makes haggling and bargaining a little bit easier. Just be firm with the price you want and take care of your belongings. One thing though, i am not a fan of cats and you can find them literally everywhere, so if you are not a cat lover like me, just be noted.

Marrakech bustle condensed. I love to absorb city vibes. In Jemaa el-Fnaa you can do this for as long as you like - just keep low profile because if tourist is spotted for juice/food sellers then no mercy - you have to say lots of "no, thank you" before left in peace :)

So much atmosphere. This square is the hub of Marrakech. you see all life here. Every type of entertainment can be found here. People of all nationalities an cultures are there as dusk falls, but it is entirely safe . Loved it.

Great Experience. Main square and leads to numerous alleys of Souks. You can pretty much buy anything from traditional morrocan goods to genuine fake handbags! Lots of restaurants and entertainment by way of snake charmers! Be wary of pushy shop owners and always haggle! I would recommend starting off at half of what they ask for.

iconic piazza. This is an ever changing scene at every hour of the day and night . By day it is a market place where every perceivable thing can happen and everything is sold . At night it transforms into a huge alfresco dining place where many different stalls all selling Moroccan food can be purchased at reasonable prices . You sit on bench seating beside other people,The food is generally good wherever you eat , a waiter will serve you , he will tell you you need to tip him more and then you will be on your way. The piazza is lined with many coffee shops and restaurants , snake charmers and sellers of all manner of things .
Night Life. Best seen at night for the atmosphere. Best place to eat. Cleanest square anywhere all down to the sweepers. You cannot dislike this place. Its all theatre or film set.

Heart of Marrakesh. Spectacular place! For us Jemma el Fna as the Fez medina translate the "mystique" of Moroccan traditions (in the big cities anyway, totally different in the desert).Not so crowded during the day, the tourists can enjoy walking trough snake charmers, a few salesman and women doing henna tattoo. (if you are going for that, seek the ones tattooing the locals, and ALWAYS negotiates!). By the sunset the place is crowded with food and orange juice stands, more salesman, more snake charmers and acts of street theater (from boxing to big man dancing in veils). So it's definitely a nice and fun place to end the day. We didn't have any problems of robbery but they are often reported so be careful with you wallet. If seeking for a terrace to observe the square from above (and sneak some traditional photos) try alternatives from the traditional café that tends to be more expensive and with worst service according to the latest reviews.

Best at night. It was a hub of activity and watching the fast food restaurants and their waiters trying to lure you in was an experience in itself. The food looked great but we were going to the coast the next day and didn't dare try it! We felt safe, it was pleasant to stroll round and soak up the atmosphere. The big screen TV was well supported by locals too. By day, it is easier to get accosted as there are fewer people, this time by snake charmers and monkey handlers. We kept well away, having read the reports, and I would also advise the same. However, the musicians, if you like to watch and listen can be fun and they are worth paying, just be careful a monkey handler doesn't put one on your shoulder!

Step into the pages of National Geo. This place is amazing, you'll go into sensory overload. Give yourself several hours to enjoy this place, here you'll find night time street performers, and you'll most definitely chose to visit the square several times.

A must-see!. The Jemaa el Fna provided me with some of the most memorable moments of the trip. By day it's interesting if a little seedy-looking, with monkeys dressed up and on chains 'performing' for the tourists alongside snake charmers and a few stalls and attractions. Late afternoon the square clears and there is a noticeable shift its use and atmosphere as the pop-up restaurants appear. I recommend going to one of the hotels or restaurants on the square at this time - order a tea or coffee and watch the transformation by sunset (be careful if you decide to order food as it often costs considerably more to eat on the rooftop terrace of a restaurant than to eat downstairs). Honestly, the street food in the square is of such a high standard that it's hardly worth eating at the restaurants, unless you are looking specifically for fine-dining. You can eat like a king at most stalls for 20-40D - stall 114 is a favourite with the tourists as the staff are so cheerful and the food prices are clearly displayed which is useful - it's also the only place i saw that served squid and prawn tagines which were delicious!
what a place!. We loved the square and all the activity. Everyone was very friendly and helpful providing directions and advice.

What a treat for the senses. Jemma el FnaIs a treat for the senses. There is nothing you cant buy there.but remember to haggle for everything if not they will rip you of and if you go to souq buy taxi agree the price first.
interesting. Great to see local Moroccan life and all the and smells are amazing, bartering in the souk is fun and I think you should have an idea what you want to pay.

Go for a buzz on your senses. Traditonal water sellers in costume, monkeys, donkey carts, snakek charmers, stalls selling local created goods, carpets, acrobats, motor bikes, cars pedestrians food drink you name it its there to see. Didnt meet anyone unfriendly treat people as you would be treated yourself this is a real culture lesson.

Great vibes.. There are great places to visit in this. It's a huge market with alot of various foods that are cooked right in front of you. Lots of entertainment, like a group of guys dancing and playing old traditional instruments. There are some rude people though, but that is normal. Great things to buy as souvenirs.I recommend to go at 9-10 pm. or even 8 just so it won't be crowded yet.
Interesting. We went at night and found it not at all the traumatic experience some reviews suggest.A polite 'no thankyou' or "La Shukran" was all that was needed to stop the hasslers

Two Sides of the Same Coin. By day, the Big Square, as the locals call it, is a place where if you sit long enough you will see the Whole World go by. Snake Charmers, Monkey Trainers, Whirling Dervishes and Fake Dentists are all there. They all have one thing in common: to relieve you of as many Dirhams as possible. Do not pay more than 2 Dirhams for a photograph with any of them. There are many Fresh Juice Stalls which serve excellent whole orange juice. They all display the same price but, like everything in Morocco, don't be afraid to barter. Close by there are lots of banks and ATMs. Not all accept all cards. If you can't find one which will accept your card try another. Be very aware of anything unusual at the ATM and watch for people standing close. Having said that it is the same in any Capital City in the World.By night the square is transformed into a vibrant open air market for "Street Food". Most stalls sell a variety of traditional Moroccan dishes. Chose one which has a limited menu. They usually do a narrow range of dishes very well. The "acid test" is how crowded and how many locals are eating there. The best place to people watch, by day or night, is from the Roof Terrace of many of the surrounding restaurants. Food there is generally of good quality and most restaurants sell wine. You will not find it on the menu as this is a Muslim Country.A "must visit" if you are in Marrakesh.
Must see. You have to go to appreciate it words don't cut it.This is Marrakesh in its raw best.It starts to build up early evening the Souk is massive haggling a must,but it is busy all day long

Stay Close To Me. What a fun place to go. Perhaps a little too dark once the sun goes down but a truly pulsating lively and buzzy atmosphere.Likes: exotic chaotic, noisy, drumbeats, festive, lively, interestingmonkeys, vendors and energyDislikes, snakes but we did want to see them not touch them. Animal droppings, too crowed at times, different type of haggling from other ethnic vendors the dark. Some of the smells.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XO5HYbOWcEY
Not as expected. Called sahet Elfanna with a lot of gipsy and magician with snake shows I didn't like it much but it's a different experience and different culture

OK but a lot of hassle. The atmosphere was great but every stall hassled passers-by to get them into their area, which became a bit of a pain.Food was pretty average and it was much better going to one of the many restaurants surrounding the square which had better food, toilets, better service and were probably just as cheap.But you have to eat at a stall at least once to savour the atmosphere of Jemaa El-Fna

Night time is the right time!. Best place to go for a cheap authentic street food. Yes you will be harassed by sellers - just get over it and if you cannot handle that don't come to Morocco. It's part of the local culture, you don't wanna buy - just ignore them. But back to the foodie experience. Food stalls start to open round 5pm so the best time to go for food will be after 6. Otherwise you will be served with reheated leftovers from yesterday. We have tried cooked snails (10 MAD for a medium bowl) You will be given coctail sticks to get the meat out of the shells, and don't forget to drink the stock - that's the best part! The portion's ok to taste but if you want to feel full, you'll need quite a few of those. After reading some reviews on Tripadvisor we've went for some food to Stall 14. It's a seafood place. Absolutely fenomenal! It's always packed but they will squeeze you in, trust me. Be prepare to eat with your hands, on a paper. You won't be given any forks or knives. Forget about the health an safety regulations too (no rubber gloves, no tongs - everything is touched witch hands), but hey - it's a local street food stand not the Ritz! We have ordered a mix plate (battered calamari and 2 kinds of fishes - 30 MAD), and aubergines (lovely, flavoursome, can taste the lemon juice) and grilled peppers (10 MAD each). As usual here you are also given a local big flat roll with your meal.My tip - just break the bread and grab food with it. It was the best meal we have had in Morocco! And the cheapest! A wee PS. There's a lot of nice reviews for a stand 114 but for us it was a greasy dissapoinment with litte portions and "tajine" cooked in the pot and just placed in a tajine dish for the looks - a cheat for tourists. Don't go!

Fun but crazy!. I had read all these reviews about this place before going, and was exactly what I found: Really crazy! There were a lot of vendors everywhere, monkeys, snake charmers...but it was definitely fun, I enjoyed watching the great variety of colors. Just try not to look too close or stare at something if you don't want someone insisting on you buying stuff or asking for money for taking a picture. We really didn't have any troubles, walked around looking sure about where we wanted to go (even though we were sometimes lost) and noone bothered us; we didn't stop or pay attention to the people that called us, and when someone approached us we just smiled and said "no thanks". This place is a good point of reference when going to other attractions, especially by foot as we did. We really enjoyed the experience.

Exciting and delicious, but keep your guard up. Compared to similar sights in Morocco, Jemaa el Fna has a little more hassle. Although I blame myself for not being more alert, I was really annoyed by the woman who grabbed my mother's hand and covered it in henna before we could move away. Trying to sell is one thing, holding onto someone and not letting go is just intrusive.On the other hand, lots of people were super friendly and helpful. OJ seller #45 jumped into the action to help us wash off the henna and we felt we had a friend there in future visits.I actually prefer Jemaa el Fna at night because the Moroccan population appears and makes things feel more authentic and relaxed. Plus, the people watching is priceless.

Disappointed. This was to be the highlight of my trip. What a let down, dirty, smelly full of people trying to rip you off. The monkey men were vile, you couldn't even glance at the monkeys without them trying to get money from you.One tip take anti bacterial hand wash and use every time you have to touch the money. Also I was unaware you have to complete a landing card at the airport, by the way is one of the worst I've ever been in. When leaving you also need to complete another one. Would it visit Marrakech again, no.

Fascinating by day, fun at night. At night the square transforms into a huge open-air food market. Walk through and take your pick from the dozens of eating stalls, all of whom insist they are the best in the square with claims of varying degrees of improbability ("Eat here and we promise no stomach upset for 6 months"). We settle for the guy who tells us with commendable honesty " We serve the same old cr*p as all the others so you may as well come here". It is all very good-natured and, unlike many places in Morocco you don't ever feel hassled. The food itself does tend to be much the same whichever one you choose - chips or couscous with skewers of meat or fish, eaten sociably on long benches, and perfectly OK for even the most delicate digestion.Definitely an experience not to be missed in Marrakesh.

some from everything. Jamaa Al Fena the most important place you must to visited in the marrakesh in the morning u can get fresh orange juice and make shopping from the artesana and the afternoon u will enjoy the mystery stories (Al 7ale9a) and snake/monkey spectacle and at night u will surprise with delicieuse local dish as tangiya or sheep head and more more that place was announce by unesco as "Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity" im sure u will get a great fun

The heart of Old Marrakech. Worth a visit especially at night. But as with all these 'tourist must do magnets' be careful. Especially after dark with all the locals trying to ply you with monkeys, snakes, henna tattoos etc.As the main thoroughfare to the Souk it is worth a walk through when going shopping.You can take a carriage ride from here round the Old City Walls but haggle a price before leaving.

Great Fun!. This place is simply mad - in a good way! It is an essential experience for everyone that visits Marrakech and is absolutely great fun. The one downside is that the purveyors of goods and experiences (i.e.having your photo taken with monkeys etc.) can be quite insistent and you need to evolve tactics in dealing with them. That aside, go there and enjoy it!!!! :-)

Full of life!. What an experience and people who have been here will say the same thing. This place is buzzing with people and activity and watching it all leaves you in awe. They have the best orange and grapefruit juice in the world!! They make it fresh right in front of you and there is no added sugar, its amazing!! You see snake charmers, dancers, monkeys, crazy games, ladies putting henna, and lots of food and drink (not much for veggies). There is so much madness, it makes you smile and happy!

Life and Madness!. What a different square: day time works as a tourist attraction (snakes, orange juice making, henna painting) and night time as a food tasters stall market; always busy, life is buzzing around...

Crazy happiness. Everything is nice, diferentes as you have seen so far, but you have to be careful with ppl as even if you are just looking, they are jumping on you, some of them are really nice but lot more, weren't genuines.

Hmmm....ou et la 'fuss'?. Ok. It's a big square. It sets up various stalls and 'acts' as the sun falls. ALOT of range juice stalls, ALOT of food stalls. A FEW arguably drugged snake acts struggling to 'rise to the occasion'.This is it.They also have people selling, quite forcibly and impolitely throughout. Half us badly lit and sprinkled with scooters and cars flying found quite unsafely. I have seen many markets across Europe, Asia, the Middle East and america's.This is far from the best.But hey, if you're in Marrakech, you need to go! Just don't make this the sole purpose of your visit! You may be disappointed
Great environment. Beautiful place, with great environment, I will come back for sure. There was the international film festival going on and that was really good

Contrasts everywhere!. We visited Marrakech exactly for the liveliness of this crazy city! Contrasts everywhere - beauty and dirt, the smell of sandalwood and tanginess cooking and also of butcheries and rot. Vendors who were both pushy and helpful. I learned (after I gave them money) that the monkeys are poached and used and often abused until they become violent and then are killed as the cycle begins again. The square is calm and quiet and not crowded in the day and at night, it is wall to wall people and noise and busyness everywhere.

Crazy, bustling square... an unforgettable experience. Wow. Just wow. Experiencing the hectic, bustling Djamaa El Fna Square is a must for anyone who visits Marrakech. The square is bustling with vendors, shops, restaurants, snake charmers... you name it. From snails, to freshly squeezed juice, to fake electronics, to henna tattoos - you'll find it here.Watch out for pickpockets, and expect to be approached many times by people wanting to sell you something. Being accosted is part of the experience. But remember, tourist police regularly patrol the area so if you are being hassled or have any problems, you can always try to find them (or threaten to call them) - their job is to protect the tourists.

Clinging on to that authentic Morrocan feeling - just. Anywhere with "Get lucky" blaring out is more MTV than Maghreb. The main square in Marrakesh and, according to the guidebooks, the crazy happening centre of the city full of traders food stalls and entertainers.I visited 10 years ago and all that was true.This time we got a seat on one of the rooftop terraces to watch the sunset with a mint tea (well.... you have to don't you ?) and enjoy the view of the square. As well as the noise of the general hub bub "Get Lucky" was blaring out louder than anything else. I think this summed up the issue the Morrocans now have with this place - is it a square which is geared to cater for western tastes - and western pockets (And hey - these guys have to make a living) in which case cool - western disco music - guys who's job it is to have tourists photos taken with them in traditional morrocan gear - a huge tourist coach park and a big screen projector in a corner (which there was) OR is it going to remain a buzzing trading storytelling square which Morrocans can afford to visit.At the moment it's still an amazing place. There is still the local vibe and still the large numbers of locals buying things and relaxing here - the orange vendors and food stalls are all authentic and exciting - but compared to recent visits it's changing. More monkeys held in appaling conditions for tourist photos which is appaling - more western music and more hassle from vendors and photo guys who are there not to trade but to prey on tourists. I half expect a KFC on a corner next visit !So yes its certainly a must see - one can still lose ones self in the general local vibe and it is the focal point of the city - but someone needs to arrest the slide into this turning into a simple tourist trap soon IF they want it to retain its local vibe or it'll be lost.

The heart of Marrakech. It's difficult not to gush about the world famous Djemmaa-El-Fna but you really will find the beating heart of intriguing Marrakech here. It's impossible to walk around the town without finding yourself in the city's main square.The atmosphere is something you won't forget. Be there when dusk gathers & it comes alive with fire eaters, conjurors, snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers, musicians & medicine men.I understand some people not liking it, but when in Rome........

A chaotic exciting experience. A place of total chaos and you need to have your eyes everywhere . You will be constantly accosted for buying something or just giving some money to the poor , Of which there are many . It is however a diverse experience not to be missed and so much to see . Just go in and get involved . Just say a firm no and keep walking if you don't want to be bothered. They will probably follow for a while but tail away to the next target . Night time is best .

Wonderful place. Main sqare in Marrakech, Djemaa El Fna is the most important place in the city. It is very busy, full of different artists from sneak charmers to acrobats. The best moment is when you just sit in some terrace restaurant around the square and drink mint tea (aka berber whisky) while watching the sun goes down. Amazing!

A part of Morocco that time couldn't change. Jemaa El Fna is a place that time and modernity couldn't change. Snake charmers, fortune tellers, very traditional food, old carpets, bazars.... Once you're in there, you feel the true charm of Morocco.My advice would be to keep away from the tourist guides. It's better to get a proper hotel guide, even I as a local can't trust a complete stanger to show me around.Have fun!

Buzzing!. Fantastic, loved it! It was absolutely buzzing, a great place to grab a coffee and just people watch (especially as the sun goes down and it all comes to illuminated life!) Locals so friendly and not at all aggressive in their selling and such a surreal array of stalls - I saw people selling snails, teeth, prickly pears, as well as snake charmers, monkey handlers and all the touristy bits and bobs!

What a place. What an amazing experience... so busy, so much hustle and bustle a definite must see on your wish list. Smells ( smoke & spices) snake music, monkeys, women wanting to Henna you, men trying to get you to buy their wares and not forgetting the lovely fresh orange juice or mint tea..

CHAOS !. This was fascinating by the sheer chaos of the place all the stall holders offering their menu's although most when told "maybe later" left us alone however a woman I met on the plane home complained of having her bum felt several times as she went around. keep you hand on your wallet it is known for pick pockets. It is a sight to see an experience not for veggies sheep heads being cooked might put some off.

Don't eat at 118. Good salesperson and they clap when you sit down but food was very very DISSAPOINTING. All the food stalles look the same and ARE! THEY TALK ABOUT QUALITY BUT THEY DONT KNOW WHAT IT IS!

A tourist attraction with lots of people.. A noisy big square with attractions that felt bad in my heart. Monkeys chained for tourists to take pictures. Snakes that you had to pay the owners to get a picture. Horses with wagons for a ride in the city. It smelled bad from all animals. To crowded. Not my favorite place but it is worth going there. I think its very different from other squares. Go and explore it!

World Travel Must See Market. The little stalls in the middle of the market are the place to go and eat like a local at local prices (choose wisely) and feel the pulse of one of the worlds great open markets.
LOVE IT!. A must see place if you're in Marrakech! absolutely loved the food and the freshly squeezed orange juice ^.^

Abuse & Chaos....good cheap food though!. I was looking forward to visiting this supposed wonder only to be disappointed. The stalls selling food (snails, orange juice etc was nice) however the entertainment not so much. Monkeys with large chain leads wearing frilly pink dresses and being taken to tourists by men who try and encourage photos and handling of monkeys only to then be very demanding and abusive in regards to payment is not fun. I kept my distance as I do not support nor encourage this trade however I witnessed people being followed and yelled at...people who weren't interested in the first place!The Puff Adders and Cobras lying around the square have clearly been defanged and here's to hoping not worse (mouths sewn). I would not rate this place.

Very Lively. Its a deserted square during the day with a couple passerbyers but at night it comes to life and is so crowded you'll be elbow to elbow with everyone. Prices are higher than elsewhere because of all the tourism but I still spend every night I had in Marrakech here!
famous square. in the morning we find snake charmer and a monkey trainer against the evening it is the largest full-area restaurant

Very pushy restaurants and people all around the square. On my second trip to Marrakech, and Morocco and as a sole travellor i found the guys who try to get you to go to their restaurants too much. All smiles until you decide to carry on past to browse and some can turn pretty nasty, insulting if you dont stop at their place. Some of the places were ok, and served good food for the price, just a shame its so difficult to walk around. Away from the most touristy ones is better and As a group its alot easier to deflect trouble.The other people on the square, snake charmers and drum players, if you ever stand and watch , never mind take a photo, you will get requested to tip tip tip, and whtever you tip it wont be enough. And again they can turn very pushy whether or not you do tip £2 +...Overall its puts you off engaging. Watch out for people giving you any sort of directions too, you will get told the wrong directions to somewhere where one of their friends communicating by mobile will try and take advantage of you. Sometimes its relatively benign, just a big waste of your time, but sometimes yet again if someone along the line doesnt make some money from you , you will get insults. Gets tiring.....Positives: Good atmosphere, smells, sounds and generally good values for money.Away from the square ( Jamaa El Fna ) and Morocco in general can be quite different, but watch out those who seem to be your "friend" will often lead you down a path to exploit you.

The place to be at Night. when you are in Marrakesh, this is the place to be at night. there is nothing better than to see this town come alive at night, everybody seem to come out and enjoy themselves here, lots of stuff to eat and try something you had never eaten before, all the stores around are open until late at night, and this square is the center for it all, be careful of the with the animal handlers if you watch you will have to pay and they will call you names and might get aggressive if you do not tip them right, no pictures allowed if you do not pay either so be warned. Although there is lots to see for free musicians, performers and big crowds around them to enjoy regional sounds and snake enchanters. enjoy Marrakesh this city is amazing
nice lamb trotters. Jemaa el Fna is a Unisco protected sight, it's nice to have a mint tea or 'ataye' at Café France with an aerial view of the square. Its a must see and difficult to describe.
Incredible place and experience!. One of the most exciting places I've visited, people, culture, noises, food, everything is special in Jemaa el Fna.

One of the most special places in the world!. A must-see when in Morroco / Marrakesh; You will have the best view from Cafe Glacier! And you have to experience the ambience on this place during day and during night - what a contrast!

Shopping Made Easy . You will be meeting the same face every day who'll be asking you to shop with them. I got what I wanted at the price I asked for at many of the shops. Go through every shop to know exactly what they have in their store. Then only decide what you are going to purchase! There are many beggars at the market. If you give to one which you think deserve, then tell the others who will look for you, (definitely! News travel fast in between them) politely - a NO. Make sure prices are 1/3rd of the said price, or at least half. They will call you back if the price is acceptable! The weather is very hot and dusty at times. Make sure you have a Rose Spray which can be bought in the shops to cool down the eyes! It's very effective and handy when you are travelling around Morocco!
Busy all day long. Orange juice sellers in the morning, street food at night and lots of terrace bars around the square

Be Warned. I think this square could very well be magical at times but there is also an unsavory side to the magic. The monkeys are kept in small boxes when not needed with nappies on and are not treated very well. We saw one being flicked off a stack of boxes and it landed on it’s back. Not nice really and much better to see them in the wild in Morocco! The snakes if poisonous sometimes have their fangs ripped out or mouths sown up so they cannot feed, again not very pleasant. AND BE WARNED, if you take a photograph of the snake charmers or the monkeys without paying there is less charm and more aggression as this is their livelihood after all. If you don’t want to pay, take a photo from afar and you shouldn’t have any problems.
Amazing. From fresh orange juice to the wonderful souks,jemaal el Fana is a maze of magic.You must visit this amazing square and experience the magic for yourself.

Great square and marketplace. At first, I didn't want to eat dinner on the street, but by the 2nd night my girlfriend wanted to try the food in the stalls on the square. We went to food stall #114 and the food was great and the workers were funny and outgoing. We had a great time, enjoyed the food, enjoyed the worker's vibe, and the prices were great (about $30 for calamari, shrimp, chicken tagine, beef sheeshkabob, awesome sweet mint tea, bread).

Gorgeous at night. We've visited the square with a friend during the day. Wasn't impressed as those type of markets are not my cup of tea, I've enjoyed it more when watching different videos than in live. That changed when I've seen it in the evening. Lovely lights, beautiful music, wonderfully relaxed enchanting atmosphere. We've had a tea at the terrace bar and than wandered around it.
The rain. In the hard rain, anything but food. Try a sunny day, morning time they said: snakes, apes, mysterial shows so. Rainy day, empty. Evenigs food, but not so tasty.
Fascinating. Colour, noise and all sorts of life. We only visited during the day but were told it is even more lively at night

The hub of a great city. We ate at the night market the first night, followed the recommended etiquette, wandered around, made our selection. The food and theatre was amazing all at a great price. Or so we thought until we ate elsewhere the second night. We had more food better quality for the same price. Food aside the square has just a great vibe. There are a thousand photo opportunities from every inch of the place. The views at anytime of the day, the mosque, the calaches, the souks, the beggars, hawkers and young couple. Its fab. Recommend cafe Troubkal and #34.

Dodgy,very dodgy.. The fact that a bomb killed 17 people in it three years ago should be at least a warning.If that is not enough to put you off the relentless hassle,vehicular danger and casual violence should. Maybe Marrekech was an exotic Third World Lite at one time but now it is a fully disintegrating society that I foresee very bad times for ahead.
Must see!. You can't come to Marrakesh and not visit Jemaa Al Fna! We went during the day and the evening- the evening is when it's all happening! MUST see, at least once!

Hectic. some brilliant places to eat here and great for haggling for most things you can think of. Just be careful of mopeds, cars and donkeys! The market comes alive at night with vendors, snake charmers and sellers of all kinds. Just haggle with a smile and you'll get the price you want!

Watch out for dishonest food vendor #12. The plaza itself was so much fun--exotic snake or monkey handlers, music performers, all kinds of spice and crafts vendors, etc. But watch out for dishonest food vendor. We dined at vendor #12 where we ended up being forced to pay for supposedly complementary pickled olives for extra 20 dirham and the waiter cursed us when we refused to pay additional 20 dirham for tips. I got the feeling that this happens because we are two Asian female? In any case, please watch out for such dishonest food vendor!!

Disappointing, but has to be visited. Given this is the most famous bit of Marrakesh, I found it a bit disappointing. It's touristy in a commercial way, with hawkers hassling you and trying to drape snakes around you whether you like it or not. It's a large open space full of vendors and, as such, lacks atmosphere or intimacy in stark contrast to the much more pleasant souks.

The meeting place at the end of the world. Take a deep breath, ensure your compass is working, refuse all offers from potential 'guides' and take the plunge head first into the heart of the medina in Marrakech. The surrounding souks, where all the craftsmen and their wily henchmen inhabit, are well worth a couple of hours of exploration. Just ensure you allow another couple to find your way out of the maze again. Much preferred the souks in Essaouria as well as the people but then again Marrakech is a big and competitive city. A good rule of thumb is to always be polite, smile a lot and be firm when negotiating or refusing a negotiation and say thank you or Merci or shook ran. Btw, if you do accept the offer of a guide, pay no more than 300 dirham for up to 4 hours.

Argan Music of Marrakech. Not far way from the glowing street food stalls, is a single lantern burning. Around this flame are a group of young and old Berber friends and family sharing with each other what they do best. Playing music. Exchanging musical tales. Swapping instruments. And they do it all night! You will be invited to join in and dance. Be prepared to be handed an instrument. Let your hair down and you will experience a life long memory. Feel the love in the Berber groove. (This is these guys day jobs. Do not be offended by their consistent fundraising! They're giving their best. It's only right to give yours!)Group Argan can be heard on YouTube. They are masters of their craft. Ask around for them if you are having a night at Jemaa el Fna.

Crazy. Good for a couple of days amusement - then off on an excursion would be the best bet... Lots of visual stimulation, bit of overload for my wife and daughter. Vendors are fairly aggressive. All good for fun, then off to the coast & mountains...

Snake charmers to group singing it all goes on here.. There is always something to see in the square. We enjoyed sitting in the cafés watching the people and the traders. We always felt safe in the square but apparently you need to be careful of having your pockets picked. A must do in Marrakech.

Absolute chaos at night. I was there by day and night. Better to shop in daytime but evening much more activity. Don't forget you have to offer money before you pose for a photo with someone like a waterseller. If they say yes, that is the price. Usually it costs 5 or 10 MAD, about a $ We tried snails and soup at various stalls and no bad effects!

Go at night. It's a must see. Go at night for the liveliness. Walk around the souks and explore the shops. The rooftop patios are great for a drink and a birds eye view of the square. BUT don't eat there because it doesn't taste great. We ate at Chez Hassan. Follow the smoke. We had OJ from Stall 41 as recommended by our tour guide. It's amazing and try the grapefruit juice... I don't even like grapefruit but was blown away on how refreshing it was.

Pure con . Nothing good to say about . the way tourist are being conned . the square was dirty filled with grubby. Sellers . animals being treated. Inhumanly night time was worse . overcharged for a saucer of rotten food .lots of nicer places to see in Morocco. Stay away

Outdoor circus, worth your time. Definitely enjoy this square with all its attractions and particularities. Do not be bothered by pushy food hawkers and entertainers. Just immerse yourself. Have a dinner, take a picture and pay some dirhams. Enjoy!

Need to see. It is authentic Maroco, but be careful what you do, what you watch, what you listen, because everything costs and don't forget to bargain. First price is always at least twice then normal price.

Not a place for animal lovers. Morocco is great, colourful, wonderful place with amazing people, tastes & smiles. Kindness is all around... but here the buzz comes together. There are henna artists, fresh juices, shopping, the smell of spice & laughter... it is fun to see BUT snakes are being "charmed", pulled by their tales, monkeys are on chains, horses stand in the sun all day and even though this is a long standing tradition it is kind of like the sex show trade in Thailand. Each "once in a lifetime peek" keeps this alive and for the animals in Morocco and the poor teens in Thailand trying to make a better life, it is not a great life.

It is an experience but in moderation. This is a crazy place that is worth visiting once during the day and once at night. the only bad smell was by the horses which is normal. Lots of locals. Lot of interesting performers but Many are telling stories so if you don't speak the language it is hard to understand. some of the "bands" playing music are nice. Don't point your camera at anyone unless you plan to pay them some dirham. They will spot you even when you use a zoom lens. Souq immediately surrounding the square is full of tourist junk and fakes. Go way way back to see the workshops and more interesting stuff. Prices are high but with some patience can be bargained down to reasonable levels. stopping to window shop will always result in a shop keeper coming to the door to bring you inside. If you spend time looking at the same craft at several shops you begin to see the difference in quality. You need time to negotiate - don't be in a hurry.
Mad crazy busy. A must in Marrakech.It's crazy. Markets stalls sellers charmers pick pockets and suspect characters. Just be aware like any busy place.Near souks

Djemaa el- fna. No visitor to Marrakech should miss the experience of a visit to this large square adjacent to the souk. It has two very different faces.... The daytime one where, in addition to the excellent fresh orange stalls the square is alive with a variety of people. There are certain to be traditional story tellers, although their audience is made up of locals). Almost certainly there will be a colourful water seller. Unlike some locals he is only too keen for you to take a photo of him or him and you wife - for cash! There may be the occasional snake charmer, juggler or other act and there will be a lot of loud drumming. I really do recommend the freshly pressed orange juice before you wander into the souk which is so large that you are liable to get lost and have to ask your way back to the square. If you press on to the further edges you will find area where the craftsmen work to supply the stalls. There you can find the famous Moroccan leather being processed from raw skins to the dyed article. There are metalworkers, welders, lampshade makers, basket makers et al.. Though tempting to take photos and videos it is not the done thing and you will be waved away or even have you view blocked. It is a courtesy to observe this rule. Incidentally there are no restrictions on motor vehicles or handcarts in the souk or in the square. The drivers weave in and out of the pedestrians with great skill but it is as well to keep an eye open behind you. I am pleased to say that despite the apparent chaos one does not see any 'road rage' . We could learn a lot from that.Returning to the square towards evening you will see that the hawkers are being replaced by covered stalls surrounded by bench seats. This is for the nightly feasting. The food is traditional Moroccan fare. The food is very cheap and good and the cooking is quite a sight itself with steam and flames being very photographic. You may have a little pestering to sit at a table but it is not too persistent. One view of the square can be found from the terraces above restaurants overlooking the square. Seeing the sun go down behind Koutubia Mosque and hearing the muezzins call to prayer is memorable. It is just surprising that you don't see anyone praying. But maybe they are all foreigners !

Jemaa el Fna. Totally crackers place that comes to life at night. Has lots of cafes around it, which provide upper storeys that you can sit in under the cool shade and watch the antics of the acrobats and snake charmers. Nowhere like it on earth and great fun!

Rubbish!!. If 5 pigeons tied to bits of string and a chap wanting you to pay to feed them appeals to you then go for it! Very tatty, over priced goods, whoever writes the travelogues about this place must wear the biggest pair of "Rose tinted" glasses ever made!!
Great at night. Comes alive at night with street food, shopping and shows. Might be intimidating for anybody who doesn't like crowds.

Amazing place. It really is an experience just to wander round & see what is going on. All the sellers on the food stalls will try to get you to buy but with a smile & a cheery La Shukran they will just smile at you & say maybe tomorrow. Beware we got very lost in the market place & ended up going round in circles before we found our way out of the maze of shops.

What a night time experience !. We stayed in the Medina/Kasbah and Jemaa el Fna was in very easy walking distance . If you are staying in the 'cultured' new city dont forget to visit Jemaa el Fna. The best time is to arrive late afternoon . Sit on one of the upper terraces of the square's restaurants and order a drink then and watch the food stalls setting up ready for the evening 'dining experience'. Eating here should not be missed, the food ranges from prawns, squid, chicken /lamb skewers , and local couscous and salads . All freshly cooked there and then . You will be hounded to sit at one of the food stalls , but walk around them first and choose they food you best like the look of . Prices are very cheap and food tasty. Remember that no alcohol is served , especially in the old city ; it is only served in some hotels

A wonderful experience!. As a solo 60+ woman traveler, I was a bit apprehensive to go to this vast square alone at night but with encouragement from my concierge, I went and had a wonderful time talking and sharing tables with Moroccans, watching all the entertainment, trying snail soup. Go and enjoy!
Fun. Walking the souk and haggling for bargains- lots of fun and addictive. If you are polite and don't take it all too seriously this make for a fun day out. We found the people to be very friendly.

Not for the faint hearted!. The square transform from a busy market during the day to an exciting food and entertainment centre in the evening.During the day you will be accosted by lots of street traders trying to sell you trinkets, if you want to buy start at less than half the asking price and work up to half price or less depending how good you are at bartering. If you don't want to buy just say " No Thanks " and walk away. They may follow you for a little while but they will soon get the message.

Excellent for DIFFERENT.... An amazing place to taste all it means Morroco, food, shopping, dance, listen the morrocan music, watching their games, even the place is very noisy, busy, smelly, it is by the all an interesting experience.

Very busy noisy and smelly. Arrived here late afternoon at its busiest and it was mayhem and very smelly and noisy but after a while you got used to it, from the many beggars and stalls and side shows and constant hassle to the young westernised girls in jeans striding by with their iPhones and earplugs accompanied by their mothers and aunts in full burkas. Good for orange juice but some of the restaurants were mediocre to poor especially cafe de France best to look further afield.

Interesting sights and sounds. Amazing nighttime experience somewhat spoiled by the monkeys on metal leads. Why do people think that being photographed with a scared and petrified monkey on a chain will entice tourists . Please realise that we find this upsetting and cruel.

Bustling Open Air Fast Food. During the day, you can visit the cafes and restaurants around the edge of the square. There are lots of people milling about.At night, the square is transformed with most of it taken up by stalls selling Moroccan fast food, which is very tasty. You can sit on benches at tables and mix it up with other tourists and locals. Musicians, snake charmers and other performers get small crowds forming around the edge of the square.

must visit when in Marrakech. This place is pretty unique and hard to beat. Definately an assualt on the senses when you are here during peak times. I stayed only 5 minutes away from the market so I was able to pass here during day and night. Everyone will try and speak to you and entice you with their products but if you smile politely and walk away it should be fine. My biggest problem was the animals being paraded around for show and money, I dont understand why anyone would think it entertaining when they didnt appear to be living in the best of conditions. That part seemd posivetly medeival to me and quite repulsive but the rest of it, with music, lots of different smells and being part of the experiance was something I will never forget. Would definately come back here for shopping, make sure you heavily barter, dont be shy!

Day and night. It is well worth a look day and night, but especially night time. Good location to eat - a wide choice - try both restaurants and the stalls in the square. And do go for the local food.
Not to be missed. Not to be endured too long. The sights are initially overwhelming, but ultimately more of the same. Glad we have seen it, no rush to go back.

Interesting but a little over hyped. I had a lot of expectation for the Jemaa el Fna square, it sounded like it would be a place that would leave us with amazement but on arrival it was a bit under whelming and a bit of a reality check.The bad ----The square had a few ladies sitting on stools saying 'hola' but realising i wasn't spanish said 'hey', at least they are linguistic. Then i saw a guy throwing a snake around like it was a belt and then two children going inside bins to empty them on the back of horse drawn carriage but how the horse was still standing I don't know. It was so dirty with its tongue hanging out desperate for a drink.The ugly----Then I saw monkeys being swung up and around by the chain around their neck dressed in all kinds of attire and why? Because tourists pay to have photos taken with both the snakes and the monkeys. As a person who likes animals it was quite a sad feeling to see all this and my first impression of the square was that it broke my heart.I realize the people of Marrakech need to live and the signs of poverty around this square was too evident and a feeling of powerlessness to help was overwhelming. Traditional berber people trying to make a living in any way they can, people with mental illness begging with tissues, children as young as 7 and old women without legs asking me for money for food that is the reality of the square and I was not blind to the facade of what really is going on.The Good -----Now the bad side is out the way let me discuss the good. The food stalls are absolutely delicious and the people who try to entice you onto the stalls are always laughing, joking and friendly. The impression I have of the Moroccan people are the majority are very good people that most of the time, make you feel welcome. Watching the people set up the market stalls standing on pieces of rod and preparing large mounds of mint and fresh spices is quite a sight to behold. The evening is definitely the time to see this place.Overall, if you are in Marrakech, you have to experience the square but it wasn't the most breathtaking place I've been to in the world. Okay if you can turn a blind eye to extreme poverty and animal mistreatment.

fantastic place. I ate there every night. the food was great, cheap and plentiful. I also sat there for a while most days just watching the world go by. The square is also the entrance to most of the souks and it was helpful to find my way back there so I could find my hotel.

Avoid stall 1. Food not that good.. Or cheap..Very touristy.. Relies on its historic recommendations .. Nothing special at all... Stall 95 much better .. Or indeed just follow your nose to where the Arabs eat

Fantastic place to visit. This is the must place to go. It's the trademark of Marrakech, a very large square that brings together exotic and western world rhythms, perfumes, tastes... Everything here is different, the people, the sounds, the small cafés... I though I was in another era! It would be a real loss if you come to Marrakesh and don't visit Jemaa el-Fnaa square.

Visit both day and night for the contrast . Won't bore you too much, but worth going both day and night to see the contrast. Don't get me wrong the tourist traps are there regardless what time of day, but the atmosphere at night is buzzing. You need your wits about you and the ability to smile and say no thank you...... Lots!!!

A must to see !. We visited Jemaa el Fina three times during the day and also on a Saturday evening. In the evenings there is a large eating area in the middle of the square as well as the stalls that are there all day. It's definitely frenetic ! We didn't find the street vendors pushy, just a polite " No, thank you " in French or Arabic seemed to do the trick. The children who were trying to sell things in the evening were a bit more persistent. There were snake charmers but the snakes didn't appear to move much and there were performing monkeys on chains but I found seeing them like this distressing. There were water sellers in full costume, keen to be photographed, and presumably charged for this. The nuts and dates sold in the square are worth buying. We enjoyed having lunch or a drink in the cafes in the square and sitting watching it all. Some of them have balconies which are ideal for watching and photographing. The best café we found for lunch in the square is called Seven Saints. Good service and excellent tagines !

You need your wits about you. Crazy, crazy, crazy! Its an assault on your senses, the noise, the smells, the amount of people! A must do in Marrakech. But, you need to say NO to street vendors or they will barrage you. I was grabbed by a lady who tried to force me into having a henna tattoo & then after refusing to let me go, demanded my husband pay her money. All got resolved but as I say you need your wits about you. And yes, you will totally get lost in the souks!!!

Where's the snake charmers?. We visited on a Friday evening and the lights, smoke and smells of the many outside food sellers heralded an enjoyable evening. However the various shows in the square nearly all consisted of poor musicians and local storytellers. As my knowledge of Morrocan is limited I went in search of snake charmers and performing monkeys but all I found were ladyboys and a musician with a chicken on his head wanting money for a photo. I did another couple of laps of the square to see if I had missed something but all I got was some abuse from the lady in the photo for taking her picture although she was not even the subject. Must have been a slow night.
An amazing experience. This is the heart of Marrakesh. It is a mixture of smells and colors at night it is crazy and amazing, just be careful with the bikes.
Mad!. Snakes, monkeys, water carriers, camels, magicians, performers of all kinds, street food - it's all there.

little theft of marrakech.... first like a moroccan i feel so shy when i saw all this is happening in marrakech i come from my city Casablanca with my wife who she is not moroccan ! so it was very imperissing for me every body see you like a bag of euros or dollars especially taxi drivers no one use the counter to go from jemaa el fna till bab dokala which is normally 10dh they ask for 5 or 7 Euros at least oh my god i don't know where is the community of tourists and where is this touristic police in fact my experience in marrakech was very bad i really loved the city but the people from this city.....no comments i don't think they are moroccan even, like i said for me like a moroccan i really feel so shyyyy and those people who ask you every time to buy buy buy omg im so sad to not feel comfortable in my country

Crazy. Frenetic, frantic, assault on the senses, so many sights, sounds, smells, etc. The vendors give new meaning to the term "high-pressure sales." This is true all over Marrakech. A majority of the vendors are EXTREMELY aggressive. Just say "no" and keep walking, unless you want to buy something. In that case, make sure you bargain.
Only seen externally. Unable to enter as we were not muslims. However, surrounding area was interesting and very busy with locals

One of my favourite places in the world. As you approach the square your senses are assaulted in all directions. Horses and carts line up for customers, brightly coloured costumed men look for photo opportunities, storytellers tell their traditional tales, snake charmers pipe their music and Incense wafts through the air. You will be assailed by women wanting to henna tattoo your hands or the restaurant owners inviting you to come in and eat, and the souks around the square are a foretaste of the labyrinth of passages which lay behind. It is a world away from my normal life and part of you feels you are stepping back in time. Love it or hate it you can't forget it.

A hub of energy!. We loved walking around the square, just people watching! disliked the poor monekeys and snakes on display. Only activity the kids indulged in was Henna. Tried different foods, loved the orange juice stands, had one everyday. Very different during day and night. Here our first blogpost on Marrakech http://selimfamily.com/2014/11/23/travel-theme-colourful-journey-through-marrakech/

A feast for the sense. What a buzz!. Jemaa el Fna is not really a place locals go...touristy but worth a look. We went here both during the day and night - what a contrast. During the day we spent some coin getting photos of the watermen and snake charmers (paid 5dhm for photos - they'll ask for more though). Henna tatooist will also ask a lot more than other henna places. Locals say 30dhm is the best rate for henna. At night we ate at stall 41 and was delicious. As day turns to night go have mint tea on the terrace of the Le Grand Balcon Cafe Glacier on the square and watch the stalls be set up with the activity buzzing around it. Might need to wait for a seat though.

Snakes and Snacks. We traversed the Plaza midday which turned out to be a great time - it was not packed out or intimidating. There are many fresh orange juice stands, we did not drink there though. the snake "charmers" are there, with both the baby cobras and the big snakes. Remember, they want a euro for taking a picture. Be aware that I have heard, they sometimes will drape a snakes (not a Cobra) around your neck, and them demand payment to take it off! Keep your distance! :) I did not actually see this however.
Ambience. You´ll never totally love this place; as it can be a bit scary. You will stay alert. But you will be fascinated. Any time of the day.

Busy and noisy but carries all the charm of the Medina. The square is very busy, lively, noisy, diverse, smelly, crazy and even annoying sometimes but has all the charm Marrakesh has to offer despite the touristic feel to it.

Bustling centre of Marrakech. For visitors to Morocco, this place is a must. Best seen at dusk, Jemaa el Fna is the place to eat some great street food and soak in the great atmosphere of bartering with market traders and street artists such as snake charmers. For a great view of the square have a mint tea in one of the cafés that overlook the square around dusk. However, be aware of panhandlers who try to lure you into buying things. Many don't take no for an answer and can sometimes be aggressive towards tourists. Also be aware of what is supposed to be fresh orange juice. I had a bad experience. Apart from that, enjoy the hubbub!
Chaotic. Fun, but chaotic and noisy, and always peseterd by sellers of watches/trinkets/phones etc. Better to eat on the cfes round the edges, rather that in it, cheaper yet the same food

busy place. What I really liked about Djemaa el Fna was to meet so many different people and to watch the "artists". Some woman predicted my future...everything is gonna be fine :) We had some food in one of the small restaurants, not bad. The orange juice was better in desert!

This is what Marrakech is all about. This is of course the must see, but spoilt by all the hassle, cigarettes, watches and I Phones every few yards, stop and look at any of the stalls and you can't get away.Having lunch at one of the restaurants overlooking, no alcohol!

An Experience!. If you go with good humour you will be fine. Beware the monkeys and snake charmers, they will want money even if you only take a photo. Traffic is chaotic. People are always approaching you to sell you thinks.Take a deep breath and go. Remember "la shukran" and a smile will ensure you are not harassed!

November 2014. Interesting but for how long? The souks become repetative and the "acts" do not like a photo being taken without payment.Always busy in here though and a must see. You can walk for hours in the souks.

In a word... Wow!. A cacophony to delight all your senses...the main square leading to the souks and bazaar beyond is madness and chaos that delights the senses and takes your breath away. It had me smiling from the moment I arrived. The hustle and bustle of Marrakech is evident here as so many cultures mix and mingle. Add inthe snake charmers oboes, the roar of the cock fighters gambling, the traditional garbed berbers with bells, the burning insents and spices, the freshly squeezed juices and tasty street food, to the ladies putting henna on the hand... it makes it hard to pay attention to the carts and mopeds as they trundle past overwhelmed pedestrians looking for a hard haggled deal from the sellers in the souks. Thoroughly enjoyed myself from a-z and went back almost daily to experience the living vibe of Marrakech.

Hectic or what!!!. Noise, bustle, smells. Fantastic! Also westerners get hassled by kids (and adults) selling stuff for silly prices. Women beware the henna tattooists - keep your hands in your pockets!

Spectacle after spectacle. . Do not venture here if you have trouble saying no! This massive square; home to jugglers, snake charmers, performing monkeys, beggars, fruit stalls, magicians, restaurants and god knows what else. Vibrant colours, loud noises, music shouting. This is an assault on the senses. The patter of the restaurateurs enticing you to eat is delightfully weird, "no salmonella for five years!" shouts one, "eat at twentyfive, stay alive!" shouts another.We loved it!

well what a place.. Visit at night the place comes alive and is a very busy place.Be carfull what you eat just a word of warning.Just take it all in and walk around and take in the smells,and the culture sit in a cafe and just watch,you will smile to yourself,Be firm with sellers a firm no is enough,Be carfull what and who you take a photo of as you will be asked for money the sellers and street stalls miss nothing that i can assure you enjoy it ,it is a experience.Go on your own a guide is not needed just stay alert and dont take no more money than you need also dont wear any exspensive jewellery.You can walk around for as long or as little as you choose as it is very,very busy get a horse and carrage home when you have finished this finishes the evening off.
Touristy. A busy square full of snake charmers, monkeys and tourist tat for sale. Would advise visiting cafe above square for peaceful observation of everything that is going on!

Visit once and that's enough. This may be a Unesco World heritage site but these days it seems out of cinq i.e. I'm not interested in watching snake charmers etc - we went there one night & that was grim with so many people trying to get you to pay for something. The square is a general through route to the souks etc but doesn't really warrant more than one experience of it. It starts to come alive around 5pm and is dead again by 10pm latest

Keep walking, no talking. Spectacle that has to be seen.. Changes from day to night.. Monkeys in nappies and snakes being poked.. Has to be done.. The fresh orange juice is fab, decided to not take up the offer of sleeps brains for tea though !

The reason you go to Marrakech. Some hassle, be firm and do not be afraid to barter. The local advice to to offer one half of asking price. The morrocan shave learnt this try sticking out for a much lower price. Check prices first do not be put off with hyper inflated starting points. Check morrocan craft centre for basic prices. Stimulation overload on the square but all photographs will incur a charge if they spot you.
A must-see place. Snake charmers, drummers, touts, vendors, food, entertainment -- it's all here! Plan to spend hours in and around this major square in Marrakech.

Everething happens. Want a henna tattoo? a thrilling photo with snakes around your neck and colourful picture of the water vendors? Go to this place int he evening. Don't forget to try the delicious orange juice and taste the sweet "tmar" = dates.As for the photos, note that you will have to pay for them, so be careful not starting "shooting" left and right with your camera.

Sea of People & Excitement. Morrocans everywhere trying to pose as salesman to touting waiters enticing outdoor food to tourists in central markets that oozes & smells charm of exoticness. Music & dance galore, many classic Berber style!

You have to see it to believe it. Pick up your camera or stop and watch one of the side shows and expect to hand over some money, keep some pocket change to hand to throw into the collecting hat. Take a drink at one of the rooftop bars and watch the food market unfold, delight in the smells and the atmosphere and try the food its amazing.

yes and no. the place itself is nothing special. it's the people that make it specia. if you want to take pictures of musicians, artists or... yu have to pay. it is loud and vivid in the evening.
we liked the food in the food stalls, it was very good - and we loved the orange and pampelmouse-juices ...

The crazy heart of Marrakech. The Jemaa el Fna was the final place visited on our personal half-day tour of Marrakech where our guide left us to explore on our own - and we returned again and again - several times by accident having got "lost" in the Souks! Snake charmers, teeth pullers, lots of tat for sale and surrounded by cafes and restaurants. You cannot go to Marrakech and not visit!

Exciting madness. There's lots going on. People everywhere, going in every direction, on foot, bike, car, horse, donkey or sitting on the ground. Lots of people want your attention: Juicer, Water man, Henna lady, Snake charmer, Monkey Man, 'Performers', Dodgy Salesman etc. Interact with what interests you, pay attention to your belongings and stand your ground. Be firm with your "no", for example a Henna lady grabbed my hand and did a quick scribble despite me saying no then demanded a "present" but I said no because I already told her "no" and although I wiped the henna off minutes later, it still left a dye mark. The Square comes alive at night time and there are cafés with terraces that surround the square where you can people-watch. Overall, an exciting experience.

Wonderful day or night. Do come here twice - day and night. Sort of a huge market by day and turns into entrtainment areas and restaurants at night. Huge - 20 football pitches size and no traffic other than people, people, people!

Stimulation overlaod!. What a different place this is by day and by night..... snake charmers, henna ladies, shoe-cleaners, tissue-sellers etc etc - they are all there, accompanied by travelling musicians, dancers et al. By night, it's an eating frenzy ....skewers of fresh meat, tagines of all description, pizza, kebabs etc. Anytime, it's noisy, a bit smelly, frenetic and energetic -enjoy it all :-)

Chaos and Craziness!. The Jemaa el Fna is THE place to be in the evening! The chaos and craziness add to the other worldliness of this square. We enjoyed several inexpensive dinners including restaurants #1 and #114. It is great to people watch. This place is not for the shy or passive traveler. You will be approached many times by the food vendors to take a meal at their stall. We have learned that saying "Maybe tomorrow" or " I just ate" often work to lighten the mood and allow you to continue on your people watching adventure. Go with an open mind and lots of patience and you will love it.

Poor b Monkeys. Overall, our visits to Jemaa El Fna, were full of interest.Some of the stall owners, can " in your face", but nothing too severe.Not many countries in the world, would allow the chaining of animals.sadly this is normal, in respect to the monkeys.It is indeed sad, to witness this cruelty.It does not need to happen, nor should it be allowed, or promoted.

alarming and exciting. Eveything it is hyped to be! Highly recommend going here with a guide first to understand the social etiquette of buying etc. Once we did this we grew in confidence and had a fab time buying fragrance, oil, pashminis etc for Christmas. Didn't do well with a price for henna - always agree a price before you let her paint it on. My wife forgot this rule and paid loads!

Lively. Felt like we had stepped into an Indiana Jones movie. Vibrant fun lively exciting. A real cultural experience. Loved it. Keep your witts about you though. Beware of people offering to show the way and follow them, it is a scam. They will take you all around the houses and then expect to be paid. We noticed they all seemed to be wearing something red.

A sight to behold. i can honestly say I didn't really know what to expect in the square, having seen it several times in films on TV etc. we first encountered it on our first evening after a long days travelling. Was a bit bewildering at first; the crowds, the smoke, the noise, the smells, the near misses with mopeds, bikes, cars, caleche, everyone in your face trying to sell. The next day we did it by day which is different but has similar hallmarks. It took probably 3 or 4 visits to acclimatise and to toughen up to the experience but once you do it starts to be more fun once you relax into it (but not for the faint hearted) and start to properly see what's going on.

Like nothing else on earth. Try and visit at different times of the day as the scene changes several times a day. Unless you wish - politely decline all offers of snakes, monkeys, henna tattoos and you will be left in peace to watch and marvel all that goes on. Spot the dentists!

Fabulous place to people watch - a smile goes a long way but if you photograph, expect to pay. We walked up to the square from the Kasbah on our first afternoon and naively fell for just about every trick in the book. We were called over to buy orange juice (a big thing in Marrakech) and the guy tried to short-change me from a 200 Dirham note (about £15, but it's hard to get small change when you first arrive - no-one wants to give you change). It took the guy 4 separate goes to give me the right change. Getting annoyed will not help you. I just kept handing the money back smiling and saying 'more' until he got bored and gave me the right change. He'd expected me to get bored as he served other people inbetween. I didn't. Then my partner was near enough lassoed by a dead or anaesthetised snake which a guy came toward us dangling. We laughed as he approached and he touched it to my partners hand for luck, his head for health and then looped it over his neck and pulled him in with a practiced grin for a photo. He asked for 200 Dirhams for the photo. We grinned back and gave him 20 Dirhams, and he shook my partner's hand. Ladies tried to henna my hand with a 'small flower' as I walked and I learned to keep an eye for them approaching. The whole thing is street theatre, from the acts to the salesmanship, and you just need to roll with it and smile. If you get really up-tight about this kind of thing, Marrakech probably isn't the place for you. We left the square that first evening, having sat looking down on the view from a café for a while, feeling thoroughly educated.By the second time we went a few days later, I actually loved it. The square is a fabulous slice of life with the huge Koutoubia mosque as a back-drop. You need a smile, to be aware of who you make any kind of lasting eye contact with or who is approaching you, and a firm but friendly "Non, merci", but nothing more. There are snake charmers and acrobats that perform for the ground floor cafes and then pass round a Fez for donations. If you reach for your camera, expect to reach for your wallet and some small change. The locals are hyper-aware of being photographed and it's polite to ask. I asked many people, from stall-holders to people in the street, offering a coin if it looked like it might be helpful, and few said no. Some did say no, but better find that out before you aim the camera at them! Some asked to see the picture and were good humoured about it. Looking down at the square from a roof-top terrace café (e.g. Café de France), particularly approaching dusk, is magical. Circles of people - mainly Moroccan - form and disperse around magic acts and the like. There is smoke and food stalls and a great atmosphere. The square also leads into the souks. A must see.

Extraordinary. Fully deserves its World Heritage status. This huge open space is occupied during the day time by a rag tag of snake charmers, performing monkeys and traditional story tellers. At night it gets even busier with traditional food stalls, numerous local musicians and Moroccan dancers.It would be nice to see the snake charmers and performing monkeys banned, but the square is one of the world's great sights.
Huge souks. The square is really big with many souks. If you go to smaller streets next to the square you can find more souks but it's very easy to get lost because it's really big.
Hustle & bustle. Very busy, but easy to wander around with very little pressure from sellers - loads of cafes and restaurants to rest weary feet - lots of people-watching opportunities

Old Guys Rule. Fascinating square. Snake charmers, and monkey owners, too pushy wanting photographs for money. Interesting to sit in a café terrace overlooking the square, and watch all that is going on.

Incredible. I have been to a lot of open air markets in the world, but this one takes the cake. It is over the top! Just be prepared with lots of energy and curiosity and take your time to explore as much of it as possible. When the sun goes down the energy explodes! If you get a chance try to take a few photos from the upper level of the Café Frances or the other one on the edge of square. To get a view from up high as the sun goes down is a special treat! Get there early and get a position at the rail and start taking photos.

Big let down!. Paid a visit to this market during the day and it was ok but went during the evening with friends for a meal and we were hassled none stop to eat at every stall we past and finally when we decided to eat what a rip off! Ok to have a wonder around but thats about it. The people are just poor and cunning. The people were a big let down! So greedy and selfish.

Great place to experience Marrakech. Jemaa el Fnaa is pure chaos but this is what makes it such a great place too! Visit the square around sunset and you will be rewarded with amazing colours and incredibly vivid images. Photo opportunities appear everywhere: bargain a price with the water carriers and they will be "yours" for as long as you like. Women in colourful traditional dresses, snake charmers, food stalls displaying a large variety of dishes. They all contribute to the charm of this square.Only warning is about eating at the food stalls: great food but we got ripped off as we didn't order from a menu with set prices...so be prepared!
Seen Day and Night. Only saw what we expected as it is well publicised. On an evening visit we were a little disappointed as there was not a lot happening, but then perhaps this was because mid week

Madness and too much hype. On first arriving it was exciting and looked fascinating but once seen it's done. I hated the monkeys in dresses and leashes. Every time I tried to take a photo of anything I was chased for money, sometimes quite aggressively. It's impossible to just stop and look at any of the wares and some of the stalls just sold European stuff - spots socks etc which made it feel like a cheap market you see in any town. Forget any romantic notions, enjoy it once then move on.

Fantastic Chaos. Djemaa el Fna is one of my favorite places on the planet. I love the noise, the energy, the spaces offering everything you could ever imagine needing or not needing. The leather is of superior quality and the lamps are amazing. As is the orange juice and a bargain at just under $0.50 As with any travel in developing countries, if you appear to be a tourist (like me, blond headed) you will most certainly be bombarded by beggars and hackled by men trying to get you to choose their restaurant or buy their goods, so be prepared for that.
