It is a soft sell and not at all violent or confrontational. Remember...EVERYTHING is negotiable.

An amazing experience. Know that everyone wants to sell you something; food, gifts, even a photo opportunity. Know also that they understand "no thank you" and, in the most part, respect it. Her you will find everything from snake charmers, belly dancers, purveyors of fruit, juices, leasther goods etc, etc, etc. The place comes aluve from abouyt 5 pm when the street food section sets up. From small trailers grow food kitchens and dining areas all under cover. Most are serving the same menu and each will tell you they are the best. They are very persistent and you may well feel pressurised. My advice, tell them you are going to number 100 (they are all numbered, part of the licensing) or any number you like. The best way to avoid any hassle is to walk round, following one of the tourist police - everyone will leave you alone!!! The food is very cheap and very tasty - just make sure the prices are displayed or you will be ripped off!

Scared of snakes? Me too, but fear not. Jemma El Fna is as bustling as it gets with noise, colour, food and is great fun to be in. My snake phobia has me avoiding reptile sections as zoos. It took me a good day and a half to edge my way in to the middle of the square but there was no need to fear. In my week there, there were only about two or three groups of snake charmers, and you can identify them easily from the sounds of the oboes at great distance, and they are placid having been presumably milked. So brave up and enjoy the square for the fun it is. The food stalls in the evening are sensational. All do pretty much the same - BBQ, salads, potato cakes, tan fines etc. all fresh, tasty and really cheap. Enjoy!

Amazing. Magic and different place that sends us to somewhere in the past. Snake charmers, food stalls, street artists, much orange and some monkeys mixed in a incredible square. From everywhere in the square you can see the beautiful Koutoubia Mosque. Jemaa el Fna is located inside the Medina, the best place to stay and have a rich experience in Marrakech.

Encanto y autenticidad. Patrimonio Oral e Inmaterial de la Humanidad. Es un lugar vivo, cautivador, mágico, colorista, maravilloso, misterioso… Lo mejor es ver la plaza Jemaa El Fna con los propios ojos.The spectacle of Jamaa el Fna is repeated daily and each day it is different. Everything changes — voices, sounds, gestures, the public which sees, listens, smells, tastes, touches. The oral tradition is framed by one much vaster — that we can call intangible. The Square, as a physical space, shelters a rich oral and intangible tradition.Juan Goytisolo, de su discurso de la asamblea de apertura de la Primera Proclamación el 15 May 2001.

Totally amazing, mad, african, funny, noisy.. During the day watch the snake charmers, monkeys, street beggars from a distance of course otherwise you might get caught for some cash. Try high up in one of the restaurants great for cheap food and people watching. You will get pestered but a smiling firm polite no is all you need say. No hassel we ever came across. Lots of fresh juice, and noise. At night absolutely fab! So much louder, crazy, being asked to visit every food stall, good tip say you have eaten at numer whatever or carry a small bottle of water. Then they thank you have eaten.groups of people gathering around different street entertainment so many to watch, all for a price if you are caught of course, but any coins happily recieved. There were magicians, dancers, musicians, games to bet on. The smell from the many food stalls was lovely, mixed with smoke and atmosphere of the place all great. We ate at number 97 very good very friendly. What I did notice was how friendly and happy and safe I felt. I wondered if it was the fact of no alcohol around that gave this place the feeling I got. I, as a female felt safer there than I would being out late in england at night.

Crazy place, beware of rip-offs. The Jemaa el Fna is one reason to journey to Marrakech. Snake charmers, fortune tellers, crazy dudes with crazy hats, juice bars, you name it, they have it. Go and see for yourself -- it is worth the effort.
A Must. A must! It is the heart of the medina. You need to be among the busyness of it and embrace the pace and energy.
Great for one night and day. Enjoyed it but only needed to "do" it once. The Snakes and Monkeys are cruel. The people are very friendly. The Orange juice is fantastic.
Noisy Square. Very noisy, bustling square, snake charmers, monkey handlers, orange juice & nut & date stalls. Wander around & people watch.

Probably more exciting at night!. My husband and I visited by day and other than a few stalls selling juice and dried fruits and nuts there was not much else happening! We had been informed that it was better at night but we were a little concerned because we had heard about pick pockets and being Senior Citizens were not prepared to risk it! We did help the locals by purchasing a wonderful Grapefruit juice!

"Crazy place". During the day, you see monkeys, snake charmers, teeth sellers, juice bars and many more. If you go near the monkeys or snakes, the owners put the animals on you and let you take a photo, and then they will insist on money in return. The monkey will jump on top of you and immediately another monkey owner will put his monkey on your other shoulder and you have to pay for both of them. If you want to take a photo, the best place is to go upstairs of Cafe Glacier where you can get a beautiful view from the terrace. The staff are rude, you have to purchase some food or drink in order to sit there, but the view is well worth it. One coke and a glass of mint tea cost us 35 dirham. A man sitting at the entrance of the toilet, charges 5 dirhams to use it. On the way to Jemma el fina, there are local banks, and staffs are happy to exchange the big notes to smaller notes and coins, which is needed if going shopping at the market.The juice stalls at the square serve either freshly squeezed orange juice at 4 dirhams (30 pence) per glass or grapefruit juice 10 dirhams (75 pence). At night the place is manic. The food stalls dominate the area, full of smoke. The stall holders try to tempt you to eat at their stalls. They do not have running water. Also the food is not cheap. They cost the same as the restaurants nearby.

Just as crazy as it appears on You-Tube. If you visit Marrakesh you have to visit the square after dark. It's huge and after you've negotiated the snake charmers and the monkeys dressed as children, Yikes! And wondered over to the food stalls which I thought were totally insane when viewed through my eyes as the vendors are pretty aggressive in their sales patter though on the whole good natured. By then you'll need a decent coffee just to unwind ruminate on all the sights and sounds, smells and the rest of it. In my case well away from the square! All in all well worth the hassle.

Noise smells and hassle. It had rained, the floor was awash with Horse crap and urine, some of it possibly human too. Some very dodgy people in hoodies got just a bit to close to people that were dstracted by the theatre of the place- looking to pick pockets I think. The over priced food on stalls (side streets locallly sell the same things better and cheaper- and the hygeine is better) was let down for us as a visit by the local rabbit catcher encouraging the chef to examine the rabbits and then continue cooking- 3 days of very upset stomachs ensued. HAssled at every moment by people unwiulling to take a simple no for answer.Got offered something nice to smoke more than once. Its overrated.

A must - really thrilling place. We all must have an idea how the place would be, wheather from a James Bond movie or somewhere else. Really worth of visiting during late afternoon / early evening with sunset. Feel the noises and enjoy!
A place to be.... Amazing at day and at night, a really must see in Marrakech. Story tellers, fighters, dentist on the street like in fairy tales. Good food in the open air restaurants at night.

Loved it!. Loved visiting Jemaa El Fna where in the day time you have ladies applying henna, snake charmers, monkeys, food etc and in the evening all the stalls go up for more food!Beware of the henna artists as we got harassed to have henna applied but we kindly refused. We were also given advice not to pay more then 20/30 dhirams to the snake and monkey charmers where they will try their luck and ask you for 200 dhirams! Oh no my friend, we were warned.Loads of souks, fake designers around the whole market, including fakes of Dr Dre beats, raybans, clothes, etc.Fresh orange juice for 5/10 dhirams (pennies) and lots of clay tagines available too.Remember to haggle! Morocco are known to add 75% on the actual price.

Always something going on!. Loved the Jemaa el Fna for its vibrancy and colour. Lots of touts and they require some patience, but lots of smiles and interesting things. We never really got tired of it. One of our favourite things to do was to grab a table at a café and just watch the action. Gotta do it!!
Felt touristic. I looked so much forward to coming to the square. Was a bit disappointing, expected something more exotic perhaps, more authentic. Too touristic is arrogant to say but still...

Crazy and amusing!. This crazy, amazing and funny place is worth a watch. Snake charmers, food hall, restaurants and loads of small táxis.
This place seems like a little other planet in earth. Moroccan lifestyle in the Medina is amazing.

Mad and Colourful - Have To See It, To Believe It. Whilst I didn't like to see the monkeys being thrown around by their handlers and the constant pestering of the snake charmers who would attempt to put a snake around your shoulders for money, I found the square fascinating - very clean, colourful, full of life. I didn't like being hassled by the henna artists - when I pulled my arm away she swore (in English) at me.

Shopping time . If you are in love with moroccan staff this is the place for you. It has everything and it's lace to get lost in. The only think I didn't like is that the sellers are putting a pressure on you to buy things even if it's not what you are looking for . And this hassle thing it's not for me but hey I bought some amazing authentic staff for my house so it wasn't that bad !!!

a famous landmark of marrakech. the quick and proffessinal afternoon change from its day structure into night structure. walking at night could feel a little scarry for foreighners but it is a must visit place.

Slightly disappointing, but still a must do.. I saw the square at both day and night and to be honest I was a little disappointed. I was expecting something really lively, magical and unique but I just didn't feel that. Not sure if it was because I went outside of the main tourist season.During the day there are orange juice sellers, snake charmers and story tellers. The annoying thing is that you can't stand still to admire anything as people run up asking for money. At night there are lots of food stalls. The food is reasonable priced and tasted quite nice. The cutlery was unwashed so bring your own or eat with your hands. I ate from stalls 1 (the better of the two) and 25.To summarise you must see at both day and night as the square is unrecognisable. Worth having dinner to soak up the atmosphere. Just don't expect too much, especially during the day, as you may get dissapointed.

Fun Time In Square. An evening visit is essential to see all the action with jugglers dancers and snake charmers. Try viewing from one of the balconies on a restaurant overlooking the square. You wont believe what you see.

beware of street food sellersof the orange. when going to jemma el fna beware of the food sellers.i was cheated big time .passed a food seller and i was told my meal would be 60 mod.when i sat down the food seller put a lot of food on my table what i did not order.i thourt the food was free has i did not order it .when i went to leave i was told my bill was 250 mod .there is a lot of cafes at the side of the square and you can get a very good meal for approx 100mod for 2 .so do not eat at the food sellers tables .and beware of theyou g orange drink sellers.when walking pass a drink seller i was offerd ia free drink wat i accepted.he then pourd me a drink what i did not order and he demmanded pay ment .i said i did order it so i refused payment .he got very angrey and in the end i had to call the tourist police to sort it out .if you get hassled just say to them i am going to call the tourist police and they will soon back off .

Busy place!. We saw the place half empty, getting very busy with restaurants in the evening and after dark. There is a lot of people trying to sell things and also a lot of artists. The all want to make money, so if you want to have a good time just once and a while let yourself go and get a long with it.

Crazy madness but strangely enjoyable!. The markets are crazy and sure comes alive at night time. Don't stop to take photos of the monkey / dancing men unless you are prepared to pay - agree on price, pay then take photo. I enjoyed strolling rather than shopping and didn't get into the haggling, but just being there, walking around is an experience. Be polite but firm and keep walking if you feel bothered. Have a good gps app with you to get back out as you merge into the souks rather quickly and back into the rabbit warren you go! Ate at stall 41 as part of a tour and that was enjoyable.

Unique yet predictable. The square has a unique energy and feel about it which makes it excellent and a must see but there is very little variety. I stayed four nights and by then I found the square monotonous and tedious. The same performances are performed, the same food is sold at all the different stalls and the constant harassment by stall vendors can become intense.
Comes alive at night. Love this square, especially at night, the food stalls are great and make sure and buy some Khoudenjal juice which is the Moroccan Viagra, it works ;)

mental, just mental. one of the guys who tried selling us food summed it up "same S#it different faces" its all the same stuff you can buy cheaper in your local market in the UK, and you should get used to the constant "taxi taxi, horse ride horse ride, taxi Good Price, Cheaper than Aldi good price good price" and its relentless, I was groped, grabbed and insulted for not buying. my favourite was "you English, always in a F hurry" well that's because we are running away from you. have some 10 Dirham change in your pockets for taking photos of people, I was grabbed by the snake charmer for taking a photo I didn't even take - I had to run away from himStill you need to experience it - its on everyones bucket list - just be careful
Go in the evening. Go in the evening and try the lovely food! So many stalls of food, take your pick. really buzzing in the night and completely safe.

Diverse & Cultural experience. A real fun experience & full of Moroccon culture whether it's clothes, food, spices, henna, rooftop cafes and souvenirs. It challenges you to learn how to haggle and be more persistent.The frustrating thing was the constant grabbing by the stall owners to make you come and see their stuff and almost force you into leaving with something you didn't want in the first place.I do recommend when you go towards a stall and are looking for a particular thing that you have a price in mind and you stick to this because they will eventually back down if they see you genuinely interested but at your price.

Pickpockets lurking, be very aware!. As we walked from the square towards the souks one afternoon, a man walked by me and pulled the zipper on a cargo pocket on my pants. Having experienced a pickpocket attempt on the Paris metro a few years back, I stay alert in crowded areas. I twisted away and swept my hand across the pocket as soon as I felt the grab. The pickpocket kept walking, as I checked my pocket and re-secured the zipper.The next night, we were in the square to watch the entertainment. I was standing behind my wife. I became more alert as the space between my wife and the person beside her narrowed. My wife shifted a bit left for a better view. I watched carefully, and sure enough again the person beside her closed the space. Now on high alert I watched his hand. He started carefully sliding it closer to my wife's pocket. I quickly brought up the water bottle in my hand and whacked his away. He spun and slipped out of the crowd and was gone.Enjoy the square but BE VERY ALERT!

Pulsating with life. A must see for Marrakech. We were there almost every day. Great freshly squeezed orange juice. Many restaurants. A lot of peddlers. Before of the monkey and snake handlers - they can be quite aggressive with their snakes. All they want is money - a lot - you need to be prepared to be aggressive as they are ;-)At night the whole place changes. The snake handlers leave (explanation given: try to find a black cobra a night if and when she escapes ...) - and a lot of tiny restaurants with street cooking open. For health reasons I never tried any of their food - but boy, was I tempted.We spent hours sitting at restaurant terraces overlooking the place - lots of stuff is going on ...

Not a must. This was maybe my 20th visit to Marrakech. I never liked the place Jemaa el Fna. I found it artificial, overrated, too "touristic" to my taste.The "magic" of Marrakech is elsewhere, the pink walls, the Palmeraie, the Atlas background, the roses, the horse carriage, etc.

it's sensational if you go in the right frame of mind... The Jemma-el-Fna is a huge open market area, tapering West to East, on the edge of the medina and immediately south of the warren of lanes that make up the souks. The key for us was to go prepared, both physically and mentally. That done, it's huge fun and an eye-opening experience. So, what preparation? Go with the minimum of valuables, although it doesn't feel unsafe, but it helps you to relax. We were told that pickpockets can be very active, especially at night but it shouldn't stop you. We saw nothing at all that worried us, but don't be complacent. Don't carry too many bags, you'll be focusing on them rather than the amazing sights and sounds all around you. As a tourist, you'll stand out, but you won't be alone - there will be hundreds at least, there with you, looking, browsing, bargaining or just taking it all in.Mentally, just be prepared to relax and accept that you will be invited to spend your money at every turn, whether to have an orange juice, to have a nappy-clad monkey sit on your shoulder or to be draped in a snake or two. You don't have to of course. It's easiest and very effective to keep a distance from the traders if you don't wish to indulge, to say a polite 'no', to avoid stopping to converse and to remain polite but firm and to keep walking. This worked very well for us this week. But lots of visitors do want to be part of the action. We did bargain for some cheap jewellery. If doing so it might be useful to remember you could find yourself bargaining over a pound or less, hardly worth the effort in some cases, but neither should you be fooled.We also learned that once you start bargaining, you're pretty much committed to buying at whatever price, so stop to engage the traders in conversation only if they have something you intend buying in the first place. We found the traders to be less pushy in the square than in the souks and they generally accepted a no thanks in arabic, which I can't spell -sorry - and a smile. We needed to be firmer in the souks but it wasn't unpleasant as long as we stuck to the few self-imposed rules above.The square really comes alive after dark, full of drumming,colours, the smell of spices and incense, the shouting of traders and the crowds, both local and from abroad. We got a great night-time view from the top floor terrace of the Cafe de France. Have a coffee there by all means, but don't eat there- see other reviews.The Jemaa el Fna is a must-do, but with a little care. Underneath the surface, it has a hard edge to it. As a visitor, we get just a tiny glimpse, but you get the sense that life is pretty tough for many,, that most are canny and have found a way to survive, that only a few, and they do exist, have done very well indeed, and that poverty is very evident indeed. If you're a little wary, it's safe and certainly worth the trip.

CRAZY PLACE. What a place - by day - snake charmers, monkeys, henna tattoos, as well as juice sellers.By night a hive of activity - food stalls definitely worth a visit especially stalls Number 1, Number 25 and Number 114

A transformation at night time.. We walked across this square during the day to get to the Medina and it was empty of people. We returned in the evening and it was a different place, teeming with thousands of people watching various performances going on all over the square, play acting, story telling, snake charmers etc. There was an area set aside for food consumption, lots of stalls selling all sorts of food. One word of warning, leave your valuables at the hotel and keep your hand on your wallet as there are lots of pickpockets around, one of our party had his glasses case plus glasses stolen from his pocket, he didn't realize they were missing until he returned to the hotel.

Great buzz and a bit nuts!. We stayed in a little riad not far away and popped to Jemaa el fna a few times by day and night.At night it comes alive and it is a real feast for the senses! Mostly the menus in the central bbq style pop up restaurants are the same, just follow some locals and order a few small things along with a couscous and some brochettes. Not amazing food but woth it for the experience. Expect to pay about 10 euros each?The touts that belong to each restaurant range from charming and funny to burnt out and sarcastic but in the main pretty nice.The various Berber bands are great but beware the women that grab your hand and do a quick (and poor) henna tattoo and ask for a crazy price! I luckily speak French and a bit of Arabic and had to be quit stern with this lady and sent her away with a fair price for 30 seconds of poor and un commissioned work, 15 mdh despite her asking for 300!
A must visit. Very busy square, a must see day & night, monkeys, snakes , fast & fab food & drink, stalls, lots of life & fresh orange!
Atmostpheric. must go here in the evening for entertainment, full of snake charmers, fortune tellers dancers and musicians. Plenty of food stalls including snails in curry sauce!!!

beware. we actually stayed in a beautiful riad (Ben Youseff) right in the middle of this market and but it drove us crazy trying to find our way out. We found it all very over whelming, slightly intimidating and like nothing we had ever encountered before, this is nothing like the "usual". By the time we had done a couple of days we made sure we did not look or smile at anyone as it usually meant we were approached and harassed for money. Because our B&B was deep in the middle of this circus we were lost a few times (and not lost a few other times) so we were constantly approached by young men offering to "help" us find our way and to be fair they did help us get home but there would then be the inevitable debate about money (we always offered but it was NEVER enough) and suddenly there would be 2 or 3 young men surrounding you. Not for the faint hearted.

Jemaa el Fna getting busier every day. I've been to this incredible square in the 1970's...2005, and again in 2014...every time it gets busier and crazier. The food stalls are always great but the crowds make it a bit claustrophobic and I noticed a lot of pick pockets this time. We had no problems but something to be aware of. I even noticed tour groups that each had small alert pendents so they could beep the guide if they got lost.Bathroom facilities are available in most cafe's but can be a challenge...if this is important, locate one early then remember where it is for future use...take you own paper.The sights, sounds and smells of the square and medina have really not changed however. The food is excellent and very safe and the fresh fruits, nuts, dates, and figs can't be beat.

Run the gauntlet. If this is your first visit to Marakech be warned, this place is not for the faint hearted, the locals will spot you're a tourist from a mile away and home in on you, everything from henna tattoos to fruit juices, snake charming to photos with monkeys, dodgy mobile phones and watches, you name it they can get it. If you stick to your guns and keep walking you will be ok, don't buy into any sales pitches until you see what you want and you're ready to barter. Good luck !!

Crazy fun chaos. Can you say overwhelming? The square is nonstop action. The dynamic changes from day to night! Day is more business vibe but at night it turns into a big party! Based on reviews, we enjoyed the area but did not eat food from the square. There are lots of good restaurants in the area and didn't want to take a chance on being sick. Keep in mind, when you see a man with a chicken on his head, snake charmers, men with monkies or any of the entertainers, they will expect you to pay to take their picture! Also, the people selling lanterns at night, these are very light inexpensive gifts BUT they look better in the dark than they will the light! As far as the souks go, I did not enjoy the constant bartering....it stressed me out. Just be firm and start low.....be willing to walk away. Overall, a fun experience that should not be missed in Marrakesh.

Soul of Marrakech. It's a great place to see monkeys, snakes, south african and moroccan handicrafts during the day. In the evening, the place starts to warm up with street food sellers establishing their food stalls, musicians and magicians showing their tricks. At night time, there are so many things going on and you can buy almost everything from moroccan dirhams to food, tagines, little annoying drums, dry fruits, water. I just loved this place as everyday we ended up coming back here.

vibrant. well it all happens here, the smell of spices, the colours, the sounds ,and the feeling you are part of something from the past,great place to sit with a coffee and just take in what is going on around the square before venturing around the many stalls and streets to try bartering with the locals a true feeling that brings a blast from the past.

The only good thing was the orange juice!. Snake charmers and the monkey men were more scary than entertaining. The entire square is full of weird and sleazy salesmen, constantly trying to lure you in with bad sales tactics. The 'dancers' that come out after dark are creepy and act like they are possessed; not ideal for children. Be careful of random groups of boys looking to cause trouble and the smelly horse carriage pick up point! Having said all this, the best (and worst) restaurants are in the square. We visited nearly all of them during our stay...Cafe de France - 2/10 Awful staff, tried to con us on the bill. Food was inedibleSeven States - 7/10 Reasonably friendly staff and good foodCafe Premice - 5/10 poor service, Ok foodTaj'in Darna - 8/10 good food and good service...but cats everywhere!On the plus side, they serve the best orange juice in the square and you cant not visit it at least once!

Night time spectacular. Go by day, then return at night for the true transformation! Street music, amazing good, haggling locals, smells, sights, vibe. London looks boring compared to this square! And we had to be sober for it!

THE must do Marrakech experience...... You cannot come to Marrakech without paying a visit to Jemaa el Fna. This main square in the centre of the Medina is home to a throng of snake charmers, monkey handlers, story tellers, henna tattooists, and musicians, as well as spice, fruit, souvenir, and food stalls. By day the square is relatively tame, but at night it comes alive. Keep you wits about you to avoid any unwelcome attention from the many vendors, or at worst pick pockets, and stroll around taking in the unique atmosphere. Daunting to some, make the effort and you will be rewarded with a uniquely Moroccan experience to remember !

just for tourists ?. Probably, a bit, maybe.Maybe notJust enjoy the experienceImmerse yourself in the evening food madness from "Hey Mister" to "Big Boss" (Could have been a prop) to "Bruce Willis" (Basically every bald bloke including me) to "Blah blah blah they are all the same" - eat here. Do.Snake charmers - monkeys - noise - drums Enjoy - it's not like anywhere in Europe
so nice. This is a wonderful place Expresses the nobility of the cityso niceYou can have a coffee and enjoy shopping
Jemaa by night is excellent. Nice Place with all facilities - about 50 foodplaces in the evening - shows on music or berberes, snakes and and.. it is a place - must see in Marrakech

Crazy. Don't let anyone grab you by the arm, they will sell you something you never wanted! But take a look, in the daytime to see the snake charmers and other hawkers and again at night to see the foodstalls and hear the musicians. Go on a caleche ride (horse and carriage).

Night time madness. Best to go in the evening, eat some dodgy local grub, soak up the atmosphere. Don't eat the stuff that looks like chocolate (it's not).Also the souks are still open and I found shopping more relaxed then. less hassle from "guides"

This "is" Marrakesh. You can't go to Marakesh and not come to Jemaa el Fna! This is the epicenter of life of the city, Day time sees it as a market of fresh fruits, vegetables and juices but as the sun sets it swells with a tremendous variety of food stalls, magicians of all sort, snake charmer, storytellers and vendors abound. This is one of a lifetime experience and you can't come to Morocco and not be here. You will remember the experience all your life just as we do.

Wonderfully mad, wild experience. Go in the day time and evening for a completely different experience and lap up the sights and sounds. You'll get besieged by hawkers trying to sell you anything from a packet of tissues to a seat in a circle of musicians making one hell of a rhythm on their drums and instruments PLUS the conductor parading a round with a chicken on his head! Laugh and smile at the street vendor boys trying to temp you in for dinner on their stand, offering ridiculous claims of being cheaper than Lidl but Marks and Spencer Quality! All great fun. Xxx

Wonderfull Experience. This experience is not or everyone, by day will be lots of tourists around looking for souvenirs, by night, more tourists plus amazing "local shows"... people dancing, playing with audiences, snakes, monkeys, all you can imagine.Best way to dinner is to choose places where tourists look enjoying their food, because you will be escorted by numerous guys trying to get you in their "restaurants"... so what I did several times before in this place is to ask someone who is in the restaurant what they can say about the food.. they'll be your best advise to pick your dinner, for me this always works and you can get to know new and amazing people plus good dinner knowing new people from around the world.Don't be afraid to sit in the street and try new stuff... couscous is a MUST.By the way... very cheap!!To finish you can try peanuts from any vendor around.

I think intoxicating is the right word. We kept coming back here, really enjoyed the atmosphere. Spent some time wandering around the square itself, or sitting up on the roof terrace of a cafe at the edge, there's always something to see.

Hustling and bustling. Good athmosphere and a lot of people in all ages and from all parts of the world. Interesting melting pot. Storytellers and musicans attracts crowds in this street theatre format.On the negativre side is the snake charmers and the monkeys on display. The animal friendly person will feel bad about this part of the life on the square.

Total Marrakech. Loved visiting the square, either by day to have the lovely freshly squeezed orange juice, or by night to have great food, all the time there's things happening from snake charmers and story tellers, and acrobats. We didn't like to see the monkeys on chains, and yes you do get tired of beggars but its all part of the experience
the real thing. You meet Moroccans having fun. We went at night and took in the sights from a restaurant but we also walked around and enjoyed the excitement.
This is a ghastly tourist trap. But nonetheless you need to go at least once in your life. The animals on show look a little less ruthlessly exploited these days, though.
Wonderful & Crazy. Amazing dancers surrounding the night. Lovely and cheap food with great taste booth #14. We spent a great moment visting the Manar and walking in the narrow streets
Amazing. This square becomes really amazing in the evenings. Anything goes. Music, dancing, food, shopping, lots of people walking around.

CULTURE, HERITAGE AND EXCITEMENT!. One of the best places to go and spend a lot of time and never get bored. You can shop, eat, browse, socialize and watch live dancing performances and street performers do various cultural exhibitions. Definitely a must do and its very family friendly. We went right before sundown and had an absolute blast!

An unfortunate representation of Marrakech. We visited the square on 2 occasions. The guidebooks say that haggling is the order of the day and just to have fun with it. It was not fun! What struck me was the aggressiveness of the folks who wanted money. Any eye contact at all was an invitation for them to not only approach but to hound for money. Don't even think of taking a photo, you will be immediately approached and berated to give money. When you give them a few dirhams, it is not enough! They act terribly insulted at such a measly amount. The snake charmers, men with monkeys on leashes, and woman painting henna designs on hands watch for families and encourage the children to touch the animals and before you know it you are being asked to pay. It was disturbing to see the monkeys, in particular being hauled up by the leashes around their necks. They tried to hold the leashes away from their necks, one can only assume it was painful from them. The snakes were out on the ground and unceremoniously dunked into buckets of water or tucked under lids, poked, and slung around necks of tourists. It was all a bit of a sorry situation. One of visits which was positive, was during the evening when the food vendors were there. We had a Moroccan guide with us who thankfully shepherded us through the huge crowds and helped us order a delicious meal from the food vendors! That being said, there are other places to get delicious food. Jemaa el Fna is a victim of it's popularity with tourists which brings out the less desirable element.

Wonderfull. Something you should visit when in Marrakech. Snakes, chicken, monkey's they are al there.
Watch out for pickpocketing.
Has to be experienced!. Busy with travellers, stalls, entertainers etc. If you want a photo of snake charmers, water sellers etc, be expected to pay for it.

Mystical and Vibrant. Definitely best to visit in the evening where the additional food offer, smells and lighting all add to the atmosphere.
Whilst the monkeys and snakes do provide an attraction I sincerely hope they are looked after and treated well.
Perhaps some signage would assist orientation as we did get somewhat lost last night!!
Great atmosphere. Having had a good look round we found the good stalls to eat were 95 and 41 - plenty of locals and none of our party were ill!

diverse, full of contrasts, active, dancing, eating, snake charmers. This is a must and such an integral part of life in Marrakech. Late afternoon involves the
snake charmers, early evening involves dancing,gambling and tourists eating at tables shared
with the locals in the square. There is a wonderful feeling of vibrancy, and social interaction.
.

Indescribable. Had a wonderful tour booked through viator sampling the foods of Marrakech - outstanding! Got a private tour, a history lesson, a load of foods and experiences ... Felt really safe here too. We even managed to join the local ladies placing breads in the public oven. Thoroughly recommend it. Dress with respect to the local culture for best reception!

really crazy square - well worth visit - bring change for tips. just a lot of fun - be prepared to be harassed by the hawkers and entertainers. Nothing is free - even if you stop to see a snake charmer for a photo - he wants some money. also they tend to ,fling, a snake or a monkey on you - so don't get too close you are to willing to take part ! the stalls on the main square are too overpriced - ie the dates and nuts - cheaper inside the main souk - the deeper you get in the cheaper it gets.. plus definitely haggle - some prices are just upped too much

A big square with market stall - thats pretty much it!. A lot of reviewers have been really wowed by this square but for me is was ok but nothing amazing. Similar to lots of big market squares around the world. Yes, do visit it if you're in Marrakech but it is simply a large square with various things going on so dont be expecting the experience of a lifetime. Daytime its filled with market stalls similar to souks but much more tat - 120 dirham for a wooden camel - i dont think so. He would've eventually accepted 60 but by the time the haggling was offer i realised i didnt need more vlutter in the house. Night tine is more exciting with all the food dtalls.

Holiday. Liked a lot but beware of the hawkers, monkey men and snakes. Don't make eye contact or they will latch on to you and demand money ! You can buy anything there, but don't forget to haggle. Restaurants are ok, and although the locals recommend places some are not as good as they make out.

not for claustrophobs. locals go late, after 9pm, careful when trying to take pictures with people, they will try to charge you a lot, so ask beforhand. same goes for guides, although it is worthwhile. Don´t let yourselves be trapped into Berber pharmacies, or expensive jewellery shops

Unique Sight!. Come at night for all sorts of crazy! There are crowds gathered around musicians and storytellers, but the real action is by the food carts that show up every afternoon and are gone every morning. Smoke, light, and shouting about "nice price" rise up from the area. Most places with give you a full meal, with salad, meat, bread and a drink for under 6USD. People who work here tend to want you to spend money with them - which should come as no surprise - but are generally good-natured and fun. A simple "we just ate" should be enough to pull yourself free of even the most determined salesperson. Jemaa Fna is a wicked fun place that is pretty unique in Morocco.

Very interesting but too much animal cruelty. So very different to what you are used too and from that point an amazing experience sites sounds smells (some not pleasant!) but monkeys on chains in nappies in this day and age totally unacceptable.
A hive of activity. We love this, especially as the night markets were setting up. Watching all the activity from a roof top terrace in a restaurant was definitely the best way to do this!

Bittersweet. Not sure how to rate Jemaa el Fna. There's bad and good.What you won't enjoy is people/vendors trying to get every dirham out of you. From Henna artists to snake charmers to food stalls. I understand they are trying to earn a living but some can be extremely pushy! There's not a lot to do/see during the day. The place only comes to live after 6 pm or so. That's when the fun begins. We really enjoyed the performances and games (especially 'flipping the bottle'). The food at the stall was strictly average.So, I would recommend going there at night. Be careful and say no forcefully. Do not let vendors put a cap on your head, snake in your neck or heena on your hand unless you are willing to pay them something. There's a lot to enjoy. Being better prepared for the place and having a fun outlook would make things easier.

Amazing at night. Be brave - eat at the food stalls at night in the Square - its all fine. Very good value and lots of fun. You will have never seen so many sights, sounds and smells. Incredible night time atmosphere and a unique experience for me and my husband. Be ready to fend off people selling you stuff, be prepared to get lost getting out and make sure you have small change and small notes on you. There are cash machines about (of course!)

Great fun!. You must visit Jemaa el Fna in the evening when all the action takes place. You will see clusters of people around various " acts"- snake charmers, dancers, musicians, mimes. Be aware that a contribution is expected at the end of each show. 5 dirham is enough. If you take pictures a contribution is also expected. Don't think you can get away with it- if they see the flash go off they'll wade through the crowd to find you. Be very careful of your wallet and purse and cell phone here. We did not have any trouble, but we were careful. The other attraction is the food stalls. We got big glasses of freshly squeezed orange juice for 5 dirham. The signs say 4 but they charge you an extra for the plastic cup. It is cold but you it's because the oranges are chilled before they are squeezed, not because of ice cubes which you should avoid. You can sit down at long tables with benches and have a pretty good meal very cheaply. We paid 50 dirham for a full meal with fresh bread, kebabs of beef or chicken, various salads and cold water. For dessert you can buy cookies or the special tea which is spicy and delicious. Another speciality is snails- you can buy a small or large portion. This is the thing to do in the evening and you can't really say you've seen Marrakesh unless you go!

Just send your wallet here and stay at home!. Well...I have to whole heartedly agree with all the poor and terrible reviews on here. I read them before I went and am a well travelled open minded confident arabic/french speaking mixed race person. I didn't want to believe it but I have to say it is a den of thieves and vagabonds. Without it's religion Islam ,I do not know what would become of this City.Unlike others on here,we did not find the Morrocan men aggressive...they tried to charm us complementing me and my daughter, but they do this to extract money from your wallet..thats it...this is a place where the silly little tourist is just prey for the clever Moroccans,the man in our Riad warned us and those were his words. At night,the place takes on a sinister air...our riad was in the middle of the Medina and even though we were warned to be careful we got a bit lost and let a young man help us ..he led us the wrong way and demanded money!! this happened more than once. everytime we stopped to look at a map young men /boys who seemed lovely would try to "help" us claiming to only be helping,they would not take no for an answer and then demand money!! whatever you do get a good street map and ensure you know where you are going! Learn how to say NO...go away.The place stinks....the poor animals are everywhere, limp snakes,being poked and dragged about, stinking, filthy horses stood in the sun,monkeys in dresses and sunglasses being thrust at people who were stupid enough to pose with them.Only to be stuffed into a box in the heat with dozens of others!Tortoises stuffed into cages with lizards,all with no food or water!The part of the market with animals in smelled so bad my stomach is still recoiling from the stench now!We fed a starving boy who came into the pizza place...and at every minute beggars approached us,kids,women with babies selling tissues,old ladies,blind men,cripples,whether we were eating in a restaurant or walking..it was absolutely relentless!!!! We gave money to some but it got ridiculous,,as soon as they see you give one person money you get inundated!!You cannot browse in any shop...they immediately descend upon you...most! If you go in a shop its unlikely you will leave without buying. We hardly saw anyone in the shops,the spices must be so stale as we saw hundreds of stalls but all the tourists just walk past.Too frightened and intimidated to stop. You cannot stop to watch or look at anything...a man will ask for money and don't even try to take a photo without having money ready,coins are regarded as money for babies they will expect at least 200 dh!The square looks lovely at night but it is filthy! The best place to see it all from is the roof terrace bars. we ended up eating pizza as we just felt everything was sooo dirty! the other good thing is the freshly squeezed orange juices from stall 48. Also we had to squeeze past piles of stinking gut renchingly revolting rubbish, we know its a third world country and they do not have sanitation etc but people here do not care,all they want is to climb over each other to make/con/deceive the tourists who are just rich pickings for these people. Especially with our white european faces! As another reviewer said these people are actors trained to trick you into trusting them,make you feel like you are getting a bargain and then fleecing you. They see us as rich people with money so do not feel at all bothered about it. Also we were conned by a henna woman..she was lovely and sweet and charged us 400 dh for green henna...we found out we shouldnt have paid more than 50 dh for 2 hands!! and the henna was black!I wanted to love Morocco, but was bitterly disappointed,bad traffic meant I nearly missed my plane there...I wish I had! The only good thing is that my teenage kids got to see how lucky they are to live in a civilised country,and the imprtance of honesty, integrity and compassion and what the world is really like without it! Oh yes if you are vegetarian there's only veggie coucous and pizza to eat there!!World Heritage site??? This is a God forsaken hell hole!!

Amazing day or night. Filled with performances and sights by day, it converts at night into a vast dining hall. Performers and snake charmers are aggressive about asking for money if you take a picture.

Good, but could be great. A large open square - the focal point of the medina. Lots of stalls/shops, but unfortunately many selling the same items/food. Same with entertainment - great to see snake charmers, monkey takers, henna etc, but once you've seen one you've seen them all. Be cautious about taking photos of these - you'll be expected to pay. You may even end up with a snake around your neck or monkey on you our arm and demand for money!Stunning in the evening - the lighting provides a perfect mood to wander and explore.With the size of the square and the amount of people, we just felt there could have been more on offer. Definitely worth seeing, but difficult to spend more than 1hr there.

Be prepared to be hassled. Snakecharmers, henna-tattoers and all sorts of people who want to have your money. It is a fun and special place but ten minutes is enough. Fantastic orange juice from the guy in carriage 38.

Something you really shouldn't avoid experiencing. Two sides of the Jemaa el Fna – by day and by night.By day you get the snake charmers, monkey handlers, beggars, hawkers, small stall holders, juice sellers (nice brightly coloured carts) and a few date / nut sellers. There is little real charm about the place at day, but it is an interesting atmosphere and the background noise definitely lets you know you are visiting somewhere different. It’s also a very good entrance point into the main souk area of the old medina.The rights and wrongs of the snakes and monkey ‘attractions’ would probably fill a few pages of interesting debate in itself. If you do not agree with these activities then simply avoid them and don’t be drawn into giving them any money. But be careful where you are pointing the camera. Even if you just happen to get a performer or snake or monkey in the corner of a photo a payment will be demanded of you – and it is a demand and not a polite request.There are street hawkers a plenty – if you don’t want anything then be polite and move on. They are really not as bad as some people make out. The same goes for the stall holders – a polite no with a smile and move on.By night it is different. For food stalls, acrobats, story tellers etc. move in and take centre stage. Wafting of cooking food and smoke across the square. It has a different feeling that the day, but you should witness both during your stay.FOOD:The food stalls really are very good and there is no need to worry about food hygiene. Everything is cooked from fresh and done in front of your eyes. Do as the locals do and eat with your fingers (fresh bread rolls are provided) – the knives and forks are only rinsed in cold water. No alcohol is served so wash down with a fresh orange juice or a mint tea. We found number 31 to be very good, with a lot more locals than tourists as well. Don’t miss out on the opportunity to try any of the snail stalls either. They really are very good and the broth that they are served in is excellent. And do not miss out on Fresh orange juice is excellent. They do take away or you can drink there. If you have a 1L empty bottle then they will fill that for you as well if you want.OTHER TIPS Pickpockets and bag dippers (especially at night). Ladies – turn the flap of your handbag towards your body and have the bag to the front of your body. Keep bags and any valuables on your lap when sitting down to eat at the food stalls. Locals do a good job of looking out for you – we were warned that our wives bags were being targeted by a couple of youths, and we hadn’t noticed a thing. We travel a lot and are used to bag security as well. But generally this whole area and the souks are safe any time of day and night.Side restaurants (permanent ones) – the lads working these places at night are extremely persistent. Don’t be bullied or forced into one of these at night – there is far far better food available at the temporary food stalls. Keep walking and they soon get fed up following you along the square.Is this the “Greatest Show on Earth” as described by some of the Guidebooks? That would be a resounding no. It is a must see / experience when in Marrakech – an absolute yes, especially at night.

Loud and noisy. The first thing you notice when you reach the square is the noise. There are snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers and all manner of things happening in the square. We were warned not to get henna on our hands as the ink they use is quite toxic and some people have got ill from it. There are tons of people trying to sell you stuff so it goes without saying, beware of pick pockets.

Great atmosphere. If you are in Marrakech this is a must. Go to stall no 1 to eat. All stalls sell pretty much the same food and here you can avoid the hassle of everyone trying to force you into their eating place. Buy the biscuits/ pastries that come around on carts. For 30dh you get a box and they are amazing.

A must visit site. So much going on it's hard to give details. It's the beginning of the souk areas.with local music, dancing monkeys, snake charmers, fortune tellers and many restaurants and bars. Go upstairs to the terrace in the Cafe de France which overlooks the square and order a mint tea which is the Moroccan national drink. If you take pics of the people they will want a tip. Don't go near the monkeys as they will grab something from you and want a tip to give it back.The square is incredible at night.

Seriously.... the Jemaa is a great place to have a mind-bogglingly good dinner on the cheap (the food at the No. 40 stall was WOW!) or to drink a glass of freshly-squeezed juice, but beyond that, it's an enormous tourist trap. I'd like not to be cynical, but any authentic culture that may have once existed on the Jemaa likely died in the 1970s. Paul Bowles, when he was alive, told a story about witnessing a Moroccan man (who frequented the Jemaa) whose imitation of a goat was so uncanny that Bowles swore that the man before his eyes was in fact a goat. One would be hard-pressed to find such a "performer" in the Jemaa today. What there is a glut of snake-"charmers" and monkey-"handlers" and sheisty West African street salesmen vying desperately for one's hard-earned tourist dollar, which I find repugnant, even in a country as burdened by poverty as Morocco. Go at night; it's much more pleasant to deal with the food-sellers and the street urchins selling tissues than with [word-redacted] rip-off artists.
Must do - Staul #1. Mama can cook! Try out Staul #1She opens a little earlier than some of the other chefs and both nights we ate there - she did not disappoint.

An assault on the senses. A 10-minute taxi ride from our Hotel [Kech Boutique Hotel & Spa] ended at the Jemaa el Fna square in old town Marrakesh. The noise, smells, tastes & sights of the place was an immediate assault on the senses. A maelstrom of humanity, with perfromers, tourists, locals & stalls conspiring to create a throbbing vitality that we had never experienced before, despite being well travelled. A sight to behold & I suggest it should be on your "things to do before...." list. Top tips:1. Savour the orange juice stalls - fresh & delightfully quenches the thirst.2. Secure a seat on the open terrace [3rd-floor] of the Cafe de' France which can provide panoramic views of the square [best at night].3. Easy access from the square to the 'souks'.4. If you attempt to take pictures you may be 'accosted' for a 'donation'.5. Efforts by traders to sell their wares may be 'forthright' by western conventions, but if you are not interested simply smile, avoid eye-contact, utter a polite 'no-thank you' & move on.6. Agree taxi fares before getting in - ours, for the 10-minutes journey, ranged from 50Dirhams to 100Dirhams.7. Haggle over prices - on the flight to Marrakesh a UK resident of Morrocan decent kindly mentioned that, particularly in 'the souks', you should look to negotiate down by anything from 50%-75% - we secured a leather bag at 60% less than the initial asking price [persevere, it took time, but we got there & to be honest enjoyed the experience - which the trader no doubt did as he still looked as though he had achieved a good deal!].8. We travelled in October to avoid searing heat, yet still enjoyed warm but comfortable temperatures that would put the UK summer to shame.9. Enjoy!10. Go - you know you want too!

Everything you've read is true!. It's all been said before but if this isn't the Greatest Show on Earth then I don't know what is:)Here's a tip: no irreverence intended, one evening I pulled my headscarf over my head and the touts/ sellers/guides and beggars suddenly reduced by about 80%! This tip WORKS.Be aware that even over 30 yards, if you take a photo from a distance of a band/ attraction, they will come at you with a bowl. You pay for everything; but when goods are so cheap a few extra Dhms aren't a problem, are they?

Interesting.... Kind've a must-see if you go to Marrakech... a little insane with everything happening, a little frustrating with everyone trying to get you attention, but really surreal. Snakes, monkeys, OJ, fire... Check it out - dusk is best.

Excellent place to start and finish any day. it is a vibrant place full of life and that varies though the day. In day light men with monkeys or snakes look about for photo opportunities money first photos second, the all day stalls are great for nuts, dried fruit and fresh juice, come evening loads of pop up restaurants hawk their trade and noisy entertainers tell stories, gamble, play music etc. yes there are beggars and hawkers, sad crippled people and those who will sell you fake watches, mobile phones or drugs all apparently oblivious to any legal restrictions, but it is fully alive, around the edges you may be mown down by mopeds at any moment, at night you may be pick pocketed, so stay alert and enjoy.

A real view of 'Arabian Nights' of today!. Be prepared to have all your senses assaulted, bowled over and then shaken up! From late afternoon every day jugglers, tumblers, musicians, snake charmers, monkey-handlers, vendors (of anything) and even an open air dentist assemble to entertain you and endeavour to part you from your money - in the nicest possible way.... At the same time, mobile orange juice vendors align their stalls and cry our for custom from all passers by. Their chilled juices are delicious and inexpensive, typically 4 Dirhams (about 35 pence UK, or USD 0.50 approx) but be aware that the juice is usually watered down ( happily with bottled water) but it is still refreshing on a hot day.Later in the afternoon, large mobile food stalls are wheeled, with much puffing and panting, into their respective places and rapidly swing into action preparing excellent brochettes, soups,and tasty tajines for all who would like to enjoy supper in the fresh air surrounded by the noise, smoke and general chaos! Delightful!Be aware that every enthusiastic individual who offers to star in your photographs will expect a monetary "thank you" - usually 10 Dirhams - but they will always try for more! So make sure you have plenty of loose change but spread it between several pockets in case you are in a "that's all I have" situation...The whole smokey, noisy and colourful carnival continues until very late in the night - and starts again the next day! Phew! What an event to experience!!

An experience!. We had a fair idea what to expect having read reviews prior to going, but the reality really is more intense! We took a stroll from our hotel (the Pearl) of about 15mins on our first night in Marrakech. It really is the 'go-to' place for locals and tourists alike. I would say the main thing to be wary about, is the fact that there are lots of children trying to sell your items and they will follow you! The best thing as harsh as it seems is to just ignore them. I also had one lady so desperate to show me her henna tattoo work that she actually grabbed my wrist and gave me a dot on my hand... I think the look on my face said it all!!! My partner and I were trying to subtly take some photos on our mobile phones when a couple of guys in costume offered to take photos for us and then pictures of us together with them, this would have been fine only they then expected payment for their 'services' & they were reluctant to leave us alone until we had given them something, I think the only change we had was probably equivalent to a penny! Still, regardless of these experiences, it is a very interesting place to wonder around and as the sunsets it really becomes much more vibrant. We did buy some fresh orange juice off of one of the stalls and I must say it was lovely. The Medina can feel very intimidating at times but I would say that I never felt particularly threatened or unsafe even with my experiences.

Somewhere to wander day and night. There is always something going on, in bright sunlight or in the cool of the night. It is huge, not a "square at all", and you can buy freshly-squeezed orange juice for 4 Dirhams, have your hands coloured with henna designs, have a drink (preferably mint tea) in a cafe and watch the world go buy, as well as tourist things like watching snake-charmers. It is a pity that they still chain animals such as monkeys up, to have their photo taken for a fee, but if we all boycott doing that then they will give up if there is no money in it. If you see a crowd of people gathered, stow your wallet carefully and go and have a look: it may be a card trickster or local magician, they are always good at sleight of hand - and of course, remember that they always win!
worthy of being a world heritage site. The place is very intense and the restaurants are dive-y, but this is a must see. It's a huge open space in a cramped medina. Check it out.

No place like it for watching the world go by.... If you saw the square during the day you would wonder what all the fuss is about, but from about 6pm the stalls start being put out and the lamp men set down their wares...shortly after the stalls are set up the smell of cooking food starts wafting about around the gathering crowds, lamps and lanterns are lit and there is a real buzz about the place...yes there are elements that are distasteful to us, like the performing monkeys, and snake charmers but if you can find a place to sit and watch from it is all a fascinating spectacle ... we ate at one of the stalls, the food was good and it was even better watching the whole thing from the middle.
A must see. At night the square fills with food stalls, acrobats, fire eaters and snake charmers. The atmosphere is magical

Vibrant. We really didn't like the snake charmers and monkeys which were there mainly during the day. The evenings, particularly at the weekend, are completely full of tourists and locals and the food on sale in many stalls put up specifically at this time was very good.

Busy Town Square - a bit overrated... Nicer at night.. lots of food stalls and very busy atmosphere. snake charmers and some poor tortured monkeys. Definitely a energetic place and worth a visit but overall an okay experience

a must. Great during the day or night. At night the drums are beating ,the performers are out and the food is hot. Eat at the restaurants around the square not at the actual stalls in the square because the food is amazingly bad-fun to be sat in the midst of the chaos though!!. Avoid the chained apes and the snake charmers because that is another level of sad.
Brilliant. The main square has such an amazing atmosphere - especially at night. There is always something to see and do, and you must try the fresh orange juice from one of the stalls in the square.

Probably not for me. It is obvious that this place is a magnet for tourists and touts alike. Not a chance of getting through the square without being pounced upon. Extremely busy during the day but manic at night - not for me!

ITS ALL ABOUT THE HUSTLE. During day this is an amazing place to go and pick up those all important keep sakes to bring back home with ya. If you love to barter, then this is the place to brush up on your negotiating skills. The price that the originally state to you in dirhams is way over the actual price so make sure that you pay the price you think the item is worth.During the night its totally transformed to a open air eatery with all types of food and drink on offer.A must see if you visit Marrakech

Hustle and bustle. Busy, busy, busy. During the day, Snake charmers, Juice sellers, salesmen of numerous wares trying to sell, sell, sell. This lends to the whole atmosphere. At night, food, food, and more food stalls. You have to see it to believe it.

Place with rare atmoshpere. This place has some kind of magic. There is too many different kind of people on one spot than you can imagine. And the special thing is how different is the square on the day and in the night! Great experience!

Bustling and manic. Square is the centre of the Medina, during the day it is relatively quiet and there are many place to eat and drink (not alcohol though). At night it becomes the hub of noise, drummers, snake charmers, food stalls. There are sellers of perfumes and spices, fresh orange juice and all sorts of wares. It does get a bit annoying though as every time you stop to admire anything you are hassled. I am certain that we would have spent more without the constant attention of the stall holders, others to whom I have spoken agree that the hazzle is counter productive.

Fantastic. The inhabitants having a meeting , showing their strange skills in the square.You have to taste the excellent Orange Juce they sell in the square, But remember, without ice, because the water.The typical dish is roast lamb head.

Best square in world. This place is awesome. Best market square I've been to. Ps don't take a photo of anyone unless your willing to pay. Also the henna ladies are super expensive in the square. Try find another one outside it will probably be 1/10th the price. Must go during early afternoon and then wander around till early evening the experience the vibe.

Night and Day. By day a lot quieter just mad snake charmers, monkeys, acrobats, henna ladies and water sellers. Try to sneak photos or else they want money. Different world at night hundreds of food stalls, fortune and story tellers, dancers and musicians. Ate twice at the stalls no problems, fantastic photo opportunities from surrounding cafés roof top terraces.

Mad, noisy, colourful and like nothing you will have visited before!. Felt safe, fresh orange juice available cheaply. Worth getting ther before sunset and get a front row view from one of the cafes as the sun sets.Lots of hustle and bustle at night barter like crazy!!

If you first go there at night it is overwhelming. I think I would have been more comfortable with my surroundings and all the activity if I hadfirst seen the Jemaa el Fna in daylight. It turns into a circus at night.

Needs both a day and a night visit. Two visits as my wife was indisposed during the evening. Atmosphere and life in the evening with the entertainments such as the drummers and the food stalls which I may well have been tempted but for the previous hotel meal. Lights on the buildings and walls gave atmosphere. Felt totally safe having taken standard precautions. Went back - with my wife who had partially recovered - in the morning as they were setting up. Snake charmers present looking for photo opportunities and men with birds and with sad looking monkeys. Juice and fruit stalls and shoeshines with the odd clothing stall but nowhere near the vigour of the evening.A lot of "guides", some of them obviously faux, offering guidance through the souks, but they accepted a polite decline. An original experience

Very Unique & Must See. An assembly of shows: music, dance, snake-charming etc. Starts like 2 hours before sunset. One thing I noticed was that the snake-charming show only appeared before sunset - they're gone by night.

An experience like no other. OMG! I loved it . Be wary of the snake charmers, they offer to take pictures for you then after that ask you to pay ridiculous amount of money. Make sure you go at night as well, I enjoyed it so much.

a must do on your trip. Visit the square in the day, sit up on a roof top terrace early evening, watch the sunset and watch the square fill up with the night entertainment and food stalls, It's quite magicalEat at the busiest food stalls, you wont forget which number to sit at either, trust me, the sales patter is quite funny at times. , Take your own plastic cutlery and paper napkins or tissues, or use your bread to mop up food.Food is very cheap and freshly cooked and prepared.Try the passsitllla.We ordered a dish each between three of us, and shared, it was more than enough.Loved sitting down and talking with other tourists who were doing the same. Was great to share some of your tips of places to see, do and visit

Live Dangerously!!. At night quite the most chaotic place I have ever been-but as long as you do not hold your life too dear-because of the maniacal drivers pedestrians motorbikes etc it is a genuinely unique experience of new sights sounds and smells,some great some awful but all very different. Suprisingly the one area of calm was the souk where professional bargainers take on the amateur tourists or as they say men versus boys,an entertainment in itself !

Something you should see!. Crazy, frenetic place where the stories of snake charmers are not exaggerated. We had dinner one night at the stalls on the square - a little bit of hassle and hustle from the stall owners, but quite fun. Not the best food but an experience.

A cultural feast. Everything you could wish for here - souks, sellers, snake charmers, cafe's and more. Watch your wallet though, not because of pick pockets but because the local sellers are very good at bargaining!

marketing miracle. It's a standard middle eastern square, does not deserve that much fame. All Islamic countries have that type of squares, Istanbul has maybe 10 like that. We should appreciate Moroccan people.
Crazy ....good. Loved the chaos ..the madness ,the spontaneity of the place ...incredibly crowded but felt quite safe ,it was like a celebration /party there every night ..Must go to place

A bucket list location. This place was fantastically awesome.First its important to say its not for everyone. If you find haggling or people trying to sell to you or a busy place intimidating you may not like it., However i did not find any of the above too much. It is a place of trade where locals can make money. You just need to be a little wide not to accept "gifts" from henna tattoo ladies or snake guys as they will charge you after at whatever rate they deem suitable. If you push back i found they went away fairly swiftly. I did not find this square or Marrakesh itself in anyway unsafe or aggressive. Marrakesh itself is an extremely busy city but its worth remembering the serious crime rates here are pretty low with one of the lower homicide rates in the world. Personally i think a lot of this is to do with the religious life style of the people here. The square at night is alive with lights, trade cooking and culture. A must see both at night and during the day, 2 very different experiences !!!!

Loved it and hated it.... This has been the hardest review to write due to my mixed experience here. I loved the colours, sights, smells and genuine other worldliness of every step along the way to Jemaa el Fna. The stalls in the souks and the winding streets are beautiful and walking through I didn't feel too harassed at any point until a young chap with arms covered in scars and clearly off his face on drugs approached me and wouldn't leave me alone. Some of the older men came to my rescue and apologised for his behaviour which I appreciated. We met a lovely stall owner who had the banter of a stall owner in London when he called "Come and have a butchers at my awesome swag!" - we had a chat and updated him on some new phrases from the UK and he told us if we ever got lost in the souk, all we had to do was look up for the red signs and we would find our way out - this turned out to be great advice!So far I was falling in love with the magic of the souks....then we reached the main square Jemma El Fna...This place was aggressive, noisy and full of drugged up snakes, terrified and abused monkeys, and every con artists in the country trying their very best to steal your money. I had been warned about the animal abuse, but to see a monkey screaming in pain as its owner beats it with a stick and yanks on the metal chain round its throat is heartbreaking. The line of horses and carts was a mixture of relatively healthy animals to poor souls covered in sores and dying of hunger. I know that when in foreign countries you cannot expect they same levels of animal welfare we take for granted in the UK, but as an animal lover I found this really upsetting and had to get away from there before I got myself into trouble.My advice - explore the souks. Drink tea and chill out in a hidden cafe. Soak up the sights and sounds and don't be afraid to interact with the owners there - most are pretty friendly. BUT. Avoid Jemaa el Fna, the main square, at all costs. Unless of course, animal cruelty, threatening behaviour, and getting scammed is you thing, in which case you'll love it!

Frenetic and Fabulous! . We visited the square three times during our stay. The first time was to watch the stall holders come in to set up from 4. We took a seat on the roof top of the Café de Paris and marvelled at the speed that everything is assembled and how organised they are. ..this really is a must see. We then went down to eat at one of the stalls. We chose a meat tagine. ..in hindsight the brochettes (kebabs) would have been a better choice. The second time we ate the egg and potato roll only because everyone else was! Delicious; filling and dirt cheap as it's for the locals. ..we were the only tourists tucking in! Our final visit was to do what most people do and enjoy a barbecued kebab with delicious salads. We also tried the tea stands with the cocoa paste sweet stuff. Not to my taste but the tea was a spiced version of mint tea and right at the end he popped some menthol powder into it. ...wow! !!!We drank orange juice each time and bought dates and almonds and had no adverse reactions. In our experience there was no hassle; we have visited Tunisia, Egypt and Agadir and have had far more 'encouragement' to buy! !Everyone we met was friendly and respectful. ..you get out of life what you put in.

never a dull moment. the square is touristic and hectic, but always buzzing and interesting. There's always something to see. Just take a drink at the roof terrace of one of the cafe's at the square and take time to look and enjoy.
Great Hustle and Bustle. If you dont mind the hustle and bustle you must visit the square both in the day and then experience the change at night too,you will enjoy it if you can handle the crowds.

The one to do. Very different, unique in the world, that place is the one to be done if you are staying a short break in Marrakech.Better late afternoon, Cafe de France is the best place to have a view and drink.

Jumble of activities. At Jemaa el Fna, we saw snake charmers, jugglers, gambler, trader, fortune-teller, Henna ladies, sad monkeys in chains and nappies, fire eater, tanneries stalls galore selling everything you could possibly want in daylight. The view from the cafe in the square was good and we watched the activities going on the square.  The sunset was lovely and you can see the Atlas Mountains in background. The square came alive in the evening, a very different atmosphere with fire eaters and bright lights everywhere. It was a good experience so we took a walk around and the henna ladies with their syringes full of henna and brandishing books of photos were persistent but I firmly said no. I did not want a picture with sad looking monkey or other traders. We walked to the square when it was Eid, there were crowds of locals celebrating there with lamps various activities going on. It was very nice to see the vibrant atmosphere with a sensory overload.

Call a spade a spade. This was a horrible dirty place. We were totally hounded around the square and some of the people trying to sell things were extremely aggressive. It might have been fun here years ago but now this is an extreme tourist trap and not worth visiting.

Must see. A lot happening on this square. Keep an eye on your wallet/bag and enjoy the monkeys n snakes, the henna tattoo ladies, all the different food n drink shops, the view on the Koutoubia and all the different people walking around..

Fun, if you know how to deal. As many suggest, visit day time and early night time, as those two visits will have nothing in common.Know that in Arabic countries people will try to sell their stuff to you or intimate you into buying as well as kids starting to cry if you don't give them money.If you have experience with this behavior it will be fun, otherwise you might get agitated, scarred, etc.

Crazy mix of things going on. The square itself is not that big, but there are so many things going one at the same time, it can be mind blowing, go in the daytime and then go again late evening, the atmosphere is totally different once the foods stalls have been setup.A must do if visiting Marrakech.

Need to visit twice. This square should be visited by day and again by night as it has 2 different characters. By day there is a lot going on, with the snake charmers, the monkeys, the colourful watermen, the sellars and the stalls. There is even a dentist who can make up a set of false teeth. Everywhere you look there is something different going on. There is a real buzz about the place, there is a constant sound of music which includes the snake charmers pipes, it is almost like we are hearing the pulse of this great square.In the evening there is a different atmophere, there are lots more people about, the music is louder, more stalls and sellers, people dancing and loads of food and eating areas. The steam can be seen from the great pot, like woks, cooking up tons of cockles. This place is amazing both by night and day and worth a visit.A word of warning don't let anybody put a snake or monkey on you for a photograph as they will want money before removing it.This review does not do the square justice, the only thing I can say is go and see for yourself and enjoy.
Disappointing. Not what we expected and the treatment of monkeys was cruel and unnecessary, a poor excuse of a tourist attraction and should be banned.
nice in the evenings. It's a great place to go on the evenings to discover local food, but during the day it's less crowded and less interesting.

LarsB. This is "a must" if you visit Marrakech. It is a place that is fully chaotic both during the day as well as during nights. Nightimes thousends of people are here to eat, watch all the differens "enntertainments" and to meet other people. Around the Square are severel good restourants. Beware of pick pockets though.

Navel of the world.. Fascinating, humourous and varied. You can hang out and eat here, watch the world go by and see it all. You may be pestered a bit by hawkers, but what the hell, there's a lot of poverty here and although they are insistent, they are respectful, unless you are not. Even the lowest budget traveller here has money compared to the hawker, so be patient and don't judge too quickly. Just participate.

An experience!. The area that is full of Hustle and bustle and never seems to sleep. Full of carts selling freshly squeezed orange juice, snake charmers, henna ladies, story tellers, performing sad looking monkeys and stalls selling tourist gifts. The main attraction in the evening is the food stalls selling everything from bbqed meats to sheeps brains. It's worth a look even if you don't want to risk eating the food although most stalls do guarantee you won't get ill!

Step into the past. With dusk the city square transforms into magical experience, with lights everywhere, dancing cobras, henna painting, small shops and food stalls... We loved freshly squeezed orange juices for 0.50 € - order them without ice to avoid stomach problems.
Oriental Fascination. How can anything just a three hour's flight from Europe be so different, so exotic, so wonderful? It's like a big open air theatre, and the play never ends...

View from above. Everyone has to go to the main square at least once, though getting into it is somewhat challenging - don't expect the signposts to tell the truth all the time! Though getting lost is part of the experience ! I could have done without the "pose with my monkey" vendors & many of the stall holders have exactly the same items. As a visual spectacle from any of the Cafe Terraces it is terrific, especially from the South side

Over rated chaotic market. This market square was just not my cup of tea. Nothing wrong with it but nothing very right either. It was as expected, crowded with shouting hawkers and entertainers and tourists both local and overseas. The reason why it felt a little disappointing is due to a certain sense of expectation because it is just such a famous landmark. The good thing is, it is not a place that you have to go out of the way to find. Inevitably, as you walk around the old city of Merrakech, you will reach this big square.
