The Market. The Jemaa el Fna comes to life in the evening when all the stalls with food, drink and stalls of every kind do brisk business. Hundreds of locals and tourists are around in the shops, cafes and socializing. This creates a wonderful atmosphere and one not to be missed.

Fun to go to for one or 2 nights.. We went for dinner 2 nights in a row, the food was pretty good and cheap. got ripped off badly at one of the stands selling spiced drinks and cakes. We enjoyed the music and were happy to pay up as soon as we went to listen to any group. Overall fun but 2 nights was enough.

A must and a pain. During the day it's about as big a pain as one could imagine. It's a tourist trap if you can't figure that out. At night it's a totally different place. The food, the vendors all of it. Yes the food stalls can be annoying just don't ignore them and talk with them. I already ate works well and we will come back tomorrow and say there stall number out loud. It's fun just keep a light heart.

The spirit of Marrakesh. The most delightful place, full of colours, locals, goods, merchants. Try it night and day, don´t be affraid of getting lost, you will find the way out, after an incredible experience. Try the hand made sweets and take some home. Just avoit the snake charmers, and dont even try to steal a picture. They can chase you for hours to get some money from you. Enjoy!!!

An exotic place, but beware, everything you do has a price !. The Jamaa El-Fnaa place is an interesting place, full of people, music and food. You must see it, however, you must be careful : it is massive, so you can be lost easily as it is just next to the souks. Then, the souvenirs and things to buy are sometimes overpriced since every tourist goes there. Moreover, it is impossible to feel 100% safe since everyone comes at you asking you to buy something, or just to "look at their things", and if you look you will have to pay. Concerning the snake charmers and the monkeys, it is a great attraction, but beware, if you take a picture - even if you're far away - the people will come at you to ask you to pay, or be very rude if you refuse because you did not know... Even if you're on a terrace drinking Moroccan mint tea, people will come talk to you and try to sell you things even if you're saying no...
Entertainment ++. This square is a hive of entertainment and well worth a visit. Be careful of henna artists and shoe cleaners who offer you services and then demand high payment afterwards!

Wonderful Ambience. We visited during the day and enjoyed the ambience of the square . There were many horse carriages lined up close by although some of the poor horses looked in rough condition ( ribs showing ) . We met the monkey man who did see me discretely traying to take a photo from a distance and he came running up but not in an aggressive manner .He did try request $ 600 dirham initially for the photo but we gave him $ 50 ( which was still a lot ) . The vendors selling orange juice were all over and the juices so sweet and refreshing on a hot day . I am aware there are a lot of vendors selling food during the night but we saw very few eating places in the day .

Live it and you will enjoy it. This is the main place in Marrakesh, walk around, eat some food, drink some juice, enjoy the locals that are with the snakes and eat some desserts. Please keep in mind that if you take a picture of a local with a snake, costume, etc, that person will go and ask for money. I recommend you take a picture with that person and then give him 1 or 2 Euros (no more). Sometimes the square is extremely busy and it looks a bit chaotic, then try to go to a restaurant with a terrace. Prices are similar and you will have a great view.

Beautiful experience. First thing's first. I hate snakes haha, have to be careful that the charmers don't get too close and try to put one around your neck. Watching the sun set across the buildings and the Jemaa el-Fna from one of the bordering restaurants has to be one of the most amazing experiences of my life. I drank so much orange juice in the square. I ate my share - although a bit pricey - and the food wasn't bad BUT you will pay for everything e.g. "free" bread or olives. This place is not to be missed, an amazing cultural immersion.
Is tradition falling?. It's a must see, but expected snake charmers, acrobats, dancers, tooth pullers etc but there were few. Mostly stalls selling goods at tourist prices.

Delightful local color for evening eating. The busy hectic square turns into a ferrie land at sunset with the setting up of food stands and tables. Absolutely something to do at least once; magical. Great food prepared in front of you for excellent price.

Full of bullies. Stay away from here after your first visit. The traders here will accost you and try to make you pay for anything they can. The snake charmers and monkey tampers want 200 dirhams just for taking a picture, and the ladies doing henna will grab your hand and try to start a design even while you are saying no. Go to some of the out of the way souks for the real experience.

RIP OFF. Beware! The only thing worth anything in this place is the 4d orange juice (simply the best this Floridian has ever had). Interesting at night. Food is AWFUL. The souvenirs are overpriced Chinese made trinkets. Too much hustle and too much hassle. Dedicate about 15 minutes (for the orange juice) and move on.

The heart & soul of Marrakesh. Have a wonder around Jemma el Fna during the day then return at sunset when it comes alive with the food stalls & more entertainers. Best to avoid the snake charmers & guys with monkeys as these creatures have no doubt been drugged. Look out for the water sellers but don't drink the water! Sit on one of the roof top terraces to soak up the great atmosphere from a distance.

Beware - the locals will rip you off. large square with lots of very badly looked after and smelly horses. a few snakes and monkeys but you cannot touch or TAKE PHOTOS without giving them lots of money. The souks are good. Worth a look but be aware and just remember to say LA Shakuran ( No thanks )

More interesting by night. During the evening, it's a nice place to sample different types of food, on our first night, we had kebabs, aubergines, tomatoes, I found the food quite salty but it was still nice, I did get the feeling that the vendor wasn't keen on giving us our change back, so we did have to wait around longer than we wanted to for our change.I also tried the snails, this had a hint of chili, and the cinnamon drink, this was strong!During the day, one of the snake charmers caught my friend taking a photo of the snakes, and followed us, put a snake around her neck and wanted 20DH for the photo, he wasn't pleasent at all, so if you want to take photos of vendors at the square, it's better to try taking some pictures from a roof top restaurant.

Nice experience, but a bit over rated. If you are in Marrakech it's a must visit but I believe it's a bit over rated. Food is okay nothing extra ordinary. But it's a nice experience to eat at these stalls in the open.Orange juice during a hot day is definitely a treat, we had a few. Vendors are generally tend to be nice and they don't haggle too much and if you say no, they understand. They were certainty much better than the vendors in Egypt.We didn't find snake charmers as bad as some review suggest.

Nice to see. Nice to see, but from my point of view not a must. It is interesting about daytime (snakes, monkeys, artists), at night it is good to get food for less money. But it is also anoying, people want to induce you to eat a their booth.

Magical Marrakesh. The Jemaa El Fna in the daytime is a pleasant open square,but in the evening it becomes the heart and soul of the Medina.Acrobats,musicians,storytellers,dancers and food stalls galore.Everything you could possibly want for a good night out ,you can find here.If you get tired of all the hustle and bustle you can always view the party from one of the cafe balconies.Go on,pay it a visit,you know you want to.
Total Chaos. If you want to experience everything crazy about Marrakesh come here. It is the epicenter, Snakes, Monkeys, Henna Tattoos, food, almost never empty

Not to be missed. Monkeys, snakes and henna tattoos abound and lots of good natured invitations to try all sorts spices, food and freshly squeezed orange juice.The food was good but it is the same price as the restaurants that surround the square. Be careful when ordering as they are very good at talking you in to lots of different dishes and the costs mount up.

Unique. Our guide books told us this was the place to go in the evenings, and if you want to soak up the unique atmosphere of the place - stroll around at your leisure, BUT keep your money in a safe place. The lights are beautiful, but, if you're not keen on crowds, you can observe from the many restaurant roof terraces around the square.

Worst city I've ever been to !. If like me you've read a guide book or two before traveling to Marrakech and thought that there isn't much to see and do there but there must be more to it because of all the good reviews perhaps the guide books are wrong .. There not! Marrakech is by far the most boring, overpriced and overrated city I've ever been to. And the square is supposed to be the highlight of the city, its a joke! only not a funny one. Yes its packed with hundreds of Morrocans who seem to mesmerised by some guy in a dress (the main at traction in the square) , he dosent actualy do anything but they like him nonetheless. Then there's the snake charmers dressed in traditional Morrocan nike tracksuits, the snakes are either drugged or stuffed it's hard to say because their not very animated. I could go on but suffice to say that Jemaa el Fna was an incredibly underwhelming experience and if you absolutly have to go to Marrakech then one day is enough. You can literally see the city in an afternoon. See my posts on how awful the food is and how unfriendly the people are.

The Square. It has something for everyone, a unesco site. by day there are monkeys and snake charmers plus the usual market and souks etc.there are also the brightly coloured water sellers. all geared for the tourist but by night it all changes, the are story tellers but these are for the locals and large crowds gather around, they also hold special events and shows here, one of the nights we were there there was Imichil Marriage Festival. Very traditional. a great find and purley by chanceEvery September, one of Morocco's Berber tribes holds a celebration whose origins are linked to a story reminiscent of Romeo and Juliet. Lured by the legend, and by North Africa's vibrant music, its a 3 day event and worth a visita lot of people complain about being hasseled here day and night, we were there for 10 days and didn't find it to bad at all I experienced a lot worse in places like Egypt etc. Don't let these reports put you off.. Enjoy it for what it is
Best at Night. A very lively square, with the souks around the outside. Good to see the nightlife and many jugglers, dancers and music groups, with lots of food stalls.

A 'square' of experience. Jemma el Fna isn't a square in the conventional sense, though it does have sides facing into an open space in the middle. During the day, there is little to see, with perhaps a couple of stalls and a snake charmer. At night, though, it comes alive, with tradesmen wherever you look and a vibrant cultural feel about the place with may smells and things to see (try the orange juice!) I would advice travelling in a group with at least 2 adults, preferably more, and if possible a Moroccan tour guide. A must-see in Morocco is Jemaa el Fna at night, preferably eating a mela overlooking the square - an experience to remember!
Great atmosphere. A very lively and bustling place with all the night markets and cafes sit on one of the restaurant terraces and ha e s drink and watch the world go by

Not what it was. This is still an interesting and engaging place. It was always a place for the showman, be it snake charmer, story teller, water sellers, juggler, food stall or the wide range of other entertainment. Now though it lack authenticity with the target audience firmly tourists. Take them away and this place fades into the ashes of a formerly bright fire. It was once the centre of life in the city, not any more. Local people have other entertainment.The main purpose of the entertainers is to procure money for photographs. Although why someone wants a picture of a monkey on their shoulder needs some examination. These monkeys have a hard, stressful and shameful history. Taken from their mothers at birth, often after killing the mother and other members of the family trying to protect them. For the sole purpose of using them to secure money from unwitting tourists unaware of there history. Please don't take photos or even worse pay for the privilege. You will find the charm transforms to something far more ugly if you don't play along. So make it clear that you disapprove of animal cruelty and don't prolong animal mistreatment by paying to participate in this distasteful entertainment.

A must while in Marrakech!!. This place is exactly as one would hope...snake charmers!, Story tellers, monkey's, teeth-pullers!, medicine men!, fortune tellers, food stalls, fresh squeezed juice, a sensory overload in the best way! We had a great experience, we researched a bit in advance to know what to expect and where to go. We also dressed appropriately, expect to be harassed some if you do not. Note: we read to not let "helpful" men offer assistance to find your way if you get lost a bit...well, we did accept help and if we did not we might still be lost :) Have a few DH handy to thank someone if they assist you, be confident, tell him you are meeting someone in 10 minutes and are in a hurry or else they might side track and take you to a shop.

Vibrant square. Sunset in Jemaa el Fna square was the highlight of this trip to Marrakech.Tha atmosphere changes, people start preparing everything for the evening. Loved the outdoor restaurants wher you can eat outside traditional moroccan food. Music, dance, storytellers and lots of locals selling everything you can imagine... Even teeths, in case you need some... Amazing moments!

Great Place to visit in the evening.. Although very busy in the evening (locals and tourists), it is a great place to visit and have a scroll around. Good place to taste the food of Morocco and have a glass of fresh fruit juice.
interesting. Very interesting place to visit everynight, for people watching, shopping or just passing the time. Interesting culture and diferent things to see

Mad Mad Mad. What a fantastic place to visit. The square is vast and is an overload to the senses. You will be "encouraged" to part with every last dirham by every stall and street vendor you come across.
Keep your wits about you and enjoy

a spectacle. I expected to run the gauntlet of sellers touting for business, but it wasn't too bad, beware taking photos of snake charmers, monkeys, Berbers etc, as you WILL be expected to pay them for the photo. Teeth pullers set up their shop in the square, the souks head off in all directions at the top of the square, and it is a maze of warrens selling leather, metalwork, slippers, herbs, Moroccan clothing etc, haggle,haggle haggle, as prices are over inflated.
Best orange juice ever. Best orange juice ever stall number 28 There are like 50 juice stalls but the best stall is number 28 amazing juice
A unique market!. For some people this is one of the best marketplace in the world. It´s unique and we can find things that it´s hard to believe.

Totally insane, buoyant, vibrant and beautiful!. WOW! Our first impressions were a little overwhelming. It's an absolute sensory overload with all the sights, smells, sounds, hustle and bustle, but once you settle into the pace of it, it transforms into this beautiful, vibrant hub of activity. Weaving in and out of the calls to 'come look at my shop', delicately declining offers to 'come eat at my stall' and keeping your hands away from the enthusiastic henna artists I found myself grinning at the absolute charm of the Jemaa el Fna. There's no place like it on earth. It's so alive with people; acrobats, snake charmers, gamblers and when it's lit up at night it's a real sight to behold. You have to try it to understand it! You also have to try the orange juice, it's delicious!

Henna tatoos, snake charmers, trained monkeys and snails?. It does seem incongruous, but yes, snails. There are booths selling cooked snails, a popular delicacy in Moroccan, as in France. There are also multiple fresh juice sellers, grilled meat vendors and tagine with couscous hawkers. Musicians, acrobats - they're in the square, too, but watch where you step - those snake charmers are playing with cobras and rattlers!

Jemaa-el-Fna (The place of the dead). This is where , in ancient times, wrong doers were taken for a public execution. The area is directly facing one of the many city gates. In close proximity is the ancient tannery, just follow your nose to find it. The staff who work there are training the hard way by treading hides Knee deep in fetid water. They are well paid but are not allowed to live in the vicinity because of the nauseus stench that pervades from them.

unique athmosphere. nice refreshing orange juicees during the dayunique athmosphere in the evening lights, it is an experience to have dinnar in one of the outdoor placeeveryone want you do eat at their place, difficult to pass by without being energetically invited

Hey skinny man, you need to eat.... This was the catch line from the many food stall people to my partner trying to entice us to choose their stand. My partner is a large man, 6ft 5in and broad, he does not look skinny at all...so, this would grab our attention and make us laugh. The square is buzzing with snake charmers, juice stands, men with monkeys, ladies giving henna tattoos, and lots of items for sale. As the other reviews have said, be careful with your bags to ensure you're aware of your surroundings but, Jemaa El Fna is exciting at night. During the day, it is filled with busy traders and tourists. It has a magical atmosphere at night as compared to the day.

Very cool, but beware of snakes. The square was vibrant and alive. However, I am phobic of snakes and there were snake charmers everywhere. So I didn't spend as much time there as I would have liked. It is a bit touristy. Ladies set up to do hennas, horse drawn carage rides, and yes snakes charmers. They are there to make money, and will ask for some if you take photos. The fresh squeezed orange juice stalls are a treat. There is also a night food market, but I was advised against eating there by the Riad I was staying in, as running water is scarce in the square, but essential to the preperation of food. I did enjoy my walks through Jemaa el Fna on my way to the maze of the souks.

the area of:. Vibrant area;Can be almost overpoweringly noisy at night especially at feast times when EVERYONE walks the promenade around the Souks.Be prepared to be accosted by tradesmen; children selling cigarettes and pitiful beggars either disabled or lone women with a young child. NO-ONE takes a polite no for an answer.Simply go with the flow and be in the moment- you will encounter nothing like this back home!!
Totally mad. Snake charmers, entertainers, stalls, night food market. You will hustled, so get used to it. Make sure you visit in the evening as well as the day

shops around most selling same thing. the shops aroung square where good but same as the Souk the Square comes to life at night it is buzzing with drums and snakes can have photo with monkey on shoulder etc

not a lover. I'm not comfortable in places where you get constantly asked for money or harassed for each picture you take (and I don't take photos of people as I know it's considered rude there). After 15-30 mins you get a good sense of what's going on and frankly there isn't much to do. I prefer the narrow streets or the rooftop bars.

What a Buzz. Really comes alive at night with lots of food stalls, etc. No drink to be had at these though (which makes sense !). Very friendly atmosphere as well but like anywhere in the world just keep your wits about you as it is very busy with tourists and locals.

Souks, Snacks and Snakes. A true melting pot. It is best to go during the day first when it is quieter (due to the heat of the day) look around and get your bearings. Then prepare for your bearings to disappear when you return to the transformed square at night. As other reviews have said, stay away from the snake charmers and this is where the most 'aggressive' selling techniques are employed. It is however not to be missed. We had no problems the whole time we were walking around Jemaa el Fna but you can see how people might. The food in the square is enthusiastically pushed by multi-lingual men. If you smile and laugh along with them then they are generally pleasant. We settled for one individual who on learning I was from London, England launched into an extremely convincing London accent and reeled off many obscure locations in London. We are a sucker for a good salesman. So we sat down ordered the tagine and were surprised at the price. That was until the food came, it was edible but lacked any of the flavour we are now use to in Morocco. It is well worth several visits just to immerse yourself fully into the mind-blowing exotic flurry of life the square has to offer.

Chaotic and crazy. It's busy and full of unique characters including the odd snake and monkey. It's very difficult to explain this place in words. The only way to really understand it is to experience it. The daytime is quite a lot calmer than after dark.
Enormous!. This is an enormous square right in the centre of Marrakech. During the daytime there are snake charmers and henna artists, but if comes alive at night and is absolutely packed

EXCELLENT. Vibrant, Exotic, Stimulating.
You must visit without doubt the best food ever...lovely people and misse it, this is one place where i would happily move to live. BRILLIANT.

Slightly intimidating until you get your bearings. It's an experience like none other. No wonder they made the square a Unesco protected site. I went with my two teenage daughters and husband in the first day and a snake charmer put two snakes around my daughters neck, then demanded money. I refused to pay then he threatened me. However that was the first and last time we had any hassle. Infact once we got our courage up and realised a firm no would be enough we began to have a ball. The sounds, colours, smells it's a cacophony of everything that sends your senses alive. Thinking back on our days there we began to love it and I can't help smile at all the memories and sites. In the evening it's wonderful to watch the street cafés come alive and the craziness of it all. Actually the souks were incredible with over 4000 stalls. I even had my shoes repaired. We bought masses. It was a memory that will stay with us for ever. It's not really necessary to have a guide for the first 3 visits we did it alone and on the last day we had a private guide that took us to lots of sites including the souks but we really didn't need him. Enjoy.

Hustle and bustle. This is where it happens! Souks, eateries (quite safe to eat at the stalls), but please avoid the snake charmers and monkey men - the animals are treated very badly (the details are too upsetting to repeat); if tourists stopped taking pictures of them, this cruel practice would stop.

Fascinating experience. Just wandering around the square was a truly fascinating experience. The juice stands, snake charmers, and henna arm/leg painters are truly fascinating to see. Watch out for taxis, motor bikes and bicycles who pop out of nowhere and pass too close for comfort.
very lively .. got to be very careful when you receive change make sure you get the right change . many places to eat and drink .

best for adventurous grownups. I am glad we visited, but would not go at night again with kids. I think there are probably some great things to see here if you wind through the crowds for a while and food stalls smell great, but not worth the risk with little kids. Mostly we tangled in the crowds for a few hours to see very little. The souk immediately behind the square was mostly novelty items made for tourists and by the time we hit the good stuff the kids were exhausted and needed a break from the crowds. Ended the night with a really fun horse carriage ride though.

A little disappointed. I expected a lot more from the Jemaa. Whatever time of day or night its packed.During the day snake charmers pretend to charm the snakes, they dumped a snake on my shoulder and wanted to photograph me.. I declined.By night the space fills with the food markets. They all seemed to be the same, and really hassle you to eat there. The food was alright, only did it once...That was enough.You cannot avoid walking through the Jemaa El Fna as the Souks are all behind it. Don't bother flagging a taxi in this area....None of the meters work!!!!

Most overrated tourist trap. This was the biggest disappointment of a 10 day visit to Morocco. I would skip it unless you like crowds, hustlers, bad food (hard to find in Morocco but you'll find it here at the grillers.)
An experience!. A must see... Wow, hectic, crazy, overwhelming, loved it!Sitting in a rooftop cafe watching it is amazing, especially at night, would definately reccomend A!

Beware of the Henna Ladies. Loved the food competitions at night. Wow! Just like what I saw on Anthony Bourdain's show. So much to see and do day and night. Horse carriage tours, folklore, listen to story telling, drums and dancing...honestly, it never ends. The Jemaa el Fna is super turned up! Beware of the ladies asking to apply henna designs to your skin. THE BLACK COLORED STUFF IS NOT HENNA!!! BEWARE!!! Some of the ladies will grab your hand, as did one to me, and begin to draw on your skin, sprinkle glitter on top of the design and demand money from you! DON'T FALL FOR THAT...YELL, NOOOO STOP. They'll understand. The black stuff isn't henna, and it will give you a bad skin reaction within 24 hours. I spent an entire week itching like crazy just four hours after the woman forcefully applied that design to my hand.Everyone in the Jemmaa el Fna wants your money. They'll ask you if you need directions. They want money. They'll wrap snakes around your neck then ask you to take a photo. They want money. If you take a photo of ANYONE, they want money. It's a crazy place, but you'll enjoy it all. Oh yeah, you won't need a guide to take you anywhere. Don't fall for it.

Amazing, crazzy and beautiful. We went to Jemaa el Fna four nights in our holiday and we loved it for most part. If you go to Marrakech you have to visit it, you would be crazy not to. There is a lot going on and its crazy. We ate at some of the street vendors at night 114 & 117. it was lovely, The kebabs and fish were some of the best that we had out there. There are monkey trainers and snake charmers which i kept away from but saw many people posing for photos with them. It can sometimes get a little intimidating but just be firm with people and be polite they will leave you alone. The only other thing I will say is if you take your phone out to video any of the bands be prepared to pay ALOT!! for a 10 second video they wanted £8.50!!!!! We had to pay as they surrounded us and it was intimidating, so just be careful. But well worth a visit.

Chaotic fun. Very difficult to find a place to eat without being hassled same with looking at any of the goods for sale. Surrounded by some good cafés & restaurants though with rooftop terraces to overlook the square.

Great culture but be careful.. Had a great time exploring this area as it was all of 10mins walk from our riad. It had great restaurants (not the street food which is guaranteed to make you very ill) and the souks and shops where bursting. Only thing that is a let down is if you are South asian, the people can be quite rude and forceful, which we where stunned by (remarks about being Indian and Pakistani (even thoughts where none of these)where constant). There's loads of ATMs and exchange places and taxi and caleche (horse carriage) ranks around for quick travel acess.

Animal cruelty!... Disgusting!. I can honestly say this is the most horrible, vile place I have ever had the misfortune of visiting.To see monkey's with chains around their necks and being punched in the face by there so called owners makes me sick to the bone and anyone using animals for their entertainment should be ashamed!As soon as you enter the square you are continually harassed by people trying to misdirect, confusion and rip you off!Ladies need to be particularly aware standing alone as many were groped by random men as western women are seen as 'easy'. You also need to be aware of the henna ladies who approach you, hold your then and then do some horrible rapid attempt at a henna tattoo and then demand money whilst holding a rusty old syringes over your hand.I will never visit this place again and I most definitely wouldn't recommend it!

don't like it so much. So crowded. Too many shops, everyone tells me to buy something, drink orange juice, see a performance (and he want some money), I got very tired. I don't like here so much.From the airport, I paid 40dh taking a taxi, but it's a little hard to get this price.

Excellent, fun and crazy. Me and my partner went into Jemaa El fna 4 times in out ten day stay. Although we loved it. It can be quite intimidating at times. I went to take a picture on my camera of a band in the square. It was a rubbish picture as there was lots of people surrounding them however I was surrounded my the band to pay them. Which I expected so handed them some change however I wasn't aloud to go till we paid 50 dirhams which is around £9. Which was ridiculous since I didn't even get a proper picture but it was that intimidating we had to pay. For the rest of et trip I just kept my phone in my bag. We ate at the food stalls at night time 3 times. 117 and 114. Both were delicious and no funny Tummys after. We would have ate there more if we could afford it. It's not as cheap as you may think. Deffinetly worth a visit!!!!

Djemaa el Fna. definitely a place you should go to see. In the evening the place is full with musicians and other kind of artists. Had a good dinner in one of the small restaurants on the Djemaa el Fna.

Crowded, complicated, a different experience.... The square is very different day time, evening and night time... Same place with 3 aspects... It' s almost empty in the morning, and beginning to be crowded in the afternoon, and crazy late evening... It' s a different experience to live, but also exhausting.. I recommend to watch from a distance, than to take a walk, than have dinner, than a walk again :) But be careful not to lost your family or your friends :)

Great - if you like being hassled and animal cruelty. Jemma El fna in a UNESCO heritage site. It may once have been a glorious example of heritage but is now just a massive tourist trap. From the snake charmers to monkeys chained to their owners this was a past to humanity I want the world to forget. When reading a guide book I was worried when the no 1 thing to do at Jemma El fna was ' try the orange juice stand'. I gave it the benefit of doubt but it was that bad. During the day the main square was a mass of juice stands, henna artists, tarot readers, snake charmers, monkey abusers, and horse carriages. If you stay away from the animals and reptiles you will avoid the common complaint of being forced to take part. I am no animal rights activist but even the abuse here offended me.We ate at a rooftop terrace 'cafe de france' which was horrible food, and watched the square transform overnight where the food vendors setup. We went for walk through the food stalls and have never been hassled in all my life. Had to stop my mini tour and abandon any thoughts of eating there because of the hassle. All in all a poor focal point for any city and relic of a time we all wish to forget about.
Busy, crazy and pulsating heart of the city. Busy, crazy and full on but interesting, full of life and certainly somewhere you must visit in marrakech.

Exotic and exciting. Snake charmers, live musicians and story tellers - it's like something out of the 1001 Nights. We came to Marrakech for the first time in 1976, when it was even more exotic and exciting, but we were appalled by the crippled beggars who followed us everywhere on their hands and knees. These have now gone, and the square remains a fascinating experience for tourists.

A Must See. MAKE SURE you visit here if you go to Marrakech. I would recommend going at night to really get the best of the atmosphere. The hustle and bustle of the market really allows you to immerse yourself in Moroccan culture. For the best view, have a drink on the terrace of Café Glacier. The market stalls and street entertainers provide something for everybody. Don't be frightened by the business and bustle of the market. Moroccans are very friendly, and they want your business as much as the next stall holder!

It comes down to common sense. The square is a magical place at night with the lighting and the restaurants in the centre and during the day with the hustle and bustle it is very interesting.Please remember to keep your wits about you, try not to make eye contact unless you want to buy (I kept my sunglasses on to be honest), be firm with hagglers or just walk away and ignore them, don't keep your wallet in a pocket where it is noticeable and place your bag strap from the left shoulder to the right hip (or vice versa) for security (don't take a bulky bag either, just a small one will suffice). I only had one incident with one woman grabbing my hand and painting henna on it telling my partner that she was "giving good luck to his wife" I kept saying no while she was doing it but she wouldn't let go of my hand, and after she demanded payment from my partner we just said "we said no" and walked away. The snakes, monkey and turtles are unfortunate and you can't do anything about as animal welfare is not the same in every country, my suggestion is just to avoid these stalls so not to encourage it.
Exciting. This really is a busy, bustling spot. It was great fun to go round and partake, but then find a cafe on the edge to sit over a nice cool drink and watch it all happening in front of you.

Over-rated. We passed through the square a couple of times during the day whilst walking around the city and even stopped for a mint tea on the terrace of Cafe France one afternoon, just to get a feel for the place and to give us an idea of if we wanted to visit at night especially after reading all the reviews on trip advisor. So on our last evening we made our way to the square walked about a bit and headed for another cafe with a roof top terrace where we thought we could watch the magic unfold..........................what magic, a few "street" entertainers hassling and catching out tourists with monkeys and snakes, a few guys dressed up as Moroccan water carriers and a few musicians, people selling touristy souvenirs plus a plethora of food stalls. Maybe 20 - 30 years ago this would have been a magical spectacle and for some visitors it may still be, not for me though.

Crazy place but still fun.. This is one big square of mess and crazy acts by local to rip you of some money. Most of the tourist gets scared by the snake show and monkeys running around.There is a nice big area of barbecue food once it gets evening. Worth a try, but the servers are really pushy !

A must in Marrakech!. Even if you only visit once, this is a must for every tourist in Marrakech. There are a lot of people about and it can be daunting but I think everyone must experience the craziness of Jemaa el Fna. Stay away from the snakes and monkeys but my friend and I had our hands decorated in Henna like the Berber women and ate in the stalls twice. All the stalls sell pretty much the same thing and so the competition to get you seated can be a bit in your face, but find someone you like and sit down.... we ate at number 114 and 25, both were tasty and cheap. If you want to buy anything, I would recommend finding out how much you should be aiming for when bartering before you shop.

Craziest Place on the Planet. You have to keep your wits about you and just keep your cool. The evening is the worst but it is such an experience that you have to go there and experience once in your life. The food not's bad either!
Awesome. A little daunting at first but I thoroughly recommend getting lost in the souk and then enjoying a meal in the centre!!

Absolutely fabulously chaotic.. I really cannot describe it in any other words. We spent nearly every day in a little café drinking coffee and watch the world go by Marrakech style. Traffic management appeared non-existent with taxis, lorries, donkeys and their carts plus the Horse drawn carriages all safely negotiating a collision together with various stall holders, snake charmers, shoe shine, acrobats and beggars all vying for attention

Great !!. alive !! animated love it , don't get close to the snakes !!
good for shopping you can negotiate the prices

Mixed experience . During the day the square is empty bar the millions of orange juice carts and a few snake charmers but what a transformation by night! The street food stalls are great fun but the entertainment didn't really open up to us foreigners - seemed much more geared toward the locals. Not necessarily a bad thing though in a city centre that is otherwise so tourist focused. Of course you'll have to go if you're in Marrakech but I'd recommend checking it out both at night and by day.
A grubby 'must see'.. You have to see it but it really is a grubby, crowded, over-hyped example of an Arab medina and souks.

Senses overload!. What a place! Busy, fast, smelly, funny, tasty... an eye opener for sure! We were staying in a beautful quiet Riad just off the square. I was amazing to walk just 5mins down the alley to come out to the square. There are some amazing sights as well as ones I found uncomfortable like women with babies begging,monkeys on chains, baby tortoises and snakes charmers. I found a polite but firm, no thanks ,with a little humour while walking with purpose worked just fine! The pop up restaurants are delicious but a gamble! Our first meal was at no 81, they get you in by mimicking your accent and thrusting menus at you, this crew very very funny with their Braveheart and SuBo comments so we eat there. Lovely simple cheap fast food. The next night we eat at 118.... big mistake chicken was uncooked and they brought us food we didn't ask for, they were nasty when we said we were not paying for they food we hadn't eat we put some money down and walked away. This is not a problem as there are plenty places to eat! It's a wonderful experience but not for the faint hearted!

An experience!!. Wow - this place is crazy and changes throughout the day. Best time to first visit is in the morning as it's quieter and easier to walk around without being asked for money. The evenings are best sat at a roof terrace watching the food stall set up and the crowds gathering playing games, boxing, music. The sunset is also gorgeous. Careful of taking pictures as you will be asked for money.

Smelly street circus. A must see experience no doubt, though not necessarily a pleasant one. The stench of horse dung was overwhelming until you get close to the barbecue stalls. In between were vendors for touristy products of dubious quality, street performers of all sorts asking aggressively for tips, encircled by both locals who displayed genuine interest and bemused, bewildered tourists.Many foreigners are contented with sitting in a nice square side restaurant, ordering a cool drink and watching locals eking out a living in the heat amongst the throngs of tour groups. But it's rather sad at the same time. In my opinion, the small square oppposite the street outside Koutoubia Mosque, where locals premonade in peace and quiet, is much more pleasant.

Not great and a tip off. This is my second time in Marrakech, this time I am with my girlfriend. The first time with my mate Salim who is from Morocco. Don't bother trying to buy anything here unless you know what your looking for in price and quality. I found a shop on Mohammed v where you get great quality at far prices. The address is Bd Med V Rue Med ELMELLAKH NO 1 and it's called Bazar Les Trois Palmiers. Here they are nice people and won't hassle you and you can still haggle. I managed to get myself a small tajine for 100dhs. Now for a local moroccan you pay 70dhs. I won't argue with that at all considering in the market the price was 500dhs. I know you can haggle but I see the square as a rip off and they have no respect for animals or the people visiting. If you like markets and the vibe I recommend visiting Essaouira. A much nicer place.

Great street food. We ate twice in the Djemma el fna. Once at stall number 1 and once at stall number 118. The food and experience at number 1 stall was lovely, really tasty and friendly, good value for money too. Stall number 118 were very friendly at first getting you in but then the service went down hill a little. Food was ok but nothing to boast about. I would recommend number 1 definitely.
Bonkers. Prepare for an total assault on the senses ! This is like no experience a Westerner would ever have had

An experience. First time visiting Morocco. The square was busier our first evening than the day time but we noted after this it was also busier during the day. Snake charmers, monkeys on chains (unfortunate to see), people selling their wares. Good to sit in one of the nearby restaurants and watch the world go by for a while. At night we visited the food stalls and were generally impressed. Out of 4, we had 3 good experiences-we left one before they could offer food as they were quick to seat but slow to serve and the couple behind were complaining of raw meat so we upped and left.One of the henna women offered her services; as I politely declined she decided to put some henna on my hand. I said no and pulled away and wiped it off with my tissue and she said sorry and was gone. Other than this everything was fine. There were people playing music, dancing, using fishing rods trying to pick up bottles of pop etc. The souks off the square are fantastic. We had a really good holiday.

Crazy. The largest and oldest open market square in Africa. At night there are thousands of people passing through and over 100 food stalls. get to a roof top terrace before sundown to watch it all unwind

Crazy place. This square is a must-see when visiting Marrakech, it is different at different times. During the day there is not many stalls, just a few snake charmers, monkey handlers, fruit juice/dried fruit stalls and lots of traffic. At night time the place comes alive with people, food stalls, entertainers. We had read reviews about being cautious and not taking photos etc, but I made the mistake of taking a picture of a group of musicians and immediately two men came over demanding money. My husband offered them 20 MAD but they gave it back and wanted 200 MAD. We said "No" and tried to walk away but they were really aggressive and eventually demanded the 20 MAD back when they realised they weren't going to get 200!. I kept my camera in my bag after that! We tried to look round the food stalls but were continually hassled with men trying to get us to sit us at their stalls saying "No diarrhoea!" which hardly made us want to sit there! If you look round the food stalls later in the evening you don't get hassled so much. We preferred to sit on a roofop terrace in a cafe and watch the proceedings from afar, we found it a bit intimidating being amongst it!

Fun, if a little crazy!. I visited the square in both the day and the night. The day was A LOT calmer than the night, but it is definitely worth visiting at both times. The day was nice to see a bit more. I had my hand done with henna (though was quite expensive and the minute they knew I was interested, the lady pretty much grabbed my arm and dragged me over!) There was a lot going on, the sellers weren't too pushy (apart from henna lady!) but the one thing I really didn't like was the animal cruelty there so be warned if this really upsets you. There were several groups with monkies (with nappies on) and some 'snake charmers' with snakes. The snakes were cobras and I think I saw some puff adders, they weren't really doing anything, which concerned me as I'm not sure why. The night was mental! Very fun, the street market stalls were so much fun, the food was good and cheap and the entertainment was out of this world. There were the most random things to see (man with chicken on his head!), dancers, music, story-telling, fortune telling, henna. It's very busy, but definitely worth a visit for the experience, even if crowds really aren't your thing. I described it as a 'mini - festival'. The sellers seemed to be more pushy at night, but just so long as you are firm, it's not too much of a big deal.

visit at night. Jemaa square is what Marrekech is known for - and it certainly is a feast for the senses. After a short while, we were overfull, so to speak. It is fascinating to see the "circus" of humanity on the plaza. Snake charmers with cobra snakes, monkey handlers, vendors, musicians, etc. While the crowds were mainly Moroccan tourists, we were always singled our to put money in the hat after stopping for only minutes to listed to music or watch a boxing match. With over 100 people surrounding the boxers, the guy comes over to us first and gets angry when we back away. Be prepared. These people make their living by having you take photos and they are aggressive to collect even if you don't get your camera out. We did try the food stalls, but felt like we paid too much for poor quality food . Our table had German and French tourists next to us. The stall next door was filled with Moroccans, but we noticed that their "specialty of the house" was a BBQ'd sheep's head in all of it's skeletal glory. I would recommend eating at one of the many terrace restaurants surrounding the plaza --very nice view of all of the activity, but better food.

Night Market. Head to the night market at sunset - it does get extremely busy with locals and tourists alike but is great fun - there's plenty to see...monkey men, dancers, transvestites and the food stalls!

Crazy and gets crazier as the night progresses. the sheer number of people and vendors can be a bit scary in the beginning but then it improves as you start to go with the flow. The variety of things on sale is pretty amazing starting from food and drink and extending all the way to snake charmers and performing monkeys. The shops are also worth a look.

An Assault On Your Senses. Be careful. We were warned by our guide that in Marrakesh we needed to be careful of our security and not to wear jewellery, carry valuables or handbags or walk close to the edge of the street as thieves and pickpockets exploited careless tourists usually by a motorbike with two men on it that snatch bags and jewellery. In one of the crowded souks two men on a motorbike deliberately bumped into my wife to put her off balance but she was too quick and stepped back as one made a grab for the bag she had on her shoulder. In a flash they had disappeared into the crowd. Riding motorbikes along crowded footpaths and in the souks is the norm, not the exception in Morocco. Also, expect to pay if you let the snake charmers put the pythons around your neck (they will try whether you say yes or no). They demanded 100 MAD from me and became quite aggressive when I told them no. Eventually, after several tense minutes of arguing, I gave them 25 MAD and left, quickly. Be ready to be hassled by the stall owners. There is no such thing as "window shopping" as if you show even the remotest interest in something in their stall, you will be harassed about buying it or something or anything from their stall. You really shouldn't go to Marrakech without visiting the square and souks, but it's not a quiet (or pleasant) stroll.
amazing artists. It looks like a big market with many different kind of performers, nice cheap food. Very spicy tea. All different kind of people.

A tourist trap. We were advised by loads of people to visit this when in Marrakech. To be honest, it was pretty horrible. It's simply a square where people try to fleece you of everything you have, all the while being surrounded by people who have monkeys with chains round their neck or are hitting their animals. Not the romantic square we were expecting at all!

Magical Marrakesh. this is the heart of Marrakesh. it is full of life, colour, smells, sounds, atmosphere. Great place during the day to sit at a outdoor cafe and watch the world go by, as well as the market sellers, only disturbing thing was the monkeys its very sad they should be in the wild not dressed up as girls and boys. The snake charmers were quite aggressive re money for photographs, you could not take a photo of anything without being chased for money. did not like the snakes being thrown around your neck i was terrified. apart from that it is a must. the Night was even more alive with sounds and smells and sights. The food area is not a place i would have eaten due to cleanliness and as we walked thru it to just look we were bombarded by the waiters for food but with good spirits and pater. You must try the freshly squeezed orange juice it is brought down from the mountains and it is mixed with a little water its fine no harm to you at all very cheap and very sweet just mouth watering. great place also to shop.

Busy and a bit full on. Don't get me wrong, you have to visit Jemaa el Fna while you're in Marrakesh, but be ready to be hassled for business from all the restaurant and food stall owners, and by any of the "entertainers" in the square. We'd been told about snake charmers and transvestite belly dancers, and actually did see the TV belly dancers. We ate at one of the restaurants at the top of the square and another just off the square - both were fine. My favourite thing was the market stalls piled high with dried fruit - very picturesque. Also, if you are keen to try Moroccan stewed snails then this this is the place to come :-)

Vibrant, exciting, noisy, exotic. We have been a few times, and I never get fed up with the square.See it change and come alive at night, with the story tellers, anyone that wants to do anything does this in the square, we saw men dressed as belie dancers, snake charmers, sot of tag type boxing, discussions, music, drums, all the people.Eating in the square, go on risk it if you dare to eat at the white tented portable restaurants, its a sort of meza, so order a few dishes as they are small, but well worth it, sit on one of the roof terraces and watch all the fun from above its mesmerising.You can not drink alcohol in the square, but it doesnt matter.You have to haggle hard, they do think all tourists have a lot of money, and they don't like coming under a 100DHR, thats around 8.50 Euro, even if its worth it or not, it is easy to get carried away n negotiations, and I have noticed over the time coming hear, that they defiantly want more for the goods then before, but thats inflation, lots of imported stuff and also hand made Moroccan stuff, they will start at stupid prices to throw you thin k what its worth to you and stick with that, the spice square is a great place to go for a coffee the smells are fantastic, I always buy Amba block and oil as its a lovely smell, you can walk around for hours, having a chat, they all sell the same things but its just lovely looking and buying if your a woman !!, Silver jewellery is great lots off it, again haggle hard, as they think they are selling you gold ha ha, its fun, and I often got called Berba lady!! oh well, i explained we also work hard for this money.I felt very save hear, i am blond and blue eyes and i was with my husband, and still caused a stir, but did were a scarf at night, in the day just shorts and vest, and that was fine.Its not a place to put your glad rags on, maxi dress are good really.Have fun

Worth visiting. It is pretty hard NOT to visit the square while in Marrakeach. We enjoyed seeing it both day and night. On the advice of our Riad we went to the Cafe Glacier terrace at 5:30pm to watch the stalls setting up for the night. You pay 20DH for a soft drink, but it seemed worthwhile to be able to view the activity below.

Must see in the evening. I visited the square during the day with my wife and was greatly disappointed to find it bare with a few stalls. However we returned later to find it buzzing with people, stalls and entertainment. It gives you a great experience of the culture which may be a little overwhelming but a visit to Marrakech would be incomplete without a trip to the square one evening.

Very vibrant place. Very vibrant place especially at night you can have a lot of fun, the food was extremely delicious and good prices, not for tourists :))) if you are a tourist they give you a very big price and that sucks

hustle and bustle, shoppers delight. loved it! some people said they had lots of hassle but we didnt find that. yes, people would try and get you into their shops, but just smile and say no thanks, and firmly walk on. no problems. haggling was great fun, take what they say, drop 2 thirds and make an offer. if you get it at half the original price it is a good buy.

The touristic side of Marrakech. Jemaa el Fna is Marrakech's most touristic place. It's the place you see in all marrakech's pictures and postcards. For that reason it a mandatory place to visit, however be prepare to enter a "tourist" zone that is packed with street vendors and that get quite aggressive in trying you to buy something. For the classic shot make sure you get to see the sun-set from one of the balconies of a coffee shop.

Lost in marakech. Crazy place Keep your wits about you this is an experience you won't forget. You must visit this place bustling with musicians playing authentic music street performers,market traders, snake charmers, more street performers surrounded by crowds and henna tattooists all out to rip you off . if your European they want your money and as much as they can blag out of you. The price starts high and is not cheap with counterfeit goods everywhere genuine copies they will tell you,make sure you start very low when they give you a price aim for a third of what they are asking for is what you want to pay.walk around and everyone wants to show you what they have hastle is not the word,smile and say no thank you then keep walking as they follow you up the street, take a photo and they demand money. We walked off the square through the narrow streets with mopeds scathing past us every other minute horns bibbing,keep your wits about you as you will be going on a magical mystery tour. we found ourselves walking down passages off the square, a left then a right and before we knew it we were away from the tourists and in the land of the Moroccans all wanting to be your guide and yes wanting money,sending you left,right,not a nice place to be lost with sense of direction gone looking the same and no landmarks to be seen with the high walls and narrow passages and the stench of leather at 34 degrees at 8.30 pm it's sweltering hot Horse and carts squeezing by and street sellers trying to drag you in to buy goods After about an hour and half and asking shop owners the way back Being sent on a wild goose chase We finally got back to the square seeing other tourists on the way looking out of place and also lost we had mad it with a feeling of a safer place in the open my wife hated it as it was not her thing Luckily our hotel was ten minutes away, I love the markets but let me tell you I could not wait to get out back to the hotel and relax maybe I will try on the day time which I did by myself the mrs declined the 2 nd visit.Going earlier in the morning is a better time to go having learnt my lesson from the evening visit,the daytime was a little clearer to me I could see where I was going and knew if I walk up a passage to walk back don't take the left and rights as it's like a maze, I stopped at a rooftop bar and got a cold drink watching the mad place get busier and busier.I haggled for a while in a shop for a few items starting price 1800 dogs bought it for 600 and headed back certainly an overload to the brain but worth the experience.My friend was also there with his girlfriend and told me on his evening visit someone tried to mug him demanding money so have your eyes open they befriend you but want your money. I went out clubbing in the new town and went to the so bar very good place on a rooftop by the casino live music had a great night. Went to the VIP club down the street 200 dhs £15 for a small bottle of Heineken rip off or what stayed for a while and went back to the hotel free beer there all inclusive is a must it is very expensive for drinks being it is a dry county. Would I go back yes if it was a free holiday but would I pay to go back I don't think so . Read my review on medina garden the couples hotel we stayed at 10 minute walk from the hustle and bustle of the markets
Crazy but fun.. Noisy, dangerous, eye opening. Good bargains. Kept away from the snake charmers and monkey people. Popcorn 15p!

Does Jemma El Fna mean con central?. This place is rampant with con artist of every sort. I warn you be very careful with the women approaching you for "free" henna tattoos. I knew it would not be free and told the girl I was not interested and was out of money. She told me not to worry about it as it would only be a small sample free tattoo. Next thing she grabbed my hand and started with the ink. I continuously told her I have no money with me. Then the price jumped to 500 dirham and when she finished it was a 1000 dirham.she and her "sister" kept following me around screaming that I had better pay. This went on for about five minutes and thank goodness I was pretty close to the tourist police office and went straight there to report the incident. Everywhere you go someone is trying to get money off of you for any and everything. Even the snake charmer tried to make me take a picture up close which I refused as I had heard they sneak and place them around people's necks and ask for payment to remove it. I wasn't going to literally risk having heart attack or fainting (literally) for that. He accused me of taking a photo which I did not and started shouting that I owed him money. I got the hell out of there. This square is only worth going to if you're going to Cafe Glaces for drinks and watch the crowds from above especially at night. My grade: D

Moroccan Circus. Fascinating jumble of vendors, snake charmers and acrobats. Haggle hard, prices can be four times elsewhere or save your shopping for Essouira where prices are much less and the vendors less aggressive. Worth having a drink on a rooftop terrace that overlooks the square and watching the endless parade of people.

Fascinating. Likes: Atmosphere, snake charmers, general feel of the place. Best at night when the food stalls are set up and the atmosphere is buzzing.
Dislikes: Begging kids who pester you and then deliver a mouthful of very robust anglo saxon when you don't give them anything.

Local Colour. Good cafés and restaurants round square many with terraces.
Too many snake charmers and ladies wanting to paint your hands
with henna.
Could be a bit intimidating at night for lone travellers or newcomers to the city.

Fun and vibrant at night. During the day the place is almost empty and the sun weights heavily while at dusk the food stalls get installed and there is much banter and laughs between the restaurant hawkers and the potential patrons. The food is not the best Morocco has to offer but the show is definitely worth it. The orange juice and the dates are best. The place is large and busy and the tourists do not outnumber the locals.

Huge!. We first arrived late one evening and wow, hugh numbers of people, enjoying themselves. Very crowded. Go after breakfast, when it's quieter, and you can see more and appreciate the size of the place.

The squre full of life and adventure. You can walk, buy, eat... tables and stands where you can get traditional food in a flash. They went out of their way to accommodate our huge group - even too much so, pushing a poor couple down to the end of the table to sit with us so there would be room for everybody. Chaotic and fun. Great food at street prices. in the square always nice to get a freshly squeezed Orange Juice.But be careful, to not respond to solicitation - ignore, unless you want to be followed around. Unfortunately even small children are sent out to try and sell you things. One little boy of maybe 5 years old would not leave us alone. The older children kept egging him on. Very sad. Even after we gave him some coins he stayed. Poor thing.Also be ware of pick-pockets and people proposing to get henna hand-drawings. Some friends got taken in by it and the price soared, and in addition it was not even real henna, perhaps some sort of ink.Only get henna done through people you know or through your Riyad or hotel. Do not take any chances.Otherwise, this is the obvious place everyone must go to in Marrakesh...

Crazy place - a one off!. Not surpassed it is a heritage sight - it really is a one off. Two different personalities - by day a hubbub of stalls and entertainers and by a collection of about a hundred pop up restaurants/street for stalls. Good to experience, but you do get an awful lot of hassle from pushy sellers and demands for money to take photos. At night the food stalls were good value and food seemed safe enough; but the pushy sales was even more intense and sometimes accompanied by very aggressive rudeness - so mixed feelings really; but you can't go to Marrakech and not experience the Jemaa el Fna

Get ready to say NO. I really like this city but it's a pitty that you don't dare to ask how much things costs because otherwise you will have the seller over you until you get tired! The best way to pass shop after shops it's just saying NO to the sellers. I wanted to see the cobras and the guy just put a snake on my neck. I didn't mind much but then he wanted to get notes and no coins. He wanted us to pay 20 euros (200 dirham) for few pictures.Otherwise, this is one of the cheapest place to eat (2 people including drinks, 9 euros) and the food is pretty good.

Market Square the only night attraction.... interesting but basic.for the hygiene freeks....food stalls in the evening might be an issue.Cutlery/dishes just dunked in a bucket of water and reused, flies are accepted as normal and part of sweet offerings on the stalls.Some genuine very good offerings, a spice drink "tea" from number 69 from a very pleasant old man and all the fresh orange juice bars...a must.
Fascinating place. Just wonderful to experience the sights sounds and smells of this wonderful place Delicious street food, music, snake charmers, water bearers the lot!

Crazy place. Beautiful lights and energy, I wish I could go back ! All the smells and different colours, make you feel like taking part of tale of ancient times. The tiny streets and the bike and all the life going on is so refreshing. Better go there by night though, cause during th day you've got all these sellers harassing you, which is to me very annoying. But overall a nice place to visit at least once in a life time ! :)

Chaos at its best. Great place to really get in to the Moroccan way of life. Loads of stalls and entertainers to watch but be warned that they will expect money if you want to take a photo but it is a nominal amount if you haggle. Also you can get a glass of orange juice for 4dhm which is about 30p and it is just great, don't be put off by them all beckoning you to there stall, just pick one and stick to it. Also after having a work around I would definitely recommend going into one of the bars around the square and getting a drink on the roof terrace and just take it all in. Great place that is a must if in Morocco.

BONKERS!. BONKERS! .....Not my term, but the opinion of several people staying at our riad. I can see why. This was my third visit to this vibrant, wonderful city and I don't think I shall ever tire of returning night after night to Jmaa el Fna. It's quite easy to see why it is a world heritage site. It is a perfect showcase for berber culture, especially music. A wonderful evening's entertainment, not to be missed.

The Main Square. All life is here,lots to do see and eat.Plenty of taxis,but make sure you agree the price in the currency beforhand,they will often try to double the price at the end and charge for each passenger

Contrasts. The famous square is loud, chaotic, colorful and tourist trap. Don't go there if you appreciate your private space. After traveling whole of Morroco you can se the prices are really REALLY high there and the sense of beeing only a bag of money is constant. It is someting to see and live, but in contrast you are shocked with animal treatment and lack of respect there. Don't eat food there, even locals get diarrhea, go in the restaurants.
full of crap, hustlers and animal abuse. You will inevitably end up here because it is the only landmark to help navigate the souks. The chained monkeys are pretty depressing

A must ..... Full of people, tourists, snakes....Crazy, chaotic, lively, colorful, a must see if in Marrakech. Be sure to go INTO the bazaar allies and truly experience all there is. Don't be afraid to barter. I always start at 1/10th of the asking price. Even if you aren't buying it is worth visiting just for the experience, sites, and sounds.

Crazy!. This famous square is great for people watching. You can watch snake charmers, soothsayers, acrobats, dancers and drummers. You can have your fortune told, henna applied to your skin, have a monkey sit on you for a photo and eat freshly grilled meat or couscous. The energy in this square is just amazing and fun. There is so much going on its hard to take it all in. If you get there early you could grab a seat up on a terrace overlooking the square and have a terrific view. Apparently pick pockets like the square too, so watch your valuables.
Disappointing!. Unfortunately over the years, this world heritage place has become such a tourist trap that more & more people want to spent as less time as possible on this square.

Bustling with the whole population of Marrakech. This is a very lively square once it hits about 6pm and feels like the whole of Marrakech visits here everyday. Certainly a sight worth seeing...though the noise and crowds become a bit too much after a few days!

A must see, but .... Been to Marrakech several times and coming here is a must each visit. As others have said, you have to be on the lookout for pick pockets and those looking to take advantage. If you want to take a photo of a snake charmer or monkey, be prepared to pay 5-10 dhms for it (and for them to hound you for more). Lots of shops in the Medina - found a great leather shop about a 10 minute walk from the square with lots of beautiful things you don't see in other places. It does get more lively at night. Look forward to Cafe Arganne reopening, a great place to dine at night. Make sure you go upstairs so you can see out.

Yeah! Chaos. I'm an economist and just love seeing these vibrant markets. Yeah, it gets chaotic. Yeah, bargaining can get annoying if you're wedded to Western fixed prices, but to see how really competitive markets operate and hear it is such fun for me, I just don't care about the negatives. Get some orange juice. It's about 50 cents (US) a glass and extraordinarily tasty.

Crazy place at nighttime!. We visited here during the day and were surprised that there was nothing really to see but we were told to go back at nighttime and the place was transformed with hundreds of food stalls, entertainers, hawkers and thousands of visitors! Well worth at lead tone visit

Exotic circus like air, but stay focused. But careful with the vendors. Although i did not want to hold a monkey, quicky the man had 2 of them on me. And one urinated down my back.Smells of horse urine can be strong but the site is a must for the marrekeck visitor

You must go!!. If you are a tourist, you must go! It's fairly quiet during the daytime but when the sun sets, the place is alive. Acrobats, snake charmers, food stalls, monkeys, drums, people selling their wares, etc. There is always something to see. You must go. One fun and crazy place. You can have a drink/dinner at a rooftop bar overlooking the square and even watch the sun go down from there. Wear comfy shoes and bring a camera. Bring 10 dhs to give to the performers/snake charmers so you can take a picture. Bring sunscreen during the day as it is very hot. Don't miss this!!

Another world. By day busy with snake charmers, monkeys, merchants etc, by night full of life with entertainers, restaurants, quite manic in fact. Our friends felt intimidated and could not wait to leave, we on the other hand were totally fascinated by it all. Very different to London!
Crazy place!. So atmospheric, so busy and intense, but a must-see. Keep your wits about you but enjoy the different sights and the change from daytime to night time!

Amazing. I love this place so much. It is an experience that can not be explained, you have to experience it personally. Its the only place to go after a busy afternoons getting lost in the Soukes. Find a spot either in one of the restaurants that over look the square or I like to sit on the steps of the post office, you get a great view of everything. I like to watch the food stalls being set up, then watching them haggle their trade, the snake charmers and the acrobats and course do not miss the sun set.
A must for anyone. Jemaa el Fna comes alive at sunset when the temperatures cool. Be ready to haggle, answer questions, and smile a lot!

One of life's unique experiences. We went to watch the sunset from one of the many cafe's in Jemaa el Fna. Wow! What an experience to see the gradual opening of all the food stalls, the entertainment - acrobats, snake charmers, dancing etc. - and the growing numbers of visitors, many of the locals, who come to the square to buy goods, be entertained, and eat and enjoy. You won't forget the experience!

Special. Upon arriving late in the evening in Marrakech, i went straight out in to the Market Square. Wall to wall madness. Sellers are very pushing and you often have to be forceful / rude to get them to leave you alone. Not for the feint hearted - if you don't like haggling, this is not the place for you! Great atmosphere though.

What else can be said apart from a must do in Marrakech!. I can't say much that hasn't been said, just that it is a must visit place if your in Marrakech. Chaotic and charming all in one. Even if you don't eat or buy anything, it's worth a visit in the day and by night to soak up the sights and smells.

Amazing!!. I have heard so much about this place, and it did not disappoint - fantastic atmosphere, noise, people, snake charmers, dancers, food - I loved it! For the price of a soft drink, approx. £1.50, got access to the roof terrace overlooking the square to take in all the sights, smells and sounds. Don't miss it at night.
You have to go if you are in Marrakech. Interesting experience, some fun haggling and buying souveniers, good buzz. Hot, crowded and a little smelly. Has to be done though.

At the French cafe on top of terrace. You can expend a nice ice cream. Coffee tea or what ever not alcohol though.At the terrace. Watching how people passing trough the place. Also the vista is expecpitonal.

Bustling Square with lots of shopping and culture. Loved the energy and feel of the market and photo opportunities. Negotiated for beautiful silk scarves, leather sandals, bracelets and belts. Observed local life. I didn't like the aggressive women pushing henna tattoos or the monkeys on chains who weren't treated well.

A must-see. You're not going to visit Marrakech without coming here, so ignore silly "don't bother" comments.Yes, there are people with snakes or monkeys, or there are dancers trying to get you to part with a few dirhams.It is hectic, if not quite as hassling as I expected. The juice stands are a great deal and tasty, the food stands less so. See all angles - get immersed in it at ground level, and also see the constant life and motion from cafe terrace level.My own favourites were the story telling / music / sort-of boxing fights going on.It won't be the greatest place you've ever seen, but it is memorable and fun.
A festival of sights sounds and smells. See it from a roof top from a neighboring cafe/restaurant as night is falling. Great sunset and great view of the night market below.
thrilling. fantastic shopping experience just have to barter a lot in the heat can be very irritating much cheaper then shops

Loud. Better at night when the musicians are out. If you don't like crowds this is not the place for you. Plenty of restaurants around with rooftop terraces were you can have a coffee and watch the crowds.

dont bother. smelly dirty urine soaked bad entertainment just few men playing gnawa music intermittently. street kids in dirty clothes doing acrobatics then demanding money from tourists whom they see as atms bad attitude badly or not educated felt in danger

The beginning of everything. Caotic, so many people with so much to show and to see!!! Henna ladies, monkeys, snakes, music… and the beginning to visit the souks or just to find a nice terrace to enjoy the chaos from up!

Not as fab as its made out to be. This was pretty average, lots of stalls, lots to see, but not too sure about the hot food..stayed clear. The fresh orange juice was nice also bought some lovely baskets. The surrounding cafes sold nice food and tea and good views of Marrakech from the balcony cafes.

Madness. Upon arriving late in the evening in Marrakech, i went straight out in to the Market Square. Wall to wall madness. Sellers are very pushing and you often have to be forceful / rude to get them to leave you alone. Not for the feint hearted - if you don't like haggling, this is not the place for you! Great atmosphere though.
Crazy but great place to visit. What an experience. It was amazing; the things for sale, the people, the animals. Can't really put it in to words. It's a must visit to see it yourself

Great vibe at night!. This place has a brilliant vibe at night! Was a totally different scene in the day time. Lots of local performers from dancers + singers to street fighting. Tip: Beware of a few shifty locals and look after your belongings! If you take photos of the performers expect to pay them or they can get nasty!

I was dissappointed / My husband loved it. Having heard so much about the 'magic square' I found it had little magic in it. There was a lot of noise and smoke from the food stalls, and this was added to by dancers accompanied with drums beating monotonously for the whole evening except whilst it was prayer time. Having been told of the wonderful jugglers and acobats I would see I saw just a few who performed a few tricks at one edge of the square for about five minutes and then they were gone. The snakes not at all charmed, just lay on the ground under sacks, and by the end of the evening I wanted to join them.My husband thought it was all wonderful and couldn't get enough of it - he even went back on his own one evening,

Lovely shopping. Went in August so very hot in the day walking around the markets, some places a bit smelly but it was everything i expected, get your haggling on and get some good bargains like a did. Would definitely love to come back to Marrakesh and do some shopping here
Bubbly. So many different things going on. My favorite was the pick pocketing monkeys. The food stalls has all sorts of different things and the snake charmers were great

Exciting, exhausting, frustrating sensory overload. Yep, anther plaza/square/old town, for tourists... And so much more. If you are at all into history, music, culture, simply do not miss this place at night. Touts? Yes. You need to have your thick tourist-skin on, comparable to India/Nepal style touting, but not quite as intense. Dodgy food? Sure, and oh my, did I get sick. I mean, vomit-fever-delirium-for-2-days sick. I rolled the dice on a delicious mutton, walnut, and fig tagine. That was some serious stuff...But it was all worth the spectacle and the adrenaline rush of the Djemma, a phenomenon that dates back hundreds of--maybe a thousand or more--years, of music, trade, and story telling, folks from all over the Maghreb and even across the Sahara, creating this convergence of cultures that are still living and breathing in this square. The sights of belly dancers, snake charmers, and flashes of fire and smoke pouring from the food stalls, this is why I travel. And the music was particularly fascinating to me (a music nerd), reminiscent of west African, Arabian, Berber, Andalusian and even a little rock influence, which sounded especially eerie coming from distorted amps. Jump in, join the crowds, try the snails and a glass of fresh orange juice--just make sure you eat where the crowds are, and not where the nice but lonely man begs you to eat. Old mutton will take you right out of the game, and that's no fun. Found a new appreciation for mint tea and those round seeded buns, anyways. So, it's a win-win.
Good place to meet pocket thief in the evening. It is considered as touristic must - but I think it is better to stay away from it. Crowds and darkness is a perfect combintation for pockets thieves.

Beware. Beware of chancers and hawkers suddenly foisting animals around your unsuspecting child's neck and demanding cash. They can be quite aggressive. My advice is to be on your guard and be firm but polite.
Wonderful. Great experience, hustle and bustle! Snake charmers, henna ladies, monkeys, and amazing at night, the whole place comes alive. Well worth a visit.
Busy. What an eye-opener!! A definite must, just keep your common sense with you and you'll have a great day out

Lively & energetic but tacky & congested. We went there everyday for lunch and or supper, but only tried the evening food stalls twice. The food stall waiters are incredibly in your face pushy, my children got very upset by the relentless harassment. I was really looking forward to eating on the evening food stalls after Jamie Oliver had raved about them in a TV programme a few years back. Both stalls we tried tagines and barbecued meat skewers. Each time we were disappointed with the flavour and the quality of the meat. Relatively bland and flavourless.We had much better tagines and lamb + chicken skewers in some of the restaurants + cafes around the square. Our favourite was a small cafe called Snack Issafen. Whilst it appeared initially to only offer sandwiches + paninis, they do in fact do an awesome beef+prune tagine. So good I had it 3 times in the 7 days I was there. Really delicious sweet and sour sauce, I mopped the tagine dry with my bread each time.
