My kids are fussy eaters and they initially stuck to the Spaghetti bolognese and chicken Paninis - which they really enjoyed. My daughter loves Spag Bol and she thinks this was one of the best ones she has ever had! The lamb + chicken skewers were also cooked perfectly and full of flavour as was the Couscous I tried once.The stalls selling merchandise were a great mix of tacky, ripoff and cheap. Some stalls charging twice as much as the next stall for the exact same item. My wife bought several kaftans for just 40MAD each - absolute bargain!Night time this place gets crazy packed and absolutely buzzing with life - western tourists, Moroccan tourists, snake charmers, hawkers - an absolute buzz! We often bought mint tea and ice cream and sat and soaked up the energy.

Eating at night is an adventure!. During the day, Jemaa el Fna is a great souk. It has everything you would expect in a major bazaar, including straw hats for $1 and leather poufs (cushions) that make great footstools and souvenirs. Be sure to haggle over everything and don't think about starting at 50% of his listed price, start at 5%. But the Night Market, with all of the food stalls, is the absolute best. It took me days to get the courage to eat there but I'm glad I did. We had fresh seafood, beef, vegetarian dishes, and I even tried the peppery snail soup. Very tasty and clean. We ate all of our meals there for five days and deliberately tried as many stalls as possible for variety and to test how safe it was so we could recommend it to friends. Not a single problem. Of course, we used common sense. We ate primarily at busy stalls where we assumed food turnover was high and thus produce was fresh, and we had food that was cooked well and could be identified visually. And we didn't have any tap water or any salad that would be washed in tap water. But overall, it was fine and so worthwhile.

Exotic atmosphere. This is a must-see in Marrakech. It's a very arabic square with tiny carts where they sell amazing freshly pressed orange juice for about 50 cents. So tasty! At night there are many tents where they barbeque meat and vegetables. The best place to eat dinner in Marrakech, for sure. Not too expensive either. Of course they can be a little pushy to get you to enter their tent, but that's how ut is all around. There are also some people out to make money by selling services like henna tattoos or cheap cell phone copies, but these are easy to avoid if you want to. There are snake tamers and donkeys here, simply a great north african experience.
Wow but be careful. Not to be missed but be prepared to be a bit harranged by children, shop owners and ladies trying to henna tattoo. So amazing though, well worth it.

Interesting, if a little intimidating.... The positives: first impressions - like nothing I'd ever seen before, so much to see, some nice cafes around it, and a good reference point for navigating the cityThe negatives: getting hassled a lot, some overpriced cafes around ripping off tourists, my boyfriend got henna squirted at him after I declined a henna tattoo, I got grabbed again after declining a henna tattoo...just stay really far away from the ladies with big syringes.In summary - best seen from a rooftop cafe where you can watch everything but avoid the hassle!

Amazing Experience! Take at Least Two Trips. What an amazing experience. I recommend to go there at least twice, first time I went I felt extremely overwhelmed and didn't enjoy it but once I got used to it I was fine, this made me get two more trips in while I was on holiday.I would go to the market closer to the newer part of the city first so you get a rough idea of prices before splashing out in the square.People are friendly and helpful but hold your ground when it comes to the price. Have a rough price in your head before you enter a souk and stick to it. Motorbikes go flying down the narrow paths in the souks so watch your toes.I recommend wearing sunglasses so souk owners can't see you looking directly at their shop otherwise they swarm you (but in a non aggressive way) haha.Lots of cafes around the square so you can sit up high and get quality photos with a drink, it was just amazing taking in all the sights and smells. Its probably more enjoyable if you're in bigger groups too. Go here for a great experience and new culture :)

Fantastic, cultural experience - not for the nervy!. A little empty and very hot during the day in summer months, dancers, storytellers and some acrobats ( requiring a small fee)are around but mainly touters for pony and carriage rides! HOWEVER, night time is a whole different experience, the noise, smell and sound far outweighs the sights (which are pretty spectacular). Keep you wits about you and if travelling in a group or with younger ones keep them close by as its very busy. Most traders are fair and decent but we did encounter some problems, two of our group (both female) were blocked by a couple of men from a café who stopped them from moving forward and insisted they ate at 'their' stand. We spotted this and recovered them only to be spat at and told we should go home as we were disgusting! We laughed and moved on (not to let it spoil our evening), not a nice experience but part of the culture!

Over-rated, and overly cruel. I expected Jemaa el Fna to be a huge square full of life when actually is was little more than a few stalls with a circus in the middle.I am a well travelled person but one thing i cannot tolerate is cruely to animals. I would advise any animal lovers out there to be careful when visiting as caged monkeys is bad enough, however seeing a crazed man with a handful of snakes throwing them all over the pavement left me and my family both angry and upset. I would avoid if possible.

Hectic. During the day, this was a fun experience looking around the markets with the locals. However, at night, I got lost with two of my friends (we are all girls). The place became very intimidating as there were men around who would grab you inappropriately and there were no women around which makes you feel vulnerable. It is important to politely decline offers from souk sellers who you do not want to buy from or they can become offended.Overall a good experience with a diverse range of products.I would recommend purchasing leather goods, spices and Berber medicine.

Love or hate it ?!. Well we loved it.Saw it at different times of day and night - obviously a lot busier at night. Some lovely cafes around the perimeter to retreat to. Most people would leave you alone once you had greeted them and quite firmly told them you didn't wish to purchase what they were selling. A smile goes a long way as well as an attempt at Arabic or French.Great juices and photo opportunities.The sound of music and drums will drive you mad after a while!

# 117 and 43. Rude, obnoxious, physically pushy touts from the food stalls. # 43 called my wife a name. Often heard derogatory remarks towards the English. My children felt threatened overwelmed especially #117. Not value for money at all. My advise is to use restaurants on the 'Jemaa El Fna' peripheries.

Be part of the hustle. Jemaa el Fna is a place everyone know about, but to be there, to smell the food, hear people asking/begging you to come and eat at their table, the snake dancers and the little girls selling tissues, this all you have to experience first hand. We had one of our best meals for the cheapest price ever and the cake vendors with the little art works on their carts are the cherry on top. No trip to Marrakesh can ever be completed, without a dinner at Jemaa el Fna.

The Lovely Chaos. You can feel you are in a different plaza as you visit this place in a different time of the day. From the almost market less and overdriven one in the noon to the open air greatest food stands´ meeting point as the sun goes down...

The heart of Marrakech. Love this square. It is huge with lots of spices, fruits and action. Be prepared to be hassled, but nowhere near as bad as the Souk. The night market is fantastic with plenty of stalls brimming with all sorts of foods. A great experience

Love this place. The whole atmosphere is fantastic, just remember to haggle. You can buy anything from this 'market', it is huge! Just watch out for the monkey people, they will come up behind you and put the monkey on your shoulder, if your not quick enough they will charge you. So be aware.

crazy madness. Nothing quite like this place! Crazy enough in the day but at night-time it comes alive and is even busier and noisier, lights and smoke, snakes and monkeys, people playing drums, trying to sell you mobile phones, trying to sell you excursions and all kinds of goods.

Crowded. A very bustling, busy, crowded place full of all the local tastes and spices. Can seem very pushy, and in your face if travelling alone. But well worth a visit, both during the day and again at night

Big, nothing special. A very large open-air square with horses, 'shops' and restaurants. In the summer is almost impossible to be there due to the hot temperatures. Like Morocco, not very clean and you can't feel very safe in there.

Mint, orange juice, food, entertaiment. It is like going back in the time. Especially in the evening time and late in the night.Next to markets that are more around the square, it is place for entertainment and food.In corner you find stalls with mint herbs for mint tea - it smells very good ;)Some people go to restaurants up on roofs to enjoy the view.

The Heart of the City. Don't listen to all the people afraid of their own shadow - go and get involved - sit and listen to the music , buy the odd nicknak, defo try the orange juice and then get totally lost in the souks (inevitable) yes some traders are pushy but a no and a smile is all that's needed - also only pay a 1/3 of any price asked (or at least start your bargaining there) enjoy!

a different world. Very interesting place. A lot is happening here. It is always fun to walk around, buy things and notice all sorts of unusual things. It is like being in a very weird movie. It can be overwhelming at times if you are in a hurry but magical otherwise.
Hot and busy. Here it is very hot and busy. Be prepared to be hassled and you will be fine. Just say no politely and keep walking and enjoy your surroundings, sights and sounds.

A square to remember. You will obviously go here if you go to Marrakech. It is unavoidable and worth visiting although I don't think I'd want to spend a whole lot of time here. It's worth checking out at night, when it really comes alive with hundreds of people from all walks of life. We saw snake charmers, performing monkeys, carnival games, live music, food stalls and when we were there some guys lifting weights. Just take in the sights, hold your belongings close and enjoy!
Main Square. I loved the intimate but warm feeling of this place. famous square, Snake charmers and monkeys, The food stalls look great.... .

Great place at night. My husband and I loved the square at night. Yes- be on the watch for scammers (think Carny), but overall people are friendly and if you put your wallet in your front pocket- you should have nothing to worry about.

Must visit.. A must visit when you go to Marrakech! Great food, you can eat on balconies overlooking the square and nearby souks. It's a great cultural centre as well. Snake charmers and henna artists scatter the pavement in the day, but it really starts to heat up at night. Be mindful of your belongings, make sure to try the freshly squeezed juice, and expect to pay if you want to take pictures of the locals!

Large area of Tarmac. Snake charmers and drummers set the scene for crowds that gather around to watch these poor tormented reptiles. Horse drawn carriages for tourists criss cross the square in the general hub bub as the inhabitants of Marrakech go about their business. Cafés offer mint tea and coffee etc and light meals and snacks. In the evenings it comes alive with food sellers who cook as you sit and watch them prepare your meal.

The best in the WORLD!!. In this famous square are numerous stalls selling orange juice and dried fruits ...will let you try 1 piece of dried fruit, but of course if you try more than 1 your buying it !I wanted to try the orange juice ..... and WOW ! this was the best I have had anywhere in the world ! it was amazing and cheap .... a large glass for 4 dirhams $.50 US cents ..... it was soo good that I had 3 glasses of it even though I wasn't thirsty ! it was soooo good that I just kept drinking it !!!!!! the vendor made the glasses right in front of me !!!!!!!!!The vendor was real nice and even allowed me to take a photo behind his booth !!!!!! for a change he wasn't aggressive ......A MUST DO ! too bad they don't sell it by the gallons, because I would have bought some .... I'm sure if you had a container they would sell it to you !!!! so come prepared because it's that good !!!!
Smellie!! But fun. Hot, orange juice lovely!!! Smellie as you can imagine with all the horses and donkeys!! Great place so much happening!!!

Family holiday. Amazing experience - unlike anything I have seen before. Colourful, crazy, fun and mental in the words of my daughter! You can avoid the snake charmers and monkeys if you want. Henna was very expensive - cheaper at ensemble artisanal Night market a completely different experience again, prepare to be mobbed by food vendors and hypnotised by tribal music.

Must visit. If you are firm and polite, you shouldn't have any issues here. The square has an incredible atmosphere at day and at night - definitely come at both times. I had dinner at the street stalls on multiple occasions and never had any problems with the food, though the vendors themselves can be very pushy. At any time of day, be careful what you are taking photos of - you will be charged if you try and take a photo of anything that looks like it may be set up for tourists!The orange juice from the carts during the day is really good, though I went with female friends and we got invited up into the cart for photos - the man used this as a chance to grope us (universal...)! Despite this, it's a really interesting place and is definitely a must see.
Crazy square. People watching heaven very scary though you have to have your witt's about you here. The locals try and charge you even if you take a picture of the scene

A must visit but the people are annoying. It's great to go and experience the main square, both during the day and after sunset as most books say. The place has a very different character at each of these times. However, it's not really anything special. The food stalls look great lit up with all of the steam but the people are so pushy, in your face and a general pain that it makes it a bit tiring constantly saying no or swerving the idiots who try to touch you and lead you into their stall or store. Worth a visit but you're only going to love it if you like busyness and annoying people.

Not the best of Marrakech. I have read many enthusiastic comments about this place but I cannot share them. We have been there and also had dinner but I must say that it looks a little bit too much touristic for me. Nice but I think that this is not the best thing to be seen in Marrakech.

The heart of Marrakech but beware of the henna tattooists!. Fabulous 'heart' of Marrakech. You will constantly be drawn back here at different times of the day. Be careful at night if you are a woman/women on your own, because the henna tattooists are likely to try and gram your arm and give you a tattoo, whether you want it or not. They then demand money for this. My daughter and I got caught but I told them from the outset that I would not be paying them and did not. However, if you do feel obliged to pay, do not give more than 50 Dirham for one hand. They will ask for anything between 200-600 dirham. The main concern though, is that they tend to mix hair dyes with the henna, so you can never be sure what is in their mixture!

Yay you went there, now you will regret it. The main square is the heart of the Medina and entrance to the Souks but there's nothing spectacular about it. It's large, noisy, has a very strong odor and you have vendors walking right up in your face and trying to force something into your hands. We actually had to physically run away from one man trying to force us to buy things, because in Marrakesh once you touch it you buy it. There's nothing impressive there at all, just a bunch of wagons and street vendors that will rip you off.

Sights, but also noise and tourist traps. It's definitely worth visiting, and having a drink on one of the terraced cafes overlooking the city at sunset. Beware photographing the snake charmers, who will angrily hunt you down and demand money. Other vendors will pursue you -- keep your purse or wallet safe. Many entrances to the souk here; find a rally point if you and companions get lost. Most Riad hotels are a good walk from this square, but it's a great central location for finding your way back. Restaurants all serve the same stuff; boring after a few meals, so be prepared.

Amazing. What an amazing experience especially sitting at a restaurant overlooking the square watching it change from day to night. I wouldn't walk around dressed inappropriately especially at night. However if you dress without being 'on display' its fine. The colours, smells, sights are truly wonderful.

Not as expected. We visited the square on four occasions during our recent holiday, in the morning, afternoon (2) and evening.Overall we enjoyed each visit but the evening was not as good as we expected. Perhaps the wish to sample food at different stalls was an issue as the stall holders often said "everything is the same and you should come to me not him"The people selling rip off items became a bit tiresome.

Awful. Visited this square at first during the day. The entrance is pleasant enough with some stalls selling dates and fresh fruit juices, but approaching the centre we came across the sad sight of monkeys in chains and snake charmers, and if you stop for a moment or try to take a photo there'll inevitably be someone there demanding money or attempting to give you a henna tattoo.We decided to give it a second chance and visit at night, but this time it was just plain awful. As you approach the multiple food stalls which are set up in the evenings, you are harassed left, right and centre to eat at the respective stalls. One of the stall owners actually pushed my friend after he declined and attempted to prevent him from walking around his stall, and after I said no to another stall owner the guy swore at me and threw up his middle finger! Eventually we conceded and sat down at one place where unfortunately I had the worst tajine I've ever tasted (watery and bland, I think the vegetables were just cooked in plain stock) and had one mouthful of a chicken dish where the chicken was clearly off.The square just feels like an area that is there purely for the exploitation of tourists. It's intense, and that's fine, but there isn't really much that's authentic or pleasant to experience or see here.

quite scary. We went to the sqaure as its called at night very very busy people every where; beggers pik pockets u do have to be careful howeva great experience and if ur up for it be firm and haggle urself a bargain horse an cart was great also suks very good for costs mountain trips was an experience to a lot of up hill climbes no good for the unfit an u don't get to go in the water we were very hot stay at the bottom in the water

It's getting worst and worst. . Today, I've been shocked. I have seen a horse on the ground. He fell. But, the driver forced him to stand up, in despite of his injuries and his tiredness. This is the driver 264, please, in respect of the horses, don't get on his "trash". Moreover, there is more and more peddlers, and year by year, it's getting worst. There is no legislation, and Morrocean government should take care of his twelfth most visited attraction. That's awful. Really. I'm disgusted.
Must see and experience. Go at night, find a bar or restaurant with an outside terrace and soak in the atmosphere. This is a must see, amazing and interesting city part of the city to visit.

Exploited and overpriced!. The square has two different personalities - by day the desperate sellers and our guide said by night a much more authentic experience. The use of animals isn't pretty - chained monkeys being dragged around and forced to perform for tourists and snake charmers who will demand money for any pictures of snakes taken and harrass you until you pay.Cafes around the outside such as the Glacier café are nice to spend time watching the square and worth a visit

Lively nightlife. I can recommend this place for those who don't mind the crowd and want to see how local people spend their free time. This is the square where most people meet. During the day there's a market. But at night it's totally different. We can find here dancers, serpent-charmers, small restaurants, cafès etc. It belongs to the 'real' city, or at least that's how a tourist sees it.

not as expected. This is one of the things people want to see but for me it wasn't that nice as everyone says it has animal cruelty one the scene only thing good is you can drink Verry good fruit juice fresh and eat some good things by night but there where lots of begging and that is not nice

Marrakech Magic. No visit to Marrkech is complete without a visit to Jemma el Fna at night. The Main Square comes alive around 9 pm (its quiet in the daytime) and showcases the electric energy that Moroccans seem to have in abundance.Eat street food, drink freshly squeezed juices, try out your bartering skills or just soak up the atmosphere....I HATED the monkeys on chains and sluggish, drugged snakes. The begging and pestering becomes irksome after an hour or so but a polite "no thanks" is enough to get sellers to leave you alone.Visit one of the cafes that circle the square and take photos from the top terraces. I can recommend Cafe France.

Intense and packed. Crazy and overwhelming at times - go and day and at night to experience a wildly different time. Be aware that if you take a photo of anything/anyone you will almost certainly be asked for money (and sometimes extortionate amounts) - don't be tempted to have a monkey on your shoulder or a snake around your neck unless you're happy to pay for it (it is, after all, how they make their living). An absolute must-see. Also definitely eat in the market stalls at night! And the orange juice is a steal at 4 dirhams a glass, so refreshing.
Cultural square. Best tasting oranges in the world in that square. This is a feast of culture and you must visit the square during the day and then come again at night.

better to visit evening. it was hot and less thing to do in day time. better to make negotiation when you would like to buy smth. didnt impress me so much since i am from Turkey, but you must see and smell the air.

Love the hustle and bustle. Great atmosphere - lively and hopping - a must visit in Marrakech. Plenty to do and see and lots of choice for eating from the stalls in the market place to plenty of rooftop terraces.

The place is surrounded by shouks, quite empty during day time and became alive in the evening, mostly with food stalls.. A very lively place and relaxing, the locals and tourists go here. Sales persons are very active but not annoying. No disturbance from singers nor panhandlers. Good thing is: all are halal food! However,it is not up really to my expectation - the food variation offered is actually limited. Many stalls offered the same dishes.
nice place. I loved the spirit in Jemaa el Fna, gnaw music, the food, the shopping, nice people and enjoyed buying spices and sweets, must to visit!

Loved it, but come prepared!. This is a great spot to people watch and to get a feel for the culture of Marrakech. During the daytime it is a bit quiet, but at night it becomes a chaotic spectacle that can be overwhelming at first. Once you look past the craziness and constant beggars you can appreciate the square for the magical place that it is! Even late at night there are plenty of shops and restaurants open, and lots of people dancing and playing music within the square. Do stop at one of the stalls for some fresh squeezed orange juice. Jamaa el Fna at night is an experience not to be missed!

fun. Lots of markets to shop and restaurants. But be aware as there are some shoplifters there. when you watch a traditional morrocan dance or take pictures with local pwople they charge you money for participateing in their stories, jokes, pet lovers.
The heart of the Medina. Wonderful square that really comes alive in the evenings. Had supper here every evening and was a treat.

Only need to go once. Of course, this is considered the tourist must-see of Marrakech.Bustling and chaotic by day; it remains so in a different vogue by night.Be advised, though, the entertainers tend not to be entertaining. Anyone photographed is likely to demand a fee, There is a fair chance of theft and a fair chance of getting lost.That said, it is worth seeing once, but only once.By night, the ubiqitous food stalls have varied offering: maybe eyeballs or a jaw-bone. Cries of 'Jamie Oliver' are no guarantee. I had the worst food of my life one night. Best value is perhaps the super orange (or grapefruit) juice from one of the stalls (61 of them at one count). Don't be afraid to bargain over anything.It is remarkable to watch sunset over the great Mosque from a cafe balcony; but an early seat is essential.Enjoy - but only once. Marrakech in so many respects is not the true Morocco and has been responsible for bad but not justified impressions of the country.

Beautiful at night, very busy. I loved this place, its more busy at night then during the day, but both times worth a visit. Locals can be a bit of a hassle as they push you to come and see their stores, but if you ignore and keep walking you will be ok. Don't take pictures or hold the snakes, otherwise you will be asked to pay for it all.

was awesome. VERY busy (maybe wouldnt go with kids), loads of people talking to you trying to get you to buy things (or sell your wife) but just ignore them NOTHING IS FREE, we never felt threatened. Its smelly because of the horses but pretty clean....workers are constantly cleaning it. At night its even more amazing when all the food comes out. can by souveneers and nick-nacks for reeeeeally cheap. restaurants and cafes surrounding offer amazing views and delicious food for a very very good price.

An Entertaining Experience. Definitely visit both in the morning and evening, as the square is very different at either time of day. I also liked viewing the square around sunset from a cafe terrace...you get the whole view and are out of the fray. Be aware that the snake charmers, water sellers, henna "artists" and other performers are pretty aggressive and it might be helpful to have some coins quickly accessible in your pocket to give a tip if you would like to take photos. With all of the performers we took photos with, we agreed on a price before we took the photo, but they insisted we pay more after...so just be aware that this happens and you can choose to give more, or pay what you agreed to, say thank you and walk away. Also, be aware of henna "artists" who will say "for free, for good luck" and grab your hand (while you are saying no and trying to politely pull your hand away), draw a full hand design and then demand a hefty price. If you don't want their services, be polite but clear, and walk away. Jemaa el Fna is a high energy, bustling place and a fun experience while in Marrakech.

Magical place!. This place truly is one-of-a-kind! Simply cannot be missed! At night, the setting changes and the place gets even more crowded and interesting. Best to visit 1-2 hours before sunset, so you get to see how it's like during the day and the night. Street artists will sollicit you for money if you take pictures. One small piece of advice: make sure your valuables are secured.

Chaotic but fun!. The square is very chaotic and lively. Everyone should visit here at least one time while you stay in Marrakech. Be careful with guys with snakes. They put a snake around you and tell your friend to take a photo of you. Then charge you.

Hustle and bustle of Marrakech. The square comes alive in terms of music and smells at night moreso than the day. There are people with monkeys and snake charmers as well as traditional water sellers - all willing to have a photo taken (etiquette is to give some money for this - approx 10 dhirams at most). There are plenty of food vendors (although we avoided these as it could lead to tummy trouble) and fresh orange juice stalls vying for your attention and money! There were also plenty of shops and stall sellers still open until early hours of the morning. Just have to be careful in terms of pickpockets - we were not stolen from but there are lots of people in small spaces around entertainers so it is important to keep an eye on your posessions.

Authentic, Chaotic and Fascinating!. Had the pleasure of visiting this Square recently. It is exactly how it is described in the Travel Guides with the Snake Charmers, Monkeys, Hustlers, Orange Juice Stalls etc. During the day, it can get very noisy and chaotic but in the evening, the Square turns into an open air restaurant with various food stalls. Based on the Tripadviser recommendations, my son and I ate at Food Stall N1 and the food was tasty. However, we also ate at N26 and the food was tastier and fresher and in my opinion N26 is better and wins!The Souks are amazing but remember to haggle. No matter the price you are quoted initially, you need to bargain hard, offer a much lower price and if they do not accept your price, walk away. You will be suprised at how quickly the Seller will call you back and accept your offer! I got some fantastic bargains as well. Be careful with the over friendly "Samaritans" who will offer to help you. They are after money and initially when you say no, they will walk away or ride along on their motorcycle or bicycle but they will come back after a few minutes. Say a firm "No" and they will leave you alone. You will also have to dodge Donkeys with Carts, Cyclists, Beggars etc but that is part of the experience and therefore comes with the Territory.One last advice, always agree the price of a Taxi from the Square before you get in the Taxi. I ended up paying one third of the initial fare offered each time and also on the return journey. I also told the driver to turn off the meter so that there was no confusion afterwards.Finally, have fun, be safe and enjoy your holiday!

Thats Africa for you! Simply insanely great!. Jemaa el Fna is in 1 word. Bonkers. I The place is full of so much life its quite difficult to know where to begin. My sister and I visited it on 2 occasions, 1 by day and the other by night. By night we have to say is simply the best. So what makes this place so fantastic. Firstly its the hub of Marrakech in my view, with a variety of stalls selling everything from souvenirs, bric a brad, local delicacies, fresh fruit, the most delicious mint teas; whilst its also surrounded by a variety of restaurants to suit all budgets. Great care is to be exercised in this part of town as with all places you might find the odd pick pocket, but please do not let this deter you as there is a police station right there in the middle of the square, they patrol the area on a regular basis and are very helpful. Here you can hire a horse drawn carriage should your budget permit, taking you on a ride round Marrakech particularly through the more affluent parts of town. The square comes so alive at night with fantastic entertainment coming from street artists, as well as the food traders who don't just sell food but entertain you with their wonderful techniques at getting customers which is just so humorous. Take a plunge and sit down for a meal, meat people from all parts of the world and walks of life. And don't forget to Barter, Barter, Barter head on. Thats the beauty of Africa. Enjoy
Real Morrocan Culture. Amazing place especially after dark. Some real local culture rather than the tripe served up at Chez Ali

Fresh juices, spices, the souk, oh my!! . The Jemaa el Fna is a must see when visiting Marrakech! This square and the rich history it embodies. Grab a seat at one of the rooftop restaurants and enjoy the beautiful view as the sun sets. The souks are amazing! But beware of purchasing anything and be ready to haggle and barter! Always offer half of what the seller is trying to charge you for souveneirs and knickknacks. The snake charmers were a treat, but totally ripped off my boyfriend and I! We didn't realize until speaking with our friends the next day. Do grab some fresh juice from one of the juice vendors! It's so fresh and delicious! The experience at Jemaa el Fna is one of kind, you need to see, smell, and hear for yourself.

Mad, magical and manic. So many people, sights, smells and things going on. At night this square magically turns into a huge open air restaurant with snake charmers, acrobats, monkeys and even the odd vulture which will perch on your shoulder. Sit in a rooftop cafe as the sun goes down and watch a building spectacle as the restaurants arrive on carts and are all quickly put together, watch the sea of people arrive, enjoy the bartering and lose yourself in the atmosphere.

Amazing must see experience. Loved this place lots, went everyday when we were in Marrakech. Loved seeing the sites, different colours, foods and generally walking around having a laugh. Nice orange juice stalls/food stalls. Good shops to barter.A tip - find a fixed price shop for souvenirs. Would definitely recommend and go again, maybe the best experience in Marrakech/Morocco and entertaining too.

The most famous attraction of Marrakech .. not to miss it .. prepare yourself for a little adventure and pay attention. It is the most famous attraction of Marrakech ... that everyone should visit it ..You can feel there the real traditional personality of the old city and smell its authentic historical smell..It is a very very crowded place ... when you enter you will be astonished by fortune tellers sitting on the floor and calling you to read your future , you will also see magicians who plays on the flute and making snakes & Copra dancing in front of your eyes .. while others make monkeys take photos with you ..a few steps near you will see morrocan men with traditional clothes dancing and bouncingsome very good restaurants are located arround the place , Restaurant "Chez Chagrouni" which serves a very good and authentic morrocan food , and have a lovely terrace on the placethere is also a very good french restaurant near Chagrouniyou will find a lot of boutiques of postal cards and souvenirs but they exagerate a lot in the price , try to negotiate the prices before buying (for example the vendor will give you a price of a souvenir 200 Dirhams while you can take it with 70 Dirhams)a lot of things have annoyed me , for instance , when a freind took a photo for me beside the snake dancers or the monkeys , the man asked me to pay for permitting me take a photowhen they feel that you are a tourist they do their best to take more money for youtaxis are terrible in Marrakech , there is no counter fair , they exagerate in price , try to negotiate .. but the place deserve to be visited , and don't forget to visit the souks which are very near ..

Heart of Marrakech. Absolute and wonderful chaos. Try to visit several times of the day though night is the main event. Lots of shows going on and fun even when you don't understand. Be careful to dodge horses and beware cobras. I almost stepped on one since it is hard to see. Check out the food too!

Snake-charmers. My favourite times here are early in the morning when the stall holders arrive and meticulously set up their worldly belongings for the day, and the late evening when a cocophony of sounds, smells, peoples and spirits fill the air with excitement and exotic activity. During the day it's rather touristy, but still fun. Cheapest bottled water anywhere in Marrakech too. The Cafe France terrace was a good place to people watch and take pictures respectfully from a distance. I doubt I would enjoy a camera being pointed in my face either up close.I was wary of the snake charmers, but as a blonde, tall female received no hassle as I dressed conservatively, spoke french and arabic and smiled. It was a delight to be in Marrakech.

Very intense. We were staying close to the square so visited in the day and the evening. I agree with other reviewers about the constant harassment to buy but the worse thing for me was at night. It was too intense. My two teenage sons had a Fez placed on their heads by two smiling men shouting 'Free picture', one son took a picture of the other and suddenly they changed, becoming aggressive about being paid for the photo. We had got separated by a few feet and came upon a scene that looked like our boys were being mugged. We had to pay them to leave. Also witnessed two men exchanging 5 or 6 mobile phones. No guessing where they came from. I would say visit for the experience but don't take a photo of anyone under any circumstances, stay on the outskirts of the square and get out quick.

what an expericence!. Fantastic, loved the chaos and the craziness of it, ate on stall number 13th the food was great.However make sure you avoid having your photo with the monkeys or snakes.. a very cruel way to make a living.

A sight well worth seeing ... from above. Given the square is built up so highly in the books I was expecting something more exotic, its not all that special, but yes if you want a photo with a monkey or snake or your hands decorated with Henna its the main place in the evening. On the other hand another couple had Henna painted on their daughters hand before they had agreed to do it and ended up paying 4 times the going rate, also told by our excursion guide the next day that the black cobras with the hood are one crazy snake and not to be approached. So personally I found the experience best looking down from one of the restaurants overlooking the square, they weren't too pricey but did get VERY busy from around 8:30pm.Worth a visit, don't go to Marrakech just to see this !

Folklore delight!. If you come during the day, you will probably be unimpressed: some orange juice sellers, a couple of snake charmers, slim pickings! As the day progresses, and especially after sunset, the square comes alive!It bustles with people, both local and tourists, it's noisy, at times even overwhelming!There are dancers (male), snake charmers, water carriers, and a myriad of food stalls. Try the snails, the traditional Tangia (a local stew) or some grilled merguez, and wash it down with a 4 Dh orange juice. The food is very safe there and the stalls are parked.You can also visit one of the overpriced cafes with a terrace to take in the view from a quieter environment. Some of the very busy one require you to purchase your drink before gaining access to the terrace.

No charm here. Bitterly disappointed.. I grew up on the romance of movies like Indiana Jones and Lawrence of Arabia. This place, this square has no charm. It has no authenticity. What it does have are drugged up snakes, monkeys kept on chains around their necks, beggars, and people hassling you for allsorts of spurious reasons. I saw an unsuspecting british couple take a photo of a man holding a monkey and then be chased down and hassled for money by a group of men. It is relatively busy during the day, full of tourists I expect there for the same reason I went. At night, it becomes a sort of food festival. Stalls and stalls of 'freshly cooked food'. I'm not convinced with the hygiene. The one thing the square does well are fresh orange juice..Other than that, there's no magic in this place. it's just a tourist trap and the locals make use of that with knock off goods (Dr dre beats headphones for the equivalent of 5 gbp) if you're into that. Such a shame.

an extra ordinary experience.. I liked the unusual Moroccan culture activates. Taming snakes and doing henna drawings. When you finished you can have a tour on the souq to shop and see the traditional Moroccan goods.
Full of life. This square is becomes full of life towards the evening, thousands of visitors and local gather here to enjoy. Horse cab visit is prominent.

Busy Busy Busy !!. We visited the square several times on a stay in Marrakech. It is packed full of things to see in the evening but is very chaotic! Snake charmers, acrobats, monkeys and street sellers but beware if taking a photo as they don't take kindly and you will be chased for money (£10.00 or more) for the photo. It is worth trying the street food which sets up at night we tried stall 100 which was good and had a varied choice. We were warned by our Riad not to eat any fish in Marrakech as it is not fresh and many people have problems. Also only eat at the street food stalls which have a licence (look for a number above the stall) and ones that are busy. Try the freshly squeezed orange juice at only 4 dirham (approx 30p) at one of the many stalls - again be careful it is not watered down. In the day the square is calmer and a super place to go is Cafe France - sit on the terrace at the top and watch the squares coming and goings with the Atlas Mountains as a spectacular back drop!Browse the many world famous souks which are just off the square and be prepared to bargain -start at a third off and aim for no more than half original cost. One more thing as everywhere else in Marrakech watch out for the many scooters, motor bikes whizzing up and down accidents do happen with unsuspecting tourists!!

overpowering and colourful. the square is pretty simple but what goes on in the square changes mood from morning till night with snake charmers, water men in brightly coloured outfits with hats that resemble lampshades and at night becomes a food area of all Moroccan delights, and fringes on the souks, markets that disappear into alleys and lanes full of all you may imagine in clothing and home wares and food

Crazy and exotic. It is really a crazy experience, but Marrakech would not be half as exciting if it wasn't for the Jemaa el Fna and the cast of characters that come out at night. Always carry some spare change in your hand so that you can give some out to the many who are in great need.

Amazing. The mind is bombarded with all sorts of visual sensations and a range of aromas (not all pleasant). You are constantly pestered to buy things. If you want to buy please barter and if it us not the price you want pay just politely walk away. If it is acceptable to them they will come after you and agree a price.

Great!. Fab place to people watch and drink lovely freshly squeezed orange juice for 4dh. We had a restaurant meal here and then wandered back to our Riad. A must and despite reviews we only saw one lot of snakes and a couple of monkeys on shoulders! They did seem respectful and didn't put these creatures on you if you didn't show an interest, which was good for my children! Great evening out.

unique. this market is an amasing place, where everything can happen and mostly everything that happens there are beyond imagination. Sunset also is amasing. You better have a local guide, otherwise it can get prretty wild!
Vibrant. Such a great place. Sounds, smells, colours. Crazy every night. Loved it. Didn't brave the food stalls. Restaurants around the square very good with great terraces for watching the activity.

Endless trying of hustling tourist. People everywhere trying to sell you things and fool you. Its all about money. Sorry but thats the thruth. Totaly different prices cuz you are a tourist. This is the last time a visit marrakech, to much hustle.
busy,busy.. This is where all the action is night and day.The colours,the people and the constant activity make for a very vibrant atmosphere.

Experience Jemaa el-Fina. Definitely should be on the "to do list" in Marrakech though to be honest I feel some of the reviews are a little over the top.The evenings are the best time to visit and eating at the food stalls is easy, interesting and cheap. It is very easy for two to eat for less than 100 dioramas.Orange juice at 4 dihrams is a great refresher during the day and a 30 minute ride in a horse drawn carriage can be negotiated easily for 100 dioramas.On the down side, I was very disappointed with the snake charmers, monkeys etc which are in place in some numbers. For me, these have lost there local flavour and are fairly weak experiences. A snake charmer in an Adidas Tracksuit does not conjure memories of Morocco for me!

Must see!!. The square is overwhelming with people, motorcycles, vendors and everything else!! It can be intimidating. The best way to view the action is to walk across the square to the Glacier Cafe and have a cold or hot drink. There are tons of henna ladies, be sure to negotiate the price before they grab your hand and start writing on you. I did not and I am sure I paid too much. There are snake charmers too, but I had my tour guide work out the price for me. It is an amazing collection of sights and sounds. There are tons of tourists so I do think it is pretty safe.

Heart of Marrakech. It's nuts at times, especially in the evening. Watch out for the snake charmers. They see you photographing and bring you into the cobra circle. I did it, safe and they will want $$$ $10 bucks. Lots of merchants selling all the same stuff. Haggle low low. Most people don't want pictures taken. Food is cheap and monkeys are alive. Have fun

Overwhelming but in a good way. It's worth a visit both during the day and during the night since both times provide completely different experiences. During the day, there are lots of fresh juice sellers on the perimeter calling people over for glasses of delicious fresh-squeezed juice. We walked by a young boy with a huge bandage on his head, surrounded by his supportive family, being persuaded to get his tooth (teeth) removed after what looked like a bad accident. The square is mostly open... when we came back at night, it was an ENTIRELY different world. Numerous snake charmers, smoke from a hundred different food stalls, trance dancers, musicians, fortune tellers, people staging mini-plays, monkeys, games of chance, donkey-drawn carriages. Yes, it was overwhelming but it was also an amazing experience. I could have walked around for hours just taking it all in.

What an experience!. Now I know where the expression 'the difference between night and day' comes from. The difference between visiting this square during the day time and the evening is stark. This is a 'must do' at both times of the day.On approach you'll see the horse-drawn carriages that are available for hire to tour the city, they look beautiful, but you can imagine the aroma!There are men dressed in rainbow coloured frilly clothes who sell water, but I couldn't be sure where the water came from so steered clear.During the day, it's busy but fairly easy to navigate all that's available, then at night the crowds are thick and walking through there are little clearings with performers either dancing or playing instruments, then you turn around and realise you're walking past a snake or a monkey! There is a whole lane with freshly-squeezed orange juice at only 4 dirhams, plus lots of ladies offering henna (but be careful as not all henna is safe).It's worth being brave and venturing along the narrow lanes - it's a gauntlet of street hawkers (watches, mobiles, hats for sale) and small cafes and, if you get lost, look to the roofs and follow the direction of the (hundreds or so!) satellite dishes that point back to the square.

An extraordinary feast for the senses. One of the top highlights of my recent journey through Morocco was exploring the Jemaa El Fna in Marrakech. Our Riad was only a 5 minute walk to the Jemaa El Fna, so we were able to take our time and check out this amazing place. If you are a cat lover, you cannot help but notice the feline friends enjoying themselves in secluded areas of the square.In the daytime, this square offers lots of places to purchase items, fresh squeezed orange juice and enjoy the snake charmers, barbary apes and other sights and sounds. You can walk up to a second floor cafe to get a great overview of the Jemaa El Fna, but the real action is on the ground level which a great mix of travelers visiting Morocco as well as Moroccans enjoying this famed location. Yes there are people offering to sell items, but I found this no more of a hassle than anywhere else in the world, including metropolitan areas throughout Europe, America, Asia, etc. The great thing is that bargaining is key in the square and I found people to be friendly and welcoming. As the bargaining proceeds and/or the purchases mount, be prepared to be offered and accept the gracious offering of complimentary mint tea offered in some of the souks.The Jemaa El Fna really comes alive at night when the square becomes a real communal gathering spot; friends and families meet up, the food stalls are set up and the entertainers go out in droves. You will see all manner of acrobats along with dancers and other forms of entertainment. Visiting the Jemaa El Fna is a must do if you visit Marrakech. Just standing and people watching is a transformative experience that reminds you that you are in a very special Kingdom. Enjoy!

A step back in time. Visit in the day get some orange juice, explore the souks, but an ashtray, they make the best kind, in the shape of a sort of onion dome.....ask anyone and they'll show you, return at night and visit the food stalls or head to the other side to do some late night shopping, knock offs galore :) and good quality ones too! As well as moroccan versions of three card monte type games. I went with my partner, a male, so perhaps this is why we were never "accosted", i noted that you just have to be confident and firm, they're just doing their job, don't take it personal. Head to a rooftop cafe to sort of avoid the madness, although the cafes are usually packed as it is nice view. Don't be deterred by the entrance to the square with the somewhat intense, although natural, horse smell it goes away once you're in the square.
Full Court Press. The square is beautiful. The souks are interesting. Just be ready for the hard sell. Go at night to see it lit up. Beautiful. Just practice "la choukran".

Brilliant, vibrant, feels like a scene out of Indiana Jones.. The square transforms its hustle and bustle effortlessly from day to night, the street performers play amazing rhythmic music while snake charmers whistle at their rattle snakes with flutes, the food stalls are OK (i recommend maybe just 1 try of it, but honestly, it's not worth the effort), the orange juice stalls are wonderful and super refreshing for a hot day. The monkeys are soft.

A bustling , colourful and curious mix of life in one location. You can find most things here - rides on traditional horse and carriages , people charming snakes and handling monkeys , street cafés which serve good (safe) food and lots of stalls. Everything from fresh orange juice sellers, to Moroccon lamps , clothes and plants . In fact it's a real concentration of activity in a single square surrounded by cages , bars , ice cream stands and so on. The good thing is that it's pretty hassle free. If people approach you politely and you decline they leave you alone . Any trip to this city demands a visit . It's good at night as it all lights up and food is plentiful and good .

Largest market-square in North Africa. No need to write a long review here -- if you come to Marrakech and don't visit this place, you're either very stupid or not actually in Marrakech. Practically everything revolves around it: trade, cuisine, travel, hospitality, worship...During the day snake-charmers, letter-writers and monkey-owners mingle with tourists and locals. There's a lot to see but if you're more animal-friendly, you may want to avoid the monkeys because of their questionable treatment by owners. Anyone putting something on you (a snake, a hat, a dress etc.) will expect payment for a photo with you and the object (you can just say 'non, merci' and walk off without paying if you'd rather not take part). These attractions go hand-in-hand with the beautifully fresh orange juice perfected in nearby stalls, costing around DH4 MAD per glass (made from Marrakech-grown oranges), which is a must-drink if you're visiting for the first time. By night, the snakes, monkeys and letters disappear and North Africa's largest market-square comes alive. Not only because a sea of locals carry portable stoves and setup the myriad restaurants (kebabs, tagines etc.) which cost very little to dine at (you should eat with your hands (make sure they're clean!) as cutlery isn't really washed thoroughly and bring your own water bottle to drink from) and are as authentic a Marrakech experience as you can get. The smoke fills the air and the smell of grilled lamb drifts for miles! Alongside these are magicians, henna tattooists (be warned, you need to agree a price before sitting down and no designs will ever be free, even if they promise they are -- you will be overcharged, I promise! Also, don't forget some henna can cause major allergic reactions) and lamp sellers (use a mobile phone light to illuminate the outside of the lamps before buying, as you may find an ugly, poorly-made lamp when you get back to your hotel/riad). There are also old women selling Jempo tissues and young boys throwing glow sticks in the air. Transport runs through the Djemaa El-Fna. Horses and carts sit by the water troughs on the bottom of the square, petit taxis (max. 3 people, often Dacias) and grande taxis (Mercedes, no max. passenger number) both wallow around with local motorbikes. An ALSA bus also drops off passengers nearby. A fare to your riad/hotel in Marrakech (all quarters except Palmarie) should be no more than DH20 MAD at a tourist rate. If you ask them to use the meter ('le compteur') it should be around DH10 MAD, but they may refuse (if so, you can look for another cab). Agree a price before getting in and shake on it (a gentleman's handshake is as important here as it is in London).The square also has two entrances to the souks, where you can find the usual tourist stuff -- lamps, tagines, teapots, scarfs etc. The further in you go, the better the stuff and the greater the discounts. Always haggle -- never pay the first price or anything more than list minus 50%. More on haggling can be found on my review of the souks. This is a must-see when coming to the red city. If you're visiting for the first time, be prepared to fall in love. That being said, there is petty crime so keep valuables hidden and be observant (if for nothing more than to avoid the motorcycles constantly revving past!). Enjoy yourself, but keep safe. Marrakech is a very safe country if you look after yourself.

Everything including the kitchen sink... If u take every thing u know or have experienced about markets multiply that by 100 u still come up short the shear volume is unfathomable and that's before u get to the adjoining souks. At the square there are plenty on western style resturants where u can watch the bustle but not be a part of it, you will need this respite as u will be overwhelmed at some stage. If u want local fare by local people head to the market after 7.30pm..now in Marakesh, nothing is free many locals will c u with a map, approach u and offer to take u where u want to go or at least point u in the right direction, this will then be followed by do u have a gift for me, remember nothing is for free. We were given dodgey directions twice before we cottoned on. Having said that we never felt that we were not safe. When being asked to buy things and u will, be polite but firm if u r not interested. Snake charmers will demand payment if u try to take a picture so negotiate first 10 dirham or 1 euro is sufficient . You will also find monkey handlers same applies here to. Taxis r cheap but always negotiate price.

Tourists money extraction square. This place is chaos.Best advice. Visit but get in and get out quick before it makes you want to go back on the plane. Everywhere you turn or look there is someone demanding money from you or a tourist. You'll have monkeys thrown at you, caps thrown in your face, people shooting at you from all directions. Do not venture into the Souks area unless you know where your going as everyone tries to send you the WRONG way and then you end up lost at their "tannery". Do not follow anyone. I had someone telling me the square was down one alleyway and yet I knew for a fact it was the other direction. They even scrubbed off the directions on the signs so tourists will get lost! The snake charmers do not charm snakes, they keep the snakes under a pot and they overheat until they are too sleepy to do anything when the pot is took off.The orange juice stalls are probably the only genuinely good thing on the square. I have very little good experiences of this place due to many many aggressive and greedy Moroccans who will eventually scare all western tourists away from marrakech.

Accosted by awful man and his monkey. Keep well away from the people in the square with animals. Son was accosted by a man with a monkey. Man took my son's phone and it all became very unpleasant and made us feel uneasy. Eventually got phone back but man was shouting obscenities and threatening.

The sights and smells of Marrakech in a nut shell!!. Both during the day, and especially at night, the sights and smells of the Place Jemaa el Fna sum up Marrakech to a tee!!! Facinating place to visit!!

Sensory Overload. This colourful place has everything, both fascinating and irritating:- water sellers more interested in being paid to have their pictures taken than in selling water- snake charmers with their incessant and irritating flutes, more interested in extracting money from gullible tourists than in attending to their somewhat lethargic snakes- musicians who start banging their drums at 6 pm and stop somewhere around midnight, all the while thrusting caps into the faces of bystanders for money- acrobats, one hand on the ground, the other hand outstretched for cash- persistent and annoying waiters trying to steer people into evening food stalls.Most of all, Jemaa El Fna produces sensory overload!Taking pictures anywhere in the square carries with it the risk of being set upon by hordes of people all demanding money because you took 'their' picture.Never mind that there are thousands of people milling about in the square and getting a photo without people in it is impossible.Then, for me, it was the constant 'patience tester':Madam! Carriage ride?Madam! Henna?Madam! Photo?Madam! Phone card?Madam! Guide?Madam! Taxi?Madam! Sunglasses (even though I'm already wearing sunglasses)?My God, I couldn't even finish a thought!And if I went near one of the souk entrances bordering the square, OMG!!! It was the ever-present hard sell all the way: scarves, kaftans, slippers, carpets, perfume, Viagra for women, Argan oil - to rejuvenate me both inside and out; jewellery, furniture ... whatever it was, it was perfect for me and at a 'special' price. My complete lack of interest only served to spark a series of loud invectives from the vendors trying to peddle the stuff.Endless, endless attempts to extract money!Jemaa El Fna is definitely worth visiting if for no other reason than to see just how grasping, greedy and aggressive people can be!It's a place that really tests one's patience, so it's probably best to experience it in 'small doses'.
INCREDIBLE. This is exactly what Marrakech is all about. Right next to the amazing souks, lots of restaurants and a 24/7 buzz, I will certainly be returning!

Must visit during Ramadhan and at night. It deserve 2 visits: one at night with stands and food, full of lifeand another during the day. I specially recommend it in Ramadhan when you can notice how local muslims break the fast

Craziness!. This place is absolutely crazy! I really enjoyed the market. Wish I bought more though. Make sure you bargain! Often the price that they tell you, you can bargain it down to half the price ;)
Also.. Watch out for people who self appoint themselves as your tour guide.. you wont realize until the end of the trip.

Biggest market place. Lots of shops and things to look at. Be careful as theres alot of beggers and stuff along with people trying to sell you tat. But thats only the street guys shops are ok and they do not hassle you like in Egypt

#1 place in Marrakesh. Day or night this square is a live with people, food, and culture. At night time it gets very busy. go on top of a roof in a restaurant for great views. Great food and ice cream as well. Have fun!

You cannot go to Marrakech and miss the large square Jemaa el Fna. The large square, called Jemaa El Fna, is he central hub of Marrakech. The souks go onto it.It is huge.In the day time there are fresh orange juice sellers - absolutely delicious squeezed in front of you and we dank a lot of this in the heat. Also fruit and nut sellers and a few other souvenir stalls. Also hats if you have forgotten yours.In the evening it has musicians, traditional dancers, snake charmers, drummers, people with monkeys, hot food stalls etc.There are traditional water sellers in costumes. We did not have their water (not bottled) but they are really there for photographs so pay them some money and you can have a photo - barter for the cost.Also from the square are horse and carts to take you to various places in the medina - they have a price chart.Many bars and restaurants sit around the square. We went to Grand café du Balcon and sat on roof terrace - do not recommend unless you want pizza, salad, chips type meal. But view was lovely of the square.
Rockin all Night. An awesome experience ,I just wish that all the drums would play the same groove,joking aside it's amazing.

Has everything!. Colourful gathering place for everybody. You may not always like what you see - the Barbary monkeys, snake charmers, henna tattooists, fortune tellers, people selling anything and non stop hassling - but it is compelling! Have a fresh orange juice or try the stalls for cheap food or the best, cheapest mint tea - just don't think too much about the hygiene!

Amazing atmosphere. You can't visit Marrakech without going to Jemaa el Fna, this place is buzzing with all sorts of interesting this to look at! Jemaa el Fna is at the centre of everything, it is the square at the entrance to the Souks (which is also a must), here you will find the most delicious street food, snake charmers, whirling dervishes, street performers, the best orange juice you will ever taste and plenty of cafes serving traditional Moroccan mint tea.I'd recommend trying a tagine from the local street vendors, they can be quite intimidating as they all want you custom but it is definitely worth it. Another thing that you can't miss while you're here is the orange juice stalls, fresh juice for just 2 dirham which is the equivalent to about 30p! Watch out for people trying to trick you! Many of the street performers will make you take photos of/with them and then demand money, watch out for the men with the monkeys too they will literally throw their monkeys on you and ask you for money for pictures. If you're female get ready for the henna ladies to grab you and try and draw on you, you just have to learn to say no! Don't let any of this put you off though it's all part of the experience of Marrakech! Jamaa el Fna is such a wonderful place nothing like your boring local markets at home!

Animal cruelty writ large. Hot and a bit empty during the day, fills up and does become more exciting at night, but shocking animal cruelty has remained at Jemaa el Fna so it's out of kilter with much of the rest of the world. Snakes, monkeys, lizards and even a near dead vulture all tackily on display for "tourist" photographs. Mercifully I didn't see a single person get a photo and indeed more than a few had a go at the "owners" so hopefully this is a dying (sic) feature...will be so much better when that's all gone...

It's really the main thing to see i Marrakech. It's where you will get the flavor and the sites of Marrakech...go early if it's a hot day as you will get overheated very easily here...you will have to get used to people trying to sell you...learn to walk away!

Interesting. Definitely a place to see when in Marrakech! I was wondering where the snake charmers were when my husband pointed out that I had nearly walked into them ... You seem to be able to find all kinds of things here. The water seller with his cups and interesting outfit was one of the most unique. The lamps that were for sale were beautiful and it's fun to wander through the food/restaurant stalls.If you have the opportunity try to come close to sunset and get a seat on a roof terrace at one of the cafes. It's fun to watch the lights come on and the scene below change as you sip sweet mint tea!

Ordinary during the day, magical at night. When the sun goes down, the Jemaa el Fna-place turns from a rather ordinary place into a hectic, mystical, magical and unforgetable square : sounds, colours, smells, snakes, monkeys, dance, acrobatics, ... It's all on the el Fna-place and you'll like it.

Marrakesh in one place. If you want to see things that you saw just in movies, go in Jemaa el Fna. You will find storytellers, snake shows, traditional dancers, henna painting, etc. The food is great and cheaper than any restaurant around. The orange juice was incredible. Don't accept any service if you are not willing to pay for it. Establish the price for beginning in this way you will not have unpleasant surprises. In my opinion is a great atmosphere, was like we were back in time. I love the life from there. You must negotiate everything. If you don't visit Jemaa el Fna you can't say that you visited Marrakesh.
This is where it all happens!. A must-see and a must-experience when visiting Marrakech. Se how the place comes to life when the sun is setting, and eat ind one of the many grill-tents!

It all happens here!!. In all of my travels i have never seen anything like it.Crowded, exciting, exotic m cobras, monkies, story telling and by night, pop up loacl resteraunts every where, and to cap it off, a huge screen showing Charlie Chaplain films!!

cultural shock right in your face. ...And this is coming from a Third World country citizen!The place will show you a lot of colors, noises, smells, vendors, and things that will impress you (like if you are an animal lover like me) and make you think: "why in the world would people like to have a picture taken with a poor monkey that is chained 24/7?" All in all is a must-see in Morocco, just be aware, and say "no" firmly, but courteously if you really don´t want to buy something, and don´t be afraid of bargain if you want to, they are professional businessmen (I didn´t see many women doing business, with the exception of the henna tattooers)
A must do. Atmosphere - great and definitely a must d whilst in Marrakesh but the hassling and begging gets too much after a while
Good food and a must see.. If you can out up with the 'hassle' the food is good and very reasonable. There are a number of different stalls but choose the one you like and you won't be disappointed.

Unfriendly and unspectacular. I agree with a previous review that the Square was full of 'hassle and lame shows trying to get a tourist's buck'. We stuck around for a drink around 6pm and it seemed that many stalls were just setting up as it was Ramadan - maybe the square is more entertaining later in the evening, but we decided not to stay and find out.

Biggest market place. Lots of shops and things to look at. Be careful as theres alot of beggers and stuff along with people trying to sell you tat. But thats only the street guys shops are ok and they do not hassle you like in Egypt.

An eye opener. The way of life in Marrakech- a world away from Trafalgar Square! A great experience of how life goes on in this busy city and keen to encourage tourists to buy their goods!! The only downside was the way they treat their animals is appaulling-not so good!

Quite the adventure!. We visited Jemaa el Fna towards the beginning of July. It was quite the adventure. Tip number one: please do not feel bad in saying 'no thank you' to the people who "suggest" you where to go. They will stick to you like ticks! My boyfriend did the mistake of following the suggestion of a male which he took us around places at a very quick speed under 50 degree (122 Fahrenheit) that resulted in me crying of exhaustion. Apart from that, he charged us 300 dirham for his services. Nice gentleman, but would opt out next time. It is a really nice place to visit though. Endless markets. Cheap place to buy any type of souvenirs. Do not forget to ask for a cheaper price. Definitely a must because you get to see so many things you would not see in the States or Europe.
Old Marrakech Square. Nice area in the day. Old Marrakech architecture and Mosques. Plenty of shops (modern & old style), restaurants, & cafes.
Keep walking!. You can't visit the Medina without crossing the Jemaa el Fna. This place pulsates excitement during Ramadan, but is a sorry sight at other times.

Crazy Square. This is a place where you are going to see from everything, from the most exotic food to human teeth sellers, snake charmers and trained monkeys. A huge cultural clash, amazing experience and definitely a must see in Marrakesh. Just be careful when taking pictures, they are going to charge you, so ask first otherwise you may get in trouble.
Crazy place for an explore. Loved the crazy vibe as the sun set around the square and the food stalls opened! The stall holders try to drag you to eat with them but it was way too hot for us.

The Place. Jemaa el Fna is the place to be in Marrakech. All day you can get fresh orange juice at a bargain, an in the evening you'll find nice food at the stands put up again each day. I especially recommend the cheery crowd at stand # 114 "Chez Mbark".

Over rated. Just after returning from Marrakesh and visited the Jemaa el Fna on different occasions.Its busy during the day but really kicks off in the evening where the local people and tourists visit in their droves.The amount of people begging and trying to sell you "tat" is very irritating after a while though.Its a safe environment with plenty of police about keeping an eye on things.I would advise that ,if eating in one of the cafes around the square,to sit back from the front rows of seats as you will be constantly hassled by street sellers.

Underwhelming. We were looking forward to visiting Jemaa el Fna for our entire trip. We had expected cultural shows and local food. What we got was hassle and lame shows trying to get a tourist's buck. We were very disappointed. We couldn't understand why it was a UNESCO heritage site. (Note, we were there during Ramadan so that could explain it.)

What a place!!!. This square is incredible - food, street performers, cafes and loads of people to watch. This is a highlight of any trip to Marrakech and is unavoidable. We ate from the stalls on the square and were absolutely fine. We avoided the usual suspects such as uncooked vegetables and salads but ate everything else from a few different stalls during our stay. Walking home at night when all shops are closed up proved a challenge on the first night when we weren't orientated or familiar with the area yet - a helpful local man directed us back to our residence and did not ask for any form of financial compensation, which was unusual in our experience. Highly recommend this place area - like Time Square in NY it's a must see.

Incredible...visit here or miss out!. An unforgettable experience...seeing the square at night from the balcony of one of the cafe's overlooking it. Then going down and exploring. Full of storytellers, fruit stalls and barbecues, I'd love to visit here again soon.

Bustling and typical. I think you would find it difficult to miss this busy central area in Marrakech. Awash with food stands and orange juice stalls it's not to be missed. Having tried both the ( incredibly inexpensive) food and juice, I was very impressed. Although the level of competition between the stands means that you're approached repeatedly. It's not to the extent of harassment and people are friendly and courteous. From snake charmers to acrobats this square is an experience not to be missed.

an experience!!. Much better at night once the square is full of stalls, the Souks are a maze of alleys and yes you can get lost but an experience not too be missed. Beware of pickpockets we saw some watching us and barter well for your bargains. walk away and they will come to you.If they say it is for free it isn't...they watch you and then find you later for the money..
Just have to go into it. At night bustling, noisy heart of the town. Lots to eat, much of it similar, but it' the atmosphere more than the cuisine you are there for.

one in a million. That is an exhilarating experience for the first time visitor to Marrakech. Freshly squeezed sweetest orange juice for pennies, colours, noise can be bit overwhelming on the first day, by day 4 you feel like at home though.

Vibrant square. During the day the square was fairly quiet apart from the abundance of fresh orange juice stalls.. This was Ramadan however. At night , the square comes alive after the breaking of the fast and there is an abundance of sights to see. Snake charmers , henna artists, food stalls and all sorts of items . Great restaurant on the square - Marrakachy - great food, live music and the odd belly dancer thrown in for good measure .

A Place to Browse. We visited this vast area by day and by night, both were equally busy. The day visit included a trip into the Medina (but that is for another report). The square is surrounded by shops and restaurants with many sellers of fresh orange juice at 4 Dirhams each (So cheap that they must strip the many laden trees along the many roads of Marrakech. The evening brought out many food stalls, snake charmers and children selling little nik naks. It is a riot of colour and noise and a pleasant place to spend an hour or two. Do not try to leave the square around 10pm prayers as they locals flood out of the mosque in droves, so much so that the roads are closed close by and the worshipers use both road and pavement to leave the area, It is akin to leaving a sporting event in the UK.

A certainly unique experience!. If you are in Marrakech you simply have to visit here. I visited about 4 times, each time at a different part of the day. The Orange Juice Vendors serve the most refreshing glass of juice for about 4 Dirham, the food I found can be hit and miss. I would recommend stall number 1, I ate at three others too. I would not recommend stall number 26 however as the food was certainly not on par with what I had eaten elsewhere. What is very interesting is watching the change in the square throughout the day, from afternoon to when darkness falls. It really does transform. The noise and sounds from the musicians, the smell from the food stalls, the crowds that start appearing, it really is worth seeing. Certainly an experience I would recommend, fascinating for people watching.

Busy square with so much to see!. You can think of the square as 3 parts: food, entertainment: stores. It is extremely busy there, and gets busier at night. It is nice to sit at a cafe terraces and see the sunset over the square. Great for taking pictures too. Once night falls, be aware that the snake charmers are still at work so be careful where you walk! Also the snake charmers have eyes like hawks on tourist taking pictures of their snake. They will come up to you can hassle you for money. My advise is to either take the picture from afar or just look as you go pass. They can get quite aggressive, but if you mention tourist police they will often leave you alone. There are numerous food stalls which are all numbered. All serve pretty much the same things at the same price.They will in all efforts try to bring you to their stall as you walk past. If you get fed up with they asking you to go to their stall, you can say that you've already eaten, not hungry or that you might come back later. Surrounding the square are many souks, which is a bit of a maze, so just be aware of your directions.

Over-rated.. You have to visit the Jemaa for the experience at least a couple of times, however after a while the constant talking from the vendors and the non-stop guiding advice / requests gets tiring. The food selections while cheap and accessible are not that varied at the stalls either.

Timeless Fun. A three-ring circus for the senses every night. Attracts locals in addition to tourists. Includes tons of food stalls with various specialties (some great! Try #1!) and rows of dirt-cheap freshly squeezed orange juice stands (4 dirham -- 48 cents -- for a tall glass that they squeeze in front of you). Then, there are the snake charmers, henna tattoo ladies, fortune tellers, and story tellers, who attract throngs of locals with their tales (in Arabic) from the Arabian nights and the Koran. Has the feel of a huge, vibrant party -- especially during Ramadan, when the relief of the city at the breaking of fast is palpable and the place is full of joy.

The vibrant soul of Marrakech. The Jemaa el Fna square is a must to visit if you are in Marrakech. Located in the heart of Marrakech it offers an explosion of colors and smells of Morocco. Be very careful when taking photos of any of the performers in the square. Snake charmers, dancers, water sellers and women applying henna tatoos will charge for any photo taken. You can always agree a price first and then get your deal. Beware the beggars, especially children, not always genuinely needy. However, the square is an amazing place to visit.Visited in March 2011

Absolutely Chaotic. The Jemaa el Fna square is a must if you are in Marrakech. This square is the very heart of Marrakech and everything good and bad happens in the Jemaa el Fna square. Don't try to take pictures of the snake charmers or they will charge you (or try to drape a snake around your neck.) Avoid the monkeys and their owners because they are also just trying to get your money. If it gets unbearably hot while you're in the square, I recommend getting some orange juice and sitting in the shaded park (on the opposite side of all the horses. You do not want to smell them while you relax.) If you're looking for a cheap meal, wait until dusk and all the food vendors started selling in the square. However, if you're not a fan of extremely crowded streets with pestering vendors, you may want to just stay home.
after dark shows its real face. nice atmosphere in the evenning. Very crowded. However, you may feel like an animal which is a target for the hunters!

An amazing array of sights sounds and smells!. Jemaa el Fna is the place to visit to get to see a bit of the old traditions of Marrakech. Be careful of the henna ladies though, they are very aggressive.The orange juice sold across the square is to die for. There a lots of options for leather goods, but be ready to bargain!
