Must see, especially in the evening!. Amazing place, in the evening turns into performance, where everybody is involvedTotally different during day-time

Watch an online video instead. When the sun sets the square goes into full frenzy.....lights, packed with people, and a lot of scammers and entertainers - all striving very hard to get your money. Not in the nice or flattering way, and not even in the hard-sell kind of way. Many of these folks will get up into your face and demand money just for looking their way. I'm not talking about actually watching and enjoying a performance, in which case you really should contribute, just actually glancing their way....."You pay now" and "I make trouble for you" are the only English sentences that everyone seems to have memorized. Our party of 4 (two couples) tried to browse the various collections of dinner tents and we were LITERALLY torn apart from each other by the grasping hands of nearly a dozen different vendor employees. A woman from our group understandably freaked out, screamed and bolted for the outer square, and of course we followed, having to rip ourselves from the physical grip of seemingly desperate sales people. I do recommend that you just safely view the square from one of the several balcony restaurants around the square. If you do venture into the square, have a lot of small change to hand out or be prepared to aggressively defend yourself.
Lively and exciting. Nice to walk through at night. Lots of food stalls with lively music and dance. Can still take a horse drawn carriage at night. Againeveryone seemed so friendly.

Chaotic and amazing. Just the feeling being there, Historic, chaotic. However, did not like the obtrusion of a lots of some of the people trying to get your money. watch out for the guys with snakes, hangs them around your neck, and then demands you to pay them for it.Did not like they had monkeys in cage, and tried to make money of it.

What a place. A colourful place lots of things to see. If you want too take the risk of eating at the pop up food vendor's feel free we went to some of the restaurant's around the square and all where very good. Just a xouple of things to be wary off, you will get hassled buy everyone and there cat. And be aware as we wallked across the square and there was a cobra on its own and the charmer was a good 30 meters away.This place will fascinate anyone for a few days.

Just a lot of drama. For a few hours in the evening, the place becomes really active. But most of the stuff being sold is made in China, and none of the cafes or food are any good. Some of the shows are mildly entertaining - snake charmers, magic shows, boxing matches, monkey tricks.

Crazy at the highest level. It's pretty subdued during the day lots of foot traffic--cars are allowed in the day a few stands selling souvenirs and even a few "snake charmers" but at night it's just shoulder to shoulder people a real carnival feel --games are being played,more snake charmers,lots more souvenir stands and what seems like a million food stands--too many with aggressive barkers trying to get you to eat there--still it's an experience not to be missed--

Nothing like it!. I did not go into the square or La Place at night, which is when it is supposed to come alive. I think I would find it a bit claustaphobic. There are lots of places with panoramic views around the edge though. You can sit and watch all kinds of life pass by. It is very open and very hot! If you are women on your own, beware of pushy sellers, especially the women doing the henna tatoos. Never pay them more than 50 dirhams!
An attack on the senses. An amazing square where you can get everything from false teeth to a horse and carriage ride. Hot in the day, it really starts to come alive from 6pm.

A Marrakech Must. Beautiful, hideous, quiet, loud, crazy, unique, intimidating, the main square is a million different things. Snakes jostle with monkeys jostle with orange juice sellers jostle with henna tattooists jostle with story tellers jostle with musicians! And that's not even the half of it.Much quieter din the day during Ramadan, for obvious reasons and it was a very special place to be in the evening with everyone sat around waiting for the call to prayer to signal the end of the day's fast.You have to try eating at the pop-up stalls that start appearing from around 7pm onwards, even if it is just once. They can be very in your face and there isn't a huge amount of variety but it is an "experience". Apparently stall 14 is the place to go, although the one time we looked for it we couldn't find it.Be prepared to have to shrug off a seemingly endless number of young men attempting to persuade/drag you into their stall! You have to try it but the one meal we had was disappointing to say the least. Don't expect any freebies; if you're presented with food and accept it without having asked for it, you will be charged for it. Make sure to turn away anything you do not want.We found the best way to get oriented was to use the square as a central location to go back to whenever we got too lost. Just remember which way you came in!

Best Place in Marrakech. The best time to go is at approximately 9PM so that you can get a good deal- they close at midnight so it's when you can haggle most... It's best to explore without a tour guideAs you arrive at the souk, there is a hotel opposite the horses called Hotel Ali- they have the best exchange rate (£-DHS)

Exciting place. Here you will find god and simple food. Sitting on a bench when they are cooking your food just beside you. On daytime it is a market place and in evening it is showtime. The sound of a lot of people, music, salesmen makes the place a living spot. Full of life.

The night scene is overrated. More interesting during the day!. While the square seems to be all abuzz at night there is really not much going on when you stop to evaluate it. Some live music, a few games of chance, same touristy stuff to purchase that you can get everywhere and lots of places to eat. Stay away from the restaurants that surround the inside of the square. They're overpriced and the food is meh. Better off eating at one of the hundreds of stalls set up each night in the middle of the square. Much more fun!The square in the middle of the day is more interesting because there's less touristy stuff going on. We particularly liked observing the call to prayer when a large section is roped off, carpets are laid down and the men come to pray amidst the chants.

East meets West. An amazing place to go at dusk the sun goes down the sqyre comes to life, snake charmers , story tellers, smokey atmosphere from food stalls selling all sorts of exotic foods. We ate here several times but gave the brains she eps heads and weird looking fish a miss, what we did have was excellent food .
Ali Baba really exists. He must be roaming arround on Djemaa el Fna, especially at night.Very touristy but still enjoyable and very arabic atmosphere.Beware of tourist rip offs.

Atmosphere of Marrakech. Day and night impression is different. During the day is too hot to spend any time at square. Souks that are just next to it are more interesting. Might be a good idea to watch from the rooftop terraces of nearby cafes evening transformation of the square filling with food stands. Than you can come down and have dinner. Food and fresh orange juices are great. But be prepared to constantly be addressed, offered, even grabbed by your hand to come and see or try something. Not relaxing atmosphere at all, but it is atmosphere of Marrakech and it`s not to be missed.

Interesting but scary!. If you do not like your personal space, do not go!! Try not to look into anyones eyes as they will try and sell the shirt off their back. Wear shoes that cover your feet and take plenty of water.

Back to the future!!. Great Scott! What an experience! Snake charmers, falcon handlers, palm readers and out of town market traders from the mountains. What I experienced was an ancient people mixing with today's culture. More than just a tourist attraction this was a way of life. The hawker markets are impressively stocked with excellent hosts at every one of the 100+ stalls. Sit there and eat, that's what you're supposed to do and what an excellent time we had. The souks follow on from the square and be prepared for another culture shock! Happy exploring!

Interesting place to visit, but far from relaxing!. As I first approached this key landmark by day I was not struck by much visual beauty of the place, rather I was very aware of being hassled by many different street vendors and performers. At night, the square takes on a whole new life, the noise, smells and sights overwhelm the senses - but it is a must see.

Are you ready to Rumble???. Night Experience:It all begins with horse smell, when I say it, i reaaaally mean it. then as you pass the horses, you approaching the most amazing xperience of your life: buch of people surronding stories tellers and some chineese head braking games where wining is not a piece of cakeYou will see a huge smoke comming off the barbeque restaurants, Kebabs, Tagines, couscous, all you can imagine you will find it. If you are a fussy person, Just go to Mc donnald's or pizza Hut. But if you like to give it a try, you wont be desappointed. One advice, woman dress codes: forget short skirts and tight short jeans in a clear see thru colors because it simply will cause you more trouble than nice company.Or if you are with your husband , fiancée, or even just your boyfriend, please be ashame of yourself and wear something deecent. otherwise you will simply get what you're exactely were looking for all your vacations. other that that please enjoy number 32 sausage guy Hassan its greassy but taste really good. Don't look for desert, it does not belong to the list.Enjoy your Jamaa fna xprce ;)

Noisy, smelly! - but unmissable!. This is an excellent place to watch the locals shop, pick up some bargains yourself. See the snake charmers, but remember if they catch you taking photos they will demand a donation.Plenty of places to eat at reasonable cost around the perimeter of the square. At night try any of the pop-up eating places which set up around 8pm.

Entertaining but constantly harassed for money!. The square is very large and during the day, surprising empty except tor the orange juice sellers in their carts. However, from about 6pm onwards, the square becomes a hive of activity with all sorts of sideshows, music and acts of variable quality proliferating! The main problem I found was that as soon as you stopped at the back of a crowd to try and see what they were watching, you were immediately hassled to give money before you'd seen anything! And when you did give something, they were back again shortly to ask for more! And don't even think of taking photos of snake charmers, drummers or whatever - you'll have to pay even more!Eventually I decided that to just wander around and soak up the atmosphere was enough. I did sample the food from one of the "pop up" restaurants and very good it was too. I think the best way to enjoy the fun would be to sit in one of the many cafes and restaurants surrounding the square, enjoy a meal or a drink and watch the fun from a safe distance!

WAW. the square, a place where the past meets the present, the food the stories, the music and dance, the smokes and lights,the smellall together in a weird mix..........................................................................................................

Must see. The square is a great place to visit especially in the evening when food is cooked also the snake charmers and all the other entertainment including the man selling false teeth. A visit not to be missed.

A Place You Must Experience. We walked through the square during the day while with a tour guide and it was very quiet. He assured us we wouldn't recognize it in the evening. We were in Marrakech at the end of Ramadan. Since everyone was fasting until sundown (7:45pm) we didn't arrive until about that time. While walking towards the square we passed the mosque where thousands of people were praying before the fast broke. It was a beautiful sight to see.As prayers finished, the square was suddenly flooded with people looking to eat. We didn't eat at the food stalls since they were incredibly busy but there were so many to choose from if you wanted to partake. Men are showing you their menus and constantly inviting you to sit down at their picnic tables. We did visit the fresh orange juice stands - wonderful fresh squeezed oj for only 4 dh = .40 euros. And we purchased candied nuts and dried apricots from one of the beautifully laid out stands.The rest of the square was divided between entertainers - dancers, snake charmers, monkeys, henna artists, drummers, singers, etc and vendors selling clothes, shoes, lanterns, sunglasses - anything you could possibly want all placed out on bed sheets or crates on the ground. It was complete chaos and very entertaining. After circling around a few times, we went up to one of the restaurants with a roof top patio. It was even more amazing to see it from above and realize the sheer size of the masses below.We took a horse and carriage ride back to our hotel for 100dh = 10 euros. It was a pleasant way to ride while they took us past all the 5 star hotels.

Medina el Fna. This is a noisy vibrant area, local traders and vendors selling everything from fruit, clothing, to false teeth. Ats dusk settles the square is transformed into a large area for eating local produce, cooked on the spot. Good for a very interesting couple of hours.

"The Big Square". Lots of activity and fun during the day. Ideal to sit and drink coffee and just "people watch"
Such a different atmosphere at night. I have spent many hours here over the years. Just cannot keep away

Bustling and vibrant!. This is a 'lively' place to visit and a bit of an assault on the senses, with Arabic music, snake charmers, monkeys, market traders trying to get you to buy things etc. etc.We tried the fruit juice from the street vendors and it was the most refreshing juice ever so do try this. Having a smattering of Arabic is useful if only to deter the more insistent traders but in a polite way.We ordered drinks from a roof top café and watched the sunset go down over this unique place without having to experience the Square in the face!

The culture and experience of Marrakech. It is a hive of activity, from dawn to late into the night, the soul of Marrakech. Every type of market stall during the day and as the avenging approaches the snake charmers, acrobats, boxing, gambling, food stalls and a general melee of people and animals flood into this square. Haggle for everything, keep your money safe and watch out you don't get lost in the maze of alleyways of the souk. A don't miss this place when you go to Marrakech. Taxis are very good value for money all around Marrakech, but the driving is a nightmare.

a UNESCO site that you need to experience. This large square has been the center of Marrakech for centuries. According to a guidebook, this square had a gruesome past until the 19th century. Criminals who were given a death sentence were beheaded here. During the day, the activity level as well as crowds are low compared to the evening when the square comes to life. I would recommend going during the day and come back in the evening. There is a Bank Popular on the corner of the square that gives the best exchange rates. We were told not to eat in the pop up food stands due to the hygiene. There are many restaurants that have rooftops that would be much better. We did eat at a restaurant just off the square and see my review for more information. We did drink freshly squeezed orange juice for 5 dirhams. We wanted the juice in a plastic glass so it was 1 dirham more. This famous square taps into all five senses with snake charmers blowing their instruments, fortune tellers and women haggling for their services, musicians, smoke from the grills, and an unusual mix of people. I didn't really care to walk through the Jemaa in the evening because I felt the guys from the restaurant were rude when we didn't want to eat at their temporary stands. The items sold around the square were poorer quality so go farther into the souk. There are some stands for small tangines pots for 1 euro that make good souvenirs to bring home for friends. Make sure that you remember where you entered the Jemaa so you won't get lost.

Two sides of the same coin. Jemaa el Fna is an amazing place - by day a huge square full of people plying their trade - leather goods, tourist trinkets, food - the two stroke mopeds whizzing by missing you by a centimetre... busy busy busyThen as the sun starts to go down the stalls come out - the square is covered by the Morroccon equivalent to pop up restaurants - you can get all manner of food if your stomach is strong enough... Stalls upon stalls of cooked food - dried fruits, nuts, lamps, tagines the list goes on..There are alos story tellers, who judging by how interested their audience was must have told great stories - Alas not speaking Arabic was a bit of a barrier - we even saw a few cobras thrown in for good measure.A fascinating place either by day or by night. What amazed me most was it was one of the few places were we were not sexually harrassed. I actually felt calm and safe amongst the hustle and bustle

Crazy and fun. You really never know what you will see. It is very helpful to go with a guide as when the locals start to harass you with crazy prices for a picture or something he can tell them to leave you alone. By day there are snake charmers who will put a snake around your neck, moneys on chains people selling trinkets. At night is was wild. Fortune tellers, women doing henna. Way more locals than tourists. I liked it better at night.

The soul of Marrakech!. That's a place not to be missed once you are in Marrakech. It will be (more or less) the same like going to Cairo and not visiting the Pyramids.. Impossible!Jemaa El Fna has a very old history and the charm of this place is to be emerged into the flavour of its "past" which still surrounding the whole area. Either standing by the "halqas" with their snake charmers, monkeys, musicians, magicians, story tellers.. fortune tellers.. and any other sort of different thing, or simply walking around enjoying your time overthere - you can also stop by and eat some of the traditional moroccan specialties at the square during the evening.It is one of the most lively (and exotic) places I've been and I highly reccomend it!
Jamaa fna. Very original but they are too pushy. The merchandise is worth the trip the food not bad either but no bathrooms

must see. go for a horse and buggy ride outside Jeemaa E Fna. The market and its sounds, smells, wears and beggars and snake charmers are all interesting. Don't attempt to take photos of the snake charmers or you will be bombarded with them asking for money for the photos you took.  when purchasing anything bargain and then bargain again. The food stalls start after 5:p.m. its a must try. It is very crowded and hot no matter why time of day. Ladies, watch your purses.

Very touristy now. Has changed a lot over the last few years and is now very commercial, you do get hassled by the henna ladies and people charging you to take photos. At sunset and nighttime get a front view seat on one of the terraces of the restaurants around the square and watch the sights below.

The life of the city is here. We took a number of walks around this space. There are snake charmers, wonderful food for sale, and the sites and smells of Morocco . It was where you must go when you visit.

Go at night. Day time Jemaa el Fna features hundreds of orange juice carts, snake charmers, and henna tattoo artists. The orange juice is refreshing, but look for the carts who serve ice-free juice with not sugar or additives. The snakes are lazy, loathsome, and probably abused. Get too close to the charmers with your camera, and they'll basically waive snakes at you until you pay them a tip for your photos. Beware the aggressive henna "artists." Marrakech has anti-harrasment laws on the books, and shop-owners in the souks are pretty respectful of a firm 'no,' but the Jemaa el Fna is definitely a different story.At night, the snakes, orange juice et al. disappear. In their place, singers, dancers, storytellers, and slew of tent-restaurants. Watch for a good-looking grill, wedge yourself in between tourists from France and Australia, and tuck in to a plate of hot, sizzling meat. It may not be the soul of the city anymore, but it's definitely a circus worth experiencing. Bring small change for the entertainers, as the tip-hat is passed frequently.

What a dump. This place is fake and a dump. In the main square there are "snake charmers" that you cannot get anywhere near without them grabbing your arm and demanding money just for walking nearby. There are monkeys in nappies, tied round the neck is rope held by their controller. There are a long row of barrels with oranges on to sell you fresh squeezed orange juice. It just looks like and feels like the most fake uninteresting "dodgy" place ever. Getting away from the square you enter a world of hassle and bad smells, bad service from people who turn nasty quickly if you dont buy their overpriced tack, dodging mopeds which roar up and down the small lanes and gangs of guys who try every kind of scam to get you to buy from their mates. There are indeed some fantastic places in the world to see authentic peoples selling and displaying their local crafts but this isn't one of those places.

Felt Intimerdated. The locals made me feel very intimerdated when walking through Jemaa el fna and the souks. Also the owners of the shops have little monkeys and we saw them being beaten with a stick. Not a nice place also you should never take children there.

An experience. Although I had been told about this previously, I was still taken aback by the different sounds, sights and smells. Fantasticly interesting with snake charmers, monkeys, dancers, pop-up restaurants etc. You name it, it will probably be there! Great at night, but still worth a visit in the daytime. There are reasonably priced cafes with balconies all around, and they are good vantage points to enjoy the mayhem. Be warned ladies, you may have your bottom stroked.

Among the great squares of the world, this one is an abomination. You want to be pulled at, drawn into scams, bothered for money, harassed, eat oversalted rotting food, watered down sugary 'orange' juice, have snakes be your entertainment of the day - then go. You deserve it. Its 'magical' and oh-so-oriental.There are many cities in the world, africa or the middle east in which you can have an authentic experience of a gathering place which also is a central square. This is not one of them.
Wild experience. A must to do in Marrakesh. Very fun and crazy. We were warned about pick pockets but felt very safe.

Guarded. We spent an hour , at the end of a fantastic guided tour, it was "free time" . My daughter had expressed interest in having her hand henna tattooed , being told not to get the black henna done as it usually contains " petrol or paraffin " we headed to the square , the first two women we saw who did henna cane over to get us to sit disown , may daughter enquired what colour , to be told brown/black , next she was handed a book of designs which my daughter handed back saying she didn't want this one doing as was wrong colour , as she handed the book back,the woman grabbed her arm holding her so tight. That the had red marks up her arm later, she then proceeded to scribble on my daughters hand whilst my daughter repeatedly told her she didn't want It doing , I tried to intervene,, and tried to pull her away, then another woman turned up asking for money , we told her that we never wanted it doing , then my daughter complained that It was itching and stinging her arm , I got some tissues and started to scrape it off,while the woman demanded money 600 dh ,!!!,!!Approx 48 pounds , my daughter started getting upset said she didn't have that money and gave the woman 10 dh which the woman shouted abuse, we got away shouting that we never asked for it. A kind man from one of the food stalls took my very upset daughter to his stall and washed it off with some water and washing powder . Seems they want money for everything , you takes photo in their direction and they demand money ,

A worthwhile experience. The square is a must by day and night. 2 very different experiences, by day it's snake charmers and monkeys a photo is a must, but don't be pressurised to over pay. By night it's food stalls and food markets, all are after your business.

very busy, plenty to do and see and cheap. This is a must see when you visit Marrakech, there are snake charmers, vultures, monkeys (be careful if you take a picture of them you will have to pay them, 5 dirhams is acceptable, if you only have notes on you, you have to give them that so have plenty of change available. The souks are also a must see but they can be abit uncomfortable as you are mithered a lot to view their stalls as you walk along. Also take no notice when they say , that way is closed, or give you directions as they will be directing you to their stall. There are many rooftop cafes and you can get some amazing pictures from up there. The freshly squeezed orange juice is highly recommended at just 4 dirhams.

Bustling!. Busy, busy, busy! I was not worried about being pick-pocketed, but that does not mean you should not keep an eye out for your belongings. There is so much going on in the medina that one can easily be distracted. I tried to warm my partner that nothing is for free in Morocco, but we ended up being swindled by a gentleman doing henna in the heart of the square. Use caution when looking at the money in your wallet, and assume that even products or services provided for "karma" or "good luck" will still cost you a few MDH!

Hate this place..... Starving children, animal cruelty, rip offs, thefts, pickpockets, exceptionally poor food hygiene.If this the kind of thing you love in your holiday, you'll have a great time here.

Great sense of culture. Excellent day was spent in Jemaa el Fna, once we got into the stride of it all we really enjoyed it. We did get bothered a little by people wanting to sell us ornaments, but as long as you shake your head politely and say no then they aren't so bad. We were able to barter a lot and everything we bought was at a decent price. Overall very enjoyable but keep your eyes open and be polite.

Jemal El Fna. Full of buzz in a good way and maybe in a not so good way. By the latter I mean that the sweets or biscuit type food the hawkers were selling were literally covered with bees. Great atmosphere here in the square after 5pm, when the place is alive with impromptu performances by snake charmers dancers singers. Beware if you take a photo you will be expected to pay for the privilege. The Souks which run off the Jemal El Fna are an amazing feast for the eyes with everything from leather to silver to kaftans and Moroccan pants on sale at very varying prices . By all means enjoy the haggling over prices but keep it fun and be prepared for several best and special prices. A word of advice venture into the Souks early in the morning first to get an idea how to navigate as at night it is very easy to get lost. Loved haggling but got a little bored with the sameness of what was on offer at the different stalls. Moroccan people generally very warm welcoming and friendly.

It has to be seen and absorbed. The colour and vibrancy is wonderful. Stalls selling every food imaginable from sheep heads to fish. Freshly squeezed oranges. Berbers selling water from goatskin jugs. Snake charmers, acrobats and so on. Beware the beggars for we were advised that they are not genuinely needy. One girl held out one hand and pleaded poverty and hunger whilst holding an ice-cream in the other hand. Also be careful in paying for small items with large notes - the usual trick is for the vendor to say he will go and get change and he may not return. The police are vigilant however and will help you.

Crazy place with a lot of activity. Spent parts of several days wandering around this zoo and sea of people.. Had some great street food in the evenings here. The days have snake charmers, monkey handlers, henna artists, and so many other things. The vendors are aggressive, so if you are good with this, then you might want to avoid this place. Much better to visit in the evening when all the food stalls are going...
Marrakesch at its best. I you like open air food stalls, snake charmers, male belly dancers and just the smell and shuffle of houndreds of people milling about, you will love this place.

World Busiest Square. A must visit if you are in Marrakesh, Morocco. I visited Marrakesh with a friend in Feb which is off peak season and the weather was not so hot. We went to the medina (old quarter) early to avoid the crowd. Do spend some time absorbing the hectic atmosphere of the square. There were lots of orange juice stalls, snake charmers, ladies offering henna hand tattoo and dancers in ethnic clothing. You may take a photo with them for a small fee.The square is very big with lots of locals and tourists. Be careful with your wallets and keep a close watch over your handbags in case of pick-pockets. Bring a bottle of water with you as the weather can get very hot. Otherwise, it's cheap to have a cup of freshly squeezed orange juice. In the evening about 5pm, we went to a roof-top restaurant over-looking the square for a meal and watch the square transformed in front of your eyes into dozens of food stalls selling grilled kebabs and other BBQ meats. If you are brave enough, try the sheep's head. Apparently, it's a delicacy in Morocco. There are many good restaurants surrounding the square. We were in Marrakesh for 8 days. Out of the 8 days, we had dinner at restaurants there 6 days in a roll. Try the lamb shish kebab, chicken or lamb tagine, hummus and finish your meal with a refreshing mint tea. The food we had were reasonably priced and delicious. The sight, smell and energy of the whole place was unbelievable. I will definitely go there again.

crazy. Here you will see it all monkeys, snakes, men belly dancing. I mean everything crazy crazy crazy. Definitely go there at night and eat. I went to the stall where the guy guaranteed no diarrhea tomorrow sounded like the best sales pitch to me

A square. A square like El Fnaa is always Nice to do! Just watch out for the monkeys and snakes they put on your shoulder, even nota skiede and then you have to pay for it, even of you took a picture with your one camera, but you d'ont want the monkeys on you because they are filled with fleeces

Mixed feelings. Had very mixed feelings about djamaa el fna. The chaos and atmosphere is enjoyable but the bartering of the stall holders and anybody selling something is just too much. I wanted to take my time and look through all the wonderful bazaars but I just ended up running away!
Hectic but great experience. Visiting in the day/night have total different story. Personally, I prefer visiting it at night where it's more vibrant. However, beware of the snakes and monkey.......

Be wary. Fantastic vibrant square, we ate at night on the food stalls and were fine, no poorly tummies No 25 stay alive, no 117 straight to heaven they have little rhymes to tempt you in and are really good fun. However be aware some of the men can vile touching western women, being disrespectful spitting as they see you it can be intimidating. Snake charmers and men with monkeys will approach you but are ok if you say NO sternly same with the Henna ladies if you don't want it done, if you do make sure you watch someone having it done first

Predictable. For me, this square was more exciting on TV than it was in person. I was expecting a larger than life feel. My best memory was asking a friendly orange juice stall owner for a local restaurant recommendation. He invited me to climb up with him so he could give me directions to a small side street with description of the right archway to go through. I did find it and returned to thank him again.

A word of caution. Just to make you aware not to trust strangers. My boyfriend and I visited here as this place is listed as one of the "must see" in marrakesh. First time we went there was last 7th june. Near sunset time. The market is an open square with lots of stuff being sold, and you can be enchanted and swayed and can easily get lost especially when you start entering the alleys. This happened to us and perhaps we looked like deer in the headlights, a man said "you looking for the square?" And he started talking in a friendly way and leading us as he said to the square. I didnt feel particularly 100% comfortable but then i thought oh what a nice locale just guiding a lost tourist. After around 10 min, we reached a point where he pointed out that it's just there by that end of the street. At this moment where he stopped, there were two men who clearly he knows of. We started to say our thanks and goodbye to the "friendly" guide, when his companion said to give him a little something. And then our "friendly guide" said 100 dirhams. I was incredulous and i repeated the amount he asked and then i said no, just 20. Then one of his companions started pointing his finger at me. The three of them started getting verbally aggressive and was really insistent on 100. We are not happy. We ended up giving 50. And receiving f*** y** words as we turned our backs. Such a bad experience.

Daytime fairly safe madness and evening mayhem in the square.. In the Medina near the Koutoubia Mosque. Best to circle its perimeter first on foot without stopping or acknowledging anyone. Watch our for Taxis, delivery trucks and mopeds - they won't stop! Head to the corner furthest from the Mosque and pay for a tea or coffee (Cash MAD only No Cards) in the Café de Paris and settle down. Take some photos from here using your zoom lens; you will be charged by Anyone you take a photo of in the square if they see you. Take a stroll and keep moving or stop between the Orange Juice Vendors (4 MAD a glass about £0.30 GBP) and view the musicians, snake charmers, acrobats etc. NB. If you stop and watch a show for more than a few seconds you will be asked to pay! No problem or trouble in stopping for a few seconds. If you do takes lots of small change in MAD or Euro. 5 MAD seemed to be ok for a full on long mad snake show with music and many staff - you pay when they ask you. The Water Sellers in Red Costumes will approach you for photos with them (they no longer sell eater) if you agree its 2 MAD a person photo. The price varies wildly depending on what you agree. Take lots of small change in MAD. They don't want other currencies and notes are too much to pay, smallest note is 20 MAD (£1.50 GBP). There are Caliche (2 Horse and Carriage) rides in the corner nearest the Mosque. 100 MAD per ride for 20 minutes agreed in advance was OK. There prices are displayed on the seat wall and all Caliches have a number on the back. If you have a dispute at the end take the number and call or find the Tourist Police in the Square and tell the driver you will be back to Settle it with the Police. Ensure the price agreed is per ride and not per person! Ensure you visit in the day before you venture back for the night evening and food (if you dare). There are no public WC and the cobbled square is filthy and smelly. Wear conservative clothing, cover up (linen trousers and shirts are fine with trainers) and do not take valuables. Watch your pockets and bags for pickpockets and kids on mopeds. It can and was safe and fun - but be careful. One girl with a bikini and see through kaftan and flip flops was spat at by locals (rightly so) this is Marrakech City and not the beach.
The Heart of the City. Great place to see people trading for hundreds of years but beware they have modern day tactics, especially the snake photo, once caught that's it!

Hated this place. Went to Jemaa el Fna both during the day and in the evening. It was more alive in the evening but on both occasions we were constantly hassled by vendors wanting us to buy their wares. We only had to point to something on passing and we were immediately surrounded. I also hated the use of animals for 'entertainment'. The poor horses, monkeys, snakes etc looked so sad and dehydrated. This practice should be banned and idiots that pay money to take photos should be ashamed of themselves for endorsing this. Will never go back.

Madness of Marrakech. The square is an amazing spectacle by day but more so at sunset/evening time. Take time to stroll through and enjoy the many sights and smells of Jemaa El Fna.But be very careful when taking photo's of any of the performers - snake charmers, monkeys, dancers & even the traditional water sellers or women who apply henna tattoos (they all demand payment for any photo's taken & usually ask for a ridiculous amount of 200 dirhams). So ensure to agree a price before you take a photo - don't go any higher than 20 dirhams. They will shout & argue with you, but they never refuse the money offered in the end. Also, make sure you keep a watch for any traffic, especially horse drawn carriages, mopeds & taxis.I found this place fascinating, but it's best observed from a terrace at one of the Cafes/restaurants that surround the square. Infact this is your best bet for a great photo opportunity, especially at sunset.

the heart of marrakech. it is really true that this very fascinating place is the heart of Marrakech. I went with my wife as well as the kids. we spent the whole morning watching snake charmers and monkey dressers! it was a lovely day out there! it's a must to see when you are in Marrakech!

what a place. many aspects and changes from morning to night and best experienced at night when the food stalls are in full swing. Experience a delight by sitting at a bench and being served tasty cooked and cold foods at a verygood price. walk around and see the storytellers, music dancing and soak in the atmosphere of marrakech. I just thought of Plant and Page setting up and playing there amazing.

Loved it!. Keep in mind that when you visit this amazing place to keep your belongings close and try not to look like a really noticeable tourist. There are pick-pocketers and scammers all across and they may seem intimidating wanting your money. But they wont hurt you. Just simply walk away from anyone demanding for your money. ALSO don't get henna here. A lot of the time they use harsh chemicals because the typical tourist wants it to last longer. This could cause a serious infection and the last thing you want is a hospital trip on your vacation. Try to meet locals and find a legit place and person to give you Henna. Other then being cautious, this place is fabulous. Don't go in the early morning. Try to go in the afternoon or at night. The streets are a maze and lots of fun for shopping. I something seems over priced, it probably is. They mark up the prices for tourists, and don't be fooled. Most of them speak several languages but might pretend like the barley know English. Offer to bargain with them, these little shops are not franchises so its interested offering a little less or saying you will buy the same thing down the street for half the price. Trust me they will give in when they know you can bargain.  I loved this market. It was a wonderful experience that I would never take back. Its fun, different, and well worth the time. I believe if you are traveling all the way to Morocco you gotta check it out!!

Must see. Mad place ! By day and by night be prepared to be transported to another world. Don't eat the food from the market ... Plenty of cafe to eat and drink music of an evening selling all kind of goods by day it's a food market

A must!. As it was our 1st time to Marrakech we were a little bit overwhelmed and worried. Th entrance to the souk by Jemaa el Fna was perfect, people very smiling and nice. At dawn, the place was completely different, full of little places to enjoy kebabs and Orange juice, with lot of light and a very easygoing mood. A true moroccan experience, although not very different from the Sevilla' s feria de abril atmosphere.

Mad !. An assault on the senses and not always in a good way, but on the whole great fun in small doses.My tips :-- If you eat at one of the plethora of food stalls, be careful not to be railroaded into letting the waiters choose all your food for you without letting you see a menu. You will inevitably end up with double the amount of food and double the bill that you expected.- if you don't wants snakes and monkeys thrust upon you, then keep your wits about you as you stroll around the square.- After a hard day getting lost in the Souks, grab a drink on the balcony of one of the cafés overlooking the Square, they start to set up stalls from late afternoon onwards. Once night falls, the square really does come alive. Don't bother dressing up, unless you've got a snake charmers outfit.

Draining after a couple of days.. This is the heart of the city centre, a standard market type scene during the day which comes alive at night.I personally didn't like it but unfortunately it's kind of unavoidable as you go about your time/business in Marrakech.It's grubby and smells horrible too!I thought Madrid/Barcelona and even London were a pain when busy but this is something else, you have to avoid being run over by scooters/cars/tuk tuks and horse and carts whilst trying not to make eye contact with snake charmers/monkey owners and 'water sellers' in fear of being charged for the experience and at the same time keep your wits intact to avoid being pick pocketed and/or harassed to buy junk!!!!The souks located off this square are much nicer and more welcoming, it's just unfortunate that this is a big part of the attraction!The best place to escape this square is the 'Glacier cafe' where you can chill out, watch the madness unfold and get good photo's of the sunset and mosque.

medivial circus in the modern times. this place was very colorful in the evening. cant get over the snake charmers.. im too afraid of the snakes.. sigh... the place offers almost all of the local foods. spend more time to find the cheapest table..surely pays off.

Day and night - a typical Moroccan contradiction.. As often happens with this sort of place, it has become a victim of its own success.There would not be too many among us that haven't seen on TV or read in a brochure something exotic about this place.We initially went there in the early morning with some "almost" locals, because we had to witness this famous square for ourselves.It was ~10am and was, as we were to learn alter that day, comparatively quiet.Locals crossing the half empty square going about their business, classes of children sitting down paying attention to their teacher, the odd snake charmer, some fruit/juice carts, a few tourists .....There was little to distinguish it from the many other square, such as this, throughout the rest of Morocco, other than, perhaps, its size.We wandered off into the many souks that start, and or finish in the square.We spent many hours enjoying the hundreds of stalls, stopping every now and then for a drink.I don't know how many kilometers there are of these alleys but it feels like hundreds.By and large they are in sections.One part has clothes, another has foodstuffs, another leather goods ..... but there are no certainty or rules as to what is where.Getting lost?Almost everyone within the souk speaks a multitude of languages and are astute enough to see and help a lost tourist.They inevitably will point you back to the main square, and I witnessed, and experienced their help, several times during the day. As we were staying close by we went back to our hotel for a rest before returning for the "main event" i.e. the food stall of the night market.We came back at ~8pm and the square was indeed a maze of pop-up restaurants.We wandered about looking and listening to the touts ("Fixed price menu for you madam/sir!" which seemed to change depending on who they were pitching to.), the mesmerised tourists (as every restaurant is fairly similar to the next), the disgruntled tourists (of which we overheard an alarming amount - prices, quality of food, pushy /rude staff etc.) and, to be fair, quite a few people that were in awe of the whole thing.Personally, I have eaten, and know many others that have, far better for far less with better service at the hundred of places away from the square.This does not mean that you should go for a look of a night, especially with a "pre-visit" during the early day, but don't bother with meal as, unless you have exceptionally low standards, you will be disappointed. Go, but with low culinary and high cultural gap expectations ..... and most of all keep your wits about you and don't judge.

Fun, loud, scammy, dazzling, junky, overpriced and great. Got to go. Giant meeting place/market square for the past thousand years changes throughout the day and evening. Lots of fun to see (snakecharmers, apes, spices, produce, and overflowing trinkets/clothing to buy). Heap of cool cafes/restaurants line one side of the space. Crowds build up over afternoon and get busy in evening. Easy and less crowded/less vendors during day - lights are magical in evening but super busy then as well.

arabian charm but too much harrassment. I took the uninspired decision to travel during the Ramadhan and defy the high temperatures, which is on me: by day, it was devoid of people save a few tourists and locals had no appetite to interact with *anyone* as they were fasting. Come the evening, the place is very lively and colorful, plenty of overpriced trinkets for sale, delicious fresh fruit (fresh figs are a treat), there is a lovely vibrant atmosphere all around, but the Arabian authenticity of the place is spoiled by the aggressive sales tactics of the vendors, especially in the makeshift dinner area. I particularly enjoyed the presence of the snake tamers, though I wouldn't get too close.

You cannot nor will not avoid it!. For a moment you might feel you are reliving a past that has been lost in your own country : dancers in colourful costumes, local instruments, story tellers in the middle of a throng of mesmerised listeners, snake charmers, instant eateries... one big pageant that cannot be missed

Touristy but interesting. A must see - just remember to say a firm no to the ladies trying to draw hennas and watch they will try to grab your arm and draw even though you said no. 20 dh is more than enough for photos of snakes do not let yourself be talked into paying more. A firm no thank you seemed to work

full of Money SCAMS !. do not Eat here, 2 of the stalls for food scammed me,doubled the bill. its all a MONEY SCAM.  they will show 30 MAD prices and charge you 60 because they brought you extra (unasked) for things like bread(which i thought came with the item ordered). or they will bring you different item like add vegetables to your lamb skewers and double its price when you only ordered lamb skewers, not with vegetables. so this one time me my husband and baby were having dinner, i asked for lamb skwers they said 30 MAD, pointed to the menu i said ok fine. next thing i know is im charged 60 MAD for my lamb skwer, my husband being a LAMB(naive) just paid the entire bill , i left the stall, 117 but 2 seconds later i was back, i started screaming at those guys to give me money back or ill tell all your customers that you are scamming doubling the bill...GUESS WHAT? i got my money back . as these idiots will do anything to get you seated, and double your bill? i hate dishonest work ethics so i stood up for my rights!henna lady did the same to me, for one she was rude, and in the end she told me F U....secdonly she agreed to do my palm henna design for 20 MAD and she drew a 1 inch design on my palm and said thats it, i was like we agreed to whole palm. They will say anything to get you seated, then they start becoming rude, so i said no you agreed to whole palm so please complete it, i won;t leave. then shes like leave, F U. i was like whoa F U.lol...they do this scam because they dont have a business name, they just want the bucks!i advise you all to eat the cafes around Jem El Fenna, fixed prices, no doubling the bills, no bringing in extra bread to charge you more. but the good side of the square is its lively, horse carriage ride was great fun, my duaghter was always entertained by just being at the square, the banks are all there(although the banque de poulaire machine swalloed my creditcard lol),post office its all there, so its a good location its central to it all, the orange juice stalls are great, fixed prices,fresh juices. just dont eat here, and when you have to shop, go deep within the souks, dont buy from outside shops that are in the square(they are the ones selling fake stuff,pushy salesman, so go deeper within the souks, but dont go alone into the souks,you can get lost)but if you visit the square and eat there and if they double your bill (2 vendors did this to me,second time around i went back created hell infront of their stalls until i got my money back, you have to do this, stand up for dishonest bills people, that night they lost few potential customers as i stoof loud and clear THAT YOU CANT FOOL ME,YOU CANT ADD EXTRA ITEMS YOURSELF ANd CHARGE ME DOUBLE-not me! i was going to stand there with my baby until their business reputation would be damaged !

PICK POCKETS. After our tour to sahara the driver dropped us at the square.It is great for shopping and food.i was only in the square for 5 minutes before i felt a teenage boys hand in my pocket where my wallet was... he was not successful and i spent the rest of my time in the square with my hand in my pocket clutching my wallet... terribleI had children asking me for money every 20 steps i took.It is more busy than times square in new york and on par with the Shibuya traffic crossing in Japan. VERY BUSY.Positive - snake charmers, good shopping, plenty of food stalls, plenty of police and people (who are not working there) are generally lovely and welcoming.

Mind the snakes. During the day one has to skuttle across the square keeping an eye on the snake charmers. In the evening they go home and the square is transformed into activity of all sorts. Food stalls appear and so do dancers, story tellers, musicians and people. On one evening take a walk though the square and enjoy some food at a stall. I have eaten there on 3 separate visits to Marrakech without any 'side effects'. The food is freshly cooked in front of you. Try mixed kebabs and a tagine and they will provide bread, olives and tomato dip. Mint tea is also served.

Sensory overload and worth the trip to Marrakech!. After a long, harrowing drive on back roads from Khouribga to Marrakech, (and after getting lost twice) I was so happy to finally get out of the car only to be overwhelmed by the sights, sounds and smells of this massive square! We arrived just after dusk and walked thought the throngs of entertainers, henna ladies, and a lot of fresh orange and grapefruit stalls. There is something for everyone and be sure to bargain for lowest prices. My colleagues insisted on dining at one of the many outdoor food stalls (veggies, meat sitting out at the ambient temp of 102 degrees - no refrigeration or chillers in sight) and while my stomach said yes to kebabs, etc.,, my common sense took over so I opted for only bread, olives and a coca cola. I'm having only minor stomach distress today. Be sure to bring anti- bacterial moist wipes and constantly keep your hands clean especially before eating. Be aware of your surroundings and keep your belongings close to your person or use a money belt especially at night.

Like no other place. Jemaa el Fna is like no other place I've ever been to. Exciting smells, sounds, people, food. Definitely go at night, and definitely definitely go up to Cafe Grand Balcon where you get an aerial perspective of all the stalls. The view is mesmerising.

a Nice Place to visit. a very nice place to visit but still need more security from pick pocket. there is only one camera there still need more and there is an information desk which was done to have someone inside to give information to tourists but this one is closed. so tourists are forced to ask people or have to take a guide who are most of them cheaters. Police are just focused on beside matters thats to check if moroccans are escorting tourists to make them regrets or put them in jail for escorting friends. never saw that in other countries.Good Food available for purchase no Bathroom facilities that s very terribleStairs / elevator no needs Wheelchair access okLockers / storage needs to be installedStroller parking terrible ... everybody want to be a parking agent by putting a vest and asking for crazy amount even after the time of parking machine which is from 8 am to 8pm

An assault on your senses!. Love the quirkiness of many of the layout of the souk and the attractions in the square itself. Whatever you do, ask for prices upfront and where possible get them to write it down so there are no discrepancies after. Don't allow any random person to 'show you around'....they will expect payment for doing so! Don't accept a price you've been told (unless in a prix fixte shop) and definitely haggle! Don't worry about missing out on something if you have to walk away...there will be tonnes of other stalls selling exactly the same things!! At the orange juice stalls make sure you've been given orange juice (4dh) and not pampelmousse/grapefruit juice (15dh!!). Beware also of the men with the Barbary apes...they will get you to pose with the monkey before you've even agreed and then demand payment for it. Some can be quite unpleasant if they don't get the sum they've asked for. Forget your Western etiquette here; be brash and confident and don't worry about offending with a firm NO!!

Everyone goes here. All the locals come here too and it's a crazy place very busy. Lots of people ftying to get you to buy things or be photographed holding a monkey or snake. Beware the ladies in burkhas as they want to paint your hand with henna and we were warned that it is the kind people can react badly to, Definitely worth visiting to see "life", though don't need to spend too long here. Sit at a cafe, drink a mint tea and watch the world go by.

Do not miss this crazy place!. To visit Morocco and miss Jemaa el Fna would be like leaving Pisa without visiting the Leaning Tower. During the day it's a market, with fresh orange juice in abundance for around 30 pence a glass, spices of various vibrant colours like we've all seen in the guidebooks but real,alongside mounds of olives and preserved lemons which assault your sense of smell in a very pleasant manner. Yes, you get some hassle to buy but it's part of the enjoyment.Then you go back to the square in the evening and what a place! It's so alive, with the snake charmers and the monkeys, the cross dressing belly dancers and the story tellers. Waiters in with mockney accents persuading you to try the cuisine at their barbecue, swearing that it's 'lovely jublee' and there is 'no diarrhoea here'! Yes, some of the entertainment is a bit forced and perhaps not totally authentic, you can't linger for too long without being asked for money, but it's an absolute must. This is an experience not to miss, an opportunity to be entertained, enthralled and dazzled. (I should add that the monkeys are not a pleasant sight, they made us very sad).There are lots of highlights and a few tips that would be useful but far better to go and learn for yourself! We didn't eat on the square, a few minutes away and you will find slightly less commercialised restaurants often with Moroccan musicians to entertain you whilst you eat. Do not resist the temptation to visit at night, even if you are absolutely shattered from pacing the medina and getting lost in the souks all day, you must not miss it!

not for me but.... bustling, heavy, high octane! the marketeers, performers and vendors are are grasping for your attention, huge hassle and mega impeding. These are a few of my hated things. so for me, the Jemaa el Fna is stifling and I wouldn't do it again. BUT I would completely recommend it to people who are happy in these environments, It is rich in culture, both high and lo, and for adventurers and explorers I can appreciate how amazing it must be. It's just not for me.

Too much. It is ok to visit maximum twice. We just got very tired and annoyed by persistent sellers. Some of them do not take 'no, thank you' for an answer. Henna tattoo ladies are very aggressive- I was approached twice, said 'no' and both times they just grabbed my hand and tried starting doing tattoo and I could not take my hand away so my husband had to help me.When entering souks guy asked if we were looking for some place, we said no, so he tried to take us shopping and when we started walking away asked for money and cigarettes, when got nothing started following us, cursing and swearing.Did not enjoy watching monkeys in the nappies in +37C heat.It is an experience we had, but I would not go back.

wow. I knew that a lot of people gather here, but I was not expecting this. In the day it's like any other market, but at night it comes alive.You have the impression that all the tables and the grills just appeared out of nowhere. There are big and small gatherings were they play music and dance, lots of snakes for you to take pictures with, lady's who paint with henna and many others.

Morning Freshly squeezed orange juice and Dinner all together!. Every single day there are a lot of food-stalls at Djemma el-Fna. Every people all around were coming to have dinner over there and enjoy and talk to people. We were in Morocco during Ramadan, so it was even more excited, because everybody was waiting for that second, they could start eating. We met there a lot of people, it was really fun. Although it is full of tourists, so also there are many locals and we had chance to talk to them. If you are in Marrakesh, never miss dinner at Djemma el-Fna. The atmosphere is amazing and food delicious!

Fantastic. This place is INCREDIBLE. It is one of the must visit places. It is so overwhelmingly fantastic when you see it first time...Tips:gotta be quick, or before you know it, there's going to be a Henna painting on your hand, or a monkey on your shoulder. :)for the food: see number #14 and number #94. Go watch the sunset in one of the restaurants with panoramic views.

Ok but a bit too much hassle for our taste.. It ŵas ok. The food is basic but cheap. We prefer the predictability of a restaurant menu as prices of food can be subject to a conversation afterwards. If you go just be specific about what you want to order and pay for.

A must on any visit to Marrakech. This is the place where everything happens, especially at night. Surrounded by cafés/restaurants and the entrance to the souks, the square is a cacophony of sights, sounds and smells. Food sellers, loads of carts selling beautiful fresh orange juice, henna tattooists, snake charmers, acrobats, and all sorts of goods for sale. Just a great place to wander around or stop for a juice or a coffee and watch the world go by.
Entertaining.. See my rating of the Marrakech Medina. In addition, it's a great place to pick up a horse drawn carriage for a ride back to your lodging.
Don't visit in the daytime :). In the daytime it's a smelly, barren, hot waste of space with no charm whatsoever. Apparently it's transformed at night time, but we couldn't be bothered to go back.
Wonderful Chaos. The sqaure is amazing. It is crowded and hectic, but an absolute must-do for anyone traveling to Marrakech. The food stalls at night were incredible.

Not what I expected. I'm unsure if the area has changed but I was expecting a real variety of street entertainers here. Thought the day the snake charmers that use highly drugged snakes pester you, and the monkeys chained around the neck look extremely abused. The henna ladies are the worst at pestering. The evening is more pleasant where local musicians come to play and the locals spend the night watching. I was expecting acrobats, said swallowers and fire breathers perhaps more of a circus of acts.
Rip Off bad food. Do not be tempted just for the spectacle, poor food, poor hygiene at high prices. Eat in one of the many restaurants around the square and deeper into the town

Colours, smell and sounds. Had the time of our lifes just spending hours watching people on the squares. Tourists browsing, the hustling of vendors attracking you to their foodcorner, music of preformers, all amids thousands of lights and smoke coming from the cooking on the square.Go to a balconny of a cafe, and for the price of one drink, you can sit there for hours. When the sun is setting, is best.
Jemâ El-Fna. It's located in the heart of Marrakech near to the mosquee of Koutobia, best place for shopping or eating a good tajine or as well a couscous!.

Wow. Defintely a place to visit, a lot to take in when you first arrive. Lots going on, snakes, monkeys, just be carful as a few people come running at me with a snake. There are a lot of food stalls in the evening which you should experience at least one and its defintely worth a visit to one of the rooftop cafes to see it all from above. Did get a bit boring seeing the same thing by the end of the holiday though.

Every traveler must go here once in a lifetime.. One of the best people watching places on earth. You will be'ripped off' but in a friendly way! Watch out for the snakes and monkeys and the mad hatted water sellers.Buy some fresh dates and a tagine and enjoy a mint tea.

Full of life marketplace. The main square is a must for a visit both during the day when you can browse but also at night when the food stalls open up and what seems like all the insects in Morocco turn up as well. Eating here could seriously damage your health.

Hustle and Bustle with a bit of Muscle. A perfect place to people watch but on occasion we were singled out for being foreigners. A polite "no thank you" is usually enough, but you still need to be on your guard. Watch out for the henna tattoo ladies as they have a forceful grip and once inked, demand money. Besides that, make sure you visit at least once at night to see the food stalls come to life. If you are a photographer, try and find a nice cafe on the edge of the square with a rooftop view, you won't be disappointed!

Amazing. Loved this place never been hassled much can walk around all day if you want to buy say what you want to pay for it if they haggle just walk away they soon run after you .the best time of the day for me is the evening grab a seat on a roof top cafe and watch the sun go down and the square change heaven .

Wandering afternoons. I liked the whole atmosphere of the jemaa el fna. The big square is so busy and full of life. They have entertainers and women doing henna. They have orange juice stands and dried fruit/nut stands. Along the streets leading to it you can spend hours looking through the shops. It's really an interesting place to visit.Be prepared for shop workers to approach you and ask how much you want to pay, show you their wares, etc. They are very forward about business and catching consumers here. It's easy to get lost, but that is part of the fun of it. As long as you know the general direction you came from, it should be easy enough to find your way back to the main square. If you do want to buy something, don't forget to haggle. They don't do it for food, but for most other things it should be common.Nothing ever happened to me, but keep an eye on your surroundings if you have a backpack with your wallet, passport, etc. in it.You will get get cat-called if you are a solo female traveler like myself. A pair of girls might receive the same treatment. It helps to have a male or group to walk around with because it deters younger males from saying things. It's only an annoyance and not an actual threat, but it does start to grate on you after a few days. It was worse when I went towards the evening around 7 than in the afternoons.Overall, it's an interesting place to be. You don't need to spend money here, just keep your eyes open and have curiosity as you wander through all the stalls.
Wow. After the first nervous visit we soon got used to the people, noise, smells of the square. We always started our day with a coffee or mint tea sitting on the terrace of Cafe Balcon.
Wow !. The many colours of clothing, leatherware and carpets is mind blowing and beautiful. Very crowded, but that's to be expected.
Wow. This is an assault on all senses, really worth the visit, and coming to Marrakech without it would be incomplete.

Must see. If you are looking to see the real Marrakech this is a must see, during the day there are thousands of shops to look at and barter a bargain, you should aim to pay 1/3 of the first price. At night it really comes alive with snake charmers, monkeys and lots of food stalls. If you want a picture with the monkeys ect I would only pay between 10 and 20 dirrums they will want more but just walk away. Overall a very intestetsing place and wasn't hassled at all like some reviews say.
Amazing. If you want to really experience Moroccan food, do not avoid Jemaa El Fna.Lots of hagglers, though.

Amazing place to visit. I loved the sounds and colors of the place. We visited late in the afternoon but it was hot and humid . I did not like the people who tried to sell you their staff no matter what.

Hard Sell!. I do not like haggling and a hard sell. It was very hard for me to handle as someone who does not like being accosted by sales people wanting you to buy products that you cursorily glance at.

Magic of Marrakech. It is place where you come across all kind people from all over the world, it has some historical places around the area, the square get action in the evening and it goes on till late, it is the place if you want to bargain and buy anything and everything, must be on every one's must visit list.

Very Touristy/Not Authentic. This large open area just outside the narrow streets of the medina was touted as a "must see." Personally, I thought it was quite boring (more of a show for the tourists) and seemes to have lost its authenticity. The vast majority of the visitors seemed to be hordes of package tourists (expensive cameras hanging off their necks) who just got off a tour bus. The 'entertainers' were just looking for a 'pay day' and I could have done without watching a chained monkey do flips. The food stalls are adequate, but not nearly as good (or as cheap) as those deep within the medina itself.

Hate it!. The people are so aggressive. They are practically pulling you to their shop. You tell them "no" and they will follow you trying to convince you to buy their stuff. Bad customer service in the restaurants.
Never seen anything like it. Wow,what a place,so much going on,lots of noise and street acts,you must go up to one of the balcony cafés for a mint tea and the view on a n evening

Fun (but proceed with caution). No visit to Marakech would be complete without at least one visit (and preferably several) to Jemaa el Fna square. Crammed with vendors of all kinds and many fast food tents. Wonderful melee of storytellers, magicians, acrobats, etc etc. However, I don't advise women to wear skimpy clothes after sunset - you will get hassled by some and its not worth the hassle.

Culture abounds!. The Jemaa El Fna is a fabulous place to visit during the day or night. It is always bustling and culturally fascinating. Our only issue was that some of the "vendors" were very aggressive and they would NOT take no for answer. One woman grabbed my hand and began to draw a henna tattoo. I told her no, and tried to pull my hand away from her, but she would not let go. I had to yell at her and push her away. Another guy came up to my husband, draped a snake around his neck and asked if we wanted a picture. He then of course held his hand out for money. Had we wanted these things, that would have been great. But we didn't, and so we were really irritated with their forcefulness. Not everybody was as aggressive as those two, but the rest certainly aren't shy about asking. So just be prepared to say "no" a lot! Or "laa" which means no in Arabic.Our favorite time was at night however, when the square is completely full with people, food carts, people performing and people dancing. It's quite entertaining and we thoroughly enjoyed experiencing their food and culture.

Great for people watching!. Eat at stalls 1 (Aicha), 14 and 31 (fish stall?) all fantastic, recommended by our riad and were excellent!Enjoy people watching from the Cafe Paris balcony. Great atmosphere in the evening, didn't feel unsafe, very touristy! Enjoyed watching the musicians and storytellers and taking part in some of the stall activities. Avoid Henna tattoo artists and some women grabbing your arm and putting it on you as though sold.Lots of snake charmers and monkeys!Avoid taking photos unless you want to pay a fee.
The Square. So much going on here - this place comes alive at night with snake charmers, dancers, acrobats...and much more.

Fascinating place to explore. This plaze is a cultural center, concert stage, and bazaar wrapped up into one. Explore on your own in the evening (around sunset) to experience Marrakech as Moroccans experience it. Don't book a tour, just go!

Hustle and bustle well worthwhile. It may as well be a page of medieval history. I am rather skeptical of medina centers that usually cater to tourists because many tend to be just tourist traps. This is authentic! The sounds, the sights, the smell of the grills, the locals mingling with the tourists... I loved it and it probably was this way a long time ago too! Best time to visit in my opinion is just before sunset and until after dinner...

best people watching!!!. The senses are overwhelmed here. Day or night, there is way too much to do and see. The nighttime food stalls that set up offer really good food, the fresh juice stands are wonderful. Fresh juice for about 50 cents US$. Be careful of your change as a few of them try to shortchange tourists.Plainclothes cops are all over Marrakech so it is very very safe.

This is a must visit. The place is an absolute must visit. It's what sets Africa apart from the rest of the world. Apes, vultures, snakes, people boxing, boiled snails and all the noises and smells you can imagine. Try seeing it from one of the many balconies that surround the square. You will be required to buy something, but a coffee or soft drink isn't expensive and it's well worth it. Go on the evening if you can, when all the restaurants suddenly appear and the place is heaving - the atmosphere is so much better. The souks are connected to the square so do them both together, and the impressive moqsque can be seen from just about everywhere and acts as a landmark when you want to get back to where you started. Wherever you are staying, there are a number of bus routes taking you to the square for next to nothing. Prepare for haggling and some light pressure from the street seller, but there's nothing there to worry about. You will either love it or like it - either way - you must visit this place if you are in town.

Too much aggression from locals. If it wasn't for the constant and persistent hassling by locals Jemma wold be great fun to visit. We found it exhausting trying to enjoy it as everywhere you turned people were aggressively demanding money. We felt quite shell shocked and angry after spending a few days in Marrakech, we had hoped for a relaxing break, but I felt like a body guard for my wife most of the time. At one point , while visiting an attraction someone approached us and said it was closed, and we should follow him to another attraction, we realised quite quickly he was lying, and had to run away, being pursued and physically and verbally abused ! Most of the shop keeps we encountered were equally hostile, not allowing us to just enjoy browsing in their shops, they would follow us and constantly make us buy things and look at things that we were not interested in. This made us less likely to enter shops, despite having a long list of things we wanted to buy for friends, we ended up buying very little. Even the taxi driver our hotel had pre-paid to take us to the hotel from the airport tried ripping us off, and the toilet attendant was demanding tips at the airport (been though he wasn't the attendant, And the real attendant was being paid to do their job !). . ..so, literally at every stage in your Marrakech experience people will try to aggressively take money from you, I was threatened with a knife by some teenagers inane alleyway, and forced to give them money and the beer I was carrying, the next day we witnessed a machete attack, in which a boys leg was nearly cut off, and locals didn't even seem to care. . . . the following day a man whom refused to leave us alone when we refused his offer of showing us directions followed us into a restaurant and tried to intimidate us while we were eating. honestly, its not even safe to take photographs without being asked for money, you have been warned....stay away. Its not worth the effort, you have been warned !

An Eclectic & Exotic mix of people!!. To describe what is on this place and what is special is to best explain what there is and isnt on this square and its hard to imagine something which isnt there at some point of the day... food stalls selling you everything from fresh juices to bbq to cooked snails and hot sweet mint tea..... to hundreds of musicians, performers and story tellers. I almost also stepped on a few snakes on my first night here which taught me to look at the ground when walking more than around me at everything else....

Hustle and Bustle. What a difference from day to evening.Relatively quiet during the day, lovely fresh nuts, dates stalls, fresh orange juice.By evening buzzing with music, local food producers, Snake charmers etc

You can't avoid this place.. This is a place you can't avoid in Marrakesh.It is a Unesco world heritage sight! It is very noisy and chaotic and not very pleasing on the eye.However,it offers a fascinating insight into life in Marrakesh.It is horrible to see the poor monkeys being paraded for photos.So many people want you to part you of your dirham.Don't buy water off the orange juice sellers as they will charge you double the price.It is a mad place with every form of traffic coming at you from every direction.Definitely worth walking through it at different times of the day.

Step back hundreds of years. A definite must-see and experience! Snake charmers, acrobats, fortune tellers and by night the glittering lanterns and smoke from the restaurants make this square totally magical.The view from the surrounding cafés is splendid, but don't be tempted to eat in the truly dreadful Café de France. The food is execrable! Far better savour the kefte or brochette at Aicha, one of the restaurant stalls in the square at night.

Back in Time. The Jemas el Fna is the old town of Marrakesh, taking you back in time to another century. Thesouks (markets) are still as they were a hundred years ago, maybe more, maybe less, but allhave that ancient feel. Thousands of goodies for sale, waiting for the next buyer to haggle theprice. But, beware, look with your eyes first, then think hard about whether you want to buy theitem or not because once you pick it up the merchant will constantly be at your side trying to getyou to haggle with him. They will come wayyy down in price but be reasonable as not to insult them with a ridiculously low price as they also must make a living. Keep some fun in the game!
Unbelievable. Soooo much to say. Food stalls, snake charmers, traders, con-men, camels, donkeys, monkeys, acrobats, hat-sellers. Go see.

An Authentic Marrakech Experience. To really get a feel for the square, you need to visit both during the day and also at night.During the day, the Jemaa el Fna is a great place to shop and engage in all quirkiness that is Marrakech. From the snake charmers, the henna tattoo artists, to monkies on a leash, there is no shortage of unique things to see here. During the afternoon, the workers are setting up the open air restaurants in preparation for dinners at the restaurants they put together daily.During the evenings and late at night, there is so much to do and see, to include snake charmers.Enjoy yourself and indulge in an experience that you'll only have in Marrakech.

Great for the hustle and bustle. Afternoon to evening is magic. Yes people are there trying to make a living but I found a firm no thank you was respected. Choose a busy food stall and take a seat and eat. Great place to get gifts.

The city's heart. Travel to Marrakech and don't go to the Jemaa El Fna is like travel to Disneyland and don"t meet Mickey Mouse ;-)I had a feeling that people there trade the same way they did five centuries ago, you have to bargain everything, don't be ashamed to offer back 10% the price they ask.Whatch out you wallet and purse - pickpockets

Great place to get the feel of Marrakech. Our tour set us free with several hours to explore this giant plaza and take pictures. The large plaza is filled with stands selling orange juice (see picture). The plaza is ringed with restaurants where one can sit outside and watch the crowd while eating a reasonable priced meal. There are second floor balconies where you can take in the sundown while having a drink (non-alcoholic) Down the street on the south east side are many shops. Stay around have dinner, watch the sunset and you'll have great memories of your Morocco trip.

festive fun. simply billiant, you can not go to marrakesh and not experience the evening festive fun every night. from snake chamers and monkeys, to the chaming marrakeshis shouting over for you dine at their food stall.a great buzz for all.

not for everyone. I can see why others might find this place amazing, it's busy, exotic, weird and you can see the things you would never see in a square in Europe like monkeys on chain (pure animal cruelty to me), henna tattoo women, snake charmers and so on. But let's face it, it smells pretty bad, it's seriously dirty, you get hassled a lot and definitely overcharged if you even look at a monkey or snake. Would I recommend going if in Marrakech? Yes, it's a necessary experience, but don't expect a lovely place, or wonderful or friendly.

Dazzling but amazing!. We visited during the day due to our hotel being quite far out & offering a shuttle bus during this time. From all accounts the square gets a lot busier at night but it was busy enough when we went. There are snake charmers (which my boyfriend hated as he is scared of snakes, a man came straight up to him with a snake & he ran away!), lots of floor stalls & Henna tattooists. You may want to keep your hands in pockets whilst wandering through, as the Henna ladies will come up with the syringe pens & do your hands without asking then demand money. Luckily we had no problems. Once in the souks, it is Amazing. So many sights, sounds, smells & stalls.
