Do not worry about getting lost, as you will, there are so many passages & alleyways but there is frequent signage leading back to the square so you will find your way back eventually! If shopkeepers are yelling for your attention just ignore them unless you are genuinely interested which seemed to work for us. Be prepared to barter & haggle for what you want, if you are unsure re prices or don't want to haggle, visit the ensemble artisanal which is where objects are made & the prices are fixed.

Madness. Complete chaos and madness but this is definitely a must see! Do not be shy when buying goods as the seller will normally give you a price that is at least double. Beware the Ladies offering Henna Tattooes as they grabbed a few arms of children and commenced to draw patterns and then demanded money.

Wonderful, colourful, exciting but keep your wits about you!. We'd heard mixed reviews about Jemaa el Fna but thought it was a must see whilst we were in Marrakech. Some say its wonderful and others think it is a seedy tourist trap. In all honesty its a mixture of both. Go in the evening and experience the colour, noise and atmosphere. Its a total sensory overload - acrobats, musicians, food stalls, market sellers, horse and carriages drivers dashing about, missing each other by inches. Sad to see the snake charmers and monkeys on leads being put back in tiny boxes (cruel) but I would still recommend you see it all for yourself and make your own judgement, it certainly isnt boring, that's for sure! People approach you all the time, mostly with good intentions but its probably not wise to take large 'obvious' handbags and cameras. We took a small purse with just the cash we needed for that day and were fine. The first time we went we were a bit 'rabbit in the headlights' but when we returned a second time to go back to the Souks (which are at the back of the square) we felt more relaxed and happy to enjoy the madness! Most of the resturants on the square are average and quite expensive. Go a street or two out and find a more authentic eatery - try the Pigeon Pastille (surprisingly good)

amazing and as crazy as you have seen it in pictures. THis place is unbelievable. It looks sleepy and deserted in the afternoon. It gets packed in the night and every night. We assumed that there must be some kind of festival going on. But the Moroccans come in droves every night. You can see the snake charmers only during the day. We did not try the food stalls but they looked very tempting. Shopping in the souk was a bit hectic as everyone is out calling you and sometimes it does get on your nerves. The price sometimes was 4 times as someone else would quote. So visit a few shops. It is a bit more commercialized and personally I think I liked the Fes souks and medina a little better. No one bothered you in Fes and it is a working medina. If some one takes you somewhere in Marrakech, expect to pay money. 10 Dirhams was not enough; it was almost ridiculous as they would demand 50 dirhams for a few minutes work. Fez has much better leather goods. The fossil place in Erfoud has wonderful gifts at reasonable prices also.

Lots to see and do. Jemaa el-Fna is the main square of the Medina in Marrakech, and probably the biggest square in the city as well. I won’t try to describe everything that goes on there because I’d probably use up the entire dictionary, but it ranges from snake charmers to acrobats, musicians and dancers, stalls selling food, fruits & vegetables, and of course entry to the endless and justifiably famous souks. It’s kind of like Times Square in New York: if it doesn’t happen there, it probably doesn’t exist. The whole atmosphere changes from daytime to nighttime, but there’s always lots going on. A word of caution: you WILL be hassled by people trying to sell you something or direct you to a particular shop. Just learn to look straight ahead and keep walking; if you make eye contact they figure they’ve got you.

Have money will spend!!. Shopping for all your take home needs, you can find a gift for anyone here. The locals barter so its like one big giant yardsale but with better gifts!! You get to see snake charmers, hold a real live monkey and see some of the wildest things Morocco has to offer in this amazing outdoor shopping experience!

Shopping Adventure and Culture Lesson!. Go here to buy all your souvenirs and you will find more than you can take home. I recommend hiring a guide to help with any language barriers, and to get best bartering deals! All part of the Marrakech adventure. Just be aware that bathrooms are far and few!!!

Morocco at its finest. This is the main square, and provides ceaseless entertainment, particularly when the sun goes down. This is when the food stalls are up and running, a variety of street entertainers ply for your coins, including snake charmers, street fighters, quacks, water carriers and all kinds of vendors, dodgy or otherwise. We enjoyed the horse and carriage ride, which takes you away from the square, through the Nouveau Ville, and past several prominent buildings, mosques and public places, including the tile frontage on the Gare de Marrakech. The other way to enjoy the sights is to pay a small amount for a soft drink and relax on one of the roof terraces that surround the square, with its amazing activities on show below. You simply won't believe it!

The most crazy over the world. It's really unique and so beautiful and there's a lots of things gonig at the same time. And also it's the city wher you can feel the time, and you can see the good combination between the traditional and modern life at the same time

Authentically hectic!. A hub of activity in the Medina. Snake charmers, monkey handlers, street entertainers, souks, stalls and henna artists. It's overwhelming and many of the 'entertainers' are pushy and persistent. Be polite and friendly, but FIRM when saying 'no', or they will push, push, push. Don't take photos unless you're prepared to pay for the privilege. There are many rooftop terraces around Jemaa el Fna, perfect for people-watching without being hassled. Stick around late afternoon/evening to watch the square come to life as the street food vendors start setting up and selling their (delicious) food. If eating the food (recommended!) be sure to eat with your fingers as the cutlery isn't properly washed between diners. Kebabs make great finger food, and taste delicious! Enjoy the banter of the street vendors as they try to draw you in - they're fun, friendly and usually get the message if you politely decline.

Make time in the evening. On a guided tour our experience of this place was rushed and we didn't get to stay and watch the snake charmers, dancing & all kinds of things going on in the square. Next time definitely going freelance.

Not as good as it was. On my first visit I was simply blown away by the feeling that I had entered a very different place, in a world which is now so much of the same old!On my most recent visit I was disappointed that there seemed to be a lot less on site production and was rather horrified to see so many made in China and made in Indonesia goods for sale in what I thought was probably one of the world's best remaining examples of a genuine market place.I was looking for specific products so we hired a guide from out the front of the market. That was ok I guess. There was a scuffle that broke out in the market and the guide seemed to move off in the other direction from where we were, so at one point I did not feel particularly safe.
A magic place!. It was like moving back to the period of Thousand and a Night. With orange juice seller in the morning, storyteller in the afternoon, and a immense mix of restaurants in the evening

unforgetable. The fresh orange juice is underfull, Do not be afraid to taste the meals. The food is amazing. The thing we loved most was the misture of so many diferent types of people. It is on my top ten of places in the world.

Over-rated. This is the must go to destination in Marrakech. It has its interesting sights I suppose and is much better at night. You have lots going on snake charmers, dancers, sooth-sayers or whatever. Monkeys, water carriers. Lots and lots of food stalls and restaurants with rooftop views. Lots of orange juice stalls - make sure they do not add water. It will give you a tummy upset.You will be asked to take photos of water carriers and lots of others - they will expect a big tip. I must admit that we went there purely because of it is supposed to be the place to go. Glad I've been because I won't have to go again - I'd rather go to a pop concert (and I hate such things). Must be getting old.Heard different views about pickpockets. They are supposed to be rife but I didn't notice anything like that going on.

Exotic and Overwhelming !!!. We loved everything. From the way the food stalls popped up out of nowhere at night fall and the way the stall owners tried to 'get u' into their eating stall, to the snake charmers, to the colorful lamps and decorated shops, to the orange juice stalls, to the traditions musicians singing and playing different musical instruments, to the simple eateries around the square, to the great mazes of shops around, to the view of the minar from the square and the most simple, ever smiling local people ...Everything really.. Marrakesh is just pure amazement!!

It certainly is an experience. I do not know if it's better in the evening or during the day. Always you will find the actors, jugglers, snake, stalls with food and beverages. During the day you may feel better. Beware of shooting - they need to pay in advance, it's better than guess then. € 1 is enough. Fresh juices are excellent for less than € 0.5. The best you'll see from the balcony cafes, coffee is more expensive than elsewhere, but for about 2 €'s really worth.

Well you've gotta go. Perhaps less dazzling than I had hoped or imagined this place is great fun to wander round in early evening. Ropes snake 'charmers', henna tattooists, monkeys, dancers, fake boxing etc etc. I would avoid the food stalls. Basically a rip off and far more expensive than surrounding restaurants. Best view is from The Cafe du Grand Balcon but you'll pay for the privilege on the drinks.

Very traditional. Really enjoyed the hustle and bustle of the square, full of performers and market traders. There are lots of restaurants in the square, and would strongly recommend walking around before settling on one. Often, the best ones are well hidden away. As an example the Salama Lounge was well hidden away, but was fantastic.

Over-rated. This is billed as the highlight of the city,we found it chaotic,dirty and the constant hassle of the traders,beggars etc wears thin very quickly.We visited both during the day and the evening and didn`t think much of either experienceto be honest.

All the Fun of the Fair. After 6pm the square comes alive with the hustle and bustle of vendors selling food, fresh juice, sweets and trinkets. Alongside the colourful water bearers, monkey entertainers and snake charmers. The people are friendly and welcoming. Watch out for traffic (horses).

No Place Like It On Earth. This place is crazy, but in a good way. There are so many sights, sounds, and smells to catch your senses and the best part of the square is that it changes by the hour. At night it is real busy and there are lots of eating options. During the day the entertainers are out to include snake charmers and monkeys on chains. This place is quite an experience for children and adults a like. My daughter loved it and you must visit on a trip to Marrakech!
The maddest square I've ever visited. Amazing place full of snake charmers, henna artists, entertainers, and more. Go at night but be prepared to be hassled, and take care with eating !

Fun hours in the night. Heart of the medina.Please be careful with your bagand do not answer the whole questions that shoppers ask. Best place to eat is number 44.Cheap salads and couscos and tajines but if you do not like oil say them to use olive oil.Try lemon and mandarin marmalade.

Crazyness abounds. During the day the square is filled with juice vendors, snake charmers, bell ringers, and vendors selling just about anything. In the evening the crazyness happens. Small restaurants are set up in the middle of the square. When you walk around someone at each restaurant is trying to get you to eat at their place. We ate at #1 and it was average food but good prices. The place is packed with people which got overwhelming very quickly. It is a definite must see but not someplace you want to stay very long.

hassle city. During the day it is a lot quieter, but beware in the evenings it does become maddeningly busy. There are scam artists and pickpockets everywhere, and it starts grating on you once you've been there more than once. One person asked my wife if she would like a henna tattoo. She said no, and the person grabbed her hand and started drawing on it anyway! The restaurants (and we went to about half a dozen of them) are poor, both in terms of the food (accompanied by bland bread) and the interior (they were really unclean). Most people do not leave you alone even when you say you don't want their services. We have been to many parts of the world and this has been the worst hassle we have encountered. You cannot even eat your food without being hassled to buy watches etc every 2 minutes. The same is for the souks nearby. Watch out for many scam artists, who will try and tell you to go somewhere like the leather market 'nearby', and then direct you down lots of passages until you get lost. We didn't fall for this, and we suspect they do it so you can then pay them a fee to help you find your way back again. We also encountered people telling us the attraction we sought was closed when this was incorrect. The main thing is do not trust anyone there. Our advice: if you want the bazaar experience, go to Istanbul. There is more variety, better quality and less hassle while shopping.

Amazing. As much as the square is a great destination, the walk there through the souks adds greatly to the experience. The square changes significantly between day and night so visit it at least twice to experience this. By day it is bustling with a big open square, by night the pop up restaurants come out, as do so many more visitors. I can't say why but there seemed to be at least double the number of people there at night. Make sure you keep aware of your belongings but we felt very safe there. Be careful taking photos of locals, you may well find yourself surrounded by a group demanding payment which can be intimidating. This is especially so of the snake charmers and other groups that frequent the square. Also be careful when negotiating prices that you both understand the agreed price. This is especially so with the horse carriages and taxis. Even then you still may not get the full value or trip you thought you negotiated but prices are cheap by European standards so it should be good.

Lively square!. Beautiful big square, extremely hot during the day in summertime, nice and cool in the late evening. There are a lot of market stands. It can get quite busy in the evening. Best is to go in the early morning
A square of delights. The square comes a lived at night with snake charmers, monkeys, street venders and street cuisine. the atmosphere is busy and the sights and smells are awesome

If you are from Hyderabad (India), AVOID it!. I was thoroughly disappointed with Jemaa El Fna. If you are from Hyderabad, India...it's like going back home. If you are from Europe or South America, you might find it interesting but this was nothing new to me.
Excellent Entertainment. Best time to visit is it nights. It is difficult to really explain it. All I can say is go see for yourself.
Busy Square. Only visited in day time. Perhaps there is more atmosphere at night. Surprised the snake charmer had a plastic snake!

Too touristy, there was too much pressure to buy.. "European" looking travelers get hassled a lot more, we had other friends there at the same time who because they looked Moroccan got away with enjoying it without being nagged to buy things.

Too much hassles!. The same with Medina's entire area, but especially this place, it is a true hassle! It's great to see this place for one time, or maybe twice. At night the view is nice. Cobra's show, monkey's show... you can see them. Street food area is nice but I can't guarantee how strong your stomach can take it, so just be careful. Basically this place is turned into a large commercial area, with market, shops, cafes, even they will offer you woman!

Crazy place!!. This place is the beating heart of Marrakech so should not be missed especially at night.Beware though of the waiters who try to force you to eat at their stand. They don't even let you breathe and the stand we went was disappointing...

Vibrant both day and night!. Having stayed near the square for 3 weeks we were able to really see what the fuss was all about both during the day and night. It's a lot of fun during the day seeing all of the souks - keep alert of belongings though. Fun to be had with haggling as always and usually some friendly banter as well. Stall owners sometimes even recognise you once you come back! Marvellous place during the night as well with great street food at very cheap prices with over 100 food stalls. The freshly squeezed orange juice for sale all around the square is brilliant and most stalls offer seating areas in the square (tented). Plenty to see and do - this was pretty much our dinner stop every day!

A Must See!. The main square contrasts very differently between night and day so it is best to go both times. In the day it is quieter, juice stands, a few stalls selling oils or maybe carvings, some snake charmers, acrobats, and the odd person with monkeys you can have your photo with. All want some money from you even if you just take photos from a distance and they see you, but this is how it is. The main souks also go off of the square and are quieter to wander through in the day. At night the place is alive and much more crowded with locals and food stands. Storey tellers, gambling games, musicians all surrounded by many locals. The food stands all have seating areas and a wonderful display of the different foods they cook...including sheep's heads and tongues! Lots of kebab type things, fish, soup spicy sausages etc. so a good choice if you dare to try. There are many westerners eating there and you can see generally the food is well cooked. The sellers try hard to persuade you to eat at their stand, don't look and just walk on if you are not interested (also do that if someone comes up wanting you to buy anything, they usually give up quickly). Lovely views of the square any time of day from one of the balconies of the cafes surrounding the area. Souks are busier in the evening but great fun to explore and haggle.

Crazy Crazy Marrakech. Totally amazing place - I can't believe there is another place on earth like this, surely? Words fail me doing this experience justice. We popped along after a visit to the Kosy Bar - this was the first time for my three companions on this evening trip, my husband and two friends. I had experienced Jemaa el Fna last April with 12 friends so I knew exactly what to expect but was even more impressed this time. The vendors are always up for a good laugh and walking through the outside food stalls you will certainly be invited into Jamie Oliver's Marrakech with lifetime guarantee of no diarrhoea!! We nearly fell over for that one! As Graham said, we'll eat there if you can spell it?! The square certainly does come alive a night although it's busy during the day it has nothing on the evening time when there are more acrobats, snake charmers, vendors etc. Always worth bearing in mind that the "square" has got a number of roads traversing it! I can heartily recommend getting to a rooftop café to view the goings on, catch a cool breeze and take mint tea.You will be asked if you want a henna tattoo, or to buy this, or to look at that, just be polite, smile and say no thank you or non merci as this seems to pacify the eager sellers. Enjoy. Again, will be returning to this amazing place.

Absolutely amazing place.. Having seen the square on the television on numerous occasions, I was afraid that I would be disappointed, but I was blown away by everything. It is a feast for all of the senses. A melting pot of life.

amazing sights. My husband and I did a food tour of jemma el fna ,it was mesmerizing, astounding, one of the most interesting places I have ever been, our guide took us all over the different areas of the market ,we tasted all different types of morrocon fare,we saw the spices and herbs used for cooking and medicinal purposes, Sellers of everything you can think of, beautiful teapots,tajgines ,tyres used to make furniture and decor for the home.the center square of the jemma el fna was teeming with people ,food stalls,restaurants, shops ,sellers,snake charmers ,entertainers, I and my hubby posed with a monkey, its definitely worth a visit, a must if you visit Marrakesh.

Stay alert. You get a lot of claim to be tourist guides in jemaa el fna, so when asking for directions do not follow any one at any cost because they will want you to pay them in return that is it, marrakech is 100% safe and you will fall in love with their people as soon as you meet them but they want your money because you are a tourist.On my first day in jemma el Fna I was lost and I asked some one for a location he told me I am going that way my self because I live there so unfortunatley I followed him and as I was walking I realised this guy is reading out his cv to me and how he has been a tourist guide for 30 years and what not as he was speaking I saw my self walking in the ally ways going left right left right and this guy is still talking about his experiences and how his my Muslim brother and of course after every 10 words he drops a welcome in there too. cut the story short he made me pay him 100 dirham for extending my route from 10 minutes to 30 minutes.

A Great Place to Hang Out. I visited in January and went to the square every day! I only ate one supper in my hotel; the rest of the time, I ate in the square. You can find musicians, snake charmers and vendors all looking to separate you from your money. The thing I discovered about the snake charmers is that they are really snake teasers! The snakes generally would be content to stay curled up and sleep. But a little bit of teasing would bring them up out of their coil. I did get lost in the souk and back streets but that was fun. It is a photographers paradise. I did purchase a couple of frame drums (a tar and a bendir) but the quality is not that good. I also bought a couple of djellabas (long hooded robes) for my wife and daughter and likely paid a bit too much. I looked at carpets at the Criée Berbère but they were mostly tourist quality carpets (e.g. machine spun wool with synthetic dyes). Sadly, I could not find any quality carpets with hand spun wool with natural dyes.Marrakech is one of my favourite places to visit.GJS

Must see at both day and night!. Go to the square with an open mind, as your senses will be overwhelmed with the music, smell of grilled meats, snake charmers, and people everywhere. Must go in the late morning and also at night since you will find 2 completely different atmospheres. Recommend having a late morning tea or coffee on the upper terrace of Cafe La France to get a beautiful panoramic view of the square and enjoy some interesting people watching. Be mindful of where your purse and money are. Ladies, don't look scared because you will make for an easy target. Just keep your purse towards your front rather than letting it hang behind you.

very interesting.. this square by night is brilliant,snake charmers,monkeys,water boys,henna tattoo women,food sellers,orange juice stalls,story tellers,overall this is the place to be at night ,locals and tourists alike mingle in a mass crowd ,a must for any visitor to marrakech.

deserves a visit. I'm sure this spectacle, which is what it is, has become more tourist orientated over the years but there's still a wealth of experiences here in one huge space. We didn't eat at the food stalls which spring up as the sun goes down as we preferred to watch the action from a roof terrace cafe. Be prepared to have a snake put round your neck, or a little monkey hold your hand. The drummers expect some coins in their upturned hat and the biggest crowds are often around boxing matches. But as the sun sets and the lights come on, hazy in the smoke from the charcoal burners it's a magical place to be where acrobats appear out of nowhere, story tellers weave fantastic tales you can't understand, and everyone is very good humoured and enjoying the quite unique atmosphere.

It's a show!!!. Watch out for pick pockets. The real show starts at 6:30pm or so with moroccan bands, boxing matches, snake charmers, ladies doing henna, the food stalls which are safe to eat at, snail and orange juice vendors, and people with monkeys! Food stall #1 advertises as the best but stick to where the locals eat, try not to chow down next to the person who flew next to you. Obviously you're going to Marrakech for an adventure try something new!

TOP TOP TOP ATMOSPHERE. Jemaa El Fna is a place, where I have to go always when I am in Marrakech. Amazing place full of life, colours, great atmosphere and specific aroma. My advice is to go before the sunset, to one of the cafeterias (I recommend Grand Balcon), to enjoy the mint tea and to watch sunset. As late you will be in this amazing square, more local people will come and enjoy night life. Everywhere you can buy fresh orange juice (glass with 10 MAD = cca 1 euro), as well we were eating on the square fresh grilled meat, it was fantastic and you enjoy much more the atmosphere. So my recommendation is to go afternoon, when is not so much hot, cca 17:00, to go for shopping to the souk and for sunset to watch from upper terrace the square and after that to go to eat down and to enjoy!

Aha...its an amazing place to be...I go again and again . Loved walking there and soaks narrow streets. I like:
The Walk, The People having good time, Orange Juice, The food Stalls, The shops, The narrow streets, Friendly people
I dislike: This place needs to be cleaned more often. Beggars should be kicked out,
Atmospheric at night. But watch out for gropes from young males if you are a female: happened to me at least twice. But otherwise fun to go to at night. Looks like an empty car park during the day.

Very colorful!. We spent the day wandering the souks there. The square itself was lively with snake charmers and others...walk well away from the snake charmers or they will drape a snake on you, and then you have to pay to have them remove it!

Sonmething not to be missed. Mind blowing, snake charmers, dice games, music, a souk, local food, magicians, vendors selling wonderful food, Not just for tourists but visited by local people in a Moroccan version of the4 passagiata.

Snakes and Monkeys. This is a must see attraction large square in front of 60'000 shops on Sunday night it look like Glastonbury Festival just a sea of people.remember closed currency so you need Moroccan dirham..

Hits you on all levels!. Market square in the centre of Marrakesh, surrounded by restaurants, cafés and the meandering lanes of souks to the north. Best visited in the evening when the food stalls open and the smells and smoke mix with the voices of hundreds of visitors and locals, the incessant beating of drums, the stalls calling for your custom and all kinds of entertainers. You must sit at one of the benches and enjoy the wonderful variety of food on offer. Service here is quicker than at any restaurant!

Food poisoning. We decided to take a gamble by eating at the food stalls. Needless to say the gamble did not pay off and both my friend and I were extremely i'll later that night and the next day causing us to miss the next days activities.We should have guessed it would happen really as the vendors do not wash their hands or plates properly but instead wipe things down with newspaper...serious lapse in judgement.DO NOT EAT AT THE STALLS!!

Circus on the street!. Oh, dear. The food, firstly. And the acts, always an interesting show to watch! It's always all happening in the Jemaa el Fna. You must go. Just one word of caution- don't shop for things near here. The further from the Jemaa you are, the less expensive and touristic it gets (in terms of shopping).

Vibrant and lots going on. Most of the compliments have already been said by other people, so not much more to say, other than if you don't want to be hassled, then don't let the snake charmers see you taking photographs or they will race over demanding payment.

An onslaught for the senses! But a must visit.. The heart of the Medina.Entertaining by day but a little daunting at night ... keep a tight hold of your wallet --- my husband had attempts on his at least twice on our first visit ... But hey ho, same advice for travelling anywhere eh?

Chaotic interesting square. Expect to be not alone in the square of Jemma el Fna, wherever you go or turn there will always be someone offering you help or directions of course you must tip no more than 20 dirhams. The interesting square gives you a feeling of how time goes slow here especially if you are coming from western countries. You can buy so many beautiful artisan lamps, leather goods, scarfs, spices but make sure you wheel and deal, to get the best price. In the night the square will be packed with local people street food which is tasty and still around. You can get the most fresh squeeze orange juice for only 5 dirhams. Take a break in one of the rooftop restaurants around the plaza to take great pictures. It's very hot can got 45 now in May therefore make sure that you wear light cotton clothing and a hat.

A Marrakesh Must See - A Cheap Thrill Ride for the Senses. Go at night to get the full effect. Sounds, smells, constant motion everywhere, bumping into people and then the many tastes from the food stalls. I recommend you hit the single food stalls so you can taste and see more things. Ignore the food stalls with the full menus. Try the snail soup, the many different soups, teas, sweets and the sheep's head for the truly adventurous. Just tell the food stall hawkers you ate and they leave you alone.

You'll have to go through it if you visit the city. It's fun for tourists. More interesting at night with all the food stands in the middle. The souks are fun to visit too, make sure you have a "system" to go back, or just ask a kid and give him a coin. Do dress appropriate please, it's a Muslim country and I am ashamed to see the lack of respects of tourists...
Watch the day and night go by. Loved the squareStart and end your day here. Day time it is busy and you can watch the whole world go byAt night it comes to life - sounds, smells, sights - brilliant

Watch out for food stand scams. We went to one of the many sit-down food stands at the Night Market at Jemma el Fna. We were lured in by a charming hawker and ordered off the menu. They proceeded to bring us our oder along with food we did not order..Of course they then wanted to be paid for what we did not order. We suggest you write out your order, or at the very least, track exactly what you order and pointedly refuse anything you did NOT order. Unfortunate that this happens to spoil an otherwise pleasant experience.

A must see experience. Nothing can prepare you for the spectacular show and cultural experience of this square. Sit and watch the world go by in one of the many cafes sipping an Arabic coffee or refreshing mint tea or enjoy a refreshing freshly squeezed juice from one of the stands. Get lost in the 300+ meandering streets of the souks - don't forget to barter. Watch the snake charmers, story tellers and street performers. In the evening eat at one of the street stalls serving all kind of delicacies. It is safe if you choose a stall that 'looks clean', cooks the food in front of you and is really busy with locals and tourists alike. Have fun ....!!!
Never fails. Been here before a few years ago and was exactly the same if not better from what I could have rememebered. Definately a place to visit to get the real wow factor.
Enjoy the show!. Wander around the craziness of the square where you'll find snake charmers, water sellers, food stalls, orange juice stands and everything else.
100x Harvard Square. What can you say except you must go a both in the day and night and experience this. Crazy, crowded, great smells and tastes. Enjoy!

A must experience. No one would go to Marrakech without a visit to this square. Make sure you visit both day and night to see the transformation. It's a special place in the evening and captures the best of Marrakech.

A must if in Marrakech. This is surely the main reason to visit Marrakech. It's mad, but fascinating and, with care perfectly safe. There are acrobats, snake charmers, henna painters and lots of food stalls. Yes, all those stalls are serving snail soup, but there are plenty of other stalls serving fish, lamb etc - wander about and let the front men tempt you in. If the food is cooked in front of you, it'll be OK.

tourist trap. lonely planet praises this square as top choice, but in reality it is a tourist trap, sellers and especially henna tattoo artists are very aggressive and unpleasant, square is very touristy and not authentic

With kids, horrible experience. We travel a lot with our young kids. But here at night time the hawkers come to you to take advantage of your kids. They know kids are easily persuaded and then you are confronted with a crying kid and a hawker that tries to take advantage. Numerous times our kids got toys put in there hands without asking, and other times hawkers coming quite imposing towards you because one of you kids had looked 5 seconds at a turtle or snake which should cost 5 euro.... We learned that respect is important in Morocco but we felt it was not likewise here. There are nice and pleasant people here but the some unpleasant ones spoiled our experience.

Must see ...... The evening entertainment is second to none ! Reminded me the stories "1001 Arabian Nights " . So different from the day time. Loved it ... good to see something like this isn't for the tourist.

Haggling in the markets. If you only go the the Jeema al Fna when in Marrakesh then you are sorted! Its an awesome place to haggle for the lowest price possible. Our strategy worked every single time. The guy would open with a price of say 500 Dirham we would give our bottom price. Say 200. He would laugh of snigger and we would walk away. As soon as we do they ALWAYS come running after us to seal the deal! Use it and abuse it. Its a powerful too. NEVER pay more than half of the asking price. If you do, you've been taken for a fool! You can find all kind of goodies. Their leather products are of really good quality and its mostly hand stitched. We stayed in Marrakesh for 5 days. We always ate in restaurants but on the last day we decided to have a kebab on the market square. Thank goodness I had it on the last day because I got food poisoning! I was ill for 3 days, lost 6kg and was very poorly. DON'T eat on the square. Its a real gamble. Or do if you need to loose a bit of weight. Thanks for reading my review and happy haggling!

The Market. Usually I do not like crowds, yet this was more like a blending of the human race as it must be meant. Everyone's beauty is original, whether Morrocan, middle-eastern, or southern European.

Fun Madness. This is where everyone that visits Marrakech has to go during the day and the evening to compare the differences. The roof bars get very busy in the evening.Try "Square Foods" overlooking the square for cheap pizza!
Full of life. The square is amazing. Lots of people from an enormous diversity. Great food and cheap, many bazaars and shops to keep you busy and make you dizzy.
Great experience. Great fun. Great atmosphere. Like no where else I have ever visited. Drink the delicious orange juice, eat the great food, relax and enjoy the ride!

Manic ... but Marrakech!. The square (or Jemaa el Fna) is full of stalls and shops both indoor and outdoor. It pays to shop around and know what you are willing to pay because the art of haggling is just that ... an art!! Decide what price you have in mind and divide it by 3, that way you will be getting a good deal. Some traders are really helpful whilst others irritate, just stick to your guns. Most of the locals we came across were genuine, hard-working Moroccans. The whole Jemaa el Fna is certainly an experience not to be missed - and made all the better in the knowledge that there is a quiet oasis in the form of your hotel room/riad.

An extraordinary experience!. Full of color, life, smells, and music - this is an experience you will only get in Marrakech! Come during the day to see the place less crowded but return at night when the hot air has cooled off, the breeze has swept in and the place comes alive! Get lost in the souks. Get a fresh squeezed orange juice (or a mix of orange and grapefruit). I absolutely felt in awe while visiting the place Jemaa al Fna.

Fab day and night. This is a must see for all visitors day and night to see the transformation during the day all the snake charmers and monkeys then night the lights from all the food stalls all the different smells and sounds amazing

Go during the day and then again at night!. My wife and I went to the square during the day and it was good there were snake charmers people with monkeys and story tellers doted all about the place. the guys with the monkeys and snakes were want you to get your photos taken with them for a small charge but if you say NO in a firm voice they leave you alone. We had lunch in one of the cafes over looking the square and people watched as we ate it was great. The down side to going during the day was it was SO hot but it was good to get a basic feel for what the place is like.We then went in the evening and it was 100 times better there were so many more people about food stores and dancers drums and music. It was great. the temperature was much better as well and it was great to see the sunset. two tips i would give you would be haggle for EVERY THING and try the orange juice it was great.If you only have time to go once during your trip make sure it is in the evening.

Crazy!. This is an experience not to be missed, but at the same time, not all that great. Didn't see anything that was really worth buying, and the hustle was unrelenting. Not from the merchants but from the teenage boys offering to guide you to your destination, usually via a store or stall where they want you to buy something, and always for a price for taking you. Don't fall for "It's closed today" or "You can't go there because there is a mosque there - to it's private " If you're lost look for an older person - they will help you.

Vibrant and Chaotic. A must see city square where your senses get attacked by bright colours, food smell, cacophony of sounds from street performers, snake charmers, smelly monkey's and their shrieking yells, to souvenir sellers all wanting you to release all the Dhirams you have. Like all cities be vigilant and ignore constant hassle from all types of sellers. Good cafes around the square and reasonable.
Mad. Seeing is believing. A "must see" in Marrakech. Look out for the band where a man is stood on a drum with a turban on his head, with a chicken and a dove on top of his head. Awesome

Different faces, different times. Try and visit this at different times as you will see different sides to it. It is specially nice in the evening going into night. Very noisy and very persistent food sellers. Good choices so don't settle for the first. Lots of drumming!

Very nice square. Went to morocco for a hen do and Jemaa el Fna was a very nice highlight of our trip.Open both day and night and well renowned for its reputation as the barter and bargain central of the country, we throughly enjoyed visiting there and spent so much time there we made many friends. Yes there are lot of pushy beggars and dodgy characters but that doesn't remove from the attraction and entertainment of the square. There are also some excellent cafes present both day and night especially the one serving ice-cream and crepes just by the atms. There are many bureau de change and cash machines nearby in case you expend all your money on buying gifts for family and friends. Freshly squeezed orange juice is available for just 4 dirhams and the best food on the street is brought out once the sun goes down. My advice would be to visit earlier in the day, have some fun and go on the horse drawn carriages then visit later at night from about 10pm until 2am. There are snake charmers, story tellers etc but beware of the henna as they try to cheat you and the black henna leads to an allergic reaction as experience by at least two people from our group. If you are eating at night, stall 114 is one of the best for food.

Lively but dirty. During the day it's a normal plaza, but at night it changes completely and all the people come out of their places. It's full of stalls with food, people offering you a seat in their restaurant or stall, snake charmers, women who tattoo your hands with henna... Still, the floor is quite dirty, so it could be tricky walking with sandals.

STAY AWAY FROM NO.31. The square is mad and full-on in the evening, My husband and I used to love to go back for dinner since we arrived in Marrakesh 5 days ago but I had to give it "Average" rank here as one last night dinner experience put us off. No.32 had been the place to go for us but one night, we wanted to try somewhere different, quickly checked the review on google and although No.31 was not as hightly reviewed as the other stands we've tried, it had a okay review so we decided to give it a go and soon found it was a big mistake. We knew most places charge for the bread served as you sit down at the table which didn't bother me much. It came with some other condiment-looking stuff such as mushed spinach(I assume that was, still not sure), olives and whatever we didn't know whats called, which we didn't order so thought they'd be free like anywhere else we've been to did.Just before our plates were served, I saw some cockroaches crowing in the booth, gave me a chill going down my spine. We had a mixed grill(70DH) to share and my husband ordered 1 coke(10DH), the bread was 10 DH each(I noticed its double the price compared to others)So we were expecting the bill to be 100DH but it came out as 135DH in total!!!!!!!!!!!! They charged us for the condiment we didn't even order, we tried to explain the situation but they didn't seem to get it. One guy who understood English a little bit better than the other staff came out so my husband asked if that was a trick and he said yes. My jaw dropped! We didn't touch the olives so after the argument, they eventually took it off the bill but still we had to pay 125DH. It's just a few quid more so couldn't be that big deal but we were definitely not happy at all that the staff turned out to be so rude to us and even swore at us as we left.We so much wished we were sticking to No.32 or just went to Cafe Arab(service is great and they will give you goodquality, free condiments there) now...

AWESOME AREA BOTH DAY AND NIGHT. Brilliant area to explore both at night or during the day . Beware however of people letting you take the pics for free and they then can demand money off you, so work out how much max you willing to pay in advance.

Amazing square, must see at Marrakesh. We arrived here by night, and we didn´t know what we where seeing...I think it will be an image burned in my memory for all my life.All your senses are awakened ... The view of the smoke coming out of the food stalls,The smell of the food and the square itself... The buzz of all the people walking around you...The music of coming from everywhere... Just wander around and be amazed...Of course people will try to get money out of you and try to convince you to pay for what they are offering... But if you know how to handle it everything will be perfect.Definitely come her by day and by night as it is completely different every hour of the day you are there.

Makes Marrakech what it is. I was surprised to see this was the 10th highest attraction in Marrakech as I can't imagine a trip there without visiting. It's a great place to soak up the atmosphere and I'd recommend visiting in the early evening as there is a real buzz as the sun goes down. As a seasoned traveller I wasn't surprised by the people on the square trying to con us, but my friend was taken in by a henna tattoo 'present' which she was then charged 400 dh for (around £28!), she paid 200 but tourists should know not to pay more than 25dh for something like that (around £2). A lot of people will offer things for free only for you to find out they're not free. If they do then you can walk away or tell them you will call the police. They leave you alone fairly quickly when they realise you won't pay. Snake charmers will only want paper money of around 400dh. I paid 50dh for two of us after much haggling, which is still a reasonable amount of money. It's an amazing place and people shouldn't be put off by what they've read about being conned. Just be aware. Also almost everyone I spoke to who ate off the square got sick, so it's probably worth a look but not worth the risk! Go and enjoy and once the sun has gone down, visit one of the cafes overlooking the square to hear the sounds and drink some mint tea.

Why so much fuss. Slightly disappointing, given how much it is bigged up. Lots of food stalls, loads of sellers of junk and offers of fortune tellers, snake charmers etc. Story tellers looked fun but obviously better if you speak local language. Go once to sample the atmosphere. That's enough.

Worst part of Morocco. We travelled around Morocco recently ( I just arrived home today ) and from all the places we've been, Marrakech - and particularly Jemaa el Fna - was the worst experience we had. It's a scam paradise, you can't walk 10 steps without someone trying to get money from you. And yes, they're persistent. The animal cruelty there is also horrible. Monkeys, snakes, horses, donkeys, lizards, all animals in great distress. Don't forget that, we as tourists, are the ones that feed this cruel business, so avoid taking pictures with these animals or giving money to their owners. Morocco is one of the most beautiful countries where I've been so far but Marrakech was simply annoying. We skipped Fes because we knew it was going to be similar. If you like nature and to connect with real people that can teach you their culture and share experiences, head to the mountains of toubkal, explore the desert in Hassilabied, get lost in the road to Imilchil or check the monkey forests near Azrou. The real Morocco is seen in the countryside, if you really want to see the true country, get out of big cities and get off the beaten path.

This is the melting pot!. Amazing atmosphere almost all day long... from morning hours you see "dancing" cobra snakes, fresh orange juice stands, guys with tamed monkeys, false teeth stand, leather handbags, hand crafted lamps, it's all around the place... you can all observe it on the ground or from one of the restaurant's balconies/terraces near by... but it's after sunset when this place comes alive. Temporarily built tents as "wannabe restaurants" with extremely good food and great value for money, combined with even more local artists and performers with tribal music in the background... and the crowd is 100 times larger than during the day... quite a hassle, but hey, if you can't handle it, then don't come in Marrakech at all...

Life never Stops. Overflowing with energy. Snake charmers traditional water sellers, acrobats you name it, its here. Cafes, restaurants and riads (all price ranges) all round the square if you want to be close to the action. Don't forget to visit the Night Market for even more bargains.

Like nowhere else!. An absolute must if you are visiting Marrakech! We ended up returning almost daily for either lunch or dinner because the buzz of the square was just irresistible. Be prepared for anything and everything - and be careful not to show too much interest in or photograph anything you have no desire to pay for. Performers like snake charmers and belly dancers are incredible to watch and set a magical atmosphere - but if you're caught taking a photograph they will ask you to pay, and may encourage you to take one so they can ask for money afterwards. Young females beware - either be prepared to cover up modestly, or travel with an elder or a male. The square was incredible but one evening we braved some sundresses rather than maxi's and had some fairly explicit advances which made us really uncomfortable.
The Square. Make sure you visit this square at different times of the day, it is constantly changing and will always entertain

Nighttime so beautiful. A must see is the Djemaa el Fna. Especially at night with a scene like in an old movie. Typically arabian. Thousands of people performing with drums and snakes. Dancers and storytellers. A wide variety of food is beeing offered. A once in a lifetime impression!!!

Very busy. Great range of eateries.
Didn't like the snake charmers who would put the snake around your neck with out asking!
Watch out for the Henna ladies, they will try to paint you without your permission!
Interesting Place. Lovely place for bargains.. snakes, monkeys, horses etc DO NOT buy from the first shop.. you will notice price keeps dropping... and pay max 40% of asking price.

Be self-conscious and assertive when walking through the square.. At first I want to say that because of all the reviews on TripAdvisor I could not help being very tense when walking through Jemaa-el Fna for the first time. I have to tell you, it is not that big of deal. Yes, people will approach you with snakes and monkeys and more than once per minute you will hear "excuse me" or 'Hello". Yes, it can be hard when they try to persuade you, but just stay with your statement. No means no! "La Chokran", no thank you in Arabic, is also very effective . Do not communicate with the henna ladies, snakecharmers and water vendors (dressed-up beggars) unless you want to pay. If you do, always assemble a price at first!Tip: Wear sunglasses so they don't see you look at them :) The foodstalls you have to experience yourself since I have not eaten there. Good luck and have fun!

Busy square. This was the highlight of our visit to Marrakech. Definitely go at night. Marrakech was a relatively safe city. We went to the square at day and at night and were surprised at how much it transformed at night. It was fantastic to just walk about and soak up the atmosphere. This was really all there was to do in Marrakech. You wouldn't need more than 2 days to see all Marrakech has to offer.
Must Go and do. The food stalls that come out at night are so full of colour and favors.... Just a must for anyone who loves food... we will be going back next year

Interesting visit but beware!. Went to visit the square on two occasions, the first at night. Lots of hustle and bustle so be prepared to ignore requests and barter for purchases. We returned during the day and wandered around the souks. We walked passed a snake charmer and they insisted we went over. Knowing we would be asked for money (which we had none left as we were on way to get some) we tried to refuse but eventually were taken over. Whilst there a lady came and took hold of my arm. I tried to get her off me but she began drawing up my arm ( henna) I insisted I did not want a henna as I am quite allergic and that I had no money. She said my normal price is 600 dirham, but you choose your price. I said I don't want it and tried to get her off me. She got quite angry and said she would walk me to the bank to get 600 dirham. Quite scared we walked to the bank and got money. We handed her 100 and jumped in a cab home, cutting short out visit to the square. It's a real shame that such a lovely exciting place and such an experience can be ruined so easily. Be careful when you are walking about, no is never taken as an answer!I have now got a large orange stain up my arm which is getting increasingly stingy!
A must see. A great place to visit when in Marrakech. The square really livens up at night so make sure you head in just before sunset and watch it go down from a rooftop terrace and see it light up!
Crazy sight to see. Loved the colourful orange stands and seeing the tooth pullers. So full of energy and life - completely crazy. Lots of hustle and bustle - not for the faint hearted.

Different Times, Different Vibes. The main market square in Marrakech where all order of business is done. Sellers of juice and water, acrobats, musicians, storytellers, transvestite dancers, monkey handlers, snake charmers, and to the sides all type of merchants selling goods from rugs, to leather to brass, to minerals...all compete with the terraced cafe's where tourists can get incredible panoramas of the square, the city, Koutubia Mosque, and the Atlas mountains beyond. At night add all the food stalls that roll in starting at 5 PM and you have one of the most vibrant and colorful places on earth.
Easter Visit. We visited during the day and whilst very touristy the square certainly has its attractions. Even being hassled for tips and for photos wasn't too bad
A must-see! Both by day and night ;). Full of life and so much to see and feel :) a short walk from there to the Kotoubia Mosque and the Souks are just right by the Jemaa el Fna square!
Pure madness. Nice cafes, food stalls, snake charmers, ape monkeys in cages, horse carriages and pure madness and unusually wonderful.

The world's largest restaurant. That's how Jemaa ei Fna bills itself with some justification. The food stalls compete for business with their front of house staff (!) producing an array of incentives. Favourite amongst these has to be, "Eat here. Guarantee no diarrhoea for three years!" Three months later and all's still well!
Confusion!. Be prepared for a place with confusion, many people trying to sell you things. Orange juices, fruits, mixed scents, mixed music.

The joint was jumping day and night. Really fun to hang out in the square. Nonstop activity and exotic sights - water sellers, snake charmers, acrobats, monkeys, transvestite dancers, musicians, and of course, the tooth puller. At night there are food tents, crowded with Moroccans enjoying the evening out. I wish we had the guts to eat the street food rather than sticking to more conventional restaurants. It looked and smelled terrific.

Hustle and bustle. This square is too much to take in in one go. The square is devoted to food. At either end are the fruit sellers and the juice sellers. You can buy an orange juice for 4 MAD. The centre of the square is devoted to many many eateries all trying to draw in the throngs of people. The square is adjacent to the souk with it's many alleys lined with vendors selling practically everything. We will visit a few times over the next few days
Sounds and flavors. Love the food, eating on stands, fresh squeezed orange juice, and 10000 people arriving every night. A sight to see!

You just have to see it. It is exciting being able to see this attraction as it is UNESCO listed. It is interesting how the Moroccans collect in squares in many places for social life and this square has it all. The entertainment is variable and it is interesting how a sense of excitement is generated with the sounds of the music and the busy food stalls. The herbal teas made from 10 or so herbs are a must. I nearly went without trying it but when I did I was hooked on it. There were plenty of vendors with beautiful freshly squeezed orange juice too. Just off the edge of the square there are food stalls that sell lamb cooked on a spit. It was delicious. I ate at these places without any concern as the food is all fresh with high turnover.

Method in the madness. A trip to Marrakech wouldn't be complete without coming to this lively square full of sounds, smells, people (lots of people) snake charmers, food stalls and everything you have read in the reviews before mine. Having travelled to other mad paced countries similar we were prepared yet relaxed about it. A couple of times we had our back pockets touched but we held our money inf front pockets, didnt take our phones or bags. I am not saying it is full of pick pockets or thiefs but we are just cautious when in a very cramped environment. We sat and drank coffee, we ate at one of the stalls (100) and walked through the medina looking at all the things for sale. Sitting by a junction and viewing the traffic is entertainment all by itself. You have to go - its great

Manic. I went here everyday during my 4 day stay. It was absolutely crazy place and one I have never experienced before. I was with my 2year daughter and had to constantly watch over her as the locals would always try and offer her things. The atmosphere and acts on offer were great entertainment. I over killed it by going every day. It can get very hectic with large crowds gathering every evening.

You must visit this.. This is a sure fire bucket list addition! we had been prepared for the square by our riad staff and so were not tricked into having henna or photos taken. This was great preparation. we really enjoyed seeing all the amazing things here even though some of it is clearly for the tourists.

Crazy but fun. A must visit (obviously!) whilst in Marrakech. Its a crazy place, like being taken back 20 years, but the general buzz of the market traders, the orange juice sellers (at 40p a glass!) and the entertainers makes this a worth while place to spend a few hours soaking up the culture.

The biggest restaurant in the world. As from 8:30 PM The Place Jemaa el Fna is turning as an enormous restaurant under the stars. Escargots, Tagine, Couscous, Grillade, everything you can expect from the delicious Moroccan Cuisine. Small portion allows you to taste a lot of different dishes.
bit of novelty. a large plain square with hawkers and some entertainers. Some activities may be novel eg teeth sellers or snake charmers etc

Go at night. We went here at various times of the day. Midday it is like any big square but the orange sellers are very tempting with their half litre of fresh orange juice for 40 cent. We went at sunset and it was stunning with the Koutoubia mosque silhouetted against a glorious ever changing sky which rapidly became night. But if you can only go once, go after 8 p.m. when it becomes like no other square with all the food stalls set up for the night, the snake charmers, the berber water sellers, the storytellers (I wished I spoke arabic as they garnered the largest crowds who were rapt in their attention), the musicians .... and it goes on and on. It is the most vibrant place I have seen but do beware of the pickpockets who are there in numbers and can easily catch you out when you are distracted by the mayhem going on around you. Not to be missed.

Exciting Food and Entertainment Options Here. Having a leisurely exploratory walk in the evening here is unfortunately impossible here. You will be bombarded by food/drink places trying every trick in the book to get you seated to order something. Surprisingly, the prices in the open air stalls were very affordable (and good if you're coming from a country with a stronger currency), despite it being a tourist trap. We tried a few stalls here and the food was pretty decent and most of them served exactly the same stuff, though a bit modified for tourist tastes. Do not miss the chance to eat goat's head and snail soup here!Next to these stalls would be performers in the evening (i didn't see any snake charmers, though i did see a few kick-boxing fights) as well as those selling cookies or henna tattoo services. If you can somehow block out a random person trying to sell you something every 30 seconds, it's a pretty cool place to soak up the atmosphere and energy of this wonderful place.

Don't miss this!. This is what Morocco is all about! The market sells the same things as the markets in other cities in Morocco, but this place is a sight to see! Snake charmers, orange juice sellers, amazing food vendors, henna artists, plus tons of places selling everything from clothing to spices. We had sheep's head here, which is delicious, if a little fatty. It's really pretty when the sun goes down and all the lights come on at the vendor stalls.

must see. great place to visit, with market stall, food sellers and snake charmers. Many inexpensive restaurants with terraces surround the square- providing tagines and other traditional food- great place to eat an evening meal

An international hub in the desert!. Brilliant atmosphere particularly at night. I was here during Ramadan, and at dusk, the place becomes alive with street hawkers and a myriad of food stalls - try the snails!

be brave and enjoy the food. On our first proper evening in Marrakech we ate at one of the best fine dining restaurants in the city. By contrast in the following night we had sheep's head, calamari, chips and the rest in the Jemaa el Fna. It is such an amazing place - the sound, smell and ambiance are unique. My advice to any traveller is make sure yo have clean hands when you eat, take your own water bottle and be brave.

Vibrant and Exciting. Bustling heart of Marrakech! At the entrance to the Souks and home to some delicious food. Prices vary significantly depending on what you chose: we had a lamb tagine for two with crusty bread and drink for 70 diram (about £5!) but then in the evening had fish on the market for £15 for a full meal. This is however one of the few times in Marrakesh when you do not need to barter. All prices listed.

The place to go when you visit Marrakesh.. Well, where to start with Jemaa el Fna? This area is one like no other we have visited.By day it is filled with large volumes of those selling their wares, ranging from scarfs, plants, snacks, jewellery, henna and the best testing orange juice ever, just to name a few...Certainly an area full of unique charm however we felt we had to on our guard as the buskers/sellers were pushy and were reluctant to let you walk away without a purchase with a hiked up price for Westerners - we were also offered pot by the locals on a regular basis. By night, the area is full of buskers, story tellers, snake charmers and a large array of food stalls. All the food stalls had good sales patter and knew how to entertain the tourists although I highly doubt they have ever considered food hygiene a priority. Definitely worth a visit!

has to be seen. but seems to be overrated. Lots of 'looky looky'men trying to sell phones and headphones etc. and stalls selling football shirts, which detracted from the traditional sellers that there were.
Amazing. There's nowhere else quite like this place: food is cheap and good; entertainment is bizarre and wonderful; shopping is even fun.

Incredible open air restaurant. We have been to two very posh restaurants and a mediocre one in Marrakech and we ate on the food stalls in Jemaa el Fna the other two evenings. We chose the stalls where mainly the locals ate as opposed to the ones where there were only tourists. The food was delicious and we had no stomach problems at all. Every evening we had fruit juices on the square too. It is exceptional food at very reasonable prices. Since we were determined to eat at the stalls despite all the warnings against digestion problems we took probiotics for a couple of days and had no problems what so ever. There are all sorts of attractions on the square. Enjoy it or not, it is part of life in Marrakech, therefore it must definitely be seen. Vendors and buskers approach you but they don't pester.

jemaa el fna. great both in the daytime for a spot of lunch or at night, but during the evening this place comes to life. some fantastic resaurants around the square or brave the hussle and bustle at the food vending stalls complete with snake charmers.

Cacophony of sensations. The square in front of the Medina is the most famous Marrakech’s square, Djemaa el fna is the real gem of the city and is not hidden, you just have to discover the two completely different faces of – one at day and the other one when sun goes down and bustle of the day increase at night. Definitely this is the most impressive vibrant heart of the city. Don’t miss to go there after sunset and to dive into aromas, flavors, colors… fest for your senses! Don’t be afraid to try the real taste of Morocco. Feel the inspiration!
incredible!!!!!. loved the noise the smells the atmosphere a trip NOT TO BE MISSED the locals have smiles a mile wide and love to practice their English with you and as always have a good haggle!!!!!

Large and absolutely fascinating. By day this is a very large open space surrounded by restaurants and entrances to the various souks. There are various temporary stalls within the square, selling fresh orange juice (delicious), pottery, knick knacks etc. also dotted around are the ubiquitous snake charmers - bit of a shock to the system if you don't like reptiles. There are other performers that turn up, do their thing and then move on so it is ever changing.However it's in the eveningwhen the square really comes alive. It is jammed packed at night with temporary food sellers - the pre-runner of the very fashionable pop-up restaurant in the UK. They do seem to congregate by type so for instance all the (what appeared to be) clam stalls were in one area with kebab stalls in another. They all have sheltered seating areas outside for customers to sit and enjoy their food. It's a really colourful place and much larger than I imagined it would be. Apart from the snakes (!) it is not scary or threatening just very entertaining. Well worth a visit.
Bit disappointed after the hype. Less theater and more naff sales and pushy restauranteurs who will happily fleece you. Stiil its fun to watch the bustle from a roof top terrace........
Not to miss. Eating here at night is a must do. Look, listen and feel the square, it's great. It really comes to live at night, but during the day you can just watch the activity

Not to Be missed. The centre of Marrakesh where everything leads to or from. By day fairly quiet with a few frit/nut/juice stalls, snake charmers etc.By evening the food stalls and market sets up, which is delightfully chaotic, the traders will rip you off mercilessly, unless you are very strong.We were advised not to eat from the stalls, which was a real shame, as the only cleaning facilities they have is a single bowl of water for the whole evening (the plates and cutlery are the issue, not the food)It is almost impossible to just have a look without being descended upon by very keen traders. but just smile and say you have already eaten and they back off (eventually)Most of the restaurants around the square are tourist traps, but still OKCertainly an experience not to be missed.

Chaotic but beautiful. I think I must have strained my neck several times when first entering the place at night. It is so full of life, people standing in circles listening to music or watching curiosity being presented. It can be a bit overwhelming, especially when you're a woman. The people at the food stands trying to lure you to their tables, the orange juice sellers calling you over…so much is happening! If you're looking for a very special dinner experience I can recommend this, however if you've had a long day and want to sit down in peace maybe less so ;)

Must do, but beware aggressive buskers. We visited the square several times and it's a true feast for the senses. All sorts of products, entertainment and services are available and you can experience "marketing" in it's purest form. After sunset a lot of mini "restaurants" appear with kebabs and other fare. We enjoyed the food, but it's basic street food so don't expect fine dining.Do beware the aggressive buskers and shop owners on this square. This is the only place I've visited where people grab arms and blocked you from moving in an attempt to make you listen to them or buy something. In one instance my 12 year old son was held by the arm by a man with a macaque, and he had to free himself by violently wrenching his arm out of the persons grasp. This left some red marks on his arm and a small scratch. In another instance I was blocked from moving for about 10 seconds by two gentlemen who where trying to get me to visit their clothing stall. After determining that I wasn't being mugged, I said "No" loudly several times and they eventually moved away. Neither incident was particularly troubling to us, but I think these kinds of tactics might bother a lot of people. Both incidents happened during the early afternoon in plan view of the square.
Lovely. Beautiful place to visit, always be polite and courteous and you will pick up some great things for not a lot of money

The Center of the Universe. It is a cacophony of sounds, smells, colors, action. The starting point of any visit. From there you go into the small streets and bring your GPS. Really, a lot of fun. It is surrounded by restaurants, none of the ones we visited any good, but fair to kill hunger at lunch time. Best deal is to eat from the stands after 4 pm when they get set up. Enjoy Marrakesh. No other city like it.

This square is magic. I love this square especially at night time when it really comes alive with the smell of food and ornate lanterns creating the most amazing atmosphere. I would recommend stall 97 for some of the most delicious tajines and couscous you will ever taste, many of the others are a bit of a let down in comparison.

expect to be fleeced. the traders here can spot a tourist at twenty paces. they'll charge a huge amount and expect you to barter. things are not cheap in marrakesh. they are a lot cheaper outside. so buy gifts outside elsewhere. sometimes one will latch onto you and follow you about trying to get you to go with him to stalls where he gets a percentage of whatever you buy from the trader. trying to get rid of them is like trying to get chewing gum off your trainer on a hot day! and if you're a woman on your own its worse because whatever you say, it's worthless in this arab country. there may be evidence of the old berber african tribe that lived here before the arabs invaded but the culture is not african. it is definitely arab. even women in numbers get the same treatment to women on their own. so cover up. hide your eyes behind shades, dont expect to shake off men easily, dont expect to be able to browse or window shop and be left alone, dont expect to go into a shop and ask the price of something and be told it. they want you to put in an offer and then they'll take it from there.. its pretty much a place you can only visit without being able to do some serious shopping in. you just cant assess price. they wont let you. and if you get a guide he will often take you to the traders stalls he gets a percentage off the items you buy.dont freak out if you get lost in the maze of streets. everyone does. but comes out the other end. noone is going to attack you. most will try to help you, via their shop of course. expect to get lost in the maze but dont freak out, noones going to assault you. watch you dont give away where you're keeping your purse as there are some clever thieves there. and just ignore any hisses because not everyone likes westerners here. but they're not usually vocal about it. they need the tourism too much. (this wasnt a visit. i lived here)

Very few places in the world are so full of life.. It is a huge open place full of stands and groups, from exotic food (what about some lambs eye-balls?), orange juice, dates, fish, ceramics, snake charmers, rural dentists, colourful water sellers, musicians, dancers, story-tellers, spices, jesters, donkeys, etc...Ah, and pickpockets!The actors change along the day, and night!A MUST not to be missed in Marrakesh.

Well worth an evening visit. During the day this is full of market stalls, however the entertainment in the evening (snakes/ monkeys/ belly dancers in drag...) were definitely worth seeing. Don't take photos, and if approached walk away - you shouldn't need to pay anything out for this experience!

Noisy and colourful. Unlike many destinations in North Africa the vendors are not aggressive and understand that sometimes you just want to look - the Night Market is colourful, noisy and vibrant - eat there once (although don't expect haute cuisine - the pastries from the barrow vendors are very good and at 30 dirham (£2-25) very good value.The fresh orange juice is another must !
The nicest square on earth. Always things to do or things to see. Have a fresh glass of orange juice for only 4 Dirhams (30 Eurocent). From Sunrise till dawn: I miss it already ...
A Must Day or Nights. This place is a must. Snake charmers by day food by night,.Crazy place. A mus see. Pref from a bar overlooking square to apprecaite it

Hustle Me Outta Here. Delicious, freshly-squeezed glasses of orange juice for 40 cents amid the chaos of henna-tattooers, snake charmers and the same old things to buy in shop after shop after shop were the best part of this huge, huge open square. It's a must-see, but keep on going

A must see. The square is an amazing place to watch transform from a quiet and mostly empty square during the day, into a hive of activity at night. Go to the top balcony of the Cafe de Glaces for the best view - way better than the view from the Cafe de France. The food stalls are entertaining, but the food itself is nothing special. Good if you're on a budget though. Wonderful watching th story tellers, teeth sellers, fortune tellers, snake charmers etc. Ask before you take photos of people here - they mostly don't mind but will expect a few dirhams for it.

Do not miss it while in Marrakech. Amazing huge colourful square surrounded by souks. Take a visit in the day but do not miss an sunset visit. It's a worth to see attraction . Snake charmers , Orange juice sellers , Dancers , Outdoor food serving and thousands of people .

Enjoyed a walk through. If visiting Marrakech one needs to experience the square of a day and a night, very different experiences. Of a day the square seemed filed with orange stalks and was a place one walked through o access another area. Of a night it became filled with performers and food stalls, snakes, monkeys, the dentist with his pliers and teeth, a carnival atmosphere. Be aware if you watch or take photos of performers you will be expected to pay, personally the monkeys on chains and dressed in clothes did little for me, whilst I enjoyed the drummers and musicians, take coins with you. We had a walk around the food stalls staff were very keen for you to sit and dine, however we were pleased to return to our quiet riad for a tagine and glass of wine.

Really, you have to do this. Yes, some reviewers call this a tourist trap. But how can you go to Marrakesh and not see their ground zero?! This is the soul of the whole Medina! For your first time, just walk around and take in the sights, smells, sounds during the day. Give the barkers a friendly but firm "no thanks". Have some amazing fresh-squeezed fruit juice. The scope of people and activity will amaze you. Then come back at night to see the whole circus in its full glory. If you are brave, eat at the food stands. Lots of tourists and locals do--it won't kill you! It was the cheapest, most authentic meal we had. Warning--at night the barkers for the food stands are at their persuasive peak. Just keep moving if you don't want to get pulled in. Or get a solid recommendation from your hotel/riad for a specific stall number, and just head straight in. The square is not to be missed!

Worth a visit. While clearly a touristy place to visit, it's still worth taking in Jemaa el Fna - both during the day and again at night. Don't buy, just look -- especially avoid the foods. Buy fruits, dates and nuts from a place off the square where there's less dust and things are fresher. Be wary of ingesting anything that will cause intestinal distress (You drink bottled water, why would you then want to buy water from one of the water sellers?) Go to one of the rooftop cafes for a great view of the hubhub and have a mint tea, instead!
nice. Really nice atmosphere, beautiful mosque, guaranteed to get lost in the markets. Will always lie when they notice you are not from the local area

Touristy waste. It was surprising to me that prior to leaving for Marrakech we were not told just how terribly touristy the Jenaa el Fna is. The street food is not near as good as we expected. The salesmen are constant and annoying and rude. And during the day, the square is an oven. The souks surrounding this area are far more calm and enjoyable. Skip the Jemaa el Fna.
Amazing, both day and night. A must visit, hot, bustling, busy, noisy, but absolutely fantastic. Comes alive at night..... so interesting by day.

A complete let down. On a November afternoon, there didn't seem to be much going on - just a few animal tricks and the odd food-seller here and there. No musicians, no story-tellers, no crowds. Maybe it gets livelier at night, or in the tourist season.

lovely space, but useful to learn how to say no in arabic!. interesting, lively particularly in the evening, lots to see, but the story tellers we saw 15 years ago seem to have gone -helpful tip I hope - if people want to sell you what you don't want - just keep saying no thank you in Arabic -(la shock eram - doubtless this isn't how you spell it in Arabic but this is how it sounds in English) - say it with a smile, and a shake of the head and you will get a smile back.- guaranteed!! To greet someone say Salaam (peace) Making the little extra effort really does pay off - enjoy your trip!!.

The place to go. This is the place to go especially at night.If you stay at the Moroccan house hotel it should cost around 30 dh to Jemaa el Fna. After 8pm it will cost between 40 to 50 dh.This area comes to life at night with street entertainers.During the afternoons / early evening you will find snake charmers and men with monkeys.

A super place to go to but be aware of your values....and little kids. You can walk quite freely here, but do be aware of your values like wallet watches or chains. There is a lot police around and they help you very good as they know the locals so well

A must on any visit to Marrakesh. Excellent fresh orange juice from the many stalls, just watch out for the snakes and monkeys running around the square.Easy place to eat from the many stalls put out each night. Super atmosphere.
Crazy and nice. It's absolutly crazy. During the day it's a market. From around 6 pm it changes and it's full of food stall where you can have dinner.

Terrifying and horribly cruel to animals. Seeing the monkeys pulled back and forth with chain really upset me. Seeing lizzards looking dehydrated in the scorching sunshine was distressing!The worst thing was, seeing small children run to the tables to pick up your spare scraps of food after you had finished. This really upset me!!!!I'd never go again!!!
