Heart of City. I thought this was going to be all tourists, but it is not - it is a mixture of the city people of Marrakesh as well as tourits and has something for everyone. Again go by day and night to get the different feel for the place. Eat here, drink here and shop here.

Amazing place!. Okay, where to start?! This is the gateway to the souks in Marrakech, the hubbub, sights, sounds, smells! A large pedestrianised area that is constantly changing. Stalls selling orange juice, nuts, etc, etc. During the day it is bustling with people buying, selling, just taking in the sights. You can hitch a ride on one of the famous calèches (horse drawn carriage). From here you can see the Koutoubia Mosque, in fact, if you get lost just make your way back to the Mosque, it is the tallest building and visible from just about everywhere! At night Jemaa el Fna transforms into the night market, a hustling bustling place full of interesting food stalls, street performers, musicians. Candles and lanterns make for a beautiful if surreal atmosphere, quite unlike anywhere I had ever beeen before!

Can't miss it. The square is full of sights, sounds & smells you just can't get anywhere else. Go both during the day and at night to get the full effect. My husband and I loved the sense of community we saw here. You just don't find stuff like this in America, where people of all walks of life come together. Be prepared to tip to be allowed to take pictures -- you don't have to tip much. I never felt harassed in the square. We were certainly approached and called out to -- you just have to get used to ignoring people. On our first night, we were photographing the crowd and apparently inadvertently took photos of some police officers. They stopped us and asked to see our pictures. They did not speak English and we did not speak French or Arabic, but we figured out what they wanted. Once we showed them our footage and attempted to explain what we were doing, they let us go. It was not until later that night when I was reviewing our film that I saw the cops in some of our crowd shots. Not a big deal, but certainly interesting

Electric atmosphere. A must visit while in Marrakesh, you'll find freshly squeezed orange juice, local delicacies and spices you've never heard of before.Make sure you visit in the day time as well as night for a completely different scene.You'll find all the shopkeepers hassling you so don't be afraid to just walk away and smile.Try out some of the best orange juice you will ever have and venture into the souks to test out your bargaining skills.If you're around near sunset, it's worthwhile to dine at one of the many restaurants with a terrace overlooking the square to enjoy the spectacular views.

Heart of madness. Mainly tourist trash for sale and then some horrors like chained Barbary apes, tortoises piled up in small cages and even a hedgehog... Food stalls, noisy bands, some good cafes on the edge - Cafe do France for example if you want to get above the hustle!

amazing sights. Everything from teeth pullers to snake charmers, to mad local sellers. A must. Visit day and night. You can be bothered by sellers trying to sell you everything from food to hand painting (Henna) but you get used to it.

Cannot rate too highly. This provides an unbeatable experience for the sights sounds and smells. The best time to visit is early evening when the place comes to live with music, snake charmers, food stalls. I have never been anywhere more exciting

heart of Marrakech. The main and most famous attraction of Marrakech is the Jema el Fna square which primarily has lots of markets stalls along the edges, and market areas branching off from it. During the day within the square there are a lot of orange juice sellers, dried fruit and nut stalls, as well as snake charmers and performing monkeys. If you get too close, the monkeys will jump on you! The real fun though starts after dark.At night countless food stalls descend onto the square. Each stall sells basically the exact same stuff and has a team of vendors trying to convince you to eat at their stall. They can be quite pushy but in very funny way. They have learnt English phrases to attract people like ‘we’re better than Primark,’ ‘No horse meat here,’ ‘you look starving marvin!’ They have even perfected their accents to Cockney or Geordie! Whether they actually knew what they were saying is a different matter but it was certainly enough to catch your attention.

disgusting animal cruelty on display everywhere you look. I can not believe in this day and age people would still pay to watch or even worse take photos of poor animals being exploted and worked to death in the most appaling way, shame on you all the poor snakes, monkeys and horses in this square are only there because you idiots give money to the barbaric low lives that beat them half to death for your amusment.these activitys along with the constent harrasment by henna ladies and stall holders to con us out of money ruined our day trip around marrakech, its a shame as we had such a loverly day visiting all the beautiful things marrakech has to offer.

The Only Real Reason to Visit Marrakech. Jemaa el Fna is grand, it is unique, it is an unprecedented phenomenon, the magical place, it is the soul and the rythm of Marocco and maybe even of the whole North Africa. You may see much better markets and bazaars in Istanbul, much more sophicticated and amazing islamic architecture can be discovered in Andalucia, but only in Marrakech you will find the mesmerizing and enchanting Jemaa el Fna. Make sure your hotel is located nearby this is worth the money spent.

Great by day and night. It is worth going in the day to see the snake charmers and go to the souk but then go again at night and either sample food at one of the many places that set up there in the evening, or just wander around and take in the atmosphere

The square. The night food market was fantastic. The vendors won't stop trying to get your attention until you respond, so tell them you'll be back later when you're hungry. They like to banter. Be careful around the snake charmers and henna women. They will try to "show" you what they can do, and then insist you pay them inflated prices.

Must do in Marrakesh (and you can't miss it anyway). The hustle and bustle, constant cacophony of drums, snake charmer flutes, CD sellers and noisy street sellers on the same time makes you wish for a quieter place, yet keeps drawing you back. I have been to 40+ countries, but never experienced anything remotely like it. Has its own particular charm.Try the orange juice at day and the food stalls at night. Freshly cooked and great value. The menus are fairly similar, but take your time to look at what each place has to offer. Look for places that have plastic utensils if concerned about cleanliness. For the more adventurous eater there are booths that sell sheep head and some smaller stalls only selling snails.
OH YEAH BABY!!. By far the most entertaining part of Morocco, Me and the Mrs went there every day. It was Brilliant.

A fun evening. This square is much better in the evening than during the day. We ate at one of the outdoor "cafes" that spring up at night and had a simple but enjoyable meal, made all the more fun by the antics of the "barkers" trying to get one to eat at their restaurant.

Not overly impressed. Visited the square quite a few times, can't see what the fuss is about. It is just a large area full of noise and people trying to extract money from you, legally or otherwise. The pop up restaurants of a night results in you being bombarded with people pushing laminated menus into your face and declaring "two years guarantee no diarrhoea" hilarious..... not.

A Must. Follow the coloured signs through the souk and find this amazing space. Day and night it is a feast for the senses. Many cafes to people watch, stalls, acrobats, snake charmers, dancers, food stalls... Glorious
food after sunset. dont acknowledge the 'would be' unoffical guides, they get in your face but you must ignore them, we are polite but you just have to.

You have to visit. No point in going to Marrakesh if you do not go to the Jemaa el Fna. It is a must see place and as such should be ranked higher.It is of course very commercial and there are things which are not very nice. Snake charmers and monkeys are interesting, but if you take a photo within a hundred yards of them, they will be after you for some money, and quite aggressively. Shame.The best thing to do is go to one of the roof top restaurants, have a relaxing drink and perhaps food there and take photos from there.At night the place transforms into an open restaurant. Walk between the food stalls at your peril, the people trying to get you to eat at their place are really pushy - unlike the Souk areas.So must not be missed, but whether you enjoy it or not, that is another matter!

An experience. The square is buzzing night and day, its great for people watching from the roof terraces of the many restaurants surrounding the square. The snake charmers were a disappointment, we expected giant cobras winding their ways out of baskets, but instead they were tiny snakes being proffered for photos.

Hell on Earth. I hated the whole place, the cruelty to the animals, one monkey was so distressed I left in tears. They pester you more than any other country I've visited and they just don't let up. I would never ever go back to that country if my life depended on it. They don't even sell anything worth purchasing!

Jemaa El Fna. Jemaa El Fna in the walled city of Marrakech transports you to another age. It's full of bustling activity. You'll see snake charmers, donkey carts, carpet sellers and cafes all around. There's loads of exciting things to be bought - leather shoes, scarves, jewelry, ceramics, carpets and kilims. (Be sure to bargain) You can also amble through the busy streets to the Jewish quarter or go to the spice bazaar or just sit in a cafe and enjoy chicken with plums.

Unforgettable sensory overload. The smell, sounds and views will long live in my memory. Orange juice to die for at prices that made buying water pointless! Just make sure you check your change as this place is all about taking money from the tourist. Snake charmers and monkey handlers will try to pull you in and when you say no thanks, don't accept a handshake as you will quickly find a snake place on your arm and then you are expected to pay them!Watching the market transform in late afternoon to the restaurant was amazing. Words don't do this place justice. It's like nothing I've experienced before. Sensory overload. A must see place.

Know how to bargain. Freshly squeezed orange juice is one of the best in the world. A much sweeter taste than Florida's oranges and Brazil's oranges. If you're gonna buy products from the street vendors, you have to know how to bargain in order to get a good price. Since it's a big place it's easy to get lost, so be careful!

The heart of Marrakech. My goodness, when you arrive here, you are in a totally different world than Western Europe. And a big square it is. People everywhere, dancers, noisy music makers, singers, storytellers, snake charmers …. One expects Ali Baba to turn up anytime.But also loads of people trying to sell you stuff. Very hard to get them off your back.And stalls everywhere, selling you freshly pressed orange juice, dried fruits etc.A part of the square is for open restaurants, all selling you the same food for exactly the same prices and men in front of their stalls trying to make you eat in their stall. 'Oh mister you look like ... come and eat with us, we sell you the best, the freshest' etc, etc. We tried to have a look to see what the others had on offer, off course, but it became impossible for me to coap with this constant bombardment. So my advice, don't go through it too long, get a bench where locals eat, and you will see, it all stops and becomes somewhat quieter.Food was ok, don't expect too much, enjoy the athmosphere.And I agree with other recencents, the architecture hasn't much to offer, it is more for the athmosphere. But without a visit, I believe you missed the very heart of Marrakech, so it is a must see.What you also can do is go up to one of the high terraces, have a drink or a bite to eat there and watch what's going on. Do that before all the marketeers arrive and watch how the whole square changes.

Unforgettable. You have to experience eating at the food stalls...we chose one with lots of locals eating there and had great food. Watching all the stands arriving and being set up in the afternoon is recommended. Also take time to enjoy a drink from one of the adjoining restaurants and people watch. We avoided the monkeys and cobras for animal welfare reasons. Morrocan Masterchef was being filmed in a corner of the square on one occasion. There is a lovely street heading off the square which does not allow motorbikes so it is recommended. The general hustle and bustle is great.
A taste of exotic Marrakech. Great photo ops, street food, snake charmers, henna artists, costumes, masses of people, etc. every visitor is drawn to this place.

Breathtaking. A cacaphony of sound sights and atmosphere. Enjoy the street entertainers, snake charmers, market vendors and in the evening enjoy a meal at a pop up restaurant on the square. Beware have a good idea what you would like to order before you sit down otherwise you will end up with a selection of some 10 dishes and be paying £25 a head, that was my experience first night a bit disorientated travelling all day but still teaches you a lesson for rest of your stay.

Not for us. We felt we had to visit the Square as it was our first and last time in Marrakech, It was as we expected, very touristy, very noisy and busy, I was groped, and hassled to the extreme. Really not worth the visit. The food stalls were certainly not that clean looking and the constant hassle from the traders was beyond a joke.Beward of even taking photos, as you will be chased for money, if you refuse, you will be shouted at.The souks were full of cheap tat made in China.Not for us at all.. seen it done now I will forget about it!
be careful. there are a lot of people in this place and every body want your money so be careful. there are all kind of happing but it is more busy in the evening then during the day.

Had very little desire to spend time there. Mostly took a moment after our morning tour of other sites in Marrakesh to sip a cook beverage at a café with rooftop that overlooked Jemaa el Fna. If we had been staying longer in Marrakesh, I probably would have come back in the late afternoon to see the square transformed.

A must see but be careful at night!. We visited in the afternoon and then went back at night when theres much more going on. Word of warning at night though - i was approached within minutes of arriving with someone offering to sell me drugs & also when standing watching one of the many performers had a male brush his hand by me inappropriately - something he greatly regretted because i pushed him so hard he almost fell before running away when he saw my husband approach. After speaking to police they apologised & told us that although they do have plain dressed officers mixing with the crowd these things unfortunately do happen. I would say dont let it put you off but do be aware of whats going on around you & behind you especially when watching the entertainers. The snake charmers and men with monkeys expect money for you taking photographs which is understandable as thats how they earn their money - we found daytime best for pictures.

Very Vibrant. Just get pass the supposed local guide and you will have a great time in and around the square, start your bidding at approx 30% of asking price and do not go above 50% and you will get your item. Take time to have photos with the local dancers and snake charmers adds fun to the trip.

Makes Marrakech Marrakech. Mad house! Smoke, snakes, drums, acrobats, market stalls, false teeth salesmen make Jemaa el Fna the unique place it is and go at different times as the atmosphere changes. The cafes and restaurants around the square are not expensive by central location European standards and provide welcome respite from the heat and hustle. There are a number of ATM's on the south side of the square which you may find useful.

Lots to see. We visited around mid day. Lots of activity with tumblers, snake charmers, monkeys etc. but always check the fee before photographing anything. Lots of room to walk around and enjoy the atmosphere. Worth a visit during the day but on reflection we should have gone in the evening too.

Al Fresco Dining. The place is great during the day but at night it comes alive with food stalls and tribal drums. you can sit and watch the world and its snakes and monkeys forever. the food is incredible and so cheap.

Mad, exciting and surprising!. Mad because of the sheer number of people, motorbikes, donkeys and horse drawn carriages you have to negotiate.Exciting because of the smells (spices, smoke, food etc), noise (drumming, snake charmers and music)Surprising because it was actually less 'touristy' than we'd expected. Yes, they will try to entice you to buy food and souvenirs, but the majority of people are locals just enjoying everything on offer. Great place!

A must, day and evening. It is a must to visit Jemaa el Fna, both during day time and during the evening, e.g. 7-9 pm. A lot of people and a lot of activities different from back home (at least for us coming from Northern Europe)

Be there at dusk for a beautiful, lively atmosphere. I would have liked to experience this more than the once that I did and it is the main reason why I would like to go back to the medina of Marrakech. Beautiful voiced musicians, food carts and people all around as well as a lovely sunset.

first visit. bit sad seeing snakes/monkeys/vultures being so heavily handled for tourist photos. Food stalls bit of a major let down and very pricey, so not sure what the big hype was about. However it is where the souks begin so all good.

a wild ride!!!!. it was still chilly when we were there, so there weren't many performers out at night, but the performers were unlike anything we've seen- and the food!!!!! you must go. You'll never see anything like it again.

Just go there. This is a most wonderful place, but even more so in the evening. The noise is incredible and the hustle and bustle is all around. You must eat off the stalls. The assistants attached the stalls come out with wonderful phrases like - they are Jamie Olivers brother! Wonderful stalls stacked up with oranges, selling fresh orange juice and stalls selling dates, apricots and such wonderful things. If you dont go you have missed something really unique

Has gto be experienced at night. The sounds and smells are a unique experience. Not hassled as much as we were 6 years ago. Had a drink in one of the restaurant terraces. Note that you have to eat to get a window seat, but you can still see and experience the square. A drink is a soft drink, no alcohol is served if you can be seen.

Full of chaos but an amazing experience. This place is incredible, especially from dusk onwards when the crowds really arrive. A mix of stalls, food providers, snake charmers, monkey entertainers and orange juice salesmen.If you are looking for a super view of the action, head to "Residence a la Place" which is next to the famous "Cafe de France" the view from here of the square, the sunset and the mosque is simply beautiful.

Chaotic!. After reading previous reviews we decided against eating here and after walking through found it easy to resist the not so delicious looking delicacieson offer. There were many street performers to watch and enjoy, the most popular with the locals was clearly the storyteller who drew a far bigger - mostly male - crowd than the so-called belly dancers!

Must see. Back in time - it is the place to start, surrounded by the souks. Lots of restaurants. Lots of Moroccans frequent the square for the storytelling shows. It's a huge place, lots of people but still easy to get through the crowds. Fantastic food in the evenings.

Be ready for the hustle but have fun. Be prepared that everybody tries to get you to their stall. I just picked one to eat. As it was early for dinner, boys let me take a lot of pictures of thier food and with them. Also the carts with sweets were fun. They give you a box and you pick the ones you like. I bought loads to bring back home.

A must watch. A must see just to breathe in and absorb the atmosphere? From snake charmers, dancers, acrobats to henna painting and food. Upsetting for me was see the monkeys with chains around their necks which were clearly discomforting.

The best square to get a general idea of Morocco, fun and friendly. Bargain as much as you can, the prices for a foreigner is 3 to 4 times those of locals! Which is very disappointing, when some salesmen get so greedy!

Worth a visit, just for the madness. Have read quite a lot about this square but wasn't quite sure what to expect.The square wasn't as large as I expected but there was lots going on, day and night. During the day there are lots of orange juice sellers, with a few other attractions. During the evening there are lots of small restaurants, with a few other attractions.You can eat in the square for about £3, including drinks, and it was of a reasonable quality.Go to the cafes surrounding the square and be prepared to pay quite a lot for a drink!Just for the fact that that you are dodging bikes, motorbikes, donkeys, motorised carts, buses and cars whilst several hundred people are milling around it's worth a visit!

very dirty. the square is very dirty, the food is very expensive and dirty the portions very small I have ordered piece of lamb liver I had chicken liver instead so I had to return it this was first night and then by the same amount of money I ate in clean and respectable restaurant.
OK but .... Worth going to see but spoiled by the continual hustlers. Sit in a cafe/restaurant and safely watch it all happen.
Pure madness. This is the experience you need to have to really feel Marrakech. Watch from a restaurant balcony and or wander through the mayhem.
Soak up the atmosphere of Marrakesh. Madness at night - eat at No 1 Ayisha's stall, the only woman to have a food stall, excellent food and great entertainment

the square. At night, this was a wonderful and vibrant experience, avoided the kebab stalls as got ripped off last time we visited Marrakech, but tried the snail soup and bought a box of pastries, lots of gatherings of people playing music, story tellers and children playing hook the bottle. It was very busy but we felt safe.

Just go!. If you enjoy having your mind blown and drinking amazing, fresh-squeezed orange juice, you'll love "the place." Buy the handmade hats from the ladies at the Night Market and avoid the guys who want to throw a monkey on your shoulder.

Dirty and smelly. What a disappointment, I'd wanted to visit Marrakech for such a long time, it always looked interesting and fun, not at all, I found it filthy dirty and the smell in the air awful all the time. the souk wasn't too bad, but the minute you step outside the gates it's another matter. The square was nothing to write about, I certainly won't be visiting again

Mental, in a lovely way.. Difficult not to go here if you are going to Marrakech.In between the snake charmers, henna artists and street performers it is a travelling treat. The whole place is buzzing and really comes to life at night.Try the fruit juice stalls. Lovely and refreshing for just 4 dirhams. The covered restaurants are cheap and hugely competitive. Way better value for money than the other restaurants in the area.

Wonderful night spot. This was a great location to wonder around, or see from above on one of the many patios in the area. Do watch out at night when walking through the food and drink stalls however. As they approach you quite a bit, and assume you are walking through for food, not to just see what is happening. So please be aware of this. Another issue we had, was when buying orange juice from one of the sellers, the one next to him took a dislike to us for not purchasing from him. He then repeatedly yelled at us and gave us the finger. We were not taking pictures, or talking with him prior to this happening and it was entirely unprovoked. Beyond these issues, the square is a wonderful place to wonder around and experience the Marrakech eve with tourists and locals alike.

Amazing ambiance in the heart of the old city. A definite must-visit and must-see when visiting Marrakech and Morocco in general. Lots of energy and things to witness.It is best to visit in both the early afternoon and at night. The square transforms into an even more energetic atmosphere at night with street vendors haggling everyone that their restaurant is the best and has the best prices although they are all roughly the same.Words of advice:The snake charmers and the henna women are quite aggressive. The henna women came up to me after I was admiring someone else's henna and even though I said I did not want it and that I had no money she continued to draw and kept saying "bon prix"... eventually I shook my arm free and she wanted 350dh (around 35Euros) for the design which I refused to pay and I ended up giving her a 50dh bill (around 5euros) as I had nothing else on me. I later learned that I could have tried to negotiate for even 20dh but oh well.

Fantastic!. Djemaa El-Fna comes alive at night. Thousands of chefs set up shop and lay out their tables, and the huge square is filled with entertainers including fabulous Berber percussion groups. It's wonderful!
Mayhem and madness. I guess it must be seen once! An array of food and spice stalls getting busier and busier throughout the day

Crazy but good. It's a step back in time place, get past the square which in the day time has the horrible dancing monkeys and snake charmers. Down the lanes are really good loads of bargains to be had with a haggle, again a polite no thanks does wonders on shops that your not interested in, was never felt that I had to buy anything

Hassled and harassed. Oranges, bottles of water, vendors yelling nicknames to grab your attention (Marco Polo, Ali Baba), vendors, sellers, taxis blocking your path, offering their goods or services. "Experiencing" the plaza is difficult and stressing when you're constantly hunted for money. Some food stalls mocked us openly in front of us, several reataurants at the plaza refused to give change: you bought for 30 Dirham and paid with a 100? You paid 100, then.

Great for people watching!. We first arrived in Marrakesh in the early evening and sampled the night market. This was very vibrant and exciting.During the day, the square is busy with the fresh orange juice vendors, monkey handlers, snake charmers and henna artists; all of whom are very persuasive!The square is surrounded by cafes. They all have roof terraces which are slightly more peaceful than the ground floor, but still full of atmosphere. We had teas and coffees there, as well as some lunches. All were reasonably priced and good value. A note of caution, if you find stairs difficult, stick to the ground floor as there are no lifts!Our Riad was only 5 minutes from the square so we visited every day of our 4 day trip. However, if you are further away, you must make a special effort to go!

full-on experience for the senses!. A must when visiting Marrakech. there is everything you would expect here from snake-charmers to henna tatooists along with a fantastic array of street food in the evening. the food sellers can be a bit annoying trying to drag you into their particulat cafe when in reality they are all pretty much the same... but all worth eating from! The smells and sounds of the square are irresistible and will live with you long after the rtip has ended. My friend described it as "more Moroccan than Morocco" and it's enjoyed by locals as well as tourists

Chaotic!. Great place to wander around. In the daytime there are a variety of OJ stalls (4DH a cup) and people selling dates/figs etc. There are the snake charmers and a variety of people ripping tourists off having photos with them. At night the square comes alive. Pop-up restaurants appear from nowhere and the real chaos starts! You cannot wander through the restaurant area to 'look'... you will be hassled by every vendor - all part of the fun though! The food is very cheap, we ate at one restaurant and the food was great. Take some time to just wander round and take in the atmosphere.

All kinds of crazy. It was pretty much what we expected it to be: chaotic. Fun looking around as long as you stay away from street performers trying to harass you. Orange juice stalls were awesome. It's all same price and same quality (so cheap and delicious), so our best strategy for getting directions to somewhere was to buy some orange juice first and ask the orange juice guy. At night, most of the orange juice stalls are gone and instead there will be lots of food stalls selling kebabs to some unknown local dishes. First night we made a mistake by going to a kebab place (we can't remember the number) and it was horrible. It's hard to pick a place because everything looks pretty much the same and everyone from each stall will try to grab your arms and get you to eat there. Some of them were VERY rude. Second night we set our sight on one place with only the locals sitting and eating with their hands. Stall number 98. Go there. Deep fried fish and calamari were so delicious but their mashed eggplant was honestly one of the best dishes I had in Morocco. It was magical. This place was really cheap and we came back the next day for some more.

Exotic. It´s like going to another world. It´s an experience you will never forget. All different kinds of entertainment. We were there 30 years ago and not last year which I wrongly clicked on and cannot delete. When I read Christa E´s review I was surprised that it nowadays are mostly stallholdersthere. We were enthrilledof the snakecharmers and all acrobats.

Everyone's trying to make a dirham.. Point a camera, you are beset by three men bullying for a handout before you can click the trigger. Walk anywhere near a food stall and everyone is the best in town. It's fun for a while but palls after a few visits.

Chaos and fun together. Plenty to eat, plenty to see but some to watch out for, people walking around with snakes and monkeys suddenly appear and push them onto you for photos, the restaurants on the edge of the square give great advantage positions for photos but go early evening to get seats, if you are not interested into buying just ignore them they usually will move on to someone else.

Hugely entertaining.. During our stay we visited the square every day - you're not going to get free entertainment like this anywhere else in the world! Despite the warnings of some reviewers we did not find the vendors and entertainers particularly pushy or insistent. Try the fresh orange juice, it's excellent. Best of all, try to get a table on one of the restaurant terraces overlooking the square in the evening - it's a brilliant experience and the restaurants we used were far from expensive and rarely crowded.

The heartbeat of the town. Everything happens here - I have never seen so many people on a regular basis at 10.30pm. The hustle and bustle of the stallholders, mopeds, caleches in the daytime and the foodstalls in the evening has to be seen to be believed. A photograph will cost you money - that is how the entertainers make a living. The snake charmers are part of the scene but it did seem cruel to make the snakes move etc simply for money
Not what it used to be. It's now mostly about food stalls - the charm of yesterday has waned and I do not see what a visit to this once magical place could possible entail

Exactly as we Expected...but disappointing. Do not under any circumstances take directions, photos or any interest in what the locals are selling or offering (help with finding certain places, men with snakes/monkeys etc) as they WILL extort money from you. If you refuse to pay they get nasty and aggressive. It's frightening and enough to ruin your holiday. Trust me, we knew the dangers and were still conned out of handing over over 250dirham
heart of the city. Busy place even more fun at night when it fills up with food stalls and sellers Hassling for trade anything from fresh orange juice to snail soup

Intensely chaotic and tremendously fun!. A great place to walk around during the day to shop and at night for inexpensive, delicious local cuisine. It's loud, chaotic, crowded, colourful and you will be approached by every single person you pass to eat at their establishment. We loved it!

fun, interesting , safe. Interesting and bartering is fun if you don't take it too seriously. People are friendly, keen for a sale but it's all amicable. Live animals which is not everyone's cup of tea. Night food market is great.

one visit here is enough. the square is somewhere that everyone must see once but for me that was enough. we were asked by stall holders to buy their produce but didn't feel threatened or harassed when we declined. I found the henna ladies to be more pushy. we did not sample any of the food here, we were advised by our riad owner that the food was barbecued and was often overcooked and ran a risk of leaving us unwell. we were left feeling quite traumatised at seeing the snake charmers with small live chipmunks in cages waiting to be fed to the snakes and the chained bald monkeys wearing nappies being dragged around the square. we visited the square by night to sit on one of the terraces overlooking the area, the square comes to life at night with lots of noise and locals.

Great atmosphere at night!. This square miraculously at sunset turns into an open air food market with lots of restauranters touting their offerings and competing cheerfully with each other. We ate here several times and never got sick. The food was cheap and fresh. Get fresh orange juice from the local vendors and enjoy yourselves!

An evening here is a must. No trip to marrakech is complete without an evening on the Jemaa el Fna. There are acrobats, snake charmers, musicians, story tellers and games, and rows of food stalls (which do lovely and very cheap kebabs, fish, chips and for the adventurous snails or sheep's head). You do need to keep your wits about you and have a pocket of coins for the entertainers (and you will be expected to pay if you take photos). Ten dirhams seemed to be the going rate. When you have had enough, retire to one of the cafés around the square to chill. The grand balcony has a toilet upstairs that you can use for a small coin.By day, the square is emptier, but you can buy lovely freshly squeezed juice.
Chaotic and exciting!. A must for any shopper! Surrounded by stalls and entertainers, dancers, drummers, acrobats..... And in the evenings food stalls galore which altogether make a great atmosphere.

An explosion of sights and smells. Not to be missed. It's another world full of sights and specticals from the snake charmers to the tooth pullers and yes they do exactly what it says on the tin! Buy day it's full of nic back sellers but by night it turns into an open air restaurant filled with amazing smells but be warned I'm not sure they wash the dishes properly between service..... So get there early!

Make no eye contact and you'll be okay!. This is the main square and the place to be, apparently. It transforms at night time into a food square, but in the day time is filled with touristy stuff like henna painters, snake charmers and street performers and blokes trying to get you to have your photo taken with their monkey (no, that's not a euphemism). If you pause for long enough, you'll find yourself with a monkey on your shoulder or a snake around your neck and of course the only way to get these removed is to exchange some cash. Don't dawdle, don't make eye contact, keep moving and you'll be okay!
Very interesting. This place was so different from what I am used to. You have to see it to believe it!! Snake charmers and monkeys, I kept well away from them.

Just Enjoy. You cannot visit Marrakech without also visiting Jemaa el Fna. There is always something going on and you can just walk around and watch, or secure a seat in one of the restaurants around the plaza and observe the colourful goings-on while enjoying lunch or dinner. In the evenings food stalls are set up to accommodate locals and visitors alike. Entertainment goes on well into the night. Just be careful where you point your camera, as the plaza's living "tourist attractions" are expert at spotting picture takers they, rightly or wrongly, suspect of photographing something they should pay for.

Just Walk on By. OK, so do it the once to say you have been there but better and cheaper food with no hassle can be found not so far off. This place, day or night, does not warrant the hype you read.Pass on by. Go to the square of the tin smiths in the day time and in the evening anywhere else.

Marrakech madness. its exactly as its portrayed in all the guide books !! Very busy, noisy , you need your wits about you but nothing to be frightened off.Just go with the hustle and bustle of north Africa .

Hustle and bustle. It's an exciting place it changes from day to night. Had a few orange juices there ( only 4 dirham each! what? 35p in sterling ) in many of the street stalls throughout the day, be it waiting for excursion tours to start in the morning, or having a stroll around the street food stalls at night, or browsing the souks, a good place to gather and experience Marrakech famous plaza - but 1 or 2 visits would be enough - Marrakech is more than just the bustle and madness in the square and the souks.

Incredibly annoying.. The mother of all tourist traps. You will get hassled every ten feet by snake charmers, henna ladies, hash dealers, tour touts, restauranteurs, trinket salesmen, etc.It would be a stimulating environment if it weren't for the constant, aggressive harassment by every kind of merchant.

Simply unique. First of all, I LOVED Morocco! Really, I had the chance to travel a great part of it, and loved everything. El Fna is for sure one of the favorite things I've seen, something you couldn't see anywhere else. I can't explain it by words, so just go there and enjoy!

Interesting place to visit. Incredibly interesting place to visit. Definitely recommend buying a drink in the Cafe Glacier on the square and patiently waiting for a seat overlooking the square as this makes for brilliant people watching! Expect to see snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers, many people selling their goods, monkeys on leads!

Fantastic atmosphere - but be prepared. The square is street theatre at its best. Its noisy, lively and full of hawkers trying to take money off you in every way possible. Igmore the snake charmers (sad and cruel), the trained monkeys on chains (even sadder) and the musicians who will try to charge for even the slightest excuse. Just soak up the atmosphere and enjoy the sounds and sights. We saw the sun go down from the balcony of the Le Grand Balcon du Cafe Glacier (think I remembered that right) - you will pay a few dirhams extra for the view but worth it.The fresh organe j juice stalls are good value at 30p for a large, cold fresh orange juice (watch out for being charged 3x that for pamplemousse (graefruit). We ate at a food stall 2 evenings - v cheap and no health issues at all - I expect due to the quick turnover of food and customers.tip- above mentioned cafe has a relatively clean toilet on the top floor - you don't need to a be a customer, just put a few coins in the attendants dish.

ugh...get me outta here.. Have to say I was very disappointed with the square. After hearing all the tales I envisaged being transported to an arabian medieval fair to delight the senses. What prevailed was a bunch of money hungry locals banging rhythmless drums and flinging half dead snakes around. After 5 minutes the boredom sets in and you'll wander towards the food stalls. DONT. The next minute you'll find yourself seated in a dodgy tent with food being thrown at you, all foul, cold, slimy and after a few mouthfuls you'll realise you've been conned. The bill comes in at 400MAD (as much as the best restaurants charge) abd then you'll spend 24 hours on the toilet, both ways. I lost a days holiday. Go, look, sigh, leave and DONT eat. Good luck.

What a place!. If you like it quiet...do not go here. It is amazing. Sure it is a tourist trap but such an enchanting one. Music and storytelling and flames and buzz. It really comes alive at night. The food venders try to win you over and are bright and lively and even when you say, "Sorry" they smile and wish you luck. The drumming is incredible. It is very difficult to leave and go back to your boring hotel

hectic but fun. went here about 10:00 am ( best get there early before main crowds ) square itself fun to be in, headed for the souks great experience but after a couple of hours got lost in the maze and started to feel a little claustraphobic, usual invites to look at shops quite intense but they do take no for an answer

Energy, chaos and deafening drums. It's one of the most amazing squares in the world where people are encouraged to spend an eternal carnival time, surrounded by hawkers, street entertainers, musicians (not quite), balloons, food, jugglers,. tumblers and stealthy figures out of Star wars.Certainly not to be missed.

Unique. There cannot be anything like this anywhere else. Sure its full of tourists, but also popular with locals which helps to maintain its hectic charm. Take some pens for the kids and be prepared to be hassled, but its not nearly as bad as the Souks. Great fun.

Interesting... Lovely place, loads of people don't go on a friday! gets really busy! Make sure your bargain with the people and walk around the whole square first before you buy anything because when you buy something from somewhere, you might find it cheaper in the next stall!

Crazy Marrakech. Do not go into this area or the Souks without a guide if you want to walk in peace. They will not leave you alone. And you will have people constantly coming us to you and wanting to 'show you where to go' then they want to be paid for it. Its a crazy place to navagate alone, esp. if its your first visit so you will want to have someone show you around and its very easy to get lost. The day we were there with 'our guide' was a totally different experience. It must be an 'unspoken rule' that they leave you alone when they see you are with a 'guide'.

A must see at day and night. I have been here in the day and also at night and its like two different places, it has a massive transformation on the night, it really is a spectacle to see, you can buy anything you want in the day from pottery to fake nike air max trainers and a world of food on the night. I would reccommend a tour on the horse and carriages as you can see the sights without being bothered buy the local snake chamrers and the likes.One word of advice it is not really suitable for small children, i went with my two and you have to be very very alert as people will talk to them, try and lead them off, put monkeys or toys in there hands and demand payment for them, just be very aware!

These are crazy, crazy nights.. Brilliant place but make sure you have enough small change to pay for photo's, if they catch you trying to sneak one they will show you up and pretty much embarrass -in the nicest of ways- you to pay up. I wouldn't advise eating at any of the stalls, they all sell the same stuff and it's not up to much, best going to a local cafe over-looking the square...Cafe de France and the Le Grand Balcon Cafe Glacier are two that offer superb views and if you aren't wanting to eat just buy a drink to go up there...mint tea 30 Dirhams, cheap enough to get the photos and experience the action from a different angle.Every one is very friendly, at no point did we feel threatened... well other than getting our bums groped whilst standing in a very tight crowd -hey ho!
No way, not to see it.. The most famous square in Morocco, this a place where you can be so near to Moroccan culture.It is becoming an international destination.

Different by day and night. What an experience. This quare is filled with a few street sellers, people posing for photographs with monkeys, snake charmers and orange juice stalls and by night it is a total transformation as food stalls appear and cook in front of you and people sit down to eat on long tressle tables. Fantastic!

once is enough per trip. well you have read about it, heard about the snake charmers, street food etc. You must check it out once. Personally I avoid it, the crowds whilst not aggressive, are tightly packed and one always looses friends in the crush. Its emblematic - go but don't take anything you care about losing..

a must see in Marrakech. Here is the place to understand Morocco and it's spirit: a vibrant place where locals are trying to gain money from tourist making hena tatoos, singing, playing with monkeys or snakes,Tourists can eat local food, enjoy a mint tea on one of the top terraces, have pictures with the snakes for a small fee, have a ride with a horse carriage or purchase - after bargaining a lot - some of the local merchandise like leather bags, traditional slippers, spices or fresh local fruits.You may enjoy or not this colorful experience but you will never forget it.

Sights and Sounds. Massive square full of sights, stalls, entertainers. You hear the call to prayer at various times. There are lots of sellers and at night it transforms into a food paradise. Lots of wonderful aromas.

Nice place. Yes its amazing, yes its wonderful and colorful, yes it has a wow factor, but it has some downsides as well just like any plaza/bazaar.Go for a stroll between the narrow streets and enjoy your shopping. Be careful from the beggers.Keep your belongings with you all the time in a safe zipped small bag, not in your pockets.Be safe.

Chaos and spectacle. The square is always busy day or night and there is tons to do, eat, buy and see. However, I didn't find it all that great. The best time I had there was when I was on a rooftop cafe watching the madness below. The vibe in the day is completely different than at night so at least try out both before deciding how you feel about it.

Magic & Horror experience all in one!. I do understand the fascination of this squire for most western people as it's far from beyond what we're used to in our daily life's! You will surely not get bored with many attractions around of which some might be even frightening. From snakes and cobra's until dodgy people who are looking for naïf tourists to ripp-off. The fact is that it's certainly nice to experience it once in your life, but surely enough to limit it with one day. We stayed at a raid close to this squire and after the second day the smell became unbearable as well as very tiring to be cautious all the time. The food at the stall are not that great. After all, you get for what you pay! Who expects to eat a skewer of lamb of the better parts for just a few dollars?

Chez Mbarak. Very good fun eating out in the square here. Good food, cheap and clean. The waiters are a lot of fun and sing you into their tables. We mostly ate fried food, perhaps not such a good idea to eat salads anywhere in Jemaa El Fna :)

vibrant town square. busy busy busy, the food stalls at night are a brilliant place to eat, all the stalls serve much the same food, expect to be pounced on from all directions. not too keen on the photo opportunities with snakes, monkeys birds and the like, just say No. the smells and the sights both day and night will take you to another world, visit the souks up every alley from the main square. we felt perfectly safe all the time and the locals friendly and helpful (a bit too helpful), so glad we stayed within a 5-10 min walk Jemaa el Fna.

Noise and madness!. Very busy especially in the evenings.Good street food- not too expensive.Very noisy but interesting and not to be missed.Great opportunity to haggle but also there is hassle factor of persistantly invited into shops.Easy to be ripped off.

Unbelievable. One of the most amazing places on international tourist map. Don't know how it has not been corrupted more by forty years or more of international tourism. Its full of drama, energy, and the sense that one is in a completely different culture.More nervous travellers might find the crowds and the energy a bit overwhelming.

Great atmosphere in the evening. This is a huge square with lots of opportunities for people watching and things to see including stalls and snake charmers. The orange juice sold in the square is really cheap and delicious but avoid the people trying to get you to have photos taken with monkeys. We didn't go anywhere near them because we don't agree with it, but heard of people being charged 200dhm for one photo!We visited the square at various times of the day and loved the atmosphere when all the food stalls were set up in the evening. We ate here twice during our stay-the first time we chose a stall with lots of locals and they gave us a selection of food which was all really tasty. The second time we got sucked in by pushy traders and although we enjoyed the food, it was full of tourists and the service wasn't as good. I'd recommend choosing a food stall as quickly as possible (preferably with lots of locals eating there) and not faffing about, because the more you faff the more you get hassled!

Avoid. Really over hyped by guide books and reviews, honestly go and have a look and then avoid for the rest of your stay.Unless you enjoy being pestered and badgered by stall owners, and no this is not their 'way' they are very pleasant and friendly within the souks, nothing like they are in the square.We visited both in the day and the evening and on both occasion we couldn't wait to run and hide! I personally do not find monkeys on chains, snakes in baskets or stall after stall forcing their objects on me enjoyable in any way. Nothing within the square is good quality, especially not the food. It was described as a must by the guide books as a place to eat but it is not a pleasurable experience at all. There are far better places to experience authentic Moroccan food.

Crazy crazy, but worth the stroll. It's total chaos in Jemaa el Fna - but you need to walk through it at least once. Sit in a cafe to the side of the square to see the bustling city go about its day; if you find the ex- Bank Al Maghrib open for a visit: don't miss it, it's a fantastic building (open in March 2014 for the Marrakech Biennale)

A traveling experience, never to be forgotten. The food stalls are awesome. Great fun, amazing experience and excellent food. Just be prepared to be pulled and grabbed by the staff who want you to eat at there stall. You can eat and drink for as little as £10 euro. On average me and my wife would have 2 cokes and 4 dishes, like tagine, calamari, cous cous, prawns and this would be around 14 euro. Bargain for such tasty quick food.Stay away from stall 117, terrible service and food, plus more money than the others we stayed at. Especially the lad with the most manicured eyebrows I have ever seen. Very very rude and wouldn't let me pay for the bill so that I would buy more. The best stall was definitely number 1. Amazing food and the quickest service ever.Enjoy and don't miss out on the main square dinning experience.
To be avoided, sadly. Great architecture and atmosphere utterly ruined by aggressive traders. Tourism has ruined them. Only go if being man-handled and abused is your idea of fun

A feast for the senses. such an interesting place. not quite as varied as the write ups but a great place all the same. however don't make eye contact with any of the s ellers as it cost dirham! if you are taking photo's try to not make it obvious you are photographing anyone specific as they want money for it. always barter and a rule of thumb is start at 20% of the price they ask for.

Unlike any other square in the world!. We didn't eat in the square but were fascinated by how the food stalls sprung up at night and enjoyed the atmosphere. The best place to eat on an upstairs terrace looking over the square is Marechki - a decent price for set lunch menu bit you have to ask!

I hated it. Full of aggressive sellers/hawkers, locals begging with children or the disabled, monkeys being yanked about by chains around their necks before being shoved back into tiny cages.
At the same time mopeds are driving erratically around the square and in and out of the Souqs,

Really buzzy place especially in the evening.. The heart of the city and always things happening. In the evening the crowds are incredible. The food stalls are a real sight although not really good value for money (unless you eat at the soup ones). Just wandering round listening to the story tellers or taking a fresh juice from the many stalls is a great entertainment.

The Magig Square. Two words "Absolutely MAGIC". Plenty of attractions, colours and flavors. You could easily get lost in a moment of observation. There is so much going on that you wont want to miss a thing. When the night time kicks in that's when Jemaa el Fna really becomes full of life..

Crazy. This lovely square comes alive as the sun goes down. By day it is crazy, by night it is doubley so! People crowd the square to eat at the bar b que stands, drink fresh juices and mingle with the snake charmers, water sellers and men with monkeys. If being crowded is too much take to one of the roof terraces or patios that surround the square and watch from above. A great way to spend the evening without the chaos.Be warned though, if you take photos of water sellers and others they will demand money and sometime quite aggressively so. Even if you take a panoramic view and one happens to be caught in it.

After 2 days this place get's annoying and boring. The first 2 days this place is nice and you get a lot of impressions. But after this days this intrusive people all around the square become very annoying. The prices for food and drinks are very good around the square but it's almost every restaurant offers you the same menu. We just came here each day for our fresh squeezed orange juice and for some food.

Go to a terrace!. Whether you visit the main square at night or during the day I recommend going to one of the many roof terraces for drinks or food, from here you get a panoramic view of the action & you can soak up the atmosphere.

Nice to eat. We went there to eat twice. Don't forget to haggle, first evening we ate for 50 Mad pp, and bought 15 cookies for 30 Mad, last evening the bill was 30 Mad pp and 24 cookies. Don't hesitate too long, because they can be ennoying.

open all hours.. We visited "the big square" almost every day whilst in Marrakech, and loved wondering around during the day seeing the monkeys, musicians and snake charmers. At 4pm the whole square starts to change as carts appear from all directions bringing in mobile restaurants which are set up by an army of men climbing all over the growing structures like ants, pulling on plastic roofs and starting charcoal fires to cook on. Within the hour the square is transformed into an enormous complex of mini eateries, all of which employ several men to entice passers by to chose to eat at their place rather than any other. It can be quite fun to walk past all of the stands and listen to the often quite witty heckles from the guys desperately trying to get you to chose to eat at their restaurant. Do not be surprised if, when you do finally decide where to sit, you get a huge round of applause.For the best experience of the square, take a stroll for an hour around at around 2pm, then head up to one of the rooftop cafes to have a coffee and watch the carts descend on the square at 4pm. Once the stalls are set up go for another walk past as many food stalls as you can before sitting down for a tasty Moroccan feast. (Take a bow if they clap and cheer)

Unmissable. You cant visit Marrakech without a visit here .During the day its slightly more relaxed with snake charmers , dentists. storytellers. acrobats , monkeys and some stunning fresh fruit juice stalls.At night it transforms into an amazing place full of musicians , brilliant outdoor eating cafes that seem to pop up out of no where, Its a buzzing heaving amazing attack on the senses,. Keep your valuables safe and you will have an unforgettable experience .

a sight to see. by day this square is pretty unassuming with cafes and souks surrounding it. By night the square comes to life with hundreds and hundreds of people decending to see the local entertainers and food stalls appear. The food stalls are OK but there are literally hundreds to choose from all offering pretty much the same food. It was OK, cheap and tasty. The orange juice sellers are probably the star attraction for me. Again, plenty to choose from but all selling wonderful fresh juice at about 40p a cup! Dont feel intimidated by the crowds, get involved.We felt there were alot of people there to view....kind of not a lot. But still it was worth a viist and a real spectacle. If its all too crowded for you then go up to one of the roof top terraces surrounding the square and observe from above.

Nothing like it on Earth?. This place is a human menagerie. All life is here - every day. Alive with merchants, traders, tourists, acrobats, snake charmers, game players, musicians, food stalls, drummers. There really is nothing like the experience of this Square.

Amazing - another world !!. The main square in Marrakech is like no other place I have visited. The cacophony of sound and people is an amazing experience and not to be missed.
During the day it's busy, but at night it really comes alive.
We ate at stall 27 and the food was great !!

Noise & bustle - all you'd expect. Exactly as expected - lots going on and everyone trying to get you to spend your money! People will ask you for money if they think they are in your photos so take care. In the evening, stall 25 was great for dinner and 41 for fresh juice.

I can't see what all the fuss is about!. We went during a cold, grey Monday in February. The square was flat and uninteresting with equally uninteresting buildings surrounding it. The square was full of sad looking scavengers trying desperately to sell you something. The performances were touristy and not very impressive. Maybe we went at the wrong time of day. Give me a European city square anytime.

An experience!!. There is plenty to look at in Jemaa el Fna, not all of it good. Lethargic snakes, monkeys on strings posing with you for photos and annoying men in costume who force themselves beside you to have their photos taken. You have to be strong to resist all these pushy tourist 'attractions' but if you can relax and ignore them there is fun to be had. The food at the night market is excellent and reasonably priced, well regulated and no dodgy tummies for us. Likewise the cafes in the daytime, no problem with banana juice etc where we went. At night you can also try the restaurant Marrekchi which has good food in a wonderful location.If you want to see some Moroccan street theatre, hear local music, have your hands henna painted and just soak up the atmosphere then it's a great place to go.

Bustling, noisy and worth the visit. The square is chaotic - full of fortune-tellers, acrobats, story-tellers, appalling musicians (the banjo player with chickens on his head...), snake charmers, monkey-owners, henna tattooists. Find a cafe with a rooftop terrace, order a coffee and soak it all up.

Crazy. Loved the hustle and bustle and hated it at the same time! Snake charmers, men with baboons, water sellers, medicine men and so much more - but if you pause to look you are likely to have a monkey on your shoulder, a snake round your neck or hennaed hands so just don't pause for long. Also, you WILL have demands for money for taking a picture of a cobra, even if it is from 30 feet on a telephoto lens - they just know!Go to the square at night as well and sample the food - it is tasty, freshly cooked and incredibly cheap. Did not try the snails but I am told they are tasty and as for smoked goat head......Sit in Cafe Glacier, have a coffee and watch the stalls from above - a fabulous way to see what's going on.

Amazing Market & Experience. Jemaa el Fna is at the heart of the Medina. Amazing sights and sounds. Delicious freshly squeezed juices and wide array of foods. Find a terrace cafe above the square, order some tea or hot milk with verbena and enjoy the view. Do be wary of the women who will grab you for Henna and be sure to read all the advice from the guide books about do's and don'ts. I felt sad for the monkeys on short chained leashes...

Crazy, fascinating place. Whatever time of the day that you visit, there is always something or someone fascinating to watch. Orange juice sellers in the morning and food sellers in the evening. Entertainment of all kinds all day and night long from cobras to dancing Moroccans playing traditional instruments with a chicken AND then a dove balanced on his head!!

Huge Square that keeps changing. We visited Jemaa el Fna in the morning, afternoon, evening and at night. It is constantly changing. Morning has the least activity and you can get the sense of just how big the square actually is. The entertainers slowly arrive, but there were not as many as I expected, and they were not nearly as interesting as I thought they'd be. The evening and night were the most interesting and enjoyable - with the food stalls, games, merchandise, and just overall activity. We were also lucky to see prayer time. The square wasn't nearly as loud or hectic as I expected. But yes, there are (unfortunately) touts harassing visitors - guess it's all part of the show. Saying 'no' (or La) to them does not work….ignoring them completely and keep moving works much better. Overall, it's a pretty cool place.

go for the atmosphere. This has to be a must ! Go to soak up the atmosphere, be warned you will get buzzed by mopeds in the tiniest of alleyways. Buy your Argan oil products here and make sure you barter for everything as they expect it. Enjoy the snake charmers, dancers and acrobats!

Hectic. A wonderful place that changes with the sun. In the early morning it is fairly quiet, with a few traders and wide open spaces. Come sunset, the place is suddenly full of thousands of people all vying for food or to listen to storytellers, a magical atmosphere, but not for the fainthearted.

The heart of Marrakech. Loved the vibrant colours, the snake charmers, the monkey, complete with baby's nappy. Enjoyed it much more in the evening when it really comes to life with all the food stalls. No 1 stall was recommended by our Riad and it did not disappoint. One of the best meals we had in Marrakech.

A must see. The Jemaa el fna is certainly worth a visit just for the experience! The vendors are determined for you to part with your money, but either try haggling or just walk away politely. During the day the square is more focussed on selling wares but at night there is food and entertainment however, be prepared to be hassled to eat at every stall and to tip the entertainers if you so much as look them in the eye! Saying that, it is a fun experience so don't be put off!

Heart beat of Marrakech. On my last trip to Marrakech, I spent several evenings sitting here at the Cafe de France from sunset onwards drinking mint tea or café au lait and watching the magic unfold....great people watching spot.

Marrakech Magic. This main square is an absolute "must see",particularly at night when there are hundreds of food stalls,acrobats,story tellers,snake charmers and pickpockets.Be very careful with your belongings - I lost a passport and iPhone and didn't feel a thing.

Touristy but vibrant. As close as it gets to being in a real life Indiana Jones movie, this place has a little but of everything and a whole lot of hustle. This place has everything snake charmers, monkey handlers, juice stands, and shops during the day. At night it turns into dancers, drum circles and food stalls at night. Most of the entertainers/vendors are hustlers so be careful. As others have said, if you approach one of the groups (snake charmers, etc.) be prepared to pay for a picture. Large circles often form around these entertainers so I also kept an eye out for pick-pockets.This place has such great energy at night and is really a must-see.

Loved it - Single woman travelling alone. I was in Marrakech as a single woman travelling alone and spent an evening wandering around the square - it is incredible - the whole world seems to be there and the entertainment is second to none - got hustled into having a meal which wasn't terribly good but everyone is so friendly and sweet that I was not overly worried - I am not sure why all these nervous women get so uptight as I chatted away to lots of people and did not feel in the slightest bit unsafe. As I have said in my other review about the souk - these things are about your attitude and being from Glasgow I have had more than sufficient experience of cheeky boys to cope easily here. The photography issue is easily solved by buying yourself a tea in one of the balcony restaurants and shooting your pictures from there. The horse drawn carriage ride I eventually took around the square and city was excellent value for money and the horses were in magnificent shape. Carriage number 31 - highly recommended.
nothing. nothing to see nothing special just like all touristic place alloverthe world.don't buy anything there probably you will have the highest price all over the city.

Fascinating. A melange of activity, hustle, bustle.Snake charmers, acrobats, musicans, monkeys, food sellers even a man selling dentures or single teeth if you need them. It is brillant day and night. You will get asked to pay if you "happen" to take a photo near one of the performers but stand your ground or pay up, it's up to you.The cafes around the suare are great for taking a mint tea and people watching, The balconies of Cafe de France are good as is Le Grand Balcon of the Cafe des Glaces with views of the Atlas Mountains.You can take the Hop On/Off bus from the bottom of the square a good way to get to places and see both sides of the city. Tickets valid for 24/48 hrs

Hasn't changed?. Been here before but its just amazing. Stayed until they changed over to the food stalls, then wandered round. Fabulous colours smells? And sounds, such a laugh, the trades men laughing at you no idea what they are saying but who cares?not offended just Loved it

very oriental. 'la place' is amazing. Just walking around there you feel like straight out of 1001 nights. It's like being in a fairytale. All sellers and attractions have their reserved places. You come back another day and will still find your peanut seller or snake tamer right were they were before. Just before sunset, you'll see all these carts hurry to their assigned spots on the square. Stands are being assembled in no time and people start cooking and offering their food. A lot of locals eat here. We were going to also, but since we were so unlucky with the weather we decided we'd be much warmer in a restaurant. We'll just have to come back ;-)In order to get a good view of the hustling and bustling, you should go up to one of the cafe's. We went to the Cafe' Glacier. Great view! Go when the food vendors start setting up shop. It's amazing!
Hive of activity. Love it! Just wander and check out everything random that is going on! Only in Marrakech! Dentists, juice, snakes, monkeys, henna....the list is endless!

So Alive. In the day, there are snake charmers and women painting henna; at night, the food comes out and the square fills with music and storytelling. It can be overwhelming with all of the vendors attempting to get you to eat or drink something but they are all really friendly.

Intense. We have visited many trimester during the day but decided to visit in the evening to eat. Quite a different experience. We had a drink on the "grand balcony" of cafe glacé which was well worth it. You have to buy a drink before you go onto the balcony (only €2 for a coke) and the view is stunning. Take your camera! We then headed down to find something to eat. Everyone wanted us to join their stall and choosing was hard (and a bit fraught) but we found somewhere and the food was lovely. Only one word of caution, we only ordered a main course but were brought 3-4 starters each and charged for them (although they didn't cost that much). Not sure how we could have avoided that. A real adventure.

Dont bother, tourist trap. Dont go near the music, or the snake charmers or anyone selling anything. The snake charmers take some great fotos and are very friendly and then demand 30 euros because you took 2 pics with your camera. I was surrounded and they were demanding money, in the end i gave 5 euros and left. Its very busy and interesting, but me and my partner didnt feel comfortable or safe any time we were in this square.

FANTASTIC!!!!. It's an amazing experience, so much to see and do! Mad how close Morocco is to the UK and yet it's so completely different. The smells, the food, there are carpet shops, fish markets, monkeys, snake charmers, fortune tellers and so on. It's an amazing experience! I will be returning for the third time, I absolutely love Morocco!!

Not For a Single Women to Go Alone. A man followed my for over an hour trying to get me to go to his shop. When I politely declined he called me every name in the book. I had to leave to escape him. I've never felt so vulnerable in my life.
Nothing special. I had expected more from the street entertainers, certainly during the day there isn't a great deal to see and expect to be hasselled.

A must-see. Hectic, lively & interesting. Visit in the daytime to look around the stalls, shop for souvenirs, try the delicious fresh orange juice, watch snake charmers & hold a monkey (although be prepared to tip!). At night time, a huge fast-paced food market takes place, selling tagines, cous cous, pastille, even snails. Stall #1, Chez Aicha is highly recommended.

amazing place. You have to just stand back and take it all in ... a riot of people, colours, noise, sounds and of course smells !!! ... Be careful taking pics though !!! People want money for everything here ... My guide told me to not say no as it starts a conversation ..just smile and ignore.
The Best Market. The best tradional market... The oranje juice is spectacular... be careful with people because they ask for money any time...
Open Theatre. A live theatre, drink a Orange Juice, sit in the Cafe's to watch WORLD GO BY and in the evening eat from local food stalls ( #1 and #14 highly recommended).

Bustling hub. Excelllent place to sit in one of the cafes and watch the world (and wildlife via donkeys, snakes,cats, dogs and monkeys) go by- a really busy space used day and night, when everything seems to come to life and stalls spring up selling everything from tasty food to henna tattoos. watch out taking photographs of people- the will expect payment.

a living place. this is one of the places to visit at MarrakechYou should go during day time, all kind of people perform their acts, show birds, snakes, apes, sell some fake viagra powder, propose henna tattoos or sell orange juice. In evening time, the square becomes a large restaurant with seats and plenty of open kitchen, impresive to see.Beside there are also some dessert/coffee/tea stands.Be aware that they ask money for every photo you take!

Dont encourage the animal handlers. This is the place to use as a reference point as all sign posts in the Medina appear to point this way. Please, Please, Please don't take pictures of monkeys on chains, snakes etc. These people are only here because tourists pay for pictures. The night market is a worthwhile visit one night although be aware you will get hassled until you sit down and eat somewhere. So move around the outside and pick one of the end of the row as they are pretty much all the same fare. Be aware they charge for the bread if you take any which is not what they say when you down. If the bread is not eaten it is just handled and moved on to the next punter (euchh).

The centre of the trouble. A nice location, within the days crowded with people always trying to cheat you. The guys with their Snakes, Hennapainters and so on, not the greets thing during the day. But in the evening a lot of small mobile kitchens are coming out and a bi Foodcourt is created every day. With the beginning a dawn the change begins- this is also a nice thing to be watched from one of the Rooftopterraces adjoining the place. But just take your drink there and go down to the Djemaa for Dinner. All in all a little bit strange, but with great food. Don´t let the pickers push yourself into the first "restaurant". Take a walk and decide where you want to go to take your food. A nice and unique experience with real good food at a really low price.

A step back into time. You've seen it in movies but this is real life. The central square (and medina as a whole for that matter) is like taking a step back hundreds of years in time. The food stalls are unique (but can be unsanitary). Follow the locals and look through the tripadvisors for the safe reviews of each stall. We went with the TripAdvisor recommendations and never had a problem. You will be hounded by locals trying to sell there wares. Just be firm and keep walking. Remember nothing is free......locals will come to you with snakes, monkeys etc for pictures. Rest assured they want paid. Have a prepaid tip ready if you want a picture or they will have you erase the free pics. All in all, it is a really cool experience if you can handle the high pressure sales. If you have a keen eye you will be able to buy some really unique gifts that weren't made in China (keep a close look at what you are buying because a lot of it IS still made in China). If you are buying any name brand items, remember, almost all are fakes (and you get what you pay for). At night the place turns into a party. Really cool atmosphere that is a must see. Marakech is probably one of the most unique and interesting vacations I have ever been and I do not regret it!

Spectacular, constantly changing. What a wonderful look into Marrakech life. In the evening there are snake charmers, water vendors, dried fruit and nut stalls, and all kinds of food vendors from snails to offal. Huge seating areas and a mix of locals and tourists. In the day it's dotted with fortune tellers, market vendors and there are carriage rides.

A busy market at night!. When I arrived at the Jemaa el Fna I was instantly greeted by the sounds and people. In the daytime you have snake charmers and men with monkeys etc. My tip for them is to put what you're willing to pay in coins into your pocket before you take any photos etc. You also have fruit stalls and orange squashers which are reasonably priced by western standards. You also have plenty of stalls selling bits and bobs etc. At night the square comes to life and you have a variety of pop-up restaurants to choose from. I personally found the stalls on the sides of the square quieter and nicer to eat at. I had a bad experience with the pop up restaurants and found them to be very rude and they all claim "no diarrhea 2 years" as if thats supposed to reassure me...You also have a variety of entertainers and musicians as well as a regular pop stool where you have to hook the bottle (near impossible to win, but it's a bit of fun). You also have horse drawn carriages on the edge of the square, I can't comment on whether these were any good. Overall the Jemaa el Fna has a wonderful atmosphere and I'd recommend it, but as with anywhere don't feel pressurised into buying anything you don't want and be safe as there are some undesirable people about.

absolute caos, snake charmers, monkeys on chains, moroccan street entertainers...the lot.... Absolute caos, unimaginable...not sure what I expected of Marrakech....but found the whole square overwhelming...monkeys on chains, snake charmers, moroccan street entertainers, very pool people trying to sell anything and everything....pj's seems to be the most popular....so many people...did not see much money changing hands....everyone looking but no one buying....finally ate at a small very modern restaurant called yamys..could not face the caos of the street restaurants.....

Great atmosphere. Really loved this square with the snake charmers and many orange juice stands and great insight into the way of life in the Medina. We enjoyed sitting on the terraces overlooking the square. Please don't tip the snake charmers or monkey handlers however as all you need to do is to look at the state of these animals and realise its not very ethical. very much suggest walking around there at night as it has a different feel then in the day and the smells and sights are amazing. Street food stalls are set up night after night there on the square and its amazing
Wow!!. From about 5pm the food stalls start setting up and the entertainers arrive. Grab a table on a balcony somewhere and watch the sun go down - pure magic.

Must see. Beautiful, lucky as we were there in February so not too packed. In the day there are monkeys and snake charmers, even a vulture. At night there are an array of pop up restaurants.I have seen the reviews about being harassed, ok it is annoying. But having been to markets up and down Egypt and in Turkey, this was nothing in comparison! Everyone was very polite. Just fun to walk around each day and look around and even get lost!

Jemaa el Fna. Definitely an experience to visit at night - watch out for the hena women who grab your hand for a free tattoo and then demand money - otherwise worth a look. Had a really nice meal just off the J e F - Lots of places to eat nearby just off square. Felt safe but kept hold of cash in pocket.
Must see!. All the mess of this mix of snake charmers, street food sellers, future tellers is certainly the greatest touristic spot and a must see in Marrakesh.
well worth its UNESCo status. 'all human life is here' Loved the atmosphere , night and day and seeing many different sorts of people . a great place to eat and people watch

Wild Crazy - Must See!. There is nothing like it... a wild assortment of sights, sounds and scents! Amazing snake charmers, monkeys, donkeys, food, fortunetellers using cards and human teeth, music, carts, motorbikes. We did find as two blond women, there were many rude but not dangerous men mulling about and a few nice and gentlemen sellers in the stalls. I was happy to experienced this frenetic place and happy to leave!

The Past Meets The Present. It is the main market square in the old town of Marrakesh, Morocco. Here traders meet travelers, travelers meet snake handlers and snake handlers meet fortune tellers. It is a little bit loud, chaotic and hectic. And there is really a lot to see. It is a feast for the senses. If you choose one of the restaurant around the square, choose one with a view. The souks around the square are huge and give another good experience about Marrakesh. A ride with a carriage is romantic and fun. The horses look in a good condition.
