different. Depends what you are looking for,we are all different,sorry not for us.To much hassle with the people selling food

Not to be missed. Loved the hustle and bustle of the square, but would not like to be without an escort at night. Do be aware of the women who try to give you a 'gift' usually trying to push it into your hand, pocket or bag, then pester you to buy something and when you refuse snatch back the 'gift'.

A lively myriad of people and animals.. This is a vibrant if not chaotic huge place with stalls, snake charmers, money tamers, peopled not only with people but donkey carts and horse driven carriages.
it has some pleasant cafes and is the entry point to the many souks.
Food!. Check out the food booths that set up every night..amazing food for CHEAP!! Circles of musicians also set up and play. A great experience!

A lot of fun!. Enjoy a drink or meal overlooking the square and spend ages looking at everything that goes on.Sellers try to sell you all sorts of things, but there is no real hassling and we (2 women) felt quite safe. Gives a real feel of Morocco. Remember that you can look for free, but be prepared to pay if you take photos.
Crazy Place. You cant go to Marrakech without visiting The Square with all its Smells...Sights and Sounds its a must.
A must to see at night. Definitely an experience to visit at night and to have dinner. So many stores and restaurants to choose from

Fun But Hectic. You can find many interesting things here. Started from orange juice seller, souvenir seller, snake charmer, dancer, water seller (with Berber traditional clothes), henna seller, foods bazar and many more. It was very interesting to see all those people and activities in the same time. The plaza itself, during the day, it was not really crowded, even it was almost empty. Started from 3 pm, some sellers started to come and exhibit their stuffs. Some dancers start to dance, water sellers are busy to get people that want to have pictures with them. Remember, you must pay them. It was fun, but sometimes, it can be very active. On the afternoon, people are started to come. The plaza became very full not only with people, but also motorbike, car, bicycle, horses and many more. The noises can be too much as well with the musics. The music just stopped when azan (praying call) came. It was fun for a while, but, when it was too much, it can be so hectic.

Just a square with orange squasher stands and a few "artists" bugging tourist for some backshish. If you have never been to an Arab market or to an Arab country can go just to have a look, otherwise it is just a waste of time.

Fun time. Snakes, monkeys and food sstands all in an open air market. What else could you really ask for?Fun area with plenty of "acts" to entertain kids and adults alike. The various food stands are interesting but other than snacking, I'd recommend one of the numerous restaurants surrounding the square instead. Stands carry mostly touristy trinkets and any serious purchases will have to be found elsewhere. There is an area where horse drawn carriage rides are available. I grabbed one back to the Sofitel after a long night of exploring Marrakesh with my 3 year old (mom stayed back at the hotel). It was a nice touch to end the night on and one of those special "daddy/daughter" moments.
fun for all. Lots to see, lots to eat! If you're an animal lover, avoid the snake charmers and monkeys on chains, etc !!!

Funny bazaar. Very good wood handcrafts, tea sets, textiles, and shoes. Sellers inflate prices, so the first price is around 2 to 3 times the value of their product. Generally they are friendly and open to bargaining and explaining 'their art' but other could get unfriendly with no real reasons

enjoyably disturbing. amazement and shock at the same time - not for everyone, but definitely worth the visit
Taking pictures of the acts here means also paying for it, or be prepared to be handled.
Some animal cruelty and other strange act here, so don't support these if it bothers you.

Experience!. If your in Marrakech you have to come here. My friend and I had an amazing time and visited Jemaa el Fna 4 times and were never disappointed. Remember to haggle with the locals they often over price things as they expect you to haggle. It's great during the day for grabbing some bargains and it comes alive at night. You do get harassed by the locals however I found Egypt much worse. There is so much to offer, I would highly recommend the fresh orange juice and the amazing entertainment. Definitely worth a visit.

A busy hub of harassment... but worth a walk through. The busy square is where all the flotsam and jetsam of Marrakech ends up, it is good for a walkthrough on the way to somewhere else. It is where all the poor and desperate come to pray on tourists for their money. Most of it is quite harmless but there are a few 'entertainers' that if you had a camera with you, even if the lens cap was on they would accuse you of taking a picture, and demand money. Or they would put their hat on you as you walked by, and demand a picture, to then demand money. It is best to take it all with a grain of salt and enjoy it for what it is, a busy tourist trap, designed to distract you and get your money! The orange juice stands are worth trying and there is a restaurant called Yamy (sp) just across from Cafe de France which has a really good breakfast (the 30 dhm one)... Best Msemen I had while in Marrakech
Crazy!. Everything you could think of to buy, superb orange juice and food options although hectically busy! Really vibrant after dark, good experience.

Okay, but the heart of Marrakech lies elsewhere. This is the main square of the old city, but feels as though it has lost its heart. Yes it's lively, but it feels more like a stage show put on for tourists. The further you get from here the more interesting the city feels.

Colours, smells, noise and vibrancy. Jemaa el fna is vibrant and full of strange and wonderful sights. There are snake charmers with large cobras , dancing man, donkeys, food, orange juice fresh squeezed. its a place unlike anything i have seen before.

Soak it up but keep moving..... You can't miss this for sheer sensory overload, but if you stop walking you become a hustler-magnet. Learn to say "Laa, choukrane" (no thanks) repeatedly and you'll be fine; don't give more than about 20dirhams for a photo op, don't encourage or support the people with monkeys on chains and be smiley, polite and respectful: it's al part of the spectacle. The evening food stalls have to be experienced too: charming but persistent barrow boys draw you in and the food is pretty good and v cheap if you choose yourself ( as opposed to the waiters choosing for you!). An unforgettable evening; be brave and just go for it.
The Square. Didn't stay long in the square as was on our way to the restaurant and the minute you slowed down you got hassled

Spend a day at the square. This is a busy square that has market stalls and street entertainment during the day and awesome street food at night. Well worth a visit. Lots of coffee shops and cafes to sit and people watch

Marrakech's most famous attraction. You can't visit the city without taking in the iconic square. At the time of year we were there it's perhaps quieter than high season but still busy with the friendly orange sellers 30p, 30 cents EU or 40 cents US for a cup. It's good to see that the dancing bears have gone and the dancing monkeys and snake charmers are also on the way out. their passing shouldn't be mourned as the animals suffered terrible cruelty. Most tourists ignore the few charmers and trainers that remain, killing their trade. Food is passable in the balcony cafes around the square but for the best dining experience you really must sit in the communal dining pitches that pop up in the square in the evening. the balcony terraces are great for having a cola or a tea and watching the world go by though. The most iconic Café Argana is still being refitted after the terrible events of 2011 but should open later this spring. if you really need a beer it's not that hard to find and there is a great bar just round the corner from the Café de France above La Salama restaurant.

Must see main square. Great place very busy so you need to be super careful A lot of henna ladies and they constantly ask you if you want it done so it's quite exhausting especially in summer heat but my advice the best thing is to always have a smile don't even have to say anything as the Muslim people at the market are very persuasive and won't stop until they get a sale. So be ready it might get exhausting other than that it's the main attraction of marrakech in my opinion.

A bustling square but pushy locals. A bustling square but pushy locals. Great food here at night at the stalls (try No. 100) but watch out for the local hustlers, particularly if you take any photos or walk near the snake stalls.

Very nice place but pay attention on some people there. You have lots of attractions there - you can see cobras, plenty of people, small restaurants (not sure about the hygien) etc... But there are lots of people who profit as you are tourist. The is the biggest negative problem in Marrakech. You take a picture and immediately behind you there is the person asking you plenty of money. As my, a photo with cobra and then asking me 40 euros!!! and if trying to negociate,sometimes that person tries to increase the voice to make you fear ... And also another experience, I was walking down the square and there was a guy with the monkey, I refused he put the monkey on my shoulder but he did... Well, that time I decided to take a photo and made an agreement that I will give 1 euro to the guy... But while taking the picture, the moment I couldnt move as I had a fear the monkey will fall down, there was another guy who put the second monkey on my second shoulder. The monkey was peeing on my Tshirt, I was disgusted, angry and the guy asked me for 10 euros and I already gave him 1 euro as the agreement. He began to touch me and increase the voice as he tried to make me feel as a thief... The only thing that helps you is to use the word POLICE, as there is always the police on that square. Make understand these people that if they continue to be bad, you go directly speak to the police.

A must do in marakesh. No visit to Marrakesh would be complete without a visit to this place which assaults your senses and transports you to ancient times. Lovely food (try the fish dishes), great fresh juices and spiced tea. a ton of fun...
Fascinating. The heart of Marrakesh - lively, vibrant with so much to watch. Head for a cafe with a high terrace and look down on all the activity.

Unmissable and unremarkable at the same time. Of course if you come to Marrakech, you have to visit Jemaa el Fina, the center of all activity and reason for a lot of people to come here.It is good, it is "exotic" (to some extent), but it did leave me with the feeling of being in a poor version of Epcot Center. Maybe there was a time (before EasyJet), when snake charmers, and monkeys dressed as ballerinas was exotic. Now, it feels like vintage tourist trap.Nevertheless, as I said on the title: it is unmissable. If you are around the Atlas Asni hotel, it is a good walk (about 20 minutes), or a 30 dirham taxi ride. Pay 50 if you feel generous. Above that, the driver is just being greedy.

Lively Square. The square is all you would expect it to be and more. In the morning, it's full of orange juice and spice/dried fruit stalls. Come 4 o clock and the evening food stalls start setting up. At night time it can get a bit too much when every stall holder is trying to grab your attention to eat at their stall, particularly if all you want to do is browse and pick somewhere in your own time. I can highly recommend stall 42 as somewhere with friendly faces and lovely fresh food on offer.

Visit but be careful. A must see for sure but a few things to consider:1- Don't be shy to say NO for people begging you for money2- Some of the show men will make you feel that you "owe them money" as they happened to be in a picture you took. Don't pay attention and keep walking3- If you are interested in the snake charming shows, get closer to take some good pictures but consider paying and don't pay whatever they ask for... Bargain and pay your price. 4- Ladies be careful during the day and in the evening and know that there are several Police stations around in case of need. 5- If you're shopping in the souk, no need to remind you : Bargain!Again, worth visiting once but they should change their attitude and let tourists enjoy without harassment.
Interesting. It was everything we expected. Fantastic atmosphere. Food stalls in the evening cheap and delicious.

Different place day and night. You are met by a sea of people coming towards you. They are holding snakes and monkeys. Do not take photos unless you are willing to pay them. They will expect this. If you get eye contact then someone will come over to you and offer their services as a guide or want you to take a picture of them. If you go for this then agree a price in advance. If the henna ladies come up to you then keep your hands away. They will put the henna on your hands and expect money. Do not fall for them saying it a gift. The mood by night changes. The entertainers change and the food stalls come out. The guys working on the stalls are funny and have lots of phrases related to the country you are from. All food stalls seem to do the same food so you can't go wrong. You definitely learn by tthe end of the trip and the Souks that the word no or No merci is all you will say. The food was tasty and atmosphere was good.

STALL 55!!!. The Jemaa el Fna at night is sensory overload. Everyone wants your business and comes calling as you walk through the food stalls. Stall 55 was recommended to us as one that is more hygienic than the others and the food was so delicious that we ate there two separate nights while in Morocco. We can personally recommend the mixed skewers and the calamari. The gentlemen who run the stall are lovely and the prices were very reasonable. The egg/potato sandwich guys next door also had booming business both times we were there and I came home regretting not trying their food. Definitely enjoy some fresh OJ while you're there...and ladies, keep your hands buried in your pockets if you don't want to get henna-ed. Despite having my hands in my pockets, a lady got me while I was out shopping and it took forever for it to dry.

A big square. This also listed here as the Marrakesh Medina. This is the large open square that is the center point of the medina and the starting point for wanderings down the side streets into the souk. It is interesting, but not overwhelming.
delicious and good value. Ate at stand no. 1 and the food was brilliant and service very good, also try the freshly squeezed OJ for about 40p a glass mmmmh
Avoid #100 and #12 food stalls in the square. Avoid #100/#12 food stall. They charged us 520Dh for 4 x saucer plates of food. No drinks. ABSOLUTE RIPOFF BUYER BEWARE.

Different place at day and night. Well to enjoy this place... Be open and kind. There are polite ways to say no 'la shoukrah' and they don't harass you. Lots to see and if you wish to but, be prepared to haggle it is art of the culture.If you get lost which s very likely if you then to see the tannery - avoid if carcass being treated for colored leather is not your thing - always follow the sign Jemaa El Fna... You will get back to the entrance of the market.

CENTER SQUARE. Full of life! It is a must by the late afternoon, when starts the work to built the night restaurants, in the middle of the square. It's na everyday work.And GO THERE FOR DINNER. Choose the restaurante with local people. Eat the grilled meat....GREAT AND VERY CHEAP.No wine or beer.....

The reason I love Marrakech. The vibrancy, life, color, sounds, cheap food... I love it! The constant calls of "ma'am! ma'am!" and other sales pitches can be a bit overwhelming at times, but really I love all of it. Stall 95 of the night market has very cheap, decent food. You'll notice that it's mainly Moroccans there. Ask for the tangia (not the tanjine) - it's simple, hardy, and good!

Hectic and virbriant. One of the main locations to visit in Marrakesh. Full of interesting people but be prepared to say know to all the very active sales people present. We found the best way to enjoy the atmosphere of the square was to sit on one of the rooftop terrace cafes.
Bonkers!. Well worth the visit, but you will be hassled endlessly, stand firm on you price and don't be afraid to walk away!

You must go here. No visit to Marrakech would be complete without coming here.
Great in the day but tourists are excessively hassled at night by the food vendors.
Be prepared to deal with it (its just their way) and enjoy !!

Its not what it seems. Looks great when you see it on TV & it is great fun there when you first arrive at the square. You need to be very streetwise though as all the Street Sellers/Henna Tattoo Ladies will quickly part you from your cash & quite honestly most of it is just tat. The Fruit looked very fresh & inviting & the hot food vendors food smelt delicious but I never plucked up the courage to try it as did not want to risk the dreaded Morocan Movement.The discusting part is the way the animals are treated, we saw the monkeys being roughly treated & Manhandled in order that tourists had their photos taken with the monkeys for cash.This is not right or fair on these lovely creatures.The Snake charmers were conning their punters, the Cobras dont react to the music but to the movement of its owner, the snakes looked drugged & certainly not healthy. If you attempted to photograph them even from a distance one or their spotters would approach you & demand money from you, if you did not pay as I didn't an altercation would take place.They were not nice people so it was best to just walk away & ignore their demands which is what I did. The Birds of Prey had clearly had their tail feathers cut to prevent their escape & this is not fair.To stop this from continuing, Tourists visiting Marrakech need to stop paying these cruel people. If there is no demand there will be no supply!!!

Large busy square. This was a mixed experience. It was interesting to see the hustle and bustle of Marrakech but we were totally put off by the constant hassle to buy and especially horrified by men approaching you with snakes (which I detest). I am not a delicate little woman but I was so glad I was with my husband, I dread to think what it would be like if I was by myself or with just female friends. I did not cover my hair, nor did a lot of women I saw there, so it is good that this did not attract any adverse attention which I did appreciate as it was a hot day and I would have not cared for wearing a scarf! All in all, interesting but I would not go back.

Great place to spend time. Day time, few snake music pay for photo, then the monkeys , and plenty other attractions, and the fresh fruits juices for only 0.40 cents then selling dry fruits stalls. During the evening the place become a big open restaurant , the food stalls grow like mushroom. Music, people, ginger beer tea, stall, this is a must place to go.

Great food, service and price!. Most stalls sell the same food so just choose one that you like the look of and enjoy! We tried the snails first... nice,hot and pepper broth. Then we moved on to another stall and had meat skewers, calamari and prawns, aubergine and sweet potoato cakes, bread, olives, all washed down with Arabic coca cola all for under £15 for 2!

The Big Square. Great shopping, very large and overwhelming. one needs at least three days to walk the entire souk. The only negative thing is most vendors will harass you to stop to "look not buy" in their respective shops. I always doubled back to the nice vendors who gave zero pressure to me and my friends.

Magical. Been here in Dec 2013, weather was still hot in the day bit windy in the night, busy, exotic, weird, abrakadabra, surprising , fun, haggling, magical at night, I love this square ! You will love the souks its colorful market, weird Morocan haggers, , tasty foods fakes rolex, cell phones, blend of tradition and modernity, ....the Magical J EL FNA !

bustling square. absolutely amazing,so busy day and night, plenty of places to eat and drink, entertainers in the square snake charmers, monkeys, water sellers, street sellers we didnt tke photos of the entertainers as they all wanted paying not just a few dirhams alot it was an experiance, which i would never have missed,

Moroccon Bustle. By day square selling orange juice with entertainments - monkeys, snake charmers, musicians.Just outside the main souk.By night it converts with fifty odd makeshift eateries, all put up from barrows from 16.00 to 17.00 and taken down again at 02.00. The operation is almost military with each restaurant fully coordinated for their kit. We had a wonderful afternoon in a nearby balcony retaurant watching the work evolve.The food is cheap. It is fresh, varied, and cooked as you wait so little risk of "untoward issues". We ate at No1 Chez Aisha on four nights, a different meal every night. Each night for less than £15 for two people including drinks. Note it is almost impossible to get a beer or wine anywhere near the main square, in fact I only found 4 cafe/restaurants in the Medina (old town) that served beer, despite extensive searches.There is a public toilet (1dhm) on the square under ground near the botanic sales section.

Be ware. The square is amazing.... Snake charmers by day, Food stalls by night. It's an amazing sight... So different from Europe. Just be careful., they want paying for any photos you might take , just give them a small tip and it's fine. The food stalls all vie for your business, just make sure you order what you want. Read up on here about the food stalls before you go and it will be fine.

First place to say "Bonjour Marrakech". It's the place you must see in Marrakech. This place is biggest the real life show, you can sit in the cafe & watch other people about or the activities going on the square day & night.At night, there're a lot of food stores in the square. A lot of the quiet rip you off by the prices (the prices on the menu & the bill are totally big different!). Try to avoid to eat there if it's possible.

a vast, bleak, boring square in the early evening. A huge square with a few dried fruit and nut stalls around the perimeter when we went at five o'clock....don't bother with it in the day time. Apparently it is marvelous in the evening when all the food stalls set up and it livens up. However I live next door to Camden Lock Market and I thought that maybe I would be better off going there if I wanted crowds food stalls and tourist tat. Sorry to sound so mean. I know that some people adore it.

Bargain deals..... Every step you take in Jemaa EL Fna will amaze you... Plenty of things to buy at very resonate price. Foods is almost free with plenty of options. Make sure you have freshly squeezed orange juice from Jemaa El fan...

Unique organized madhouse. One unmissable experience, the atmosphere is incredible, the food stalls colourful and bright, the banter of the stall holders to attract customers is cheerful and funny the prices incredibly lowand the quality surprisely good.Do not miss the spiced tea stalls for an extremely warming cuppalate in the evening!!

Jemaa el Fna. Fantastic atmosphere day or night. Do try a horse drawn carriage ride . An excellent way to take pictures without being asked for cash at every snap. Be prepared for visit to usual haunts, e.g herbalist , leather shop, but very enjoyable and great way to see the city.

Great cultural experience!!. Bring extra cash for shopping. Bought a beautiful tea set and Moroccan mint tea. Marrakech is generally abit pricey. Even though the currency us low they sure do bump up the prices. £9 for chips, cheese burger and spirit.

Its Wild. If you want to see Marrakech at its most exuberant then there is no other place to go. This is the main square and it has everything from food stalls, orange juice sellers, snake charmers, music, monkeys (watch out for photographers passing the monkey to you), false teeth sellers (what!), flower sellers and lots of things just happening. You can't miss this place!!!!
colourful market. Had great fun around the souks..although with my wife being very blond she was harassed quite a bit!

The magic is the people. A huge square. Full of little kiosks, stalls, cafes and some restaurants, and very close to the Medina of the city, with a big mosque in one end. The magic of this place is not the architecture, or beautiful buildings or some tourist-oriented feature, so do not expect that or you could be a bit disappointed, as other reviewers were.The beautiful part here is that you get to see the real people of Marrakesh, it's them enjoying the place. Very specially at sunset (great photo opportunity from the Cafe Francais in one of the sides of the square!), and late at night.People here are proud to use their traditional clothing and it can be quite striking until you get used to it, specially in winter when the djellabas (long robes with a huge hood) are out - you really feel like travelling back in time. And then the families coming to the square for a quick snack, or some real food (there are great food stalls) or a coffee, or for a walk between the marrakeshi music, or go through the square on their way towards the medina alleys and tiny stalls. Thousands and thousands of people, mostly locals. The smells of the myriad stalls, spices, exotic fruits, strange things like cigarette sellers that sell cigarettes by the unit, or a man with a bathroom scale checking your weight for just one diram. Life is lived and enjoyed in a different way over here and this is what you get to see in this mythic square.

Great place to eat in the evening. By night the square is transformed into rows and rows of food stalls. The fresh juice and food stall no. 25 we tried and enjoyed traditional tagine lamb and mixed kebabs. Watch out for pickpockets, men with snakes and monkeys and the little kids that try to sell you anything and everything,

Very different day and night.... Really livens up around 5pm... we enjoyed just watching the people and listening to music. Go during the day for shopping, go at night for food and to chill. Best value and interesting foods were the soups (about 3 dh), lamb head (if you're into that stuff - delicious and different - 15 dh for 1/4 pound), snails, and this ginger drink. Basically follow crowds that look local. Skip the restaurants around the square. Skip traditional meals like tangines and couscous - esp if Marrakesh is your first city - you will be sick of chicken tangine soon enough and if you do any desert tours all the included dinners are tangines. Food here is fairly representative of good street food if you choose the right things, though if you want even more local and even cheaper, find the stands hidden throughout the souks.

Experience the sights and sounds of this market. A good place to explore for a few hours. See the snake charmers in the main square and drink freshly squeezed juice from one of the many stalls. Then get yourself lost in the alleyways lined with colourful shops selling leather bags, shoes, rugs, jellabas, lanterns and pottery or just sit in one of the restaurants that face out onto the square and enjoy a glass of Moroccan whisky (sweet mint tea) and absorb the hustle and bustle of this lively colourful market. Whatever you decide to do, this place is worth a visit.

Straight out of a movie. From eating to people watching to soaking in cultural entertainment this square is a must see. Its truly a bit overwhelming with all of the people sights and sounds but i cant imagine a trip to morocco without a visit to this epicenter. Be sure to stick close to the outskirts until you get your bearings if you are afraid of snakes. Dont be shy though; sample the food!

What a great experience.. You'll find it all in this square!Wonderful colourful place and so much to take in. Don't be put off by stories of being hassled this is a safe and friendly place. Stall holders will try to suck you in but also accept "no" and are often good humoured with it.Lots of cafés where you can have a dink and watch the world go by.Also cheap and atmospheric places to eat in the evening.

Busy, Busy,. We arrived just at dusk, people milling around and getting busier by the minute. Do try the pamplemousse juice from one of the juice stalls.....a really refreshing taste. We ate at one of the food stalls...fast food but good. As the night progressed it was like battling through a football crowd!! Lots of music, snake charmers,monkeys and colourful water sellers.Be prepared for loads of people and noise!

Lovely and Crazy the same time!. when you step your foot in the square for the First time its a sock! this place is beautiful and crazy mixed in a amazing way ! the First day we went there and had lunge in one of the little restaurants on the square had a orange juice and just walk around you need some time to get used to all the things happening around you but when you do you understand that this is the heart of Marrakech . I suggest first visit on daytime to you can fully understand how to get in or out of this place. I loved the people with the water and also the orange juice sellers everyone was very kind . the snake charmers truly don’t bother you if you don’t go next to them to take photos . I can honestly say that in my 14day in Marrakech no one was rude or pressing to much.

Human zoo. You could spend all day just watching people here. In fact do so from one of the restaurant terraces (though space is at a premium). There's a bloke pulling teeth out, snake charmers, tattooists, dancers, beggars...and that's even before you get to the souqs. At night it's transformed into revelry with west African tribespeople dancing and holding court while centre of the square becomes a maze of alfresco diners. Experience it while you can - there's nowhere like it on earth.

Something Else. When you visit all you senses are attacked at the same time sounds sights smells there cant be to many places like this Snake charmers Men with Monkeys acrobats dentists drummers this place has the lot you need an open mind when visiting it looks and sounds scary but the place is brilliant yep the locals will approach you yep they will try to sell you stuff but smile and say no and be firm they will leave you alone we did avoid the monkeys and snake charmers as they don't seem very well looked after but have to say the lace is just brilliant

Never a dull moment in Jemaa el Fna. It's big, noisy, full of people playing drums, charming snakes, selling trinkets, cooking food, making orange juice, acting out stories, taxis and horse drawn carriages.If you like peace, quiet and no strange smells then this isn't the place for you.Best to enjoy sat in a cafe on the sidelines and watch the whole crazy scene unfold before you.(Just keep an eye on your valuables..)

Great experience. Don't be put off by negative comments. It is a bit hectic and mad. As ever, a polite and smiled no thank you or La-a Shukran usually does the trick. Then just enjoy. If you do join circles around performers you will be asked for a donation. It is not a charity act and people earn a living in the square. My partner fancied a small bracelet type of henna tattoo on her wrist and got quoted 250 dhirams which was about €22. It was an entrepreneurial opening offer. Don't scream and shout. Come back with a better offer. We finally said we would agree on 50 dhirams and that was more than we would pay in the UK. This was accepted. You must try an orange juice, they are beautiful. All charge the same, just 4 dhirams. For some reason I kept going back to a very cheerful sole on stall number 28. And finally you must try the food from early evening. It is one of the great street food experiences of the world.

Where life lives. Most amazing place I've ever visited. The amount of human interaction going on during the day is of the chart. But when the sun sets, it doubles in awsomeness. All though it takes some time to get used to this kind of harmonic chaos, it's definitely worth while.
party party. must be experienced at night .so much going on to infuse the senses. street market and square like no other street cooking ,snake charmers acrobats little bands of musicians -felt safe
Hectic. Has to be done, but you will be constantly harrassed for photo opportunities, henna tattoos and the like. Nicer at night.

Don't miss this. This place is amazing. Yes it seems a little scary, and if you are afraid of pickpockets, put your wallet in your front pocket and then put your hand in there. It's amazing at night, tens of large circles of people crowd around different performers, musicians, story tellers, healers, comedians, simple carnival games, this place is wild, like an old time bazaar out of Ali baba etc. simply mind blowing. Don't be scared, there are lots of police around, dive in.....

Utter madness. I'm astounded by the negative reviews of this place. It's busy, hustling, and if you look you kinda have to buy. Read up on it in guide books before you enter as you need to know how to behave. No one is out to rip you off. They're simply trying to earn a living! A crazy place but a must see. Lots of fun once you get it.

Heritage site, those snake charmers are on salary!. Interesting, entertaining, watch for the pickpockets. The one who targeted our group looked to be a five year old girl, who managed to take money from our Morrocan tour guide

Busy Square - Worth a visit if in Marrakesh.... Jemaa El Fna Main Square - just a busy square with lots of people TRYING to do interesting things. Watch out of the guys with cobras & monkeys who try to get pictures with you THEN demand lots of money.... ALWAYS agree an ACTUAL price first... they can get a bit pushy if you take pics first then don't pay what they expect.Souks nearby have plenty of small stalls selling anything you need... from fake clothes, leather bags / belts to herbs & oilsFood - there are plenty of local food stalls within the souks & square. I am a fussy eater & this did not tempt me. I walked away from the square and ate in the restaurants

Snake Charmers and all. Typical market with lots of juice sellers orange juice the fruit of choice and not surprising at 20p a kilo that's not a misprint 20p! Still they do have orange trees growing on some of the streets. The market also leads to the Souks (kinda indoor market stalls) an experience in itself. This place also has a night market and the whole thing should not be missed.
must visit. It is very lively place specially afternoon and night. You can see a festival each night , nice food and strange performers. Just be ware of pick pockets!

very crowded. very crowded! I don't like crowded places, I don't feel safe in them! in plus, it's a total mess, it makes me feel lost. Foreign tourists may like this place because it's different, but as moroccan I don't! For me, it's like a big Souk! & I don't need to go to marrakech to visit a Souk!

Only if you like old style Souq 🚖. I am a fan of modern areas ! I did not like el Fana cause it's unorganized and it stinks :( it's worth visiting if you want to see the traditional shops of marrakech but 45 min is more than enough .. Especially if you can't handle noise .. You'll notice that many sellers try to rip tourists off by doubling the prices for cheap quality items .. I wanted to buy a Jallab and as soon as they knew that am a tourist the price was doubled .. Found out the original price from another shop and I ended up buying the Jallab for 50% less ! El fna is good for people who enjoy the taste of different cultures no matter how loud and dirty is the place .. :) won't go back it's not my cup of tea !

A must. Tourist magnet, snake charmers, water sellers, market stalls, jugglers and acrobats, even a street dentist and hustlers. Everything changes in the evening when the area fills with food stalls and cooking smoke, don't be afraid to eat here everything is freshly prepared and hot!

At evening and night is the best time. Avoid it at daytime, unless you like to see animal exploited for weird street shows. But at night is just a dream ! Take a dinner in any of those busy stands. They are cheaper an thousand times better than any chic restaurant in Marrakesh. And take a coffee in a terrace bar around the square. The view is really special

Alive & exciting. In the day the orange juice stalls with freshly squeezed fruit quenched our thirst. Nuts and dates were great to buy, inexpensive and really good quality.Snake charmers and people wearing local costumes were interesting.In the evening food stalls were erected, the kebabs were tasty and safe to eat. Quite an experience!Beware of the henna women who will draw on any bare arm or hand and demand payment.
great place. its everything you ever wished to see in marrakech. full on, crazy madness. food entertainment, shopping.
interesting square. The evenings were quite lively. During the day the snake charmers took over the square. If you do not like this sort of thing just be very careful.

Must see and taste!. Very interesting and extraordinary experience all together! Dinner circus! From snake charmers, water sellers, story tellers, musicians, belly dancing transvestites and what not to delicious street food. If you can avoid women wiling to draw henna ornaments on your hands and feet and be able to say NO to all other services and goods that they offer - eating at Jemaa el Fna stalls is really a must! and it is not going to kill you! Barbecued meat, sea food and vegetables, Moroccan salad, couscous, soup and steamed sheep heads, which I didn't dare to try.. It's buzzing, noisy and a little overwhelming experience, yet really worth it!
expreince of lifetime. be prepared when eating as you will be charged for every thing that come to your table even if you have not asked for it

You just have to eat here at night. Food amazing - just get over your fears and do it! Choose any food stall as they all cook the same, we tried 2 different ones and they were both excellent food and value - each had a catch phrase but I remember "Eat at 25 and stay alive" - well we did and we did!

Noisy and busy. This market is bustling at night. It gets a bit tedious because all the stalls have the same menu. The waiters who market the places get quite annoying trying to get you to eat at their stall. We had food at two different stalls. No complaints. The food was good - just be careful when you order. They tend to be in a hurry all the time and say things (like adding salad etc) to your order and you just say yes to everything. So take note and be clear when you order. Like if you're ordering salad - don't just say "salad" say ONE salad. Otherwise they bring salad for each person. The food seems cheap but once you add it all up it seems a bit pricey. It's worth a try though. There are people selling desserts as well. These look amazing and it's only 30dh and you get to choose 15 different mini desserts and pastries. We didn't like any of them. Most of them were tasteless and not very fresh. Again.... something good to try but don't have high expectations. The nuts were all amazing, as well as the Turkish apricots. Juices were fresh and the harira soup is good. I didn't try the snail soup.It's a cool place to hang out at night because there's a great vibe. There are restaurants around the square as well if you're not in the mood for Moroccan food.Around the square the souqs are very busy - put your haggling hat on for this one.

Crazy place. Whether by day or night, this place is constantly buzzing with people selling wares, juggling, story-telling, snake-charming etc. Walk through the crowds for an assult on your senses, then sit back and sip mint tea on a nearby roof terrece and take in the sights below.

Jemaa el Fna square. This square has absolutley nothing to see except the crowd, street vendors and filth. The square stincks of horses due to horse carriers which are exhorbitantly overpriced. The vendors are ready to rip off your money as tourists

great place to bargain. Just a cool place to hang out, eat there, watch the street entertainers, bag yourself a bargain. Just don't get sucked in to the sellers who will try and sell you things, by insisting you buy.

Interesting. It depends on the time of day you go what the character of the square is - almost domestic in the morning and as the day progresses it gets more 'commercial'. The horses used in the carriage rides from the square all looked in OK condition; I saw only one obvious case of lameness although non looked particularly comfortable in their work. For these reasons I did not have a carriage ride.
Mad.... A crazy, dynamic central hub of the city with all sorts of traders vying for your Dirham. Watch out for the wandering Henna painters who grab hands and paint whether you want it or not!

CRAZY PLACE. Be prepared for harassment from vendors, to pay for taking anyone's photo and to run from anyone approaching with a snake or monkey. There's lots of street food, orange juice and souvenirs to buy, music, dancers and performers. Top tips - don't make eye contact or engage with anyone hassling you to buy their goods or show you the way and always carry tissues as there's rarely any toilet paper available in the cafes/restaurants.
EXCITING BEDLAM. Liked the noise and energy of the square, incredible experience, something going on all the time, food was great, people interesting :)
Very busy,large square. Although it is a very interesting place, I am not to keen on seeing animals exploited, so only walked round the edge. A couple of nice cafes at the far end.

A magical place. This square is at the heart of Marrakech and the Medina. So many things to see and do throughout the day and well into the night. Suggest having a meal in one of the terraces overlooking the square both in the day and the night. Some of the animals kept for entertainment might not be appreciated by some people.
Dinner at stall n. 55. Being there with friends living in this beautiful city, we followed them to this stall and were filled with delicious beef, lamb and chicken kebabs.

Everything and More. A crowded square with the strangest mixture of things. Orange juice vendors, snake charmers, male belly dancers, drummers. Watch out for the henna ladies, though. We were waylaid and hennaed before we could say no, then they asked for a ridiculous sum of money. Pop-up restaurants after dark are a great place to enjoy the local color.

Daily/Nightly celebration, lively, must see. If you go to Marrakesh, you MUST go here. It has the feel of a festival that goes on every day and night. Tourists and Moroccans all flock here for food and entertainment. There is a little of everything. Full of every kind of person and life.

Fun, fun, fun. Unlike most tourists, I didn't get hassled a lot for the three nights I trawled the square. Sure some vendors were a bit persistent offering their wares, but never too pushy. The square is super busy day & night. I love the fortuneteller, the healer, & the many random games. Unlike what some say, the square is also full of locals (not just tourists). Be there right when they're setting up the stalls for dinner. The seafood in Morocco are very bland, so avoid. The lamb sausage was delicious, though. Make sure you ask the prices for each thing put on your table because at the end of the meal you can sometimes be surprised by the extras. Be discreet when taking pictures, most vendors (& some people) only relent being photographed if you pay them money/buy something from them.

Fabulous chaos. During the day you really do get entertainers and snake charmers etc. And stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice for 30 odd pence! (beware, it is customary to pay to take photos - only a few 5/10 dirhams should do although they will moan whatever you give). As the day goes on have a mint tea in one of the cafes and look down from one of their balconiesAt night is the street restaurants. Do not go for the "cuisine". As one of the the "pullers in" said "We all serve the same s**t, but our restaurant is cheaper!". But do go for the almosphere . Mad! The patter is fun. if you want fish, go to no 14 (Kriti). Only fish which is constantly being prepared along with the best mashed aubergine.And there is more evening entertainers.

Full of life. If you like the hustle and bustle , smells ,sight and sound this one is for you...to be honest no one hassled us and we strolled around at leisure...the surrounding souks are a shoppers delight and the locals were very friendly....simple people...but one must definitely haggle..
Great Atmosphere!. Wouldn't have any seafood in the evening food stalls, but chicken on skewers were delicious! Great fun, loud music, very busy, it's a laugh!

Better at night time.. It comes alive at night. We liked the food stalls in the middle but you can get the food cheaper in the resturants surrounding them. What i didnt like was the women trying to sell you henna tatoos, if you say no they try to get your hand but dont let them put anything on there as they will charge for the tinyiest dot and if you dont want one they will shout abuse at you. I found you couldnt soak up the atmosphere and watch as someone would approch you and try to sell you something. The sweets and buscuits are really nice though.

Snake charmers, storytellers, food stalls - it's what Marrakech is all about!. The evening is when, for us, it was most fun as the lights from the stalls and the food market comes alive. We were recommended to eat at No 1, 14 and 100. We ate at No 1 and ate well with no consequences! A nearby stall did say that no one had suffered diarrhoea for 2 years at their stall so that one might be worth a try! Apparently fines are imposed if any of the stalls do make you ill so it's in their interests to keep us safe. This is where to find the bank machines and enjoy the rooftop restaurants at sunset to watch the lights of the market come alive.

Buzzing during the day and night. During the day there are fruits sellers,snake charmers, henna tattoo artists etc with lots of horse and carts for visitors to view the the city. It leads into the busy Medina and is flanked by shops and cafes/restaurants many of which have rooftop areas which is a great place to view the city and well worth traipsing up the flights of stairs to. At night the square gets extremely busy with food stalls many of which have eating areas enticing you to come sample their goods e.g. Tagines, fish, etch plus there are lots of storytellers and artistes where people gather round and at the end are expected to put some money in a hat. There are usually a large crowd of people in the square and there is certainly a great buzz around the place and lots for you to look at and keep you amused.
Crazy Town. The hustle and bustle of this square is about all that Marrakech has going for it. Steer clear of the snake and monkey men and enjoy the performers after dark.

Crazy fun!. It's crowded and crazy for sure but it is the heart of Marrakech. Enjoy the snake charmers and monkeys say thank you, give them what you think it was worth and walk away. They will ask for 200Dh each. We gave them 50 or 100 total. Not for everyone but we loved it. Yes we held our bag tightly as we would in any crowded place but never felt unsafe.

Charming and fascinating mess!. From snake charmers to smokey food stalls, thousands cram this beautiful square. Start by observing from above, from one of the many restaurants with a "terasse". Good day and night.
people watcher enjoy!!. Jemaa el fna is definitely not a boring place to be whether at night or during the day there's always something happening.

An assault on the senses!. An experience that must be had for any visit, an intoxicating blend of sights smells and sounds. Go there late afternoon and watch it change from day to night, the food stalls build and the locals arrive. Watch out for the henna tattoo ladies who'll grab you and ink you before you know it!

Becoming too much of a touristic spot. Very lively and funny. But too many people chasing tourists. Food is cheap but quality is cheap also, except for the wonderful fresh orange juice and the dry fruits. Avoid the pastries, they are very average. Also the restaurants with a terrace overlooking the place : worth a tea, not a dinner. Better go to a soul or get lost in the medina and enjoy a fresh moroccan dinner there :)

Monkeys and Snakes. This is the central square in Marrakech, next to the souk and in the middle of the Medina (old town). Lots of things to see and buy, and you get to have your picture taken with monkeys and snake charmers.

Visit during the day and at night. Very large, very lively square. During the day there are lots of entertainers, musicians, snake charmers etc. All were very agreeable about photos IF you accept their right to a small donation (5 to 10 dh app $1). At night the square is transformed into a large outdoor restaurant. Lots of photo ops but most of the stalls serve the same food items. Good idea to go to one of the several restaurants with balconies overlooking the square before venturing into the square. Savour the experience.

Quite a cicus. Worthwhile seeing for people watching if nothing else. At one time this square was used for public executions, now it is the hangout of fruit vendors, acrobats, story tellers, snake charmers, monkey handlers, and street dentists. It is very crowded, but a sight not to miss.

熱気ある広場　a heated square. マラケシュを訪れた際に必ず行くであろう場所。2014/01/01の夜に行きましたが、その熱気に驚きました。タイのカオサンやインドの喧騒にも負けていません。フナ広場は夜になると屋台がたくさん出展されて、あちこちで声をかけられます。人がたくさん入っている店でモロッコ料理を満喫しましょう。絞りたてのオレンジジュースも名物で4dhで飲めます。日中はまったく違う顔になりますが、いずれにせよ刺激的な広場です。When you stay marrakech,you must go there.I went to there at 01/01/2014, I was surprised the heated square.The square are as good as khao-san-road(Thailand) and New Delhi(India).There are a lot of the food stand in the night.You are satisfied with Morocco food.And it is also famous for orange juice (just 4dh).It is very incentive square.

So Called "Square of the Dead" - not too impressed. DJemaa el Fna was a bit spooky if you read about what used to happen there in the old days. Moroccan culture is so different and traffic is madness. Anyway, the traders were always trying to get some money out of us and of course trying to overcharge for goods. It was also low season so that explains their prices. So barter, they will drop prices slowly (have 50% of the asking price in your head at least). I didn't think much of the quality of the goods in the markets though. However, we purchased few handmade rugs after major bartering fight. We won after we threatened to leave shop !The worst thing was some of the snake charmers. One of them walked up behind me and placed it over my shoulder without warning ! Gave me a real shock. I told him to remove it immediately. He did so but started cursing me. I noticed a lot of bad attitude generally during our trip.Morocco is definitely worth a visit to see the mountains, the historical places and major towns and walled cities such as Fez and Casablanca. We took a very nice first class return train journey from Marrakech via Casablanca to Fez and back. Just beware of beggars, tricksters, hyped prices, snakes and taxis of course ! Remember you can't take any Moroccan currency out of the country, so make sure you spend it !P.S. The Tagines are absolutely lovely - do try those ! Their available all over !

Fun and should not be missed...just stay away from the monkeys. During the day the name of the game is street entertainment, and at night add the chaos of food stalls with very aggressive touts. Luckily we were armed with advice on where the good food was, and found lots of locals at certain stalls and less aggressive sales tactics, and managed to have a good meal in the middle of it all. If you're going to take a picture of any of the street entertainment, be prepared to pay the entertainer, whether it be snake charmers, monkey handlers, or musicians. Once you realize how it all works it is less stressful. Just let go and enjoy the madness and take it all in. There are nice cafes overlooking the square which provide a good vantage point over the carnival atmosphere below without the hassle of ducking the monkeys or other vendors.

Great spot. Djemaa el Fna is the epitome of exotic. The sights, sounds and smells of Arabic Africa assault your senses at every turn. Snake charmers, soothsayers, amateur pugilists, roaming musicians and water bearers alike wander the food labyrinth stalls of smoke and fire serving everything from snail soup to sheep head sandwiches.

nothing special. smelly, full of rip-off merchants. If you travelled to Marrakech just to see this you will be disappointed. Takes less than a day to see the whole place. Be prepared to part with cash if you even want to ask anyone a question. Would recommend going to see the markets on the friday morning, you seem to get less hassle as its like a sunday for the locals. When it comes to bartering for goods you can start as low as a quarter of the starting price but dont pay more than a third. At night time they fill the square with food stalls. Again it can be a bit of a rip-off. They will bring food to you even if you dont ask for it and expect you to pay. Best just to take a quick walk thru then eat at one of the many restaurants around the side as they are all pretty good.

Chaotic, weird and mind-boggling!. I have read many negative reviews on here and I can understand where the people are coming from. You really need have your wits about you in this place that certainly keeps you on your toes as you dodge the bullets of the insistent vendors, beggars and dodgy looking characters.I suppose I am a bit weird but I do revel in being in an environment of the weird and unknown. This place is a huge culture shock and is certainly a different world to the new Marrakech that is so aptly divided by the surrounding red wall!Yes, there are many conniving and dishonest characters trying to get you to depart with your dirham and any other approved currency but you soon wisen up to their approach and can shrug them off without too much fuss.I was saddened to read other people experiencing aggression and hostility from the vendors and street entertainers as this is something we did not experience at all. When we said no that was the end of the matter, the most we experienced was disparate pleading to buy something or have hennah painted.Take a stroll and observe the chaos and characters that are everywhere. There are lots of restaurants dotted around the square where you can sit back with a nice cup of mint tea and watch the action. The food can be decent too depending on where you go and we paid what we asked for, it seems the rip-offs take place at he food stalls where the vendors try to entice you eat there as you're clearly 'starving Marvin' and they have a no diarrhoea guarantee! Pretty funny to listen to their limited patter of English slang but I would be careful if dining at these stalls. There's a raw vibe about the place, the young lads have a rough and ready demeanour about them But they were never intimidating or rude.Witness the local woman sitting and having a good natter, the men also doing the same and the young lads being boisterous and rowdy. This is a great place for people watching!This is not a place for the British stiff upper lip, there's no room for it here!There are some decent things to purchase but the bulk of it is tacky souvenir tat. The lanterns for candles are pretty when lit up at night but they are not made from sturdy metal so the quality is lacking and they are worth about £3 each at most.The decorative souvenir tajins should be properly inspected as many contain chips in them so make sure you look at them properly before you purchase.I did not like the fake beggars, they are not genuine it's just an act to get easy money, you will find this out when you offer food instead of cash which is refused. I am happy to give food / buy food for someone who is homeless but I won't give cash and it's even worse when you get the kids begging as they have been set up by an adult to do their dirty work in using the kids to collect cash. This is unacceptable.I also do not condone the exploitation of the monkey's and cobras to 'entertain' the tourists. This form of so called entertainment needs to be stumped out. This equally applies to the horse and carts where the horses are in such poor condition. If people stopped paying for such things then it's one step towards these acts being eradicated. Me and my husband were never once harassed to have pictures taken with the monkeys and cobras and this is such a bad thing to do given many people have fears of snakes in particular. I was particularly amused by young lads pushing buggies with stereos being powered with car batteries blasting out Moroccan music, they really added to the atmosphere. The souks have lovely leather bags and I enjoyed wandering around and around just soaking in the atmosphere and looking at the stuff for sale which to be honest is all pretty relative around the souks. The scarves are really pretty too and come in array of designs and colours. As previous pekoe have mentioned, haggle, haggle, haggle!Some parts of the souks are really smelly and quite disgusting but you soon move away from these smelly parts to move to an area that smells of all the spices displayed outside. Enjoy! Or maybe not ...

THE PLACE. we loved the square ,we visited every day ,and we had something new to see.after finishing a ride with horses ,we started walking in the square .watching the snakes ,the musicians and the ladies drawing women hands ,of course we had our juice there,and a tea at the shop next .We went two times for lunch in one of the restaurants there and it was very nice .

Jemaa el Fna for One Night. Jemma el Fna is a marketplace full of business' pulling you in every single direction. It is a must see and you can't go to Marrakesh and not go here, but truth be told it is exhausting. There are tents in the middle of the square where everyday food stands set up and each stand has a person that their sole purpose is to speak to tourist in every single language until they respond and accept to eat at their place lol. Go and see it on your first night so you can say you experienced it, but I personally wouldn't be thrilled about returning every other night. Also, for women, I was told by my Riad to not do Henna tattoos in the square because the ink they use causes allergies and rashes so just a pointer. Be sure to use your Riad/hotel as a reference on what to do and where to go as they are all very helpful and ready to help. Enjoy Morocco as it is a beautiful country full of culture and history!

Vibrant but a bit stressing. Even though Jemaa el Fna was the place I preferred in Marrakech, it is somehow a place where it is very hard to feel not a tourist, as you are constantly "assalted" by food street vendors and their menus, so the option "just looking" is not a reliable one. The first day is quite shocking, but on the second night, just be confidente and you will be able to go and sit exactly where you want without feeling bad for the other very persuasive food street vendors.In my case I was looking for a food spot where mainly locals were eating so I ate a very good hareera soup and honey sweets for almost nothing and it was the best part of my trip, just sitting there, feeling part of it.Go there at sunset when the square change its face, it's really special.

Must Visit. We really enjoyed the atmosphere here, but some of the ladies doing the henna on your hands just pull your hands and start putting the henna on although you have said NO do not give them any money if this happens, also beware of taking photos even if you stand a good distance away they spot you and come over and demand money so be prepared to give them some money, so go with lots of small change if you want to take pictures.

Load of rubbish. Dirty square filled with nefarious characters just out for tourists money. There is nothing positive to say here. But keep on the edges and don't bother going into the center.Pure hassle.And please don't take photos. Or you'll be accosted for money like We saw various couples be.
Nothing like it.. Just go, day, night as much as you can. Keep your wits about you, remember a lot of people earn a living so just be confident and enjoy the sights of which there are many.

jemaa el fna square. jemma el fna square is a place mostly for tourists. This is due to the costly prices of food and shopping. However there are a lot of con men in the square who may charge you for more than the actual price. Once I was eating hareera(soup), the shef said it was 3 dhms, after I ate it, I only had a 10 dhm coin on me so I payed him and he didn't give me no change back. Jemaa el fna is full of hustlers selling lanterns, toys, organ oil, handbags and a lot of other things. There is also a souk(market) nearby, in which you can shop for more goods. You may find the prices there are more suitable. Just opposite Kutobia mosque, there are horses parked. If you can bargain with the horse riders, do so and enjoy your first time experience of siting on a horse. You can ask the horse riders to take you anywhere close by for a few dhm. We traveled on a horse to Gueliz new city. In Jemaa el Fna, there are also people with snakes and monkeys. Ask politely if you want to take a picture with a monkey or snake round your neck, they should do it for a few dhms.

Worth a visit. Its like the centre of the the walled city and lots to see there. Sit in a cafe overlooking the square and watch the goings on whilst resting! beware of service charges though! Very colourful and well worth a visit.

Should not be missed but.... Previous reviews have accurately described in that much time does not need to be spent on a brief walk through here. We did take issue with blatant mistreatment of monkeys by their handlers when others were not apparently looking.

Worth a visit. There is really not much interresting to see in Marrakech, so this is way up on the list. While interresting to see some fakirs and snake charmers, it gets old quite quickly. It probably also depends on the time of day you visit. We went in the afternoon in December, and it was not too crowded which was nice.

Fascinating. This place is buzzing beyond belief in the evening. Its crammed with snake charmers, palm readers and other entertainers and has numerous open air food stalls. Its a huge square in which most of the souks start. Be prepared for a little hassle from the various stall holders selling their wares but a polite 'no thanks' is usually enough!

Anti Climax!. The central hub of activity in Marrakesh, i was expecting something spectacular but all i found were half dead snakes, silent musicians and a crazy lady screaming at a tiny plastic cup!! The stalls all sell pretty much the same thing and you could get them cheaper if you head further into the souks. Additionally every manner of con artist is in their element here, you will be charged for taking pictures so be careful and get smothered by professional beggers (i say this because i offered to buy one food because she said she was hungry, she refused the food and wanted money!) some advice steer clear of giving them any money as they work in a network around the square. some people say it comes alive at night having experienced it at night it remained the same!If you have travelled anywhere in south asia you will see the' berber' culture is in no way unique and the whole place had shades of pakistan and india written all over it, This is in no way a bad thing but not what you expect when you read the other reviews people post......draw your own conclusions and look out for the crazy lady with the cup :)

Must see as a quick stop. We visited the square with our small tour as well as on our own, night and day. It is a spectacle to be seen. There are monkeys, snakes, henna ladies, water salesmen and various orange juice sellers and places to eat. To photograph the monkeys, snakes or water sellers you have to pay them 10dh, even if the animals are not on you. Best to pay upfront and then snap a few shots to avoide an issue. They do have spotters so its not worth trying it on the sly. Henna ladies, guide told us some people can have a reaction to an additive the henna mix they use and your hand will swell up very badly and it's possible to be left with a permanent marking as well. Wait until the countryside where you can get an all natural mix, typically more green color than the black used here. Water salesmen, obviously this is tap water, don't drink it. Pay 10 and just take the photo. Orange juice, guide told us this is fresh juice MIXED with water and sugar much like lemonade at home. They don't juice it in front of you so don't trust it if you are avoiding the tap water. Outside the city we saw places where they would cut the oranges and juice it into a clean glass while you watched. We did not eat in the night market but I would have just stopped at a place where local people were dining. We grabbed a kabob to go at a place on the perimeter in the afternoon(20dh). It was fine. We also noticed a small gap between the two restaurants on the perimeter that lead to even more food stands which looked more local and I'm sure had tasty food at even better prices.

Noisy, busy and unmissable.. A panoramic terrace is a good place for mint tea and for watching the constant activity of Jemaa el Fna. There are all manner of entertainers and sellers of services. Snake charmers, monkeys on leads, raptors, a vulture, henna tattoo ladies, tarot card readers, musicians, dancers. You name it, it's here. The orange juice sellers are there all day and for 4 dirham you get a big glass. Highly recommended.

A spectacle, but chaotic. Part freak show, part theatre. Still fascinating once you learn the ways of the people in it. If you take pictures of, say, the snake charmers, they will demand money in a unpleasant fashion. Also the women who start to paint henna on your hand will then demand insane amounts of dirham for this, even if they first say that they don't need money for it at all.

all roads start here. the square at the center of the medina is a constantly changing diaspora of moroccan culture.in the day the snake charmers and the curios salesguys take over. the music of the charmers, and the monkey handlers awakens you to the environs. a few hours later the center is clear, cleaned and the food stalls are in full swing the cooking overwhelms the senses, and by the morning, it starts all over again.
The main square. Very busy lots of hustle and bustle...but fun....lots of places to eat...or you can just sit with a mint tea and people watch..!
must do. You can't avoid this place. My opinion is that you should go to the roof top of the bar at the angle and sit there for one hour or two when the sun is going down and look at the life below.

Busy and a bit gimmicky!. Worth a visit once to experience it but then once done no need to do again!Try eating there at night ,try a freshly squeezed orange juice and buy some fresh dates and people watch!

Experience the Hustle and Bustle of Marrakech. How can anyone go to the beautiful Marrakech and NOT go time after time to the Jemaa el Fna.Experience the hustle and bustle of this wonderful square and smell the delicious smells of the Moroccan cooking by night.This square is great by day but even better as soon as dusk falls - food vendors cater to your tastes and the African/French cuisine is a joy to taste.......It opens ones eyes and is a sight not to be forgotten in a hurry....!

Great experience!. If you'd like photos of the snake charmer etc, then you need to pay them (not much, around £1/1.50) and they happily accept dollars as well as Dirham. Incredible atmosphere and it really comes alive in the evening.

Difficult to rate!!!!. Very difficult to rate Jmaa El Fna square. You will either like or hate it. All depends on your expectations are of the place. But in all cases, prepare yourself for a culture shock- Exotic, but chaotic- Aromatic, but unromantic- Ancient, but not lenient.This place is not for the naive and soft hearted. (or animal lovers). You will need to keep you wit about you all the time. Everyone wants you dig into your pockets. (or in some cases, they dig into your pockets, yes there are some pickpocketers). But the positive side, is that this place offers some great feast of food, fresh squeeze orange and exotic aromas all arounds. Square entertainemnt is abound, but beware when taking photos!!! You will be asked to donate some money for the privilege of using your camera.The traffic is a nightmare, the narrow alleyways in and around the souks are more than a maze, you will most certainly need a sense of direction to remember where you start and where you may end up. because saking for direction from the locals comes at a price!!!The Square is more enjoybale at nightime from the roof top of one many cafes and restaurants around. From there you can take as many photos as like without anyone bothers.

Guard your Loins!. I am a regular visitor to Marrakech and love the souk but only during the winter when its not so touristy. Prices are more reasonable and haggling is easier also as its off peak and the sellers just want to make money so are easier to handle. Just take a map cause its very easy to get lost which I have done many times. They have new signs in the souk now pointing to where you should be going but the nice sellers will happily tell you after trying to sell you something :-)

Tourist trap but a must see. Busy, bustling, and constant hassle to look at, ride in, want photo, have henna tattoo or buy. No better place to pay for the privilege of having a sedated snake wrapped around your neck if that is what you wish. Having said that, its bustling and vibrant, a bewildering assault of noise and colour- a definite must experience where a 'No Thanks' delivered with a smile always works. Relatively tame in the day, it becomes really alive at night Sit in one of the cafe terraces and watch the square change as the sun sets. One thing not for tourists is the performance of the storytellers - very much a moroccan tradition and I'm told they always end on a cliffhanger. We were advised to eat in stall No1 and had a good meal.

Eat at number 14 in the evening for authentic food. If you can manage to weave your way past the people trying to pull you in to the various other makeshift restaurants in the Djemaa el Fna square at night, eat at number 14 - they don't provide cutlery or napkins but you'll be eating fried calamari with the locals and the aubergine dip is delicious!

Day time is great nighttime is madness. You really cant go to Marrakesh and not experience the madness that is Place Jemaa el Fina. During the day its filled with bargain hunters heading into the Medina, henna artists, musicians, snake charmers and people wanting to take your picture with monkeys (this is wrong wrong wrong) By night the place is just mad, story tellers, 100's of food stalls, hustle and bustle, soothsayers and locals selling their wares. It really is a great place to visit. Head to one of the panoramic restaurants and you will get the chance to capture the true essence of the square on film

A must visit! Noisy, fun and like nothing else. It's a complete experience of Arabic life. Snake charmers, small bands, monkeys, henna artists.... Go eat in the evening at the stalls - number 1 stall - we ate with fingers and avoided salad to be safe.

Perfect. Place to go before die ;)
Africa is perfect i will go there again next month and im so happy
Alot of good food and onrage juice very tasty

Beware of the locals. They see a lot of tourists and it does feel a it like walking around with a target on your head, they will target you and they don't always give up easily! We got professionally tag teamed by 2 natively dressed men who pull faces and offer to take photos but then expect to be paid, while I was trying to get rid of them 2 henna hand painters grabbed my son and started drawing while I was distracted, they then expect to be paid too, despite my protests they all want more money and if they don't see a policeman around they continue to annoy you. It is a fascinating place but everything costs and it Definately best to keep moving all the time which means you can't really relax there. It is a sensory overload and be prepared to take your life in your hands any time you try to cross the road! You will never have seen anything like this place and it is fascinating, go enjoy but beware!

Sights, smells and sounds at sunset. If you like your destinations clean and well ordered, stay away! If you're ready to take in the full experience then be prepared to just let yourself take it all in and enjoy something completely different. Have dinner in a restaurant overlooking the square at sunset and you're in for a real treat of sights, smells and sounds.

Don't get sucked in or they'll smell blood.... Heard about this square long before we arrived in Marrakech, it's definitely not for the faint hearted but being aware of what's around you is key to enjoying this experience.In the day it's all about the snake charmers and monkeys, and at night it turns into a food festival with added storytellers. Either way it's very entertaining, but ultimately it's a tourist trap that mostly preys on Europeans that act like typical Europeans. We didn't take the chance of eating at one of the stalls, menus looked very interesting but relaxing is a word you cannot associate with El Fna. You must have eyes in the back of your head to understand what the square is all about, but the best attitude to have is not to take yourself too seriously or you'll come unstuck. Jemma El Fna is the image that should be represented on all postcards of Marrakech, but a word of warning is stick together at all times if your travelling with a loved one or you'll get chewed up and spat out within minutes...

Bring a peg for your nose. We only visited here during the day having been dropped off by our hotel shuttle. Boy is this place mad! Its absolute pandemonium, take care not to be run over by the locals on motor scooters, or the donkey carts or the horse drawn carriages. There are food sellers, musicians, snake charmers and Barbary Ape hawkers all out to grab your money - in my advice (unless you like being photographed with a smelly monkey on your shoulder) - save your money for the souk's.The whole ambience is historic; named the 'place of the dead' after the square where executions took place and at the foot of the largest mosque (good for a skyline landmark) it is an absolute must, just bring a peg for your nose

Sensory overload but don't miss it. Had cheap and delicious food at centre in the evening. Delicious calamari, fish, grilled aubergine etc. Just wander and see what catches your eye. Yes they are quite insistent about trying to get you in but a smile, and 'la shokran' with eye contact is good and just keep walking.Same goes in the souk with haggling. Don't be shy about asking for a quarter of what they first say and going up from there. I bought a small carpet for 300mad and he started at 1100mad. This is not always the case of course. At the end of the day, if you like it and you don't feel ripped off then it's all a great experience...usually if you say thank you and walk away they will come after you. Marrakech is fantastique!!!!

The reason to visit Marrakech. This souk is the reason many visit Marrakech. You cannot go to this city and pass on Jemaa el Fna. There is more than meets the eye as you pass through this historic location. We were privileged to have a walking funeral procession pass by us as we tried to cover even a small part of this expansive site.
Avoid Food Stall #26. Rubbish food, you'll get ripped off. If you must eat in the square go to another. Maybe have boiled snails ?

Interesting experience. We were there during the day and night, and the place seems to come alive at night. The snake charmers, dancers and monkey owners make the place really interesting but as we're had 3 young children in tow, we had to fend them off politely. Thankfully they respected our wishes and stayed away. However, we thought the food vendors were way too persistent and kept shoving their menus at your face and attempts to grab you to their stalls.  Overall, it's an experience not to be missed if you are in Marrakech.

Beautiful chaordic fun!. I loved haggling with the vendors and came away with some great things for my new apartment. Made some friends, enjoyed the atmosphere, loved getting lost in the covered souks!

When in Rome... ..go to Djema al-Fna. It's a must for Morroco, but at the same time you will not really miss much in my opinion. It's fun and full of life, but it's also full of people trying to grab hold of as much money from you as possible. The prices are not necessarily bad and you will find local ppl eating at the stalls, but the food is in our experience neither the best at Djema al-Fna. It's a fantastic crowd if you like that, and if you easily tire from that, you should have a easy back-up plan...

Over crowded and over rated. Marrakesh is an amazing city with rich culture and sights, in our view the Jemaa ei Fna is over rated. It is a very crowded place - the epitome of a tourist trap. it is all designated to extract money from you , the ore the merrier. The markets are very colorful but there are some areas that can be defined as very unpleasant while some of he products are actually not locally made. Conclusion - a site not to miss but you need high level of vigilance and awareness.

Marrakech in a nutshell!. What an amazing part of the city - the sounds, sights, smells and fun to be had is well worth the visit. Yes, many people will get a culture shock, and will find the snake charmers, monkey owners and (especially) the henna ladies a little bit of a pain at times - but isn't that what the place is all about? Use common sense, say 'maybe tomorrow' or 'non merci' or for the ladies, it helped me to keep my hands in my pockets sometimes. Another thing that everyone should do at least once is eat at the stalls! If you can watch them veing set up too thats great - we ate at stalls 117 where they sang 'thats the way I like it' whenever someone came to sit down, and said their chef was Jamie Oliver (haha!) and stall number 1 where Hassan is a total character and loads of fun. The food was great, cheap as chips (or as they said regularly, cheaper than Aldi, or Asda price!) and we didnt have any 'tummy troubles' at all. Some stalls even made a joke of this saying 'guaranteed diarrhoea free' and 'stall 25 you stay alive!' Enjoy what the locals enjoy, and get fully immersed in what they have on offer.Get haggling, try the street food, have a look round, enjoy listening to the entertainers (even if you put a couple of dirham in the pot - who cares? It's a pleasure to enjoy!) and enjoy what Jemma el Fna has to offer - its certainly an unique place you cannot miss visiting.
