Must see. This area is very busy specially in the evening. There you can find food stalls and vendors of almost everything.In the food area the vendors are very persistent. They try to grab your arm to show the menu. They speak any possible language to convince you.Keep an eye in your pocket.You cannot miss it!

A place to know. The square is unique, and must be experience troughout the day. In the morning, with all the exquisite foods and fruits. In the afternoon, with the serpent enchanters. In the evening with the rythms, storytellers, fortune tellers. It is a special.
Crazy. Snake charmers abound…Great fun if a little crazy. Enjoy the atmosphere. Go to one of the bars that overlooks the square
assult on your senses. Everybody has got to see this place. It's noisy and not very clean and i wasn't keen on the tired looking snakes

A Taste of Marrakesh. The busy, bustling market of Marrakesh has everything to offer. It was a great experience to walk around the square and then through the markets.Be careful as you watch the local entertainers (snake charmers, monkeys, acrobats, musicians, etc) as they will grab you and take you to the center of the crowd for photos and then try to shake you down for money. This holds true for those "guides" who just point in a direction to "help" you find your way.The experience is unique with a lot to see, smell, hear, enjoy, but you must be careful as you go around. It is easy to get lost in the market area, just keep your eyes open and try to follow the signs and other tourists.One thing we did learn is don't point at something "interesting." My son made this mistake once and every vendor in the general direction came to us trying to sell their wares.This square completely changes in the night; the musicians come out, they put up food tents (all really good food) and it becomes a bit more lively (not that it's boring during the day). I recommend you visit both during the day and then again at night.Again, this is a neat experience with a lot to see and do, but be ready for crowds, agressive vendors, and A LOT of haggling/ bargaining (even with the "entertainers" in the square).

Keep your change in your pocket and smile. Keep your change in your pocket and smile while watching the artists and salesmen. Trying to get all tourists to spend some money. Hava a drink at the Café de France or one of the other cafe's and watch all the action from a rooftop.
main point. this is the central point to visit in Marrakech, it is a good summary of what you are going to see over there, love the smells and the locals!

Manic main square. Fantastic mix of snake charmers hucksters and every local drama you can imagine during the day, and over a hundred open air stands serving food right off the grill at night. Brilliant!

A feast for the senses. A stop in Marrakech won't be complete without a visit to this famous market. A good place to start exploring the market will be the main square. If you arrive early in the day the square will be littered with snake charmers, palm readers and women offering to give you henna tattoos . Beware, however, that if you take photos of anybody (or anything) you will be demanded to pay 10-20 dirhams. I took a photo of a snake charmer and immediately a man approached and demanded I give him 50 dirhams! I haggled fiercely (which the man appreciated, as negotiating is part of the Berber culture) which ended me paying him 20 dirhams with the condition I take more photos of the snakes and snake charmer. Once inside the souks I found the same attitude towards photo taking - unless you buy something most merchants are not happy with their items being photographed so try to be conspicuous as possible or simply step right up and buy your souvenir! And most likely your seller will have different stores where you can also take photos of his other shops (which happened to me, actually) The second best part of our trip to the Jemaa (The BEST part being the food of course!) was witnessing a carpet auction among local carpet vendors which I later found out only takes place on Sundays. This is when locals from the villages in the atlas mountain come to Marrakech to sell their carpets. It was a neat thing to see!If you are not afraid to explore, to be curius and to have a conversation or two with the locals, there are so many things to discover and enjoy at the Jemaa. Definitely a must!
Incredible at night.. What a beautiful and wild scene at night. Go, go, go. A highlight of my traveling life. Try the food, listen to the drums, watch the snake charmers.

Definitely overrated. The square is good as a location and an excellent way to know where you are in the middle of the maze that is marrakech. But, don't expect too much. If you want to buy, explore other areas, the area is too noisy and crowded. If crowds is what you like, so go for it!

Good views from penty of bistros around the Square. When in the square do have the fresh orange and grapefruit juices. They are very cheap and fresh. Do not be fleeced by the snake charmers...not worth the photos with them.

Unique blend of exoticism. From the moment you arrive Jemaa el Fna , you’ll get the distinct feeling left something behind with its unique blend of exoticism, shopping & proximity to Europe mix with Arabian style. The city’s souks and its way of life, and even today, in the crowds and performers can still seem quite distinct. Marrakesh is a major city in the northwest African nation of Morocco. ‘Morocco City’ is the way foreign travelers called it.
Fun chaos. Well worth a visit... endless shops, many of them sell the same stuff, but still a large variate in the items. - The square was a little boring.

Stunning. By night or day this square is a sensational experience. Many many people with all types of merchants Less intrusive than other shops (unless you go at night where there will be many very instant people inviting you to eat at their pop up restaurant).

Excellent place for food. This place is a very good place to get your bearings. The food stalls at night have very good food, but the hassling by the various staff can get a bit tiring. I would recommend trying the snail soup.

Unique. The square is something unique. You'll find there a mix of any kind of people you could find in a normal square (all together) plus others that you'll hardly find somewhere else, such a the story tellers, the snake charmers, the storytellers, etc.

The heart of Marrakech. The Jemaa el Fna is the central square in Marrakech and is the place to start all of your trips. It is easy to find and is a good meeting point. You will find a huge number of different stalls selling food and drink as well as entertainers, snake charmers and monkeys. If you want to take a photo you can but they will ask you to pay for the privilege. You will also find that all the streets running off the square are full of shops and this is the entrance to the souks.

Crazy place - beware of where you eat at night. This has to be seen to be believed and a very difficult place to describe unless you have seen it.However you need to be careful where you eat on the night market. Stalls 114/120 are extremely friendly and the food was good too. 25 was good however 12 should be avoided.

Crazeeee!. ...but wonderful. The drumming, the trumpets, the horses, the calls of the stallholders, the enticements of the snake-charmers, jugglers, magicians, the delicious smells from the charcoal grills. The souks tempting you to vanish inside....The essence of Marrakech.

The very essence of Marrakech. Morning, noon or night, there is always something to see here. Whether you want to be frightened by snakes, haggle for metal lamps or just have a coffee and watch the world go by this is the place to be. The food in the market at night is delicious, and choosing which stall to eat at is fun. Enjoy!

Visit in the day and evening. In the day, the area is filled with snake chambers, henna tattooists, orange juice sellers and fortune tellers. Evening comes and the area is changed into the best eatery. Sitting on one of the cafés above the square is perfect for watching the place transform - from about 3/330 lots of food stall are set up and as you walk around, the sellers know all the lines.....asda price, cheep as chips but my favourite.....guarantee no diarrhoea for two year! We ate at a few if the sellers and the food was just as good as in any of the local restaurants plus you had the atmosphere. The cafés are perfect for watching the world go by with Jemma El Fna, a must to visit.....good luck in the souk though, ventured in many times but there was just the once we got lost and it took us an hour to find our way again. On the plus side, we did find the many different areas of the souk and it was an hour well spent. Throw away any map in the souk and just be prepared to wander around the sellers, just make sure you are on a time limit!

A must see - why else would you visit Marrakech? . A must see - why else would you visit Marrakech? The atmosphere is amazing! Don't be affraid. Walk at a leisurely pace and take in the ambience. You don't have to engage in conversation. It is not deemed rude to ignore anyone that interrupts you from sightseeing. Enjoy.

Keep on walking!. Nearly didn't go but pleased we did. If you don't want to be hassled keep walking and watching. Wear sunglasses so the entertainers / store holders cant see you looking at their goods othewise you'll be getting dragged in. Don't shake hands with anyone, or you'll find a snake put around your neck which they wont take off without payment! There's a couple of cafe's with balconies overlooking the square - great for people watching!If someone offers you directions, or tells you the path you're going down is closed - just ignore them and smile - they're trying it on!

Disappointing. I suppose I shouldn't have watched "Hideous Kinky" or I should have come to Marrakech at least three decades ago... Jemma el Fna was disappointing. It was just full of stalls and performers doing their best to get hold of the yankee dollar, put on for the tourists, and all in all, pretty inauthentic. Aye, sure, if you've never been to anywhere out of Europe you will be wowwed by all the middle-Eastern craziness, but if you have been to countries like India you will be underwhelmed by Jemaa el Fna.If you want an authentic taste of Marrakech, get away from all the tourist-tatt saturated and labyrinthine souks and explore the back streets where there is nothing for sale except for wee shops selling stuff to the locals. Better still, leave the Medina behind and walk out into the suburbs and see what modern Marrakesh is like. The people out there are friendlier, and they ain't trying to flog you something. They are just being.

Not like home!. Constantly changing kaleidoscope of part market part street happening. Snake charmers, storytellers and orange juice. A must see.In the evening they bring out the food stalls. Just try it and join in the fun. Barbecued or out of a cauldron it's not what you're used to and it's perfectly good to eat.

You need to prepare yourself. We were there during the day and night and I would certainly recommend coming here around sunset time. Come enjoy the view from one of the roof patio. We were at the glacier patio and it provided a amazing view of the koutoubia tower and the stalls during sunset time. Come early since it gets packed around 4.30ish.After sunset, be ready mentally and come enjoy the circus (literally) on ground. Yes the food stalls can get pushy and tiring but if you are firm and say either you are not hungry or you ate already they will leave you alone.We had stall 1 for the snails. So good and you can ask for extra soup afterwards - perfectly spiced!!We ate at stall 31 - don't get the skewers. Get the plate or liver sandwich. The sausage is also quite good. One of the guys speak English so you will be taken care of. So good for 30 dirhams. They charge for the olives and bread so decline if you don't want it. We also ate at one of the Harrira stalls. They were packed with locals. For 3 dirhams you get a bowl of hot and filling Harrira soup. To wash it all off, we had the orange juice. After dinner, we walked around more and felt more immune to all the touting...

Crazy Compelling Place. The very essence of the Square is entertainment and it can't fail to entertain. As long as you know what you are letting yourself in for you will enjoy the experience. Don't get taken in by snake charmers who want Dh 200 for a photo with a snake! They will accept anything upwards of Dh 5 even if rather reluctantly. The freshly squeezed orange juice was delicious.

Mad. During the day snake charmers and chained monkeys!! Totally disagree! How r they treated? Women hassling u for henna tats!! Just consistently pushy pushy!! By night food stalls everywhere, street preformers , snail stalls, a vibrant noisy square! A must! But stay safe!! Not for single women

Wow!. Went here as part of the 'Marrakech Royale' excursion booked through Thomson.Wow, what a place! The Jemaa El Fna [square] is so alive with action and adventure. From the steaming food carts, magicians/performers, monkeys, snake charmers and stall owners - there's so much going on in this square.Yet, the place becomes even more vibrant and alive when it turns nighttime - weirdly enough! The only thing I suggest is to be wary at all times, specially with it being busy - as someone may try to pickpocket you. But overall, this is a must see for anyone visiting Marrakech!

Spectacle!. Wow, what can I possibly say which hasn't been conveyed by some 5,000 reviews! This place is truly a spectacle of human life - food, fun, entertainment, shopping all rolled into one! My only advise is Djemaa must be visited at least twice - once during the day and again during dusk to enjoy the sunset and the subsequent transformation! I think a visit to the Grand Balcon Café Glacier is an absolute must - it's rooftop terrace is really *THE* vantage point! This isn't just a tourist trap for foreigners either as we noticed loads of locals enjoying the sights and sounds of the Djemaa just as keenly as we did!
Wild vibrant and in your face. Take everything light heartedly. Enjoy the price negotiations. Start low, stick to your guns, walk away if it's not in your budget. Bring back great gifts.

Be Prepared To Be Hassled. Its interesting to visit once or twice preferably at night when all the shops are light up and the atmosphere is a lot more vibrant. You get hassled so much its hard to enjoy the sights and browse through the stalls. I travelled with my 6 year old son and many people tried to target him one man even grabbed his arm and tried to drag him into his shop which could be very scary for a lot of children. Its defiantly worth a visit if your in Marrakech but I wouldn't go out of your way.

Mad. Well what to say - everything from snake charmers to monkeys, horse carriage rides, Souks, restaurants. This is a mad place with so much going on. Be careful not to roped into trips by random men
Terrible. Terrible dirty mountains of people in the night time We think dangerous. Best look in day time better
Busy vibrant and fun. This is a must go to place. You'll find the same items in many different shops allowing you to haggle and grab a good buy.

Must see place when you in Marrakech. Place is great. Something totally different than Europe. You can see snakes , monkeys .... They do some sort of Morocco music show. You have nice orange juice there for only 4 dirhams around 20cents and is fresh. Food is also good but if you want to eat there and enjoy choose place where all Moroccans siting or waiting to get table. Around is a lot of souks and restaurants with terrace view. Definitely worth it a visit and explore this place by yourself is very magical specially and evening.

THE PLACE STILL JUMPS. This place just never changes. The atmosphere is something you will just not experience anywhere else in the world. It's like going back in time. Absolutely wonderful experience and a place that you should just not miss.
100 YEARS AGO. Is like to be 100 years ago with the same dirty!Everybody wants to be paid for a photo and this is 2013 life!

Hell on earth. I liked Marrakech, but upon visiting this square it is the worst place. We were two young women, dressed very conservatively. Harrasment worse than anywhere, multiple robbery attemps. Its hard to enjoy when your on your guard. Worth a visit but stay safe!!

Lovely and plenty to see. I loved this square and came back here time after time.. my advice is to visit at various points of the day if time allows you.I had breakfast in the market, you'll never want to drink orange juice anywhere else again, I also had a long lazy lunch on a friday afternoon overlooking the square, watching the call for prayer and all the different activities around the square is amazing.Close to sunset find a good spot on a roof terrace and just watch the sun go down while everything comes to life around it, the smells, music and the atmosphere just transforms in front of your eyes.Best place to people watch and take some amazing pictures.

Nowhere else quite like it. A visit to the square is a must when in Marrakech.The ambience of this place is amazing,with so many colours,sights and sounds which change depending on the time of day.If you visit during the evening (when most of the activity is) a good idea is too find a restaurant with a roof terrace where you will have good views of the square,and is a discreet place for taking photos.

Not as interesting as it used to be. We were last here about 15 years ago but it doesn't seem as good as it used to be. During the day the snake charmers and monkeys were all looking a bit tired. A lot of noise from the charmers pipes but not much response from the snakes. However quite interesting if you've not seen this sort of thing before. Different in the evening though. The food stalls were very lively and their salesmen trying to get you to go to their particular stall were good humoured and offered such enticements such as a six month guarantee against diaorrhoea! You can watch the food being cooked and know it is properly done. We had a selection of brioches which were very tasty, better than we had eaten in some restaurants and piping hot of course. Probably as well to be cautious about the salads. We stuck to peelable fruit. Plenty of band music and dancing in the square too, some of it pretty entertaining. Enjoy the atmosphere and just put up with the hassling. Make sure you've got small cash to give out to the entertainers, especially if you're taking photos of them, It's only fair to them.

Enjoy the evening food!. Ate here every night we were in Marrakesh - really enjoyed the little grilled sausages. One place had the best ones!!! Unfortunately can't remember the stall numberThe "sellers" will battle for your buck - and tell you only to eat at the busy ones, but the best one we went to didnt have a ton of people! The ones busiest with tourists are the best sellers not the best food ... BUT all the food is good, great or excellent so you cant lose (esp when you can eat your fill in under 40 dirham!)The olives are awesome and tasty as well as the bread and sauces (all for 5 dirham each!)

Tourist trap but has to be done.. Tourist trap. Interesting to see once or twice - preferably sitting up high in a cafe with a mint tea as the sun goes down and the lights come on. Food market is interesting place to grab a quick cheap meal. Otherwise just full of hustlers.

jeema el fna not traditional food.... annoying touts and food sellers. Food here is nothing compared to local tagine sellers outside the main square. Just look for stalls with hot steaming clay tagine pots, point at a pot sit down and eat whatever tagine your served for less than 25 dirham! The square chefs charge 30 per tagine and its not the real thing.Its cooked in a pan and served in a clay pot and tastes nothing like real tagine.Being a chef I like good for and if you are going to eat here look for where ethe locals are sitting and not the touristsBeware of taking photos of men in costume they charge. Henna women are rip offs never ever pay more than 30 dirham. Great experience but very annoying if you just want a quiet feed.

An exceptional place but also a glimpse of hell.... I thought that I was prepared for Marrakech but at times I was truly overwhelmed. Jemaa el Fna once a "possible" place of execution is still a place not far off from a nightmare. During the day, it's a busy benign square that offers the tourist and local populace a drink from the juice sellers or a meal from the many restaurants along the periphery leading to the souks. In the evening the food stalls are set up with row after row of these mini establishments selling all means quick meals. A brigade of young men relentlessly touting for your business. With smoke choked air, I'd give this place a wide berth if you suffer respiratory problems like asthma but it's the countless heartbreaking beggars that did me in. Mothers with listless infants, limping elderly eating scraps from the ground. My appetite lost and and any spare cash gone, my husband and I fled back to our riad. It made me sad and depressed on the last evening of what otherwise was a fascinating journey.
Be sensible and you will be fine. Have your wits about you, and enjoy yourself, the food stalls are really lovely and very safe to eat from as there are many tourists, the standards are high.

Not what it's cracked up to be. We went here both during the day, and at night. It's not a great experience during the day, and although the snake charmers, henna tattoo artists and monkeys are ok, they failed to hold our interest for more than a few minutes.At night the character changes and the venue has many more food stalls etc, so I would say give it a miss during the day and visit at sunset till the early evening

good experience. Enjoy the food at night in the food stalls, its all fresh and cooked in front of you. cheap as well. Be specific what you order. we asked for mixed kebab and salad and ended up with a table full which we could not eat all of it. keep away from the monkeys, Vulture and teeth puller!!

Overrated. Not trying to buck the trend but the main square sort of feels like a caricature of what it should be for all the tourists. Snake charmers, fortune tellers, and music men, rub shoulders with droves of henna tattoo artists and fresh orange juice stalls. It's an experience and beautiful at night, but it's very overrated.

Interesting Place. This is the place where you can see just about anything from drummers, to dancers to snake charmers to monkeys, to food. It's a great place to experience both day and night. I don't recommend the restaurants right inside the square, as they cater primarily to tourists. However try the stalls in the middle where you see Moroccans eating. The food is good and cheap. You can usually make interesting conversation too. :) Solo female travelers the men will make frequent comments to you, but they are harmless. Be firm, yet respectful with them and keep it moving. Currently the International Film Festival is going on and they are showing a film on a big screen in the square every evening. Definitely experience the vibrancy of this square. I highly recommend it!

Madness, loved it!!. Loved the chaos of this place. Hawkers and blaggers everywhere trying to get you to spend money. It's great fun and all in good spirits, just be firm and fair and say No, but smile whilst saying it. If you stop to look or listen to what's going on you'll be asked to give some money, simple as. Did some cracking shopping in the markets, loved the fresh orange juice. If you don't go here whilst in Marrakech you need your head testing.

Plenty to see here. We went in the evening and started off with some fresh grapefruit juice which was delicious and at 1 euro, pretty cheap! Beware of local scammers - they have so many money making activities - I got caught out with a friend looking at henna tattoos - big women grab your hand without asking and start making a Henna tattoo and before you know it they have you sat down and demand money which is quite scary but mainly just a pain in the bum. In november it is relaxed and easy to walk around which was nice - I am not sure if I would be a fan in the high season as I imagine crime is much higher and it would be difficult to get around. I'd love to go back and recommend it to anyone - the food, jewellery, handicrafts, bags, souvenirs and dates/nuts are amazing and the fakes are really good! Better than I have seen in spain and italy.

Not all it's hyped up to be. I want to preface this by saying we went in November when it's a little more off season so we probably didn't get to experience the full craziness of it all. I'll start with the good points:- Amazing orange juice at 4 dirhams per person- The food, of special note is stall 81 on the market which serves the most amazing tagines and cous cous starting at 25 dirham a plate. This is much cheaper than the prices surrounding the main square. - The business and buzz of the area- The view over the main square as the sun sets and you calmly sip a mint teaThe bads are:- All stalls are very repetitive - a lot of cakes and orange juice- You will get hassled a lot more around the square than you do in the actual souks, the henna ladies were a particularly annoying culprit here. They'll henna you without permission and then charge you for it. - Can be hard to find alcohol

Exciting, colourful, magical, fascinating......but it can be hard work at night. Let's face it, there's no chance you'll go to Marrakech and NOT go to Jemaa el Fna, so you'll all find out for yourselves, but here's a heads up. YES, it's an awesome place full of spices, food, stalls, noices, buying and selling, bars, restaurants, locals selling everything from freshly squeezed orange juice to peanuts, sweets, mint tea and everything else inbtween, monkeys, acrobats, vultures (literally and metaphorically!) snakes (again....). YES, it's surrounded by market traders, barrows, stalls and shops a plenty where you can find a real bargain (if you're prepared to haggle hard and be determined) and meet some real characters. YES, it's one of the few places in the World you'll visit where you'll feel so alive with being totally caught up in your environment and finally......YES, I too completely loved it and would definitely go back at the drop of a hat................howeverAs fairly well travelled as I am, I've never experienced hassle and (in some cases) quite aggressive and oppressive selling tecniques. Not just here in Jemaa el Fna, but in the whole of Marrakech. From the tuk tuk drivers I experienced in New Delhi to the bumsters on the beaches of The Gambia and Red sea resorts of Hurghada, nothing prepared me for this. Obviously I'm not talking about everyone here, just the majority! From walking in front of your face for a dozen yards just to get you to eat at their food stall, to taking a tip themselves out of your change without even asking, to the more extreme cases of actually demanding money with menace. I actually had to intervene with a new young couple who were being told to give a snake charmer "MORE MONEY" than they had already just given just for a photo. We all expect tp pay over the odds as tourists, but not 10-15 times the going rate for taxi's, shops etc. Just remember to be strong, don't be intimidated, always check your change and never forget, be polite and courteous but VERY firm.I don't like being negative to I'll try and leave on an upbeat note. Jemaa el Fna is without a shadow of doubt, a must see place in the World to experience and I'm so happy I went. I'd say in it's own way and with everything being relative, it's almost like the New York of the Arabian World. Sure, Northern Africa and the Middle East have much bigger and dynamic Cities, but they are predominatly Islamic. Marrakech is a beautiful melting pot of many different cultures, religions, creeds, nationalities and faiths. In 4 days I saw Chinese, American, African, Indian, Australian, Canadian and from virtually every European Country, including Scandanavia, but Marrakech is far more than just this one square.

It is what you make it.. The square is always busy with locals trying to make money anyway they can. Keep on your guard and know that if you partake in any of the locals activities such as if they put a Fez on your head for fun and tell you to take a picture, or grab your hand without asking and start making a Henna tattoo, they will charge you after and if you refuse due to not wanting what they gave you they may get aggressive. However, if you keep on your guard and say 'no thank you' before committing to anything you don't want to do then it can be fun and surreal and at night it's always lively with lots of fun things happening and picturesque scenes and there are also many restaurants around the square which overlook it which beautiful scenes and crazy cheap prices.

Very lively. The best time to go is about 4pm and bag yourself a seat In one of the restaurants overlooking the square in time for nightfall when the square comes alive with a cacophony of drum players, snake charmers, dancers etc and food stalls.

"Local Colour"!. Wow! And its all absolutely authentic. Just as it was when I first came in 1965. Nothing about Disney here, its all real. (although Hashish/Marijauna is now banned I guess).And I was told categorically that all food stalls are inspected by Inspectors frequently. So eat what you want...the busier the stall the better the food. Yes its busier at weekends now but thats life. Wonderful on hot summer nights but great anytime.You can get your hair cut, your teeth pulled or replaced or have your fortune told. The colourful water sellers are for photos only -not lke in 1965 when there were no plastic bottles..Please be aware that there is no Social Security at all in Morocco and that those selling tissues (10-DH?) here are very genuine Blind or Disabled who have no other support and may have travelled 2 hours to get here. Please do consider saying hello to the young guy with Cerebral Palsy (he is often selling tissues in one of the cafes) who loves it when people say hello -in another life he surely would have been the life and soul of the party. He supports himself and his elderly mother.

Enjoy it for what it is. For some, this is Marrakech, with snake charmers, Berber drummers, acrobats, street food, fortune telling, horse drawn carriages, even a tame vulture! Despite the noise and the crowds, still it felt a safe place to be. View from a rooftop terrace over a tajine to get the full effect.
Not many English speaking tarot readers. This square is very old town with gypsy tarot readers and live snake shows and little monkeys tied to old men. It felt a little creepy, I was happy to leave.

Bonkers. When in Marrakech, you have to visit the square both during the day and at night but becareful not to be caught taking photographs. Watch out for mad old lady's stalking you with what looks like a hypodermic needle to provide Heena Designs. Well worth a visit and the Souks are a must but don't stop to look unless you are prepared to barter hard.

The magic of Marrakech. It's wonderful, don't get me wrong. Only the scooters, mopeds and cars are pretty annoying. They just don't care it's busy, they have to drive there. Make sure nobody spots you making photos or videos ;). The atmosphere during the day is completely different as in the evening. Make sure you visit both days and do enjoy the food in the evening, it's worth it :)

Must visit twice- day and night !. Great experience and so very different experiences during day and night. Night time much busier and the food is wonderful and all freshly prepared and very very clean! There is something for everyone . Be prepared to be entertained and possibly hassled a bit!!

The Good and the Bad. A lovely square where you can get lots of shopping done as well as to quench your thirst with freshly squeeze orange juice. However, watch out for some nasty sellers when you refuse to step into their shop or even buy anything from them. We had some bad experiences from it.

Manic after dark.... We attempted to eat in the square after dark and regretted it. We asked for a meat tagine and were immediately given cooked peppers and aubegines that we didn't ask for. I again asked for tagine and was offered chicken skewers! On the third attempt I got what can only be described as a raw piece of lamb on some thin sauce. We didn't eat it, paid and left!

Contrasting day and night.. the square by day is really like any other square with some shops restaurants and a few stalls selling wonderful fruit juice and nuts, figs and dates. By night it bursts into life and is full of street food sellers trying to persuade you that there's is the best. We ate at stall 100 and were not disappointed but think that we should have checked the menu first to see how much things cost!!!! Its lively and vibrant and not to be missed!

Marmite!?. Quite simply you will either love it or hate it.........absolutely nothing grey about the square. It's mad, noisy, crazy full of life a roller coaster of sight, sound, smell and eclectic entertainment. Fresh squeezed orange juice, dates, snake charmers, monkeys, acrobats, bizarre storytellers, water sellers dressed like hobbits and henna tattooists everywhere!! Artisans selling everything you could ever imagine including one old guy who has a table selling second hand false teeth and actual single teeth......huge heap of.... Honestly, see it to believe it. Absolutely not for the timid or faint hearted but a really extraordinary experience. The souqs are amazing and provided you are happy to haggle you can enjoy some great banter with the locals and take an empty suitcase out with you cos you are sure to fill it coming home! Shop till you drop and until you cannot walk another step and then there is more! Enjoy!

bargains, local color. You gotta go. It is what the Marrakesh experience requires. They eat late. Try the stalls that set up in the square. The beautiful restaurants are overpriced, but the views from their roves are priceless.

Busy busy busy. The whole world seems to be there. Very vibrant day and night. General stalls and the snake charmers and jugglers by day and food stalls at night. Try sitting up on one of the terraces overlooking them all to take your pictures or you will be hassled to pay if you get caught taking someones picture.
Fascinating. Very busy day and night. If you can ignore the hustlers or get a laugh with them, its a fascinating place for people watching.

Interesting but chaotic!. Very busy square full of various stalls and shows, eg snake charmers, water carriers, henna artists, musicians, acrobats.Food stalls are at the top end. Walk among them and expect to be hassled to eat - sometimes difficult to say no but be firm. Keep your sense of humour and just say maybe later!Great aerial view from the terrace of Cafe de France - just go to the top but don't eat there, the toilets are filthy.

Best value, tasty food!. Spend an evening here eating amazing food from the stalls and people watching - we had one of our best meals of the trip! Our hotel suggested some stalls they knew to be good, and the whole experience was incredible - from the clouds of smoke sweeping across the square from the cooking to the clusters if lamp sellers and crowds around the storytellers. Don't miss it!

Lively market square. Very busy area, less crowded on Friday holy day, haggle for everything on sale as goods. Fresh squeezed juices especially orange very good value. Food stalls appear at nightfall, good simple meal at a low price, we were advised to avoid fish and sea food but lots of other people were eating shell fish. Felt safe but were hassled a bit by most traders, a polite firm NO seemed to work well as long as you don't show any interest in the goods, otherwise expect to be tried to be sold something. If you take photos of snake charmers, animal handlers, acrobats or people in traditional display costumes you will be asked for money.

Join the crowds. So much to see here, not all of which may be to your taste. Wandering the souks passers by insisted on directing us to "the square" (Jemaa el Fna). It is mainly a spectacle for visitors - organised chaos. During the day market stalls, as dusk falls, it turns into a huge food court as vendors compete for your money. They can be insistent, and you may soon tire of their attentions. No visit to Marrakech would be complete without a visit to Jemaa el Fna.

Empty during the day. It certainly got busy at night with groups of entertainers that the locals and the tourists enjoyed. Did not like the captive monkeys or snakes. Just don't pause at the food stalls or they will be all over you. Learn to smile and say No Thanks. We tried the steaming snails and the lamb and offal, lovely!

Carnival Atmosphere. The central market, Jemaa el Fna in Marrakech is a crazy carnival atmosphere every night. What's really interesting, is that they take it down every day and set it all back up again every afternoon. Set up starts about 3pm and isn't really completed until 5pm. Before 3pm you can buy juice, dried fruits, some sweets, etc. After 5pm, there are a plethora of food stalls begging you to come in and sit down. "Maybe Later." and "You promise?" will be phrases you'll hear a lot. It's worth a wander through the whole market to see what's being served. There's fish, soup, pasta, meats, etc. After watching everthing for two days, we decided to have grilled meats with Stall 31, located on the outside corner near the Grand Balcon du Glacier. This one was smoky and packed with locals the minute it was set up. There can even be a wait to be seated. It's an experience you shouldn't miss.

An extroverts dream. So many reviews set out what their is to see and do so I won't add to them. This place is all about the atmosphere created. It heaves with people, its noisy,exciting ,your senses are battered but you can escape to the balcony of the Cafe De France for a mint tea or a coffee and a respite from the madnes but soon you will want to go back to it . It is beguiling and hard to leave behind

Sensual overload. The Jemmaa el Fna square is a sensual overload, the sights, sounds and smells are overwhelming and of course the totally over the top isses like snake charmers, acrobats, sorcerers and so forth. Of couse a heightened sense of awareness is needed as there is a slight presence of danger (probably of the unknown and unexpected such as a snake charmer sneaking up from behind to put a large snake near your ear!!!)Its edgy, fabulous, fantastic and not for the feint hearted. And go at night as well just to ensur all your fears and prejudices are well supported.

117 stairway to heaven. The square heaves with people at night. The transformation from day to night is quite amazing. The stall holders are all smiles and jokes as they try to lure you to come and dine at their stall. Do yourselves a favour and go check out stall # 14. It was recommended by a local and since we dined at a few stalls on the square I can say without reservation that the food was by far the best.

Plenty of everything. During the day: you can find charriots, snake charming, people with monkeys, women who makes the henné-tattoo on your hands, stalls with fresh orange juices and the beginning of suk, with a lot of shops/sellers of a variety of artisanal productsDuring the night: group of moroccon people singing their songs, other playing local games, women for henna tattoo, stalls (bunch of stalls) where you can eat for a cheap price, but, remind they literally push you inside its stall and make you sitting down :)

Colourful and exciting.. Vibrant, exotic atmosphere. Food stalls aplenty, excellent value and loads of witty banter.Get pestered a bit too much by food vendors, and beware of people pressurising for money if you take photos.

Got to go!. I'm sure it's all been said before..... this is a MUST on a visit to Marrakech. In fact, it would be difficult to miss it. Early evening sees the whole place come alive with the fast food stalls, the trolleys of sweet pastries, acrobats, dancers, storytellers and people, people everywhere! We were there in the morning and took the offer of a guide through the souks for five Euros for one and a half hours. Well worth it, he left us three hours later after giving us a fab tour of all the artisan workshops, Riads and took us places we would never have found! Don't miss it!

night-time only. During the day I hated it. Full of people trying to sell things, tattoo me, put a snake on me, etc. But at night, it comes alive with stalls & vibrancy, and banter (often hilarious) from the boys on the food stalls. Maybe you need to see it for 5 minutes during the day to appreciate how it changes at night.

DON'T GET LOST. Markets and souks are amazing but please please please don't get lost down all the alley ways and little nooks and crannies - people offering to show you the way out will mislead you and then demand money from you. Have your wits about you at all times too or be lucky enough to look like a local
Very busy. Didnt eat there but tried a few of. The restaurants facing the square, I felt the place is over hyped for what it is....beware of vehicles and scooters whiz zing through!

A spectical like no other on earth. As the sun fades a gentle orange glow something magical starts to happen on the square. Snake charmers and monkey men start to take their retreat along with the sun.Before your eyes the simple square transforms into the largest outdoor restaurant in the world. Stall after stall of flame-licked meat, fat-laced smoke rising into the African night sky and touts all trying to fill their nocturnal dining rooms.You will be haggled, harrassed and sometimes hated, but, if you can push through, find a place loaded with locals and sink into your seat with a smile on your face, you're going to experience something that's impossible to find anywhere else in the world.It's all a bit crazy, and for some it's overwhelming, but I can assure you that if ever there was a time to dive into the madness, this is it. You wont soon forget the magic unfolding before you.Happy eating :)- A
Vibrant heart of Medina. Great place to shop, eat and to just sit on one of the higher floors of any of the numerous restaurants and to take it all in.

Lively. Lives up to the moroccon vibe... yes perfect to soak in the atmosphere. Very very busy, hard to get a table to eat- so pick your timings carefully especially if you want a table with a view of the main square, otherwise you can eat IN the square from the stalls (we didn't fancy it though!). Plenty to see, enjoyable.

The heart of Marrakech. During the day it's just a big square, but in late afternoon and at night the square transforms into a wonderful crazy mixture of food stalls, peddlers, dancers, monkeys and snake charmers to name a few. It looks like something out of the world of Harry Potter and Assassin's creed. Tourists and Moroccans mix at the tables. It's definitely something you shouldn't miss when in Marrakech.

the main square. snake charmers, monkeys, vultures, male belly dancers, food, noise, colour, smoke - you must see this place at night. Blew our minds - in a good way. The boys from the food stalls trying to tempt you in with their english slang and sayings - very amusing. Some people told us not to eat there but we had some very good meals there. A must see on your marrakech trip.

Holiday feature - ordinary. I was very disappointed by the Square attraction. At night I was harassed by kids and in the day run over almost by bikes. A very untidy area and nothing to write home about. The snakes and monkeys looked jaded and in need of retirement

The heart of Marrakech. It's a MUST GO. Jemaa el Fna square is big and throughout the day gets louder and louder. During the day it's almost empty but around 6pm all the food and fruits stands just appear from nowhere and fill all the square with light, people and some animals ( monkeys, snakes). The heart of all Moroccan culture is here. Tourists and locals meet here in a mix of caos but in a good way. I read a lot of bad things about women in Morocco but I felt very safe here. I think all women visiting Morocco need to dress according to a Muslim country in a sign of respect. I just love the vibration here.

craziest market I've ever seen. The fun starts at 4.00 PM. People start to gather on the square. Story tellers, souvenir sellers, henna tatoos, snake charmers, food stands and so on. the energy level is intens and there are people everywhere. It's quite a sight to see.Never let your guard down though, everybody seems to have the same goal and that's the content of your wallet. If you want to make a picture without having to pay somebody go and enjoy dinner at the balcony of some restaurant.

An unbelievable market!!. I have been to a lot of open air markets in the world, but this one takes the cake. It is over the top! Just be prepared with lots of energy and curiosity and take your time to explore as much of it as possible. When the sun goes down the energy explodes! If you get a chance try to take a few photos from the upper level of the Café Frances or the other one on the edge of square. To get a view from up high as the sun goes down is a special treat! Get there early and get a position at the rail and start taking photos!!
Temporary Food village. Loved all the atmosphere and friendliness of the Restaurant staff bartering for your business. Food was good. They were such a laugh saying they were Jamie Oliver.

exploring Marrakech. Marrakech is a warren of back streets and twists and turns, you need to have your wits about you, no matter where you go someone will try and part you with your money, the key is if you hear the word free it means you will be parting with cash, all streets seem to lead to the square and the country is filled with all kinds of people animals and flies...

Bargin Hard. I am not really into shopping for teasets or what have you but you cant go to Marrakesh and not visit the Jemaa El Fna. Its nice to experience the culture and the cute shop fronts with the array of goods that they have on offer. Try go to the one of the art galleries/shops and find the painting with the boy having a circumcision. The painting made me laugh. hilarious stuff

A historic landmark not to be missed. A lot of people warn about the merchants in this square - the proverbial snake oil salesmen. It is virtually a theater, a theater of wonderful human beings trying to engage their fellow human beings into entering into an economic transaction. In one sense you can say these are all "sleazy snake oil salesmen." But aren't we all? Many of us don't realize it, but we just differ in degrees from these wonderful Moroccans selling their wares and showing off the cobras and their lyrical flute music. They have their cobras and flute, we have our powerpoint presentations!So keep your wallets deep inside your pockets, then enjoy the sight and aroma of a truly human experience!

An experiance not to miss. Took a guided tour of the labyrinth of the medina ending up in Jemaa el Fna. We started from the outer medina walls and passed through the various sections of the medina which we would not have found on our own, tanneries, bakers, lighting, much to see and very hectic. Well worth paying for a tour.Once in the Jemaa el Fna we were treated to a sweet tea in a cafe overlooking the square and Marrakech. The square was being transposed ready for the evening, very busy location but worth the visit.Time to view and barter the vast array of stalls and find some bargains.

somewhat overrated. perhaps because it is hyped up in all the guidebooks and given World Heritage status, it has suffered from the curse of too much exposure. So all the tourists are there, and all those who use tourists for easy money are there also, not trying too hard. Snake charmers and people with monkeys on a chain I can do without. Similarly with men in fancy dress who bang a cymbal a couple of times and then want money. Had a reasonable meal in the central stalls, and fresh orange juice was very good. but don't expect to be overwhelmed by the exotic sahara gathering you will have read about

An experience not to be missed. During the day, the square is relatively quite with juice and tea stalls. At night, the square comes alive with food stalls with every combination of meat/fish/chicken/veg and for the more adventurous lambs heads and local delicacies.. although not many tourists in sight on those stalls. Then there are various performers surrounding the outskirts of the food stalles from jugglers, snake charmers, traditional dancers to fortune tellers, henna tattoo artists (although advise strongly not to get due to the allergic reaction that may be caused by the ingredients in the henna).

A fabulous place for an evening out. The square turns into an entertainment and open air restaurant centre in the evening. The entertainment included a kind of pantomime in Arabic, dancers, singers, tarot readers, fairground games etc, most of which was provided for local people, rather than for tourists. The choice of food is fantastic and, as it is all cooked in front of you, you can be sure that it is safe to eat. Do not miss out on this fantastic dining experience. I paid about 300 dirham for as much as four of us could eat and drink, in fact we were giving away the surplus to passing locals.

Great experience but beware....!. Liked the bustle and the mile after mile of stalls in the souk, but barter hard, at least half of what they ask and do it with fun! If you are looking to eat you will be surrounded by 10 or more people trying to get you into their restaurants! Daytime square is empty, but night time it comes alive.
Great Square. A great big square in the middle of Marrakech there are lots of cafes for a coffee and at night there is a good street market with all kinds of food well worth a visit

Insanity, but in a good way. Djmaa el-Fna is absolute chaos, and is the most fun you'll have in Marrakech! The daytime is fun, but the real insanity begins at night. The young men attracting customers for the food stalls are charming and insistent, the coils of smoke from roasting lamb soften the electric lights, and the noise of snake charmers and storytellers fills the air. It's a magical place.It can also be overwhelming if you don't like crowds, or if you can't say "no" politely and firmly. People will physically block your path to give you a menu, or may reach for your hand to start a henna tattoo. Just be polite and firm in your refusals, and enjoy the craziness. It's awesome!

Food Stalls. For excellent entertainment you must eat at stall number 75 - the young men are funny, loud and charming.For the best food according to the locals go to stall 31 - much more rustic than number 75 but food great and cheap - try the sausage sandwiches that all the locals line up for with the hot sauce - whew!

Must spend time here day and night. This square is a must visit place both in the day and night as the atmosphere changes.The acts differ between day and night time so you will see very different performers. The food sellers were not there during the day when we visited (November) but magically appeared at night!We ate at the stalls 3 times with no ill affects which did surprise us! And it was an interesting experience. The orange juice at 4 dirhams was a steal!Be prepared that if you take a photo of a performer, even if you think they can't see you they WILL come and ask you for money!We also sat on one of the rooftop cafés to watch the sun go down over the square, which although overpriced for mint tea and pastries was worth it just to soak up the atmosphere.

Chaotic but fun!. At night the atmosphere is electric and the smells from the various food stalls is exotic. The square is crowded and you will get jostled but it was completely safe. There are large groups of local people surrounding performers and story tellers and it is not always clear what is going on but that adds to the atmosphere. The touts trying to drag you into the food stalls are a bit of a nuisance really - they don't give you the chance to even look at what each one is offering in terms of food before they pounce which made us less inclined to even look at the menus being thrust in our faces. The whole place is an assault on the senses - smells, sounds, sights - it really is something to be experienced while in Marrakech.

Dazzling and hectic. Worth seeing both during the day and night. There is more to see at night and the square really comes alive with the food stalls and shopping stalls. Would definitely recommend wandering around, grabbing some food from one of the stalls and people-watching. It's arguably less impressive during the day but provides a nice contrast to the night-time mayhem.

Magical place. It has a real mystical feel about. It’s buzzing with energy and tons of people. I was there for Ramadan therefore it was extra busy at night but the atmosphere was brilliant. The food is fairly cheap and you have a lot to choose from (a lot of meaty dishes) however this place did teach me to say no. You will have a lot of people coming up to you etc and a polite smile and no doesn’t do any harm but everyone there seems to be very humble and sweet. I went with my family and felt safe.

Vibrant, energetic, crazy. We visited the square on our first night in Marrakech and was greeted with drums, dancers, magicians, and the madness of the food stalls. We ate a meal at no. 41; typical Moroccan bread, salad, grilled eggplant, sweet potato, mixed meat and vegetable skewers and chips. Sweet pastry sellers wheel their carts from stall to stall offering a 'all you can fill' box for 30Dh. During the day, the snake charmers and monkeys come out. Try a rooftop terrace for a nice view of the square, and get lost in the maze of souks. Expect to tip the acobats and musicians playing in front of the terraces if you are sitting in the front. A 4Dh orange juice is great too.

Drives your soul to a magical world. Time can stop in this place. You will have a relaxing great time here, especially in the night when it becomes rhytmic and noisy. I did love the meals and food market where everything is fresh and cooked in front of you. You can eat delicious roasted lamb, kefta, and much more. The amazing sunset from the cafes arounf the square. Clearly a must see.

You just have to have visited it. Why do we come back year after year? Probably because the nighttime spectacle of the steaming food stalls is unique (and we are not too put off by the prospect of contracting amoebic once again). The standard of food in the surrounding restaurants seems universally poor and the service glacially slow - but with captive audiences cramming the balconies, why should they bother? Despite a thousand traders trying to rip you off it's still a great night night venue, in the best funfair tradition.

Great place for a quick, fun, inexpensive meal. We arrived at our riad late and a lot of the restaurants were closing. So we walked down to Jemaa el Fna square and sat down at a BBQ stand cooking up mini sausages. We ordered a plate of these, a mixed meat plate, grilled eggplants and a salad. What a wonderful meal! Reminded be of the LOLO's in St. Marteen, or the fish market in Barbados. The meal cost 2 of us $10 US. What a deal!

Sit and watch the world go by. There is a lot to see and experience in Jemaa el Fna and I found the best way to do it was to sit on the terrace of either in Le Grand Balcon or the Cafe de France. If you sit one row back from the front edge of the terrace the beggars and peddlers can't pester you but you have a great view of all that is happening on the square including snake charmers, water sellers, acrobats, henna tattooists etc.

Mixed bag really. In a way I loved it and in a way I was disappointed by it.At day it is a collection of snake charmers and monkey merchants with a few dance troupes as well and a continuous ring of fresh juice stalls.It is certainly a hive of human activity in the day and you can while a way many a pleasant moment people watching from the terraces of the cafes.The people in the square such as the snake charmers are the entertainers, if you like, if you want to take a photo then expect to pay to be entertained by the snake, or the monkey or the dancer when you take a photograph.It galled me to see how people reacted when they asked to take a photo and were asked for a coin or two....it is how they earn a living and if you don't want to pay then don't think you can just take a photo up close without some hassle...it's an easy concept. A dirham or two isn't going to break a bank!Daytime though I was a tad disappointed as it wasn't that full of anything, however night time and this place comes to life in a riot of noise and the smells of many food stalls selling full meals, soups and snails assails your senses.As you walk up and down the food stalls you will be constantly asked to visit their eatery, it is all good humoured and great fun to see the responses to your I'm full or I've eaten whilst trying to decide which one to eat at.All the food is freshly brought in and cooked in front of you near enough so the chances of being ill are probably far far far less here than at your hotel buffet.The musicians start slowly but build up to a crescendo of noise and sounds, all very rhythmic and trance like.Henna tattoos will be offered everywhere by women sitting down, just be careful as the black henna is chemically laden apparently.There are a few market stalls selling wares, again haggling works and there are many juice, spice and fruit sellers. The sweet carts offer excellent value.There are kids who will try to sell you a few toys (the rage was propellers with LED in that float down when we were there) but a polite non merci does the trick.When you've eaten your fill, when your ear drums are full and your legs walked off then sit down in the Cafe Glacier and watch the crowds mill around in front of you.So a bit dull in the day but wow what a place at night...if you can visit just once then make it the night but if you can do both then Jemaa el Fna is a must see.
Dirty and you are hassled. The only good thing here is the orange juice sellers but take a straw and always check your change, If you can get any from them that is.

Best viewed from a cafe rooftop. The square is the heart of the medina in Marrakech. It is a bustling street market by day and evolves into a tented eatery by night, plus street entertainment. We viewed the many activities from the Cafe Glacier from late afternoon through to early evening and watched the transition.

Crazy place. Visit during the day as well as at night as totally different. Expect to be approached to go the food stalls or into the shops but you can always so no. The square at night is alive with snake charmers, performing monkeys, dancers, henna artists and loads more. It's an experience not to be missed.

Big square. All roads out of the souk leads here somehow. It is a rather desolate and big square with orange and nut vendors as well as snakecharmers and hennapainters...Around it, you will find several cafes, beware since some of them our less concerned with hygien. Your best option might be to stick to bottled beverages and only eat in the well established venues frequented by many!

Culture in a square!. this is why we visit Marrakech - not because there are loads of Disney type attractions but because you can see real people living real lives. be prepared to have all your dirhams sucked out of you though. If you make eye contact you are saying I'm a tourist fleece me! But its all part of the experience. Do it once, be prepared to part with dirhams and enjoy. tip - they always ask at least double what they will settle for and that's just for a photo!

Fervent!. There are 2 sides of this square. During the day it is full of people with the snakes and monkeys triyng to get some money with photoes, it's sad to see the monkeys arrested in chains and being pulled by the owner. But the night, it's completely different. The square gets more live and crowd, a lot of drum beat and people dancing. There are a lot of stalls where you can eat safe treet food and drink fresh and cheap orange juice. The souks are in the climax and tourists are mixed with locals in a fervent way.

Be careful. We visited here in the daytime and at night.It was much better in the day as it was a lot less hassle as there is not so many people.Be careful of the scooters and bikes they drive straight at you,also be careful if taking photos as someone will ask for payment.Lots of overpriced fake goods are on sale you would not buy them at home so why buy them here.At night there are a lot of performing monkeys and snakes they tried to charge us for just looking.Children as young as 3 are begging you for money just say no and walk on.At night the place comes alive it is packed solid be careful of your bags and wallets.We haggled a ride on one of the many horse and carts to get to the square i recommend doing this but don't pay too much.Overall it is an experience not to be missed.

Fun tourist trap. Djemma el fna is great fun. By day it's full of shopkeepers, snake charmers and monkey wranglers. By night it's Morocco's largest restaurant. Food is cheap and tasty but it can be a bit daunting with the touts as they are. Well worth a visit.

Colourful tourist trap. Brilliant place to watch the world go by. Try to get a good spot on one of the roof terrace cafés around the main square around around dusk to watch the twilight skies and the square lighting up.
What an experience!. Brilliant evening. If you want to eat proper Moroccan food go there. Be prepared to be pestered about eating at each stall though.

Amazing as it changes from say to night!. This square is a great place to see throughout the day - from the afternoon with shops and orange juice stalls (delicious!) to the evening where the food stalls all come out. We watched the sunset from Cafe du France which I highly recommend due to the beautiful view of the area. We are at food stall 31; the food is all pretty much the same but the guy was so funny and quoting various British things that we had to go and try!

2 different places in one. s long as you arte good humoured and jok and laugh with people you will be fine. If you take the effort to try and say no thank you in arabic - la la shukran - you get left alone with a smile

Different. We saw this during the day, found the Cafe de France and had lunch overlooking the square at midday. We wanted to see it as aftrnoon became evening but unfortunately this didn't work out for us.
I like it. Well, i like those kind of places. I ve been to some eastern countries and i speacially enjoy those open air squares with all their unexpected atractions.

Fun, Excitement and Sights to See!. The town square, the Jemaa el Fna, was an interesting space to visit during the evening. We first went over during the day time on a private guided tour and it was fairly uneventful, but come dusk, the square lights up with lots of entertainment. I cannot say that I'm a fan of the monkey trainers or the snake charmers - it is clear that these types of entertainment are only in place for tourists and locals are eager to try to rip off tourists for photos and even small talk. It made the experience a little uncomfortable as we were weary to look in the direction of any street performer at the risk that he would want money for our gaze. We did give tips to those who put on interesting dance and music performances that we stuck around to watch, but did not contribute to performances in which we didn't linger around (though we were still asked for pay, even as we were simply walking by which made the square seem more like a site for artistic beggars). The food stalls were the highlight of our trip to the Jemaa el Fna - once we got over the overwhelming pitches from every single stall owner who attempted to physically drag us into seats or follow us around until we agreed to dine at a particular stall, we did have a very affordable meal. Every stall seems to serve the same things - couscous, lamb, chicken, seafood, etc. We finished off our night with a glass of freshly pressed orange juice and grapefruit juice and found it very comfortable to walk around at night back to our hotel that was several blocks away through the medina. A visit to Marrakech is not complete without spending some time in the Jemaa el Fna.

Hectic but worth the Visit!. I have been here three times before over the last 30 years and the place seemed to have gotten more polite. It still has all the crazy things going on, however I was not haunted by the locals as before. Always worth a visit!

unique atmosphere. The square comes into its own at dusk. It's a great place to wander around and soak up the atmosphere. Full of people buying and selling, as well as musicians entertaining the local crowds. The food stalls are a fun place to eat, but beware of the plumes of smoke coming off the barbecues. Try to choose a stall with lots of Moroccans.

Unique experience. Really enjoyed the ambience. I recommend going in the evening when the food stalls are in full swing. The smoke, crowds and lighting are a great experience. We got excellent photos from one of the restaurants with a second floor patio. Word of warning to females - do not let the henna women touch you. I said no to having the henna, but the lady took my hand and said "ok, free flower". I should have said no again, but let her continue. She did my entire hand in the span of 10 seconds and then demanded 400 MAD. I gave her 50 and walked away. Also, the restaurant touts are quite aggressive. This aside, it was a good experience.

Assault of the senses!. This place is everything that Marrakech is about, the signts, the sounds, the tastes and smells! In the day time it is a bustling market with horses and carriages and fresh orange juice stands galore. It comes alive in the evening with street performers and outdoor food stalls too. Must see while in Marrakech and the Kutoubia mosque looks spectacular from the square too. A lot of the restaurants and cafes have roof terraces around here too

Scary, exhilarating, and more. Go, enjoy the performers, haggle prices, watch your wallet and argue. It's all in good fun. I argued with a cobra charmer who wanted money after he put a snake (water snake, not dangerous) around my neck. Needless to say, it was funny but NO WAY was he getting money. Just stand your ground and have a ball.

Litlle bit regret. Very spread squere full of Henna ladies whose never let you walk peacefully around, thousends of orange juice sellers and restaurant customer hunters. It is apparently very special place but a little bit regret for me and my fiancee, this place offers all the same stuff completely same decorated in different places of square. Sometimes you can not find any difference between more shopsof. All shops looks absolutely same, same prices, same productes , same decorations, only sellers are different.after two days you will be fed up and you will try to avoid this place as much as possible.

There is no place on Earth that resembles this square. You can't visit this place and leave it with an "ok" impression!You can't rate this place with 2, 3 or 4 stars; simply, because you will either love it or hate it! That will, obviously, depend on your background and personality.A market in the morning and a huge open-air restaurant and theatre in the night, this place keeps on fascinating me every single time that I visit it.

Terrible Place... Everybody recommended to visit and see this place, but it's really terrible, fully crowded, snake players, monkey players, cheap magicians, beggars and of course thiefs everywhere..If you really curious this place be my guest, but for me really bad place to visit..

Animal abuse and hassle. The square is generally filthy. It seems that everyone wants your money. Constant hassle to get you in to shops, to buy things you just don't need, to get your money. Snakes drugged up and prodded to get them to perform. Monkeys on chains. The monkey owners stalk you around the square as you desperately try to avoid them. Homeless cats wonder around the square and the souks. This country is no place for animal lovers.

Central square. Amazing place. Beware of the snake charmers and henna tattooists. Too pushy and not great value. Best to keep walking and get into the sooks and back streets which are the heart and soul. Find a rooftop bar/restaurant and watch the world go by.

Another World. The Jemaa el Fna is a must see on any trip to Marrakesh, and what a vision it was! Swirling smoke, piles of figs and oranges, carts, plates of gorgeous food piled high on plates going back and forth. Reputedly offers some of the best street food ever.

Atmospheric. The first night in the square my friend and I held onto each other like limpits, just in case we were separated and couldn't find each other. Its useful to have a plan as to where to meet up if you do get lost in the throng of people. Probably in one of the rooftop terrace bars (which don't sell alcohol, even with meal) is best. We did find the square a little intimidating the first night but once you soak up the smells, sights and sounds, it all becomes very atmospheric, in a really good way. We were sorry to leave on our last evening and cannot wait to return.
amazing experience. I loved the hustle, I dressed in morroccon dress to disguise the English , and it worked, Its best late a night to sit around the open dancing. Great bargains for shopping.

Magical. This is the place you can spend your entire evening. From the nearby souks to the juice stalls to the amazing food stalls and the music. This place is magical in the evening. As soon as the sun starts to set, the magic starts kicking in. You can shop at the nearby souks and relax and unwind in the evening having some nice tajines and sipping some mint tea later. Perfect place to spend hours and do alot of people watching.

Great!!!. It's loud, it's crazy, I love it!All day you hear snake charmers, drums and the usual buzz of the merchants from the souks. It's almost always filled with people, but the great thing is that it's tourists and locals alike, so you get a great mixture and get the feel of it. And try to get a room at the charming Riad Andalla to have a wonderful stay and a great view on the Djemaa el Fna from their roof terrace (if you sneak up at night, you can even see it at its most quiet time).

Worth a visit. Worth a visit- the surrounding streets are far more interesting though. Stalls and shops closest to the stall will rip you off far more than the ones even a few streets back, so pick your purchases carefully!

Special square. If you are going to Marrakech, you need to pass by Jemaa el Fna, like other reviewers said : its a place with snakes, monkeys, henna tattos, story tellers, food stalls, a lot of locals and tourists.Its kind of surreal place and a little bizarre, and if you dont like walking around, you can sit at one of the caffes, and enjoy the view.

An experience!. Bustling, dirty and a bit smelly but an experience! Lots of people, lots of horse and carriages, so not good for allergy sufferers. Monkey trainers, snake charmers - if you take a photo give them some change - or you will get hassled. Lots of women offering henna tattoos.

Must see in Marrakech. Amazing place - absolutely abuzz with a fantastic array of shops, food stalls, street performers and much more - really very much the 'real Marrakech' . Be prepared to be pestered by sellers left right and center but enjoy the haggle as it really can be a positive experience even if you don't buy anything!

The marrakech soul. Every way you choose take you to Jemaa el Fna. During the morning and the afternoon, the place is occupied with the snakes men, with the watermen, the monkeys men.At the late afternoon the place is transformed by many food cars with the orange juices, the spices, the nuts and dried fruits, as with the snails and the meat skewers.The plaza has it own soul, and from the diferent souks, we can reacj Jemaa el Fna.

A fantastic experience, one you'll never forget. Went to Jemaa el Fna several times, both day and night, during my visit to Marrakech. In the day, I found it not as exciting as the night time but still worth a visit. At night the place really comes alive with the tempting food stalls, story tellers, musicians, dancers and stalls selling a huge variety of lovely souvenirs. I've wanted to visit Jemaa el Fna for a very long time and I wasn't disappointed. I loved every minute.

Over rated tourist trap- but I bet you end up here!. Having run the gauntlet of monkey-throwers, snake drapers and dubious henna ladies*, I was left wholly underwhelmed by Jemaa el Fna.At night it changes, and I can almost understand it's UNESCO status- the story tellers and shows are not put on for tourists, but entertain crowds of locals. Guaranteed some of the best banter in Marrakech at the night food stalls. But during the day I found no atmosphere, just a tourist hotspot. Whilst some people have found a magical atmosphere here, sadly I was not amongst them. *Don't get me wrong- I think henna is stunning. But too many horror stories about dodgy ingredients and allergic reactions for me to want to risk it here.
a must by night. was a bit nervous about going to the square at night but park your self in a cafe with a view and enjoy, the drinks and food are very reasonable.

cool but not amazing .... ... it was nice for a one-off visit and have a go and eat at one of the stalls, be wary when taking photos of performers or objects being looked after by someone as you are expected to give money. if you're not prepared, their gesture could be perceived as bordering aggressive. we ended up just looking and using our telephotos, shame as it would have been a nicer experience if locals are more passive and not wanting to take every opportunity to take your money. still an interesting experience to be in the square.

Be careful. People at the market are very determined to sell you everything! Women doing hena tatoos will grab your hand, tell you they will draw a good luck flower even if you don't want it and then ask to pay for it. People will give you things saying it's for free and then will ask you to pay. You ask for directions - they will ask you to pay - DO NOT believe if they say they are doing it for free. Sooner or later you will have to pay for everything! But the night food market was brilliant! Even so the food wasn't the best, you must see the whole play and be part of it.

Lively and bustling!. Went during the evening, was very lively and bustling. Massive square, could easily get lost!!! Lots of culture to soak up, majority of the people spoke basic English. Good place to get a gift for someone! Also tried some of the food, mixed meat skewers were nice! Definitely worth a visit if your going to Marrakech.

Great place to wander. Really great place to visit and watch the goings on in the street. Sit in one of the terrace cafés late in the day and enjoy the atmosphere and craziness of the place ... Loved it.

Almost too much. It's one of these places you have to have seen , but once is enough.Loads of traders trying to get your money. Be aware: as soon as you take a picture of someone or something ,they want money for it! But usually it's just some coins, so if you really want a picture go for it! During day time you have all the traders, snake charmers, water bearers , henna tattoo women ,etc. At night its food stall after food stall and some street musicians. you get hassled all the time , but just be firm and polite and say "la schokraan" - meaning "no,thanks". If you fancy some really good food for very cheap go to food stalls with loads of locals eating already. We had some really good fish and chips, fried calamari served with bread,aubergine puree and tomato salsa plus drink for hardly anything!

It has changed! still amazing though, however.... Still amazing and a worthwhile visit especially in the evening. We have seen it first five years ago. Its is crowded as ever and the actors are all their performing their unique daily spectacle. However, the intensity used by the waiters of the food stalls was excessive. We finally decided for one after having been pushed hard (not physically!) to eat with half a dozen of their competitors. There are plenty of food stalls and plenty of visitors so why all the fuss? A second issue is the Henna painters. The one who painted two tattoos on the hand and shoulder of Olga used brown thick henna. We paid 90 DHM and it all disappeared after a few hours. It was not worth it not even for fun. So beware of the Henna painters on the square itself. We have the feeling that the Djemaa is turning slowly into a fun fair. Its still save though apart from the dozens of vespas going full speed through the little streets that lead to the square.
A must do.. The best thing in Marrakesh. Horses, snake charmers, dancing monkeys, donkeys all together with food stalls and smoke. Its difficult to describe.

Buzzing. Whether you like it or not you are bound to have a look around the square. It's the centre of activity of the old town at night. It is lively and there is a lot of stuff going on .Not quite.... "animal carpet wall to wall" ..a la CSN..There isn't a great deal of quality food but plenty of tourist cack for sale. Didn't see any striped djellebas I could wear at home tho'. I didn't feel particularly unsafe

Tourist trap but should be experienced; just have your wits about you!. We visited Marrakech for 5 days in early October 2013.Marrakech as a whole is supported almost entirely by tourism and it is big business. The square is populated by two groups: (i) locals who are providing goods and services for consumption by tourists; and (ii) tourist who may or may not want them!The square is pretty quiet first thing in the morning with only fruit juice stands. There is perfect competition with every stand selling a glass of juice for 4 dirhams. We had juice every day we were there. It was delicious from every stand we tried. One seller offered us pink grapefruit juice which we thought we'd try for a change until the guy said it was 15 dirhams! We said "no way" so he dropped the price to 10 dirhams. Still too much in our opinion but we took it at that. Not worth arguing over a couple of dirhams!There are a number of cafes around the square. Our favourite was Cafe du France which served excellent coffee but sadly no food. Good place to watch over the square.Lots of snake charmers sat under tents making cobras sit up by playing their musical instruments. They leave you alone unless you go over to watch. We didn't get that close as I have an aversion to snakes. We saw some tourists have monkeys put on them and watched them give the owners 50 dirhams (just over £4) for the experience and a couple of photos which was met with hostility. So, beware. Henna ladies offering to paint hands/arms for a fee. They have books with photos of their designs that you can choose from. If you are female, you will be approached but just say no and that usually does the trick.
