One woman I said no to said she wanted to paint a small design on me for good luck but I said no firmly and with a smile and she was fine.A good tip is to smile if you don't want a service. We found the locals to have quite a good sense of humour. By night, the food stalls dominate the square although the snake charmers, henna ladies, monkeys etc remain out in force. Our only bad experience of the whole trip was eating one time at one of these stalls. As you walk through the stalls, you are practically mobbed by various stall owners waving menus in your face and shouting at you to eat at their stall. Most of the stalls offer identical food save for a few selling snails and sheeps heads/brains. We decided to try one selling mezze and grilled meats. Once we sat down, there was a cheer and clapping. This, we discovered, was not so much because we were going to eat at their stall but because they had 'snared' a tourist who they would attempt to rip off. This, it would appear, is how they operate: the menus are expensive (for eg £4 for some tomato and onion salad - what local would pay a quarter of that?), the portion sizes are tiny and they bring you things you haven't ordered and charge you an enormous amount for it at the end for example, we ordered 4 items from the menu which, given that it equated to approximately £18 we thought would be more than enough for two of us. They served us tiny bowls for us to share and then brought six tiny meat skewers with hardly any meat on them (just placed them in front of us and tried to charge us an additional £14 equivalent for them at the end) plus they brought us a bread roll and two dips (added £3 equivalent for the bread roll alone at the end)! Overall, the quality of the food was less than average, very bland, and there are flies everywhere. We asked for the bill and what came was an unitemised series of figures equating to around £30. We told the guy that we were only going to pay for what we ordered, not that there was much of it. He started remonstrating but we kept firm and said in no way were we going to pay £3 for a bread roll we didn't order or eat for that matter! We asked for the bill to reflect what we ordered. He wouldn't give us the correct bill so, we ended up giving him 200 dirhams which was way too much for what we had. We also said that if he wasn't happy with that, we would be happy to speak with the tourist police. Suddnely, there was no longer an issue. To conclude, I think you should experience eating at the food stalls and if I were to do it again, I would tell them up front that I only want what I ordered and to ask how big the portions are before you order as only then can you assess the value/if you're about to be ripped off! One other tip, don't wear anything nice as you will get totally smoked out and your clothes will smell!There are lots of horse drawn carriages at the entrance to the square and you will be approached by drivers eager to take you on a tour of the city. Nice if you like that kind of thing.About taxis, it's basically a cartel. Ever meter in every taxi bar two was apparently broken (yeah, right)! The two trips we did take wtih the meter on came to under 10 dirhams. The taxis we took on day one cost us 50 dirhams! For the rest of the trip, we refused to pay any more than 20 dirhams per taxi ride anywhere in the city which is more than double what it would cost if the meter was running and the taxi drivers seemed reasonably happy with this. Just wear a smile and be firm and you'll be fine.One last thing on taxis, the maximum fare they can charge from the airport to the sqaure is 70 dirhams. You can see them swimming around like sharks when the planes arrive with fresh bait!! We said we'd take one from the street when they tried to charge us 150 dirhams. Again, just tell them that you've been to Marrakech several times before and it gets the price down, although not to the 70 dirhams it should be. We did manage to pay this on the return journey however. Interestingly, the taxi meter was running and read just over 20 dirhams when we arrived back at the airport but we paid the 70 dirhams as agreed. You have to admire them for trying it on! Top tip: if you don't want to be harranged for services you really don't want, just tell whoever that you've been to Marrakech lots of times before and you know what the deal is. They leave you alone instantly!
Busy. Plenty of places to browse and eat.Sadly there are monkeys and snakes being paraded round, but tourists seemed to be avoiding them.

Exotic,crazy,fascinating!. This isn't a place to explore on your own if you don't speak the language and if it's your first time.The best way is with a guide.Merchants are loud and very pushy so be firm when refusing to buy and negotiate when you are interested in buying.Keep your wallet in a safe place at all times and ask if cards are accepted before showing interest.The food market with its unusual fare such as snails and camel hump is a must visit and the many varieties of moroccan pastries should be tasted.The merchandise could be of a good quality, especially leather goods but I don't recommend to make expensive purchases especially in antique stores and rugs.Think of this place as you would of a big flee market/ same concept.

Jemaa el Fna somewhat over-rated (avoid stall nr. 22). The square is definitely worth seeing, as it is by the the largest open space in the Medina and a lot of people gather there. It is possible to observe the bustle during the day, and spend some time having a drink and watch the world go by. However, come evening time, part of the square is converted into cheap restaurants and it is impossible to walk around without getting heckled constantly by waiters, trying to lure you into their little stalls that go for "restaurants". The stalls are numbered, and some locals will swear by the quality of food at their favourite stall. I had a particularly poor experience at stall Number 22, where the waiter pulled a fast one with the bill. We observed it happen to several other guests at the same stall, and we warned others who were arriving as we left. The amount involved was small, but the combination of: a) waiters heckling you constantly; b) poor quality food; c) fiddling with the bill; was enough to discourage future visitors from having high expectations.

main square. This Jemaa el Fna square is absolutely mesmerizing and everyone should experience an evening there. My husband and I went on a Tuesday, Wednesday, and Friday evening. There are thousands of people, restaurants, shops, and a beautiful view from any of the restaurant terraces. There are entertainers, musicians, etc.

Electric Excitement. Complete chaos in an electric excitement.....from the snake charmers,jugglers, acrobatics, henna tatto ladies,monkeys,music as well as the hawkers selling their wares,food and sweets stalls to families strolling about as if this was a walk in the park......this sets the scene of the Jemma el Fna .. This is worth experiencing by day and by night and a must to really get the feel of old Marrakech!

Ultimate tourist experience. Typical tourist experience - street performers, snake charmers and hawkers (not only Moroccan goods but lots of cheap "made in china" light up toys). Basically, lots of people trying to find ways of getting some money out of you. Interesting way to spend 30 minutes two times - afternoon and night.

Love lost. Seven years ago, i fell in love with Marrakech, so we thought this year we thought it might be a good idea to revisit... (with my parents)... Although i still found the place fascinating, I think the magic I felt all the years ago, had gone. I think for me this place has become too much of tourist destination and however authentic it still trys to be, its not.

Chaos!!!. Our first experience of Jemaa el Fna was awful. We found ourselves looking at the wonderful ceramic plates,wooden ornaments and beautiful lights and as we continued to walk through the alleys we eventually were lost. A young fella said he'd help us get back to the main square 'for free' but led us to the leather market and then demanded money. I have never spelt anything as vile as the combination of pigeon poo and ammonia and the bunch of mint that was given to help eliminate the smell didn't help. We managed to get back to the main square once we found the signs but we noticed we were not the only ones falling into this trap.The square it lovely by night and a lot calmer. If you do buy anything from the souks then haggle - haggle hard. You'll meet some characters that know exactly what to say but don't be fooled. Offer an eighth of their asking price and stick to your guns. If they don't accept, walk away because you WILL find that same piece elsewhere.
go at day and night!. snake charmers, acrobatics, fruit carts, mopeds, loud music, chaos, henna tattoo ladies, argan oil sellers, food stalls, drums, monkeys :( it's worth a trip or 2!!

A very busy/buzzing square. A fabulous place to eat, rest and shop. Take in the atmosphere there's nothing like it!All the souks seem to lead to this square and you should spend time getting lost around to here to experience the real Marrakech
Also very nice.. Lovely to walk aroound. Pay attention to the café,s. You can have a drink on top of a restaurant. The view is perfect.
Always Fascinating. I've been to this square a few times, in different times of day and night. In short: sensory overload!

Hustle and bustle and the daily transformation. Jemaa el-fna goes through a daily transformation to cater for different audiences throughout the day. Starting off with juice stalls and some light entertainment. In the afternoon, the trained Berber monkeys and snake charmers appear followed by younger dancers and henna artists in the latter part of the afternoon and early evening. As the sunset begins, the food market stalls start to appear in the middle along with group entertainments, local story tellers and musicians. As the evening progresses, young children appear with bright toys which they catapult into the air and lamp shade vendors who display their beautiful products to sell. The atmosphere is amazing and the real hustle and bustle starts in the evening. Be prepared to be approached by locals trying to sell you something. Tip 1: If you don't wish to hassled then the trick I have applied when travelling across the world is to look down and never make any eye contact but be aware of the surroundings. If you try to take a picture of the snakes or the men dressed in colourful clothes then expect to be charged for the privilege. Tip 2: Never take picture of local people unless you have have asked for permission.Tip 3: be aware of surroundings as the monkey owners may place the monkey on you shoulder, the hat sellers may put a hat on your head, or you may accidentally trample over a Snake. Tip 4: when approached always smile and say "la shukran" if you wish to decline their offering. They are very nice people trying to make a living and please do not be rude or insult them. Keep smiling and be patient they will appreciate it and you will enjoy your timeline Marrakech much better. Never let the hassling get to you, it is part of the experience of large places of gathering and souks. Tip 5: if anyone uninvitingly gives you directions then politely ignore them. Only ask shop keepers or restaurant workers for directions. Jemaa el-fna is safe to visit and enjoy the real experience of culture and food. Don't be scared or be out of by the hustle and bustle. If you really want to get the most out of the visit then 5 Dhm for each act may be worth paying. Eg listening to folk music, dancers, taking a pic of the snakes, monkeys etc....If you want to admire the scenery from a distance with no hassle then goto one of the roof top cafés and relax with a coffee or soda and a bite to eat,,Enjoy your time there and keep smiling.

Heart of the medina. This square really is the heart of the Medina. It really needs to be experienced at different times of day to appreciate how much it changes. In the morning, workers are trying to clean up from the previous night while shopkeepers and stand owners start to set up their businesses for the day. In the afternoon, the square is a mix of stalls, snake charmers, and all sorts of people trying to separate you from your money in exchange for something. At night, the infamous food stalls are erected and thousand of locals and tourists pour into the square. Drums circles provide the ambience while you eat shoulder to shoulder on benches. Throughout the day, the hubbub will be pierced by the prayer call. Really a must visit if you're in Marrakech and a true experience. Yes you will be constantly harassed by the entrepreneurs that fill the square, but if you can't handle that then what are you doing in Marrakech?

Incomparable. A wonderful centre to Marrakech. Through the day, there are wonderful orange juice stalls (freshly pressed and tastes great especially in the warm weather) - only 4Dh (35p) - make sure they squeeze it for you, otherwise it might be a watered down version, snake charmers around (be careful - they will try to put the snake on you and then charge you to take it off), and lots of other things to see with restaurants all aroudn the outside if you want a calmer place to jut sit back and relax whilst watching all that's going on!Nighttime is when this really comes alive, endless food stalls all trying to get your custom. A wonderful Moroccan experience, cooking your food right there and then for you, be prepared to say no a lot as everyone is quite pushy but the smell of spices and this wonderful food, Moroccans and tourists alike bustling around is unforgettable. A must-see and -do if in Marrakech.

Massive transformation from day to night!. Beware of the henna ladies. Give a very firm "NO" and walk away! The souks were great, though very busy. The square totally transforms from day to night, I would recommend going in the day and then at around 6pm where the square really comes to life! Such an amazing experience! Grab a freshly squeezed orange juice on the square for around 4 dirahms.

A magical, mystical place. Went to Jemaa el Fna the week before Christmas as part of an organised trip via Thompsons from our hotel (Rui Tikada Palmeraie- very good hotel btw).It was part of a trip which also included a calege ride (horse and carriage) through some of the more salubrious and affluent parts of Marrakech it has to be said.The cost of the evening's trip was very reasonable and included coach transfer into and out of the city, a knowledgeable guide and a free soft drink in a local café overlooking the square (not suitable for disabled clients as it involved climbing about 15 stairs-however, the market itself did appear to be wheelchair accessible).Even at 10.00pm the place was abuzz.The smells of the food being prepared in the open air, the spices on offer, the mountain of fresh oranges stacked sky high on stalls and the locals making their own entertainment via an impromptu ensemble of instruments was an experience never to be forgotten-highly recommended.Did we feel safe? Yes, but you need to have your wits about you. It is a well lit place, even at nights, but you need to be firm and keep on walking and not become detached from the main group (this is where the guide comes in handy). Keep your hands in your pocket, don't take much money with you and I am sure you will enjoy the mystique of an unforgettable experience?

A truly Moroccan experience. It is worth visiting Jemaa el Fna at different times during the day as it changes considerably. In the morning you can buy delicious fresh orange juice and visit the stalls. At night there are fires lit with musicians playing. During the afternoon you are likely to find snake charmers, monkeys (to be avoided) and women offering henna tattoos.

Stalls, Shops and the annoying people!. Be wary of anyone that approaches you, If acrobats or weirdly dressed people come upto you and perform and convince you to take photos of them with you, they WILL demand money after! You will be hastled by everyone! Not for the easily conned!

A true African marketplace. Marrakech is a very disorienting city. It is the only place I have ever visited in which the compass somehow changes every half an hour, with the effect that we got irremediably lost within ten minutes of walking from the snug riad in which we had bolt-holed ourselves. But the center of Marrakech, the Place Djemaa el-Fna, where we kept arriving back after walking for several minutes in a straight line away from it, is filled with snake charmers, fortune tellers, henna tattoo artists, acrobats, turbaned potion sellers, red-robed water sellers, astrologers, healers, Gnaoua drummers, story tellers, beggars of all conditions, shapes and sizes, Berber musicians and, in the evening, food stalls lit with kerosene lamps. We walked around (mostly in circles) and had something to eat, although this was not successfull. We stayed in a quiet and friendly riad in the southern Medina where breakfast and dinner served with style on the roof were memorable experiences, perfect also for watching the many resident storks and doves nesting in and on the Medina walls.
Mad!!!. Mad, crazy, exciting, busy are just some of the words to describe this mad mad city square, enjoyable but keep hold of your purse and be firm if you are not interested!!

Not your everyday experience. the Square is a place that will feel all of your senses with an experience that will not be duplicated. I had the opportunity to see it for the first time more than forty years ago, and for the most part it has not changed!It is filled with peddlers, snake charmers, dancers, food merchants,and people. literally thousands of people in the evening, One notethe activities change depending upon the time of day, enjoy.

Hideous tourist trap. First off, do not judge Marrakech on this review. Marrakech is a wonderful, safe and vibrant city. Just not the awful square. Had really high expectations for Jemaa El Fna. Had read about its history in guidebooks, had heard from others how entertaining it was... not our experience at all. Tacky, hellish place filled with aggressive 'entertainers' demanding money. They will literally band a cymbal in your ear, out comes the hand for money. If someone in a costume is in the vague area of the thing you are taking a photo of, they'll launch at you and demand money. Men punching monkeys in the face because they were pulling at the rusty metal chains around their necks. Men slamming toothless snakes on the ground for not dancing to music, food sellers getting angry when you don't want to eat in their stall, henna tattooists pulling your arms and putting henna ink on you despite repeatedly saying no. All of that in the space of 10 minutes while trying to get from one side to the other. Couple all that jazz with the heat, crowds and noise and it was sadly a harrowing let down. I suppose you've got to see it at least once, to say you've done it. Just be prepared to be hassled, to get angry and irritable and to feel on edge after. And be careful where you eat. My partner was on the loo for three days after eating at the square. Just bad luck I guess. Best advice? Arrive at one of the rooftop bars at about 6pm, get upstairs, get a table, relax and watch it from above as the sun goes down. Take as many pictures as you like. Just avoid watching the monkeys get kicked in the face for not jumping on cue.

Definitely a place to visit – but stay on your guard!!!. You will have heard lots of stories about the markets in Marrakech and this is probably one of the biggest and most famous. There isn’t anything you can’t buy and you will get hassled at every turn, this can be quite exhausting after a while. I’m normally very tolerant of hawkers but I have a story which I feel I should share. There are lots of street signs placed which should guide you back to the market square, also many locals will offer to walk with you and guide you for some ‘change’. However, many of the signs have been twisted so that you end up where you started or deeper into the middle of the market. One local insisted in ‘helping’ me, even though I demonstrated I had a lack of coins. However, I was guided to an ATM, this I found to be quite aggressive and I expressed my irritation and no money changed hands.If you need directions stay assertive and best always ask a woman.
How can you miss it?. Make sure you visit both in the day and in the evening...it's a street fair atmosphere with lots of food and fun to be had.

Not worth the time and it is overhyped. The Jemaa el Fna square was dirty and the snake charmers were very aggressive and belligent demading money from people taking photos and in my case I was just standing nearby without a camera. In fact I do not go near "entertainers" beacuse you will always end up with a demand for money.The food stalls were also very uninviting

A Marrakech Experience Not to be Missed. This huge square is a focal point of the Medina. it is where the an astounding array and variety of people congregate and interact. During the day the square is filled with hawkers of all kinds - snake charmers, men with monkeys on leashes, dancers in costumes, sellers of all kinds. The myriad of souks radiate off the northern and eastern edges of the square. In the evenings, a night market of food stalls with tables fills half the square, and the crowds only get bigger. There are Arab story tellers and drum-pounding groups. The one downside is that many of the local populace have their hands out for money constantly. And if you are a visiting foreigner, you will be targeted immediately as a potential sale. But if you've traveled, you'll know how to evade with a smile.The square is partially ringed with restaurants with outdoor terraces on their top floors. When you feel like escaping the immediacy of the crowds, these terraces are a great place to sip a cold drink and view the human escapades below with detachment.This is assuredly a unique Marrakech experience which one cannot miss if in the city.

Music and Mayhem. The first thing we noticed about Jemaa El Fna was the noise of drummers competing against each other, the howl of the snake charmers pipes and the buzz of scooters and mopeds as they dashed around at high speed narrowly avoiding accidents to themselves and pedestrians. The square is fascinating with all the juice stalls, pottery sellers, acrobats and musicians. In the evening we ate at the food stalls and were greatly amused by the sales patter used to attract diners into the various establishments. This is a great place to watch the sun go down from one of the roof terraces with a mint tea or freshly squeezed orange juice after a day's sightseeing. Beware the high speed bikes and mopeds!

jemaa el fna. A visit to this square has to be one of the highlights of the Marrakech experience, looking through sanitised european travellers eyes it is all too easy to disdainfully describe it as noisy ,chaotic and dirty : but there is more to the square than this .As night falls and the aromas of exotic spices rise from the food stalls and the cries of vendors give way to the exciting rhythm of the drumming groups ,magic and romance drifts in the air to form an enchanting melange of sounds colours and and aromas that quickens the imagination and personifies the magic of arabia .From the bright electric light of the juice sellers to the naive beauty of the flickering tea lights to the whirl of acrobats and the persistence of street sellers result in an atmosphere that is a truly exciting whirl that assails all your senses,Stand back and observe or join in with the crowd eating buying or haggling whirl of sound sights and movement . Ignore the mobile phones and the trappings of the 21st century and let yourself be transported back in time ,enjoy your journey back in time you can soon return to your comfort zone and eat a big mac !

Daytime and not very lively. I visited during the day and whilst most guide books will tell you that from noon it if full of all sorts of interesting activities in fact when I was there there were very few entertainers and large area were empty.

Appalling!. When I decided to give Marrakech a try having never been before, I did expect some noise and unacceptable conditions it being what and where it is. However nothing prepared me for the appalling use of animals in what is classed as entertainment. The beggars and constant mither from "guides" made for an unpleasant and very annoying experience. This leaves me to comment on the squalor. But I don't want to go there!Having previously been to Istanbul I expected something similar however Marrakech beggars belief. Thank goodness for our beautiful Riad. If that hadn't been so lovely and welcoming I would have got the next flight home even if it meant travelling indirect.

Buzzing square of magic and mystery. By day the square is quiet with a few snake charmers and men with monkeys wanting money from you to have your photo taken with them, loads of portable fresh orange stalls everywhere and cafe, shops and restaurants surrounding it. With a few hotels all around the square. By night it's a different story the square is alight with people selling handmade candle holders ( tea light holder) groups of men and boys singing and playing musical instruments, people selling all sorts of light up toys for children, stalls of all kinds of moroccan food, takeaway and seated, people practicing magic, and the snake charmers and monkeys are in there somewhere. When we visited the square at night it was amazing, mystical, and noisy and bustling all at the same time a real sight to behold and not to be missed when visiting Marrakech .
Magical. A definite must see. Just ignore the mitherers! Absorb the atmosphere,its brilliant. Drawback, cash machines didn't seem to work, but there are a couple of exchange bureaus.
Dirty and noisy. As the centre piece of the Medina you would think that they would look after it better - don't buy anything here you can get it much cheaper in the souks

Jemaa el Fna. Wow what a experience!! What a great place, there were many things to see such as Snake Charmers, Local story tellers, Acrobats, Monkeys and many others things. Make sure you agree a price before any pictures or any handling of animals.I personally don't like people using animals this way but we were in their country and we must accept this is there livelihood.When you visit the square during the evening there is a large area with food this is a must during your visit, the food is great and the banter you get from the different seller is good fun!!We had a great time in the square both during the day and during the night, a must when you are here.

Simply another world!!!. I would just like to say what an amazing time me and my girlfriend had here!! The best food stall was No1 (opposite the snail stalls). Tried the snails too which you have to do simply for the experience along with the tete de agneau (sheeps head) which is a delicacy in morocco. The orange juice stalls provide you with the most amazing freshly squeezed juice going. You will just want to keep going back for more. I would also advise sitting in one of the terraces overlooking the square late afternoon and relax until the evening with a cold drink whilst watching the square transform into the most busiest place I have ever seen. Simply an amazing experience and would recommend it to anyone.

A contrast day and night. The main square in the walled old city teems with market stalls, snake charmers, music and people during the day and in the evening sparkles with lights, music and what seems like hundreds of open air cafes and food kiosks. Just the sight, sound and aroma is worth a visit. The perimeter offers a wide choice of restaurants with open roof terraces to take in the view.

Jemaa El Fna. Jemaa El Fna square is quite a sight for sore eyes! Snake charmers, monkeys, street performers, women doing henna tattoos, pottery and silverware stalls, fresh orange juice vendors, food stalls with snails and other exotic delicacies and young men who literally pounce on unsuspecting visitors to entice them into their eating places all await you on this most fascinating of places. At night smoke billows from the rows upon rows of food stalls and clouds the sky in a whitish/grey thick mist. Traditional music blasts from small music stalls and street percussionists attract large crowds of enthusiastic locals who huddle around and clap and sing along to their rhythmic sounds. Nothing is free on the square and in fact anywhere really. Do not attempt to take a picture of anybody, or animal unless you are prepared to pay. Same goes for street attractions. If you stay and watch be prepared to give money. I recommend some of the silverware and traditional clothing stalls. I bought a beautiful traditional teapot which looks very much like silver. Ask the vendor for teapots you can actually use as some are merely decorative and get damaged very quickly if you use them for non decorative purposes. And of course barter for the best price. Definitely a night out at least once when you visit!

Unforgettable. Go for the day and experience the exciting way the world famous square changes character through morning, noon and night. I approached the Square via the Souks, another great experience, and at eleven o'clock it was already bustling. Snake charmers, belly dancers, the lot. The pace quickens during the afternoon, and around seven o'clock the place is transformed into a huge open air eating experience. Wonderful street food, Huge variety from kebabs and salads, to snail soup. Go for the experience. Everything is fresh and clean and I didn't suffer from jippy tummy once!

Colourful and noisy. Lots of juice stalls by day and food stalls at night. Very push sellers and a some con artists. You will be charged to take pictures of snake charmers, monkeys and dancers. Keep your wits about you and your belongings close.

A Must-See For Any Visitor To Marrakech. Well, I don't know about 'must-see' - it's hard to avoid! The day time is interesting and enjoyable, with pedlars, performers, and an inconceivable number of orange juice sellers (the juice cheap and unforgettably good). At night even more sellers etc arrive and the whole square becomes a chaotic throng. It's only spoiled by the inevitable pedlars of cheap counterfeit goods, but then you get that anywhere like this.Don't be afraid to eat from the stalls grilling food. Like the orange juice, it's tasty and cheap.

Colourful, vibrant and a must visit. Snake charmers, fez vendors, fresh orange drinks & bottled water, potions and lotions (just to name a few) - different mobile stalls that can be found in this square apart from the permanent ones. Have a drink (for your eyes as well) on one of the 1st/2nd floor terraces and enjoy the hustle and bustle.

Nothing like it. Haven't experienced anything like Jemaa el Fna anywhere else in Morocco nor anywhere else I have been in other countries around the world. The square takes on a different atmosphere at night as well, so visit it at day and night if you have the opportunity.
exotic and funny. it is a very special Place With a lot of People, a lot of noise , a lot of smoke from grills and very facinating.

Crazy!. This is the fast beating heart of the Medina. In the early morning you can have freshly squeezed orange juice from the carts. During the day you have typically tourist attractions avialable, like snake charmers, monkeys, men dressed in traditional outfits, etc Make sure you agree a price with them for the pictures and videos before you start recording. You have to haggle nearly everywhere in the Medina. In the evening the place is full of story tellers and you can have something to eat at the food stalls. Be picky as there are lots of them. It's good to ask at your Riad which ones are the best. The stalls are cheap but you have to tip.
Great Experience.... This place is really full of life, but at night it is really crazy.... Entertainment, stalls, food..

Venue Moroccan charm.. Before entering the square, it is better to be patient and resist the attacks of the aggressive vendors. It is better not ask anything, Moroccans always will offer you guides to places of friends and then receive a hard sell.

the famous Market Place. It wasn't our kind of 'thing'. Too busy with Tourists - I know we are all Tourists, the ambience wasn't quite what we expected, the Cafes around this place were not very charming - this is our experience which doesn't mean others like that place

The essence of the Medina. Fantastic market place - incredibly vibrant and to me, the essence of the Medina. We spent every evening of our 4-day stay walking around the Jemaa el Fna and seemed to never tire of it as there is so much to see - it is very very busy and crowded with locals and visitors - attracted by food sellers, snake charmers*, knick-knack sellers, people with monkeys*, horse and carriage cabs, shoe-polishers, craftsmen, tattoo 'artists', entertainers* of all sorts, to name a few... all milling around incessantly and all assiduously vying for attention. (Those I have asterisked do expect you to pay them if you want to watch them and/or take photos of their 'act').You can have a really cheap dinner there (we did twice - the food was great and between 70 and 110 Dirhams did the trick!There are plenty of restaurants and cafes surrounding the marketplace so if eating a bit 'rough' is not your thing, fear not: there are many options...Not to be missed!

An assault on the sense at night.. Eat, drink and be entertained. Its all happening here at night. The animals are not really my cup of tea to see in captivity but its not your own high street so take it in and make what you want of it.

A must to experience - but.......... A World Heritage site and worth a visit day and night - but it's all a bit seedy and smelly. The performers are clearly after your money, so make sure you have a supply of small value coins in your pocket. The tented restaurant city, all air-conditioned of course, appears from nowhere in the late afternoon and the hustling for custom starts early - but it's amusing banter! As the sun sets behind the nearby Koutoubia Mosque, one appreciates the ochre colours of the buildings and the sunset is spectacular. Do visit - but be prepared for a little disappointment.

Nice place . If you want get feeling of old arabian market like in move you muat go!!! Just dont forget all prices minimum 3 times biger as should be!!! Some people so nice some nacty! Choose seler which speak little english and you will have less head touch!

Great place but beware!. We visited the Jemaa el Fna quite a few times as our riad was quite nearby. It's a fantastic place in the day, we'll worth stopping for an orange juice at one of the stalls and just taking it all in for a bit but beware ladies! You'll hear about the henna ladies being sneaky but they are as quick as lighting they just reach out and grab your hand and in a few seconds they've drawn something on you and want money, we were warned by a local guide and I just kept my hands under my shawl. We won't put too much on here about what you'll see in the square so as not to spoil it for you but there are some really interesting things and it's worth wandering through a few times or even getting some lunch or dinner so you can take it all in. We stayed away from the snakes and the monkeys as they were really ill looking and we didn't want to encourage it, most tourists were doing the same as they don't look after the animals well there. But there are plenty of stalls selling herbs, spices, shoes, all sorts of things and they all have well cared for pets outside that you can pick up and play with without getting charged for it.

Not to be missed but be prepared. My husband and I are seasoned travelers and it is not lost on us that in Morocco, where so many have so little, that Canadians must seem rich beyond belief. I must however admit that I have never faced such anger and violent reactions to simple picture taking than in Jemaa el Fna square. We were more than pleased to pay the fee to hold a snake and snap a pic but just standing near a magician or musician with a camera on my shoulder did not merit the response that occurred on more than one occasion. Taking a picture of a food vendor elicited demand for payment. It was awkward and uncomfortable and detracted from what should have been a highlight of the Marrakesh experience. Even the bartering process, that I always find a little distasteful, escalated to a level of anger beyond what I have experienced in other countries. I would not have missed a trip to the square and in fact visited both in the evening and daytime but it is not my fondest memory of Morocco.

Mesmerizing Place. Jemaa el Fna is a place you have to experience. Whether it is during the day and you visit the stalls or at night and you eat at the Night market, watch the performers, etc., it is a real cultural experience.

Unique experience - visit once for sure!. Disliked the being hassled constantly but it wasn't as bad as I thought. A firm no thank you gets rid of them, until the next one! The stalls are amazing. Make sure to visit one of the cafes with a panoramic view for brilliant photos. The stench of the whole place wasn't pleasant but part of the experience. We only went in the evening and felt that was enough, far too hot to walk around in the day. 2 hours was more than enough time to explore and try one of the food stalls. Good sales tactics by them, even doing English accents to make us laugh.Lovely time to view the call to prayer people rushing into the mosques. The square suddenly went very quiet so was a great time to walk around and barter a bit more. Always start at a quarter of their price and walk away if they won't budge. They'll lower if they can!Try one of the orange juice stalls for 4 Dirhams, although there's too much choice! Enjoy it!

worth a visit. cannot miss this market - however, not really worth lingering. avoid during the day and at night great to have a snack at the food stalls and walk amongst the stalls however, everything on sale here is (potentially) cheaper and better and more plentiful in the souk.

unique experience with awful sell. it busy area in Marrakesh.everyone after your money. Take a photograph-money. Stand and look and a beggar or hustler appears.i hate disgusting small & dirt in this area.

Wow!. This huge square, with its history of parades and executions, is now the hub of the essence of Marrakech. Things to avoid are the beggars and the would-be guides - non to the first, non merci to the second. If you like dried fruits, fresh orange juice, snakes, water sellers, this is for you. It also starts you on your trip into the souks, which are magic. We went back three times.

Every evening, a medieval fair.. At dusk this place draws hundreds of local people to watch dancers, hear music, see boxing, hear stories, watch charmed snakes and also eat at the evening food stalls where meat is barbecued. You need lots of small change if you want to take photos as each one must be paid for.

A unique experience. Hustle. bustle, noise, energy, the odd snake and monkey, orange juice a plenty... I don't think many people would visit Marrakech and not visit the 'big square' you wont find anything quite like it in the UK

Just unpleasant. Everyone after your money. Take a photograph-money. Look at the appalling conditions of the animals-money. Buy anything-expect to be short-changed. Stand and look and a beggar or hustler appears.

Holy cow everyone has got to experience this..... Snake charmers, monkeys in dresses and diapers, young men street boxing, crazy food stands everywhere, and horse drawn carriage rides. This place is insane at night and so amazing to experience. Hold on to your wallets at night because the street kids are eying everyone and there is a seedy feel. If you want to take a picture be sure to give 5-10 D to whoever you are photographing or they will get very upset. Carry change on you at all times.
Jemaa el Fna - Not to be missed. You cant come to Marrakesh without coming here early evening for the experience. Snake charmers and the atmosphere are unique.

Nice fresh Juice. After sundown they squre become to life. Have small coins available for give aways. Beware of personal belonginging and wacth out before you kwow there is a snake arround your neck waiting for a tip! Choose you food staal carefully (undercooked food).
jammaa el fna...amazing.... this place is magic, full every day of thousand and thousand of person, you found everything inside, restaurant, handcraft, music..plenty of life...
Good atmosphere for tourists. It's interesting and it certainly had a fabulous atmosphere for tourists. The restaurants in that area were not too expensive either.

a different experience. there were people selling local products and food and also artists performing all kinds of different performances eg. snake seducers,fortune tellers. It was like living into a completely different world. People were very poor, they were constantly trying to sell you things and everything was dirty, you could not feel at ease

hated it. Not my cup of tea at all - pushing and shoving, constant hassling, beggars, noise, smoke, snakes, and the most revolting cafes around the edge - had a "lunch" in one of them - totally inedible and got it taken off the bill. If you are in Marrakech it's got to be done however ,you'll never see anything like it elsewhere.

do not miss a visit at night. The square transforms from quite quiet to unbelievable madness at night with musicians and juice sellers and the largest outside eating area that I have ever seen.Just walk away if you don't want to eat and carry on going they will get the idea in the end and leave you alone

Enjoyable and stressful at the same time. This square is absolutely manic. It's alot better to go here and to the souks (which branch off) in the day in my opinion. All there is in the night is bothersome idiots and dodgy food at night. Whatever you do, AVOID the animals!! Especially the monkeys. The risk of rabies in Marrakech is very high, so if you get bitten and are not vaccinated, then you can die if not treated quickly. And getting medical treatment in Morocco is not easy. Me and my girlfriend had to cut our holiday short and return to the UK for an injection because she was bitten by one of the monkeys.

Jemaa el Fna. This place was just amazing. The hustle bustle of the square was just incredible - something was happening in every spot! From snake charmers to monkeys on shoulders, henna being painted by ladies to fresh orange juice stall owners fiercely trying to get customers! The night life is incredible - so many lights and lanterns and so many food stalls (food is so much cheaper in the square than anywhere else) and so much entertaiment. Was just amazing!

The Big Square. Very busy place. Lots of snake charmers and stalls around this area. Need to watch out for traffic as well. Enjoyed sitting in one of the roof top cafes watching the scene below and taking in the atmosphere.

Ambiance and cheap tasty food. In daytime nice ambiance, from 17 o clock starting to set up several kiosks with delicious and cheap food, from meta to vegetables, to dessert, to cookies, to end up with a Minth tea, and this all together with the local people. Very nice.
All life is here. The foodstalls in the evening are challenging but once you have braved them the food is great. We used stall nr 1 as it had a good crowd and were not disappointed.

Fascinating. Loved the atmosphere, but were constantly harrassed by people who wanted to be our guide. You have to be polite but firm as they
wont go away. Loved the square by night - vibrant and fascinating

The heart of Marrakech. What a brilliant place! The square is alright during the day but really comes alive at night when it is closed to traffic. Food stalls, people with monkeys, bands playing music, henna artists, people jostling for your attention. It's not for the faint-hearted, but if you go into it treating it as a game (and being willing to say 'no' every five seconds), you'll have a brilliant time. We didn't eat anything as we were on our way back from dinner but had great fun chatting with the various food stall hawkers and having a laugh. Thoroughly recommend!

The heart of the city. Watch the world go by (and it feels like the whole world!) as you sip your sweet mint tea. Watch the pop-up kitchens appear and delicious smells of spices linger. You have to be brave, barter and join in the fun. And you need to note some landmarks so you don't get lost in the souk!

Like nothing I have experienced before. Saturday night is the night to go. The noise and activity level is super charged. An amazing place to experience the real culture of Marrakesh. I have never seen so many people in one place. With food stalls, snake charmers and groups of people listening to music or watching any number of entertainers.

It's a must. Going to Marrakech and not going to Jemaa el Fna is a crime. There's a very interesting mix of sounds, people and even scents. You can go there and just sit in one of the restaurants that surrounds it and enjoy the experience.
alive. it is the heartbeat of Marrakech and a potpourri of sights, sounds, smells and tastes (if you are brave enough for the street foods)...just amazing to walk and watch

bustling market square. very vibrant. Could get to many different entrances to the souks.Didn't like the hassling from the henna ladies especially. One walked next to me and went to put the needle looking henna tool on my hand which freaked me out so I had to pull away. She frightened the life out of me!
Not a fan. Big place where you can find juice makers, snake charmers, tooth resellers. Get a picture with a monkey or a snake this is the place. Personally this is not my cup of mint thee. ;)

Front row for sunset. Get a front row seat@ le grand cafe balcon glacier by 530pm...buy a coke and watch the world go by for next 2 hours as sun sets. Balconies get busy by 6/630. Head down into the square by 730 and wander about taking in the sights smells etc for an hour or two. Highly recommended merely because it's an experience not replicated elsewhere and it's obvious that there's as many locals as tourists enjoying the atmosphere

the heart of Marrakech. The confusion and the variety of people make this place a must visit in Marrakech... And don't worry if you get lost in the Souk, you have a high chance you're going to end up there....

Chaos, crazy, fun. It's a must-do in Marrakech. A little daunting but it's lots of fun. Snake charmers, guys tossing diapered monkeys onto you to sell you a photo, music, crowded storytellers (all in Arabic), it's unlike anything you'll see elsewhere.

not a place i wanted to stay for long. personally im not into the main squares of most citys as everything is packed and overpriced and people arent friendly they just want your money, there was nothign authentic about it, just snake charmers forcing you to pay them for pictures you dont want, every restaurant im sure was crap and over priced, i ate at 2 places in the square and they were bland.

Best at night. I first visited this place during the day but found it a much better experience at night. As sun sets the square comes to life, there are snake charmers, magicians, monkeys in dresses, lots of 'pop up' restaurants serving freshly made local dishes, locals selling anything and everything trying to make a living. If you are an animal lover you may see some very distressing sights, so beware. There are lots of roof top cafes/bars, if you secure a seat before sunset you will witness an amazing sight across the square.

EXCITEMENT. This place is to be seen at daytime and at night. The changes from day to night are amazing. Always bustling with people and vendors trying to get your sale. The food stalls at night were great to experience.

crazy place. snake charmers,musicians,merchants,hustlers,vendors ,guides tourists,smells, noises,colors etc. Just a crazy hectic place. A must visit when in Marrakech. Be aware that if you take photos of anyone or anything you will have to pay for that. The souks are pretty interesting as well. Do not forget to bargain heavily to lower the price.

Never again. The barbaric treating of snakes, owls, falcons, baboons, mongooses is shocking. It's time to move into the 20th century and ban this kind of thing. Every orange juice vendor had a try at short changing and if you pulled out your camera an individual would appear from nowhere hustling and begging.

At least visit once. If you're already in Marrakech, you may as well stop by and see this place. Yes, it's loud, crazy and somewhat overwhelming. Personally. I don't like the place much. The monkeys made to entertain people is too much for me and crowds aren't my thing. But! I am still glad I went to see what it was all about. Oh, and the orange juice alone is totally worth dealing with the madness at least once. SO GOOD!!
town. very vibrant place, BUT - Beware of snakes and monkeys. Beware of people asking you for money. Ladies - Donot use public toilets. Men - we are ok.

Exploitation of tourists. Across the square there are different prices for locals and for tourists.They can ask you 20 times more than the actual value of what is intended to buy. Even haggling, you might do not always get prices down to a reasonable value. I did not buy everything I wanted, because I can have the same things from Morocco at international fairs in Portugal that do a much better price, which is ridiculous.

Over-rated. Maybe my wife and I are less tolerant these days, but the square is frankly awful! Why people want to cram in to average looking cafes to scramble to roof terraces to view a human zoo defeats me. It is dirty, and there seems to be no protection for pedestrians. Locals seem to find it funny to drive their horrible little motorbikes at you. Note that none of the cafes serve alcohol. Forget the square and walk 5 minutes to Hotel Jardins de la Koutoubia. Beautiful oasis of calm and lovely local wine at £11 a bottle.

Magical!. You've probably seen this place in pictures and movies, it's the traditional moroccan souk, where you will find all sorts of moroccan things and souvenirs. It's really beautiful and has it's own charm, but the salespeople WILL rob you. Try to go there with a moroccan person that can actually negotiate with the people who work there if you dont want to overpay.

madness. snake charmers monkey trainers its like a movie set keep your wits about you if u want a henna tatoo agree a price 1st and dont let the women near u till you have a deal i stood still to look at the designs and a women started painting the design before i even asked

NEARLY RUN OVER. Well Im glad we went to experience the noise and mayhem, but the constant motor bikes and scooters trying to knock you down got a bit tedious! Really felt upset seeing the monkeys being hit and locked in crates (dont have your picture taken with them), also with the snake charmers who seemed to torture the snakes for fun! We did do a horse and carriage ride after picking a horse who looked quite healthy! Theres a man selling old teeth which is worth a photo if you pay him! All in all ok, got the t shirt wont go back!

Sights and Sounds. Visiting with two girlfriends Marrakech is a hive of activity. I highly recommend a visit to the main square and souks. Do not be afraid to say no, by our third day we realised that it is not considered rude and in fact a little bit of banter and a firm no will stop you having to eat at every street cart, restaurant and market stall. Everyone is extremely friendly but remember directions and photos come at a cost. Keep small change to pay for photos if needed and never settle on the first price, after all part of the fun is having a haggle. Also we ate in old town nearly every night of our trip and had no issues with the food. Sometimes some of the language towards us was a little questionable but this was few and far between and normally we just heard shouts of Shakira and Kim Kardashian!!
Jemaa el Fna. Good fun, not worth buying anything here though. Nice restaurants around the edge and some good cafés to sit in and watch the world go by.

Tourist Trap. Only go For the best orange juice in the world!. Jemaa el Fna used to be amazing to visit, However now its a nightmare to walk through during the day as there is no shade and just loads of people trying to get as much money of you as possible for the littlest things such as taking a photo. At night this place is super packed and there are way to many men so for women, go with a man or prepare to be harassed. The pro's : Young children would like the monkeys and snake charmers by day and the best part is the Orange juice, if you can decide who to go to as there's a whole row of orange juice stalls trying to get your attention.' And at night if you can get through the crowds you can buy items at a fix price so you know your not getting ripped off.

Worth ONE visit only - the smell is not pleasant. As smelly markets go, this is worth a visit (or even one night stay) but do not book your whole week in this area, it really grates on you...monkeys in nappies, cobras with their mouths sewn shut and rotten fruit! As a female I was shouted at and inapproproate comments passed daily. I didn't appreciate the contact hassle and men trying to sell you things! Would go for a look, but once is more than enough.

Great free entertainment. Go after 7 pm for the most activity. Lots of open air restaurants, the food looks and smells great. Easy to get taxis. Very crowded, but really fun. Snake charmers, monkeys, palm readers, henna ladies, comedians, jugglers, musicians, and on and on. Amazing. One of the great sights in the entire world.

You MUST go at night, it is a completely different atmosphere than in the day. We stayed near Jemaa el Fna so experienced it in many different lights. If you don't like crowds, hectic scenarios or are put off by scammer's and poverty then I am not sure why you are even travelling to Morocco. But for those of you that love to experience a bit of culture and soak in what Morocco has to offer then this is the place to be. During the day it provides a great place to choose a restaurant/cafe to eat at, yes it may be a little more expensive to dine here as it is in the main square but what is an extra couple of dirhams when you can sit for hours just watching the world go by. The juice carts are functioning at all hours, so treat yourself to a 4 dirham drink when your sweating it out in 40 degree heat. This is a good place to start your shopping and explore the area. Once it gets to about 6pm you see what is the only "bare" area in the square start to transform. Heaps of little stores are set up to sell dinner. Mainly the same sort of thing so don't spend to much time choosing one, but you can sit and enjoy a cheap feed, fresh off the grill. The rest of the square, although already seemed full in the day fills up with about 8 times more people and you can easily spend a few hours walking around watching the buskers, musicians etc. I don't fancy watching the snake charmers or money tamers but I am not going to let it bother me. Practices such as these in countries like this probably wont ever change so just carry on experiencing the things you do enjoy and try not to let it upset you. We spent every night down in Jemaa el Fna and found that when we went to other parts in Morocco we missed the action and community attached to having such a festival style main square.

As crazy as ever!. this has to be the place to come if you are visiting Marrakech! Be prepared for the crazy sights and smells of this magical country! Don't be afraid and let "horror" stories put you off! If you don't want something simply say no or walk away! Do beware of pickpockets and we did hear of some women having their bums groped on the sly!

Crazy place!. This place cannot be described it just has to be seen. So crazy and lively. You've got people selling stuff, guys sitting there with monkeys and snakes, a guy selling teeth (!!! yes teeth), henna artists, storytellers, people playing games and food and juice stalls. When you're there definitly have an orange juice and enjoy it while taking in all the crazy around you...

Best seen after dark.... You have to see the square but I didn't really enjoy it during the day...don't like the monkeys on leads, animals in tiny cages and snake charmers, but I accept this is a different culture to mine. At night though, it's kinda fun - so busy and noisy with the musicians, food stalls and a throng of onlookers. It's fun to watch from one of the bar or restaurant terraces too. There are lots of guys selling tea light holders and lanterns on the ground and these do make the place look pretty. It also feels safe when you're walking around.

Must see it. Don't come here in the heat of the day. Instead, wait until the early evening when the place really comes alive with stalls, animals, restaurants and carts selling sweets, juices and all manner of dried fruits. I don't really like to see the snake charming or the treatment of the monkeys (I consider it cruel), but it is very unique and you won't miss it from afar; just don't go in too close or show excessive interest as you'll be expected to part with your money for watching.

Mixed Feelings!. This square gave me such a mix of feelings, one minute I would be really loving it then the next it would get a bit much! Sitting on the terraces of the cafes watching the sun set with the call to prayer being sounded was amazing! The square was hectic but fun, we had orange juice from a stall and it was lovely. Be careful with your change though they always seem to give you the wrong change!

A must see-but nothing special !. Nothing more than a tourist trap - just a central square with fortune tellers, snake charmers, acrobats, comedians (performing in arabic), and insistent men trying to sell you things you don't want !

The Esscence of Marrakech. It was exactly what I had been told. The fresh squeezed orange juice is superb. If you want to photograph the monkey handlers and snake charmers expect to give them a few DRMs, after all it is how they make their living. No one else is paying them so cough up a coin. I actually felt safe there and one of the best way to spend a balmy evening.

Where Marrakech comes alive. Visited the square once at night, not really my cup of tea, too terrified of stepping on the beady-eyed snakes scattered on the floor and trying not to make eye contact with the man with the monkey on his back! Yeh seriously at night you will see all manners of wonders of the night...Covent gardens this is not! However if unlike me you are a bit more spatially aware of your surroundings at night and want to sample the buzzy feeling of locals enjoying the night life then you will enjoy this authentic atmosphere. Lots of cafes and riads and places to watch the fire eaters and snake charmers from a safe distance. The smells are incredible as this is when the food sellers mainly set up, if you are brave, indulge in some street food crammed in next to other locals at the same table watching 5 foot flames cooking your food, smells are mouthwatering indulgent. By day the square has a more sedate feel. Take your time and meander round the souks, ensure you have your haggling skills ready. Enjoy the moments and keep your wits about you, as lovely as the people are, as a tourist you can meet some shady characters looking to part you from your dirhams. But have fun by beating them at their own game!

better at night than day. As mentioned briefly in the souks review try orange juice, avoid the henna ladies as they will grab your hand and tattoo you before you know it. We both preferred it in the evening as weirdly it felt safer and more relaxed than day time and 'came alive' with story tellers and much more. Its hard to describe the sights and sounds but its a great place - very different just beware if anyone in traditional costume wants you to take a photo as again they expect payment. We took a taxi in and make sure you agree a fare before you get in - we even haggled and got a return trip 2 hours later. If you can speak French then do as they appear to appreciate it. When you visit at night you will be hounded by people trying to get you to eat on the food stalls but just be polite and take it in the spirit it is meant. Find a roof terrace/bar and take photos from above - we flew over it at night on our way home and its amazing to see all lit up.

Heart of the city. We stayed in a hotel nearby so we came here a few nights in a row. There are endless of things to see and do. Drink orange juice, eat in one of the restaurants in the center, watch some acts, there's a double deck bus that takes you all over Marrakech for about 5 euros per person. This square is a must see in Marrakech, you'd be missing a lot if you didnt visit this place.
amazing by night. a very big square just common by day but by the end of the afternoon it starts to be very crowed and there is something to see everywhere around you

Quite a spectacle!. Noisy, bustling, the spirit of Marrakech. Loved the food stalls, although would be worried about buying there for fear of contracting "Marrakech belly". Lots of lovely tea lights in little glazed ornamental tagines. Don't like the animals on leads; animal cruelty charities haven't reached Morocco yet!

Fantastic place and culture but keep your wits about you.. I really enjoyed Jemaa el Fna but the people on the market and the street performers are very pushy and you should keep your wits about you. That being said it really is something you must see a really historic market and some fantastic food. I would also suggest the markets at the back but again you are likely to get hasseled if you do not look Morrocan/Local, also it's best to be with a couple of other people especially if you are a woman travelling alone.

Marrakech - Jemaa el Fna - A night to Remember. We visited Jemaa el Fna initially during the afternoon and although there were a few orange juice sellers and other stalls, together with a few locals attracting the tourists with snake charming and monkeys it all felt a bit of a damp squib after all we had been told. This coupled with the near forty degree heat left us a little deflated but determined to see if the place would liven up later in the evening. And liven up it certainly did.Two days later we set off for Jemaa el Fna once again but this time early evening to catch the sunset over Marrakech from one of the surrounding restaurant rooftops. This time we were not disappointed. Just before seven pm we made our way to the top level of the Hotel Restaurant Café de France. We had been recommended this place as the best to see the sunset over the city and watch the square come alive. Luckily we made the rooftop just in time to secure a table at the front and over the next hour or so the sun went down and Jemaa el Fna came to life. This was a truly wondrous sight to see from up above. The stalls expanded and just about the whole area was a wash with local vendors, entertainers and seemingly the whole population of the city. What a sight and what a way to see it. On top of the Café de France, although seemingly a little further away from the action than others, was looking directly at the sun as it descended and this gave us a brilliantly coloured perspective of the whole area. Later we then descended ourselves into the square where we never felt vulnerable or ill at ease. We wandered around the place taking in the activities, the street stalls, entertainers and the abundance of locals and tourists who were there to take in everything Jemaa el Fna had to offer. It was truly brilliant. My advice would be to get a rooftop facing where the sun goes down at about 6.45 pm ( this was September ) and watch the sun set and the square below change. Then head off into the melee below to enjoy one of the spectacles of Marrakech.

Comes alive at night. This is a must while in Marrakech. While it is a busy place during the day, it really comes to life at night filled with thousands of people. Would recommend having drink at one of the rooftop terrace watching the world go by and eating at the stalls (we ate at number 1). Just beware when taking pictures or even just watching all performers including acrobats, monkey handlers, snake charmers etc...as well as people wearing traditional costumes as nothing is free. Once they see you're looking you're paying!!!

Eat what local eats!. The food market itself dose not start until at least 6pm in the evening. Amazing food at the stalls and we ate many times there throughout our trip. The best stalls usually only have one or two people only outside holding their menus and they won't push you inside. One of the stalls at the connor (number 31?) was packed with locals buying takeaway and we had the best food there. The snail and soup are both worth trying and the orange juice is a must every night.

Marrakesh at night.... The square is a must see. I ate here most evenings i was in Marrakesh; at stalls 1 and 25...(more times at the latter) - it is the place for cheap food - yet tasty. A real atmosphere at night - a visual feast. Just keep a good sense of humour - don't let henna tatooists near you unless you want them to ink you...take photographs carefully or with permission ...If you get orange juice ask for plastic cups to keep your stomach safe:) For solo travellers - a great spot where you would never feel lonely.
Good, but was not able to be visited by the time I went. It was quite nice, but was not able to be visited by the time I went, so it was such a shame we could not get inside. Maybe next time

Chaotic paradise. Amazing place to see especially at night!Impossible to explain to others as its not just about the photos. It's all the sounds and smell as well.Go to a rooftop terrace to have some mint tea which seems to be a signature non-alcoholic drink and enjoy the views. Just a word of warning: Be careful where you look or you'll be followed by all the "lovely entertainers" demanding payment for you looking at them or taking pictures of them.
Square with many acts.... The square is filled with many acts like, snake charmers, henna ladies-go for the natural brown henna, monkey acts, horse and carriage ride-brilliant. Vibrant and bustling!

Beware of snakes!. Walk around here with purpose or you will get bombarded with Snakes, Monkeys and henna tattoos!Be confident with the but not insulting, I can recommend the fresh orange from the sellers on the square and spend a few hours of an evening in one of the cafe balcony's to spectate the wonders.An experience which you must take in whilst in Marrakesh.

Over rated. Views from restaurant terraces in the evening were good but over all, found the constant haggling by snake charmers, toilet guardians etc fairly tedious.Food was generally quite dull and did not meet expectations.

morrocain fast food. You must go to the famous square and try it.you will not be disappointed,the ambiance and food quality is quite amazing. Beware the extras that will be placed on your table but they ARE CHEAP.

Visit it during the day, but definitely again at night. Relatively calm during the day, but definitely comes to life at night. The open air entertainment is worth seeing, but expect to be hassled for money when you take videos or pictures.The Food Stalls cover a broad array of offerings, but be sure to trying the local food instead of the European / North American type of food - I liked both the meat from a smoked/roasted goats head as well as the bowl of snails.
Amazing!!. This place is simply amazing!! i have never visited such a lively place. The food... the atmosphere! Cannot wait to revisit

Go at night!. This square is like two different places day and night. During the day it is full of people going about their normal business but at night it becomes a frenetic, exotic place heaving with life, colour, sights, sounds and smells, snake charmers, berber water carriers, men with barbary apes on their shoulders, food stalls, stalls with all kinds of other goods and trinketry.... and crowds of people enjoying it all. If you are not staying in Marrakech, don't bother with a day trip as you will miss this. You must take a two day tour to have the night time in the square. Not to be missed.

Overwhelming. The square takes a few visit to get used to. Be aware of the snake charmers, henna ladies and the monkey keepers these are all con artists who wait for you to merely glimpse in their direction and them demand payment for nothing. Make sure to keep hold of your handbag or belongings as the square gets very packed and personal space is non existent. There are some lovely items available for sale however be sure to haggle and if possible do not purchase anything on your first visit be sure to check prices as it is easy to get stung by one of the hagglers. The horse drawn carriage looks lovely however the smell of the horses is enough to put anyone off and if it isn't the prices they attempt to charge will make you rather walk back to your hotel. If staying anywhere near the shops such as ZARA and MANGO do not pay more than 100 dirhams for two people to go in the carriage or maximum 15/20 dirhams for a taxi. Do not be afraid to haggle and tell the driver that you will go elsewhere if they do not agree on your price this tends to work most of the time.

The heart of Marrakech. This place is action packed at night....Tons of food stalls, Fresh squeezed OJ (ask them to give it to you served in a plastic cup) snake charmers and lots of good, cheap eats. The atmosphere here is buzzing with so much energy. Take a seat, eat some great food and enjoy the people watching!

Day or Night, A Must. The people, the food, the vendors, the story tellers, the snake charmers, the dancers..., all in all, the chaos that needs to be experienced.
You have not been to Marrakech, if you have not been to Jemaa el Fna.

A different world. You can't go to Marrakech without taking in the sights and sounds of the square, especially at night.
Found it quite disturbing to see very young children (5/6 years) trying to sell all sorts to tourists (single packets of tissues seemed very popular). There is evidence of extreme poverty if you care to look - very humbling

why we were in Marrakesh. After a day of exploring the rest of the city and Medina we anxiously awaited this experience. Our tour company, Around Morocco, had hired a guide for the day and split the day into two parts for us. The second part was for this time. Idir met us at our hotel and we walked toward the large square. It was still early and the multiple juice vendors were lined up on one side of the square serving lines of customers. The food vendors were setting up and telling us to come back for the "best food in Marrakesh". We watched the musicians and snake charmers. Be prepared to pay for the privilege of taking pictures of anything interesting. We found a rooftop terrace to choose a table with a view of the action. We did this fairly early and it was a good thing as it became standing room only in a short time. As the sun set the visions became more and more exciting. The many tall flames from the food stalls were mesmerizing. All of the music reached our ears in a mad jumble. The dancers became even more crazy. There were carriages carrying people into the chaos. The square was very crowded. This was everything I hoped for on my last night in magical Morocco.

Great food and lovely ambience. The best food in Marrakech can be consumed at the famous square if you ask me. The people are very friendly, you sit down with locals as well and the food is prepared in front of you. Great experience!

Women do not go alone or with only other female campion at night. The market center during the day was full of life of snake charmers and such but don't be scammed. Do not let the snake charmers put a snake on you because if they see you scared they will not take it off for anything less than 100 dh. You can rake as many photos as you like but have a 5dh in hand after your done for them and just walk away. At night, hundreds of people gather and it can be annoying when the food people harass you to eat there. If you do eat, just go to the busiest one and sit down. As a woman, I already did my research and knew what to expect but they took it up a notch. Being Asian I stuck out and might as well had a bulls eye on me. Everywhere was "hey Japan, konnichiwa, sexy (I always wore a scarf,pants and sleeved shirt). This was tiring and seemed to followed everywhere I went. I was touched a few times and that was when I had enough and shouted back for them to leave me alone in French. I heard there are uncovered tourist police but I didn't see their help.

Oh Wow! A must do!. Walk, look and eat!!! Amazing place to seize the vibe!!!! After a great walk into the old medina, go to Jemaa El Fna and loose yourself..Look, taste and enjoy this remacable place!! Food is great and cheap!! Of course waiters and sellers can be anoying but take it as a game and smile!!!

Very noisy, people try to sell things all of the time.. We have been seeing many great photos of the square. It is smaller than our expectation. Street food worth trying, but you have to be clear what you order as they always want to try make more money off you all of the time.25pounds for few plates of Moroccan food and is not very good quality either. Snakes or Hanna tattoo are things to avoid.

Spectacular. It's is sort of impressive during the day but after say 21.00 it is really amazing, try the local food and fresh orange juice etc. It sort of hits you in the face and not easy to decribe but please don't miss it!

Cheap local food. Really nice, local atmosphere for food. All food and drinks prices are standardized so there's no need to shop around. This market sells all types of Marrakech delicacies, from kebab, sausage, tagine, to snails, sheepskin head, sheepskin brain.Do not take photos of the street performers unless you are willing to pay... It's dodgey but that's their culture...

Nothing special. Worth a look if you're not afraid of crowds. There are many performers, but we didn't see any particular talent. Walk quickly to avoid drummers coming up and playing for you and claiming money - monkey trainers also. We didn't try the food from the stands so can't comment, but generally the people trying to get you into their food places were funny and polite - to them we all look "starvin' marvin'" :)

What An Experience .... The Sleepless Square. OK! you have to be very aware that each picture you will take, you will find someone asking you for money! Be very wise & smart when you are around the square, the beats of Genawa music beats up all day & night, the Snakes , the monkeys shows all around the square, the wooden artifacts, and clothes all over the place, you must try the orange juice by the square it cost 4 Drhs for 1, also you must try the dry fruits & nuts back there. the square can lead you to the old market which is can take up to 2 or 3 hours of your time, so be ready for it.I wouldn't recommend eating by the square it self however there are some beautiful restaurants around it and with a view to the square as well.

A microcosm of Marrakshi life. There is always something happening here.Freshly squeezed orange juice vendors, water sellers, musicians, acrobats, craft vendors, henna artists and that's before the place is taken over in the evening by the pop-up food bars.It's a melee at night and the night goes on well past midnight for locals and tourists alike.
All humanity. Very busy all the time. The main souks are here - wander in a little bit to avoid the touristy stuff. Excellent food can be got from street market from about 8pm, cheap and tasty.

A plethora of smells and sights to excite your senses. The medina is best seen from the grand balcony - restaurant to one side of the square in the early evening when the stall holders are setting up for an evening of dinner and entertainment.There is always something going on in this busy square, by day there are market stalls selling orange juice and nearly every other thing imaginable, with ladies sitting n the ground offering henna tattoos. By night the atmosphere changes and the square becomes even more alive, a plethora of smells and sights to excite your senses. From food stalls serving chicken, fish and beef kebabs, to snake charmers, dancers and a men with monkeys.Never a dull moment here. Make sure to go on a horse and carriage ride around the outside of the medina to take it all in in its entirety.

Has to be seen!. Went once whilst staying in palmerie area, it is certainly an experience and a must do in Marrakech. Once was enough for us everyone selling similar products vendors not exactly happy happy. Really didnt like monkeys kept in metal boxes squealing and snakes in tiny cages, some owners demanding £10 for photo! had seen same monkeys in wild couple of days earlier those were the lucky ones. Would imagine it was fantastic years ago but not now! Cafes that surround it not nice but sure there must be a little further afield.

Bonkers. The title sums up this square - it's literally bonkers & is a place we instantly fell in love with.We arrived during the peak of a hot summer's day to the rows of orange stalls dotted around, as well as the snake charmers, monkeys & water-boys. During this time, we mostly saw tourists milling around, having their pictures taken & taking it all in.By the time the sun sets behind the Koutoubia mosque, the place completely changes. People flock to the square (locals & tourists alike) to experience & be part of the unique atmosphere. Dozens of open-air restaurants are set up & smoke rises from the hot grills cooking lamb, kebas & seafood. Eating at one of these stalls is easy, grab a seat, wait for the menu, order, wait five minutes & enjoy. The whole experience is somewhat magical - there's nowhere else quite like it & it's amazing how it changes.We were hooked on the place during our two-night stay & ate here both nights. It's also worth getting up onto the terraces of one of the surrounding cafe's to take photographs & watch how it changes.This was without doubt, the highlight of our trip & the smells, sounds & sights more than make up for the hassle you might get from the locals wanting you to spend some of your money.

Tourist Trap!!. I always wanted to visit .... because of all the publicity this gets. But it is a tourist trap. The food at the stalls is awful, the worst food I have had in Morocco. Please skip this completely and save time and frustration. In one of the stalls where we ate, they overcharged a family from Germany, for things they had not ordered. They will just keep bringing plates to you so be careful and return if you did not order something. But the orange juice stands offer excellent orange juice, must try.For shoppers, Medina is a good place to stroll and pick up few items. Overall spend few hours here, shopping, drinking orange juice, but please please skip eating at the stalls, it is just awful!

Overwhelming, but necessary. I was not a fan of getting harassed at all sides by merchants, but walking through Jemaa el Fna was a necessary experience in Marrakech. I've never experienced anything like it and it was exciting and a little scary.
