Great fun but very busy. I really enjoyed Jemaa el Fna as it was full of fantastic sounds, sights and smells. It really feels like the heart of the city. However it is very busy and you have to be careful not to let anyone hassle you into taking photos after which they charge ridiculous prices. Have fun but be hard headed and don't let ANYONE hassle you into doing something you don't want to.

Crazy Jemaa el Fna!. The square itself is very big! Bustly, noisy and full of life! It just depends on whether you like that kind of thing. For us it was too hot, and we got out of the square as soon as possible I think it would would be much nicer in the evening, when it is cooler and there is maybe more going on.
Wow. An assault on the senses. Feels exhausing, overwhelming but exotic and exciting. A must do to tick off your bucket list.
nightmare. Total nightmare hounded constantly I felt very intimidated you will need a hard skin to keep saying no as they don't seem to like that

Great fun.. loved this place daytime and night! So much to see and take in. Dont go near the 7 Saints cafe. Lots of other places to sit and enjoy the sights and sounds. Loved the orange juice off the sellers. Lovely and fresh.

True Moroccan theme market. i liked this place,from the Arab style snake dances and random monkey shows while you walk around!lots to see and buy(although you will get ripped off as a foreigner of course),as a women men will throw lots of comments at you but nice anyway especially in the night time
Crazy but very interesting place!. It is a cultural experience! If you want to bargain, go there. It is big, dont get lost! You can't say you know Marrakesh if you dont go to the main square.

Great fun. Bustling and exciting, this is somewhere not to miss! We went to the night market and enjoyed a late dinner. We were careful to avoid the salad but the varying meats and bbq'd veg were delicious. Enthusiastic front of house would be an understatement!

The madness of Marrakech. The place Jemaa El Fna is mad but fun! During the day it is filled with loads of traders, henna ladies, dancers and other stalls. At night it fills up with food stalls, orange juice sellers, snake charmers, acrobats, dancers, men with pet monkeys and people who will sell you anything!The edge of the square is the souks on one side which draw you in with wares and goods to amaze, the other side goes off to the streets of the Medina. The horse carriages congregate here so always a good place to pick one up, but always agree your price first!We enjoyed two evenings by eating on high terrace restaurants and looking down over the square as the evening unfolds, it is a mass of people, bustle, trading, and energy.Be wary of your purse and wallet, although we had no negative experiences. Never allow a henna artist to take your hand as once pulled in they have you caught and will paint henna on your hand whether you want it or not and then charge you, even if the sentence begins, "free for you pretty lady"!As other reviews have stated nothing is free, whether it is advice, directions or holding their monkey/snake (whether you wanted to or not) so be wary. No thank you, non merci became well used phrases!The square is easy to find and is a great location for cash points, bureau de change, coffee and food. No trip to Marrakech would be complete if the square was missed out.

Wonderfully exotic but with too much pressure from vendors. When you first walk into Jemaa El Fna, especially in the evening as we did, it really is a mixture of excitement and trepidation of what to expect! The smells are amazing and the sounds of food vendors shouting just fill your head. The food from the stalls was very tasty and quite cheap. However, finding a place to eat can get a little stressful, as all the vendors are yelling at you to try and get you into their stall, and we found a few to be very rude when we declined their offers. I personally don't like the monkey on chains and snakes with venom removed, for the tourists to be photographed with during the day, and as charming as some of the little stores are with beautiful trinkets for sale, this was marred again by rude traders when we declined their services.A must see and do on a trip to Marrakech, and whether you love it or loathe it, you will remember it forever.

Night Market nothing like it!!. Truly a sight to behold. Atmosphere terrific. Loads of food stalls selling wonderful traditional Moroccan food, snake charmers, dancers and the souks and market stalls in the background. Just keep belongings safe as it is extremely busy and pickpockets are always about.

Nice but nasty. Not ever I really warmed to the area but do appreciate the history and culture displayed. The snake people seem to be crooks and crowded in to get a piece of the action when one of our group showed curiosity - they insisted on several hundred dirhams. Kids trying to force you to buy things and swearing at you if you don't. Keep your wits about you here and move on.

Hectic by nice. The Square was very hectic in the evening but was an exotic experience to attend some of the shows made by entertainers and acrobats. We had a drink in a cafe overlooking the arena and we took some fabulous shots of the sunset.

Every night is like a festival. I really enjoyed the square - at night it is worth a visit because the atmosphere is electric! However too many visits at night can be overwhelming, people trying to sell you things, snake charmers etc. If women come near you trying to henna you just walk away and be firm saying no! Similarly with snake charmers, they will try and put snakes around your neck, and then charge you to take it off - best to stay away from them!

Wonderful!. This is the heart of Marrakech! Be sure you will cross it several times during your stay! As classified by UNESCO this is the place where people and culture meets! Funtastic place to be at evening for dining and see cultural venues and of course have an orange juice!

Gat experience. Worth it at night. We went here for dinner and it was a great experience. The stall holders all try to get you in by speaking like Jamie Oliver. Very weird and amusing with lines like: it's pucka mate, there ain't no Primark ere luv! We chose stall 31 as we had read reviews. Probably the least touristy with locals eating there. Very cheap food prepared in front of you. Do it!

What can one say ?. This is probably one of the most over-praised attractions for a citytrip. Noisy but foremost full of pretty aggressive merchants whose only aim is to empty your pockets in no time. The only way to enjoy it is from a terasse in one of the café's around the place. Go when it's dark as the immense lights add something to the view.

A must at least once!. Drummers, acrobats, fortune tellers, snake charmers. it's been like this for hundres of years and is actually a UNESCO heritage sight. bring small change to give to the performers

Busy even at Ramadam. A hive of activity. Can be a little over whelming so if you are new to such places I would recommend you hire a guide or tag along with a more confident tourist. Battering is prevalent and watch for people putting stuff in children's hand. Mine kept tight little fists and were under strict instructions to not take anything from anyone.Is still and amazing place and definitely my favourite place in Marrakech.

Great experience. This is a bustling place at night, so full of atmosphere and smells. There are African bands, storytellers, lots of food places and many many stalls with oranges piled high. We also had a caleche ride through the Jewish quarter ending in the square. So much more to see when the souk is quiet. A must do if in Marrakech. Thanks morocco countrysidetours company for great tour

Locals. With all the stalls - there is only one which constantly packed - look out for this one. Nearly all the stalls are the same price and same menu....and all are safe to eat in. Enjoy the theatre as this is world herritage site and truelly a wonder.
Certainly an Experience. Despite being bothered from all angles by juice vendors, henna artists and monkey handlers, the main square of the medina is a must-go place for an tourist

Night & Day. This square is very different in the night time to during the day. It comes alive at night but gets very busy and crowded. One thing that remains consistent is the amount of motorbikes intent on running you over!

The Amazing Square. You can not miss Djamaa El Fna Square! It is quite an exciting place with lots of colorful water sellers, dancers, traditional musicians, henna painter, men with monkeys and snake charmers! BUT be aware, taking a photo with one of these guys will cost you money, money, money. Luckily we were with our guide so the visit were flawless..

Well worth visiting. You feel like the whole world is represented here. Worth visiting at night and during the day, for the contrast, leads into the souks. You can buy all sorts of spices, trinkets and food here, with locals and tourists all blending together.

Crazy! But fun.. Everything you could want and moreThis place is great for a daytime wander. Suck it up and haggle outrageously. However.. come back at night and it is simply incredible. Noise, smells and sights that will simply knock you for six first time.You cannot do Marrakech without seeing this spectacle. So find out for yourself. Only words of advice being. Just take care to guard against 'friendly' locals who want to give you directions, unless you want to part with cash (or have a row about not parting with cash after being followed for a bit).Enjoy.

Another world at night!. Do not miss having a wander round the square after dark! What an experience. The noise is unbelievable. So much to see and take in. Hard to believe it's the same place if you 've been there in the daytime. The roof top cafes and restaurants are the perfect places to watch the world go by at any time. The orange juice from the stalls is amazing - 40p for half a pint!

Nice site with good views. The site is so filled with activities, simply got indulged. I went with a group of friends and it was indeed fun to hang around with the monkey players and snake charmers. The nicest thing about Jemaa el Fna is the food that we had from the vendors. There was some exquisite kind of taste in the fried fish and kebabs that we had. It’s quite enjoyable with so much of hustle bustle, but you should always be careful about the pickpockets. On the whole, a nice place to chill out, especially in the evenings!

abit too much for me and the kids. lots of beggars ,my children got rammed by a little girl and a push chair then asked for money !!!! don't think so ,she then followed us around annoying us ,a little boy followed us asking for money,my 9 year old said no and it worked ,blonde apparently is good luck so adults touched the heads of my children often

Visit at Night. The Jemaa El Fna is the place you want to visit at night. It is a circus of side shows and shopping. It is in the square outside the Souks and you will be thoroughly entertained by all the goings on around you. Just make sure you dress down, don't carry any valuables with you and if you want to take pictures of what you see, make sure you have some Dirhams in your pocket because they will shame you into paying something for your photo. Everyone is trying to make a Dirham in this place so bring lots of change. With large crowds of people, tourists become easy targets for pick pockets so again, dress in jeans and a t-shirt and leave your valuables at home. No need for lots of money here. Everything is quite inexpensive.

amazing but so dirty. The square it so amazing and fun but very dirty . I wonder if all the monkeys are well taking care of...staying in small box all day long with such heat with a tiny window or on leash...very sad !!!!

history in modern times. Jemma el Fna is centuries old and full of modern as well as traditional life, from the vendors to the age old products of silver, perfumes, herbs, silks, ceramics, glassware, leather, carpets and more that they sell, to the life in the central square. This is an essential historic part of the Red City and not to be missed

Some tips for a great visit. The square is indeed chaotic- very fun and so much energy. Prior to coming I read many reviews about trouble people experienced on the square..we did not have any issues at all in the 5 days that we were in Marrakech. We had a great time people watching and exploring. I think this review is more about tips for the square...Yes, there are snakes and monkeys that are thrust at you in demand of money, but when you see them, simply walk around and they will not bother you. DO NOT take pictures (at least from where they can see you) unless you want to get shouted at..and if you do want to take a picture, simply ask! It's so easy to do but most people don't. If you do happen to want your picture taken with the snakes/monkeys/musicians/acrobats...whatever, negotiate a price BEFORE you start. In all our interactions in Morocco we found this is the only way to get a fair price. If you sit with the monkeys etc. and take pictures and then try to pay, they will demand silly amounts of you. We sat on a terrace and watched this fun for hours at a time. People handle this is so many ways. Be firm, but do not get angry when setting a price. The snake charmers come up to people and try to shake your hand and when they have your hand they put the snake around your neck. If you do not want this, but want to take pictures with the snakes, negotiate a price first and they will respect what you ask of them. Once you pay, you are their client and they are happy to let you get some really fun pictures. We saw many people negotiate a price first and they were not harassed with snakes around their necks. Same goes for the monkeys. We took tons and tons of photos without having to pay anything simply by asking first. The vendors will usually even smile and pull a pose for you :)The henna ladies will also try their charms on you- set a price in advance. I had one lady grab my arm and try to put henna on it while I was walking away..just keep walking... The food stall vendors can be somewhat aggressive in their tactics, but the best way to avoid this is to select a place to eat prior to walking down the center walkways, and just go and sit down. We tried looking at menus and viewing the food for offer, but this lead to the vendors pulling at us and demanding that we sit down. They seemed to put their hands on me to stop me from walking, but did not do so to my husband... it wasn't really aggressive, but be prepared for this. Stall #1 is excellent- we ate there twice. The staff speaks English (as well as Spanish, French...etc.), They serve you quickly and are honest and attentive. There are many, many things to buy on the square. You can get a reasonable price. If you want cheap souvenirs there are many set price shops with items starting at 10 dirhams. We got many little things in this way. For larger items, stand firm! Also, do not start negotiations unless you actually want the item. If you spend 15 minutes talking about the price, then walk away, it can lead to yelling. Some vendors will throw the item into your hands so you catch it, and then demand you pay...I just put the item nicely on the floor and said NO. As far as pick pocketing...we only met one lady who had been robbed- she left her wallet in the outermost pocket of her backpack, and left it on her back. If you have a bag, keep it zipped and carry it in front of you and there will be no issues. Use common sense!For attire- respect their culture, they are Muslim! While they are of course used to seeing tourists wearing all sorts of clothing, just remember that you are in their country and cover up a bit (ladies). They will try and touch you or say rude things if you are dressed scantily. Also, if you cover up a bit and want to wander through the local areas of town, you will feel much more comfortable and will get no hassle from the locals. If you want to eat at the restaurants off the square- look where the locals are and sit there. We ate at so many places and the best were found by following this advice. We went to a few with only tourists- worst meals of our trip. You can easily find harira (soup) for 15 dirhams, tajines for 30 and water (1 L) for 10. Cheap and delicious. A super great place to people watch is from the top of the hotel nearest the snakes (I will find the name and update this soon). There is a mandatory charge...just grab a drink from the cooler (they are 20 dirhams), pay, and grab a seat. We literally spent about 2 hours here a night. You will not get bored people watching. If you have a good lens on your camera, you can get really great monkey/snake pictures. It's a fight for the nice seats at the edge of the terrace overlooking the square- get there a bit before sunset for spectacular pictures and great seats. This review may make the square sound intimidating, but it's more cautionary advice. Please enjoy the place- it's unlike anything you've ever seen! Above all, do not let it stress you out and do not get angry. Stay calm and enjoy! My husband and I travel frequently around the world, and these are really good tips to follow.

Like Going Back in time, or to the City on the Planet Tatouine out of Star Wars!. Must be visited during the day time, and again at night time. Two different worlds. The day time is for the orange juice sellers (40 cents! 4 Diram for a glass of freshly squeezed and conversation to boot)...the monkey handlers, and a few snake charmers not afraid to roast in the sun. Children love this place. It's just a big circus of craziness, more in the early evening and at night where the variety of people coming and going is just impressive to witness. Locals head there to hear some types of story tellers, or make bets on things which are complicated to understand. Seems like it hasn't changed in hundreds of years - except for the cars and motorbikes which pass!

Chaotic Square. It is an extremely unique experience..Especially during nights the place turned out be a chaotic square where snake,monkey chambers are all around with traditional moroccan dancers..And smoke of the barbecus never ends on the top of the square with the orange lights of fruit tables..Wizards,fortunetellers,horse riders and lots of tourists from all around the world..Must visit place!

Got to be done!. Let's be blunt, this probably why you chose to come to Marakech in the first place and hence is a must for a tourist. I was a little disappointed. It was Ramadan and so during the day, it was relatively quiet. However, at night it comes to life - big time!i didn't eat there, although I met people who did and said the food wasn't that good or looked particularly well-cooked. I chose restaurants overlooking the mayhem and there was a couple of quite nasty disagreements between the locals themselves which was a little disturbing.Still, has to be done!

Good Experience. Good fresh food, all on display so just pick what you want them to cook. You do need to order a few dishes though as you don't get alot but for the price you can't complain. We paid about £15.00 for 4 drinks and about 5 dishes including camel spleen!
Chaotic. The center of the city. Everywhere you go you might pass the square. I personally didn't like it at all, because it's been fed by the tourists and everybody wants your attention.

Below expectations.... I heard soo many things about this square in books and recommendations that when I was there I got quite disappointed. Locals will assalt you with monkeys to take pictures (and then you must pay them), the orange juice (all the vendors looked the same) was pretty tasteless, although refreshing, and in general the square is dirty: your feet seemed to be glued... If this is the "local experience" I did not enjoy it.

Crazy but unmissable experience.. You cannot visit Marrakesh without experiencing the onslaught to the sights and senses that is Jemaa el Fna square! Visit during the day and you will find a completely different square to that at nighttime - I would recommend going at both times. Night time is when the madness truely begins... you will see everything and more; snake charmers, story tellers, monkey handlers, teeth pullers, water men, musicians, birds, henna ladies, horses, motorcyclists, sellers of all kinds... it gets very busy and I would recommend going up to a terrace cafe for a drink to soak up the atmosphere! You will be asked if you want to buy things pretty much constantly, and taxi drivers will drive up to you asking if you need a ride, but just smile and say 'no thank-you' and carry on walking. Every night is a different experience!! Be prepared if you are an animal lover, there are some sad sights here i.e. the monkeys pulled around on chains by their necks, donkeys loaded up too heavily, birds with wings cut.

Lively atmoshphere. Especially our kids loved it! All the life, all the noise, animals (apes, snakes), the smells.In every corner something new, and a beautiful henna drawing for my daughter.She was delighted! My son was happy, when he could touch a snake... He said, he wants to become snake chanter, when he´s grown up. Let´s see.For me and my husband, it was a little bit too much. But we had our reliable guide Younes from Desert Dream4x4, to guide us through all this organized chaos. This gave us a feeling of safety, otherwise I would have felt a bit lost, I have to admit. I don´t like too crowdy places (maybe because I´m from Norway).But as I said, our kids loved this place, and so it was definitely worth a visit!

Not to miss this Moroccan experience!. Great by day or night .... Prepare for an experience you will not forget in a hurry... By day ... Walk past fruit stalls and vendors ... Lunch at one of the many terrace cafe's .... By night ... A whole new experience ... Get prepared for the entire center of the square transformed into food stalls ... Eat and enjoy ! The lights... The sounds ... The hawkers ... Snake charmers .... Monkeys ... Fruits stalls ... Souks with everything under the Sun !!! Stroll and take it all in! It's an experience worth every minute! Unforgettable !!

Night time. Big square in the middle of Marrakech. It comes alive after sunset but there are still things going on in the day. Drinks stalls ( obviously no alcohol) cakes stalls, very good pastries in Morocco, snake charmers, monkeys on leads, henna tattooing, acrobats and musicians. Be prepared to be continuously hassled but just smile and say no thank you in French or Arabic.if you do not wish to buy. It is very dirty and smelly but that is just the way it is. There are a lot of beggars so take a lot of change as when you see them you will want to give to all. Everyone is very friendly and happy and it is a very safe place to visit. Only venture into the souks if you know you will be able to find your way out again. Great experience, not to be missed.

Crazy place but quite an adventure!. This square is relatively tame during the day. The orange juice stalls, the henna tattoo ladies and the guy with the monkey. Watch out for the guy with the monkey, by the way. I felt a little stalked by him at one point. The snake charmers will put the snake around your shoulders, try to take your picture and then ask for a ridiculous amount of money for the "privelege". I had one henna lady grab my hand and try to tattoo me but I pulled my hand back. I've heard of quite a few people getting a really bad rash afterwards. At sunset, the whole place transforms into a magical place. The food from the stalls is very good and very reasonable, if you choose the right stall (such as #26, for example). The square at night is a crazy experience but one you don't want to miss (watch out for pickpockets so you don't end up missing your wallet!) We spent a few nights dining on roof terraces at restaurants that overlook the square while we watched the whole thing as it's set up. We even saw a fight break out among the acrobats that were entertaining people. Tajines were thrown and a wicked looking knife was grabbed from a nearby sales stall. Thankfully, we were safely on the roof terrace at Les Premices. Don't forget to take one of the horse-drawn carriages for a nice, breezy tour of the city. Enjoy!

an assault on the senses. an amazing space, and a real assault on the senses. Probably the largest bar-be-que in the world. Freshly squeezed orange juice is cheap and refreshing, and food from open stalls is very cheap. Be careful of being ripped off by either the snake charmers or monkey keepers. Be careful of pick-pockets, but don't be afraid, there are pleanty of plain-clothed police around to protect the tourists. Visit it morning, afternoon and evening to get an ever-changing diorama.

Nuts lol but amazing. Top tip, if your eating in the square at a stall, eat from 1 to 10 as they have been their the longest, I ate at no1 and had the mixed grill and was very pleased, especially the sausages, will visit again

The best sight to see. A dazzlingly spectacle every night. Try to be out late, say around 11 pm. We ate food from the vendors and had no problems. There are beggars and people trying to sell you trinkets, tissues, etc., but you can easily (but firmly) tell them "No" and be fine. When you're finished watching, you can take a horse drawn carriage for a ride around the city and outside the wall. We went multiple nights and had fun each time.
Fun Souk. We were there during Ramadan so a bit quiet then normal but still very hustle bustle and fun to watch the world go by! Must sit in an outside café!

Night life in Marrakech. What a place! Especially in the night, you don´t know where to look first (always be aware of your own purse and bag). There is so much going on, it´s almost - but not really - too much for the eyes and senses. We went there several times during our stay in Marrakech.We had just finished our tour with Desert Dream4x4, our great tour operator, now we wanted to explore the city, and see it´s heart beating - Djemaa el Fna.Definitely one of the most important spots in the city! But not one of the most quiet...We were taken by the noise, the masses of people, the lights and many things to see.And then fled to one of the restaurants, to relax with a cup of tea....

Interesting!. Monkeys, snake charmers, storytellers but don't you dare try to take a picture unless you are willing to pay. I love sitting on the terrace of one of the cafes and just watching all the people go through this square. Taxis cost a bit more in the evening 30 dirhams, instead of the daytime price of 20 dirhams...not a big deal.
Eat the street food!. Watch out for the snake charmers, and go in the night to eat the wonderous foods they set up. I loved Marrakech and you will as well.

Highlight of Marrakech!. Wonderful! We stayed 5 minutes walk from the square, so saw it at many different times. During the day it is much quieter, and there are only orange juice stalls and henna ladies. We returned every night for dinner (31 was our favourite), and to see the sights: story tellers, snake charmers, dancers, boxing! Can also try the snails and sweets (one of every sweet on the tray for 30 dh)!It is very crowded and smokey, but everyone was nice and we had no trouble (nb we are very obviously student backpackers).Can't wait to go back!

Crazy!. I loved the chaotic nature of the market, especially at night. There are hundreds of people milling around; horses and carriages, donkeys and carts, mopeds and bicycles vying for right of way and all this to the backdrop of stalls selling vibrantly coloured spices, fresh fruit and fruit juices; steam rising from the temporary restaurants within the market and groups of drummers each playing more loudly than the next! Amazing!

Part circus, part street food fair. During the day you will see lots of street performers, snake charmers, monkeys, ladies who will paint henna on your hands, musicians and dancers, drummers, etc. Lots of fun but be wary of some of these people. Always remember they are out for your money. Don't take pictures unless you are willing to pay for whatever they are hawking.At night all the food vendors come out and cooking smoke fills the air. You can get everything from grilled goat heads to snails. Our guide told us to only eat things you see are on the grill and not to get things like tagines and couscous. There is also a very good souk (market) attached to this that we enjoyed.

The heart of everything. Keep your wits about you as henna ladies reach for you, monkeys chatter, snake charmers make their music and motor bikes whiz by.Definitely a must-see. Experience it on the ground, observe it from one of the restaurants ringing the plaza, and see it as things come to life in the morning, through the day, and into the night. I'm guessing someone has done it already - but I would love to see a time lapse photographic series - maybe every hour on the hour.

Kind of magical place!. I loved this place! Spending time over there at anytime of the day was great! It´s a mix of cultures, local people and others from everywhere gathered at the same place. Nothing like have an orange juice from the vendors around the place, seeing snake charmers, monkey handlers and acrobats and grabing something to eat from one of the food stalls... We had the best nights eating at the stall number 12, service was great and food even more, the server Hassan make us feel very welcome but I must admitted all of them were fantastic... The ambience of this square is amazing... To sum up, it is a place that everyone must visit in Marrakech! The only thing you must to do is to arrange the price of a henna tattoo before they start to do it, otherwise they will charge a very big amount...

No. 14 !!!. If your looking for a cheap fish dinner then try No.14. There's not a lot of choice but they service is efficient and the food is fresh. We tried No. 1 after reading some of the TA reviews and were so disappointed we went back to No. 14. You can tell its popular because it is always busy and the locals eat there.

Same food, lots of hassle. Every stall here is selling the same thing at the same price. But you just get hassled like crazy that it's not even fun.They try to rip you off too. They will place what appears to be a free plate of bread and dip then charge your for it afterwards (even after we asked if its free). They will add things up wrong too.Say no to the "free bread" and total up on paper what it should cost (you need to show them the maths).Yeah it might be cheap, but it casts the view in your mind of Moroccans just being rip-off merchants. They should differentiate their menu, charge different amounts and properly compete with one another.

Great Place to Visit!. I would say the best time to visit the square would be at night time. The food stalls brings an atmosphere that makes the square alive buzzing! There are so many varieties of food, spoilt for choice!!

Chaos, but you have to go. The most famous landmark of Marrakech. Chaotic but a 'must see'. Fresh squeezed orange juice from one of the many vendors is worth trying. Snake charmers, monkeys, hawkers, horse drawn carriages, they are all here. The place comes alive at night with food stalls and crowds. The souks lead off from the square. There are several cafés and restaurants all around, of varying prices and quality.

Overwhelming. This square is so overwhelming, especially by night. The streets around the square are always crowded, just like the square itself. It really is an experience, just to walk over the square. There is so much to see, to do and to buy. I would definitely recommend to have dinner at one of the stands. The food is great, the atmosphere is great and it's really cheap. Top it off with some pastries and a fresh orange juice and just enjoy the fuss at the square.

Alive and crowded!!!. Dare to walk all over the ambient square Jemaa el Fna, dare to lost your way in the hundreds of souk of the local market, dare to have an orange juice from the locals, dare to dine in the restaurants at the middle in long tables with everyone around you, melting different cultures and ethnicities... but don't you dare not to walk around and discover this unique place. Moroccans are harmless and they respect you as much as you respect them so you do not have to worry for anything...

Mad Marrakech. I love Marrakech. It's mad, but that's the charm. Don't forget to pack your sense of humour, and keep your spirits high.Sure, you get bothered, but keeping a smile on your face is the best response.After you've been through the souk (market) they get to know you, and they can be quite funny.I buy my grapefruit or orange juice from a different vendor every day - also my nuts and dates, so I make friends with them all.I love the spiced tea and spice cake every evening, after my meal.Just don't let the ladies grab your hand and start painting henna before you agree to have it done or agree on a price.Sometimes I call it 'running the gauntlet.'

Moroccan Cultural Immersion. This square can be exhilarating and terrifying at the same time, but in a good way of course! There are so many people here in the evening, especially on a Sunday night and there are really no rules to this place. OK, there probably are, but with what we saw I'd say you're in for an interesting experience. Food vendors set up in the evening and we had wonderful vegetable, lamb, and chicken kabobs. The smell is amazing. We brought some ion for our stomachs and luckily we didn't get ill! While sitting there two Moroccan men got into an argument and started trading punches. Other than that it was peaceful. You'll hear the standard music, drums, and storytellers. You'll see the snake charmers, monkey wranglers, and henna tatoo swindlers. I say swindler because she swindled my wife out of 200 dirhams. It lasted only a few days. Also, beware of the musicians and charmers, if you have our camera out (not evening snapping a photo) they will think you took a photo and actually chase you around the square for a tip (cough fee cough), just as one did to me (hint: take a video of the madness from the safety of a restaurant's balcony). Around the square you'll find some of the more established restaurants, but some can seem a little too touristy, even if the food is phenomenal. We used a restroom in one of the restaurants; just order something like a drink or snack. Although we felt slightly weird being dressed in western clothes, we still wore pants and covered our shoulders to be respectful of the local culture, but we saw everything from shorts and flip flops to full burkas, so anything goes. Near the end of the square is the Koutoubia Mosque and the opposite end houses the famous souks. Get lost in them, that is the point! Go to Marrakech and enjoy, it's safe (except for one day in 2011)!

Just an amazing experience. Marrakech is, in itself, a culture shock for westerners. The colours, the smells, the food and the people all make this colourful city an experience of a lifetime. Taste the fresh oranges, nothing like it in the UK, the fresh nuts and fruits are just amazing. Be careful of the pick pockets.

Scary, rip off and over rated. After many good reviews I expected to see great things but first of all Morocco in General is over rated, is dirty, insecure and not much to see. In the market there more than half of the things made in china, those things you can buy anywhere in the world and cheaper. Sellers harassed you to buy and the always try to rip you off with the change. There nothing special to see unless the people begging for money! My best advice stay away for Morocco. South of Spain has better Arabic things to see in Andalucia and lot safer:)
Don't go alone as a female. It would have been SO much better had I not gotten followed and bothered so much. It made me sad I couldn't enjoy the spectacular views, smells, and entertainers.

don't skip it, but don't linger. Let me preface this by saying I think that everyone who goes to Marrakech absolutely must go to Jemaa el Fna. It's crazy, and you'd be crazy not to witness the craziness.On the other hand, it's crazy. From the moment you step onto the square (and possibly before) you are likely to be absolutely accosted by tons of buskers. People will do a little dance, put a hat on your head, and expect money. People will come up behind you and put a snake on your back, then expect money. When watching a show on the square, people will act like they are taking money for the performers but, in reality, they are just keeping it for themselves.I also found the shows to be rather boring. Some dudes beating drums and hollering. A Moroccan Ron Jeremy lookalike screaming at crippled people until they walk. Ladies trying to read your fortune. Etc., etc., etc.When you go bring a lot of 1dh coins! Often that is the only way to get people to leave you alone, and if you respond "I don't have any money" they are not likely to believe you, even if it's true.

Great vibe. The square is full of activity. There are snake charmers, ladies wanting to do henna tattoos, monkeys in nappies which I didn't like- everyone just trying to get your attention for some dirhams. Obviously whoever you have a photo with wants money. Don't let them talk you into giving more than they deserve. The markets are good and you can bargain with people. It is different by night when the whole square comes to life with food stalls. If you get the opportunity try both day and night as it is a different vibe. Obviously watch out for pickpockets there like any place especially when in crowds, we had people that would come and feel our back pockets in a crowd to see if we had anything in there and I saw some children running with a camera. Overall though, it's a great experience

Must do. An absolute must do in Marrakech - definitly watch the sunset over the Medina in a rooftop cafe. We found the Jemaa el Fna most enjoyable at night when it was cooler, so get there around 8pm-9pm, the souk closes about 10pm but the night entertainment goes on until 1am

Hustle and Bustle. I really do love Jemaa el Fna, I pretty much went every night we were in Marrakech just recently from sitting on the rooftop bars watching the sun set go down to just wondering around on the square seeing all the crazy sights. It helps to be able to shrug off a few pestering people but all in all its a great experience, just stay away from the monkey and snake people (they will throw them at you and then expect money for the privilege of being attacked) also if you try and take a picture of anything in the square, be prepared to tell someone who may not have even been in the picture to leave you alone as they all want money.Get over the fact that everyone is trying to swindle you and you will have a great time taking in the sights and sometimes lovely/sometimes putrid smells.One last word of advice, if people try and lead you somewhere, think twice before following them as they will lead you somewhere you don’t want to go which will probably involve asking for money along the way.

Main Square of Marrakesh busy and exciting!. There is so much going on here that you just need to experience it for yourself.Thursday night appears to be the business night.You will experience everything from Snake Charmers to Restaurants. Keep your back packs close as a friend had her backpack grabbed and stolen by a guy on one of the many motorbikes which roll through the area.
Treat for all of the senses. You will see things which you never imagined, and it is a treat for all ages. The food, animals and sights have to be seen to be believed!

Total experience, especially late at night. This place comes to life after dark - that is the time to be in the square and experience it. The food stalls are OK (but care as not all have a great standard of Hygene - stalls and were recommended to us as being safe). A fun thing to do is get a Cinammon Tea from one of two stalls between the food and the entertainment. For just 6 Dhm you can have a lovely spicy drink that just adds to the experience

Strange traditions!!!. As a group of single women we were surrounded by men which was most uncomfortable and this behaviour in the UK would result in them signing a register!!! They did eventually take NO for an answer but my tip is to be firm with them!!

Interesting main square. Maybe because it was Rammadan, but during the day it was quite quiet, coming to life in the evenings. Freshly squeezed orange juice for 4Dir (35 pence) a glass was a reason in itself to return

A center of Marrakech by all means. The square is surrounded by endless labyrinths of bazaars and alley-ways covering all of the Medina. There is always something to see at the there day or night: snake charmers, acrobats, sooth-sayers, musicians and food stalls. At night the square really comes to life as people navigate toward the exotic aromas and the entertaining sights. The exotic music appears louder and more hypnotic. For more information visit alextravelblog.com

Hectic. This is a busy place. It awakens early evening . The food smells great but be warned there is no running water so hygiene might not too good and you are hassled by waiters wanting you to eat at their stall. Motor bikes, cyclists, handcarts and donkey carts all mingle with pedestrians. amid stalls selling flowers, household items, fruit, orange juice and spices. It is noisy. There are monkeys on strings, mutilated cobras being charmed or not as the case may be; water sellers vying for trade to get their photograph taken and dancers, drummers and henna artists. Some people will love it and others like me might like the experience but not want to go too often. However, it did feel safe enough. There was no visible signs of policing and no trouble. There was also no alcohol, just groups of men, women and children and tourists having an interesting time.

No snake charmers (shame!) but loads of great banter. We spent an evening here, starting at about 7.45pm. We ate at a restaurant, sitting on their terrace high above the square. We wandered through the stalls and had brilliant, funny conversations with stall holders whose English was amazing. The combination of people watching from the terrace and being part of it all before and after was fabulous.
Most amzing place on earth. What can I say - love it - a constant changing cabaret from afternoon to 3AM . Take a pew anywhere around the square and just sit back and take it all in.

Tourist hub. This square is two faced. During the day it most contains sedate orange juice sellers and the like but at night it truly comes alive with all sorts of questionable people and sights. The whole area is transformed into hundreds of little restaurants with lots of banter and noise and crowds of people each being treated to a memorable experience. Remember to bargain hard, be aware that everyone there is out to make money from the tourists whether by legal or other means. A magnet for pickpockets for the unwary. Relax and drink a mint tea at one of the roof top cafes and watch the scene unfold.
The square. Totally enchanting, just watch for pick pockets and don't let the locals harass you. A firm NO Thank you is good and they leave you alone

Dirty but lively. Generally an unattractive place, with horse manure and rubbish everywhere. Expect to get lots of hassle from Orange juice vendors, food vendors, beggers, snake charmers etc. Also, many pickpockets in this area. The atmosphere in the evenings, however, is quite enjoyable.

Best food on our trip. If you get in the spirit of things the square is great for eating. It's cheap and lively and the people have some top class banter. We recommend 31 for the sausages and 55 for everything else. Our tip: they will bring you bread and olives at the start but these aren't free. Also once you've seen the menu you won't see it again so bring a pen to jot down what you ordered so there can be no debate when the bill comes! Also: the cake trolleys that go round the square are great value and really tasty.

you will find everything there. you will find everything there, go early bc u will get lost if u want to be adventurous bring water some negotiation skills. if u are looking for argan oil don't buy it there go to the county side if you have time

Especially when it gets dark !. You cannot visit Marrakech without going to Jemaa el Fna and I would especially recommend this when it gets dark and you take part in the buzling and special atmosphere surrounding this place. Taking a photograph, any photograph, you'll surely attract some local asking for money. That's why they are at the Jemaa el Fna with their monkees, snakes, storietellers and an incredible number of fresh fruitjuice vendors. The advantage of going there when it gets dark is that it's easier to look around unnoticed than during the day.

Highlight of the trip. Nothing like the buzz and atmosphere of the square and the surrounding roads. Lots of people selling things, but not too pushy - you have to be firm if you're not interested but everyone was friendly

Great Fun. So atmospheric! During the day, the square is a mass of orange juice vendors, people selling random stuff, and taxis, mopeds, bikes and horse-drawn carriages. Keep your wits about you, else you may find yourself having to jump out of the way quickly! Sit at one of the restaurants around the square, and just soak it all in with a soft drink (no alcohol). Just before sunset, get a front seat at one of the roof terraces, and just watch the square change from day to night, accompanied by the calls to prayer echoing out from the mosques as the sun goes down. Definately try one of the street market food stalls - there are rows of them, and the prices seem to be set - so just pick the vendor that makes you laugh the most with his promise of 'Jamie Oliver' cuisine, 'air-conditioning' and a round of applause when you sit down! We ate there twice, and the food is filling and cheap. If you want to take a picture of the snake charmers, do make sure you pay him for taking a picture of his cobra or snake, otherwise he will get a bit aggressive with you. And ditto with the dancing monkeys if that is your thing.

Day and Night in the Djemaa El-Fna. Make sure you hit this market both during the day and night because it's a totally different scene depending on what time you're there. You'll feel like your on a movie set, so many cool things to see: snake charmers, performing monkeys, henna tattoos. But please know, if you take any photos, you must give a little money to those performers, it's how they make their living.
Buzzing. Everything is going on here in the evening, just fascinating. The only down side are the annoying scooters, seem to miss you but only just.

Buzzing. Everything I expected Marrakesh to be was this. Snake charmers, dancers, haggling. It was Ramadan and in the evening was full of Moroccans enjoying themselves. So friendly. Ate a meal at one of the stalls in the market for £12 for two and enjoyable.
Happy Madness. This is only a short walk from Riad Hayati and is the center of Marrakech. Drummers, acrobats, fortune tellers. It's been the same since ancient times. Unique in the world.

Spend the time.... It is worth taking more time than you think you need to in this remarkable square - though you will be accosted by persistent locals hawking food or goods, this is all done in good spirit. We were warned about people who draw you in and then demand lots of money, so were careful to always decline invitations and approach on our terms. How could kids resist a snake charmer? I approached one and asked some questions, then said we would come back. Rather than focussing on the "snake show" we talked about them first - where they came from, what role the charming played over time, what types of snakes they used, etc. Only then did we watch the snakes, and the men were so nice we got a highly entertaining cobra-strike on video. We spent a good 20 minutes with the men, and paid them handsomely (for them, not us) for an unforgettable family experience. We all agreed - take the time in Jemaa el Fna.

Organized chaos - a must do!. We wandered through the streets at sunset the night before Ramadan to see all that the square had to offer. While slightly overwhelming at first as there are thousands of people crammed in to one area, you can eventually see that all of the vendors have their own place to be. In addition to the number stalls, there are a variety of people (entertainers, artists, animal charmers, etc) who bring a stool or blanket and sit in the same spot each night. The food vendors seem to sell all the same thing for the same price. They have their most charming workers in front of the stalls, trying to persuade you to eat at their booth. Most have mastered a few tag lines in English - we selected our stall based on the funniest line we heard. Stay away from soup and salad, especially during the summer months, as they are most likely to spoil in the heat. Question what your waiter offers/brings you, as many times they place additional plates (olives, french fries, eggplant patties) in front of you, regardless of what you ordered, and then demand that you pay for them at the end of the meal. Be cautious when standing near the snake charmers, monkey men, musicians, and henna ladies - the majority of them will demand payment for observing of photographing them. This is how they make their living, so are very good at making sure they collect from you =)There is a public bathroom available near the police station (across from the alley where the horse and carriage line is). A man sits at the bottom of the stairs to collect the fee (1 Dk, I believe). Be prepared this is NOT a Western bathroom...I was shocked to open the stall door and find just a squatting hole. It was an eye opening encounter and made me appreciate even more all the luxuries I have at home. We were so fascinated by the square that we returned the next two days, both during the day time and after sunset. If you don't like crowds, loud noises, bartering, then this is not the place for you. But if you want to see what it is like to blend in with the locals, then you wouldn't want to miss this!

Quite an experience. We found this market after being accosted by one of the locals and taken to a berber to buy a rug.The square comes to life at sunset. we took a coffee in one of the cafes at the edge of the square and people watched for a while. we ate at stall 117- lured in by the waiters who will say 117 takes you to heaven! They recommended we try a little of everything- vegetables, couscous, kebabs, lamb chops, fish, calamares, prawns, and chips! Reasonable at 300 dirhams- we could not eat it allWatch out for the womenwho grab your hands and put henna on- need to be very firm.Plenty to see and sense. We visited during Ramadan watch the people go to pray at sunset- truly fascinating.
Like a constant fair ground. Best way to enjoy is to get a rooftop restaurant and sit in the terrace, enjoy your meal and just observe.

Crazy manic Marrakech. Having arrived at our Riad Anyssates we were keen to experience Marrakech immediately!!...possibly unwise in the darkness as negotiating our way back through the myriad of lanes was an experience in itself!! However armed with our trusty map...shame we can't map read!! We venture forth and finally find our way to the main square having been put off course a few times by locals after a quick dirham by being your guide! A ploy fellow travellers need to be aware of!.....once there though it was amazing, I felt like I had time travelled to another century! Buzzards yes buzzards on leads, snake charmers, painted ladies, fire eaters! Your wildest imagination can lose its self here....also unfortunately your pocket with the constant harassment to buy tacky goods and food...but hey surely that is all part of the experience......enjoy the moment....
the square. scary be carful and have tour wits about you dobt hold your hand out as ladies grab it and put henna tattoos on which scar and cost you £20 hold on to your bag wear no jewellry

Jemma el Fna. The main square in the centre of Marrakech is a fabulous experience, it is a genuine eye opener, from snake charmers to local artists and everything in between.Best visited at night on Friday or Saturday for the best experience, amazing.
good in small doses. be prepared for the hard sell...kids with ballons, monkeys, snakes, acrobats. It's chaos but good fun.

full of everything. First, take some pictures with the local water sellers and with the singers gnaou. than, buy the delicious fresh orange juice and give a walk around. after you will be tired of so many beggers and seeing so many...everything, eat some cactus fruit, than sit down at the terraces-roof cafes and enjoy the best tea in the world-Marrakech Tea.
amazing market. very busy. best time to go is after sunset. its mainly a night market. the food is cheap. loads of entertainment snake charmers and monkeys :), henna. loads of fun.

Amazing- Its a must day or night!. FUll of horse drawn carriages during the day, but I would recommend sitting in a Cafe roof terrace (get there around 6pm grab a drink and watch as the jemaa el Fna changes into a night time street food market) Amazing and the roof top terraces get very busy from 7 onwards.Food stools 1 and 91 are really really good! All the food seems the same listed but Stall 1 spinach was amazing and spicey. Just be warned of all the hassle you will get to try and pick a food stall but by saying you remember their number and you will pop back later seemed to work.. although it feels very repeative after the 10th time! Its a must day or night

too crazy for me. Each to their own, This is def a place worth visiting but personally too much for me. good for shopping if you don mind he smoke from the food stalls or the constant harassment of vendors.

Amazing atmosphere!. Go in the late afternoon, find a seat in any of the rooftop cafes and just watch the square come alive! You might have to buy a drink or two to get that seat but it is well worth it.The snake charmers, storytellers and monkey performers will slowly make way for the night market. Try a glass of orange juice from the numerous stalls or get lost in the medina. Mostly touristic stuff and souvenoirs. Be careful who you take photos of as some street performers and stalls might ask for a tip! Unfortunately, i did not stay late enough to try any of the food from the stalls. But there's always next time!

Lovely week in Marrakech. This is where everything happen.A desert in the early hours of the morning and a crowd in late afternoon.You have the snakes, the monkeys, the traditional musicians, and all the street vendors.And don't forget to try the local cuisine.

smelly. Hyped up and very disappointing - the sewers were being worked on so it was really smelly and the place was full of horse droppings and pee and on a hot day wasnt that nice! The souks were good but it was just constant hassle from people asking if they can help you and showing you the way if you looked lost - all for money of course! Glad we saw it but we were very disappointed and enjoyed the new town rather than the old town much more

Overrated. This one is fine, but I thought the medina and souks in Fez were 10 times better! I paticularly enjoyed the tannery factory, which was the highlight of the medina, in my opinion. In addition, I like combing the small alleyways, as opposed to the big open area here as I think you're much more vulnerable to pickpockets here.

Don't hang around. It's vibrant, yes. You can buy all kinds of random items, watch snake charmers and monkeys, get a henna tattoo. However, most of the street traders are extremely rude and demanding. Avoid conversations if possible. One artist manhandled us, squirted a henna tattoo, and then demanded money. If you look foreign, you will be heckled. Be warned.

energetic market. so many orange juices, but grapefruits better i think, night time about 20-30 food stalls serves only 2 types of food, 1 is kebab, fried fish, grilled veg etc, and the other is beef and its brain.. i love warm night with market but to be honest not that special.

Unesco World Heritage site. Full of forceful street traders.. I can't see the culture behind monkeys on chains being kicked, snakes with their fangs pulled out, horses pulling carriages that are poorly treated, street artists trying to squirt henna tattoo's on you, others trying to pick pocket you < apparently that is classed as culture, vendors shouting at you as you walk past, pushing you into their makeshift restaurants and repetitive shops. One good point; Great place to see satellite dishes if you've never seen one. There are hundreds on the buildings around the square, if you like satellite dishes?? No. Well that's about it.
Get a guide. Great to go and see rage different way they live. Go and see the dentist. Be aware of the begging children. Def go with a guide

Dirty and trapped with ripoffs. We stood shortly in this square, amidst a chariot round. It is full with vendors, women reading hands, other wmen taooing henna, snake enchanters and monkey players.We stood by a serpent spot, they greeted us and offered the snake to be held by ourselves, We asked how much it wasm and they said n Frech (don't worry, pay as much as you want". Not really, after all the snake functions, I pulled a 20 dirham bill to give them and a guy demanded firstly 100 euros, then 20 euros, in a very aggressive and intimidating way. I had to be equally aggressive and intimidating, threw by dirham bill and waled away. No need to tell how much one gets upset after a ripoff trial.On top of that, found the place dirty and ugly. It may have hed some originality in the past, today it is little more than a ripoff spot forme.
Exciting after dark. Don't miss an evening visit and take plenty of small change. Take your time to choose a good place to eat.

Markets. What a place - day or night makes no difference, so much to see. The roof top bars around the square make a great place to watch the world go by. No evening visit to the square is complete until you have eaten from the vendors, we had such fun talking to them all while we tried to make up our minds where to eat

Not for the feint of heart. The main square of Marrakech, Jemaa el Fna, is the place to be. The square starts getting lively around 8pm, when the heat of Marrakech is finally bearable. There are the notorious snake charmers (actually pretty lame) and monkey men (kinda cool from a distance). Bear in mind that a picture with either of these animals will cost you a pretty penny if you don't negotiate a price ahead of time. There are also the rows and rows of 4Dh freshly squeezed orange juice carts. All of the juice is pulpy and delicious, very refreshing on a hot day in Marrakech. And finally, there's the hundreds of food stalls.Some tips for food stalls:-ask if the bread and olives/sauce costs extra (it usually does and this is where they try to make their money)-look at the prices on the menu ahead of time; know how much your bill will be-problems with the food are rare, but be wary of undercooked chicken and fish that has been sitting in the sun all day-lastly, have some fun! The stall owners are always funny guys who love their customers. Stay long enough and he'll be insisting that you have mint tea on the house, followed by pictures with the stall owner.Jemaa el Fna is a place to have fun. Be friendly to the market people and your experience will be pleasant.
Just what I hoped it would be. The main square in the Medina was just as I hoped it would be - the day fairly sedate and the night wild and un-European. Great fun

Fresh orange juice:). If you are in Jemaa el Fna, you should be aware of everything you may meet. You can watch a monkey show, snake show or you may give your hand to women making henna. When you visit the souk and the streets of Jemaa el Fna you learn how to drive a hard bargain. People treat us so friendly in Marrakesh, miss you.

Worth the visit, but be aware!. We wandered to the Jemaa el Fna after dinner at Pepe Nero. It was every bit as chaotic as people say. There were dozens of orange juice stalls- we didn't eat anything or drink anything here, snails, men with twirling hats and googly eyes, mean henna women, drumming and singing, fluorescent toys thrown at us, men with monkeys and lots and lots of local people. We felt a little out of place wondering around, but weren't bothered too much. I have a pretty solid, stern "no, don't talk to me face" when approached by merchants. No henna ladies tried to tattoo my arm, but the monkey men did get awfully close to us with their monkey's hands which we didn't like at all. That required a very stern NO and dirty look not to touch us with their monkeys! We tried to enjoy the drumming and the music circles that all of the locals enjoyed but as soon as they saw us, 6-7 rows back, the immediately approached us and asked for money. Even if we weren't apart of the circle and just standing nearby, we were scolded for not giving money. One group was a lot of fun to watch, had teenage boys in the center dancing away to this wonderful beat. We listened for about 10 minutes, then were quickly approached by a stern faced man demanding money. If he didn't demand and expect us to pay we might have reacted differently, or given more than we gave. We were surprised by the organization of this square. Every type of merchant had their own spot, food merchants in one spot, soap/oil sellers lumped together and drumming and singing in one corner. Overall, it is worth a look but watch out for those monkeys!

An amazing experience. Went twice. The first time was in the afternoon about midday. Was quiet outside but inside was extremely busy. Great atmosphere but with the heat you can see why people wait til night. Do get hassled a lot but its all part of the experience. Everyone is very friendly.In the evening the place is magical. Filled with hundreds of people, so if with small children best to keep them close. Theres food, more stalls and the restaurants are divine.People are amazing, really great atmosphere and experience. Remember to haggle.Also, horse and cart carriages are all parked nearby so great way to go home after shopping.

Beware of certain food stalls. This square is often crowded and chaotic. There is a police presence but we still feel we were targeted by pickpockets. Their food may look good, but some of the food stalls were quite deceiving - they gave us more dishes than what we ordered; and not only they refused to admit their mistake, they still forced use to pay the overcharged bill. The food was mediocre. The tea stalls were good though - we tried the mint tea and the cinnamon tea (the latter was very strong) and it was a quite unique tasting experience.

Busy and an experience. This definitely changes at night and comes alive. The snack bars and restaurants around the place are all 'dry' and only sell pop and tea etc, so not like I would usually expect to sit with a beer people watching, you need to go further a field for a beer.Watch out for the forceful and aggressive henna sales ladies - they are bigger than some men, grab your arm and pull out a henna syringe! they attack your arm with henna and make you pay! Its black henna too which some say gets into your blood stream - they scared me a little and to be honest I was at the point I may have punched one of them if they'd tried it with me!We didn't try the OJ in the square but apparently its raved about - make sure it freshly squeezed and not just squash!

You should see it, but in fact nothing special. We have been to Marrakech last summer, and we went to the Djemma el Fna square. The square should be a scene from Thousand and one nights, but in fact it was just a square. Yes there were stands to have dinner, but there were also really anoying woman, which took your hand and start painting on them. If you refuse to pay them, they became extremely unpleasant. We even saw a young couple in a fight with two of them. On the sides of the square are some pretty good restaurants with a great view at the square. Be carefull with the change you receive back after you paid. They try to rip you off everywhere you come.
It is what it is. You either get very frustrated with all the hassle or you smile and walk on. There is no fee for looking in their shop!

A bargain for dinner. Three of us had food at Hassan's on Jamaa el Fna square. Food was tasty, cheap and, importantly, didn't give us food poisoning. We really enjoyed the experience, but some of the food stall holders can be very pushy. Also , the woman sat next to me was being bugged by local children, which she clearly wasn't enjoying...

must-visit place. Jemaa el Fna, it is part of the Medina, in Marrakech, this beautiful city, this place has alot of ''carts'' where they cook food and serve it to u, its very tasty, and u get a menu where u get to chose what u wanna try, also there are people there that hold shows, snake shows, monkeys, dancers, acrobats, or even story tellers or live music, its wonderful, not forgetting the henna tattooers, i dont care what people say but i have been there and i loved it, and i will visit again :)

Would have been better if hadn't rained!. Brilliant, unmissable, sadly the day we went it poured with rain and a lot of traders and the snake charmers had gone home the markets are brilliant though. Go hard on the bartering, if they see you walking away they'll soon bring the price down.

A must see.. The squre is a must see during the day and at night. There is such a contrast with market stalls being dominant during the daytime and making way for food stalls at night to sample local foods. In the evenings there are also dancers, musicians, fortune tellers, henna tattooist and of course (though I don't recomend it dur to the cruelty) snakes and monkies.Just beware that if you take a picture of anything happening in the square, someone will expect payment.

The Marmite square, love it or hate it. We were in Marrakech for 11 nights and visited the square a number of times.My wife loved it, I didn't. We only ate at a stall once after being warned by our hotel manager about poor food hygiene practices, we didn't suffer from any ill effects.We took a horse and carriage ride, after a bit of shopping around we got it for 200 DHS for an hour which compared to some of the money people wanted for looking in their direction was a bargain.I refused to have a photo with any monkeys as they were being kept in poor conditions in small cages.I stupidly wanted a photo of a snake and should have stuck to my guns and agreed a price beforehand or just walked away as they asked for 600 DHS afterwards, no they didn't get that but suddenly felt very intimidated. Until reading this forum today I hadn't realised they sew the snakes mouth shut to stop them biting, I had wondered why I hadn't read of dead tourists. I wish I hadn't taken the photo now because of this.The souks were interesting, we were never hassled, all the banter we had when we stopped to look in a stall was friendly. There were a few lads who would insist we were going the wrong way back to the square even though we knew we weren't.I can't see how these people make a living, there are so many stalls all selling the same stuff, if one was to diversify they would make a killing.The orange juice is the best bargain at 4 DHS, the Vin Diesel lookalike at number 37 was the nicest seller.The weekends at the square are unbelievably busy, worse than Oxford Street in the sales. If you are struggling to find somewhere to eat there is always the KFC opposite where the horses are stood.I don't know if many of the restaurants 'dumb down' the Moroccan food for tourists but I found most of it very bland, certainly not what I was expecting from the proliferation of spice stands.

What can you say!. This is an amazing place - full of constant, hectic activity! There is such a variety of incredible things to see - snake charmers, monkeys, horse and carriages, food stalls , knife sharpeners - don't miss it and let's hope it's around for many years to come!

ok to see once. This place only comes to life at night. It is mainly a place for locals to make money and scam tourists. The women who do henna rip you off and scam you especially fatima who does henna. I would highly recommend ladies keep away from them. If you take a pic in this place they want money from you. It is full of locals who sing and dance. Also there is snake charmers and food stalls. I would recommend eating some food from the square.

Like being stuck in a theme park. As you wold expect inthe heart of Marrakech, it's a complete hotpot of noises, smells, people & animal. Everything you would expect to find, is here. From the henna painting, to the snake charmers, acrobats & food a plenty, colourful water carriers & donkey carts delivering the local shops.Soak it all up, enjoy it, but keep your hands firmly on your wallet & expect to pay for everything - even a simple photo!!

Unique place . A totally unique place on earth. Enjoyed the relaxing stroll down to the square every evening. Missing the orange juice. The annoying things. People pointing out to you the wrong direction or the to the direction of there store when you clearly know it isn't the way. Kids begging to show you the way for some money. A big no no by the way. When asking a store keeper a price and his reply beeing jow much would you like to pay. At this point I wouldn't bother with any sale and would walk off. You've gotta get clued up there. Luckily for me and my wife, we have experience in these environments. The shop Guijjane which is opposite the hotel restaurant café de France was the best shop and shopping experience of my trip to marrakesh. It was owned by a young man named Redouan. He was the nicest guy I met in the whole of morroco. I genuine human and an excellent salesman man. His store was a souvenir shop which was the lowest fixed prices with no hassle from the worker's in the whole of jema el fenna. Ideal shop for acquiring tasteful gifts for a low price. Taking plenty of chewing gum for haggling with is a good idea. This place could be over whelming to the weaker minded person. Personally me and my wife didn't enjoy the food from the square. Over priced with no taste. Local restaurants and cafés serving food to locals is the better option. The shopping experience itself is awesome and overall the people of morroco are very good. I cannot wait to return.

Vibrant and fun.. The Jemaa el Fna is the very essence of Marrakech. We loved it and ate here on our first evening. All the stalls looked very similar, prices the same too, and the place we ate at was lovely. The bill for three of us was 15 euros, including lots of sides and tajines to taste, superb food and unbeatable value and entertainment. Unmissable!

Intense and incredible. The food on the stalls was gorgeous, and there is so much to see and smell in the square. It can be quite exhausting constantly saying 'no' to people trying all different ways to get you to part with your cash however. Definitely recommend stopping for freshly squeezed orange juice at 4 dirhams whenever possible. Steer clear of the monkey men!

Crazy place.. You need to see the square at different times to really get a sense of the place. There were things I loved about it and some things i hated. Firstly this is a place to keep your wits about you. There are lots of people here targeting tourists to rip them off or pickpocket them, so keep your valuables in a zipped bag in front of you. During the day there will be the orange juice stalls, which is delicious and only 4 dirhams. Apparently the quality can vary so when you find one you like stick to it. Also by midday there will be ladies wanting to henna your hands, I declined this saying i was allergic. Be careful with this some of the henna can be rather toxic and if you do this agree a price/design before you start. There are lots of snake charmers and drummers etc. Again be aware if you take photos money will be demanded sometimes very aggressively. There were also men with monkeys dressed in clothes, on leads etc. I find this practise cruel and inhumane the animals are often drugged and mistreated. I'd urge tourists not to have photos with them and not to give them money to try to stop this. Also there are many stalls here but you'll get much better deals in the souk. At night the place is full of food stands, we had delicious meat skewers from stall 1. Be aware they will try to get you to have more than you want, if you don't want bread etc just say. If they give you something they will expect paying for it at the end. We loved the cinnamon tea for 3 dirham and found this a great people watching spot. If you're a good customer you may well find your glass topped up for free to keep you at a stall.

Interesting by day magical at night. Since Jemaa el Fna is the main square in the medina this is where you'll inevitably end up when you explore the souks. We didn't find it that interesting during the day and wouldn't have gone there that often if it wasn't for the delicious fresh orange juice that you can buy at just 4 Dirham a glass from the many vendors there. May sure to ask for "No ice" though. We were not keen on the snake charmers and trained monkeys so we just walked around them and were never hassled. It was all too obviously touristy. Snake charmers in India are much better ;) At night Jemaa el Fna turns into a magical place. The whole square is illuminated by thousands of lanterns that are placed on the ground by the lantern sellers. There are musicians and especially drummers that create a constant sound and rhythm that the whole square almost feels like it's moving. The vibe felt Arabian nights mixed with Africa just as it should.

Felt threatened. We were really looking forward to visiting the Souks and Jemaa el Fna however, despite my 19yr old daughter dressing conservatively, she was constantly shouted at with males coming right up to her face. On one occasion, it felt as if a man was trying to come between us. He passed us several times (talking on his phone) and each time either bumped against one of us or tried to use the crowds to weave between us. We left immediately! On another occasion we started to look at some woodwork and were then immediately surrounded by men who would not let us leave. The mopeds are a pain and you are constantly jumping out of their way!! Also, will someone please tell the café touts that shouting 'you will not get diarrhoea' does not attract the customer to the food!!

Sketchy but a must see.... Wow, the Jemma el Fna is "THE" market in Marrakech. Leave your valuables behind and prepare yourself for an incredibly exciting and at some times scary, experience! Here is where you'll see dancing monkeys, snake charmers and fortune tellers as well as people eating sheep brains and camel tongue!

Exotic and exciting. Wonderful aromas, the souks are sensory overload with all the colorful wares. In the evening the entertainment on the square is so varied from modern to traditional. Great shopping!!Watch out for the guy with the monkey- he cusses a lot if you don't have you picture taken.
Mad - but in a nice way. It is what it is - after 6 it is a vibrant maelstrom of noise, food, hawkers and music. Busy and bustling but intrinsicly safe.

Jemaa El Fun. Oh huh, the very definition of fun, fun that makes time irrelevant, vanishes and disappears, leaving you wondering if you were in a dream of part of a fantasy film. Had these mean grilles to die for and oh I just loved the orange juice. Sad to say the only place to get such fresh orange juice for only 4dh is this place. I tried many times to fish a bottle of soda in the square unsuccessfully. Maybe next time after honing my skills a bit beforehand I will be more successful. I met this wonderful tour guide called Fouad, who makes you see the city from a Moroccan viewpoint with the rich history. I would love to recommend him to anyone who wants to visit, he's worth it. (Fouad: 00212649307706)
Magical at night. The square comes alive at night with the quickly set up restaurants music & atmosphere, lot of bars & rooftop restaurants to choose from
Pure Marrakech. The heart of the medina and of Marrakech. Worth visiting at any moment of the day. Eat in the stalls, you won't be dissapointed.

You cannot help but pass through here at least once. A large bustling square. Full of many moroccan s as well as other tourists. Many roof top cafes around to take your photos from but agree dont get your camera out in the square unless you are prepared to part with cash. Always ask before taking a photo of someone working ie snake charmers, henna ladies, Vulture parader musicians etc. There are many sights we witnessed a little girls ferocious boxing match eeek. visit day and night so different but not somewhere for a 2 week holiday. there are so many other fantastic places to see in morocco. the orange juice is excellent. We filled up plastic bottles. Also the food stalls are fantastic but make sure you know the price first.

The pink city of Morocco on the fertile land below the atlas mountains. Flying straight into the heart of Morocco from Manchester into the big Kesh ...Marrakesh ..3 party animals decided to venture into a land and culture so different from ours and the nearest country to the west side of southern Europe .Spain . Having been there before , it was good to have some worthy companions to go around with . August hot ! but not too hot to get out and about..3 days dotting about and staying @ the C T M hotel on the main square Jema El Fna .Slap bang in the tourist hotspot ,where all the action takes place .both day and evening / into the night . visited the souks where they sold silver , copper , leather , silk , and of course the magic ali baba flying carpets ans a whole lot more . perfumes wafting and scenting the air mixed with toxic motor bike fumes , spices , preserves of many bright colours .Sunsets making this low built city glow in the evening light . Stunning views across the plains and the snow capped atlas mountains in the distance . Few cities can rival this ancient capital that has survived almost intact, but its lost its title to Rabat . The new capital of Morocco .time moves on .....

Must be experienced!. Must be experienced! Its like being at a dinner show! Snakes, monkeys, people and their wares.... Hawkers everywhere --- Just be assertive, and aware of your surroundings. Stall 118 across from the famous and too-touristy stall 1 is delicious. Their tajina was the best I've tasted. Also order the sheep's tongue if you get a chance!

Noisy and lively. If you manage to survive and not get run over by the motorbikes you are doing well. Avoided the snakes and the poor monkeys. Great place to soak up the atmosphere. We ate in one of the ''cafes" in the market. Quite disappointing as miniscule portions. We were told to avoid anything that was cold as their hygiene is not that great. Loads of stalls selling snails - no thank you! Stop off at one of the ginger tea stalls but if you see them dip a teaspoon I to clear liquid and don't want it turned into a eucalyptus drink do no! Very strong to say the least.

The place to go at nights.
