This is truel filled with eastern promise.You will need to visit more than once as there is so much to see and hear and smell with the stalls cooking all kinds of street food but this is not the best place to eat.Be warned,as soon as they see a camera,you will be approached for money also if you give to one beggar, you will be surrounded by 20 othersThis is a must for every visitor to Marrakech

Not so magical after a while. Fun and exciting at first but then the pestering begins. Take a picture of snake charmers, musicians, acrobats, etc and they will be in your face demanding money. 10-20 dirhams is normal but a snake guy demanded 300 and screamed at me for giving him 50. Ugly scene. Same with other entertainers--have a camera and you will be hounded plus the only video footage will be of a hand up to the lens asking for more. Food vendors are just as bad-take a photo of the guy selling sheep heads and brains or the orange juice carts and they ask more for the picture than their product. Yes, I walked away but often had to deal with these creeps following and shouting at me for several minutes.

It`s a must. Not much more to say than others have already said. It is indeed a must see, try to the see it during the day first and then by the evening you will notice the diffrences and don`t be affraid to taste the food is good and very affordable not to say cheap, and the orange juice is really good avoid taking it with ice, just the plain orange juice.

Soberb!. This is an absolutly magical place! Go there with an open mind and enjoy everything... It's crazy and beautiful and just full of energy! There are no words to describe it, just go there and absorb it all!! The colours, the smells, the sounds, the life...P.S. Dinner time is great and you can enjoy the sunset on one of several terraces. I recommend the restaurant Taj'in Darna! Go for the menus!!

Great for People Watching. Amazing place to people watch. Of course, wherever there are tourists there are people who pray on tourists. Do: have a mint tea in the day and evening at any one of the roof top terraces to watch what goes on - the cool breeze is wonderful!Have an orange juice (with a straw!) - tastes amazing freshHave a meal at the pop up restaurants in the eveningDon't:Make eye contact with all of the snake charmers, monkey handlers, etc... Admire from a distance, but unless you want to get parted with your money, don't let them get close to you, take any pics or interact with the animals.

Disappointing but lively. Watch from afar or join in, the square is interesting to an extent. The square is a definitely the place to visit for one night of your trip. Arrive at 7-8pm and watch the square develop with the arrival of food stalls (cheap but not exceptionally), snake charmers, monkey handlers and other such entertainers. If you have done some travelling around the world it is likely that you have come across this sort of thing before and it isn't that interesting. If not, could be quite exciting.

Another world!. A very bustling square full of snake charmers, acrobats musicians and various characters all trying to attract the tourists. You can buy freshly squeezed orange from the stalls. There are many restaurants and at night it becomes full of eateries and entertainment. I didn't like all the motorcycles, cars and donkeycarts which were all around you constantly.

Unforgettable!. Pick a rooftop bar to watch the setting up of the square in the late afternoon, then once darkness is falling, go down and enjoy the experience. You will never forget the fantastic sights, sounds and smells of this amazing place.

Best in the evenings. It's nice to sit amongst the local entertainers in the evening. The music is very enjoyable. Ladies if you are offered a seat then the best thing to do is to take it otherwise the crowds can get a bit busy

Central Square of the Medina. Well, it is the central crossroad of the old city of Marrakech and cannot be missed! But the aggressive snake charmers and assorted hustlers were a little too much for our children. We highly recommend a local guide, provided by your riad or hotel, to take you through the souks (and protect you from the overly assertive locals). For us, this small expense made our tour much more enjoyable and certainly less intimidating for our children.

Madness. Snake charmers, fez hats, monkeys in dresses, what's not to like!?? Comes alive at night with an amazing selection of food. Watch out for pick pockets as I felt someone put their hand in to my empty pocket. Definitely a safe place regardless.

Over rated open space!. Came here in the day and not much going on..stalls of orange juice..monkeys being pulled around and some snakes. Aggresive henna ladies who you should avoid. We were told to go at night as it changes into something magical. So came back, the smell of donkeys, horse poo and stale wee along the way was nice-not! There were some people telling a story and loads of food stands which i wouldnt risk eating at as they were covered with flies. We walked around to have a look and it was frustrating as we just kept getting hounded with people asking us to eat at their standsBe careful here. The square is one to tick off the bucket list but it wasnt anything magical. Very over rated

Fun!. Good food and drinks at reasonable prices, great entertainment, great shopping (although I'd like to say prices are higher around the square). The atmosphere just gets crazier as the sun sets, you don't want to miss out.Suggestion: You should tip around 10-20Dh to take photos with monkeys, snakes, etc.
Loved it!. Felt safe whilst walking around! Have never seen such manic driving, but it was all part of the fun. So much to see and do!

A must see world heritage site!. Much can be said about Djemaa El fna square… It’s impossible to walk around the medina without finding yourself in the Jema el Fnaa. The atmosphere, the people, the colors can keep you entertained for hours. It’s a very safe place, BUT, be careful of your possessions
An experience to remember. It delivers what you read about the area. Crazy, colourful, vibrant, busy, strange but wonderful. Careful about taking photos, observe customs and cultural sensitivities

Crazy madness. This square has all manor of crazy things going on.
Monkeys, snake charmers, plants, orange juice and fortune tellers. Mind you, unless you speak morroccan or french, not entirely sure how you would understand what fortune you had been told!
Cash machine in the square - feed in pound notes/euros etc and out pops Dirhams!

Not what we expected!. Generally disappointing. Too many beggars, people trying to clean shoes, shouting, women physically trying to sit you down to cover you in henna tattoos. If you want a drink it's better to sit upstairs overlooking the square - that way you don't get people trying to offer their wares and services. Wouldn't ever return!

Not my cup of tea. This place is described by many as a "must see". So we went. It is really what I will call - a human spectacle. In the day time, the palace is filled with vendors who's wares are not interesting and who's customers seems to be mainly locals looking for a bargain. There are, of course, lots of snake charmers, hena tattoo painters, acrobats, dancers, mountain man, and the like, trying to get your attention. With the exception of the tattoo ladies (who are selling a service), the others are trying to get paid for photographs. Curiosities they may be, none of them appears attractive. They are all rather shabbily dressed and none have any kind of real act. The animals appeared listless (concerns for their well-being aside). It distressed me that we tourists come to gawk and marvel at this sight.At night, the place transform into a food market with raws and raws of food stalls. We went to one that was recommended by tripadvisor reviewers and found the food to be mediocre. You'd be better off going to the roof top terrace of one of the surrounding restaurants and look on the spectacle below.

just be awared of croweded areas. best thing to do in marrackech is walking there. i only take my cellphone and little money to buy that day purchases. in crowded places. just put ur hands in ur pants :)

What a place. you must see at night which has a completely different vibe tot he daytime - and try the orange juice! I would suggest you stay well clear of the snake charmers and monkey's though - not nice in my opinion and very pushy.

Great place!. Prepared to be shocked! There is a lot going on here, ladies will grab you for henna,men will try to by you with camels. We went thought the day the first time, there was snake charmers ,go careful as they may try and put it round you but I think they could tell we were scared so didn't bother. Before I knew it, I had a monkey on my shoulder I didn't want a photo as I thought it was cruel. There are vulture, turtles, all sorts! Try any of the orange juice stands we had a lot from different stands and they were all lovely. Only 4 dirhams each, about 30p well worth it when you need a quick cold refreshing drink. We had a paninis at yazzis (thinks its called that) very cheap and you can watch it all at eye level but no one bothers you (unless people selling cigs) we went to several cares around there and all nice and cheap, great shade to watch everyone go by. Be prepared to haggle. And dot ask he price unless you really want it,my husband wanted some dr dre beat headphone and the man said he couldn't take less that 300, we walked off then he said we could have them for 150. Go careful about when they give you change. I saw alot of police and undercover police patrolling around which makes you feel safe. Go at night too as it completely changes from the day. Had a lovely time there, make sure all your belonging are safe on you and enjoy. Wear sunglasses too so you don't make eye contact, you will be saying " no thank you " a lot!

The heart of Marrakech. This is a very lively area with everything going on day and night which are two entirely different experiences.Around the nearby stalls you will be hassled and the seller's can be a little more determined than those away from the square. At night that is replaced with market food stalls.I preferred this area at night as the lights and colours make great photos, not a fan of the captive animals on show be it monkeys or snakes so we stayed away from those guys.The fresh orange juice is excellent from the numerous stalls and just what you need on a hot afternoon.A great thing to do is to try and find a nearby café or restaurant with a roof terrace to experience a view of the square but be prepared to pay a premium. Somewhere like cafe de France works for the view from the roof terrace and is reasonable cost and quality.

Smile but watch your wallet.. Loved the atmosphere in the evening. Amazing variety of people and activity in the square. But a lot of pressure to eat or participate and pay for the myriad of interesting things going on. Do not put your hand out for anything or you'll find yourself being henna'd and then negotiating as to how much you pay. You will also find yourself paying for the pleasure of photographing interesting looking people. Just remember, it's all part of the experience.
Great. Great experience, busy, cultural and lots going on, just say no to the beggars and dont make eye contact

Crazy Jamaa el Fna. We were staying in the medina and found the jamaa el fna was within 10 minutes walking distance. If you visit marrakech YOU MUST visit here. The square gets busier around 4-5 o'clock onwards as they set up food stalls, during the day its a little quiter with snake charmers, dancers, music. All in All this place was one of our favourite of the whole week. Lots to see and do.

What a unique place!. Could sit in one of terrace restaurants and watch for hours. Very interesting and live during a day time, and does become a magic place in the night time. Already miss the vibe,colors and smell of it!
Not a great experience. Hot, a crush of people, lots of touting and stalls aimed at tourists.Worth a visit but also worth a quick exit
Very vibrant and exciting. Spent a few nights in plae Jemma el Fna including dinner 2 nights. Incredibly vibrant and exciting. Great food, try the snails!

very interesting. The markets were so interesting, chaotic random I loved just watching the poeple and vehicles including donkeys going in all directions with such purpose. The markets are a must in marrakech. There are also snake charmers and henna tattoo ladies. Be careful of the henna ladies unless you want a tattoo agree a price before hand. enjoy!

Absorb the culture!. We are not shoppers, but we LOVED getting a railside table at a restaurant overlooking the square at sunset and watching the beautiful view and the people. The square comes alive as the sun goes down, with vendors setting up food tents where everyone descends for an evening meal. Walking through the haze of steam and smoke as the food cooks is awakens the senses--and lets you know you are not in Kansas anymore! Snake charmers, monkeys, absorb the real Morocco!

Prepare to be amazed, bewildered and cultured!. This square is probably quite unlike anywhere else you will have ever visited! By day it is a hot open square with a few canopied market stalls selling lots of different crafts, food and drinks. By night it gets much busier as new stalls, barrows, lights and performers fill it with every kind of item to buy and all manner of improvised shows to watch.The maze of souks lead directly off the square and it's handy to have a small map to guide you back once you go in to explore the thousands of little stalls, workshops and tiny industries within it. They are unbelievable and you shouldn't feel intimidated at all - just a constant gentle persistent babble of attention seeking from the many stall-holders all vying for your attention and of course money to spend on their wares. The souks are an unbelievable sensory treat with colours, smells, sights, tastes and textures constantly changing throughout as you walk through them. DON'T MISS OUT! We didn't encounter one aggressive person but some are very persistent and people (often children) will offer to lead you to a "spice market" in exchange for a few dirhams. My advice would be don't engage eye contact or chat to them, which seems harsh as they're being friendly, or you'll be constantly approached and begged for coins before they leave you alone, only to be replaced by another eager face. You can also find yourself being led on a goose-chase to nowhere and have to find your own way back which is just a waste of holiday time.Our teenage lads were fine with the busyness and excitement of it all but smaller children (under 10s) might find it a bit intimidating. Even so, we found the Moroccans were child-friendly and generally polite.You should definitely go at least once, get a feel for the geography and go back and explore more for yourself. We took a guided tour for our first visit (booked in the hotel via Thomson) which was an ideal introduction, then did two more two hour visits under our own steam in the early evenings. To be honest, two hours was enough as it's a madly intense, slightly surreal but a genuinely fun experience. Amongst the crazy confusion of amazing sights and magical smells we saw snake charmers, monkeys, huge pots of spices, miles of beautifully coloured hanging fabrics and a woman quite clearly casting a spell on a little jar of something she was mixing in it! You've got to take it as it is- but that's surely why you travel in the first place ?Top tips.Even if you speak French or Arabic, don't chat or you may engage a persistent new friend who is hard to shake off.Be prepared to haggle- start at 25 to 30% of the asking price and go up to 40- 45% max depending on what you think things are worth. Remember that these traders have to earn a living but nerve is everything when you bargain. ( We bought a bag for £6 which started at £36) Be prepared to walk away if the price is too high and you may actually be pleasantly surprised! Traders expect to be beaten down and ultimately they're experts. Very few stalls have any prices showing ( a few do ) so don't feel intimidated. Almost everyone we bought from was charming and friendly and not in a purely "give us your money" way either.Visit an upstairs cafe on the edge of the square for a cooling drink and some time away from the busyness. Also great for taking photos.Anyone you take a picture of will expect a small payment. Give what you think it's worth.Be aware that you may be approached by men with monkeys or snakes asking for money in return for you taking a photo. Unless you want one either avoid them, ignore or just say no thanks. It's not rude as there are so many people constantly asking you for something, yet it's not half as intimidating as it sounds!As you enter the square you may be approached by guides (claiming to work for "the government" but clearly don't). Harmless and probably genuine but maybe not, so avoid unless you want an unofficial tour.Finally, someone described the Square and souks as "an assault on your senses without any pain" which is a pretty accurate description. This is an amazing place to visit and once is enough for some people but we had to go back for more. Don't avoid it as it's as close to engaging with Marrakech's busy culture as you can get as a visitor. You will ALWAYS have lasting memories of your visit here so just go for it.
nothing special. Large , dirty square with motorcycles riding hectic. Only good thing was a cafe on the 3rd level serving mint tea.Save time and money and go some place else.

The Hub. This square is like the hub of Marrakech, the main attraction. The snake charmers try to put a non venomous water snake around your neck...i refused as I asked for a cobra around my neck...and got it. They took pictures of me with cobras, I was watching my camera more than the cobras but was safe. Afterwards they asked for ''paper money''. Make sure you have a few Dirham notes in 20's and 50's.Iwas not interested in monkeys as they had them on chains like dogs on leads which I thought was cruel. If you want to see monleys, go to Gibraltar.Keep an eye on your bags, pockets, keep your wits about you, be aware of what and who is around you and you will be safe. It is busy and generally safe here. I looked around in 1 to 2 hours. I enjoyed it.

Eat where the Moroccans eat. Jema el Fna is apparently a UNESCO World Heritage Site. I have no idea why. During the day it is a rather dull, hot open space, with not much going on. In the evening it becomes home to lots of food stalls and street entertainers. The food is rather ordinary Moroccan fare, kebabs, sheeps's heads, tagines, etc, but do eat where the Moroccans eat, as some of the tourist places can be ridiculously overpriced and poor quality. One place to avoid is the "lovely jubly, ASDA price" guy at one of the first stalls you find as you arrive from the taxi rank, very friendly until you question the bill (some friends paid nearly 30 Euros for the same meal we had in the Kasbah for less than 3 Euros). The other thing to be aware of is that the street entertainers are there to earn a living. Taking a photo of a snake charmer, dance troupe, monkey, etc. will require payment. Many people don't pay, but if you don't, you will get a very aggressive reaction, although usually only verbal. The square is also full of pickpockets, con artists, sexual predators and muggers, keep your street smarts about you and avoid talking to strangers. Despite all these negatives, it is worth visiting for one evening and the square is surrounded by some pleasant roof top and terrace bars where you can relax with a coffee after all the madness.

Not as busy during the week. . I went on a thursday so the main area wasn't entirely filled with stands. Vendors will call out to get your attention but they werent too demanding. I got a henna tattoo which looks great. Here's a scam I didn't look out for though- they show you the book with prices, I piked one for 30 Dirham. They close the book and put it away, work on your arm and when they're done I take out a 50 and they act surprised, take out 'the same' book except now the prices are in the hundreds. Other than that everything was great.

Busy place!. Jeema El Fna is the busiest place I have ever seen in my life: people eating, performing all kind of shows, singing, taking pictures with snakes, with monkeys. Madness! We learned that the best place to eat is where the locals eat. True indeed! This place is a more that I can handle! However, for a short period of time….it’s ok!

Watch your wallet. Our first visit to this center was with a guide and even then didn't spare us from being pickpocketed. Luckily our guide spotted it and stopped it in time.Nevertheless, it's worth visiting. It's mystic and something we don't experience in the US.

A must when in Marrakech. This is a must see for everyone going to Marrakech. It's the main square! Just don't go there in a bad mood or you will end up getting very stressed. My advice: Go in the morning to shop when it's quieter and cooler, or in the evening to eat or just check out the views from a high roof terrace. Also, if you're thirsty, get the 10 Dirham orange juice...freshly squeezed orange juice.Unlike the guide books say, women do not need to cover-up or are not made to feel uncomfortable by the locals when wearing shorts, skirts, or vest tops etc. Just take a lot of 10 Dirham coins in change to buy things with, and be prepared to pay when taking photos of people and their monkey/hat/stall/"talent".Oh...and watch out for kids riding large bikes they can't control, mopeds, or anything else that moves quickly and can crash into you.
Busy shopping. Be prepared for gropers!be prepared to haggle, Smile! Try the food stalls eat where the locals eat,the green tea is fab. Don,t be afraid to join in the dancing.stick to yourbudget.

Amazing place. Jemaa el fna is unlike anywhere i have ever been before. The main square is a crazy place with snake charmers, monkeys and we even saw a vulture at one point, Be aware that if you take pictures you will be expected to hand over some money and will harassed to do so. You can be sneaky as we were and went to a terraced cafe and took some distance photos from there. The orange juice is lovely to drink when it is really hot. We didn't sample any of the food because we didn't want to take the risk but there seem to be people sitting down to eat, particularly at night time. You must take a trip at night when it is completely different from daytime. The square is much busier and you will see different things like dancing and story tellers. We did venture down some souks but remember what twists and turns you take because it is so easy to get lost. There is lots of haggling to be done and we got some real bargains. Make sure you agree prices before you do things like henna and photos. When you haggle offer 75% of the price they give you and start from there. My husband became a expert at this :)Loads to do here and well worth the visit!!!

Go prepared & you'll be fine. Be prepared to walk away. Traders will often accept 10% of their opening price. Beware of women grabbing you to give you henna tattoos, then wanting 450Dh off you. If you want the tattoo, ask for the price before letting them touch you. NOTHING is free.Beware getting stiffed by the goons round the snake charmers. They'll hassle you for money after draping a snake round you for photo opportunity (whether or not you want it). Same applies to monkey handlers.Don't be afraid to walk away from stalls. You'll not offend anyone, as they know that there's 1000 tourist behind you who will buy.Soak it all in but don't feel under pressure to buy. Looking and smelling is free. Do lots of both.

Pure chaos - but exciting. Especially if you go at night. Be prepared to be moved by the rhythm of drums, lost in a crowd, confronted with snakes and monkeys, solicited to buy all manner of wares, all while dodging donkey carts and maniacs on mopeds. Just let go and join the flow, you'll adjust sooner than you think.

Must see. I was like in a dream. You have to see this by sunset. Unbelievable. I can not really recommend the food you get there. Nevertheless, eating there can be an adventure. But it is too expensive. Jemaa el Fna is a really cool adventure!

BE READY FOR the unexpected. so lively, many things to see, many things to buy. nice people too :) they have public toilet for only 1 DH next to the police station. pay attention with people offering help if you are lost because at last they ask for money and will lead you in the wrong way so then it takes longer for them and they canget more amount of money. In cas ethis happen, give them no more than 20DH.

To be experienced - BUT BEWARE, ie cart #53. Wild!! Everybody is selling something and accosting you to buy something. Snake charmers, monkeys, dancers, and lots of food. But beware. We had just come from the airport and money exchange and had only 200 dm bills. We asked the vendor at cart #53 selling orange juice if he could break it, and he assured us he could. We fell for an old money shorting trick. When he gave us our change he folded a 50 dm bill to look like two. When we unfolded the change later we found we were 100 dm short. It was only about $12, but it left us feeling cheated and wary.

No place like in the world.. Night time is by far the best time to visit. All the vendors are out with their food and the place is very energized. Walk for hours and enjoy the sights you'll see nowhere else.
Amazing buz. Spent most of my evenings there . Lot of the buz about the place . So much going . Very exciting place to be .

Be Prepared for Madness. This is a crazy place full of all kinds of performers and anything beyond a glance in their direction will illicit a request for payment. Its well worth a visit, even just once as long as you keep your wits about you and accept it for what it is. If you need to retreat from the madness and watch from afar, the Cafe De France is a good spot for a mint tea

What an experience!. Excellent place, just be careful, wear sunglasses to avoid to be spoken to all the time! Catch the snakes, monkeys and the birds. Enjoy a drink in one of the many cafes around the famous square! Watch them set the market up, early evening is nice!

Worth a visit for food at night. I really enjoyed the experience of eating out at Jemaa El Fna. However, we had to be very weary as my wife has a Phobia of reptiles. They have many reptiles and charmers in the area so had to be Very careful.

Great if you love hustle and bustle. There is so much going on all day and night - watching the transformation is amazing. Watching someone perform something - they will expect money, there are lots of beggars some trying to sell you something small, some just want money, they expect money for showing you the way to anywhere or giving you any information. At night all of the stalls are restaurants and they have 'touts' all trying to pull you in to their 'restaurant' if you don't want to be hassled walk around the outside or walk with purpose thru the middle, be firm but polite. Beware the cake people wandering around, our hostel told us they are unsold cakes that have been on display all day often with flies on them :-/

Explore!. Although the sales shops all run the same, you should do an evening stroll through the square. Stop and enjoy some snails at a stall. Make sure to try the lamb's head stew! So tender and delicious. Most of the food stalls are the same, so you can't really go wrong. Just find one with locals. This is the best place to find your dried fruits to take back, you won't be able to beat the prices!

Not to be missed. This was top of my list of places to go and things to do!We went to the souk late afternoon and then into the square as all the stalls were setting up. Went and ate in one of the rooftop restaurants and watched it all from a safe distance.Was expecting loads of hassle and aggro but it wasn't anywhere near as bad as expected, though we did leave before it got dark! I think if you ensure that you don't go too close to the monkeys / snakes / dancers etc, then you won't get pulled in for a photo "opportunity" etc. We kept moving and got no hassle at all!Just keep your bags close to you - we found that the magicians / entertainers encourage the audience to come close in to watch them and it gets quite crowded and at one point my husband was aware of a man who'd got very close to us on more than one occasion but we moved away and there was no problem. Like any city, there'll be people up to no good but don't let that put you off. Just keep your wits about you and enjoy it!

fantastic to visit especially at night time. excellent plaza and markets, the best time is at night when the place is more festive and the food stalls are set, the lights and crowds make it very attractive

What Marrakesh is all about. After visiting this square with our guide, Hashim, we decided to go again in the late evening - 2 females. Our driver dropped us off, and was there to pick us up after an hour or so. We felt rather safe on our own, even though my shoulder was touched a few times in an attempt to get our attention. Visitors should be aware of the care of the horses, as we saw a horse being hit by a man because the horse stumbled and likely was hurt. This is not acceptable in any society, and travelers might not want to pay for carriage rides if horses are abused. Other than that, the night visit to this square was intriguing.

Amazing food and people. Eating at the stalls at Jeema al fna is a must. The banter the stall owners give to entice you into their restaurants is fantastic. Competition is fierce and you won't be dissappointed. We ate at stall 14 after reading an earlier review (thank you), fully intending to have just a few calamari before moving on to another stall, but the food was so good we gorged ourselves on calamari(3 plates of) chips, roasted aubergine (2), fish (sole) and tomato salsa (cheap cheap only 140dh for 3 of us) Yum yum! Earlier in the day we stumbled across a little stall in one of the lanes near to the square- cooking small tagine pots over a bbq. we ordered one out of curiosity - it was bbq vegetables in stock and it was delicious we had 2 lots, bread and 2 drinks for just 50dh! Marrakech is an amazing city. Marrakechies are so friendly and they have a wicked sense of humour. Locals do want you to visit their own shops and will ask you for a small payment for showing you around but what's a quid or two here and there for some local company and good humour. We had an awesome Hammam and massage at les bain d'alhambra for just 450 dh. We went in at 1710 and came out at 2000! You can eat posh nosh too- try Azar- it's good and they have. Shisha! Cocktails at La Mamounia are overpriced but worth it anyway..... It is lush. Word of warning though, the security guard initially wouldn't let us in - he said it was because we had flip flops on.... so we had to work on him a bit to let us in. It was about midnight on a tues eve so may be why.All in all a really wonderful few days and a great city to come to for a short break. It's my 2nd visit here and I need to come back, there is still so much more to see and do.I hope you enjoy it as much as we have. 3 girlfriends on holiday in the sun!......shame we have to leave

Chaotic madness at Jemaa el Fna. This is a must see bustling square. There are snake charmers, henna, street dancers a whole cacophony of things going on. Orange sqeezers.Watch out for speeding scooters, they buz all over the place.The best time to go is at night, as all the sit down outside restaurants are open. This is a must do in Marrakech. Clothes, spices, horse dung and henna all make this whole place is a sort chaos. We were there in September 2011You can also venture off to the back of the square to the souks.

Exotic Chaos. Too much fun!! I felt as if I was in a National Geographic Special. The food stalls at night are wonderful. The food is fresh and delicious. The square is crowded and chaotic but like nothing you have ever seen. The performers are pretty aggressive but just keep some small change on hand and enjoy the show. The square in the day time is very different but still a wonder.I really liked the snake charmers and the water sellers.

Exotic Locale but Very Aggressive Buskers. The evening at the central square is amazing. Food carts, monkeys, musicians, vendors, orange squeezers and much much more. We were a little annoyed by the fact that the street performers (buskers) demanded money even before they did any sort of show. We enjoyed the various soups, and the stands with candle lanterns glowing in the night, but were happy to return to our riad to escape from the chaos come 10 pm.

time warp. It really feels like Laurence of Arabia days when you get off the bus at Jemaa el Fna. You cannot decribe the smells - from horse poo to henna - the myriad colours of the clothes and the spices, the impossible number of people and the noise! but it's what Marrakech is all about, yes we did get hassled, but when told 'No thank you' they went away and didn't keep on, like i've found in other places like Khartoum and Nairobi. Didn't feel unsafe or nervous of the constant crowds, everyone seemed very welcoming and we didn't get 'the look', like the Parisians do when you try out your best schoolgirlf French! Lots of stalls - food, jewellery, leather, spices and live tortoises :o) Beware of the men who throw live monkeys on your shoulder then charge you to take a picture and remove them, but apart from that it's all good and silly to go to Marrakech and NOT do this visit.

all and nothing. here you can find all you can expect to find and maybe more, good or bad. In the day one place, in the night after 5 pm another place. Probably better in the night with lights, sounds , noises, perfumes and smells, in the day can be hot and chaotic
The heart and soul of Marrakech.... Not to be missed, it has so much to offer... and it changes over the course of the day and evening, so be sure to visit it at different times of day...

Crazy, iconic, not to miss! Stall nr 14 for good calamari!. I love this square, it must be one of the most iconic places on earth.It's always full, the orange juice vendors, the henna ladies, the snake charmers, storytellers, waterbringers, the monkeys, dancers, musicians, people on motorbikes, cars, bycicles, donkeys, ...The sounds, the smells!It's chaos in colour as someone described it on here so well :-)If you want to kinda get away from it, go have a mint tea or nuss nuss in Café de France and enjoy the views from the roof terraces.The toilets there are clean, always a plus! :-)At night it turns into one big smoky open air restaurant.Do not miss this experience, you will be eating in very simple conditions between tourists and friendly locals.Stall nr 14 (chez Ali) sells very good calamari. Also fried fish etc but I didn't try that. Next time!Henna ladies can be quite tenacious, just stay polite but firm: la, shoukran (no thank you) will get you a long way.Go and live the atmosphere there, both during day time as night time! A must.Can not wait to go back.
Overwhelmed. It was just too much to take in, people begging, and people always trying to mug you off for money, be stringent with people!!!

A bit over rated but ticked off the bucket list. Nothing more to say what others haven't said already. Go to number 27 for orange juices and ask for crushed mineral water ice in your juice. What a treat in a sweltering hot day.People pushing you to purchase, watch, eat, touch animals gets a bit annoying.The food scouts were very impressive with their sales pitch in any every language.

Assault of the senses!. By day you can buy freshly squeezed juices. The stalls all line the edge of the square. There are shops that sell tourist items, but that is all they are. There isn't really anything of exceptional quality on offer. There are men dressed in traditional Moroccan clothing and you can have your photograph taken with them for a small price. There are also men with pipes and snakes and acrobats etc. If you stand to watch they expect you to pay. Interesting to watch though! Traffic just goes where it wants. At first I was very wary but you soon get used to the bikes etc riding up beside you from behind! Women sit with stools and umbrellas offering to do henna tattoos. By evening the place really comes alive. The cooking smells are wonderful and the food does look delicious! There is music and all the other stuff that was there during the day. Some young men offer to show you round the souks for free, but like everyone else they want to be paid so don't believe them. I went to Marrakech because I watched a youtube video of Jemaa el Fna. I have to say it did not disappoint. It was certainly an experience!
Crazy night life. Loved the snake charmers, sword swallowers.. and other crazy folks.A definite MUST SEE in Marakech. Also has the best fresh juice in the city.. and only US $0.50

A must. you cannot escape the Place. It is part of the Unesco heritage site. Full of life, you can see the snake charmers, the henna tattoos , the shops, the restaurants, the musicians. It comes to life around 5 o'clock with all the restaurant setting up. Don't forget to buy a fresh orange juice for a big 4 dirham. Delicious.
Crazy place. A lot of people and a lot of noises do not know if this is the best part of the cityyou can also eat there i had a good orange juice

Overrated hustle and bustle !!. This square is dirty busy and you get harassed left right and centre!! Once your find your way there through the souks especially you have already had enough of the pervy men calling out or trying to get you to come in their shop! The stalls all pounce on you as soon as you look there way and you have to be very confident haggling or you just get ripped off ! Some men were quite aggressive and forcefull too ! Do once as an experience but unless you wanna buy something there is no need to go twice. Souks have the same thing for sale and are less smelly and overpowering !

Unique Experience. The market has lots to see. From cobras, to street performers, to restaurants, it is the number one thing to visit while in Marrakech. Food prices are generally fixed but do not pay asking price for anything else. A good rule of thumb is to instantly go to half of what the merchants want. They are quick to over charge tourists so make sure to haggle. They can be grabby and very assertive so be careful as many will try anything and everything to get your money.

Ate at No 1 food stall.ŷŷ. Great fun and plenty of delicious choices.The place to go to have a true Moroccan experience .Get into it and try everything.A family run stall ,they helped with ordering and suggested options.Ate great koftas,lamb chops and fresh salads.Don't be put off ,it's great food and fun

Avoid at all costs. Way too over-hyped. This square is horrible. It's dirty and does not feel like a safe place to be at all. We have been to Marrakech twice - fell for the hype the first time, but didn't even go back to it the second time we were there. Would not recommend at all and if you ignore this and do go, for goodness sake DONT eat anything there - you will regret it!
Busy and Bustling. Busy and bustling - a Saturday night every night - pretty busy in the day also - you take a photo and someone will want money! But after all they are trying to entertain.....

Wonderful. Definite worth it.. Specially view from restaurant called cafe da France is beautiful. More French is spoken here then France itself. People very poor understanding of English. French and Arabic is widely spoken.

Keep your wits about you!. You can't miss passing through Jemaa el Fna if you are staying in Marrekech. Day or night there is always something new to see. Don't let anyone tell you that you get hassled a lot, - you don't. You get far more hassling in Thailand than we did [myself and two daughters aged 28 and 31 - both stunning]. The Morrocons are just so welcoming and if you say no to something they usually say - ok, perhaps later or tomorrow. There are bikes whizzing about everywhere so keep your wits about you. Just take a moment to stand and see the route the cars and bikes are taking and avoid getting stuck in the middle!! Don't be afraid to stop anywhere in the surrounding cafes, they are all very much evenly priced and you can just go in and order a tea or soft drink, sit on the top terraces and watch the world go by. They do not expect you to order a huge meal and are quite happy for you just to have a snack or a drink. If you want to buy any herbal remedies or perfumes this is the place to buy. We purchased some 'stuff' somewhere else and found same 'stuff' in the Jemaa el Fna for a fifth of the price and you can still haggle with them.

The whole reason for visiting Marrakech. The Djemaa is the highlight of a trip to Marrakech - eating in the tent city is incredible, but if you can't stand the crowds head to one of the restaurants with a terrace to admire the chaos from afar. Although it seems touristy, many of the good restaurants surround the square, it's just a shame you have to face this totally sober!

An assault on your senses!. What a place! Brace yourself for the sights, sounds and smells of this market. The square itself is full of snake charmers, traditionally dressed dancers, dressed up monkeys, entertainers and traditional places to eat. If you are eating find a traditional riad and sit on the rooftop terrace, a welcome break from the crazy streets below. Granted, snake charming and performing monkeys go against our modern opinions of trained and/or caged animals so don't be afraid to keep walking with a firm no thank you. Expect to be hassled! Remember though that these people are trying to make a living and want to take you to their shop or café in the hope you will spend money with them. We found everyone we encountered to be very friendly and if we weren't interested we just kept walking. The most fun is the bartering - stand your ground! The hospitality and sense of humour you can share with a shop owner is a wonderful experience. Do venture into the souk especially for traditional items and lovely fragrant spices. Quite simply, going with the right mind-set will ensure a memorable day out!

A must see!. A sight to behold... lots going on and the bartering is great fun. The vendors always start ridiculously high so make sure you start unrealistically low and end up somewhere at a happy medium. We had no trouble but there was lots of potential to be pick pocketed due to the sheer volume of people so be careful and enjoy!

Amazing place :)))). Just relax and enjoy in everything that this square is offering. I wish I could go back again just to take a walk, see all those beautiful people, colours and to have an orange juice which is perfect.

The main square where it all happens.... Great place for just mooching and watching people. Different at different times of the day but best as night falls. Snake charmers, water sellers, acrobats, food stalls etc, so much to see.

The Heart of Marrakech. This is kind of a circus in a square. There is food, vendors, entertainers, musicians, dancers, hotels, and eateries. Most likely you will wander through this square a few times in you exploration of central Marrakech and the souks.The day is pretty tame compared to the evening where the crowds of tourists come to watch the entertainers and eat some of the local food. I was warned by my riad not to partake from the places in the square. I watched many tourists seated and eating there but it was a risk I was not willing to take. The entertainers, usually in Arabic, can tell stories, jokes, have plays, play music, and dance in the square for a few dirhams. If you take a photo or video expect to pay a few dirhams too. This is an excellent place for pick pockets. The crowds can be large and when watching the entertainers your focus shifts from your self protection to the show. Otherwise like most of Marrakech it is very safe at all times of day and night.Depending on the time you spend on the entertainers and shops you can spend a few hours here. There are also some eateries with balconies along the square. These make for great seating during sunset and to watch the square really come alive in the evening. Get there early to get a good seat.

Animal cruelty & more tourists than locals. Most travellers & expecially eco-travellers will find the chained monkeys & trapped (defanged?) cobras offensive & heart-breaking. Never mind this was historically a part of Moroccan culture--it shouldn't be now. It was painful for me, my husband & my fellow travellers to walk through it averting our eyes. Perhaps it is fitting that under this square exists a notorious government interrogation facility. For me, this world heritage site merely elevates all-around insensitivity to mistreatment to the level of a cultural institution. In addition, while this square is touted as quintessentially Moroccan, tourists outnumber locals at least 3 to 1--at least in the high travel season.

WOW!. This was our second holiday to Marrakesh and the "big square" as the locals want to direct you to via several friends stores is its main attraction which never fails to deliver, ok you get hassled but thats the whole fun of it and have a joke with them and give them a bit back and it is a real laugh, all the locals know its a big game so just joih in and enjoy yourself.
Must do experience. Al fresco eating in the warm evening air watching the locals flock into the square for traditional storytelling is great

Fantastic vibe. Great vibe in this square, we ate in the square and in the restaurants around the square and all seemed ok to me. Just please don't take photos of the monkeys and snake charmers as it's funding a cruel attraction, there are other ways for the locals to make money. Everyone very friendly just keep your eye on your pockets as someone tried to pick pocket one of us! Great place to people watch though

A magic explosion of life. This square is one of the most incredible sights I have ever seen. It's just magic one of those rare places that could be a tourist trap but somehow manage to be maintain a real local flavor!In the morning it's the world of snake charmers, monkey trainers, horse carts, street vendors (of just about anything). But at night it completely booms: hundreds of delicious food stalls, music, noises, dances, people everywhere, in a word: fun. Two hints. You'll soon find out that this square is not only the Marrakesh number one must see but also the main meeting point wherever you want to go: knowing where it is will help your orientation so make sure it's one of the first places you visit. The souvenirs they sell in the shops all around are not the cheapest: go deeper into the souks for better bargains.

Mental. Snakes, monkeys, drummers, acrobats, horse carriages, bicycles, mopeds and people, lots and lots of people.Best place to watch it all unfold at sunset is Cafe de Paris. Yes, the cafe is extremely touristy and a bit dirty but it also has two big terraces where you can sit and watch the food stalls setting up and the whole thing take shape.

Not to be missed. Experiencing Jemaa el Fna was mind boggling. To see so many thousands of people was incredible. Certainly there were tourists there, but we felt many were local people, enjoying a warm spring evening. It was fascinating to people watch. Although we couldn't understand the story tellers, watching the expressions on the faces of the older women and men sitting around the actors was unforgetable. A short distance away, young boys that couldn't get through the crowds were watching from above, propped in trees and moving to the music playing loudly for the younger generations. Watching people enjoy the many food offerings was another great experience, especially the ones putting away great quantities of snails! And although the snake charmers and monkey handlers were likely there mostly for the tourists, our young grandson treasures the picture of the monkey that jumped up and sat on his grandfather's head. We did not see any animals being mistreated and certainly didn't feel any of the monkeys were dressed in ways more degrading than some of the ways we have seen people dress their dogs at home. We loved every minute, even went back for more, and never felt we were being unduly pressured (obviously sellers of anything will try to sell their wares), or pushed around. A simple "no thank you" was all we ever needed to say. We didn'd try eating at any of the food stalls on "ground level" but did enjoy sitting outside in the upper restaurants where we had great views of all the goings on and enjoyed light meals and coffee breaks.

Not enough adjectives to describe this place. We loved and hated Jemaa el Fna equally its an amazing hectic atmospheric place but the constant hassling drove us crazy. We felt like we couldnt stop to look at anything as if you show any interest at all you soon regret it. We would love to have eaten at one of the stalls but even that proved to be challenging as they have boys trying to drag you in to their stalls and so decided to try one of the restaurants with a balcony to sit and wonder at this crazy place which we did on several occasions :-). Saying all of this I think everyone should see this square its amazing just do your homework regarding the tricks used to get your money

Never seen anything quite like this. This place needs to be seen to be believed. Noisy, chaotic and totally overwhelming to all the senses. Not as much hassle from the locals trying to sell you stuff as you would expect (compared to our experiences in India for example) - apart from in the food stall area at night.So a must see attraction with a couple of caveats.... You will get ripped off at the food stalls if you don't bargain. Also I found the treatment of the animals (monkeys, snakes etc) to be a bit distressing.
Square. Brilliant nice atmosphere, went to the great balcony and paid 20 dirhams for a drink to see the view which was worht it.all the markets were there and was able to hagle.

Not for me. I really was looking forward to the famous Jemaa Al Fna,but found it to be too much hassle to enjoy. Be prepared, brace yourself to be poked, prodded and intimidated (yes ) into parting with your money!! Do not go there taking photographs of the locals or monkeys, snakes, without paying for the photo as you will be shouted at to hand money over. The whole area is chaos watch out for motorbikes, and cyclists as they take no prisoners!! There is a very strong smell of urine not sure if this was from the horses?? If you want to buy an item do not pay what they ask, get the price down start really low if you don't want to pay what they ask just walk away and chances are they will come for you and meet your price. I did this successfully. I went back to the area again in the evening just to see it lit up. Again it was chaos everywhere. Not suitable for small children and the faint hearted!!

Madness and mayhem. A must see especially after dark when the whole place comes alive. We ate a few times - would recommend 75, 14 and 111. Look out for tea sellers and sample delicious cinnamon tea. The spicy snails are worth trying - I was a bit unsure about these having never eaten snails before but I enjoyed these. You do get hassled by restaurant front men and you will see some distasteful sights such as monkeys in chains with dresses on performing dances etc. it's a little shabby round the edges but hey, that's marrakech

Daytime hustlers. Go for the sights and sounds. Chaotic. Watch activities and be prepared to pay, but don't be hassled into paying more - you will be asked for more money. Bargain like mad for any item.

A square like no other. Street theatre and street food at its best. This quite rightly is an amazing experience but not for the faint hearted! Be prepared for large collections of snakes, monkeys on leads, henna tatooists, herbalists, various animals for sale in cages, birds of prey and lots of food stalls! Plus street sellers and children hawking anything and everything to make a few coins.

Tourist trap with an air of bygone authenticity. Despite all the hoopla about Jamaa Al Fna I found the place to be annoying full of tourist traps and touts. Everyone seems to want to throw something at you or force you take a picture. Especially the so called water carriers and the monkey trainers. Animal trainers had poor animals that made me feel quite sorry for them (the animals), having to endure all the stress of the noise and the performance on demand. The food stalls offer tiny portions of food that is not really tasty or cheap, compared to other places where we had food (including many roadside butcher/grill shops where the food was much more flavorful and the setting a lot less touristy). I suppose the only two things, worthy of the second star were the rhythms of the gnaoua and drums and the sheer volume of odd things taking place. Otherwise, not impressed.

Made me sad. Passable at night, but awful by day. Bad energy - hated seeing monkeys on chains being made to do backflips ...and the people behaving like monkeys for a tourist dollar. The only bad experience in Morocco. Guess it has to be seen though!

Nothing else like this!. Go at night! Are you in a dream? A James Bond movie? A circus? The action is every where; the place is charged! Old and new, tourist and local, young and old. It's an incredibly interesting melange not to be missed to put together all your Morocco experiences.
Fun and exciting. The main square is full of life. Restaurants are for tourist and not good. Walk down some of the alleys to find better choices

The highlight of any trip to Morocco. It's very difficult to choose which food stall to eat at, especially when every single one of them has guys out on the street doing and saying anything at all to get you to eat at their restaurant. We just walked through the first night, and decided that we needed to know exactly which stall to go to before wandering through and then make a surgical strike so as to avoid the hassle.We decided on number 114 based on other travelers' reviews, and were disappointed. First of all, they were just as aggressive, even when we were headed straight to their stall. Second, the chicken was way overcooked and dry, and the couscous was served on the teeniest and most overloaded plate, so it was impossible to cut said chewy chicken without getting couscous all over the table. The veggies were overcooked to the point of mush, and also without much flavor.Once you're sitting down, the wait staff is friendly enough, and it does have a great view of the market, though be warned, you will be hassled by the paintings, jewelry, tissue and desert vendors as you eat. They invite you to the "kitchen" to see what you will be getting before you order it, The best meal in our group was by far the mixed kebab skewers of veggies, meat, chicken, lamb and sausage. The diners at stall 117 just next door seemed to be having more fun, so give that one a try instead.
Great in the day, a bit scary at night. Interesting in the day, got a bit lost in the back streets at night and was very scared, luckily came out OK.

great place for supper.. during daytime you can see snake charmers, at night it turns into a nice place to eat out. we can recommend food stand no. 25! friendly people, no stomach troubles, nice food. :)

Crazy and wonderful. A mad house on steroids!! No words can truly describe the frenetic and hyperactivity of this square in the evening. Snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers and colourful water carriers to name but a few. Couple of hints - if you want to take photos of all the characters expect to pay them 20durhams and dont give them any more. Do not eat in the square despite what the travel books tell you - it is not the food that is the concern but the oil in which they cook the food so best to avoid. Best advice is sit in one of the cafes and watch the theatrics go one from a distance - you could easily spend hours doing so. A must see in Marrakech and be prepared for the onslaught of both pleasant and unpleasant aromas!
A wild and crazy place. Everything from snake charmers to fortune tellers and stands of every kind. It is always busy especially at night.
Can't miss!. It's a focus for everything: directions, entertainment, entry into souks, the place to get grilled food... who could miss seeing this?
The centre of the city. Action packed square that closes to traffic in the evening; lovely safe atmosphere with many roof top restaurants overlooking all the fun of the stalls.

Go at dusk!. We went to the Djema twice while in Marrakech. Once during the day when it seems a large, sprawling market square. And then in the evening when the place is just dazzlingly bright and noisy. It can be a bit intimidating but if you remain polite with the hordes of people trying to sell you something and the packed streets into the Souk it is a sensational experience. We ended the evening by eating in a Riad.

Absolute Chaos But Embrace It !. My partner and I recently visited Marrakech and came here most days - what an experience!Our first visit was on the day we arrived and we were a little taken aback by the spectacles in the street; monkeys (in clothes & nappies), snakes (cobras & pythons), henna artists, dancers & musicians.... completely nuts! This was fabulous to observe however be mindful of where you walk and keep your wits about you as we were approached very suddenly by a man who practically threw his monkey onto my partners arm whilst another man approached with his smaller monkey, another with a camera and then a lady offering henna! We must have stuck out as new tourists to the area and it was a little overwhelming to begin with. Obviously these people want paying to allow you to have photographs and hold the monkey but they leave little time to negotiate prices before they place the animal in your arms. They tried to charge us 100 dirhams for both (£8) but we managed to get away with paying 70dirhams. BEWARE the monkey actually bit my partner, thankfully he didn't break the skin but these are still wild animals and still caused havoc by snatching our sunglasses and hair clips before throwing them across the square... Only in Marrakech!There is also plenty of restaurants to grab some lunch or drinks, both in the square and off the side roads which is a nice rest bite from the craziness. Also in the Jemma El Fna locals have their own little stalls and what only can be described as car boot style areas where they sell the traditional items (tagine pots, cosmetics, jewellery, hats, shoes, ornaments etc etc). These are positioned in the centre and around the square. Be prepared to haggle (advisable to offer 45% of the asking price) and stay strong with your price THEY WILL BACK DOWN! You can grab some really great bargains! During the day we found this to be quite tame compared to the evening, at night the place comes alive! As mentioned already there is this and more - the stalls are set up where you will find rows of local Moroccan food being cooked. We didn't try this however I have read that it's a must do in Marrakech and the food is meant to be good very tasty and very good value. We were recommended to try stall # 31....As it's outdoors it is free to go and turn up which is great if you are travelling on a budget. It's the sort of place you can visit again and again, and probably spend a few hours walking round or simply sitting with a drink taking in the atmosphere. Top Tips:* Be prepared to tip and pay for almost everything - photos, looking at items etc! Be assertive if you are not interested and don't ask how much if you don't really intend to buy. * Go with an open mind - it is dirty, there are animals dressed up, there are mopeds whizzing around everywhere and the locals can be very persistent but remember this is Morocco!

This is the Heart of Marrakech!. I have no idea how many people are there every night but it seemed like thousands. Fortunately it is a big square and everyone was enjoying themselves without any problems. Do eat at one of the stalls there.

Unmissable. You have to see this place - both by day and by night. The famous arrival of the food vendors at dusk is great - the food less so. The drummers and singers are exciting and the snake charmers strangely disturbing. Be prepared to pay for everything you look at

Unique experience. An absolute must visit, yes it is dirty, crowded and smelly but that is all part of the experience of being in a very unique City! You see things here you would never see anywhere else! From snake charmers to stalls with hundreds of second hand teeth! A definite must-do in Marrakech!
So scary ,too much hassle especially for women. Will not recommend this area in the night time for women alone Too much hassle , dirty and noisy .we did not try the food either
Heart of Marrakech. If you are not there, then u r not in Marrakech. Heart and Soul of Marrakech, A Must visit towards the evening. Amazing space and activities

Hubbub of activity. The former site of public executions (pre 19th century) has become the centre point of old Marrakech. At night there are thousands of people eating at the huge number of food stalls that have been erected. This is surrounded by streets of shops and the souk.We found the whole experience most exhilarating. It is just a place to enjoy the ambience, and food.

Dirty, dusty and smelly, nothing to see. If sitting in overpriced cafes watching beggars and being bothered by hawkers is your thing whilst being wafted by the smell of horse urine then this is the place to visit, otherwise go to the Badii Palace or stay in the new city.

Watch the city change shape from from morning to evening. You cannot go to Marrakesh without a visit to the main sqaure. By day snake charmers, horse and carts, orange juice stalls and balcony drinks overlooking the hustle and bustle and watch it transform in the evening with story tellers, music, food stalls. My words do not sum up how magical and magnifcient this square is.
It's all been said. I should think that the Arab spring is threatening here. Hence the lack of enforcement by the authorities. Avoid

Good crazy experience.... This is a crazy place to be... It is buzzing. There are performers, henna artists, animals, food and people selling things...it can be a bit overwhelming but definitely worth visiting for the experience. The food, while it is cheap, is poor quality on the food stalls...so you get what you pay for. You will get harassed by the food stall holders to eat at their respective establishments, these guys can be charming and very pushy. It can get extremely crowded so watch your pockets and bags. Be careful not to get run over by people on scooters whizzing past. Not everyone's cup of tea...but worth visiting!

A seething mass of population. The best place to sit and soak up everything that is bonkers about Marrakech - the noise, smells, people watching, snakes, monkeys etc all add to the brilliant atmosphere.

The must see place in Marrakech. Absolutely fantastic attraction, the must see place to visit in Marrakech / Morocco. Imagine a massive crowd of people leaving a football ground at 1650 on a Saturday afternoon. Now imagine yourself trying to go in the opposite direction against the flow of the people -but some of the people coming towards you are riding bikes, moped, motorbikes, pushing wheelbarrows and even the occassional car or horse drawn carriage. Now imagine that loads of other people are going in your direction, again interspersed with mopeds, bikes etc and randomly stopping to look at things in shops, stalls etc. Now imagine doing this on the dark, whilst walking around people sitting on the floor, doing henna tattoos, snake charming, trying to get you to pose with monkeys, or trying to sell you crap you don't want to buy or give you directions to a place you don't want to go to! Now throw in dwarfs, acrobats, crippled beggars, drummers, musicians, people throwing stuff in the air, hawks, hawkers and just random mad stuff. That is Jemaa el Fna!!!Totally mad and fascinating place to visit, great for people watching. Food generally bad in the centre,easy to get frustrated, best to just a table on the balcony of one of the restaurants and watch the world go buy. Only bad thing is no alcohol - but that's probably not a bad thing!

Really?. The tour books say that this is the place to be. After 4 visits in as many days, I'm not convinced. Yes, it's big. Yes, it surrounds the souks - but then they are very interesting and vibrant. The square is a sad array of orange juice stands and stray groups with chained monkeys and cobras. Not impressed.

An experience. Arrived here in the morning and wasn't impressed just a big empty square. Walked around the Souk and came back, and it had come alive - market stalls everywhere, cars, trucks, mopeds and donkeys criss-crossing, snake charmers, monkey wranglers and hundreds of people milling around.I'd recommend having lunch or coffee / ice cream in one of the restaurants around the square with a balcony and just take it all in from above.

crazy crowded fun!. The square is teeming with people, snake charmers, belly dancers, food sellers, purveyors of every imaginable item, animals and MORE! Shoulder to shoulder crowds of lookers, sellers, beggars, etc. Exactly what you would expect and NOT to be missed! The center of all things Marrakech!

Sensory Overload. Shops, horse drawn carriages, bicycles, snake charmers, commerce, food sellers every evening. The sights, smells, the kaleidoscope of colour all collide in Jemaa el Fna. It feels like all of Marrakech meets here, probably because it does.

Incredible. Great to see all these colourful food stands at night... but when will these people learn that blocking the way and harrasing girls is the best way NOT to sell?
We were two girls and did not feel very relaxed in this atmosphere. Not unsafe, but uncomfortable!

mind blowing. What an experience! Loved it all, the snake charmers, the monkeys,music,the market and open air food stalls, the horses and caleches etc etc.Magical at night with all the lanterns flickering . Of course you get hassled but just smile, say no thanks and walk on. The stall holders will make you laugh by shouting out "Asda price" or "Primark price" when they realize you are from the UK.

Absolutely loved it!. Had heard all sorts of warnings, but we absolutely loved it. Never felt anything but secure. We were drawn back to visiting it all the time during our stay, sometimes walking round and most times having a front row seat over a cup of mint tea. No hassle to leave from any of the cafes even when we had finished eating or after just a bottle of water. Quite different at night, but just as magical. Fewer snakes and monkeys apparently and certainly 'not in your face'. Loved the noise, food smells and freshly squeezed orange juice at 4 Dhs a glass. No hassle from anybody, just good humoured encouragement to buy. Every stall holder we met was polite and helpful even when we said 'non merci'. Wish I had discovered Marrakesh when I was younger! Really sad to leave. Pick your places to eat, all good, but prices do vary.

fun and distractions, great for sunset views and people watching. be prepared to pay a few dirhams if you take photos or get too involved but fun to look around. stall 98 is best for cheap fresh quick fish feasts but be prepared to wait a few minutes for a seat. if you get tempted by other food stalls be careful as can be over double the cost of the busy ones like 98 where locals go. I recommend using a small empty water bottle to get filled with fresh orange juice from the stalls there as the glasses are not always clean and are often reused but the juice is delicious. Nearby the Patisserie of Princes has amazing icecream in great flavours for a good price, all the classics plus fig, cinnamon etc. Ask for hotel Tazi if you are in the square and you will pass the icecream shop/bakery on the way.

Another world. This is the number one place to visit in Marrakech and the snake charmers and other entertainers really make an impression. There is a tangible sense of risk in the square, with motor scooters zooming around and people regularly approaching you for money for one thing or another - and my normally cool teenager grabbed my hand and wouldn't let it go til we had entered the souks

Very bad experience, very bad food. Whole marrakech is full with people who try to get your money (up to 50% you spend) The whole touristic business is ruled by these foux guides. Misleading guides. On Jemaa el fna the concentration of these wrong people is the highest and here there is another variety, people who try to put henna on your hands, put a monkey on your shoulder, put a snake around your neck and asking then lots of money. People from holland should see http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1johps9_CaY four parts of the misleading practice in marrakech.We also catched one day food on the square because it looked so romantic, five days of diarhea, the quality is bad and for the price you pay you can realy join excelent restaurants in marrakech, look for the other reviews from restaurants in marrakech.

main square. Since our last visit 36 years ago the police have stopped the harassment the tourist had to endure and generally brought order to what used to be an exhilarating experience. People now are largely in western cloths, there are fewer snakes, dancers, acrobats etc but lots of noise food, orange juice and lots of beautiful horse and carriages

chaotic. loved the smells, sounds and sights and exactly what we imagined it to be. felt very comfortable walking around at our own pace and were not hassled at all. got some great bargains and could of spent a great deal more money if we had it!

Fascinating insight into Morrocan life. If you are looking for a real experience of life then this is the place to go. May not suit everyone if you are a bit squeamish about the sights and smells of some of the local food stalls.

Best souk. We visited the souk my fiancé and I twice, there are so many things to buy! Try the djellabas!!!
There are snakes and also monkeys to make the show in the place.
Also it turns itself into a giant world food market at the end of the day!

The heart of Marrakech. Love this mad square and the people in it.
Everything you coud hope for from water sellers to snake charmers.
Get a table overlooking from one of the cafe's and enjoy.

What a crowd. What a square! What do all these local people try to sell you "things", from stones, over curries, to the right to take a photo.
The orange juice for sale is very cheap and very tasty.

All passages lead to Jemaa el Fna. Possibly the most famous square in Morocco. In early morning, it is quiet and serene. Only a few orange juice stands open, #46, a lovely man that doesn't attract his customers by any boisterous yelling. Along with the juice vendors are street cleaners and people on their way to work. Late morning, some action begins as surrounding square vendors prepare to get ready for a new day of brisk business. As the heat penetrates, it surprisingly gets busy. Everything from pedestrians, donkeys, tourist vans, and buggies circumvent this open square. But, something different lies just beyond the setting sun.... this square becomes electrified! The story tellers come, the snake charmers play their mesmerizing tunes, women offering to henna plumped from heat hands, and the best part, all the wonderful food vendors set up shop! Tajine, couscous, fish of all sorts, harissa sauce for dipping bread, mixed salads, sweets and all vendors vying for your business! #1 is great, #20 is accommodating when doing take out and escaping back to your riad to eat in peace, #65 has a very lovely host, not too agressive. What a spectacle, not for all. But, one must experience this incredible world. I love this Square and Medina for all those opposing things, the energy, aggressiveness and plentitude. The incredible beauty of everywhere one looks. The old muslim culture grasping for it's place within it's modern culture. The textures, rich color, and scents. A must see!

If you're going to Marrakech you have to come here.. What is a visit to this wonderful city without coming here! It's great during the day time and at night it's lit up and there are many activities. Make sure you bargain for a great price on the items you buy.

Catch the vibrancy of the square.. I think that travellers should visit the square at least once in their lives. There is much to dazzle the senses. I have been to Marrakesh several times, and always get the feeling that I am intruding on something personal to the local population. Stopping for a better look at anything results in requests for money. The orange juice seller at #44 yelled all kinds of English obscenities at us when we paused to buy from his neighbour. After the tirade, he tried to wave us over. We were well treated by all vendors in the souks quite well. My friend encountered some trouble when she was taking photos of some inanimate objects: olives and pottery--no people in the photo, but vendors reacted as if she had insulted them.I do not like to see chained monkeys. After visiting the monkeys in the Atlas Mountains, it is disconcerting to see them confined and enduring the blistering pavement.I have yet to find a food stall that is tasty, and will avoid them on future trips.
Total Mayhem - but fascinating. You can't go to Marrakech without coming here. Sit on the first floor of one of the cafes (no alcohol) and watch it all going on. You won't believe it!
A spectacle for the senses. What a crazy place! Shop, eat, and indulge your senses here. Come at night to eat at one of the many many stalls that set up at night.

Pretty cool. Just like the movies with the snakes and all the stalls. I loved it, and we weren't hassled either. Just don't take pictures of the snakes, monkey’s or the Bedouin people in costume unless you are ready to pay them a tip. They will run after you for money. In the stalls, just tell them what you will pay and haggle, if you don’t like the deal, or feel overwhelmed, just walk away and say “no shukran”. Most of the time, you will pay what you want.

Crazy in a good way. This marketplace has to be seen to be believed and I'm glad we experienced it, but it was quite confronting at times and tiring.Between the sheer volume of people, motorbikes and scooters darting this way and that and the sights and smells your senses will be overloaded. Beware though, you need to keep your wits about you. Nothing is for free, the guy who pops his hat on your head and says he wants to be in your photo for free will change his mind the minute the flash goes off. I would recommend avoiding walking between the area of sit-down food stalls if you aren't looking to buy anything. We had a crappy experience just strolling through there where a waiter ran up and asked for money for cokes we had bought earlier on in the day elsewhere, and then another waiter conveniently came to our "aid" and we were soon tightly surrounded by all these staff. When we walked away from them my partner realised the money belt hidden under his t-shirt was halfway open, and we recalled that just before the first waiter asked for money another had rubbed my partner's belly in passing and yelled "we need to fatten this one up". Code? Who knows. We were lucky that time.I also had a woman start drawing on me with henna without warning or permission, which gave me a fright. Gear yourself up to say "La shukran" (no thank you) to the many people who will try to lead you to and from Jemaa el Fna, you just have to keep doing what you're doing and be polite but firm until they leave you be (they want money for helping you).Enjoy!

Madness. This place is chaotic madness which works. Can't wait to go again one day, perhaps eat in one of the restaurants looking down on it.Notes: Keep your wits and watch your change. It is expected that you tip, 10mad mostly, if you take photos of performers, snake charmers, calligraphers etc etc

give it a go. Great place to visit,always something going on. Admitedly the scooters do get on your nerves a little wizzing past but thats their way of life.The square is full on during the evening and you must experience the food from the stalls.Its all part of the marrakech experience.Food here is very cheap under £10 inc drinks for two people.The snake charmers and bands are just trying to earn some money,but i didn't venture too close.I would say keep away from the HENNA TATOO girls as they try to grab your hand,design a lucky flower on you for free then want you to pay them when you have said NO several times,just walk away and do NOT pay them unless you agree a price before they start.If you do want to shop ,head towards the goverment store and shop in that area as its loads cheaper than the square.You may have to walk about 5mins away but it will be so worth it.

Square of Despair. As with elsewhere in the city, there are too many hustlers to relax, let alone enjoy this place. Snake charmers do nothing exciting- just put a snake around your neck and charge for photos. Henna women graffiti your hand- whether you ask them to or not. Musicians are sub-par- if you linger for a moment, you will be expected to pay. Resteraunts charge upwards of the going rate.... Obviously. if you're a woman, don't be surprised if you get your bum pinched. Otherwise, it's fine.
CRAZYYY. You need to have patient! Everything happens in this place, you will find people, cars, motorcycles, horse carriages, snake charmers, restaurants, street vendors. But it is a: must go!

A fun place to eat - basically.... Be prepared for heads of lamb lying next to a lamb barbecue, motor scooters almost running over you in the small streets of the souk on your way to that main square...We arrived at the airport, unloaded our baggage at the hotel and then and went on Jemaa el Fna square for dinner. We parents loved it, for the children this kind of start into a foreign culture was a bit heavy! So if you are travelling with children, maybe don't eat there the first evening, but let them go acquainted with moroccan culture before you do it.

A big maze. me and my husband felt everyone just wanted to rip us off with everything. Luckily i believe i am brilliant at haggling the prices down. We bought a few watches and handbags but the quality isn't as good as dubai! The food in the evening out in the square wasn't special. He gave us extra food even though we didn't request it and still charged us. We ended up paying 200dh for two kebabs,two chips and a bit of salad, so you know we truley got ripped off.The first day we got there i didn't like it at all and was quite scared as beggers would follow and watch you get cash from the ATM machine. after a few trips to the market i soon got use to it. We only got lost there once. You definatley need a good sense of direction as its like one big maze!! Overall, just be careful with your handbag and belongings and always haggle down to atleast a third of their original price, if you even pretend to walk out if they don't give you the price they want, it always works. They end up calling you back into the shop.
