Go at least once. It is amazing, and also a bit intimidating, especially at night. We went twice, and had dinner on the second visit at stall 31, which did very good sausages and chicken tagine. We were lucky enough to sit with a local girl and her mother who we chatted to whilst we ate. Very cheap food although the smoke from all the cooking can get a bit overwhelming.
This is it!. Get ready for non stop drums, acrobats, snakes, monkeys, fire-blowing and whatever circus you like, followed by the best food selection ever. Life itself :)
an absolute must!. This is the center piece of the city. It is hard to miss and it should not be missed. Also check out the nearby ruins.

Heart of Marakech. The square is the heart of the medina. It is a wonderful place to visit with children. Mine were mesmerised by the snake charmers and the monkeys, the musicians, the traditional dancers, the fresh orange juice stalls and thoroughly enjoyed the horse and carriage trip. The sounds and smells are truly authentic and worth the visit!
The worst place in Morocco. Everyone wants money from you. Bad people around. My big disappointment after seeing lots of places in Morocco.

The best square in Morocco. This was our nightly entertainment in Marrakech. We would buy dinner, fresh orange juice and wander through the square watching street performers, snake charmers, henna artists, fortune tellers and more. Enjoy the opportunity to mingle with the locals. As a tourist, don't be annoyed by everyone shouting to you and trying to sell their wares; they are just trying to make a living and "no thank you" is a perfectly valid response if you aren't interested.

not the same as it was. I came back to Marrakech after 15 years: many things have changed, in a positive way. But Jemaa el Fna has lost some of its magic: less interesting people, less show and crazy things to see, the square is invaded by the eating stalls, with nhuge plastic covers and long sitting banks, which have nothing typical nad surely nothing magic. Not even the food is as good as it was before. A pity!

You get hassled a lot!. A must place to visit especially on the way to the Souk. Not very pleasant due to all the very poorly treated animals around and people hassling you for money to take photographs with them.

Main square. This main square is very open and spacious. I expected it to be packed with people, but due to the size and location of the stalls, you can walk around comfortably. The atmosphere is very nice and if you pop into Snack7Saint you can get a nice mint tea and free wifi. Make sure to sit row 2 or further unless you want to spend your time being hassled by cigarette/tissue sellers. The orange juice sellers will shout at you to get your attention and you will find for the first few hours you respond to the shouting but you'll soon learn to ignore or say a firm 'Non'. Especially the henna tattooists are very persistent and will grab your hand. From here onwards wander into the beautiful souks. Should you wish to have a breather; the main square is signposted in several placea in the souks.

The heart of Marrakech. No visit to Marrakech would be complete without a trip to this Square . Go just before Sunset and pick a rooftop bar to watch the sun go down and then take a stroll through the Square and taste, smell and see Marrakech.

Atmospheric. Walk through and be amazed. Prepare to be approached by men with snakes and monkeys (poor animals). They will ask for money if you are taking photos. It is a place that is a must-see but on my trips to Marrakech I never dally long as it's chaotic. Try the fresh orange juice. Eat at least once at the stalls in the evening. Have a mint tea on one of the terraces outside just off the square. Savour the experience but keep your wits about you.

Very good place. This is a great place to visit. If you are in Marrkesh, this place is a must see location. iTS very cultural and very busy. just beware of being conned by the horse riders. 100 Dirhams is farrrr too much for that
Only at night. The food stalls at night is a must do as the food is cheap, good and the atmosphere execellent. During the day the area was fairly boring.
Really spectacular!. - Snakecharmers, exotic potions, music, noise, bicycles, mopeds & people everywhere. A bit difficult to find a decent meal to a good price ...

Great atmosphere. So much fun wandering around the square, taking pictures and chatting to the traders. Be sure to ask before you take pics of peoples stalls as they can often be quite offended or annoyed if you don't.
Had merguez sausages and salsa for dinner from one stall, delicious!

It all happens here!. Of course, the Place Jemaa el Fna is touristy, snake charmers, tame monkeys, whirling dervishes, tooth-pullers (I didn't see any but believe they are there!) are not really part of authentic everyday Moroccan life, but what fun! In the evening tantalising smells (amazing how fried onions can get those taste buds salivating!) waft from every one of dozens of tents, unfortunately the quality of the tent food seldom matches the aromas. There are plenty of restaurants surrounding the square where you can eat reasonably, drink well and watch the life beyond. At no time did we feel unsafe, interesting that my husband's iphone beeped unprompted with the information that 5 minutes ago the Place Jemaa el Fna contained 41,369 people! Beware of the henna hawkers, they are apt to grab your hand, ignore your protests and quickly entwine dots, tendrils and flowers along your fingers saying "For luck, for luck", then demand 100 dirhams - for luck!

Just get lost and relax. When in the souks and the jemaa, just relax and enjoy people asking you into their little shops. We were not hassled at all. We did get lost an a local did show us the way to where we wanted to go and we gave him a 20 dirham tip (about £1.50). Enjoy the banter and don't be scared.

Amazing experience. Very busy, try to get on the rooftop terrece of nearby eateries to experience sunset here, everybody is trying to make a buck here, but the women doing the henna tattoos are the only ones who are in your face, cant see how it can be justified as a world heritage site, but great experience.

The food stalls in Djemma Al Fna. The food stalls in the main square are really good value and have great food, if you want fish go to number 14, but be prepared to speak french as they don't speak English. You can tell they are good because its always full of local people.Number 1 is also good and has an extensive menu of meat and fish, and they do speak English.For afters you will be hard pressed to beat going to the spiced cardamon tea and cake stalls, these are situated on the edge of the food stalls looking over the main square where the snake charmers etc ply there trade.And for the adventurous among you, you have to try the snails cooked in a lovely spiced broth. Once tried never forgotten.Have fun.......

Find your way by day, get lost and love it by night.... First, try to have your first encounter with the jemaa el fna during the day...it is helpful to be able to orient yourself before you get there at night! Daytime is interesting...monkey people, snake people, henna people...all vying for your attention and your dirhams. The orange juice stands are good, especially stand number 44, and just what the doctor ordered. Visit the dentist after...definitely NOT what your dentist ordered! Admire the piles of teeth and be glad you brush and floss. If you don't already you will after! Then nighttime...the food stands are plentiful, loud, smoky, and all will have young men trying to get you to eat at their stand. The place itself is packed with 10,000 of your best friends....and dancers and musicians and motorcycles and donkey carts and cars....all in one place. Pay the price of admission to get a view from the upper deck of one of the restaurants...you have to buy at least a drink before they will let you in at night....wait your turn and then jockey for a front row table...and then turn on the video on your camera...when you get home you might THEN be able to describe the chaos and the adventure to your friends!

Food choices. Tagines everywhere and fresh orange juice. A great food market at night lots of options and very good prices. We went vegatarian to be on the safe side, even though i am not a veggie i loved the market food. Good taste, good value alot like a stew. We also went berber dancing in the square great fun.

Not for me. Before I came to Marrakech everyone was talking about this square. I personally did not like it as much, I can't really enjoy spectacles using animals and there were too many touristst and too much hassle.

WOW!. Possibly the busiest square I have ever been to!By day it is filled with snake charmers and henna ladies. Be sure to ask for a price before hand, or they may try and charge you 200 Dirhams simply for a photo, which you may have been dragged in to, the actual going rate is a tenth of that.By night it fills with 100s of food stalls and all of Marrakech descends on the square. Pop yourself in to one of the roof top panoramic restaurants and enjoy the displays!

One. For Bucket List. As others have said must be done - you need to visit at least twice the day is good but the night food stalls even better. Also as others have said look out for Henna women & the Monkey men both are very aggresive and very very difficult to get rid. Two women grabbed my partner & pulled her away before i realised. There is no such thing as a tester - i had to get very aggresive & gave in a luttlr because it was upsetting my partner - guys do not let them near your loved ones unless you are willing to part with 100 - 300 D for a bad job!!! In the good side the noise the smells & the atmosphere wonderful. Cafe France Balcony great place to sit & sosk up the view - without being bothered nice change sometimes- & food is Ok but not great

A must do while in Marakkech. This city square is always bustling with people and action. An experience everyone must have while in Marrakech. Beware as there is no real road and mopeds, bikes and carriages are going everywhere with no regard for people in the way. There are snake charmers, exotic animals who will pose for pictures at the right price, Henna tattoo artists. All street performers are always watching to make sure you are not trying to take a picture. If they catch you they will chase you speaking in arabic asking for money, so be prepared to pay. Do be aware of your surroundings as this place is an ideal spot for pick pockets. I had a lock on my bag and did not have any issues. Watching the sunset from one of the patios is a must. You have to purchase at least a drink to sit. Prepare to negotiate for everything from vendors. I purchased two small hats that were originally priced at 260dh and I got for 40dh.
It may shock you. Whilst this is a great spectacle its not for the squeamish. Seeing monkeys tied up with a chain was not quite our thing

Be careful !. During both day and night this square is busy with people, cars, horses and carriages, mopeds and all manner of exotic animals. While interesting you need to have your wits about you. Pick pockets operate here especially in the night market and with so many distractions its easy to get caught out ! All kinds of transport will not stop or get out of your way and snakes and monkeys are everywhere. The ladies doing henna on your hands will just grab you and do it then demand money afterwards, and any photos you take of these exotic sights money will be demanded for too so enjoy but be careful. The Tourist police are there if the worst happens, so do report anything to them if you need to.

Marrakech at its best. There is nothing like the Jemaa el Fna at night! Smoke, drums, bands, food, vendors, storytellers, monkeys, and snake charmers with cobras! It's just fun to walk around and look. We ate dinner at a restaurant with rooftop dining that overlooked it and had fun.

Negotiate and stay safe. Go with a whole day as very time consuming but worth it as great atmosphere. Prices are always set high so be prepared to negotiate hard but try not to insult them as they take it personally. There are also loads of pick pockets so be very careful and take only what you need, I found dividing your money in different pockets helped so even when you took some out it didn't look like you had a lot. Remember for every shop that has something you like there are always atleast four others that have the same.

A Culture trip. Mainly comes alive at night and there are some great views from the restaurant terraces, but be advised to book or arrive early if the want a good seat. Word of warning if you take pictures of the snake charmers or African dancers, expect the pay - keep a few coins in the pocket as they wont' let you off lightly. The fresh orange juice from the stalls is delicious!
need to be seen. Djemaa el fna needs to be seen as this is emblematic square of Marrakech :)like a lot the organe juice stands where you can enjoy a organe juice for 4 dhs!
a touristic "must". although meanwhile very touristic, its a special place in this oriental world where one can visit from the restaurant's roof gardens thosemanifold artists, players and local life

Impressive at night. During the day the place is not very interesting but at night it gets really busy: there are story tellers, restaurant stands, other types of acting, games to play.....I really thought it was great but after an hour or so it was enough for me: a lot of people and especially at the restaurant stands they were quite aggressive in trying to acquire customers.

Go for atmosphere not for food. Busy and there's lots to soak up but the food stalls in the evenings are a rip off- food is average at best and more expensive than eating in a little restaurant, which would frankly be a lot nicer. Wander around and experience it and then go elsewhere.

Circus square. There are three things to do on Djemaa el Fna
1) Have a meal or a drink on a terrace overlooking the square (no alcohol anywhere in the square)
2) Eat street food from the numerous stalls, especially at night
3) Watch street entertainers: drummers, snake charmers, henna ladies, and so on. Drum circles are popular
market square. very busy especially at night..snake charmers,etc...but again if you like something different and hectic..this is it.

Smells sights and sounds!. We had previously been to Istanbul so I think it helped us prepare for this! Yes you get hassled but once we said no they left us alone. We found them quite amusing..."Cheap as chips! Asda prices" they quite liked it if you were 'cheeky' back. Of course you have to have your wits about you as with any city. It's a mix of horse and carriages scooters snake charmers, entertainers, water carriers, food and drink stools. You can eat a starter and main course for 2 people at around £7!I would recommend 'Chez Chegrouni' near Cafe de France-very cheap and tasty-you are given a piece of paper to write your order on. Would recommend going through the week as apposed to over a weekend when it's a little less busy. Some of the signs in the Souks are mis-leading-they point to the square being in the opposite direction to what it is. There is certainly never a dull moment in Jemaa el Fna!

Shopping and Snakes. By Moroccan standards this felt fairly safe - but I'd still keep a close eye on your wallet. It is interesting, there are plenty of shops and easy for the inexperienced to get ripped off. In fact you will get ripped off, it is really just to what degree... But, enjoy the experience.The actual square is best at dusk or evening with the snake charmers and other attractions, best to take some time and absorb the atmosphere...

This place is like being in a strange dream its a total head rush!. In the day this square appears like any other, come back at night mad berber drumming and tribal dancers send you into a trance! crowds and crowds of people, stalls and stalls selling everything from oranges to dried dates to oraments. Snake charmers, monkeys on leads its totally crazy, mad buzzing and beating like your heart after too much strong coffee. And in the centre are bench after table after bench of food stalls. However couple things to watch for are pick pockets one put their hand in my back pocket, silly fool never put anything in there. And the food is not clean at the stalls, got bad screaming Abdabs and vomitting at the airport on the way home!! was not much fun! But generally Jemaa El Fna was marrakech for me, nothing else compared.....

Beware henna ladies. We are 2 females. Each time we ventured into Jemaa el Fna we were accosted by the Henna Ladies. They continually grabbed hold of our arms trying to give us a free gift of a henna flower. They don't take NO for an answer, very persistent. We had to keep turning and walking away, not conducive to sight seeing. Also note when walking around the old town; the touts approach you pretending they work at your hotel and have just come off shift and although you don't recognise them, they recognise you and they would be so happy to show you the Berber exhibition which is on for this day only !!
All they say and more. Sights and sounds and smells - assault on all senses - completely worth the visit ... over and over - went each night and was not disappointed

Great experience especially in the evening. We visited during the day and were a little underwhelmed but when we returned in the evening it had changed completely with loads of entertainers , meal stalls, lots of lights and hundreds of people. We went onto one of the square's cafe's upper terrace. (be prepared to pay a little more for your drinks) - but it is worth it to take in all the sights without any hassle( not that we experienced much hassle as it was nearly all good natured competition between the stall holders. The prices for food and drink at the stalls or the surrounding cafes was very reasonable.

The square comes alive at night!. Jemma el Fna is a great place to spend the day and night. We walked into the square when we first arrived and had a drink at Cafe De'France to take it all in. At night time the square comes alive with performers, street food and market sellers. We ate at No.15 and No.25 - both were good, No.25 being better but more expensive. Dinner is around 200dirhams which includes bread,olives, water, and a great selection of moroccan dishes. Be weary of the snake charmers and locals who try to approach you with Atlas monkeys. My boyfriend just responded to a hello from one local and before he knew it, had a monkey on his shoulders!!

Great food & atmosphere at the night market. The food at the night market was so good that we ate there twice. Though not having the luxury of a sit down restaurant, there's several stalls to choose from and there's lots of variety. The cous cous and kebab dishes were great. I was concerned that we may get ill from eating here, but didn't at all. The atmosphere is great and some of the best food on our trip was eaten here at a very low price. It's ideal to eat here, enjoy the entertainment on the square and then head off for cocktails.

Amazing. Wonderful place.... MUST SEE.... big open market square full of people and tourists.... so much activity, so much to see, to try...Be carefull when taking photos or some people will ask you for money afterwards... also be aware of henna tatoo women as they start the tatoo without asking as a free gift that you must pay ¿?¿?¿I recommend to try fresh orange juices...really nice taste and cheap price...and avoid to eat at the market central restaurants as the food is really bad.

Soul of the city. This place represents, with no doubts, Marrakesh city itself. Is good for walking, seeing, shopping minor things, eating at huge tables, admiring snake charmers, etc. Also choose a riad nearby to see and hear, when do you want, its noises, views, places - unforgettable experiences.

Must visit the Jemaa el Fna... is really Marrakech!!! . What can anybody say about this square.... Unique square that compines tourists from all over world, locals that sell anything you can imagine (leather things, souvenirs, plants, fresh orange juice, vegetables) , animals (horses, snakes, monkeys). Probably you will feel like playing in a movie or you are back 20-30 years. It's a life time experience and worth the visit 100%. After finish looking around you can take a car with horses (we pay 50drm. each) and drive us to Bahia Palace. You can see and admire the Chaos of the roads (cars, horses, motors, people mixed together and try to reach their destination)

Enjoy being scammed and hassled constantly? Then this is the place for you!. Our first night at the Jemaa el Fna consisted of the multiple food stalls vying for our business. which included people sticking menus in our faces or literally blocking our path away from them. We were convinced to stop at a stall by a friendly young man who insisted this was a family run business with good cheap food. Unfortunately he was a complete liar as him and his wonderful family attempted to bring us multiple things we didn't order, and when we walked off refusing to pay for anything all we saw was his chimpanzee-like grin learning at us from afar. If you come into contact with this fellow, AVOID!

what a place !. snakes, monkeys, magicians, comedians, dancers, musicians !!! walk and enjoy the show :) they will harass you for money or make the monkey jump on you, just have a good laugh and keep walking :) be prepared to be harassed :) and its a must visit during the night as well !!! orange juice is really fresh :)

A bizarre experience. Jemaa el Fna square is one of the most bizarre place I've ever seen. Full of locals and tourists, lots of cars and motorbikes on the streets around it. On the square itself, you'll find locals with monkeys, snake charmers, henna tattoos, all trying to get a buck out of you. Once you cross it, you'll find 3 big hallways were the "bazaar" starts.Word of advice if you want to take some pictures, stay on the other side of the street near the postal office and you'll be able to take good pictures from monkeys or snakes if you have a zoom, and not be bothered by the charmers. They won't cross the street.

Crazy, but magical!. A crazy crazy square - full of noise, colors, smells! Do try the fresh orange juice it's lovely! Keep safe at night and look after your belongings when walking in such a busy area.
god awful place. charged £6 to take a pic of snake, they tried to charge £20 and only after an argument was it less, very nasty hostile atmosphere. rip off area basically!

Interesting but be careful. You kind of have to go to the square for the experience but be careful and be very strict with your money. If someone has already taken photos with you or painted henna on your arm without asking you, there's very little they can do other than curse at you if you refuse to pay the full extortionate prices they are asking. It didn't feel particularly unsafe, just not very comfortable.

Photographers can have a field day here. This place is like a circus. In the daytime (and in the heat) there are acrobats, jugglers, snake charmers and folks doing anything they can to catch your eye so they can get a few Dirhams from you - but it sure is colorful. In the evening it is a bit more quiet with a lot of locals peddling there wares.

The Wild West... be prepared, and have fun!. The Djemaa El Fna square is a madhouse. You need to go into this knowing what to expect and mentally prepare yourself... otherwise you will probably not have a good experience. Expect people to ask for change constantly... and when you give it to them they will probably keep asking for more. And expect everyone except the food vendors to ask at least 10 times what something is worth. I didn't bother to barter with the food vendors... but I did with everything else. An example of the way the performers do business is the snake charmers. We stopped to look at them, because I know a little about snakes and wanted to see what they had. They had puff adders and Cobras (probably Egyptian cobras), lizards and a hawk and were playing a little horn. We were immediately given a warm welcome and I had a (non-venomous) snake tossed around my neck, and the guy took pictures of us, and everything seemed fine, with him taking pictures of us. Then he pressed the snake's head against me and my traveling companion wishing us wealth and a happy life etc... after about two minutes of hanging out with us, the guy said "how about you give me 300 Dirham for this experience"... to which I replied with absolute awe followed by a hearty laugh and a "What now?" He was asking for over $35 for spending two minutes with us. I offered him 40 (which in retrospect was more than I should have paid)... which he told me was "nothing" and he wanted 300. I told him he could have the 40 and he said "No". So I started to walk away, then he grabbed the 40 out of my hand and looked at me with disgust as he walked off. The same thing will happen with everything... if you take a picture of the snakes, or monkeys, or even someone painting Henna on another tourist... expect them to ask for a ridiculous amount of money "for the picture" or "the experience". Expect people to physically step into your path of travel, and try to herd you into their shop... maybe even grabbing you by the hand and pulling you in. Expect people to non-stop jump in front of you and tell you they have the best restaurant or food stall and try to seat you. That's pretty much all the bad...The good... this place really is an "experience". I think it's incredible... although I wouldn't want to spend more than a couple hours in the square in a stretch even if I were sitting at a foodstall and eating during that time. The "wild west" atmosphere really wears you down... but you can get fairly good deals on things... usually better from the people without stores who just have their wares spread out on blankets. If you see something you would like think how much would I pay for that at home (do a quick money conversion in your head 10 to 1 for Euro or 8.5 to 1 for US Dollars) then offer them about a quarter what you would pay at home. They might laugh, one of them even told me "go get some sleep you're obviously tired... this is good quality" but you come up a little, get to just under half what you would pay for it at home and then say "No? Ok... then I can't afford it. Sorry we can't do business." Then walk out of the store. If you don't leave the store before they accept your offer, you aren't getting a good price. The food vendors are all pretty good, especially the guys with dried fruit and nuts. Those are incredible!So prepare yourself mentally and venture off into the square for an hour or two at a time, taking breaks in restaurants or ice cream parlors along the outside of the square. It really is a neat, albeit tiring experience!

The very best type of chaos..... Great,Great fun.....but don't go half hearted. The reputation of the square is well deserved, it is pure theatre,from snake charmers and drummers to acrobats and dancers.Don't expect not to get hassled for something or another,but that is all part of the fun......remember "la shukran" (no thank you) and keep walking !The best time to go is just before dusk.... its absolutely electric and great to try a mint tea or coffee on one of the roof terrace cafes.... you won't be dissapointed

Must see when in Marrakech. Okay, this place is a nightmare to find. You will hear Moroccan's screaming "square, square, this way, this way". Much of the time i think they're trying to get you purposely lost in the Souks. One chap said he would show us, naively we accepted, and then he harassed us for payment. The people of Marrakech turn what should be a nice city into a threatening one and i won't go back. Having said all of this, Jemaa el Fna is worth a visit. There are restaurants surrounding the square and at night there are hundreds of stalls that sell food - go for it and try some! I had about 20 guys try to sell me weed :s and had a monkey jump on my head... interesting to say the least. The square actually gives a bit of calm from the Souks which are a nightmare to navigate.

A place like no other, It´s just got to be done!. Since childhood I was intrigued by Arabian tales which told of a land so strange, so different and so far, far away which I longed to see. Last week my partner made my wish come true, so there I stood, speechless in the pulsating dizziness of Jemaa El Fna and now I know that it was worth the wait. It is an indescribable, magical & re-active place, everyone you speak to experiences it in a different way.I suppose it´s a bit like marmite, you either love it and embrace it there and then with all its facets, or you hate it - we love marmite! And now we love moroccan pancakes and the little morrocan girl that simply took my hand to lead me safely across the invisible road that seems to run right through the square (I received the biggest smile for giving her 1Dh reward) and the marrocan shopkeeper who after accepting that we simply could not fit his ware into our luggage opted to discuss how Marrakesh has evolved over the past 50 years and I could go on and on. However, you will probably want to check it out for yourself.

Great food & drink - avoid the Henna women. Ate with the locals for next to nothing - drank fresh juice each day. observed a lot and didnt get too much hassle - all good humoured apart from the henna women. We listened to one of them offer her service then was surrounded by 3 women and 2 men demanding 60 euros for the tester she had applied. Was extremely difficult to get away ( we are quite experienced and happy to pay for a service and a bit of banter). We then watched them effectively rob people. It was frightening to see people being physically sat down and henna being applied then being surrounded. This was the only thing we saw that was upsetting.
a must. surprising, tantalizing, even scary square. magicians, vendors, all kinds of shows. Impressive. Like going back to medieval times.
Go at night. Jemaa el Fna is exactly what you expect to see in Morocco, snake charmers, dancers, peddlers of any / everything.

Chaotic. You have to visit the square if you come to Marrakech. Its quite scary at first, but you soon get used to it and nerves settle. However, the traders and hawkers can be very aggressive, as other reviewers have noted. We didn't avoid the monkey man, and got into quite an argument over the cost of a photo. And I ended up buying a huge and expensive bag of nuts from another trader. Overall though, its a unique experience you won't forget in a hurry.

Wildest place in Morocco. Be prepared to have all your senses assaulted when you reach the heart of Marrakesh - the square Jemaa el Fna. Snake charmers, monkey trainers and food stalls all vie for your attention but oh, what a lovely way to feel alive. If you love fish, try booth #14. Enjoy!
Crazy!. Exactly as I thought it would be. Sights, sounds and smells like no other place I've visited. Just be wary of the crazy moped riders!

Great square, eat at one of the stalls in the evening.. This is a bit touristy but we still loved it! Great place to people watch to just take in a different way of life. Highlight was returning one evening and eating in one of the mobile restaurants, loads get set up every evening serving traditional food. Those meals are so cheap, we paid about £4 each for a couple of courses and soft drinks. I'd avoid eating in the restaurants overlooking the square - food is OK but over-priced for what it is. Fascinating square.

A good place to watch tourists. There were lots of these here, so one could observe how they dressed (the Japanese are usually super chic) and try to identify their languages. The snakes, though charmed by pipe playing, scared me. One can find many products made in China here. The sidewalk cafes and restaurants that I tried were good.

As original as can be!. This is the great square of Marrakech medina and lies in the center of the city. This is an experience everyone should live at least once - it is as original as it gets. Try to come at different times during the day, in the morning it is quite calm with only the fresh orangejuice vendors here, but as the day progress, os does the life of this place. In the afternoon you will find a mix of storytellers (if you know arabic, do not miss their stories!), hennapainters, snakecharmers and gerrabs (men in bright red clothes selling water). When the sun sets, the foodstalls is put up and come to life and part of the square turns to be a huge openair restaurant. Come and feel the moroccan ambiance at it´s best!
Amazing and Mad. Avoid the Monkey menHead towards stall no. 1 for dinner, Hassan was a charming host and the food was yummy
Thousands of people!. We went even though we don't like crowds - sit on the terrace of a restaurant and watch the show below. An amazing spectacle.
an absolute must. fun - wild - dive in! Have a plan and try to visit in the late afternoon when all the food vendors are cooking up a storm and charming passer bys to dine with them.
amazing!. its amazing! the hustle and bustle, the street sellers, the food markets, the little street theatre type skits that take place at night! Great fun!

An assault on the senses. This square is unbelievable & "an assault on the senses". From the moment you get off the bus or out of the taxi the noise sucks you in & the sheer volume of people mesmerises you. I've no idea how many people are there: probably 5,000????? There's every kind of local entertainment you could dream of from urchins selling chewing gum to snake charmers by the dozen.It is pointless me descibing it further - it is something everyone should witness first-hand. And then onwards into the winding passage ways of the souk.....Just do it..............!!!!!!!

OK for those not spooked by snakes... This legendary square has been much eulogised, and it is certainly worth a visit [for all the reasons so regularly rehearsed here]. If you're frightened of snakes, or phased by heaving throngs of people, it is a nightmare!

Better than expected!. We were expecting to get a lot of hassle at Jemaa el Fna. Although we did get a little, it is not nearly as bad as we had imagined. It is far less chaotic and busy than we thought - our kids happily and safely ran around (although you do need to watch for scooters coming from all directions). We had dinner at food stall no.1 (recommended by our Riad) a couple of nights and service was fast and very polite - and the food was good at a very reasonable price. Our kids had their iPads out while we dined and it felt perfectly safe and OK to do that.Overall, we really loved it (although we hated the men with the chained monkeys, hence a 4 rating and not a full rating)

Real Marrakech. Overwhelming in terms of the noise and bustle. It was not liked by my young children who didn't like the noise and the pestering. One henna lady was especially aggressive, painting the henna on despite protestations. The monkeys didn't look well cared for and the snakes downright scarey! However it was colourful and exciting. We retreated to a rooftop cafe to admire from a distance!

Literature coming to life. The Jemaa el Fna gets a recommendation not because of its cleanliness or beauty or for anything it can offer (except for the fresh orange juice vendors - my idea of paradise). It gets five stars because it is just as the books about Marrakesh describe it. The vendors, snake charmers, water sellers all come to life as you walk around the square. The cafes which line the square have all been mentioned in some guide or novel. You will get accosted for your custom. If you are averse to this, an idea would be to head to a nearby cafe and witness the action from the relative safety of its roof terrace.

The best square in the world. Just before I travelled to Marrakech, I had read somewhere that this was 'the best square in the world'. I imagined this to be an exaggeration on things. After checking into the Riyadh in the Medina (the historic centre), we proceeded to make our way to the Jemaa el Fna through packed streets. This had made me feel stressed and nervous at first and had made me want to leave the city as soon as possible. However, on finally reaching the Jemaa el Fna, my stress had turned to amazement and joy. This square is so full of life, with various local North African cultures gathering in the square almost 24 hours a day to sell their goods. The colours, lights, smells, etc. are all a joy to investigate. The people are also very friendly. Should you want to escape the square for a bit, there are plenty of restaurants around the square to choose from and to look out over the amazing atmosphere of the square. This is particularly great when the prayer calls are coming from the mosques surrounding the Jemaa al Fna. The souks with their amazing array of goods are also just off the square adding to its appeal. This square is so full of life, I had to get my last fill of this at great atmosphere once again before we departed on our last day.

Crazy and exciting. Love or hate this place you cannot fail to be impressed by the immense size of this square. It's huge and at first glance overwhelming. There is everything on offer here from traditional music, food of all varieties, henna ladies, animals and endless amounts of people and noise. Some of the hawkers - particularly the henna ladies - can be a bit pushy but as long as you are firm but polite then they soon drift on to someone new. We've never risked eating food from the stalls but it's great fun walking round watching all the side shows and the locals. Tamer during the day but quite frenzied at night. Make sure you have an agreed meeting point in case you get separated from friends or family and keep a tight grip on children. One man threw a monkey at our daughter which she instinct lay caught which I did find worrying as it didn't look too happy. Have your wits about you but definitely go - it's a terrific experience

A gap in the sunless souk. A chance to examine purchases in daylight. Cafe des Épices, the more charming sister operation to Terrasse des Épices, is here.And there's another chance to get that henna tattoo/beanie/fez...

Aminated. The square was lovely. When I visited the first time, there were tons of people and performers. It was great to be able to interact with them. Unfortunately on this trip the performers were on strike so they weren't out to be seen. There are also lovely places to stop for a drink or lunch when you need a break while exploring the city.

Not for the faint hearted. The square is every bit as mental as you would expect. Take your time to explore and see the sites and then have a coffee in one of the restaurants with a terrace and watch it all unfold. The sights and smells are mesmorising and exhausting!

Slight dissapointment. For years I have thought this place would be an amazing visit but it did not live up the expectations, just noisy and busy on a Saturday evening. If you hire a bicycle and cycle around you won't get stopped by hawkers.

No. 14 for Fresh Fish. I had read somewhere that No. 14 is the best stall for fresh fish, and it really is - plus extremely good value and great staff - go early as there is always a queue to eat here - but really worth the wait... the fish is brought fresh from Essaouira on the coast every day and quite delicious with yummy chips and saucers of pulverised fresh tomatoes and similarly served obergines. Our next best choice is No.1 for regular vegetable and meat tagines - just as good this year in 2013 as it was in 2011 when we were last there.
Shoppers Paradise. Take some time and wander deep into the Souk. There are fewer tourists, better bargains and a more relaxed atmosphere.

A cacophony of sound and smells. You need to go back at different times of the day because it changes in character between the day and night markets. Lots of fun but don't let any of the sellers tell you something is free-it won't be!

Fascinating. During the day, there are snake charmers and stalls in the square, but at night the place comes alive!
A must do, in Marrakech, it's fascinating!

Too many touts to enjoy as much as it should be enjoyed. You really need to be aware of what's going on around you from the first time you visit. Keep your eyes straight ahead and do not show even the slightest interest in the baby animals, the snakes, the henna tattoo designs or the barbary apes, or you will have some very unfriendly, unwelcoming people demanding your money very quickly - and making you feel like you should part with even more of it. You're better to get a few coins and go join in listening to one of the story-tellers, musician groups or actors, even if you can't understand Arabic. Don't get me wrong - you'll still be expected to hand over a few Dirham, but at least you're getting entertainment that nobody else is suffering for (although there can be a degree of racism in some of the acting out, I think). Also, unless you *know* you want to eat, don't bother walking anywhere near the food stalls because you will just get unnecessary hassle. Watch out for the little kids trying to sell you tissues, too - they'll have their hands in your pockets very quickly.It's a great place and you can tell it's oozing with history, but sadly the pressures of poverty combined with the influx of tourism have made this place somewhere you have to be aware of, *beware* of and be wary of all at once.

Must see once - especially at night. This square is bustling with snake charmers and vendors by day, but in the evening the night market takes over with all kinds of food. The only commonality between day and night are the numerous orange juice vendors - and it really is good OJ! At night there are even a row of stalls serving up cooked snails to the hungry masses. It seems people are a bit more liberal at night, as there were fewer jalabas, more PDA, dress codes a bit looser. Wander around and then have dinner at one of the many outdoors restaurants on the second or third floors of the surrounding buildings - the square is great evening entertainment! Taxi's are easy to find a block away, with no wait. The experience can be a bit intense, but is definitely worth it.

Crazy. The Fna square is buzzing with life which changes throughout the day. The temporary eateries that open in the evening are worth a go. Fresh orange juice is gorgeous. I felt sorry for the monkeys on chains and I wasn't keen on the snakes lying around waiting to be charmed for a fee though. There were people dancing, tumblers doing acrobatics and horse drawn carriages queuing up by the hundred waiting for mug tourists. You need to go prepared to say No a lot or have a pocket of small change on you.

This is Marrakesh!. Soak up the atomsphere by having a drink on one of the roof top terraces and watching the sun set over the square. unfortunately did not find the food stalls until after we had eaten on our last evening otherwise would definately have sampled their fayre.

One of a Kind. there is nothing in the world quite like Djemaa el Fna. The main square in Marrakesh, under the watch of the Koutiobia Mosque, never fails to enthrall and amaze. In the daylight watch amazing snake charmers and the generl bustle of the city, (as well as the less brilliant and a bit cruel dancing monkey acts)Then later, watch and the vast stalls and shops set up and sell traditional Harira Soup and Dates. Or go to the other stalls and drink some truly gorgeous fresh orange juice.But the best thing about djemaa el fna is the alround buzz. just wandering around and watching the makeshift stand up comedy circles and traditional bands, as well as the sale of literally everything you could think of all make Djemaa el Fna truly unique, and something yu wont forget in a hurry.

Very atmospheric. The square is huge but very atmospheric. You can easily transport yourself back to ancient times. Good to check out at different times of the day as the vibe changes throughout the day and into the evening.
Crazy and exciting!. Snake-charmers, monkeys, musicians, henna artists, food stalls- it was a wonderful experience. The centre of Marrakech, really comes to life at night.

Lose yourself in the labyrinth of the souk. Endless shops with everything you can imagine for sale! You will get sollicitated from all directions. Bargain hard and hold your price. If you don't get it, another guy down the street will offer the same stuff - try again!

See it at least once. When crowded with drummers,dancers,acrobats,monkeys and snake charmers it's complete madness. But uit's been like that since ancient times and the Moroccans come from all over to see the spectacle.
Food food and more orange juice. Hectic in evening, food quality however excellent on all stalls we ate at. Argue the bill price however. Orange juice men excellent and well worth several visits.

Has to be seen, to be believed. Nothing can prepare you for the assault on your senses of the main square in Marrakech. Get there before dusk to take a drink on the terrace of one of the cafe's that overlook the action and watch as people assemble, and the small businesses set themselves up for the evening - as the lights go on, you'll see story tellers, snake charmers and food stalls setup for the night around the edges of the crazy souks. Only when it gets dark should you venture down into the square to experience the noise and spectacle of the street entertainment, or take a stroll through the food vendors who will try and get you to sit at their stalls in almost every language of the world!If you dare - sample some smoked sheeps head, snail soup - or maybe just some freshly fried fish, grilled meat and cous-cous in the open air stalls that are an amazing sight.An amazing place - worth the trip to Marrakech on its own...
Absoloutley Awesome!. I'll never forget the experience I had here and no words can descirbe what i was feeling you can only know this feeling once you've been nthrough it yourself. Trust me.

A balanced review - gorgeous and worth it, a little bit intimidating but don't let that put you off. This place is worth visiting because it is so iconic, and it really does have a mysterious and exotic atmosphere. Some of it is clearly for tourists but that doesn't really matter. Yes, people are pushy, but everyone except one was genuinely friendly if you were friendly to them and had a (respectful) sense of humour.As a woman I was glad I had covered up (although angry that I had to, but I wanted to feel safe on holiday), and I was especially glad that I had long sleeves to pull over my hands to stop the henna ladies, who will just grab you!We sat in a cafe overlooking the square as the sun set, then had a brief wander round, with an eye on the exit just in case, but there was no need. Be prepared to take a deep breath and dive in.
A day here. You'll need to spend at least a day here to see the surrounding area, eat on the side roads is good. Shopping for bargain leather items.

Crazy market!. We visited the Jemaa el Fna several times in March. It has lots of stands to buy stuff, plenty of food stalls, and is surronded by more restaurants and stores. Fun to visit, and people watch.

Fun amidst chaos. Visit in day and visit in eve when the lights are on - You will see a new place altogether. In the day time, you will find the snake charmers, people in ethnic costumes and lots of activities happening in the square. While at night, its all about the place being lit up, square gets covered will infinite eating stalls and the shops look all lively. But beware of the charmers in the square, even if u click a photograph of the activities happening, they will ask you for money. So, better ask before clicking a pic. In the shops, you can experience considerable bargaining. Prices are quoted much high for the things. But you can easily spend hours and hours in this chaos and still have fun. We went there twice, but still felt was not enough. Also, in the main entrance you will find horse carriages which you can hire for a trip around the city, which is a good experience. But beware of getting cheated in terms of money. They might quote the price for a good distance, but might just take a very short round and get you back.

nice shopping area, has a buzz to it. saw some monkeys on the loose lol. as well as snake charmers. i didn't like the way they would approach you and say, go ahead, take a photo of the snakes. after you do, comes the demands for payment lol. threw some pennies at him. i only like this place due to the horse and carriage stands nearby, offering great scenic routes. we paid 200 dirhams for the carriage ride.

Go at night! Or find a terrace. This square is alive with the energy of Morocco. But beware, if you get too close to the snake charmers or entertainers they are very good at getting your attention and making you pay money. Shopkeepers are also quite aggressive and persuasive.At night, the open air restaurants are in business and it is such an amazing experience, plus extremely cheap.At any time you can also find a terrace to have a berber whiskey (actually just mint tea) or coffee or full meal and admire the bustling square below. But food here is definitely more expensive than in the square.
a must. Great to go before Sunset to overlook it from one of the Cafes which has Rooftop seating. Went by day as well which was a rather quiet atmosphere against the evening buzz .
A one off. Visit the square at all times of the day and see the transformation as the light fades.Recommend eating at one of the many cares or restaurants surrounding the squae

Jemaa el Fna. All the official entertainers were on strike whilst we were there, the story tellers and the snake charmers etc. However there was still so much bustle and character and of course, the traders are all an act in themselves anyway, so we didn't miss them..

Met our expectations. This is exactly what we thought Marrakech would be like - hustle and bustle, glorious smells, vibrant colours and plenty of haggling. Definitely worth going during the day as well as the evening.

A heady mix of fascination and fear, but mostly fascination. A wonderful experience, with a whole lot of crazy going on from morning to night!Snake charmers, witch doctors, fortune tellers and acrobats are just some of the sights you will see during a morning stroll through Jamaa el Fna. The atmosphere in indescribable. At night, food stalls set up -again, a must see and wonderful to walk through and experience the delicious smell of chargrilled food. ( We were not brave enough to eat here though as the hygiene seemed pretty lax)Walk along, buy (haggle) wonderful goods and if it all gets too much, take a break at one of the many cafes to drink utterly delicious mint tea (unlike any other mint tea that I have ever tasted) and watch it all unfolding before you. I look forward to going back.Not recommended for children.Only downside - it is upsetting to see the many stray dogs and cats in bad health and the donkeys and horses don't seem well treated either.

Lovely at night !. The famous square has changed beyond recognition over the years. It is now still atmospheric but no longer has any suppressed air of vice or menace as the tourist police keep a watchful eye.Old hacks will bemoan the passing of more raffish days, but anyone can now get a feeling of old Marrakesh without feeling the slightest bit nervous.Some activity during the day - snake-charmers and traders - but really comes to life in the evening with the local food stall.

Its fun!!!!!. Great place to walk around at night, it full on music, singing, shouting and people trying to sell you something - the food stores a must (at least once) the food may be a bit over done but its tasty, cheap and clean and a great place to watch bewildered travellers all taking it in.

A buzzing hub of color, culture, food and freaks!. JEF was my absolute favorite place to people-watch in Morocco. The square was always buzzing with performers, vendors, food and drink. The square is surrounded with rooftop restaurants and has several entrances to the souks. There are many street performers and if you stop to watch, you should tip. You will be expected to tip if you take a picture or film. I never had a problem with any of the performers but had heard they can be aggressive. Aside from the typical 3rd-world attempts to get you to watch or participate, I found everyone quite pleasant. Many travelers are lured by the aggressive invitations, participate or watch the show, then expect to just walk away. These performers and entertainers are providing a service. If you partake in the service, expect to pay. If you do not want to pay, do not participate or watch from a distance. Nothing is free in Marakkech. Things to look for: OMG check out the tooth-puller! He will have a small table with a blue tablecloth. He will have a huge basket of human teeth and several dental instruments. With sugary dates beings a Moroccan mainstay, rotten teeth were and are quite common. The tooth puller will yank out those baddies right in the square! Snake charmers - they are everywhere but I do not recommend you support their business as the poor animals are exploited and often treated poorly. I've seen these same tricks in India, Central America and Mexico.Belly Dancers! Remember, the Islamic religion requires women to cover everything and abhors the woman who draws sexual attention to herself - as such - look closely at the veiled belly dancers flirting with the men in the crowd and flitting around... awfully tall for women...and not very curvy...why don't they ever say a word? See if you can figure out their secret!Henna: Meh. I don't trust these Henna formulas in the square - you never know what you are going to get and I have heard horror stories about allergic reactions. If you are near the beginning of your trip, it's not worth the risk IMHO. Monkey Men: Do NOT walk close to the men with monkeys on a leash. They will grab you and put the monkey on you. If your companions laugh and snap a picture, you will be expected to pay. Aside from being blind-sided by a monkey, I don't like being hustled into tipping. Also, I feel this is an exploitation of animals who belong in the wild BUT to each their own! Orange Juice!!! I was skeptical about eating/drinking in the square but finally took the plunge and bought the AMAZING orange juice. It was delicious, sweet and I could have drank gallons of it. Don't miss it!!!***Culturally speaking, Moroccans do not like their picture taken without asking and expect a tip if you take a picture of them or their shops/products/performance. If you want to take someone's picture, just ask and give them a few dirhams. Sometimes they will say no - but I never had a bad experience when I was polite enough to ask.***

Ok, people are friendlier then a few years ago. Still a lot of action going on. If you participate in anything agree on money first. Vital! Just walk around and enjoy . Less harassing the a few years ago.

These dysphemistic reviews. I've just gotten back from Marrakech, and please don't let negative reviews dishearten you. I'm 17, and I went with my 21 year old sister. Needless to say we were a little worried about going to a culturally diverse country as two young girls, but we had little to no trouble at all. You have to realise that the people in this country are significantly poorer than anyone in England or Europe. For some of them, begging is a way of life. If you show interest in someone's Souq, then they will come out and try to encourage you to come in. Sometimes you'll even be approached and asked for money. Don't be fooled though, the people of Marrakech are very friendly, they aren't violent or rude. If you don't want to go inside of their shop, give them money, have a henna tattoo from one of the women or buy something, then just shake your head, give a little wave of the hand and firmly say no. It's as simple as that. If you find people trying to tell you which way you need to go to get to the square or museum or what have you, then just ignore them. They won't send you the wrong way, but they may ask you for money. This is a wonderful place full of wonderful and funny people. Things I'd advise not missing are: the Moroccan mint tea, a tagine or two, the museums, and a traditional Hammam spa (I went to Le Bain Bleu and had the time of my life). This was more of a response to negative reviews, but if you do your research and go with an open mind, Marrakech will be a trip you'll never forget.

Ying and yang. Amazing place but I found best viewed from the rooftop terrace of one of the many restaurants surrounding it.During the day beware of the snake charmers, who will rip you off for having photos with the snakes( asked our friends for equivalent of £30, so beware). They are very persistent and physically hold onto You until you give them money!! Lots of beggars, constantly being pestered to buy things and intimidating at times but fascinating all the same.

The happy hub of Marrakesh Madness. The Jemaa el Fna is the central hub of Marrakesh where street entertainment clashes swords with market traders, and outside food vendors, juice sellers and spice stalls overload your senses with smells and colours and taste. This really is a bustling busy area with a real feel of ancient Berber trade routes where a hagglers skills are tested to the limit. We found a polite "La,Shukran" (no thank you) fared you very well when approached by vendors or stallholders, you do get hustled a little but we have had worse and as we say just a polite no thank you always worked. The square is fringed by restaurants and coffee houses with superb verandahs offering vistas of the mellee unfolding below you (you will find almost no alcohol sold though, due correctly to local religious observance). A feast for all the senses and of course a must see on any visit to Marrakesh.

A tourist trap to avoid. As beautiful and feastful the place is to the eye, I was shocked to see the amount of beggars. The sellers also tend to set a very high price and expects you to bargain it down. But often the you can obtain a much better price if you venture the peripheral of the square.

Worst place ever. I stayed close to Jemaa el Fnaa for the 3 days I was in Marrakech. I really hated every time I had to go through it. All the hustlers, scammers, rude people etc etc really could ruin every day. Every time I would look at something, even from a distance, there would be someone trying to make money out of me. The ones with the monkeys tried to get me to take pictures with them, the ones with shops tried to pull me in, others tried to guide me in another direction and so it goes on.Normally I like a big crowd like New York or Bangkok, but I will never recommend people to visit this place for a longer time. There are a few good restaurants here and there, and it's more fun to sit and watch all the frenzy from a distance. Also, there are soooo many scooters and bikes that I was constantly feeling I was in danger of being hit by a bypasser.
Morrocan version of "The Apperentice". Jemma at night - great atmosphere. Not really for the food but to experience the Morrocan art of persuasion. Join in the fun. A must do for visitors :)

Food poor. I really don't recommend the central restaurants in the evening, shoved together and over priced for quality, choose some of the small restaurants/cafes around the edge, some great tagines for 3€. Please don't have photos taken with the monkeys, these are taken from the wild as babies and mostly seem very unhappy in their life hugging tourists and probably tied up all day. But do talk to the men with them, I met one who had a good relationship with his monkey and seemed to be kind though I still see it as prison for these animals, i gave no money but encouraged the guy to use a soft, supple leather collar rather than a chain and said how important it was to treat them well. If lots of people say that tourists like to see animals treated well perhaps it will help the life of those already taken. Living in hope!
sooooo much fun!. listened to story tellers.. saw and held snakes & monkeys.. great experience! great atmosphere .. i fell in love with marrakech.. and i enjoyed this 100%.

the soul of marrakech - lively and vibrant. perhaps one of the most tourist filled places within Marrakech, Jemaa el Fna still recieves 5 stars for what an adventure it provides. More commercialized than its old medina counterpart, the bright sun filled plaza beside a mosque provides visitors with full ambiance of french - moroccan tourist culture. The plaza is filled with fruit and spice stalls, locals with monkeys and snakes that they offer tourists to take pictures with for a small fee and a mixed plethora of entertainers such as magicians and story tellers and bystanders. The aura of the place is so rich in its culture and diversity that one will notice peddlers selling carriage rides or toys being able to speak at least 11 different languages to the basic degree. the liveliness and bustle of the place is turned into solemnity during their calls for prayers which happens 5 times a day. A completely different experience and culturally enriching adventure. Anyone who calls themselves worldly must simply experience something like this at least once in their lives.

A vanished extravaganza!. We last visited Marrakech 17 years ago and were magnetically drawn to the attractions on offer in the main square: acrobatists, fire-eaters, snake charmers, soothsayers, mock dentists pretending to extract teeth etc. However, the magic has vanished and all that remains, in the day, are several rows of juice sellers, a few women applying henna and at night there are the endless rows of food stalls.Marrakech's main attraction has disappeared and the square is virtually empty; it's very sad!

Great!. A very large place, with cafes and restaurants all around it and entry to the souks. There are locals selling their merchandise also, for example the orange juice stalls and nut stalls in the place itself. Unfortunately we did not see the acrobats and snake tamers of which we were told about but Im sure they will be there some of the time. The best are the night markets when the Place becomes of full of life and light. Food stalls are set up at night and everyone is merry and filling their bellies! We experienced this on a sunday evening which was even better as on Sunday many locals have a day off so the place is extra busy! I suggest though if you dont like crowds perhaps go to the night market in the week - if they are on then, please do check!
market. shuttle bus free from hotel,needs to be prebooked,but once you get your confidence you will love the maze of craftsmen working

Hustle and bustle. It may not be for everyone, but no visit to Marrakech would be complete without a visit to the square - preferably both during the day and the night. Keep your valuables safe, take in the sights and sounds and smells but be careful who you take a photo of, they may take offence and/or ask for money.

at night it's just wow. yeah, hearing so much about it, i got a bit dessapointed when i saw it. It seemed to be just a great mess with no harmony. But the restaurants on that square are just nice looking and some are delicious.Nevertheless... the Jemaa el Fna square during the night is JUST WOOOOOWWWWWW!!! SO MAGIC!!! Because candles are lit... and it's just magique.

awesome square. we spent 3 evenings there. its a great place. you have to visit to understand. you can enter the souks from various places from the square. if you prefer to see it from the top, there are a few restaurants with open terraces. we did not like the food on the square but i guess you have to experience it once. The famous orange juices are still 4 dirhams (under 40 pence UK), and are fresh and tasty. traffic - mopeds, cars, vans, tow trucks, roller blades will come at you from all directions. we did not see a single accident in our 3 evenings even though it was total chaos. Setting up of the stalls start t 5 pm if you want to view that. Post office is just there and offers good exchange rates in a quiet and safe environment.

Beware. A fine place geared up for tourists, but somewhat disappointing with touts hustling you, beggars, and overpriced food. Good to say you have been, we only went once and enjoyed it for what it was, but once is enough.
Madness!. It was mesmerising if scary and crazy at first! Stayed 10 days so got used to the mayhem. Snake charmers,stroy tellers, Berber singers and musicians, transvestite dancers! It's all true!

The heart of Marrkaech. This is the heart of Marrkaech, particularly in the evening. Not sure where all the promised snake charmers were though! But good, cheap food and somewhere you can always head to if lost in the souks, to start navigating again

Blew my mind. The place is a complete chaos and that's why is so charming, you walk around aside a multitude of people, bikes, horses, monkeys, snake charmers and etc.. Lovely place to watch the sunset from one the cafes' terraces or to sample some of the local delicacies at night; that's when the square really becomes alive. Apart from everyone trying to hustle you for money and attention, Jemma El Fna is definitely worth the trip.

Fun Place. This was a fun place to visit with juice stalls selling fresh orange at about 40 p per glass. In the evening there are stalls set out which cook and serve food. We chose a fish stall No 14 that was full of local people, we had freshly cooked fish and calamari which was delicious and cheap.

Very busy, fascinating. Well worth a visit. Find a terrace cafe, get a mint tea, spend an hour or so just looking out onto the busy square. Go there during the day then back in the evening.. its very different!

Wow!. A total assault on the senses. The sounds, smells, sights, people, animals and food. What a place. We loved experiencing this place. It is a glimpse into a totally different culture. Snakes, monkeys, donkey, horses. Amazing. No need to feel uncomfortable. Just breathe it in.
Fun. Lots of male attention but harmless and polite. Ate on the food stalls and was excellent food and value.

Crazy spot!!!. This place is absolute mayhem....In a good way! You definitely need your wits about you to dodge the scooters and cars coming from all directions. The street vendors can be a little annoying but once you're firm with your no thank yous you'll be fine. Best way to appreciate the square is from one of the many rooftop restaurants

Beware of the acrobats. I inadvertently held up my phone when I was facing towards the direction of the acrobats (a bunch of young men doing somersaults and such) in the square (didn't take a picture)They thought I took a picture of them and demanded I give them money and wouldn't leave me alone (even though I showed them there is no picture on my phone). They all started to gang up on me (I'm a single female traveller). Got into a huge argument and finally a French gentleman nearby helped me out of it.

Totally overrated. Jemaa el Fna is 100% overrated. The street food is some of the worst i've had anywhere in the world. No locals seem to eat there, which should tell you something. Don't eat at the stalls.
Interesting square, overrated. Guide books suggested it was exciting and full of life - we were there only in daytime and it was quite quiet and just a route to the souks and other sites

must see - all human life is here. Great to just stroll around and take it all in. It changes hourly so there will always be something different to experience. View it from the highest terraces of the surrounding cafes, then eat at one of the stalls. The souk in the middle of the square is quite claustrophobic but those on the edges are slightly wider and less crowded - lots of fun. Unfortunately for us it rained on our second night and by the time we got to the square it was emptying - although there were some intrepid souls out there still trying to sell their wares.

Strangely enough I think I like this Square!. It is certainly a 'must see' in Marrakesh. I liked it early morning as it was far less crowded, but it is a spectacular place to watch the sun go done and very lively after dark. There are one or two reasonable places to eat in and around the Square, but many are best really just for a drink.Some of the entertainment is really quite good and there is a strong police presence virtually at all times, so much more relaxed and safer than the rest of the Medina. the acrobats we saw were truly spectacular. We saw so many mixed reviews about whether to eat the food in the square that we in the end decided to be cautious and gave it a miss. Pity because it smelt delicious.Animal lovers may find the Square a little hard to take - monkeys on chains yanked about, Cobra snakes ( milked of venom) slapped repeatedly to perform basic tricks, dozens if not hundreds of stray cats which look like they are starving, donkeys and carts abound but sadly some (more than one!) donkeys were lame. We saw one moving across the square with a lame back leg, literally sliding it's stiff back leg across the floor and being beaten savagely. The Square would not only survive but in my opinion it would thrive without all this nonsense.Truly felt like a trip back in time, and on the whole though it is flawed I liked it.

Just take a deep breath and go for it.... Love it or hate it, you will inevitably find yourself returning again and again to the heart of all the action in the wonderfully crazy and addictive city of Marrakech. Architecturally, it's nothing at all really (and it's not even a square by most people's definition; just a rather formless and tatty space, fringed by a series of not overly impressive cafes, whose main recommendation is that their roof terraces provide a sort of grandstand viewing point for the action going on below). By day, there are stalls selling orange juice, dried fruits and nuts; itinerant water sellers; groups of young macho acrobats and of course, the obligatory snake charmers and monkey handlers. By night... the transformation is extraordinary. Dozens of stalls appear, complete with bench seating and lighting, where a weird and wonderful variety of culinary delights can be had. You may well pass on the whole sheep's heads - but they are evidently pretty popular with the locals. Less worryingly, all the usual Moroccan stand-bys, such as tagines and kebabs, can be had, and for a fraction of the price you'll pay in less temporary eating places. It's said that eating off paper, rather than the many-times washed plates, using limited water supplies, is a safer bet, but that's your call. Expect some serious hustling here, as rival stall-holders vie for your custom, but don't miss out on the opportunity to be part of possibly the world's greatest open-air dining show.

Sensory overload!. An evening in the "square" as it is called is almost too much to absorb in one visit. Performers of all kinds (yes, with cobra charmers), most with pounding percussive music, rows of colorful carts of fruits, nuts, vegetables, etc., souks peddling every imaginable item, outdoor eateries with hawkers trying to gain your attention to sit down, carriage rides, and on and on. A must to experience in the Medina, but very crowded and I wouldn't blame you from buring out on all the activity!

Like no other place you’ve been!. Just as crazy as every travel show you've ever seen on Marrakech. Within minutes I had a snake man trying to adorn me with his carpet dweller, a chimp on my shoulder, a fes hat wielding magician, an insistent henna artist – utter chaos haha! The words "La Chukran" are easily the most important in Marrakech and never more so than in the square. There is so much going on. Avoid eye contact and you probably won’t be hassled quite as much. Certainly an experience.We later had our farewell dinner for our tour group at ‘stall #1’ – amongst the long wooden tables as it was supposed to be typical local food and frequented by locals – to be honest it seemed likely mostly tourists to me. We had vegetable cous cous and chicken cous cous. It was just average really – we found better at many other Marrakech restaurants. The guy had a little scam running to charge an extra 5-10 dirhams (per person across the whole group) for stale flying-saucer shaped bread shared between 2 even though no one ordered any and many of us didn’t eat it – bread was complimentary at every single other restaurant we later ate in – particularly if you don’t actually order it.

Amazing hub of culture - watch out for the orange juice!. An Invigorating melting pot of theatricality and culture the Jemaa el Fna is a great place to visit particularly at night when Marrakech comes alive. I will advise to be wary of the orange juice sold on the square - it is watered down with tap water which isn't suitable for drinking - my boyfriend had a terrible upset stomach from this. Stick to bottled water, and ladies be careful of the 'henna ladies' who come across quite aggressive and will grab your hand and start drawing on it without your consent and then demand money. So keep your hands close to you and firmly tell them 'no' they will soon disappear. Remember it is polite to tip whoever you are photographing as Marrakechi's tend to be dubious of having their image taken (stolen) and please please please remember to dress appropriately - the occasional tourist walking through te square in hot pants and vest top is actually quite offensive.

Unmissable. A fascinating cacophony of sight, sound and aroma that will provide the essence of Marrakesh in one extraordinary location. Walk around the square avoiding unfortunate monkeys on chained collars and keeping a pocketful of small change for the touts with collection hats who will appear from nowhere anytime you want to take a photo of a snake charmer or a band of musicians or something else you haven't seen quite like it elsewhere. You don't have to pay but you may as well - its not much and it reduces the interference to the view. For the price of a soft drink and a sense of the whole scene you can go up onto one of the terraces that overlook the square.
great time. Beware of the motor bikes and the scooters, they come at you all the time from every angle at once. Felt quite un-safe in the evening when this happened.
What an experience.... Great experience during the day, extremely busy at night,. Lots to see, and experience - great shooping if you are happy to barter

Bedlam with Charm. This is a must see. As you emerge from the maze of alleys that make up the medina, all your senses are assaulted... fully and frontally! There are colors and sounds and music and noise and drums and snake charmers and acrobats and boxers and food and story tellers and beggars and tourists and locals and hucksters and smoke and dust and carriages and motor bikes and monkeys and fruit and water-boys and arabs and berbers and bedouins and asians and europeans and africans and voices selling anything. I could have stood there for hours and just sucked it in. It was Bedlam. No apparent organization to it other than it seemed to be self forming and self managed. I really liked it. I mean, really liked it.
Most exciting and stimulating place!. We were lucky to be staying close by and spent hours here, day and evening, eating, drinking and enjoying the entertainers and general ambience.

Great Tourist spot. The square's prices of food and entertainment reflect that it is made for tourists, but it is definitely a unique experience. But pay attention to where your wallet and money is at all times, and do not let yourself get pressured by people who want you to buy their goods or services.
not to be missed. same as the medina if you dont go to the square especiallythe evening you might as well have gone to cleethorpes
Nice - for one evening.. we spent one evening at Jemaa el Fna, which was interesting but for the rest of the week we stayed away from it, it's too touristic and there are always beggars around.

A bit tacky- but what can you expect?. As already said by others, loads of people trying to sell you things, get your picture taken with a snake or monkey. (Note: the monkeys often wear disposable nappies!) The juice sellers are all fine and all at the same price of 40Dm for an orange juice. We were daring and did indeed eat at one of the night cafes. Amazingly, we weren't ill, though it is best not to look at how your dish is washed up! (Along, in multi-used, water with a lot of others!)
Enchanting. Great food, especially the calamari on the plaza, and the snails :) And great people watching and always entertaining

An experience!. Absolutely loved it. It is a mish mash of Moroccan life and worth seeing. There is everything there from the craftsmen to shops selling touristy bits, clothes, shoes, leather, jewellery, fruit, veg etc. you need to haggle, don't be afraid enjoy it whatever amount they give you halve it and work from there I got some good bargains. Make sure if you want to buy Argan oil you buy it from one of the Berber pharmacies or a reputable shop but treat yourself to some its fabulous. My husband bought a Berber jacket for 250 dirhams which is roughly £20. Now for the snakes! I have a real fear of snakes and have been known to pass out on occasion if I see one. There are snake charmers only in the main square and my tip is to walk away when you hear the snake charmers flutey things. You will see the odd person walking about the square holding one but unless you show an interest they don't come up to you. There are monkeys as well in the square and I was surprised to see how good they looked - I have been to Tunisia and I won't go back there mainly because they treat their animals so badly, but here I was pleased to see it was much better.
the grand attraction!. the heart of Marrakesh... the atmosphere here is second to none. There's no point trying to sell this on here because words and pictures just do not do it justice!

mad but must see. I was prepared to visit the main square once and then stay away as it is quite mad but it is actually quite fun if you head straight for one of the restaurants with roof terraces and enjoy the madness from a bit of a distance.

Attractions outweigh the scariness. Let me start by saying the square was an amazing experience.My wife and I went to Morocco for our honeymoon in October, it was by far the best holiday we have had. The square in Marrakech was huge and full of life...including monkeys and snakes. We had a guy shove a monkey on my arm and being dumb we each took a photo of ourselves with the monkey - the monkey didn't look happy out the setup one bit but that's another subject - then I was taken under his umbrella where he asked for about 800dirhams, I know it's not huge amounts but I gave him what I could, he wasn't happy but then he came to us with the monkey not the other ways round.We found the spices area of the maze and had a good talk with a helpful salesman who then proceeded to sell us some great spices which we still have in our kitchen and use regularly.
