Prices are acceptable but if not you have to haggle, it's the number one place in the world to haggle so get used to it.One thing I will you of though is the roads, if you are going to cross them make sure you look, look and look again...and then wait because you've probably missed a car or bike that will most certainly knock on your behind....it's madness.Amazing honeymoon, would love to go back.

Fascinating! Noisy! Atmospheric!. A must see city! Fascinating with lots of hustle and bustle. Beware of the locals with monkeys or snakes wanting you to photograph them for money - they are very pushy. Take treason one of the terraces and watch them from above - enjoy!

great intertainment both day and night!. This place is full of motivated people who are dedicated to provide you with local or street performance for a small change. these were the most happiest people I have seen with the little they do have. at night unti 0100 in the morning, this area comes to life, lots of shopping!!
worth visiting. Nice place,mosque to pray,a lot places to try the local cuisine,local shops of different types, Fresh orange juice to drink.

Madness. You will be hassled by people trying to sell anything and by beggars. If you take a photo of the snake charmers or the men holding the monkeys - they will expect to be paid! The spices are amazing. It is unique and busy.

Busy,bustling and barmy. Atmosphere is all what you would expect from this place.Alive with jugglers,dancers,snake charmers,animals,music to get you in the mood,if that is your thing.I actually found it very intimidating because of the amount of people there.Not my cup of tea.they have no respect for their animals which are there bread and butter.Those poor donkeys.

Absolutely mental!. The main square is a must see! There are snake charmers, story tellers and magicians in one area and then countless food stalls selling everything from goats testicles to sheep's tongues! The only thing I would say as a word of warning would be people offering henna- one woman just came up to my girlfriend and started doing henna on her hand without asking- then demanded 400 dirhams! You just have to be wary but it is excellent fun!

Mixed reaction. Plenty going on, entertainers and shops around, banter at night from food stall reps was funny, we ate at one it was fine, beware free samples from vendors may not be free, avoid walking close to snake/monkey people, be prepared to haggle and aim for 1/3 of the asking price, if u take pics of ppl u will be asked for money, have small change with u, lookout for passing bikes/donkeys/etc, for cheap and good food visit Toubkal and have their tagines (corner of the square).We werent a fan of the pastries sold by mobile cart stalls. Dont feel intimidated by the sellers, customer is king. Enjoy

Mayhem. Thronging with people - beware the traffic (wheeled and 4-legged) coming seemingly from all directions. Notorious for pickpockets and chancers (just like being in any UK town ;) ) so be cautious, careful and politely assertive. But for all that do enjoy it ... BTW the local dates are pricey but delicious (I mean fruit as in palm trees, not a different kind of date).
People watching / central locale. Great central point with many wonderful terraced dining locales all around. No alcohol, but easy to have some with food at nearby restaurants on Mohammed V.

In the evening, an experience like no other.. I hate being hassled but once I got used to not making eye contact with anyone I really enjoyed the madness. There are street performers, snake charmers, henna tatooists, and of course the food stalls. Try it, it's an experience!

Chaotic to say the least.. Couldn’t understand the attraction. It was full of beggars and people out to make a quick buck. Watch out for the monkeys and snake charmers and try to avoid temptation of the fresh oranges and drinks. You’ll be charged and shouted at for taking photos directly of any local, be prepared and stay alert.

Hectic, smokey, local. Great way of experiencing night life in Marrakech. Everything is happening here and the noise level is high. Find a place on one of the benches at ine of the popular street kitchens (go for the place where you can see most locals) and order some of the freshly cooked food. It tastes great and is very cheap.There are tons of juice vendors where you can get your daily ration of vitamin C and lots of street vendors selling everything from candles to clothes. Storytellers, musicians, snakes, you name it.

A carnival of tastes and smells. One-of-a-kind place. There is just too much to see and absorb, especially at night. Do not miss the fresh orange juice and the mint stalls, look for the "dentist" who sells human teeth and stop by to listen to the hakawati - traditional story teller. Beware of pickpockets and anoying youth trying to see you stuff and cursing you when you dont.

An assault on your senses!. So much going on in this colourful and lively square. Take a table at one of the restaurants and watch the world go by. At night the food stalls sell delicious tagines and you sit where you can find a space next to other tourists trying out the local cuisine. Be aware - a man placed a live snake around my husband's neck - not really a problem for us but some people would not like it. We managed to avoid the men with the monkeys, they were placing them on unsuspecting tourist's backs. The people can be quite persistent to get some money out of you - the worst I encountered was an old lady who grabbed my hand really tightly and had put henna on it before I could stop her, then she demanded £10!!! (She didn't get it). Always something to see here but it can be a bit overwhelming and it's nice to get out of it into a quieter area.

Interesting but noisy. Go around 4.30-5pm and watch the locals set up their stalls for the evening market, the atmosphere is buzzing, we saw squabbles, laughter, dancing, a man holding an umbrella with a little table laden with dentures! There several cafes to choose from, we chose Cafe Glacier, rooftop tables are at a premium where you visit in the square.

Spend all your evenings here!. Must stay at the square as evening dawns when it becomes full of activity. Snake charmers, games, food stalls, group singers and dancers and various group activities. You name it and it is all happening at the Jemaa el Fna! You will never get tired of hanging around here.
Busy but fascinating. I hated the monkeys on chains & snake charmers for photographs but loved the atmosphere acrobats & food!The fresh orange juice is delicious.

Intense. I found it a little bit touristy. We were advised not to eat here or drink the orange juice. There are a lot of beggers and so so "attractions" but like everywhere in Marrakech, everyone seems to be out to make a sheckle or 2! Worth while seeing but 30 mins will do it.

mind the monkeys. First experience of Marrakesh, loved the vibrant atmosphere - plenty to take in and explore. However, PLEASE don't give money to the snake charmers (especially the ones forcing birds of prey to jump over snakes with sticks!) or men with monkeys on chains - they are kept in tiny cages even in the highest summer temperatures, and the way they are trained to 'perform' is pretty cruel (I did some research). Some of the horses pulling carriages were in quite poor condition too! I loved Marrakesh except for this aspect, and would ask any like minded travellers not to encourage these practices.

Highlight of Marrakech. For me, exploring Jemaa el Fna during the day and at night was the highlight of my stay in Marrakech. During the day, there are lots of interesting souks (shops) to explore, and at night the square fills with food tents and an abundance of traditional Moroccan food. The tent owners can be a bit... enthusiastic, trying to get you to sit at their table, but just ignore them and pick the one you want. They're all pretty similar. And, you must try the fresh Jus d'Orange (orange juice) while you're there--only 4 dirham (about .40 euro), and absolutely delicious.

Worth a visit. The famous Jemma el Fna is worth strolling around, there are water sellers in fancy attire, snake charmers, many little stalls around the perimeter and cafes where one can sit and watch the world go by. One warning watch out for pick pockets and don't let the snake charmers hassle you for too much money for taking photos!!.

Busy busy. The square is definitely worth a visit, everything looks so chaotic but it is organised chaos, fresh orange juice from the stalls is lovely and watching the food sellers set up their stalls is amazing, just keep your distance from the men with the monkeys.

Expected a magical experience - got quite the opposite.. If the sellers in the Souk are pushy, the Jemaa el Fna is a downright terrifying place. I had been told there were pretty restaurants and cafes surrounding a lovely square. It's not pretty. It's a giant slab of concrete surrounded by far from picturesque buildings. On arrival I saw a chap sitting with a few snakes including a cobra. I love snakes and asked if he would mind if I took some photos. He then put one around my neck- great, and of course we planned to give him some money. But he demanded 300 dirhams, and we were quickly surrounded by 3 of his colleagues all shouting "you give us 300 dirhams for our family." We gave him 50 dirhams- pretty generous for a few photos- and they continued to shout at us and insult us as we walked away. A few steps further and a very old woman grabbed my hand. And held it so tightly that I couldn't break free. A younger woman came up and quickly started to put henna on my left hand- with me saying "no" and still trying to break away. I realised that the hand she was pulling was the hand with my wedding and engagement ring on- and it was the rings that they were trying to remove. I got away, rings still on my finger.....but they were still shouting and demanding money, for the henna I didn't want.  This all happened in broad daylight- not in the evening.  I will be writing other reports about our stay in Marrakech in the next few days- sadly most of them bad experiences.  I would add that I have lived in both Yemen and Egypt, so am very used to Arab culture. But I have never experienced violence like this, anywhere. Very, very disappointing.

Hast to be seen. Busy interesting with a selection of restaurants around it where you can sit and watch. Square dirty and very smelly!
Beware of the snake charmers and the monkeys who may also pick pocket you!
It all happens here. The only thing I didn't like was the use of animals- monkeys, snakes even a guinea pig and hedgehog. I steered clear of this area. A great place full of life.

a cultural treasure. A cultural treasure — the most famous shopping therapy in the heart of Marrakech! The square along with its souqs are greatly entertaining as it features lively crowds, drum beats, hustling touts, fortune-tellers, musicians, acrobats, fire-eaters, healers and fakirs, snake charmers. The souqs are famously for beautiful pottery, rugs, lanterns, bedding and ornaments.
The Night Market. What can you say but you have to try the Night Market whilst in Marrakech. The food, bustle and activity has to be experienced. The food is freshly prepared and tasty.

It was magical. All the stalls that just popped up were really cool and we even got to witness the most gorgeous sunset as we ate at a stall with many local people. Only, i did get food poisoning from the experience but the food was so yummy i wouldnt hesitate to do it again. Just make sure all ground meat is fully cooked and you should be fine (my husband was)

Jemaa el Fna. The main square in Marrakech - this huge open space is a bit daunting at first due to the sheer numbers of people. Go early and get your bearings when it is relatively quiet. However you must go there at night. Cafe de France in the north east corner is a good place to get a break from the madness.

Proper madness. There's no quiet moment on the square. No matter what time you go, there's always action going on. If you fancy a bite to eat, that's not a problem, be in from the stalls in the square or any of the restaurants with terraces surronding the square. Snakes, monkey, eagles, dancers, henna artists, food sellers, orange juice sellers, fruit and nut sellers, horse carriages, etc etc and all within stonethrough away from the souks!

Where it's at.. Very large open space which fills with traders and performers from early morning, and temporary food stalls from early to late evening. A good place to go people watching at all times of day. Eating at the food stalls is fun, but not necessarily cheaper than eating at some of the very good value restuarants to the south of the Square. Arrange to meet friends either in front of the Poste office, or the Cafe De France. After a visit to one of the Artesanal stores (e.g. in rue de Kasbah near Saadian Tombs where prices are fixed) to understand fair value for what you might be buying, practice your negotiating skills with the traders for (non-food) goods you want to buy.

Great place to eat!. We had only one meal there (stall #14 a seafood place) but it was an excellant meal. Every food stall has several very assertive guys around it who want you to eat there, I would suggest looking around on the net and figure out were you want to go. There are obviously better and worse stalls.For the entrainment in the square, lots of it is very local. Standard stuff of snake charmers and monkeys (neither of which I think is very interesting) but watch your wallet and enjoy the show. But we very prepared that as soon as your spotted the performers or assistants will be after you hard for money.
amazing. lively fun, but lot of hussel and bussel ! but a must see. everything in one place,taxi only between 2-4 pounds, depending on night or day.

Really Interesting. The best time to visit Jemaa el Fna is in the evening. There are always people playing different drums, dancing. It's busy and chaotic. There are also several snake charmers, monkeys, fortune tellers etc. It is like stepping back in time. In the evening they light fires to cook food for sale and you can buy freshly squeezed orange juice and a variety of fruits (although these seemed to be covered in flies so personally I wouldn't buy anything) There are several people wandering around with small snakes that they try and put around your neck and women offering henna tattoos.

Good, but hostile touts. I'd prefer to give this 3.5 out of 5, but i'll round to 4. The square is everything you's imagine from the guide books and was great both night and day. However, the touts, were increedibly pushy, please dont think this is unfair, i've travelled a great deal and have no problems with touts, they're normally just trying to make a living. However, in the square (and surroundings) they can be verging on aggressive. The henna girls will grab the ladies hand and attempt to draw on it without permission, all the others will demand money instantly for anything. We stopped to look at what a crowd was watching, we couldnt see as the crowd of 50 or so people obscured what turned out to be a small traditonal band, we stopped walking for less than 20 seconds and suddenly we have hostile demands for money, we walked away and was followed with repeated demands. The food stalls are similar, very hostile sales techniques. Of 40 or so countries visited, this ranks as the most hostile i've ever been to and i've travelled other parts of the region numerous times. All in all, worth a look, but bear in mnd the touts.

An experience like no other!. A must. An assault on the senses. Everything costs you, even looking at the snakes! If you look up at the buildings surrounding the square you will see roof terraces. Try to go to one of these as the sun goes down and you can watch the sunset over Koutoubia mosqueover a mint tea and watch all that goes on in the square too.

The Place to be. Amazing what you can see. Cobras, rattlesnakes, large and small monkeys, food, food, food and a lot of other things. You have to go after sunset - the local people sell everything!!!!
life at its most intense. just go, day and night, and soak it up, a taste of medieval fairs with yes some hassle but a firm no stops it and allows you to look and enjoy

Square at night. This was good at night it is very busy with a lot going on. However for me it was not as exciting as it appears on TV as there is a lot of th esame going on. Many of the stalls sell a lot of the same stuff but you can't really go to marrakech without visiting here. We ate in a resteraunt overlooking the square which was fun.

A very big, busy square. Great for street meat... Jemaa el Fna is a large public square selling anything and everything except alcohol (just wander a minute off the square for this) Make sure you eat at the food stalls, same rules apply eating in the likes of India/Asia just keep your hands clean and get stuck in. Merguez sausage and spicy a winner, sheeps head and snails if you fancy.

Often more tourists than local people. The Djemaa el fna, or place of the dead, comes to life in the evening, when the sun sets and the market stalls start to attract customers. In the past, people would gather round the story tellers, or henna ladies. Today it has become voyeuristic with little regard for the local people and traditions. Take time to talk to the people trading and selling their wares or services, dress modestly and ask before taking a photo. The Djemaa has changed because the tourists are changing it, and it is rather sad that this is the case.

What vibrancy!. What a stimulating place! You'll love it here, day or night! Marrakech isn't a dangerous place at all, i.e. there's a low crime rate. I wouldn't say the same for the traffic and motorbikes however, which you definitely need to watch out for all the time!

Fun but be wary.. Full of people, sights, sounds, smells, colours. Loved all of that. There is a lot of animal cruelty. If you eat in the pop up restaurants they are artists in making you pay much more than you thought. Only eat what you order or you will pay for it heavily. inc bread, olives etc. We were stung!
Avoid snake charmers and monkeys. The atmosphere is lively especially from 4pm onwards, but avoid street traders as they want money from you just for taking photos of them

Feed your senses. Jemaa El Fna is a must visit! In order to enjoy the square you must be open minded and truly enjoy seeing other cultures. The square is transformed at night and is full of tourists, locals and performers. You will see monkeys, snake charmers, story tellers, and of course if you stop they will try to get you to take a picture, that's how they make a living. We have been here many times and never had a problem. If we don't want something a firm no thank you and keep walking does the trick every time. The different food stalls offer a wide variety of meats and things to eat. Feed all of your senses here from the excitement you see, to the delicious grilled meats and sounds of music and people all around. This is a great place to people watch and appreciate another culture. If you can be open minded it's well worth a visit.
Loud, Fun, What you'd expect.. Loud, fun, tourist trap, easy meetup point. Great for an hour and a cheap meal. Overall great, but get lost in the souks and palaces.

" People watching heaven". No trip to Marrakech would be complete without 30 mins coffee break in a rooftop restaurant looking down onto the square. Go around 4.30-5pm and watch the locals set up their stalls for the evening market, the atmosphere is buzzing, we saw squabbles, laughter, dancing, a man holding an umbrella with a little table laden with dentures! There several cafes to choose from, we chose Cafe Glacier, rooftop tables are at a premium where you visit in the square.

Fun But Absolute Madness. the Place is only a few minutes walk from the Riad . It's certainly something to experience with drummers,acrobats, snake charmers and fortune tellers. What is really charming is that most of the on-lookers are Moroccans. It's not just for the tourists.

Crowded and adventurous. The Jemaa el Fna is a must for everybody staying in Marrakech. It is the centre of life in the medina. You eat there, you stroll there, you shope there and you are being pulled money out of the pocked there. Beware of high prizes and the reckless Henna-painting women. They don't really ask you if you want your hands painted and then you end up with a very high prize and a week-lasting visible souvenir...The Food is okay, the juice is great, people are nice. There are even nice restaurants with roof-tops, overlooking the busy marked!

An experience. It was ok, once was enough. It's a shame that you don't end up seeing much because if you make any eye contact they pounce so you end up walking with your head down. I'm glad I have been but I won't be returning. I would recommend going to the Cooperative markets, you get the real deal, don't get hassled and you can appreciate the work that goes into the pieces because they encourage you to touch and look. If you survive not being hit by a moped you may be finished off by a respiratory illness from the pollution.

Greatest Show on Earth. The Jemaa (or Djemaa) el-Fna used to be the place of public executions, now it is more of a carnival or circus atmosphere. Snake charmers, henna tattoo artists, and costumed water sellers who pose for pictures. This is Marrakech's answer to Times Square at New Years, except that it is all day, every day.The square is central to most attractions in Marrakech. It is inside the medina close to the Koutoubia mosque and is the entry point into the souks. You will probably start and end each day in Marrakech right here.

touristic. entertaining place , full of life and color . to see just to have a glimpse at it ...but not a great memory as some of the local were very aggressive , seeking only for money (don`t look at the snake if you do`t intent to leave a few dirham !)

No visit to Marrakech complete without Jemaa el Fna. Its a must to go to Jemaa el Fna in the day and the night just to see how very different the square is.By day, there are the snake charmers, monkeys, birds of pray, dancers and 'doctors'. By night, there is a total transformation as by 5pm - the entertainers make way for the night food stalls. It's a real spectacular and an absolute blast! Word to the wise when eating in the evening from one of the stands - don't be pushed into eating somewhere when you haven't quite made up your mind. Just tell the vendor that you' have just eaten' or' it's too early to eat', and they will back off. We had some delicious food there - but got food poisoning at 'HASSAN' stand one evening.
Pretty Cool Place. Lots to see, captured the color and controlled chaos of the city. Beware- the food at the restaurants surrounding the square with a view is mostly terrible.

Certainly different!. The square is manic - carts, donkeys, motorbikes, bikes, snakes, monkeys and people wanting to sell you something everywhere you turn! You have to visit it and admire its deserved UNESCO heritage but do be aware of everything happening around you!

1001 nights stuff - amazing. My well travelled mother experienced her first ever culture shock! Jemaa el Fna is straight from fairy tales. Snake charmers, story tellers, magicians, dancers, super food, cheapest orange juice in the world, horse drawn carriages (we selected a lovely pair of horses, well looked after, knowledgeable driver who even allowed me to drive for a while - i know how :-)), henna tattooists, great photos of water sellers etc to be had - for a small tip, monkeys, pet pigeons, donkey and mule darwn carts and everything under the Sun. Most animal keepers seemed to have a genuine bond with their performance partner, vast majority of sales people will accept a polite "no" if delivered firmly, but with a big smile. We loved our chosen food stall hassan 114 and 32. Sausages were amazing and much recommmended. Locals seemed to enjoy them as much as we did.

sights and sounds that are one of a kind. Our riad was conveniently located close to the Jemaa but still tucked in a neighbourhood so it for a good escape from the sounds when it all got too much. We loved all the nightly festivity, we ate every day at Chez Aiesha (recommended by trip advisor) food was great and plentiful and people were equally awsome. Dont forget to try the tall glasses of mint tea with a "brick"of sugar.........our kids and both of us used to have 5 or 6 glasses of mint tea everyday.

prepare yourself for the insanity.... but visit at least twice!. This square is worth visitng several times, at least once during that day and once during the evening. The day square and the night square are essentially two completely different venues and it is worth seeing both. Many of the people will try to get money from you if you happen to take a picture in their general direction. This inculdes the snake charmers, the traditional "water salesmen", and any performers. If you visit Marrakech, this square is something that you MUST visit, but do it both at day and at night.

Tourist mayhem, but good for a laugh and an outing. Before we went to Marrakech we read reviews that were all over the place, so we didn't really know what to expect. We were staying nearby, so it was easy to pop in and out. First thing in the morning the square was all but empty, and was nice to walk around. It quickly filled up, and lots of the stallkeepers were friendly and welcoming. As the day wore on, we were in and out, and the touts became more and more insistent, to the point of being beyond pleasant banter to downright aggressive. There are several restaurants around the square, and if you can stake out a table, seeing it all from above is a treat. As the day draws in, the food vendors appear as by magic, and you're set for an evening treat - food is plentiful and interesting, and you'll be happy to be there. The caleches are stationed on one side, and around the edges. They are apparently regulated, but we were a bit dismayed by the condition of some of the horses. You'll see snake charmers, and don't fall victim to the monkey you may suddenly find in your arms. I felt badly for the hawks tied down to entice tourists, but it's never all that helpful to judge different cultures by your own standards. Go and enjoy, you'll likely only do this once in your life!

symbol of marrakech. this is the most important symbol of the city of marrakech. u can spend several hours hanging around the square, drinking a tasty orange juice and watching the morrocan life going on
Oh wow...don't miss it. Surely one of the great squares of the world. No building to speak of but it's nearly all about people, food, stalls, music, acts etc evening time is by far the best.

The very heart of the city. Visit this place anytime, in the morning to get fresh orange juice (yes, it is safe), in the afternoon to watch the snake charmers and acrobats, in the evening to dine at one of the 100+ food stalls (yes it is safe too). This must be ione of the most exciting places on the African continent.

A tourist trap but good for an afternoon out. Loved the Argan oil and Black soap sellers, make sure you drive a hard bargain on price. The tea sellers are real characters and the early afternoon evening the atmosphere changes. Felt a bit sorry for some of the snakes, monkeys and animals used by the people to attract the tourists but it is their culture. Don't go here if you don't like crowds or being touted but you will miss out as some of the stall holders are very nice.

Exciting and terrifying in one.. A mad boiling pot of people and animals. Went though the day and at night. Had the food at stall 114 in the square and lived to tell the tale. The food was plentiful, tasty and cheap. Worth trying, a fun atmosphere.

The must see in Marrakech. Even though I did not fall in love with Marrakech, I must admit that this square is extremely charming and very different from any other Moroccan square - the only comparison I can think of (in very small scale) is the main square in Meknes.It is the absolute must see in Marrakech, possibly in different times of the day to fully appreciate the changes of the square. Try the divine orange juice, walk around the square and expect to see anything, from apes to snakes. I did not like the way animals are treated but it is part of the scenario... I enjoyed on the other hand the acrobats and a tasty tea on one of the terraces! Do not eat in the restaurants with terraces because they will rip you off, try instead the food in the square itself.
The heart of Marrakech. We visited here every day, at different times of the day, and it was endlessly fascinating. Eat there at the night market - it's a must.

A must see. The square is located in the medina. It is a vibrant part of the city filled with monkey chalmers, snake chalmers, water sellers, food stands and people selling local crafts. Be careful, becuase they snake chalmers will just approach you and put snakes on you for a fee. Our guide told us to expect to pay 20 Dirhams for this. It doesn't matter how many people (we were a family of 4) or how many photos (we took a couple each). Although, I think if you are a large group it only stands to reason to pay more. When we were with our guide we were not harassed for more money for this, but when alone the water sellers tried to get us to pay more. We simply said no, we know that is the rate and that was the end of it.

Get ready for this!. Liked....the colours, the smells, the buzz, the sights, the haggling.Disliked....a Mother & daughter travelling alone, we were targeted non-stop for money, being 'rescued' and being English we didnt want to be rude but we soon got the hang of saying no!! Beware of the henna ladies - thems no ladies and can be a bit aggressive if you are not firm.Once we had mastered how to dodge unwanted guides we had the most wonderful time...looking at the stalls and experiencing Marrakech first hand.

An different cultural experience. First impressions of the square was that it wasn't quite what I was expecting. We went at about 2pm in the afternoon on the first day. Orange juice here was amazing! Lots of henna tattooists, mulsicians and a few souks on the edges. We went into the souks for a few hours and emerged to find the place under transformation for the evening! Lots of food stalls being erected! Big crowds of locals gathering around performers and storytellers. Felt quite overwhelmed and intimidated on the first day, but we held our nerve and returned every night to watch life spontanaously erupt. Every day we discovered something different and met some new friend.

Amazing. We had a great experience, with visit both by day and by night. This was partly due to our Moroccan friends who helped us both in the Souk and in finding good places for enjoying Moroccan food.

Amazing. The chaos is exciting, overwhelming, and brilliant! Get fresh juice from the vendors, but ask for a paper cup. Eat at the food stalls (or get a sausage sandwich to take away), but be prepared to pay for all the extras they offer you. The fresh (and expensive) dates are worth the splurge for a handful. Best of all is watching everything from the rooftop of a restaurant or cafe as the sun sets.

My favorite place in the world.. It's busy, be ready to be harrassed and bumbed into. Get over it. Look for the magic, look at the people. This square changes personality with the hours of the day, it will never bore you and you can people watch to your hearts contents. Also enjoy the fantastic food. No silverware or napkins but it will be the most AMAZING food ever. I especially liked the stew and bread and the lamb sausage and olive sandwhich, Yes you will get scammed a lot. Just count that into your budget and dont let it ruin your vacation. These people are hustling for their families. Also remember that taking a picture of anything and anyone comes with a cost. Enjoy!

Crazy!. An assault on every sense in every sense of the word. Blind dwarf violinists, snake charmers with little charm, crazy moped riders, delicious fresh orange juice, hypnotists, barbecues, half of civilization meandering about, donkeys, caleche drivers hustling for trade, strolling musicians, con artists and preachers, stalls selling this, that and everything else.All of life is here and most of it is for sale. Grab a seat in one of the terrace cafes when it all gets a bit much and watch the sun go down while the relentless scene below pulses on and on.Go on your first night in town and the rest of the city seems calm by comparison! Amazing place.

A must. Just keep on walking, otherwise you get pestered a lot. Fabulous buzz and well worth the hassle. The evening was even better, although the food is anything but cheap. The portions are minute, but who cares, it's a great experience.

HUSTLE AND BUSTLE!. the square is just an extremely busy place with lots of people trying to sell things! lots of people will try to get you to buy things, come into their shops, eat at their restaurants etc, but a simple 'no thank you' normally does the trick! We ate at the square twice (no tummy problems), and the food was delicious both times. You have to try the fresh orange juice for just 4 dirhams (theres loads of sellers, you can't miss it!) Don't pose with the monkeys, snakes, local people dressed up in traditional costumes etc as they will ask you for money straight after. All in all, we loved the square, even if it does get a bit much at times!
Amazing!. First visited at night and were just blown away by the colours and smells and sounds. Just be firm with anyone offering you things you don't want!

this place is feast for the senses. extremely busy most of the time with a great authentic atmosphere,wonderfull stalls selling everything you can imagine,watch out for the sometime over enthusiastic sellers theywill try it on!go to one of the cafes upto a roof terrace and look down on the whole specatcle,entertainers etc

Literally A Tourist Trap. We came here on a rainy day and loved it (although not the rain)As all the other reviews say this place is vibrant and there's loads to see amidst the chaos but everything has its price. The snake charmers will love you to have a photo but then insist on 200 Dirhams (£15) for the privilege - we just pressed 20 in their hand and kept walking but they do get a bit abusive ("It's not enough")This felt like 'proper' tourism - just keep your wits about you!

Great to experience. The Jemaa el Fna is a great experience - vibrant, colourful, and bustling. We think it is a place to watch more than to be part of.In the evening the food sellers are more in your face than anything in the souks, and during the day everything is sell sell sell - monkey pictures, snake charmers, henna tatoos, cigarettes, oranges etc etc. Sit on a terrace at one of the many cafes and this great to watch, otherwise walk around the edge to limit the pestering.Make sure you get a roof top seat for at least one sunset over the city before you leave.

Where everything in the universe collides!. This place is a real spin out. you have got to go many different times of the day to see how it changes. Nothing like this could ever be planned or re-created anywhere. Perhaps the most interesting at night- cheap food at the stalls at night. We ate there a lot and didnt have any problems. Would recommend getting shave here- paid 40D for it and it was a great experience!

Busy busy. The Jemaa el fna is full of Maroccans trying to squeeze some dirhams out of tourists. If you take a picture - it costs money. The vendors pull you, block your way, and if you are female - they complement you a bit tooo much. Jemaa is a must when you visit Marrakech, but be prepared for kaos.
Hussle and bussle of Marrakech. Dont come here if you dont like hassle. Do come here to experience it and have fun. No need to be impolite.
Keep walking. Great place with a vibrant atmosphere, snake charmers, dancers , monkeys but if you stop to look you will be hassled to give them money.

My favourite place. What's not to like? Surrounded by souks where I learned to bargain like a pro, this centre of activity kept me entertained no matter what time of day I wandered through. From the snake charmers, to the musicians, storytellers, orange juice carts and various traders. It's impossible to not be entertained. The street food here is amazing, don't be afraid to dive in and it was safe. We ate at several with no dodgy tummies after. Don't be hassled into going for the first stall, smile have a banter with the server and keep going. I went round to every stall and had a look. No.25 was great. Look for the places with a crowd.

WOW!. A very lively atmosphere! Many snake charmers and monkeys during the day along with people selling their goods. Date and nut stalls everywhere. Stall number 13 has great orange juice. At night the square is transformed. Belly dancers and story tellers take over the square. Women offer to do henna on your hands and street food stalls are set up. Stall 32 has pretty decent lamb sausages and is ALWAYS busy. There are also stalls for snails although I didn't try them, but they looked good. A must see for Marrakech!
So much fun. This is the meeting place of Marrakesh. Although the square is always active it truly comes to life after 7 pm. An absolute must see

One of a kind but beware !!. I highly recommend visiting the Place while in Marrakech but be careful when dealing with shop owners and monkey& snake handlers . Almost everyone tries to rip you off or separate you from some of your money . The food in the stalls is similar in quantity and price . Harira soap and orange juice are recommended . Try the restaurant around the square for a change .Most of the stuff you see displayed for sale is cheap Made In China crap including those carrying famous "designer" brands . Diesel jeans for 200 dirhams ? I don't think so . All fake !!After walking all over in the square don't forget to wash your shoes on your way back home unless you don't mind horse/mule manure& urine.

Marrakech March 2012. We first visited in the evening of our first night, we didn't really know where we were going and just ended up strolling around to get the feel of the city, around 9pm it was still full of life, with lots of makeshift stalls set up mostly all selling food and tea. The men running the stalls were very pushy, at one point literally trying to drag my boyfriend to come and buy some of his food, aside from that they were all very friendly and eager to chat to us, when they realised we were English they started doing their best cockney accents and one man took a particular shine to us and we ended up having dinner with him at stall while he talked about his life and so on and we managed to pick up some interesting information on the city and about how the people there feel about tourism and so on. During the day it had a relentless energy, the outskirts of the market was full of performers, musicians, henna artists and men with animals. One lesson we learnt too late was if a man puts a monkey on your shoulder, when you take a photo... he will expect money! And rather a lot, in the market place you need to haggle for everything. As you walk into the main marketplace it's a seemingly endless maze, a covered narrow walkway teeming with stalls and people all trying to sell you more than you could ever need, its a wondrous labyrinth of treasures and trinkets. It would seem easy to get lost but after a while you start you recognise particular areas within the market, distinctive stalls or indeed stall holders!Hustle and bustle doesn't quite cover it! It's constant, the stall holders will all try and entice you and there's so much to see and buy, the atmosphere is incredible but you'll be relieved to be back in the calm of your hotel room. It's an absolute must see without fail. My advice however is be prepared to be hassled, ensure you haggle for everything and don't be afraid to be firm with the stallholders and occasional beggars. The restaurants on the outskirts are a wonderful place to sit and relax with a tagine and some tea and just observe the energy and atmosphere.

Incredible Place. This place is just brilliant, crazy but brilliant.Food market at night is amazing,1 tip i will give is if you truly want to experience the best food here, go where you see all the locals eating. don't get me wrong all the Stalls are great, but the locals eat there everyday for a reason!

Incredible experience. We came here for about 4 of our 6 nights in the city. Amazing atmosphere, friendly people (about 30% western tourists) and so much to see. Pictures don't so it justice as they don't show the noise and smells but there are bbq's, acrobats, snake charmers, spice merchants, fortune tellers, witch doctors, drummers, dancers etc as well as the obligatory tourist orientated stalls.Try and get there early and choose one of the smaller cafe's with terraces (the large ones mentioned in all the guide books are busy and expensive) - that's where all the photo's are taken from. Note that it's pretty quiet in the day - it's the evenings that have the activity!

Jamaa El Fna, Corner acquaintance 24/24h. This place is full of life and movement everywhere, restaurants, stalls selling everything, snake charmers, jugglers, musicians ... With a nice view of the Koutoubia is a place to spend time sitting drinking tea and watching the bustle of people.
Impressive but overwhelming. Sake charmers, monkeys, peddlers galore! A must do, but can be overwhelming. Less touristy at night, though more crowded.

Touristy centre. Although you have to come here on a trip to Marrakech to see the bustle of daily life, it seems that what was once a central meeting point has no become really touristy. There is nothing romantic about the entertainment and particularly the snake charmers here, it is just low quality attempts to make money from tourists. It saddened me to see western tourist encouraging the poor treatment of monkeys and snakes by paying money for photos. It is still a fascinating place to see life going on, but in a very different way to what we were expecting.

Great. Enjoyed every bit of this site. Orange juice is a must to try. Nice restaurants around the square. Beware the people demananding money from you for photo's you take of the place. Get a view of the market from above (in a restaurant) day or night, its amazing!

Yikes!. I visited Marrakech with a female friend, and we wanted to experience the square and the medina whilst we were there. We went in and bartered (very badly) for some shoes and scarves. Having spent all our money, we decided to call it a day and return to the hotel. However, we got lost. Not your usual kind of lost. 3 hours later, we were still lost. And being followed by a local chap who kept demanding money to show us the way out of the medina. We were being hassled, left, right and centre to buy things, but when we asked for directions, they wouldn't tell us where to go without payment, if we kept asking they refused to speak English. We later found out that the locals don't like to barter with women, and that we would have been hassled less if we had travelled with a man. I've travelled to lots of places, and been hassled for money lots of times before, but nothing prepared me for the intensity of it here.We were hassled very aggresivly by some of the guys in the square, who came up and put snakes on us then started demanding money from us (grabbing at us, squaring up to us etc). It was very scary and intimidating. I don't think I would go back unless I was with a man, it's just too intensive and ruins the experience.You will be asked for money if you take a picture of anything or any one. If you ask someone a question or for directions, they will ask you for money. On the plus side, we had some nice fresh orange juice, it was great to experience some real Morrocan culture and meet people. I've given this attraction 3 points out of 5, as if you travel with a man, and are quite strong willed - you may survive and enjoy the experience! Just be prepared!
excellent. Magical to walk there on the afternoon with all the shows and people hanging around there. Excellent to eat at night on one of the little restaurant in the middle of the place.

Good place for food and shopping!. This is the main square but very busy and very crowded. Good place to bargain items such as leather bags, argan oil, etc. Good place to eat too because it is very cheap.

Bonkers!. It has to be experienced but it's like being inside someone's hallucination, absolutely bonkers. Don't point your camera at anything or someone will come after money, don't stop for anyone unless you want to part with some change, just keep on walking - and don't worry too much about the traffic, it seems everyone on or in whatever form of transport, has the right of way, so just go for it!

chaotic and hassly but a must- see..once.. The square is a UNESCO world heritage site, and as such is a must-see if you are in Marrakech. However, be prepared to be hassled. You will be expected to pay to watch any of the street entertainment ( nothing in life is free) so make sure you have coins. There are snake charmers and monkeys on chains; there are belly dancers and children and women boxing (!). Storytellers attract large crowds of Marrakshi people, as do the musicians, dancers and acrobats. There are food stalls galore in the evenings, where you can eat all the normal offerings ( kebabs, olives, bread, tagine) or you can try other delicacies including various offal and snails. Freshly squeezed orange juice is cheap and delicious. Watch out for the henna ladies - they will paint you a tattoo before you have a chance to say no. Unfortunately they do not use proper henna and the stuff they use can burn your skin.
The centre of everything. Everything happens here - entertainment, food market, open air eating places, juice bars, music. But beware of pickpockets!

OMG!. A bucolic atmosphere, which will amaze you & take your breath away.We went there in the evening...it was chlly, so don't forget to take a jumper.We'd already had dinner, so didn't eat there, but the food looked good value & the variety plentiful. Check out the snail sellers.

Square of chaos. Tiring, constant hassling from sellers and very very stressful. Hundreds of motorcycles driving past around you, no traffic/pedestrian system...was scared for my own life!! however despite all this the square Is beautiful at night and you really just to have an open mind to enjoy all the chaos!

Obviously a must see in Marrakech!. We first went at night and then again during the day. It was incredibly busy but quite a sight. We ate at one of the many food stalls, food was quite good! Yes, as many people point out, there is a lot of hassling but that is all part of where you are. In the end it wasn't that hard to get rid of people, just keep on smiling and stay polite even if people are not always that polite to you! I read some reviews telling people to stay away from the square - that seems a bit over the top to me! Its part of the culture and a very interesting sight as well as fun to walk around!

Great place as long as you use your common sense and stay firm!. My partner and I visited the square and souks at least once a day for the past week! I personally prefer the square just as sun sets and you can watch the food stalls set up! If you go here with a handbag or wallet in your back pocket then unfortunately as a serving police officer I would say your we're asking for trouble! I advise to use a money belt and to only keep about 150 dirham in tight pockets ect for when buying from souks etc (it makes it easier when bargaining if they think you only have a small amount of money)When you go in the day it's worth only having loose change or 20dirham note to hand out of the money belt! IF you want a photo with a monkey or a snake (personally I did!) let them do their tactics and approach you!!! Once you've got your pics ect and get told 400dirham just pull the 20dirham and say its all you have on you. I paid 20dirham for my partner and myself to have 12 pics with a monkey in total, worth it for memories! Again at night food market, just go with you gut or more sensibly look for places with English menus and plenty of locals eating at the stalls! The lambs brain just tastes like lamb fat, the tongue is gross though in my opinion.

Best thing 'bout it is the Fresh OJ!. This Huge Square is where the locals come to pass their time, It's quite eclectic with snake charmers, Henna painters & Little dressed up monkeys vying for your attention, there are endless carts selling cheap freshly squeezed Juices from as little as £0.30 or so! Personally, I had my hand-bag stolen going there (whilst on a horse & carriage trip) with every bit of ID, cash & cards I had including my passport etc., which marred my trip to say the least, so I am not a happy bunny, the beaurocracy is a nightmare & I was so very lucky that the owners (Lisa & Michael May) at Dar Charkia-the Riad, I stayed in, helped me get all the necessary documents & emergency passport to get back to the UK- otherwise I believe the nightmare would have continued until today.

Great place, but be careful of the scammers. I really love the square here. I've been there many times. My only annoyance is the way the performers and snake charmers try to scam everyone with obscene "donations". Some guy threw a snake on me and then expected me to pay him money to take it off me. He tried to charge me 50 euros! Things like that are a joke. One gets sick of the utter disrespect they have for tourists.Avoid those street performers where you can, avoid making eye contact with them.Other than that, there are amazing food stalls both day and especially at night. Also take the opportunity to have some fresh orange juice from the stands - be sure to use a straw, as the glasses don't get washed often.Take the time to just immerse yourself and zone out all the hagglers and the annoying shopkeepers. It really is a magical place and evidently hasn't changed much in the last 200 years other than the satellite dishes above every roof.
Mayhem. Organised chaos.Fresh orange juice was superb. Snake charmers!! were a big turnoff. seemed to be full of beggars in one disguise or another which took away from the beauty off the place
All roads lead here. Lots of carts serving orange juice, all at 40dhm, leaflets thrust at you rather tiresome and everytime you slow down, you are called in to "only looking" but an experience

Great experience, but be careful!!. Definitely a must! This is a great place to pick up traditional Moroccan souveniers. Mornings are filled with amazing stalls of fresh orange juice, and at night it comes alive with snake charmers and a vibrant atmosphere. My only warning, keep your belongings close - within 3 mins of stepping into the Souks from Jemaa el Fna we saw a young boy pickpocket a tourist speaking with a shop owner. Might not happen all the time, but take only what you need and don't give in to the first price the shop owners tell you.

Big Square.... Great time to be had here. A little scary at first as mopeds are flying round but plenty to see and do. Snake charmers and monkeys. Plenty of people geared up to take your money for anything at all! Be careful taking photos as people will expect to be paid for them. We sat up on a rooftop terrace with a Mint tea taking it all in then went down and had a look round. During the day the square is full of entertainers, snake charmers, market stalls selling all kinds but during the night there whole place changes. People making music, games, and of course the food markets. You will get hassled lots to sit down at all of them you walk past, "asda price", "cheaper than morrisons!", "my food is finger lickin good!" they all say. its quite funny to be honest. Stand your ground and find somewhere you like the look of, sit down and enjoy. My wife is vegetarian but there where plenty of options for us! Stall number 81 we ate at was really nice and also the soup stall just opposite it. Enjoy a glass of orange juice for 4 DH when its hot during the day. very refreshing, use a straw. As with anywhere, be vigilate. I did see at least one person get pick pocketed by some young children. Keep your wallet in a buttoned down / zipped pocket. I just walked arounf with my hand in my pocket on my phone and wallet. have some small change in your other pocket so you dont have to get loads out infront of sellers etc...Did the red tour bus available at the entrance to the square. it killed a couple of hours and as we where only there for 3 days it was a good way to see everything.

Dirty and noisy. Sorry, it might be wonderful for some people. But the tired snakes, the dull eyed birds and monkeys, the frenetic salespeople and the low quality junk being hawked just did not do it for me.

Hive of activity!. This was my second visit to this famous square and it did not disappoint! A myriad of entertainers, food and merchandise stalls. It assaults the senses in a very pleasing way. Numerous side alleys leading to more shops or the cavernous Souks. Always be perpared to tip Snake Charmers or those wretched Monkey owners even if you point your camera from afar. Enjoy a meal from one of the cafes that line the square and watch the show unfold!

Crazy square with a lot going on!. Really enjoyed Jemaa el Fna and all the different activities going on from water sellers to snake charmers and monkeys with nappies on! Enjoyable to have a wander through although gets a little much at times with people hassling, I know that is just the culture difference but be open minded and try not to let them stress you out! Good selection of rooftop restaurants around the square to watch from a height.

The show must go on. Thre are more stalls and less entertainers than when I last visited, 20 years ago. I loved the fresh juice stalls - cheapest drink going! the plant stalls were like a garden, the spice stalls smell great, and expect free samples at the date & dried fruit stalls. The hassle is mostly good natured, though I did get annoyed with a woman who grabbed my hand and started to paint it with henna without my permission. There is some entertainment all day, but early evening is when some stalls leave space for more musicians, snake charmers and other delights. Great views can be had from the roof terraces of several cafes in the square.

What an experience!. We spent a lot of time just sitting drinking mint tea and watching the world go by in the square. It is a truly amazing place.... snake charmers, musicians, acrobats and wonderful food stalls.
A square to be visited. The magic and culture of Marrakech in a square, An ideal place if you want to do your shopping and see entertainment all in that magic square.

Beware. Great place to visit, full of life, watch out if you take a picture they will want paying. We had dinner here one evening and I don't regret it but unfortunately we read the guidebook AFTER eating here and they adise youto make sure you get what you ordered. We enjoyed the meal but it was very different from what we ordered and cost us twice the price, we refused to pay for all of it but try telling them you did not order what they brought, very difficult.

You wont get bored here. Fascinating, great variety of things to see, buy and eat. Experiment with the various restaurants especially those with elevated terraces. Not all places will take credit cards, or, will charge 5-7% extra. Quite safe. Learn to haggle for the best prices. There are more souvenirs that you can imagine.......although the best quality ones were at the airport where prices are fixed. However, 2-3 days of walking around the souks might be enough for some

Attack on the senses!. This place is chaotic, crazy and a complete attack on the senses. It is loud and busy and filled with people trying to make money and all kinds of animals, cars, motorbikes etc going every which way. However, this is Marrakech and we went there expecting this to be the case. We chose Marrakech as a short city break to get out of our comfort zones and experience a different world. We definitely got what we asked for and we had a great time.The square is filled with a variety of people trying to make money in a variety of ways - snake charming, henna tattoos, selling orange juice, using monkeys etc. We had an old guy follow us trying to be our "guide" at one point - please do not fall for this unless you are prepared to pay for being shown around (they aren't just being friendly because they just want to help you!)One thing we were unimpressed with was the animals as we felt the way they were treated was cruel - monkeys in nappies and leads, snakes slithering everywhere and being pulled back to the rug they are supposed to be on or put in tiny boxes, horse and carts standing all day long in the heat. This part of the Marrakech way of life was quite upsetting but unfortunately there was not much we could do about this, as much as we would have liked to!Many people will try and lure you over to them and then do things such as place a funny hat on your head, try to start drawing a henna tattoo on you, place a monkey on your shoulder, place a snake round your neck etc then demand money. We found it best to avoid hassle and demands for money by taking a wide berth and not making eye contact. We managed to enjoy ourselves and see everything from a bit further away and not get hassled.I enjoyed the square by day but enjoyed it even more by night when the place fills with food stalls serving all kinds of food, from quite normal dishes to the more weird and wonderful (or sometimes just weird!)If you are visiting Marrakech you cannot miss a visit at least once to the Jemaa el Fna. You must go with an open mind and be prepared to see some wacky things! We very much enjoyed our time at this crazy place and hope anyone else who visits does too!!

Far better in the evening. During the day there really isn't anything much to see in the main square, just a few salespeople and tourists. At night, however, the Night Market is a fantastic place to stop for dinner, and should be experienced at least once. Be prepared for eager salesmen, and even to be dragged along food stalls to see what's on offer. As long as you keep a sense of humour and understand how to say no, you should be fine - saying "we just ate!" seems to work well. It's worth stopping in them though, as they're all pretty much the same, so just go for whoever is the most convincing!

Maybe we were just tired. After a long drive from Ait Ben Haddou through Telouet and across the mountains, we finally arrived in Marrakech just before sunset. After checking in, we decided to eat dinner at the riad and then hit Jemaa el Fna. We'd heard high praises from our friends and although we were tired, we were looking forward to snake charmers, monkeys, and the usual semi-controlled chaos that reigns in the public spaces of Morocco. It may very well have been us and not Jemaa el Fna, but we were very disappointed. We didn't see a single snake charmer or man-with-monkey, but we did find plenty of people wanting to sell things to us. We wandered through the fruit stalls and then through the small eateries, but after the 4th or 5th high-pressure salesman tried everything short of physical force to get us to eat at his stand, we decided to head back to the riad and relax. Again, we were tired coming in to it, so that probably colored our experience, but we only spent 15 minutes on the square, and we didn't feel like we needed any more time there.

Timeless. We were expecting Jemaa el Fna to be totally crazy, with people constantly hassling us. It's nowhere near as bad as we expected. Yes, you do get pestered if you show any interest in something/someone but you should expect this. It's part and parcel of being there. I don't like the idea of people using monkeys etc as money making objects, so we avoided them by just taking a wide berth and skirting around them. It's bright and vibrant and a great place to watch the world go by. There are restaurants dotted around the outskirts and for the price of a drink you can sit on the balcony, watch the sunset and look down on the square with absolutely no hassle whatsoever. My advice would be to go there expecting it to be crazy and busy and full of people trying to hassle you and you'll be pleasantly surprised that it's not so bad after all. And remember, these people are just trying to make a living and what would Marrakech be without Jemaa el Fna?

Organised chaos. We found the evening at the square just chaos, scooters bikes, cars ,horses everywhere not to mention traders trying to sell, some people like this but as my partner is partially sighted I particulary found it stressful as just too much going on. Atomsphere was buzzing and its filled with tourists and locals alike.We went back a couple of times in the day and found it far nicer, less hassle, had a meal and sampled the fresh orange juice which is just refreshing.And as some other reviewers have said you just have to keep saying no, which did spoil it to some degree.

The centre of your trip to Marrakech.. The square is the centre point you'll use during everything you do in Marrakech. It has snake charmers, monkey trainers and musicians by day and transforms at night to Berber performances and food stalls for relatively cheap.It's best to be seen at dusk, when the two worlds overlap and the locals come down. Be careful taking photos, as people will demand payment for being in your photos. Also, the restaurant touts will wear you out, but pretty much every stand is the same so don't stress over your choice.People will tell you horror stories about the food. I ate there most nights I was in Marrakech and at the food, the bread, stank the water (bottled) and used the cutlery - never a problem!

Awful during the day better by night. To be honest I didn't like the square during the day! It was like a war zone with everyone trying to get 'a piece' of the tourist dollar! I don't like cruelty to animals so the snake charmers, monkey men and the horse and carriages didn't impress and being grabbed by henna women was awful! I understand they want your money but its too aggressive for me!On a night the square is a mottled better, with the stall holders trying to get you to eat but with a little more humor! Quoting Del Boy and morrisons ads at you! It's one of those things you 'experience' in your life but I avoided the square after day 1 and won't be going back!

Disappointing. A much vaunted UNESCO Heritage site. Of great historic culturan significance, no doubt, bot of limited interest to us. No architecture, nothing going on which we have not seen elsewhere, just milling crowds and a few hawkers.

Must experience if in Marrakech. Fresh orange juice stands, touristy cheap stuff for sale on ground and in small makeshift booths, snake charmers, horse and buggy's for hire, acrobats, street food, scooters everywhere, crowded, noisy, wild, and pretty much the beating heart of Marrakech - especially comes crazy alive at night.

Heart of Marrakech. Fantastic location. During the day an area with snake charmers, drummers, musicians, transformed in the evening with loads of temporary restaurants serving Morrocan specialities.The view of the square from the balcony on the Cafe de Glaciers is memorable

Don't miss the experience!. You need to be prepared to say 'no' a lot, as people try to sell all manner of things to you. But eating at the food stalls in the evening is an experience not to be missed. We ate some good fish and very tasty fried aubergine at stall no. 81. The waiters were entertaining. It was cheap. The sweet sellers walked by upmteen times and we kept saying 'later'. We then managed to escape before buying their sweets, and found them 10 Dirhams cheaper on a stall on the outskirts of the food stalls. A scary 'Henna' lady tried to grab my sister's hand but I dragged my sister away. You have to be careful as cheap henna can cause burns or allergic reactions. But it was all part of the mad experience of the square. I'm now wishing I'd accepted the offer of a thousand Ferraris for my sister!!
Amazing Place. Jemaa el fna is an amazing place where you can see and meet many magicians and story tellers ,taste a cheap food but good and have fun.

Rather overrated tourist trap. The edges of the sqaure have souks and shops selling the same goods (slippers, lanterns etc) as deep inside the souks, but at even more inflated prices. The rest is food stalls and rows and rows of juice stalls. There are people entertaining, but mainly snake charmers and men with monkeys on chains so you can get your picture taken with them. Not keen on this sort of animal cruelty myself, not atmospheric and basically a bit behind the times! The henna painters are very persistant and grab your hands as you go past. A friend had hers done, and it looked like a 5 year old had done it! I normally like this sort of chaotic scene, but really it is just overrated and touristy, and lacks authentic atmosphere. Go once, just to say you've been.

Crazy place but a must visit. The main square in the Medina is an absolute assault on all of one's senses. It is like nothing I've seen before. Swarming with people day and night (more so at night in fact), motorbikes, horses, donkeys, monkeys, snakes etc etc. You just have to go there and wander around and be prepared to be hassled by all sorts of people wanting to sell you things, take their picture (beware - if you take any photos of anyone -especially the snake charmers and the people dressed up - you are going to have to pay them - so have some money at hand!), go in their taxi, ride in their horse and carriage, let them paint you with henna. It's nuts! But brilliant. Sit in the Cafe de France or any of the cafes on the square with a roof terrace and look down on the madness.

Change all the days. Visiting this Place should be several during the day.The sphere change from the morning with the reseller of fruit Juice. During the afternoon with the monkeys and the snake. During the evening as an open doors restaurant. Event crowded the place must be visited for it atmosphere!

Could be WONDERFUL if EVERYONE didn't demand money for a picture.. It's such an interesting square but it seems the minute you take out your camera, you are demanded some money for doing so- even if you didn't take that person's photo! I gave a coin to one band I just walked up to and was asked for more. When I didn't have any more to give, I gave up and walked away. Another girl got yelled at before she even took a photo of the band playing. What a shame. It made me want to leave the square altogether and not participate in any of the bands or musicians playing. Also, at night it seems to be the perfect opportunity to get a wallet lifted. Take care of your things!

Very fun to watch, but be aware. I came several times during my visit. It's wonderful to look at everything and haggle with them on the prices, but you need to pay attention. If you take photos of any of the jugglers, etc., be prepared to pay. Also, if you get lost, be prepared to pay a little kid a tiny bit of money to get out. I ate a variety of quick snacks in there, but my favorite is the orange juice! Just make sure they put it in plastic cups before you drink it!I loved looking at the towers of spices and all of the noise. However, the mood changes at night- I went back to my riad since I was a woman travelling alone. . .

Use your imagination. Not what I had always pictured it in my mind. It's basically a giant market with gypsy style stalls and souks off it. At the entrance everything is expensive, inside the souks a lot cheaper but you need to barter I.e. bought pashmina in souk for 40 dirhams after bartering, same one in main square he wanted 150 and no less! The snake charmers come and go when they please and you pay them so you can take photo. Lots of beggars and kids hassle yo.
What a feats for eyes and belly. Great food fresh orange juice and sweet pastries.A great spectacle of people, food, barbeque smoke and music

Fascinating. We have never experienced anything quite like this before - the crowds, the chaos, the noise and the range of crazy goings-on during the day. And then, the transformation in the evening with the arrival of the food-stalls/cafes. Although we were based in a quality hotel, we chose to eat here most evenings - brilliant!

Keep an open mind. The main sq. is frenetic and although it looks like madness, families are walking around with no trouble.Even the street food vendors with their constant invitations to eat at their stall may get wearing after a while, all you need to say to them that you have eaten already.We tried one stall at the back; Dos Mohammed, one of the smart restaurants with a terrace ; Premises and one restaurant/cafe at the back of the sq called Snack la Place with white tables and benches over three nights. The Stall was most expensive at 170 DH, Premises Restaurant was 2nd most expensive at 120 DH and the Le Snack was cheapest at 73 DH.We had similar types of food at all 3 places although with different meats and styles and Le Snack was the tastiest ( easily).

mental mayhem of a square. What I like about the square is the many different people you will find in there some good, some funny, some horrible and other plain evil so its a real mixed bag , you do have to watch your bag keep an bum bag hidden under your clothes and nothing in your pockets if you are tourist you could be targetted,There are plenty of police around though should any trouble arise which Ive personally never seen much of in the square.Night time is just soooo busy and squashy not for the clustrophobic, The coffee shops are cheap and cheerful, and there are plenty of cheap orange juice stalls to quench your thirst.Yes you will get hassled and hustled but that is to be expected they will soon stop if you are firm with them.Definatly AVOID at all costs the men with the monkeys, which is so cruel if you so much as take their photo they will be jumping on you and demanding money and they can get very nasty if you dont cough up so avoid those horrible lot.Avoid also having henna done there as its mostly done using hair dye which can cause serious skin reaction , they do not use natural henna.The square is a good expereince thats for sure.

Cool for a quick visit. During the day, there are people selling food (with bugs flying around), ladies doing henna, a guy with a monkey and a snake charmer. We took our picture with the snakes and I got henna but that was pretty much it. At night, the square is crowded with people dancing and playing games. It's fine to breeze through and look but I can't picture spending too much time there.

Amazing. The first day is mind boggling, but once you get into it, it's great, just remember the car's, mopeds, donkey carts and horse drawn carriges will go around you as long as you don't dither just follow the locals, they have dodging traffic down to a fine art.

better at night. During the day we found the snake charmers and monkey men rather demanding and rude and its all abit touristy but at night the men working the food stalls were really lovely and a great fun atmosphere where you dont feel hassled at all Lovely to see Moroccan families out enjoying the games and lots of live music and the food was great and really good value

Great atmosphere. If you can relax and enjoy the drums, soak up the atmosphere, watch all the various characters that mill around- this is a top people watching spot. If you get approached by the snake charmers or monkeys on a lead, then it feels touristy and your animal rights feelings start to rise- but move on and go with the flow

Madness, but fun.. This is only a five minute walk from the Riad and certainly worth one visit. It is a World Heritage Sight with acrobats, fortune tellers, snake charmers, monkeys all competing for your attention ( and a few dirhams ). Do it at least once.

Eat at the food stalls!. Please immerse yourself in local culture and foods here. The orange juice stalls are great (why so many?) and the food stalls at night are entertaining and delicious. Get your fried seafood fix at stall #89 (the only stall with a wait for seating) and for couscous and kebab-style skewers you should visit #117.

An acquired taste.. It's a bit of a cultural shock especially as you are constantly harassed by local vendors. After a few days you grow to love the place and then on your last night you can't believe you will be leaving.

Fun and not as hectic as you'd think. Visiting in winter, the square was good fun and mercifully unstressful. That said, it definitely isn't the 'greatest show on earth'. It's worth braving the shouting vendors to eat there once for the experience but there are a lot of better places to eat in Marrakech.
Real buzz. So much going on in Jemaa el Fna we visited 3 times. Sights and smells were amazing. Real North African vibe.

Loved it.. It really is the heart of the city. The shops, the people and las but not the least the food. If you happen to eat at the stalls in the evening I strongly recommend stall number 14. It was the best of all I had tried. Serves only seafood coming from Agadir and Essouria and does really feel fresh. The fish was very nice and the aubergine dip was a perfect accompaniment.

Assualt on the Senses!. I first came across the Place Jemma el Fna from the souk at dusk and immediately felt all of my senses assaulted with the smell, sound and sights to behold! We sat in a cafe drinking mint tea overlooking the square and just drank it all in. Later I returned during the day to try my hand at bargaining for souvenirs and was told by one of the stall holders that I bartered like a Morroccan woman which i hoped was a compliment!

Not for the faint hearted. Whatever you say about this place, will not do justice until you experience it yourself. Its like marmite ( you either love or hate it - no middle ground here). We stayed in Marrakech for 5 nights and we visit Jemaa el Fna, every single night..amazing food and friendly locals. ( In a place like this, you will be bothered by vendors, but a firm "No thanks or La Shukran" - would do the trick )Dont miss the experience...

Buy? Buy? Eat here! No here!. Get ready to be forced down in a seat or in a store to buy something, eat something, or be forced to do anything that will aquire money.. Don't be naive and have a strict NO ready if you really want to say no. Nice to walk around but might be a bit exhausting after 2 visits to keep being forced. Be carefull for the guys walking around with snakes and monkeys cause they will just randomly put them on or around you and demand money.

Totally unique. Enormous square full of stalls, storytellers, snake charmers, open air eating places, vendors. Buzzing with activity at all hours of the day. The dates, figs and freshly squeezed juices are all excellent value. Crowd is good natured, but watch your wallet!
There is no Marrakesh without this place!. this is the heart of the old city and the place to be both day and night. If you visit in the day, also go at night - it looks completely different.
Manic - Day and Night. Watch out for the snake charmers and ladies with Henna. Be prepared to be hassled - but all part of the charm of the place.

welcome to Marrakech. this place is a must, and you might have to go there by day and by night..2 different places!!! it's very crowded at nights and you'll many uncommon things. Becarefull though, as many shows are made for tourist purposes. I recommend to have an orange juice, 10 Dirham. SO GOOD !!!!

Always bustling!!. I looved, looooooved how full and lively the square is. It is a sight by day and a pleasure by night. The snake charmers and the monkeys, the caroussels and the Henna....the culture, the artisanal objects. Jemaa el Fna is an absolute experience.

Must visit if in Marrakech. slightly stressfull as you cant walk around without being pestered, but and amazing atmosphere, and most of the stallholders are friendly if a bit pushy, you just have to laugh and politely decline.

Sooo different. eat there - with the Morroccans - in the evening . Lots of tourists of course as well . aside from the aggressive waiters trying to get you onto their tables the rest of the experience was very different and the food good . The entertainment on the square was unique .. a grea experience overall

Not as good as it used to be.... Over the years, the Place (as everyone calls it) has lost a lot of its charm. It seems that health and safety laws have banned the fire-eaters and acrobats, and there are far fewer decent musicians than there used to be. We find it disappointing these days. Our favourite thing is to go there to eat from the open air stalls in the evenings. We always go to stall number 22/93, called 'Chez Sefiani'. It's cheap as chips, great tapas-style food, excellent choices for vegetarians, and brilliant for people-watching. Elsewhere, those with cast-iron stomachs can dine on half a sheep's head or boiled snails. You'll get hailed/dragooned by many stall-holders as you wander round - just smile and tell them you've already eaten to save getting hassled.

Without this place Marrakech would be nothing. You can spend many hours, day and night, sitting and watching the signts. But if you think you need your Lonely Planet Guide to tell you "Where to eat" - save yourself the price and the weight. The whole place is restaurants!
Hectic!. Certainly a hive of activity! Very clean and always something going on....from musical storytellers, to henna painting ladies and snakecharmers. Certainly adds to the magic of Marrakech.

Must See!. Its as mad as you think it will be but was the best part of our holiday. Felt safe yes you did get people hassling you to buy but they have plain clothed tourism police ensuring tourists are not harrassed. Great food stalls at night time.

Eat here at least once!. We loved the atmosphere and the photo opportunities in this place. The night market is great for authentic street food and everyone who visits Marrakech should eat here at least once. One the other hand I suggest avoiding the permanent restaurants around the perimeter of the square; they are expensive and uninspiring.

A remarkable feast for the senses. A memorable experience and one I shall always remember. The exotic array of performance, sights, sounds and smells are exciting. It is unlike my UK culture so I found the constant demand for money a little intimidating, even though I was happy to pay.

Chaos, lanterns and tagines. A UNESCO world heritage site. Need I say more? OK, great food (after you deal with all the touts), interesting people watching and crazy shopping. Go at the end of the day to see the transformation into this wonderful night market.
It looks like you're in another planet. Very crowded plaza, with a mistic atmosphere, specially during the night. Eat in the small tends at least once, it's good food, altough not very clean

must do. this place is a must come when you are in marrakech! how can you not miss this place if you are visiting the mosque? the surrounding of the market is filled with lots of restaurants souks as well. its amazing to see what some people do for a living everyday. be prepared there are animals as well & yes the snake dancing to music too!
