A great place to people watch.. You can see it all at Jemaa el Fna. Make sure you go at night as well as during the day. So many things to look at and we were not bothered by any of the vendors there.

Check one off the bucket list. This was my 2nd trip to Marrakech and of course we have taken several visits to the Djemaa el Fna. What an amazing place. From the monkey handlers, snake charmers, prayer sayers, story tellers, to the food vendors the collection of merchants and artists paint an amazing picture overwhelming the senses. In the daytime the picture is a vibrant and wonderful, and in the evening it is like the entire square is transported back in time.It remains one of my all time favorite places.If you have the time, go at night and visit the food stalls for dinner. Then visit one of the cafes in near the back and ask to sit on the terrace ( you might have to wait a bit). You can overlook the whole square, with Koutoubia in the background...an amazing site.

simply a must!!. this is morocco!! simply amazing, the buzz, smells, aromas pour out from every corner!! alive from dusk till dawn, eat, dance, drink (non alcholic) ahop & just soak it up!! amazing food, mint tea & the best orange juice ever!! don't miss this place, you'll kick yourself!! it is a busy place so be careful with your possessions, a few of the usual shady characters that make & spoil morocco at the same time love to prey around here!! a friendly but firm no is all thats needed as persitant as they are!! but don't by any means be put off, really a must see.....

Take in the scene for a few minutes and get away. Or maybe a bit longer if you can view it from a roof terrace bar (most non alcoholic!). It's just not my kind of circus...monkeys, snakes (they shouldn't be on a leash but in the wild) and very aggressive people.

Oh my goodness. An assault on the senses! We passed through briefly in the daytime, really didn't like to see the monkeys and snakes ... went one evening and it was crazy! It's very hard to walk around and look at the food stalls as you are accosted as soon as you walk by. It turned out to be a bit annoying really as we genuinely wanted to see what food was on offer, and the kinds of people who were eating it! We ate at stall 117, which was good - although we felt that the selection on offer was probably priced up for us as tourists! Our tip would be to choose of the menu and make sure you're not over charged ...

Medina main square. Colourful and chaotic. All hustle and bustle. Snake charmers, brightly coloured water sellers,herbalists and sellers of all sorts can be seen here. Lots of food and orange juice stalls. A Unesco heritage site - this square changes throughout the day. Caleches (horse and carriage) rides can be booked here. Try to choose those caleche drivers who look after their horses to encourage others to do the same. Plenty of places to eat and drink (non alcholic) surround the square.

A very busy place. I liked the buzz of the place with so many sights,sounds and smells to discover.I wasnt keen on the people trying to get your money any way possible especially using their children to play on your emotions
Magic Place. Just go there, go in the morning, go in the afternoon and go in the evening. Drink some fresh OJ, walk around, Feel the magic and enjoy it.

The Mosaic of Morocco all in One Place. I have often read that Morocco is like a mosaic... So many different pieces put together into a whole. Jemaa el Fna is like this! A mosaic -- dare I say kaleidoscope -- of sights. Monkey men, snake charmers, charming carnaval games, street performers, lights and ordinary people -- and sounds -- flutes, drums, the call to prayer, and calls to buy.... It is exciting and beautiful! Don't blink! You'll miss something!

A Crazy Orderly Chaos. This is one of the main attractions in Marrakech. Do try to go early in the evening, or late afternoon, and see how they set up all of these eating places under awnings and chairs with all kinds of local foods, as well as the spices and dried fruits You'll see musicians, story tellers around a bonfire(it was winter so it was kind of cold) playing their music or telling their stories. This is besides all the souks surrounding the Djemaa El Fna, which you could get lost along with mayhem of traffic of people, donkeys, bicycles, motor scooters.
Main square. Perfect place for dinner, excellent food great experience and very reasonably priced. A must is the dessert cart which charges 3€ for a whole selection of wonderful cakes.

You could spend an entire afternoon people watching here easily!. This is not to be missed in Marrakesh and most likely you won't miss it. It is bursting with activity day and night (but night time is really special because of all the food vendors). There were snake charmers, transvestites, comics, and preachers.... all coexisting in the large square near all the shopping. Do not miss this wonderful Moroccan experience.

Nice place to hang out.... and you can watch open air films at night. Be careful with your belongings, do not be easily intimidated by the aggressive hustling from stall owners. Be friendly but firm and you'll be fine.

Jemaa el fna. dive into the heart of Marrakech, where no other city can imitate the energy of the main square. Taste the famous Marrakech orange juice (best I have ever had), walk by snake charmers and henna artist and get lost in the alleys of the old souq.

the square. full of hustle and bustle with lots of entertainers - snake charmers, musicians, acrobats and more. It was lovely to sit in one of the cafes with a drink and just watching the world go by.

busy and full of live. enjoyed this place as it is heart of Marrakech - full of mint and fresh orange juice- lots of watch and fun to be in- not mad on the restaurants around here tho- try terrasse des epices for a bit of sanctuary and flavour.

A nice quiet spot for a rest. Lol. Madness, utter madness! Everything is happening all at once, it takes a while for your mind to adapt to the speed things come at you at, but just smile, keep moving and say "merci, non!" a lot. The snakes are half dead, the Berber dancers are a bit touchy feely and the monkeys, well, that's up to you, but I'm not happy about it. Hey ho, everyone has to make a living, and most do it here.The orange juice is excellent, the snails are pretty good and in the evening the number one food bar is good, clean and cheap. I had a sheeps head, but was devastated when it was served "off the skull!"

it never get boring. we liked to just stay at the square (or in one of the many roof top cafes) and watched the bustling life happening. its worthwhile to spent a whole day there from afternoon to late evening as it changes so much within a couple of hours
Unique experience. Go upstairs in the Cafe De Glacier at night and just take in the sights, smells, sounds over a mint tea. It's a cultural experience

madness central. The times square of morocco! So much to see by day and night. You keep coming back and through it to navigate through the Medina. Very hectic haggling and sometimes intimidating traders but will respond to a polite no. Get out there!

Utter Chaotic Fun. The whole world and its exhuberant, hyperactive son is here....snake charmers, monkeys, acrobats, scam artists, everything for sale, cheap food, horse-drawn carriages, noise noise noise. Unmissable. Try the freshly squeezed orange first thing....stall 59 was clean and the best oj i've ever tasted.

Crazy,busy, unique place.. Jemma el Fna is a touristic spot, so be prepared to be approached every step of the way, shopkeepers inviting you just to look, snake charmers, monkeys, water sellers, food stalls all after your business. You need energy to keep up, just say no thanks, la sultan and the people do leave you alone until the next person spots you, there are some lovey roof top terraces to eat and have mint tea from and enjoy the hustle and bustle from afar.

Mad but real. The madness of the crowds a rush hour London Bridge station but with added horses, motorbikes and the occasional snake with everyone saying hello and buy my stuff. This is is real Arabia made atmospheric by the constant music and Berber drumming.

Mad as a box of crazy frogs - but amazing!. Busy, crazy, mental ... but an absolute must to understand the melting pot of cultures that is Marrakech. It's like organised chaos on a grand scale and there is always something to look at. Careful where you point your camera though as some of the locals expect to be tipped if they "pose" for your photos :-) We never ate here, although our Riad owner suggested that the best food stalls were Numbers 1, and 114 to 117. Try them if you dare ...

false teeth?. false teeth sellers snake charmers monkeys and more. The smells the noises are all down to Marakechi people going about their daily lives, this is how they live, watch out for the mopeds donkeys and carts so you don,t get run down.

Marvel. The square is full of tourists but still also a world heritage and in fact very genuine. It is magical in the evening. See the sunset from a terrace and hear the music from the local performers. Then walk around in the evening and look at the rings of local people listening to story-tellers, musicians or simply dancing. If you want to buy food, do it in the evening, be detailed about your order (what is included or not), buy were local people eat, avoid smokey cooking oil, avoid unclean silverware and enjoy the atmosphere.
BRILLIANT VIBE,GREAT SMELLS. experience worth it...bustling with energy,and foods to die for.keep your wallets close to you...and arrive there hungry!
Nice and Dirty. Stop bigging please and let people walk safely, it's very oriental and very warm place but it need to be as much natural as it can be

An interesting experience. We visited the square twice on our visit. The only reason for this was because the first time was a little scary so we thought we'd give it a second chance. I'm glad we did.The first time my wife got ambushed by a Henna lady who wouldn't take no for an answer and grabbed my wife's hand, which scared her somewhat. If that wasn't bad enough on our way out I got a monkey put on the shoulder by a monkey charmer, which at first I enjoyed, then another monkey on the other shoulder, again no problem. They encouraged my wife to take photos. After they demanded 200 DH per monkey, 400 DH in total! Con artists!We had a talk about this after and decided we'd give it another go. Enjoyable this time!After coming out the souks we had a wonder around the square.There are various stalls selling souvenirs etc.The snake charmers have got to be the bravest men I know, there is no way I'd get that close to a king cobra! They're amazing to watch those!They had dancers in the square which was traditional, music men and various other entertainments.We stopped to have a refreshing glass of freshly squeezed orange juice, only 4 DH each.

It's a square. but it offers plenty of entertainment; street vendors, artists with snakes, apes, food stands (if you manage to catch stand nr. 14 at night, take the chance and eat there! Best for fish apparently!), some souks (obviously the prices on the squares are amongst the highest), and there are a few cafés and small restaurants where you can dine or simply have a coffee or mint tea.

Soul of Marrakech, but be careful. The Jamaa el Fna is the most famous place in Africa with it's own soul. There you can feel (see and hear) the beat and the spirit of Marrakech, the way of living. Depending on time of day there are differnent things too see: awaking at 9am in the morning you'll find taxis, donkey carts, horse-drawn carriage and motorcycles. Later people apears with apes, dressing like babys. Beware of them: faster as you can say "NO" the ape is on your shoulder and the man claims money to get it away. The same for the snake charmers. Both species are first nice, invite you to come closer and take a photo. Later they claim high fees (10€ for photo of a snake) and become really loud, agressive and touched me/my camera as I didn't pay. Beware, or use a zoom objective ;)The henna-women also are very intrusively, if you don't be fast they start painting your hand before you stop walking. Men in shops close to the La Place are also brash to get you in their shops, prices there are higher then deeper in the souk and they become agressive or unfriendly if you don't buy. Bad behaviour, as single woman I lied, told I was married but that won't keep them away from insulting sentences and touches. In the afternoon they start to build up the food stalls day by day. Taste the local cuisine there. No matter which time, it is always interesting to see the people and listen to different music groups there. Best place to do this are the restaurant terrasses around the place, save from everybody be friendly first and claim money therefore in the end.

Great Shopping!. If you're looking to buy souvenirs for friends back home or gifts for yourself, check out Jemma el Fna. There are performers and nice fruit and nut stands during the day. But at night the place really comes alive with many performers and restaurants. The restaurants hassle you to come and eat at their place but the food is good and cheap.

Exciting and wild, give the monkeys a miss!. The square comes to life in the evening, and the food sold in the central stalls is excellent, well worth a try! It was friendly and exciting all at once. Everyone will want your attention in the square, but a friendly 'no thankyou' is all it takes to be free. The "charmed" snakes and dancing monkeys made me sad - its not a good life for animals, so don't encourage that, heh?

organised chaos. Very open plan and some of the tastiest orange juice you will ever taste! slightly dubious snake charmers and some over zelous henna ladies, but overall an experience not to be missed.

Overwhelming & Exhirlating. The square is just bursting with activity and things to see. Walk around, look at all the stalls, stop in one of the many cafes to have tea and watch all of life go by (both street level and rooftop viewing are fun,but different experiences). It can be overwhelming, I was definitely a little nervous. My friend plunged right in; at one point I had a snake around my neck and then one of those fez hats. Just be careful with these guys and money, they will try to intimidate you into giving them more money; give them a few coins; whatever you agreed to and then walk away. Watch out for the henna ladies, do not let them grab you or put henna on your arm.

Large, Loud, and Exciting. Just as we expected the Jemaa was large, loud, and exciting. We stayed at a Riad close by (Riad Carina which we highly recommend) and came to the Jemaa most nights. Sometimes we were greeted by Snake Charmers, and story tellers, other times we ate at the food stalls, drank fresh orange juice, and got pestered into getting henna tattooos.If you don't want a monkey on your shoulder or henna ink squirted on your hand, then walk through with your hands in your pockets.A few nights we had a potentially semi inebriated native come and speak to us, and keep us for an hour or so with the topic of conversation going anywhere from Obama to our favorite food, to the last movie we had seen.We grew to love the people of morocco and their helpfulness and genuine friendliness.

Definitely something to see!. This place is like the heart of the city. Everything from slippers to teapots, jewelry to spices are sold here. There are women doing henna, men with performing monkeys, snake charmers, dancers, singers and musicians everywhere you look. You have to remember that everyone and anyone is there to make money so don't be fooled into thinking someone is just being polite! Keep all valuables hidden, and never pull out more money than you want to spend with each stall. Ladies, dont wear sleeveless tops or shorts as the staring can be a bit much, and expect to be looked at as if you are an alien if you have blonde hair or/and blue eyes!! When haggling with a stall owner start at verrrrry low prices as they start extremely high, but they expect you to throw a price out first. The atmosphere is pretty cool, very busy after 4pm, but that's when all the stalls appear. Try getting a seat in a cafe with a terrace around the edge of the market if you need a break, you can sit and watch it all happen instead of being in the middle of it all. All in all, it's an experience you have to have !!

fresh orange juice and go... Had a good laugh :-) and had a good fright ;-) if you make eye contact you say non mercy or lele.. One of the henna ladys grabbed my girlfriends hand and just started to make a crappy henna creation... Then she will say you give me 400 Dihram :-P I start laughing say that its crap and give her 20...she walks away cursing....they really think money grows on our backs...You can buy 4 breads,a bottle of water, some cakes and vache Kiri for 20...at the small shops so..I think its well payed for an unwanted crappy henna tattoo.. have fun and stand your ground :-)

All life passes through. If you enjoy people watching, this is the place to go. All life forms pass through at some point or another. The diversity is amazing from little old men with a donkey and cart to a sparkling white Mercedes 4 wheel drive. Mopeds galore
don't miss it. Bustling and exciting! All the action is here. Be sure to eat here, especially at No. 1 (we didn't try them all, but of the ones we did, this was the best).

I love it. I know they said that you etiher love it or hate it and I love it! We ate at Stall no 1 - Chez Aicha and it was wonderful. The square was lively night and day. I love it! A pity about the mopeds and horse carriages though. There is a smell of horse urine permeating the air but not at the stalls.

Vibrant!. Great place to visit in Morroco! Multicultural and vibrant, with the food court (by the way, great place to have a cheap and good meal), the tea sellers, orange juice, snakes, monkeys... A world of atractions! You can also have a great general view from the terrace of one of the cafes in the square.

Organized Chaos. You need to experience the square during different times of the day to see how it changes with different vendors coming and going. Food in the tent stalls is not a lot but is definitely expensive. You will do better in the restaurants at the edge of the square if you are desperate for a bite. If you visit for the first time at night be prepared for the attack of the monkey. Entertainers with monkeys approach children for an innocent photo. You take the photo and then you are asked for 250 dirhams. Stay cool!! This is Marrakech and you make your contribution by offering a few dirhams. If you don't want to be harrassed while taking pictures get a seat at one of the nearby tea places overlooking the square. Do negotiate hard before you buy anything from the stores in the souk. Vendors do inflate prices for tourists. Ask a vendor you purchased something from for the local price of an item you are interested in buying.

Piping hot snails!. I liked the fact that we have experienced something that many people have encountered for centuries. The boxers, orange juice stalls, hot snails, snake charmers, actors...all a cacophony of moroccan culture. What i did not like was the continuous attempts to create distance between me and my meagre dirhams. Would have liked to enjoy the square without having to pay for everything I lay my eyes on.

Scary but exciting. The square was a shock to the senses, but a good one. So many exotic smells and some not so good, lots of horses and carriages, as well as donkeys!! Sat having a mint tea on Friday in a roof top restaurant and 1 pm prayers called, hundreds of people going into the mosque and carpets laid outside for the overspill, I felt a bit like an intruder really watching people pray. Cars, bikes, mopeds all carrying on as usual around them, a bit of a fight broke out between a horse and carriage driver and a local youth, very surreal indeed. Snake charmers, performing monkeys, which I found very sad, am sure they are not well cared for. The food in the restaurants in the square was surprisingly good and cheap, no alcohol in the square, but the mint tea is good.A very different experience.

Buzzy buzzzzzz. We had dinner there at a few of the tent lookin restaurants, i must say the lamb joints r very good. The lamb brains etc wow gd stuff really tender the meats and who knows what other parts of the lamb. It really keeps you warm. There is a stall selling fish n calamari fried with batter, beautiful. Its very busy n u have to hang n wait ur turn.If u have not eaten at Jemma el Fna, ur not in Marrakech.

fascination. What an amazing place, like nowhere else on earth. Hustle bustle, mopeds from every angle, everybody wants to talk to you, everybody wants to help you ( for money). The food stall at night are breathtaking, the aroma's amaze. The street enetrtainers - its trully bizzare but captivating entralling. Different place during the day. Dont be frightened to say no! Thet persist but ignore them and they eventually give up.

Brilliant place. Throw yourself into the madness, it's great fun. There is a great atmosphere in the square day and night. it's not for the Faint hearted! A few survival tips, don't take pictures of the monkeys or snakes, if you do you are expected to pay. Keep your hands in a safe place, the henna tattoo ladies are very quick. They can tattoo you in seconds and then want money. Haggling is a national sport, you have to play the game. Start off very low and slowly get to half of what the person originally asked. Don't pay more than half. If you walk away they will follow and give you the price you want. If you don't want to be hassled, just smile and say no thank you, if you are firm and polite they will not persist. Compared to Turkey, the hassle to buy things is not bad at all. Make sure you have a coffee in one of the main balconies overlooking the square. It's a great way to watch the madness ans soak up the atmosphere
WOW. pure excitement and you will see something different every time you go to this amazing place,it is just pure entertainment at all times but obviously keep your wits about you at all times
crazy square. No words can describe this square : two different faces characterized the place, one during the day and another one in the night. You can't miss it !
Not Just for Tourists. There were plenty of tourists milling around with us but we were few among the thousands of locals doing shopping, running their little stalls and living daily life.

Exotic and Safe. While at first a little intimidated by the jostling crowds in the square we soon came to feel very comfortable there. The stalls were set up in attractive manner, the entertainers approached without being obnoxious. The snake charmers got a little angry when people photographed without giving them a gratuity but you have to remember they are doing the show to make a living. The fresh orange juice stands had the best juice I'ver ever tasted and I live in Florida! We ate from the food stalls at night and thoroughly enjoyed it - especially the one with the fried fish and eggplant. We stood by a few minutes watching in confusion until the cook found us a place to sit and started putting food in front of us - delicious. Many locals eating there and they were all friendly. For a few local dollars a great meal and evening of entertainment. Don't miss it!

Did not enjoy being here!. Firstly I should say that my partner loved it here! However I could not of felt more bothered and stressed! From the women trying to give you a henna tattoo if any of your arms/hands are on show to people expecting you to pay them money fro doing a dance you did not ask for I want!! We were here in the evening just before it got dark and observed from high on a rooftop, from here I was content and quite happy to absorb the sights, I waited here till the coach was due to leave. We walked back throught the busy square and I was pulling at Dan to hurry up, I couldn't wait to get out of there.. even when you think your safe there is someone trying to sell you something! I wanted to give the place another chance so we returned friday morning where I thought it would be calmer but still couldn't enjoy it.

The heart of the city. Please do not fail to experience this square!It really is an attack on the senses - sight, sound and smell will hit you and in an instant you will be swept up in the fast pace of La Place!It has two lives - one by day and one by night. At all times you must respect it but moreover enjoy it. Keep your wits and do not neglect to watch out for the snake charmers and monkey trainers - I kept a safe distance. Likewise, don't engage with the henna ladies unless you want henna - they will take advantage of a polite soul. Have banter with the food market workers who will chant at you to eat with them. Keep a knowing smile on your face and if all else fails just keep walking.
main square. what an experience particularly at night - not like anywhere else in world I've visited - truly amazing...
The heart of Marrakech. The square has an amazing atmosphere, especially in the evenings. I'm not that fond of the snake charmers, but the food stalls are amazing.

This is Marrakech. Very crowded place,lots of people,food and confusion! Here you can see the truthful Marrakech ! It is a must see! And you will love it or hate it! Go with an open mind and have fun!

Wow - just WOW:). You could spend a whole day just watching the world go by in the jemaa el Fna. We never felt threatened - though ALWAYS haggle price before touching anything or taking photos of people. The food here is delicious and safe. Just thinking about the orange juice is making my taste buds dance. This is also where you can get a local tour guide (horse and carriage), though remember haggle the price before getting into the carriage. Marakech is a family friendly destination - they seem to prefer families traveling together. We were treated very well by everyone we met and often people would go out of their way to make our daughter comfortable. Of course it was for a better price but when you are so far out of your element it's the little bits that make you feel at ease. Highly recommend a visit to Jemaa el Fna - you haven't seen Marrakeech unless you see Jemaa el Fna.

Not quite what I expected. We may have gone the wrong time of day, but was expecting much more, there was the usual charmers, music etc, but somehow I expected more atmosphere, perhaps early morning or eveing would have been better

Marrakech = Jemaa el Fna. Jemaa el Fna is the big square in the medina of Marrakech. This is the place you must see. Here are the men talking to snakes, the women doing henna-tatoos, the men pretending they are dentists and everybody else

a mad melee...... I love the Djma el Fna at night, get there before the sun goes down, go up to the Cafe de Paris (sounds posher than it is) and sit on the room with a cold drink and watch the stall holders set up for the night, the braziers going and the mad melee begin.....you can then venture down into the throng and try out the stall.....the Jame Oliver banter does get on your nerves but hey they are trying to attract your business......be friendly in Morocco and people will always be friendly back....I love the place!

Amazing Sights. This was tops on my bucket list for years and I finally got here! People of all ages, all countries, and financial means are hanging out in the square. I wasn't expecting so many tourists, it was great! I recommend going there at night though it closes up by 10-11:00PM. There is lovely singing and music, tons of great food stalls with picnic table seating, glittering lantern lights everywhere! Rooftop seating is available at many of the square surrounding restaurants.We loved the food and wished we could have stayed for weeks!

Freshly squeezed OJ. After a busy day exploring the sites during a "Marrakech City Discovery" walking tour there was no better way to end it with a freshly squeezed chilled OJ. There are plenty of vendors to choose from but I'd recommend having one from Stand 42.

Interesting but some very unfriendly people. The place is really interesting, I never saw something like that before.Problem are the vendors, that are pushing and insulting you. If you take another Orange Juice Seller (there a lot of them with all the same juice), some vendors shout you (like "f*** you). After we ate, we just wanted to walk across the center of the square, that has a lot of restaurants to have a look, not to eat. If you are going into a restaurants, some owner got really angry as well (like f*** you and leave my country....). Same for these girls that wanted to draw you something on my girlfriends hands. There are very persistent and dont leave you alone and try to rip you all the time.I would recommend to visit the square for one time, but then do something else.

historical place to experiment. lot of people, very crowdy, very typical! the market is full of nice things to buy. is nice to go around all this place, listen to the music, try some snails or other typical moroccan food. it is nice to see during the day, but it is even more impressive at night. a place to visit!

Fun. Everything it promised to be, busy, noisy, lots of activity, entertainment, food. A great buzz in the later afternoon early evening when the light changes and the square comes to life. Not too much hassle from vendors if you are not interested in buying anything. A lot of fun.

Fun. Fun watching the world go by in Marrakech in this famous square. Be prepared to be cornered day or night into buying fruit juice, food, a picture of a water seller or snake charmer. Take it for what it is and enjoy it.Get a seat at one of the bars with a balcony and get a great view of whats going on - and use your zoom for ree photos of the charmers etc!

Fun, busy and essential to visit at night. The sounds, sights and smells of Jemaa el Fna have to be seen to be believed. Visit during the day for a lively but civilised adventure in the souks, but make sure you return at night and experience the food stalls - you'll be hassled by teenage boys to dine in their establishments, but it's all part of the fun. The food stalls cook the food in front of you - and it's good stuff - so don't be afraid to eat it.Also, try the ginger tea - it's amazing!

Market and Dining al fresco.. This a market during the day, with snake charmers and monkeys and men selling sets of false teeth and single teeth. At night it changes into a massive outdoor cafe, with many different stalls. Kitchens are set up, also trestle tables and food is cooked to order.

2 sides of the square. i loved it during the night, because it becomes full of people coming to eat on the square for a few money. They have carriages whit lots of different food and you are invited, or pushed if you like, to sit in a bench and have your dinner in the middle of a messy crown..this is simply amazing! During the day this square is desolate, just a few people and sellers are there with their umbrella and nothing else.

Crazy place you must have seen. The place to be, specialy after 5 PM, eat and drink all you can. Many foodstalls offer good food for very fair prices. Our favourite was nr 81, Chez Simo. During the day I hope you will ignore the the men with monkeys en snakes, don' t pay them money. This abuse of animals is a shame.

Not like anything you've ever seen. The square is full of characters wanting to henna paint you, sell you orange juice, put snakes around you, groups gather around story tellers, musicians and drummers. The whole experience is absorbing and a little scary at the same time. You can witness it from any of the surrounding Cafes' roof tops, or you can get right into the heart of the action and eat at one of the multitude of 'pop-up' cafes that appear every evening. Good Luck!
The square. Don't let the monkeys on your shoulders otherwise you'll have to pay. Avoid the square to eat as very touristy. Fresh orange juice at 4 dirhams is well worth it!

You Have To Do It Once!. It's totally wild with dummers,fortune tellers, monkeys and snake charmers all competing for your attention (and dirhams ). Smile and stay positive and you'll enjoy the experience.

Manic!. You will struggle to avoid this square if you are staying in Marracesh as everything seems to lead to it and from it. My daughter hated it as she was continually accosted by Henna ladies who appeared to be about to stab her with a hyperdermic needle but I think (hope) thats just what they use for doing the henna. You will hear endless shouts of 'maybe later aligator' 'give me good democratic price' 'hey u skinny eat here' as you pass through. You will also at some stage have a poor mangy monkey with a nappy dropped onto your shoulder for a photograph. The snakes could do with some viagra as they struggled to be roused by the snake charmers, but all in all its an experience. Any rooftop cafe gives an excellent view. Its a different place at night when all the food stalls are up and the tacky lamps look beautiful lit by candles. Enjoy!

what an experience. It looks like all the picture sou have ever seen but it is far mre then that. The noise, the smells (not in a bad way) and just the atmosphere you could not do justice to describe it to anybody you just have to be there to savour the pleasure.

INTENSE, OVERPRICED, and OVERRATED. The Jemaa el Fna is the open market part of the old Medina in Marrakech and the stalls all have hawkers that can be extremely agressive to the point that one phycially slapped our son for going to a competting eating group.During the day, there are the typical citrus juice, date, and spice stands along with the snake charmers (with half dead snakes) and monkey handlers. They will approach you and place the monkey or snake on your shoulder and expect a tip for a picture. A simple no will not prevent this, but shift to a command voice seems to stop them in their track (think drill sargent). The shops that surrond this open market square sell very high priced junk (sic fake labels, poor qualify, excessive prices). For an example, for a poor quality scarf we were given for free on a tour, they were priced at 20 DAR but further into the madina/souk, they were only 10 DAR and negitiable from there down. There are varsiou restaurants / cafe's around the markter as well, with the furtherst one overlooking the court yard fit only for the view and drink (i.e. tea with mint leaves). There is a recommended restaurant 2 doors down from this cafe that has excellent food and value and a reasonable view as well - however, this restaurant is great for lunch, but close early for diner.Durning the night, the intensity intensifies as the food stalls really get going from 6 PM - midnight. There are sooo many food stall and the hawkers get even more agressive, essentially grabbing you or standing in your face. In this case even a command voice seems lost in the free-for-all. We compared the food prices and fond that the restaurants were either targeting the 'white' tourists, including some going so far as to hang fake Trip Advisor #1 signs from the roofs of their stalls. Comparing the prices, clearly these 'tourist traps' were hightly over priced. We opted to start with the snails on the far end (would only serve us the 10 DAR size serving, not the 5 DAR serving also listed); then submitted our selves to the accosting of the various hawkers (hey - I sort of like this 'sport' while others in my group clerarly did not) and found a grill place that was occupied by 'locals' (i.e. not a lot of white faced, white/blond haired people). They were able to find a place for us and the ordering was fast and furrious. Some locals helped identify which foods to avoid (i.e. veg tangine, minced meat only partially cooked, etc.). Finished up with ginger cake and tea then off to the closest cafe near where the horse carrages que-up for a tea with mint leaves to observe the chaios from afar (an take pictures with the telephoto without having to pay).Everone should experience this once in their life time . . but for us, it was poor due to the phycal assault on our youngest son.

NOT FOR THE FAINT HEARTED!. There is much to see and hear. Don't get duped into a guided tour around anywhere in this vicinity. Everybody is out to make big money......... for nothing. Whether it be a guided tour around the souks or just buying something from a shop. Nine times out of ten they will fleece money off of you . Yes, i know that it is all part and parcel of travelling to somewhere like this, but seriously a polite but firm no thank you/ la shokran / non-merci, will generally suffice. Just don't buy anything at all, you will get far better quality at your own local market or from many internet sites that specialize in quality moroccan goods, and all for a quarter of the price that is asked.

amazing. What an amazing place. During the day henna stalls , orange juice stands and lots of fab sights , in the evening a huge great outdoor barbecue arena with stall after stall competing charmingly and very competitively for business. Food delish and we loved it . Loads to see . Really great

Bonkers. You'd think this was put on for the tourists, but when there are locals gathered around a storyteller or magician or medicine man you realise it's not. We didn't eat there but plenty of tourists and locals were. Must see.

An unparalleled experience. I haven't been to any place quite like this. Yes, there are aspects of Istanbul, other African or Asian cities and markets around the world. However, it is the timeless quality of the mixture of old and new that creates the spectacle. The snake charmers mingle with the orange sellers, the scooters, the horse drawn buggies,the monkey tamers, the henna ladies and the throng of people. Then, not long after you have absorbed this daytime scene, it changes. Carts are pulled in by hand, loaded with battered sinks, stools, tables, elaborate teapots, large snail cooking pots, boxes of ingredients and a collection of well battered equipment. Within an hour, the square is transformed into a food market. We walked around surveying the scene before settling on the stall right opposite the Cafe Glacier. It was really good value and certainly good enough for the price.

Mad, eye-opening and learn to say no!. The Riad we stayed at was just off the streets of the square, a peaceful haven to run to after the madness!Street sellers start opening early, in the morning some of the market is open along with some exhibitioners such as snake charming, monkeys and horse & carriages. We were dumped just outside the square by the taxi when we arrived in the evening and taken through the square with our luggage carried by a man with a barrow, we fought our way through the crowded madness of the square packed with people, motorbikes and cars. Very overwhelming, especially after carting our stuff down side streets!We ventured out into the square that evening and coming from the Midlands UK it was a shock to the senses. Fascinating though!The food stalls will try every trick to get you to eat there, we had songs sung at us, were crowded around having menus thrust at us and they even got other customers to clap to get us in. The food wasn't great though and be warned about various dishes being placed in front of you that you didn't ask for, you will be expected to pay for them.Watch out for the henna artists, they will come up and seem pleasant but after a minute they will grab your hand and try to ink you. Be extremely firm and say no, I felt rude but after the top of my hand being covered in ink twice and it now being indelibly attached to my clothing it's necessary. Everything has a price, ask for directions and you will generally have someone lead you to a location but expect compensation, not a problem but be prepared.The stalls are repetitive but bargains can be had, especially with leather, bags and spices. Be prepared to barter, more fool you if you take the first price as the seller will always go lower, such is the location and the culture. but know there is a lowest price so don't be insulting. Be sure of a price you want to pay and don't exceed it no matter how much you like it as you will likely be the loser. The sellers are willing to barter with anyone and will try any trick, like the food sellers, to get you in there.. Such as saying everything is 20dhms, when this isn't true, ask for the price of everything.My biggest issue is the lack of ability to browse, items are thrust into your hand or you are directed to certain products and you can either miss things you really like or leave in annoyance.Firmness is key, if you are being harrassed too much just go down a few stalls and you will find the same item without the hassle where you can purchase what you want (also a good tip for bartering, find out a price at one stall and you can use that to negotiate a better deal elsewhere).After crossing the square many, many times over the space of 8 days it does get a little intense but it is definitely worth visiting.We took a horse and carriage ride one evening, they have a tarriff and we arranged for a 30 min journey for 6 people for 400dhm, in my view worth the money, the driver was very friendly and took us on a very pleasant route through several areas taking over the allotted time and taking pictures of us on the carriage at the end.Seriously mad place, everything and anything has a price, if you stop to look at any display expect them to approach, and expect them to want payment. Pictures are not free so be warned as there is so much to see:)

Where to eat at night in Marrakech. This is a central square in the middle of Marrakech which has attractions during the day (snake charmers, jugglers, acrobats)but comes alive at night as the food stalls set up. You can eat delicious food cooked in front of you so there is no danger of food poisoning. Budget between €5 and €10 per head and I recommend restaurant Nº1. The noise of the various bands playing in the square and the vendors selling their various wares is incredible. Note that the restaurants on the sides of the square with viewing balconies are really expensive and not nearly as good - a glass of suspect orange juice costs Dh20 whereas in the square you can see it being pressed and it costs just Dh4.

the mystical square. the square is brilliant for souveneirs and for observation, it is always busy and the hustle and bustle is constant with sellers, snake charmers and other merchants, at night it is mystical but can be overwhelming at the same time

Not everything it is made out to be. To capture the atmosphere you need to go at night not during the day! During the day there is not much to see but in the evening that is when all the action takes place and it is worth sitting upstairs in one of the cafes to soak up the ambience.

Lots of Hustling of Poorly Made Goods. You see the same thing at so many shops and each one touting their goods. I enjoy negotiating, but most people I saw hated the process as they felt they were being ripped off! You need to look hard to find quality merchandise, but it's there if you are patient and willing to negotiate hard.

You might be disappointed!. If you like colour and masses of stalls offering a wide assortment of tourist trinkets and love to bargain then this is a place to be. However, expect to be jostled and pestered and do not expect to find a clean area. In terms of value for money ther are better markets in the villages around the city.

Street Food at Stalls in Jamaa El Fna. We enjoyed the food at the street stalls. Ate at a few nicer restaurants as well (including Azar) but the quality and taste were just so much better at the stalls that we ended up eating there most of the trip.Few tips -1. Eat at stall #1: We tried a few others and none matched either in price or in taste.2. Avoid stall #31: They are extremely disorganized. Tried to charge us more than what we owed, put extra food in front of us (olives, potato fritters etc.) when not ordered and charged us for them at the end. Plus the food took forever to get to us, was cold when it arrived and tasted below average.3. You have to pay approximately 5Dhr for the bread and sauces that are placed in front of you as soon as you sit down. Some (like #31, charge 10Dhr) so remember to ask if what is "given" to you is free..same story with anything else just put in front of you. You can also ask for half of the bread if you like4. Ask for the spicy sauce - delicious5. Mint tea at the end of the meal is usually free..and refreshing 6. A 10% tip is typically expected/appreciated

It's an experience!. Day and night in Jemaa el fna couldn't be any more different!During the day the squre is somewhere to pass through when shopping in the souks, grab some lunch in one of the many surrounding restaurants.....but by night WOW does it change! Snake charmers, LOTS of bustling food stalls and other selling their weirs.Be sure to have some of the freshly squeezed juices but be on your guard to the henna tattooists who will grab at you......don't be afraid to say NO!

The Balcon de Europa (Nerja, Spain) on steroids. This is the most interesting thing to see / experience in Marrakech. Go there as the sun sets behing the Koutoubia mosque, sit on one of the terraces in the one of the restaurants which surround three sides of the square. Then go down into the square and join in the mayhem. If you don't keep moving your shoes will be shined and your hand henna'ed. Listen to bands, watch the snake charmers, marvel at the acrobats, avoid the monkeys, see the colourful water sellers and then select your favourite stand and have dinner. Choose from endless stands serving every sort of tagine imaginable; there are even five stands just selling snails. Just remember that if you want to take a photo (and you will) to agree with the person first and pay for the privilege (20dh should do it); that's how they make a living.
Place to be. It is a lively square, full of food stalls, snake charmers, street sellers, ocean of people can be seen and heading inside
Excellent. Monkeys....snakes...fresh Oranges..."Colourful" personalities it's all in the square. a few good cafes to chill out in as well. Go and enjoy!

Too much hassle!. It's a great place if you like to say "No thank you" all the time. It is filled with people that will sell you anything: orange juice, argan oil, people with monkeys, henna artists and snake charmers. I do recommend having dinner at the square since the food is relatively cheap and tastes good. The best crowded food stall was n. 32. Cheap and delicious merguez sausages, soup and cous cous. But once is enough! Also beware of pickpockets and an overall seedy element that seems to have taken over Marrakech.

nightmare square. Just like everywhere else in the medina, you can't even look at anything or anyone without being forced to pull out the wallet. After a while i just looked at the ground the entire time, but then I got even more verbal abuse.When you walk past the eateries in the evening, they pull your clothes and force you to sit down and eat there. I got forced into one of them. Got diarrhea after 10 minutes. Asked somebody directions to the nearest toilets. They're in the back of the square behind some bushes. It's a toilet where you use your hand and a bucket of water. So beware if you have an explosive digestive tract.I enjoyed buying a glass of orange juice on the square during the daytime. It's a bit more relaxed then. I was just minding my business when some guy with a monkey came over and pushed the monkey in my arms. That meant I had to pay for the experience.It's not like i was some halfnaked chubby American lady staring at stalls for ages without buying anything.. I would walk at a normal pace and lay my eyes on some tourist tat 100 meters away. ( Because I did really want to buy something, I just didn't want to be hassled) The sellers would catch my eye and then start their usual chat, then if I would say no in a friendly way, they would start getting aggressive and personal. " Why aren't you buying this, isn't it good enough for you? What's wrong with you?"Marrakechians are so aggressive to tourists, I don't understand why anyone still wants to go there. There are far more interesting places in Morocco than that overcrowded tourist-trap. I hope tourists stop coming there, and they learn how to treat people.

madness at night. you wont have visited marrakesh if you avoid jemmaa el-Fna especially after dusk the place really comes to life then grab yourself a terrace cafe seat and enjoy the noise and sights of this unbelievable city you are safer than your home town honestly just enjoy

Fun from a distance. It's a great place if you like to say "No thank you" all the time. It is filled with people that sell orange juice, argan oil, people with monkeys, henna artists and other things that did not really attract me. After walking around we found out that the best place to observe the activity on the square is by drinking a mint thea at one of the rooftop bars that surround it. I do recommend to have dinner at the square since the food is relatively cheap and tastes good. Tip: have dinner at a crowded food stall.
A bygone age. It is not the square itself but all the different acts that makes this place very different from the usual town square. Early evening is the time to go.

manic. The square at night comes alive with snake charmers,henna painters, "have your photo taken with this money/snake" water sellers, etc. Worth a visit for the brave amongst you. Constant pestering keep your money and valuables near to you and beware of your hand being grabbed and tatooed with Henna!

fun/ crazy. its a buzz. just enjoy it :)BEWARE the henna artists will try to rip you off! for ONE person you shouldn't pay more than 10-15 DHS!you also must try the orange juice thats freashly squeezed- you might be able to get a photo with the shopkeepers.

From an oriental dream to a dumpster. I know morocco now since more than ten years and as i organised tours and rallyes inside the country i ve been countless times in marrakesh. i remember marrakesh as an interesting and save place, wlaks through the medina and staying on or around the djemma ek fna were of no trouble at all. nowadays you can be happy if nobody hassles you when you get 100m from the car to the riad. it s no fun any more, the place reeks of bad smells and is basically a huge dustbin, despite the efforts and daily cleaning. you want to see morocco, go somewhere else, there are much nicer places than the sell-crap-to-tourists-place djemma el fna, of course that is just my humble opinion, cheers, mike

A rare experience put on by and for the locals, tourists are incidentals. Loved it. Where else in the world can you see a tooth puller showing off his range of extractions and inviting you to sit down! The place changes personality throughout the day but, however you look at it, this is predominantly a place where locals come to be entertained by story tellers, snake charmers etc. A tip for the photographer......take a telephoto lens and you can get fantastic pics without getting hassled. Of course you have to play the game, if you stand to watch a performance then expect to throw a few dirhams, no different to covent garden, these people are trying to earn a living. Loads of great food at night, hot, fresh, tasty and reasonably priced. Yes they try to encourage you to sit down but no different to many European beach resorts! We had no problems at all, just walk through and soak up the atmosphere.

Fascinating. By day there are snake charmers, monkeys and Henna artists but it is in the evening that this place come alive with the smells of the cooking snails and the sounds of the drums. You must try to see it both in daylight and in the dark.

Don't go into shops!!!. Unless ou're certain you want to buy something. Also make sure you take someone who is good at navigating if you really want to go deeper inside. It can get really confusing, really quickly!

A lot of fun but beware...... Exiting area but a real tourist trap! Where ever you read its recommended for having cheap meals but what a bunch of bullocks. All the foodstalls have hustlers outside with one mission; to get you to sit down and eat. When we ordered our food they brought us way more than we asked for and kept it coming. Sure, we were beginners but in the end we paid more than for a dinner at a topnotch restaurant such as Kosybar or Gossip. The bill was a shock and there was nothing we could do about it.Soo, if you are eating in Djemaa, watch out! When ordering pay attention to exactly every little thing you order and agree about the price before they start to cook. Even if you do that its actually not very cheap nor good. Every part of your meal is from 5-15 Dirham so of you want to be satisfied maybe you'll order 4 skewers, a piece of bread, some salad, couscous and some fried veggies. For this you pay about 70-80 Dihram. You'll get a better meal from one of the many restaurants around the square for less money.
People watching and monkey dodging. Always something going on here. Monkeys Snakes. people selling selling selling. Watch from the roof terrace cafes if this is too mad!

Hustle and Bustle to extreme. but i loved it... I love the noise, smells of this square - so this year i took my two teenagers who also enjoyed the experience. Buy your orange juice from one of the stall holders - tis only 4 dr (30p) - becareful not to take photos of snake charmers, traditional dressed men as they all want money - the shop owners just off the square can be quite pushy - but remember they want you more than you need them and you can always walk away.... At sunset it is worth going to one of the terraces to watch the sun go down and watch the square from up above. Although it seems like bedlam I felt safe (single mum of two)...

Crazy, disturbing yet unique.. This place in the evening is just crazy,, you can find anything in here starting from food, souvenir, the hena woman and story teller. If you like crazy and suoer criwded place you should come but if you are the opposite just AVOID it,, not really worth thr visit. For the first time in my entire life, I hate being White Asian! The people there is super aggressive towards me and my partner,, keep stopping us and try to speak some Asian language that I dont understand. We just come here to see and then eat,, the food from the stall is not really special but is cheap and authentic I can say. Not reccommended for people that cannot control their patient!!!!!

Medieval fun fair. It's amazing! Entertainers, story tellers, dancers, musical players, veiled fortunetellers, boys with monkeys, snake charmers... everything in one place at this big noisy square with a lots of movement. In the morning, noon, evening, and even after midnight, it has its own charm you'd love it!

Well worth seeing. You can't visit Marrakech without ending up in the square at least once. During the day there are countless snake charmers, storytellers, musicians, monkey handlers, dancers and henna artists, not to mention the crazily clad water sellers. Just bear in mind that they are all after your money!At night the square comes to life with the erection of the food stalls - anything from snails to sheep's heads. I'd be inclined to seek recommendations from where you are staying as to which are the best to eat at.We enjoyed nothing better than to sit on one of the cafe terraces and simply watch the free show.
Amazing to see!!. Amazing to see but dont feel intimidated by the constant monsier, monsier - A firm No Thank you will suffice.

First & last visit. I stayed in Marrakech for 5 days in a Riad hidden in amongst the souks. Maybe this was where I went wrong as there was no escape from the madness. Aggressive madness. I really did not enjoy myself.I consider myself well travelled&was prepared for hassling/haggling with shop keepers etc but this was another level! Everyone is out for your money, even the school kids are out to get you. They want money for saying hello. Strolling in the Medina was too much hassle to enjoy. The scenery is stunning&the atmosphere is exciting, but it just could not be enjoyed. You cant stop, take a photo, look around&soak it in without someone approaching you&trying to lead you off to their shop/restaurant. This would be fine if I couldve simply smiled&said no thanks, but this won't do! I got verbally abused constantly.Even when you agree a fee with a taxi drivr before geting into the cab, as soon as they close the door they'll turn around&up the price. The cabbies will ask for 150mad from airport to medina. There is a bus no. 19 for 30 mad which does the same trip. I managed to get a taxi gueliz to medina for 25mad, but theyll try&charge 50mad+. I got a cab from medina back to airport for 60mad, despite it was agreed 50mad, but i just couldnt wait to get back on a plane home so whateves.In tourist attractions-museums, saadian tombs etc i found some tourists who just didnt want to leave as these were the only places they werent hassled. I like to visit places&take them in, enjoy the experience, but I never felt relaxed. I tried friendly banter, simple no thanks la shukaran in arabic&quiet treatment-all met with the same aggressive abuse&begging for money for simply looking at something.Also i paid to visit a berber village in the atlas mountains which turned out to be ladies dressed in lab coats waiting to sit you down&fob off the millions on various argan oil products. A trip to the atlas mountains (which are absolutely stunning) could not be enjoyed as first stop was a 'local'restaurant filled with tourists with the choice of 3 diff things on the menu, each costing 120mad!!then being told we had to pay for a guide to walk to the mountains despite already paying for the tour-so double check whats included when you pay for a tour. Our 220mad payment was only for the driver! It's a shame as Ive always wanted to visit Marakech&some of my friends have been&loved it. Unfortunately I did not feel the same.

Very fascinating place. I believe, there is not a place like it. So fascinating and full of life. The square changes with the day. We ended every day there and couldn't get enough. You can watch the buzz far away from the aggressive sales Marrakechis in nice roof terraces.
Everything You're Told Is True. Awesome, brilliant, entertaining, magical. Contstantly changing and full of life. The very centre of a Marrakech trip.

Amazing atmosphere. We came here quite a few times during our 4 night trip to Marrakech, choose one of many cafes with a rooftop terrace and watch over the square, we went at night too and the atmosphere on and around the square is amazing.

Chaotic but absolutely loved the buzz and locals hustling you for your money.... Absolutely loved every minute of it. UNESCO heritage site, I stayed at a riad literally 7 minutes walk from the square, and absolutely loved the buzzing atmosphere where half the entire Marrakech come at night - stunning view from the rooftop bar...You must try the snails, offals, orange juice, mint or ginger tea, as well as tagines and sheesh kebabs, at food stalls at night. Price wise similar - they will come after you like mad showing menus and keep telling you to look at the food display (not usually good sign but the freshly made food is normally excellent). Everything is inexpensive anyway so I dined most of my week here... My absolute favourite? Sheeps head and brain (power boiled) I think it was either No. 41 or 44 (you will see the head and brain on display) - got a sample of offal meats with spice pastes for seasoning with free bread and mint tea (and free photo taking) - 30 DH.. Seriously acquired taste but if you are used to offals and freshly made food (and non-vegetarian - you can find excellent veg tagine and sheesh in most other stands). Souks surrounds the square - you can never stop haggling with people. Never accept the first price quoted - always start with 40-35-50% of the price quoted and set yourself an absolute max price you are prepared to pay. Otherwise, walk away - and if sellers very pessistent then another good reason to walk away...Snake charmers, monkeys, musicians playing all day, henna tattoos, etc. I don't know how much more space I have got - but as long as you know the basic rules of not accepting the first price, ignoring the locals trying to speak to you (always end up asking for money afterwards even if they ask where are you going etc unless you absolutely need help - ask the older people less likely to rip you off).Cafe Toubkal on one corner of Djemaa El Fna is an excellent cheap restaurant as an alternative to the food stalls...Overall - this is an absolute must even if you are in Marrakech for a short stay...
Markets will never be the same. Of course there are sellers trying to get your business but we haggled and had the fun of believing we did get the best deal

Gotta be seen at night, but intense and money driven. A bit of a let down for us this. On the first walk round a Henna woman come up, we politely said no, but she suddenly had my wifes arm and was "giving" her a present. A shot of henna ink sprayed onto her arm, and instantly starting reacting to her skin! We then not so politely said go away! A revisit at night was really much the same. Felt like a tourist trap, could not walk a few metres without having to say no to someone for something. Just maybe not for us, but I don't see the enjoyment in it. Real shame.

Unexpected madness. Loads of fun. A must see!. The Jamaa el Fna in Marrakesh is THE place to be! It’s a huge central square at the entrance to the Souk i.e. market place. This square comes alive at night. Full of snake charmers, monkey handlers, story tellers, entertainers, local food stalls, locals, tourists alike are all part of the show! This place can be both exhilarating (fresh food made to order, on the spot entertainment and surprises) and a bit exhausting (too much going on at once, monkeys on your back, and relentless Moroccan merchants in their attempt to sell their goods). If you don't want to be a part of the action, you can watch from one of the nearby bars/restaurants. The square has an exotic appeal to it that also feels gimmicky (it's a very popular tourist attraction! It's a totally different scene during the day in that it is a lot less chaotic and somewhat manageable/navigate able. I enjoyed being there at night but only in small doses! It loses its appeal after the first or 2nd night. Nevertheless, it's definitely a MUST see in Maroc.

Probably unavoidable, but meh.. If your idea of a good time is having moneys and snakes thrust upon you, the Jemaa el Fna is for you. Be especially wary of the henna tattoos. The henna comes off an will ruin the bedsheets at your hotel or riad and they will charge you. We didn't try the food stands, but we were told that Stand #31 is the best, and to avoid the others. The place is kind of unavoidable because it's so central, but it was not the high point of our visit to Marrakech.

Too Busy. Jemaa el Fna is a livley place with a buzzing atmosphere. I couldn't go here every night its just not my thing! Be careful if you try to take a picture of the the monkey or snke charmers they demand money off you, we had a funny experience in relation to that. Been to Marrakesh three times was really sad to see the Argana Cafe area which was bombed. The souks are good pick up a bargain or two but theres loads of different ones I actually got lost lol .. Defo worth a visit but too hectic for me :)

Great to book your excursions but rip off for food.. As this is one of the main attractions in Marrakesh you have to go, otherwise there isn't much else to do. The lead up to the main square is the best bit as this is where we found our travel company (one of many) with who we booked our excursion to Orika Valley. It was only 150 dirhams per person(appox £13) which was great. It is a bit worrying when they want to take you to their shop which is hidden away but don't be scared as they all do this and there shops are normal. It is a very bustley area with lots of people trying to stop you for money or trying to buy there things. There are loads of food place here which may be cheaper than the main square. Once you get to the main square it is very noisy from all the music but there are no snake charmers, belly dancing or monkeys. Its just loads and loads of food stalls and horse and carriages that will take you on a 30min tour of the Madina and surrounding area. There are soukes and stalls when you venture deeper in but we weren't there for shopping and couldn't be bothered to barter so avoided them. We sat down to eat at the busiest food stall in the square as we had read on trip advisor before hand that it was the best one. Biggest mistake in the whole trip. They completely rip you off as they know you are tourists. We didnt want to eat much as we had had a big lunch so we ordered lamb kebabs and sole fish and a bit of salad. However, they bring you out something completely different. They bought us out a mixed kebab plate each and they were tiny yet we were charged 170 dirhams which is like £15 and it wasn't even tasty. We were so annoyed and wish we had never eaten there. The square is really smelly too as there are loads of horses but that could have been dismissed had the place been fun. The only good thing about it was Cafe Arabe which is in some quite side street in the Madina which you could only find if you had the address and asked locals for directions. Overall, nothing to do and just don't eat there.

eat cheaply and enjoy the nightlife. We had planned to go to a very expensive ryad for dinner but couldn't find our way in the souk. We came back to the big square El Fna and enjoyed a wonderful selection of offered and freshly cooked foods. We had a lovely meal and watched the first rain fall of the season. The colours, music and families eating, were all part of the show.

Blast all your senses. Noise, colour, smells, it is all here. Fascinating place. The whole of humanity seems to come here, especially after about 4pm when the action really hots up. Watch out for the man with the monkeys and the snake charmers if you don't want an unexpected animal on your shoulders. If you want a bite to eat and have an iron stomach go for it - tripe, snails........ Or just watch the world go by from the safety of the overlooking terrace bars.

Crazy, smelly, noisy and rip-off. - Liked: fresh orange juice and evening food market. Nice sunset scenes. - Disliked: Cannot be relaxed there as there are two much pressure and hassles from the street vendors and beggars. I hate the monkey and snake shows - they were just animal cruelty. Too commercial to enjoy its exoticism.

Obviously. We didn't spend much time here during the day, but wandered through frequently at night (the film festival was on, and the huge screen playing free Bollywood movies was a big draw). Eating well here at night probably requires greater artistry than we possessed, particularly at the beginning of our Moroccan trip. We made the mistake of walking - or attempting to walk - right down the main artery of food stalls, and were bombarded from all sides by touts. It finally reached the point where every employee at every stall was applauding us, and a tourist policeman came to calm them all down. It was funny rather than sinister, especially in retrospect, but we didn't have the leisure to choose where we wanted to eat - we just sat, and were served, and the food was pretty average. The showbusiness of it all is worth watching, though. I suspect the food stalls the Moroccans actually eat at, outside all this hullabaloo, are the ones worth trying, but once you're vaguely within the radius of the touristy stalls, it's hard to extract yourself. And the life of the square itself is fascinating.

What can you say!. This is an amazing experience. All life is here and it takes on a different cloak in the morning, the afternoon and in the evening, and all times are good. We wouldnt have missed this experience!

Chaos!. Wow, it was an intant attack when we set foot in the square. We had monkeys on our shoulders and henna tattoos on our hand. My advice is to say no to everything and keep your hands tucked away until you settle on a price first! They do not want to settle on a price. They say "no problem" then yell at you and follow you trough the market if you don't pay them what they want. We learned out lesson and got the hang of it after, but it was an expensive lesson learned! The food is mediocre and they claim it won't give you diarrhrea. Great selling tactic!

Marrakech Life. This is exactly what I would expect to see, a lively market place full of life that attracts both locals and tourists. Yes,everyone does try to separate you from your dirhams whether its a snake charmer or colourful water seller but any seasoned traveller knows this is part of the visit. Loved it !

Chaos, but fun!!. Be prepared to barter and say "La"..alot!Great atmosphere and great fun. The snake charmers are a bit full on and they will demand money from you. Be firm and give them some but don't go crazy. Enjoy it, it is mental!

One the worlds MUST SEEs. A visit to Marrakech (nay, Morocco) isn't complete without a sundown track thru the Jemaa el Fna. Take in the view of it from a restaurant balcony on its fringes, then JUMP IN! You'll regret NOT eating here. Might seem odd for westerners, but COME ON, you've come this far. Sit down at a booth that seems most appetizing, and dig in. The waiters will bring platter after platter of what SEEMS to be free appetizers, but they aren't free. Even aft you order your main dish, they'll keep bring LITTLE TINY plates of bread, veggies, etc, until YOU tell them to stop. EVERYTHING will be on the bill at the end! Don't worry too much though. If you were unable to say NO, the bill will still be quite cheap!!!Snake charmers, medicine men, dancers. . .its all there, AND MORE. This is no circus. . . It's the real thing people! Don't get to close to the snake charmers if you hate snakes! You'll find someone sneak up on you and put a big one around your neck!! Won't take it off until you pay them!! Pay them, though, and get a picture you'll never forget. This is place to put your squeamishness aside, take of your PETA hat off, and throw away your western tendencies of looking away when your food is "dispatched"! Dive IN! For Gods sake. . . .dive in!!!! I LOVE that this place exists! Took my wife, and daughter here, and we loved every moment. It takes several trips to Morocco (which we have done) to feel safe here. You ARE quite safe, but its so different, that its hard to be totally comfortable the first few times. . . . But trust me, you are quite safe. Morocco and the USA share the oldest treaty on the planet.

unique with a real central place in old Marrakech. Djema el Fna is a unique place with a real central place in old Marrakech. Central because that's what it is, but also because no matter where you go in the city you end up finding yourself, again, in the square. Very alive there are things happening here all the time. You'll never get bored and no matter how many times you go back you still find different things to enjoy and experiment. Do take a rest from the medina (and you will most certainly need it!) frequently, at one of the cafés (all of them with roof top terraces) and enjoy sipping one of their very sweet mint teas.

Touristy and a bit sanitised but still a can't miss.. Came about twenty years ago and now back. Lots of changes and a second visit never produces quite the same culture shock or impact when you return. I clearly remember the poorly tarmacked and rough surface with a vast number of busy mostly food stalls squeezed in all across the square. Lots of bare light bulbs strung out higgledy-piggledy, lots of spicy and meat smoke smells and a lot of food smoke. But when we came back the square had been resurfaced in a genteel way, rather like those prefabricated driveways you see advertised in suburban colour supplements, there are rather fewer stalls and the hustlers seemed to be less of a novelty, more sullen and nasty rather than just irritatingly persistent. On our previous visit there had been a few fantastic and authentic feeling French or Arabian cafes around the square, many on first floors with great views and usually three quarters full of locals. This time they were largely sanitised and europeanised with not just English menus and anglophone staff but often a majority of northern European food options. I was still glad to be back but the intense north African culture seemed to be diluted. Still recommended

too much begging, food of poor quality. square is very attractive at night with all the food stands in action. However do not expect to eat in peace (too many people will stop by your table and beg for money or food) which can be bothersome. Food quality is very poor and overpriced for what it is (rather go in the side streets to have a proper meal).

Be Aware. Unfortunately you are hassled all the time. Be wary of the women who are in the square doing henna tattoos. The women grabbed my hand, would not let go even though I kept saying no and she was very aggressive when demanding money that we refused to pay. Other people we met were robbed, be careful of the mopeds which speed around and it is very upsetting seeing the number of beggars. The best thing to do is go to one of the restaurants in the square that has a balcony where you can sit and watch life going on in the square.

Avoid the souks, enjoy the restaurants.. Rude and ignorant salesmen, they don't believe the Ryanair baggage rules after explaining that even a mint tea bag puts you at risk of a €50 surcharge! But the restaurants at night are great. Good food, BBQd fresh in front of you, and all you could want for €10 for two. Downside, not even a beer on offer.
Hassle!. lovely open area, but if you stop to admire it or take photos you can be sure you will be pounced on by a would-be guide or someone else keen to separate you from your dirhams!

Fantastic atmosphere at Night. When you visit Morocco you have to visit the Jemaa el Fna square in Marrakech! It is wonderful place for submerging yourself into the local atmosphere. We had tea on the above restaurant terrace and dinner in a Moroccan Restaurant with a lively view over the bustle of this magical square. It's an experience of a lifetime! End up here in the evening to wander around and enjoy the atmosphere.

Fun. The square is just fun. During the day you will see the monkeys, snakes and whatever the people think of. Make sure that you are on a roof terrace by 4 in the afternoon and watch the square slowly changing to one big restaurant for snack food. Feel like eating fish, visit number 14, it is the best

Terrible. This is a very terrible place, people force you to put henna. They take your hand and put henna without permission and than they charge you for that! You are forced to pay to take pictures! This was the most terrible experience since i've been here! Never go there anymore

A totally mad must go experience - but beware!!. In Nov trade is down and the hastle level is at times unbearable. I found swearing in German helped get the message across. Most food stalls are tourist traps and are not used by locals. There are many restaurants in the area with much better food - see Trip Advisor lists.However you must experience the atmosphere. My wife and I both had a severe reaction to the levels of pollution - even the locals were complaining.On the positive side we never felt physically threatened even in the most crowded souks.

Eye opening. Great place to visit, we ended up eating here every night at the same place. Just be aware of traders wanting to take your photo with animals etc, they are very persuasive and expensive !!

a circus. its one of the places you dont know if you should love or hate.. its for sure crowded at night and a little bit confusing so you better keep close your friends / group / or family you're traveling with. Be sure people who work there will trick you into paying them for taking pictures, or ladies with henna will try to grab your hand to put some painting there.. just be firm with them. Say loud "LA" which means NO. They think tourists are dumb and their pockets are filled with money. Any tea / coffee place at Jemaa el Fna is good to have the amazing mint tea I would die for! You should also try the quite famous " NOUS-NOUS" coffee. means half-half ( 50/50) its coffee -nescafe with milk and sugar.. in a tiny cup. Perfect for a busy morning to stay awayke. Power of an espresso but delicious! :)

Mayhem, madness - this IS Marrakech!. Jemaa al Fna is the main 'square' at the heart of Marrkech and gateway to the souks. It is a totally bonkers experience. You've got market stalls leading to the souks, snake charmers, men with monkeys on leads, ladies coming at you try to henna anything that isn't covered up and, well, if you need a tooth pulled out - this is the place! Seriously, it is a wonderful experience, but only if you can bear the hassle and crowds. I would suggest you leave your polite self at home for the day and dive in feet first, adopt the Berber haggling style and when you say no - in whatever language you choose - say it and MEAN it. If you can manage this then you can have such fun buying stuff here, sampling things, talking with the locals who generally have a great sense of fun and just be a part of the Marrakech madness for a while. When it gets too much, simply head for one of the cafes (most of which have roof terraces) and get yourself a calming mint tea and watch everyone else going through it below you!

Open air cinema with touches of folklore. I'd heard a lot about the Jemaa el Fna, maybe in December it's not at its most colourful, but some of the ingredients are still there, snake charmers, musicians, fortune tellers, transvestite dancers...The snake charmers will waylay you, drape snakes round your neck and demand insane prices when photos are taken. It's their job, give them what you think it's worth, if you dare.Didn't see any of the traditional storytellers though. Their place seems to have been taken by a vast cinema screen to the S. of the square, where hundreds were watching a Bollywood movie. Pity they can't stay at home and watch it on their IPads.

Disappointing. A bit bland compared to what I had expected. Quiet during the day but comes to life in the evening. The snake charmers did not live up to their reputation - not the colourful tribesmen that one reads of but a rabble of pretty scruffy chancers out to get money off the tourists any way they can. Quite seedy. Other men walk chained monkeys around the square - really quite depressing. Be very careful taking pictures - the locals will try and maintain that you have photographed then (even if you haven't) and demand money off you. It is impossible to cross the square without being constantly hassled for money. It become wearing and tedious - some of the people can become quote aggressive if you don't hand over your cash. If you try and be polite they take this as sign of weakness and persist in chasing you across the square. You need to strike a balance of being civil but assertive.
