Discover Marrackech. This was final part of our excursion, we spent about 45 minutes here, the atmosphere was great, food stalls, dancers, musicians, locals etc, I think you need more time and perhaps this should be a separate excursion on its own.

Chaos at it's best. you must experience the medina. so much going on, you don't know what to look at first. don your haggling skills, and you can get great prices. don't pay more than 75 dirham for scarves, and you can get beautiful leather footstools (just the skin) for 150 dirham max.

Jemaa El Fna. Certainly a different place to visit ! Lots of hustle and bustle. You need to be firm to get the henna tattooist's, guys with monkey's for photo's, snake charmers, and various street artists away from you !Sit on a roof top terrace with a cold drink, and watch it all from up high !

This is where it all happens!. If you want to see where all the people in Marrakech gather, then this is the place. Food stalls, spice stands, fruit stands and all sorts of stands really. The square is full of life all day, every day by the looks of things. There are also plenty of cafes around the square where it would be nice for anyone to go and enjoy the sunset with views over the Koutoubia which are quite impressive.

Worth a visit. If you don't like people this is not the place for you. In the day the square is quite calm with vendors selling fresh orange juice, snake charmers hypnotising their slithery companions and monkeys and their slightly inhumane keepers. If you don't want to be aske for money, keep away from the above as they will expect payment if you show interest (naturally). From the calm day the to bustling night, this large square is transformed into a hub of social activity with story tellers and musicians trying to earn a living. The food is good and cheaper than the majority of restaurants (try Simo's stall, the staff are amazing and applaud when a new customer sits down). Surprising the square is very clean, a little dusty but there is no trash to be seen anywhere. We were hassled (being 2 blonde white girls we didn't exactly blend in) but most comments were said in jest and the worst thing I was called was "Bella from Twilight". Overall everyone is really friendly, take it with a pinch of salt and enjoy the atmosphere.
overwhelming.... Loved the smells and the sounds, not so keen on the monkeys and the snakes... Beware of people trying to charge you for something you didn't have !

a slice of all life. This place is amazing during the daytime with all the stalls selling oranges and dates but in the evening it comes alive with all manner of street artists and food stalls, all vying for your business. You have to eat here once but that is probably enough. Everything is freshly cooked but if you aren't careful you could end up spending more than you wanted to.

The center of activities. During daytime many artists or would-be artists are showing you their skills. Djembe , snake charmers , monkey's for pictures, they are all there. You have to pay for a picture. At night the place is transformed within an hour or so into a hughe open air restaurant.

Fantastic. every visitor to Marrakech has to visit the Jemaa el Fna! It is wonderful for submerging yourself into the local atmosphere. We did eat here one night, right in the middle at one of the food stalls. It's an experience and we survived with no bad after effects! End up here in the evening to wander around and enjoy the atmosphere.

Crazy and Busy. We were staying in a Riad minutes from the square.Look out for veiled women with a syringe of henna (always near the monkeys & orange juice stalls) ready to pounce on you,but just be firm and say no. The mopeds are every where and how no one gets hit is beyond me but it truly something to be seen! In the evening we tried a couple of the food stalls 114 was excellent food and service but 117 did not take us to heaven as promised and in fact the service and the food was terrible. My advice would be to give them a miss as there are plenty of other stalls that will give you a much better dining experience.

Crazy and amazing place!. Image a place with snake charmers, acrobats, dozen of street musicians, thousand of people, donkeys, horse charriots, women making henna tattoos, restaurant stands, dancing men dressed as women, pickpockets, undercover police, old story tellers, magicians, .... crazy indeed. a live time experience specially on Friday night.

Better in the dark!. Was staying in a Riad minutes from the square, our first day and encounters with some of locals made me want to get back to the airport and fly home again! It got better after day 1!!!! So my main advice would be to persevere and be prepared to be firm and say 'NO' or 'Non Merci' alot!!! Found the square during the day to be full of people trying in so many ways to take money from you, numerous attempts from a veiled women with a syringe of henna (always near the monkeys & orange juice stalls) ready to pounce on you, with words of how my eyes are good eyes whilst grabbing my hand and trying to draw on me before demanding 200dirham, despite me politely pulling my hand away and telling her no. To guys wanting to show you to various souks, sights, shops all also demanding 'gifts' (dirham) to the restaurant touts, guys with monkeys who look as though they'd be much happier free to the guys selling juice. It's a total culture shock, the smells from the drains, donkeys and mopeds is truly something to be seen! In the evening we took to one of the terraced restaurants, taking to one of the upper floors with mint tea to watch the night unfold and found the relative safety from above to be worthwhile and well worth the small amount of dirham it cost. Unusually we felt safer in the evening than the day and before leaving felt less uncomfortable with saying no, not making eye contact and just ignoring the pestering. We also saw a few women begging with small children, a few elderly people too and only once had children ask us for money.
Incredible experience. I have never seen such a crazy place like this in my life...it is incredible how this square fills up with people during friday and saturday night.

The original 24 hour lifestyle !. The " big square " as it is known locally is alive, a constantly changing sea of people and activity, and it has different moods that change during the day.In the heat of the day it is full of traders, entertainers, fresh orange juice sellers etc. Then as dusk falls the mood changes, day traders go home and make way for the "pop-up" food stations which are wheeled in and quickly set out their tables and begin cooking. By the time it is dark the square is filled with a hundred different smells from fish and chips to boiled snails, coucous to shish kebabs, seafood to vegetable stews and tagines. Fire eaters, story tellers and acrobats view for your attention and the cries of the street sellers fill your ears. Amazing !!

Marrekech main square. It was a slight let down as i expected more to be happening! The best time to go is in the evening when there are musicians and many more people, during the day there are the obligatory snake charmers etc

Good kind of Crazy!. This square is quite open during the day - and in the late afternoon it begins to fill up with food carts. Everything from simple couscous to smoked goats head is on the menu! Snake Charmers and musical groups.... Busy place!

Crazy but so wonderful!!!. People seem to have a black & white way of seeing Jemaa el Fna. They either love it or hate it. No in between. Well, this woman LOVED it. Yes, it's crowded & noisy & people are always calling out to you to buy this or that BUT it's so interesting. I never tired of walking through the square. Steer clear of the men with monkeys or else they will try to put one on your shoulder. But as long as you don't get too close, they don't bother you. To me the monkeys did not seem happy, so i couldn't bring myself to contribute to this industry. You will also see snake charmers & woman with henna. I never had anyone get pushy with me. I did get a henna tattoo & asked beforehand if she had brown henna. Only let them use brown, it's more natural & less likely to have filler chemicals. They are many cafes & terraces lining the square. I recomment going onto one of the terraces & taking your Jemaa el Fna pics & video from there. If you do so from within the depths if the square itself someone may want you to pay them if they think they are in your picture. I loved it here, found it fascinating & completely embraced it. You simply cannot go to Marrakech & not go here. And at night too!!! Incredible at night!!!!!! Go go go!!! :)

Lively and Delicious. This place is buzzing! The food stalls set up about 5pm and that's when it starts going. The food on the stalls are delicious. We particularly recommend stall #1. Good prices as well! 25MAD (£2) for a tagine! The moroccan cakes are also yummy, very nutty. There are acrobats, snake charmers and men with monkeys on leads. I peraonally don't agree with the monkeys being treated the way they are but is interesting to see.Lots of women offering henna. They can be quite aggressive and will grab your hand and hold the henna syringe close to you. Again, be firm and dont get a 'free flower' done! The souks surround this place so you can also shop around! Have a coffee on a panoramic terrace, the views are amazing! Enjoy the sights. Again, keep your wits about you as there are pickpockets!

Crazy!. Amazing place... all your senses are awake in this crazy place. It always smells of something, you always see movements and colors, you always hear noises and music... Jemaa el Fna never sleeps...

Underwhelmed and Over-Hassled. Of all the sights we took in in Marrakech and Morocco, I was a bit disappointed by this one. In the daytime there are fruit stalls, monkey handlers, snake charmers, and the odd dancer. At night more locals gather for stories, music, and performers. But the experience of it was overshadowed by the fact that if we showed even the slightest interest in something (and of course we did-- that was the point of our visit!), we'd immediately be approached and asked for money, or have handlers force their monkeys on us. It was unpleasant.On the other hand, I highly recommend situating yourself at a rooftop terrace cafe on the square and watching from afar (with a zoom lens camera!). We had a lovely afternoon people watching over mint tea.

Vile square. This square is filled with unpleasant people who want your money and don't care what you want. After wandering through it twice - trying to find where the much-promised 'magic' is - we gave us and started to give it a wide berth.

A Square For Rubes and Marks. The Square in Marrakech has a huge rep, particularly if you grew up listening to the Stones or Jimi Hendrix or if you think dreads are still acceptable current fashion. Jemaa El Fna is more truthfully a market square, where everything is marked up even higher than the 25% sellers price their wares at in tourist Morocco. There is usually music, or at least some tam-tam, but it isn't very good, to be honest, and the square is dominated by guys abusing monkeys and snake-charmers. It's incredibly noisy, memorably filthy, and every five steps you will be harassed by a vendor or near-flattened by the motorcycles, scooters, taxis and trucks--yes, trucks--which run through the square making up routes as they go. I love Morocco, but the Square, which everyone has to visit once, is a first-timers experience. So if you go, hold on tight to your pocketbook and look for the restos off the square, where the value increases and the health hazards decrease in equal proportion.

Never ever will i go there again!!! . Even though we had read every single review about the place, it was worse than what we had ever imagined. Within 30 seconds of stepping into the square, my boyfriend was pulled by the sleeve by some man with a monkey. The monkey climbed on top of my boyfriend's shoulders and the man was demanding that i take a picture of them. We didn't want no photos whatsoever and in trying to get the man to take the monkey away, the monkey scratched my boyfriend's neck and made it bleed in a few places. My boyfriend got absolutely furious and started raising his voice and i threatened the man that i will call the police. He finally took the monkey away and then asked for some money. Needless to say, we didn't give him anything. We walked away and 30 seconds later we were asked by someone if we needed a guide. We walked passed him just saying 'no', so he started insulting us and swearing at us. He called us quite a few nasty words, including racists, which we found absolutely unbelievable. By that time we both were so angry that we just went back out of that place. The next day a nice local man told us to not go there at all because if's full of crazy people and that if for whatever reason we go there, we shouldn't let anyone touch us. Sadly it was too late for this good piece of advise. We will definitely not be going back there ever again if we ever come back to Marrakech.

Crazy Marrakech!. During the day the square has snake charmers, beggars, dancers, musicians.By night it it transformed into a huge bustling crazy street food market. I have visited Jemma on numerous occasions and every time it is very very busy.You do get approached by all and sundry but usually a firm but polite No will persuade them to leave you alone. In my opinion the square is safe for tourists and never have I feel threatened in any way.If you dare take a walk down the centre of the food stalls. You will hear every cliche in the world.Locals would say that they wouldn't eat on the square. I have eaten here on a few occasions and am writing this review! Say no more!

Avoid!. Just touristy and a pure rip off - once this must have been quit a magical place but meanwhile has lost its charm completely... Take a carriage from here that's more fun, but do not pay the 150 they will ask for, don't settle for more than 70...

Sit back and drink in the ambiance. A must do trip whilst in Marrakech is to Jemmaa el-Fna which is the main square leading to the souks. The sights and sounds are best enjoyed from one of the panoramic cafe terraces where you can sit and enjoy the coming together of the wonderous sights, sounds and exotic smells whilst enjoying a refreshing drink. Through the day there are several stalls and various street entertainers to watch, but as the lights go down the square also becomes a mass of open air eateries all vying for your business.

exciting-take small coins-sometimes best from above. Keep your eyes open here. there is lots to see but dont look too long or you might have to pay for it. theres snake charmers and singers and preachers and snails and really good orange juice. The best thing we did here was go to one of the many roof top restaurants and cafes over looking the square. you can see and hear the excitement up there and its a bit more relaxing. Make sure you take some small coins with you in case you want to watch the entertainers or get some fresh orange juice.

Saddest square in my 55 country, 400 + visit. Too many people with no order or rules in the street/square. It's means people, car, bike are everywhere and come from every directions. You never can truly enjoy twatch someting there. You have to worry about your safty first and to avoid sales. I also saw young boy was kicking the poppy beside his father and the sales saying nothing but watch. I had to say "stop" to abuse the animal. There is no wonder the suare was for open excision ground. I know people had to live day to day, but it was really sad to place to be. It's better to watch it from the top of cafe or restaurant and it's not wotrth walk there.
Great place for fun. We had lot fun and we try a sheep’s head showing the eyes. It wash it down with Khendenjal, a spicy nut-based aphrodisiac.

My first impression of Marrakech was Jemaa el Fna. It was a Thursday night well after dark when we entered the square and we had to walk about 20 mins through the souks and alleys to our Riad. I firstly was very glad I wasn't a lone female and secondly we had arranged for someone to pull our luggage in a cart. The square and alleys are a fascinating and chaotic maze of noise, bright lights then darkness and people. However the electric atmosphere in Jemaa el Fna especially at night time, is not for the faint hearted.Mopeds and bikes come at you from every angle as do the beggars and pick pocketers. The hustlers rudely demand what you want to buy. Jewelery, leather or carpets? The stall owners relentlessly jostle you into buying goods you don't want or need. I thought it was amusing they have cultural signs posted about how rude it is for tourists to take photographs of them without their permission. Fair enough I felt until we came across many young lads who were a big problem to us. With each visit to the square we politely refused their guidance back to the riad and for our politeness we got spat at, sworn at, had footballs kicked at us and lastly fire crackers thrown at us. I think I would settle that a distant photograph being taken was far less rude. The food stalls were amazing and to watch people enjoying the cuisine was great but knowing how much they charge and how they rinse the cutlery was enough to not use them more than once.One day and night would have been long enough as it is a must for the sheer experience. Definitely take your camera, bottled water and a good humour but importantly keep your wits about you!!!

Magical at night, overwhelming. Don't go to the Djemaa el Fna as a girl by yourself! Luckily I went with my strong boyfriend, because otherwise I would have felt unsafe. It can be a rough place. I saw men fighting, the locals are pushy when trying to attract your attention. A woman who made Henna tattoos forced me into having a Henna tattoo by simply putting the Henna on my hand, even though I had said I didn't want a Henna tattoo. The dancing snakes, the little monkeys who ''perform'', the smells of the eating stands at night. It's something so different from everything we have in Europe that it's a once in a lifetime experience! Be aware that at the food stands they charge you more than you expect! They give you larger portions than you ordered, so you'll have to pay more!

Watch out for the hawkers. An incredible array of marketeers,fruit stalls and sadly street performers sometimes with chained monkeys and the like. Be careful if you try and take a photo as they may intimidate you into coughing up some money for the privilege. We tried the some of the food.Was actually cooked well and was tasty. No upset tummy the next day!

Atmospheric & Exciting. We loved sitting in a cafe on a higher level and watching the sun go down at the same time the mobile restaurants/cafes being set up. The fresh orange was welcome. An exciting atmosphere, my partner loved the brain/tongue cooked in front of you, I loved the tagines. We did not like being hassled for money if we took a photo - not of people, but of the whole scene ....
A bit disappointing. I thought that this would be my favourite place in Marrakech but I was disappointed. Maybe it was because it was November but there wasn't that much in the way of entertainment.

great food. This square is rather dull during the day, but in the evenings there are great food. I would recommend people walking around the square first and looking where local people eat before deciding to chose a dinner location.

Hive of activity. Best orange juice in the country and no risk of a rip off - lots of sellers - all at 4 Dnr. Hotel cost was 40!Get to a restaurant terrace for lunch and at about 5 o'clock to watch what is going on in the square.Eat dinner in the square at the pop up restuarants - good fun and good food for less than 200 Dnr for two people!

hectic and interesting. but bear in mind that if you just stop for a secoond to take pictures, someone is asking you money for picturing their "business", snakes or whatever. Have 10 dirhams coin with you (they ask for 100, but ignore that)

Seen to be believed. This place is like nothing else. From the snake charmers and monkey owners during the day to the fantastic food on offer at night, this place is a MUST SEE. Be aware of pickpockets, henna ladies and overly assertive animal owners who want money for taking photos on your own camera. The souks are also amazing as long as you can cope with being constantly harrassed by market traders trying to sell you stuff you neither want or need.

Life unfolds here. It is an unbelievably lively place. The Jemaa el Fna is a town square that hosts everything that catches your fancy. There are pedlars, jugglers, salesmen, food stalls, shops and what have you! It was crowded with people and yet it was not intimidating. Well, the food stall owners are persistent, but what the hell. You could spend hours exploring this place and still won't be satisfied. Simply lively!
This is the place. We went during the daytime. It gets pretty busy and exciting at night, I am told. The tourists are all here, and it is the entrance to the souks.
Crazy Good. It's a must, I read lots of reviews all very mixed. If you go with an open mind and make sure you keep your wits about you, you will have a great time
Buzzing. An amazing space - not really a square - which comes alive as the sunsets. Lots of places to eat and a great place to people watch.

So-so Square. The guide books rave about this big square, but we found it rather schlocky. For some reason it just seemed like a half-hearted tourist trap. We much preferred the smaller square in Meknès, which had attractions almost exclusively geared to a Moroccan audience. They were often incomprehensible but seemed far more authentic. (A young man in Meknès accosted us to ask what was the capital of Rwanda; which we knew! One would be pardoned for suspecting the opening wedge of some sort of scam, but in fact he was just doing an Arabic crossword puzzle. He thanked us and went back to work.)

Don't miss it. Jemaa el fna is the most amazing, fascinating and overwhelming place I have ever visited. Whether by day or night, there is so much to see and experience and the guide books cannot do it justice. This is a place you need to experience to understand it. The memories of Jemmaa el fna will stay with me for ever.
Great!. This is Marrakech! Start your visit around sunset, when food stalls come to live! Have a drink on one of the rooftop terraces. Best spot to make some nice pictures

A Must!. Presumably if you are going to Marrakesh you intend to go here, if not you are missing out on one of Morocco's treasures. Don't miss out on a glass of freshly pressed orange juice at about 30 pence. If you take photos of snake charmers they will probably want paying so beware, Go to see it at night too, have a coffee on one of the rooftop cafes, you have a wonderful view day or night.

Ideal for people watching!. For people watching it was a great place; watching the sun go down and all the stools coming alive with cooking and the smells were incredible! Just need to be careful with your purse, but overall was great!

must see. very touristy, like the whole old town, but a must see and you find very good food on the place.the people selling their food are a bit nervtaking, just try to ignore them and find a stand with some locals in it. Dont eat the all marrocan tasting menus they try to sell. Have a look at the food and chose for yourself. And be nice and PERSISTENT, like always in morocco.

Like Taking LSD. This place is like a living carnival, especially at night. It is perfectly safe, however, make sure you read up on the various scams meant to party unwitting tourists with their money.

Ultimate people watching. Busy, vibrant, diverse, lots of street sellers and food stalls. Everything you would want a main square to be and more. Take some time to find a good spot from one of the restaurants/cafes around the outside and sit and sip green tea while watching the madness. Great place.

OMG!!!!!. An experience not to be missed. But don't be shy. If you don't want a monkey on your shoulder or a henna tattoo on your hand (as you are walking away) be firm but polite and say no! Amazing and intriguing is the only way to describe it. Felt totally safe and enthralled by the noises, sights, smells and sounds. Not to be missed!

Seeing is believing. Prepare to leave sanity at your hotel or riad door. The square changes life between the day and night. A daytime visit (before immersing in the souks) is a cacophony of tooting mopeds, squealing musical pipes from snake charmers, constant drumming, klaxoning taxis eager for a passenger (to where?), clapping acrobats and the mesmerising calls to prayer. The nuts/dates stalls are worth a visit although you'll find cheaper in the souks. Careful at the orange stalls as we had heard they top up with dodgy water so make sure you see his preparation. The henna tattoo women should be avoided as we observed several people being accosted by arm. The monkeys - some in nappies - looked sad. Prepare to pay to photograph anything. For a bird's eye view go to any of surrounding cafes overlooking the square and away from the hassle. Night-time is a different story altogether. The celebrations start at nightfall with countless food stalls to accompany the daytime orange/fruit/nut stalls. Plumes of smoke rise from various storytelling ensembles but thankfully the snakes do disappear. If you want to get a close-up of the tribal story-tellers or musicians then be prepared for a crowd to stop and stare at you and ask for money - so make sure you're always on the move! My wife and I will try a food stall once we have plucked up courage. Make sure you saunter through the stalls though if you're looking to select your fate. Stall number 82 (Simo) seemed a comical bunch able to recite soap opera phrases in side-splitting accents. We've been told to take our own cutlery and eat off paper plates - avoid the goat's / sheep's head.

Best food I had in Marrakech. We ate in stall number 31, definetely the tastiest meal I had in Morocco and one of the cheapest too. Do not use their cutlery or glasses (use your bread) cause they just rinse it in a bucket.

The number one attraction of Marrakesh. You need to visit the grand square after 5 when the whole area is transformed into market and food stalls.The food stalls are most enticing although having got food poisoning from eating in a highly recommended restaurant i declined to take the risk.instead visit the top floor in one of the restaurants come coffee shops, drink mint tea and take superb photos of the activities below.

Be bold - try the food stalls. Most Riads will advise visitors not to eat at the local food stalls due to the risk of getting ill. However, I've found that local food stalls are often the best value food in town - this is true in Place where you can tuck into a tasty mixed grill for only 7 euros and enjoy the banter with the young men running the stalls.

Best in The World. I would say that the Jemaa is one of the top 10 things that everyone should see in the world. It is a truly amazing experience that has to be soaked in over time. Plan to spend several hours of at least two nights here to really appreciate everything the square has to offer. Be prepared for the touts and the food sellers who will constantly harass you. The best way to handle them is to talk to them and be nice. Please avoid the tourist food stalls that all look the same and have agressive guys pushing menus in your face. Eat at the stalls the Moroccans are eating at. Yeah, the food is different but it is all safe and all delicious. Don't miss out on a truly genuine experience because you're afraid of getting sick.
animated!. amazing atmosphere and very animated. Bring your camera to take pictures of snakes, Monkeys and spice market

Is this it ??. We visited the Jem el fnaa on several occasions at different times and found it to be a waste of time . I cannot believe all the reviews here , and after reading them again I fail to see what people are marvelling at . There are lots of people yes , mopeds etc , but where is the entertainment ?. We expected acrobats , dancers etc , but there was nothing like this . It was just a place for locals to try and scam tourists , and beware of pick pockets and molesters which we did see with our own eyes . We tried the food on a stall that people had recommended here and it was awful , I dont know what some people must be used to , but this over priced offering is not even adequate .
Crazy. Mad by day and even madder by night! You MUST eat in the stalls, the food is wonderful, the smell, the sounds!

soak up the atmosphere. Great place to get a feel of what it's all about.it is the place where everybody ends up. you get sellers on the side of the road from the morning, and then as the day progresses they start appearing in the middle of the square. orange juice, dates and various other nuts. then the small sellers arrive and you can get raffia bags, various incences and have your hands decorated with henna. by the evening the centre of the square has restaurants set up and you can sample all sort of food - if you dare! :-)
SNAKES AND MARKET. In the daytime climb up to the top , terrace panoramique ,of the Cafe de France and have a coffee.Go by day and then again after dark.

Madness.....!!!. where to start?? it is the most amazing place to just be and watch everyone going about their business, women to henna tattoo your hands ..snakes, cobras and rattlesnakes!! monkeys, and an amazing array of colours everything and anything to buy and when night falls...the smell of street food and belly dancers, the most exotic place...the only drawback is the insistance of some of the sellers that wont accept a polite "no thankyou"

Has to be seen to be believed. People, motor-cycles, bicycles, mules and carts, caleches and cars share this irregular open space in a sort of organised chaos. They weave round the many stalls, and various acts with snakes and monkeys and so on in a never ending cacophony of sounds. Many of the daytime stalls are replaced by nightime food and entertainment delights.Really impossible to describe - just has to be experienced.
See it to believe it. Go at dusk and stay for hours. It will blow your mind. Music, comedy, snakes, monkeys, food, henna. But most of all, the energy.
An exciting hive of activity. Something to see everywhere you look. It's great to watch the sun setting over the town from the roof of Cafe to France.

Bit of everything. During day lots of tourists,horse drawn carriages and a few jugglers, artists and snake charmers. In the evening lots of food stalls, lots of smells, loads of people,tourists and locals noise level increased and belly dancers,more snake charmers, musicians, magicians and card readings. Watch your bags and pockets!
Never boring!!!. I like this vibral in life Place, especially at night. I tasted here many delicious Moroccan dishes. I don't like swindlers to hunt on tourists.

Like the wild west!. This is a scary place to visit. Without a guide or reasonable sized group we were mobbed by conmen and salesmen. People were trying to guide us into small alley ways and sales men were excessively pushy. The Souks are atmospheric and have some amazing stuff on offer. Frankly if the salesmen just sat back and were pleasant we would have bought loads. In reality they ruin it and we were intimidated away from most stalls. The cafes over looking the Jemaa El Fna were great places to people watch and see people being harassed with monkeys and snakes (yes it happens A LOT!). After gaining as little confidence we walked around some more but when enquiring about horse and carriage ride the drivers (probably 30 of them) mobbed us shouting prices then broke into a fist fight amongst themselves. Some great people and sights but spoilt by conmen and pushy sales people. Yes I want the genuine experience but this is not a genuine reflection of Morocco it is a tourist trap.

Where Marrakech comes alive.... ... again and again.As a moth to a flame each and every tourist will be attracted to visit 'La Place'. Offering an insight in the old and traditional Morrocan culture, this place is really an amazing experience.The changing lights and the colours are overwelming: photographers will be in heaven.Locals are always trying to seduce you to buy , eat, get on a picture, have a tattoo, but: as friendly they are, the more agressive they sometimes get. Nothing's for free.Maybe you get scared at first, but once you get used to local habits, you 'll discover a whole new world.Tip? Enjoy the panoramic view Café de France is offering, while having a fresh mint tea!
Like nothing you have seen..... Story tellers, teeth men, snake charmers, food stalls, musicians and all manner of other sights to keep your head spinning.....
Food Booth #12. We were told by 2 guides that #12 was the place to eat. Good, cheap and not scary. The real deal. Just get what everyone else is eating. Easy

Experience of a lifetime. Hustle, bustle and noise. Not for the faint hearted. Beware of the men offering photos of snakes and monkeys as they will with hold your camera in exchange for an exorbitant fee and it also encourages animals in captivity. As long as you can handle the bartering systems in the souks (always aim for half what they initially ask for and dont be afraid to walk away as they will give in if you do.

Absolutely amazing but be aware of your surroundings!. Absolutely amazing - great food and drinks from the market stalls.We heard some stories of snake charmers demanding £30 for photos taken so be careful and agree a price before hand. Also with ladies giving henna tattoos as "a present" and then demanding money. Just keep your wits about you and you will be fine.There are a few pick pockets around however we didn't have any problem with this at all. We ate at stall 100 and it was absolutely amazing. It cost £10 for bread, olives, maroccan salad, beef tagine, chicken and saffron scewers, two soft drinks a bottle of water and mint tea!

Changeing all the time. Jemaa el Fna is a wounderful and an terrible place, and it is changine all the time depending on when you are there. You can see snakes, apes and musicians. But you will also be "attaced" by different people wanting to help you and earn some Dirh. But this is life, real life in Marocco

must visit place. You can not visit marrakch without visiting jamaa el fna....traditional shops, restaurant with good moroccan food by night, animation all around the place with musicians, story tellers, snake chrmers.....dancers and many more surprises

Wauw Amazing !!!. The Square is real amazing place to go, nice music, full of magic and you will step into a dream whitout an ending...If you go in the Souks near the big square, you can visit a music shop called "Bob Magic Music" with traditional musicians who like to gif you a demonstrotion or free workshop, a nice cup of mint thee and a lot of fun. For a lesser price as all other face music shops...
All life is here!. From the storytellers to the musicians to the fruit sellers, you could never tire of just people watching.

The Square. Tour guide introduced us to the Souks, hundreds of narrow cobble-stoned passages, easy to get lost in! Some small, some large stalls lining every alley, selling everything imagineable, the bartering is a must and is expected, we bought some good bargains. Definitely reccommended, stall holders a little pushy at times.

Loved it.. Complex and fascinating. Tried it on our own. Go away from central square and find streets without motorbikes. Wonder around peacefully for hours. Some very upscale shops that cater to interior designers and some typical every day shops with the basic scarves, shoes andleather goods.  There seems to be a scam to get you to tanneries. Avoid it if young men who claim to be on break from high school offer to show you the way. If you have not seen the tanneriers or want leather goods it might be worth going along with them. If leather items have bad smell it won't go away after you purchase it. Buyer beware.We were not overly hassled. No more than expected and certainly less than Egypt.Laugh and move on.Tried to by a Moroccan lantern and could have had one at very reasonable price but ran out of time to get to train station for trip to Casablanca. When I got home checked internet prices and same lantern I could have gotten for $75 is about $375 here. I have lots of regrets regarding what I didn't buy!Unlike Fes this medina has good map and is very manageable without guide if you have some navigation skill.The is action and activity everywhere and every sense is assaulted.think I will think of this place again and again with fond memories.

Like watching a film. We spent quite a few lunchtimes and dinners overlooking the square either in a cafe or restaurant. Some people find the square intimidating but, having travelled with a man, we didn't get any hassle. It is very underlit in places but doesn't feel threatening despite this. A great place to watch the world go by.

Amazing experience. Scary. The square is an amazing place to visit, full of unusual sights, smells and sounds. I can honestly say I was a bit freaked out upon arrival at Marrakech as our riad was close by, so the jemaa el Fna was the stumbled upon fairly early into our stay. It is hard to stop and look at performers, as people will constantly hassle tourists, looking for money. My boyfriend had a monkey and a snake thrown upon him on separate occasions, however we didn't take photos and made it clear we didn't want any. If you visit, just don't take any photos. A firm "no" should keep hassle at bay. It is so much fun to wander around the square, even the hassle was amusing at times. I wouldn't go here alone though!

Absolute madness, where every sense is assaulted and you are constantly hassled and blagged to depart with your money.... But wouldn't have missed it for the world!! I had read quite a few reviews on here and seen it on TV many times, but none of that still prepared me for what it is 'actually' like. As me and my partner first walked into the square the first thing that hit us was the noise (which was almost very quickly followed by 1 of the many scooters whizzing by). There was all sorts going on as we wandered through towards the various food stalls that were just setting up for the night. We went there each late afternoon/early evening of our 4 nights, and found there was still plenty to see and do each time. Although I must admit I did start to get a bit fed up of constant hassle to buy things from the vendors at the souk in the left hand corner by the mosque, especially when then kept grabbing my arm. We much prefered the Berber souk which we accessed from just behind the opposite end of the food stalls, as it was much more relaxed and more of what I expected a souk to look and feel like. There is a few restaurants/cafes over that side and it was nice to take a break in 1 of these with a drink on the balcony and watch the ensuing melee down below, before going back for some more.Beware of the women doing the Henna tattoo's. My partner had 1 and was assured it was a brown 1 which is supposed to last a few weeks, but costs more than the orange 1's that only last a few days. Guess which 1 she ended up with....The snake charmers (as will most people will to be fair) will try and blag you silly money to have a few pics taken with the snakes, asking us for 300 dihram, but don't be scared to give them what you think its worth - they won't set the snakes on you if you don't pay up!

Busy. this was exactly what we had anticipated!! snake charmers and all!! - we did not expect the rain???? but hey-ho not the Square's fault! Charmed more by the locals in the coffee shop, than by any business in the square. The Marrakech people are very tolerant.

Chaotic, somewhat frightening but the experience of a lifetime. Things to note when visiting the Jemaa el Fna:1. Do not miss the orange stalls. They are amusing as they vie for your attention. It's cheap, try a few stalls!2. Everything has a price. in other restaurants things that were complementary (bread, etc) was extra here. They will put things in front of you that you didn't order. DO NOT assume it's free. You will be expected to pay for it. If you didn't order it immediately tell them so they can take it away. Check your bill. Twice.3. Avoid wearing anything flashy. I couldn't figure out why people only approached me from my group to sell me things. A friend who lives in Rabat told me it was my ring. I wear a fake diamond ring when I travel and in the dark area they think it's real. You will be hasselled less if you look like you have no money.4. They will try to sell you the best even if you want the worst. One guy told my aunt "You want camel for price of donkey." To which she tried to explain "NO, I want a donkey for price of donkey."5. Deeper in the souk you will find better prices (and more options). Don't think this is the only place to shop.6. It is really easy to get lost and separated even though it's physically a very small area. Have a rendezvous point in case you get separated.Overall, just enjoy the experience. It's like being in the middle of a movie set. People bustling and shouting. The smoke fills the air with smells of delcious foods and the lights twinkle everywhere. Definitely not something to miss!!

The beating heart of Africa. An experience like no other, by day you can hear the sound of the snake charmers miles away & by night it transforms into the biggest open air BBQ on earth. A lot of my fellow reviewers mention the constant hassling, I must have been lucky as I walked through the square at day several times & never encountered any issues with the henna ladies, snake charmers or monkey people. My biggest issue was continually being offered hash! By night the square comes alive and it is experience like no other. The music, colour & smells have to be seen & smelt to be believed. My advice to anyone is leave your western sensibility at home & embrace it. Eat in the square the food is wonderful & very reasonably priced & the hawkers are hilarious. 'Hey MR you need to eat you are too skinny' 'Come & eat in my stall, Jamie Oliver eats here'. If it all gets too much I found a smile and a no thank you or non merci worked wonders....

snake charmers or monkeys?. an afternoon sitting in a cafe watching the happenings in the square is very entertaining. from snake charmers to monkey stunts. acrobats to henna tattoos. it all happens here and of course in the evening even more goes on. definately worth a visit.

Beautiful but beware. A lovely area for strolling around or visiting cafes or restaurants, something for everyone. A very busy square so be careful of the traffic, cars, horses, bikes, motorbikes etc., A lovely array of food, visuals and aromas. However, be on your guard, if you take a photo of for example the man with the tooth stall, he will want your money, the 'ninja' henna ladies will grab you and say "its a present, its a present", dont be fooled. I was approached by one of them and she put a large blob of henna on my hand, which had to be cleaned, then she continued to put a pattern on my hand, which I did keep saying i didnt want. When she had finished she asked for the money, which I refused much to her dislike so I popped a few coins into her hand and she was annoyed, so i took the coins back and started to walk off. She followed me saying "give me give me" so i gave her the coins back and she retreated obviously awaiting her next victim. They keep their faces covered obviously so you cant recognise them if things get out of control.. Take a stance and stay away from them. This place is to enjoy and enjoy it you can, just be careful and dont be fooled.

Be prepared to be hassled.. Has to be seen - it's so different from anything I've ever seen before. Having dinner there in the evening when all the stalls pop up was brilliant. However, it's absolutely heaving so have your wits about you. Be prepared to be hassled by anyone and everyone - taxi drivers, snake charmers, men in traditional costume, beggars, women wanting to do henna, men with monkeys etc etc. The list goes on. It was good to see it all but they all wanted extortionate amounts of money for anything from just looking to taking a photo. We had to be very firm but they can get quite forceful so just be cautious. Also I was quite upset by the men with monkeys - they were treated horribly. They had chains round their necks and were dragged about, so don't encourage them by posing with them and paying them. Having said all that, a trip to Marrakesh wouldn't be complete without wandering around the Jemaa el Fna, there are some brilliant things to be seen, but just be careful!
Fun!. Lively and fun, must eat at a stall, no1 was great. Orange juice stalls cheap and refreshing, must go to a rooftop cafe at night to look down at the chaos of the square.

Be prepared. At sunset it's like a medieval encampment with the crowds, stalls and smoke rising.Rather than say no to everything it's easier if you have a little supply of 5dh and10dh coins (70p and £1.40) and then you can actually linger and watch what's going on. We avoided the food and drink stalls (not that you have to) and instead ate at Chez Chegrouni looking over the square. Simple brilliant food, cleanly and efficiently presented, and lovely place. Recommend the chicken skewers with rice, chips and salad.
very noisy. very noisy, scooters everywhere, traders very rude and pushy, monkey handlers, snake charmers all after a quick buck.

Wow!!. It's well worth a visit....if only to say you have experienced it. The sights, sounds and smells are second to none and can at times be overwhelming. Night time is when the square really comes alive with the food stalls and tea bars. The food is tasty and cheap, just don't expect UK hygiene levels!! The snails.......hhmmmm an acquired taste but seem popular enough. One major drawback is the people who have monkeys on chains. I really don't know what was worse though, them or the tourists who stood and allowed the monkeys to be put onto them while a photograph was taken in exchange for a few dirhams!! These monkeys were chained, hauled about and kept in boxes, a horrible sight and a huge negative. Please don't encourage this by funding these people!! Be warned if you take a photo of the 'streets performers' too, they will want paid for the privilege. The souks are plentiful and have a stock line that Delboy and Rodney would be proud of!! If you can overlook the monkey folk, snake charmers and the fact you will be approached by EVERY shopkeeper it really is a super experience and a place I will never forget. Don't miss it if your in Marrakech.

Unique, and quite fun at night.. Loads has been written about this so will keep it short. Stay clear of snake charmers. Best way to view s spend 4dh on an orange juice, grab a plastic chair and just watch.Most of the food stalls are pretty good too. 114 and 31 were the best we tried.

Really exciting. What Marrakesh is all about. Enjoyed walking around with all the different sights and sounds. Need to be resolute and keep saying "non merci" or "la shukrahan" as you do get bugged quite a lot. But get used to it after a while and it is very good natured.

No longer the value it used to be. Eating in the Jemaa el Fna in the evening used to be a place where Moroccan and western tourists enjoyed a good value meal together. Sadly, on my last visit, the locals were noticeable by their absence - for good reason: the food on offer was now tourist prices. Worth doing once for the atmosphere, but no longer such good value

Sensory Overload. The first thing I want to say is that if you're visiting here, please do not pay the guys with the monkeys. It's condoning animal cruelty. We witnessed the monkeys physically being dragged on chains tied round their necks. They're also continually pulling at the chains trying to free themselves. Passing by them hearing them squealing from the tiny boxes they are locked in is heart breaking. The people who pay money to pose for photos with them should be disgusted at themselves.  Another negative point is that I'm fairly well travelled, especially to Muslim countries. I'm used to all the people trying their best to get you to come into their stalls etc and practically following you down the road to do so. However, Marrakech is the first place I've ever been where I've been physically grabbed and pulled towards a stall. I was absolutely furious and made it known I was! Apart from these negatives, the rest of the experience is fairly incredible. You get a sore head from your eyes constantly being drawn from one thing to another. It's fairly busy during the day but at night it comes alive. The food stalls are dirt cheap and the food is incredible - if you can get over western food hygiene standards!! The tagine is the best I've ever tried! There is a cafe on the edge of the square with a roof terrace that overlooks the square. Fantastic photo opportunity and amazing to just sit and watch all the comings and goings. You can't come to Marrakech and not visit this place, but just be alert and ready for the constant stream of sellers trying to sell you everything and anything.
mad mad mad!!!. you have to go there to experience it for yourself!!it is a combination of every smell /sound/sight that Marrakesh has to offer-including the odd tooth puller

Not as amazing as expected. Atmospheric and worth experiencing, but generally felt the snake charmers were miserable gits, the guys with monkeys too pushy, the acrobats nothing special and was warned not to touch the freshly squeezed orange juice unless we fancied dicky stomachs.

Chaotic and amazing!. The heart of Marrakech's Medina, Jemaa el Fna is not to be missed. Go during the day for the snake charmers, and again in the evening for the food stalls (it's tough to avoid the guys trying to get you to come to their booth - best thing is to say you've just eaten and keep looking - we found a quiet stall with 2 old men cooking and a couple locals eating - AMAZING french fries and not half bad fried calamari!).Fresh orange juice and a variety of nuts/dried fruits can be had any time of day (and are all delicious, if you can get over Western standards of hygiene...!)
transformation in an hour. from the orange juice sellers to a buzzing vibrant array of restaurants which were built before your very eyes, amazing

Crazy square - must go to eat. By day it is touristy and crazy. By night it a smoke filled eating delight. We ate at Stall # 1 - the most highly rated stall here on TA and by our Riad. It was fantastic. I had the lamb couscous and it was delicious.
Nice place. nice place..be ready to bargain if u wanna buy things from there.best time is to visit by 5 pm..its so colorful

Interesting and Exotic.... I'm not sure that you can make a trip to Morocco and not experience this place but if I decided to go back to Morocco, there are a host of other places I would visit again, and this probably wouldn't be among them. Our tour guide described the vendors as "sticky" and they are. They don't readily accept the words "la shukran", "la" or even "la la" and by the time one has left you be another one has found you. Admittedly, they are very good at remembering people, so if you pass them again, you won't get another round. But admittedly, once you've made one round, there isn't much more to see. The square is also filled with western tourists that don't quite get the idea of appropriate dress and my preference is to just stay away from them. The souks are like many around Morocco, though we are reliably told that the products aren't hand crafted as in many other areas.I think this is a place worth seeing, but not for more than a day and a night.

An incredible place !. Great place to go have a drink at sunset and see how the crowds of people change form day shoppers to arrival of evening where food stands are put up for dinner. A great mix of sounds (music, people talking, singing, motorcycles, laughing etc...) have a drink at one of the bars around he square and watch this from up high. Also drink the fresh and cheap orange juice if you go here earlier during the day. Take a big empty water bottle and fill it up to take back to hotel (if you don't dirk it on the way...)
2600 shops!. As long as you can refuse the persistant merchants, but be warned once you show an interest they won't leave you alone!

Amazing.....!!. I ended up visiting the square at least once a day on my 6 day trip...! It is a magical place.... With great food stalls (very cheap!).... Henna artists are always calling you over for a tattoo, they will start at a ridiculous price like, 300dirhams, stick to your guns and tell them you will only pay, 30-50 dirhams, n then walk away, they will end up agreeing!It's the same principal with the people at souks in the square, always be prepared to barter and haggle with them.... The people are very friendly though and haggling is always a good laugh..! Don't be out off by those people who tell you on here that you get dragged into shops and are forced to buy... I didn't experience this and didn't see anyone else go through this either.On a final note, as I've mentioned earlier, it is jus magical, a place I feel the people from the RSPCA would enjoy as well, with monkeys on chains being dragged around and snakes looking like they're drugged up...not to forget the horses that are carting people around from dusk until.....dusk!!! No rest for the wicked :)

great food, but watch the henna-witches!. the food stalls, juice bars, mint wagons make the square smell and taste like heaven's kitchen, and all looks clean & sanitary (I don't know anyone who got sick eating in the square). Check out the snake charmers, story tellers, but look out for the henna witches. They offer you a 'free gift' of some henna, usually on harnds and arms, then the boss appears and forces you to pay for it. It's a recognised trick by the police, but it continues to happen. My girlfriend had her arm literally twisted into getting a henna, which we then had to pay for when 4 women surrounded us shouting and stamping. Be warned!
Madness. The Jemaa el Fna is unique, snake charmers, musicians, dancers, street vendors selling food, fruit and lots of other things. Noisy, hectic, but different and unique and great fun.

Monkey thieves !. It is a sea of people and This place can be costly! Be very careful around the snake charmers and the monkey men.. They tell you " pictures by donation" and then want all your money after you take the pictures with your own camera!
Lively!!. A sensory overload with so much going on day and night, lots of interesting local traditional entertainment.

A charming hussle and bussle. The monkeys and snakes are not treated well - hopefully these animals will not continue to be an attraction. The place is VERY lively and a very fun place to experience - the locals will do their utmost to get your attention to their attraction for a few dirhams - if you wish to be let alone you have to pretend that you do not see nor hear them.

Breath Taking. Loved the atmosphere, the souks and all of the interesting characters. Go and watch the sunset from Cafe Glacier and listen to the sound of drumming, the snake charmers playing their pipes and the call to prayer sounding out across the square. Disliked some of the pushy characters, especially the Henna ladies who aren't afraid to grab you to try to entice you in.

A Truly Amazing Place!. If you visit Marrakech, you must spend time in this place - preferably in the evening! It feels like the centre of the universe and just teems with life and amazing sights, sounds, and smells!One of the best ways to enjoy it is to have a meal in the square - either at one of the places set up in the square (we favoured No.114), or even better in one of the establishements that have roof terraces overlooking the square.The only downside that I would like to comment on is the use of 'wildlife' (monkeys and cobras) as tourist attractions - I like monkeys and snakes but I refuse to support them being used in this way.

Legendary. One of the relatively few places I have been to in the world which was as magical and mysterious in real life as it looks in travel guides and films.Arriving at dusk with music from the four corners of the earth ringing out across the square ; berber tribesmen mingling with conjurors , snake charmers and snake oil salesman is a truly exotic experience enhanced by the smells of charcoal grills cooking heaven knows what. Secure your seat at one of the many restaurants looking over the square and you will have entertainment and wonder for the rest of the night.
nice if you like to be bothered 24/7. I realized that this place is only famous for tourists to be talked badly to or asked for money. not my favorite place in Morocco!

Chaos. This traditional marketplace was nothing that I've seen before. It was utter chaos with traffic still running over the place which is packed with foodstalls, marketstands and streetartists. It's a wonderfull experience and having dinner at a foodstall at the market is highly recommended.

what a buzz. this area of the medina is so amazing with its food stalls and souks and street entertainersjust strolling around is funthe food stall choices are extensive and the food is deliciousthe only dislike is the constant hasle from the shop keepers, but i would not say its too much to handle

Amazing to see but can be threatening. Jemaa El Fna was an amazing sight to behold but unfortunately you couldn't hang around much to take in the sights without being forced to part with money. I recommend buying g a drink from one of the surrounding cafes with a roof terrace and take in the sights and smells from there. As two male travellers we were constantly harassed and even threatened when we refused to part with our money. We were also followed by shady looking characters when we refused to buy drugs and had to take refuge near the police station to escape.

Like something out of a film.. As we sat having a drink in one of the cafes above the square and the sun was setting I truly felt I was on a film set. I kept waiting for Michael Palin and his crew to turn up!At times intimidating but always exicting this is a little patch of another world. Defintely worth going to at night where the carnival atmosphere takes over and you find yourself sharing dinner with complete strangers!The food was okay but the experience was first class!

Gateway to the souks. Crazy place, full of story tellers, henna tattoo women, chained chimps, snake charmers, drinks bottle catchers (like hook a duck at the fairground but on a huge scale) and beggars and pedlars everywhere. Glad we went but don't hang around and look interested for long or you will have a Barbary ape on your neck or a snake in your arms before you can say Salam and your pockets will be lighter for it. We didn't see the square fully at night but the change involves lots of cooking and food stalls. A diverse city, busy and hectic, you cannot come to Marrakech and not experience this!

Travel back in time. Jemaa el-Fna square at dusk is one of those thing you cant describe. Snake charmers, fortune tellers, acrobats all mixed up with smokey bbq stands and lots of people.The only bad thing is the constant hassle and begging for money. Put on a big smile and you'll be fine :)

A wonderful sensory experience. The square hits you in so many ways. You must do this on your time in this city or you have wasted all your money. We went with our 4 year old daughter and she loved and so did we. Start with a mint tea at one of the restaurants around the square,get your bearings , build up your courage and then go for it! Monkeys, snakes, mad men and henna ladies, it is everything you have heard and more...You must embrace and enjoy and once you are done get the horse and carriage home you will not be disappointed.

a big open circus. Marrakech is busy, crowded and full of tourists and no other place in Marrakech can sum up the city than this square, if is full of orange juice stalls, food stalls and filled with acrobats, snake charmers and other entertainers day and night, you have to visit day time and evening/night time to experience this square as it is different at these times. We really enjoyed every minute we spent here, the only thing is the salesmen who are standing outside the food stalls are very pushy and won't let you view the menu/tiems on display in peace, if you are there just wondering and don't want to eat then saying something like "I have already eaten" works well. If you are with young children then wachout for small boys and girls who may hand over any toy or biscuit to children and then ask for a euor or something for it, most of the time the shopkeepers/food stall owner will shout them away. I used to drink orange juice always at the same stall and used to waive at him all the time, it is best to waive and the touch your hand to your heart (which says you are greeting him from your heart) which is appreciated by the locals. we also met a shopkeeper who would not sell us a peice of cake for the children as it was not fresh, next day when we came again he was happy to sell as he had fresh stock. we enjoyed our stay in Marrakesh and would revisit again.

Crazy. During the day, fairly quiet in terms of stallholders. Snake charmers and monkey handlers will try to pull you in for photos. "Gratuit" (free) is anything but so be very firm with your "no" if you don't want to part with your money. At night it's an altogether different proposition, teeming with activity and all the mobile restaurants hassling and hustling for customers. We had a great meal at No 25, less than 400 euros for 4 people and we ate loads. Watch out for your handbags and pockets, keep bags firmly zipped up and close to your side.

Unhygienic. People would be openly urinating in the middle of the square it was swamped with beggars and chained chips. I'm glad I've been but it was a disappointment as its just a huge dumping ground with some poor animals stuck in the middle of it,

Now this is a marketplace!. So many people doing so many things. Very entertaining. And especially, a wonderful place to have dinner at night: tongue of sheep, merguez, pastries... Excellent. But go where the locals go.

A real culture shock - and a bit scary with kids. We'd visited here several years ago as a couple and this was the first trip with our young daughter. We did spend a lot of time feeling terrified that we'd lose her and also getting increasingly annoyed by the "in your face" attitude of the people, although they're only trying to make a living. Very annoying the way you can't even take a photo of anything without someone trying to make you pay for the privilege. Myself & my daughter got a henna tattoo from a group of young women who said "pay what you like" but then got really argumentative when we did pay what we though was reasonable (and twice the amount we later paid for the same thing at our hotel!).My advice is take a big deep breath before venturing in!

Must see in Marrakesh. Jemaa el-Fnaa will assault your senses -- with the noise, the smells, the crowds. You could easily spend a couple of hours exploring it and sampling the food.I would highly recommend eating at one of the food stalls in the square itself; it beats eating at one of the restaurants surrounding the square.Beware of the snake charmers! They have a habit of putting a snake around your neck and only taking it off once you've paid a handsome fee.
jemaa el fna the square. best thing about the marrakech . Lively with lots of atmoshere.Disliked agressive hawkers and beggars

Annoying and expensive . This place is annoying. We went there twice and both times got away as quickly as possible. You cannot watch anything more than 10 seconds before someone wants a lot of money. We were overseing some kind of music show but they hadn't started playing before the begger came over so we went. The first time we were there, snake tamer repeatedly tried forcing me into holding a cobra. This place is not vibrant, it's a very expensive snake pit with a bunch of orange juice. Go there if you have too much cash and just loves being bothered.

Don't go during the daytime. I went with a group to the square - during the day, it's totally dead - save a few people walking apes and some snake charmers. The animal cruelty is frankly unacceptable. If you care for animals, do not go and support this barbaric behaviour
Well worth a visit. Despite the rain - well worth a visit. Take small change and barter with the taxis for the journey home.

Must do. Every one should visit this famous square, Jemaa el-Fna. All of life can be found here and many hours can be spent sipping tea and eating Morracan cakes while watching people of all nationalities passing by. I think all children should visit - it is an education!
Exotic!. Night time is the time to visit this wonderful Square, when it is full of food stalls, story tellers, musicians, snake charmers...We loved it & found it very exotic!

Attack on your senses!. Wow!! What to say and where to start on what is the main square, Jemaa el Fna. At first, this open space appears to be nothing particularly special in comparison to other city squares around the world, a bit dirty and busy, and nothing too enthralling. However, taking up a pew at one of the many bars/restaurants that have rooftop terraces, you soon realise how much there is to take in and how the square evolves over the course of day and suddenly springs to life at dusk.The snake-charmers are the worse offenders when it comes to attracting the tourists and they charge you if you want to take a photograph. They will often approach you, even when you ask them not to, and try to tempt you to towards their stand. Quite frightening if you do not like snakes and intimidating as they work in gangs to lure you in. All the while, very entertaining to watch from afar.The night market is perhaps the most entertaining time of day when the street food stalls are in full swing and their waiters attempt to entice you to dine at their stalls. Smoke fills the air and you are overwhelmed by choice of food and banter from locals. A good tip is to take antibacterial handcream and only eat the very hot (and thus well-cooked food) street food. Germs are rife and we both experienced food poisoning after a visit. Definitely worth going back time and time again.

Evening atmosphere. The best time to visit this lively square is at night time, when this whole area is alive with locals and tourists; there are outside cafes, musicians and speakers - very Marrakech.
Fresh Orange Juice. Best viewed from one of the many roof top cafes. Look out for snake charmers. Try a fresh orange juice from one of the many orange juice sellers.

Totally crazy. This is the place to eat in the evening in Marrakech. There isn't much going on in the day, but from about 5pm it comes alive. We ate at the stalls in the middle - the food has lots that is familiar, and lots that isn't, and you see plenty of locals as well as tourists. Steer clear of salads and soups, stick with the hot and freshly made and you'll be fine. If you can get to one of the terraces at the top of the restaurants around the edge (the ice cream cafe is good value for money - view wise) it's worth being able to see down over the square to get an idea of the size and the bustle. There are taxis from here, and carriage rides. It's also on the edge of the souk and there are lots of vendors of all sorts of things

People-watching heaven!. Find yourself a seat in one of the many cafes surrounding the square. Treat yourself to a coffee (~£1.50) and an ice cream and just watch the world go by at 100 miles an hour. We had a very cheap lunch from one vendor (small bbq'd sausages in a flatbread) for around 70p. So much happening here you have to see it to believe it.

It's all there. Jemaa el fna at night fills your senses. It's everything you might imagine morocco to be..snake charmers ( don't over pay for a picture), food stalls, amazing colors and smells. Enjoy!
Don't miss the herb tea stands. It's a very nice way of digesting a good meal in the square. We met dozens of locals and travellers too.

Centre of Marrakech life. Recommended by all tourist guides, particularly watching from a roof top cafe as the sun goes down. Perhaps a bit overrated as clearly a tourist trap. But on the other hand the performers are merely carrying on tradition in 21st century style. And sunset over the Atlas Mountains is stunning.

must both night and day. Wander around in the daytime surrounded by sights, smells and sounds of the sellers and entertainers and clip clop of the fleets of horse carriages and carts and avoid being knocked down by all manner of criss crossing vehicles, animals and people.Return after dark to a unrecognisable dimly lit buzz of street entertainers surrounded by crowds of happy locals enjoying and joining in their entics and music and a hundred plus street food stalls creating a smog of steam and smoke and producing the most aromatic and delicious food imaginable.
you cannot miss it at nightfall. You cannot miss it at nightfall. I liked it all. It IS a place to visit. The square itself, is worth the visit to Marrakech.

Unique experience. The first time I arrived to Jemaa el Fna I felt I was in a totally different place from anywhere I've been before, it's exotic, full of live, and I felt as if I was in a Indiana Jones movie. During the day the orange juices are refreshing and just great at a good price, at night you can have grilled food of all sorts, usually good, again at affordable prices. Highly recommended experience.

Daily circus. This is the gathering place for all the people in Marrakech. During the day there are lots of individual sellers of general tourist rubbish, snake charmers and orange juice vendors but by the time the sun starts going down the food stands appear along with musicians and story tellers. This is the place to be for locals as well but you really run the gauntlet to get from one side to the other. Beware of donkeys, horses, mopeds and taxis.... You will get shouted at, beeped at and need a few more pairs of eyes but find a bar with a panoramic terrace to sit at and spend a while watching the world pass by...

Ate dinner here 3 times. This is a great spot for a quick dinner. We liked everything we tried. The crowds can be frustrating. We didn't see it much during the day, except when it was getting towards dusk. We did get really tired of the motorcycles whizzing by us. You have to be very careful walking around here!

charming night bazza. during the day, the snake handler may hassle you with tiny snakes around your neck, what amazing was the music they use for the snake all over the square. best time to visit is the evening, when food halls opened up, try where the local sits (travellers tend to choose where others sit), but just have to ask the price first, or you will be charged more. yummy grills and lambs.

Sights and smells.... Sights and smells galore. A tourist trap if ever there was one... but also, very authentic and historically important. Shakespeare's, "All the world's a stage, And all the men and women merely players..." runs very true for the Jemaa el Fna

Psyche yourself up the take the plunge.. It took me about 2 days to orientate myself to the sensory overload that was Marrakech. It's hard not to be hypnotized, enchanted or maybe a little unnerved by the hub of the market. At first I watched it from a distance on the terraces of a couple of cafes that sit on the perimeter of the the square - this in itself may be all you need if the pace is too much for you. However, eating in the heart of the square in the evening is a definite highlight. Get to see what the locals experience - orange juice stalls, tajines, snails and seafood will get your mouth watering. Be wary of the monkey dressers, henna women and snake charmers that sit on the perimeter. However, once your in the heart of the night stalls you don't have to worry as much!

A most for first timers. It is the focal point of the city and a must if you have not been there. After dark the area comes to life but the cafes and eateries are packed and more expensive than other areas.

CRAZY. We visited the square both in the daytime where there are still the fruit stalls, the snake charmers, the monkey men and the henna stands, and at night where the activity level multiplies a hundred-fold at the very least. At night the place just seems so crazy, the noise level is high and the air is filled with smoke from the cooking food. I don't mind the sounds and smells and smoke, what I did not like are the aggressive attitude of the hawkers. It felt like every 3 steps you take somebody accosts you offering you dinner, or a henna tattoo or souvenirs or whatever it is they are selling. I could understand the competition for a sale but it could get VERY overwhelming and intimidating. I probably would not want to come back here at night unless I am with someone who is obviously local as it seems that the obvious visitors are hassled the most.

Wow..... definitely visit here as night falls - it's noisy, busy, bright, vibrant - full of colour, sound, life and the smell of food (mostly grilled meats, so not great for vegetarians). It could be overwhelming, but my best advice is to just soak it all in. Can't be in Marrakech and not get to this square during your visit - even if only for half an hour

Entertaining and definitely the place to eat. The bustle of the Square in the daytime is multiplied tenfold in the evening. Smoke rising from the BBQs and twinkly lights everywhere. A typical, busy, Arabic square, it's hectic and hassle and great fun! Our highlight was eating at stand 22 - we ate here twice. Getting to the place you want to eat is not for the faint-hearted as the stalls' staff compete for your custom. Keep your sense of humour and keep walking and you'll be fine!The sweet sellers are charming and the treats delicious - a whole box for around £2, such a bargain!

Crazy place. You have to see it once in your lifetime. All of the sights that you have read about are true, if a little commercial. Eating there? not sure, but the choice is huge. When you have had enough, grab a glass of wine on the square, and view this spectacle from the terrace.
Crazy place but great fun. A million people in space for 100,000!! Scooters, bikes and people vying for tiny spaces - bonkers but great!

A place to avoid. The "square of death" once used to judge and execute the non-believers of a strict religion ruled by the human. It is the heart of medina, emiting a blood of fear, death as its name signifies, noise and stress. The red city of evil, with its heart full of stalls and markets, pushy merchants and lucrative thieves looking for their next victims. With music emiting suppression, sadness or anger, peace is absolutely absent from this spot of earth. If vortex had an opposite, this would be the medina pumped by its strong heart, Jemaa el Fna. Absorb the orange juice in any of its stalls, this will give you the energy needed to stay in this place of unrest. Avoid any kind of people, especially taxi drivers, merchants, snake owners, tatoo women, shoe polishers, generally anybody else than tourists. Eat at night in one of its stalls, each one has different cuisine, some are touristic but many are not, food is Mediterranean and tasty.

So much energy!!. Very much energy in one place. There is so much players, restaurants, mens how will make orange juice from fresh oranges for you, jugglers, but be careful everybody want "baksis". I recommend to visit this square after sunset.

Sensory Overload - takes getting used to. The first time we visited the square, I was very intimidated, mainly because I had read so many negative reviews. In a way, I was glad that I was prepared, but so happy I didn't let them put me off.The square is unlike anything I've ever experienced before. Through the day, it's filled with henna artists, snake charmers, monkeys, men in traditional berber dress, orange juice stands and plenty of horse and carriages. By night, it transforms to an outdoor market and is filled with hundreds of food stalls, making you spoiled for choice about where to eat! Locals and tourists alike all come out to take in the atmosphere...but it takes some getting used to. The sounds, the smells, the sights, everything in excess!My advice, never let your guard down. If you buy something (like orange juice in our case), always check your change. While we tipped often and well, we preferred it to be our choice. While walking through the square, beware that cars and motorbikes/mopeds will come from nowhere! They will go around you, but it's still a little disconcerting! Also, be prepared to have to pay for any pictures you may take..snake charmers don't do it for the art, they do it for the money and if someone puts a monkey on your shoulder, they'll expect you to pay for the pleasure, whether you asked for it or not!But, with all this said, it was an amazing experience, something I've never had the pleasure of seeing before and would definitely recommend to anyone.
TheFamous Square!. Again - we last visited 6 years ago - we thought that this time there weren't so many visitors or stalls etc, but maybe it was because it was later in the year.

Love the hustle and bustle but idiotic vendors. There is a lot of hustle and bustle, it's busy and noisy too. Come here at night, it's fab!! Come here for shopping not for look around because they will haress you no matter what even if you politely say no several times, they get aggressive and hurl abuse at you - these minority mindless idiotic vendors RUIN the decent and average Moroccan citizen.Having said that, there are some chirpy and fun vendors too who you can have fun with and do a bit a bargaining too.Go there if you are ready to bargain with the vendors and if you have a price in mind that you are prepared to haggle for - that's exactly what I did

A Once in a Lifetime Experience!. like nothing you've ever seen before. The square is a throwback in time, monkeys jump on our shoulder, men charming pythons. not for those who dont like crowds. I imagine the square has not changed much in hundreds of years
walk through to the souks. Square was squalid, and we did not like being hassled to have photo taken with snakes and monkeys.the indoor market at the back is good to see and buy items.,

Mindblowing variety of culinary delights!. Do not miss this in marrakech, every stall is just as good. From snails, orange juices, tajines, fish/calamari and chips, lamb heads, patisseries...you just name it....Tried almost everything and yet it costs less than 200 dirham for 2 persons!

Crazy Place. At nigh,just enjoy the theatre.Dress down,dont be reeled in to eat if you dont want to.Dont go if Morocco is playing a football match anywhere in the world!During the day, not much happens, unless you enjoy watching snakes being charmed.
Fantastic square. never a dull moment. Just go there and see what is happening! You can eat at the small stalls. People might be pushing, but if you react friendly they also will be friendly to you!
