Shiny object syndrome!. I loved this place - it was chaos, in a good way! Just relax and have fun with the experience. The vast majority of the people are so friendly and fun to talk to. It is a shoppers paradise and bartering was a lot of fun. The culture is very different from my own, but I ended up just falling in love with the people and their warm hospitality and vibrant way of life. It's not for the faint of heart, but just remember, it's high competition to outsell the vendor next door, so just have fun with the experience and relax. They are very skilled at getting your attention, but a simple "la shukran" (no thank you) will let them know you are not interested. I absolutely fell in love with Morocco during my stay - they are absolutely delightful people and I loved it there!
Arab night feeling. Definitely go there at night and go up to the roof top terrace across the square. You have a beautiful view and you can take lots of pictures.

unmisseable. Everyone comes here anyway so a review is a bit pointless, but by day or by night this is a lively fascinating place, from the snake charmers, to the man who makes false teeth at a little table in the middle of the square (no, really), to the stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice, and of course the evening barbecue stalls. Try the little stalls selling ginger cake and ginger tea from huge urns. Marvellous. The cacophony of drums and pipes adds to the atmosphere.

fascinating scene. We liked the bustle and sheer bedlam of this square, with its street entertainers including drummers, snake charmers, hawkers and all manner of characters. Plenty of eating places in the evening but watch the hygiene.
Something of nothing.. A disappointing tourist trap with little character, though we did visit during the day. Restaurant unappealing.

noiseey. Noisey, bustling and wonderful in the evening. Friendly staff trying to get you to eat at their stall, Jamie Oliver this Rick Stein that etc etc. Ate here once for the experience. You have to visit this place at least once when in Marrakech then tick it off your to do list

Wow. What a place, packed every day and a real taste of tradition.
Saturday night was busier than other nights, show men, snake charmers, be careful of the groups standing watching the muscians, give or throw your coins to the actors as guys come round asking for money for the muscians but keepit for themselves. Hold tight to your bags.

Wow!. This central square has to be seen to be believed! Full of noise and excitement by day with stalls, water sellers, snake charmers and monkey owners. At night turns into one large eating place with amazing smells and sights.
The Amazing Square. This was definately the place to be, great to sit and watch the goings on during the day and the transformation at night!

best by night. active by day with snake charmers and stalls, but best by night when the cooking stalls are active and the drummers begin. enjoy being in the square, but also think about eating or drinking on one of the terraced restaurants and watching the action. snail selling stalls are cheap and delicious, some of the food stalls are poor quality and quite expensive. check the quality of the produce that they are going to cook before being dragged into a stall!

Take care!. Unmissable, of course, but be on your guard. If you linger you pay, especially the snake charmers. They will have a snake around your neck quick as a flash and then charge you up to 100 Dirhams to take it off again. Short of walking off with their snake - which would take some nerve! - they've got you. Also, the snakes mouths are stiched up and they starve to death, so please, please avoid them. I'm no bunny hugger, but..... Boiled goats head? You got it, with fries if you want them probably, from the food stalls in the middle. The cafe's around the square are a mixed bag, but if you want a loo you'll need to at least have a coffee or mint tea at one as the public toilet defies belief. Lads on bikes hissing at you just means 'look out' not what it does in the west, and you WILL be offered hashish, repeatedly, under the pretext that they are handing out hammam flyers. Rent boys tend to hang around near Club Med entrance (just follow the smell of horses), straight hookers further down the same road. Careful with photos, don't if there is a woman in a burkha in shot. A day visit and a night visit recommended as it is totally different at night, and quite spooky in a nice way, and when the drumming starts it hits you that you really are in Africa. My nephew say's it's even better if you are stoned!

Smelly. Apart from the cafes and restaurants scattered around the square, this site did not appeal to me. It was smelly due to the number of horses being paraded for customers, and I did not like the treatment of the monkeys and snakes used for attractions.

A must see.. Its the tourist center so you won't be able to avoid it. The night market is brilliant. You must have food there at least one time. Its a great experience.Do not take any photos of anybody unless you are willing to pay for it as that's their livelihood and it will be relatively expensive. They do know what they are doing!

Exotic!. Somewhat mystical and exotic at the same time. The food is great- don't forget to try the Moroccan whiskey. Just enjoy the bustling activities around you and be amazed -you won't see anything like that anywhere else.

Crazy Day and Night. All sorts going on during the day - snake charmers, market sellers, orange juice stalls. At night it turns into a busy outdoor dining place, and is full of musicians and storytellers. For the best views, go to the Grand Cafe's terrace. Beware of pickpockets. If you're hassled, just say no and walk on.

Great place but it's at night when it comes alive.. This place is buzzing at any time, but for me after dark is when this place comes alive. Go in the day, have an orange juice, get a photo with a Cobra or Monkey or just people watch from one of the many cafes or get lost in the souks.By night tho its totally different with story tellers, music etc it's just a totally different vibe. Eat on the stalls, it's crazy manic so just walk round and pick one, they are all virtually the same but its a great experience, take time to have banter with the guys running them, They are a lot of fun.Last word it my seem intimidating but look past that and enjoy the sights, sounds send smells. If you don't want anything don't have it.

What a lovely place. Fascinating atmosphere. Imagine many people with things to do. Doing businesses of their lifes, enjoying time of stay in Marrakech, people being hungry and thirsty, talking with pleasure. Enter the world of smells and senses. That's square!True difference starts at evening. At this time food businesses offers their culinary treasures.Square is safe and perfect for category: must see!

Visit 10 times , every time it is new. The center of the city, if you want to see marocco. You have to vistit this square. In the evening you van eat cheap and good on ghis square. And all day drink a fresh made orange juice. Watch out for the misician , begglars, dreesed up berbers and snake

Overwhelming. Once you find a way to cope with hustlers, you can just wander around and take in the extraordinary sights and smells. Fridays are a little quieter. Evenings are amazing!Women should beware of henna tatooists that just grab your hand and start doodling! Keep hands in pockets or covered.

Disappointed. I had read so much, heard so much, anticipated so much about this "magical" place. I dragged my poor mother to the famous square to be delighted, stimulated, and have a memorable experience. No acrobats, no snake charmers, no trained monkeys. OK, not that those would've necessarily left an impression alone but they would certainly added a little to the obnoxiously aggressive "restaurant" guys grabbing my arm, waving menus right in front of my face, yelling "Japan!" purely out of ignorance, or the pitiful older men swinging their pom poms around on their heads clanging finger symbols together hoping for a dirham, the endless wreckless motorcycles adding to the chaos, groups of "musicians" all playing seemingly similar music.....there was no magic. Maybe we were there on an off night. We did try 3 stalls for food: soup, tag ones, and orange juice. Juice won, soup second. It was stimulating, I'll give it that, but for all the wrong reasons. I'll stick to Fez or Merzouga. Thanks.

C'est la folie. here, either you go with it or don't bother going there... the sound of this ginormous square is out of this world... I never felt anything like it since or before... a must visit... the food... the snake charmers... no words to describe it ... you have to be there!!

Once is enough. From what I’d read about the square I was a little disappointed. Don’t get me wrong it’s a totally crazy place but the number on animals being exploited (monkeys/snakes/birds etc) and the amount of begging that’s going on really put a downer on it for me. Worth a visit, but once is enough. Also the restaurants around the square are over rated and over priced.

LOVE !. Gosh this place brings alive all your senses, sight, smell, touch and sound ! everything is going on at once. As with the other reviews on here be prepared to pay if you take a photo of the snake charmers and water men who by the way are not the kindest of people, I was videoing... they got into shot then demanded money, they cornered me and were shouting and touching me.. was a little scary.. i deleted the video and told them where to go....The orange juice, I was looking forward to tasting this famous orange juice, what a let down, it is diluted with water and i can most definatly get better tasting orange juice out of a carton or better still frehsly squeeze it myself.... We could of sat all day watching the life on the square unfold, so much to see, it truly is an amazing place to behold, had for a restaurant for lunch called CHEZ CHEGROUNI, this place is situated at the narrow end of the square, the meat (lamb) tagine was the best lamb i had in Marrakech at only £5.00... and i sampled some "fine dining" in marrakech !

Exciting, vibrant & authentic....BUT. Avoid the snake men at all costs! Do not even attempt to take a photograph, I was chased and grabbed at for not paying them..I explained I was photographing some kittens nearby. My husband had to tell them to leave me alone. The snakes are not cute, and as observed by another reviewer, they are restrained. The monkeys on leads didn't look happy either. Other than that, this is great place to saunter, everyone apart from the snake men are friendly and welcoming.

Busy!. By day a vast concrete platform for scam artists with monkeys, snakes or henna; by night it transforms into a busy, bright, noisy place with a charming Moroccan beauty (as well as the scam artists!). Certainly an experience not to be missed, the food is beautifully cooked and the atmosphere is fantastic. Walking around the stall staff will pick up on your nationality instantly, offering hilarious phrases (normally from tv 10-15 years ago) spoken in your local dialect. We chose the most convincing "only fools and horses" impression and ate there. The prices are very reasonable and worth a try.During the day especially, please do be aware that while the majority of people are harmless and friendly, tourists can be targeted (it can get crowded) so keep a hand in your wallet's pocket if standing in crowds and don't accept "gifts" - on our first day my girlfriend ended up with a very expensive henna tattoo - so don't let people hold your hand, place a snake round your neck or pose with a monkey before arranging a price, and don't afraid to walk away if you feel your polite "non merci" is not being heard.

OMG. If you only go to one place in Marrakech, go here. It is a vision of everything from jugglers to acrobats to snake charmers, medicinal herb sellers, women who paint beautiful henna designs on hands and feet, food exotica, and so much more. It is a feast for the eyes and heart. Enjoy!
Hectic, dirty and full of animal cruelty. The cobras have their hoods stiched back to keep them erect and the monkeys on leads just look frightened and miserable. I couldn't get past that.

Great place to people watch.....above in a cafe. Watch out for snake charmers, who will try to get you to wear one of their snakes and let you take pics until it's time to pay...per pic!! Just say NO!

nice animated place. this square is noisy and full of animation and movements, yet people/sellers are relatively calm and they don't harass you all the time. That makes a nice walk in a pleasant atmosphere, good for souking, and a perfect scenery for photo shooting.

You like it or You hate it. I've been this type of night bazaar/market many many times. So, no surprise to me and I would rather stay in Riad during the noon as the weather is extremely hot. If you like to bargain on the market, please go to wikipedia/wikitravel search for Marrakech, you will get some tips from there. Food at night market is not expensive if you compare to the price in Europe, Australia or America. But I guess, this place is purely for tourist and you pay everything in tourist price tag. : ) Nevertheless, just enjoy!
A crazy place. This place is just crazy. During day, cars, motobike, bicycle, horsecar and people everywhere.During night, food and BBQ, snake charging guys, and so much people.
Mad!!!. This is just a mad area extremly busy in vibrant. A word of waring, the market traders are hard work , and when you dont wnat to buy can become aggresive and abusive

Experience the real Marocco here!. Experience the real Marocco here!Learn to bargain before you buy or accept anything! You will be asked to buy a lot of things from tissues, drugs, massages to keyhangers, fake bags and to come for diner. Cant find your way? Just ask anyone and they will show you for just a couple of Dirham (10 Dirham is about 1 Euro)

Be sure it is a unique place in the world. So busy, so chaotic. Full of mouvement. colors and smells , We can drink a great orange juice. to eat since calamares to snails.... we can be lost and can find so many things over there. It is so busy. What I like best it is the golden moment of sunset...the light over the walls look golden paint to all colors of the world. It is very beautiful and strange but spcialy unique.. We can listening an Africa music completing the ambiance. It is a great sensorial place. Impossible to miss. You must even once in life to meet a date there.

Exotic square. This is the highlight of my day in Marrakech, exotic snake charmers, monkey handler, people selling herbs, potions, water etc. Orange juice was very very sweet (did they put sugar in?) and cheap. If it gets overwhelming go to one of the rooftop cafe and enjoy the people watching with a bird's eye view. The smell, sight, sounds really gets to you. P.S. Watch out for your belongings

A must see. The market comes to life at night, but leading up to that you have folk law stories, acrobat artists and snake charmers, one thing we didn't like was seeing the monkeys attached to chains lead by the handlers, this was in very poor taste.
Do it at least once.. Complete madness! But you have to see it. It's Something about of Arabian Nights with snake charmers, acrobats, fortune tellers, drummers.

a feast for the eyes. Come after dark and you wont be disappointed. The square literally comes alive after dark once the food stalls have setup.During the day it's quite bleak with just the orange "juice" stalls, henna artists and snake charmers, later in the day it's a buzz with locals and tourists eating and watching the shows.As expected pretty much every stall vies for your attention, women will get tired of telling the henna artists they aren't interested, but this is all part of the fun and buzz.

Magical Square. Amazing Hustle and Bustle day and night (both need to be seen) so much going on that a roof top cafe with a super zoom lens or binoculars is the best way to nose at what is going on with out being roped in to anything or spending a fortune. A bit over whelming getting a taxi from the square we found if we crossed the road we were not hassled at all and got a taxi easy but on the bus stop side of the road we were hassled and even followed by some drivers

Disappointing. Food was tasteless, overcooked and looked tired. Too much disturbances whilst trying to eat and an enjoyable expereince. The street entertainment is not soo great unless you understand Arabic as all the acting/comedy is in Arabic, the drummers are all the same without any dancing.
Another world!. You've seen the photos - the reality is an incredibly intense experience.The sights, sounds and smells can never be imagined!

Interesting square. This large open area is the main focal point of Marrakech. It contains a number of entertainers such as jugglers, snake charmers, men with performing monkeys etc. All are happy to have their photographs taken with you for a fee. carriage rides around the medina also start from here and it serves as the entrance toe souks. After atiring few hours around the souks and medina head back here for a taxi - there are always some available here.
Glimpse into History. The square is bustling with actors and musicians. Would have preferred more light at night. We ate at number 14 in the dining area.

Just as i imagined. So much to see, Snake charmers, Jugglers, Monkeys (not so good) Food stalls, Water sellers, Story tellers, Souks, Orange kiosks. 1000s of spectators. Thats just the start, never seen anything quite like it. 10/10

Totally exotic and brilliant. This is a really amazing place and so exciting. TipsIf you are nervous or not good with gpcrowds, dip in and out. My friend isn't mad keen on big crowds so we would go in for 20 mins at a time, then come out and have a mint tea at a terrace cafe.Try to plot your path as you go in as it is very winding and a bit confusing.Lots of places sell the same stuff so don't just buy from the first stall as you can usually get a better deal further in. Do, however, try to remember where you saw items as it may be that only that stall has that design in stock at e moment so you can go back there.I was nervous of haggling but it is fun once you start. Don't be afraid to be cheeky or walk away. The smallholders won't take offence and you shouldn't either.Lots of smallholders will call out to you. Don't be afraid, they won't pull you in or follow you. A smile and a "no thank you " particularly in French or Arabic will be fine.Take your time as it gets hot and it can be a long way out.It gets really busy at 5/6 and is used a thoroughfare for people on their way home, including for mopeds.CARRY WATER WITH YOU AT ALL TIMES.Watch out for horses.Stick around as the food, music and atmosphere in the vending are beautiful.

A must see/experience. Bonkers - that's this place - enjoy the sights, sounds and smells. Visit this place at different times of the day - purchase an orange juice and people watch then keep moving, be prepared to pay for photos of the "attractions".

Very interesting marketplace. Lots of ladies offering henna in this area. Only visited in the day time as we were told that it was very busy during the evening. Lots of different things on sale in both the open market in the square and also around the back of the square along the small streets. Found quite a few things such as children's clothes, perfumes, spices and shoes and the prices were quite reasonable if you shopped around.
Not to be missed. Going back in time to what life must have been like in times gone past. Snake charmers, monkey's teeth stalls, smells and noise of time gone by

Charming Snakes & Colourful Water Sellers. Now a market square, this was originally a place of execution. Standing around for more than a few minutes watching the snake charmers will attract them to you and they will place snakes around your neck before you know it and then haggle a price for taking a picture with your OWN camera.Watch out for the Henna women,apparently they can take your hand and tattoo it before you have had chance to say "La Chokran (No thank you)" if you are not careful. We saw them and they asked my wife if she wanted her hands doing but we had no problem when she said "no" - Sights, sounds and smells are fantastic.

Manic, Mad and Mystifying !. No visit to Marrakesh is complete without a visit to Jemaa el Fna. With the hussle and bustle, Orange stalls, snake charmers,(be wary of these as if you have a picture taken they will try to charge you extortionate amount of money even after they assure you - whatever you like) monkeys, Gypsies, performers, food stalls... Marrakesh at it's magical best !

Crazy!!!. Called the 'Big' square, during the day it was a little quieter and most of the stalls are around the outside but it is still busy with people trying to get you to buy things they are carrying, we didn't see any snake charmers but a few 'monkey men'. At night it is mad but fantastic exactly as you will have seen on TV, the centre is filled with food stalls and around them are groups of musicians, boxers, acrobats and people selling all manner of things, it has to be seen to be believed and no trip to Marrakech is complete without experiencing it!

No atmosphere like it!. Incredible to sit on the roof of one of the bars and watch everything going on below. You will get harassed here to buy things - I pretty much got attacked by a lady desperate to give me a henna tattoo but be firm with your 'no thank you'. I didn't really enjoy the food but there are so many cooks here I think I must have just been unlucky.

Great Experience. We went to the square basically every night since it was less than 5 minutes away from our riad. We ate there three nights. Go to stall number 114, their food was so fresh and we really enjoyed the service. It is a litle intense with all of the motorbikes that rush through the crowds and the children selling tissues can get annoying. We were still happy we went.

A great place to eat. Jemma El Fna during the day is great but at night it is fantastic. The square transforms into a myriad of open air restaurants which are generally safe to eat in. The choice of food is stunning and together with the constant drumming and playing from the musicians in the square makes this a must visit attraction. Go along you won't be dissapointed

The most vibrant and atmospheric place in Marrakech. If you go to Marrakech, make sure you come here.The square transforms at dusk each night, from being a place of shopping and street performers, into a set of open air food stalls serving local food.Make sure you get yourself a seat on the balcony of a roof top terrace before sunset and watch the place transform.

Fascinating, know the rules.. I love the excitement of the square, but you have to realize that this is where many make their living. It is customary to pay any of the touts or performers especially when there is personnel interaction. Its like not leaving a tip in a restaurant. If you are uncomfortable with the custom, keep a distance. They will often ask or demand a huge price and I always make a small joke of it rather than get nuts. It's best to keep it light hearted. Once you get the hang of it you will do fine. Be prepared and you will enjoy it more.

Evening visit. took the last free shuttle service to JEF and staye duntil it got dark when the place really comes to life. too hot visit during the day and not quite the same. Wonderful sights ans smells and worth getting aroof top seat for some good pictures and a mint tea!

Not particularly exciting. There were loads of young boys (teens and twenties) trying to pinch ladies inappropriately. Besides, I didn't find the events and shows (not to mention all the street sellers) in the Square particularly exciting.
quiet during day, bustling at night. During the day you'll see some monkeys, snake charmers, henna practicioners etc., but at night the square lilvens up with lots of people, food cooking and lights.

You want chaos? You get it!. Bring on the snakes, monkeys, hasslers, buzzlers, oranges pressing, money searching people. And add up some charcoal smoke, horses and you have it. Total chaos, but what an atmosphere!,! ;)
Noisy but exciting. Very noisy around snake charmers but that is part of experience. If hassled a polite no is sufficient.

Noisy and Smelly. This was supposed to be the highlight of our visit to Marrakech and what a disappointment we found it to be - we visited during the daytime and at night, but the just found it to be very crowded with the aroma of hot horses and barbecue's - the street entertainers were not very entertaining and there was just the normal hustle to buy something that you get in the Medina.

Quietish during the day, mayhem in the evening. This is really like stepping back in time, snake charmers, tooth sellers, story tellers, henna painters, monkeys, food and plenty of things to buy. Lots of cafes to just sit and watch.

Great for people watching. Great multi cultural clean and serine area. Watch out for the tour guide scams one will pester you and one will appear to rescue you telling you to watch your bag as it is an attpt to steal it. They then try to make you feel safe by asking if you remember me I work at your hotel. Ask them what hotel and they disapear swiftly

Experience better than the food. This is the highlight of Marrakesh. Its a great experience to wander around the groups of people huddled around some event and be endlessly asked to come and eat and drink orange juice at the stalls. I would say the experience of wandering and looking at the world of people is better than the food that is on offer
Crazy. A busy but exciting Market square, so much going on, snake charmers, horse and cart rides ( wouldn't recommend that ), all forms of transport whiz zing by, and a fabulous market.
Be courteous!. Remember to tip performers in the medina even if you only want to take a picture. It may cost you a dirham but this is how they make their living and it is appropriate to do it.

A must see on your itinery. The square of El Fna is great. I had watched the Jamie Oliver series in Marrakesh and seen him there. I'm guessing he didn't eat there though otherwise he may not have made it home straight away :) I wouldn't recommend eating at the market stalls in the middle as we have been ill for a few days but do go and have a look and marvel at the theatre of it all. There is a place to the left of Cafe France that is good. Cafe France offered a very mediocre set menu. Definetly stop by somewhere, order mint-tea and watch the goings on. We enjoyed a man with some scales charging people to be weighed, he did very well out of it:)

Always something going on..... The square is the true idea of the culture in Marrakech. In the evening it is alive with different circles of people performing plays, music, snake-charmers, henna artists, food stalls and the souks. During the day its quite hot so not as much going on. The orange juice sellers and horse-carts are out as are the souks and restaurants. Highly recommend - a definite must see in the evening.
A must see. Something out of an indiana jones movie. Amazing scenes going on all around. Its a sensory overload. Dont be a fool and miss it.

Chaotic but a Must Do. The Jemma el Fna is a focal point of Marrakech, during the day it is quiet with not much of a crowd. You will see snake charmers and fresh orange juice stands etc, it all comes alive in the evening when the madness starts. It is very very busy so be aware of your belongings. We had a great time with stall holders getting a bargain for our goods and they actually expect you not to pay full price which we never did.

Hectic, Mental, Crazy, Brilliant. Be sure to watch where you step otherwise you may step on a snake, end up with a monkey on your shoulder, walk into a horse/ mule or be run over by a local on a motor bike. Give on of the restuarants with a roof terrace a go for a mint tea to over look the craziness of the main square while the sun goes down, the place kicks it up another gear when the sun goes down.

An absolute must experience!. On visiting Marrakech I knew this was one place I had to see for myself. I first visited the square by day and had a look at the cafe's to plan my next evening visit to take photographs. There is nothing on earth to compare with this. The whole place explodes with activity once the sun has set and is teeming with people. Whilst dodging the horse poo, bikers, horse drawn carriages and snake charmers, it is a place to try to enjoy whilst trying to keep your wits because there are many distractions and it is easy to misjudge the intentions of the locals. It is quite safe if you take care and enjoy the chaos that is this square! Afterwards go to one of the cafe's around the square and have a soft drink as majority of the cafe's and bars around the square serve no alchahol. Altogether an absolute must if you are in Morocco!

one of a kind. the main square is amazing. super loud, crazy, chaotic! but so much fun! You should definitely try the food in the night market. delicious! I believe its the craziest place in Marrakech! Totally worth being there every night :)

of course, need to be visited.. over crowded, just TO BE VISITED, and also have one dinner on the place (do not dream, the food is just "all right", do not look at the glasses ... just enjoy the music, the people around, the snakes...
bad: lok at your pocket.. like in many cities, tourists/crowded place.. mean some steals
Amazing by day or night. This square is amazing by day & by night, during the day you have snake charmers & markets 7 by night pop up restaurants!!!!

So busy!!!!. A must do in Marrakech. Very busy & full on. But well worth a visit. Particularly after 6pm, when it's starting to get into full swing up. The choose of different foods is amazing. Be prepared though to be approached by many stall vendors. You'll see snake charmers, performing monkeys, tarot card reading & everything in between. Be aware that if you take a photo of a person, you may be asked to deleted it or pay the person a small fee.

Amazing place ...... surely a UNESCO world heritage site. This place is not only a UNESCO World heritage Site, but also the most popular touristic area of Marrakesh for both foreign and local tourist. The place in one word is magical and seems it came out from the pages of Arabian Nights, especially at night. During day time, the Medina is full with snake charmers and tribal waterman. Most of the time the snake charmers encourage the foreign travellers to hold snakes for photos. Once photo taken, they start to ask for good amount of money and there is no escape. If you want to take a picture with snake, first fix a price with the snake charmer and then take photo. I have 15 dirham to a snake charmer and took many photos of him with snakes. Same goes with waterman, they also encourage people to take photos of them and start asking for money. But you can still enjoy the place is you keep your eyes open and be bold. At evening the whole medina turns into a magical place with 100s of food stalls. I smell of the food is overwhelming and intoxicating. It is difficult to resist the temptation of trying the foods. So be bold and try anything you like. The stalls sell chickens kebabs, lam kebabs, fish, sea food, vegetables and many more food items. There are few stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice and they are nice and cheap. Few stall sells snail soup as well. The sail soup stalls are popular among the locals. I will recommend this place strongly as trip to Marrakesh is incomplete without going to Medina. Be hold and enjoy the atmosphere.

Assault of the senses. Jemaa el Fna square is one of the most magical place i have ever experienced! During the day it is nothing special however as night falls it comes alive! I would recommend sitting on one of the rooftop terraces for a drink. Firstly because the sellers start setting up their stalls around 5pm and it is an amazing scene to witness, and secondly it is a great way to get your bearings. The food served on the stalls is fantastic. I was really dubious about going having read some of the horror stories on here. we went into the square 4 times all together and all were good experiences, We found them to be less pushy then other places we have visited in North Africa and Turkey and although there were loads of tourists we were hugely diluted by the locals, giving it an authentic feel. We were blown away by the sights, sounds, smells and general ambiance of the place, could not recommend it enough. Keep your wits about you but don't be put off visiting!

Must See. Where everyone comes to meet and wander and eat and watch the parade that is life, in all its forms. Sometimes too much as when the sale of the obnoxious fedora is now part of the scene.Arab dress is not suited to that hat. At times too much of a sub carnival. But the food stall don't disappoint.

An experience not to be missed. The best place to watch all the drama unfold is Le Grand Balcon. Grab a bite to eat or a drink and watch the hustle and bustle unfold below. We sat here on many occasions during our stay. We watched in awe as the food stalls wheeled in during the late afternoon and erect their stands from nothing in a matter of minutes – amazing. The sellers on the square are persistent and can be cheeky – for instance the henna ladies that sit out on the square may attract your attention and before you know it they’ve started drawing up your arm and demanding payment. Also, if you’re an animal lover you may find some of the entertainment on the square unsavoury – mostly the monkeys. The colourful water sellers, bands and dancers are a delight to watch but be weary – taking pictures will cost you here! We took advantage of our perch on the roof top terrace cafes and snapped happily for free!

Amazing but..... The place is amazing with a life on its own.... People everywhere and great cheap food. However, be careful of parents using kids to get you to by random object and all the small vendors. If you get henna, make sure to set the price and design BEFORE they start the design. It will save you endless, frustrating negotiations.

Best at night!. The food is delicious and extremely inexpensive, just make sure you are prepared to be bombarded by people trying to sell you everything/ services, charge you to take pictures and get you to eat at their stall.If you are only women, just be prepared to have men give constant inappropriate calls. Just ignore it and enjoy your night!

Prepare to be overwhelmed!. A very interesting cultural experience. Going there on a saturday night be prepared for a mass of people. There are dozens and dozens of food carts in the center surrounded by people watching performers, selling wares, etc. Some of the performers can be very forward by placing their snake or monkey on your shoulders and taking your picture with your camera, all without asking and then demanding money. I found after wandering around one of the surrounding rooftop restaurants provide a great way to take in the festivites at sundown. All of the locals recommended against the food carts in the center unless you have a strong stomach but the food is tasty a cheap ($3-4).
my time at jemaa el fna. only down side beggers keep on at you.just be firm loads of people great exsperience loads of tourist shops.snake charmers .monkeys .have a horse a cart ride

crazy. My 4th time in Marrakesh and always go to the square and have agood time, not anymore! we were sat at a cafe at 8ish, when a crazy local approached me and started pulling my hair from the roots [blond curly hair]. The staff had to get him of me. I am a 55yrs old lady, do not dress provocatively, so why he targeted me I don't no. He carried on acting threatening in the distance with other people as far as we could see, until a european man decked him. It is getting quite risky in the square now, people must be aware, especially in the evenings. It was a thursday evening. It won't stop me going again though.
Nice people, Nice place. Jemaa el Fna is a meeting point for all the people as Moroccans as foreigners. You will enjoy it when you are there. Just be patient and do not miss it too.

A unique and thrilling experience. It seems strange to give the main square of the medina a mark out of five, but we were so overwhelmed and delighted by the bustle of people, the good-natured banter and hawking of goods and services, the smells, colours and sounds, and the sheer craziness of it all that it couldn't be less than full marks. We didn't have any problems with unwanted attention so long as we were watchful against monkeys and henna and cheerful in our refusal of other unwanted offers. In fact I found the offers of "fish and chips!" from some of the stallholders very funny, if indicative of racial profiling!Either wandering around on foot, sitting to eat at a food stall (delicious, but be very very careful if your stomach is delicate), or watching over everything from Cafe de France, the Djemaa el Fna was an unmissable experience.

Cool. When you get there you have a bad impression, but when you get used to people approaching you, all the time, to sell their stuff, you are able to enjoy the place. Do not accept anything from local people because they will charge you for that.

Just Amazing!. There is just so many things to see and buy! Mind you that you HAVE to visit this during the day and during the night! IT changes so much just within a day! Just make sure that you are ready to be dragged into every single shop you pass through! Such a great experience!

it depends.... you will enjoy if you like crowd, ants like streets with all kind of mix of smells , sounds and types of people. I found it disturbing seeing poverty, mess, and 10 y/o boys and girls selling stuff at 1 am and poor horses standing all day and night in the heat on streets waiting for a ride :( that all literally drove me into tears...
Wow!. Snake charmers, henna artists, storytellers and so much more. The square is busy enough during the day but comes alive at night. Wonderful aromas and a visual feast, highly recommended.
Somehting amazing. It is a nice area, with lots of attractions from food, to shopping to entertainment, remember you have to tip people making their show.
Fast food Marrakech style. Atmospheric, delicious, loud and bright & fun. Plenty for vegetarians as well as meat-eaters. Not a place to go for a long, lingering meal.

Try the experience !. Eating on the place center is a must in Marrakech, definitely a great experience. Waiters are nice and funny, and the food is exactly up to its price : basic but worth the experience.

Jemaa el Fna - Watch your wallet. I've visited many souks throughout the a variety of countries and this was by far the least impressive. The general overwhelming foul stench was the most off-putting feature. One expects to be harassed as part of the course but I was followed for quite a while by a sinister, swarthy looking character wearing a suit who would have looked more fitting at a 1920's mafia poker game rather than the bazaar. Unsure of what to do, I deliberated with confronting the man then decided to approach two kind policemen to whom I pointed out the stalker. Immediately, the creepy character swiftly turned on his heels and disappeared into the crowds. I noticed the zip of my cross body shoulder bag was open. Annoyingly, I realised that 600dirhams had disappeared from the dark recesses. I would have thought that it would have been easier for Houdini to escape from a securely locked chest flung into the sea than prize money from me! Perhaps I am not the hardened and savvy traveller that I consider myself.I was very conservatively dressed - jeans, trainers and short sleeved t-shirt, as well as a icy glare that would have given Posh Spice a run for her money - as I did not wish to attract any attention and give off the vibe that I was 'up for it.' Still I was inundated with offers to be my boyfriend from male youths that looked as if they could do with a jolly good wash. I think if I looked like the hunchback of Notre Dame and had donned a burkha for my stroll around the souk these pests would still be following in droves like the rats enchanted by the Pied Piper. All things considered, it is imperative to visit Jemaa el Fna during a trip to Marrakech so not to disappoint when sharing tales with friends and family that will have expected you to do so.

Insense. fantastic, the smells of the food, charcoal. very busy even in early afternoon. watch the city come alive at dusk.. you can get a good deal as long as your sensible. the slippers are great for presents. but rarely go up to a size 8 unless mens when you are oushed to get a size 9. they have very small feet! the henna ladies who are sitting are the ones you should use recommended buy our guide. the henna ladies walking around are not liecensed and use alchole in the dye, it doesnt last. make sure you set a prive before you agree to let them paint you. approx 30d = £7

Tourist Trap. Visited this square in expectation of something special, it really wasn't . Our first encounter came from a local street performer wearing the Berber garb. We showed no interest and he still accosts us with expectation of dropping money into his hat despite doing nothing for us. The busy square in the day is dominated by orange juice carts, henna tattooists calling " come over here baby" , snake "charmers" , monkey handlers and several horse and cart rides. This place screams of TOURIST  TRAP!. We walked over to the horse and cart dodging people offering us help to find things or the offer of some ill treated chained monkey for photo opportunities . All never seems genuine.We were called over and offered a ride around all the sights for 300dirhams, he said would take about an hour to get around. From past experience in several cities horse rides have been a good way to see parts of the city you may miss on foot. Sadly this was the opposite. We were taken to the new town past KFC busy streets etc, not what we asked for or agreed. A 3rd into the journey we stopped and the man told us he is taking us back to the square now as we have been an hour! He said to take us to the palace etc would cost another 100. A disgrace I reiterated what was agreed, I told him just take us back. AVOID AVOID these conmen.Avoid these people they are a disgrace, the whole square is an advert for animal cruelty. Malnourished animals.Go and see for a day, but your better spending your time outside of the square and into the mountains where the true hospitable morrocans live and not out to get your next dirham.Watch out for the henna women they grabbed my girlfriend and nearly put a dirty henna pen on her, avoid any eye contact in this square. Watch out for scooters who seemed to have access to anywhere , we were both very close to being knocked over. Head into the souqes for a bit of shopping then spend the rest of your holiday elsewhere.

An absolute must ... but take care!. This is a very large square and butts onto a huge network of souks. First the square: in the daytime, there are stalls selling freshly squeezed orange juice, spices and nuts. There are also people with snakes and monkeys. If you don't want to be charged, then don't let them see you showing any interest in the animals/reptiles as they will plonk a monkey/snake on you and agree to a small price but once you take the photo they will demand a much higher price and become quite aggressive if you resist. Throughout the square and the souks, people ride dangerously on motorbikes so it feels quite unsafe and also the air is very polluted. In the evening, the square transforms and is quite magical with beautifully lit stalls where you find old men selling incense stones and sandalwood for burning, plus lots of other fascinating momentoes. The square becomes filled with entertainers and lots of outdoor food stalls (research these before you dine so that you can take some on board some food safety tips to void you getting the Morrocan equivalent of Delhi Belly!) The souks are very exciting but after your first 100, you find that they all sell similar types of things - spices, lightshades, pottery, leather goods, etc. We had some bad experiences with heavy handed salesmen. Again, if you show any interest, they will not let you walk off without making a sale. Even though it feels rude, you have to be assertive when you say you are just looking. They try it on with their pricing so, if you are interested, it's always a good idea to come in at about half the price they quote. Be cheeky, and if they let you walk out of the shop, then you know you might have bartered a bit too strongly! Warning: when people from one stall say that they have what you are looking for at another stall, don't follow them. They are often on commission with the other stalls and can become very aggressive if you refuse to buy. Similarly, be careful who you ask directions from as, again, they will not take you where you want to go to but will take you to a stall that offers them a commission for every customer they introduce who ends up buying. The best advice I can give generally is don't be too trusting and keep your wits about you, AND never pay the price that they quote (even negotiate with taxis).

Must be the first on your list. As soon as you are settled, head towards this square if you want to know where the energy of this place lies..filled with street food, snake charmers, and everything else you can imagine -monkeys to take your pic with included-go there, keep an eye for the many scooters buzzing around in all directions. Best to go at sunset..not too many people and you will see how the plaza transforms into a huge food market.

Keep your wits about you!. This is one of the places you have to visit, no question. It's absolutely packed and a pretty exciting place to be - the noise, smells, sights, everything's so different. You do get pestered but most people accept a polite smile and "non, merci" but you do get fed up of it after a while. I only gave it 3 stars because I got felt up twice, both times by quite young lads, and I should add I was very conservatively dressed. Our riad owner said she'd never heard of sucha thing happening so maybe I was just unlucky. But it spoilt it for me.
Time travel!. No matter what you choose to look or buy this place will set youback 100 years. Evan the Hollywood can’t produce such scenes.

Heartbeat of the heartbeat.... THIS is where everything happens... where the sellers come in from the desert, from the coast, from other market places... where you see snake charmers, buy Amber and Myrrh, argan oil and drink fresh orange juice. Where cents can get you anything.. and if you sit with the salesmen as you bargin they might bring you some traditional moroccan mint tea... yumm. THIS is Marrekesh. you can sit for hours and watch this world unfold, in it's African Magic

Good and Bad. Good:There are lots to see and lots to buy, me and my friend are suckers for the fresh orange juice for 4 dirhams each. The mix of food, spices, noises and the people is very unique experience.Bad:If you are walking around the square in the day and especially in the night, expect to be pestered very 2 steps by people trying to sell you things, make you eat in their food stall or offering you assistance in any way for lots of your money.Verdict:Worth a visit if only once, much less busy during the day.

An Alien Experience but Amazing. Jemaa el Fna is a place that one learns a huge number of life lessons that you would never expect to need until visiting:Whether it's dodging a snake charmer trying to drape one of his attractions around your neck, bartering with a group of ape-wielding men, fending off the over-amorous advertising of the cockney-esque food-stall owners or trying to decide which of the 50 nearly identical orange juice stands to sample there is always a new experience awaiting when you step into the square.

Exciting. If you like lots going on and can have your wits about you but still enjoy a full on experience then go for it, spend the evening there, eat in the food market and No 1 Stall and get a real Marrakech experience of dining for minimal Dirham, you will get bothered thats part of the charm just deal with it by being polite but confident. No one is rude or pushy. Monkeys, snakes, story tellers, fortune tellers, dancers, orange juice traders, the biggest BBQ ever seen mixed in with sellers of music, tissues, sweets, lighters etc, it was a great experience and I would love to return.

shock to the system. I was expecting more, but be prepared because is nothing like you ever seen before, especially if you go to the food department.The crafts area is very good, because you can see them working.If you get lost, be prepared to be stalked with offering you the right directions, for a price of course. We always said no.

Great if you like people watching. This place at night is noisy and lively the quality of the music is poor and you get hassled to contribute after listening to 30 seconds of it. The other acts ? Seem to take for ever to do anything and not that interesting to me. The smells and sounds and sights are fascinating and it's an experience.
Amazing !. We loved it here, it is absolutely fascinating. The culture, different types of entertainer, the food, storytellers its great.

Vibrant but with too much emphasis on animal abuse.. Lovely lighting in the evening with plenty of locals and lots of activity. The only thing we did not enjoy was the amount of animal cruelty going on. Horses were mistreated and underfed, the snakes were constantly manhandled, and all the monkeys had horrible chords tied tightly around them and were constantly being tugged and dragged everywhere by these chords on their necks. If you care about animals please do not pay these people as it only encourages more abuse.

Lively. Buzzing and intriguing place to be. The square is quieter in the day and busier in the evening, the square really livens up with food stalls, morrocan singing and dancing. The locals are so friendly and welcoming. No other place like it...

Don't be afraid to go there.. A lot of people were put off by negative reports based on ??We went in the daytime first to get our bearings.Don't let the taxi driver persuade you to go where he wants- be firm that it is the square you want to go to.Pay as little as possible for your fare. There are hundreds of taxis.The atmosphere is great. Be prepared to pay if you want to take photos.We went to the panoramic restaurant, just for a drink, to get a good view.Do what you want to do and don't be dictated to.Marrakesh is great.

Morocco's most magical place. Eating, drinking, singing, praying, fortune telling, snake hypnotising, monkey petting, dancing, eating an ice cream, watching the whole square from one of the terraces. It's the most magical place in Morocco!

Snakes alive. Comes alive at night, great eating, shopping and people watching. Dont forget to bargain. There are Cobras in the square during the day and explore the sooks. The oranges there are the best tasting in the world.
Fun!. Lots of fun, an electric atmosphere at night. Enjoy bartering for bits and bobs in the souks, Watch out for the snake charmers, and the men!!
Incredible. Wow, what a lot goes on here! Providers of new teeth, hairdressers, snake charmers, monkeys, food, goods, boxing, etc. Lovely at night.

myth. The place has been selected by Unesco as one of the great monuments,or places,of our globe.It must be true.Yet,it is now a kind of local amusement park,outdoor restaurants(snails in all forms),games,story tellers,only a few monkeys and hardly any snakes,thank God.When it is hot the locals gather at the place,hustle and bustle as on Time Square,friendly though.Attention:the water offered by men in clorful uniforms are not send out by the tourist office-they want to be paid.But;rather water than these boiled snails...

night time must. experience at different times of the night - it's crazy but fun- be careful taking pictures though - my partner got chased & accosted when we were watching the transvestite dancers & we didn't even take pictures of them!!!

A night to remember!. You have to visit the night market if you come to Marrakech. It is an assault on all of your senses and an amazing experience. Eat at the busiest stalls, usually a good sign that the food is good. The highlight was drinking mint tea, sitting in a rooftop cafe overlooking the market and hearing the call to prayer from all the local mosques. Pure magic!

Jemma el Fna- an experience you should try!. But do keep your wits about you! My husband and I were a little apprehensive about what would greet us at Jemma el Fna after reading the many reviews on here, but we went anyway (how could you not?!). We had an amazing experience, it is very-very busy, you will see water sellers, orange juice stalls, beggars,monkey trainers, acrobats, bellydancers, Ganoua Musicians, Magicians, cigarette sellers, storytellers, Snake charmers, henna ladies and Millions and millions of people everywhere! Not to mention bikes, horse carts, human pulled carts, Caleche's, moterbikes and cars!We had no problem with henna ladies, a firm no and not engaging with them was sufficient, no problem with monkey men either, polite no with smiles. Same with snake charmers. You do need to be careful where you take photo's water sellers will try to run into shot so they can ask for money, if a snake charmer thinks you took his picture he will run over and demand money! But if you didn't then no problem.PHOTOS Set a price before taking pictures, we did this with water sellers, Ganoua dancers, and snake charmers, as well as some of the stall holders, they ARE very cheeky and will encourage you to take lots of shots and then demand more money, but just be firm and tell them they can have what you agreed, if they complain or disagree offer to give them nothing at all, make sure the money is in your hand and start to walk away, they'll soon settle for the agreed price. The food stall holders will chat and have banter but it's good fun and they are really friendly no hassle at all.BEGGARSThere are some beggars about, this is a poor Country, but we didn't find them a problem at all, they are far more insistant in places like India. It is fine to give small coins or bits of food if you wish, many of the Marrakeshi's give as charity is one of the pillars of Islam.HENNA LADIESThere are a lot of them about, we were warned by our Riad manager, that if they put any ink at all on you, you were expected to pay, and that agreeing a price first was imperative. I didn't want Henna as I don't trust the quality of the Henna they use, so I wore a scarf round my arms to cover them a bit, just to prevent any possible issues with grabbing and daubing, which I had read about on here, but it never happened, I was never grabbed, and only approached a couple of times, I just smiled and said no Thankyou, but kept walking.FOOD STALLSIf you come to the square you should try them, but pick busy ones, and I wouldn't choose anything you can't eat with your fingers, as I don't think the washing up facilities would be like home! We also took wipes and tissues, but there were children going round the stalls selling tissues to the patrons if you didn't have any. The food was cheap, and not bad, the atmosphere was fantastic! Stall 1 Aeisa - that has been mentioned a lot on here, was very mediocre, the food wasn't hot, and portions were bit small.  We also ate at number 81, which cost the same but the food was far better, the chicken skewers were tasty and well marinated, and piping hot. We wouldn't recommend sitting on the end of a table, you get pestered by children (not beggars just cheeky kids!) asking for your coke, or some food all the time. Be aware that there are pick pockets and opportunists about like any busy city, split your money into different pockets, don't bother with a handbag if possible, and don't pull out wads of money when buying things. We didn't have any problems, apart from being followed about by some cheeky kids for a bit. I had my bum felt for a potential wallet, they were disappointed though because all I had in my pants was my Butt!!CAFE BALCONIESA fantastic way to see all of Jemaa el Fna, and highly recommended, it gives you a break from the madness, but you have a great view of the activity, we went to Cafe Grand Balcon and played table chess to get a ringside seat! The drinks were pricy by Marrakech standards but you are paying for the show! We also had lunch one afternnon on the ground floor terrace of cafe de France.OVERALLYou should visit Jemaa el Fna preferably in the day and at night if you visit Marrakech, it is an amazing experience, an overload on the senses, of sights, smells and noise not to be missed. Go, Smile a lot, look after your money, be firm but nice, agree anyones pictures first, and just enjoy it, you get out what you put in!!

This is Marrakesh !. Our group was due to meet in the morning at Riad Monceau cooking school (higly recommended) and as the workshop was finishing after lunch we then spent the afternoon on the Djemaa El Fna square and in the souks that are nearby. The whole place is absolutely amazing and anyome coming to Marrakesh should absolutely spend a couple hours in this area which is definitely the most interesting part of the historical district.
I was surprised!!!. It is good only for whom that enjoy local culture... I loved it!!! All those tents, a noisy place, full of pelople selling and buying everything... Amazing!
nice open area. i love walking and having diner therepeople are nice and you can enjoy the best orange juice ou can have everdon't miss the snails food ! Lol

Exotic and full on experience. We liked the exotic mix of snake charmers, henna tattooists and acrobats. A fascinating place to view life in Marrakech. We ate at the market stands which are full of tourists and all the food was great. The people serving were lovely and helpful... in the day it's empty except for the orange juice sellers ...but it's sooo hot as the ground is dark cobbles so we didn't spend time in the day.We went in August it was Ramadan...so don't do that! it was also 50degrees...so it was limiting what we could do with our time...walking anywhere was too hot! We didn't like the hawkers at the food stalls some of whom were touching me so I told them not to touch and they then called after me with some not nice things ... i didn't care but it did make my sons tense as it was way out of their comfort zone.
Complete Madness But Fun. We learned that Moroccans working abroad come homefor the summer andlove to visit theJemaa el Fna. Very crowdedbutfun for an hour or so.

Madness but fun. We went to the square during the day and also at night. They are very different and I would definitely recommend an evening visit when the snake charmers and vendors are in full flow. Try and find an upstairs restaurant spot to look down on the activity

Real Life.... Never and ever miss this place if you are in Marrakech.This is an unbelievable square and it is next to old town (medina).There are many street performers such as various dancers, street boxing, theatre playing, cobra dancing, street lottery, acrobatics, pantomime etc etc etc. very full of life.Also try the local food from the cookeries which start coming early in the evening and start assembling their mobile restaurants. Many of them are must to try and full with local great taste. Their seating arrangement around the cooking station is great.during the day there are many street cars that sells orange juice on their push cars with generated electric.Enjoy Jemaa El Fna from the roof terraces of cafes around this square. You need to pay for them to use their terraces to watch it. Enjoy this place, great experience.

Wow. What can you say about this that hasn't already been said - it is so alive and vibrant and offers so much. You do have to be careful, look after your belongings and politely turn down all the offers for photos, being draped by snakes - it can cost you a fortune and detract from just soaking it all up. You most definitely have to go at least x2.

Please visit!. This is best visited late in the evening, but even during the day was busy, with people selling orange juice, and people with monkeys and snake charmers. Your a few steps from the Souks, and surrounded by cafe's and restaurants. Sat with a drink in an open front cafe I felt like I was in a Michael Palin programme...it was one of my favourite moments!

Great place to eat. I travelled as 3 girls aged 24-26 and we visited the markets three times during our stay to eat in the evening.The food was incredible and SO cheap!! Visit the corner stall closest to Cafe Glacier (the one overlooking the bottom right hand side of the square) for some gorgeous sausages. You can't miss it, it's where all the locals were!!We got a bit hassled but only as much as you would expect in any resort trying to get people into their restaurant, a simple "Non" and carrying on walking did the trick!

Go, wander, get lost and just relax. Don't let the intensity get to you, go with the flow, don't be afraid to to say "no" with a smile (often), and you will have a great time just wandering and watching the spectacle. Eat at food stall number 35: the best merguez sausages, bread, tomato sauce, olives. When we went, we were the only tourists here. Everyone else was Moroccan. Next two us, two elegant teenage girls in full headdress shot shy glances at us and giggled as we tried to eat without using our left hands, and then surreptitiously demonstrated that it's not so hard. Get the fresh orange juice. several times. Buy some nuts and eat them while wandering and explaining that, no, you really don't want that henna tattoo. Listen in awe as the calls to prayer drift across the city. Go at night after the heat has abated: 9 o'clock, or later, when all of Marrekech comes to stroll...
A lot to see. Always busy and nice place to stay and watch for a while. Every hour of the day new things to see.Sometimes the traffic is dangerous.
Must see. this place is amazingi had there the best orange juice i had eversnack charmer, musicians ,you will find all the mix of moroccan culture

Completely crazy.... ... but excellent - go up to a balcony restaurant on one night at least to appreciate the chaos from above. Be aware of yourself and have confidence and some excuses (eg. we've already eaten, we'll come back after shopping) to stop you getting dragged into something. We found "No thank you" was good enough in most cases. Check out snake charmers, monkeys, story-tellers/skits, henna artists, Orange juice sellers, gymnasts, dancers, food vendors and shops (though be careful of prices here as often higher than in the souks).

Great atmosphere. This is one of the major landmark in the city. Is a commercial center and big restaurant at night, great atmosphere. For one EURO you can make photos/movie from snakes in the morning and in the afternoon. I felt safe and everyone was so friendly.

Not as exciting as I thought. Very hot, witnessed three confrontations between locals in first two hours. Mainly orange sellers and stalls repetative of souuks.Lots of hassle which we expected but did become tiring.

So disappointing. This square was the whole reason I went to Marrakech and I was really underwhelmed. The food stalls were fairly quiet and not good value for money (I paid 7 euros for a very small portion of couscous and a sprite) and there is much better value in the restaurants around the square. The atmosphere I was expecting was also a bit lacking - there were entertainers but if you don't speak Arabic you are totally lost with the storytellers and otherwise it's just snake charmers and the odd group of acrobats. Overall it's quite dirty and I felt uncomfortable there.
What a buzz!. Great atmosphere, lovely fresh orange juice stalls. BUT hassled for money in the late evening when you stopped to look at anything or take a photograph.
crazy!. so much fun! definitely visit as well at night for teh night market- a real experience! everything you think of when you think of marrakech.

Mazes of the medina. I love the jma el fan! What crazy fun. You have to get used to all the shops haggling with you and people begging for money but that's prt of the experience. It's so ig and so many paths to take with cool ouvenirs tht you can get lost shopping for great trinkets or fake designer everything! The food and fresh squeezed orange juice is cheap and delicious. It is a must see and do of Marrakech. Everyone was so friendly and fun! Loved it!

Vibrant and exciting. If you only do one thing whilst in Marrakech you have to visit Jemaa el Fna! There are stalls all over the place and some restaurants with terraces if you don't fancy a more traditional meal. Lots of hilarious sales pitches from the locals too!
A treat for the senses. Once you acclimatise to the chaos, the square is a treat to the senses - the sound of snake charmers' pipes is unmistakeable and will stay with you forever.

Crazy world of performance and food.. Loved the food and juices and all the souks, but the monkeys on chains was wrong. I was approached by a guy with a monkey and it was such a uncomfortable experience watching these monkeys either on a chain or in a box.
brilliant. you must experience the square.unless you have been to tunisia or egypt this place is crazy.a truly wonderful expereience.

monkeys,snakes and henna tattoo. have to expierence! chaotic, but traditional. be aware of the moroccans with monkeys and snakes. if you dont want to pay for taking pics of them, run away:) the ladies offering henna tattoos are overpriced..i gave 26 dirhams for one henna, it lasts about 2 weeks, then gave 30 dirhams for other henna that doesnt even have colour. dont give them more!and agree on the price before she starts.the orange juice is amazing and cheap!

" Food Glorious Food ". The Souks are fantastic and you need to bargain hard, best to go at night when it is cooler and there is more people to share the hassle from the traders.Night Food Market was fantastic although every stall offers pretty much the same food menu with slight twists here and there, would recommend stall No.1 for best service and value...!!!

Unique and cheap eats. Eat for a fiver per head, make sure you pick somewhere busy and has a fast turnaround. Comes alive after sunset, and gelato and coffee on one of the terraces is a nice way to see out the day

Assault on all your senses. What a place, souks, food stalls, orange juice stalls, cafes, smakes, music, monkeys and so much more. Don't be scared just go. If your not interested in anything just keep smiling and walking and you will not be bothered by anyone, but keep an eye for mopeds!

Wonderful atmosphere. A must when visiting Marrakesh. It has a great atmosphere and buzz that you'll love. If you're female dress appropriate.. If you're bearing flesh be ready to get lots on unwanted attention. It can take the enjoyment out of it if it gets to you. The souks are awesome and I personally had fun haggling and bartering with vendors that would be trying to pull you into their shop. If you don't enjoy these kind of things, avoid this place. If you do get drawn into the shop - don't pay their asking price and start about 50% of what they ask for.Food is nice and there are a few good restaurants on the edge of the square. We also tried the stall restaurants and were pleasantly surprised with the food. Have a good wonder around and enjoy the buzz..

markets and food. visit this place in the morning and also at night, 2 totally different scenes. You'll find henna designers, monkeys, reptiles, horse rides (day). And at night lots of food carts, fresh squeezed orange juice, sweets. Next to that lots of vendors with clothing, shoes, home decor, souvenirs, etc, just remember to bargain down to less than 50% than the price asked.

Really great place spoilt by a sexual assault !. Really loved looking around this place and even the kids coming up to you to sell their stuff was ok, the 'entertainment' at night is really interesting, you really feel the authentic atmosphere within this square at night. During the day there are lots to see also but you have lots of people approach you (monkeys, henna etc).Can see how some people may find it intimidating as some food stall vendors can be quite aggressive when trying to tempt you into their seats. The whole visit (actually the whole holiday) was spoilt by a local coming up behind my partner feeling her backside while smiling at her then melting back into the crowds. This really really angered me and spoilt our night here, we noticed perhaps 10 men raising their eyebrows repeatedly towards my partner which apparently means they are interested ! This feels like some sort of animal mating ritual when you are in the thick of it and should be avoided if you think this may upset you. Its unfortunate that the pest that decided to sexually assault my partner doesn't realise that his actions upset and annoyed us for days afterwards and my partner was afraid to go out at night after this visit. Surely the authorities should stamp out this behaviour as in our own countries that behaviour would get you locked up (at best)

Mad, magical .... just go there and experience it!. You just have to go there. You will get dusty, hassled, amazed, astounded; you will drink freshly squeezed orange juice, have a monkey stuck on your shoulder (if you don't run away), dodge snake charmers, water sellers, henna tatooists, donkeys, horses ..... oh, just go, and you'll find out. It's fantastic!!!

Constantly Harrased!!. My family and I went and it was a horrible experience had by us all... Although for me it was to be expected... And we were warned back at the hotel that it wasn't the best place to visit.. ESP with children! From the moment we arrived we were being bullied and intermediated into paying for a tour guide to take us around the souks!.,I loss count of the amount of times we said "NO".. We don't want one!!... At which scare tactics was used to try and make us change our mind!. The market traders were just as bad!.. Trying to sell things at ridiculous over priced amounts!.. And when we showed no interest in buying they then became quite aggressive!.,Half hour into the visit my Mum wanted to go!..and my 7 yr old niece was crying and scared!. We cut our visit short and returned to the hotel... Overall the souks is overpriced and too much aggressive behaviour for my liking!. Would never go back!... Found a more civilised, less hassled and cheaper place to shop!.. Called Plaza (Modern City)

marrakech magic. We, ovec hanging out in the medina which came to life T night given we were there during Rammadam. The food stalls, restaurants, snake charmers, musicians, hat twirlers, monkeys, dancers, henna painters, you name it you will see it there. No rude or offensive traders and a real positive energy about the place. Go! Enjoy!
Busy. A square with lots of stalls, mainly Orange juice. And plenty of encouragement from the stall owners to buy there stuff!

Have to go but only once. I guess its a must see. Its the main square,a tourist trap and one of the ways into the souks.expect almost continual harassment to eat,buy,pay for photos etc. its tiring when you cant just observe it without five people per step demanding your attention and money.

Stall No. 26 - Food VERY Ordinary (unhygenic) and touts a nuisance. The touts rush at you from everywhere even when you let them know you are not interested. Don't be fooled into thinking that the bread and olives placed on the table are free - THEY are NOT and are added onto the end of the bill. Also make sure you know the total of the food you have eaten/ordered because they will try to add on extra dirhams making out it was an adding up mistake. NO Health and Safety and Unhygenic practices- We found out that the food is not prepared on order, but is prepared beforehand and is brought into the market for sale where it sits in the hot sun and breeds bacteria. We also saw where one of the waiters emptied a dish of salsa, which had been left on a table, back into the big serving bowl that they were dishing out for new orders. Makes you wonder what other practices they have.

Quintessential Marrakech!. The Marrakech of the moies lives here! Make sure to go in the daytime and also at night, it changes drastically between the two. Plan for at least few hours here and there so you have time to wander, and also to sit at one of the outdoor cafés and watch the world go by.Don't want to tell you much more...it is a constantly changing, loud and exciting place, and full of surprises.
Jemaa el Fna. Very interesting cultural experience but a little overwhelming having to worry about picketpockets on mopeds and everybody wanting money to take a picture.

Don't trust the monkeys.... Just kidding. One of the Moroccans told us they pick pocket...While that's possible it definitely didn't happen to us. The Jmaa was definitely interesting but sadly we found it extremely touristic compared to Fes and they definitely carried much more of the Chinese junk than the soukhs in Fes and Meknes. The food vendors and juice stands are definitely worth seeing and tasting...My only real gripe is that I got tired of being called "Ali Baba".

Love it. I never tire of the sqaure - it is so entertaining even though it is pretty touristy. Great to wander around day or night. I have found the henna women to be a bit of pain - one grabbed me arm and starting painting henna on my wrist without permission - I stopped her and refused to pay!! I also encoutnered a bit of groping one night whilst watching some story tellers in the square. I also have an issue with the dancing monkeys which should not be allowed. Sounds awful I know, but it has not put me off the square and i visit Marrakesh often. Despite the odd incident it's a vibrant, great place to visit.

The square is great, avoid contact with acrobats.. found this place to be lot of fun, I even tried to eat at one of the stalls, I didnt suffer from any illness, that was a good sigh after lot of thinking. The problem is the fake acrobats and charmers... they all do what they do for money, I noticed lot of locals gets in a circle and watch but nobody ask them to pay; but once a tourist get closer , one of the players would jump with his hat asking for money, - That's if you dont take a picture- if you do!! you'll be in troubles bargaining and yelling...The square is a must to see, but would be better to cross it and go to one of the terrace and watch the whole thing from up.

Mad but great fun. Once we had found our bearings we had great fun sauntering through the stalls picking up bargains. Very hot day but nice and cool under the roof. Everyone polite and not pushy at all, seen worse on Bury market.

Enchanting to the senses. This square comes alive at around 5pm every night. Lots of little food stalls appear. Set up like restaurants, full menus with fresh food cooked on the spot. Each stall has a number. I ate at number 1, 2 nights. Food was amazing, cheap and the wait staff extremely funny and loved a joke. Learn how to say please, thankyou, yes and no in arabic and you will have some fun. The square pumps with entertainers, boxing, betting, tarot readers, snake charmers and henna ladies. Everyone wants to sell you something, they will touch you, yell out at you and tell you how beautiful your eyes are. A smile and easygoing nature will get you through this square. Don't take offence, don't get angry, accept it for what it is and you will love it. Please be wary that if you do take a photo of any "entertainer" you will need to donate some cash. I felt safe here until about 10:30pm, after that for me, the atmosphere seemed to change and being by myself seemed not a great idea. Don't eat the seafood in Marrakech, its not as fresh as the other meats etc. I went to this square every night in Marrakech - I loved it.

Loved it!. visited here twice on our 3 day visit, so different, loved the sights, the smells and the sounds of the Square, especially the entertainers with the bird on his head ( thought it was stuffed til it flapped its wings and landed on the floor after their show! )They will charge for photos but a few dirhams is enough and you will also be given a stool to watch the show too!Had no problems with snake charmers, monkeys or henna ladies, a smile and a no thank you was enough!

At least once.. The interesting thing about the Jemaa el Fna is that there are probably more Moroccans there than tourists. Moroccans come from all over the country to spend part of their holiday in Marrakech , just for the the Jemaa el Fna.

City's Pulse.. Love it or Hate it, this is where the action is.I particularly enjoyed watching the spectacle unfold from a balcony as Ramadan finished..about 7.40 pm while I was there.The fast finished and the eating began. A real buzz in the air

Crazy. We had prepared before going to the Jemaa el Fna, reading about all the schemes going on there. Still, after 15 minutes at the square we had been tricked into getting a big, poorly done, henna tattoo, had a snake and a monkey on our shoulders and had arabic dancers performing around us. It cost us a lot of dihrams, so our first tip whn going to Jemaa el Fna is; bring coins! The way they insisted on getting payed for theire services( wich we didnt ask for ) is really hard to say no to if you havent been there before. We had to escape to a roof top cafe to breathe for a while and laugh about it all. There is so much to see and smell, it unbelievable. You have to see experience it both day and night to really see it all. There is a lot of shops there, so you can get almost anything you want. Food in the tents at night are really good and cheap.There are a lot of beggars and hustlers there, who are "on" you all the time, trying to get you to buy something or give them money. We found that sometimes it was best to pretend that we didnt hear them.If you are in Marrakech, you really shouldnt miss this.

The best quare in Africa. Go there at any time of the day or night. Get yourself some fresh orange juice, it's safe ! Snack around in the evening, snails are very much OK, soup (watch out for the 2 or 3 dedicated stalls) is excellent. Grilled meat or fish where ever you like, I prefer stall number one (Aïcha), been there numerous times and it never failed on me.

You've got to see it .... ... but you may be disappointed.Perhaps my expectations were too high ... perhaps the weather was not good enough to enjoy it ... but I thought Jemaa el Fna is vastly overrated.Lots of very basic food stalls, but none of it particularly inviting and you can't walk 2 feet without a new hustler appearing. And as for the the rest ... loads of people wandering about aimlessly hoping something of interest was about to happen

A must see!. Beware, this is not for the faint hearted. You will see beggers, snake charmers and monker tamers, all after your money. But remember you can say no. The colours, smells and atmosphere of this square are unbelievable. You cannot comprehend them unless you have been there. A must see for all travellers to Marrakech.

The essence of Marrakech. Jemaa al Fna is the hub of the medina and cannot be missed. Highlights are the wonderful orange juice vendors and, as evening falls, the street food.
