The vendors engage in the most creative of promotional pitches in competing for diners' favours (they know all the celebrity chefs and supermarket advertising slogans) and your experience is so much enhanced by stopping to engage in lively discussion with them rather than simply fending off their advances. Dining at one of the stalls instead of the restaurants around the square, you get to experience life as a Marrakchi. The "pigeon charmer" seemed to be the most popular entertainment of all. Watch out for the overly aggressive Henna ladies who will grab and tattoo you without permission! Everything else is pure spectacle!
haggling!. great for atmosphere! good to haggle, great comments from stall holders i.e, "cheaper than asda!" then hand you your goods in a tesco carrier bag!

Not for the fainthearted - be brave!. Mad enough during the day, the square comes alive at night. Don't let anyone put a snake around your neck, or a monkey on your shoulder, unless you want to part with some cash for the privilege. But once you get the hang of saying no, this is such an exciting place! One of my all-time favourite experiences. Watch out for motorbikes!
Like a market. Disappointed we did not see snake charmers. Watch out for beggars. Good place to haggle for clothing, souvenirs.

Hmmm. Most for tourist!. Big Square! Yes, and their are snakes, monkeys and place to shop souvenirs and cheap orange juice (4 Dh, great offer and taste), but most people at the place are like you, tourist looking at things and tourist! Go instead for sightseeing and shopping in the souq/Medina.

Something attractive for every one, young and old people. I like the snake enchanter. The man with the monkeys, the places where they sell orange juice, during the day. The regional attire of the vendors of water. How do they tried to fish inside bottles to win a prize( on the nights)Jemaa el Fna changes from the day to the night.Perhaps is more crowded during the night.
Beautiful and lively place.. Pick one of the cafes around the square, pay for the overpriced soda and enjoy the view. You can see all the buzz of the square getting ready for the night market.
magic place. the placa jemaa el fna its a great place its awesome.you will spend amising time there with all kind off peopls and from all the world .and alot of the sorts of musics and foods.
Must see. Place Jemaa el Fna is a must see when you are in Marrakech. On sale is all kinds of stuff but the main reason to visit is the atmosphere and the beautiful sights.

Not my cup of mint tea. Opinion on this site is divided between those who find the square an amazing and life-enhancing spectacle, and those who find it a squalid and frightening trap dedicated to the fleecing of tourists. We went after dark with open minds as fairly experienced travellers, expecting plenty of in-your-face hassle and ready to deal with it but taken aback by the aggression of the hustlers and their menacing hostility when rejected. We tried our best to see what the famous Marrakech buzz was all about, but there was little joy or charm in seeing scrawny animals abused to provide picture opportunities for tourists. Above all, the square is not for the faint-hearted. It is full-on bedlam: shrieking noise, choking dust and heat, surging crowds, throbbing drums, roaring motor scooters charging through the throng, and the incessant tugging at your arm by children and fake guides and strident demands for baksheesh. Amid this cacophony Arab bands play what sounds interesting and distinctive music and other talented performers catch the eye, but if you stop and try to listen or take a picture you will be surrounded in an instant by intimidating characters demanding large sums of money. Now, many people say they find this great fun and the highlight of their holiday and so forth. But I just didn’t get it. To me, whatever charm and interest there might have been in the square has long since been replaced by a cynical and ruthless fleecing operation in which every tourist is seen as fair game. As for the fabled tourist police who were meant to calm all this madness down, we never set eyes on them. To put this in perspective, it has to be remembered that most Moroccans get by on very little, and perhaps it is naïve to imagine that Western tourists toting expensive cameras won’t be seen as a meal ticket, especially when – as other posters have said – the tourists are there to take pictures of how the poor Moroccans amuse themselves. So, it didn’t do it for me, although I was glad I went to see it (and even gladder to get out in one piece). Yet the Moroccans in the square are not at all representative of the rest of the city: in our hotel, and in the new city and elsewhere, we found genuine friendliness, great courtesy and real charm. Away from the square, Marrakechis are delightful people. Perhaps it’s no different from saying that a crowd of English lager louts are hardly representative of the English as a whole. Still, if you want to live dangerously and feel your hair stand on end, don’t miss a visit. Hang on to your wallet, though. And I am aware many will take the opposite view and say I am missing the whole point of it.

Must see. Unique. Vibrant, crowd, different of everything we have in the western world. You will see things that you may not like (animal cruelty, begging for money for everything, people trying to cheat you..) but that's exactly the reasons we should experience. Good to visit a couple of days and experience the marroco culture.

Exciting!!. This square has everything from snake charmers to a dentist! We got some good pictures of the performers but be careful they don't try to take to much money from you. The henna tattooists will have a design from the tip of your finger to the top of your shoulder in seconds if they get hold of your arm, so try to watch out for that. Barter for everything and don't be afraid to walk away, chances are you'll get it even cheaper then!

nice place to disconnect from city. nice place to disconnect from city specialy at night , whith the heat during the day its hard to apprecit the place.by night many restaurents are set in the middle of jamaa el fna with different choices of food.people will try to get you to their tables by screaming don't woory about it its normal there try to find one guy where you will come back more often during yourstaying.prices are aproxm the same and they are shown next to the food.please verify your bill at the end and ask for detailed prices sometimes mistakes happenafter your meal whats best is a cup of tea in one of rhe cafee aroud the placeenjoy your visit

Overwhelming. Walked through during the day and at night with the tour guide. Happy to do just that. I found the place overwhelming: trying to walk among the crowds, look at the wares, take pictures, keep track of purse and mind bumping into others or being honked by motorbikes, is too much at once for a long, hot, smoke-filled walk through.
Crazy Place. Visit the square at night and take in the noises, smells and what appears to be chaos. No other place like it
Marrakech never again. Animal cruelty, people asking for money for everything, even looking, culture of tips on every corner, was happy to leave

Nothing like this the first night. Upon arrival, especially if you are staying in the old town medina area, the walk to the Jemaa el Fna in the evening and then the opening out into that square is an experience that can never be forgotten and probably not replicated. The seeming madness, excitement, smells, sounds. Amazing!
fna square. excellent at night always lively and worth the wait
what a different world. brilliant experience .. you must get used to the haggling and the hassle you get with people trying to sell things but thats part of the whole experience.

Busy, smelly, fun, annoying, fascinating, etc.. That is how it is. I thought the food was good, it was fun to sit and eat while watching the people. But many restaurants serve just as good or better food. The henna women running around, trying to paint on you and boys trying to place a monkey on your shoulder are very, very extremely annoying and have no respect for a no, thanks at all. I also felt really bad for the monkeys, horses, donkeys, snakes, etc. But watching people perform with song, music, dance, etc. was nice :) It's a cliché, but fun to have seen it :)

Brillaint experience. So many different things to see like the snake charmers and different types of music but seeing the monkeys on leads were upsetting. The market stalls were brilliant, bartering was fun but the men that owned the stalls could be really pushy and sometimes intimidating.
Do It Once. It has been described as "absurd madness" and that it is. But you have to see experience it or you haven't seen the heart of Marrakech.

Very diverse square, but come prepared. If you come to Marrakech, you must visit Jemma el Fna ( also spelled Djamaa El Fna) main square. We saw everything from people with monkeys and snakes hanging about, to a man who you could pay to pull your teeth right then and there. However, come to this square prepared. We knew that immediately we would be targeted to receive "gifts" from the sellers here -- a "free" palm reading "gift" in exchange for a "gift" of our money. Even taking a photo of a snake charmer will cause someone to come up to you asking for money. Only take people up on their offers if you plan to pay them -- if they put a snake around you neck, say no thank you and walk on unless you want to shell out some cash. And if you do take them up on their offer for that much-needed photo of you with a family of monkeys on your shoulders, only offer 1/3 of the price they are asking. Sure that story about their family starving sounds convincing, but it simply isn't true. Once you get past these slightly overwhelming first impressions of the square, you will have a great time. Enjoy the culture that is Marrakech!

Goat heads on sticks. Jemaa el Fna was like finding myself walking through a movie. I could not believe I was in such a mysteriously different place while in Jamaa el Fna. This is definitely not a trip for the faint hearted!While visiting Jemaa el Fna, I saw many things which confused me including cooked goat heads on sticks lined up in front of chairs, amazingly beautiful crafts, fresh squeezed orange juice for .40 USD, and a monkey riding a horse through a tunnel.

Fascinating place. It is here in the heart of the old city of Marrakech that one can see so much life both during the day and more so at night.Watching the entertainment from the local people ranging from dancers,snake-charmers as well as others is enchanting. There are also the market stalls and plenty of places to eat and drink.I recommend the terrace of Cafe Glacier for the best vantage point for photographers who want to catch the action without your subjects being aware of you because down in the square the demands for payment for having pictures taken can be quite expensive by the time you have finished.The trip by taxi to and fro from lodgings to the square is very resonable at all hours. my friend and I who are two females found it very safe to wander around this area alone as long as you keep your wits about you.Highly recommended.
What an experience. Definitely worth a trip day and night.Stall # 14 for fish - superbAnd you must have fresh orange juice
awesome madness. crazy but fun. Definitely a high light at nightime when its buzzing

A unique experience.. All what i expected to see was there; Snake charmers, Apes, Dancers, Food stalls. However, as a young blonde English girl, i got extremely hassled, But i just said "La Shukran" a lot and it seemed to deter many, Find a nice bar over looking the square for a time out. Its a must see. I loved it.

Eat dinner here!. It's a little intimidating but SO worth it!! also: If someone tries to henna your hand, pull your hand back and tell them you are allergic, otherwise they will scream at you for $30 for about 15 seconds of scribbling on your paw! (unless that seems like a deal to you, and then go for it)

Amazing Spectacle. Every visit to Marrakech will include the Jemaa almost by default, but to really see it in all of its glory it's best to go after the sun sets. In the hot summer months the incredible festivities really get into full swing only after 10:00pm, and last for many hours!!!

This is where it all happens. Best seen at night when all the locals meet to discuss thier day and sell anything to us disurning foreigners. Snake charmers, stilt walkers, men with monkeys (not nice), stall with over priced wares. Children running around bare foot with hand out stretched makes it all what is, Marrakesh.
Interesting Marketplace. This place hasn't changed since I first visited it in 1955. It's an authentic experience of old Morocco. Not to be missed.

The bustling big square. There's always something happening but the square gets really lively around dusk when the food stalls are being set up. There are great places, on the perimeter, for people watching!
The main attraction of Marrakesh. Lively, central square of Marrakesh. Loads going on with snake charmers and henna artists and storytellers. Best time to visit is late evening.
Not to be missed.. The heart of Marrakech medina. Incredibly charming at night, with the smoke from the food stands enveloping torists and locals alike. Beware of pickpocketers.

An experience so far removed from the UK. The sights are so unusual like 4-5 people on a moped etc the sights and sounds are so differant from the UK snake charming etc, The only thing we did not care for in a temperature of 40-44 C a few of the small carts with quite a heavy load with only one donkey were never seen to have a drink. we saw some with their tongues hanging out

incredible, noisy, unique. Incredible place, go there for an evening dinner. restaurant 114 was ok (not the greatest food we had but an amazing atmosphere.Be careful with the very aggressive women who tried to sell us a henna tattoo 'for free'.

Tourist trap. Yes, you will go there -- every tourist who visits Marrakech does -- but it's not that great. I really felt it was mostly a show for tourists. You can get much better, more authentic food than was served in the stalls. And cleanliness is a concern with the glasses and dishes you are using. (Think about how they are cleaning them.) Some in our group who ate there got sick. Don't walk through the food area unless you like getting insults yelled at you when you don't stop. The snakes and monkeys looked pathetic, and I felt sorry for them. When you go, I advise going to one of the restaurants surrounding the square that has a 2nd floor outside seating area. Go upstairs, buy something to drink, and sit outside watching the activity in the square below. You can take all the pictures you want of the entire scene. If you go about 30 minutes before sunset you can get some great photos. Then go somewhere else for dinner.

Bitten by one of the MONKEYS!!!!!. I was taken here by my guide and at first enjoyed some of the antics.. I agree that it is total harassment for money, but the worst was that the guys that force the monkey on you and then take a picture. A monkey bit me on my face and I had to come home early from my trip. Monkeys can carry a fatal virus and I have had to take a ton of medication and have tests done. I have heard that they have tried to get these monkeys banned, but the government will not do anything about it. Very dangerous!!

Be Careful. Almost everyone here expects to be paid, be it taking a picture or asking directions and a substantial sum too.I was asked for 100 dirham’s for the privilege of a monkey being thrown on my back; needless to say I did not pay.You are chased by different people trying to sell you stuff or simply asking you for money for taking a picture of them but a simple smile and ''La Shukran'' (No Thank-You) has a positive effect and makes roaming the square much easier.I prefer the square at night as there is food stalls set up and some good food to be had but again you are beleaguered by almost every stall to eat at theirs and their comments can be offensive if you decline but with a little common sense and humor you will prevail.

Come Hungry, Leave Happy. I'll admit to borrowing the title of my review from a U.S. restaurant commercial, but it's the first thing that comes to mind when I remember Djemaa el Fna. As a resident of New York City, I call this crazy public plaza "The Times Square" of Marrakesh, with heart, soul, public performance, music, great people-watching, and of course, the food stalls. You can't visit Marrakesh without coming here. By sunset, over one hundred food stalls have set up, and it's really great to wander the aisles and marvel at all the culinary offerings. I like to sample as many as I can, so I order one dish from one stall, then move to another. There are stalls that offer a wide variety of Moroccan dishes, and others that specialize in one food group (the 'meat' stall was unnerving but delicious---cow tongue, brains, innards, etc.!). Be specific when ordering, because they may try to serve you more than you want. Also, be aware that bread, olives, etc. are all extra charges. And if someone from the stall offers to take your picture (with your camera), be assured that they will ask for money. Save room for the dessert carts that come up and down the aisles. After dinner, wander the square and catch the crazy energy of performers and musicians. As a single female traveler, I felt perfectly safe here, even at night, but as always in a crowded big city, take care with your belongings. I did not worry about eating the food, either. Bon appetit!
overrated. boring food . harrassed by everyone. animal cruelty. thousands of tourists. worst aspect of the Marrakech i love. everytime you stop to even look they chase you for money. a place to avoid

Overwhelming. We found this plaza interesting but a bit intense, especially if you go there without a guide. There is a lot to see. Do NOT take pictures of anyone unless you are prepared to pay. I was practically attacked by a man with a monkey after I took a picture of his back, while I was walking by.
jemasa el fna. not to be missed day or night but particularly at night comes to life with thousands of people.
Very different. Good but odd place i think the fotos on site say it all. Its like going back a thousand years.
Interesting. Although crowded, it was a typical souk. Lots of interesting activity of daily life going on all around you.

Seedy. Seedy and felt dangerous and threatening. Not a sympathetic place. Go without any bags, cameras etc. and with empty pockets. We followed our own advice and encountered no problems, but found no merits...

Get ready to feel like you are going back on time!. I'd imagine the medina has changed very little since its first establishment. Going here mademe feel very immersed in the local culture. There are side shows happening everywhere you look, food being cooked up, henna tattoo artists, you name it! This sight is something that will stay with you forever! Not to be missed, but just watch your belongings and be ready to haggle and stand up for yourself! Also, try to be inconspicuous when taking pictures of people or otherwise agree to a price beforehand, because they will run up and demand a crazy amount of money from you! Just expect that kind of behavior going in and you won't have any nasty surprises!

real morrocan culture. If u want to get closer to morrocan culture and arts u must spend a lot of time there; listen to different kind of musics; storry tellers; Snakes trainers; and much more....its crowdy, lot of smells "due to the food installs"; i dont recommend eating there; but try the unique orange juice

wild!. What a difference between day and night! At night, it's a scene with monkeys, snake charmers, musicians and some of the best food (so cheap!) we had in Morocco, really excellent grilled meats, etc. Just be careful not to get too close to the snake charmers or monkeys unless you're willing to pay up (have also heard of monkeys biting) Our guide warned us that they will put a snake on your and walk away if they don't get the $ they want, so beware!

PLACE TO EAT. At one stall we had our dishes selected for us which was way too much. Most of the food was left! Was this a ploy? When they gave us the bill instead of paying the 460 dirhams, I just gave them 400. Don't let them rule.Stall No 1 is excellent.

BUSY BUSY. Amazing and Busy... look out for the motor bikes, monkeys, carriages, people! Remember if you want to take photos of the water sellers, snake charmers etc they will expect money, pay them no more than 10dirhams

Wow. What an amazing place, full of people , good natured bustle , snake charmers, jugglers, water sellers, fresh orange juice stalls [no alcohol sold publicly] mesmeric drummers, fire eaters, what wasn't there?

Great experience! . We headed out at about 11am and when we arrived we were relieved that it wasn't too busy, the square itself was relatively quiet with a few snake charmers, orange juice vendors and lady's doing henna. As we headed into the souqs we were not as intimidated as we anticipated after reading other reviews. we expected to be hassled and in a crowded hot bustling market but that wasn't the case. I really enjoyed looking at the stalls but most contain the same items, lanterns, scarfs, shisha, kaftans, cooking pots, jewellery and we decided after walking for an hour that we had seen everything. We returned to the square at night and ate at the night market which I would definitely recommend! The main meals are 30 dirhams! A fraction of the price of most restaurants!Would definitely recommend this cultural experience at the heart of Marrakech!

Monkeys on chains, and unpleasant folk. Yes the place bustles with energy and noise, it's colourful and enticing with its orange juice stalls and entertainers...BUT scratch the surface, look closely and wonder how great is it to see monkeys chained, snakes thrust upon people, aggressive and abusive henna women? It's an experience.

Snake charmers, orange juice and henna tattoos. Jemaa el Fna Square is a beautiful assault on the senses, filled with color, sound and energy. Have dinner in one of the restaurants upstairs looking down on the square at sunset - the views are amazing!

Really big. i liked the monkeys and snakes but do not take pics of the snakes cause the guys will come after you and follow you and ask you to give them more money, it's very easy to get lost so be careful who you ask for help
Traditional. A great way of experiencing the old traditional morocco.

Souks!. Barter galore here! Alaways give the sales guy a ridiculously low price you are willing to pay so he knows you are not going to be mugged. Persist and eventually they will sell it to you!. There is a KFC there if you fancy and the La Marrakechi restaurant is a great place to eat for around 8pm. Over looks the whole square and you have singers and belly dancers for entertainment

It's all true!. The labyrinths souks will either drive you insane or you will grow to love them. There are so many beautiful and interesting articles one can purchase at the souks, but the bartering could become a bit exhausting for the inexperience. I will give the same advise most people offer here. If you find something you like. Set in your mind the price you feel comfortable paying for it, and stick to your price. If no agreement is made, move on. You will find something else more interesting and probably better.

Wear Tennis Shoes and Carry a Big Camera. This main square of Marrakech is a cross-roads for people of northern Africa, Europe, and all points east and west. I liked thinking about all the import and export that must have taken place here over the centuries. There were water-carriers, snake charmers, and water sellers, to name a few. I f\you need to try a few local acitivities on this square, drink freshly sqeezed orange juice or have your hand "tattoed" with henna.

Wild and Exotic. You can't go to Marrakesh and miss this! Snake charmers in the early evening go home after dark and then things get busy. Dancers, story tellers, men with monkeys on leashes....Outdoor food stands... You never know what you will see. Just watch your pockets!

Street party. Very busy - fun to sit in a square side cafe to watch the buzz. Eat the the night market! It's a great experience. Ladies, keep your hands in your pockets if you don't want henna on them. Lots of mobile stalls set up to sell various bits. Go to the cafe Le Grand Balcon du Café Glacier it has the best views of the square by far.

Chaos but good. You have to visit here with everything all around you. Snake charmers - performers - even someone to sell you false teeth. It is something to see and don't feel forced into buying just be firm and soak the atmosphere up. Relax in the Cafe De France with a coffee and watch the world below unfold , enjoy a meal cooked before you in the market finished of with a fresh orange juice from one of the many stalls.
Great walk. Walk carefully :) especially near snakes because someone can put it around your neck :) even thou this snake are not dangerous feeling can be pretty shock!
Amazing square. We've eated there several times in the middle of the square, would recommend N° 14 if you enjoy fish

How could you miss it?!. To me if you go to marrakech and don't even walk through jemaa el fna its like you haven't been- where did you go!? Visit in the day and at night- watch everyone arrive from a roof top restaurant. Full of great food stalls, henna tattooists, snake charmers, monkeys, story tellers, orange juice stands... embrace and enjoy

Stress free in the Souks. We were worried about hassle, but if you say a polite "no thanks, I'm not interested" they leave you alone. When bartering, don't start too low - these people need a sale, don't take the mickey out of them, be respectful and offer what you feel is a decent price for them and for you. If you can't agree then go elsewhere. Take time to think of their lives and to take in all the beautiful colours, sounds and smells. Go deep into the Souks where the Moroccans do their daily shopping for a real experience.

Can be scary at night. Very exciting place. Very different to anythig I have seen before. Visit and be confident. Don't feel intimidated, it is noisy and there are hundres of people, locals as well as tourists. Enjoyed the experience. went back in the daylight but not as atmouspheric during the day.

Chaotic but brilliant. You can't go to Marrakech without visiting here. It is livelier in the evening with snake charmers, musicians, open-air restaurants and stalls selling everything. You do get hassled a lot but "La, shukran" (No thanks in Arabic) seems to work. Don't buy a monkey.
Wild and wonderful. snake charmers by day, great food stalls and belly dancing by night.
the pearl of Marrakech. If you go to Marrakesh and don't visit Jemaa el Fna you weren't int Marrakesh. A real experience from the busy Medina to fulfill all your senses.

Maybe two weeks of arguing pricing was just getting me down. So much of the same, same but different. Where was the exotic thrilling sights. 42 orange stands and everything seemed and little tired and dirty.

amazing experience but be careful. Amazing experience and a must see but people are too pushy and try to rip you off! If you are buying anything always offer them half of what they start to offer you. Haggle is the word. People say no pressure but if you say no they seem to get worse. There is a street off the main square where there is a lot less hassle (if you stand with your back to the souk it is on the far left hand side). In the day time there are snake charmers and monkey handlers as well as fortune tellers and henna tattoo ladies, be careful as they will talk to you and say you can take pictures then ask you for a lot of money. With the monkeys and the snakes the owners will just put them on you so if you are not up for it keep a distance. There are juice stalls everywhere which are really cheap and nice and refreshing in the heat. At night the square becomes an amazing place for eating. Make sure you choose things off the menu rather than letting them as it can become quite pricey with way to much food. In the souk make sure you can always see the way out, there are so many amazing things to look at but you can get trapped! There are people who work in the square and offer to show you around, these people are just trying to get you to buy items off there brother, son, sister etc. Once you have bought something there will be another stall that you HAVE to see, but try not to get sucked in.There are horse and cart rides which leave from the main square which are worth a go, just agree on a price before you set off. I would recommend going at night as its lovely to see everywhere lit up and is a lot cooler than the day.Its well worth going in the day and at night as it looks like a different place. Just be careful not to get ripped off!

Tourist Beware!. Before I went to Marrakech, I did my homework and thought I was prepared. My family and I were dissapointed. The snake charmers hounded us. The henna artists lie and cheat you. My daughter fell for "pay what ever you want" and then the henna artist wanted to charge her $30 dollars. The vendors in the market place hound you after getting a price from them. They will follow you and practically yell at you when you don't buy from them. Bad experience over all. Won't be going back to Morocco.
Full on. Go to the square around 7pm for the cultural experience of your life
The square. Gives you a real taste for what Marrakech is all about. Best time to go September -May. Uk sommer months average 40-47c

Hard to get your head around- not sure how I felt. We went there in the morning and returned in the evening- both totally different experiences. In the morning there was more space to investigate and haggle for locally made merchandise, but animals are treated terribly. In the evening it was intoxicating with the sights and smells but scarey with the huge throngs of people- I was groped by man who walked closely past me and my friend was harrassed with henna. I'm glad I went but I won't return.

Take a chill pill, gather up your courage and it'll be an experience. Probably one of the most amazing and annoying places in Morocco. First of all what not to do; don't take photos of the snake charmers or water carriers (even from far away) and think they won't notice and hassle you for payment; don't let the henna artists (ladies dressed in Burkas) even put the smallest dab on you and think it'll be free; don't let anyone guide you anywhere and think that they'll take you to where you want to go (you'll end up in a shop or restaurant... just on the way...); don't eat anything that isn't thoroughly cooked (hepatitas A is prevalent in Morocco) and don't drink the orange juice and think you won't get sick... All this said, I love the square and think it's just amazing. So take a chill pill, gather up your courage and it'll be an experience!
Worth a visit!. Make time to just chill out and soak up the atmosphere here, it's wonderful!

One of the best places to eat, shop, & people watch in Morocco. This place is alive day and night, but especially at sunset and beyond. There's so much to see and do that your head will spin. Just keep your cool and tip the performers, snake charmers, and anyone else whose picture you take (ask them first) and then shop until your bags are full. Or, watch everyone else shop until their bags are full. Dinner starts around 7 and the food stalls/seating areas get full by 8. There is a lot to choose from, so take your time and look around to see whose food and stall looks cleanest and freshest. Definitely get fresh orange juice! Only 4 dirham and it tastes amazing. There are 30* vendors to choose from but they are all good. Ladies, cover your head if you want to not stick out like a tourist. This is a great place to sit and get elaborate henna tattoos, ESP at night when it's not so hot and you can sit and people watch while your henna dries.

Just "Authentic". It the most Authentic place i have ever seen. There are lots of activities in Jemaa el Fna. The best time to visit here is after 18:00. Square starts to get crowded at these hours.You should taste local foods. Bargain is a rule to shop in Maroc so always bargain before u buy someting.* Just be carefull while u walking near monkies and snakes. They throw the snakes on to you and they dont remove it until you pay them.- Drinking cafee in big restaurants may be risky there was an terrorist attack to one of these cafe's in 2010

A wild cross-cultural experience. Relatively calm during the day, the plaza becomes a six ring circus at night. Grab a seat in one of the nearby upstairs restaurants and soak it all in. If you take a photo of a snake charmer, expect to pay or be chased down by his snake wielding assistant. No kidding!
Go For the Orange Juice & Night Life. Fresh squeezed o.j. ($0.50 USD) is refreshing on a hot day. Also go at night for the circus-block-party atmosphere.
too crowded. too crowded, too many people trying to get money out of you,example, wrapping snakes around your neck without your permission
Heart of city!. Make sure you agree on a price first! Haggle, enjoy the maze of surrounding souks, food at night and get up on the rooftop terraces to watch the world go by below!

The place to feel Marrakesh. There are actually two places. It's the same but the day and the night makes it as if they were two.In the day, you can understand the topography of the city better. You cn take pics with monkeys, snakes etv. Don't forget to drink natural fruit squeezed juices. In the night, it is a concert of sounds and smells, a tourbillon of people, the chaos of the city in all its splendor. Beware of pickpockets and beggers but except this, enjoy the deep and true Marrakesh.

A must see attraction in Marrakech but.... Definitely the heart of the city, there is something for everyone here. The smells, sights and noise of the square is something to see. Restaurants are around the outside that offer great views of the square if you want to get above the chaos. I would have rated this a 5 if it wasn't for a little Monkey and henna tattoo incident. Be aware when walking through the square, especially the middle. At one point monkey's were thrown on my wife and I no matter how much we told them we weren't interested. The owners would then demand a ton of money. A lady covered head to toe in traditional islamic clothing also grabbed my wife's hand and started applying a Henna Tattoo with our her consent. When we pleaded that we didn't have any money yet (which we didn't) she said it would be free. Her story changed after she was done and started to demand money. If we would have known about these things happening we would have been more vigilent in the square but we didn't. With the exception of those two incidents the square is an amazing place and worth seeing. Walking around the outside, near the restaurants, would keep you away from the monkeys as well.

Superb atmosphere. We ate at the market on a night time, the atmosphere is electric, be prepared there are loads of touts getting you to try there stall, be patient, look around and when you get seated order off the menu the food you want, be clear how many and send back anything you didn't order, there trick is to bring you a pile of food and you just accept this. Apparently stalls 1&14 don't do this! Enjoy the experience

Transposed into another world. Yes very touristy and lots of guys trying to get something out of you but still an amazing place retaining great local feel and ambience. I just love the buzz of this place.
A must see. Crowded but very nice place where you can see snakes and moroccan musiciens
Busy noisy and vibrant. Eat at the fish stall in the evening - its packed with locals who obviously know best, and they do.

Chaos in colour. I love the madness of the square everytime I visit Marrakech. Its should be a must on your visit list and especially at night-time when it comes alive. Visit Stall No 1 run by a charismatic lady called Aisha for great food.

It wouldn't be Marrakech without it.. Yes, you will get ripped off. Yes, the Henna ladies are aggressive. Yes, you will get animals literally thrown onto you and people will try to charge you for the privilege.......HOWEVER, you will probably never see anything quite like this square in your whole life and you must, must, must go! Accept what comes your way, take it in good humour and appreciate the craziness! During the day you can walk around this square 'reasonably' peacefully, it's only at night that the square really comes alive. Walk around and see snake charmers, monkeys, story tellers, musicians, water sellers, fortune tellers, henna ladies and so much more! Be told to come into a 'five michelin star restaurant with full air-conditioning', look to your left and see a cart with a few metal tables! Expect beggars, expect to see people asleep on the street in the midst of it, expect the unexpected and you won't be surprised! I genuinely cannot sum up the charm of this square and I don't think you can say you've been to Marrakech until you've seen it with your own eyes! Enjoy and be amazed!!!
busy. well its hot and busy, easy to get lost too, all want you to look in there shops, you need to barter too,orange juice from the trader is cheap and refreshing about 35p glass,

The best experience. Wao. I was with my wife in Morocco last week. My suprice lay on the big square of Jemaa el Fna which is one of the best places that I have visited. The snake charmers - the monkey handlers - the story tellers and also the food at night is amazing and delicious.We would like to recommend any one going to Morocco to visit Marrakech and its square.

Crowded and noisy but a great experience !. There are so many odd things to see here....snake charmers, tooth pullers, fortune tellers......plus a bunch of orange juice stands (famous for this square, however the juice we bought was watered down so not as good as we hoped), vendors and restuarants. All the restaurants have rooftop terraces and xou can sit in any one of them and just enjoy the view.

Magical. this square is just bedlam! From the performing snake charmers and fire eaters to the motor bikes wizzing from one end to the other.The atmosphere is amazing but scary especially on a Saturday nite where it is just a maze of thousands of people. You just have to go with it and take it all in.
sight. The mousk was great the gardens were welcept the fountains were off the hole time we wear there drained.
Entertaining. A great way to spend the night strolling and watching the action. Make sure to eat at the stalls set up!

A MUST visit!!. The largest square in Africa is a MUST visit. It is transformed at night when it comes alive. Thousands of people come to experience acrobats, story tellers, snake charmers, henna ladies and so much more.A truley memorable experience.
Cheery Madness. Has to be experienced at least once. Joyful madness that can be a bit exhausting if you are not in the right fram of mind.
magical. this square comes to life at night a wonderful place to visit. A very busy place, expect to be bothered by people but do not let it put you off.

The Heart And Soul Of Morocco. My husband and I arrived on a Sunday where some places are closed but it didn’t seem to make a difference as there was a flurry of activity as we walked around Jemaa-El-Fna. This area has been described as the heart and soul of Morocco where life as it once was still thrives today. The sights and sounds of Jemaa-El-Fna transported us into another time and space, it was magical and captivating. As we walked around the square we saw vendors selling their wares, orange juice vendors (this is the land of great oranges and mandarins after all!), snake charmers (yes men encouraging cobras to come out and perform the dance), henna painters (women in their kaftans or takchitas ready to paint a selection of designs on hands and legs as you wish), musicians, dancers, acrobats and more. Both foreigners and locals alike gravitated towards this square for entertainment at all hours of the day and night. However the true beauty of Jemaa-El-Fna showed itself at night. The square took on an increased intensity and excitement as outdoor food stalls were set up within the square and more people descended towards its centre. It was hard to pass by the food vendors and not sample some of the dishes on offer as the aromas drifted throughout the square. My husband and I were fascinated by the storytellers who were encircled by groups of people enraptured by the stories they were telling. I’m sorry that we couldn’t understand the stories as this is where you will find the heart and soul of Morocco through its folk stories. The people gathered around the storytellers were like children listening attentively wanting to know what comes next in the story. This is what travel is all about - finding authentic places like Jemaa-el-Fna that are still true to its traditions - definitely worth a trip to visit.

It's a Circus. The big square, as the locals call it, is part souk, part restaurant, and part circus. It's a gateway into the souks, and the landmark for getting back out. There are great food stands, with very annoying waiters trying to get you in, and lovely cafes to eat at. And at night, the performers come out; snake charmers, story tellers, monkey handlers, and other sideshow acts. All and all a very entertaining spot all times of the day.
Visit in day and night. Totally different atmosphere day and night loved both Felt safe and able to be assertive when approached by 'guides' to say no or non
so so. I liked the different merchandise, but not the pushy peddlars
Interesting and colorful. A very nice place to go at night (not so late, of course) and a good place to buy some gifts (specially some foulards). A MUST in your trip.
Hustle and bustle!. This is a real attack on your senses. Freshly squeezed orange juice is a must at only 4 dirhams (about 30p). The place is best after dark when it really comes to life
Just for orqnge juice. I love this place as you can have the best orange juice in Marrakesh for 5 Dhs.

The Best Kind of Chaos. The epicentre of Marrakech - comes alive at night. The place is heaving with people and it would be best to leave any valuables at home, but otherwise a amazing experience.We ate at Stall 1 in the square and had a great tapas kind of meal of cous-cous, sausages, kebabs etc. All of which was under a fiver. It was tasty and we didn't suffer for it.The snake charmers can be a it 'hassely', keep a few coins on you to ward them off.
A must see. You can't really visit Marrakech and miss a visit here. Fantastic fun and lots to see
Total mayhem. Avoid men with monkeys as they put them on to you and demand money for a photograph. the animals are filthy!
A genuine cultural experience.. Loved the bustle, the fire, drums, singing, mopeds, horse drawn carriges, selling is an 'as well'. It is a market for locals not just tourists. Also loved the ATM!
don't believe the scare stories. We ate at the street stalls several times and lived to tell the tale! Just make sure you look around first and don't be persuaded into the first stall you pass

Enormous public square, filled with color and activity. At dusk the square was coming alive with snake charmers, food stalls and tooth pullers. The macabre display of human teeth was pretty exotic! A must. This is why you came to Morocco...for the more adventurous traveler.

Interesting. Full of live at night time,it's fun and a must if you are in Marrakech, but there are some "gypsies" that will try to take advantage of you. keep your purse close and be careful with the food that they sell on the street, it's not very clean.
You can not miss it.. Heart of the Old Medinah, have to visit this place both during the day and at nights. Just let yourself go, and get inside the zocos as much as you can.
WOW!. Nothing like it in the world.....get a view from one of the cafe terraces.
This is the place. This is the place, this is the center of all action within Marrakech. This is the place where you really can feel the truly morocco culture.

A crazy square. At night, the square is full of all kind of exhibitions, like men with najas, monkeys and dancers. There's a lot of stalls selling typical food, spices, fruits, etc. I didn't feel safe to eat the local food there. A very interesting and crazy place.
Hustle n Bustle. It was a good paart of the trip. If you opt for the trip with this in it, don't bother because this is where the free shuttle takes you!!

My favourite place in Morocco. My favourite place in Morocco and one of my favourites worldwide. You have it all: the exotic twist, the local people, the tourists, the spontaneity, typical food, the commerce.You can drink a freshly squeezed orange juice from one of the over 50 salesmen, take a photo with a snake around your neck, have a lamb stew for dinner, make a henna tatoo, buy virtually anything (like real teeth...) or just sit and watch the movement at this coloured hotspot.An experience not to be missed.
great place to go during the evening. you should go there to see the musician and danser at night

The heart of the city. Arriving in Marrakech and the first impulse is to go to the famous square. Indeed it is the heart of the city with its extraordinary history behind it. I was surprised by its cleanliness in spite of the multiple street vendors and stalls located around it. I did not imagine it like this.Fresh squeezed orange juice parlors, henna painters and snake charmers are the main attractions during the day, while at night the whole place is revamped with food stalls and dining tables, offering everything possible to eat.Around it is possible to find in te many cafes a shady place to relax and have a drink, or just to watch from above the hassle and buzz of the market.
Spectaculat night market. Many eat points surrounded by attractions in a very friendly atmosphere...definitely great experience (try the local tea!).

Shopping fun!. The markets were a lot of fun, however one day was enough. I expected to be hassled far more. We had a few negative experiences where shop owners demanded money for showing us around despite us not even wanting to come into the store in the first place. But overall we had a great time taking in the sights and doing some shopping. A must do when u visit Marrakech.

Crazy Place. Good place to have dinner at the food stalls. Check out prices first!!! they can be very tricky and over charge you.Nice and crazy place to walk around and buy gifts. Always negotiate prices!!

Amazing!. Such a magical place. We had never seen anything like it. There was some weird and wonderful food to be had. If you're in the area, visit at night time. That's when the madness begins! I can't recommend this place more, just remember to keep an open mind.Oh, and try the orange juice! The onlt thing that I would say is the tourists tend to get targeted for being ripped off. Just be careful with this. I would also say, don't eat any food that you haven't ordered, you will get charged for it! Other than that, it's amazing. Enjoy!
The focal point of Marrakech. A must to visit by day and night. Great food in the evening, be wary of getting too close to the snake charmers/monkeys on ropes in nappies !
Awesome - the only word I have. Different by day and by night - you must come - its a melee of people, monkeys, traders and snakes. Have tea in on of the cafes and watch the world go by....

smaller than expected. I enjoyed the different acts. Didn't try any of the food from the stalls. I was constantly followed around by a henna tattooist who wouldn't take no for an answer, LOL. Fun place. But smaller than I was expecting.
Nice market. Nice place for shops and to see the markets you can see some street shows at night

Visit after 9 pm!. We spent 2 hours (4-6 pm) people watching on a Thursday, then came back for dinner at stall #1 around 7.30 pm, and then returned at 9.30 pm on Friday night. This place is amazing and has to be experienced at different times. The evening was abuzz with locals and activity, and the energy was electric.

Watch out for Snakes!. We went as part of a tour group to the square as I was unsure as to how safe we would be just the two of us wandering around. However I was plesantly surprised and if I ever find myself in Marrakech again I would have no hesitation going alone. The people were all very friendly and so long as you are firm in saying "no" they won't hassle you too much.I would advise that you watch out for the snake charmers, monkeys and henna tattoo ladies as these people are a little harder to shake off. They are however quite easy to spot and avoid should you wish to. (Make sure you speak to a guide or holiday rep about how much you should be paying for things, they do expect you to haggle and if they see you are a touriswt will try and rip you off)!The square it self was a bit barer than I was expecting, however we did you mid afternoon and I have been told that the evening is the time to go as it is cooler and it picks up a bit. I would definitley recommend buying a glass of fresh orange juice from one of the many stalls, at 40p you can't go wrong! If you can get into one of the cafes on the edge of the square as well, most have rooftop terraces which are great for panoramic photo opportunites with a nice view of the Atlas Mountains in the background.Overall worth seeing as it is known as the heart of Marrakech, but there was nothing special there.

A large slice of madness. Snake charmers, henna ladies, orange juice stalls, fortune tellers, all trying to part you from your money with the greatest possible amount of noise!Fantastic fun, slightly wearing

interesting, but. gets going after dark - lots of food stalls, street performers and musicians, snake charmers, water sellers - all out to make a quick buck off the tourists. An inexpertly aimed photograph gets you accosted by people demanding payment.

Unique. The main square is unique and does attract tourists due to the snake charmers and horse drawn carriages, but is not the best part of Marrakech. Personally I dislike the snake charmers but I accept it is tradition and the snakes are well looked after. I was not keen on the monkey's on chains made to perform for tourists so we ignored them and did not give any money to try and stop this practice. The best time to visit this square is at night when it truly comes alive, with many more stalls.

Excellent - Must see!. You have to go to Jemaa el Fna when in Marrakech!! It's so lively - very exciting and the food was the best we'd had all holiday - from little stalls throughout the centre of Jemaa el Fina - and cheap! Snake charmers, people playing music, dancing... but be careful - if you stand and watch for a second, they expect you to pay. Maybe just walk real slow past them whilst looking :)

A fiesta place!. Stalls and various foods all over the place. If you're keen on trying local recipes, Jemaa el Fna is the place to go. The smells and smokes add to the magical atmosphere. It might feel overwhelming in the beginning but one does eventually melt in the crowd and enjoy the one of a kind scene the square offers.
BIG. Get ready for lots of music, snakes, food and getting spoken to. Nothing is for nothing here.
A must. Every time I went there I felt lie I was on a movie set!
strange. One must come there more than once in order to understand what is going there and for what. Coming back from Marrakesh, now I feel it was nice.
Not too keen on this. Too much things going, on and the stalls of food would not reocmmend, there is a KFC quite close if you think you cant do local food. We didnt mind.
An experience. At night the place comes alive with storytellers, snake charmers, food stalls and bars, henna tattoists - its a memorable experience.

Amazing vibe. An amazing place, our first night in Morocco and we walked straight into the hustle and bustle of the square. Thronged with people, with food stalls and musicians. The food is great and so cheap we eat there a couple of nights and the food was as good as some of the upper class restaurants we went to.If your getting photos with the traditional bands or the snake charmers or anything like that, agree a price first and keep small amounts of cash separate or you'll be plagued. You can sit back on the terrace of one of the café's over looking the square and take in the atmosphere over a coffee. Mind your belongings and be firm with the locals and you'll be fine. We met some great locals so don't be put off by the pushy one's.

Ok. It's good to experience, but not for too long. Go to stall #14 if you want good seafood. Brace yourself for intense hassling as you walk the stalls. If you are open to it and have fun with it not too bad. Expect some people to cuss you and harass you if you don't go to their stall. They have a lot of tricks, like saying they remember you and so on. I just play along and say "Yeah we sat next to each other at the Super Bowl," and so on. This catches them off-guard and they let up a little. When people try putting things on you, just throw them off unless you want to give them money. Basically, if you are prepared for tons of people to border-line assault you with some means of getting money out of you, and you go into it with a carefree attitude it will be fine. Otherwise, it will be an experience worth forgetting.
Nightlife to remember. This is one of the most exciting squares in the world. So much to see and to do, if you want to. Henna tattoos, snake charmers,food bars, light and colour
If you like bad food, bad service and being harrased. This is the centre of 'tourist' Marrakech. It is a blot on a wonderful city.

beware the first time. Me and my children were pounced on and fleeced when we first arrived and my son really frightened by all the monkeys that were put on him which scratched and sprained his neck. We ended up paying £10 for this privilege. After the first time it was amazing and we loved it but when you are totally new to it you give off a certain energy and are a target.

Coolest place ever. Best is to go when u are hungry, at around 8pm where everybody is out, the foods stalls are there and bbqs are booming. You will get pressured to eat but dont take it as agression, just have fun with it. We went to Hicham #97, the guys were cool and fun. Its never gonna be great cuisine, but its great fun.sit inside if u dont want to get hassled by beggers abd street sellers, make sure you have paper napkins. Never go out of small change.Very dynamic place, snakes, monkeys, tooth seller, souks, orange juice, henna ladies watch out for them! Have a great time, probably one of the coolest plazas on earth.

So interesting!. We loved the famous Square.. It is very different at day and night. The smell,s the noise, the banter is superb.. I must have been introduced to Jamie Olivers Brother's foodstall a dozen times!A word of advice though, do keep your personal belongings close to you and secure as we did see a couple robbed of thier wallet, but the police soon intervened.

Dreadful place full of dreadful people.. I genuinely have no clue what the people who rate the Jemaa el Fna square well on Trip Advisor are talking about. Reading through the 'Terrible' comments brings back the horrible memories of this place much better.Greedy, agressive, pushy con men and women, purely there to try and rob as many tourists as possible.Horribly abused monkeys and de fanged snakes, all par for the course in a city where people watch their over worked donkeys literally die of thirst and malnutrition in the streets with impunity. Said monkeys and snakes will be thrown on / at you if you accidentally wander near enough, and then of course, money will be demanded with a certain amount of menace for the pleasure.It is physically impossible to enjoy any of the things in the square that might be interesting or pleasurable, because every moment of your time will be spent fending off henna tattooists (Aggressive as pointed out by many others - will grab your hand if you are a girl without asking and start drawing, then demand payment even if you just say 'no' right from the start) men in traditional dress who will demand cash if they are anywhere in your general vicinity if you are foolish enough to try and take a picture of anything, and young men and children who will follow you home a demand yet more cash for .... well, for absolutely nothing.Oh, and the 'hash' (Drug) dealers - lots of those too.Best advice I can give you? Don't bother. But if you must, go in the evening, for half an hour, just to see what I mean, and then do something else - a long way away if possible.
Madness. Loved the madness of the place but disliked the fact that anything you do you generally have to tip ie. asking for a photo to be taken you have to tip the person who takes it.

Fun but be defensive. There is plenty of action in the square. Snake charmers, food peddlers - especially after dark when they grill food for you in the square, monkeys, tooth pullers, etc. They can be extremely pushy and no is not a word they understand. If you are near a monkey the owner will throw it on your shoulder and demand money. An Australian couple we ate with had markings all over their hands. In the square a henna lady started painting the girls hand when she was not looking. The boyfriend had tried to wipe it off and got all smeared with henna. Same with the snakes. They will almost force you to hold the snake and then demand money. The food stalls will try to rip you off by not giving correct change. So get price in advance and have them written down or you are asking to be over charges.The Square is great fun. Several of the restaurants were good and cheap.
Complete Madness, But Fun. With the right attitude this is great fun, but it's best to keep it in small doses.

Great experience. The square dates back to the 12th century. It was sort of entertainment district at the time where story tellers and snake charmers , come to entertain the crowds. This centuries old tradition is still alive one is taken back to the middle ages. During the day it is mainly occupied by orange juice stalls at night it is more lively with food stalls ...etc it is worth a visit at least once.

feel like a movie star. the place is magical, you just need to explore it! its a lot of chaos there, thats true but thats why you can feel like in the middle of movie action.there is everything there-food, artists, snails, monkeys, donkeys, horses, theatres, dancers etc etc etcYou can eat for 3eur amazing dinner, traditional one and have fun at the same time with locals. ok we were 3 girls so sometimes commentaries were quite annoying but on the other side you can still meet strange people everywhere ;)you can spend hours looking at square and its life, the best option is the terrace of one of the coffees shop/ restaurants upstairsyou just cannot miss it

Disappointing. If Jemaa el Fna used to be "magical" to me it seems the magic has been lost. It's such a pity, it could be great, but rather than feeling authentic it just seems like an incredibly overpriced "show" for the tourists, who the locals are keen to fleece of as many dirhams as possible. As others have said, its a pity they badger you for your money constantly as it leads to you not wanting to visit the square or buy anythingat all. A nicer, more welcoming experience would encourage visitors to spend a lot more - of their own free will.

Madness of the city!. The main place to explore - be prepared for chaos! Food vendors selling snails, sheep brain soup but also meats, cous cous etc to eat with the locals, We paid £20 for dinner for two at a stall though so not the cheapest...prices are on the menu and the same list is given to the locals, was tasty though as BBQ food.I asked to take a photo of the street dentist and the he tried to charge me 150dh ! I gave him 30dh...A smile and fim thank you but no 2-3 Times generally wards off any unwanted attemps to sell you tissues, bracelets, photos with monkeys etc.Lots going on,,,particularly liked the locals with their rods fishing for coca cola or fanta bottles....like we have at the funfair back home.Friendly people....anyone offering to show you the way wants money from you though or will tell you the road is closed! Part of the local way so just smile and say thanks I'm okay and they politely leave you alone!

Terrible but unmissable. It is the defining centre of Marrakesh. Missing it would be like going to Paris and not seeing the Eifel Tower. It is full of hawkers with Barbary apes who will try to charge you a fortune for holding them for a photograph and rip off stalls which will try to charge you €10 for a bottle of water etc. The roof top cafes are well priced with good local food and the horse drawn carriage rides (kalesh, I think they are called) are worth the money if that is your thing. The souks are as hectic and colourful as you would expect in North Africa and a good test of your haggling skills. Well worth seeing once during the day and not too bad for casual dining at night if you like a bit of noise with your couscous

A MUST See. The night market is very impressive and must be seen. The food is amazing and really cheap. Don't let any old ladies henna tatoo your body as they made a real mess of mine - ugly, lasted 2 days and cost a fortune. Anyway, hope her 7 kids felt the benefit:)))

Certainly lots to see!. You have to go and have a look. Just ignore all invitations to look at anything unless you have already decded you want to buy something as they are very insistent! The minute you give eye contact or reply its hard to get away. View from a distance or wait a couple of days to acclimatize before entering into the whole thing. Fascinating tho. View the sunset from a terrace, maybe Cafe de France.... above all the hectic goings on... Lovely! And watch all the food stalls set up.... and the stalls light the lanterns... Looks lovely...

Gotta love the buzz. The square itself it's not beautiful, but it's just great to walk around and see all what's going on there... Watch the cobras, monkeys (careful not to take pics, or they'll ask a tip for that), the food stalls, or simply get dinner on one of the terraces... Food is touristy but the view is unbeatable.
Special. The place to be in the evenings specially! Great atmosphere! The food, people, the mint & spice smell...an amazing place
Night Market. Very interesting but extremely crowded. Don't make eye contact with entertainers or they will demand money.
Day and night. I liked "la grande place" in the early morning, totally empty, before 9 and crowded, late in the evening. The best view over the place is on a terrace of one of the cafés.

a great place to watch the world go by!. good selection of restaurants around the square...all pretty much serving the same kind of foods..tagines, meats pizza and pasta. try to get a panoramic view point from one of them and you can sit for hours watching the chaos of jemaa el fna going on beneath you.be carfeul when trying to take pictures...you may be asked for money for it...i got pictures taken of me with the snakes and was asked for 300 dirham (about £22) for the privilege.i ended up just giving 60 dirham(about £5). if you can stay for a sunset its well worth the view from the restaurants...quite spectacular...especially with the call to prayer being sounded not long after.
Best live entertainment around. You can sit here for hours just watching the goings on.

Centre of everything in Marrakech. Great place to spend an hour or so. Go and have a drink on one of the many cafe terraces for views of the square. Just be careful taking photos close up, payment will be demanded so be prepared before you even take it out of your bag.

At the heart of the nightlife. This is the place to be in Marrakesh, especially at night time! :-) With plenty of live music, performances and food there's always something that will grab your attention. There are snake charmers, belly dancers and other traditional performers, hand-painters and musicians, all giving the square a very lively, entertaining and authentic feeling throughout the day and night.It is relativelly safe too, except for the "organised-chaotic" traffic of Marrakesh - something you must be aware of in the entire city, but becomes particularly important at night, since there are no street lamps in the middle of the square.

Try it. anothe must do in Marrakech. Do at least one in the day - and use it as your safe harbor when scooting into the souks - and once at night when the place changes tenor completely. Be prepared for an aggressive exotic hot mess at night. Not the so much in the day.
Jemaa el Fna. A UNESCO world heritage site, but the snake charmers and Monkey performances were distasteful.
Huge !!. We visited in the early evening, before the sun went down. It was OK then, but did not become atmospheric unless dusk - the place really comes to life then.
simply madness. didn't spend a lot of time there because it was so chaotic, although I can handle that sort of thing. It was great to observe from the sidelines however at one of the coffeeshops.

Street food with a different. The atmosphere was unbelievable. Once you get around the stall owners trying to entice you into their stall and settle for your choice you can sit back, enjoy fabulous fresh food at incredibly low prices and watch the world go by.
Eye opener. Not for the faint hearted but the hustle and bustle was great. Maybe stop trying to fleece tourists for every penny. It gets a bit tiresome. Great place to visit nonetheless.

Get ready to be over stimulated. Some of it is very tacky and dirty. Keep an open mind and look for the once in a life time opportunities - monkeys, snake charmers, fresh squeezed OJ and hand made crafts.
A feast for the senses. Visit both day and night to appreciate just how it really comes alive in the evening. Stall Number 1 is great for food.

Get involved.. After 4pm this square really starts to get happening... There are activities all during the day but the best time is after the sun goes down! The vast majority of visitors to this famous spot are Moroccans but all are most welcome wherever they come from. A frenetic centre of activity where a sense of humour and the ability to smile and say no helps withstand the multitude of tempting offers.

Give yourself time. Try and do this in the evening so you can soak up the whole atmosphere, not only the food and drink, but the entertainments. Everything is simple and maybe a reminder of how we managed to keep ourselves entertained on dark evenings without a mobile phone or electronic gadget.
Fun but best at night. The square felt tired and dirty in the day, but at night it comes alive and is a fun place to try some local food

Couldn't wait to get out of here. Pretty much take the review below mine word for word - and there you have it. The name of the square translates from Arabic as the 'final meeting place' or ' the place where you meet with death', as back in the day they used to hang and decapitate unruly folk here for all to see and even today the place is a bloody mess. It could literally go that way if you don't jump out of a scooter's way in time or get roughed up by a rabid monkey jumping at your throat. If you're expecting a city square in a European sense where you can stroll past nice cafes and look into a few shops and chill on a bench with a gelato - forget it - this is a damn battlefield and you're a target.

A frenzied disappointment. We decided to stay four days in Marrakech to see the exotic culture. I have to say that we were extremely disappointed in this enormous, asphalt square. Yes there are snake charmers, henna painters, monkey handlers, acrobats, etc. but there is a frenzied, aggressive, money demanding undertone (on the verge of threatening sometimes) that we found very disagreeable . It took any pleasure out of trying to just absorb the cultural experience.The beggars can be quite aggressive too, with one woman actually doggedly following us and repeatedly tapping me on the shoulder.Lastly, there are motor scooter riders zooming amongst the crowded square, nearly hitting pedestrians, so one had to be on the lookout, constantly, and ready to literally jump out of harms way.As you can guess by this review, we were disappointed in the experience.
not that good. Of you want to be amused by apes, being seen like a moneymachine ten this is he place to ge. Nog my style of amusing andere enjoy

Busy square lot's to see at night.. The square offers a lot, there are performances at night, there are a lot of food stands, but for one of the main touristic attractions it was still a bit disappointing to me. Still you can see people with snakes (if you like them), there are acrobats... but it is difficult to see as it is so crowded and then there are the pick pockets, beware of those as my mother in law lost here purse there!.
Full on Marrakech. Crazy & high energy. Don't miss this nightly circus! Don't miss the rocking fresh squeezed OJ (4dh=50 cents a glass). I drank it every chance I got.
Vibrant Square. So much to see and take in - henna painting, monkeys, snake charmers, comedians performing, take a horse and carriage ride. Brilliant

Great at sunset & the evening. This is where Marrakech seems to come alive with all kinds of street entertainment (snake charmers, monekys, story telling, cross-dressing dancers etc etc) and food. It really does deserve the World Heritage status as the atmosphere is incredible.Worth taking your time to choose a stall where the locals eat for dinner- likely to be the best food on the square (and best value)

Enjoy, but be careful. Fantastic experience, but keep your wits about you. Haggling is great fun and there are bargains to be had but beware of beggars and people wanting to charge you for photographs you take whilst there.

Snake charmers charming only snakes. A must see in Marrakesch-you feel like you travell in time. But ist very vibrant and buzzy-so be aware and prepared to stay cool. Peaceful people-no pickpocket tries in 7 days just allot of haggling with people who want to sell you something or hang a watersnake around your neck to get some money for a photo. These snake charmers have been actually the only really stressfull people to me because they can be really uncharming if you dont pay them a fortune for the photo charming a snake. Leave them with a smile and a fair amount and they vanish in the smoke of the food stalls as quickly as they arrived.
MAD!. Thats about the size of it. Watch out for professional pick pockets working in teams of 3. Apart from that enjoy!!!

Heart of the city. This is an incredible bustling place especially at night. There is a variety of street sellers (fresh orange juice for 30p!!) snake charmers and the like. Don't take photos unless you have a long lense and can do so without being noticed., The locals are very aggresively against photo taking. It did not seem to be a religious thing, just that they see it as an opportunity to demand money. They can get very menacing when money is at stake and you might have to part with 100dn (£8.00) just to keep the peace.
Vibrant area. lively any time of day, but at night it comes alive, A smattering of French is useful but not necessary.The night market is one great big outside bar b q
Nothing Like it. Same as the title, it is nothing like it, the place which drive you back 100 years ago while you still get all what you are looking for

magical. everytime I step back into the Jemaa el Fna I adore it. The sights,sounds,smells are all a heady mix of the true heart of Marrakech. Just make sure you visit morning,noon and night- a different experience everytime.
THE Square. This is undoubtedly the most famous landmark in Marrakech, combining street food stalls with all manner of entertainment. Rather grubby but vibrant and exotic.
The oldest square in Africa. Visit at night for the best effect. East at stall 31. Safe and delicious

The importance of oral and intangible heritage. Better known simply as 'The Square' by the locals. This is the market place in Marrakesh's old city.Rather embarrassingly it took us a while to find it after attempting to walk there from our hotel, on the plus side we ended seeing other parts of Marrakech!Once we did get there through the narrow streets lined with shops, restaurants and tour guides we end up in the Square which is edged along the sides by the souks. In the day it is occupied by orange juice stalls, water sellers, performance animals, snake charmers and street entertainers. There will be Henna ladies and various assorted characters who want you to spend money with them. Later in the evening, the Square becomes more crowded. Part of it is replaced by food stalls where you can sit and eat. The entertainers, dancers and story tellers emerge and there is a little bit of organised chaos. It is this aspect of the Square that has been recognised by UNESCO in its aims to raise awareness about the importance of oral and intangible heritage as an essential component of cultural diversity.It really is the soul of Marrakech and would be a must see in any visit to the city.
Sights in all directions. It was fascinating to see the sights and sounds of the area, to be fully immersed in a place I had only heard about.

pestered all the time !!!. I enjoed cobras, but I didn't sellers who were rude !!! And do not drink a "real fresh orange juice " there, beacuse is mixed with water and sugar !!! I saw that !!!! my husband had a stomach problems after drinking it

Chaotic, noisy and interesting.. Lovely place to go and people watch. I personally do not like haggling at all or being pestered to buy. My husband could have had his shoes cleaned 10 times. Wear trainers or sandals not 'proper' shoes.
Jemaa el Fna - crazy:). Crazy place with fantastic atmosphere. We had dinners in one of the grill places - nice food and most of all incredible feel of houndreds of people moving all over the place

A must see, but a few warnings. Best to go with Moroccans as they will ensure you won't get ripped off or harassed. First, be prepared for people to come up to you and try to put snakes around you and also, you will be bothered. Just be firm and tell them to go away, they want money and may still bother you. Next definitely go into the souk, but its better with a guide as its huge and there are many good sites you may miss if you wander in alone. Be expected to be ripped off, you won't receive the "moroccan price" unless you're with moroccans. Just try to haggle and remember that they will always go lower. At night this area turns into a restaurant area which is quite cool but once again expect to be bothered, just make sure you take the time to pick where you want to eat, as there are different things in different areas--also carts go around with some traditional desserts, if you like almonds, enjoy! if not, stay away as nearly all the desserts are filled with almonds in one way or another

Perfect for people watching. Grab a drink and watch the world go by for a few hours. Eat at one of the stalls (117 and 114 are good). People are incredibly friendly, stay strong and don't be pressured into anything you don't want to do and you'll enjoy yourself. Always ask how much people want for something before committing to anything, saw so many tourists make this mistake!

Must see, must smell!. The heart of the city and a constantly moving animal, this is the place to experience. We sat at three or four cafes during the day and night and marvelled at the constant movement, the sounds and smells of the place. Coming from England as we do - Jemaa el Fna is properly exotic!

What a place!. Loved the barbecue stalls that set up in the evenings, with all the Moroccan boys vying for your custom. Snake charmers, transvestite belly dancers, fresh juice stalls, magic acts. it has everything! Watch out for motorbikes and caleche!

Busy, Loud and Hot.... But AMAZING. I love visiting the Market when in Marrakech. I rarely shop in the actual market but I love to visit all the little souks that are hidden around it. You get much better value for money. Do not be afraid to haggle. My bf is marrakean and the vendors often try and bump the price up when they see me, he still says no. Whatever they ask half it because thats usually what it really costs.I often walk down for a coffee and sit there and watch the world go by. Be careful of the monkeys. The 'masters' often ask for as m uch as £15 per monkey and they do try and get as many on you as possible. Agree a price before letting them sit on you, a friend of mine had that trouble. Also the monkeys will rob you given half the chance so keep your goods zipped away.In the morning its so peaceful between 9 and 1pm, Marrakeans dont start work till 1/2 in the afternoon after the highest heat has gone so you can shop in peace. But from 2 till midnight its absolutely chaotic. So if you hate hussle bussle and nearly being ran over by bikes carriages and taxis I would recommend going in the morning. I love Marrakech and I cannot wait to move there in the future.

sunset and great food at the night stalls. go there before sunset and chill in one of the cafes on the square. Cafe de France is a good one. Then head to get some tasty and cheap dinner on one of the food stalls. Tip is to eat at one with many locals. Tend to be tastier food and cheaper!

Exciting and atmospheric. After being lost in the souks on our first day it was great to finally stumble upon the Jemaa el Fna....although it's so big we couldn't believe it took us so long to find, but be warned if you're staying in the Medina...you will get lost at some point....although we wouldn't have had it any other way! The atmosphere is great, we preferred daytime as at night it was just heaving and even though we had intended to eat there, we decided not to and heard afterwards that its not that great and is expensive for what it is...and you also run the risk of being ill...not a chance we wanted to take the night before we set off for the desert!!
lovely but too pricey. even after haggling for ages, the shop keepers were arrogant

Better at night. This place is an assault on the senses to begin with but fab once you get used to it. On the plus side, it's colourful, fun and definitely the best place to eat in the evening. There are a few down sides to be aware of. The snake charmers are anything but charming. Get your camera out in their vicinity and they get irate, even if your not tring to take a photo of their poor little reptilian captives. There are people with chained up monkeys too, which didn't appeal to me either. Watch out for the mopeds too, they are buzzing about all over the place, and through the souks too.At night, the place comes alive. The locals are there in force, eating and enjoying the entertainment. The food village that springs up in the evening is fantastic and a great place for a cheap meal. I ate there three times and recommend the smaller stalls that don't have gangs of jolly chaps trying to drum up business. One stall selling vegetarian dishes with beans and lentils was superb and cheap. It doesn't sound very exciting but it was very good indeed. Another small stall just selling fishy things was very good too. Avoid the ones selling a bit of everything.
