Ons stall that always had a big crowd, right on the edge of the food 'village' was selling sausages and other tasty looking meaty things. It looked great but I could never get a seat! Don't forget the orange stalls. A big glass of fresh OJ for 4 dirhams - fantastic! Entertainment in the evenings is quite low key. Groups of blokes thrashing discordant instruments and bashing drums but it is atmospheric and quite interesting and the locals love it. You will be asked for contributions, though, so keep a few coins ready and ignore any requests for bigger donations.One wierd and quite pointless fairground game is trying to lasso bottles of fizzy drinks with gaily painted fishing rods. Just buy some more OJ instead....

Worth a look but move on!. Fascinating to watch all the performers and wander round the stalls for a while. Take a few photos and soak up the atmosphere but then move on to somewhere quieter and more sophisticated.

Bustling tourist place.. Good food, excellent juice in the juice stalls. If you take out your camera to photograph snake charmers, dentists and the like, be prepared for an unpleasant experience when they start to demand payment. The demands are outrageous, but stand your ground and haggle.
the most amazing live circus. This place is like no other on earth. It has to be seen once in your lifetime-seriously!

The world famous square!. The first time you step here it's incredible, the noise, the smells, the hustle and bustle. But, after a while the constant hassling from the people selling things or wanting money for photos wears you down. There are "marshals" in the square to stop this but it still goes on. I would have loved to spend some time watching the snake charmers but it was impossible.

exciting smells,colours and sounds. i first went to marrakech alone two years ago to do some volentry work and celebrate bieng newly single,i fell in love.ive been back many many times for varing ammounts of time and loved it every time.november is a good time cheap flights with easyjet and hot wether,its cheap cheap cheap there i always come back with money...i would reccomend just booking flights and finding somewhere to stay there surrounding the square are hundreds of hotels and riads hotel for 2 a night is roughly 200 durham.haggle haggle offer half or even less than half but try and remember its a poor country,everyone is very friendly the men can be a bit letchy but i didnt find it too oppressing and when they said "fish and chips"i said "tagine" which raised a laugh.eat at the stalls in the square at night they all selll roughly the same thing give you free bread,sit relax soak up the hustle and bustle.a small taxi from the airport should be 100 durhams less if your strict,theres endless daytrips out of marrakech to enjoy the waterfalls are lovely.but spend a good day aimlessly roaming around the souks,drinking coffee and taking it all in get lost xohhh take loo roll with you whereever you go a lot of loos dont have it,i got into the habit of picking up the servietts with coffee,and a small bottle of hand gel may be usefull x
Excellent atmosphere. Fascinating place. Unique experience. Better during the night than the day. Wonderful food and entertainment A must see for all visitors to Morocco.
Bustling and vibrant. liked - souks and items on saledisliked - bikes / motors racing through alleys

no words is good for describe this. Never in my live i dint sorry that I dont speak english very well till now. I dont know enought words to tell you about this place. It was amaising and desgusting, in the same time. It was interesting, it was dirty, it was great! This is my first time in Maroc, and I thing that I am falling in love with Jemaa el Fna.I loved the smel of the horses, I loved the thousents of people, i love the foods, I love the cobras, I love the fruits, I love the marocans. I never, never saw such place in my life. Go there, my friends, is one of the most interesting place in the world!

The place you should avoid in Marrakech. It's hard to understand why everything in Marrakech seems to have their starting point in this square. Leave it as soon as you can and walk around in the souks and in the smaller, local squares scattered around the Medina: Better food, "real" people, fun things to see...

Day and night totally different. Did not love it during the day. People forcing monkeys and snakes on you. However, night is much better. It's a scene out of this world. But bring change for the street performers because they don't want you watching without paying. You MUST go just to see the way the square lights up. Eating there at night is quite a chaotic experience but you should try at least once.

Great for people watching & eating. Fascinating place, storytellers, acrobats, water carriers, henna tattoo artists, the winding passages of the souks. At night they lay the tables and everyone eats outside. Be aware of what's going on around you, take a photo of a water carrier & he could run up & demand money for letting you take it..!
Assaults all the senses.. Soemthing our og Arabian nights, drummers,dancers,fortune tellers. This is not just for the tourists. Moroccans come from all over to experience the fun.

Main square. You should not miss thew Square --- though it is kind of crazy!Meals at night at one of the stands were great. We were told to aim for stand #1, #114 and #117. But it seemed like all were pretty much OK and had the same menus. cost for dinner was about 40 dirham (4 euros) per person. We loved ther couscous.

what a night?. More than a square or a souk, it's a bridge between past and present... snakes, monkeys fortune teller, hene tattoo... a traditional clothing, a local food... All in one place... Enjoy the night in jemaa el fna.

Wonderful at night. It's a great experience at night - especially from a restaurant terrace. It's a little bit scruffy during the day and prepare to be constantly pestered with monkeys and snakes. Just ignore and walk past everyone - a firm NO will put people off as well.

Prepare to be shocked. Injured and sick animals, child beggars, glue sniffers and abusive market sellars, we even saw a woman going to toilet under a tree and showing her backside! we witnessed a motor bike accident no one stopped to help, they just sounded their horms to get them out of the way. (maybe i'm just to English!)There are bargains if you stand your ground and stick to a price you want to pay, and the Riads and hotels are beautiful, peaceful havens among the madness. Worth a visit, just for the experience.

Souks, snakes, snails and apes....... The Jemaa el Fna was a comfortable walk from my hotel. I visited during the late afternoon. The hundreds of food stalls for the evening festivities had not yet been set up. This place is unbelievable ! The souks that were off the square had remarkable deals on all things Moroccan. The aromatic spices and the light filtering in through the roofs of the many stalls will make you feel like you have been transported back in time. Squabbling is a way of life and expected from the buyer. Returning through the labyrinth of souks to the main square, I made the mistake of looking at one of the Barbary Apes chained to their owners. The ape was immediately thrown on my back, which is an interesting experience to say the least, then the owner demanded some money. I quickly walked away only to be confronted by a guy that thought I was taking pictures of his king cobra....Again, a demand for money. I caught on to the fact that the owners of these exploited exotic animals have "spotters" in the crowd which alert the owners and will confront you if you stare too long. By now the square was being transformed into a multitude of food stalls. Amazingly the entire process took only about 45 minutes ! Now I was surrounded by every possible smell and food product, some recognizable, most not. I did not realize that snails and their broth were a Moroccan specialty. I passed on the "treat"...The square is fantastic as it turned from flying apes to snail stalls ! I found a restaurant that had an upper terrace and watched the bustling crowd below. Definitely worth the walk from the hotel.

Not impressed. We were really looking forward to seeing the snake charmers and story tellers as well as then returning in the evening to see it full of life. When we arrived at 4pm it was more or less empty. There was a couple of snake charmers and a few monkeys on chains. We couldn't even look from afar without them running up to us demanding money. My partner made the mistake of not agreeing a price before a snake was put on his neck which then resulted in us being insulted and shouted up as we left having given them 20dh for a quick photo! We decided not to return at the evening as we didn't feel that safe after having witnessed someone getting stabbed in the souks and then someone trying to snatch my i-phone from my hands as I was taking a photo. I'm sure if it had been fuller at least the enjoyment of seeing lots of things would have outweighed everything else, but as it stands we weren't very impressed!

Just GO!!!. What a wonderful introduction to Morocco, an assault on the senses. From the bright oranges and spices, the wafts of various epicurean delights, the music, just a delight, a wonderful magical place where carpets are sure to fly

one word, MENTAL!. Never have I had so much fun not really doing anything.People/monkey/snake watching this place is as they; Unique!Be prepared to pay for any photo you take. But a wee tip:- if you see police coming to move on an unlicensed or unscrupulous seller take pictures as he's getting his gear together and watch him try to run after you for 20 dirhams whilst moving before the police take his stuff. Well funny.You have to go at all times of the day to appreciate it. Lots of vantage points on the Place for pictures though too.Street food at night was great... Stall #117 is the stairway to heaven. Tell him you're scottish and you'll get "haggis! mince nnnnn tatteez" back at you. Truly amazing, I've never had this much fun with my clothes on for less than €10
A must see and do while in Marrakech.. It was a little walk from the center but very much worth it. I did get lazy on the way home and took a taxi. Really busy place and goes well into the night.

First visit to the 'Big Square'. This square looks best in the early evening dusk when the lights start to go on and the call to prayers comes from the amazing Koutobia mosque. Very romantic and eastern. There are all sorts of wierd things going on. not hassled by beggars which was nice.
Incredible sights. The snake charmers and the monkeys are amazing to look at -- from a distance!

The place to watch life!. The square is large and a lot is happening; snake charmers, fruit sellers, musicians, people selling toys, food stalls etc etc etc. Some will want money for watching, but just strolling around is fine - or have soem mint tea at a café and just watch whats going on. Lots of locals go there. We also had dinne at a resturant on the second floor with view over the square. Recommended!
A must see!!. Very vibrant, comes alive at night with so much going on. You have to have the orange juice and sit with the locals to try the harina (moroccan soup).
A must!. One you have to experience, but it's intense both day and night.

Hectic, Noisy and Exciting. This is the hubub of Marrakech life where everyone stands to benefit from the countries tourism and they respect that. The people are very polite despite the fact that they are there to maske money. It is safe although noisy withe traffic filtering through the crowds

WOW. Its like nothing else I have experienced ... Its colourful, vibrant, noisy, exciting ... You must visit at least once, be careful of the alleyways off into the souk you can easily get lost.. But its a fantastic experience, lots of stalls and entertainment, just be aware of the hassle from the men if you are women. Its weird how after about 11 the hustle and bustle just dies away and all is eerily quiet. Loved it

The market place. If you have not been there, you have not been to Marrakech. It is what a market place should be, you can buy almost everything. There are fortune tellers, snakes, monkeys, soup stalls etc. The soup stalls are worth a visit. The place is crowded and the traffic is awfull but a place you must see
Quite unique. Has to be seen to be believed, during the day but particularly at night. Be prepared for some hassle but never aggressive.
Watch the world go by..... Never a moment without something to catch the eye. All these people and not one moment of hostility. If lost, always someone willing to assist.

A bit hectic for us. Even though this is a definite for any trip to marrakech it is a really busy place, and to see anything of interest eg snake charmers there is someone to charge you for even looking. Glad we went but only stayed for a short time.

What an experience. Busy, vibrant and very very noisy. Avoid if you dislike snakes! Women will try to accost you to give you a henna tatoo which we avoided because we were told it is not good stuff and toxic, so use the hotels for a better quality tatoo. There are monkeys and dancers and the incessant pipes and drums. Night time the pop up restaurants appear. Every night seemed to cost the same no matter what we had! If you are mad on hygiene this might not be the best option for you to eat there! All restaurants surrounding the square have panoramic terrace which are magnificent but all serve the same sort of fare. A "must do" experience day or night.
Very vibrant. animals, music, food, dancing... you can find it all here
The beating heart. it's bonkers but day, or more so at night, it rammed full of people and not to be missed.
A must. So much going on both day and night, the pestering of the locals does get you down a bit but you get used to it.

A market for everyone. A fabulous place to sit and people watch. The only issue we had was seeing children selling products - a way of life in Morocco but very hard to see. Fab night market - an experience in itself.

the square. Not so much a square as a large open space filled with people buying, selling, looking at just about everything; more market during the day at night the story tellers and snake charmers come out
shame about the poor monkeys. mad mad place but the poor monkeys are chained and dressed up - please don't give the owners any money as it is degrading and wrong
must. must , must & must . spcial , difirent , noisy , atractives 24 oures, best fresh orang juice , the hot spices drink at night is a must

Don't miss ! Eat dinner under the stars here!. Go when it's warm but not hot, eat at all the stalls at night, listen to the musicians and snake-oil salesmen, gawk at the carved lamps and medicinal products being sold, eavesdrop on the local families and tourists, watch the grand parade of life pass by on possibly the most wildly captivating square on earth.
Charming and caotic!. Be prepared for at lot of people, sounds and smells. Open up and take in the atmosphere.

Hard to describe.... I have very mixed feelings about the square. On one hand its a vibrant , bustling sensory overload, wich plenty going on, but on the other its an agressive money drain, if you let it. I am fairly assertive so I was ok but I did see some less fortunate tourists intimidated by the many, many people who see you as a walking wallet.I understand this is a poor country, and people will do almost anything for money and I am happy to share it when I choose! Not when one of the snake charmers henchmen assumes I have taken a photo ( I hadnt) and demands money. They can be quite aggressive so stay calm and show them the last photo taken. This became really annoying. I did ask to take a photo a few tines and paid accordingly.Be careful of your belongings at all times as there are many pick pockets also. If you can stomach the aggression, or ignore it you can have an amazing time here, The orange juice vendors were mostly nice smiling people which great juice so dont miss that.

Lovely place to see careful of the food and drinks though. Absolutely stunning place to visit day or night. Everything they say about the weird stuff being sold is true and more! I spent so much time around the square I loved it so much. Around 4pm food stalls start popping up and by 5pm are in full flow with the smoke billowing to let you know they are cooking. I wouldn't recommend the food or the drink stalls, the restaurants screw you out of an extra 20/30 dh per person. They could tell you they will charge you for bread etc and make it all very pleasant but they don't. The food is generally lower quality, smaller portions and colder than elsewhere. The atmosphere is not to be equalled, though you don't have to eat there to experience it. Orange juice vendors sell watered down concentrate.
Exotic mayhem. Learn the arabic for no thank you and keep a few coins easily to hand for the street acts.
Interesting. Dissappointed with day time atmosphere/entertainment, but the place comes to life in the evenings.
A world heritage site. How can you not visit a square with so much charm and history it is all about the people of Morocco!
Must see. A true reflection of the genuine Arabic markets -as in the movies. Very safe environment and it's the soul of Marrakech. Never say "been to Marrakech" without visiting Jemaa el Fna.

Beware pickpockets !. Unfortunately I had my camera stolen from my bag, very quickly and cleverly, even though I had my bag on the front of my body. The big square is a crazy place at night, with many people hassling you, if you can avoid the trouble some of the music is really good, with Moroccans singing and playing bowed instruments with great passion and fervour. Only take what you need, a bit of cash, ladies if somebody feels your behind, they are not sexually molesting you but checking your back pockets for wallets. The street food is very good and cheap, we had it several times and it was tasty and filling, I even had sheeps head which was surprisingly nice. The orange juice is the best I have had, and the cheery stallholders are good fun, the herb tea and sweet cakes are also great value at 2Dh and you can stand and watch the world go by. There are dried hedgehogs for spells and tooth pullers, frankinsence and mercury, spinning tops and whirling dancers, don't miss it but keep well zipped up.

Try different times. I went to the Jemaa el Fna at different times of the day (which was easy given I staying so close) and can recommend it for getting different experiences. Sunset is a great time to go!

Jamal EL Fina. Dont miss the Jamal EL Fina at night if you are in Marrakech. This place comes alive at night with story tellers, musicians, snake charmers, foods stalls, singers, dancers etc.
Just be a bit careful about the food. Better to avoid the food stalls as cleanliness may be an issue
Chaotic but fun. The fresh orange juice stands are a must, delicous and only 40 cents! The night market is a great way to get cheap, sit-down dinner, begins about 5pm.

Busy, Loud, Touristy. Worth every second. Don't come here unless you're willing to negotiate street vendors, haggle with store owners and generally get jostled. Better late at night when the real treats come out.

The heart and soul of the medina. It's like the centre of the universe...what a great place to experience. The sights, sounds and smells will be a memorable experience for you...don't be threatened, it's safe to walk around freely. Just be assertive.
A feast for the senses. This place is incredible! A must, sitting at a food stall and watching them try to lure folks in! Good times, Can highly recommend 117!
Market day every day. Crazy and fun but traders pushy and very annoying after a while but to be expected

Must see - morning, afternoon and evening. The square is different at different times of the day. Join in or watch the activity from the cafes around the edges. Shopping for souvenirs, dried fruit and nuts, fresh orange juice. Henna tattooists, snake charmers, song and story tellers. Eat at the food stalls that are set up each evening. Watch the dancers.

A place unlike any other.... My wife and I spent three days in Marrakech and explored the Jemaa el Fna square on several occasions during the day and evening and found the experience remarkable and at times overwhelming. Prepare yourself for sensory overload. The square was jam packed in the evening with people from seemingly all corners of the globe gathered around in restaurants, dining on street vendor food, and enjoying performances. We were told to beware the food vendors in the evening because their cleanliness practices were not the best, but you're definitely safe in any of the numerous restaurants surrounding Jemaa al Fna. As for performances, we showed interest in a snake charmer one morning and before I knew it I had three snakes draped around my neck and I had swapped hats with another snake charmer. Also, my wife had her camera taken out of her had by another snake charmer who began snapping away to get as many pictures of me with his snake charming friends before the began asking us for 200 dirhams, which was way too much for their "performance." Let's just say that in the end we paid them much less and that the entire time I was more concerned about the snake charmers themselves than the black hooded cobra two feet from me. However, in any large square with that many people gathered together you always have to be wary and use caution. It was totally worth the experience, but anyone and everyone will be eager to make a few bucks from you if they can.

Over-rated with hawkers. We headed straight to the square once we had checked into our Riad. There is plenty of commotion during the day which steadily increases once the sun goes day. What detracted from the place are the number of hawkers who try to fleece you. A snake charmer wanted 300 Dirhams (£25) after a couple of photos but once we declined and offered 2 Dirhams instead, he forced us to delete a few of the photos.We heard horror stories from a couple in a cafe that they were forced to pay over the odds for Henna hand painting as an aggressive husband of one of the Henna wives (sporting a black eye) was overseeing things. The square is best viewed from one of the panoramique restaurants that line the place.
beware of the snakes... and the taxi drivers. watch out, it a tottaly different world over there..
Great atmosphere. Loved the drums, juice bars, plant, fruit, spice & vegetable stalls. Disliked the snakes and being approached to have picture taken with them!

Magical amazing and unique. Went to the square almost as soon as we had got off the plane which was a bit of a shock to the system but were soon enchanted by the sounds, smells, snakes, storytellers, stallholders,....it remains where the Sahara meets North Africa and ultimately Europe.

Unique and beautiful place!. It was the most unique and beautiful place with so many market shops. Alot of variety of restuarants and eating places with resonably cheap prices. And have so much diferent things going on from snake dancing to fortune telling, henna painting and so on. My favourite every attraction everything you need or want is there!

Big let down. After hearing so much about the " amazing Djem el Fnaa " we visited the square on numerous occasions , at different times of the day and night and every time it was very disappointing .No acrobats etc that you hear about , just people standing around . The henna tattoo ladies are a nightmare , persistently trying to rip you off . The food stalls are rubbish . We had a meal one evening , worst meal in Marrakech , some of us were sick later , and on top of this the money they charged for this muck was outrageous , cheaper to eat in a normal restaurant !.
Overrated. OMG Like a bad Indiana Jones movie. Go but keep walking and dont sit with a view of it as it is dirty and ugly.
Mental. If you like being bombarded and hassled then this is the place for you. See it at night and also during the day when it is quieter. Food, drink, entertainment, sales, the lot.
the heart of the city. always busy, night and day, lovely orange juices and great food at night. Food sellers try to catch you all the time... the are quite anoying...

Looking at the many sides of oneself. What can you say about something that reflects so much a part of the human spirit, imagination, talent, capacity for mischief, deceit and tradition. A vast Bruegel painting someone said--it is, carnal, sacred, defiant, exquisite, it pulls as much as it pushes. Amulet makers weave poems into their brass treasures, veiled women who appear like oriental caricatures drawn from the Western imagination apply henna to a variety of skins. Men dressed as women dance to the sometimes melodic music of aging instruments. Acrobats of varied skills and training hope for a few dhirams. Gnaouan musicians play on.
real marrakesh!. Evening especially when everyone comes "out to play". Unique experience, even if we didn't have the courage to eat from the stalls in the centre of the "stage".
lovely culture. liked the atmosphere, culture, music and storesbe careful with hagerlersrobbersbeggersfake brandscons
Buy and Bargain for good. Highly experience in bargaining, andd you can find absolutly all you can desire in the Morrocan market site. Very safe and clean. Friendly morrocans are very helpfull, too

Great food, Great atmosphere. Best food we had was in the square on an evening. You also get the best strawberries (and biggest) I have ever had from the fruit sellers!
Lots of wierd sights: snake charmers, dressed up performing monkeys, a hook a duck style game with fishing rods and bottles of pop.

One square, thousands of things to see and do. Jemaa el Fna looks like a collection of different squares, depending on what time of the day you visit.It is an absolute must see, whether during the day (all the merchants selling dried fruit, and all those other millions of things you probably don't need) or at night (bustling atmosphere, plenty of people, nice illumination). It is definitely worth a stroll across the square, to get an impression of true Marrakechi life. Also nice: go and sit on one of the terrasses around the square to enjoy the atmosphere with a little distance.
Buzzing. The atmosphere, I love it. Its like one great big party
Must see, but not the thing I enjoyed most.... Lots of hawkers and stalls. We ate here twice at stalls, in the centre, in the evening and it was very good value and tasty. A good if noisy atmosphere.

Quick visit. Was not that many stalls in the day. It was more busy at night time. We found it too crazy to eat at the many stalls. I would be worried about the hygiene. We were warmed about the snake charmers and guys with monkeys to take photos. Did not find much entertainment going on to stay around for.
authentic. What is great is that so much of the entertainment is for local people - story tellers, Berber singers etc - not pre-packaged for foreign tourists
A fascininating square. So much to see, you don't know where to look. Be careful taking photos, everybody wants money!
Enjoyable. Walking around and enjoying the scenery was a pleasure. Worth learning a few Arabic words, pictures are not free.
Big and bustling. Lots going on here and it changes throughout the day/evening. Nice spots to eat/drink and just sit too.
Big square. This is obviously the center of the city. Every path leads to this square. If you do not like snakes, then beware of the snake workshippers.

Don't miss it!. Think of a 3-ring circus and the Atlantic City Boardwalk rolled into one. This marvellous square teems with shops, strolling friends and families, hawkers, street performers, food stalls, sidewalk cafes, snake charmers (!), fortune tellers, donkeys, water carriers, etc, etc. Everywhere you look, something is happening like a giant collage come to life. Although, initially, the entire experience is an assault on the senses, don't miss it. Eat at the street stalls - food is way beyond yummy! - try your hand at bargaining in some shops, make new friends, and just enjoy. We certainly did!
jemaa el fna. everything you expect, snake charmers, monkeys, merchants selling dried hedgehogs and ostrich eggs, henna painters, storytellers, and lots of food.

It's a big square area which is packed and poorly maintained. I could try to big this up but there is nothing special about it. If you're into trained monkeys (no), deadly snakes you could easily walk into (no), guys dressed in traditional consumers deperate to make money from you (no), and 20 close calls per hour from taxis/other cars/horse drawn carriages/mopeds/cycles/donkey carts etc. then this is the square for you. If not it's simply an over-crowded, unattractive square with expensive cafe's on it's perimeter. I guess you could say 'its' a visual spectacle of human life' or something like that but it's not pretty to view or a particularly fun place to be. We genrally tried to get through it as quickly as we could.

Crazy!!. Too much hassle....pushing and shoving everywhere didnt feel safe there with my girlfriend in tow. She doesnt like snakes and they come towards you with snakes for a picture and try to charge you. She freaked and he was following us like it was a game...i was not happy as she was petrified.
Liveliest spot in Marrakech!. Lively, fun, great food and great for shopping! Shop around for good deals. Open till late, great place to relax.

We were disgusted, if you like animals, don't go during the day!. I am shocked how there is not more reviews about the conditions at the square during the day! yes it is different, yes it is buzzing, yes it is unique but this is just not REAL! In general the place has been tainted by tourists! If you walk in here, expect to be looked at as an ATM. They know you have money and they want it! I travelled around - in my opinion (and our local berber driver) - the real Morocco; stopping at small villages, brought our own groceries to a local man who grilled it right there beside us, shared an apple with a curious wild monkey, had tea with a desert nomad who had nothing but insisted to give us tea, picked up 5 berber women on the side of the street to give them a lift to the next village. Then coming to Jemaa el Fna made me so upset and sad because this is all a show! It might have been a world heritage sight years ago but not anymore. And if you didn't know: The snakes that they have here, - their mouths have been sewn together so they can be placed on the shoulders of tourists - they eventually die by a mouth infection and how they eat, I don't know, they probably don't. And when they die, they capture new ones, just so the tourist can have their pictures taking with a snake..... The wild monkeys we saw in the forest have been captured by the monkey owners at Jemaa el Fna, where the monkeys get a chain around the neck, placed in diapers and have to jump every time the man shakes the chain. = these people might not know any better, but I certainly hope the tourist soon will!!The reason why I have chosen to give some positives if because it at night is more appealing with music, games and good food!

Exotic. The sights, colours,sounds and smells of the square are amazing. Taxis, horse drawn carriages, motor bikes all criss crossing the square with pedestrians weaving their way among them. Snake charmers, drummers, stalls selling spices, oranges, hats etc all add to the colour. We ate at a food stall one night, which was fun, inexpensive and we were OK the next day! One warning - if you look too hard or take a photo you are likely to be asked for money.
Overwhelming, but worth a visit. Snake Charmers, Monkeys, Horse-drawn carriages, dried-fruit sellers and hecklers galore. Also an ATM and Post Office. Quintessentially Marrakech-
so busy. if you go to marrakech you have to go to that place :)

Be tough but polite - they are. I love shopping in markets and this square and the surrounding souks are a treat. Haggle, some prices were ridiculous so we left. Some shopkeepers persist, some do not. There seemed to be a general misunderstanding that we are all rich. Whilst by their standards we may appear so, don't feel obliged to tip everyone who asks.One snake charmer was very aggressive to the point of pushing me in an attempt to make me sit down with the snake. This was after he walks right up to me and put 2 snakes round me neck - fine, but to them ask for 200 dirhams because we forced my partner and friend into a photo .... No chance. A shame because we hen just left the area, annoyed as he shouted.Otherwise, 5-10 dirhams is plenty in exchange for an agreed photo or if you feel like giving t one of the many genuine beggers.Night time is a different kettle of fish. We went to a very expensive restaurant but felt we had better or equal food at the cafe type places on the square.
jemaa el Fna. Be sure to go in late afternoon when the restaurants get set up. You have to pay everyone to take their photo, but that's how they make their living.

Hard to Miss, But Non-Remarkable. Did not find any magic here. However, you should try it and form your own opinion. Here you will see a large square with throngs of people. You will probably see a guy or two sitting on a blanket with some sad-looking cobras that appear to be in bad health or half-dead. He will periodically play his pipe to try to pique tourist interest. If he sees you look at him, he'll immediately stop, call you out and demand money. The same story goes for the guy with some miserable chained monkeys. If you walk in the periphery of a crowd of locals surrounding a guy selling some snake-oil remedy - you'll be singled out as a tourist and have to immediately walk away. There is nothing authentic that I could find about this place. You could arrive early and grossly overpay for a drink so you can sit on the roof of one of the surrounding cafes (we picked Cafe Glacier, which seemed to have the best view) and watch the goings-on. If you go down to the food courts, be prepared to eat bad food and get food-borne illness. This was the only dance with gastro-intestinal distress we experienced in 19 days in Morocco.
Visit in the day and at night. Totally different atmosperes Watch the entertainment at night Dont forget to bring loose change to show your appreciation

Heart of the city. It is the heart of the city and to appreciate its many facets visit at different times of the day. Particuarly enjoy the food stalls in the evenings especially the one serving plates of spicy sausages with bread and dips all the locals frequented plates of spicy sausages bread and dips all the loc

Nowhere else like it in the world!. We loved the authentic storytellers and drummers and the atmosphere when their audiences gathered in the evening amidst the swirling smoke from the food stalls. We didnt like the barbary apes on leads.Otherwise you just need to be on your toes for the mopeds coming at you from all directions in amongst the crowds, often with no lights on!!Remember if you stop and look at snakes, water sellers etc you will need to pay!!Never been anywhere quite like this - you have to go at least once!!

5 stars because I can't go higher. After two visits to Marrakech, Djemaa el Fna is one of my favorite places in the world. The site has been there for a thousand years, and the carnival atmosphere offers something interesting for everyone, from monkeys and snake charmers to bellydancers (some of whom are men in drag) to musicians, acrobats, comedians, fruit sellers, juice vendors, henna artists ... you name it. Be aware of your pockets - pickpockets abound - and be aware that you'll be asked to pay if you take pictures of people (hint: figure out who you want to photograph first; once you've chosen and paid, you can take as many as you want). Go around sunset when the show begins, and when you need a break, hit one of the cafes that line the square to get away from the crowds.

Fun and exciting Square with yummy food. My boyfriend and I went to Jemaa el Fna square almost every night to eat delicious food at very low prices. All the food stalls are numbered and we found two really great ones where locals and tourists alike ate. Number 32 had yummy sausages, bread and tomato salsa (if you can't find it just follow the smoke!) and number 5 had the traditional soup, mint tea, dates and chabakia. I would definitely recommend looking for the stalls with locals because those are the better places that tend to specialize in a few dishes rather than trying to serve every type of Moroccan dish. The servers can be really pushy trying to get you to eat at their stall, just keep walking, smile say no and don't feel pressured :) On a side note, the fresh orange juice is delicious (and nutritious) and the fresh dates are also really good.

THE square........... So big you can hardly see the other side..........full of magic and a million things to see and do.......a must for most evenings and you will never do or see the same thing twice.........
A Kaleidoscope of Life. One of the world's unique places. Different at every hour of the day. Every time you visit there's something new to catch your eye.

all action. This place is a must see at night. The crowds are there to be amazed but the various street acts, snake charmers, monkey handlers, water sellers and total action. Go to a restaurant with a terrace, have a drink and view the action from above to take some unobserved photos. If you have been out earlier take a jacket as it can get windy and cold form the terrace.
Wow. Exciting, noisy, sometimes smelly, but wow. Snake charmers during the day, monkey dances and exciting food.
my holiday. be prepared for a full muslim and very busy experience
Busy main square. People there very aggressively want money for photos .. annoying. In the evening it is wall to wall people, a bit overwhelming .. the snakes are only out in daylight!
Opens up your senses. An experience to be relished. If it's good enough for the locals them give it a go and you'll be rewarded with another tick iin the box in the experiences of a lifetime column.

What an experience. Great crowds, snake charmers, story tellers, musicians, dozens of fresh orange sellers, stalls, food stalls (including British cheek if you don't take up their offer!), horse and carriages, wizzing moped riders, people selling things and Henna artists to name but a few! An expereince I will never forget - try both day time and night time visits.

A one of a kind square. This is the place you will not miss anyway. very hectic life especially at night . We ate too much in here. brought some pounds back. don't worry , a gym adjacent.give it atry!!!!

Food stalls. Food prices and quality are similar almost everywhere . I recommend the harira and orange juice . I did NOT like the aggressive stalls employees who try to persuade and even grab tourists to eat at their place . I usually ignore them completely and move on .
What a culture shock!. What a culture shock.. Must-have place to visit, very cool and remarkable place to visit!

An experience to enjoy. Jamaa el Fna is different day and night. We only visited it once in the evening and wished we had come in more often. At night it is just fun to stroll around and experience what is going on around you, it is mad and crazy but enjoyable.Walking around the food stalls you will be continually hassled by the stall vendors but in a fun way and as long as you get their number for going back to, they will leave you alone. We ate at one of the food stalls which came recommended and if you like fish look out for number 98. There were no vendors here trying to 'sell to us' and when we sat down we seemed to be the only tourists, the rest locals. We had two portions of sole, chips, one portion aubergine and one of tomato and bread at a cost of 50drm and it was excellent and no upset tummy etc afterwards.Finished off with another stroll then a coffee on a terrace overlooking the square. A most enjoyable evening and one everyone should experience when visiting Marrakech.EnjoyBrian - homeexchange50plus
BEWARE OF THE BIKES AND DONT ANSWER PEOPLE OTHERWISE YOU WILL BE PESTERED. Its great both day and night, less busy during the day but manic at night.

Completely Unique. I have visited Marrakech twice now, and both times the squre at night has been one of the highlights of my trip. The unforgettable atmosphere filled with smoke and lights, the unique aroma and the instraments playing, then as dusk falls the squre springing to life as the stalls all start to cook and sell food, there are dried fruit and orange juice traders all around the square, the men with their monkeys and snakes and the ladies with their henna. In total it is an attack on the senses that becomes an unforgettable experience.
Joyful Madness. It's really something to experience. A mad circus filled with fortune tellers, drummers and acrobats.
avoid the beggars. too much hassling. Good to see from one of the roof terraces.

Essential Experience. Visiting the Jamaa el Fna at night is an essential part of any Marrakech itinerary; a stunning experience.To enjoy, take your time strolling around at dusk, appreciating the stalls, acts and so forth from a slight distance (and without showing too much interest) if you do not want to be pressured into buying, then retire to one of the terrace cafes overlooking the square.

Disappointing.... Good atmosphere first few times we went but became tiring and repetitive.Food was sometimes cold or overcooked and there was too much hassle for business from each of the stalls. It was nice to sit beside and chat to tourists from other countries and share experiences.

An assault on all the senses. This is the must see part of the medina, a vast open square that transforms from a tourist trap in the daytime to Marrakesh's entertainment centre at night. The abuse of live animals is disturbing but it would not go on if tourists stopped taking photographs and paying those exploiting snakes and monkeys.The food stalls at night is an experience not to be missed, you don't have to eat at them (and it may be wise not to)to soak up the atmosphere.Our favourite activity was to watch the children (and grown men) trying to hoop-la litre bottles of soft drink using long fishing rods.

Quite and experience... but not for the faint hearted!. Not long come back from a week in Marrakesh and obviously as its the main square we spent a lot of time here.I have really mixed feelings, because as an experience of a different culture it was amazing in some respects but scary and horrific in others.Yes, its great to sit in a restaurant overlooking the square and watch from above, but when you are in the square you are constantly hassled for money, followed and have people trying to get you lost so that they can get money out of you to take you back. On the way to the square in the evenings, and in the day for that matter, we constantly had people blatantly trying to tell us that the square was in the opposite direction. We are two girls in our 30's and were always fully covered and respectful, but on the first night we had a terrifying experience. All the approaches to the square are narrow cobbled streets - this is just the medina- but on certain nights it would appear that local gangs gather to squash people with the sole purpose of pickpocketing and groping.We were suddenly caught in a massive crowd, squashed together unable to move and thats when the groping started, hands blatantly everywhere - one guy even undid his trousers and started rubbing himself up against me.... I was horrified. We were spat at and called racist when we politely declined persistant attempts to be dragged into herbalist shops.I'm glad I went, because the experience of the different culture was a real eyeopener, but I'd never go again. If we had been older, or with men, maybe the experience wouldn't have been so scary..... but it was.

Simply blows your mind. I had read about Jemaa el Fna, but the place simply blows your mind, especially at night. It is a once in a lifetime experience. The combination of sights, sounds, smells is simply out of this world. We saw musicians, snake charmers, dancers, and all sorts of interesting people. and the food at the food stalls is great. I have travelled a lot, but this is one of my favourite places ever! the funny thing is .. there is no "attraction" to reveiw, it is simply the experience.

Excellent. The best time to go is in the evening after maghrib all the lights sounds and noise animals is a great experience for adults and children. I've found morocco is a very safe place to be and it's best to have a good attitude to new experiences and not to expect too much but I found jemaa el fna delightful.

A world in itself.. Crowded, bustling with activity, so many odors your head swims with an overall dizzying effect. From food to cheap goods, to the restaurants that vary in cost and more people than you can imagine, fruit vendors, a small department store, and a gelato stand, Jemma El f'na is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
what a buzz. haggel to yoiurs hearts content loved it.just be ready for them

less than expected. Maybe its better in the weekend, but on the Tuesday evening we visited the place there was not so much entertainment (some drums and a snake, not the enthousiasm as described in the LP)

Arabian Nights. It was so different, during the day the usual stalls selling hats, trinkets etc with Monkey Handlers and Snake Charmers what a place!! At night it transforms into a meeting place for story tellers, fortune tellers etc and the stalls are cooking and selling all the local Morrocan delicacies.

Not just a big square. The large square Jemaa el Fna is both the best and the worst of Marrakech - it had snake charmers monkey trainers side shows musicians food stalls etc and it had a few people who were just trying to harass you and rip you off - not to be missed but be careful - you cannot help looking like a tourist - having said that we got lost in the side streets and were helped by someone who did not want anything for his trouble - like most places Morocco has some really nice people

Iconic site in Marrakech maybe built up to be more than it is. This square is what makes Marrakech Marrakech. Without the square it is said the city is just another city. After reading so much about this site before we arrived in Morocco, maybe I was expecting too much. During the day time, there were many Moroccans walking around with monkeys or ladies offering henna tattoes, a few snake charmers, a few men dressed in traditional clothes beating on drums, but no acrobats, street dentists, story tellers etc. Also not so many tourists when we were there in March. At night a lot of food stalls are set up at the edge of the square, many selling basically the same foods, and lots of juice stands. The centre of the square itself becomes very dark and filled with the local people. We have visited many night markets all over the world, esp those in Asia. Maybe the travel writers made this place a bit more glamorous, exciting, exotic and mysterious than reality. Still worth at least 1-2 visits both at daytime and nite.

Much to see. Such a large space filled with orange juice stands, spice stands, snake charmers, henna ladys etc etc that there is a site at every turn. Nice to have some space after the busy streets and some good photo oppitunites too.

Best market ever. A large, complex, market adjacent to the main square of the old Medina, a world heritage site. The traders try to get the best possible price but that is part of the fun, negotiating about different items of a multitude that would make any mall in the Western world look pale and boring. Monkeys and snakes are to view only, but non-living produce can be bought and traditional food is available for quick breaks from shopping.
We went there every single day ... for a different experience. A very touristly thing to do is sit in one of the cafe terraces around the square sipping coffee.

You should definitely go once, but go with eyes wide open.. I think we tourists all envision the square to be an exotic gathering of locals, tourists, entertainers, and food stalls. Yes, I don't doubt it might have been this way once, but the reality is that it is officially a tourist attraction. The locals are completely aware of this and will work very hard to get money from you in many different shapes, sizes and forms. I would recommend visiting, but go prepared and have your wits about you.The first night I went there, I wanted to go to Stalls 1, 14, 32. However, the food stalls are not in any order. I was able to spot 1 and 32 easily; 1 was in the Northeast corner of all the food stalls, and nearby 32 was in the Southeast corner. However, 14 was not found. I wandered up and down the aisles of food stalls and this was a terrible idea. I was getting grabbed and stopped by every food stall worker, luring you to sit down and eat at their stall. I would politely say no and ignore, but that wasn't enough and I also had to aggressively pull my arm away. We finally gave up and sat at 32 to have some of the lamb sausage they are known for. The entire place is packed, but I actually didn't think it was very good. We grabbed an OJ at nearby stall to wash away the taste.I also avoided eye contact with any of the men with the animals (monkeys, etc) and did not stop to admire any of the belly dancers (they were not good) or the men with their ornate costumes and instruments. I also knew not to take a picture with any of these people, as they will immediately ask for money. I did, however, stop to watch locals playing a game that involved fishing rods. I surreptitiously took a picture with no flash, and immediately a man approached us for money. My husband at first resisted and was causing a scene; I was worried other cohorts would join in the argument. I persuaded him to give the guy a few DH and we were on our way. So, overall, avoid pictures in the Southern part of the square that has all the entertainers. It is not worth it, unless you are ok with parting with a few DH.This particular part of the square is also very dark; the food stalls are lit up by all the lights that are hanging, but the entertainers gather in very dark places. Whenever there was a crowd huddled around a certain entertainer, I did notice young boys that were cruising the crowds and looked like they were trying to pick pocket. If you are using a bag, keep it in front of you and zipped up. If you are a man, try to wear pants with zipper pockets or keep your money in a safe place. My husband was also approached to buy illegal drugs; ignore and keep walking. As for the ladies, watch the women that want to do henna on your hands. Most are easy to ignore because they beckon you from a seated position. However, some are more aggressive. They will compliment you and even if you decline, they will grab your hand and try to give you a "sample", or "gift" and will attempt to henna your hand. I would quickly snatch my hand away; make sure those henna pens do not leave a drop of ink on your skin or they will demand money.I was a little shaken by our initial visit, but we were undeterred and came back again another night. This time, we went straight to Stall 1. Yes, the entire place is tourists, but we wanted an easy, casual meal. The food may not be the best, but it was good enough and cheaper than many of the restaurants in the area. Also, whomever the food stall worker that seats you and takes your order - stick with that person for all of your additional orders. I think they all fight for tips; whatever they get, they keep. So, we stuck with one man, Fiesl, who was so helpful and friendly. We enjoyed his service so much we came back the next night. He immediately remembered us, sat us down, and even wanted to take a picture with us. He was truly the shining star in an otherwise chaotic square.Also, be aware that there are little children and women selling tissues. Oh, yes, bring your own hand sanitizer and tissues! This proved to be invaluable in my visit to Marrakech as a whole. Sadly, there are tons of women and children that have been thrown out on the streets to fend for themselves. You become numb to it, but there are times we would have small pocket change or leftover food and we would give them to the beggars we would see on the way back to our riad. I was hesitant to do that in the square because everyone will swarm you, but perhaps be mindful of them when you can.Lastly, I enjoyed finishing off our trip to the Square with a stroll to Patisserie des Princes. It is on a pedestrian only street directly south of the Square. It is lit up with white and red lights down the middle of the street. The Patisserie is on the left. They sell gelato (I liked Nougat) for 9DH. Overall, it was definitely an experience. If you go in cautiously, but also don't take it too seriously, you will come out having a good experience.

You have to go, but maybe don't eat there. So when you're in Marrakech you have to go obviously. It's a bit of a random spot, loads going on, lots of noise, esp at night. It's a great experience if you can get past the constant 'hassling', which you should do, but yo can probably find better food. We were pounced on as soon as we got there by four different guys thrusting menus in our faces telling us they all serve the same things so come to my restaurant. But one asked us "What's the craic???" and being Northern Irish we had no choice but to eat there. The veg thing was disgusting, the meat kebabs were only ok and considering we only had two bottles of water, almost 200 dirhams was kind of extortionate. There were some other places off the square that are more reasonably priced and the food is better. But don't miss out on going at all.Just keep an eye out for people with snakes and monkies...they will want money! ANd shout for police if they give you bother.
time stands still here. you can eat very cheap here...the stand holders can be pretty pushy though....go in with a sense of humour otherwise they can drive you nuts!
Try stall number 1. Very cheap lots of fun and we ate at the number one stall many nights - service was great as was the food - especially the potato cakes

Why we went. Place to be but expected more lots of story tellers but only good for locals, snakes, monkeys etc daylight only very dark in square at night hard to see whats going on. food stalls good but try to sell it a bit over the top to the point were they anoy u

Enjoyable madness. You can have orange juice in the day, get lost into any of the streets coming out of it into the soukhs, wander around at night trying to find some food.As long as you are not easily annoyed by the people from different stands and shops to follow you around trying to sell you something or another, and take it in as part of what it is, the fun of haggling, the fun of finding what you want to eat, having a joke with them. Relax and let yourself go, and you will not regret it.
Dont be put off by Hawkers. Yes you will be hassled and sold everything under the sun but it is part of the experience. I polite smile and a firm no usually do the trick.
Amazingly magnificent. Really good just beware of palm readers and there tricks please and for pick pockets who will try and take money etc.
Amust see!. If you haven't been before. it's like nothingyou've ever seen before. music, monkeys, snakes,acrobats, dancers,dentists, boxers etc,etc.

Visit the the place of storytellers and merchants. This is a place to get lost in wander around in the souks shopping and haggling. If you visit Marrakesh you have to go there. In the night, after 8pm, there is is an excellent food market
Mad and fabulous. Brace yourself and keep smiling the sellers can be persistent but usually friendly and good natured.

The pulsing, exciting heart of Marrakech. I don't know if any other open space in the world has achieved UNESCO world heritage status, but when you come to the wild and chaotic Djema el Fna, you will know it is deserved. By day home to snake charmers, dentists, tattooists, jugglers, orange-juice sellers...and by night by an incredible variety of food sellers selling everything from bubbling pots of spicy snails to brochettes of beef, merguez, sheep's head...and it is a riot of life. At least once during your stay, do make sure to eat here.

not what we expected. bustling but not with toursist, infact we appeared to be the only tourists in the square - this was good - getting a real impression of what the locals get up to, but it did mean we got a lot of hassle, particularly from the food stalls. Also we expected lots of small stalls selling different foods - one with lamb, one with chicken and to be able to flit from one to the next, however it was more a case of every staff had everything - how do you decide! We had a fantastic chicken kebab in a bun with hot chilli sauce from number 32 (because it was crowded with locals) and then had fantastic deep fried squid and prawns at number 114 - the harira soup was disappointing though!

lively and noisy!!. Jemaa el Fna was very touristy but I suppose that is to be expected! The square was alive with sights and sounds, snake charmers, transvestite dancers, colourfully dressed water sellers,monkey trainers etc. The people were very friendly and not intimidating, as I had feared they may be. Very lively. At night the square was also full of food stalls. Preferred in day time though as I could see more!!
Excellent for people watching.. A great place to rest hot and tired feet and watch the world go by with a cooling drink.
Fast and Furious. This square was wonderful,full of exciting things to see.The food served on the stalls at night was great as was the banter that came with it! Don't miss the fresh orange juice.
Interesting.... I've seen nothing else quite like this place, and it's an essential visit if in Marrakech, in the day and the evening.
Pure Theatre for ALL the family. Love the ambience in the evening, enter the square at sunset to sound of the call to prayer - goosebumps for even the most jaded traveller.
must-see. go any time after night fall - fascinating. Dont go if you dont like to see monkeys to haveyour photo taken with

Atmospheric, but not particularly amazing. Busy atmospheric centre of the Medina. It was a good place to people watch and soak up the atmosphere but it is also a tourist trap. Having spoken to some locals about it, they think it is losing its identity - not very authentic any longer and mainly for the tourists. The orange juice sellers in the morning water down their juice with water...so if you have a weak stomach, probably best to avoid this....food in the evening at the stalls is overpriced for what it is, it's not amazing quality-but a fun experience. The poor horses who drive unthinking tourists around mostly look like they are dying on their feet so probably best not to support this. Also, I have serious animal welfare concerns about the snakes as some of the snakes being held by the snake 'charmer' looked pretty lifeless/possibly drugged. Henna women will grab you by any means so do stay clear of them if you don't want a little 'gift' left on your hand....remember that nothing comes for free and you should be okay.

Wild night in Jemaa el Fna. This is a wild place to visit. A place where all life is ! Every type of street entertainment - dancing, music, snake charming, magic tricks. The goal is to collect money from you for the entertainment so make sure to go with coins in your pocket rather than a big note (like we did !). Moroccans gather at the central food stalls to eat authentic local food - its lively, noisy and incredibly cheap and delicious . Alcohol free but its amazing how quickly you get used to tea with everything .
Amazing Square. Attack on the senses - so much going on but absolutely amazing. Snake charmers, food markets, fortune tellers, monkeys, tooth pullers. You name it, its there!

Insane and wonderful. Monkeys in skirts, donkeys, camels, snakes, storytellers, motorcycles, pedestrians and trucks, and hey, let's have dinner in the middle of all of it! that's the wonder of Jemaa el Fna!

Great food, stall number 1. So much fun in the square, its worth eating there even if you only do it once. Been to Marrakech twice and never been sick from eating at stall number 1, you can easy have a big meal for 2 people for about £8. Also try the "viagra" tea on the outside stalls, only 30p and tastes amazing.
The world biggest outdoor show!. Wild - unbelievable - wonderful sights. hated the poor monkeys with nappies and on chains. Horrible. The rest is just so fascinating.
Crazy place. Hated the hustle but loved the colour smells and atmosphere

Vibrant, Alive, Colorful!!!. so different to european sites but a must visit! If you are not keen on getting a henna tattoo, do not let the ladies in the square grab your arm even if its 'free' or 'a small gift to try', because it will NOT be small and it most definitely will not be FREE!! under any circumstances, do not pay more than 50 dirhams for it (app. 4 pounds) and and agree on the price BEFORE SHE STARTS!!! also, if you don't want anyone to put snakes, monkeys and other animals on you, do not make eye contact with them, and if they approach you say NO once, and firmly. just ignore them if they persist. if you are going to take poictues of them, be prepared to be asked for money - which is the case EVERYWHERE in Marrakech! before taking a picture of others (unless its a general one, i.e. of the square, the souks etc) check if you have to pay. and 20 dirhams for a picture (1.50 pounds) is the absolute maximum!!! :p DO negotiate the price for EVERYTHING, no matter how guilty you feel at first and no matter how hesitant the seller is. if he is not willing to lower the price, just walk away - you are guaranteed to find it elsewhere for a LOT cheaper and there is a 85% chance he WILL come after you with a lower price!! :p

The Energy is Electric Indeed. There is always the twangy music coming from somewhere or other .. hawkers.. people trying to get a dirham out of you.. shops after shopsthis is one of the more unique places for a tourist in the world

Magical Square. We visited the square both in the daytime and again in the evening. We thoroughly enjoyed walking around, watching people ply their trade - whether it was snake charming or even someone selling false teeth! The evening was even more amazing, I've never seen so many people out enjoying themselves eating food from the many, many stalls. Proves to don't have to have alcohol to have good time. Has to be seen to be believed!
Loved it. It loud and busy and you get hassled by sellers but it's wonderful. Full of colour and wonderful smells

Truly, the quintessential Marrakesh experience. Jemaa el Fna must be seen to be believed. It's a huge open square, with a crush of humanity milling about. At any hour of the day, it's utterly fascinating. In the mornings, there are cars and taxis making deliveries, mule carts, tour busses, and the start of commerce setting up. Later on, the cars, taxis and tour busses are relegated to the edges, but caleches and many more people take their place. Come dusk/nightfall, the restaurants spring up in the center. At all times, large crowds, people on bicycles and motorscooters going in all directions, snake charmers, ladies doing henna decorations, jugglers, monkeys. Raucous and endlessly fascinating.
Daunting. Beware everyone is after your money and wants to be paid even for a photograph or if you film! The Orange Juice is a MUST for just 4MAD a go.. yum!
Snakes. Lots of fun and extraordinary things going on including street boxing!

Madness. By day it's full of henna tattooists and snake charmers but it changes into an amazing night time experience with the food stalls and performers. Be careful of the traffic - you need eyes everywhere. Don't miss out on the fresh orange juice - what a treat for 40 dirhams

awesome!!!. the highlight of marrakech, go there enjoy the sounds, the smell and the charm of the snakes, storeytellers etc. and have dinner on the square.. its a great experience. We often went to number 26 Chez Mahoud :)
Why are you in Marrakech?. If you don't know what Jemaa el Fna is, you're in the wrong place.

A bit scary. If you don't mind a lot of noise and hectic bikes passing you and drums and snake charmers then you will lvoe it. Nightime it turns into something else!! When you want to eat you just want to eat. And this could be tiresome when everybody is haggling with you to eat at their "number 34" or 46 stall. Not my cup of tea, but you gotta visit it in the daytime and the evening once just to have that experience in marrakesh.
Packed full of things to see. Another fantastic experience - beware of traders offering a 'present' they will then expect one in return - namely money!!!

The world's a playground !. Loved the non-stop animation. Enjoy the fresh juices, best vitamins ever. Open your eyes wide, spot the evening stalls where the turnover is high and enjoy the view from one of the terraces (La Place is nice, easy-going and tea not overpriced !)
Utter madness but fun...... It's a crazy place, especially at night but the atmosphere is fantastic. We ate a couple of of times at the stalls in the square... the food was excellent.

Not as good as it once was historically. Just a very large area with shops, banks, restaurants, food and drink stalls, locals selling all sorts of things and lots of tourists.There use to be a nice buzz about the place but now it feels very commercialised and everything seems so much more expensive than it used to be. This is the main attraction of Marrakesh so you will probably go there a few times. Enjoy it for what it is but its not so special!

Crazy chaos. Any visitor to Marrakech needs to visit the square.Full of perfomers annd entertainment.We ate there in the evening food was delicious and we suffered no ill effects.
Animal cruelty apparent though particually with monkeys this was the only downer.

Too aggressive. My kids were scared to death by the agressive tactics of the vendors in the square. The way they chased you, particularly when we had small children, was unforgiveable. We had to redefine our Jemaa el Fna strategy, only going at less aggressive times (at night where you're not as noticable) or if we went in daytime, kept a wide berth from the center and made no eye contact whatsoever. Was disappointing.

Culture with a twist.... This huge square is unique. During the day the orange juice verdors rule the plaza. At night it's overrun by the food stalls and street artist. All stalls are numbered. Some of the best tips we got (from locals) for foodstalls were stall numbers 1, 15 and 31.The only downside is that some street artists are too greedy. As soon as you want to look what's happening inside a circle of people, they shove a hat in your face to demand money. This makes me walk off while in a different situation I would deffinately give them something if I see a show.

Another world. Like a three ring circus, there's something for everyone at Jemaa el Fna; from animal acts and snake charmers to acrobats and henna artists in the day and in the evening, there are musicians, story tellers and games. There are fortune tellers and desert nomads to sell you a good luck talisman and merchants selling anything you could want. Then there are the evening food, tea and sweets stalls serving food representing the tame side of Morocco all the way to the more exotic side of this amazing country. It is not to be missed.
a must see. exciting, colourful , terrifying (just the traffic) place , have a mint tea on a terrace and watch from the outside for a while.
Yummie food!. Go for the stalls that have many locals sitting and enjoy.

Too crowded. interesting place but we were bothered a little by beggers and sometimes it felt a little intimidating with some tough looking guys who try too hard to be your clendestine nguide , the best thing to do is to ignore them....

Traders by Day - Restaurants by Night. A hub of snake charmers, entertainers and fruit sellers by day.Fun to watch the place transform into many outdoor restaurants by night.Even more fun to watch the tactics of the restauranteurs to entice you to eat at their stall - each cheering and applauding every time they are successful. The food at these outdoor restaurants is delicious and good value for money.
a site. classic and exciting, vibrant, noisy, great buildings, easy access, a must-see

Tourist trap - avoid. In all honesty, the medina, souks and Jemaa El Fna square that are recommended as a must see in all guide books was the least enjoyable aspect of our stay. We couldn't enjoy browsing the souks because of the constant hassle from sellers and others. It was not friendly, it was intimidating and completely over the top. Jemaa El Fna square at night is just a tourist trap and in my opinion not even entertaining. Dark, seedy and very dodgy. The snake charmers, male belly dancers etc just want your money and if you don't play along they are verbally abusive. Go for half an hour and never go back. We made the mistake of eating at stall 118 and were totally ripped off..avoid. This is in total contrast to the rest of our experience in marrakech where we were met by friendly, helpful people everywhere. Would recommend the Marjorelle Gardens, Gueliz and L'Hivernage area for bars/restaurants and day trips out to Ourika Valley and Ouzoude waterfall. Oh, and a Hammam...we booked a couples one at www.easyspamarrakech.com which was fantastic.

Hectic and charming. Always something going on from morning 'til night. You have to be on your guard against the multitude of 'salesmen' just waiting to become your friend but once you're used to it it becomes part of the charm.

Manic and Chaotic. On our first full day in Marrakech we took a taxi from our hotel (Le Meridien N'Fis) as we had not orientated ourselves. The taxi driver did the usual 'its closed today, go this evening I take you on tour' which we declined and after going in the wrong direction for some time eventually we managed to get him to stop the taxi in the Medina and find our own way to the square!During the day there are juice sellers (the water they sell is sealed and fine to drink didn't try the juice) snake charmers, 'costumed water sellers' and a variety of musicians. If you want to interact with the above they will flock to you like magnets and you can quickly become surrounded by jostling musicians placing their hats on your head, they will then look to be paid 10 - 20 Dirhams each for the privilege, fine if you want to interact in this way, but they will also do this to you as you merely walk past. One gent placed a live snake around my husbands neck without any interest in him being indicated, whilst we were walking through the square to the souks, it took several strong requests in French before this man removed the animal, and still he looked for some money. You may well be fine with such behaviour, but if you are not be firm and keep walking, they are after making a living and won't pursue you for long. The souks lead off the square which were very pleasant to walk through, there are polite invitations to look at the various shops but no hard sell. In the evening the square transforms into a large number of eating stalls serving all manner of foodstuffs, there are also dancers, musicians, show shine, snake charmers, monkey handlers to name but a few. The dancers and musician attract large groups of both locals and tourists around them, this is the time to be aware of pickpockets, which are no worse here than anywhere else you may find them, just be aware. I looked around and noted two young men who were obviously looking at us with more on their mind than what clothes we were wearing. I caught the eye of one and shook my head, at which they both moved away. This place is perfectly safe and I would have had no problem being there on my own, we split our money between various parts of clothes mostly in an anti pickpocket wallet down the front of my husbands trousers!To get a good view of the evening activities make an early reservation in the La Marrakchi restaurant in the north west corner of the square. It has an upstairs dining area with panoramic views across the square, with Moroccan and European dishes on offer. They offer a variety of wines with a good Moroccan red being about 190 Dirhams.Also available from a promenade which leads from square to Avenue Mohammed V are the caleches - which a horse drawn carriages. These will whisk you around the Medina for an hour for about 200 dirhams. There are touts who will approach you offering the services of the horse carriages, we chose to deal direct with the carriage driver and where then harangued by one of these touts who decided that we had slighted him in some way, and owed him money! As neither my husband or I are timid creatures we gently but very firmly told him that we chose who we hired and he should go away. His friend eventually took him away. We used carriage number 180 which has a lot of polished brass with two very well looked after horses, he proudly displays yearly awards he has had for the excellent care he gives to his horses. If you want to avoid the touts walk along any of the streets and you will soon be approached by a passing caleche, likewise this is the best way of getting your taxi as the touts operate even more aggressively in this area for these especially at night, one tried to drag me out of a taxi as he wanted me to use his, I dared him to touch me and almost growled at him. Not a pleasant experience and not one I would want to repeat. A good alternative during the day is tourist bus, it stops on demand as well as having designated stops, you can get it from the caleche and taxi area, for 24 hours its 145 Dirhams per adult and for 48 hours 190, so good value. You can hop on an off when and wherever you want, and you can get to and from just about all the main attractions. If you are staying in the Le Meridien it stops just outside, runs every 30 minutes, last one being 1745 hours.We had planned to eat in the square one evening, we love street eating in the Far East, but for a reason I cannot explain we didn't do so, possibly that there were some aspects that I found distasteful eg snakes and monkeys being dragged and draped around.An excellent place for lunch is the Marrakech Ground Zero restaurant which is located opposite the Koutoubia Minaret and Mosque, with open terrace and closed dining. Does Menu du Jour, but highly recommended is the excellent Salade Nicoise.If I can help further please do not hesitate to contact me.

Bonkers but entertaining. We found the henna tattoo ladies very pushy. They tried to put henna on you as you walk past. Make sure you negotiate a price before they start as one tried to charge 50 euros!! We stood firm and gave the going rate.

A great place, day or night. Whether watching the sun set over the Koutoubia Mosque as the men set up the food stalls below, and the snake charmers and musicians, storytellers and henna artists delight passerbys, or having a meal at one of the grills, this is a magical place at any time of the day.
Complete madness. You have to see it once, although they try to sell you everything, it's really vibrant at night time...

The most famous and lively place in marrakesh. I advise travelers to go there after six, as before that they will not feel the place in its climax. The place is very crowded by people from every where in the world, and by the people showing their talents in training monkeys, in making snakes dance, in plying music and dancing, in offering different types of foods and drinks. The atmosfere is magnifesent and every one will definitly enjoy it and remember it for the rest of his life. Please do not miss the fresh orange juice served there, and choose a cafe to enjoy the moroccan tea, or you will miss much.

Where everything happens. From snake charmers to story tellers, everything happends in el fna square. At around 5pm all the food shops get mounted for diner. We tried no. 1 and werevery pleased withthefood
Never ceases to take my breath away!. Late at night its just the sheer theatre of the place, in the early morning grab a pancake at the cafe near the OJ stalls and just sit and watch the world go by.

A place where you can spend hours just watching what's happening!. There is so many things going on there with monkeys, snakes, musicians, gymnastics performing, places where one can buy juices, have legs, feet and hands decorated so one can just walk around for hours, - or even better sit down at one of the cafees around the square.

Interesting and Busy. It was lovely to sit on the side and watch the hustle and bustle of the folks going about their business. My wife hates Snakes but as they were confined to the centre of the square, you can easily circumnavigate the snake charmers and enjoy the rest, without problem.
stunning. dont miss it.....and dont eat before you go in the evening

unique. just unique and magical, snake charmers watermen,story tellers
the very pushy henne ladies, and the great food stalls set up every night, and my favorite , the sausage stall.....

PEOPLE WATCHING PARADISE. Orange sellers early in the morning followed by snake charmers and men with monkeys! Acrobats in the afternoon then a profusion of food stalls in the evening plus the musicians, fortune tellers and story tellers.There is always something to watch in this most amazing of squares.
Essential Marrakech tourist spot. Great experience - the view of the sunset from the rooftops, just as the action is starting in the square is definitely something that needs to be seen.
Nightlife. Crowds of locals and visitors being offered and often bombarded with a wide variety of street food.
Hustle and Bustle. A must-visit location to sample the atmosphere of Marrakech. You need to have your wits about you. Everyone is on the make.

Didn't get the hype. Before going to Marrakech this was one of the 'sights' i was most looking forward to seeing and experiencing. After being there for a few mins i just didn't understand what the hype was about.It's a square, which during the day has hundreds of people pestering you to either buy orange juice, photos with monkeys (don't get me started on them), photos with snake charmers, or henna tattoos, and that's about it. Very busy, and you can't just stand still for 5 minutes to relax and take in the sight. At night it gets really busy, with food stalls, storytellers, dancers, etc. Again, constantly getting pestered. We sat down to eat one night as we wanted to experience having a meal on the square, what a mistake. Poor quality, cold and expensive for what it was, food. We ended up paying around €40 for two, and all it really was was poor quality spanish tapas type food. For a little bit more we were eating in beautiful, classy restaurants with wine. Every other restaurant person tries to quote English phrases, which for the first 5 minutes is amusing, until it gets very annoying!Unless we missed something this square offered nothing to our 4 day trip, and if anything we tried to avoid where possible going through it. We've been all round the world and visited many similar places, but just didn't understand what all the fuss was about!
