Snake charmers, camels etc. A place from Arabian night that you did not know existed still. Freshly squeezed juices, good food from the food stands and entertainment makes this one of a kind. There is no other Jemaa el Fna!

THE place to go. Jemaa El fna is the very heart of old Marrakech. This is the place you see on all photos as well as in all movies about Marrakech. Simply put : amazing !! The best time to get there is in the evening and if you do so we'd recommend you have dinner at "restaurant riad Monceau". Best Moroccan restaurant in town and it's just about a hundred yard from the square (a 2 minute walk).
Busy square. The square, is a definite place to spend some time walking around. There is so much happening, and very lively all day.

A must see. Of course its crowded and tacky and in your face and offensive to anyone interested in animal welfare - but it is the timeless face of Marrakech. If you chose not to visit why are you in Marrakech?

must experience. we were hoping for more snake charmers but at the same time were glad there were only a few! It's fun to witness the sellers, snake charmers, monkeys, and fully dressed belly dancers along with grabbing a bite to eat from the instant restaurants that appear every evening. It's the sound of this square you'll remember most. (relish for its excitement and energy as well as be happy you booked a Riad far from its noise)
Wow. Watch out for the people who either put a monkey on ur shoulder or plaster u in henna they soon ask for the money for it even if u did not ask for the experience
A circus for tourists. If you like hordes and multiple hands grabbing you to take you here and there, asking for coins (and never satisfied), this is the place. Some may like the food stalls.
A cross roads of the World.. Just sit and take in the atmosphere. Afica's answer to Piccadilly Circus, but with hugely added charm. Sooner or later i am sure everyone passes through here
magic each day of the year. dont miss a late afternoon visit in Jemaa el Fna. it s magic

Assault on the senses!. Everybody visits the square. During the day a bit smelly and busy with traffic winding its way across. During the evening transforms into an area with a real buzz! Food stalls amusingly vying for trade, lots of diffeent lovely smells, noise lights.. a bit of a wow!
Must see. Not to be missed - one of the classic attractions of Morocco.

Had to be seen but nothing special!. The square itself was nothing special - just lots of stalls selling tat, nothing like what is on sale in the souqs.The best bit is sitting high up on a roof terrace with a drink (although non-alcoholic anywhere near the medina and mosques) and people watching.

Full of tourists and pushy street sellers. We saved this until the end of our trip because we had such high expectations, and were very disappointed. Having spent the whole week walking through souks and nice markets being treated well by the sales people and buying several items, it was such a disappointment to visit the square. Everywhere else in Marrakech people were keen to speak to us, rather than just sell us something. The snake charmers were terrible, and later we found out that for special occasions they bus in real snake charmers. The snakes were just wandering off around the market chased by charmers. We started in the square on an organised tour and I was literally grabbed by one of the snake charmers and told - 'pay money to take photo', when I said I didn't want to he simply repeated over and over again, while holding on to my arm. In the end I was extremely firm and he shouted '[--] you' at me. I would simply say this is not the real Marrakech, the people are purely there to make money. The only saving grace was we ate at a very good food stall (117) recommended by our hotel. If you venture into the square I would recommend the chicken tagine there.
Entertainment. Great Fun watching your food cooked in front of you and the world go by at the same time, one of the great delights of Marrakech

prepare to have all your senses awakened!!!. whats not to like!!!!...by day story tellers and snake charmers,bustling souks full of incredible colours and craftsmanship.but by night it transforms into a massive restaurant full of all kinds of delicious dishes just waiting for you to try.

Try to eat at the evening market. Jemaa el Fna is one most magnificent places I've ever been. Take your time; try to enjoy the crowded admosphere and drink a glass of fresh orange juice (which costs 4Dh (40 eurocent))! But the best way of visiting this square is dining there in one of the many eating-houses on the square itself. Do not worry about hygiene, we did become sick! We went to number 65. Great experience!
Chill out!. Fantastic - just go with it, and enjoy the amazing sights and sounds....

amazing tho wild. had to constantly watch ourselves so couldn't relax, if we stood still we were hassled, we wanted to be left alone to enjoy the fantastic sites, sound and smells. would have been easier with a man with us i think
Djeema el Fna. Amazing! The atmosphere, everything about this place I loved.

Busy but fun!. You need to visit Jemaa el Fna in the day and night but prepared to feel harrassed and to say No thank you hundreds of times as the stall owners will try to get you to eat/ drink at their place. We didn't like the monkeys in chains and clothes or the henna artists (one was so persistent she grabbed my hand and hennaed me while I was trying to walk away).We were advised not to eat in the market itself, but there are plenty of reasonable cafes/ restaurants just round the edges, many charging 30-60 dirhams (£2.50-4.50) per tagine/ couscous/ kebabs.
on going entertainment. sit, relax and watch all the comings and goings, watch your bag though, esp at night!

total assault on the senses !. A must see just to experience the craziness that is the square - snake charmers, story tellers, henna artists, orange juice stalls, (very refreshing after making it through the souks) - everywhere you look there is something going on.

Jemaa el Fna. A completely crazy place! But brilliant fun to sit on a cafe terrace and enjoy people watching. Great to take a walk around watching the snake charmers, magicians, musicians, food and drink stalls and markets sellers. A day here is wonderful but don't miss everything else Marrakesh has to offer.

Day&Night. At daytime, you can come here to sip from a nice 'Thé glacé' while watching all the choas of Henna artists, fruit juice makers and the traffic. At night, storytellers are surrounded by interested people and tourists are enjoiying the good food! Don't forget to take a look at the different shops!

Too much to see. It is one of busiest places I have ever seen. Be careful when taking photos, you get asked for a small fee. There are pickpockets just like in most crowded areas. There is so much to take in so make sure you have lots of time.
wonderful. you'll try to take in all smells and sounds here, but you won't be able! Remember what you can and reflect afterwards, the best way to remember La Place!

A must see when visiting Marrakech.. Make sure you are prepared to be starred at and approached by everyone! A good place to have a laugh with the locals. It is best to go to one of the cafes/resturants and sit on the terrace and watch the chaos of the Jemma el Fna. The only thing that myself and my partner did not like was the way they treated the animals- monkeys on chains and the upkeep of horses used to take tourists around Marrakech! We also did not go up to the snake charmers as we know that as a tourist you will be ripped off, so we chose to watch from afar. The cleanliness of the square was brilliant, and even when it rained it was clean and not muddy. The food stools were also good. Although the square can be daunting at first just try and relax and enjoy yourself!

Wonderful, noisy, exotic, hectic, crazy!. I loved Marrakesh in comparison to Fez. However, I found the square to be a dicotomy to me of wonder to disgust. I really struggle with the treatment of animals, and stayed miles away from the snake charmers - I think animal rights organisations need to get a handle on this. The square bustles and comes alive at night, and I loved the energy and excitement. Moroccan culture means that you will be pestered, you will be asked to buy, you will be asked to see this and see that - its part of the excitement. IF this bothers you, stay in your Riad. Keep an eye out for pickpocketers - especially children who will prey on you, but stern words, and walk away with confidence and show you are actually in control (even if you dont feel it!) you will be fine. I loved enjoying the square from the restaurants, especially from the terraces, where you can enjoy the energy, without being pestered.Generally clean. The orange juice sellers were wonderful and that juice is so nummy!I did however expect more of a "circus", with acrobats, and dancers. The story-telling got lost on me - especially as it was all in arabic or berber, and there are only men which made me feel uncomfortable. The excitement for me was the cooking and all the stalls that roll in at sunset. Quite fascinating!

a feast for the senses. during the day, the square is relatively empty with just a few stands selling fresh squeezed orange juice (about 50 cents) and figs/dates. Snake charmers and monkey trainers can be found near the south end. As the sun goes down, the square fills with food stands. It is hard to make a recommendation - they are all good and reasonably priced. Al fresco dining at its finest!

Crazy. This is an experience of the craziness that is Marakech. Extremely good fun though. Yes there is a bit of hard sell at the food stalls at night. But it is all part of the good natured banter. So long as you are not too fussed about hygiene you will love it. Warning. Do not drink from the glasses. Or eat from china. Ask for plastic or paper plates, cups and cutlery. As there is no running water at the stalls, everything is washed in the same bowl of water.

UNESCO world monument status very worth it. Ask yourself what it would take to give a living, breathing square given UNESCO world heritage status...hard to imagine until you see this throbbing, lively open heart of Marrakech in full swing, at almost any time of day. From the orange juice men and snake charmers by day, or even the dentist who offers to extract teeth with pliers...or the food stands at night...It is truly amazing. Eating at one or several of the food stalls is an absolute must...just choose stalls that have a lot of people at them--always a good sign. I've had great experiences with stalls 65 and 28...but you will surely find your own.
Amazing. spend 3 or 4 hour here, eat at one of the many restaurants or in the night market that pops up at dusk, beware of the monkeys you will be chared for a photo with them
The Square. Magnetic, exciting, packed 24/24. Snakecharmers, acrobats, scribes. henna painting, monkeys, food and people , people eveywhere.

Overrated. I know this is the #1 attraction in Marrakesh, but it didn't do anything for us. Lots of people, poor monkeys, snakes, and their handlers who will harass you for money to look at, touch, or take photos with their poor pathetic animals. We purchased some very tasty roasted, candied nuts in the square.
Experience. Its a different experience if you go during the day to if you go during the evening, i enjoyed the evening alot more as you can sit on square and have some food at one of the stalls
wow. This is the place everyone has to visit whilst in Marrakech. It is an amazing mix of all kinds of people, food, smells, spices...

Mental!. Watch your pockets as they have teams of very clever pickpockets still working the square despite the efforts of the undercover Tourist Police.
We did eat at a food stall, but the food was very average and a little overpriced.
Mania. LOVE IT! But always give the snake charmers a wide berth
Stall 118. Very good food, no hard sell. Tip : do not sit at the edge of the tables or you will be bothered by sellers.
as expected. busy,noisy,hawkers,beggars and crowds.as seen on t.v.
crazy crazy!. wow totally changes daytime, monkeys, snakes, henna, nice juice, night time crazy food stalls and the best chai tea ever!
wonderful by night. Try the food at the stalls, you can eat as much as you like at ownest prices.

busy, smelly and a little scary for 1st time visitor. I don't really get the excitement of some other reviewers. We arrived expecting a 'cacphony of music and dancing' and didn't really witness this all the time we were there. At night the whole area was covered in a dense fog of diesel fumes, although the temporary cafe style food area that sprung up every night was exciting to walk through.
Busy. Gets really busy in evenings with dancers, monkeys, snake charmers & stalls.

Visit day and night!!. What can i say, what an experience, snakes and their charmers, monkeys with dresses, animals in cages, ostrich eggs for sale, chameleons being handed to you, live music, food stalls and their touts, all trying to get you to eat there, snail soup and tea stands!!! Its great fun and amazing, its making me laugh just writing this review and remembering the whole experience!! A must!!

Neither as large or as busy as I'd expected, but good fun.. I'd been lead to believe the square was huge and so packed with market stalls and people that it was impossible to move. Just shows how you shouldn't always listen to what others say!The square, whilst a reasonable size and certainly busy at times, was not as huge as I'd feared nor was it as packed as I'd expected. Which was a pleasant surprise.Plenty to look around, and a few things to watch out for.If you like orange juice, you are in luck! Many stalls selling very VERY fresh orange juice, sometimes squeezed there and then for you, pretty cheap and tasty not to mention refreshing.During the day there are various stalls selling all manner of wares, and by night the square transoms as it fills with countless open air restaurants each doing their best to tempt you to theirs which is always, of course, the best in the square... The food is good value and certainly tasty with meats, fish and salads aplenty. Things to watch out for - be wary of the people with snakes or monkeys, they will try to get the animal on to you and pose for photos, then demand money - watch out especially for the monkeys who often are trained to bite you if you start arguing about the price...And be careful of the "henna" people who will grab your hand and apply "henna" (not always henna) and demand money, you need to be firm and ensure they understand you do not want it before they start. A firm "no" or 3 does the trick.But those aside, the square is a lovely place to visit and hang out, the food at the stalls is tasty, and if you prefer something a little more sophisticated there are several cafes and restaurants around the edge of the square, some with balconies and terraces with good views over the square, great for a late night coffee before heading to bed.

BUZZING & CRAZY. Jemaa el Fna is amazing - full of snake charmers, monkies, men selling teeth, acrobats, dancers, actors and amazing souks. Watch out for people trying to put animals on you and then charging for it. Barter hard - work out what you WANT to pay, and then offer 1/2 - dont be afraid to walk away

Experience the culture of north Africa here. amazing square with people from all over the world in the cafe's and food stalls. Snake charmers, stalls and acrobats. would be better without the annoying bikes
An Experience. Every visitor too Marrakech should experience eating here just once in the trip. Food is cheap and ok but the street theatre of it will live on forever

A terrifying experience - to be avoided!. I was deeply disturbed by Marrakech and - in particular - Jemaa el Fna. It is NOT for the faint hearted!1) People WILL follow you to try and entice you to purchase their goods. They will stalk and pester you and it can be very disturbing. If you refuse to buy something when offered, you will often be SHOUTED OUT. I got called something incredibly hurtful because I walked past a stall holder selling orange juice and didn't want to buy any.2) Animal torture abounds here. Monkeys are CHAINED UP, BEATEN and FORCED to perform for tourists. It actually made me cry. 3) Women offering henna tattoos are disturbing and often supported by local gangs. I witnessed them start tattooing a woman WITHOUT HER PERMISSION. They then chased her down the street for payment. She was terrified and in tears and her husband had to shoo the gang away.4) The locals are terrifying and disturbing. As a previous reviewer stated, I too saw a woman get beaten by a man (presumably her husband). It was a disturbing and haunting sight that will stay with me forever. We got STALKED back to our hotel and it was a truly terrifying experience that I never wish to repeat. Locals stare at you with disgust if you stand out as a tourist.5) How anyone can eat here is utterly beyond me. There is NO CONCEPT of health and safety of food hygiene. Locals cook food after it has been dropped on the floor, and re-use cutlery without washing it. Yes, it's cheap, but isn't your health worth more?
staggering a scene from a werid dream. snake charmers tooth pullers so werid if made me outside of my comfort zone but good experiance
Wow. I defy anyone to find anywhere so close to Western Europe that is so radically different. Go. Just go here, stand and watch/smell/listen for a memorable moment in your life.

A must!. You can't go to Marrakesh and not go to the square. Its a must!Go at night to see the lively traders and the shops in the souks stay open too so you can shop, eat and watch. The sounds and sights are fascinating. We saw pictures everywhere of that scene but don't forget the camera to capture it for yourself.

Busy - worth a trip in the daytime and evening. This is the focal point of Marrakech. A large open square surrounded by bars, restaurants and market stalls. During the day there are snake charmers, monkey men and henna tattooist pleading for your money, along side orange juice and water sellers. At night the street kitchens come out and join the party with hundreds of waiters trying to convince you to eat at their table, even though they try to convince you all the food in the square is the same! We just went to the busiest one - seems like a safe bet... There are also dancers, musicians, magicians and 'doctors' in the evening. Some don't like photos, some are ok with them so ask permission first.My girlfriend is scared of snakes so we had to plan our route carefully during the day but in the evenings was fine.

great experience. During the day this place is full of street acts, but they all want money so watch from a distance, also take care with henna painters even if the offer you a free trial, the hassle will be on for money! At night this place really comes alive, so a must experience with lots of food stalls and acts, and a electric atmosphere.
Madness!. A whole collection of animal rights and health and safety infringements!
Busy, busy, busy. Go here to enjoy the bustle, but watch out for the monkey handlers, if you're not wary, you'll have a Moroccan makak on your shoulder before you know it.

Can't leave Marrakech without a visit!. Atmosphere, atmosphere, atmosphere!!!! Watch the snake charmers do their thing, partake in vendors selling their wares, and people-watch in this fascinating square. It really comes alive as the sun starts to set, so grab a mint tea & watch over the square from one of the many terrace cafes. Then, as all the smoke pours out of the food vendor stalls, jump back down into the square and grab some great tangine, seafood, meat skewers, and snail soup. What an experience!!

crazy jemaa el fna. didnt know what to make of it at first,but eventually loved it,such an experience,must eat at the night market,delicious cheap food,fresh squeezed orange juice and dates are delicious!! sip hot sweet mint tea from a terrace roof top and watch the craziness below.

Jemma el Fnaa. Jemma el Fnaa is a big square that in the daytime is filled with orange carts selling juices and nuts. But at night it transforms into a circus like arena definitely a must see. With vendors selling all kinds of things from hats to argan, candle holders to lamps. I read all kinds of stories of snake charmers and male belly dancers however did not see any of that when I went in Dec. 2011. Just vendors selling things and big crowds of people playing music and cards. There are ladies that will do henna for you. It is lively place to go see if you don't mind crowds.

Manic Centre to a Manic Town. Everything in Marrakech centres on the Jemaa el Fna. The huge Place is like a place to breathe after being caught in the almost suffocating souks. It is also where you meet and eat. It transforms from an open piazza with snakes and monkeys in the day to countless cafes serving overpriced and poor quality food in the evening.But despite the poor food, the experience is worth it. The barbecue smoke-filled air is full of the noise of waiters persuading you to join them. They change from accent to accent just to get you in - one recognized us each night and continued to quote lines from Kath and Kim to make Australians feel at home.But the best food here is not the night-time barbies - it is the fresh dates, nuts and dried fruits on sale to complement the freshly squeezed orange juice.
Day & Night. This has to be experienced at both ends of the clock. Just be wary of the 'moped-mayhem'!

MADNESS!. Great fun! Lots of good places to eat, sit down where you see the locals eating. Saying you've already eaten good response to the touts. Orange juice tasty. Watch out for monkeys and snakes, unless you wish to hold a monkey or snake (and pay for the pleasure).
A MUST. From shopping, to eating to entertainment, THIS is the place.

It's a Must!. If you visit Marrakech you must see the Jemaa el Fna square. During the day a marketplace with a handful of traders but by night a teaming mass of colours, sounds and sights. Take change and hang onto your bags and camera.

Everything you expect and more. Lots of locals , lots of wonderful Orange juice, great fish and chips, Morrocan style at night. Fortune tellers, snake charmers, musicians, and Henna artists. Probably would give a Health and Safety inspector a nervous breakdown!
Just wander around and visit both during the day and the night.

VERY BUSY...love it!. If you do not like noise, carnage, crowds then you will hate it!
But this is the heart of marrakech...if you do not visit then you will not be experiencing marrakech!
I loved it and visited every day...during the evening the square comes alive with both locals and tourists.

On my second trip.... I felt more relaxed and more eager to shop than ever. Since I never buy one of anything, bargaining was easier for two or three of the same item. It was also a different shopping experience in December than it was in July - not so touristy and it was easier to get the price I wanted. I also learned between visits several phrases in both French and Moroccan Arabic: Thank you, No Thank You, How much ? Never mind, and Where is ? I found being able to say just those phrases was very helpful especially if English is your only language. If crowds are not your thing - go in the morning. By the afternoon and evening especially in the summer, the square is THICK with people. At night, the spaces that were open during the day are filled in with outdoor restaurants. Really an exciting place to be. Yes, there are public bathroom facilities in the Fna. Past the orange juice sellers, past the nut and date sellers, behind the garden shop you will find stairs leading down to the facilities. Ladies on the right men to the left. There is an attendant outside (pay small dirham). Inside you will find little buckets, a water spigot, stalls, and a hole in the floor of each stall. Enough said ! There is a post office in the square where you can mail packages back to yourself. It takes about two-three weeks from Marrakech to Boston. Do Buy: a Sabra Silk scarf, a pair of Babouche, a djellaba, a leather bag, Black Soap, Kissee, Set of Tea Glasses, Tray, Tea, and Pot,Tassels, leggings ( in winter - warmest things ever) , Sliver anything, a rug or runner, and other things to fill your suitcase ( bring one empty) Eat: Dates, Nuts, Msemmen ( for breakfast -to die for), a Tagine, Bread, Fanta orange soda ( yes Coke is there), fresh squeezed orange juice, prickly pears ( summer) and of course drink lots of Mint Tea- but don't forget to just wander around and be engulf in the wonderment of the Jem3 el Fna. d

Avoid Ramadan when the people are as hot as the temeratures. Great place with lots of interesting things to see and history that is almost unparralelled.I would not want to go back again during Ramadan when the people are as hot as the middle of the day. The food is great and although the variety of great the prices are not as cheap as other places n the gastronomic world.

Lots of colour and activity. The best place to witness the square's hussle and bustle is from one of the many terrace restaurants lining the square. It is a riot of activity, and quite full on when you're amongst it. Beware the monkey owners, who will put a monkey on your shoulder and then ask for money to remove it, and of the snake charmers. Our riad told us a foreign snake expert spent time with them recently and none of the snakes have even had their poison sacks removed, they're just kept drugged. So you wouldn't want to get accidentally bitten by a strung out viper! Early evening is a lovely time to stroll around, so many locals out and about, lots of musicians, people hanging out. A nice scene. As with everywhere in Marrakech, be careful of the motorbikes that come out of nowhere, and the horses and carriages, keep your eyes open in every direction people, especially with small children!

Best Traders ever!. I liked it all, once acustomed to the vibe, it was very special and would liked to have been there longer. Dont be afraid to say no, be respectful, we are there because we can afford to be and they know it. Be open minded.

Be prepared to have your sense assaulted!. Good to be among the real Marrachis who stroll among the snake charmers, dancers, diners on local food. Did not like the captive monkeys that do not seem to be well cared for.

The place to be!. This is the epicentre of Marrakech. From snake charmers to henna tattoos this place has the weird and the wonderful. In the daytime you can grab a fresh orange juice from many vendors lined in there cabins on the square. It is also a pivotal point in which to orientate around the city as there is a huge minaret close by. Shops and restaurants surround the square that offer a wide variety of things. At night the atmosphere changes and lots of restaurants open on the square from which to get food. Be warned you will be hassled and sometimes physically touched to get you into restaurants, I cannot stress how much you will be hassled so expect the worst and then it will not be such a surprise. In the square there will be people playing banjos and drums with a crowd gathering around enjoying the sound and atmosphere as well as a fishing for drink bottle game. Absolute necessity to visit but with it being a tourist hotspot you will be highly hassled.

The center of the Marrakchi universe, part hub and part circus!. Every day, we ended up passing through Jemma el Fna at one point or other. It usually turned out that wherever we were going, the best way to orient ourselves was first to make our way to the square, then consult our map, and then strike out. And usually on the way back as well, we would go to the square.Honestly, neither one of us was keen on getting our picture taken with a monkey, or seeing a snake charmer. And we certainly didn't want to get stuck with those henna needles! (I wonder how many young ladies allow themselves to be stuck with needles?) We did wander through the square at night a couple of times, but it was more for the purpose of shopping and eating. We found that we saw more amazing sights on our way to and from the square than in Jemma el Fna itself. Nevertheless, we will continue to be big fans!

The centre of everything in Marrakech. I doubt if anyone visits Marrakech without visiting the main Square. The busiest and probably most exciting time is Sunday afternoon. So many things are going on here - from snake charmers to storytellers, to acrobats. Go to the top terrace of one of the many restaurants around the Square for a great view, especially at sunset.Evenings are different again. Many food stalls set up and you can sit and eat a complete meal here for around £6. Great fun.
Madness. Exactly what you came to marrakech to experience. Watch out for the mopeds.

Great for Nosh. At about 5 food stalls appear and the food is the best priced in the Medina - even ate crevettes there with no ill effect. Watch the extras - olives/bread/salas/dips all cost 5Dh each serving. But at 25-35 for Couscous or Taghia dishes its great value quick service and fun!Its pretty good in the day with the snake charmers and water sellers who charge you to photo them - but its better at night.Use the Mosque towers to orientate yourselves or you will get lost!
Beware. Very busy, beware of people offering to 'take you somewhere'. they will become threatenting if you don't pay them. I didn't but it can be intimidating.

A world in a day. Amazing melting plot of a place, changes throughout the day. Quiet mornings with juice stalls joined by various human and animal diversions later, full blown barbecues by night. Of course you can get ripped off, but keep your eyes open and wits about you and you will have a great time. Not a fan of monkeys with nappies though, or any captive animals used in this way - simple way to stop it is not to take photos of them!

loved the mayhem. Very busy place with entertainers during day, had been previously warned not to take photos especially snake charmers as they demand high prices. Night time was great as plenty of places to eat and atmosphere very good. only down side was very hassled to eat by every stall to the pont of nuisance. Food was good though when eventually sat down
must see. a unique experience that attacks all of the senses
Insanity on Toast. The universe writ small. Wonderful craziness! Don't be afraid to say no...

Lovely place but had very bad experiences. The people seem so friendly n nice e.g, lady forced me to wear henna. I kept saying no but she insisted after 30 seconds she finished. I asked her how much she demanded 300 dirhams. I pet saying no in the end had to give her 200. That I could've done for £1 in the uk. She charged me 20 times more. I looked a man playing with snakes there was 50 people there watching him, but he decided to come unto me and say you like. So I said yes very nice, he then asked me to take a photo but I refused as I was scared of snakes, it's ok watching them 20 meters away but getting close to them, nah!so I walked off, but he came in front of me and said I had to give him 200 dirhams. I didn't receive a service from him why should I pay. But then everybody gathered round me so I kinda got scared and gave him 200 to shut them up. Horrible experience. Taxis conned me. All in all I spent 500 pounds on taxi and looking in the souks minus shopping for 1 week. What a rip off!!!!

You will not get bored!. I don't think I have been in place were there is so much to see, touch, smell and hear!There is the people selling nuts and the best dates I have eaten!! You must try the dates and the nuts! The more you get, the more you can bargain the price down. Some places will show a priced as "fixed" depend what it is of course, the more Moroccan the product the most likely it is bargain-able. Forget in trying to bargain for shampoo and conditioner..The orange juice stands are incredible, very cheap (5dh per glass) but bring a bottle and they would do it for 20dh, you most try the juice! The restaurants far away from the Djemma el Fna are cheaper but hey 4dh is barely something in UK.During the day you have the snake charmers, the guys with the monkeys (which I personally don't like as I don't like animals for shows) If you don't like it, do as I do, completely bypass it. You have also the henna ladies, which you have to be careful for because they are FAST at doing hennas and in 5 secs can do the whole arm! Be very specific to what you want to get so there isn't any confusion or annoyance. During the night the place transforms drastically. There are restaurant stands selling everything. I most point out that they are VERY persistent with tourist to go and eat at their stand. I must also say that you are the visitor in Morocco and you must respect the way the do it, they even do it to Tourist Moroccans or Arabs from North Africa so it is a general rule. Just smile and kindly say "you will come tomorrow Inshallah" and they will leave you alone. Try to never be rude in Marrakech or to take it seriously. This is how they do it there and it is not personal, it is just another culture that once you experience, you will be very happy and will miss it lots!Back to the restaurant stands, they are not cheap for sure there are many other places to go and eat. There is one specially which is not inside the zone of restaurants but it is actually on the edge of the souq. It is exactly the same food but a little bit cheaper.. if it helps!You will find kebabs, skewers, lovely harira sauce with bread, olives, tajines, couscous, everything! Even you will see some goat head! haha very good. On the square there are the story tellers, they are normally speaking Moroccan (french/Arabic) but it is quite nice looking at them and see how they tell the stories.. their audience are usually huge crowds!Hopefully this was useful. If you need information about Marrakech, let me know!

good but take care. Worth while in the evening. So much to see and nice food to eat. But watch out for people who sell you something before you they did. Like the women painting your hand with henna. She does say you don't have to pay and at the end she will ask EUR 20 (where the locals pay only EUR 2).

you have to be there to feel the spell. Actually nothing in itself (a big ugly square with some shoeshineboys, foodstalls, juicecarts, surrounded by rooftopterraces, and some snakeshows etc....) there's a strange spell about the place, and the spell grows every time you pass (which is many times). Special place to say the least...

Vibrant settings. I particularly liked the orang juice kiosks. If you like orange juice the way I do, that should be your favorite hangout. With 4 dirhams, you drink a freshly squeezed orange juice. You have to remain alert as you would do in all squares. There are so many entertaining acts that can easily distract you. It's a fun place to be to take the pulse of Marrakech.
Great experience. Incredible experience, visit during different times of the day to get the whole picture!

A must to visit. It is better to go in the evening when there are plenty of eating places, always best to eat in the busy ones, with lots of stalls and entertainment. I have never had a problem but always advisable to watch your bags there as it is very busy. Always bargain when buying from the stalls and pay what you fell is a good price for what you are buying.
The crazy square. the square is in equal perts insane and wonderful, I really loved the place
once seen soon forgotten. full of people trying to rip you off much better places to vist

Amazing!. Hit up the night markets for dinner - just be prepared to be attacked on all fronts by eager market owners trying to get you to eat their food! Choose from snail stands, egg stands, meat stands or the ever popular stalls in the centre with everything from grilled meat to tagines and cous cous. There are also dried fruit and nut stalls, sweet carts that get pushed around, tea stalls with spiced tea (the white powder is menthol and will blow your top off!). In the morning the orange juice stands are especially great (less than E40c for a fresh juice!)

Djemaa el-Fna, Marrakech the place to be !. Now that the low cost airlines fly to Marrakech it makes it a great and cheap place for a spring and winter get away... You have all seen the photos of the main square, Djemaa el-Fna, lit up at night, but nothing prepares you for the smells and sounds of the square. When your taxi drops you at the top end of the square you will walk past the highly decorated horse drawn carriages and then enter the square itself...bathed in an orange light and smelling of spices and warm desert air you will encounter snake charmers, musicians of all kinds and story tellers, there are stalls selling fruit, snails, nuts and spices and as you wend your way towards the back of the square you will see more stalls selling food, goats head meat for the brave, kebabs, chips and salad for those of you that hesitate to join the locals for dinner. Over 60 food stall keepers add to the noise and merriment in the square, persuading you to eat at their particular stall with cries of 'LOVELY JUBBLEY' and various other English sit com and TV advert stock phrases...to enable a quick getaway tell them you have just eaten! At the far end of the square, if you have had enough food and entertainment, there is the opportunity to shop, from bathroom products to wooly hats, lamps and tourist paraphernalia; it’s all there waiting for you. Taking a wander down the ally’s of the souk will test anyone’s resolve not to spend money on things you don’t really need, but there’s the fun of it...how cheap can you barter for a cone of henna and a bag of figs? In the day time Djemaa el-Fna square is a great place to people watch and to spend time in the cafe's and balconied restaurants drinking coffee, eating cake, talking with friends or reading a book. It’s a place you will never get bored with and you will return night after night, day after day.

Simply Awful. This could be a wonderful, colorful place, but so many of the people who work it view visitors as "walking wallets." You cannot stop and take in the sights without being harrassed by touts, beggars, salesmen, hustlers, and snake-weilding wackos.

Lived up to all expectations!!. If for no other reason go to Marrakesh to visit this unique place and wonder between story tellers and dancers, snake charmers and potion hawkers filling your eyes with unforgettable images. Hungry? Go to eat fish at no.14 along with the locals, no need for aggressive sales here, the people waiting for a seat tell you it's worth waiting for.

you can see why its a world heritage site. the mass of people can be initially intimidating - with snake charmers and monkey men; however there lots of food stalls in the evening which are very clean; and souks are excellent shopping 'entertainment'

A little bit in your face........ It was a great experience although a little overwhelming for some with every step taken and the guys trying to get you to eat at their stall! But if you are brave enough and run the guantlet it's great fun and you just take your luck if you made the right choice! Usually go with the one that's busy. Great fresh orange juice squeezed just at you need it. Lovely!
This is why you go to Marrakech. Hang on to your wallet. Keep small change handy and enjoy

Really good for a day, not much more than that. The djemaa al fna is a must see in Marrakech. You probably won't miss it because your hotel is most likely right off of it. They have food stalls, snake charmers, guys that throw monkeys (seriously, watch out), henna, toys, and everything else you could imagine. Things start up around sundown and continue to around midnight-1am. For food: -skip out on stall Number 1 (they're all numbered) even though it's where everyone says to go. UNLESS you want calamari; they're the only place with fresh hot fried calamari.-go to the black stall near the performers (perpendicular to orange carts) for what i've dubbed the 'egg pocket.' For 5 dirhams you can get pita stuffed with potatoes, eggs, and cheese that beats all of the tajines and couscous you find in the square. If you're looking for good tajines and couscous, you've come to the wrong place. Another good thing to keep in mind is that you WILL get hassled to eat at every stall and nothing will prevent that. If you know where you want to eat, stay on the edges far from the stalls and only swoop in when you have to.
Lots to see. We tasted the food and survived. Wash it down with Coke and you will be fine

A busy square. One of the busiest squares in Africa and you feel it, especially after sunset when the place is packed with food stalls, snake charmers, henna ladies, people trying to sell you stuff. The main bus hub is here too.

One of the great sights of Morrocco. This sprawling square is the heart of the Medina and a mix of Africa, Arabic and Berber culture, the 'Place' (as everyone calls it in Marrakech) is best visited just before sunset as the foodstalls, performers and shopkeepers get going and the lights change from dusk to dark. Incredible!

Entertainment plus!. The smells, the sights, the sounds - brilliant. If you don't enjoy crowds stay away. We arrived late afternoon, perched ourselves on a terrace and watched the square transform as night fell then we hit the night market. The food stalls all have spruikers and every single one of the 100 or so will approach you however it is all good fun as long as you smile, play along and be clear that you are just browsing. The food is cheap and good. During the day you can get hassled. We found that learning to say "no thank you" in Arabic was very helpful at keeping pushy vendors at bay. The henna ladies can be very bad - I had to wrench my hand away before one could stain me! The orange juice from the stalls is refreshing and delicious. You can spend hours wandering around the alleys. If you get lost, ask a shopkeeper rather than a person, they will direct you in the correct direction.
Make sure to go at night!. At night time the square comes alive with people serving food in tents, all cooked in front of you! Very lively and a good way to experience Marrakech!

Fun and eclectic. Ana amazing place especially at night. Go eat in the night market at least once and be prepared to experience a real treat. Phrases like "Fully airconditioned" "Asda price" "Just like Harry Ramsdens" are commplace. All done with great humour and in no threatening.
Manic!. If you don't like bartering, stay away on Saturday late afternoon/early evening. I loved it, but then I'm a seasoned 'barterer'!
Jemaa el Fna. Nice, buzzing, busy, the real Marrakech. 1 or 2 visits enough though. With kids - probably 1 visit is enough.
Vast and entertaining. Loved the various activities including the night market and the water sellers. Managed to avoid the snakes and monkey handlers!

Lively!. Many many people from everywhere, the smells, the movement, the daylight and then the nightlife. All pretty amazing. On the bad side of it they are always trying to sell something and that can be bad at times.
A different experience for the Westerner. It has to be seen to be fully appreciated. And take videos if you can as well as pots - the videos will catch the movement and life which s brilliant.
Like no other place. the square , it is a true time machine , you step in that square and you are right in ancient times , snake charmers , monkeys , pick pocketers as well ...

Hugh array of food/games/music stalls. Wonderful mix of Moroccan food and hucksters, snake charmers and music groups. But the hustlers did keep following you - hard to shake off. Recommend going in a group.
FUN !!. Must see. mentioned previously in my review. the shop stalls have all same food same prices. very bubbly at night and also nice to see during the day... if you are not scared of snakes :-)
Snakes. Oh my... So many... And I'm absolutely phobic. The Square though is amazing!

Hustle and Bustle.. Jemaa el Fna...by day if you get there early it can be a quiet place, take a seat at one of the many cafes around the square order a coffee or fresh orange juice and sit and watch the square steadily fill with traders stalls and attractions. Snake charmers, henna tattoos and photo oportunities galore for a small price. Late afternoon they start bringing out and setting up the food stalls and BBQs for the evening. When the square is transformed into a bustling place full of people, eating at the many food stalls or just taking in the entertainment, musicians, dancers and my favourite the story tellers...and although I did not understand the language and so the story being told, it was fascinating to watch how the story teller held his crowd enthralled. A trip to Marrakech is not complete without a trip to Jemaa el Fna.
must see. you have to go just for the buzz with the people the smells the street acts snakes henna artists and the souks
Mediocre. Maybe it was the time of day - dusk - but I expected a lot more hustle and bustle.

Chaotic place but unique experience. This place is the centre of a lot of chaos and very aggressive salesman but becomes a entertainment hub in the night. It is not for everyone, be prepared to get harassed by sellers but it is part of the experience.

A good spectator sport. To be honest every visitor to Marrakech has to see the buzz of Jemaa el Fna square at night . It has a wonderful bustling atmosphere but you will get the life pestered out of you. I prefer to walk through quickly and then observe from the balcony of a nearby restaurant--that way you can appreciate the sight without the hassle.

Snakes!. It is definitely a 'must-see' on any Marrakesh list, but I found it slightly more 'touristy' than I would prefer. Lots of heckling, not terribly clean, but definitely worth a visit during the evening.
this is the big square in the medina. you gotta try it ,but be ready for the hassle , its too much for me i wont be rushing back
The best place in all Marocco.. The sights, the people, the cafes, the food, everything was excellent
Crazy square!. Go here and enjoy! Take a the and enjoy! Bargain, bargain! If the sellers start with 200 dirhams, its maximum worth 100. Dont pay more then 50 - 60 % than the first price.

Marvels abound. There is probably nothing on earth that can prepare one for this experience. No guide book, and no other city in the world. If you are wary of snakes, avoid getting to close to snake charmers as they may want to put a snake around your neck.

Do not miss in Marrakech!. Absolutely out of this world. The sounds, the smells, the noises, the people, the animals, the food stalls, the performers, singers, acrobats and vendors. This is a feast for all the body senses and you will be bewildered and even overwhelmed by it all!!
An absolute must-experience in Marrakech!

The cave of Ali-Baba. Our passage is marked by unexpected encounters with the wizards of snakes, monkeys jugglers, ladies who insist on painting us hands with henna, everyone who wants to sell anything and everything. The injudicious in the Medina lost the north and we will be hiking the labyrinthine paths of souks bidos treasures of the cave of Ali Baba. It's very rich in handicrafts.

Assult to the Senses. In a good way though, there was so much on offer that we got confused about what to eat or where to go because it all looked so good. We enjoyed dinner immensely, the food on offer is very cheap and tasty. Careful though, there are salespeople everywhere trying to steer you into their shop, but that's what the whole city's like.

Trip back in time. During the day it was a well used touristy square with lots of stalls selling their wares, but at night it totally transformed into the hub of the district. the quare filled with outside food stalls and musicians and nationally dressed men dancing, monkeys and hennah tattoos, we ate most nights in the square it was just so much value for money. we tried to try lots of different stalls to eat from but it was an imposible choice. we used to just wander up and down amaised by everything. YOU MUST GO HERE.

so and so. not up to my expectations!!! thought it was a colourful market place, but it's sort of chaotic...loved the orange juices and the dates kiosk though. especially one: no. 11 with massimo, the most beautiful eyes of marrakech!!!

Amazing Madness.... See it, believe it. The OJ is the best... Make sure you pick a point to return to if you get disorientated, maybe The Club Med sign... Beware of the dodgey Henna artists. Try the snails, YUM... Most of the food vendors so rude, FYI...

Worthy of World Heritage Site. Unfortunately not able to be present during the evening or during Ramadan. can only image the dynamism and vibrance during this time. Was there during mid-day and still quite amazing. Moroccan life and tradition all to be found on this square!

An assault on the senses!. You need your wits about you in this place. Avoid the aggressive henna ladies, the monkey men and snake charmers who will try to charge you hundreds of Dirhams for very little. Food around the square can be excellent but choose carefully.
Watch it unfold..... Find a good spot on high or sit and watch amongst it all but sunset over the building of it is a sight to be seen

A sight not to be missed in Marrakech. Jemaa el Fna square and the souks that surround it are eye-candy for the soul. Completely different by day, than by night. During the day, vendors are everywhere on the square, along with the snake charmers and monkey tamers (we only saw each of these once though, as they are supposed to be outlawed in the square now). The souks are amazing and you can easily get lost in the passageways. Everyone wants you to buy from them and is happy to barter. Once you start bartering though, don't make a deal and then not buy. This is rude and insulting to the vendors if they come to your price and you then say no. A souvenier shoppers paradise, or a great place just to walk around and take in the sights, sounds and smells of the square. At night, the square is a place of activity, food vendors and the like. We did not end up eating in the square although that was our original plan. Our riad manager told us not to risk it as most vendors are not very sanitary and there is no one to regulate what is sold, how it is cooked etc. We saw vendors selling snails and then rinsing the used bowls in dirty water. We also saw vendors cooking and smoking over the food. This put us off eating in the square even though the smells were diving. We got caught by someone wanting me to take his picture - insisting - and then trying to get money out of me for the privilege....NOT happening. I told him off and walked away.Both my daughter and I got our bums grabbed numerous times at night in the square, either from passers by, or those standing around to watch the performers. Luckily it was only bums and not handbags (which we wore on the front, or did not bring at all). Saying this though, someone DID have the audacity to steal a handbag one night, and honestly, half the square chased him. It was amazing to see. A vendor told us that the people of Marrakech do not want this reputation and do everything they can to prevent purse snatchings and tourist intimidation. In this instance, I don't like to think of what happened to the bag snatcher, with over 200 or 300 people running after him!All in all, a sight to see, both at night and during the day.
A colourful spectacle. Lots to see street entertainers, fortune tellers, water sellers lots of photo opportunities good for dining experiences but be aware of pickpockets and beggars

Winner winner chicken dinner. Great fun.. no snakes after sunset for the phobids....dinner stalls great fun, once you sit down! Watch out some stalls sell brains, guts etc... oooooh!.. Take a flask with the good stuff to add to your coke!

Interesting place to hang out. Snake-charmers, monkey handlers, henna designers, street performers gives this square the charm that it is famous for. If you want to get mehndi (henna) done on your hand/body then this is the place for it. There are plenty of ladies sitting around doing henna patterns on various people. You should scope out which one you like the best and go with her. There are a lot of cafes/restaurants around the square but none serve alcohol so if you are thinking of just hanging out at one of the restaurants/bars there, doing people-watching while sipping beer/wine, fuggeddaboutit!Be careful and aware of all your belongings, in Jamaa el Fna (and morroco in general) there are a lot of pick-pokets around waiting to lighten your load of cash. Be aware of all the various street performers, they are extemely pushy. They will catch hold of you and make you wear something like a cap or a snake around the neck or a monkey for picture to be taken. Well they expect money immediately since we took a picture with their stuff. It is best to say no immediately if you are not interested. One thing to remember when you are in the souks is to start bargaining with the shopkeeper only if you re actually interested in buying the item.

Visited once and will not go back.. I can check this off my to-do list but I will never consider going back. I believe in supporting the local economy and understand that the locals are trying to make a living, but being forced and harassed into paying for something I did not ask for was just not acceptable at all. One of the vendors physically placed 2 monkeys on my back after I repeatedly told him NOT to do so and had the audacity to demand money for it. I ultimately backed off and allowed him to take a picture of me with the monkeys. I paid him 100 dirhams (about 10 euros) for ONE lousy picture and he DEMANDED that I pay him more more. I just walked away. This happened again when I was taking a picture of my friend. Two guys in some sort of costume worked their way into the picture and then demanded we pay him money. Walking through the souks were somewhat better, however people were still pushy and one guy actually FOLLOWED us for 5 minutes trying to get us to visit his shop. Overall, I was glad I visited and Marrakech is a beautiful city with great history, but this will be certainly the last time I will step foot there.

So so busy. We much preferred it in the evening as you don't get any hassle - But in the day we escaped the bustle by sitting on 1 of the many roof top cafes enjoying the sun and wathing it all from a distance. There such an amazing vibrancy to the city - it is incredible to experience.

Crazy crazy place - everything we expected!. Chaotic, vibrant and interesting things to look at in every direction. We ate out at the open air food stalls a couple of times - good atmosphere and food but I didnt like getting hassled to sit down at each place. You couldn't really stop to look at anything without getting pounced on.Despite being busy, full of bikes, cars, mopeds, horse and carts all going in different directions we felt safe all the time.
Great souk. it was wunderfull, full of beautiful things and nice food and also cheap.
A magical place. A must see on any visitor's trip to marrakech - magical, best after dark when the food stalls are4 all set up

Crazy mix of madness. We loved going to Jemma el Fna square, it was a mix of many things going on everyday and no two days were the same.There are snake charmers, henna ladies, acrobats, boxers, story tellers, you name it, they will be there.In the evening the square changes and there are literally hundreds of food stalls set up. You must try the food here, it is not the best but the experience itself is a once in a lifetime opportunity.There are many cafes around the square, if you get a little tired then take to one of the terraces and chill out there.

Sense Sensation. This square truly has to be enjoyed for the sheer senses that are arroused. The colours, especially how they change with the setting sun, the sounds of hustle and bustle, snake charmers, ubiquitous music, to the delightful wafting smells of spices as the daily temporary restaurants set up in the square from 4pm. Brings new meaning to meals on wheels as from a cafe high up above you can watch the hive of activity as this daily spectacle begins with all the necessary equipment and food being brought in on hand pulled carts. You can imagine that this amazing spectacle as been going on for centuries.

A unique experience. J'Ma'Fna was vibrant, noisy and very different from any market we were used to.The pestering by the locals got a bitt much for us by the fifth night.Food was good and reasonably priced although they did try to sell us more than we had asked for.
Must do. you just always feel drawn to what's happening there. we were in marrakech several times, but also this time on the last day, the kids just needed to go to La Grande Place.
Morroco at its most diverse. Brilliant for experiencing true morroco. The souks, the food and the buzzing atmosphere.
Crazy square. This is an amzing place - sit back with a mint tea and watch the show!
Crazy, loud and a lot of fun. Terrific place to spend an afternoon people watching and shopping. Remember to have fun and that it's OK to say no, which can be difficult sometimes.

People who want to learn how to watch their back the hard way should visit.. This place is incredible. Fascinating and frightening at the same time. There must be hundreds of hustlers, thiefs, con mans in and around this place. If you are visiting Morocco or any other underdevelopped country the first time, you will soon learn that these relatively poor people is after your money and they try to cheat and trick you in many different ways. They seem to think it is ok since you are richer. Watch your wallet carefully; be very clear to anyone showing you a direction or offering help that you do not need help; do never reveal any details about you, your hotel, where you intend to go next etc. They then follow you to your hotel or the place you want to go, or they go a few steps before or behind you and provide completely irrelevant information, then at the destination, they try to charge you ridiculous amounts of money for their "guiding services". When talking to the salespeople, do not even tell them your country of origin or your mother tongue because they will use this information immediately to "charm" you. If you do not want help or do not want to buy, always make it very clear that you are not interested, avoid eye contact and conversation. On the square, always have a few coins ready to give to beggars so that they do not harrass and steal from you or try to spit at you or touch you with their stinking and dirty hands. Never ever take your wallet out when a beggar is near you. Have a few small notes ready in your pocket for emergencies when you feel under a lot of pressure to pay a false guide and make him believe that this is all the cash you have. They will take and leave. If you show the wallet, they charge much more or ran away with your wallet. No chance to catch them. Avoid taking pictures of people on the square, they will immediately gather around you, behave very insulted and try to charge ridiculous amounts of money. If you take pictures, do from distance, ideally in the vicinity of a policemen or next to many other tourists who take pictures at te same time. Also, there are some very crowded and overprized restaurants where locals cannot enter because of prices and from where you can take pictures savely.
amazing. Must see, bursting in colors, aromas and entetainment

Crazy place!. Everyone knows the medina's a crazy place, but I don't think anything can prepare you for this! The diversity of smells, colours and things to see is incredible and you're never bored. I would say, however, that the way animals are treated in the medina is horrible - beware of the monkeys on chains. This really upset me.... I would urge you not to encourage it. At night, try the street food - it's a fun experience chatting to the waitors and trying the local foods.

madness!. Loud, brash, entertainers, food, horses, mopeds, taxis, street vendors, smells, sounds, and the chance to look over it all from one of the many terrace cafes. The heart of Marrakech, and a great place to while away hours watching the world, or wandering off into the souks.

No way to describe the Jemaa el Fna!. This is what most travelers must come to Marrakech to see. Experiencing it during the day was quite the experience, but going back at dusk into the early evening was mesmerizing! Just keep your wits about you, your personal property out of anyone's reach and look around 360 degrees for an experience you won't forget! Yes...snake charmers (cobras), monkeys on chain leashes performing, food stalls everywhere, fortune tellers surrounded by hoards of men waiting to be attended to, etc.

Buyer beware!. You can't miss this place, but beware of people trying to help you, "hi remember me, I work at the hotel and I can help you." Agree to a price for pictures of snake charmers before taking pictures. Don't fall into the trap of "pay what you like"
A magical experience. it changes three times each day from quiet place to circus in a few hours- A big attraction. Felt safe for the most part. A bit hassled by vendors especially around dinner
The heart of the city. Not just a tourist trap but something for everyone, food, fortune tellers, musicians etc. Take time to just stand and stare.

Crazy!!. Seems to have been given a UNESCO World Heritage status for simply being one of the maddest, most eclectic and frenetic places on earth. Changes at sundown when the atmosphere becomes absolutely electric. A great place to eat and take in the whole spectacle.
Very busy but fun. If you can survive the hordes of people pestering you to sell you things and services, this is a great place with an excellent atmosphere
Crazy place!. You've got to be prepared…stuff that will amaze and delight and stuff that will shock

Snakes and monkeys and Henna. If you hate snakes and are afraid of monkeys dont go during the day wait till night when its more the storytellers.The henna ladies will accost you and start drawing on you without your consent
Buzzing. The place is buzzing with lots of places to eat, fresh orange juice, snake charmers, story tellers and henna artists. Best time to go is in the evening just before sunset til late

Activity galore!. This square just never stops. Abuzz with street sellers during the days it transforms around 6 to 7 at night into a food and entertainment venue like no other. If you want a photo with snakes, monkeys, water sellers just slow down and they will find you otherwise walk at a steady pace past them, motion disinterest and say "La Shukran" and they will generally move on to the next tourist. The food is cheap but very repetitive - one nights feed is probably enough as you get better variety from restuarants (try Piknik south of the square) at about the same price. But you won't find orange juice cheaper (4Dm) on the planet and worth a glass every night.

Like nowhere else on earth!. A definate must see both during the day and at night. The contrast is amazing. Sit in a rooftop cafe in the late afternoon and watch the spectacle that is the construction of the foodstalls and marvel at the efficiancy then stop and wonder how they can do this 365 days a year then pack everything away again at the end of the night. When night falls the lights and smoke from the cooking transforms the whole square. The transvestite dancers appear along with musicians, fishing for bottles of Coke, boxing matches, I once saw a dwarf orchestra perform and a fire eater. It really is like nothing you've seen before.Take plenty of small change to tip the performers.
Fantastic Place. This is a place you definitely cannot miss when in Marrakech. Snake charmers, henna painters, and all kinds of street food in the evening!
crowded at night. Awesome place. Plöace to be at night. Amazing how this place changes though the day. Don't miss it.
wow. Sounds, sights, smells, it's all there. And then some. Careful with your camera tho.

Crazy! :). So busy at night! Best to be avoided if you look like a tourist and you don't like being hassled though! As you will be hassled to eat at all the different food stalls, which we did on 3 occasions! Didn't really go during the day, only once for a short time, but they had henna painters, snake charmers, water sellers, etc....

Crazy!. This is the main square and hub of Marrakech and it's totally crazy! Mopeds whizzing at you from every angle, sometimes bearing 2 or 3 passengers, or perhaps a sheeps head can be a little bit disconcerting at first, to say the least. It's noisy, busy, fast, and bustling with interesting characters such as snake charmers, musicians, storytellers, drummers and artists. Delicious fresh orange juice stalls are out in force ready to quench your thirst.As the sun sets, sit in one of the rooftop cafes for a fabulous view, then head back downstairs to have dinner from one of the pavement stalls which suddenly spring up and turn the square into the biggest outdoor restaurant you have ever seen. This was my third trip to Marrakech but the first time I have eaten here and I would recommend it highly. The atmosphere alone is wonderful... a true taste of Marrakech in every sense of the word.

Probably the craziest main square in the world!. This was my 3 rd visit to this wonderful city. All tourists end up in the Jemaa el Fnaa particularly at night when the whole place transforms into an amazing street food restaurant. To appreciate this find yourself a rooftop terrace bar just before sunset and watch the transformation before your eyes. The square is thronged with activity with mobile pop up restaurants appearing before your eyes. Breathe in the smell of barbeque everything and watch the square tinkle under the thousands of festoon lights. Finding somewhere to eat is entertaining. You are surrounded by traders enticing you to their stalls with cheeky faux English Cockney banter of "take a look best air conditioned restaurant in Marrakech!" Basically we are a fan of no. 18. Good food and the owner proudly shows off his picture taken with celebrity British chef Rick Stein who once cooked there on TV. Enjoy!! My only warning is to ignore the musicians who have an intimidating habit of following you hassling for money and firmly hold on to your wallet!!

Just like you would expect a medival market. Snake charmers, (male) belly dancers, female boxers, story tellers, you name it.Story tellers are in arabic ofcourse. But rest you can watch. Monkey owners seem to be a bit agressive. I found the food to be average if busy. Expect to pay 40 dhs for starter and sausages with bread.Go at dusk. There are toilets at the north side.

The big square. I liked the excitement, the food and the olive souk. I did not like the treatment of the monkeys. It broke my heart to see them in cages so small the poor animal could not even move, stand or turn! I also somehow, felt sorry for the cobras. They deserve respect too. I did not like how the vendors try to cheat u at every turn. It was disappointing but since I am familiar with Morocco, I was still able to find bargains, especially shopping at Marjan. If ur persistent in the souks u can also find great bargains. I bought Pashmina scarves for 50 dirham (approx 6 dollars) and even bought some for 30 dirham...good quality and unusual designs.

A Glimpse into the Past. The square is a flurry of activity at night but tourists are the interlopers. The experience would be more profound if one spoke the language and could understand the skits and performers. The area is not well-lit at night.
Exciting!. Make sure you are packed with patience to bargain and get good deals!

Be prepared to bargain, and end up paying only 1/3 of price asked!. All sellers will inflate their prices once they know you`re a foreigner.Don`t just buy at first sight, browse around and don`t fall in the trap of any charming sales person or `guide` who pretend to be helping you!They only work for their commission.Think like this:It`s a jungle out there, and you need to fight for your sole survival...We`ve been ripped off on few occasions, until we learned the trick of the game...
#1 reason to visit Marrakech. Great place with lots of things happening and much food offered, especially at night.
Go in the evening. Great experience when dark. I wouldn't advise any but those with strong stomach to eat there unless you like your lamb with its head and eyes staring at you while you eat!!

Alright during the day but night time is when the atmosphere sinks in. During the day there are basically just orange juice sellers and snake charmers .......not very interesting. But visit at night and things are totally different. the bustling food stalls and different smells and sounds and performers everywhere. A bit of a sensual overload at times but just go with it. Be vigilant of bags, cameras etc. as its easily to get distracted and fall victime to pickpockets.
Too many aggressive locals for me!. Would someone tell these people that if they want us to spend money stop trying to rip us off and overcharge us. When we say no we mean it.

a wonderful place. wonderful if the hassle to donate money to whichever musician or dancer you happen to photograph doesn't bug you too much. Snake-charmers, fortune-tellers (some of them women in burqas!), musicians and all sorts of food - including delicious cinnamon tea and little brown desserts in bowls, that look like chocolate ice-cream but are I think made of some kind of cereal and lots of spices, quite delicious and very cheap.

Too dangerous for Tourists. I don't even know where to begin, I just want to warn every tourist that is planning a trip to Marrakech to avoid this hell-hole.Myself and my boyfriend are very well travelled, and have never experienced something so scary, disgusting, intimidating and dangerous all packed into one square!During the few times we visited the square and the sooks (we gave the place way too many second chances) we had three people try and rob us, beggers surround us, a henna tattoist grab my hand while I was looking at someone elses stall and start painting on my hand while i was screaming for her to let me go then she demanded money (which she didnt get), after all this my boyfriend got held at knife point in the middle of the square are some dancing men surrounded me and wanted photos (which i kept denying) and then they tried grabbing his wallet (we ran away after yelling out 'Police, Police, Police').People death-stare you, hiss at you and yell abuse at you (even tho you dress appropriately for there culture and try to speak their language).The people of Morocco are experiencing financial difficulties, and this is evident in the majority of the people there, so the country is best avoided.

The center of the city. This main plaza is always bustling with life, but now it seems to be filled mostly with tourists wandering around. We ate a decent meal here and enjoyed the action, but it's not my favorite place in Marrakesh.

Life lived here in the present. Thousand and one night in real life. Here you can eat, laugh, cry, and enjoy the madness. Smile, but be strict.he music pulls you into a unique atmosphere not found anywhere else in the world. Smile and you will be overloaded with smiles from all sides. Put pennies in your pockets and give to those who beg. They have no food or income. Good luck.

Explosion of sight, taste and colours!. Our expectations were completely thrown at the square, as instead of the rude pushy sellers we were expecting, we were greeted by friendly and humerous individuals with their comical quips of ASDA price and fish and chips! Although they invited us to look at their stalls, when we explained we were just looking or walking they said maybe later and welcomed us to Morocco wishing us a good stay. I'm not too good at bartering, I always feel a little embarrassed, and am hopeless at suggesting a starting price, but I do know how much is 'too much' and stood my ground when I had seen goods sold cheaper in other stalls. It pays to look around and compare goods, and the sellers get to recognise you too, which helped when I returned to buy what I wanted as in most cases they were willing to give fair prices. The sellers have amazing memories and as we both have tattoos, it made it easier for them, we were often met with greetings of 'prison break' . It seems you only get a tattoo in morocco when you're in prison LoL.The 'Henna women' were the biggest pest! Walking around the square they call out to you and run up to you with their syringes full of henna brandishing books of photos, they often won't take no and on our first evening, one chancer grabbed my hand saying let me see tattoo and squirted henna onto me. I shouted , NO' at the the woman, rubbing the henna away in disgust, she just shrugged and walked away ... If you dont want henna, you have to be FIRM!I don't care much for animal handlers either, and think its very cruel to drag a monkey in a nappy around on a chain merely to make a quick dirham for the photo opportunities of tourists. They cage them ( unhappily I might add, listening to their screeches) in tiny boxes when there is no interest. Very sad sight. As for the snake charmers, well I watched a snake lurch at a passing man and made sure I kept my distance LOL. The food in the evenings at the square was fabulous. Basically all the stalls sell almost the same food just cooked or served differently. Everyone wants you to eat at their stand and the banter is fabulous. We made any number of promises to return the following day! We ate at a number of stalls, I have no recommendations except let your eyes and nose guide you!. We found the Morrocan salad fab with flat bread, deep fried aubergine and mixed olives and there is a variety of meats and fish to choose from and small enough portions to try different dishes each night. Mint tea was free courtesy of our host stalls although you may have to ask for it.Freshly squeezed juices for 4 dh was lovely and a massive choice of nuts and dried fruits available. Your dessert is a range of sweet pastries to choose from the barrow and at 30dh for a mixed box, there is fierce competition for your money with 2 barrow boys racing round the food stalls vying for trade.Try to get a rooftop view and have a Mint tea on the terraces at be if the large cafes. It's amazing

Crazy but good. Everything you want is on offer. Refuse to let a guide take you round as they cost too much. It is easier to stroll around on your own and just say no thanks to anyone you do not want anything from. Easy....

Crazy Madness. We went to the sqaure a couple of times, once at day then in the evening and its madness! Glad i experienced it but did not really enjoy it. I knew what to expect but still didn't like all the grabbing and hassling. As others have mentioned if you stop to take a photo someone will try and get some money out of you. We enjoyed seeing it in the evening watching from above in a rooftop cafe.

Shopped and Hassled to death. Plenty of shops selling bags, watches, jewellery, start at least from half what they say and you'll get somewhere in between. Beware as soon as the hawkers think you may be interested in something they will push to far to get your business..we walked away when it got too much! Snake charmers around the main square so beware! We bought bags, spices and had best fresh orange juice..

Only place in the world with this ambiance!. Great place to visit both day and night (two very different experiences). However is tarnished by some shopkeepers and artists being very pushy, almost agressive. Even other Moroccans find them too pushy. However this is a must-see.

Star wars revisited. Is sounds like I've been trnasported back in time and to the future to Tattoine in Star wars! Amazing sights, smells and noises we went there for food every night stall number 1 gorgeous!! Cafe de France is well worth a mint tea visit too.

Meh.. Underwhelming.Couldn't stop/stroll/walk without being pestered by a monkey/snake/begger. The locals are desperate to chat - though you'll have to pay to hear their wise words which more often than not include the questions "first time in marrakech?", "there are many souks to shop in", and "liverpool football club is best in world". These delights will set you back (after a barter) anywhere between 300dhs (which got a hearty laugh from us) and a pleasant spit on the ground in front of you.In all the Jemaa el Fna would benefit from 2 simple changes. Fewer motorcycles and a decree from the King that pushy locals desperate to rip you off should be forced to stay indoors during the moring. and the afternoon. and the evening. and at night.All that said, in the evenings the food stalls are pretty sound. Food is good. Sheep head is the local...delicacy...and the stall workers know every stereotypical english phrase in the book. Well worth a visit (esp. as the noms are 20-30dh per course) for the LOLZ. There is enough competition for your affections you can barter free drinks and food tasters without issue.
Night life. Colorful and full of hussle bussle. Make sure your valet is in front jeans pocket for safety. Do not carry your passport and other documents. Make sure you drink sealed bottled water.

Alla what i can say is WOW. im Moroccan local from Marrakech, as i have the rights as well as others to review this attractions, i have a lot to say about it, as i have many experiences with Jamaa el fna, but i will say all what i have briefly, frankly speaking jemaa el fena , is one of my favourite places that i spend time at the afternoon with my friends, or visitors, and sometimes i meet some tourists come for a visit to Morocco and i share them hoa great is Morocco.actually i can not say perfect because it's my honest look and observation about this location , and no one is perfect till now, i like snake charmers, i like sneals and Harira soup restaurants and orange jus, so i stay in Glassier cafe watching the view from the panoramic sometimes, jemaa el fna has something that i did not like as a local, is many mixed people make it a bit feeling unsafe sometimes even it's surrounded by the tourists police.Moreover; i would recommend Marrakech, to spend a little time in every place, and do not give it a lot time because Morocco has a lot to offer and so many important things than Marrakech, as we can call Morocco sometimes Marrakech, because it's the only one make it known and famouse.so Welcome to Morocco, and enjoy the diversity.

Unforgettable!. Apologies for the somewhat poetic and pacey review, however I feel it does justice to the frantic, buzzing, amazing feeling that is the 'Main Square'... full of charm, flavour, colour and movement. Full of Oranges, food, smoke, monkeys, horses, ponies, men, women, children, locals, homeless, tourists, heat, cold, food, fish, markets, hats, gloves, leather, lots of leather, barbers, burbers, incense, fire, more oranges, sun terraces, pashminas, carriages, hay, mint, spices, stars, songs, belly dancers, more monkeys, motorbikes, cars, carts and life. Full of life in every way, shape and form! You have to see it for yourself! Be prepared for a whirlwind journey of fun!
magical in a crazy way. the sights, smells, noise all make for a wonderful time. hit the food stalls
