make sure you visit twice - once by day and once by night. snake charmers, musicians, food, boxing, mopeds and every type of person you could wish for......everyone friendly except perhaps the henna ladies who are a bit intimidating
This is a must see!. its craziness is the attraction. Crazy people doing crazy things. The food stalls are brilliant, the entertainment (even watching the people), all the madness. Brilliant.

bonkers but an essential part of your trip. monkeys on leashes? Snake charmers and the most delicios orange juice ever? it's all here. It's not terribly exciting by day but it comes to life in the evening. Avoid the goat's head restaurants if you're squimish!

Gives a new meaning to chaos ....... This is the central square in the middle of Marrakech, just in front of the souk. And just getting from one side of the square to the other is a major obstacle course. You really need to keep your eyes and ears open because there is potential danger from every side. There are scooters/bikes and horse-drawn carriages coming at you from every direction, men with monkeys, snake charmers and cobras all over the place, street entertainers, dancers, fortune tellers etc etc. If you try to take a photo, they will demand money and can get quite aggressive about it. There are also all the market stalls, mostly with fruit and spices - but the most pungent fragrance is that of the horse manure. There are many small gift shops around the square so if you're looking for typical souvenirs like postcards, magnets, snow globes, this is the place to get them. You can't go to Marrakech and not visit this square, but you need to keep your wits about you.

Mayhem!. My boyfriend and I would while away hours sipping mint tea and watching the hustle and bustle of the main square, or getting amongst it all in the evenings. A few tips, in the evening be very careful when crowding round to watch storytellers/witchdoctors/general entertainment. A few times I felt fingers trying to get in to my pockets. The square is very dark at night and you can definitely feel a bit vulnerable when away from the stalls and souks etc. It's like anywhere though, as long as you trust your instincts and be careful it's a great place to be! I was quite surprised, and actually quite reassured at the lack of police presence though!! In London I usually find volumes of police in one area a reason to avoid it!!

center of Marrakech tourist attraction. You have to go through the square to go anywhere in marrakech. But there is not much to see architecturewise. Lots of merchants, story tellers, snakes and other street demonstration.
brilliant & crazy. an abolute must see donkeys, snakes, orange juice sellers, henna artists - you must go
Better at night. ok during day but comes alive at night with food stalls and more things going on

food glorious food. this is one of the ten things to do before you die. if you have never seen a snake charmer next to a juggler while you devour some sort of meat from a barbeque then you haven't lived. try the restaurants on the balconies, not as good as barbe but cheap and filling( mostly tajine but good )

Chaos!. At all time! Snake charmers, monkeys, henna ladies, guys with twirling hats, water guys, guides, it will not stop! and its amazing. What an incredible escenary of theatre and acts, story tellers at night and performers and the kebab restaurants at night. Just dont get annoyed when they pull you around and my best advice, go to where the Moroccans go!
MAD. Must try, but expect to be hassled, best advice be firm but POLITE,

don't take pictures of the animals. Good atmosphere and has to be seen at night, but be warned do not take pictures of the animals on display unless you do not mind parting with 10dirams per picture (80p) i was taking a picture of the square and one chap thought i was taking a picture of his monkey and he attacked me when i refused to pay just be careful, but dont let it put you off going to the square its great fun.

Wow!. This is a 'must see' if you are in Marrakech! Experience the colourful sights, the sounds of street performers & snake charmers, the smells (some good & some terrible!), and the excitement of the square. It can be quite intimidating at first, but wearing sunglasses helps to avoid unwanted eye contact. It is worth doing a quick round and practising a firm 'Non monsieur/madam' with a warm smile if you really don't want to have your hand painted or buy items, before returning with a little more confidence to enjoy the general excitement and bustle. Make sure you return in the evening to experience the magical atmosphere, or watch from the safety of a restaurant roof terrace while sipping hot mint tea.

Charming Cobras in the Square.... After growing up listening to CSN's Marrakech Express song, it was great to see this big square alive with snake charmers, acrobats, food, etc. I paid a snake charmer for photos that others were sneaking because without our money they will eventually disappear...I did shun the monkeys cuz they are not treated well...A MUST IS TO WANDER INTO THE SOUKS RIGHT ABOVE THE SQUARE! Reminds me of the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul...

Ubbeliveble - amazing!. Welcome to the magic, the love, and a wonderful atmosphere. It is so funny with all the street perfomer, monkies, snakes and all the trailers with orange juice which taste so amaziiiing!!!

best square in the planet. The place remains the main square of Marrakesh, used by locals and tourists. During the day it is predominantly occupied by orange juice stalls, youths with chained Barbary apes, water sellers in colourful costumes with traditional leather water-bags and brass cups, and snake charmers who will pose for photographs for tourists

Best orange juice in town!. Get your orange juice from juice stand number 28! It is by far the best juice in the whole Djemaa El Fna square! I went back there about 10 times over a few days (yes, a little addicted). It's in the North/Western corner just near Cafe Argana, second from the end beside a nuts/fruits stand. Enjoy!

Great market!. I loved the market in marrakech - although there are lots the Jemma el Fna is the best by far. There is a central point to keep coming back too so you don't get too lost and the stalls inside sell everything from Lamps to jewellery, shoes and bags. Great!
A Not Miss Location. The center of life in Marrakech. Food, Snake Charmers, People watching - it's all there. A must see.

Loved the buzz!. We accidentally had saucisson at Stall 31. Totally delightful. I tried not to pay to much attention to how they were washing the plates. If Iyou canignore that and just enjoyed the taste of the food, you will enjoy!

Learn this phrase: M'andish floos!. The square was full of vibrant Marrakechi culture, with no shortage of fresh juices, horse-drawn carriages, and various entertainers. The entertainers are aggressive and have networks of people who work together to rope you in. If you show the slightest bit of interest in a snake charmer or a band, you are led over by the hand, and the next thing you know, you are digging for change! Sunglasses are an asset because you can glance over without them knowing! The henna women will follow you for business, but are generally more polite. I acturally had one grab my hand as I walked through the square and start a design before I even expressed interest! You are also surrounded by souks and shops with lots of tempting items. Look around for a day first and compare quality - it can really vary - before you buy.

A Feast for the Senses!. The square had it's own personality which changed with the position of the sun! In the daylight, you could see the snake charmers, the "dentist", men praying during the call to prayer and all sorts of other activities. As dusk approached, the carts and propane tanks all rolled in for the grilled dinners and a whole new group of "entertainers" took the night shift! Never a dull moment.
Marvel. A sight to see every night. Really cheap fresh juices. Fantastic places to eat and drink.
A must see at day and night. Manic.....try a roof top bar early evening for Marrocan whisky (Mint tea)

Unique Clutural Experience not to be missed. It is very difficult to navigate the medina, but worth the adventure. Be prepared for pushy vendors and to pay to take photos of snake charmers, etc. It is a must-see stop on a visit to Marrakech.
Must see site!. Incredible market with snake charmers etc. The sunsets are a must for a photo.
Some Restaurant!. Hsutle and Bustle all day and more chefs than you can count by night.
pop up restaurants. the atmospherer and food was very good. we ate there three times
Magical!. All likes - no dislikes! You don't know which part to visit first, as so many things going on. You don't want to miss any of it!

A must see if your in Marrakech!. The square is full of hustle and bustle, we had heard the horror stories of the square however we spent a good few hours in there without being hassled or pushed and pulled in directions. A polite no is suffice and they won't bother you again. I had a massive big lady come grab my hand for the henna, I told her no and quickly put my hands in my pocket, she just replied ok have good time in Marrakech, the sights and the smells are certainly and experience ( some of the smells not good if you have a weak stomach) we had good fun with some of the stall holders and then got a taxi back to our hotel for 40dirhams...... A great experience certainly not to be missed

Vibrant and fun. We ate in the square on our first night - what an experience. Quality food at a fraction of restaurant prices. All the stalls have promoters trying to persuade you to eat with them. Have a laugh and joke with them - they don't get offended if you walk away.Do try the freshly squeezed orange juice from the stalls in the square - at around 40p per glass it is a cheap treat.

Great Ambience !. Wonderful place to visit and experience in Marrakech.It must be seen both at night and at day, two whole different experiences.During the day is is awash of story tellers, snake charmers, and henna ladies (be scared, be very scared!)At night it is fast food stalls, great fun, you will be asked if you are a relative of Jamie Oliver, if you like sheeps brain, sheeps heads.. great place it has to be seen to believed!

a must see while in Marrakech. but be careful.. this is a place that you must see while in marrakech. the smells and sights are one of a kind. but you need to be careful. you need to come prepared with an open mind and thick skin. the orange juice is a must but make sure you actually see it made. probably the most exp place to buy souvenirs but some of the shopkeepers are very reasonable.
top of the 'to do' list. a little disappointed - felt as if it had sold its soul to western consumerism, I felt guilty.
mesmerizing Marrakesh market square. Review title says it all- a unique experience, a cultural cornucopia of colour, sounds and smells

Crazy Busy. The square is a heaving throng of people night and day, but this and the souks are the main attractions after all. Keep your wits about you, watch out for snakes, women grabbing your hand and trying to apply henna to it before you can say no, and everyone that wants to sell you something for a few coins or a photo op – at your expense. Do try the fresh squeezed fruit juice from one of the many carts (they are all the same price) and eat at least once from the stalls in the middle of the square. You will not be able to walk past without someone trying to talk you in to going to their stall.....but if you persevere, look for one that gives you a view of what you want, then take a seat and have a nice cheap meal (don’t look too closely at how they are cooking it or cleaning up after!!!)

Twenty years on and it's changed only slightly!. And for the better too. 20 years ago I was pestered non stop. The Morrocans have learned that if they are to attract infidel tourists they have to be less "in your face". The square still has all the atmosphere, drama and excitement that it had on my first visit. It's a delightful madhouse where you can wander at will!

Lots of hussle. Daytime it was vaguely bearable, but at night they seem to think that you should donate a great amount just looking to see what is going on. And when you give a few Dhirams they abuse you and start demanding Euros. If you can stand that there's lots going on, but otherwise it's miserable

Not that impressive actually. When we first arrived in Marrakech I was petrified - I am not a city person and all the horror stories about being pushed and pulled about were scaring me but there was no need. I speak French and I was polite to people and no one followed me or grabbed me, no one tried too hard to sell me anothing or put a monkey on my shoulder! That said it busy and the animal cruelty was heartbreaking but the crowds who gather to watch shows, music and boxing are Moroccans not the tourists! The banter for the food stalls in the evening is great as they try to guess the nationality but again politely declining in French always received a smile back. Oh, and the orange juice (if it's freshly squeezed while you watch) is great!

Intense experience of Marrakech. Loved the profusion of stalls and shops. Quite an experience walking through the Souks and haggling over prices are part of what makes it fun. The people are generally helpful and friendly - save a few.I did not quite like the few people who tried to get us to go to some "special sale". Avoid these politely. Also had good food in some of the places within or close to the Medina.

Hustle bustle and exactly what you expect of marrakech. Be careful where you go. We had two young men try to get us up a particular path when we got lost and an Arabic lady stepped in and told them off!! Haggle as if your life depends on it! They expect it and want it and are far less pushy than the Egyptians! Most are quite funny and friendly.

Amazing!. Very interesting by day or night. The night market offers all sorts of food and enjoy the banter of the stall holders trying to get you to eat at their stall. Disliked the use of the snakes and monkey to entertain.

Vibrant and full of excitement!. I simply love the medina. So much things happening at the same time, the surroundings so colourful, it's definitely a treat for the senses. As always, be careful of touts and pickpocketers, but other than that it's a brilliant place. The DH4 freshly squeezed orange juice at Djemaa el Fna is the best! My mum and I cannot get enough of it.
The highlight of Marrakech. Liked the whole atmosphere and the colours and people from al over the world however disliked the cons

Great to see but once is enough. We went twice- once to go and eat and the second time we went before sunset, settled ourself on a terrace over looking the square and drank mint tea and took photos which was lovely. The first night was interesting, we had food at one of the stands- all of the guys trying to get you in knew Jamie Oliver and Gordon Ramsey and used phrases such as 'chillaxe' which was fun. The food was ok but found it a little bland but for the price, can't complain. Also, meat everywhere seems to be cooked very well so can be dry. The second night we had a walk through the stalls again and bought nuts and juice. The guy, Muhamed, from where we ate remembered us and although we were not eating he sat down with us and had a mint tea and a chat, this was nice and unpressured but some of the stands were overbearing. If you are on a tight budget it is great for food.I did not like being approached with monkeys and things. Some animals did not look like they were treated well which I find distressing.
A must see!!. You must visit this open air market at least once....go during the day and stay into the evening.Watch the change of atmosphere from day to night!

Everyone goes there, but why?. The show is a combination of a carnival midway (musicians, snake charmers and the like) and food tents where one is aggressively hustled to eat. Be sure to check what is served with what you order and the bill. The side streets off the show are interesting and crowded with redundant shops, but worth a stroll. Lots of hotels nearby and the hype given to this attraction is just that.
Madness!. Crazy central square in Marrakech! Never short of something to feast your eyes on!
A must see during your visit to Marrakesh. Just wander around - it is nice during the day and during the night when it is transformed to food kiosks everywhere...

Worth a look. This seems to be touted as one of the top attractions of Marrakech so maybe I missed something. It is definitely worth a walk around, but I found it much more enjoyable to sit on a room terrace and look at the view (we went to Cafe de Paris). As for entertainers, we saw a few snake charmers and people with monkeys, but gave them a wide berth as don't agree with the way they were treating the animals. Other than that there are the food stalls - which I would probably have tried if we'd had more time in the city - and other stalls selling things. I didn't need or want to buy anything, so kept my distance - the sellers don't hassle as much as I was led to believe, a polite 'non merci' and walking on does the trick, but if they see you show a glance at anything, then they're on to you. A shame because it puts you off browsing - in a more relaxed atmosphere I would probably have taken a closer look at their wares and maybe picked up a couple of souvenirs. Haggling only really works when you know what you want and have a good idea of its real value. The square is an impressive sight though, and the whole atmosphere of Marrakech is worth experiencing for something completely different.
A crazy mad place, defo must see. have to go during the day and night to fully experience this crazy square!!

Fascinating and crazy. I doubt there is any other place on earth like this. The souks are heaving with locals and tourists - some of the stuff for sale is tourist tatt whilst some of it is beautifully crafted goods from hand made slippers to stunning lamps. You do need to be very aware of mopeds, donkey carts and pickpockets but don't let this put you off just take extra care. You are expected to haggle so be prepared for this. If you can find Rue El Bacha there are some fixed price shops here which will give you some idea of what you should be paying.The juice and fruit stalls look stunning and the tiny cafes on the perimiter were perfect places to people watch. There are monkeys and snakes - if you don't like these they are easy to avoid just firmly say no if you are approached.It changes completely at night when all the food stalls set up so it's worth visiting at different times of the day.

Amazing Experience. There are not that many places in the world that offer such a unique experience - especially for food lovers that like the adventure of street food. This is the capital of world when it comes to street food. We particularly liked #14 for seafood (Mohamed El Krita) which offered the best french fries (chips) we've ever had, and deep fried calamari and fish which were excellent. Stalls #31 and #32 were also excellent. We had orange juice at a few places, it was also amazing.My advice is to walk around and identify the places that the locals frequent (e.g. 14, 31, 32). They must know something more than the tourists!Would love to go back.

Dazzling. It does overawe you as expected. The streets are full, with throngs of moroccans and tourists who come to see what it is all about. The food stalls are all serving very similar meals, so be selective if you wish. Look at the stalls with the locals as a guid to what has good food. In the day there are performers, snake charmers and henna painters. In the evening the food stall set up, the orange juice vendors arrive and the hassle changes. There are boxing matches, fortune tellers, hoop-las, musicians and lots to watch for free, although they will spot you watching and ask for money.Also watch the proximity of others around your pockets and bags. The police operate fiercely here as a marked and undercover presence, and there is a police station the left of the square, so you can feel safe.Go to one of the cafes roof terraces to watch it all before you feel brave enough to dive in and practice your french and arabic!
Yummie Orange Juice. Crazy, loud, vivid - must visit place in Marrakesh both day and night. The market with freshly squeezed orange juice, entertainers, food stalls, locals and tourists.

This square comes alive at night. Enjoy the hussel and bustle of this square at night. Food markets, juice carts, dried fruits, snake charmers, tarot card reading and host of Morrocans trying to sell their wares. Get used to saying a firm NO...
the place to go. great at night , so many thing going on .dansers, musique snakes , monkeys ect

magical place. Jemaa el Fna is the heart of Marrakech. Some even say the heart of the Northern Africa. It's a magical place where each time I visit everything is almost the same, yet everything is different... It's a home of storytellers, snake charmers, fortune readers, drum players... It never sleeps and is the most lively place on Earth... I just love the atmosphere there and for that I keep coming back to Marrakech.

Exciting. A surreal experience that changes from night to day. Every day there is something new to marvel at. The snake charmers, potion sellers, viagara merchants!!! Freshly squeezed orange vendors that offer amazing juice for 4 Dirhams a hguge glass!! Only upsetting thing is the people who have pet gibbons on leashes for tourists to take pictures!!! Avoid at all cost..please.

Marrrakech at it's Best!. Brilliant! If you are scared of snakes and monkeys I suggest you give the first part of the Jemaa el Fna a wide birth, but once your in there, enjoy an fresh Orange Juice and go barter for some stuff!!Yes it's a little scarey at first if you haven't experienced this sort of thing, but please throw yourself in there, go explore the Souks and you are guarenteed a unique experience! We bought a few little gems for the family. You won't find the finest bone china, but you are guaranteed something different. I found a 'boite du magique' (magic box) for my niece and a few other good gifts for the rest of the kids.Get in there and enjoy it.
What an experience. It's a given that every visitor will go to the square but nothing prepares you! Go at night and it comes alive

Assault on the senses. Difficult to do justice to in words or pictures...you have to experience it for yourself...the smells, the sounds, the hustle, the bustle, the place is alive and is a real eye-opener.Try a glass of orange juice, and don't let the snake charmers bully you into paying over the odds...they'll try and hit you for 200dh (about £20) for five minutes of draping snakes around your neck for photos...a few quid is more than enough.Lots of places to have a coffee or mint tea, and get your haggling skills brushed up as you'll need them. Oh, but most of all, keep an eye out for the mopeds, the donkeys, the carts, the bikes and the mules which will travel down the little streets which make up the souks...you soon get used to it but at first it's a bit hairy!Great place though...
Jemaa el Fna. The Lonely Planet recommendation to sit and watch the sun go down and the stalls set up from the cafe overlooking it was spot on. Fascinating.
Go here several times - in the day and evening. This has to be the place to visit in Marrakech. It changes very much between daytime, early evening and late evening, so go back several times.

Not an experience we wish to repeat. Too dangerous in so far as road (or lack of it) - cars, motorbikes, cyclists, donkeys, horses coming at you in all directions. Harrassed by people who wanted money for photos.

Crazy main square in Marrakesh. It's completely nuts but a real assault on the senses, and really there's nothing like it, you just have to experience it. You'll get hassled beyond belief from guides, touts, entertainers, all manner of people who make their living in and around this square, but you just have to wise up to it, and not let any of that spoil your experience if you can!

Marrakech madness and avoiding the snake charmers. The square takes two forms - the day and then the night market. The daytime finds the square full of snake charmers, henna tattoo ladies, orange carts, dentiss and monkeys on chains to name but a few. I really can't stand snakes so I did fing it hard to go to the square during the day, however, you can skirt the edge and even go to some of the panoramic restaurants to watch the happening of the square. Also it's quite easy to find out where the snake charmers are by locating the large green umbrellas they sit under and listening for the music being played on the flute. Even for someone as terrified as me, it's worth looking - even from a distance. The evening however is totally different as certainly in Oct/Nov - there were no snake charmers at night. The square comes alive with food stalls which are fun, fast and furious but have to be experienced. Bands play at night and various other entertainers draw crowds. I do think you need to keep your wits about you at night, I certainly felt uncomfortable in the dark square away from the food stalls - but you just have to go and see this and experience it for yourself.

Such fun!. We spent alot of time in the square and loved every minute of it, from the snake charmers to the acrobats to the musicians, there's always something fun going on. We found that stall #12 had the best fruit juices (he'll even invite you in to the kitchen for a photo!) and stall #32 had delicious sausages! (many locals were eating there). Don't be afraid or weary just go hang out in the square!!

something should not be missed. Should not be missed...mix of market, fans and resturants and almost everything you think about. The most popular site there, few people knows its history...something you need to reseach and discover to apperciate the place

Scary but fun..food excellent. On our first evening in Marrakech we felt a bit abused by being hassled in the square .. but when we returned after a week in the South we were better adjusted and enjoyed it, and ate excellent food at one of the stalls.. for very little.. I'd recommend these stalls above most of the other restaurants we ate at for freshness and value.
the famous square jamai Elfana.. in 2001 this square was proclaimed a master piece of the oral and intangible heritage of mankind,by UNESCO.The square is the heart of the medina of Marrakech.i
the famous square jamai Elfana.. in 2001 this square was proclaimed a master piece of the oral and intangible heritage of mankind,by UNESCO.The square is the heart of the medina of Marrakech.i

Worth trying the food!. We weren't that impressed with the entertainment but the food was good! We ate at stall 11 - can recommend pastilla and kebabs! If you don't try to take pictures with the acts or animals then you are fine. We had a drink at Cafe Glacier - good view soft drinks 20 Dhr
Unique experience. The square gives you a real insight into traditional Morocco and rarely do you find such an honest and unaltered location.

a complete different world. gut: lots of exotic atractions, cobras dancing, water-sellers, dancers, henna painting stalls....bad: you can´t take a picture without being asked to pay...sometimes it becomes nerving!We accepted the company of a "guide" , who for 3€ showed us around in the backstreets, helped us bargain, and kept the rest of beggers away from us. Spoke German and was big help.

Comes to life in the evening. The main square really comes to life in the evenings with street theatre, food stalls, snake charmers, henna artists, music, dance.....the locals & tourists mingle. It´s worth drinking a mint tea in one of the cafés that overlook the square to get a better view and take a few pictures.

Cultural overload. Jemaa el Fna is not to be missed at night. In the day there isn't much to see, and watch out for the snake charmers who will rip you off! They tried to charge my brother 200 dirham for a picture after throwing a snake around his neck ( he gavce 50 which is way to much). At night look out for the food stalls that have locals at them, we had a really bad experience at a tourist stall, where we were bullied into sitting down and then not even offered a drink, given overpriced rubbish food and then shouted out by a waiter when asking about the bill. However another night when we went to a local stall is was amazing. Definitely go for a drink in a bar overlooking the square.
Beware the waiters. The food was delicious, but the guy tried to take a ridiculously high tip.

Hassled at every turn. The square while interesting and a must see can ve quite a stressful experience. We were hassled and abused by people trying to sell us things at every turn. When we didnt want to buy some of the men got very insulting and followed us around the square. While my boyfriend was taking pictures of the sunset over the square a man with a monkey came up and insisted we pay him for taking a picture of him and his monkey he was very abusive anad would not back off until we deleted a picture of him in the backround. My advice would be confident and stern and don't stop and stare at anything for long or you will have to pay for something!!
Souks. There is sooooooo much to see here! you could spend hours walking around and spending money. Be careful not to get lost.
Culture for all the senses. Fabulous cultural centre, food good and cheap, snakes, monkeys, music, magicians - excellent experience

Interesting, but be wary. There's definitely an energy to Jemaa el Fna, and undoubtedly it's a must-see at night in Marrakesh as it's central to the Marrakesh identity (or so I gather). However, it does feel like a bit of a trap. There are loads of dancers, story tellers, musicians, snake charmers, henna artists, but be careful not to stand too long or engage, and certainly don't take any pictures, unless your prepared to shell some dirmahs.All and all interesting, but perhaps not worth the hype.
Fun!. The square was exciting. But really once you've done it--it's a bit overrated. We even at one of the stalls. (no. 1). Food was fine for what it was--grilled kebab and salad.

Beware of the monkey!. It's everything you'll expect and more, in both a positive and negative sense.There's loads to see and do and you'll have become an expert haggler after a few days, but the amount of hassle and bother you'll get from beggars and/or people with monkeys/snakes/slightly scary hypodermic looking syringes full of henna mean that you'll have to be on your toes.Going during the day and night are both recommended as it's like a totally different place. The food stalls are excellent value at night but depending on who you're with, the atmoshpere can be a little intimidating, although you'll get over this very quickly and soon be enjoying the sights, sounds and (sometimes) the smells.
nice place to visit. the location and setting dont like it when they follow you but you never feel threatend at all
too many people. In the day it's OK but not very interesting. At night there are far too many people. Maybe a young persons' place!

Great place in heart of the old city. Jemma el Fna square, a great must see place in the world. The square has two sides to it, one is in the daytime when it is full of enterainers, snake charmers, acrobats, story tellers, musicians, different things will occupy and entertain you.In the evening, the mood changes, food stalls are setup and different musicians and story tellers arrive, the place seems to be buzzing with atmosphere.Take time out and watch all of the enterainment and chaos on one of the cafes overlooking the square, it is a great experience.
magical. this is a real must if you are visiting and make sure you do a day and a night visit they are so different!
Excellent. A must see and always entertaining. No trip to Marrakesh is complete without a visit.
A myriad of experiences in one area.. Great sights but without a guide, you are pestered constantly by determined people.
Bustling. Something you have to experience, but not too long and not too often. Crowdy, noisy, and it's impossible to look at anything for longer than half a second without being harassed.
Madness. Brilliant food try stalls 25, 31 & 32. People everywhere! Lots of noises and smells. Can be a bit crazy on your first visit but gets better.
Worth visiting. Great atmosphere, especially in the evenings. Souks definitely worth going to as well and you don't get hassled any more than you would in countries with similar set ups.
Mad but good. Interesting by day but fantastic by night. Stall 117 was recommended to us for eating. We tried it and it was very good.

Don't pay full price!. Every price at Jemaa el Fna is negotiable. For leather bags priced at 880, offer then 300 and then close at 4. For those marked at 400, offer then 150 and close at 2. Try not to pay more than half of the original asking price. Also, buying 2 or 3 items helps your bargaining leverage.And of course, if a woman offers to give you a henna tattoo and you say no and asks to give you one for free, still say no. She'll invariably ask for money once the deed is done. At night the belly dancers come out - but incase you can't tell on your own, be aware that they're all men, dressed up as ladies, so consider that before falling in love. And when you gather around the musicians or snake charmers, know that you'll be asked for change at a certain point, for enjoying the spectacle, so make sure you have a few loose single dirhams in your pocket to appease the performers. The shuk is crazy and there's lots of stimulation. Hang on to your bag and have fun!
Not as I expected but I did go in at night as you get less hassled than in the daytime. The monkeys on chains and in cages thought this was cruel and I don't like snakes so kep my distance
Eat here!. The stall number 1 run by the redoubtable Aicha is the place to go for an evening meal of both quality and cheapness.

Lively !. Busy ,noisy but a must ! There are plenty of eating stands to try out the local fare ( sheep's head ,snails or kebabs ). Berber ladies who will design a henna tattoo for you that lasts 3 weeks ,snake charmers ,fortune tellers etc Just be careful not to get run over by all the scooters that drive among the crowd .

The old central place of Marrakech. Crowdy place who drive you in the streets of old Bazaar.U can try to taste the snail prepared food in the central place.It is delicious!!!!!!!U can find everything about Marrakech.I bought very beautiful paints for my house and some species and many extras.u must deal. The first price is always up.t. The deal in bazaar comes from moroccan culture and when the agreement done, u can drink the menthe tea with the seller (generally he offer).The moroccan hospitality is well known.There r also serveral snake charmers lollllI personnaly enjoyed so muchthe minus that it is not always clean like turkish bazaar for exemple and u can be harassed from some street sellers
A must see in Marrakesh.... ...watch out for the monkeys though! They are being thrown at you so that you take a picture and PAY for it!
A must see!. This place was like stepping back into time into a place that is frozen in time - a feast for the senses!

An experience. Lots to see, do and buy.. must see in the day as well as at night... have a drink in the Cafe de France and get an amazing view of the square. Food in the Marrakech is excellent. Wear comfortable shoes if entering the sooks (never ending).... Only down side the amount of people it gets rammed and even worse on a weekend!
The Square. Amazing at night. The Times Square of Marrakesh.

An amazing aural and visual treat. You need to have eyes in the back of your head - and not for the bad reasons. There is so much going on you cannot take it in. There surely cannot be anywhere else like this in the world.
Jemaa el Fna. Wonderful atmosphere both night and day. Eat at the stalls in the evening - all food freshly cooked and incredibly cheap.
not to be missed. there is so much going on in the daytime and at night it gets even better

A crazy place for all the senses.. We have been to Marrkech 4 times now, and LOVE the Medina and square. The smells, sights, noises...there is nowhere like it.If you are not a seasoned traveller then it can be quite intimidating (I have taken people with me & their faces on the first trip in are amazing!!)You will get approached by EVERYONE, snake charmers wanting to throw a snake around your neck, monkey trainers offering to take a photo of you with their monkeys, water sellers, dancers, lots and lots of Ladies with henna (if you don't want henna, keep your hands in your pockets, they are clever at getting a bit on!!) Of course, they all want money. And watching from afar, they tend to do their bit first (ie offer a photo opportunity) then demand a silly amount of money from you. (water sellers ask for around 200dh - £16 at time of writing) The tooth puller/dentist will let you take one photo for 20dh - £1.60 - but just one!! Stall holders will only let you take photos if you either pay them, or buy something. Don't try and sneak photos, they have eyes in their bums and will rush over demanding payment. (Frightened the life out of my poor old mother)Personally I don't agree with using animals like this for entertainment purposes so if they approach me I simply do not make eye contact and hold my palm up toward them, seems to do the trick. Do not feel obliged to put money in the hat of the bloke that's just done a quick wiggle in front of you, just walk round him and resist eye contact.If you do decide to tip, they remove the tip, look at it in disgust, and ask for more :) We watched many a tourist dig his wallet back out.That sound so negative, but if you are willing to open your mind and enjoy the culture, it is a fascinating place with the most wonderful charactures.Grab a mint tea in one of the many cafes with a terrace on the roof - just walk in, no one waits to be seated. Make sure you have a 1dh in your pocket though if you need to use the loo, you are still expected to tip the loo-lady even if you have bought a meal or refreshments. (And carry a pack of tissues ;) )If you settle in one of the cafes around 3.30/4pm, you will catch the food stall setting up for the night. This is a treat, watching them come to life and start serving food to locals and tourists, however, I have never been brave enough to eat at one of them, having seen the bucket they wash the dishes in ALL NIGHT!! Always haggle in the Souks. I have never paid more than half for items, but don't start haggling unless you really do want the item, they don't like time-wasters. If the price is too low they will let you walk away, 9 times out of 10 they chase after you, inviting you back for another deal. It could take 15 mins to buy one item, but persevere and you will get it at a good price.Also, do check out the sellers that set up on the pavement, they can be well cheap, I got a candle lantern for just 20dh - £1.60.If you enter the souks, don't fall for the old (This way is closed) line, once you start hovering and looking unsure you will end up with someone walking beside you, and steering you "towards the Square", you will get there yourself eventually, if you go with the "friendly bloke" he will expect a good tip ;)If you really are lost then barter with someone to show you the way, never go with them without fixing a price first or you can get lumped with a large bill. Ask, if they say 50dh, offer them 20dh. If they say no, walk away, they will soon chase you for that 20dh. And don't pay until you have reached your destination. Above all, always look confident, even if you do not feel it. It gets you a long way.Enjoy.

The entertaining-monkeys should end!. I hate the way the monkeys look so terrified of their handlers, and hanging on to their collars like their lives depended on them. I hate the way I saw them being shoved into the cramp and small box they were brought in with. I saw one wearing a nappy and it disturbed me to think that he might have been abused. I cried at Djemaa al Fna feeling helpless and sorry for the monkeys.
Mad but fun!. Loved it! Just keep your wits about you and be prepared to pay if you take pictures of people!
This place is nuts!. Everyone should go there at least once in their lives. It's even better at night.

A unique experience at night!. Wow is really the best word to describe it! Hold on to your hat as at night the square fills with people, motos zoom by, the monkeys tap you on the shoulder and people try to sell you anything and everything. The food stall waiters are very aggressive, but the best response if you don't want to sit down is "I've already eaten!" We loved food stalls 1 and 31!
MAGIC IN THE MIDDLE OF THE MEDINA. Simply a magical place. not to be missed. snake charmers, orange juice sellers, dancers and performers - its the beating heart of north africa!
Dangerous Mopeds. Watch out for the dangerous mopeds.Still worth the risk though.
Mad place to visit but so worth it. The ladies tried to put henna on your arms and you are a little hassled but say no thank you and they are very polite back

Amazing experience. True view of Marrakech, the souks are a complete maze of tiny hideways and walkways. The bartering is expected and there are surprises around every corner.Monkeys and Snakes in the main square in the daytime stopped me going in daylight.
Entertain your senses!!. Busy, colourful, amazing - make sure you have a cup of tea on the terrace at the Cafe de France

Have the orange juice!. Having read reviews I was nervous about going. We were about the square a lot as staying nearby. A simple no to unwelcome attention was suffient. We ignored snake charmers and monkeys as we did not like animals used this way. The orange juice was only 4 dirham and excellent. We did not feel brave enough to risk eating here at night, but enjoyed nearby cafes and people watching.

Heart of the city where it all happens. This is a huge square where they used to execute people.Now it is where everyone goes to eat, be entertained or just watch the world go by.During the day it is quite quite, but at night comes alive with entertainers (music, dance, snake charmers, magic tricks etc), storytellers, food sellers etc. At the edges are cafes with roof terraces so the people watches can sit, chat and enjoy the view. There are also some very good local restaurants around the square, plus the wonderful mobile food sellers (some good, some not so good - look for the queues) and of course the market stalls (look out for the false teeth sellers!). A wonderful place to wander around in.

Didn't live up to the hype.. We visited the Jemaa during the afternoon and again in the evening. We'd heard of all the snake charmers, storytellers, etc and looked forward to an exotic experience. In the afternoon the place was somewhat crowded, with lots of stalls set up with henna artists, said snake charmers, etc. But virtually nobody was watching the show - it seemed that most people knew that they would be harassed if they stopped to look or, heaven forbid, took a few photos. So with lots of avoiding eye contact going on, it was sort of sad, not an experience I enjoyed.In the evening we strolled through again, and there were hundreds of food stalls set up. We had a mediocre appetizer at one place, but didn't have dinner because we had planned a dinner at a noted restaurant, so we can't really judge the food there.Maybe the Jemaa is more lively at different times of the year, but all in all we were very disappointed in the experience.

In danger of being swamped by Tourism. There's no doubt that the square and the surrounding alleyways and Souks are well worth a visit. In the evening the square itself is chaotic with people, bikes and mopeds heading in all directions and there are all sorts of performers in the main square, although it is verging on the edge of tackiness. Quite a number of locals go to listen to small bands and story tellers and to eat from the street stalls. That said, the place is overwhelmed by tourists, hence the tackiness, so it is hard to feel that you are in "authentic" Marrakesh and when you sit down to eat at a street stall you could just as easily be in Dusseldorf as Morocco. I have to say I got more fun from walking the narrow alleys near the square that tend to cater for the locals.

Must see!!. You have to see this both during the day and also at night...very different contrast. Spend some time on the ground taking it in; also get a vantage from a cafe overlooking the square. I literally spent 4 hours here soaking it in over 2 days.It actually is pretty easy to NOT get hassled. Just don't take pictures of the obvious performers who want $ (snake charmers, guys with monkey, etc) and if one of these guys tries to force something on you (like putting a monkey on your arm), say no and keep walking. Easy!
You have to experience it to believe it - amazing!. The reviews about how amazing the square is are all true, but until you don't experience it for yourself you won't believe it!

A Feast for the Senses. A visit to the Jemna el Fnaa is a must for any trip to Marrakech. Be sure to visit during the day, as well as at night, as the experience differs greatly. The ginger tea is a novel treat--and an aphrodisiac according to an experienced local. The nighttime entertainment ranges from games of skill and all types of musical performance to amateur boxing matches. The sounds, smells and sights are almost breathtaking.

Great food. We went to the night market at Jemaa el Fna every night to eat during our stay in Marrakech. I loved the relaxed atmosphere and the variety of food. The food is served in small portions and you can order like tapas. There was a huge variety of food. The bill for two people was around £10. There are also other stalls selling fresh orange juice about 30p per glass and snails too. It great people watching too.
Dusty, dirty, stank of urine and feces.. Dusty, dirty, stank of urine and feces.Had an allergic reaction every time we went into the old town etc.
Out of this world. I know it is apart of the culture of marrakech but I found it quite difficult watching monkeys and there keepers and snake charmers, it seemed wrong.

Open all hours?. Just to add a little more information to these reviews (good and not so good) is the fact that on the morning and afternoon of Eid el Kabir, aka le fete de mouton, falling on November 6th this year (2011), Djemma el Fna is all but deserted. A very strange sight to behold, especially with a few disorientated visitors wondering why everything is closed! The Moroccan families of course are celebrating Abraham's sacrifice of a sheep instead of his son to God, and enjoying many meals together. The square returns to it's normal fascinating and frustrating self in the evening. This is the only day in the year that la place can be experienced like this.
To be seen.... Very crowded, lot of animations, a lot of sellers. Fantastic squeezed fresh orange juice.

Beware of the Local Thugs. I have mixed feelings about Djema El Fna. I really enjoyed the buzz in the square and loved that it was so different from Europe and America.It really is a memorable place. Despite this I think that it is absolutely disgraceful that thugs are allowed bully and intimidate tourists here. If a tourist happens to take a picture of the snake charmers or monkey handlers in the square they are then promptly harassed and threatened for an unreasonable amount of money. These people and their buddies surround the unsuspecting tourists and demand in no certain terms that they want 200 dirhams(about 20 euro)If you refuse to pay up then you will suffer the consequences. There was absolutely no police presence. For such a famous place I think that the Moroccon police should be there to help tourists from these minority of thugs. This is a pity as these people give Morocco and its peole a bad name. The square is great but just BEWARE. If you want to take a photo go into one of the coffee shops that have a balcony and take your picture from there. Its safer.

Madness. Best to go straight to the terrace of the Cafe de France and view it from above, where the theatre of the street is provided day and night.Beware catching anyone's eye as everyone is out to make a fast buck and see tourists as walking dollar signs.Don't take photographs of anything unless you are willing to part company with 20Euros.If you go with the flow it's a uniquely insane experience.

What a place!!!. Been to Marrakech 3 times and still can't get enough of Djemaa al Fna. Some of the bad reviews don't surprise me as the culture there is completely different to the western countries so you'll either love it and appreciate it for being so different or you'll hate it. Here's a few tips for those travelling from western countries:1) Do not ask anyone for directions, you'll be taken on the longest route ever and then asked for money and most likely you won't get away until you have paid. Instead ask staff at riad to show you way to the sqaure if you feel the need or look for signs, symbols, shops etc on the way to the riad which may help you to locate the riad in case you struggle to find way back. 2) Don't feel sorry for the children begging and asking for food, these children aren't poor, its just a way of earning some money and getting free dinner.3) Do stop to take a look at the men with monkeys and snakes, but as soon as they look at you, ignore them and walk away and do not look back or feel guilty for walking away. Certainly do not start taking pictures as you will end up paying money for it. I tend to stand far away and take pictures.4) Do not eat from the food stands at night or cafes in the square as they're a rip of and food isn't that great. Instead search for smaller restaurants away from the main square where food is tastier and cheaper.5) Don't start negiotiating on prices unless you really are interested in buying that item and start bargaining with a price much lower that what you want to pay.6) For lone females, avoid staying in the square after 10ish at night if you don't have a male with you or aren't in a large female group as you'll get a lot of funny looks from some weird characters.

Busy, not particularly a highlight. We went to the Jemaa el Fna as it seemed to be a must from Trip Advisor reviews. My main thought is that it was busy, you didn't get the opportunity to browse without being harrassed by women doing henna tatoos, men with monkeys, people offering horse drawn carriages around the town, restaurant staff trying to get you to eat in their restaurant. It was all a bit of a sensory overload, but a must see place!I wouldn't rave about the restaurants there, it was fast food Moroccan style - 'rack em up and get em out'. My kids love pasta but it was something we steered them away from in Morocco as it was usually pretty poor.The other unnerving thing in Marrakesh is the number of people wanting to show you the way to somewhere for money. They walk very quickly so you don't really known where you were taken and we were even approached by a friend of our "guide" who also wanted money for some reason! Don't be fooled by the older gentlemen telling you their wife works in your Riad - she probably doesn't and they want to take you on a tour and get paid for it. They take you in with this line and you generally feel obliged to go with them - don't!

The heart of the city. When in Marrakech, you MUST see the Place Jemaa el Fna at sunset! It's the center and heart of the city, both geographically and emotionally. We walked through it a few times during the day, there's nothing much to see, but WOW do things change at sunset. Try to get a rooftop table at the Café de France; watching the going down from that unique vantage point, one of the highest in Marrakech (?), with the beautiful Koutoubia mosque in front of us, was something I'll never forget.

ELECTRIC. This place is definitely a must see. It is alive during the day, but really comes alive at night. iterally a hundred temporary restaurants spring up instantly at night, and it becomes a wonder of lights. Motorbikes zipping by in all directions,with 2, 3 and even 4 people on them.A word of caution, there are many kids harrasing you to buy knicknacks, and such, and plain old begging, so just learn to ignore.Also, take as many pictures as you want,and of anyone or anything, but DO NOT FEEL COMPELLED TO GIVE ANYONE MONEY!!! It is an open public square, and there is absolutely no obligation to give any vendor or performer any money.There is so much going on there, and the energy is electric.

A real experience - watch the sun go down from a roof terrace. Be careful when you approach the place, the motorbike traffic is mad and you need eyes in the back of your head. The 'place' is not to be missed and is as others have described in prior reviews. I would recommend getting there for 6.30 and take a drink at one of the cafe roof terraces whilst watching the sun set. Do check first if you want a cocktail as not many serve alcohol within sight of the mosque. The colours are amazing and you will see the square transform as the evening sellers set up their portable kitchens and wares. We ate twice in the market square on benchs and took in the atmosphere. The brochettes (kebabs) are excellent, as is a plate of freshly cooked fish and seafood. You can eat very cheaply and well there but I would advise you to find seating away from the outside aisles as beggars will constantly be pleading for food. Very distressing, especially when they are elderly. We made up filled rolls with the remains of our meal and gave them to the needy who are really grateful. You will be approached by the food vendors to go into their particular portable restaurant but generally it is done in good humour and a simple 'we have already eaten' will suffice. We liked number 22, good food and nice characters. When you have eaten, wander into the souk and have fun bargaining. Beautiful shawls, kaftans, shoes and rugs etc. Lovely leather pumps for c.£6. Starting price was £18. It is a great experience but can also be tiring so wear comfy clothes. All in all it is an intoxicating place.

One of the most exotic and magical places I've ever visited. Jemaa el Fna is one of those places you must visit during your lifetime. As I read in another review, Jemaa el Fna is a magical place. No words or pictures can describe it. You must live it. You must smell it, hear it, feel it in your body skin…yes, you may feel it in your skin…the snakes rubbing your neck and the heat attacking your body as the sun gets hotter and hotter.Things you can’t miss at Jemaa el Fna: a) Drink an orange juice, they are delicious. We drank several but the stand we liked most is number 38. Sellers are usually very nice. Don’t be scared if they shout at you. They are just competing to get your attention.b) Take a photo with one of the “animation teams” that “work” in Jemaa el Fna. We have chosen to take a picture with snake charmers. You may feel harassed by them, but don’t take it as an offence. If you don’t want to take photos, just say it politely. They will leave alone. But you must say it two or three times  And I advise you to discuss prices before taking pictures. c) See it at night… It’s incredible how the square gains an extra energy from 4pm till 1am. Food stands begin to organize their places and at night it’s an incredible show. The smell of the different foods, the sounds of people advertising their stands, the music from dancers… You have to live it. Me end my wife didn’t have the courage to eat at the stands…but many tourists do it. I regret not doing it.d) Have a nice and peaceful meal in one of the several terraces of the square’s many restaurants. See my reviews about them (Café de France, Terraces Alhambra, Café Glacier)e) Buy some souvenirs from the stands that exist around the square. The souks offer much more products but buying in the square is also a good deal. I did it and my barging made me save 500 DAH.If going to Marrakech, don’t miss Jemaa el Fna.Visit it during daytime and feel it at night.
Visit by night!. Fun and exotic at daytime, but fantastic after dark!! Have dinner here, amazing morrocan food, very cheap!

A magical place. We loved the market! Ignore all bad reviews and check it out for yourself.Yeah, it can a tiny bit overwhelming at first - but after 10 minutes you will realise you are safe and just to be a little firm with saying no. Just be polite about it.You can barter things down from 600dh to 50dh if you know how to play their game.You will get approached by people with monkeys, interesting outfits, small trinkets and toys - the snake charmers will call you over but it's all part of the fun.You will have to pay for a photo. Just be prepared to barter with them too. They could ask for 200dh for a photo but just give them 50dh max and walk away. At night the market really comes to life and you can walk around aimlessly for hours just looking at everything. Don't be scared to go too deep into the souks either. People always help with the way out and they do not ask for money. The food, the shopping, the entertainment - everything at this place is excellent.

A tale of two cities. A beautiful city such as Marrakesh trying to rebuild its reputation after the bombing needs to get rid of the vermin that have infested its main attraction; I am Asian (Indian sub continent) of origin and dark of skin tone, and traveled with friends and their families of the same origin, we were subject to open racist abuse, constant harassment and then when a henna artist started screaming abuse at my mother in law, wife and friends wive, confronted by 40 or so "nationalists" for daring to question her dishonesty! disgraceful, appalling, never again!! I have been all over Morocco as my wife is Moroccan, but Marrakesh and Tangiers give such a bad impression of such a beautiful country; Ifrane, Fez, Oualidia, Essaouira, Mohammedia, Dar el Bouazza, Safi, Ouarzazate, El Jadida, Casa and Rabat are much nicer and chilled out places with lovely people as opposed to the other two cities

The heart of Marrakech. Fantastic! You can not go to Marrakech and miss the Jemaa el Fna...This is the heart of the city. This square come to life right after sunset, when all the local food places set up. Food is not the greatest although it is worth to take a sit, get some food and enjoy the crazy atmosphere.

Crazy but fantastic. We only spent 2 nights in Marrakech but came here for dinner both nights. The food is cheap but delicious, there is a lot of hassle from the waiters on the stalls but it's all good humoured banter and mostly very amusing. It's incredibly busy in the evening but we never felt intimidated, we kept our distance from the snake charmers and guys with monkeys so they never bothered us (stick to the edge of the square). The sounds and smells were amazing although away from the food stalls the smells were a bit iffy. Daytime wasn't particularly exciting but at night it's just a big exciting theatre.

Avoid at all costs. We were taken to the medina on our first night and it was awful. There was so much poverty. The horses / donkeys were clearly distressed and looked malnourished, dehydrated and had scars on their hides where they had been beaten. Moreover, there was an intoxicating smell of horse manure throughout the medina. We saw birds that had had their wings clipped for entertainment and monkeys in shackles being paraded around for photo opportunities. The men at the medina often tried to push monkeys onto tourists and place snakes around shopper's shoulders to create money making photo opportunities (this happened to our friends. They were told to pay 150 dirhams (£13). When they refused, they were surrounded by 5 Moroccan men and were forced to hand the money over).There are lots of beggars: from the very old to the very young and the severely disfigured. After a few days we became aware that the children who were running around the medina begging had to hand over their money to a large "Fagin" like man. Terribly upsetting. Also, if you're white you are going to get ripped off. We speak fluent French but despite that the prices where inflated 10 fold. For example a shop owner tried to sell a cheap metal tea pot and glasses for over 1000 dirhams. When we attempted to haggle and told him that a Moroccan friend of ours had advised us we should pay no more than 100 dirhams, he became very aggressive and confrontational. We have haggled in other countries (Iran, Italy, Egypt, Turkey) and have never experienced this level of animosity,

Magic place :). Very very crowd place! Mix of oriental smells, sounds of reed for snakes, dances of men n womens clothes, fortune-tellers and magicians... The oriental market works all night long.... All squarre is full of street restaurants , where u can taste pure maroccain dishes ... Very good place in night!

nice markets. I like the markets. I was disappointed about the beggars and trying to force you to buy what you don't want. I don,t like to have things put on my head to buy.I liked the food it was a really good choice. I don't like the idea of people selling things to you.I liked the markets at night because you see all the lights everywhere.

A spiritual experience.... positive for some, negative for others, and creepy for many. But, this is the heart of Marrakech's tourist industry, and it's worth seeing. Action generally starts around dusk. If you find yourself overwhelmed by the activity, find yourself a table in a nearby sidewalk or rooftop cafe at a safe distance.Words of adivce: some people in the tourist industry can be pushy at times, but you should never been compelled or manipulated into doing something that you don't want to. Say no, and walk away.

The place to be. Jemma el Fna square is the place to be in Marrakech. It is a tale of two sides, it has a totally different atmosphere in the daytime compared to the evening, both are unique and must be experienced.The snake charmers, henna ladies, story tellers, musicians etc,etc will keep you entertained, even if you dont understand exactly what they are saying.

fantastic atmosphere. The medina is amazing and really lively at night, especially when all the tables are set out and the cooking starts. It is noisy and very busy, so watch as you are crossing the square. it is amazing to see the snake charmers, actively encouraging the various snakes to appear from the baskets. amazing to see the cobras- you can watch them from a safe distance! It is worth wandering the souks to see all the stalls and also go into the pultry area - quite unique! the souks are now well sign posted and worth walking all the way to the top end of it.

Lively and cultural atmosphere. This place is great for afternoon and night time it gets more busier in the night with many food stalls opening up. You have to go and check the shops around the square and in the souk to get the best prices. You must try the orange juice the only nice orange juice stall was number 27 had to have 2 glasses.Take your camera with you as you can take pictures with the monkeys or snakes or on the horse and carriages. One of the best experience was eating at the food stall in the night, however there will be many workers trying to get you to eat at there place. Number 81 lamb kebabs were delicious. The square food is better then the restaurant food in my opinion

Miss it and Miss out!. I had some reservations about venturing into the medina after reading some of the reviews on trip advisor. I am in my 20's and took my mum with me and being two blonde female travellers I wasn't sure what to expect!It was a brilliant, brilliant experience all of your sense are awakened and it really is a sight for sore eyes.On our first trip to the square we went around the souks with a guide who we picked up at the entrance to the main square, for a couple of quid he took us around and helped us get our bearings in the maze that is the souks. After a morning walking through small winding alleyways coming out into light airy courtyards with merchants selling spices, art work, jewellery, clothes and food and the rest we were navigated back through the cool shade of the souks to the Jemaa El Fna. You have to dodge mopeds, avoid stepping on snakes or cuddling a monkey on the way!I would recommend the fresh orange juice you can buy and going up to one of the restaurant roof terraces at night. Another tip would be as the sun goes down you can take all of your photographs of the square's activities from the roof terrace to save some of the hassle.Talking of hassle yes you do get approached and asked to buy things, eat things, get tattoed, hold monkeys, kiss snakes etc etc, however if you remain laid back with a smile on your face and politely say no thank you if you don't want to participate you are met with a your welcome, a smile or welcome to Marrakech back. We never had a bad experience always kept a sense of hunour and immersed ourselves in the culture.I personally always covered up when I went to the square wearing long dresses and taking a shawl this was to show respect and also to make myself feel comfortable. I did see tourists in all states of dress but as women I feel that you do get alot of attention anyway so if you don't want to add to that then dress to suit the area your in.The food stalls were also part of the experience, I had to persuade my mum to try them as she is used to fine dining more than I am but she loved the atmosphere the fast food that was mouth wateringly tasty and the excellent service. We went to food stall one alot which I would recommend and they do love it if you visit more than once, we ate tangines, cous cous, kebabs, salads, vegetables and dips and no one that we ate with or took there ever had a stomach complaint. Also they cater for any tastes and we had a vegetarian woman in our party one night who asked what they did for vegetarians to be presented with a feast of vegetables and cous cous etc all for under £5.This is a great place to meet new people, experience marrakech and is also a gateway to book tours, or get guides and information. A brilliant place which I miss already!

Excellent food. We have been to Marrakech twice and each time we have enjoyed our time spent around the square. In the day time, its a hive of snake charmers, monkeys and henna-ladies all vying for your attention, whilst at night it changes with the restaurenters trying to get you to eat at their table. All the stalls we ate at where great, and we never got sick eating there. It was definately a cheap alternative to eating at the restaurents overlooking the square, and you felt part of the pulsing nightlife.Also the spiced tea (served in the urns) on the edges of the square was really nice, and a bargain at 2dhr.

Cool place for food and shopping. This square offers a lot and there is so much to take in at once. You will certainly want to go back again and again. Not much into watching the snake charming but since I love Moroccan food it’s great to go to the food stalls and try so many amazing foods. If you love shopping then visit the souks. I had so much fun going from place to place. I’ve bought several scarves, trinkets, oils, small bags and a small lamp. Be careful as it is very busy and of course you will have someone trying to lead you astray to buy this or that. There will be loads of people being friendly but at the same time trying to rip you off. You will get a mix of things and attitudes but it’s a must see.

A truly unique experience for tourists, a vital revenue for the locals. I have visited Marrakech often now. I have a few favourite stands to eat at, and as i speak fluent french and some arabic have now learnt a lot about how the 'business' of the 'Place' works. Plenty of tourists wander through but never stop and eat anywhere. Life is tough for the guys on the stalls. Tourists wander through and gawp, and get hassled to stop and eat, its worth being aware that the average wage for the night (4pm-1.30am when its all packed away) is 80dh... buy the macaroons from the children, their mothers' make them and for the sake of 2dh a piece, they are delicious, and the smiles of thanks are worth it. Be aware that if you don't finish your food,please give it to the people who beg, who are often ravenous, and if they don't want it and want money instead, draw your own conclusions! If you want to do something usefully charitable seek out the lentil stall next to no 12 - he supplies food to the many that can't afford to eat, and give him some dh for his efforts. Try the delicious' the epices' spice tea - bloody amazing, and will sort out any colds you may have! As mentioned above ref to snake charmers and story tellers beware the cost of taking a photo - and women beware the groping in the story telling groups! If you look like a tourist expect to be treated like one is the most useful advice I can give, and showing flesh is an open invitation, whether you approve of the culture or not.. If every toursit who visited marrakech actually ate a meal on the 'place' we could make sure that this amazing experience continues. It would be a tragedy to see a McD's there!

Beware of the snake charmers, monkey tamers and henna women. We loved Marrakech! The food was amazing, our riad was gorgeous, the architecture was beautiful and the people were beyond nice. Well most of the people were beyond nice. When dealing with people in the Jemaa el Fna square, do not make eye contact and ignore them unless you want to pay for something. If you are interested in taking a picture, getting a henna tattoo or seeing the monkeys - ALWAYS negotiate payment first.Here's what might happen if you don't take precaution. When we were walking through the Jemaa el Fna, we saw a couple of snakes about 20 feet away. The snake charmers were sitting behind the snakes but seemed to be on break. No one was near the snakes and they were not in the middle of a show so I snapped a quick picture. A man approached me waiving his hat in my face demanding money. When I said I had no money, he grabbed my arm and would not let go and started waiving his hat again. I kept saying "Sorry I did not realize the rules and I will delete my picture" and started to delete the picture. He then began to drag me through the square at which point I loudly stated that I deleted the picture. He lightly shoved me and then walked away.Later that day we were approached by women that did henna tattoos. We repeated "No, merci" and kept walking. One girl grabbed my hand and would not let go. She started drawing after I repeated numerous times that I had no money. Her two friends then started grabbing at my boyfriends pockets while she held tight to my arm. My boyfriend quickly grabbed his wallet to try and keep it out of reach of the women. To show them, he opened his wallet to show that he had no Euros or Durhams and that he only had a $20 USD. The two girls grabbed the money out of his wallet and turned away before he could do anything. Once we got to the food tents it was great, the path to get to the food was an adventure.

Beware of the snake charmers. A great place at any time of day, but truly buzzing at night. I'm not going to repeat all that has been said before by other members.But please beware of the snake charmers, we got sucked in and after 6 or 7 photos received a demand for 300 DHs, needless to say after a heated debate, we settled on a much lower figure. I guess it may be the same with the monkey trainers too.I let my gaurd down this once and learnt my lesson!

Jemaa el Fna Lives Up to Its Reputatio. If you go to Marrakech then YOU HAVE to visit Jemaa el Fna its a place to be any time of the day - mostly at night. During the days its like any hot spot where you find entertainment and tourists try to experience the sights and sounds of Marrakech. During the night however its a different kettle of fish. The orange juice sellers along with nut and dates stall are a permanent fixture (try some they are delicious). You HAVE and i repeat HAVE to try the orange juice!! its not only sweet but taste like heaven! all the oranges are grown locally and the all year around sun shine helps. i made stall number 1 my pit stop in and out of Jemaa el Fna.At night this place explodes when the food stalls start to cook - and your drawn in by sense of smell. The food is excellent no matter which stall you eat at. its all down to how each of the vendor entice you into their piece of Jemaa el Fna. Don't be afraid to tried the food its fresh tasty and cheap - but try the mint tea after your meal.If you haven't visited other poor countries you may find the square overwhelming but nothing fazes me after Cairo and turkey (then again i am born and raised in Kashmir). Ignore them and they will go away, I tend to wave my hand, shake my head and say no firmly and they go the message. Just be courteous and they will leave you alone.

Fantastic...safe even at 9pm. If you can overlook the beggars and peddlers then this is a place for you. We ate soooo much...and never once did we get sick. Do try out the tagines at the proper restaurants that surround the square. You will know what you are compromising. We found the tagines at the restaurants superior to the ones at the street stalls. One might roll their eyes and think...well, of course! but that is not true for the kebabs and the desserts we ate at the stalls. Do watch out for your wallet. Do not hold anything someone is trying to sell you...before you know it they will not want it back and will ask you to pay for it hahahhaa (oldest trick in their book).

The place to be on any evening.. If you are in Marrakech, then you must visit Jemma el Fna square. The place is full of peole in the daytime and you can easily spend a while here watching the world go by. Then in the evening the food stalls come out and it completely changes, a great place, must see.

Unmissable!. I was most looking forward to experiencing the madness of thee square and was not disappointed! It's so intense, with henna tattooists, stall owners, juice sellers and men with snakes, monkeys and bright costumes all competing for your attention (and money). If you intend to get a henna tattoo I would highly reccomend you do it on the first day - that way even the most persistant tattooists will leave you alone. For orange juice go to 34, they guys are really friendly and the juice isnt watered down like some other stalls. For food in the evening go to 12, again the guys there are really friendly and such a great laugh.

Madness, chaos, and electricity whirling together in a wild dance!. There is nothing that can prepare you for this experience. It is a must see for any trip to Morocco. 99.9% are not tourists. You need to arrive in the afternoon as they're putting up the restaurants and stay into the night. Take pictures and videos. Don't worry about all the street performers who will say, "you must pay me to take a picture.". There's no such law. You do what you want. The motorbikes, cars, horse drawn carriages, and donkeys all share the same space. Somehow they're not knocking people over. maybe it is part of the road test in Marrakech. If you pass through the square without hitting anyone, you get your license. Take your time and take it all in. It's an experience you'll never forget.

Nightlife of Marrakech. The square came alive at night. There were orange stalls, nut and date sellers, lots of food stalls and plently of halal snails (slugs in shells!) stalls ie Escargot. The food at the stalls was cheap and plentiful. See my photo of the menu and prices of stall number one. It is what it is, but I couldn't have eaten an entire meal at a stall as it was rather cramped and uncomfortable. Stall food is not my cup of tea but it was for many as they were very busy. The henna tattoo ladies come running over to show your their patterns but I dislike henna at the best of times and Indian Henna is a better colour. Little children beg for money and try to sell you tissues. Please try and remember many of them are poor, they are just trying to make a living.If people haven't visited other poor countries they may find the square overwhelming but nothing fazes us after Cairo and Istanbul. Ignore them and they will go away, I tend to wave my hand, shake my head and say no firmly and they go the message. Don't make eye contact. I was throughly dismayed at seeing all the animal cruelty, illegal poached animal skins and eggs. The monkeys were on chains which they deliberately kept tight and they look distressed, please avoid having your photo taken with them as you only perpetuate their trade and the animal suffering. The snakes were handled badly and I imagine most live a miserable existence. If you do stay in the Medina area of Marrkech, and you love cats and kittens then i'd take cat biscuits/treats. The incense smell in the square irriatated our eyes and my partner's nose. The drumming beat sound gave me a headache and I didn't find it mesmerising as other posters have said. The motorcyclists were everywhere so you need eyes at the back of your head to avoid collision. All that being said we thoroughly enjoyed our stay in Marrakech.

Food Stalls. Spent a great week in Marrakesh the Jan 2011. Spent most evenings experiencing all the entertainers, curiosities and food stalls in the Jamaa el Fna square.Trying to fing the best food stall was a great challenge. Number 117 was were I ended up most time, but had to try a little bit of food from each.Having been approaced by a couple of guys, I settled down at one stall, I think it was number 44, really nice meal. As soon as I had finished and got up, the guy from the next stall, number 21, tried to persuade me to go to his stall. I told him that I had just eaten, he had seen me sit dow, and that I would eat at his stall either later or the next day.His friend also working on the stall started calling me a liar. He then asked me where I was from, I said London, he said all English people are liars and are 'people of questionable birth' (my words). I had never had such comments in all my visits to Marrakesh. I told him that perhaps I would not be visiting his stall.The next time I passed stall 21, I saw them giving abuse to an elderly couple, also English, He was saying if I or they ever eat at his stall he would spit in our food.So, a warning to all, stall 21, watch out.Other than that, the other stall where great.And the orange juice stalls were great also

The Square and Taxi Advice. The square has a circus feel with trained monkeys, snake charmers, little shops and the sound of drums that seem to never end. Very pretty at night.Some taxi advice: Small taxis have meters and are legally bound to use them. Make sure they turn it on, just refuse to get in, if the driver doesnt turn it on or says it is broken. Trips will usually cost less than 20MAD.For big taxis, i.e. the Mercedes, the price has to be arranged before you get in, they will usually require more, so smaller taxis are to be prefered. Taking taxis from the Airport: Here the stuff written above doesnt apply, take the bus into town and take a taxi from there. If you take a taxi you will get ripped off. It will be about 20 MAD per person with the bus, but it will be cheaper.
