Love this place!!!. I absolutely love this Square! So much so that I was in Marrakech for 4days and only spent 1day doing a day tour. It is such a great experience and is a lot of fun haggling, trying the different foods and people watching. Be wary of the women who try to do Henna tattoos though. Try to keep your hands away from them at all times. It is also great fun when the Moroccans dress you up in their traditional gear. They dont want money and they are not trying to get you to buy anything, they are just being friendly. You will also get offered in for Moroccon Tea practically everywhere you go. They are just being polite but you can still decline.Also be wary of men offering you marajuana. I was told by the hotel manager that more often than not the police are in on it and once you buy, the police swoop in on you. They kept pestering my younger brother and friend, following them through the streets but you just have to be very firm.Also be wary of the snake charmers and the men with the monkeys. The snake charmers will just place a snake on you and expect you to pay them money to have it taken off. Luckily I did not have this done to me but I seen it all too often with niave tourists. As for the man with monkeys,they will do the same but I would never give them money in a million years as they drug the monkeys and they are kept in the smallest cages all day in the square. It is such a sad sight.more often than not the people are genuine but it does become very hard to tell the genuine ones from the ones that are just after your money. You will be approached constantly asking where you are going, they will insist on taking you or showing you another place you can visit and it is very hard to tell whether they are genuine and dont want your money or are just after your money. It did get annoying at times so if you dont want to be led away, just tell them no straight from the start.But all in all it is a great experience and I cant wait to return next year!

The most magic city in Morocco. It's big, it's dusty (especially when harmattan blows), it's nosy and it has this special exotic smell. You can't miss it when in Morocco. The central point is Jemma el-Fna square that is adjacent to the extensive medina. There are many souks around Jemma el-Fna so you can do a lot of shopping there. Remember to haggle, though. The most unusual experience starts after dusk when Jemma el-Fna turns into probably the largest open-air restaurant. There are many strange things to eat (like sheep brain) but you can definitely find something for yourself that is edible by European standards. Don't forget to get a cup or two of freshly squeezed orange juice from stalls all over Jemma el-Fna. The place is truly magic and you can feel it with all your senses.

Wow. My boyfriend and I visit Marrakesh recently and spent some time in Jemaa el Fna square. We were amazed with all the noise and activity, definetly a place to go. We took part in a tour named Discovery Marrakesh which finished at Jemaa el Fna just before sunset. We were then able to look around and take a break in a nearby cafe. This place is amazing, especially with all the snakes and monkeys. My favourity part was walking through the middle and being hecked by the vendors "cheaper than primark" and "alright guv".MUST SEE!!!!

fabulous and great bartering. We went to Marrakesh April 2010 with large group of friends and loved it. The square was amazing, especially at night. As always expect hustle and vendors trying to persuade you to eat/buy from them. The square transforms from night to day, expect to see monkeys on leads and snake charming! the windy paths that run behind the square are full of stalls trying to get you to but. Be prepared to barter, you'll know you've got a good price when you walk away and they come running after you with an even lower price, not that it really matters even if they do rip you off its still probably only costing 20p in english money!

You have to see this during the day and.... You have to see this during the day and night it really different...at night there is heaps more going on and it really good going up on one of the seccond story cafes at just watching it all

Fantastic atmosphere - a great place to eat. I'm a bit suprised by some of the tourist trap comments as the majority of people we saw here were locals (especially at night). We visited Marrakech during Ramadan so once the sun went down there was a real sense of celebration in Jemaa el Fna.To really enjoy it you have to be bold and not give in to any pressure put on you by people asking you to see their goods or pay money for acrobatics. If you are polite they will leave you alone (wearing sunglasses during the day also works wonders as they cannot catch your eye!)The food at the stalls and restaurants around the edge is cheap - about 50DH for a good Tajine, and the sounds and smells from 8pm onwards make this place well worth at least one visit. Don't lock yourself in your hotel, get out there!

Night Lights of Marrakech. The best way to experience the 'big square' or 'la plaace" is to get there before sunset. Take a slow walk throught the square and stop by the acrobat circles, get the hennae tatoo on an ankle,and grab an orange juice from one of the stall along the sides. Then head up to one of the surrounding terrace restaurants and grab a seat on the rooftop at an edge. Order a drink and something to snak on and settle in to watch the sun go down and Marrakech come out to play. Take your time and listen to the sounds of the snake charmers and their horns, and the horses, and the water sellers. When the sound overwhelms you close your eyes and ears and take a deep breath, the smells are a story in themselves.Make sure you have a good zoom on your camera as ypou can take alot of pictures from this great vantage point without the hassle of paying the objects of the pics..i.e watersellers, monkeys, snake charmers, cymbal players etc. I dont mind paying, but sometimes you dont even have them in the picture and they are still quite aggressive being paid. When all of the lights of the stalls have come on, take yourself off to have some real dinner at one of the stalls. I choose one with alot of smoke coming from it... dont know why. Basically they all offer a good deal and the food is fresh and tasty. After the meal take a slow walk around the square and then wander home to your riad.

Djemaa el Fna is lovely - but AVOID the ANIMAL CRUELTY. Whatever you do, don't get your photograph taken with monkeys, snakes or other animals in the market square. Keepers are incredibly cruel to these animals - taking baby monkeys from their mothers and pulling out their teeth to prevent biting. Snakes' mouths are sewn up for the same reason. The animals don't live for very long and it's tourism that keeps this barbarism going.

You have to go. Jemaa el Fna square is a must visit, go at dusk, have a seat at one of the cafe's first to watch without being hassled, watch the smoke and steam rising through all the lights from all the food stalls, then venture out and soak it all up because there is a lot to take in. Story tellers (in Arabic), drummers, acrobats, snake charmers, orange juice sellers, lots of food sellers. We went to number 81 which was great. They all looked good value. Sure you will get people trying to sell you things and get money off you but it won't be a fortune and if they didn't get any money one of the world’s great spectacles would disappear. The drumming and music is particularly mesmerising. Go and enjoy and don’t get stressed it’s a memory you’ll not forget, even if you paid 20 DH (£1.60) more than you wanted to. My partner did end up getting a henna tattoo she didn’t want, very sneakily (cleverly) applied during us trying to say no, but we’re laughing about it now. By the end of your holiday you’ll be a master at saying no and you’ll breeze along without any trouble at all.

terrible place. The square is a tourist trap, the markets are expensive and there are poor monkeys kept in small boxes for tourists to take photos - shame on the tourists and the 'owners' of the monkeys. Marrakesh is a total nightmare with people trying to scam you left right and centre. Don;t go!

Breathtaking!. Whilst staying Marrakech, you have GOT to visit the Jemma el fna. There is such a big contrast from day to night. During the day, there are story tellers, dancers, snake charmers & lots more. However, at night, the food stalls light up the entire square.Although daunting at first, don't let the food stall holders put you off. They will surely try and get you to eat at their stall. I strongly recommend stall 81 - the guys here are fantastic, speak great english, and will leave you in stitches!A special thanks to Othman & Simo at stall 81!

Overwhelming. Love it or hate it, but don't pass by without observing such a great open air theatre! The musicians, the dancers, the story tellers, the games, the henna tattooists, the orange juice and food stands... there's such a great atmosphere with locals and tourists. We loved it!! We didn't spend much time during the day and when crossing the square they will follow you with henna design books and even hold your hand, dance in front of you or try to put a hat on your head to get some change but if you're not interested just look away or say "no, thank you" with a smile. It really is that simple. At any time we got aggressive behaviour. When we would stop to watch or take pictures of dancers or musicians, someone would come straight away with a hat asking money and 5-10dh was all they got. Once they even pulled me to middle of the crowd and let us take pictures with one of the dancers without asking for more change. During our 8 days stay in Marrakesh we had always dinner at #114 (except when we had a lovely dinner on the desert). At the 2nd night we tried #97 and we wanted to try tangia. The waiter told us to take a look how it looked like and when we were ready to order, they told us they didn't have tangia any longer. After being ignored a couple of times we made our way quickly to #114. They are all such friendly, funny and caring people always with a big smile on their faces. The food is delicious and yes, even eating there several times we loved it! I would recommend the tangine of chicken, tangia and kebab. If you plan to pay them a visit, and I hope you do, please say Hi from Clara and Mohsen to Aziz (a.k.a Robert) and Hicham.

Beware of locals directing you to the Tanneries. On the first day of our visit to Marrakech, we left our hotel (around the corner from the square) to look around the souks. As we entered on the left, a local guy on a moped pointed to the right-hand side and, although we didn't catch what he said, he said it was the last day. We assumed it was some local craft market or something similar and headed in that direction, thanking him for his help, while he set off in the other direction. After walking for some minutes, we were unsure which way to go and he turned up again and pointed out the way, this time walking with his moped and chatting to us in broken English. He was telling us about the "tanneries" (which must have been the "word" we couldn't work out initially) and he took us through a door in a wall and introduced us to another guy inside, who gave us a large bunch of mint to use as a "gas mask" as the smell was horrendous from the animal skins etc. After showing us around the numerous concrete "baths" containing skins (and I'm not sure what else), he took us across the road to a shop selling leather goods and carpets and introduced us to the owner and then left. We were shown the different types of leather and some carpets but we told him that we couldn't take any home, as we were restricted to weight and capacity (Ryanair!) As we left the shop the "Tanneur" appeared again and pleasantly told us that he would direct us back towards the "square", for which we were grateful as we had lost our bearings. As he took us along an alleyway, he suddenly stopped and demanded 100 dirhams. We told him we hadn't asked to be taken to the Tanneries and no-one had even hinted that there would be a charge but he turned quite nasty and repeated his request. My husband offered him some change but he gestured towards my husband's pocket and said he wanted notes. When my husband said he didn't have any notes, he was quite threatening and told us not to mess with him. I started walking off ,hoping my husband would follow but he was trying to reason with the guy and, as I got further along the alleyway, I noticed another guy at the exit and assumed he was associated with the "tanneur" My husband followed me a couple of minutes later and said he had given him 30 dirhams in change and walked off, without giving him chance to object. This was a scary experience as we didn't know what these guys were capable of and it was all done so slickly - the guy on the moped went off in the other direction, so no alarm bells there but he was obviously following to direct us when we took the wrong turn and, once the tanneur had taken us to the shop, he appeared to leave but was obviously waiting outside to "show us to the Square".

Not so charming charmers!. The Jemaa el Fna, with its adjoining souks is undoubtedly the big draw to Marrakech. It's full of hustle and bustle and colour, and is generally an exciting place to be. The air is filled with the sound of drumming and the reedy music of the snake charmers. It's worth having a stroll around to soak in the exotic atmosphere, but be wary of the snake charmers and the guys with the monkeys. Wander too close to them and you're likely to find a snake around your neck or a monkey on your shoulder - and they won't take them off until you pay up for the privilege! I found it safer to withdraw to one of the rooftop cafes and watch the comings and goings froma safe distance. Most places seem happy to let you sit on their terrace for long enough with a mint tea or a cafe noir. Its a great way to get a feel of the place or relax and unwind after a spot of heavy-duty haggling in the souks!

A place that won't appeal to everyone.. This is regarded as the chief tourist attraction of Marrakech, but I fully understand why some would find it unappealing. If you could stroll with the majority Moroccan crowd all would be well, but tourists are seen as fair game for the more unsavoury types that inhabit the square and along with the insistent traders there are more sinister people offering drugs and other illegal services. Everything has a price in Marrakesh and although I enjoyed posing for photos with some of the square's more colourful characters they expected of course to be handsomely tipped. Also if you stop to give money in this way to one, you are immediately surrounded by a gaggle of other hustlers. As a female I was particularly targeted by the henna tattooists and these women (always in scary face veils) were a real nuisance and I had to be very assertive with them to make them go away.At night the place becomes a huge open air eatery with fewer people pestering you, but the burnt barbeque smells were too unappetising to persuade me to eat there. My advice to anyone planning a visit would be to take a table on the terrace of one of the cafes overlooking the square and do your people watching from a comfortable distance.

Don't go home without visiting this!. This is without doubt the main attraction in Marrakech - all I can say is you HAVE to experience it. Some love it, some hate it... but you cannot go home without visiting this and judging it for yourself.I would recommend you go firstly during the day to familiarise yourself with the location and whats where... then go during the evening when the square comes to life, its a whole new world.BE CAREFUL about people asking for money after theyve tapped on a drum for 2 seconds and keep your belongings close at all times!I personally loved it, some great cafes with terrace views around the square to sit at and enjoy the chaos of the city!

Interesting, but..... This place was a must-see after all the things we had heard about it. It certainly was an experience, with the crowds of people, the music and the sights. It was very difficult to stop at look at anything though, as everyone wanted money. We were stupid enough to offer a 50 dirham note to a group of acrobats, in the expectation we would get change after stating what we were prepared to pay. Never, ever show paper money, only stop and watch if you have small change you don't mind paying. Also, animal lovers may find the treatment of the animals distressing. We avoided the monkey men like the plague, and we were distinctly uncharmed by the snake 'charmer' we saw trying to force a cigarette into the unfortunate creature's mouth. Much nicer to sit on the balcony of one of the nearby cafes and enjoy the sounds and the atmosphere without being hassled. We also ate here one night, the food was nothing to write home about, although the stall holders were very funny and it probably everyone should try at least once.
*THIS* is worth the whole trip to.... *THIS* is worth the whole trip to Morocco! If it's the only thing you see, go here at night! Totally beyond belief!

Fantastic. This is one of the greatest places I've been to. The animation in the evenings is incredible. Most of all, this place is real: street performers carry on ancestral folklore and tell traditional stories, not for tourists but for Moroccean people (who constitute most of the audience). Definitely a must-see.

Not to be missed. you simply couldn't come here withiout visiting the sqaure, however I didn't feel it was all it was cracked up to be.On the plus side its pretty unique & different by day & night. Surrounded by cafes its great to just people watch without the hassle. If you stand still in the square to look at anything you will be approached.On the negative side-the traffic while fun to watch takes some dodging.I had expected lots of snake charmers but saw only one but lots of men playing the music.Some of The henna ladies are quite aggressive so be assertive.The banter from the food stall men is on the whole good natured but the odd ones can get a bit too much

magical and wonderful. I can't believe the negative comments about Jemma El Fna -I found it truly magical and everything I had hoped for. Yes -you get hasselled to buy -but i expected that. I found that being polite worked -I certainly had no one shouting abuse at me. The locals are lovely friendly people. We went to the square every night for a week -everything fascinated me -from the henna ladies, snakes charmers, story tellers to the hundreds of food stalls selling everything you can think of ( I recomend no 12!). Amazing and cant wait to go back.

The worst experience in Marrakesh. Went there on my first night in Marrakesh and it was absolutely disappointing. Coudln't believe that noone had warned me about this tourist trap. Some might call it authentic, charming, magical - I call it a complete scam where even little kids are taught that money talks. Once you get to the food stalls, it gets even worse: every where you look you see pushy men that have only one goal: to get as many people to eat on their stand as possible - using every sleazy trick in the book ranging from giving you cheap compliments to trying to woo you with their 3-word language skill in every possible language. Once you show no interest you'll get a big serving of ugly swear words and pretty evil looks thrown at you...very hospitable indeed. The only light amongst this mess was stand 114 where we actually found a good guy who sold pretty good, honest food. If this had been my only encounter with Marrekesh, I would never go back but fortunately the experiences I had aftewards made up for a bumpy start.

The soul. If you want to feel the city's soul, you can't miss Jemaa el Fna in the evening. People start arriving and you are able to see all sor of things - traditional games, story tellers, music players, serpent enchanters, and so on. We were advised to look after our bagpacks, but felt it was quite safe. If you don't want to eat at the square, try to find a terrace around it, because it is a very enriching to feel this square's soul - the smell, the sound, the people... Everything! We loved it!

Over-rated & hideous, all things considered.... This is a really crappy, disgusting place, and I would not recommend it to anyone. There are so many more interesting souks in other parts of Maroc - Rabat and Fez, for instance, offer genuine, authentic and engaging central areas of cultural interest within their medina's. Jemaa el Fna is a big, grubby rip-off. I spent 10 days in Maroc, and loved every minute of it until I got to this hideous square, and my whole impression of the nation dived thereafter, which is wrong, because thankfully most Moroccans are not as mean-spirited and deceitful as those that inhabit the area in and around this hell-hole known as Jemaa el Fna. I've travelled extensively in India, Egypt, Thailand etcetera, and I know an interesting cultural hot-spote when I visit one - and this square does not qualify. Avoid it! It's sad example of how global tourism can sometimes create horrid, monstrous places... Unfortunately Jemaa el Fna pretty much tainted my over-all impression of Maroc. The authorities should close it down..

Try Booth 41 for yummy food at Jemaa el Fna. We were in Marrakech two nights, about 10 days apart, as part of a small tour group. Had two great meals at Booth 41 - great kebabs, pastilla, tangier, tagine. Accomodated our group of 7 wonderfully - an atmospheric and delish meal to remember both times.Cap it off with fresh OJ and dates from neaby stands.

Possibly the world's biggest tourist trap. Once upon a time, I'm sure this must have been a place of miracles, but the fairy tale has definitely ended. Today's Jemaa el Fna is a very rough place, intimidating to say the least and not in a good way. The cultural outbursts that once were spontaneous and genuine are now clearly a facade put up for tourists. In fact, the most impressive act on the square is how these people manage to get money from tourists for not doing much at all. Just crossing it at least five people will yell at you to drink their orange juice, give them money for looking at their snake for two seconds or visit their overpriced hammam. It broke my heart to see those poor monkeys, chained on tourist's shoulders, before returning to their miniscule cages. Of course, those tourists should be ashamed of themselves too. The sad thing (for me AND them) is, I would happily have spent some money there to see a genuinely good act or experience real culture if the atmosphere didn't feel so hostile. They're killing their own business.

One of the best bazaars anywhere.. Jemaa el Fna is a fascinating place to shop or just explore. During our stay in Marrakech we spent a lot of time in Jemaa el Fna. The experience is completely different during the day vs night. It is amazing how the open square fills up with restaurants offering exotic and/or delicious foods as soon as the day starts to fade into night. There are women doing henna, snake charmers, and dancers in the square at night. During the day there is an endless supply of souvenirs to explore in the souq. Be prepared to bargain hard if you want to buy anything and also to be followed and hassled by vendors as you pass. Our experience was that almost everyone was very friendly although they did get too close for my personal comfort at times. Don't be afraid to say that you are not interested and walk away if you don't want to buy something. Usually being polite will work fine although I did on a couple of occasions have to turn sturn to get someone to let me pass. It's all part of the experience though so I found it to be very fun and exciting. I came home with many interesting souvenirs and pictures. I also tried the food and liked everything I ate and didn't get sick. There were many tourists in this area so there didn't seem to be any need for women to be too concerned about dressing conservatively as is the case in some other parts of North Africa. Overall it is a really exciting and enjoyable experience as long as you are mentally prepared for the high level of stimulation and engagement from the locals.

Brilliant - went every night of my holiday. Jemaa el fna is the heart of Marrakech and my reason for visiting and it didn't disappoint. The atmosphere is amazing and there's so much to see from transvestite dancers to snake charmers and so many places to eat with the boys sent out to get you into their area hilarious with their chat. A must-see.

Not much there (2009). I read all these reviews and was expecting something exotic and interesting. I do not feel this square lived up to the hype. The snake charmers were tired and incapable of understanding that their audience might be more interested in photographing the snakes than in taking pictures of them dancing and waving an orange plastic bucket in front of the snake. Taking a picture of the square in general resulted in a hoard of mean-spirited street people decending- demanding that the picture was of them and they should be paid.Maybe this was something in the past-- now it appears to be coasting on its reputation---- as Medinas go, Fes was more interesting.

The best and cheapest night time barbecue in the world. This place did live up to the reviews we read before going here. During the day it's usually empty, all there is are the orange juice and fruit and nut stalls, and snake charmers. But at night this does liven up with music and the various BBQ stalls and 'restaurants' with their own benches and tables. And it really doesn't matter which one you go to, there's probably about 50 where you can go to and they'll all have the same menu. You can have a meal of brochettes (skewers), veg, bottled water for a fiver max. Best of all for us, we didn't get any food poisoning! For those people who are afraid of eating at these stalls or getting hassled by the men coming out to get you to eat at their stall, just choose one and eat!

The place like no one else. It's hard to find the words to describe Jemaa. Exotic; absolutely. Confusing; probably. But when you come back to home and your friends are asking to tell them something about your holiday, it's very likely that you start from the Jemaa el Fna.We visited in Marrakech in February and were very impressed about this big square, even there were not any fire eaters or cobras in this season. In the summer Jemaa is surely even more exciting.There are so many food stalls that it would be very hard to choose the best. It WOULD, but "luckily" there are some thousands of very keen waiters who are trying to get you in. When you finally give up and just follow some waiter to his stall you'll notice that there is almost impossible to get any kind of service because all the waiters are desperately trying to get the other new customers, and other and other.. And I think the food is not worth of taking a risk to get some disease. We tried three different food stalls and every of them was a disappointment. Luckily we stay healthy.Even if you'll have only one hour to explore in Marrakech, you can't pass Jemaa el Fna. It's something unforgettable.

A Magical Cultural Phenomenon. This is the heart of Marrakech and has to be experienced to understand. Yes, its noisy, raucous even a little intimidating for the new traveller - but doesn't everyone come to Marrakech to experience the exotic? My advise is to experience it over several days AND in the evening and night. Daytime it is merely a third world market, but at night it is the extravagant entertainment, restaurant and enveloping experience that you will take home with you from Marrakech.

We loved it. I cannot think of a more eye opening experience in my life. Yes, they charge you for photos, yes the food stalls are very aggressive in getting your business, yes the hygiene may not be what we expect in the western world. But isn't that what travelling's all about?Food was super good, cheap and well worth it. A fresh squeezed glass of OJ for 3 Dh (about 40 cents) alone is worth it.

Be prepared!. The Djemaa El Fna, the Assembly of the Dead... I had looked forward so much to being there, soaking up the atmosphere, being entranced by all that was different and new. I wish I'd read some of the reviews here before I went! The square is filled with snake charmers, musicians, story tellers, yes yes yes... But, as one reviewer put it, they are there not as a cultural expression of Moroccan identity anymore, but as a tourist attraction. Pay no more than 20dh for photos taken - they will try and demand 100, 200, 300dh, some of them will get very aggressive. And woe betide you if you sound American or English - if there are two prices for locals and tourists, then Americans and Englishmen are at the high end of the tourist spectrum. I expected to be inspired by Morocco, instead, I was too intimidated to take any photos in the square. We were hassled for money continuously, having to endure fez, monkey, snake, and henna being put on our heads, shoulder, necks and hands, all without request or permission. "Laa shukran" (Arabic for "No thank you") became a mantra, to be repeated over and over again, in the square, the souks, the medina. Say no, over and over again, then walk away if they get overly aggressive. If anyone follows you, say you'll call the police (there are usually some plainsclothes policemen hanging around the square). Ignoring people, although it feels very very rude, also works, but some may also curse and swear at you if you ignore them. Not a good feeling all around. There is some magic still in the Djemaa, most noticeably at sunset, but be prepared to be hassled and harassed by those that make their livelihood here.

Eating it the Square - is a big risk. If you go to Marrakech and do not go to the Jemaa El Fna then you have so missed out. It is like nothing else you will experience.Course you might not like everything…but everything is not there for it to be liked. The square is very quiet in the day with a few entertainers and orange sellers but as soon as it gets dark (5.30-6pm at the end of October) it transforms. There are about a hundred food stalls all trying to get you to eat with them. Dont' take any photos of them unless you eat there otherwise they will shout at you. Most stall are the same selling chicken kebab, couscous, salad, sausages and frites and lots more all on display for you to see. Some have sheeps head and some are eggs which they fill a big bap type bread with egg and anything else you fancy. We went there with our two children age 10 and 7 who found the whole place out of this world and was never once bored. We decided on our 3rd night to be brave and eat at one of the food stalls. For 4 of us to eat with a coke each (no alcohol allowed) it cost £16. BUT hygeine is not the best and thinking about it we took a big risk eating there. The food is brought in fresh but not refrigerated (not that it was hot when we were there) but they wash up in the same water all night. The next day my husband was very ill with diahorrea had a high fever and five days later is still suffering - doctor says he has viral gastroenteritis which is caused by poor hygiene. Luckily out daughters have not had it, and I have had a very mild dose. I would love to recommend eating there because the atmosphere is brilliant and the guys working there are pure entertainment. And out of 4 of us only 1 got ill. But think would you eat there if it was England and the guy who has just handled your food is also dealing with money washing the table down and shaking everyones hand.It was a shame because I loved it there - to me it is what marrakech is all about. But if you do eat there remember you are taking a risk and you might be ill.

Taking Care. It's a several years since I last visited Marrakech. During my first visit I was advised by our Hotel and holiday Rep' to hire an official guide if visiting Jemma el Fna and the souks. They will take you to all the places that you want to visit and will fend off any thing or any body that you do not want to talk to and will also advise on haggling. We did and it worked extremely well. If you are staying at a hotel, their reception staff shuold be able to book you one. If you are not staying at a Hotel, I should imagine that a tourist information office would be able to book one.

Djemaa El Fna - Square of the Dead...is the place to be!. OK, how can anyone say that this square is ‘definitely worth not seeing’? I mean if you go to Marrakech and do not go to the Jemaa El Fna then I’m telling you, you have so missed out.Course you might not like everything…but everything is not there for it to be liked. I loved the place. Go for the orange juice, it is the best I have ever tasted I am not kidding so that alone contradicts the saying ‘definitely worth not going/seeing’.The food was lovely, most places had the same thing on the menu but it was dirt cheap, I recommend stall number 97 as they had the friendliest staff, they shook your hands and made sure that you were ok and looked after you until you have left their stall. Their food compared to the other stalls we have eaten in were more fresh and cooked right, it is also one of the busiest with tourists, so that shows number 97 must be one of the better ones. All stall have numbers so what you tend to find is that they will tell you to remember their stall number and come back for it later or another day. Yes, they are pushy and yes they want you to eat in their stall and yes, its Marrakech…its all for themselves, the way they make their living you just have to join in and laugh it off and blend in with them it works, just be one of them and they will laugh back and make jokes! The big trick to these food stall workers is you PRETEND you have already eaten so then they will stop and just ask you to come back another day and remember their stall number, and they will smile and welcome you to Marrakech then leave you alone. Done.There is so much to see, henna artist calling you to come over and ‘just look’ but they will like you to actually do one. Just don’t go and look if you do not want to do it, your just going to make them think you want one done and make yourself spend around 50 dirhams on henna designs which you did not want in the first place. So just don’t go if you don’t want it. Snake charmers, well they are there charming the snakes and they do offer to put one round your neck and take pictures…no way I was doing that, then there are cute monkey which are being put on to your shoulders and the workers get them to pose for the camera which you have to of course pay for at the end. Acrobats and watermen belly dancers and performers are scattered around, be careful with these lot if you even look they will draw all their attention on you amongst everyone in the crowd and at the end will ask for money. Some will do nothing and will still ask for money. There are other things like fortune tellers, story tellers and much more. There are a line of horses and carriages and their owners asking if you want to go for a quick spin around the area with them. You will also find motorbikes zooming past you dangerously so be conscious. The square leads to the ever ending souks :).Personally I did have bad experience in the square, with people asking for money even though all they did was bang a drum 3-4 times; all we did… was give them 1 dirham and walked off. They still bothered you but just ignore and walk off, at the end of the day remember it is down to you how you will get treated there and how much you pay. There was one henna artist came up to me and showed me the henna book and forcefully took my hands and started decorating it, I was really cross, I wanted to save my hands for the last day so I can get a henna artist on the last night to tattoo it so when I come back to London it will last longer. I was not having it; :-( she demanded money for that forceful act. I was not going to give her anything. And I didn’t. But like I said you will experience a few bad times but you expect that. You will get lost if your not careful so be careful! Keep an eye on your crowd in that way you will not be separated. Beware of pickpockets they do exist. Orange juice is the best 3 dirhams you get a freshly squeezed juice. With 10 dirhams you get orange and lime yum yum that is delicious you will need to try that as well. (Recommend stall 17).You will get beggers they are not ‘horrible’ as some people put them they just want a bit of help. I don’t mean splash your money out, no don’t do that, but use your instincts and look out for the ones you think will need it. We gave some of our food to a few children who asked they thankfully took it and went. There was an old lady sitting in the corner praying we gave her around 10 dirhams she didn’t even look at the money to check how much we gave her and all she did was dearly thank us no matter how much we gave. There was an old couple the man was blind we gave them a few dirhams and they were so happy and appreciative, that’s it we didn’t splash hundreds out. There were a few annoying children that were sent by their parents trying to sell biscuits n wouldn’t leave us alone. But we got through it with a help from locals.The Djemaa El Fna goes through a huge transformation from the morning to night. Wow you will see the difference, it’s quieter in the morning but after about say 7 you will see the stall getting built and slowly music from snake charmers and drummers flooding the square and smoke from the cooking flying in the air and gets buzzing with people. What we done was sometimes buy a few soft drinks and water in a café and sit there for few hours and watch and talk. It was really relaxing.So in conclusion a definite place to go. If you don’t like the sound of what I said then don’t go Marrakech at all. Because that is what Marrakech is all about, it is what you imagine from a North African/ Middle Eastern part of the world. Maybe Paris will be the place for you.

Sensational ....however, be very aware of the pick-pockets !. There is no doubt that this is a must see, especially at dusk and as the square shifts identities into the early and late evening. What has already been stated with other reviews is all true. The only problem I encountered and by far the biggest was that I found Jemaa el Fna to be 'infested' with pick pockets. Came within seconds of someone stealing my wallet one evening, saw a daring guy open a young ladies bag and snatch 50 dirhams on broad daylight and stood back from the crowded throngs another night to see how these youngters stalked their prey. Do not be put off by them, just be wary - don't take any precious items in your handbags or in your wallets. Take small amounts of money if need be and enjoy the events that transpire around you.

Least favourite part of Marrakech. The Jemaa el Fna was my least favourite thing about our time in Marrakech.It seems nothing more than a way for the locals to intimidate the tourists. If I dared to spare more than a fleeting glance at either the snake charmers, the dancers, the water carriers, etc. then they would be demanding money (and a LOT of it) for the pleasure of looking at them.How dissapointing. When I return to Marrakech, I won't be going back to Jemaa el Fna, especially at night.

Medina Landmark. Big, paved, open-area surrounded by restaurants and shops; A completely unique experience, not to be missed if in Marrakesh!Here you will find snake-charmers, drummers, monkey-handlers, henna-ladies and OJ carts by day. All of the above plus food stalls, freaks, more musicians, cooking smoke & beggars by night.Much busier at night than by day. It starts getting busier around sundown. It's all pretty much rolled up by 11PM.Jemaa el Fna is an excellent reference point when navigating thru the maze of alleys & shops in the medina...You can't miss it!Returned for 3 days straight to eat and people watch while visiting Marrakesh. Certainly worth a visit!

Dissapointment. Everyone raves about the Jemaa el Fna however i didn't really think it was all that special. The food stores at night were ok, the nicest food i had was at a store that only sold lamb and was very popular with the locals, it was about 30dirham for a lamb sandwich and just 1dirham for mint tea, everywhere else sells the same thing and the staff can get quite pushy in trying to encourage you into their stalls. The orange juice stands are nice however and are really cheap, just make sure you ask the owner to press the oranges infront of you because normally they serve it out of a jug with pre-pressed oranges mixed with water.The so called amazing entertainment is a let down too, i saw a few snake charmers, and people with monkeys on chains that were clearly VERY badly treated - all for the tourists and a massive let down. The locals can also get a bit "touchy" with western girls despite the fact that they might be surrounded by western males! For me the jemaa el fna refelected the rest of marrakech, a dissapointment, fake tourist trap that is ok but i wouldnt say was definately worth seeing!

Jama El Fna. When I Visted Morroco I Went For Five Days And I Personaly Thought It Was Amazing But The Thing That Really Made Marrakech That Speacial Place For Me Was The Jama El Fna It Had A Wide Range Of Shops Selling Lots Of Different Things From Hanbags && Clothing To Morrocan House Decorations. It Was Also What My Dad Called It A One In A Life Time Experience I Absoulutley Loved It So Much That It Was A Once In A Life Time Experience For Me Because I Went Back There Twice. For Any One Who Is Staying In Marrakech Going To The Jama El Fna Is A Must Do. I Miss Marrakech So Much That I Have Actually Booked A Long Holiday Out There So I Can Really Get To Learn More About Marrakech. I Know This May Sound A Tad Sad But I Actually Loved It So Much That I Named My Fish Jama El Fna. And In My Own Personal Opinion Marrakech Was A Better Holiday Than Dubai And Thailand Were Even Though In Dubai We Stayed In A Five Star Hotel And Went Camel Riding And Every thing Marrakech Still Beat Itt. Right Then Must Go Phones Ringing. Thank You.

Some great music to be heard. One night, after dinner at one of the stalls, I walked around the square until I was drawn in by one of the musical gatherings -- electric guitar and three or four drummers performing gnawa music. When the music stopped, it was clear that a financial contribution was expected from me, the only obvious foreigner in the crowd. I knew in advance that this was likely, so it didn't bother me at all. When they stopped again after the next tune, for which a banjo player joined in, I gave more, and I was ushered to the center, where one of the drummers gave me his seat.It was well worth coughing up a few bucks for some great music! (But I steered well clear of the snake-charmers.)

Fun and exotic. We spent four days in Marrakech recently and every day we went to the square and loved it. Day and night are completely different. We found no hassles and were not groped. We felt completely safe in the city. We did dress modestly - long sleves and long trousers. Maybe that helped, but everyone else is covered up and it only makes sense. We ate at the night market - not the restaurants with the view on the market, but at the stalls. Each meal we had was delicious and the people were so friendly around us, especially at the soup stalls where few tourists were. Yes, there are beggars and yes, one asked for food. We didn't give money, but one cannot turn down another asking for food. Charity is good for you.Daytime - snake charmers can be a bit aggressive, but just don't give them the silly sums they ask for the couple of pics you'll snap. They'll argue and push, but so what. It's all part of the fun. Remember, 99% of these folks have never been outside of their reality and have no idea what westerners like/dislike and what makes us feel uncomfortable. So, just ride with it and enjoy.

Different Day and Night. Once upon a time a group of 3 western women entered the square attracted by the music, bright lights and throngs of people. Almost immediately, having tried to edge into a crowd to see what was happening (storytelling), one was groped. The tall, slim, blonde and blue-eyed youngest? No! The squat dark haired fat-bottomed one! They like the ones with child-bearing hips it seems. We soon discovered an effective deterrant was to slap the intruding hand very sharply whilst shouting "ne me touchez pas!" and turning to face the perpetrator who usually slinks away. Sorted! The next step into the unknown was to dare to eat at the open air food stalls. Do it! Do it! Do it! The food is great, cheap, you will not get Delhi Belly and the young men are heaps of fun if you joke around with them. An easy solution for the beggar children (yes, they approach you) is to give them a sweet (bon-bon). They are usually delighted and rush off to devour them alone. During the day, the square is more tourist trap snake charmers, Berbers in fancy dress charging for photos and henna tattoo ladies. I had 3 tattoos done and it took me that long to find out the local price. It is 10 dirhams (and a packet of gummy bears) for a small tattoo on the foot and 50 dirhams for more involved hand or leg tattoos. One shocking women tried to charge me 400 and was told to go away in no uncertain terms - do they think all tourists are fools? Of course, all around the square there are western (tourist) restaurants where you can get a beer or bottle of wine and the many souks selling souvenirs. Before you even start haggling there, visit the complexe artesanale on Mohammed V which is govt fixed prices where you can see the craftsmen working. These are your top prices so do not pay more in the souks. The most important thing to remember is that you are supposed to be enjoying yourselves. Have fun, smile and the Moroccans WILL smile with you.

Watch out for the gropers. A lot of people on the web had raved about Jemaa el Fna, especially the night attractions - snake charmers... dancers... theatre... It was the place to be! Sadly, it was anything but. Firstly it is always highly recommended that you go to one of the restaurants which overlooks the square and have a meal up on the balcony. Sadly, like most tourist traps, the food is substandard and generally a poor imitation of pizza or pasta.But the real disappointment is the so-called night time activity. One quarter of the square is given over to an evening eating area, and about two-thirds to brightly lit stalls selling very cheap trinkets or dates/orange juice (out of dirty glasses). And the 'magical' activity? What little there is all takes place on the darkest periphery of the square. As two western females in Morocco we were already aware that, no matter how old or how conservatively you dress, you are constantly verbally harassed (with sexual innuendo's) by Moroccan youths. So given all the entertainment was taking place on the darkets edges of the square, there is something very intimidating about plunging yourself into a dense crowd of Moroccan men in the dark. So we didn't.Finally we found a little puddle of light with a crowd no more than 2 people deep, and some Moroccan women at the centre which gave us enough courage to pause and try see if this was a snake charmer or a magician or something else.... We edged up to the back of the crowd and almost immediately, youths from all over swarmed all around us and within seconds, fingers were sliding up our backsides, down our arms, across our backs. We fought our way out and wandered around until we found another less crowded show. And the same thing repeated itself. We left in disgust. So if you are a western woman who wants to see these night activities in Jemaa el Fna, be prepared for some very intimate and disgusting groping from invisible fingers and hands.

A MUST for Marrakech. We have just returned from Marrakech and loved it. Whilst certain things are true; you get hassled a lot in the souks, people do tend to stare, beggars approach you a lot, the city has a great deal of colour, culture, tradition and life. We spent about 70% of our time in the Jemaa El Fna and in the souks and each time learnt more and more. Marrakech isn't a rich city and the people do not live well - you will notice that Moroccans are very proud of their country and look after their own. We noticed many locals who were better off give very generously to the poor so what is the harm if you give a few dirhams too? There are times when you will be digging for change in your pockets a bit too often, I found that children supposedly leading the way - by leading, I mean walking a metre in front of you then stopping to ask for payment was rather annoying especially as we had not asked for the assistance, or dancers in the square who happen to be in your eyeline asking for cash rather cheeky but a firm no will see them on their way.Eating in the square is a must. The locals do it and if tourists want to get to know Marrakech in any way then they should too, if you find it too much then might I suggest somewhere a bit more sanitized - perhaps a beach resort in Spain? It is true that it is hectic, dusty, manic and busy but this is part of the city. It is not a city of sights but rather of senses and colours and culture. The cuisine is superb and a feast can be had in the main square.. we found the selection of kebabs, tagines, grilled vegetables, fish all to be fresh and very well flavoured and cooked. You will get the opportunity to sit with other tourists and locals if you're lucky and talking to them only adds to the experience. It is true that people do approach you asking for money or trying to sell things but the waiters and chefs are very protective of their customers and quickly shooed them off. We found that the more we went back to the square, the more we liked it. We were recognised more and more too which meant less hassling. Highly recommended!

terrible. Avoid at all cost !! Marrakesh is a dirty dangerous city, the locals have one thing in mind ripping you off .The food is horrible the beggars hound you when you are sat eating in the square. On one night a man in a wheelchair was put next to us by a small child when I looked the man had a colostomy bag on full veiw !!! the child then pointed to it and held her hand out for money. Not what you want to see whilst eating.Taxi's : you cannot show the drivers an area on a map because they can't read we got dropped off in god knows where after 10mins I'd had enough tried to get a taxi back a driver wanted to charge us 200 dh the oringnal journey had cost 20dh. We just felt exhausted every time we went out it was constant hassle from large gangs of locals hidding in the alleys. and as for the motorbikes that's another story . Stay away from marrakesh !!!

2 Great Days. I spent 2 days in Marrakech in Oct. The weather was sunny and 88*. There is a lot of building work going on plus the pollution from all the vehicles. This makes the city hot and humid to walk about in. The ride from the airport to Gueliz, the new part of the city, takes about 15 mins by cab. All the taxi drivers told me it would be 150dh. Although it was only 100dh when I ordered the taxi back via the hotel!There are many sights to see and they are all explained in any good guide book. I found the Time Out book to be very useful. The real beauty of the place for me lies in the sounds,smells,sight and feel of walking around. The noise is never ending from traffic, people and animals. Crossing the road can be test all on it's own. You get to compete with cars,buses,mopeds,bikes,people,people on donkeys and most things that move. There is a right of way, but this gets easily ignored. Find a local and cross when they cross. The Souks provide their own entertainment. Clothes,food,livestock and more. You will get lost wandering about. Not too difficult to get back on track though.Jemaa El Fna has much to offer by day and night. During the day you can find the snake charmers.Around 6.30pm the food stalls start to set up. Here you can find all manor of goodies. Couldn't bring myself to taste the Pigs Head! The only annoying thing about the square are the boys who work the food stalls. They have picked up little phrases from tourists and spend most of the evening practising them on you. Nevermind. Cafe de France provides an excellent view of the square from the terrace. Away from the square there are many other places to eat. Grilled chicken,bread,olives 2 spicy sauces and a coke for 30dh. I walked the 25 mins from my hotel to Jemaa El Fna both during the day and night and back. I felt safe at all times. The area is well lit and very busy. Just take the same care you would in any city. Taking photos was never a problem. Don't point your camera directly at anyone and you won't have a problem. I'm sure a few Dirham will sort out any misunderstandings.I have no doubt that you will enjoy Marrakech. Get caught up in the magic and try not to but too many slippers!!!

A square with a difference!. My wife and I visited the Jemaa el Fna on a few occasions. We found during the day it was to some extent very different from the night.Many people gather in this area and it is a great experience. There are performers, henna artists, snake charmers and the list goes on and on and so many varieties of acts to see! Also from the Jemaa el Fna you can get access to the souks (about 20,000 shops in a maze like sorrounding!)The atmosphere is lively and very raw. I would advice you dont relax too much and stay on your guard. I do not mean we felt like our belongings were not safe or we were not safe but the fact that for many people this is an area where they will making their livelyhood. Therefore:- If taking a photo, there is a 90% chance you will have to pay something to someone. It wont be much maybe 10-30 dhirams- There will be VERY FEW but some people who will force you to take part and then expect money, e.g. a guy holding a monkey placed it on my shoulder, my wife took the photo and then he demanded money, and yeah he go a little loud and asked for 50 dhirams. He ended up getting 15 from me- Some people do not like appearing in any photos so be wary of this as this are not comfortable with it- If you are not interested simply smile and reply in French/Arabic/even English but do not do hand gestures or show disrespectA lot of this common sense and even a tourist picks up the pace and surroundings very quick.Overall its an amazing experience where lots and lots of tourists go. Theres things to buy, food to eat and entertainment to watch or even take part in. We very much recommend you visit the Jemaa el Fna and guarantee you will return!

Great Experience. Have just returned from Marrakech and enjoyed the 'Square' .We visited in the morning, lunch and evening. And have to say the evening experience was the best time.Yes there are different folk trying to obtain cash out of you but on the whole its amazing just to sit on the rooftop terraces and watch the goings on.Whilst the Moroccans are very friendly I also felt I had to be on my guard. The experience was amazing and I would recommend anyone to go and experience it once in your life!

"Still fascinating despite the changes". I appreciate Morocco Traveller's thoughtful, experienced review of Jemaa el Fna, yet also agree with the reviewer that his or her history has become a bit of a hindrance to enjoying it today. I went to Morocco for the first time in June 05 and could not have been more fascinated by the constant whirl of activity in the square. It was like a vortex of exotic energy, zooming this way and that, charming, beautiful, bizarre, sometimes a little scary, always intoxicating. Yes, the performers ask you for money; yes, it would probably be even more wonderful if they did not; and yes, the health standards of the open-air vendors probably don't pass muster. But honestly, as an American who had never been to a non-Western country before, I was still absolutely bowled over and would highly recommend Jemaa el Fna to any first-time visitor to Morocco, even though it is not what it once was (which I totally believe).

How much more can this city take?. I have been visiting Morocco since the late 70s (most recently a few weeks ago) and have seen significant changes to the Marrakech over the years not least to the activities taking place in the Jemma el-Fna. I too am coloured by my past and on each subsequent visit find it harder and harder to find the very thing that brought me here so many times in the 80s. With so many cheap flights now available to Marrakech - plus the undying interest generated by various journals - the city (particularly the Medina) has become distinctly over-touristed. How much more can it take?Some performers in the Jemma el-Fna (the snake charmers, monkeys, acrobats and “Gnawa” musicians who perform during the day) have no doubt cashed in on this influx and see tourists as a major source of income. These performers have always taken the opportunity (and dirhams) to pose for tourists when it came along but in my view, the emphasis has now shifted.The evening shift on the Jemaa is slightly different however. The atmosphere is different. The circles surrounding the musicians and storytellers are mainly Moroccan and the place has a bit more of an authentic feel.I worry about Marrakech and the Jemaa el-Fna, it ain't the same. The very thing that made this place special is in danger of being lost forever (watch out Fes). Just read Juan Goytisolo’s book “Cinema Eden”. He puts into better words what I and others have tried to say.

Felt Very Safe At Jemma El Fna. It is so sad to read the negative reviews about Jemaa el Fna. Have just spent 4 nights in Marrakech end of Jan/ Feb 2007 and really in my opinion, the square is the heart of Marrakech.The atmosphere is very different during the Day and at Night, both offering quite a magical experience. I agree there are the occassioanl beggars etc , but a firm but polite "Merci Non" would be good enough to get rid of most of these.While the square is very very busy, the hustle and bustle may seem a little intimidating at first, but within a few minutes you are more mesmerised by all the activities, that you are not really concerned about the beggars etc. Quite a magical, adventurous experience.

Running the Gauntlet!. We agree with all those negative reviews of the Jemaa el Fna -here and everywhere else in Marrakech we were afraid to stand still for fear of being accosted by shoe polishers, snake charmers or people offering to show us 'good restaurant'. If we ever went again(we never will)we would get t-shirts printed with 'leave us alone' in arabic - the irony is, we would have spent a lot more money if they had only done so!

Not what it used to be!. I am hindered by my past history with the Jemaa el Fna. I have seen it in the 60's, 70's, 80's, and 90's. It used to be one of the most amazing places in the world. I have watched it over the last four decades become more and more commercialized as more and more tourists "discover" Marrakech. There is still a certain magic to it, but the magic is tarnished by the over commercialization. Whereas in the "old days" you could roam around the plaza without any hint of being bothered by "performers" asking for payment, now, sadly, that is what it has turned into. The snake charmers are still there. The monkeys. The acrobats. The story tellers. Unfortunately whereas it was once done as a cultural expression, it is now done for one reason alone: money! The city should try to get it under control before tourists make a complete pass of it. The best thing about the plaza is the orange juice, still as fresh as it ever was. The food stalls have multiplied exponentially over the years and while the sanitation isn't the best, thousands of tourists eat at them weekly. I probably wouldn't anymore.... there are just too many other choices in the smaller restaurants on the streets leading away from the plaza. But I can't get enough of the orange juice! Sadly, Marrakech is becoming like so many other "number one tourist destinations"... I don't think there is anything that can be done about it. Still worth a trip to see it, especially in the evening, but not a must see destination anymore.

Didnt see what all the hyp was about this place!!. This place is probably worth going to while you're in marrakech, as most reviews say but avoid the food! Its very unhygenic, crowded and the prices are not much lower than a proper restaurant. Its not a place I'd like to visit again and again...so hope that sums it up!

Brillient. jamaa el Fna was really intresting,
you could spend you a week looking around it and never reach the end. me and my friends loved it.

Heart of Marrakech which can keep you entertained for hours. A friend and I spent about 5 days in Marrakech and absolutely loved the Djeema el Fna. If you're staying in a riad (which is the only way you should stay in Marrakech - who wants to stay in a hotel that could be in any city in the world!), you'll more than likely get out of your taxi from the airport/train/bus station to here and then walk to your riad. Surrounding the square is the entrance to the souqs in the north, then to the south is the Koutoubia Mosque - which is off-limits to non-Muslims, but you can look at the exterior. Near the mosque, is the the starting point for horse and carriage rides should you want them. inside the square, during the day you'll see storytellers attracting a crowd, 'teeth-pullers' which appear to be the alernative to dentists should be desperate enough - but they will pose for photos with you.. .for a tip of course! I recommend getting to know money and tipping rates before you get here, because you could get seriously overpriced if you've just arrived. I had my photo taken with the snake charmer and held a snake on my lap and the guy tried to charge me 200 dirhams, which was a joke. 20 dirhams was perfectly acceptable and he took it. After initial meals in actual restaurents (such as Las Terrases de L'alhambra which was good) we ended up eating most of our dinners on the street stalls, which are set up after sundown. The food is v good, the atmosphere is brilliant and the price is v cheap, plus you're likely to make some Moroccan friends too. Day or night, you can't visit the Djeema without going to the orange juice stalls as often as possible. The juice is freshly squeezed and tastes amazing. There's tons of herbalists and women doing henna also. The henna women can be a bit too persistant and one actually started drawing on my hand when I said no so you have to be v firm and perhaps say "la shokran" which is Arabic for no thanks, and that should work a bit better than saying no in English.

Give the Jemaa el Fna a miss. We visited Marrakesh in November 2005 after an absence of 15 years. What a disappointment the Jemaa el Fna was! This used to be one of the world's great street theatres, full of snake charmers, whirling dervishes, Nubian drummers and dancers, story tellers, sword swallowers, fire eaters and general nutters all doing their own thing; all free AND the real deal, not put on for the tourists. Now all gone (except for the story tellers) to be replaced by dubious fast-food stalls and T-shirt sellers. So sad. On the way to the square our cab driver warned us that the place was not what it was and he was right. Don't be fooled by the guide book guff about the excitement and romance. European women should be aware that at night the place is full of repressed Moroccan youths who will molest them given the opportunity. Marrakesh has plenty of attractions but the Jemaa el Fna is no longer one them. Give it a miss.

The heart of Marrakech. The square itself is nothing.But there, you find the beating heart of the intriguing Marrakech, being impossible to walk around the town without finding yourself in the Jema el Fnaa.The square is insignificant in itself: the atmosphere, on the other side, is something you won't forget.Be there during the daytime and have a fresh squeezed orange juice from one of the dozens stalls for 2,5dirhams (about € 0,20).Ore, much more suggestably, be there after 6pm and watch a snake enchanter, or a street fighting (be it real or fake), or have your feet tattoed with hennè by one of the many artists sitting around.If you dare, have dinner at the collective eatery (restaurant is a word hardly usable to describe it) that appears in the evening, occupying half of the square - I have tried the stall n. 114 and had a very good dinner, with a wonderful cous cous for the cost of around € 7, for two persons, drinks included.First, be sure to have a good health insurance!
